comment: Cf. s.v. 1. *k̑erh₂- 'brechen, zerbrechen (intr.)' (IEW 578). LIV² etymologises the Tocharian forms to a nasal-present stem *k̑r̥-né/n-h₂- (cf. Ved. śr̥ṇāsi 'zerbrichst'); for the proposed cognacy of {ref Adams 2013}:173-174, cf. s.v. *kreu̯s- 'stoßen' (IEW 622) [without Tocharian lexemes connected]
IE *h2(e)r 'thus, so'
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷresno- 'wood, tree' from PIE *kʷres- 'bush, thicket' (IEW 633), cf. OEng. hryst 'bushes'.
S.v. δίδωμι 'give' < PIE *di-deh₃- 'to give'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *edinъ, *edьnъ 'one' from *h₁ed
-(H)iH-no-.  The origin of the initial element *ed- < *(h₁)edʰ- is unclear.  On the origin of *(H)iH-no-, cf. *jьnъ 'other'.

S.v. Alb. qep 'to sew (together), to seize'. Several proposed etymologies: (1) From Pr. Alb. *klepa, related to Slav *klepati 'to beat, to knock', cf in particular Russ klepat' 'to join together by riveting' (Orel's preferred etymology); (2) Related to Gk καπτω 'to swallow, gulp down' (Camarda); (3) < IE *skep- 'to split' (Meyer); (4) to Lat capiō 'to take' (Pedersen); and (5) onomatopoeia (Trubačev).
S.v. Alb. pemë 'fruit-tree, fruit', borrowed from Lat. pōmum 'fruit', pōmus 'fruit-tree'.
S.v. Alb. shkoj 'to go'. Etymology unclear, cf. entry in Orel for various proposals. (Principally cf. Jokl 1911:80-82 < *shteg 'path', alternatively Meyer 1891:408, comparing Lat. sequor 'follow').

Rejects Jokl and others from PIE *stei̯gʰ 'schreiten / walk' on the basis that the tectal should be preserved in *stoiGh-, consequently considers the proposal of a loan from Lat. sequor (so Meyer 1891:406) more likely.
Cognate with /cognate/161/ 'when'.
Cognate with /cognate/665/ 'where'.
Matirosyan prefers cognacy with Skt. YÁ-(< IE *yós, yéh(a), yód, Mallory 2008: 421) over a root as in the majority of 'where' /cognate/337/.

S.v. Alb. krah 'arm, shoulder, side', a loan from Slav *krajь 'end, side, extremity'. Etymologies proposed by other scholars are also mentioned: (i) comparison with Lith kárka 'shin, shank' and Slav korkъ 'id' but this is morphophonologically difficult, (ii) comparison with Skt kisku- 'forearm', (iii) < IE *kar-skā and compared with Skt kará- 'hand, elephant's trunk', (iv) to Arm. srunk' 'calf (anat.)', Lat crūs 'shank'.
< IE *bhes-, one of two terms for 'to rub', the other being *merd-. Other cognates include Gk psáo 'rub', Skt bábhasti 'chews thoroughly, devours', psáti 'chews, swallows'.
Derived from root attested in shij 'to thresh', a borrowing < Lat exigere 'to drive away, push out, throw'.
< IE *kwom-, a special development of the masc. acc. of *kwos-, cognate (among others) with 'if' in /cognate/2750/.

S.v. *mé 'inmitten, einschliesslich; mit' Partikel, inklusiv; Adverb, lokal; oft mit Lok.  Base form is *mé- many sub-branches have created new adpositions through compounding of further adverbial- or case-endings.  AGk. μετά, PGmc. *meða- < *mé-th₂, PGmc. *meði < *mé-dʰi-. The Albanian forms are derivationally unclear, and they may be original, but borrowing is in principle possible from Modern Greek με (from μετά with haplology in sequences with the n.pl. article *μετά τά >> με τά), cf. fn1a.
PAlb *semdza goes back to IE *sem-gho-, a suffix derivative of IE *sem- 'one' (/lexeme/23632/), as in Arm ez (same root).
S.v. Alb. rëndë ~ randë 'heavy'. Continues PAlb *raunta derived from the verbal stem of aor. rashë < *rauša 'to fall' (s.v. bie), a sigmatic aorist of IE *reu- 'tear'.
S.v. Alb. godas 'to strike, to beat', borrowed from Slavic *goditi used in a meaning unattested in South Slavic.

S.v. Arm. erkayn 'long' and Arm. erkar 'long'. The majority opinion connects the Armenian forms with Gk. δηρός 'lasting long', Lat. dūrō 'to last out', and Skrt. dūrá- 'far' < *du̯eh₂-ró-. Cf. possibly also Lith. er̃dvas 'wide, spacious', however this Lithuanian connection is uncertain since the Lith. accent and Skt. árdha- 'side, part, region' point to a *-dʰ-.
S.v. Arm. asem 'to say, tell, speak', usually compared with Gk. ἦ < *h₁e-h₁eg̑-t 'he said', Lat. aiō 'say', etc.
S.v. Arm. antaṙ 'forest'. Several interpretations from different IE sources are possible, but ultimately the origin is uncertain. Cf. entry in Martirosyan for an examination of possible proposals.

Discussed s.v. Arm. awij-kʻ 'collar'. No widely accepted etymology. Possibly to Gk. αὐχήν 'nape' (Aeol. ἀμφήν) to PIE *h₂u̯eg̑ʰ- but the relationship between Armenian viz, dial. xiz, Armenian awji-k‘ and the Greek lexemes are disputed.
S.v. Arm. gišer 'night'. Generally connected with different IE words for 'evening', cf. Gk. ἕσπερος 'evening(-star)', Lat. vesper 'evening(-star), West', Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ 'evening'.

S.v. Arm. aǰ 'right', connected with Skt. sā́dhati 'to succeed, reach the goal', siddhá- , sidhrá- successful', sādhú- 'straight, effective', sídhyati 'to succeed, be successful' from PIE *sHdʰ-i̯o- or *seh₂dʰ-i̯o-.
Loan < MIr [= Middle Iranian], cognate with OI bahu-.

"The etymological connection with Lith. júrės 'sea' < *i̯ūr- (*i̯uhr-?) seems quite plausible, although the evidence for a development *i̯- (or *hi̯-) > ǰ- in Arm. is meagre, but the suggested further connection with Skt. vā́r 'water' etc. can hardly be carried through."
< Lat crustam 'crust, shell; thin slab, leaf’ (de Vaan, 2013: 147).
< Lat dūrum 'hard'.
cf. grisch 'grey' < Gmc *grisi.
< Lat masculum.
< Lat massa 'id'.
< Lat culmen.
< Pre-Rom *trogiu.
< Lat appodiāre 'to be on one's feet (?)'.
< Lat planta 'plant'.
< Pr bosc, cf Fr bois 'woods' (/lexeme/5902/).
< Lat seniora.
< *ettiā 'feather' and *leg- 'to lie down'.
< MEng roade 'road'.
< Lat cortex.
Either < OEng lopust 'lobster' or < VLat locusta 'grasshopper'.
< Fr croc.
< *wastos 'servant. Cf. Ir foss also 'servant'.

S.v. Hitt. pai- / pi- 'to give, to pay, to grant, to hand over'. Kloekhorst prefers to split the Anatolian lexemes from Tocharian and Greek (αἴνυμαι), instead setting up a derived form *h₁p-ói̯-ei̯/*h₁p-i̯-énti, in comparison to Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'to take, seize'.
This cognate set is originally a loan into Classical Armenian from Syrian mezze 'crines parvi'.

The traditional etymology ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}) holds that κρύσταλλος a derivative of κρύος 'cold' (cf. /cognate/1463/).  {ref Beekes 2010}:787) rejects the traditional etymology as a derived noun based on κρύος 'cold' on the basis of the presence of a suffix -αλλο- which he considers a morpheme in Pre-Greek. Certainly, the suffix -αλλο- is derivationally opaque in IE terms, but a comparison of the semantics of κρύος 'cold, frozen' and κρύσταλλος 'ice' is very suggestive of some relationship between the terms. Pace Beekes, it may just as well be that we are be dealing with some sort of lexical contamination of inherited κρύος with some other unknown substrate element. In my own opinion, I think the traditional etymology according to Frisk and Chantraine is probably correct, with a caveat somewhere along these lines. In any case, for the purposes of establishing cognacy in the database this is presently an irrelevant argument, since only the Greek branch attests the disputed element κρύσ(τ)- as the (potentially) semantics-bearing element for in the meaning 'ice'. The root ref. form for this class has been given as κρύσταλλος. For further proposed connections to Tocharian A kᵤraś, Tocharian B krośce, cf. discussion in /cognate/8386/ and /cognate/1463/.

S.v. ὄρνεον 'bird' < PIE *h₃er-n- 'bird'. Both ὄρνῑς and the alternative form ὄρνεον share an n-stem suffix with words in Germanic and Anatolian meaning 'eagle' *h₃er-n- (cf. Goth. ara, ONor. ari and ǫrn, OEng. earn, Hitt. ḫāran-.  Greek ὄρνῑς is expanded from a feminine stem (transponat) *h₃er-n-ih₂- which has added an extra -θ- in the oblique stem.

Originally a euphemism for the left-side in Ancient Greek.  Formed using the -tero- contrastive suffix to the same root of the suppletive comparative and superlative of 'good' ἀρείων 'better', ἄριστος 'best'; thus ἀριστερός 'better of (the) two' > 'left(hand) side'.  Less-commonly found in Ancient Greek is  εὐώνυμος 'of good name' (lit.) > 'left', but this usage is rare.

S.v. φθείρ, -ρός 'louse'. Beekes considers the form a folk etymology with φθείρω 'to ruin, destroy' < *dʰgʷʰer-i̯e/o- 'flow away, disappear'.  Cf. Chantraine (1968-1980:1198), however, who considers the form to be a true root noun.

S.v. σελήνη 'moon'. The different dialectal reflexes of Attic σελήνη, West Greek σελάνα, Lesbian σελάννα may be accounted for from Proto-Greek *selas-nā (cf. σέλας 'light, brightness'). No further etymology, although the nominal formation of may be compared to the PIE word for 'moon' *l(o)uksneh₂, as in Lat. lūna 'moon', etc.
S.v. AGk. στόμα 'mouth, muzzle, front, peak edge' < PIE *sth̥₃-mn̥ 'mouth' (cf. Av. staman- (m.) 'mouth (of a dog)', Hitt. ištāman- 'ear').

S.v. AGk. στενός 'narrow, close, small, tight, slim'. Variants in Ancient Greek dialects στενός (Att.), στεινός (Ion.), στεννός  (Aeol., gramm.) point to an original u-stem *sten-u- which was later thematised to *stenu̯-o-. No known cognates outside of Greek.
S.v. ῥίς, ῥινός 'nose' (of man and animal) 'nostrils' (in pl.). No etymology outside of Greek.

PIE particle *mē 'not' is used with special modal constructions (prohibitives, etc.) and not the Swadesh term in Proto-Indo-European.  It has, however, been generalised into the function of both simple indicative negation as well as prohibitive negation in the Tocharian languages.

Some scholars consider Greek οὐκ and Armenian očʻ to come from a fossilised phrase *ne h₂oi̯u kʷid 'not ever in life' > 'not' following the proposal of {ref Cowgill 1960}, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1123) who tentatively accepts this proposal.  Other scholars doubt this cognacy judgement, cf. esp. {ref Clackson 1994}:158) who stresses that this etymological proposal is ad hoc, and suffers some difficulties in phonetic development. Likewise, cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:531) who regards Clackson's arguments for an inner-Armenian creation for očʻ more plausible. Cognacy of the Greek and Armenian lexemes have therefore been split.

S.v. AGk. ἄνθρωπος 'man'; it resembles Hitt. antuu̯aḫḫaš, antuḫš- 'man', but this is superficial since the Hittite word can be derived from *h₁en-dʰu(e)h₂-s- 'having breath/spirit inside'. No IE explanation has been found, so the word is probably of substratum origin.

S.v. ποταμός 'river'. Etymology uncertain.  In earlier scholarship the word was thought to be connected with the same root as in 'fall' /cognate/1991/ found in the verb πίπτω 'fall', with the semantics of 'waterfall' → 'river'.  More recent scholarship has determined that this root ended in a laryngeal *h₁, making this identification formally difficult, as one would expect †ποτεμός < *peth₁-mó-.  A second option connects ποταμός with the verb πετάννυμι 'spread out' (LIV² s.v. 1. *peth₂- 'ausbreiten'), to which can be compared Germanic forms OSax. fathmos, OEng. fæðm 'extension (of the arms), embrace, fathom'.  Another proposal connects ποταμός to the other *peth₂- 'fly' (LIV² 2. *peth₂- /cognate/1486/) which is formally more satisfactory.  A final possibility that is not excludable in principle is that the word is borrowed from a Pre-Greek substrate language.

S.v. -κναίω.  Usually connected with Baltic, Celtic, and Germanic cognates.  Cf. Lith. knóti 'to peel, tear', OHG nuoen 'to make smooth by scratching, to make fit together', OIr. -cná 'to bite, gnaw'.
From PIE *kneh₂- 'scratch, plane'? poss. cogn. with 'bite' in /cognate/1220/ and Ind. words /cognate/1816/.

S.v. ῥάπτω 'to sew (together), stitch, instigate'. No etymology.  Previously ῥάπτω was connected to Lith. ver̃pti, 'spin', Latv. virpêt 'spin with a spindle' (cf. IEW 1156, LIV² 590), but the attestation of Mycenaean e-ra-pe-me-na (perf.participle) which does not attest initial *u̯- demonstrates that this old etymology must be abandoned.

S.v. ὀρθός 'upright, straight, right, true'. Traditionally from PIE *h₃rdʰ-u̯o- and cognate Skt. ūrdhvá- 'raised, high' and derived from *u̯ordʰ-u̯o-. However, there is no evidence for initial u̯- in Mycenaean where it is expected.
Cf. s.v. ὀρθός 'debout, dressé', cf. for an overview of competing etymological proposals.

Reconstructs *h₃egʷʰi-, but the precise PIE reconstruction is disputed as not all reflexes attested can be reconciled to a single reconstruction. There is likely some taboo distortion occurring in this lexeme in independent branches.

S.v. ξανθός 'yellow, golden yellow, reddish, brownish, blond'. Etymology unknown. Previous attempts by Walde (1930: 1.357f.) to suppose IE *kas- 'grey' (cf. Lat. cānus 'grey'), or Heubeck to Etruscan zamθic, supposedly, 'of gold' are tenuous.

S.v. ἐυλή 'worm, maggot'. Etymology unclear. Traditionally connected by Frisk GEW with εἰλέω 'roll, turn, revolve' < PIE *u̯el- /cognate/3141/, but it is no longer possible to assume a prothetic vowel *ἐ-ϝλ-ή unless one assumes *h₁u̯el-, but the zero-grade *h₁ul- would have yielded ὑλ-.  A metathesis from an earlier *ϝελ-η is also improbable.

S.v. ὕλη 'forest, wood, timber, firewood, shrubbery'. Earlier etymologies connecting Gk. ὕλη with Lat. silva /lexeme/20570/ are to be rejected. There are two possible etymologies which assume the original meaning was 'firewood'.  The possibilities are either (1)  *su̯ol-h₂- > ὕλη from root *su̯el- 'to smoulder' (LIV² 609, IEW 1045), or (2), comparing ONor. usli 'burning ashes', from *h₁eu̯s-l-h₂, an l-stem formed to the root *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, singe', cf. εὔω /lexeme/31502/, Lat. ūrere /lexeme/31504/ 'to burn', etc. (cf. LIV² s.v. *h₁eu̯s- 'verbrennen, sengen', IEW 347-8).
S.v. εὐρύς 'broad, wide' < *h₁ur(H)-ú- (cf. Skt. urú-, Av. vouru- 'broad').

S.v. *gʷeh₂- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten' (IEW 463-4), *gʷem- '(wohin)gehen, kommen' (IEW 464-5).  AGk. pres. (1.sg.) βαίνω < *gʷm̥-i̯e/o-, aor. (3.sg) ἔβη < *(e-)gʷeh₂-t; Skt. gáccha-, Av. ǰasa- < *gʷm̥-sk̑e/o-, Skt. aor. ágāt, Av. aor. gāt̰ < *(e-)gʷeh₂-t.  The suppletive present/aorist pairing appears to be of Indo-European date, and probably originally aspectual in nature, i.e. imperfective (present) '*continue taking steps; > come' vs. perfective (aorist) 'take a step'.

S.v. γλῶσσα 'tongue, language'. Derived form in -i̯a- from *γλωχ- 'point' (γλῶχες 'beard of corn', γλωχίς 'end of a yoke strap, barb of an arrow, etc.'). Possibly a PIE preform *glōgʰ-s, gen. gl̥gʰ-ós 'point', but there are no certain cognates outside of Greek.
S.v. οὐρά 'tail', from PIE *h₁ors-h₂- 'rear' (cf. OIr. err 'tail' < *h₁ers-h₂-).

From grammaticalised phrase διά (τοῦτο) ὅτι lit. 'through (this) that'.  ὅτι itself is a fossilised collocation of the neut.sg relative pronoun univerbated with the neut.sg. indefinite indefinite pronoun: *i̯od-kʷid.  Cf. LSJ s.v. ὅστις, LIPP (Vol. 2) p.321f.  On διά cf. /lexeme/18655/

Usually understood to have formed from a collocation of Ancient/Medieval Greek preposition εἰς + pronoun (e.g. εμένα) with subsequent reanalysis of the initial vowel of the pronoun as part of the preposition, i.e.  εις εμένα [is emena] > isemena > ise-mena]. (Initial unstressed /i/ is later lost.)
S.v. μαύρος, ultimately from Ancient Greek ἀμαυρός 'dim, faint, lightless'.
S.v. κτύπος 'strong noise, cracking, stamping'. Etymology unknown.
From Ancient Greek κρατέω 'be strong, have power; rule; lay hold of'.

S.v. λειμών -ῶνος 'moist, grassy place, meadow' and λιμήν 'harbour, protected creek'. The Greek forms are are generalised from different accent/ablaut forms of PIE N.sg. *lei̯-mōn, A.sg. li-mén-m̥, gen. li-mn-ós.   λίμνη 'stagnant water, pond, lake, marsh' itself appears to be a secondarily derived ā-stem derived from the weakest stem, i.e. (transponat) *li-mn-eh₂
S.v. γελάω 'to laugh' < PIE *g̑elh₂- 'laugh' (cf. Arm całr 'laughter').
S.v. *g̑elh₂- 'in Lachen ausbrechen' (IEW 366). A Greek-Armenian isogloss.
S.v. βουνός 'hill'. Etymology unknown. The word appears to be originally a Doric dialectal word that spread in the Hellenistic period.
S.v. κόκκινος, -η, -ο 'που έχει το χρώμα του αίματος' [that which has the colour of blood, red], from Ancient Greek κόκκος 'seed, grain'.

Buck is cryptic here, but I think that he considers them as cognates as well. This is also the case of Walde-Hofmann, which he cites as a source. A Celtic borrowing from Latin is impossible, as Latin or Vulgar-Latin gr- becomes gr- in Brittonic. e.g. Breton grad from Latin gradus. An eventual loanword from Latin should thus be Breton *grass. A similar loanword is Early Modern Breton gross 'big, coarse' from Latin grossus via French (Deshayes 2003, 294).

Middle Cornish ty, te and Old South-West British ti, te /tɪ/ < Late Proto-British *tɨ < Proto-British *ti. Old Welsh and Middle Welsh ti reflect Late Proto-British *ti < *tī. The attested form can be generated from Proto-Celtic *tū, *tu in more than one way. The Proto-Celtic nom. sg. *tū became Proto-British *tȳ < *tī, while the Proto-Celtic acc. sg. *te became *ti. Of these forms, Old Welsh generalized the former variant, Old South-West British the latter. A parallel development is found with the 1st person pronouns.
From Ancient δρόμος 'course, race'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *lindu-, *lindo- 'liquid, lake'. IE etymology unclear.
From Ancient Greek σχοινίον 'small rope, cord, thread', diminutive of Ancient Greek σχοῖνος 'rush, reed'
Modern Greek τρίβω from Ancient Greek τρίβω.
From Proto-Celtic *oli̯ο- 'all, whole, every' < PIE *h₃oli̯o- 'all'.

The Goidelic and Brittonic words probably belong to separate cognate classes. According to LEIA O-5, OIr ocus belongs to the preposition oc and further to the PIE verbal root *h₂nek̑- 'to reach' (LIV 282), while LIPP vol. 2 (2014: 11) reconstructs Middle Welsh â, ag etc. as *ád gʰe.

Based on Proto-Celtic *leu̯-tu- or *lou̯-tu- 'ash' (PIE *leu̯h₃- 'to wash' LIV² 418), but different stems or reshapings in Goidelic and Brittonic. Matasović (2009, 246) postulates MIr. lúaith < *lou̯-tu̯-i-, MW lludw < *low-tw-o-. Alternatively an underlying *le/ou̯-tu̯-ah₂ is possible, see the discussion in Irslinger (2002, 115). Brittonic could continue this stem directly, while the Middle Irish word has become an i-stem. OIr. lúaithred and Scottish Gaelic luaithre (and Manx?) contain the collective suffixe -red (Thurneysen 1946, 169).
S.v. σπείρω 'to sow, seed'. Mycenaean Greek pe-ma, pe-mo and Ancient Greek σπέρμα reflect PIE *spér-mn̥.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *wello-, *wallo- 'error, deceit' (cf. OIr. foll 'crime', MIr. fell 'deceit, treachery, crime'). Connected by {ref IEW} 1140 to Lith. vìlti, vìlbinti 'deceive', Skt. valh- 'puzzle (by riddles)', Gk. ἐλεφαίρομαι 'deceive', in which case we should reconstruct *(h₁)u̯elh₁-(bʰ)-. The geminate *-ll- in Proto-Celtic may be from *-ln-, but the loss of the laryngeal is surprising.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *druko- 'bad'. The etymology is quite uncertain. One might want to try to relate Proto-Celtic *druko- to PIE *dʰreu̯gʰ- 'deceive' (IEW 276, Skt. drúhyate 'deceives', OHG bi-triugan 'decieve', gi-trog 'deceit') from an appealing semantic connection 'false, deceitful' > 'bad', but the the voiceless *-k- in Celtic (instead of *-g-) is problematic.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *rūsk(l)o-, rusko- 'bark'. It is possible that some of the Brittonic forms (with -u-) were borrowed from Goidelic, or Romance in the prehistoric period. The vocalism of OIr. rúsc is probably original, though DIL states that it was borrowed from Brittonic. If inherited, then the forms may be analysed as *rū-sko- < *ruH-sko-, cf. PIE *reu̯H- 'to rip, to tear' ({ref LIV²} 510, {ref IEW} 868), i.e. bark is conceived as 'something ripped' (cf. ON rýja 'shear (of sheep)', OCS ryti 'dig', Lat. ruō 'dig out', TochB ru- 'pull out', etc.
Cf. s.v. 3. *sper- 'ausstreuen' (IEW 933-4).
The Brittonic words originate from PIE *prō-ko- (no exact cognates; Avestan, Old Church Slavonic and Latin have *pro-ko-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *smēha- 'small', an exclusively Germanic lexeme. The older proposed connection to Greek (σ)μικρός 'small' from *smh₁-i-k-ro- in untenable on formal grounds.
Modern Greek forms from Ancient Greek σκωλήκιον, diminutive of σκώληξ 'worm, earthworm'.
From French par l'amour 'for the love (of)'. Earliest attestation 1499.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *māro- 'great', from PIE *moh₁-ro- (PIE *meh₁-), cf. OHG māri 'news; known, famous, great', Gk. -μωρος in compounds.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *fet-no- 'bird', derived from PIE *pet- 'fly'. The thematic stem *fetno- is presumably generalised from the heteroclitic stem *fatar (gen. *fetnos). Cf. also s.v. Proto-Celtic *fatar / gen. *fatanos, *fetnos 'wing, bird' (to which may be compared Hitt. pattar, Skt. pátra-, Gk. πτερόν, Lat. penna).

S.v. *dʰeu̯b- 'tief' (IEW 267f., EIEC 154). Celtic forms are from Proto-Celtic *dubu- 'black' in OIr. dub 'black, dark', OWel. dub MWel. du, OBret. du-, Middle Cornish duw 'id.', these forms are directly cognate with Lithuanian dubùs 'deep' and may be accounted for via a u-stem adjective *dʰub-u-. The proposed connection with Gk. τυφλός (with an alternative -λο- suffix) is dubious, cf. p.123n4 for further discussion.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *swizd-o- ‘to blow’ (PIE *su̯ei̯s-d-, IEW 1040, cf. Gk. σίζω, Ru. svistát'). The words are onomatopoetic, therefore the possibility cannot be excluded that IEW's proposed cognates in other IE branches are independent creations.
Reconstructs the Celtic verb as *su̯isd-e/o-, which has no cognates beyond Celtic.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *bruson- 'abdomen, womb', from PIE *breu̯s- 'belly'(?), cf. OE breost 'breast', Russ. brjúxo 'belly, paunch'. Proto-Celtic *bruson- is an n-stem derived from the zero-grade of the PIE root (*bʰrus-on-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *yegi- 'ice' < PIE *i̯eg- 'ice' (IEW 503), cf. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', ON yaki, Wakhi yaz 'glacier'.

In Brittonic, the paradigms of the the verbs 'to go' and 'to come' are highly suppletive. The finite forms are based on the stems a- < *ag- < *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' (LIV 255) and el- < *pelh₂- 'to approach' (LIV 470). In the paradigm of 'to go', these forms are used uncompounded, while in the paradigm of 'to come', they contain the preverb *tu-. In Middle Welsh, some imperative forms are based on *ret-e/o- < *ret- 'to run' (LIV 507). The verbal nouns of 'to come' Welsh mynet, Breton monet originate from PIE *menH- 'to step, to stamp'? (LIV 438). The verbal noun of 'to go', Breton donet contains the same root prefixed with *tu-, i.e. *de-vonet, cf. also Old Breton diminet. The Welsh verbal noun dyfod 'to come' contains *tu- + bod 'to be' based on PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to become, to grow' (LIV 98). See Schumacher (2004, 189-193), Hemon (1975, 236).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *truk-, *truxso- 'trunk, broken part', from PIE *treu̯k- 'cut' ({ref IEW} 1074, cf. Lat. truncus 'mutilated; stem').
S.v. *dei̯-, di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f.).
From Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'dig, bury', cf. PIE *kelh₂- 'hit, break' (LIV² 350, IEW 546f.).
A Germanic-Celtic cognate set.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *luk-o- 'see, perceive, set eyes upon', from PIE *leuk- 'shine' (IEW 687, cf. Hitt. lukk- 'get light, dawn', Skt. rócate 'shines', OLat. lūceō 'make light', OPr. luckis 'torch, log', TochB luk- 'to shine'). From this root is also derived OW licat (MW llygat) 'well, source', OCo. lagat (gloss 'oculus'), MBret. lagat.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷello- 'far', perhaps from PIE *kʷel- 'to turn' (IEW 640), although this etymology is speculative.
The Brittonic Forms are from Proto-Celtic *ne-kwāt- (Schrijver, Old British 2011, 55).
Consists of the negator nep and meur 'big'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *tefnet- 'fire' derived from PIE *tep- 'be warm'. The Celtic form presupposes an original s-stem *tepnēs-.
S.v. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (LIV 629f., IEW 1069f.).

Cf. s.v. OIr. sná- 'couler (d'un liquide ou d'un cours d'eau)', going back to the IE root *snā- (cf. Skt. snā́ti 'il se baigne', Gk. νήχω 'je nage', etc.). The Brythonic forms are from the same root in a derived dental stem (cf. Lat. natō 'je nage', Bret. neijal, nijal 'voler').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *treget- 'foot', cf. PIE *tregʰ- 'run, walk' (IEW 1089).
S.v. Proto-Insular-Celtic *-dī- 'setzen' from PIE *dʰeh₁- (LIV² 136-138) > (+ pro > ro-) Middle Welsh roði 'geben'
S.v. Proto-Celtic *mati- 'good' from PIE *meh₂-t- (cf. Lat. mānis, mānus, Mātūta 'goddess Dawn').

S.v. Proto-Celtic *gʷeltā 'grass', further derived to Proto-Celtic *gʷel-o- 'graze, eat'. The identification of the IE root from which the related forms in Celtic are not generally agreed upon. Perhaps with Arm. klanem 'swallow', Russ. glotat' 'swallow', Lat. gluttio < PIE *gleu̯- (so {ref IEW} 365). Alternatively OE ceole, Germ. Kehle 'throat' < PIE *gel-, but if OIr. gelid is related to the word for grass, then the Celtic proto-form must contain initial *gʷʰ-, since PIE *gʷ- > Proto-Celtic *b-. There does not, however, appear to be evidence for a root *gʷʰel- 'to graze' in Indo-European.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *durno- 'fist', probably a loan from an non-IE language.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷenno- 'head'. The ablaut attested in cognate vocabulary within Celtic suggest that the lexeme is inherited rather than borrowed from a substratum, but no successful identification with a known PIE root or cognate vocabulary outside of Celtic has yet been made.

Generally assumed to originate from Proto-Celtic *magos 'plain, field' and cognate with Welsh ma 'place', Old Breton ma 'place', Old Irish magh 'plain', and the locative copula Middle Welsh yma, Middle Breton ema 'is (in a certain place)'. Cf. also Deshayes (2003, 483).
*delg̑ʰ- 'to become fixed, solid' (LIV 113), Proto-Celtic *delg-o- 'to hold, contain'.

Irish and Breton ma belong to PIE *mó 'who?, which, whoever', a pronominal stem which is used in  interrogative and relative functions as well as indefinte enclitic. The Insular Celtic conjunctions originate from *mā́ < *mé-h₂-(é)h₁ 'by what means? how?', an instrumental adverb based on the collective.

From *kʷé-h₁ le 'far' < 'how far?; how far!', a collocation consisting of the interrogative pronoun *kʷé-h₁ 'how?' (instrumental) and the deictic particle *li, le 'over there, yonder; then'. At an early time, *kʷé-h₁ le was reduced to *kʷéli/e. This latter form underlies among others Brittonic pell < *kʷel-so-.
S.v. *kʷó-, *kʷí- 'wer?; irgendwer' (Pronominalstamm, interrogativ; indefinit, wenn enklitisch; ?relativ)
S.v. Proto-Celtic *slad-yo- 'to hit, to slay'. No convincing IE etymology.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *dol-V- 'leaf', from PIE *delh₁- 'blossom' (cf. OE dile 'dill', Arm. dalar 'green'). There are different stems formations in Irish, Brittonic and Gaulish: OIr. duille should be derived from *dolnya, while the Brittonic forms are from *dolya, and Gaulish seems to have a reflex of *dola.
Cf. s.v. *dalh₁- 'herausquellen, hervorsprießen' (LIV 132, IEW 234). Brittonic Middle Welsh deil etc. and Latin folium < *dʰolh₁-(i)yo- (with question mark. Alternative etymology possible).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *klēyo- 'left', from PIE *k̑lei̯- (cf. Lat. clīuius 'inauspicious, ominous', Goth. hleiduma 'left', Lith. šleĩvas 'bow-legged').

S.v. Proto-Celtic *garrV- 'calf of the leg, shank'. There is no good Indo-European etymology. Matasović suggests that it may be possible to derive these forms from the PIE word for 'hand' (PIE *g̑ʰesr > Hitt. kissar, Gr. χείρ) and gives two possible developments that would yield the Celtic forms regularly. The semantic development was then 'hand, arm' > 'limb' > '(calf of the) leg'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *awV- (?) 'liver'. The Proto-Celtic reconstruction is very uncertain, therefore an IE etymology based on it is even more speculative.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *sīro- 'long' < *seh₁-ro- 'long lasting' (IEW 891), cf. Skt. sāyá- 'evening', Lat. sērus 'late', Goth. seiþu 'evening'.
Cf. s.v. *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, *dʰg̑ʰ-ém-, *dʰg̑ʰ-m-´-, *g̑ʰ-m̥-m-´-, f. 'Erde' (IEW 414ff.).

The origin of cals is obscure. It may be the same word as Modern Breton kalz 'heap': ur c'hals teil 'a dunghill'. In fact, Modern Breton ur c'halz is sometimes used instead of kalz itself: eur c'halz ac'hanomp 'many of us'.

Cognate class B seems to be wrong. Check Dyen, Isidore Kruskal, Joseph and Black, Paul (1992). An Indoeuropean Classification, a Lexicostatistical Experiment. Transactions of the American Philosophical Society 82/5.
[delete citation]
S.v. Proto-Celtic *melino- 'yellow', derived from Proto-Celtic *meli 'honey' (from PIE *meli cf. Lat. mel, Gk. μέλι, Hitt. melitt-, Arm. mełr, Alb. mjal).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *blēdanī- 'year'. The forms point to three different stems: an ī-stem in OW bloidin, MW blwyddyn and a thematic stem *blēda, or *blēdom in W blwydd, OBret. blid, MoBret. bloaz m. and Co. bloth 'year'. W blynedd and OBret. blened originate from zero grade *blid-nii̯o- (originally an adjective?).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kayto- 'wood', from IE *kai̯to- 'wood, field' ({ref IEW} 521), cf. Goth. haiϸi 'field'. The reflexes *kai̯to- are restricted to Celtic and Germanic; perhaps a borrowing from a NW European substratum language.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *mogu- 'servant', from PIE *mogʰ-u- 'young person' ({ref IEW} 696), cf. Goth. magus 'boy', mawi 'young girl', Av. maγava- 'unmarried').
S.v. 1. *ko, 1. *kóm 'zusammen, mit, bei' (Adverb, lokal; oft mit Instr.)

First attested in the Catholicon (1499). Verb related to the noun torch m. 'cork, stopper, torch', first attested in the Catholicon (1499) and borrowed from Old French torche 'torch' (1170), from Vulgar Latin *torca from Classical Latin torqua.
Verb derived productively from this borrowed noun or rather from the French Verb torcher 'to wipe'? (CHECK attestations)

S.v. παῖς, παιδός 'child, boy, son, slave, servant', more rarely 'girl, daughter'. The Greek forms are from PIE *peh₂-u- 'few, little' with further stem enlargements in *-i-d-. Disyllabic forms in epic and dialectal texts point to original *παϝ-ι-δ-. παίζω 'play' is a denominative verb to this lexeme.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *awelā 'breeze, wind', cf. PIE *h₂uh₁-el- (IEW 81ff.). Neuter l-stem, probably with nom. sg. *h₂ewh₁-l, gen. sg. *h₁uh₂-el-s, cf. Gk. ἄελλα 'stormwind'.

Pedersen thinks that ir. fracc 'woman', Welsh gwrach, Breton groac'h 'old woman' are cognate with lat. uirgō 'virgin', uirāgō 'warlike woman'. He thus reconstructs a Proto-Celtic n-stem nom. sg. *u̯ragṓ, gen. sg. u̯ragn-ós. The genitive developed to *u̯ragg-ós > brit. *u̯rakk-ós. In British, a new nominative *wrakō was then formed for this genitive. This nominative underlies Middle Welsh gwreic, Modern Welsh gwraig, Middle Breton gurec etc.
Pedersen (159) doubts that these words are cognate with the word for 'man'.
Latin virgō 'virgin' is not cognate with PIE *uiHro- 'man'.

S.v. *flitano-, *flitawī 'broad', from PIE *plth₂u- 'broad', *plth₂u̯ih₂ 'the broad one' (cf. pr̥thivī́- 'earth', Gk. Πλάταια (toponym)). Proto-Celtic *flitawī directly represents the feminine form, while *flitano- is from derived *plth₂-no- (cf. Hitt. paltana- 'shoulder').

Interrogative, nom. sg. animate *kʷí-s 'who?'. The full-grade *kʷei̯-Ø 'who' of the Insular Celtic interrogative is unparalleled and originates probably by analogy with the anaphoric pronoun nom. sg. *éi̯-Ø 'he'. Cp. the alternative analysis p. 463 with fn. 60.
S.v. φαρδύς. From Medieval Greek φαρδύς < Ancient (εὐ-)φραδής 'wise; linguistically correct' (with metathesis /fra-/ > /far-/).
Oir. cía and Late-Proto-British *pui reflect Insular Celtic *kʷē(s). Its ultimate origin is unclear: Proto-Celtic *kʷes-est(i) 'who is?'
From pez tra 'what thing'? The noun pez 'thing' developed into the interrogative 'what'.

Petra does not belong to cognate class A. Pe- < *pez just happens to be homonymous.      CHECK Dyen, Isidore Kruskal, Joseph and Black, Paul (1992). An Indoeuropean Classification, a Lexicostatistical Experiment. Transactions of the American Philosophical Society 82/5.

S.v. δένδρεον 'tree'. Ancient Greek δένδρον is generally connected with PIE *deru-/*doru- 'wood' (cf. also Chantraine, DELG pp.262-263). Δένδρεον < *δενδρεϝον agrees with the Germanic word for 'tree' (Goth. triu, OE trēow 'tree', etc.), but the form of reduplication to the stem is rare in Greek. Cf. also Gk. δόρυ 'wood, tree (trunk), spear' from *dóru-.
From Ancient Greek ἐπειδή 'after that, since, when'

S.v. Bret. kof 'ventre', borrowed during the Middle Breton period from Old French *coffe, variant of coffre (1175) from Vulgar Latin *cophinum in turn of Greek origin. First attested in the Catholicon (1499).
S.v. Bret. labouss 'oiseau'. It has been assumed to originate from Latin locusta 'grasshopper' but rather of unknown origin. First attested in the Catholicon (1499).
Although a borrowing seems to be likely, the sources proposed so far are semantically unconvincing.

Related to Middle Breton croc adj. 'attached, taken', m. 'catch, hook, efford' from Old French croc (end of 12th cent.) from Scandinavian krôkr. Croc and creguiff are both first attested in the Catholicon (1499).
The Middle Breton verb may be productively formed from the noun and is thus not borrowed itself.

S.v. Bret. oabr 'ciel, nues' corresponding to W wybr, also equivalent to Co. ebren 'firmament' and W wybren 'id.'; Bret. koabr coll. 'nues, nuages noirs' from k- + oabr supposing *com-oepr. First attested in the Catholicon (1499).
From Proto-Celtic *lutno-.
Also in the placename Cevenna 'Cevennes', which points to Gaulish *Cebenna. From Proto-Celtic *cebn-.
S.v. Bret. gwad 'sang; sève' from Old Breton gouet and corresponding to Cornish gos (Old Cornish guit), Welsh gwaed (Middle Welsh guayt) and to Gaelic féith from Proto-Celtic u̯ait-o-.

S.v. Bret. kont 'compte; mention, situation', a borrowing from Old French conte, deverbal to conter 'compter, calculer', ultimately from Lat. computāre. Associated verbs kontañ (contaff), kontiñ (contein), conto 'compter, considérer'.

Middle Breton niveraff is first attested in the Catholicon (1499). It can be analyzed as a denominal verb. The basis niver 'number' is borrowed from Latin numerus. This borrowing took place early, cf. Old Breton nimer 'number'. Middle Breton niveraff thus is either inherited from Old Breton or formed productively from niver.
S.v. Bret. lous 'sale', corresponding to Cornish lôs 'vil, souillé, misérable, sordide' and Old French los 'misérable, méchant, taquin'. Of obscure origin.
Cf. s.v. OIr. secc 'desséche, dur, rigide', a borrowing from Lat. siccus, also borrowed in Brythonic, cf. OW sich, MW, W sych 'sec' Corn. sichor 'siccitas' MCorn. sech 'sec', OBret. sech 'sèche'.
S.v. Bret. poultr 'poudre', like Corn. polter a borrowing from Old French poldre (< Lat. pulverem).
S.v. Bret. skouarn 'oreille, anse, oreillion', cf. Co. scovarn, W. ysgyfarn, from Proto-Celtic *skob-erna.
S.v. Bret. douar 'terre, domaine', from Old Breton doiar with correspondences in Co. dor and W daear. Of uncertain origin.
From Old Breton diprim < *di- + prim. The second element corresponds to Irish crim- in crimóg 'morsel' (where attested? Neither in eDIL nor in Ó Dónaill).
Cf. the cognate nouns Breton kouez m. 'fall', Welsh cwydd 'fall'. Based on Proto-Celtic *kei̯d-.

Attested in the Catholicon (1499). (Deshayes gives 1396 as date of first attestation. What source is this?)
Borrowed from Old French lard, lart (12th cent.) < Latin laridum 'fat'.

S.v. Bret. kann adj. qual. 'blanc' from Proto-Celtic *kando-; from the adjective is derived the verb kannañ (cannaff 1499) 'blanchir, laver; se battre, combattre, bagarrir' identical to Cornish canna 'blanchir' and to Welsh cannaf, cannu 'blanchir'. The original meaning of the verb is 'to bleach laundry (by beating)' > 'to beat'.
S.v. Bret. pesk 'poisson', first attested in the Catholicon (1499). corresponding to Cornish pysk (Old Cornish pisc) and Welsh pesg. The three are borrowed from Latin piscis.

First attested in the Catholicon (1499), cf. the cognate noun flod 'flood, tide; fleet' (beginning of 16th cent.). The latter is borrowed from Old French flot (1175) from Frankish *flôt 'flood' and Skandinavian floti 'raft'.
Pre-Modern Breton borrowing.

S.v. Bret. brum 'nuage de brume', a loanword from Old French brume 'hiver', in turn from Lat. bruma. First attested in Maunoir, Les dictionnaires... 1659. Productively formed from Middle Breton brume (1499). Only the latter is a loan-word.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *danto- 'tooth', from PIE *h₁dont- 'tooth' (cf. Lat. dēns, Skt. dánt-, Gk. ὀδών, Lith. dantìs, OHG zand). The reconstruction of the initial laryngeal is uncertain. Some prefer to see an original participle of the verb 'to eat' *h₁ed-, but others reconstruct *h₃- from which Gk. ὀδών is derived more straightforwardly.
Denominal verb based on the lexeme for 'tooth'. Parallel formations possible. CHECK
S.v. *h₁ed- '(beißen →) essen' (LIV² 230f., IEW 287ff.).
S.v. *h₁ed- '(beißen →) essen' (IEW 287-289).
S.v. Bret. frwezh 'fruit', corresponding to Co. fruyth, W. ffrwyth, which are all borrowed from Lat. fructum.
S.v. Bret. gwer 'vert'; presupposes an older form *guerz equivalent to Welsh gwyrdd (Old Welsh guird) which go back to a late Latin *virdis (Latin viridis).
First attested in the manuscript version of the Catholicon (1464). Borrowed from Old French coraille 'guts, intestines' (1160) based on Latin cor 'heart'.

S.v. Bret. blew 'chevelure, cheveux, poils, robe (d'animal), from Old Breton bleu and corresponding to Cornish blew (Old Cornish bleu) and to Welsh blew, further from Proto-Celtic *blou̯i-, without nay further cognates (cf. Henry, Lexique étymologique du breton moderne, Rennes 1900).
S.v. Bret. kalon 'cœur, âme (de cordage)', from Old Breton calonn and corresponding to Co. colon and Welsh calon, from Proto-Celtic *kal-ona-.
S.v. Bret. pounner 'lourd; exagéré, grave', a borrowing from Latin ponderis 'of weight'.
S.v. Bret. sko s.m. 'frappe, heurt; échouage'; denominal verb skoiñ (squeiff, 1499). The noun continues Old Breton sco 'coup', but the further etymology remains obscure.
S.vv. Bret. chass 'chiens', 'dogs' a borrowing from Old French chace (chasse) 'hunt' (n.), the verb chasseal 'chasser' is productively formed within Breton from chass 'chiens'.
Verb formed productively from a borrowed base.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *selgā 'hunt' (noun), from which the verbal forms are derived, based on PIE *selg̑- 'send away, set loose' (cf. Skt. sr̥játi 'sets loose, discharges', AGk. (dial.) λαγάσαι 'to set free', MHG selken 'to trickle, drip'). MoBret. emholc'h is from *ambi-selg-o-.
Cf. s.v. Bret. hel'ch 'fait d'être essoufflé', from Old Breton holg 'recherche, enquête, chasse' and corresponding to Co. helgh 'chasse', and Olr. seilg 'chasse'.
S.v. Bret. skorn 'glace', a word of obscure origin. First attested in the Catholicon (1499).

Favereau cites Cornish scorn and Old French sorne (Ernault). Cf. scorne 'scoria, vitrified/petrified mass found in the melting vessel originating from metallurgic processes'. How likely is it that a borrowed technical term like this becomes the Swadesh term for 'ice'?

Proto-Celtic *mā, *ma 'if', conjunction < PIE: *meh₂- (particle) (IEW 966), cognate with Greek mḗn (particle).
"The short vowel seen in Olr. ma and MBret. ma could perhaps be
explained by shortening in clitics. Cf. also particles such as Hitt. -ma 'but', Skt. sma." Matasović takes ma and mar to be identical.
Breton ma corresponds to Irish ma 'if', while Breton and Cornish mar originate from a Proto-Celtic noun *maros 'worry, anxiety'.
Note 1: "The origin of mar, also found in Cornish, is obscure. It seems to consist of ma and an element -r, perhaps a reduced form of the verbal particle ra, Old Breton ro."

S.v. Proto-Celtic *swar-yo- 'laugh', from PIE *su̯er- 'sound, make a sound' (IEW 1049f.), cf. Skt. svárati, ON sverja 'swear', perh. Lat. susurrus 'whisper'. "The attribution of these Celtic forms to the PIE root *swer- is semantically difficult, but possible (see KPV 609)."
S.v. Bret. c'hoarz 'rire' corresponding to Co. warth, W chwardd, going back to Proto-Celtic *su̯er-d-o-.
Breton gourvez has cognates in Cornish and Welsh. Verb related to the noun gourwez m., compound of gour- < *upor- and Breton gwez, Corn. gweth, W gwedd 'aspect, form'.
Welsh gwedd etc. from PIE *u̯idā 'sight, aspect', root *u̯ei̯d- 'to see'.
On the TochB form *śiñce, this form is usually derived to *snigʷʰ-en- (cf. {ref NIL}, {ref EIEC}, {ref Adams 2013}), but cf. Adams (2013) for other proposals for the Tocharian stem formation.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kīkā 'breast'. According to DIL there is some evidence that OIr. cích was a neuter s-stem, so perhaps *kīkos- might be a better reconstruction. Matasović assumes that the meaning of MIr. cích 'beast' as primary and that the word is a popular expressive word often used for female body parts.

S.v. OIr. cích (rarely) 'téton, sein'. LEIA assumes that the meaning 'meat' is the original one because of the compound adjective mir. ciccar 'voracious' (LU 2148) < *cig-car 'meat-loving'. Cites an uncertain connection with Greek κῖκυς 'force' by {ref Pedersen 1909}:51.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *lugrā- 'moon', from PIE *leu̯g- 'to bend, twist' (IEW 685f.), cf. Gk. λυγίζω 'bend', Lith. lùgnas 'twisted', Skt. rujáti 'breaks'. Previous connections made by IEW 690 connecting the Celtic forms to PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' are implausible for phonological reasons since there is no evidence for the root having a voiced velar.
Alternatively relates W lloer etc. to Lat. lūridus 'pale, yellow', from a putative PIE *lou̯s-, *leu̯s-, i.e. Late Proto-British *loer < *luðrā or *luθrā < *lusrā. A mere possibility.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *genu- 'jaw' from PIE *g̑enu- 'jaw' (IEW 381), cf. Skt. hánu-, Gk. γένυς, Lat. gena 'cheek', OEng. cinn, TochA śanweṃ (du.) 'jaws'. The singular of this word is reflected in OIr. gin u m. 'mouth' and in the Brittonic words for 'cheek', MW gen f.'cheek', OBret. gen gl. maxilla, MBret. guen, MoBret. gen f. 'cheek'. The Brittonic words for 'mouth' is based on the plural Proto-Celtic *genou̯es.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bek(k)o- 'beak, snout', probably an expressive word comparable to Lat. bucca 'mouth', cf. Gaul. beccus (Suetonius), *bekko- > Fr. bec. No further etymology.
Discusses the different reconstructions of the PIE word.
S.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (LIV 264f., IEW 42f.).

S.v. Bret. tost (adj. qual.) 'avare; serré, sévère; minutieux' and adv. 'presque' and prep. 'près de', corresponding to W tost 'sévère, dur, véhément, furieux; douloureux' borrowed from Lat. tostus 'grilled, burned'.
S.v. Bret. gouzoug 'cou, col, gorge, goulot', from Old Breton guodoc and corresponding to Co. *ghuduk and W gwddwg from Proto-Celtic *u̯udok-.
S.v. *neu̯- 'neu' (IEW 769).
The adjectives *néu̯o-, *néu̯i̯o- are based on the particle *nú 'now'.

S.v. 1. *negʷ- 'dunkel werden, dämmern' (LIV 449, IEW 762f.). PIE nom.sg. *nokʷt-, gen.sg. *nekʷt- 'night' from the root *negʷ- 'to become dark' (LIV 449) with devoicing of the final consonant next to *-t-. See fn. 1 with a discussion of the different stem analyses and inflectional patterns which have been suggested for PIE.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *srognā 'nose', from PIE *sregʰ- 'snore' (IEW 1002), cf. Gk. ῥέγχω 'snore', Arm. ṙngun-kʻ 'nose'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kotto- 'old'. "According to Sims-Williams (2006: 67) Cat. cot 'hill', Sp. cueto are from the Gaulish reflex of this word. The semantic development was presumably from 'old' to 'curved, humpbacked hillock'. In any case, these words are probably of non-IE origin."
Cf. s.v. *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, *dʰg̑ʰ-ém-, *dʰg̑ʰ-m-´-, *g̑ʰ-m̥-m-´-, f. 'Erde' (IEW 414ff.).
Cf. Old Breton guari, huari, Middle Breton hoari, Modern Breton c'hoari m. 'game' from Proto-Celtic *su̯er-o-.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *rig-o- 'to bind', cf. *(H)rei̯g- 'to bind, to reach' (IEW 861, LIV 503), cf. Lat. rigeō 'be stiff', MHG ricken 'bind', OHG reihhen 'reach', Lith. réižti 'to stretch, tighten'. OIr. con-rig 'binds together' < *kom-rig-o-, MW gwarny 'play' (GPC gwarny, gwary), MBret. hoari 'play' < MW gwarny and MBret. hoari < *ufo-rig-o-.
From Proto-Celtic *u̯rako-.
From PIE *h₁eti 'still, also'

Latin animāl- originally a derived noun in -al- to animus 'mind, spirit', meaning 'living thing'.  Ultimately from PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'breath' (cf. Ancient Greek ἄνεμος 'wind' /lexeme/19002/, Arm. hołm 'wind' /lexeme/28663/, Old Irish anim 'soul').
Latin bestia is of uncertain etymology.
Latin ad, Oscan ad-, Umbrian -ař, all from Proto-Italic adposition *ad, in turn ultimately from PIE adposition/preverb *h₂ed.

S.v. Lat. dorsum 'the back, a ridge', a compound of dē- 'away from' and versus 'turned towards', i.e. *dē-worsum 'turned away from' > *dēorsum > deorsum > dorsum, as Paul. ex F. considered. In the sense 'the turned away part'; Lat. versus 'turned towards' from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around' (cf. s.v. ve/ortō, -ere 'to turn around').
A Common Brittonic (and Irish) borrowing von Latin tendere 'to stretch, to direct'.
Cites literature for both assumptions.
An inherited word based on PIE *ten- 'to stretch, to span' may have mixed up with a Latin borrowing.

S.v. *tens- 'ziehen' (IEW 1068-9). LIV points out that the root *tens- could originate from the desiderative of *ten- 'wanting to stretch'. If this was the case, *tens- was perceived as an independent neo-root already in Late PIE.
From Idg. *eti „darüber, hinaus“
Attempts to derive Lat. bēstia from PIE *dʰu̯es- 'breathe', but the necessary phonological developments are uncertain.  Cf. de Vaan (2008) s.v. bēlua 'beast' with references to recent literature.

S.v. Lat. cinis -eris 'residue of fire, ashes, ashes of a dead person'. From an s-stem *ken-is-.  de Vaan reconstructs the s-stem as an extension of an earlier PIE i-stem noun *kon(H)-i- / *ken(H)-i- 'dust', of which Latin cinis continues the e-grade.  Compares to Ancient Greek κόνις 'dust' from the o-grade, TochB kentse 'dust' < *koniso-.  Dismisses Walde-Hofmann (1938-1954)'s connection to PIE *kneh₂- 'to plane, rub' (Ancient Greek -κναίω) as 'not compelling).

S.v. Lat. malus 'mauvais, méchant', Etymology uncertain. Appearance of Oscan dolud malud, perum dolom mallom in the Tabula Bantia may give evidence for Proto-Italic *malo-, however this legal phraseology in Oscan may have been borrowed from Latin.  Scattered attestation of lexemes such as Old Irish mell 'destruction', Ancient Greek μέλεος 'idle, unhappy', Classical Armenian meł 'sin', Lithuanian mẽlas 'lie', Latv. màlds 'mistake', suggest a possible PIE *mol-o-.  Because of the different semantics, however, this connection remains uncertain.

S.v. Lat. malus 'unpleasant, bad', from Proto-Italic *malo- (cf. O mallom, malom [acc.sg.], either from O. *malu̯o-/*mali̯o- or a borrowing from Latin), from PIE *mol-o- 'bad'? (cf. OIr. mell 'destruction', Gk. μέλεος 'idle; unhappy', perh. βλασφημέω 'to slander'; Arm. mel 'sin', Lith. mẽlas 'lie', Latv. màlds 'mistake'. "The etymology given here is proposed by [{ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}]. It is semantically fine, but since it concerns a collection of largely isolated words in different IE branches it remains uncertain."

S.v. Lat. cortex, -icis 'bark of a tree', from PIE *k(o)rt- 'a cutting' (cf. Skt. kr̥ntáti, YAv. kərəṇta- 'to cut', Arm. kʻertʻem 'to peel off the skin', Lith. kir̃sti 'to hew off, cut', OHG herdo 'skin, hide', OE heorda 'hide'. Latin cortex was formed with a productive suffix -ek- (also found in caudex 'tree-trunk', frutex 'shrub').
S.v. Lat. cortex, -icis 'écorce', connected to the group of Lith. kertù 'je coupe, j'abats', OCS črъtǫ, črěsti 'couper', kratъkъ 'court', Skt. kr̥ntáti, Av. kərəntaiti 'il coupe', etc.

S.v. Lat. venter, -tris 'belly, abdomen'. Latin uenter is generally agreed to be from PIE *(H)ued-ro- 'belonging to the belly' however the exact origins of the word-internal nasal is unclear.  Cf. also s.v. uterus  'womb, belly' < *(H)ud-ér-o- for the sound change of medial *-d- > -t- in this word.

S.v. Lat. grandis 'grown up, big, tall'. Etymology unclear.  Previous proposals in Walde-Hofmann (1938-1954) to connect Lat. grandis to a root *gʷʰrnd- (Ancient Greek βρένθος 'pride' OCS grǫdь 'breast') dismissed on the basis of poor semantic comparison.
S.v. *meg̑- 'groß' (IEW 708f., EIEC 344). Cf. entry for extensive discussion of stem derivations found in individual IE branches.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *magyo- < PIE *meg̑h₂-. The Irish and Gaulish forms go back to PCelt. *magi̯o-. According to NIL this in turn maybe from PIE *m̥g̑-i̯o/i̯ah₂-.
S.v. Lat. avis 'bird', from Proto-Italic *awi- (Umbrian avif), from PIE *h₂eui- 'bird' (cf. Skt. váy- [nom.sg. véḥ/viḥ], YAv. vii- 'bird', Gk. αἰετός (< *h₂eu̯i-eto-), Arm. haw 'bird').
S.v. Lat. mordeō, -ēs, momordī, morsum, -ēre 'mordre'. Ernout-Meillet consider the only possible form for comparison Sanskrit mardayati 'il broie', whose stem is formally identical to Lat. mordeō.

S.v. Lat. mordeō 'to bite', from a PIE iterative present *h₂mord-éi̯e-, accepting Ernout-Meillet's comparison with Sanskrit mardáya-, but also comparing Ancient Greek ἀμέρδω 'to deprive of' and Old English smeortan 'to hurt'.

Cf. s.v. Lat. āter, -tra, -trum 'black' < PIE *h₂eh₁-t(-)r- 'fireplace' (cf. OIr. áith, W. odyn 'furnace, oven' < PCl. *āti-; Pal. hāri 'to be warm', Av. ātarš, gen.sg. āθrō 'fire' < PIr. *ātr-). The Latin derivative ātrium 'first main room in a Roman-style house' seems to indicate that this room originally contained the fire-place.  The development of Proto-Italic *ātr-o- appears to have undergone a semantic development 'fireplace-like' > 'having a fireplace-like colour, black'.
S.v. Lat. niger 'black, dark'. Unknown etymology.
S.v. Lat. niger 'noir'. Etymology unknown.
Cf. s.v. Lat. flō, flāre 'to blow', from PIE *bʰleh₁-/*blh₁- 'to blow'; many compounded forms with preverbs.
Cf. Old French boute < bot 'blow, ' (1160), bouter 'to collide, to clash, to push' (1190).
From Proto-Celtic *u̯olau̯o-.
S.v. *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'rot machen' (LIV 508f., IEW 872ff.).
Cf. s.v. *h₃reg̑- 'gerade richten, ausstrecken' (IEW 854-7).
S.v. NHG recht (adj.), from Germanic *rehta- (adj.) 'right straight' in Gothic raiths, Old Norse réttr, Old English riht, Old Frankish riucht, riocht.
S.v. pa-si (II), equivalent to Attic φημί 'speak' (Dor., Aeol. φᾱμί).
S.v. 2. *bʰeh₂- 'sprechen, sagen' (IEW 105-6).
Cf. s.v. PIE *h₂ep- 'water, river' (Anatolian and Baltic), ?*h₂ep-h₃on- 'river' (Celtic).
S.v. *sengʷʰ- 'singen, verkünden' (IEW 906-7).
PIE *sent- 'to go' >> 'to perceive' LIV 533 (NOT cognate with *sengʷʰ- 'to sing, to announce' LIV 532)
From Proto-Celtic *sentu- 'path', cf. PIE *sent- 'head for, go' (IEW 908).
Middle Breton is borrowed from Old French corde (1175) < latin chorda of Greek origin, while Cornish corden and Welsh cordyn originate from English cord.
There are no arguments to sustain Deshayes' hypothesis. A common Brittonic borrowing from Latin would be equally possible. Borrowing probably pre-Middle Breton.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *bragno-, *bragni- 'rotten, faul' (OIr. brén, MW braen, MBret. brein), cf. PIE *bʰreHg- (IEW 165f.). "Although these words are sometimes derived from the same root as Lat. marceō 'be withered' (PIE *merk-, IEW 739), this is unsatisfactory from the formal point of view, since *mrk-no- would give PCelt. *mrikno-."

Verb based on Proto-Celtic *tara-u̯o- 'hit, strike', PIE *terh₁- 'to drill, to rub' (IEW 1072, LIV 632) . Cognate with MW taraw, taro, (GPC trawaf[Pres 1 s]), OBret. toreusit gl. atriuit, MBret. tarauat 'rub, use', MoBret. tarawad.

The reconstruction of the PIE form is difficult. The underlying noun may be either root noun or an l-stem, belonging to one of several possible accentual patterns. The proto-forms of the individual branches display thus varying degrees of analogical levelling. Possibilities: *săl- < *sh₂l- or *sh₂al-; *sāl- < *sah₂l-; alternatively < *sh₂ḗl- or *sh₂ṓl- with analogical influence of *săl-.
Reconstructs a hysterokinetic l-stem with the following ablaut: NSg. *séh₂‑l‑s, ASg. *sh₂‑el‑m, GSg. *sh₂‑l‑ós, cf. Kortlandt (1985:119).

Brittonic (Welsh traeth, Corn. trait, Mbr. trez 'sand') and Goidelic (OIr. tracht 'shore, bank') loanword from Latin tractus 'drawing, trail track'. Loth, Les mots latins dans les langues brittoniques 1892, s.v. traeth considers these words as Celtic however.

The analysis as a loanword is less probable if one considers that the underlying root is well represented in Insular Celtic (PIE *treHgʰ- / *treHg̑ʰ- or *tragʰ- / *trag̑ʰ- 'to drain off, to ebb away', cf. Schumacher 2004, 635-36) and that there are nouns from this root belonging into the same semantic field: Old Breton tre, MW trei m. 'ebbtide', Old Irish tráig 'i, m/f' 'ebbtide, beach' < Proto-Brit. *trăgi̯o-. The word for sand could thus originate from an inherited tu-stem cognate with Latin tractus, i.e. Proto-Celtic *traxtus.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *lab(a)ro- 'eloquent, talkative', from which the verbs in this class are denominal. Further cognates uncertain. "These Celtic words may have been onomatopoetic in origin; the connection with ME flappen 'hit' suggested by IEW (831) is a mere possibility (if this is correct, the PCelt. form of the root was *flab-), cf. also Germ. labern 'babble'."
Usually understood to be from PIE *k̑m̥t- 'along with, downwards'.  From Proto-Greek *κατι (cf. Hitt. katti /lexeme/20328/). > *κασί > Arc.-Cyp. κάς, Att.-Ion. καί.
Reconstructs PIE *gʰu̯eh₁r-
From root *gʷi̯eh₃- (s.v. ζώω).  Ancient Greek ζῷον originally a derived adjective 'living being' > 'animal'.

S.v. σποδός 'ash, ember, metal ashes, dust'. If etymologically connected with ἄσβολος 'soot, dust of coals' and σπολεύς 'a kind of loaf', then σποδός would be a loan from a Pre-Greek substrate language.
S.v. σποδός 'braise, cendre, poussière', of obscure etymology.
S.v. τέφρα 'ash' < PIE *dʰegʷʰ-r-h₂. Cf. PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. Skt. dahati 'burn', etc.).
S.v. AGk. τέφρα 'cendre', plausibly connected with PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn'.
Greek ἐπί from PIE *h₁epi- 'at, on'.
S.v. νῶτον 'back'. No obvious etymology, perhaps may be compared to Lat. natis 'rump, buttocks' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008} s.v.) but the connection is tenuous.
S.v. νῶτον 'dos'. No obvious etymology, cf. entry for various older proposals.

S.v. φλοιός 'bark (of a tree), rind, skin of a fruit, pellicle of a leaf or egg'. Etymology uncertain, may be connected to verb φλέω and φλύω, possibly from a potential root *bʰleu̯(H)- 'overflow' cf. LIV² 90, 1. *bʰleu̯H- 'überströmen' (IEW 158-159).  Beekes, however, argues that the word may be Pre-Greek.
S.v. γαστήρ: "On admet sans hésiter l'étymologie habituelle, de *γρασ-τήρ «dévoreur», tiré de γράω avec dissimilation des deux ρ"

S.v. γαστήρ 'belly, paunch, womb'. Beekes is not convinced of the usual etymology assuming an agent noun in -τηρ formed to the room *gres- 'to eat, devour', on the basis of the semantics: "the belly is not an "eater"".

S.v. μέγας 'great, big, large' < PIE *meg̑-h₂- 'much, many'. Greek μέγας reflects a stem *meg̑-h₂- which is also found in Sanskrit maha- 'great, mighty, strong'.  (In Skt. *-g̑h₂- > -h-).  (This additional *-h₂- on the stem is however not found in the comparative μεῖζων/μέζων << *még̑-i̯os- and superlative μέγιστος < *meg̑-is-to-.)  The oblique and feminine stem of the positive form of the adjective μεγάλο-, μεγάλη have an enlargement *-l-, the origin of which is unclear, but is also found in other lexemes in Goth. mikils 'great' and Lithuanian dìdelis 'great' < dìdis.

S.v. *denk̑- 'beißen' (IEW 201). The identification of this root with TochAB tsāk- 'bite' is debated.  Ringe (Sprache 34 1988-1990 p.71) plausibly derives the Tocharian forms from *dʰiHgʷ- 'hineinstecken' from *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'hineinstecken, stechen'.  Cf. fn1 s.v. *denk̑- and fn4 s.v. *dʰei̯Hgʷ- for further details.
Cf. s.v. *denk̑- 'beißen' (LIV 117f., IEW 201).
Etymology obscure. Evidently an adjective suffixed in -νό-, but the stem κελαι- is unexplained.
Etymology unclear.  The stem is morphologically isolated and difficult to assess.

S.v. μέλας 'dark-colored, black' < PIE *mel(h₂)-n- 'black'. The feminine stem μέλαινα is traditionally identified with Skt. malinī < *melh₂-n-ih₂ and the masculine/neuter stem μελαν- would be a modification of an earlier thematic *μέλανο- equivalent to Skt. malina- 'dirty'. It should be noted, however, that malinī is only known in the form of a gloss 'menstruating woman' and malina- is an epic classical  Sanskrit derivative from Ved. mála- 'dirt', which could in principle also be derived from *molh₂-o-. There are additional colour words which may be compared from Baltic: Latv. męl̃ns 'black', OPruss. melne 'blue spot', Lith. mul̃vas 'yellow (of clay)'.
S.v. AGk. αἷμα 'sang'. No convincing etymology.
S.v. αἷμα 'blood'. There is no established etymology outside of Greek.

S.v. ὀστέον 'bone' < PIE *h₃esth₂-i- 'bone' (cf. Av. ast-, Lat. os < oss < *ost, gen. ossis, Skt. ásth-i, Hitt. ḫaštāi). Ancient Greek ὀστέον is clearly connected to the inherited word for 'bone'; Beekes reconstructs *h₃esth₁-i-, but supposes a thematised full-grade of the suffix *-i-, yielding *-ei̯-o-, which in turn would have given ὀστέον as it is attested.
S.v. ?*pneu̯- 'hauchen, keuchen' (IEW 838-9). The root is only attested by Greek and possibly Germanic if the comparison to Old Norse fnýsa 'sniff, snort' is correct.

S.v. πνέω 'blow, breathe, respire, smell' < PIE ?*pneu- 'breathe, cough, smell'. The Indo-European origins difficult to ascertain as there are only Germanic cognates that may be compared: Old Norse fnýsa 'sniff', Old Norse fnasa, Old High German fnehan.  Beekes suggests that the entire group may be onomatopoeic.

S.v. καίω 'to kindle', med-pass. 'to burn' < PIE *keh₂u- 'burn'. Attic καίω may be explained as a yod-present from *κάϝ-ι̯ω, ultimately from PIE *keh₂u̯-i̯e/o-.  The Greek forms are possibly related to Baltic material in Lith. kū̃lės 'Brandpilze, Flugbrand, Staubbrand des Getreides', kūlė́ti 'brandig werden', Latv. kūla, 'old, dry, grass of last year'.
S.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV² 448, IEW 315f.).

S.v. κρύος 'icy cold, frost'. The etymology is difficult to assess. There are two alternatives: Either (1) Possibly from IE *kreu̯s- 'shiver', cf. ON hrjósa 'to shiver', OHG hroso 'ice', to the root *kreus- 'to stamp, strike'. Semantically TochB krośce 'cold' would be a perfect comparison but the -o- in the TochB form is difficult to account for; or (2) a connection of the group of words connected to Av. xrūma- 'horrible' < *kruh₂-mo- and connected with the *kruh₂- 'blood' root.

S.v. ψυχρός 'cold' (adj.), which alongside ψῦχος 'cold, frost' (n.) forms a Caland System within Greek suggesting the word is old. It does not however have an Indo-European etymology.  Older suggestions have attempted to derive 'cold, chilly' < 'blowing wind'?, comp. 'blow' in /cognate/190/ but Beekes rejects this connection (s.v. ψυχή, ψυχρός.).

S.v. ἔρχομαι 'to come', also 'to go, travel'. The precise Indo-European etymology is debated. Possible connection with PIE *h₁ergʰ- (cf. OIr. eirg [imptv.] 'go!', regaid [fut.] 'he will go', Skt. r̥ghāyáti 'tremble, rage', possibly within Greek as an iterative ὀρχέομαι 'dance' < *h₁orgʰ-éi̯e-) or PIE *h₁er- (cf. Ved. r̥ccháti 'to reach, arrive at', Hitt. arške/a- [iter.] 'to reach repeatedly, make incursions'.)

AGk. ἀριθμέω (and its descendants) is a denominative verb to ἀριθμός 'number', which itself is ultimately a derivative form in -θμ- formed to a zero-grade *h₂ri- from PIE *h₂rei- 'count'. The root without the -θμ- suffix is also found in the negative adjective νήριτος 'countless' < *n̥-h₂ri-to- (cf. Chantraine 1968-1980; Beekes 2010:131). Note *h₂rei̯- is a secondary verbal formation in Greek and not listed in LIV².

S.v. ἀριθμός 'number; payment'. Beekes compares nominal forms in Old Norse rím (n.) 'account', Old High German rīm (m.) 'row, number', and OIr. rím 'number' connecting the forms to PIE *h₂rei̯- 'count'.

S.v. κόπτω 'to strike, smite, hew, hammer, disable, tire out'. May be Indo-European if cognate with Lithuanian kapiù 'hew, fell', Albanian kep 'hew'. Alternatively, the lexeme may be of substrate origin if related to σκάπτω (cf. notes in /cognate/202/).
S.v. 1. *(s)kep- 'hacken, hauen' (IEW 931-932). Greek, Balto-Slavic and Albanian cognates are attested.
S.v. *(s)teud- 'stoßen' (IEW 1033-4).
S.v. *temh₁- 'schneiden' (IEW 1062-1063).

S.v. ἧμαρ 'day' < PIE *Heh₂mer-.  Attic ἡμέρα was the result of a secondary derivation. The Armenian form awr reflects a form *amōr, which may be found in the Mycenaean attestation of a-mo-ra-ma /āmōr-āmar/ 'day after day'.

S.v. ἦμαρ.  The earlier consonant stem ἦμαρ found in Mycenaean Greek and Homer was replaced by Attic-Ionic ἡμέρα, which had been remodelled as a feminine ā-stem noun.  The aspiration found in the Attic form only (West Greek, Arcadian, Lesbian, etc. ἀμέρα) usually considered to be analogical on the basis of ἑσπέρα 'evening'.
S.v. θάνατος 'death' < PIE *dʰ(u̯)enh₂- 'die', from which -θνῇσκω 'die' is derived from the same root (via *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑e/o-).

S.v. *dʰenh₂ 'sich in Lauf setzen, sich davonmachen' (IEW 249).  The Greek present –θνῄσκω must be derived from a zero-grade sk̑é/o-present *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑é/ó-.  The writing of the iota subscript (-ῃ-) is secondary.

Older etymologies (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:287) compare forms related to Skt. dhvān- 'dark', however the internal structure of the Greek derivatives θάνατος, θνῄσκω must be accounted for in terms of preforms *dʰn̥h₂-eto-, *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑e/o- respectively, thus {ref LIV²} reconstructs *dʰenh₂-.  The Modern Greek present πεθαίνω was backformed from Ancient/Medieval Greek aorist (ἀ)πέθανον, with replacement of -ανον with present morph. -αίνω and regular loss of initial unstressed ἀ-.

S.v. ῥύπος 'filth, uncleanliness'. "No convincing etymology." Other derivatives of ῥυπός "dirt, filth" (including forms of the derived verb ῥυπάω "I am dirty, filthy") are also used in this basic sense. Possibly related to Church Slavic strupu 'wound' (ModSlav 'poison, pus, scab, crust, etc), but root connection is dubious (< *sreu- 'to flow'?).
S.v. ῥύπος 'crasse', of unknown etymology. For hypotheses cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:665-666, {ref IEW} 1004.
S.v. *peh₃(i̯)- 'trinken' (IEW 839-40).
S.v. πίνω 'to drink'. The root is without doubt connected the PIE root *peh₃- (cf. Aeol., Dor. πώνω), but the exact analogical origins of the present stem formations in Greek are debated.
S.v. κόνις 'dust, ashes',from IE *konis- (an s-stem), cf. Lat. cinis, cineris from e-grade *kenis-.

S.v. χθών 'earth, ground, land', from PIE dʰg̑ʰem- 'earth'. The Greek form was reanalysed synchronically as an n-stem from the regular development of *-m > *-n in final position in the nominative (gen.sg. χθονος); The word-initial cluster developed *θχ- > χθ- by metathesis.
S.v. οὖς 'ear' < *h₂ōu̯s, *h₂ou̯s-n-.

S.v. AGk. γῆ 'earth'. No certain Indo-European etymology, cf. Doric γᾶ.  The word is probably related to the poetic variant γαῖα, whose earlier form *gai̯a- was likely contracted to *gā at an early date.
Cf. s.v. AGk. γῆ 'terre' (par opposition au ciel, par opposition à la mer) Neither γῆ nor γαῖα have an established etymology.
S.v. ἔδω 'to eat' < PIE *h₁ed- 'eat'. Thematic ἐσθίω is formed on the basis of the inherited athematic imperative ἔσθι (Ved. addhí). < *h₁ed-dhi.

S.v. Gk. λίπα 'fat, gleaming'. An inner-Greek innovation from λίπα (adv.) which is usually used in Homer in the phrase ἀλείψασθαι λίπ’ ἐλαίῳ 'anoint oneself richly with oil', to which λίπος 'fat' is a secondary s-stem noun. This noun is usually connected to a root noun formed to *lei̯p- 'stick' (cf. Skt. *li-m-p-áti 'to smear'. Lith. lìpti (3.sg.), limpù 'to stick, be sticky', etc.).

S.v. *du̯ei̯- 'in Furcht geraten, erschrecken' (IEW 227-228).  Armenian root aorist erkeaw from *du̯éi̯–/du̯i-, present erknčʻim < *du̯i-sk̑e-.  Greek δείδω, δείδιμεν, Luw. pres. kuwaya- from perfect stem *de-du̯ói̯-/du̯i-.
S.v. Gk. δείδω 'to fear', from PIE *duei- 'fear' (cf. Avestan duuaēθā 'threat' and, with an s-extension, Sanskrit dvéṣṭi '(s)he hates').
S.v. *bʰegʷ- 'davonlaufen, fliehen' (IEW 116). Greek φοβέομαι < cs.-it. stem bʰogʷ-éi̯e-.

S.v. φέβομαι 'to flee, take flight' < PIE *bʰegʷ-. The forms in Greek reflect the causative-Iterative stem φοβέω 'put to flight, frighten' < *bʰogʷ-éi̯e/o-. Exact cognates to the basic stem exist in Balto-Slavic, e.g. Lith. bė́gti, bė́gu 'to walk, run', OCS běžati 'φεύγειν', etc.

Proto-Romance *corāli̯a n. pl. (also Old French, Provençal). Check FEW; Pierre Le Roux / Jean Le Dû; Yves Le Berre; Guylaine Brun-Trigaud. 2005: Lectures de l'atlas linguistique de la France de Gilliéron et Edmont : du temps dans l'espace; essai d'interprétation des cartes de l'Atlas linguistique de la France de Jules Gilliéron et Edmond Edmont, augmenté de quelques cartes de l'Atlas linguistique de la Basse-Bretagne. Paris.
Clackson (among others) regards the connection between Greek ξηρός and Armenian չոր čʻor as doubtful.
Beekes doubts Greek connections to this class as the supposed pre-form *h₂ml̥h₃-u- would yield †ἀμαλύς  (REVISION REQUIRED)
Ancient Greek παῦρος < *peh₂-u-ro-.  Stem *peh₂-u- also found in παῖς 'child' /lexeme/18678/.

S.v. παῖς, παιδός 'child, boy, son, slave, servant', more rarely 'girl, daughter'. The Greek forms are from PIE *peh₂-u- 'few, little' with further stem enlargements in *-i-d-. Disyllabic forms in epic and dialectal texts point to original *παϝ-ι-δ-. παίζω 'play' is a denominative verb to this lexeme.

Martirosyan connects Greek ξηρός with Armenian čʻir 'dried fruit' čʻor (o-stem) 'dry'.  This proposed etymology is usually doubted because one normally expects Armenian cʻ from PIE *ks, *sk, but Martirosyan argues (2.1.12) that čʻ- is the correct reflex of *ks- in initial position.  The etymology is possible, but this word is the only example that Martirosyan cites in favour of this sound law.

Could be from PIE *h₃lig–o-, if identical with Armenian ałkʻat աղքատ 'poor'.  Proposed connections with Albanian lig 'angry, meager' are doubtful, since this word could equally be connected with λοιγός 'ruin'.

S.v. μάχομαι 'to fight, combat'. The root μαχ- is isolated in Greek and there has not yet been a convincing etymology proposed.  One clever proposal compares Iranian borrowings in Greek *ha-mazan- > Ἀμαζών 'Amazon', and glosses from Hesychius ἁμαζακάραν· πολεμεῖν. Πέρσαι 'to fight, Persian', ἁμαζανίδες· αἱ μηλέαι (a type of fruit), but this is very uncertain.
S.v. AGk. μάχομαι 'combattre, lutter'. The etymology has not yet been established.

S.v. ὄνυξ, -υχος 'nail, claw, hoof'. Greek form presupposes *h₃nogʷʰ- or *h₃nogʰ-u- to account for the raising of radical *-o- > -u- by Cowgill's Law (i.e. -o- > -u- between a labial and a nasal, cf. νύξ 'night' < *nokʷt-s). Similarly Classical Armenian eɫungn must also reflect the same forms, but is also a secondary n-stem from the accusative.
S.v. πῦρ, πυρός 'fire' < PIE neuter heteroclite-stem *peh₂-u̯r̥, ph₂-u̯en-s.  In Greek πῦρ was generalised as an r-stem, πῦρ, πῠρ-ος.
S.v. ἰχθῦς 'fish' < PIE *dg̑ʰuH- 'fish'.

S.v. ἰχθῦς. The initial i-prothesis in Ancient Greek ἰχθῦς is secondary, as also in ἰκτῖνος 'kite, Miluus regalis'. Cf. Lejeune 1972, Phonétique historique du mycénien et du grec ancien p.182, Schwyzer 1939, Griechische Grammatik I, p.413
Ancient Greek πλέω from PIE e-grade thematic present *pleu̯-e/o-
S.v. *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (cf. ?*pleu̯d- 'schwimmen, fließen' ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen')
S.v. *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen'

S.v. ἄνθος 'flower' < PIE *h₂endʰ- 'sprout'. The Greek noun is an s-stem derivative and directly equatable with Sanskrit ándhas- 'sprout of the soma plant', and an s-stem *h₂endʰ-os- may be reconstructed.

Chantraine has reservations about the comparison with Sanskrit ándhas- on the basis that "le sens propre de plante est mal assuré en skr."  Chantraine notes that ἄνθος is the proper word for flower in the katharevousa register of Modern Greek, but in demotic the lexeme has been replaced by λουλούδι /lexeme/7534/.
S.v. Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog', from PIE *h₃migʰ-l(e)h₂. The Greek forms are identical to Balto-Slavic words for fog attested by Lith. miglà, OCS mъgla.
Clackson regards the connection between Greek ξηρός and Armenian չոր čʻor as doubtful.  (See p.182 for references.)

S.v. Arm. cʻir 'dried fruit', cʻor 'dry'. The etymology with Greek ξηρός is usually doubted because one normally expects Armenian cʻ from PIE *ks, *sk, but Martirosyan considers (s.v. čʻir, čʻor) a viable comparison with Greek ξηρός, arguing (2.1.12) that čʻ- is the correct reflex of *ks- in initial position.

S.v. ποῦς, ποδός 'foot' < PIE *pod-. The Greek form has generalised o-grade ablaut throughout the nominal paradigm, but the e-grade is attested in some other derivative forms: πέδη 'fetter, shackles', πέζα 'instep', πέζος 'walker, footsoldier', πέδον 'soil, earth, ground', πέδλιον 'sandal', πεδά 'after, with, amidst'.  A zero-grade is also attested in ἐπίβδα 'the day after a festival'.
S.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).
S.v. *deh₃- 'geben' (IEW 223-5).  Reconstructs present stem *dé-doh₃-/dh₃- whence Ved. dádāti, YAv. daδāiti. See n14 regarding Greek  δίδωμι "Mit sekundärer i-Redupl."
S.v. Proto-Celtic *wel-o- 'to see', from PIE *u̯el-o- 'see' (cf. Lat. uoltus 'face, facial expression', Goth. wulϸus 'wealth').
S.v. Bret. gwri 'couture, surjet', corresponding to Co. gwry, W gwni.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *birro- 'short' (no IE etymology).
S.v. *⁽k̑⁾an- 'singen, klingen' (IEW 525-6).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *krok(ke)no- 'skin'. The reflexes of the individual languages do not point to a common proto-form, i.e. W points to the original *krokno-, while other languages show reflexes of *krokkeno-. The connection with PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, to grate, to cut off' (LIV² 556, IEW 938-40) is difficult. Consequently, we are probably dealing with a loanword from some non-IE language.

S.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV² 448, IEW315f.). Re *nébʰ-es- n.: fn. 6: Stüber, Die primären s-Stämme, 2002, 129ff. thinks that PIE *nebʰos- denoted the clouded sky in opposition to *di̯ḗu̯s 'clear sky of the day'.  Fn. 21: The inclusion of the Tocharian forms here is disputed. [Cf. notes in /cognate/7172/.]
Brittonic borrowing, verb based on Latin quiēscō, quiēscere 'to rest, to take a rest, to relax'.

Latin quiēscere is based on PIE *kʷi̯eh₁- 'to rest' (LIV² 393). As Brittonic is p-Celtic, the anlaut k- of the verbs in question is not the expected reflex of this PIE root. The assumption of a borrowing is thus highly probable.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *bekko- 'small'. "These words could originally be adjectives derived from the verb 'to break', PIE *bʰeg- (Skt. bhanákti, Arm. bekanem, IEW 114f.). The semantic development 'broken into pieces' > 'small' is possible, and PIE *bʰeg-ko- would yield PCelt. *bekko- regularly. However, an adjective *bʰeg-ko- does not seem to be formed according to the rules of PIE word formation."

S.v. Proto-Celtic *argyo- 'white' [Adj], 'snow' [Noun], related to Proto-Celtic *arganto- 'silver' < PIE *h₂erg̑-n̥t-o-, cf. IEW 64. Alternative etymology: Hamp 1974, GPC and Deshayes (2003: 218) would relate these words to Olr. arg 'drop' « *argo-), but this word is attested almost only in glossaries, its gender and stem-formation are unknown, and its meaning cannot easily be derived from the original meaning 'white'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *natrik- 'serpent', from on PIE *(s)n̥h₂-tr- 'water snake' (IEW 747), cf. Lat. natrīx, Goth. nadre (gen.pl), ON naðr 'viper, snake'. The basic root is PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to swim' (LIV² 572).

Verb based on the noun Proto-Celtic *skoltā 'fissure, cleft', PIE *skelH- 'divide, to spilt' (IEW 924, LIV² 553). Although the Breton and Cornish initial f- is difficult to account for, the words are unlikely to be borrowed from Old French for semantic reasons.
In favour of an inherited word also LEIA S-48-49.

Verb related to the noun faout m. 'slit, crack' (1499), adj. 'split' and cognate with Cornish fals 'slit, crack'. These words go back to *falt, which can be compared to Old French falder 'to fold, to crease', borrowed from Old High German faldan 'to fold'.
S.v. ἀλέω 'to grind' < PIE *h₂elh₁- 'grind'.
S.v. h₂leh₁- 'zermahlen' (IEW 28-9).  Reconstructs ?*h₂l̥h₁-i̯é- > Gr. ἀλέω 'mahle', ?Arm. ałam 'mahle'.
S.v. αλέθω. The Modern Greek verbal stem has been remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀλέω on the basis of the analogy κλωσ- (aor.) :  αλεσ- (aor.) :: κλώθω : X --> αλέθω.
S.v. *h₂stḗr-, *h₂ster- ́ f. 'Stern' (IEW 1027f. EIEC 543). Cf. fn.1 with a discussion of a possible underlying verbal root as well as the assumption of a Semitic or Sumerian loanword.

Proposes an etymology PIE *h₂h₁stér- 'star' < 'celestial fire', internally derived from an adverb *h₂h₁stér- 'pertaining (by contrast) to the burning', based on the root noun *h₂óh₁s- 'burning', whence 'fire'; cf. PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry up/wither by heat' (LIV² 257f.).
From Proto-Celtic *u̯ak-s-o- (??? CHECK)
Borrowed from Middle French esterquer 'to starch' (?), < Middle Dutch sterken 'to make stiff'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *magino- 'stone, place', cognate with Proto-Celtic *magos 'plain, field'. The Brittonic words are cognate with OIr. magen, magan ā, f 'place' (DIL maigen). "W maen is not just any stone, but one 'having some speciality or a particular use', according to GPC. The Olr. form in -a is a collective built from *magino-, like Lat. loca from locus. The attribution in IEW (709) to the root *meg̑h₂- 'great' is possible, cf. Skt. mahī́- 'earth' < *'the great one')."

S.v. Proto-Celtic *efino- 'right, correct, equal', from PIE *h₁ep-(i)no- 'even' (IEW 505), cf. Goth. ibns 'flat, even', OHG eban 'equal, same'. "There are some formal difficulties with this etymology; a pre-form *epno-, the exact match of the Germanic words, would presumably develop as *ewno- > *owno- > W **un. Could these words be derived from PIE *h₁epi- 'on, by' with the suffix *-no-? The vowel *-i- could have been lost in Germanic through syncope. The type of formation would be parallel to PCelt. *efirom 'behind'."
Dunkel denies the existence of *ep-nó- underlying Proto-Germanic *eƀna- in Goth. ibns, Old Norse jafn, Old High German eban. In addition, he does not reconstruct *h₁epi-no-  proposed by Matasović.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *su̯ēd-o- 'swell', from PIE *su̯ei̯d- 'to sweat' (IEW 1043, LIV² 607), cf. Skt. svedate, Gk. ἰδίω, OHG swizzen, Latv. svîstu, TochB syelme. For the semantic development 'sweat' > 'swell' see KPV 609.
S.v. *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- n. 'Sonne' (IEW 881f.).

From Proto-Celtic *lusto- or *lustā-, based on leu̯s-, as desiderative formation from PIE *leu̯H- 'to detach oneself, to losen' (LIV 374f., fn. 7). Welsh llost f. seems to originate from *lustā-, OIr. los (m. o) from *lusto-. {ref Schrijver 1995}:412 reconstructs a formation with *-st-, i.e. *lus-sto/eh₂-.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *tegu- 'thick', from PIE *tegu- 'thick' (IEW 1057), cf. OHG dicchi, OE ðicce 'thick'. Reflexes of this PIE root are attested only in Celtic and Germanic. Both branches point to an original u-stem.

Oir. mín 'tender, soft' from Proto-Celtic *mīno- < *miHno-, and W mwyn 'mild, tender, gentle', MoBret. moan 'tender, thin', OCo. muin 'thin' < Proto-Celtic *mēnV- < *mei̯HnV- (IEW 711f.). Alternatively from Proto-Celtic *moi̯ni- 'treasure, precious object', PIE *mei̯-n- 'exchange' (IEW 710) (Matasović p. 278f.). "The development of meaning in Breton and Cornish was from 'beautiful' to 'gracile' and (in Breton) 'thin'. The original meaning may have been '(precious) piece of property for exchange'."
(BI: Both etymologies semantically not convincing)

S.v. πίμπλημι 'to fill, make full' < PIE *pleh₁- 'fill'. Greek πλήρης may be compared with Latin plērus 'for the greater part', Armenian lir 'fullness', which presupposes that at least some suffixed form *pleh₁-r- can be dated back to PIE. Synchronically the Greek form has been reanalysed as an s-stem adjective (transponat *pleh₁-r-os-), while Latin plērus may reflect an original suffix -ro- (i.e. *pleh₁-ro-).
Cf. s.v. *pleh₁- 'sich füllen, voll werden' (IEW 799).

S.v. Lat. -pleō 'to fill', from which Lat. plēnus 'full' is a derived form from PIE *pl̥h₁-no-. The root -ē- vocalism was introduced, presumably on analogy to other related vocabulary which inherited a full-grade *pleh₁-, e.g. -plēre 'to fill' (usually found with preverbs: complēre 'to fill, complete', dēplēre 'to drain, empty', etc.) < *pleh₁-.

S.v. ἀγαθός 'good, fit, noble'. Etymology uncertain. Older attempts to reconcile to Germanic words such as Goth. goϸs, NHG gut 'good', etc. are to be abandoned as these require a root *gʰedʰ-. {ref Pinault 1979}:165-170 has attempted to derive the word from *mg̑ʰh₂-dʰh₁-o- 'make great' although the semantic development is difficult and the suffix *-dʰo- is rare. Alternatively {ref Beekes 1996} considers the word to be from a European substratum language.
S.v. AGk. ἀγαθός 'bon'. The etymology is controversial and uncertain (cf. entry for various older hypotheses).

S.v. χλωρός '(pale) green' < PIE *g̑ʰl̥h₃-ró-.  The same root *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' occurs in Baltic, Slavic, and Latin, but with different derivations (e.g. Lith. žélti 'to green, sprout', OCS зєлєнъ (translating Greek χλωρός, πράσινος), Lat. holus 'green plants, vegetables, cabbage').
S.v. ἔντερα 'intestines, bowels' < *h₁enter-o- 'inside part'.

S.v. άντερο. The plural form άντερα 'guts' is from Ancient Greek ἔντερα, with initial vocalism taken over from a reanalysis/miscutting from preposed indefinite article in the singular form of the noun, i.e. ένα + έντερο > *ένα-ντερο > έν-άντερα.
S.v. θρίξ 'hair'. No clear etymology; older proposals are unsatisfactory.
S.v. AGk. θρίξ, τριχός 'cheveu, poil'. No etymology, very uncertain hypotheses in {ref Frisk 1960-1972}.
Paradigmatic alternations N.sg. θρίξ [tʰríks], G.sg. τριχός [trikʰós], etc. presuppose a Proto-Greek stem *θριχ- which was subject to the Greek version of Graßmann's Law.
S.v. *tenh₂- 'dünn, ausgestreckt' (IEW 1069, EIEC 574).

S.v. Bret. preder 'soin, souci, considération, pensée', corresponding to Co. preder 'pensée, souci, soin, anxiété' and W pryder 'soin, souci'. The verb is based on Old Breton pritiri 'thought, reflexion, worry'.
Verb based on the noun preder 'thought, reflection, consideration' derived from pred etc. mit Suffix -aro/ā-, i.e. Proto-Brittonic *pritaro/ā-.
Contains ma 'place' (cognate with Welsh ma 'place') + -se. Ma is lenited to va- in Middle Breton. In Modern Breton, v- has been lost.
-se originates from Proto-British *si̯o- or *sii̯o- < PIE *sio- and is cognate with Ved. syá, f. syā́ n. tyád, cf. LIPP II 685-88
Old Southwest Brittonic i, Middle Breton, Middle Cornish y < Proto-Celtic nom. pl. *īs < *ei̯es. Middle Welsh wy < Old Welsh *ui < Proto-Brittonic *ē < Proto-Celtic acc. pl. *ēs < *ens.
PIE Pl. *éi-es 'they', cognate with Gothic eis. PIE *í- 'a certain, a before mentioned, this one', pronominal stem, anaphoric an proximal, only nom. and acc.
Corn. -ma, Breton -mañ are cognate with Welsh yma 'here' (y-ma).
S.v. Bret. taol 'coup, jet', corresponding to Co. towl, W tafl 'catapulte, jet, fronce', and Ir. tabhall (OIr. tabul) and ScG. tabhal 'fronde', all from Proto-Celtic *tab-allo-.

Cf. s.v. OIr. taball 'tablette de bois à écrire', a borrowing from Lat. tabellā and probably identical with táball 'sling (with a wooden handle), weapon for throwing missiles'. It is not to be connected with Breton taol etc.
Deshayes' suggestion does not explain why Breton and Cornish have [g] as opposed to [ʃ] in the alleged French source. They look rather like direkt borrowings from Germanic.
S.v. Bret. stag 'attaché, liant', an old borrowing from French estachier (12th c.), estache 'stake' (1080). The latter is borrowed from Germanic *staka 'stake, picket'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic 2. *rig-e/o- 'binden' < PIE *rei̯g- or *rei̯g̑- (LIV² 503). Breton eren is a compound with the preverb *ad-, Irish con-rig with *kom-
S.v. Proto-Celtic 2. *rig-e/o- 'binden' < PIE *rei̯g- or *rei̯g̑- (LIV² 503). The Brythonic forms (W gwarwy, etc.) are compounds with the preverb *u̯o-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *widu- 'wood', from PIE *u̯idʰu- 'wood' (IEW 1117) (cf. OE widu, wudu, Lith. vidùs 'interior').
