S.v. Bret. tro 'tour, alentours, partour' Denominal verb based on Middle Breton tro (1499) from Old Breton tro. This noun is Cognate with Cornish tro 'turn' and Welsh tro 'circuit, instant, occasion'. All originate from Celtic *trog-o- 'traction'.
Cites etymological suggestions. CHECK
S.v. Proto-Celtic *skiy-o- 'vomit, spew', from PIE *sk̑ei̯-(d)- 'defecate' (?) (IEW 920f., cf. Lith. skíesti 'to have diarrhoea', ON skíta 'defecate', Engl. shit.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *skei̯-e/o- 'erbrechen, speien', cf. PIE *sk̑ei̯-(d)- 'defecate' (?) (IEW 920f.), cf. *sk̑ʰei̯- 'to split, to tear' (LIV² 547f.) and Schumachers remark concerning the final -d- of the root. The Brittonic forms are secondary verbs derived from the verbal noun (MW chwyt). 
Later Goidelic verbal forms containing -th- like Middle Irish sceithid are based on the Verbal noun sceith f. ā < *sci-tā.
S.v. Bret. bale 'marcher, parcourir, se balader', a borrowing from Old French baler 'danser'. First attested in Le grand mystère de Jésus (1530).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kerd-o- 'put, lay, move', from PIE *kerd- 'swing' ({ref IEW} 934f.), cf. Gk. κραδάω 'swing, wave'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kerd-e/o- 'setzen, legen, stellen', from PIE *//kerdʰ-//, a secondary formation from a nominal compound *ker-dʰh₁o- < *kerH-dʰh₁-o-), the root being PIE 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' (LIV² 353-355).
The Brittonic word originate from Proto-Celtic *kanti 'together with', PIE *k̑m-ti- (IEW 613).
S.v. Bret. askell 'aile, nageoire', from Late Latin *ascella from Classical Latin axilla 'armpit'. Borrowing found in all Insular Celtic languages (cf. Co. askel, W asgell, Ir. ascaill).
First attested in the Catholicon (1499). Brittonic borrowing from Latin privatus 'private, belonging to'.
First attested in the Catholicon (1499). Brittonic borrowing from Latin privatus 'private, belonging to'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *windo- 'white'. No etymology outside Celtic.
S.v. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (LIV² 629f., IEW 1069f.).

Compound interrogatives consisting OW pa, Old South West British pe, pi and the word for 'place', OSWBr loc, W lle, Co. le (< *lego-), Br. lec'h (< *leg-so-). Breton and Cornish originate from Old British pi, pe, which can be connected with OIr. cía, ce, ci e.g. cía chruth 'what way?'. However not identical with Welsh pa, which may reflect an old oblique case form or an adverb used as an oblique case form. 
These words are very similar and have common origins, but they are not completely cognate.
Consists of Brittonic pe 'what' and eur 'hour' from Latin oria.

S.v. καλός 'beautiful, noble, good'. The attestation of Boeotian καλϝός (cf. SEG 29:449.1), Ionic κᾱλός presupposes that the Proto-Greek stem was *kalu̯o–.  All further attempts to find an etymology by comparison with other Indo-European languages have been, however, unconvincing.
S.v. χείρ, χειρός 'hand, fist' < PIE *g̑ʰés-r-.
S.v. σκέλλομαι 'to dry up, wither, languish, grow tired, harden' < PIE *skelh₁-i̯e/o-, with derived adjective σκληρός 'hard' is a derived adjective from the same root.
NB: σκληρός < *skl̥h₁-ró- is contains a regular reflex for syllabic resonants in the environment *CR̥HC- > CRV̄C- thus the postulation of a Schwebeablaut variant *skleh₁- is unnecessary.
S.v. κεφαλή 'head, the uppermost or top part, source, etc.' < PIE *gʰebʰ-l- with further suffixation, cf. OHG gebal 'skull', TochA śpāl 'head'.
S.v. Gk. ἀκούω 'hear', from PIE *h₂keu̯s- 'hear' (cf. Gothic hausjan 'hear'). The verb has often been explained as a compound from ἀκ- 'sharp' and οὖς, but this is not certain.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *wlikʷo- 'wet', from PIE *u̯elk-u̯o- 'wet' (IEW 1145). MoBret. gwleb preserved the feminine form, PCelt. *u̯likʷā; cf. also s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- 'rain, wet weather', from PIE *u̯elk- (IEW 1145f.). The relationship of the Celtic lexemes with PIE *u̯el(H)g- (Lith. vìlgyti 'make wet', CS vlaga, Russ. dial. vológa, Cz. vlaha 'wetness', OHG welk 'wet, moist' is unclear. The two roots *u̯elk- and *u̯elg- should be somehow related. Perhaps there was an original root noun *u̯ōlg-s 'rain' (phonetically *[u̯ōlks]), gen.sg. *u̯olg-os and assume that some languages generalised the voiceless velar from the nom.sg. throughout the paradigm.

1. PIE *u̯é- 'we', pronominal stem, 1st person non-singular, only nominative , suppletion with *nó-.
2. PIE *nó- 'us', pronominal stem, 1st person non-singular, oblique, suppletion with *u̯é-.

From Proto-Celtic *dubro-/ā- 'dark', cf. PIE *dʰubʰ- 'black' (IEW 263ff.)
In OIr. the adj. 'black' is also used as the substantivized adjective dobur 'water'. Brittonic continues only the word for 'water', Old Welsh dubr, MW dwfr, ModW dŵr, Breton, Cornish dour.
S.v. *dʰeu̯b- 'tief' (IEW 267f., EIEC 154), the Celtic forms in this class go back to *dʰub-ro/ah₂- > Proto-Celtic *dub-ro- (OIr. dobur, OW dubr, MW dwfr, Bret., OCo. dour 'Wasser').
Cognate with the noun Modern Breton gwolch, Corn. golgh, Welsh golch 'washing, lotion, urine'; all from Proto-Celtic *u̯olk-o-.
S.v. ?*u̯elk- 'feucht sein/werden' (IEW 1145), probably a variant of *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (IEW 1145).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *moru̯i- 'ant', cf. PIE *moru̯i- 'ant' (IEW 749).
"The PIE form is notoriously difficult to reconstruct. The PIE i-stem implied by the agreement between MIr. and Avestan is probably older than the thematic forms found in Skt. (which also involves metathesis) and Greek (with assimilation *moru̯o- > *mormo-, and subsequent change of *o > i̯ between a labial and a resonant)."

From Proto-Celtic *me < PIE acc. sg. *(h₁)me, which ousted the old nom. sg. *(h₁)égoH. Old and Midddle Welsh reflect Late Proto-British *mi < *mī, while Middle and Modern Breton me and Middle Cornish my, me point to /mı/ < Late Proto-British *mɨ < Proto-British *mi. The development of these forms is related to those of the 2nd person Proto-Celtic *tū, which regulary became Proto-British *tȳ > *tī. This generated an analogical Proto-British nom. sg. *mū > *mȳ > *mi. The Proto-Celtic acc. sg. *me regularly became Proto-British *mi. Thus arose a PBr. system with nom. sg. *mī, *tī, acc. sg. *mi, *ti. Of these forms, Old Welsh generalized the former variant, Old South-West British the latter. A parallel development is found with the 2nd person pronouns.
*mé- 'me', pronominal stem, 1st singular, accusative, then oblique.

From Proto-Celtic torrV- 'belly'. 
"MoBret. teur 'belly' seems to come from *tar- with the lengthened grade, but I find it probable, in the absence of a PIE etymology, that these words were borrowed from some non-IE language (cf., however, Pokorny 1024)."
S.v. Proto-Celtic *dubu- 'black'. Matasović reconstructs the root as *dʰubʰ- (zero-grade) based on a comparison Gk. τυφλός 'blind', following IEW 264.

S.v. *leh₂p- 'aufleuchten' (IEW 652-3). OIr. loscaid and MW llosci 'to burn' originate from the causative Proto-Celtic *loskī. The corresponding present stem is Proto-Celtic *laske- 'to shine, to burn' < PIE *l̥h₂p-sk̑é-, the sk̑-present of the root *leh₂p- 'to flash, to light up' (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:194, fn. 40).
Ernault, GMB 611 thinks that *skoberna is derived from a base *skob meaning 'to excavate, to dig'. Also the word scau 'elder' would be derived from this root. CHECK
S.v. *ters- 'vertrocknen; durstig werden' (LIV² 637f., IEW 1078f.). The Italic forms are from *ters-eh₂-, the Celtic ones from *tērs-es- n.

Continues a Proto-Brittonic agent noun *luk-ati- m. originally meaning 'seher' (cf. Schrijver 1995, 166), based on the Proto-Celtic verbal stem *luk-e/o- 'to look at', PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' (LIV² 438).

S.v. σκέλος 'thigh, leg' < PIE *skel- 'bend, curve' as a thematic noun *skel-o-, formally comparable to Lat. scelus 'malice, badness, crime' < *skel-o- pointing to an original meaning *'curvation, deflection' (cf. o-grade derivative in Gk. σκολιός 'crooked, bent, twisted, unjust'), also with different derivational morphology in OHG scelah, OE sceolh < *skel-ko-, Alb. çalë 'lame' < *skel-no-.
Cf. s.v. *(s)kelh₁- 'austrocknen, verdorren' (IEW 927).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *kolěno 'knee' (ESSJa X 132-134). From the Baltic forms from Lith. kẽlis ‘knee’; Latv. celis ‘knee’ (lacking the suffix found in Slavic) we can reconstruct a basic Proto-Balto-Slavic root *kel-/kol-. There are two possible PIE etymologies to this, either (1) *kʷelH- 'turn, rotate' (cf. LIV² 386-388) or (2) *kelH- 'rise, raise, lift' (cf. LIV² 349), of these Derksen prefers the latter on semantic grounds. The proposed connection with Gk. κῶλον 'limb', which cannot reflect an original labiovelar, is not secure enough to serve as the basis of a formal argument.

S.v. σκώληξ 'worm, larva'. Beekes dismisses the proposed connection of Ancient Greek σκώληξ 'worm, larva' with σκέλος 'leg' [cf. /cognate/2785/] as dubious on the grounds of an unmotivated lengthened ō-grade and is necessary, and the suffix -ηξ does not seem to have any clear IE origin.  [The same suffix occurs on μύρμηξ 'ant' cf. /cognate/5010/.]

S.v. μύρμηξ, -ηκος 'ant'. The stem of Ancient Greek μύρμηξ is derived from PIE *moru̯i- (directly continued by Avestan maoiri- Old Irish moirb, Old Russian morovij),  but like in many places elsewhere among the IE languages it appears to have undergone analogical or irregular developments.  The new suffix -ηξ is also found in other words for insects, e.g. σκώληξ 'worm, maggot', σφήξ 'wasp'.
"clearly of imitative origin. and may be ultimately related to Gk. καχάζω, Skt. kákhati, Lat. cachinnō, OHG kakhazzen (IEW 634; cf. T 122-23 and refs.)."

No lemma in {ref Kloekhorst 2008} presumably because the Hittite form is of obvious onomatopoeic origin, cf. {ref HED H}. Unlikely to be etymologically related to the comparanda given by {ref Weeks 1985}:223 for phonological reasons.

Several etymologies possible due to the merger of the velars in Proto-Tocharian.   The present stem seems to reflect Pre-Proto-Tocharian *Korei̯e/o-.  See citation for details of alternative etymologies from PIE sources.
Cf. s.v. 1. *g̑ʰer- 'Gefallen finden, begehren' (IEW 440-1). [Without Tocharian lexemes]
S.v. Ved. √has- 'lachen', possibly from Proto-Indo-Iranian *gʰas-/ǰʰas- if the connection to YAv. ǰahī-, ǰahikā- 'Dirne, Prostituierte' is accepted.
s.v. Proto-Slavic *smьjati 'laugh', from PIE *smei- 'smile' (cf. Skt. smáyate 'smile').
S.v. *smei̯- 'lachen, lächeln' (IEW 967).
S.v. Lat. rīdeō 'to laugh'. There is no good Indo-European etymology.
S.v. Lat. rīdeō 'rire', no certain etymology.
For a survey of the numeral 'two' in Indo-European, cf. pp. 1-141.
For PIE reconstruction, see discussion pp.142-297.
Cf. discussion pp.298-382.
From *pénkʷe, the first of the indeclinable numerals in PIE. Cf. discussion pp.383-569.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *męso- 'flesh, meat' from PIE *mēms-om (cf. Skt. mām̆̇sá- 'flesh, meat', Goth. mimz 'κρέα').
S.v. Ved. mām̆̇sá- 'Fleisch', from PIE *mēms- (cf. Arm. mis, Goth. mimz, OPruss. mensā, menso, OCS męso, TochB mīsa- all 'Fleisch').
S.v. *kreu̯h₂- '(geronnenes) Blut, Blut außerhalb des Korpers' (IEW 621f.)
S.v. *h₃nebʰ- 'Nabel, Nabe' (IEW 314f.).
S.v. TochB yṣīye 'night, which together with TochA wṣe, is a derivative from PIE *h₂u̯es- 'stay, remain (the night)'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *dago- 'good'. No convincing IE etymology.

S.v. TochAB läk- 'sehen', 'see, look'. It is difficult to choose between the competing root etymologies of *leg̑- 'sammeln, auflesen' and *leu̯k- 'shine'; both possible etymologies have their merits and flaws in formal derivation.  "An ideal solution would be to derive preterital PT *l’æk- from PIE *lēg̑-, and what seems to be PT *läk- from PIE *luk-, but such a strategy would hardly please William of Ockham."
S.v. *spek̑- 'schauen, ansehen, spähen' (IEW 985).

S.v. TochB pärkare* 'long'. The Tocharian forms reflect a Proto-Tocharian form as if from PIE *bʰr̥g̑ʰ-ró- (cf. Hitt. parkuš, Arm. barjr, 'tall', Skt. br̥hant-, Av. bərəzant- 'tall', Khot. bulysa- 'long').
Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.
S.v. Ved. kṣap- 'Nacht', from a PIIr. root noun *kšap-, from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾sep- (cf. Hitt. ispant- 'Nacht').
S.v. 2. *h₂eg̑- 'sagen' (IEW 290-1). Classical Armenian present formation from *h₂eg̑-i̯é/o-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ret-e/o- 'rennen, laufen', from PIE *ret- (LIV² 507).
S.v. *ret- 'laufen' (IEW 866).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *musso- 'dirty' < *mud-so-, derived from PIE *meu̯d- ({ref IEW} 742), cf. Gk. μύσος 'filth'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *brasso- 'great, violent'; etymology disputed, but "the formal and semantic parallelism between these Celtic words and Lat. grossus 'fat' is too obvious to be dismissed lightly." If this is cognate we would have to postulate something like *gʷroD-to-, *gʷrD-to- (cf. {ref IEW} 485).

S.v. *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- n. 'Sonne' (IEW 881f., EIEC 556). The Goidelic Celtic forms represented by OIr. súil 'eye', etc. are from Proto-Celtic *sūli- < PIE *suh₂l-i- (cf. fn10 for further discussion and references to further literature).
Interesting develpment in Celtic: The Irish words for 'eye' are based on the word for 'sun', tne Brittonic ones on the root *leu̯k- 'to shine'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *sāwol-/*sūli- 'sun', from PIE *seh₂u̯ōl 'sun' (cf. Skt. sū́rya-, Gk. ἥλιος, Lat. sōl, Goth. sauil, Lith. sáulė). The semantic change in OIr. is understandable from the mythological context, where the 'sun' is viewed as 'the eye of the Sky'.
S.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten'.

The root is controversial, Irslinger (2002, 60) with a discussion of previous research. *tregʰ- matching with the word for 'foot' is not reconstructed by LIV as a PIE root. Schumacher (2004, 635f.) argues on the basis of further Celtic material for the reconstruction of *treHgʰ-/treHg̑ʰ- or *tragʰ-/trag̑ʰ- 'to run away, to recede'. He argues that also Latin trahere 'to pull, to drag' originates from this root, a suggestion followed by de Vaan (2008, 626f.). Matasović (2009, 387, 389) rejects the idea that Proto-Celtic *treget- 'foot' belongs here. LIV² 154 groups Lat. trahere, showing an irregular anlaut development, with *dʰregʰ-/dʰreg̑ʰ- 'to pull, to drag'. Schrijver (1995, 136) argues that t- could have developed from *(s)d- with s-mobile, so that the word for 'foot' could originate from *dʰregʰ-/dʰreg̑ʰ-. 
Apart from these problems connected to the PIE root, the Proto-Form of the Brittonic cognates is difficult to establish.
S.v. *h₃óh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os n. 'Mund' (IEW 784f., EIEC 387).
S.v. koyn* (nnt.) ‘mouth’ "PTch *koyŭ presumably represents a putative PIE *g̑ʰoi̯-u - (nt.) 'a gaping,' a derivative of *g̑ʰh₂(e)i̯ - 'yawn, gape'"

S.v. *deh₃- 'geben' (IEW 223-5). Cf. fn17 where it is stated Welsh rhoddaf 'I give' originates from the reduplicated present *dédoh₃/dh₃- of the root *deh₃- 'to give'. The neo-root *rod- was abstracted from *rodā ← *pro-dedō- with loss of reduplication in composition?
All Brittonic verbs are cognate, i.e. compounds *(p)ro-d- of *deh₃- 'to give'. In Welsh rhoi as well as in the Breton and Cornish verbs, *đ was lost.
As Pedersen 1913.
Cf. s.v. Bret. ro 'don, vœu' from Old Breton rod 'don, présent' corresponding to Cornish ro, Welsh rhodd in the same sense.
Detailed discussion of the hypothesis put forward in Schumacher 2004.
S.v. Hitt. u̯ēlku- 'grass, vegetation', perhaps from  PIE *u̯élk̑-u-, if cognate with Skt. valśa- ‘sprout’, OCS vlasъ ‘hair’, Russ. vólos ‘hair’.
MW deifyaw, Bret. deviñ, MCo. dewy, dywy < *dau-i̯e/o-; not cognate with MW de 'burning, warm, fervent', 3sg. 'burns, inflames; grieves'.

Cf. s.v. *dʰegʷʰ- 'mit Feuer behandeln, verbrennen (tr.)' (IEW 240-1). ?MW deifyaw listed as a possible derivative to the it. stem *dʰogʷʰ-éi̯e-, but acknowledges that this assignment is uncertain in fn4, noting the argument of Schrijver (1995:316) connecting this form to *deh₂u̯-.

Matasović presents contradictory etymologies for the Brythonic forms under different lemmata. Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic daw-yo- 'kindle, burn' > MW deifyaw, MBret. devo 'burn', dev 'burned' to be connected to PIE *deh₂u̯-, but s.v. Proto-Celtic *degʷi- 'flame, blaze' (derived to PIE *dʰegʷʰ-) W deifio 'burn' is derived to PCelt. *degʷ-ye-.

Cf. OIr. daig 'flamme, feu, incendie', cites older literature concerning the etymologies of the Goidelic and Brittonic words and opts for an etymology for W deifio, Br. deuiff, Co. dewi from PIE  from *deh₂u̯-, thus connecting Goidelic forms (cf. OIr. dó-) and and Brittonic forms to the same root.
Borrowed from Old French grif (13th century) from Old High German grifân with the development *skrif > skirf and dissimilation.

S. Lane, Language (7, 1931.4, 279) (review Revue Celtique 7, 279) rejects Henry's reconstruction *blou̯i-. According to him, bleo originates from *bleu̯s < *mleu̯s from the root *mel contained in Greek μαλλός 'hair, mane', Lith. mìlas 'cloth (of wool)', cf. WP 2.294.
Lane suggests an u-stem with suffixal full grade nsg. *ml-eu̯-s,  cf. IEW 721 with μαλλός 'flock of wool' < *ml̥-nó-, cognate class H? According to Frisk, GEW II 168, the Greek word is unexplained.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *flāmā 'palm, hand', from PIE *pl̥h₂meh₂ 'palm, hand' (cf. IEW 833, *pelh₂- IEW 805-07).

S.v. Bret. kalon, kaloun 'cœur' (Co. colon, W calon 'id.') Proto-Celtic *kal-onā may be cognate to 1) Latin calidus 'warm, hot' or to 2) Latin callidus 'experienced' (the heart was conceived as the organ of intelligence).
PIE roots of the proposed Latin cognates: 1) *k̑elh₁- 'to be hot' (cf. *k̑el- 'to become hot' LIV² 323) and 2) *kHl-, also in Br. kalet 'hart', cf. De Vaan 2008, s.vv.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *trummo- 'heavy', cf. PIE *treu̯d- 'thrust, press' (IEW 1095f.), cf. Lat. trudō 'thrust, push', Goth. us-þriutan 'to maltreat', OCS trudъ 'trouble'. The stem derivation is disputed, perhaps from  *trud-smo-, *trud-mo- or *truks-mo-. Cf. entry for discussion and further references.
From Proto-Celtic *trog-o- 'to pull' (lat. trahere etc., Celt. *treg-et- 'foot').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯e/o- 'to strike, to kill', PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ-. Schumacher follows {ref Schrijver 1995}:178 who reconstructs this root, neither contained in IEW nor in LIV².
S.v. λᾶας. Etymology unknown.  The stem formation of λᾶας is unexplained, and therefore may well be an early borrowing from a Pre-Greek substrate language.
S.v. 1. *deh₁- 'binden' (IEW 183).
S.v. δέω 1 'to bind' < PIE *deh₁- 'bind'.
S.v. 1. ?*k̑eu̯k- (IEW 597), but cognates are only from within Indo-Iranian.

S.v. *sekH- 'abtrennen' (IEW 895-6).  Italic forms come from a zero-grade i̯e-present *skH-i̯é-, from which the compositional form *ne-skH-ii̯e- > ne-sciō backformed a simplex form sciō 'weiß' (cf. n4 to lemma).  Hitt. šākki < Perfect *se-sokH- (cf. n6 to lemma for further discussion).

PS *listŭ 'leaf' is related to Lithuanian laĩškas, láiškas 'letter', cf. also Prussian crixti lāiskas 'baptism booklet'.
"A reconstruction *leh₁i-sk-to-, containing the verbal root 'let, leave', would raise the question why Hirt's law did not generate fixed stress. Instead, we might posit *leid-sk-to-, cf. Lith. léisti 'let, leave', provided that this root exists (see LIV: 402-403)."

S.v. μηρός 'the upper meaty part of the shank, shank' < PIE *mē(m)s-ro- 'fleshy'. Greek forms may be accounted for from a *-ro-adjective formation from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat, flesh' (Ved. māṃsa-, Goth. mimz, OCS мѧсо, etc. cf. /cognate/437/).  There is an unexplained nasal-less variant, Ved. mās- 'flesh, meat' (vs. māṃs- 'flesh, meat') < *mēs-, to which the Greek form μηρός should go back via a reconstructable pre-form *mēs-ró- 'fleshy'.  The semantic extension is 'fleshy (part of the body)' > 'thigh'.
S.v. *ped- 'treten; fallen, sinken' (LIV² 458, IEW 790ff.).
From Slav. *krokъ, PIE *kr(o)k-u-?

S.v. Proto-Slavic *noga 'foot, leg', as though from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. Lith. nagà 'hoof'; nãgas 'nail, claw', Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *koxsā 'leg', cf. PIE *kok̑so- 'hollow of joint' (IEW 611), cf. Latin coxa 'hip', OHG hāhsa and Toch. B kakse 'loins'.

S.v. νηρός 'fresh', from νεαρός 'young, youthful, tender, fresh' (with vowel contraction of medial -εα- > -η-.  The r-formation is paralleled by Armenian նոր nor /lexeme/28560/ 'new' < *neu̯-eró- vel sim.
S.v. Lat. fēmur, -inis 'thigh', An isolated r/n-stem: possibly *dʰen-u̯r̥, *dʰn̥-u̯én-s, following Steinbauer (1979), comparing Ved. dhánuṣ- 'bow' (cf. Mayrhofer, EWAia I:773-774).

S.v. Lat. dūrus 'hard, solid, endurable', from PIE *duh₂-ró-, where the same root ablaut is found in Indo-Iranian (Skt. dūrá- 'far, distant', Av. dūrāt̰ 'from afar' OPers. dūraiy 'far and wide'.  Greek and Armenian show forms with an e-grade: Att. δηρός 'long, too long', Arm. erkar 'long (in time)' < *du̯eh₂-ró-.

S.v. Lat. currō, -ere 'to run', from *kr̥s-e/o- 'to run'.  Cf. *kr̥s-o- 'running' > currus 'chariot'. Gaulish *karros > Lat. carrus, OIr. carr 'vehicle', Welsh car; cf. also OHG hros, ONor. hross, OE hors 'horse' if from Proto-Germanic *hursa- < *kr̥s-o-.
S.v. 1. *⁽k̑⁾ers- 'laufen' (IEW 945).
S.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).

S.v. αἱρέω 'to take, grasp, sieze'. "No etymology." [No reference to new literature that has appeared since {ref Frisk 1960-1972}, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}, or even discussion of previous proposals in earlier works).

δακρύω is a denominal verb from δάκρυ 'tear'.  For Ancient Greek δάκρυ Beekes accepts a reconstruction *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' where the first compound element is from *derk̑- 'see' and the second from *h₂k̑r-u- 'bitter'. For this proposed etymology cf. Kortlandt (1985a).
From Proto-Slavic *pȅpelъ ; *pȍpelъ  m. o (c) ‘ashes’, PIE *pepelh₁-o-, cf. p. 390 for the discussion of the root.

S.v. κλαίω 'to lament, bewail, weep over'. The present stem κλαίω is from Proto-Greek *κλάϝ-i̯ω by internal reconstruction (cf. future κλαύ-σ-ομαι).  The only comparable cognates are Albanian klan, qan 'to weep', from these it is possible to postulate a PIE root *kleh₂u̯-, but the given that there are no further comparanda the evidence is very slim.
Reconstructs the PIE root as *?pel- 'to flame up', i.e. without the laryngeal.
S.v. ?*⁽k̑⁾leh₂u̯- or 'weinen' (IEW 599).  Only Greek and Albanian attested as comparanda (cf. Old Tosk claàne (i.e. / klānë /). 'sie weinen').
S.v. *kʷer- '(ab)schneiden, schnitzen' (IEW 641-2).
S.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-717).
Ancient Greek ὅλος 'whole, all' (> Greek όλος) from PIE *sol(H)-u̯o- 'whole' and are unrelated to this class.  (See now /cognate/748/).
Indo-Iranian forms go back to PIIr. *u̯iću̯a- 'all' < PIE *u̯ik̑-u̯o-.
Indic forms from Old Indic *sáru̯a- 'all' (Ved. sárva- 'ganz, ungeteilt, all, jeder'), ultimately from PIE *sól-u̯o- 'whole'.
Tocharian forms reflect PIE *sól-u̯o- 'whole, entire'.
Ancient Greek ὅλος 'whole, all' (> Greek όλος) from PIE *sol(H)-u̯o- 'whole, entire'.
Cf. s.v. PIE *h₂eh₁- 'heiß sein' (not in IEW).
S.v. Ved. bhásman- 'Asche', either from PIE *bʰes- 'to skew, to crunch' (LIV² 82) or from PIE *bʰes- 'to blow, to breathe'. The latter root is only preserved by nouns.
S.v. *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen' (IEW 243).

S.v. Ved. pṛṣṭhá- (1) 'Rücken (von Tier und Mensch)', from PIE *pr̥-sth₂-ó- *'hervor-stehend' (cf. Lith. pir̃štas = OCS prьstъ 'Finger', Lat. postis 'Türpfosten', ON fyrst 'Dachfirst'). Iranian and Middle Indic forms from PIIr. *pr̥šti- are not to be etymologically connected to this class.
S.v. kärs- 'wissen, verstehen, erkennen', 'know, recognize, understand' (tr), from PIE *√kers ‘(ab)schneiden’ (LIV² 355f.).

S.v. druimm 'dos, côte, colline'. Origin unclear, LEIA cites several suggestions, among others IEW 1075 suggests that Irish druim has been borrowed from Welsh trum, drum '(crest of) mountain or hill, peak, ridge, cliff, slope'. The Welsh word can be reconstructed as *treu̯smn̥.
S.v. *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben' (IEW 735)
Cf. s.v. *(s)dʰerbʰ- 'fest/starr werden' (IEW 257, 1024-5). As a verbal root only Germanic and Slavic, cf. also Gk. στέρφος 'skin, hide'.
S.v. *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen' (IEW 259-60, 262); primary verb in ON deyja 'sterben' < *dʰou̯-éi̯e-.
S.v. *gʷelh₁- 'treffen, werfen' (IEW 471-2).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *jēra-, from PIE *i̯éh₁-r̥, i̯éh₁-n̥-s. Generalised with an r-suffix in Germanic, Avestan (nom.sg. yārə, gen.sg. yā̊) has preserved the original heteroclitic inflection. Cf. also Gk. ὤρα 'season, year, hour, time' < *i̯oh₁-reh₂.
Proto-Italic *atno- from PIE *h₂et-no- (cf. Goth. aþnam (dat.pl.) 'years' [nom.sg. *aþn 'year' is unattested]).

S.v. καινός 'new, newly found, unexpected' < *kn̥-i̯o- derived from PIE *ken- 'new, fresh' (cf. YAv. kaine 'girl', adj. Ved. kanyā- 'girl', kanīna- (adj.) 'young', -cens in Lat. recens 'fresh, new, young').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *biti 'beat', from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' (LIV² 72).
S.v. ?*dʰreb- 'stoßen, treffen' (IEW 272-3). Root only Germanic and (?)Slavic.
S.v. ?*dʰreb- 'stoßen, treffen' (IEW 272-3). Root only Germanic and (?)Slavic.
S.v. 1. *gʷelH- 'quälen, stechen' (IEW 470-1). OPr. gallintwei < PIE ?*gʷolH-éi̯e-, secondary with Baltic causative suffix -in-, Neubildung?
Cf. s.v. *reu̯H- 'aufreißen' (IEW 868). [Without Albanian forms given.]

S.v. OLith. žū́ti 'verloren gehen, zugrunde gehen, umkommen', (derived form: žū́dyti 'umbringen, töten, vernichten'), BSl. s.v. OLatv. pazūt 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen', etc.; no good comparanda outside of Baltic.

Cf. s.v. OLith. gãlas 'Ende, Ziel' (BSl. cf. Latv. gals 'End, Spitze, Äußerstes, Wipfel, Gipfel; Tod; Unglück, Pech; Gegend, Wohnung', galinât 'hungern lassen; zu Tode quälen; töten', OPr. gallan 'Tod; (die) Toten', gallintwey 'töten'). Lith. gãlas is an o-grade nominalisation to Lith. gélti 'stechen' (BSl. cf. Latv. zdel̂t, 'stechen, brennen, beißen', PCS žel’a 'Leid, Unglück'), from PIE *gʷelH- 'quälen, stechen' (cf. Arm. kelem 'quäle', keł 'Wunde, Geschwür', MW 3.sg.pres. vel 'schlägt', OE cwelan 'leiden, verderben', OHG quelan 'leiden, sich abquälen, trauern').
PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'to vanquish, to defeat', IEW 1128-9.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay'. A Germanic-Celtic isogloss. The root may originally have been onomatopoetic.
PIE *gʷem- 'to go, to come' (IEW464-65).

S.v. caedō, -ere 'to cut, hew, fell', from Proto-Italic *kaid-e/o-. Lat. occidere is a prefixed form of the verb. Cf. PIE *keh₂id- / *kh₂eid- 'to cut, hew'. Besides Albanian qeth, de Vaan also considers Arm. xaitʻem 'to stab' < *kHei-t-, MDu. heien 'to drive piles', OHG heia 'wooden hammer' < PGmc. *xajjan- < *kh₂ei-(i)e/o- or *kHoi- as potential cognates.
S.v. ?*kh₂ei̯d- 'schlagen' (IEW 917). Only Italic and Albanian, if Alb. qeth 'schneidet, schert (Haare)' is truly cognate to the Italic forms. Cf. entry for further references.
S.v. faciō, -ere 'to make'. Interficere is a compound of faciō, -ere 'to make, to do', from PIE *dʰh₁-k-.
S.v. ?*dʰeh₁k- 'machen, herstellen'. Extension of *dʰeh₁- 'to put, to place, to make, to produce', mainly attested in Italic. The origin of the k-element is unknown.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *org-o- 'to destroy', from PIE *h₃erg- 'to perish' (LIV² 301; cf. IEW 819 *perg-).
S.v. ?*teu̯H- '(freundlich) beachten, betrachten; schützen' (IEW 1079-80).

S.v. Lat. āreō 'to be dry', from PIE *h₂eh₁s-eh₁- 'to be dry' (cf. TochA asatär, TochB osotär 'dries up'), from which the derived adjective ar(i)dus 'dry', from which in turn Lat. ardeō 'to burn' is derived.

S.v. Lat. cremō, -āre 'to burn', probably a denominative present. The only possible cognate is the Celtic word for 'beer', PCl. *kormi- (e.g. Gaulish curmi, OIr. cuirm etc.), but the alternation Latin *krem- vs. Celtic *korm- is unexplained.
Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6).  See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.
S.v. *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7).
S.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben; fahren' (IEW 1118-20.).
From BSl. *lekt-. According to Meillet (Ét. I: 180), *letěti derives from *letъ  < *lek-to-.

The Baltic words are based on a root *lek- without any clear PIE cognates; cf. LIV² 411. Contrary to what is stated in the literature, the Baltic words are not cognate with Slav. words for 'fly', e.g. Old Church Slav. letěti, which originate from *let-.
PIE ?*lek- 'to move the limbs', IEW 673. Does not contain the Slavic words.

S.v. OLith. *skríeti 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen' (BSl. Latv. skrìet 'laufen, rennen, fliegen', with closest possible cognates found in OCS krilo 'Flügel' (etc.). Clear comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking.

S.v. ?*(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'einen Kreis beschreiben' (IEW 936). Verbal only Baltic. Present stem *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾réi̯-e- > Lith. skrejù (skriẽti) 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen', Latv. skreju (skriet) 'laufen, rennen, fliegen'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fleugan- 'to fly'. The PIE root is the k-extended variant of *pleu̯- > *pleu̯k- (cf. LIV² 487-488).
Cf. s.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837). An enlargement of *pleu̯-, only found in Germanic and Baltic.
S.v. στάζω (< *stag-i̯e/o-).      σταχτή itself from feminine of Ancient Greek στακτός 'oozing out in drops, trickling, distilling'; also as feminine substantive στακτή 'oil of myrrh'.

S.v. Lat. volō, -āre 'to fly', from Proto-Italic *gʷela-i̯e/o-, PIE *gʷelh₁-ie/o- 'to raise the arm, to throw' (LIV² 208). De Vaan suggests to come back to the etymology proposed by Müller, Altitalisches Wörterbuch, (1926:213), rejected by {ref Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954} II:828. If the original meaning was 'to raise the arm', a shift to 'fly' is quite conceivable in the connection with birds.
S.v. κοῖλος 'hollow, hollowed out, spacious, deep' < PIE *k̑euH- 'hollow' (cf. Lat. cavus 'hollow', MIr. cúa 'hollow', OHG hol 'hollow', etc.).
S.v. ἀμαυρός 'hardly seen, dim, faint'. No etymology.
S.v. κόκκος  'kernel of fruits, especially of the pomegranate'.  Etymology unknown, possibly a Mediterranean loan.

S.v. Lat. frīgus, -oris 'cold, frost', from which Lat. frīgidus 'cold' (adj.) is a derived adjective. Lat. frīgor 'cold, frost' reflects PIE *sriHg̑-e/os- (cf. ῥῖγος 'cold, frost', pf. ἔρριγα 'to be cold').
S.v. *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (IEW 293-6).
Cf. s.v. *sek- 'versiegen, austrocknen (intr.)' (IEW 894-895).
S.v. *treh₃⁽g̑⁾- 'zernagen' (IEW 1073), cf. TochB treṣṣäm '(zer)kaut' << *tr̥h₃⁽g̑⁾-sk̑e-.
S.v. *(s)neh₂- 'baden, schwimmen' (IEW 971-2).

Cf. s.v. OLith. lydė́ti 'begleiten, geleiten' (BSl. lidêt, lidu, lidẽju 'schweben, flattern', a zero-grade formation to Lith. léisti 'lassen, erlauben; loslassen, schicken, zapfen (Bier)' from PIE *lei̯d- '(los)lassen' (cf. Alb. lindet 'geboren werden, Lat. lūdō, -ere 'spielen').

S.v. OLith. girdė́ti 'hören' (BSl. Latv. dzìrdêt), from a univerbation of a PIE collocation or light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- dʰeh₁- 'Kunde geben', cf. Arm. kardam 'rufe', OIr. bard 'Barde', MW bardd 'id.', cf. *gʷer(H)- 'to consent' (LIV² 210f.) and *dʰeh₁- ''to put, to place, to make' (LIV² 136ff.). See also PIE *gʷerdʰ- 'to hear, to sound' (LIV² 187).

Cf. s.v. OLith. kérsti 'ausplaudern, austragen, verkünden' (BSl. OPr. kirdītwei, kirdīt 'hören'. According to LIV² 352 from PIE *?k⁽ʷ⁾erd- 'to hear'. The root could originate from collocation *kerH-dʰeh₁-, i.e. *kerH- 'to praise' (LIV² 353) and *dʰeh₁- 'to put, to place, to make' (LIV² 136ff.). This collocation was parallel to or influenced by the collocation *gʷer(H)-dʰeh₁- 'to give news, to make known' underlying Lithuanian girdėti 'to hear'. Although formally and semantically similar, the Lithuanian and Old Prussian verbs are not cognate.
S.v. Lat. tendō, -ere 'to extend, stretch', from Proto-Italic *tend-, in turn from PIE *ten-d⁽ʰ⁾-, a dental extended form of PIE *ten- 'to stretch'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *čuti 'sense, feel, notice'. No cognates outside of Slavic given.
S.v. Lat. sentiō, -īre 'to sense, feel', from Proto-Italic *s(e)nt-ii̯e/o- / *s(e)nt-(e)i, PIE *sent- 'to perceive' (LIV² 533, fn. 1).

S.v. Lat. audiō, -īre 'to hear', from Proto-Italic Pit. *au̯izdi̯e/o- 'to hear', probably based on a compound of PIE *h₂eu-is 'clearly' (cf. Hitt. au-/u- 'to see, look' < *h₂ou-, CLuw. au̯a (interj.) 'look!', Skt. āviṣ 'evidently', Av. āuuiš < IIr. Hāu̯iš, Gk. ἀΐω 'to perceive, hear', αἰσθάνομαι 'to perceive' < *h₂(e)u̯i-s-(dʰ)- '(to make) manifest', Lith. ovyje 'in reality', OCS (j)avě 'manifestly' < *h₂ēu-ēis [or loanword from Iranian?]) + *dʰh₁-ie/o- 'to render'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *drinkan 'to drink'. The Germanic verb contains a nasalized variant of the root *dʰreg- as found in Baltic, cf. Lith. *drė́gti 'to become moist'.

Cf. s.v. Lith. drė́gti 'to become moist, to thaw', to be interpreted as a denominal verb, the basis of which is not found in Lithuanian, but in Latvian drē̡gs m. 'thawing, muddy weather'. The latter seems to originate from a Vṛiddhi-derivation of pre-Proto-Balto-Slavic *dʰréh₁gʰo-, cf. PIE *dʰroh₁gʰ-/*dʰr̥h₁gʰ- 'deposit, yeast'.
S.v. *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'in Bewegung geraten (ohne Ortsveränderung)' (IEW 511-2).
S.v. *bʰei̯h₂- 'in Furcht geraten' (IEW 161-2).

S.v. Lat. vēnor, -āri 'to hunt', from a Proto-Italic denominal verb *u̯ēnā-i̯e/o- 'to hunt', based on an adjective *u̯ēn-o/ā- 'searching, hunting' or on a noun *u̯ēnā- 'hunt', cf. PIE *(H)uenh₁- 'desire'.
S.v. *u̯enH- 'liebgewinnen' (IEW 1146-7).

S.v. *u̯erp- 'hin- und herdrehen(?)' (IEW 1156).  The connection of Greek ῥάπτω with root *u̯erp- (Lith. verpiù, 'spinnen, stochern', Hitt. warapzi 'waschen, baden; reiben') is questioned because the identification is semantically and formally unclear, and the initial cluster could reflect original *sr̥- just as well as *u̯r̥-, see fn3.
S.v. *pleu̯-º 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7).  See under 'Neubildungen (Nasalpräs.)' and footnote 8.

Anatolian languages show stem allomorphy *tī-/*tu-, suggesting a morphologically suppletive stems *ti-h₂ (Nom.) vs. *tu- (oblique) in Proto-Indo-European, which subsequently underwent paradigmatic levelling to *tu- (all cases) in PIE post-separation of Proto-Anatolian.
From Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'dig, bury', cf. PIE *kelh₂- 'hit, break' (LIV² 350, IEW 546f.) with a d-extension.
Proto-Celtic *kla-d- from a collocation / light-verb-construction *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o-, i.e. *kelh₂- + *dʰeh₁- 'to make a stroke/stab' > 'to dig'?

S.v. OIr. claidid 'il creuse' cf. in Brythonic in W claddu 'creuser, enterrer', Bret. vann. klaouein 'id.', the root is *klad-, cf. clad 'fossé', 1 clas 'id.', claideb 'épée'; with preverb ad- 'chasser', properly 'prendre à la trappe'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'dig, bury', cf. PIE *kelh₂- 'hit, break' (LIV² 350, IEW 546f.).
From Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'dig, bury', cf. PIE *kelh₂- 'hit, break' (LIV² 350, IEW 546f.) with a d-extension.
Proto-Celtic *kla-d- from a collocation / light-verb-construction *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o-, i.e. *kelh₂- + *dʰeh₁- 'to make a stroke/stab' > 'to dig'?

S.v. Proto-Slavic *loviti '(try to) catch' (ESSJa XVI 106-108). Cf. Proto-Slavic *lovъ 'hunt, hunting' and *lovъkъ 'adroit, dextrous' (ESSJa 111-113), cf. Lith. lavùs 'adroit, dexterous, clever'. There are no cognates outside of Balto-Slavic; even then one might wonder whether Lith. lavùs is be a borrowing.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *goniti ‘chase, persecute’ (ESSJa VII 23), from PIE *gʷʰon- (cf. Gk. θείνω 'kill', Skt. hánti 'strike, slay').

Cf. s.v. OLith. mẽdis 'Baum, Holz; Wald'. Lith. medžióti is a denominal verb based words for wood, cf. Lith. mẽdis m. 'wood, tree; forest', mẽdžias m. 'tree', Old Prussian median 'wood, forest', Latv. mežs 'wood, grove'. Fraenkel Lingua Posnaniensis 4 (1953, 85-108) assumes a Proto-Baltic neuter 'forest' (Old Prussian median 'wood, forest', Latv. mežs 'wood, grove', Lith. mẽdžias 'tree'), from which in East Baltic a masculine singulative Lith. mẽdis was derived. Both words got mixed up in Lithuanian due to ambiguous forms in the oblique cases. The meaning of the Proto-Baltic neuter 'forest' must have developed from 'boundary ridge, border, frontier', as the latter meanings are found in Slavic cognates like OCSl. mežda f. 'street', Russ. mežá f.'boundary ridge, border, frontier', Čech. mez f. 'lynchet, unploughed strip', meze f. 'border' etc. From PIE *médʰi̯o- adj. 'middle, located in the middle'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *jakk/gōn- 'to rush, chase'. No certain etymology. Perhaps to the root *Hig̑ʰ- found in Greek and Indo-Iranian (cf. Gk. ἰχανάνω 'to desire', Skt. sam-ī́hate 'to strive/desire', OAv. iziiā 'I wish').
Proposes a cognacy with Hitt. ekt- c. '(hunting) net (?)' from PIE *i̯ek-t-. [Not in LIV².]
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hinϸan- 'to reach for' < *⁽k̑⁾ént-e- and Proto-Germanic *huntōn- 'to chase' from *⁽k̑⁾nt-néh₂-.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *u̯ēd-u- 'wild', cf. OIr. fiad (m, u) 'wild animals, game', fiad 'uncultivated land' and fiadach 'hunt', Ogam VEDA-CUNAS, MW gwydd, OBret. guoid-och gl. aper, MBret. goez, MoBret. gouez, OCo. guit-fil gl. fera. From PIE *u̯ei̯dʰ- 'wood, wilderness' (IEW 1177). These words are probably from the same PIE root as PCelt. *u̯idu- 'wood' (Lat. siluaticus > Fr. sauvage 'wild', from silua 'wood', also means 'wild').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *widu- 'wood', from PIE *u̯idʰu- 'wood' (IEW 1117) (cf. OE widu, wudu, Lith. vidùs 'interior').

The Brittonic singular guið 'wood' was reinterpreted as a plural 'trees', from which a singulative 'tree' is derived. (Singular: Proto-Brittonic *u̯id-u-s > *guid, plural: *u̯id-ou̯-es (if proterokinetic) > *guidou).
Borrowed from Latin cortex, -icis.
S.v. Ved. tvác- 'Haut, Fell; die Haut des lebenden Menschen oder Tieres, in Kontrast zu cárman-' (Pā. taca-, tacas- 'Haut, Rinde'). Probably to be connected with Hitt. tu̯ekka- 'Körper, Person'.

The Hitt. and the Vedic words originate from a PIE root noun nom.sg. *tu̯ék (without -s), acc.sg. tu̯ék-m, gen.sg. *tuk-ós. The underlying root *tu̯ek- 'physical appearance?' is also attested in Hitt. tukk-āri ‘to be visible’.

S.v. OLith. žievė̃ 'Rinde, Baumrinde' (BSl. cf. Latv. zievis 'Baumrinde'). Etymologically isolated. The traditional connection with Lith. žydė́ti 'blühen' is not semantically convincing. No reliable comparisons outside of Baltic.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *barku- 'bark', cf. PIE *bʰorh₁g̑-. Cognate with Alb. barmë f. 'bast' < *bʰorh₁g̑-mo-. The u-stem *barku- has no parallel outside Germanic and may have split off from the acc. pl. *barkuns < *bʰorg̑-n̥s of a root noun *bʰérHg̑-s 'birch, birch bark'. The same root noun may have served as a source for the related zero-grade formation Middle Low German borke f. 'bark' < *burkō-. Related: *berkō- 'birch-tree' and *berhta- 'bright'.

PIE *rendʰ- is based on the Germanic words for 'bark' and 'scab' and on Old rándhra- n. 'opening, hole, split'. The Old Indic word is not cognate, but from PIE *lendʰ- 'loin', cf. EWAia II 432. It is thus not possible to postulate a PIE cognate set.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *basta- m. 'bast'. No further connections outside of Germanic. Hardly to Latin fascis 'bundle'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *grauta- 'coarse' from PIE *gʰroud-o-, a regular o-grade adjective to the strong verb *greutan- 'to grind, crush' (< *gʰréud-e-, cf. Lith. grū́sti 'to thrust, pestle, stamp' < *gʰrud-ie-, Ru. grúda- 'heap, pile', SCr. grȕda 'clod, lump' < *gʰroud-eh₂-). In the West-Germanic languages, a meaning shifts towards 'big' took place replacing *mekila- 'big'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. grū́sti 'stampfen, stoßen, härten' (BSl. Latv. grûst, 'stoßen, stampfen'), from PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'zerstoßen, zerstampfen' (cf. ON grjót 'Gestein, Geröll', grautr 'Grütze', OE grēot 'Sand, Kies' [LIV² -, IEW 460f.].

S.v. Proto-Germanic *stōra- ~ *stura- adj. 'big', reflecting PIE *stéh₂uro-  ̴ *sth₂uró-, two variants of a heteroclitic adjective PIE nom.sg. *stéh₂-u̯(ō)r, gen.sg. *sth₂-un-ós, root *steh₂- 'to stand' (LIV² 590-92, IEW 1004-8). (Pre-Germanic *stūró- shortened to *stŭro- by Dybo's Law of pretonic shortening). Cf. Skt. sthūrá- 'big, strong, thick, massy', YAv. stūra- 'strong', Oss. styr / (i)stur 'big, great' < *sth₂u-ró-; Skt. sthávira- 'broad, thick' < *steuh₂r-ó- (with laryngeal metathesis); Skt. sthāvará- 'standing firm, immovable, lasting' < *steh₂-uer-; Arm. stuar 'fat' < *sth₂-ur-o-(?).

S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.). Ultimately derived from *steh₂- 'stand' from a heteroclitic stem **sth₂-u̯r- > *stuh₂r-, which is found as a thematised o-stem *stuh₂r-ó- in Indo-Iranian (Ved. sthūrá-, etc.) and Germanic. Cf. discussion p.652n75.

S.v. OLith. dìdis 'groß, bedeutend' (BSl. dižs 'groß; vornehm, herrlich'). No certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic (but no known Old Prussian correspondences. Commonly conntected with PIE *dei̯h₂- 'to light up' ({ref LIV²} 108, {ref IEW} 183f.), which is however problematic, as Winter's lengthening is lacking.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *velikъ 'big, great', from PIE *uelh₁- 'to be strong' (cf. Lat. valeō 'be strong, well').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *golěmъ 'big' (ESSJa VI 202-204). "The root of this adjective may be identified with the root of Lith. galė́ti 'be able' and W gallu 'id.' which is best reconstructed as *gal(H), with "European" a."

S.v. OLith. líesas, -à 'mager, hager'. No convincing etymology for Latv. liẽls 'big' and a couple of formally similar Baltic words meaning 'meagre, slender'. They point to an underlying root *lei̯H-, such as PIE *lei̯h₂- 'to fade, to stop' (LIV² 406, IEW 661-2), perhaps also *lei̯d- 'to leave alone'(LIV² 402-3, IEW 666). Even if the Latvian word belongs here, the semantic change has to be explained.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *debelъ adj. o 'fat' (ESSJa IV 201-202) is based on a Balto-Slavic root *deb-. Cognate with Latv. depsis 'small, fat boy', OPr. debīkan Asg. 'big'; debica (Gr.) 'big'; OIc. dapr 'sad'; Nw. daper 'sad, with young'; dabb(e) (dial.) m. 'small, fat fellow'; OHG tapfar 'firm, heavy, thick-set'. Derksen: "Formally, the Balto-Slavic and the Germanic forms do not match, considering that in the case of PIE *b the Balto-Slavic evidence would violate Winter’s law. It is by no means necessary, however, to assume that this etymon is of Indo-European origin."

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *dapra- 'heavy' (cf. RuCS debelyj 'fat', Ru. debelyj 'plump, corpulent' SCr. dèbeo 'fat' < *dʰebʰ-lo-; OCS doblь 'strong', Ru. dóblij 'valiant', Latv. dabļš 'strong, lush' < *dʰobʰ-l-io-). "This adjective is usually directly compared to the aforementioned forms in Slavic, but the underlying root *dʰebʰ- can only be reconciled with PGm. *dapra- by assuming that it was derived from *dapōn-, an analogical variant belonging to the iterative *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' (q.v.) < *dʰobʰ-néh₂-."
S.v. *dʰeb- 'dick, fest, gedrungen'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *debelъ adj. o 'fat' (ESSJa IV 201-202) is based on a Balto-Slavic root *deb-. Cognate with Latv. depsis 'small, fat boy', OPr. debīkan Asg. 'big'; debica (Gr.) 'big'; OIc. dapr 'sad'; Nw. daper 'sad, with young'; dabb(e) (dial.) m. 'small, fat fellow'; OHG tapfar 'firm, heavy, thick-set'. Derksen: "Formally, the Balto-Slavic and the Germanic forms do not match, considering that in the case of PIE *b the Balto-Slavic evidence would violate Winter’s law. It is by no means necessary, however, to assume that this etymon is of Indo-European origin."
S.v. *dʰeb- 'dick, fest, gedrungen'.

Perhaps from nom sg. m./f. *mh₂-i̯ōs and cognate with Gothic mais, OHG mē(r),  'more', PCl. *mati- in Irish maith, Breton mat 'good', cf. *meh₂- 'to give sign' (LIV² 425, IEW 693). According to an alternative etymology, Osk. mais, Latin magis originate from *mag-i̯os.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *bītan 'to bite, be sharp', from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' (cf. Skt. binátti 'to split, break, destroy', Lat. findō, -ere, 'split, cleave' < *bʰi-né-d-ti, *bʰi-n-d-énti, Gk. φείδομαι 'to spare, save, refrain from').
S.v. *h₂merd- 'ein Leid antun, mißhandeln' (IEW 736-7).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *grỳzti 'gnaw' (ESSJa VII 160-161), from Balto-Slavic *gr(o)uʔź- (cf. Lith. gráužti 'gnaw', Latv. graûzt 'gnaw'). [No etymology given outside of Balto-Slavic].
S.v. Proto-Slavic *xāpàti 'seize' (ESSJa VIII 18-19). [No etymology outside of Slavic given.]
S.v. φάος 'light, daylight' < PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' (cf.  Skt. bhā́ti 'lighten, shine'). The form φῶς resulted from the contraction of medial -άο-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *golva 'head' (ESSJa VI 221-222), from PIE *golH-u-eh₂ (cf. Lat. calva 'skull'). [No connection given to Armenian lexemes.]

S.v. Lith. galvà 'head' (Latv. gal̂va 'head', OPr. galwo 'head'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *golʔwáʔ, from PIE *golH-ueh₂- "[Contrary to what is printed in Derksen 2008:176, a]n etymological connection with Lat. calva 'skull' is formally impossible. Nevertheless, it is tempting to seek a link with these forms, as the same irregular *k : *g correspondence is observed in words for 'bald', where we have Lat. calvus 'bald' and Skt. kulva- 'bald, thin haired' vs. OCS golъ, OHG kalo 'bald'." [No connection given to Armenian lexemes.]
S.v. *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (IEW 1065-6).  LIV reconstructs an essive formation *tn̥-h₁i̯é- > teneō 'halten' (with remodelling of the morphological ending), cf. Umbr. tenitu 'soll halten'.
Oscan mais 'more', maimas 'greatest' and Umbr. mestru 'greater' are cognate with Latin magnus, thus < PIt. *mg̑-no- 'great', *mg̑-i(V)s- 'greater'. (Also Kroonen 2013, 350).

S.v. AGk. κρύπτω 'to conceal, hide'. Although reminiscent of some potential cognates in Balto-Slavic (cf. OCS kryti 'κρύπτω, ἀποκρύπτω', Lith. kráuti 'pile up') there is no good Indo-European etymology.  The alternation of stem-final π~φ~β verbal forms and derived forms leads Beekes to suppose that the word may be from a Pre-Greek language.
S.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273).
Cf. s.v. 1. *h₂eg̑- 'treiben' (IEW 4-5).

S.v. AGk. πικρός < PIE *pik̑-ro- 'motley, painted'. The Greek forms are identical to Common Slavic *pьstrъ. Cf. Skt. piṃśáti 'to carve, cut to measure, ornament', OCS pьsati 'to write'.  In a different ablaut grade cf. Gk. ποικίλος 'many coloured, spotted, dappled' < *poik̑-.
S.v. οἶκος 'house, dwelling of any kind, room, home, household, native land' < PIE *u̯ei̯k̑-/*u̯oi̯k̑- 'house' (= Lat. vīcus 'group of houses, village', Skt. véśa- 'house' < PIE *u̯ói̯k̑-o-).

Cf. s.v. σκιά 'shade' (< PIE *skeh₂-ih₂, gen. *skh₂-ieh₂-s 'shadow') and s.v. σκότος 'darkness, dark' (< PIE *skeh₃t- or *skoto- 'shadow, dark'). Note p.1351 "The relation [of Gk. σκιά] with σκότος is unclear". (Cf. Skt. chāyā́ 'shadow', Av. a-saiia 'who casts no shadow'.)

S.v. χθές 'yesterday', from PIE *dʰgʰi̯es- 'yesterday'. According to Puhvel (1987:316-8), this is in turn derived from *dʰog̑ʰ-o- 'day' by adding a comparative suffix/original endingless locative -i̯es/-is. Germanic and Latin show an additional *-ter suffix.
S.v. μυῖα 'fly', from PIE *mus-ih₂.
S.v. ἔτος 'year' from PIE *u̯et-os, gen.sg. *u̯et-es-os (s-stem neuter derivative).

S.v. Ved. vatsá- 'Kalb, Junges' (m.) and vatsará- 'Jahr'.  Ved. saṃ-vatsará- is a secondary derived form from vatsá-, which is in itself a thematised form of the original s-stem *u̯et-es- >> (transponat) *u̯et-s-o-.

S.v. TochB pikul 'year', which with TochA pᵤkul/pᵤkäl reflects Proto-Tocharian *päkwäl. All attempts at an Indo-European derivation are obscure.  Katz (1994) has attempted an explanation from *pi-kʷl̥ < *(h₁e)pi- 'at, upon' + *kʷl̥-, the zero-grade of *kʷel- 'turn, revolve'.  Alternatively Van Windekens suggestion assumes that PT *päkwäl is a verbal noun derived from *päk- 'cook, ripen'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *lě̀to n. 'summer' (ESSJa XV 8-12), from PIE *leh₁-tóm (cf. OIr. laithe n. 'day').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *gȏdъ m. 'right time' < PIE *gʰodʰ-o- (cf. Goth. goþs 'good', OHG guot 'good').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *rokъ 'time', derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *rekti 'speak, say' < PIE *rek-. For the semantics, cf. Lat. fātum [< *bʰh₂-to- 'spoken'].

S.v. Lat. umbra 'shadow, shade', generally connected with Lithuanian ùnksna 'shade' and reconstructed as *unksrā-. The etymology suggests a root *(H)unk- (full-grade *(H)uenk-), but the only comparable root in LIV² is *u̯enk- 'to bend', which does not seem to be a good semantic match. No other root etymology.

S.v. Lat. domus, -ī, / -ūs. The Latin (and Slavic) forms are from a u-stem derivative of PIE *dōm, *dem- 'house' (Skt. dám-, Av. dam- < *de/om-; Skt. dáma- 'house', Gk. δόμος 'house, layer of bricks' < *dóm-o-, Russ. дом 'house', (L.sg. дому) < *dom-u-)
S.v. Lat. amārus 'bitter', possibly from PIE *h₂h₃m-ro-? (cf. Skt. amlá- 'sour, acid', OIc. apr 'sharp, cold', etc.). Some morphological details remain unclear.

S.v. Lat. persōna 'masque de théâtre'. Latin persona appears to be a loanword from Etruscan φersu 'theatre mask', which in turn appears to be a borrowing from Greek πρόσωπον 'face', but the exact relation and phonological correspondences are difficult to determine.  The spread of the word in its sense 'theatre mask' is connected to the spread of Greek-style dramatic performance in the Mediterranean.

S.v. εὕδω, which is compounded with the preposition/preverb κατά 'down' in Attic. Several unconvincing suggestions: 1) related to Goth. sutis 'quiet, calm' and Lat. sūdus 'soft', 2) to IE *seu-d- beside *su-ep-, Skt. svapiti 'sleeps', etc. ({ref Benveniste 1935}:156), or 3) to OE swodrian 'to sleep tight'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *blōda-, a neuter collective created to either *blēan- 'to blow' or *blōan- 'to flow'.

Three possible etymologies: 1) PIE *meg̑-, than cognate with Latin magnus; 2) PIE *meh₂- 'to give a sign' (LIV² 425, IEW 693), than cognate with PCl. *mati- 'good'; 3) PIE *meh₁-, then cognate with PCl. *māro- 'big' and Greek.
From *meh₁- 'big'.
The Albanian word originates from *su-petno-t- ({ref Huld 1984}:154)
S.v. Alb. zog 'bird' "An Oriental Wanderwort, presumably of Iranian origin, cf. Arm. jag 'chick', NPers zaq 'cub'."

From PIE *g̑ʰāgʷʰ- 'young of an animal, especially of a bird'. Cognate with Mod. Pers. zāq 'young animal, esp. chick' (the orthography repesents zāɣ). Borrowed from Persian: Arm. jag 'young of an animal, nestling'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *askōn- f. 'ashes', but notes that it remains problematic to bring the Gothic form and the North and West Germanic forms together. Thus he proposes an alternative source form gmc. *adᶻdʰgʰ- from a compound formed from the roots ie. *h₂ed- 'to desiccate' and *dʰegʷʰ- 'to burn'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *baka-, as though from PIE *bʰog-o-, but there are no clear cognates outside of Germanic. Borrowed into Slavic as OCS bokъ m. 'side'. Cf. n-stem *bakan- > OHG bahho, MHG bache, MDu. bake m. 'bacon'.
Cf. s.v. bʰelg̑ʰ- 'schwellen' (IEW 125-6).
S.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (IEW 116-7).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *daga- 'day', from PIE *dʰog̑ʰ-o-, a thematic noun related to PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' < *dʰṓg̑ʰ-r/n- (cf. Skt. áhar-, gen. áhnas, loc. áhan, áhani 'day' OAv. gen.pl. asnąm 'id.'). "In Early Indo-Iranian, this formation lost its initial dental, possibly in the locative *dʰgʰ-én-i, where the root had a zero-grade."

S.v. Proto-Germanic *erþō- f. 'soil, earth, land'.  If the comparison with the Ancient Greek lexeme ἔρα f. 'earth' the forms may be respectively reconstructed *h₁er-t-eh₂- > PGmc. *erþō-, *h₁er-eh₂- > AGk. ἔρα, but this comparison is tenuous.  Within Germanic the lexeme is probably cognate with *erwan- m. 'sand, soil'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *etan- 'to eat', from PIE *h₁ed- 'eat' (cf. Hitt. ez(za)zi ~ adanzi, Skt. átti, adánti, Gk. ἔδω, Lat. edō, ēsse, OIr. ithid, Lith. ė́sti, etc.).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *fallan- 'to fall'.  K. adopts a new Indo-European etymology following Praust ("What Greek can tell us about the prehistory of English 'to fall'" unpublished paper at the conference Greek and Latin from an Indo-European from an Indo-European Perspective, Cambridge, July 2005) and {ref Neri 2007} as from a univerbation of the preverb *h₂po- and the root *h₃elh₁- 'to fall' (cf. Hitt. ḫallannai ~ ḫallannii̯anzi 'to trample down, flatten', Gk. ὄλλυμι 'destroy, kill, lose').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *fehtan- 'to fight'.  Often assumed to be connected with LIV² 1. *pek̑- '(Wolle oder Haare) rupfen, zausen' (cf. Gk. πέκω 'kämme, schere', Lith. pešù 'rupfen', Lat. pectō 'kämmen, krempeln'), but this depends on a conjectural semantic shift from 'pluck, pull hair' > 'fight'.

The roots *pleu̯d- 'schwimmen, fließen', *pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' are treated as variants of *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' with root-extensions in Pokorny.  Strictly, these root variants should be listed as separate cognates, but considering 'float' is being dropped from the Jena 100 and 200 lists, I'm not bothering with this task unless the 'float' later becomes reinstated. Cognacy of Armenian cognates also doubtful.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *freusan- 'to freeze' < PIE *préus-e- (cf. W. rhew 'frost, rhime' < *preuso-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *gōda- adj. 'suitable, good', an o-grade adjective to a lost strong-verb *gadan- 'to fit' < *gʰedʰ-.  Cf. denominal verb *gadōjan- 'to fit (together)' (pp.162-163).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hūsa- 'house', an etymologically obscure word.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *īsa- 'ice'. There are no certain cognates outside of Germanic. "Av. aexa- can only be related if it continues a form *h₁eiH-ko- that developed into *HeikHo- by laryngeal metathesis."
S.v. *g̑neh₃- 'erkennen' (IEW 376-8).
Traditionally reconstructed as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) 'Laus', with frequent tabooistic distortions in individual branches.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *alda- adj. '(grown) old' from PIE *h₂el-tó- (cf. Lat. altus adj. 'high', OIr. alt m. 'height, cliff'.  From fem. *h₂el-teh₂- > Welsh allt 'hill'). From the same root *h₂el- found in Proto-Germanic *alan- 'to grow up; to rear' (cf. Lat. alere 'to nourish', OIr. alid 'to feed').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *aina-, from PIE *Hoi̯-Hn-o-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *sagjan- 'to say, recount' from PIE *sokʷ-éi̯e/o-
 (cf. SCS sočiti 'to indicate', Ru. sočít' (sočú) 'to look for, track down, summon', SCr. sòčiti 'to establish the guilt of, reveal, find'; Lat. īnsece 'to tell', Gk. ἐν(ν)έπω 'to say, recount, announce').
S.v. 2. *sekʷ- 'sagen' (IEW 897-8).

S.v. 1. *sekʷ- 'sich anschließen' (IEW 986-7); Germanic forms are only questionably attached, cf. n7 often connected under the assumption of a semantic development 'see, have one's eye on' < *'follow (with one's eyes)'.
S.v. 2. *ten⁽g̑⁾- 'dünken, scheinen (unpers.)' (IEW 1088). Only Italic and Germanic (cf. OLat. tongēre 'wissen'). Cf. n1 "Grundbedeutung wohl 'jmdm. in den Sinn kommen".
S.v. *h₁nek̑- 'erhalten, nehmen'.  Cf. Attic Greek aor. ἐνεγκεῖν < *h₁é-h₁nek̑-e-, pf. ἐνήνοχα < *h₁ne-h₁nok̑-
S.v. *bʰedʰh₂- 'stechen, graben' (IEW 113-4).  Cf. OCS bodǫ (bosti) 'stechen', Lith. bedù (bèsti) 'stechen, graben'.
S.v. Lat. flōs, -ris 'flower'. The Italic cognates reflect PIE *bʰleh₃-ōs- 'blossoming' > 'flower'.
Cf. s.v. *bʰleh₃- 'blühen' (IEW 122).

S.v. gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice', from PIE *g̑el-u- 'cold, frost, ice' (cf. Goth. kalds 'cold', OE calan 'to freeze', OIc. kala 'to freeze'). Connections with Gk. γελανδρόν 'cold' (Hesych.) are uncertain. Slavic lexemes, e.g. OCS xladъ 'coolness, cool breeze', Ru. xolod' 'cold' < Proto-Slavic *xoldъ '(the) cold' may be from an extended root *g̑oldʰo-? Lat. gelāre 'to freeze' is a denominal verbal derivative from Lat. gelu- 'cold, frost, ice'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hlah(j)an- 'to laugh' as though from *klok-ie-, perhaps to be compared with Ru. klekotát' 'to scream (of bird of prey)'; cf. ON hlakka 'to scream (of birds); to rejoice'. If so, perhaps a root *klek-.
Cf. s.v. Lith. juõkas 'laugh, laughter', which is most likely a (dialectal) German loanword (cf. Prussian dialect jōk vel sim., itself a loan in Germanic from Latin iocus 'joke').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg'. No further etymology.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg'. No further etymology.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ketwa- n. 'meat'. "An exclusively Nordic word that has been compared to Icel. kvett(i) n. 'piece of meat', Far. kvett n. 'quick cut; lucky strike' < *kwattja-, which appears to be derived from Far. kvetta w.v. 'to cut, break, bite quickly' < *kwattjan-. This causative must in turn be related to ME cutten, kitten w.v. 'to cut' < *kuttjan-, and MHG kotze m. 'spud' < *kuttan- … No certain etymology. Possibly related to Lith. gùdė f. 'whetstone' < *gudʰ-ieh₂-."

S.v. Proto-Germanic *munþa- 'mouth', from PIE *mnt-o- (cf. Lat. mentum 'chin', MW mant 'mandible, gums' < *mnt-o-. The root may also be identified in Gk. μασάομαι 'to chew, bite' (as though from *mnt-i-eh₂-ie-) and Lat. mandō 'to chew' < *mnt-néh₂- (with dissimilation of the first n, schwa secundum from the resulting form *mt-nā-, and prenasalisation under Thurneysen's Law).

S.v. Lith. var̃das 'name', Latv. vā̀rds 'word, name', from PIE *u̯(e/o)rdʰ-o- (cf. Lat. uerbum 'word').  The Old Prussian forms wīrds, wirds 'word' reflect a zero-grade < *u̯r̥dʰ̑-o-, like the Germanic forms attested from Goth. waurd 'word', OEng. word 'word'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *fūro- 'fresh', from PIE *puh₂-ro- 'pure, clean' (cf. Lat. pūrus, Skt. pūtá- 'purified', pávate 'becomes clean', OHG fouwen 'to sieve, sift'. Generally the root is reconstructed as *peu̯H- 'purify' (cf. e.g. {ref LIV²} 480, {ref EWAia} II:105-106 s.v. Ved. pav-ⁱ). Matasović, however, suggests that the PIE root is presumably the same as *peh₂-u̯r̥- 'fire', so that the original meaning of putative *puh₂ro- would have been 'purified by fire'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *klawō- 'claw' (OEng. clāwu, clā, Eng. claw, Du. klauw, OHG klāwa, klā, klō(a); Germ. Klaue, ON kló, Far. klógv, Elfd. kluo).  Exclusively a Germanic word.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *grindan- 'to grind'. Cf. OEngl. grindan, Engl. grind.  < *gʷʰrénHdʰ-e-.  Connects with Lat. frendō 'grind one's teeth', < *gʷʰréndH-e-, Lith. *grę́sti 'to plane, scour' < *gʷʰrenHdʰ-i̯e-.

S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾ʰrend- '(zer)reiben' (IEW 459), doubting the connection of Lat. frendō, and Lith. gréndu 'schaben, scheuern' at a PIE level.  Cf. n1 "Ae. grindan 'reiben, zermalmen' usw. kann dann wegen d < dʰ  nur mittelbar vergleichen werden."
S.v. Proto-Slavic *plàkati 'cry, weep', from PIE *pleh₂k- or *pleh₂g- (cf. AGk. πλήσσω 'beat', Lat. plangere 'beat, beat the breast as a sign of mourning, bewail', OEng. flōcan 'applaud').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ęti 'take' (cf. Lat. emere '*to take > buy, purchase') + preverb *vъz- 'up, back'.
S.v. *h₁em- 'nehmen' (IEW 310-1).

Proto-Iranian *karš-/*xrah- 'to draw, plough' (YAv. karš- 'to draw (furrows), plough', Skt. karṣ- 'to pull, drag, plow' (RV+)) from PIE *kʷels- 'Furchen ziehen, einfurchen' (LIV² 388-389, IEW 639-640).  Cf. Hitt. gulšanzi 'they scratch into', AGk. τέλσον 'last furrow of the field'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *běžàti 'run, escape', from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'davonlaufen, fliehen' (cf. AGk. φέβομαι 'flee', cs. φοβέομαι 'fear' /cognate/1479/).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *jьti 'go' (ESSJa VIII 247-248), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *ei- (Lith. eĩti, Latv. iêt 'go') from PIE *h₁ei̯- (cf. Skt. éti, Gk. εἶμι, Lat. īre).
S.v. Lat. rota 'wheel', from PIE *Hrot-o/h₂- adj. 'revolving'.

S.v. Ved. pátra- Flügel (eines Vogels), Feder', derived from a heteroclitic *pat-r-/*pat-n- and cognate with Germ. Feder, Engl. feather, Old Welsh eterin 'bird', atan 'wing', etc., cf. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschießend fliegen, stürzen, fallen' from PIE *pet- (cf. Lat. petō, Gk. πέτομαι, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *lauba- 'leaf, foliage', a European word with no clear PIE etymology.

S.v. ἀριστερός 'left'. Generally assumed to be connected with ἄρισ-τος 'best' and the comparative ἀρείων 'better, stronger, nobler', with the contrastive-suffix -τερο-. perhaps further to the root *h₂er- found in Gk. ἀραρίσκω 'to fit, join together' with an original meaning 'more fitting'.
Cf. s.v. Gk. λαιός, from PIE *leh₂i-uo- 'left' (Lat. laevus, OCS lěvъ).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *lěvъ 'left', from PIE *lh₂eiuo- (cf. Gk. λαίος, Lat. laevus).

S.v. sinister 'left, on the left side, adverse'. "Next to laevus and scaevus, the meaning 'left' for sinister must be a more recent development. If -is- represents the PIE comparative suffix *-w-, to which an extra *-tero- was added, the root can be *sin(H)- or *sen(H)-. WH connect the root *senh₂- 'to obtain' (Skt. sanóti), which would imply something like 'the more favourable (side)' for *senH-is-tero- > sinister. This remains gratuitous, because the semantics are not specific enough."
Reconstructs a form *senisteros prior to initial-vowel weakening "but the etymology is very uncertain".
Ancient Greek σάρξ from PIE *turk̑-, zero-grade to root *tu̯erk̑- 'to cut' (cf. Av. θβarəs- 'to cut').
S.v. *tu̯erk̑- 'schnitzen, zurechtschneiden' (IEW 1102).

S.v. φέγγος 'light, splendour, lustre'. No etymology; often compared with Lith. spingiù (spìngu), spingė́ti 'to give a weak light, glitter', OE spincan 'to spark', OHG funko 'spark', but the suggestion is formally impossible.

S.v. Ved. candrá- 'schimmernd, licht', from √cand- (√ścand-) 'glänzen, schimmern'.  Probably not to be separated from Lat. candēre 'glänzen, schimmern' from PIE *(s)kend-. The compound candrá-māḥ 'glittering moon', used in the sense of 'Mond, Mondgott' in the RV (cf. Mayrhofer EWAIa I:529), whence the semantics were transferred to the epithet candrá- in the sense 'moon', attested already in the Atharva-Veda.
Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)kend- 'erglänzen' (IEW 526).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *tungla- 'star, celestial body(?)'  Of uncertain etymology.
S.v. Lith. jáunas 'young'.  "The Balto-Slavic adjective seems to reflect *h₂ieu-Hn-o-."  PIE *h₂iu-Hon- (Skt. yúvan- adj. 'young, youth'; Lat. iuuenis m. 'young man').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *jьgrati v. 'play'.  Rejects the earlier connection with Skt. éjati 'move, stir' < *h₂ei̯g- because it is "semantically unconvincing and formally unattractive because it is in conflict with Winter's Law."

S.v. Proto-Slavic *pravъ adj. 'right'. "If *pràvъ < *proH-uo- […] we may compare the formation with Lat. probus ‘solid, decent’ provided that the latter form continues *pro-b ʰ(u̯)o- and not *pro-bʰuH-o-."
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kory 'root' (ESSJa XI 62-65), from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾or(H)-en- (cf. Lith. kẽras m. 'tree-stump, stub, bush, shrub'; Latv. cęrs m. 'bush, knotty root of a tree').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *pěsъkъ m. 'sand', from PIE *pē(n)s-u-ko- (cf. Skt. pām̆̇sú- 'dust, sand').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *vìděti 'see' < PIE *u̯ei̯d- (cf. Lith. veizdė́ti 'look, look for').
S.v. *u̯ei̯d- 'erblicken' (IEW 1125-1127).
S.v. ?2. *pei̯H- 'singen' (Slavic and Tocharian only).
Proto-Slavic *pěti 'sing' < PIE *poiH- (cf. Toch. B pi- 'sing, make sing').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kòža f. 'skin, leather' (ESSJa XII 35-36), a derivative of Proto-Slavic *kozà f. 'goat', possibly a borrowing from a Turkic language.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *nȅbo n. 'sky, heaven' (ESSJa XXIV 101-104), from PIE *nebʰ-es- (cf. Lith. debesìs 'cloud', Latv. debess 'cloud', Skt. nábhas- 'fog, mass of clouds, sky', Gk. νέφος 'cloud, mass of clouds', Hitt. nēpiš- n. 'sky').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *sъpati 'sleep', from PIE *sup- (cf. Skt. svápati, Lat. sōpīre, 'fall asleep', OE swefan).
S.v. *su̯ep- 'einschlafen' (IEW 1048-1049).
S.v. Ved. √svap- 'schlafen' (Av. xᵛafsa 'schlafe!'), from PIE *su̯ep- (cf. Lat. sōpīre 'einschlafen', OE swefan 'schlafen', etc.).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *màlъ adj. 'small, little' (ESSJa 17:173-178). Derksen argues for a derivation from PIE *moh₁-lo-.  The semantic shift is one of 'small animal' > 'small' (Gk. μῆλον 'small cattle, goat, sheep' < *meh₁-lo-; OIr. míl '(small) animal'; Goth. smals m. 'small, insignificant'; Old Icelandic smali m. 'small (live) stock, sheep').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dỳmъ m. 'smoke' (ESSJa V 203), from PIE *dʰuH-mó- (cf. Skt. dhūmá- 'smoke, vapour', Gk. θυμός 'heart, passion, courage', Lat. fūmus 'smoke, vapour').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *pjьvati 'spit' < *PIE *(s)pieHu- (cf. Lith. spjáuti, Latv. spļaũt; Lat. spuere, Goth. speiwan).
S.v *spti̯eu̯H- 'spucken, speien' (IEW 999-1000).

S.v. Lith. druskà 'salt' (Latv. druska 'crumb, scrap, bit', Old Prussian dmskins [druskins] 'earwax'), from *dʰrus-k-eh₂- (cf. Goth. drauhsos N.pl.f. 'crumbs, lumps'; Welsh dryll m. (< *dʰrus-lo-) 'piece, lump').
S.v. lavaṇá- 'Salz, Seesalz', probably from *lavaná-, √lav- 'cut' < PIE *leuH-, cf. Lith. liáutis 'be cut off', Hittite (GIŠ) lu-ut-ta-i 'window' < *leu̯H-to- 'cut out'.
S.v. *rek- 'ordnen, festlegen, bestimmen' (IEW 863).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *rekti 'speak, say', from PIE *rek- (cf. Skt. racayati 'construct, work', W rhegi 'curse').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *kāzàti 'show'.  Derksen regards the interpretation of the LIV (383, 385) that *kazati may be a causative *kʷōg̑-i̯e-, a variant of the root *kʷek̑- 'see, behold', as the best etymological solution.

S.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9), cf. n11 which assumes a voicing of root-final *-k̑- > *-g̑- as a root variant in the Slavic causative formation * kʷṓg̑-i̯e- 'betrachten lassen' (formed to the acrodynamic root-present).

S.v. *dek̑- '(an-, auf-)nehmen, wahrnehmen', assuming Arm. pres. tesanem was back-formed from a root-aorist etes < *dek̑-/dk̑-.  See n1 with reference to R. Schmitt (1981:146, 190); G. Klingenschmitt (1982:228).

S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ai(H)n-, a denominal formation from *u̯ai(H)na- 'watch, survey(or)' < PIE *u̯ei̯(h₁)-no- 'survey'  (cf. LIV² s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' pp.668-669, n5; IEW 1123-1124).  Forms a suppletive system with *daiH- /cognate/2012/ in many Iranian languages.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *daiH- 'to look, see'.  Forms a suppletive preterite with *u̯aiHn- /cognate/1969/ in many Middle and New Iranian languages. Cf. Sanskrit *dhay- 'to look at, perceive'. "An IE etymology for this IIr. root is uncertain, in the absence of any credible cognates. Only Alb. di 'knows' can be cited in the LIV: l.c., which is hardly encouraging."

S.v. βλέπω 'to see, look, perceive'. No secure etymology.  Dialectal variation between initial β- and γ- (Dor. γλέπω, also in related vocabulary βλέφαρον, γλέφαρον 'eyelid') might be indicative of a substrate origin and initial *gʷ- in the source/borrowed form.
S.v. ?*h₂u̯ei̯d- 'singen' (IEW 77). Only Greek.
S.v. ἀείδω 'to sing (the praises of)', from PIE ?*h₂u̯ei̯d- 'sing'. The ablaut (cf. nominal forms ἀοιδή, ᾠδή 'song') suggest a root *h₂u̯ei̯d-, but no cognates are known outside of Greek.
S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾eH(i̯)- 'singen' (IEW 355).

S.v. Lith. dainúoti 'sing', a denominative verb to Lith. dainà 'song'. The root of the noun is to be connected with Latv. diêt 'hop, dance, sing', and the underlying form may be reconstructed as *doih₁-n-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *vьčera adv. 'yesterday', related to Proto-Slavic *vȅčerъ 'evening' from PIE *uekspero- (cf. Gk. ἕσπερος, Lat. vesper, MW ucher, Arm. giser).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tvьrdъ adj. 'hard, firm, solid'.  Cf. Lith. tvìrtas 'strong, firm, solid', Latv. tvir̂ts 'id.'.  NB: the Slavic and East Baltic suffixes do not match.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *pǫpъ, *pǫpъkъ m. 'bud, navel', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *pomp- (cf. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell').
Albanian can't be related to Greek; etymology judged unclear by {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}. (See now /cognate/5258/)
*di-n-/dei̯-n- in Balto-Slavic and partly Indo-Aryan shows a different stem formation than *di̯-(e)u-, the basic root is therefore *dei̯-/di-.
S.v *legʰ- 'sich (hin)legen' (IEW 658-9).
S.v. 1. *k̑ei̯- 'liegen' (IEW 539-40).
S.v. *gʷi̯eh₃- 'leben' (IEW 467-9).
Cf. s.v. *spti̯eu̯H- 'spucken, speien' (IEW 999-1000).
S.v. *u̯ert- 'sich umdrehen' (IEW 1156-8)
S.v. *u̯endʰ- '(um)winden' (IEW 1148).
S.v. *leg̑- 'sammeln, auflesen' (IEW 658).
Cf. s.v. *dʰu̯es- '(ein-, aus-)atmen' (IEW 268-71).
S.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (IEW 38-9)
S.v. *bʰrei̯H- 'schneiden' (IEW 166-7) and *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5).  It is unclear to which root got. (+) brinnan 'brennen' belongs.
S.v. *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).
S.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} (cf. Alb. than 'trocknet').
S.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5).
S.v. 1. *su̯el- 'schwelen, brennen' (IEW 1045). Old English swelan from a thematic present *su̯él-e-. The OHG form is from a iterative *su̯ol-éi̯e-.
S.v. h₁eu̯s- 'verbrennen, sengen' (IEW 347-8)
S.v. *pel- 'aufflammen' (IEW 805), only Slavic cognates listed.
Proto-Germanic *kinþa- ~ *kinda- 'child' derived from PIE root *g̑enh₁- 'to be born'.
S.v. *g̑enh₁- 'erzeugen' (LIV 163ff., IEW 373ff.).  The Germanic forms reflect *g̑énh₁-ti- > PGerm. *kendi-.  (cf. n48 for Goth. kindins < PGerm. *kendi-na-).
S.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (LIV 76f., IEW 128ff.) The formation from which the Germanic and Latvian forms are derived is *bʰhor-no-.

Proto-Slavic *dětę 'child', a derivative of PIE *dʰeh₁-.  The singular *dětę was a backformation from the plural *děti 'children' through adding the suffix -ę < *-ent to the original t-stem.  The original singular *dětь is hardly attested. Cf. Lat. fētus m. 'birth, foetus, offspring'.
S.v. *péh₂-u̯r̥(?), *p(e)h₂u̯ōr, *ph₂ur/n-, *p(e)h₂-u̯er/n- n. 'Feuer' (IEW 828, EIEC 202).

Proto-Slavic *sòldъkъ 'sweet', an enlargement of PIE *sh₂el- 'salt' (cf. Goth. salt).  The Slavic forms have an additional suffix in -k- from earlier Proto-Balto-Slavic *solʔdus (Lith. saldùs, Latv. sal̂ds).
Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯k̑- 'eingehen in, eintreten' (IEW [1129] 1131).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *gorьkъ 'bitter' (ESSJa VII 55-56), a derivative from Proto-Slavic *gorěti 'burn', in turn from PIE *gʷʰer- 'become warm, hot'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *stegnò- n. 'thigh'. If Proto-Slavic *bedro- 'thigh' contains the root *bʰedʰ- 'to stab', then *stegno 'thigh' < *stegʰ-nó-m may derive from a root 'to stab' as well (cf. Ru. stegát 'quilt', OIc. stinga 'stab, thrust'). No further etymology.
S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-1060).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *dau-² 'to run', from PIE *dʰeu̯- 'to move, go' (LIV 147f.), cf. Skt. dhāv- 'to walk, hurry, flow' (RV+) AGk. θέω 'I walk', θοός 'quick'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *grabH- 'to grab, seize, take' < PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'grab, seize' (cf. OCS grabiti 'to rob', Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'to rob').

S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar¹ 'consume, eat'. The root is probably secondary to Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar³ 'to take'. Further IE connections are uncertain and postulating a PIE root *su̯el- (as in LIV², IEW) is probably unwarranted.

S.v. *bʰleh₁- 'heulen' (IEW 121-2, 154-5).
The Germanic words without -s- are traced back directly to the IE present formation *bʰléh₁-/bʰl̥h₁-, the forms containing -s- to a desiderative IE *bʰléh₁-/bʰl̥h₁-s-.
S.v. *h₂u̯eh₁- 'wehen' (IEW 81-4).  Cf. Hitt. ḫuu̯ant- 'wind' /lexeme/20324/ from participle *h₂uh₁-n̥t-.
S.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-8).
S.v. ?*pneu̯- 'hauchen, keuchen' (IEW 838-9)
S.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-8)
S.v. *gʷem- '(wohin) gehen, kommen' (IEW 464-465).

S.v. *h₁er- 'wohin gelangen, geraten' (IEW 326-9). LIV² reconstructs a preform *h₁r̥-sk̑e/o- for the Greek forms (= Ved. r̥ccháti 'erreicht, trifft, gerät in', OPers. -arsatiy 'kommt', Hitt. āraškizzi 'gelangt, wiederholt hin').
S.v. *kʷi̯eu̯- 'sich in Bewegung setzen' (IEW 539).
S.v. *meh₁- '(ab)messen' (IEW 703-4).

S.v. numerus 'number, rank, category'.  Latin numerāre 'to reckon, count' is a denominative verb from numerus 'number' < PIE *nem-e/os- 'apportioning, sacrifice', cf. Lat. nemus 'wood, forest, (holy) clearance', AGk. νέμω 'dispense, distribute', νομή 'pasture', νόμος 'custom, usage, law, composition'; Hitt. lammar-/lamn- 'moment'.
Cf. s.v. *nem- 'zuteilen' (IEW 763).
S.v. *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' (IEW 1144-5).
S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-60). Alb. v-des 'stirbt' from cs.-it. stem. *tokʷ-éi̯e- (cf. YAv. tācaiieiti 'läßt fließen', OCS точѫ (točǫ) точити (točiti) 'fließen lassen').
S.v. *h₁egʷʰ- 'trinken' [IEW 23].
S.v. *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'kauen' (IEW 400).
S.v. *h₂egʰ- 'in Furcht geraten, betrübt werden' (IEW 7-8).
S.v. *tres- '(vor Schreck) zittern' (IEW 1095).
S.v. *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten' (IEW 133-5).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *wī̆han- 'to fight' < *uik-e-, cf. Lat. vincō 'to conquer, overcome' < *ui-n-k-e-; OIr. fichaid 'to fight', W. amyn 'id.' (< ambi-wik-) < *uik-e-.

S.v. *u̯eh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'brechen, zu Bruch gehen' (IEW 1110), cf. ἄγνυμι from -néu̯/nu- present *uh₂⁽g̑⁾-néu̯/nu- 'mache (zer)brechen' and TochA wākä[t] 'zerbrach'.  The Hittite form is possibly from an iterative ?*u̯oh₂⁽g̑⁾-éi̯e-.

S.v. Hitt. u̯āk- / u̯akk- 'to bite', from PIE *u̯eh₂g̑- (cf. Gk. ἄγνυμι 'break', TochAB wāk 'to split, burst'. The Anatolian forms represent preforms 3.sg. *u̯óh₂⁽g̑⁾-ei, 3.pl. *uh₂⁽g̑⁾-énti to root.  Palaic u̯akk- 'to bite(?)' (3.pl.pret.act. u̯a-ak-ka₄-kán-ta) is a possible additional cognate within Anatolian.
[Germanic verbs listed in the LIV² under *peh₃lH- 'fallen'. New etymology to *h₃elh₁- accepted in the LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda.]
S.v. *k̑ad- 'fallen' (IEW 516).
S.v. *ped- 'treten; fallen, sinken' (IEW 790-2); the same root as 'foot' with the semantic development 'place one's foot' → 'to go in the direction of the feet' → 'fall', cf. {ref Rix 1976}:278f.

S.v. θήρ 'wild animal, beast of prey', from PIE *g̑ʰu̯eh₁r- 'wild animal'.  Cf. Lat. ferus 'wild', dialectal Lithuanian žvė́res < pl. g̑ʰu̯eh₁r-es (the normal forms in Balto-Slavic have been transferred into i-stems, Lith. N.sg. žvėrìs, OCS zvěrь).

S.v. *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (not in IEW).  Cf. Hitt. ḫarakzi, ḫarkanzi 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen' < root aorist *h₃érg-/h₃r̥g-, Hitt. ḫarnikzi, ḫarninkanzi 'vernichten', Arm. harkanem 'schlage' < nasal-infix pres. *h₃r̥-né/n-g-.

S.v. Hitt. palḫi- / palḫai- 'wide, broad' (cf. CLuw. palḫai̯a- 'wide, broad'), from PIE *plh₂-(e)i- (cf. Lat. plānus 'flat, smooth', Lith. plónas, Latv. plãns 'thin, flat', Lith. plóti, Latv. plãt 'to flatten').
Cf. s.v. *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-9).

S.v. Ved. pakṣá- 'Flügel, Fittich, Schwinge'. pakṣín- is a derived possessive adjective originally meaning 'winged', whose sense was transferred from 'winged' to 'winged creature, bird'.  pakṣín- is the source of pakkin- m. 'bird' in Pāli and other later languages, but earlier etymological origins remain unclear.
S.v. Ved. pakṣá- 'Flügel, Fittich, Schwinge' (Ind. Pā. pakkha- 'Flügel, Seite', pakkin- 'Vogel', etc.). Further connections remain unclear.

S.v. Ved. mr̥gá- 'wild animal', from Proto-Indo-Iranian *mr̥gá- 'wild animal'.  The meaning of the lexeme is transferred to 'bird' in Proto-Iranian, as already attested by Avestan mərəγa- 'bird'. Further etymology unclear.
S.v. μακρός 'long, thin, tall', from a PIE zero-grade formation *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' (cf. Lat. macer 'meagre, thin', OHG magar, ON magr 'meagre').
S.v. Lat. pluō, pluit 'to rain', from which Latin pluuia 'rain' is a derived noun. Cf. PIE *pleu̯-e/o- 'swim, float' (LIV² 487-488, IEW 835-837).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *regna- 'rain'. There are not yet any convincing etymological proposals outside of Germanic.  Connections with Lat. irrigāre and Albanian rjedh are possible but uncertain.

S.v. βρέχω 'to wet, drench', from PIE *mergʰ- 'wet, moisten', with βροχή 'rain, moistening, inundation' as an o-grade noun derived from the same root. The forms presuppose a root *mergʰ- that may be related to Latv. merguôt 'rain slowly', merga 'soft rain', but a metathesis (or Schwebeablaut) would be required in the original root form because the Greek forms presuppose a root *mregʰ- in order to yield βρέχω and βροχή as attested.
Cf. s.v. Ved. varṣ- 'regnen', from which varṣá- 'rain' is a derived noun. From PIE *Hu̯ers- (cf. Hitt. u̯arša- 'downpour', AGk. ἐέρση, ἀέρση 'dew', Mid.Ir. frass 'rainshower').
S.v. Lith. lietùs, Latv. liêtus 'rain', derivatives from the verb 'to rain' (Lith. líeti < *lh₃-(e)i-).
S.v. 2. *lei̯H- 'gießen; pour' (IEW 664-5).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrvjenъ, *čьrvenъ 'red' (adj.), *čьrviti (v.) 'dye, red, lay eggs (of insects), which are derivatives of Proto-Slavic *čьrvь 'worm, maggot', from Balto-Slavic *kir-m/w-i-, from PIE *kʷr-m-i-. The Balto-Slavic vocalisation *ir instead of *ur before the labiovelar is unexpected.
Proto-Slavic *krasnьnъ (adj.) 'beautiful'. Etymology unclear.

Cf. s.v. *gres- 'fressen, verschlingen' (IEW 404). If the comparison with *gres- is correct, Ancient Greek γαστήρ would be cognate with verbs meaning 'devour' attested as an athematic root-present in (Anicient) Cypriot 2.sg.imper. γράσθι 'eat!' or thematised γράω 'gnaw, devour', Ved. grásate '(s)he devours'.
S.v. AGk. στῆθος 'breast, chest'. [More or less directly translates/paraphrases the discussion of {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:795.]

Cf. s.v. AGk. στῆθος 'poitrine' (de l'homme et de la femme). The etymology is obscure. One frequently compares Hesych. στήνιον· στῆθος, which is directly comparable to Skt. stána- 'poitrine d'une femme', Arm. stin (gen. stean), however the suffix -θος then remains unclear.

S.v. speno-, stē̆no-, p(ə)stē̆no- 'Zitze, Brustwarze, Brust'. - However, he finds it hard to believe that στῆθος should be connected. He rather assumes an analogical spread of the σ- to a *θη-θος > *τῆθος, which belongs to the family of θήνιον and τιθήνη, for which στηνίον is the analogical basis.
S.v. *kʷer- '(ab)schneiden, schnitzen' (IEW 641-2).
S.v. *u̯reh₁g̑- 'brechen, reißen (intr.)' (IEW 1181-2), cf. Lith. rė́žti (rė́žiu) 'schneiden, ritzen', Gk. ῥήγνυμι '(zer)reiße, breche'.

From PIE *sm̥-tero-, i.e. *sem- 'one (copulative)' in the zero-grade with the contrastive suffix *-tero- added.  In most dialects the phonologically regular development ἅτερος is found (cf. Mycenaean a₂-te-ro = /háteros/), but in Attic-Ionic the root vocalism is modified to ἕ-, probably under the influence of εἷς 'one' or the 3.sg.acc. anaphoric and reflexive (±enclitic) pronoun ἕ, ἑ (cf. Beekes 2010:475).

S.v. Gk. εὕδω 'dormir'. No etymology accepted by all, cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} for various proposals. The most ingenious and most probable proposal is that of {ref Benveniste 1935}:156 who supposes *seu-d- next to *su-ep- of Skt. svapiti 'il dort'.

S.v. καπνός 'smoke, steam'. Walde-Pokorny assumes a pre-form *kwap-nó- on the basis of comparison with Lith. kvãpas 'breath, smell', kvė̃pti 'to gasp, breathe', Latv. kvêpt 'to smoke, smell'.  The comparison is also similar to Gothic af-ƕapjan 'to suffocate, extinguish', af-ƕapnan 'to extinguish', but with final -p- instead of expected -f- or -b-.  Comparison with Lat. vapor 'vapor, smoke' is difficult because of initial v- rather than expected qu-, and in any case Mycenaean does not attest -w-. This has usually been explained as a dissimilation *kʷ ... p > *k ... p, but parallels are doubtful. "Indo-European origin is improbable. […] in view of the similarity of the Balto-Slavic material and of Lat. vapor, it may be best to assume a European substrate word."
S.v. AGk. ῥῑ́ς, ῥῑ́νος 'nez' Replaced inherited word for 'nose' (cf. Lat. nārēs, Ved. nāsā [du.], Germ. Nase, etc.). The origins of the word remain obscure.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *rỳti 'dig, root', from PIE *(H)ruH- (cf. Lith. ráuti 'tear out, pull', Latv. raût 'tear, pull, take').

S.v. AGk. ὀρύσσω 'to dig (up, in, out), scrape, bury', from PIE *h₃reu-k-. The basis for the verb and derived vocabulary in Greek seems to be a stem *ὀρυχ-, but cognate forms appear to continue a stem *h₃reu̯k- (Lat. runcō 'weed out', Latv. rūkēt 'dig, scrape', Skt. luñcati 'pluck off'), thus Beekes assumes that the aspiration is an analogical innovation within Greek.
S.v. *h₃reu̯k- '(aus)graben, (aus)rupfen' (IEW 869-870).
*reu̯H- 'tear (up)' with OCS rŭvǫ, rŭvati 'tear' and ryjǫ, ryti 'dig' given as cognates.

S.v. σκάπτω 'to dig, dig out, work the earth'. There are many difficulties in the reconstruction of the original root.  Not unproblematic is the fact that it is no longer possible to postulate an e~a morphophonological ablaut in PIE.  Within Greek there is the additional problem of an alternation with voice and aspiration in the root final labial. /p/ ~ /pʰ/ ~ /b/, and the Greek vocabulary show no trace of ablaut.  Lat. scapulae and Umbrian scapla (acc.sg.) ‘shoulder-blade’ have been compared suggesting a possible original instrument *’shovel’ that formed the basis of the verb.  As a solution Beekes suggests that the word was a loan from a European substrate language.
