S.v. ξηρός 'dry, arid'. Possibly from PIE *ksē̆ro-?  Proposed etymologies outside of Greek are unclear.

S.v. AGk. καρπός 'fruit, fruits of the earth, corn, yields'. The Greek forms are usually compared with the root *kerp- (Lat. carpō 'pluck (off)', Lith. kerpù 'cut with scissors', Hitt. karp(ii̯e)- 'take away, lift, pluck', assuming a zero-grade *kr̥p-o-.

S.v. φθείρ. Chantraine accepts the etymology of φθείρ as a root noun from the same root as (δια)φθείρω 'destroy'.  Original *φθέρ- or *φθήρ- would have had to take over the root vocalism /eː/ analogically from the verb.

S.v. ἐγγύς 'near'. The first syllable seems to be the preposition/preverb ἐν 'in', the remainder is etymologically unclear.  Some scholars see an old word for 'hand' in a fossilised prepositional phrase with the first syllable being the preposition/adverb ἐν, but the etymology is nevertheless obscure.

S.v. πάλαι 'of old, formerly, bygone' (adv.). Gk. παλαιός is a derived adjective from πάλαι, a frozen case form like χαμαί 'on the ground', perhaps from *pl̥h₂-ei̯ ({ref Chadwick 1976}).  Earlier hypotheses connecting πάλαι with τῆλε 'far away' must be abandoned because the Mycenaean form does not attest a labiovelar.

S.v. ὠθέω 'to push, thrust, drive, push away or forward, drive out, throw back' < PIE iterative *h₂u̯odʰh₁-éi̯e-. The reconstruction of the initial second laryngeal is based on the etymological proposal of Kloekhorst (2008:349-352) connecting Hitt. ḫuett- 'to draw, pull, pluck'.
S.v. *u̯edʰh₁- 'stoßen' (IEW 1115). LIV² reconstructs a lengthened grade iterative stem *u̯ṓdʰh₁-i̯e- yielding Greek ὠθέω.

S.v. οὐρανός 'heaven, sky'. Probably an enlargement of a noun *u̯orsó- 'rain' (cf. Skt. varṣá- 'rain', √varṣ- 'to rain'). The old etymology to the Skt. theonym Váruṇa- is certainly wrong (cf. Mayrhofer EWAia s.v.). It has also been suggested that the word may be of foreign origin (so Chantraine 1968–1980).
Cf. s.v. Skt. √varṣ- 'regen' (cf. /cognate/1612/) for the reconstruction of root initial *H-.
Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯ers- 'regen' (IEW 80-81).
S.v. λεῖος 'smooth', probably from a root PIE * lei̯- 'smooth' with a derived u-stem that has been later thematised, i.e. *lei̯-u̯-o- > *λεῖϝο-, cf. Lat. lēvis 'smooth'.

S.v. AGk. ῥάβδος 'twig, rod, staff, magic wand; line, stripe, groove'.  Analysed as a root *ῥαβ- + suffix -δο- the word has been compared with Lith. vir̃bas 'twig, rod', Rus. верба (OCS връба) 'willow' from a zero-grade fromation *u̯r̥b-, and Lat. uerbera '(rods for) punishment', uerbēnae 'twigs of the laurel' from the full-grade *u̯erb-. "However, in view of the variants ῥάμνος and ῥαπίς, we can be certain that the word is Pre-Greek".
S.v. λίθος 'stone, boulder, rock, precious stones'. Etymology still unexplained.
Modern Greek ίσιος, from Medieval Greek ἴσιος, with stem modification from Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal'.

S.v. εὐθύς 'straight'. Etymology obscure; there are no known correspondences outside of Greek. "It may have taken the place of ἱθύς 'id.'. Perhaps a cross of εἶθαρ and ἰθύς with assimilation ει : υ > ευ : υ". DELG suggests influence of εὖ 'good'.

S.v. AGk. οἰδέω 'to swell', from PIE *h₂oi̯d-éi̯e- (*h₂ei̯d-), cognate with Arm. aytnum 'to swell' (cf. primary aor. ayteay and noun ayt 'cheek'), and some isloated nouns in Germanic (cf. OHG eiz, NHG dial. Eis 'abscess, ulcer' < PGmc. *aita- < PIE *h₂e/oid-o-).
S.v. *h₂ei̯d- 'schwellen' (IEW 774).  Greek οἰδέω is from an iterative *h₂oi̯d-éi̯e-, whereas Armenian aytnum is derived from a nu-present *h₂id-néu̯/nu-. [Without Albanian cognates listed.]
S.v. τέμνω 'to cut, cut up, split, destroy' < PIE *temh₁- 'cut'. A nasal present to this root is found in Slavic, cf. ORuss. tjati 'to beat', Lith. tinù 'to sharpen'.
S.v. *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥- 'Hund' (IEW 632f.).

S.v. πράσσω 'to pass through, travel' < PIE ?*per(h₂)- 'go through, cross'. All forms in Ancient Greek reflect a stem *πρᾱκ- or πρᾱγ-. This might reflect PIE *per- 'go through' with a *-k- extension of the root (cf. ἐρύ-κ-ω), but the root and stem are otherwise derivationally obscure.
PIE *h₂ou̯s-os-, *h₂au̯s-os-, *h₂us-es- n. 'Ohr' (IEW 785).
S.v. *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, *dʰg̑ʰ-ém-, *dʰg̑ʰ-m-´-, *g̑ʰ-m̥-m-´-, f. 'Erde' (IEW 414ff.)
S.v. ᾠόν 'egg' < PIE *h₂ōui-o- 'egg'.
S.v. *peth₁- 'fallen' (IEW 825-826).  See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into a single root *pet-.
PIE *ph₂tér-/*ph₂tr-´ m. 'Vater' (IEW 829)

Cf. s.v. erkn 'labour pains, pang (of childbirth), fear, grief, sorrow', erknčʻim 'to fear' (aor. erkeay), generally connected with Gk. δέος 'fear', δείδω 'to fear', Lat. dīrus 'fearful', Skt. dveṣṭi 'to hate', Av. duuaēθā 'threat', MPers. bēš- 'grief, sorrow, enmity', etc., derivatives from PIE *du̯ei̯- 'to fear'.

S.v. *h₁er- 'wohin gelangen, geraten' (IEW 326-9). LIV² reconstructs a preform *h₁r̥-sk̑e/o- for the Greek forms (= Ved. r̥ccháti 'erreicht, trifft, gerät in', OPers. -arsatiy 'kommt', Hitt. āraškizzi 'gelangt, wiederholt hin').
S.v. πόα 'grass, herb, grass plot' < PIE *poi̯H-u̯eh₂ 'grass, meadow' (cf. Lith. píeva 'meadow).
S.v. *k̑ḗr, k̑r̥d-´ n. 'Herz' (IEW 579f.).
S.v. ἐνθάδε 'here, to there' < ἔνθα- < *h₁eno- 'there' + -δε (allative marker).
Reconstructs PIE *steu̯p- 'beat' (cf. Lat. stupeō 'to be(come) numb, amazed', stuprum 'dishonour'. Albanian shtyp 'to crush'.
S.v. *seg̑ʰ- 'überwältigen, in den Griff bekommen' (IEW 888-9)
S.v. κέρας 'horn for blowing and drinking' < PIE *k̑erh₂-s- 'horn'.
S.v. *t⁽k̑⁾en- 'einen Schlag versetzen, verletzen' (not in IEW), cf. Ved. (Brāhmaṇa) kṣaṇóti 'verletzt' < *tk̑n̥-néu̯/nu-.
S.v. AGk. κτείνω 'to kill, put to death', from PIE *tken- 'injure' (cf. Skt. kṣaṇóti 'to injure'; Skt. ákṣata-, OP axšata- 'uninjured').
S.v. *u̯ei̯d- 'erblicken' (IEW 1125-7).  See perfect forms *u̯ói̯d-/u̯id- 'weiß, wissen'.

S.v. φύλλον 'leaf' from a PIE root *bʰel- or *bʰelh₃-.  The Greek formation φύλλον may be directly cognate with Latin folium 'leaf' if from original < *bʰol-i̯o- (the raising o > u in the root may be explained by Cowgill's Law). Forms with a dental stem are found in Germanic (OHG blat, NHG Blatt 'leaf'), TochA pält, TochB pilta 'leaf' (with a zero-grade), and Celtic bláth 'blossom, flower' < *bʰlō-tu- (cf. OHG bluot 'flowering, blossom', etc.) (with a full-grade).
S.v. *i̯e/okʷ-r/n- n. 'Leber' (IEW 504).
S.v. *h₂nér-/*h₂nr-´ m. 'Mann' (IEW 765).
S.v. AGk. κρέας 'meat, piece of meat', from PIE *kreu̯h₂- 'flesh' (cf. Ved. kravíṣ- 'raw flesh', Lat. cruor, -ōris 'blood from a wound', OIr. crú 'gore, blood', OCS kry 'blood').
S.v. *máh₂ter-/máh₂tr- f. 'Mutter' (IEW 700f.)
S.v. ὄρος 'mountain, height', an s-stem noun derived from PIE *h₃er- 'rise'.
S.v. εἷς 'one' (gen.sg. ἑν-ός) < PIE *sem- 'one'.

S.v. ἕλκω 'draw, drag' < PIE *selk- 'draw' (cf. TochB sälk- 'to draw out', pret. sälkāte, secondary nasal pres. slaṅktär) with nominal formations found in Arm hełg 'slow', Lat. sulcus 'furrow', OE sulh 'furrow, plow'. Less certain is the connection of Alb. helq, heq 'draw (off)' (if from IE *solk-ei̯e-)).
S.v. *selk- 'ziehen' (IEW 901), a Tocharian, Greek (and Albanian?) isogloss.
S.v. *h₂u̯elk- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 1145), cf. n1 for nominal comparisons suggesting the reconstruction of initial *h₂- and references to further literature.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *velkti 'drag' < Proto-Balto-Slavic *welk-/wilk-.  Derksen doubts the Indo-European reconstruction offered by LIV², preferring only to posit a reconstructable lemma for Proto-Balto-Slavic.
S.v. ὕω 'to rain' < PIE *suh₂- 'pour, scatter'. Gk. ὑετός 'rain' a deverbal formation < *suh₂-i̯é-.
Cf. s.v. *sh₂eu̯- 'schütten, regnen' (IEW 912).  The weak stem undergoes a laryngeal metathesis to *suh₂- (cf. {ref Jasanoff 1978a}:89n7, 90n11).
Cf. s.v. *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'rot machen' (IEW 872-3).
S.v. δεξίος '(to the) right (side) < PIE (transponat) *dek̑s-i-u̯o- (*dek̑s- 'right').
From PIE *sod- 'course' (cf. OCS xodъ 'βάδισμα, δρόμος', Rus. ход 'course, progress').

S.v. σήπομαι 'to rot, become rotten', from PIE *Ki̯eh₂p- (vel sim.). The Greek-internal ablaut variation σηπ- ~ σαπ- points to a root reconstruction *tueh₂p-, *tieh₂p- or *kieh₂p- ({ref LIV²} reconstructs *Ki̯eh₂p-), but no cognates are known.

S.v. κύκλος 'circle, ring, wheel' < PIE *kʷe-kʷl-o- 'circle; wheel' (cf. Skt. cakrá- Av. caxra-, OE hweol, etc.), based on the root *kʷel(H)- 'turn'. The Greek adjective κύκλιος is a derived relational adjective in -ιος.
τρίβω from PIE *terh₁- 'rub'.  The Greek form appears to be an extended form of the root.
S.v. τρέχω 'to run, hurry', from IE *dʰregʰ- 'run' (cf. Gk. τροχός 'wheel', OIr. droch < *dʰrogʰ-o-).
S.v. λέγω 'collect, gather; to count, recount; say', from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' (cf. Lat. legō 'collect', etc.).
S.v. *kneh₂- 'schaben, reiben' (IEW 560).
S.v. AGk. θάλασσα 'sea'. A loanword from a Pre-Greek substratum language, but evidently quite an early one due to the differing reflexes of -ττ-/-σσ- among the Ancient Greek dialects.

S.v. 1. *ser- 'aufpassen auf, beschützen' (IEW 910).  In Greek the forms are thematised from a root-present and have taken on the o-grade on the basis of the nouns *sor-ó- and *sor-ā́- (from which the denominal form ὁράω was created).
S.v. βραχύς 'short', a direct reflex of PIE *mr̥g̑ʰ-ú- 'short' (cf. Av. mərəzu- 'short').
S.v. ἧμαι 'to sit' < PIE *h₁eh₁s- (cf. Skt. ā́s-te, Av. ās-te = ἧσ-ται < *h₁eh₁s-toi, Hitt. eš-/aš-).
S.v. *h₁eh₁s- 'sitzen' (IEW 342-3).
S.v. δέρω 'skin, flay', from PIE *der- 'flay'. Greek δέρμα is a derived noun < *der-mn̥ originally meaning '(flayed) skin, leather'.

S.v. ὀσφραίνομαι 'to catch scent of, smell'. A compound verb containing two roots: *h₃ed-gʷʰreh₁-i̯é-. This class encodes the second member -φραίνομαι < PIE *gʷʰreh₁- 'smell (something)' (cf. Skt. jíghrati, ghrāti 'to smell').
S.v. *gʷʰreh₁- 'etw. riechen' (IEW 495-6).
S.v. ὀσφραίνομαι 'to catch scent of, smell'. A compound verb containing two roots: *h₃ed-gʷʰreh₁-i̯é-. This class encodes the first member ὀσ- < *h₃ed- '(begin to) smell'.
S.v. 1. *h₃ed- 'zu riechen beginnen (intr.)' (IEW 772-3).
S.v. ὄφις 'snake'. Probably identical to Skt. áhi-, Av. aži- from PIE *h₃égʷʰi- 'snake'. The lack of Brugmann's Law in Sanskrit points to an original e-grade.
S.v. χεῖμα 'winter, winter weather, storm' < PIE *g̑ʰ(e)i̯-m- 'winter'. Ancient Greek χιών 'snow' is a derivative of this root < *g̑ʰiōm, corresponding exactly to Arm. jiwn 'snow'.
S.v. πτύω 'to spew, spit', for which Beekes attempts to reconstruct *tspi(e)uH- 'spew, spit'.
Reconstructs PIE *skid- 'cut, split, separate'.
S.v. *sk̑ʰei̯d- 'spalten, abtrennen, zerreißen' (IEW 920-921)
S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (IEW 1004-1008). Cf. LIV entry for variety of derived verbal stems attested in the individual branches.
Reconstructs a separate root ?*trei̯gʷ= 'reiben' (IEW 1071) distinct from the Slavic cognates

S.v. AGk. παχύς 'thick, fat, well-fed, dense, stout', from old u-stem (with zero-grade) *bʰn̥g̑ʰ-ú- (cf. Skt. bahú- 'many, much, numerous', OAv. bəzuuaite [dat.sg.m.] 'dense', Arm. bazum 'much', Hitt. panku- 'total').

S.v. λέπω 'peel (off)'.  Some comparisons are possible outside of Greek, but none of the etymological proposals are entirely convincing.  LIV² lists λέπω under *lep- 'abschälen' (413, cf. IEW 678), the basis for the reconstruction rests entirely on comparison with the Lat. gloss lapit 'dolore afficit' from Festus.

S.v. οἴομαι 'to suspect, expect, think, believe, deem'. Etymological details are unclear.  If connectable to Skt. āviṣ 'evidently, before the eyes' then we may be dealing with a de-adverbial formation from a possible pre-form *h₂ou̯is > *h₂ou̯is-i̯é- which could have yielded οἴομαι.
S.v. *u̯emh₁- 'erbrechen' (IEW 1146).
S.v. *nei̯gʷ- 'waschen' (IEW 761).
S.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).  Originally a heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥-/*u̯ed-en-.

S.v. ὑγρός 'wet, moist, watery, fluid; weak, soft, flexible'. A PIE Caland adjective in *ugʷ-ro- from a root *u̯(e/o)gʷ- (cf. ONor. vǫkr from PGmc. *u̯ak-u̯a- and Lat. ūvidus from either *ugʷ- (√*u̯egʷ-) or *uh₁- (√*u̯eh₁-)).

S.v. λευκός 'clear, white', from PIE *leu̯k- 'white; (become) light' (cf. Skt. rocá- 'bright', rócate 'to shine, radiate', Lat. lūcus 'wood, forest', Lith. laũkas 'field', OHG lōh 'overgrown glade', Skt. loká- 'free space, world').  Within Greek, cf. λεύσσω 'to see clearly, look, examine' < *leu̯k-i̯é-.
S.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (LIV² 267f., IEW 38f.). Greek forms via *h₂énh₁-mo-.
S.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (LIV² 267f., IEW 38f.)
S.v. *gʷen-, *gʷon-, *gʷ(e)n-(a)h₂- f. 'Frau' (IEW 473f.)

S.v. πατέω 'to step, to tread, enter, tread underfoot'. The exact derivation of the stem is not fully clear. The secondary meaning 'treading, place where one treads, floor' of πάτος shows that it is backformed from πατέω, rather than vice-versa.  It is also not entirely clear how the form might have been originally formed from *pent- 'find (a way)' (cf. LIV² 471-472).  Beekes does not find it "evident that 'way, path' would yield to 'tread', an action which focuses on the individual movement of the legs."
Cf. s.v. Gk. ἀργής 'brilliant, white, gleaming', from *h₂erg̑- 'brilliant, white'.
From PIE *h₃merg̑- 'wipe off'.

S.v. Ved. vamrá- 'Ameise' (IIr. cf. Av. maoiri- 'Ameise', Khot. muṃjaka-, MPers., NPers. mōr, Oss. mælʒyg/mulʒug, Pašto meẓ̌ay 'Ameise', etc.). "Ved. vamrº, valmº, iran. *maru̯º zeigen Umgestaltungen eines unter Tabu stehenden Tiernamens … dem entsprechen in den anderen idg. Sprachen Wortformen, die auf *u̯ormº ~ *moru̯º ~ *mormº."

S.v. Ved. udára- 'Bauch'. The precise reconstruction is difficult to ascertain, but the word should not be split from OPruss. weders 'belly, stomach', Lith. vė́deras 'guts, belly, abdomen', Lat. uterus 'abdomen, belly, uterus'.

S.v. Lat. spīrō, -āre 'to breathe', from Proto-Italic *spīr/s-. Possibly an onomatopoeic formation imitative of the sound of breathing. There are no good comparanda outside of Italic exist to postulate a PIE root.
S.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'breast, chest'. Originally a proto-Italic s-stem formation *pektos-.  The root is likely to be cognate with OIr. ucht < *puktu-, if from earlier *pektu-.
S.v. Lat. puer 'boy', from PIE *ph₂u-ero- 'smaller'.
S.v. Lat. veniō, -īre 'to come', from PIE *gʷm̥-i̯é-.
S.v. *sekH- 'abtrennen' (IEW 895-896).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *sěkti 'cut, mow'. [NB: Derksen doubts the more widely accepted connections with Lat. secō via PIE *sekH- (so LIV² 524, via the reconstruction of an acrodynamic root present), disbelieving that the acute root can be reconciled with *sek-.]

S.v. Lat. secō, -āre 'to cut, sever', from PIE *sekh₁-ie/o- 'to cut off' (cf. Hitt. šākk-/šakk- 'to know, pay attention to' < *sókh₁-/*skh₁-; OCS sěšti (1sg. sekǫ) 'to cut', Ru. seč' 'to cut to pieces, beat', SCr. sjȅći 'to cut').
S.v. sordēs, -is 'dirt, filth, stain' < *su̯ord-o/i-, which may be cognate with Germanic words for 'black' /cognate/188/.  Lat. sordidus is an adjective derived from the nominal form.

S.v. *dʰeh₁- 'stellen, legen, setzen; herstellen, machen' (IEW 235-9). For Italic cf s.v. ?*dʰeh₁k- 'machen, herstellen' (IEW 236). Generally agreed to be an extension of *dʰeh₁- 'to put, to place, to make, to produce', mainly attested in Italic. The origin of the k-element is unknown.

S.v. Lat. pulvis, -eris 'dust', from PIE *pe/olH-u- 'chaff', which was further extended in Italic with an *-is- suffix; cf. Lat. palea 'chaff, husk' from PIE *pelh₁- 'chaff' (cf. Skt. palā́va- < *pelH-ō̆u̯(-); OPr. pelwo, Lith. pẽlūs, Latv. pęlus 'chaff', OCS plěvy, Ru. polóva, SCr. pljȅva 'chaff' < PIE *plH-u-(eh₂-); Gk. πάλλω 'to swing, sway' < *plh₁-n-, aor. πάλτο). The stem could have been derived from an original root that specified a threshing motion and thus might be connected with PIE *pelh₁- 'to swing'.
S.v. Lat. auris 'ear'. Latin has remodelled the inherited PIE s-stem *h₂eu̯s- 'ear' as an i-stem: *ausi- > auri- (with rhotacism).
S.v. *h₃ekʷ- 'ins Auge fassen, erblicken' (LIV² 297f., IEW 775ff.)
S.v. Lat. oculus 'eye', from *h₃e/okʷ-(e)lo-. Most IE languages show either a root-noun or an i-stem, so the Latin formation probably does not go back to PIE.

S.v. Lat. adeps, -ipis 'fat, lard'. The etymology of Lat. adeps, adipis is unclear. The word is often connected with Umbrian ařepes, ařipes (dat./abl.pl.) < *adēpā-, so Meiser (1986:216ff.) argues for a possible PIt. *ad-leip-a- 'sticking onto' > Sab. *ad-řép-a >> *ař-řépa- > *ařepa- which was borrowed into Latin and interpreted as a consonant stem. Weiss (forthcoming, [Language and Ritual in Sabellic Italy. Brill, 2009 – still listed as forthcoming in de Vaan so page reference is uncertain]) considers there not enough contextual evidence to exist in the Umbrian documents to connect the two words. Others have argued for a borrowing from Greek ἄλειφαρ 'unguent, oil' via Etruscan.

S.v. Lat. timeō, -ere 'to fear'. Etymology outside of Italic unclear. Older proposed connections with words for 'stiff' (IEW 1010-1011) are implausible, as that root (if it exists at all) must now be accounted for as ?*sti̯eH- (LIV² 603) would have yielded Lat. †tīm- < *(s)tiH-m- with a long vowel in the stem.

S.v. *peu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'stechen' (IEW 828).  Verbal derivatives of the root are only attested in Italic, cf. AGk. πύξ adv. 'with the fist', πυγμή 'fist; fistfight'.  Latin has nouns pugil 'fistfighter, boxer' pūgnus 'fist'.  The exact formation of the verb is unclear; LIV² suggests a nasal-infix present ?*pu-né-/n-⁽g̑⁾-.

S.v. Ved. agní- 'Feuer; das vergöttlichte Feuer, Gott Agni', from Proto-Indo-Iranian *agni- (Ved. agní-, YAv. ºāγni- in Dāštāγni-), and certainly also cognate with Lat. ignis, Lith. ungìs, OCS ognь, all 'fire'.  The precise reconstruction of the Proto-Indo-European form is uncertain, however, since it is difficult reconcile the vocalism of the initial syllable in all varieties.
S.v. Lat. focus 'hearth, fireplace'. The etymology of focus is disputed and there are no straightforward PIE solutions.

S.v. *peisk-, *pisk- 'Fisch'.  In the general meaning 'fish' the word is a Western Indo-European isogloss shared between Celtic, Italic, and Germanic.  The word may also be found in Slavic designating specific species of fish ('loach, 'gudgeon'), e.g. Pol. piskorz 'Peißker', Russ. пискаръ 'Gründling'.
S.v. Lat. musca, from PIE *mu-s-, possibly originally formed from an onomatopoeic base *mu-.  The s-extended forms are found in Latin, Balto-Slavic, Greek, and Germanic.
S.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV² 448, IEW 315f.).  Germanic and Italic forms reflect a derived noun *nebʰ-elo/ah₂- > Lat. nebula, PGerm. *nebela- 'dunkel'.
S.v. silva 'forest, wood'. No etymology.
S.v. Lat. silua, -ae 'forêt, bois'. No etymology, all comparisons that have been proposed are forced.
S.v. pōmus, -ī 'arbre à fruits'; pōmum, -ī 'fruit'. No known etymology.

S.v. pōmus / pōmum 'fruit-tree, fruit'. Possibly from *po-emo- 'taken off, picked', from *h₁e/om-o- 'what is to be taken', combined with a preverb *po-, cf. {ref Neri 2007}:71 s.v. emō. If so, the root would be the same as Lat. emō, -ere 'to take' < PIE *h₁em- (cf. OIr. ar-foim 'to receive, allow', OPr. īmt, Lith. im̃ti, Latv. jem̃t 'to take', OCS jęti 'to take; begin').
S.v. Lat. dō, dare 'to give'. The uncompounded stems dō, dāre must go back to *deh₃- 'give', but note that verbal compounds in -dō could in principle reflect either *deh₃- or *dʰeh₁-.
S.v. *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (IEW 293-296).

S.v. OHG âmeiza 'Ameise'. The word is probably a compound of the Proto-Germanic prefix *ǣ- 'weg, fort' and the stem of the Germanic verb *maitan- 'schneiden', with a -jōn- suffix for forming a nomen agentis *ǣmaitjōn 'die Abschneiderin', i.e. the insect that cuts up pieces of wood, leaves, and blades of grass.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *amaitjō- 'ant' (OE ǣ̆mette, NE ant, OHG ā̆meiza, NHG Ameise 'id.'). Origin unclear. Usually assumed to be a compound with the root of the verb *maitan- 'to cut', but K. finds the derivation of the first element of the compound difficult. To continue this etymology with the verb 'to cut' he offers PGmc. PGmc. *uz-mai̯ti̯ō- 'out-cutter', or alternatively PGmc. *ēmō-mai̯ti̯ō- 'larva cutter' (with haplology) > *ēmataijō-. A third option he offers is the possibility of a substratum borrowing which might also be seen in Gk. μίδας 'destructive insect in beans'. Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *maitan- 'hew, cut', further etymology unclear.

S.v. Lat. bonus 'good', from Proto-Italic *dweno- 'good', cf. Very Old Latin duenos, duenoi CIL 1.4 (Duenos inscription), duonus (Carmen Saliare), Faliscan duenas [gen.sg.f.], duenom [nom./acc.sg.n.]. Further IE connections are disputed, cf. entry for various proposals.

Cf. s.v. Lat. grāmen, -inis 'grass', from PIE *g̑ʰr̥h₁-(s-)mn̥- 'grass', cf. Goth. gras, OHG gras, OIc. gras 'grass'; OE grōwan, OIc. gróa, OHG gruoen 'to grow' < *g̑ʰroh₁-ie/o-; OS grōni, OHG gruoni 'green' < *g̑ʰroh₁-ni-.

S.v. Lat. vireō 'to be green'. Unclear etymology.  Lat. uiridis is a derived adjective, which has been compared to isolated forms in Baltic and Germanic (Lith. veĩsti 'to breed, rear', vaĩsius 'fruit', ONor. vísir 'sprout'(?), OEng. wīse 'sprout, stem', OHG wīsa 'meadow'), but the comparisons are very uncertain.

S.v. Lat. capillus 'hair'. Etymology unclear. Attempts to derive capillus from caput 'head' are formally difficult.  From a phonological point of view one expects capillus to be derived from a stem *kap-n- or *kap-r-, but there are no good candidates that have a good semantic match.

S.v. manus, -ūs 'hand', from Proto-Italic *manu- 'hand' from PIE *mon-u- 'hand' (cf. OIr. muin 'protection, patronage'; Hitt. manii̯aḫḫ- 'to distribute, entrust' < *mn̥-i̯eh₂-; OHG munt , ONor. mund 'hand').

Also reconstructs Proto-Germanic *askōn from Proto-Indo-European *az-g-, inspite of the problem to connect the Gothic form to it.
The extended stem *az-g- might appear in Armenian ačiwn, as well.

S.v. 1. *í- 'besagter, der erwähnte; dieser' (anaphor. und nahdeikt., nur Nom. und Akk.).  I. Stem *éi̯- (only in animate nominative), II. Stem *í- (elsewhere), III. Stem *i-h₂- (collective and feminine stem).

S.v. Lat. caput, -itis 'head', from Proto-Italic *kaput-. IE cognates exist in Celtic (OIr. cúāch, W. cawg 'cup') and Germanic (Goth. haubiþ 'head', ONor. hǫfuð, haufuð, OEng. hēafod, OHG houbit, NHG Haupt, etc), perhaps derived from PIE *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' also found in Lat. capiō, -ere [cf. /cognate/5290/].
From PIE *g/g̑ʰe/o- 'this' + *-k̑e 'here'.
S.v. *-gʰo 'wahrlich, in der Tat' (Partikel, wortemphatisch, klitisch) and *k̑e, *k̑i 'dies; hier' (Partikel, nahdeiktisch). Lat. hic < *gʰo k̑e, cf. fn15 to the entry *-gʰo for full details.
S.v. *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten' (IEW 133-135).
S.v. Lat. cornū, -ūs 'horn' < Proto-Italic *kornu-, *korno-, from PIE *k̑r̥-n-o-, a thematised n-stem derived from PIE *k̑er-,*k̑r̥- 'head; horn'.

Proto-Italic *mareito- or *marīto- 'having a young woman', a *-to- possessive adjective derived from PIE *mor-(e)i- or *mor-ih₂- 'young woman'.  Cf. Welsh morwyn, Old Cornish moroin 'girl, maiden' < *moreinā-; Skt. márya- 'young man', YAv. mairiia- 'scoundrel, villain', Bactr. μαρηγο 'servant', Gk. μεῖραξ (m. or f.) 'boy, girl'.
S.v. Lat. glaciēs 'glace'. Appears to be derived in some way from the same root as gelu 'cold' (adj.), but the stem formation is obscure.
S.v. *bʰes- 'reiben, fegen' (cf. LIV² 82 s.v. ?*bʰes- '(zer)kauen), IEW 145f.). NIL treats *bʰes- '(zer)kauen' as the same root as *bʰes- 'reiben, fegen', cf. p.35n1.
S.v. glaciēs 'ice'. "The meaning is the same as gelus, but glaciēs cannot be derived from a root *g̑l- 'to be cold' in any meaningful way."
S.v. Lat. lacus, -ūs 'lake', from PIE *lok-u- 'lake' (cf. OIr. loch 'lake', OCS loky (gen.sg. lokъve) 'puddle, pool, reservoir', Gk. λάκκος 'pond').
S.v. *Hi̯eh₁- 'werfen' (IEW 502).
S.v. *u̯iH-ró- (m.) 'junger, kräftiger (Mann)' (IEW 1178).

S.v. Lat. carō, carnis 'flesh, meat', from PIE *k(e)rH-n- 'piece' (cf. OIr. scaraid*, ·scara, MW yscar 'to separate', MBret. discar 'to sever' < Proto-Celtic *skara-, Lith. skìrti 'to separate', distinguish').

S.v. Lat. lūna 'moon', from Proto-Italic *louksnā-, ultimately from PIE *le/ou̯k-s-nh₂- 'shiny, bright, gleaming' (√*leu̯k-) (cf. Av. raoxšna- [adj., n.] 'light', Gk. λύχνος 'lamp', OPr. lauxnos [pl.] 'stars', MHG liehsen 'bright'.)
S.v. Proto-Slavic *luna 'moon', from PIE *lou̯k-s-neh₂ (cf. Av. raoxšna- 'shining'; Lat. lūna 'moon').

S.v. Lat. mōns, -tis 'mountain', from Proto-Italic *monti- < PIE *mon-ti- 'protrusion, height', (cf. W. mynydd OCo. menit, OBret. monid 'mountain' < *mon-io-; Av. maiti- 'mountain, height' from zero-grade *mn-ti-; OIc. mønir 'ridge of a roof' < *mōni-, mœna 'to tower').
S.v. Lat. unguis 'finger-nail, claw', from PIE *h₃ngʰ-u- 'nail'. The PIE u-stem was remade into an i-stem in Latin.

S.v. *pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft mit Abl.); for Lat. prope, cf. p.641, derived from PIE *pro-pro 'immer weiter, vorwärts' with dissimilatory loss of the second -r-.
S.v. Lat. prope 'near, near by, close', from PIE *própro 'on and on, ever further' (cf. Skt. prá-pra 'on and on', Gk. πρόπρο 'before; on and on').

S.v. Lat. collus 'neck (of men and animals)', from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ol(H)s/no- (cf. Goth. hals, OHG hals, ONor. hals, etc.). The word may be derived from the word for 'wheel' (cf. Lith. kãklas 'neck' < *kʷo-kʷl-o- from PIE *kʷel(H)- 'to turn'. The Germanic forms are often related to the same root as the Baltic ones, but it is uncertain whether *kʷo- was regularly unrounded to *ha- in Germanic.
Lat. nōn is to be explained by a contraction of *ne-oino- 'not one' > *nōino- > nōn.  Cf. /cognate/91/.
S.v. Lat. uetus, -eris 'old', from Proto-Italic *wetos- 'year' (Umb. vesune, Mars. uesune [dat.sg.] 'the goddess *wetsōna-, lady of the year'). Ultimately from PIE *u̯et-os-Ø [n.] 'year'.
S.v. Lat. ūnus 'one', from PIE *Hoi̯-no- 'one' (cf. Gk. οἰνή 'one (on the side of a die)).

S.v. homō, -inis 'human being, man', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰ(e)m-ōn- (nom.sg.), *dʰg̑ʰm-on-m (acc.sg.) 'earthling, human' (cf. OIr. duine, W. dyn, Co., Bret. den 'man' < Proto-Celtic *doni̯o-; OPruss. smunents, smūnets 'man', OLith. žmuõ 'person', Goth. guma 'man', OHG gomo, OIc. gume).
S.v. *lei̯d- '(los)lassen' (IEW 666).
S.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273).
S.v. *treu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 1095-1096).
S.v. fluō 'to flow, run (of water)'.  Lat. flūmen 'river' is a derived noun as though from PIE *bʰleu̯H-mn̥-.
Cf. s.v. 1. *bʰleu̯H- 'überströmen' (IEW 158-159).
Proto-Italic *wijā- 'road' from PIE *u̯ih₁-eh₂- 'pursuit' (cf. LIV² s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach', IEW 1123-1124).
Cf. s.v. 2. *peu̯H- 'faulen, stinken' (IEW 848-849).
Cf. s.v. *dʰu̯ens- 'zerstieben, zerbröckeln' (IEW 268-9). As a verbal root only Vedic, but outside of Indo-Iranian, Germanic *dunsta- < PIE *dʰu̯n̥s-tó- is also established (cf. n1).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *dunsta- 'powder, dust(?)' < PIE *dʰuns-to- from PIE root *dʰu̯ens- (cf. TochB tänts 'to scatter' < *dʰuns-, Skt. dhváṃsati 'to fall to dust, perish' < *dʰuéns-e-).
Cf. s.v. *pres- 'spritzen' (IEW 823). LIV² assigns Vollstufe II to the root (thus *pres-), but notes that for the Slavonic nouns here in question Vollstufe I (*pers-) is the basis (cf. fn1).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *porxъ 'dust', Proto-Slavic *pьrxъ 'dust' < *pr̥s-o- (cf. OIc. fors 'waterfall', Ved. pŕ̥ṣant- 'dappled, with white spots').
S.v. σποδός, etymology unexplained.
S.v. Alb. hi ~ hî 'ash', from Proto-Albanian *skina, with s mobile, related to Lat. cinis 'dust, ash'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *su̯artaz, related to Lat. sordēs 'dirt' from *sordus < *su̯ordo- 'dirty'.

S.v. Lat. rota 'wheel', from which Lat. rotundus 'round' is derived. Lat.
 rota is from PIE *(H)rot-o/h₂- (cf. Lith. rãtas 'wheel, circle, ring', pl. 'cart', OHG rad 'wheel', Skt. ratha-, YAv. raθa- 'chariot').
Cf. s.v. *ret- 'laufen' (LIV² 507, IEW 866).
S.v. *sal- 'Salz' (IEW 878f., EIEC 498).  Cf. n1 on possible alternative reconstructions and references to further literature.  Cf. esp. Rieken (1999:424f.) for further discussion.
S.v. Lat. harēna 'sand'. No etymology.
S.v. 1. *dei̯k̑- 'zeigen, weisen' (IEW 188-9).

S.v. Lat. dīcō, -ere, from Proto-Italic *deik-e/o-, from PIE *dei̯k̑-e/o-; perf. stem dīxī from s-aorist *dei̯k̑-s-, (cf. Skt. diś- 'show', Gk. δείκνυμι 'to show', Goth. ga-teihan 'to indicate, proclaim', OHG zīhan 'to show, incriminate').
S.v. *skabʰ- 'kratzen, schaben' (IEW 931-2).

S.v. Lat. mare 'sea; sea-water'. From PIE *mor-i- 'sea, lake' (cf. OIr. muir, W mor 'sea', Oss. mal 'stagnant water', OPr. mary, Lith. mãrės < *moriā, OCS morje, Ru. móre < *morio-, Go. mari-saihws, OIc. marr 'sea', OHG mari meri 'sea, lake'). If Ossetic mal 'stagnant water' is a loan-word from Gothic, then the word is exclusive to European branches of Indo-European.
S.v. serō 'to plant, sow (seeds)' from a PIE reduplicated present *se-s(é)h₁-; Lat. sēmen < PIE *seh₁-mn̥-.
Cf. s.v. *seh₁- 'eindrücken, einsetzen' → 'säen' (IEW 889-90).
S.v. *mreg̑ʰ- 'kurz' (IEW 750f.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *wambō- 'womb, belly'. No clear extra-Germanic etymology.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *blēan- 'to blow' and Proto-Germanic *blēsan-
 'to blow'. K. considers the Germanic forms without -s- to stem from a Western European thematic present *bʰléh₁-e-, the forms with -s- from a sigmatic aorist *bʰlḗh₁-/bʰléh₁-s-. Cf. Lat. flāre < *bʰlh₁-.

S.v. Lat. costa 'rib', de Vaan acknowledges the possibility of deriving the Slavonic forms from PIE *Host- with a singular development of *H > *k, but he rejects the connection with Latin costa. His argument is the existence of Latin os, ossis. Latin costa is thus "an isolated word without etymology".

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ubila- 'evil, bad'. Meaning of the PGmc. form maybe 'overstepping a boundary'. Perhaps connected to OIr. fel. The connection to Hitt. ḫuu̯appi / ḫuppanzi 'to be hostile towards, to evil against; throw down, hurl' < *h₂uóph₁-ei, h₂uph₁-énti must be rejected because the meaning 'do evil' developed from 'overthrow' in Hittite ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:369-372).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *ufelo- 'bad, evil', from PIE *h₂u̯op- 'treat badly' (cf. Hitt. huwapzi 'harrows, despoils', Goth. ubils 'evil'). The development *h₂up-elo- > *ufelo- > welo > OIr. fel is regular. The closest cognates are found in Germanic (cf. also OE yfel 'evil, bad').
"A verbal root *h₂/₃u̯op- ‘treat badly’ is recovered from Celtic (OIr fel ‘bad’), Germanic (e.g. NE evil ), and Anatolian (huwappi ~ huwapzi ‘ill-treats, despoils’)."

S.v. Hitt. ḫuu̯app- / ḫupp- 'to be hostile towards, to do evil against' with derived adj. ḫuu̯appa- 'evil, ill, bad'. Contra {ref Melchert 2007}, K. argues that the two Hittite verbs ḫuu̯app- / ḫupp-, one meaning 'to hurl, to throw (+ acc.)', one 'to be hostile towards, to be evil against (+ dat.-loc.)', are in fact identical, with the second meaning derived from the first. The date of the semantic shift is unclear; if the Germanic words in question are connected (as suggested by {ref Juret 1942}:71), then already in PIE.


 Possibly also connected: skt. vap- 'to throw', av. vīuuāpat̰ 'to strews apart, plunders, destroys'. - Reconstructed PIE present: *h₂u̯óph₁-/ h₂uph₁-, root form thus *h₂u̯eph₁-.

Tentatively reconstructs *h₂u̯óbʰh₁-/h₂u̯(é)bʰh₁- > ?heth. (katta) huwappi ‘wirft, schleudert (herab)’ in view of {ref Melchert 1988}:233n1, {ref Melchert 2007}:513-9, but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:369-71.

Hitt. ḫuu̯app- 'hurl, throw' is to be connected with Skt. vap-. Both from PIE *h₂u̯ep- 'to throw'; apart from that also PIE *h₂u̯ep/h₂eu̯p- 'evil' which is the basis for Goth. ubil etc. < *h₂up-é-lo- (for which cf. {ref Watkins 1969}:30).
Goth. ubils (+) < *up-élo- from a nominal root PIE *ə̯u̯e/op-, ə̯up-. Hitt. ḫuu̯apzi also belongs to this root and is a denominative verb.
S.v. *sed- 'sich setzen' (IEW 884-887).

Proto-Italic *kuti- from PIE *(s)kHu-t-i- 'skin, hide', cf. AGk. σκῦτος 'leather, skin', Middle Welsh eskit 'shoe' < *ped-skūt-; Old Prussian keuto 'skin', Lith. kiáutas 'shell, rind' < *keHu-to-. - s.v. cūlus: Maybe PIE *keh₂u- 'to cleave'?

S.v. Ved. cárman- 'Haut, Fell, abgezogene Haut' (YAv. čarəman- 'Fell, Leder'). The Indo-Iranian forms reflect PIE *(s)ker-men- 'Abschnitt → abgezogene Haut', derived from PIE *(s)ker- (cf. Gk. κείρω 'schneide ab, schere', OE sceran 'scheren, abschneiden, usw.').
S.v. 2. *drem- 'schlafen' (IEW 226). Forms from Latin reflect a PIE zero-grade yod-present *dr̥m-i̯é-.

Separated from Buck (1949)'s classification with *drem- /cognate/931/.  Cf. s.v. ?*dreh₁- 'schlafen' (IEW 226).  Ved. drā- is not properly R̥gvedic, but is only attested in the Vedic of the Brāhmaṇas and Atharva-Veda.

S.v. Lat. parvus 'small', from PIE *peh₂u-ro- with regular metathesis of *-u̯r- from intermediary *pau̯ro- (cf. AGk. παῦρος 'little' < id.; Goth. fawai (nom.pl.) 'few', OIc. fár 'little', OEng. fēa < PGerm. fawa- < *ph₂(e)u̯-o-); from the same root is also Lat. paucus 'few, small in number' (cf. s.v. paucus).

S.v. Lat. odor 'smell, odour'. The verb ol(e)facere is a compound verb. with first member ol- < *h₃ed-/h₃d- 'to smell' (cf. ὄζω 'to smell', Arm. hot 'smell', Lith. úosti, Latv. uȏst 'to smell, sniff', OCz. jadati 'to investigate, explore'. The main verbal element -facere is from *dʰeh₁-k- 'do' [cf. /cognate/5125/].
Cf. s.v. *dʰu̯eh₂- 'Rauch machen' (IEW 262-263).
Cf. s.v. *serp- 'kriechen, schleichen' (IEW 912).
Proto-Italic *spū̆-i̯e/o-, *spūto- < PIE *sp(i)uH-ie/o- 'to spit'.

An extremely difficult root to reconstruct; see citations to this class for a variety of attempts.  The verb was evidently onomatopoeic in PIE and underwent further onomatopoeic reformation in many of the daughter languages.  The root lemma *spti̯eu̯H- attached to this class is taken from the LIV² entry, but this root reconstruction should be regarded as provisional.

S.v. Lat. stēlla 'star', from PItal. *stērla-, derived from PIE *h₂stēr-s, *h₂ster- 'star' (cf. OIr. ser, W. seren, Co. sterenn, Bret. sterenn < PCl. *ster-, OIr. sell 'iris' < *stillo-, MIr. sellaid 'to see', MW syllu 'to gaze', Bret. sellout 'to watch' < PCl. stīrlo- 'star' < PIE *h₂stēr-lo-; Hitt. hašter(a)- 'star' < *h₂ster-; Skt. tā́raḥ (nom.pl), stŕ̥bhiḥ (instr.pl.), Av. star-, Khot. stārra- 'star', Gk. ἀστήρ, -έρος, Arm. astł, Goth. stairno, TochB ścriye 'star'). The Italic forms reflect an additional adjectival suffix *-lo- added to nom.sg. stem *h₂stēr-, from which the new substantive 'star' was taken from the feminine form, i.e. Proto-Italic *stēr-lā- > Lat. stēlla.

Cf. s.v. OLith. vė́daras 'gefüllter Schafsmagen, Wurst' (BSl. cf. Latv. vȩ̂dȩ̀rs, vȩ̂dàrs 'Bauch', OPr. weders 'Bauch', etc.), connected with Ved. udára- 'Bauch; Mutterleib', YAv. udarō.θrąsa- 'auf dem Bauch kriechend' (epithet of snakes). The Proto-Baltic form probably goes back to a Vr̥ddhi formation (cf. entry in ALEW for extensive discussion of the stem-formation in Baltic).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *mekila- 'large, great, much'. The Germanic forms based on the root *meg̑- exhibit the same derivational suffix *-ila- as in Proto-Germanic *lītila- 'small'. This is due to analogy in one direction or the other between these semantically similar lexemes.

S.v. kreu̯h₂- '(geronnenes) Blut, Blut außerhalb des Körpers' (IEW 621f., EIEC 71). The Lithuanian and Old Prussian forms go back to PIE *krou̯(h₂)-i̯ó- which is also attested in the Ved. adj. kravya- 'bloody'. The Slavonic forms go back to a root noun with zero grade, PIE *kruh₂-.
S.v. Russ. кровь 'Blut', from Proto-Slavic *kry, Gen. *krъve.

S.v. lapis, -dis 'stone, pebble'. No Indo-European etymology, but Sabellic and Latin forms may be accounted for by Proto-Italic *l(a/e)ped-.  The Italic words are often compared to Gk. λεπάς [n.] 'bare rock, mountain', also of uncertain etymology (cf. Beekes 2010:848).  This may suggest that there may be a common source for both the Italic and Greek words from a non-Indo-European Mediterranean language.
Cf. s.v. *h₃reg̑- 'gerade richten, ausstrecken' (IEW 854-857).
Lat. rēctus a verbal adjective to regō 'rule, guide, control, direct'.
S.v. *tu̯em- 'anschwellen' (IEW 1082).

S.v. Lat. cauda 'tail', from PIE *keh₂u̯- (LIV² s.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' IEW 535) via PIE *keh₂u-d- 'cleaved, separate', considering that words for 'piece, part' are often semantically derived from words for 'cut, cleave'.  Thus the 'tail' may be considered the loose 'part' of an animal.
S.v. Lat. cauda, -ae 'queue', a popular word of unknown origin; rejects the proposed connection with Lat. cūdō 'beat, strike'.
S.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-528); in addition to Italic cognates are found in Germanic (NHG haben 'to have') and Greek (κάπτω 'gulp down').
S.v. Lat. capiō, -ere 'to take', from PIE *kh₂p-i- or non-IE *kap-i- 'to seize' (cf. Gk. κάπτω 'to gulp down', Go. haban 'to have' < *kap-eh₁-i̯e/o-.

The Italic forms reflect Proto-Italic *iþei or *ifei 'there', which may go back to either PIE *h₁i-dʰei̯ or *h₁i-bʰei̯.  In Indo-Iranian there is attested Skt. ihá, idha, OAv. idā, YAv. iδa 'here, in the same way' /cognate/2691/ which may go back from *h₁i-dʰe.  If the Italic preform goes back to *h₁i-dʰei̯, then it is possible that these forms are cognate between Italic and Indo-Iranian.

Adverbial derived form to *í- 'besagter, der erwähnte; dieser' as *i-dʰe-, which may account for Proto-Italic *iþe or *iδe.  The Latin form ibī̆ (Old Latin IBEI) must account for medial /b/ instead of /d/ on analogy to ubī̆ 'where?'.  The diphthong witnessed in Old Latin (contracted in Classical Latin and later reduced by iambic shortening) must be accounted for by the addition of the deictic particle *-ih₁ or by comparison with the thematic locative *-ei̯ (cf. p.437n11).
Adverbial derived form to *í- 'besagter, der erwähnte; dieser' as *i-dʰé

S.v. 1. *í- 'besagter, der erwähnte; dieser' (anaphor. und nahdeikt., nur Nom. und Akk.). I. Stem *éi̯- (only in animate nominative), II. Stem *í- (elsewhere), III. Stem *i-h₂- (collective and feminine stem).

S.v. Lat. tenuis 'slender, thin, fine', from PIE *tnh₂-(e)u- (cf. OIr. tanae, W teneu, C. tanow, Bret. tanao 'delicate, thin' < PCl. *tanau̯o-; Skt. tanú- MP tanuk 'thin, flat', Gk. ταναός, τανύ- < *tnHu-, Lith. tę́vas 'thin, slender, high (of voices)' Latv. tiêvs 'thin, slender' < *tenh₂-u-ó-; OCS tъnъku- < *tnHu-k-; OHG dunni, OIc. þunnr 'thin' < *tnHu-). The original u-stem *tn̥h₂-(e)u- was remodelled as an i-stem in Italic yielding *tn̥(a)u̯-i- > *ten(a)u̯i- > Lat. tenuis.
S.v. Lat. agō; Lat. cōgitō from agitō, a frequentative/intensive form of agō 'put in motion, lead, drive', compounded with co- used in a specialised sense of 'stir thoughts' → 'think'.
Cf. s.v. *h₂eg̑- 'treiben' (IEW 4-5).

S.v. *Hi̯eh₁- 'werfen' (IEW 502).  The Lat. present iaciō is backformed from the root-aorist iēcī < *Hi̯eh₁(k)-.  The Italic forms are found with a -k- enlargement to the root which is absent in other cognates (cf. Gk. ἵημι 'throw, send' < *Hi-Hi̯eh₁-/Hih₁-; Hitt. pi-yezzi 'send hither' u-yezzi 'send thither' < *Hi̯eh₁-/Hih₁-).
S.v. *lei̯g̑- 'bind' (IEW 668).
S.v. Lat. arbor, -oris 'tree' (non-rhotacised nom.sg. arbōs found in Vergil, Ovid), from *h₃rdʰ-ōs 'uprightness' → 'upright tree', cf. arduus 'high' < *h₃r̥dʰ-u̯-o-.
S.v. *h₂elh₂- 'ziellos gehen' (IEW 27-8).

Pace {ref Kroonen 2013}, the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by {ref Beekes 1998}), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. {ref EWA 1} 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in /cognate/1735/). Regarding the Oscan form in this class, an alternative root etymology to PIE *h₂ep- is sometimes considered on the basis of the apparent lengthened root vowel as in the Indo-Iranian forms (e.g. Skt. āp-) cf. {ref Untermann 2000}:42-43, {ref de Vaan 2008}:19), however it is possible that the lengthening of the vowel could be secondary. While it is possible that the Oscan form could preserve an isolated reflex of the root *h₂ep- as found in Indo-Iranian, Baltic, and Tocharian, given that there are no other potential reflexes of the root *h₂ep- in Italic connections with Latin aqua cannot be ruled out, and it seems preferable, on the balance of probability, to connect Oscan aapam with Latin aqua < *h₂ekʷ-(e)h₂ (acknowledged by both Untermann & de Vaan). (NB: In Oscan PIE *kʷ > p).

Cf. s.v. AGk. στῆθος 'männliche od. weibliche Brust'. Origin unclear, the similarity to στήνιον· στῆθος (Hesych.) (to Arm. stin, Ved. stána- 'weibliche Brust' is hardly coincidental ("kaum zufällig"). (Perhaps an analogy along the lines of στήνιον : στῆθος similarly like Lat. plēnus : πλῆθος???)

S.v. ūmeō 'to be wet', from which Lat. ūmidus 'wet, moist' is a derived adjective. Based on Proto-Italic *ūmo- from PIE *uh₁-mo- 'wet', following the arguments of Weiss (1994:143f.) against earlier proposed connections to PIE *u̯egʷ- (cf. Ernout-Meillet 1995:745-746)for semantic reasons. To de Vaan, however, the semantic difference between ūvidus and its derivatives, however, does not seem large enough to warrant giving up the older etymology for those lexemes.

S.v. Lat. albus 'white', from Proto-Italic *alfo- 'white', in turn from PIE *h₂elbʰ-o- 'white', cf. Gk. ἀλφούς [acc.pl.] 'white' (Hesych.), ἄλφι(τον) 'barley groats', Alb. elb 'barley' (unless the Albanian is a borrowing from Greek).
Only known cognate is inner-Italic via Faliscan uxor, uxo 'wife'.  No good etymology.

Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯eh₁- 'wehen' (IEW 81-4). Cf. n1: The majority of forms found among the IE languages are adjectives derived from participles of the verb 'to blow', i.e. ptc. *h₂u̯éh₁-n̥t- → adj. *h₂u̯ḗh₁n̥to-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *anan- 'to breathe' and *anadan- m. 'breath, spirit'. The simple verb PGmc. *anan- < PIE *h₂enh₁- is preserved in Gothic uz-anan. The Old Norse etc. forms anda 'breathe' go back to a denominal verb *anadōjan- from the noun *anadō-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ajja- 'egg' from PIE *h₂ōu-ió-, generally taken to be formed as a vr̥ddhi-formation to the Indo-European word for 'bird' *h₂éu-is, *h₂u-éi-s. Cf. entry in Kroonen for a relative chronology of the sound changes that led to the Proto-Germanic form.
S.v. TochB laks 'fish' < PIE *lok̑s-i- 'salmon, salmon trout'.
Cf. s.v. OLith. lãšišas 'Lachs' < PIE *lok̑(-s)- 'Lachs', ON lax, OE leax. The root is attested in the meaning in Balto-Slavic and Germanic in the meaning 'salmon'.

S.v. Ved. mátsya- 'Fisch' < PIIr. matsi̯a- (YAv. masiia- 'fish', Parth. mʾsyʾg (māsīg), MPers. māhīg, NPers. māhī, Kumzārī mī < PIr. *maθi̯a- 'Fish'). Further etymology unclear, cf. notes in Mayrhofer for previous speculations.

S.v. OLith. nùgara 'Rücken', the word is not to be separated from Latv. mugura 'Rücken', which is also found as mugara. The sound-correspondence Lith. n ~ Latv. m is irregular, and the origins of the lexemes remain unclear.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *pletje 'shoulder', a derivative of the root *pleth₂- 'broad'.
The word may (in Russian) either be a loanword from Polish spina which in turn is a loan from Latin spīna, or it is a direct cognate of Latin spīna, OHG spinula etc.

Accepts connection of TochB yolo 'bad, evil' to earlier PIE *h₁edu̯ol-ōn-, a derivative of *h₁edu̯ol- 'that which eats', which is possibly connected to the family of words found in Gk. ὀδύνη 'pain, suffering', Arm. երկն / erkn / 'birth pangs, great pain' < *h₁edu̯on-.
S.v. *slei̯g̑- 'schmieren, glatt machen' (IEW 663-664). OHG slīhhan 'schleichen' is a secondary e-grade thematic e-present.
Cf. s.v. *sleh₁b- → *(s)leb- ‘schlaff werden’ (IEW 656). The Slavic forms go back to PIE *slob-o- with Lex Winter.
S.v. axis 'axle, chariot' < PIE *h₂ek̑s-(i-); de Vaan considers Lat. āla 'wing' is a secondarily derived form via PIt. *akselā-.

S.v. *h₂ak̑s- '(Drehpunkt:) Achse, Achsel' (IEW 6).  Derives Lat. āla via a derivative in -leh₂ : *h₂ak̑s-lah₂ = PGerm. *ahslō- > OEng. eaxel, OHG ahsla 'axle'.  Cf. p.260n1 on the proposed connections with the root *h₂eg̑- 'treiben'.

S.v. Lat. penna 'wing, feather', from *pet-n-h₂- > *petna > penna (cf. OW eterin 'bird', atan 'wing' < *pt-r/n-; Hitt. pattar / pattan- or pettar / pettan- 'wing' < *póth₂-r, *pth₂-én-s or *peth₂-(ō)r, *peth₂-én-s; Skt. pátra- 'wing (of a bird), feather', pataṅgá- (adj.) 'flying', 'bird', Av. patarə-ta- 'winged', NHG Feder 'feather').
S.v. 2. *peth₂- '(auf)fliegen' (IEW 825-6); now *pet- together with *peth₁-, cf. LIV addenda & corrigenda.

S.v. Lat. fēmina 'woman, female', originally a present middle participle from PIE *dʰeh₁-mh₁n̥-h₂- '(the one) nursing, breastfeeding',
 derived from PIE *dʰeh₁-, (cf. Skt. dadhúr 'they have sucked', Gk. pr.inf. θῆσθαι, aor. θῆσατο 'he sucked', Latv. dêt, dêju 'to suck', OCS děva 'virgin, maiden', CS dětь, Ru. déti 'children', PIE *dʰeh₁-i- in Skt. pr. dháyati 'sucks, drinks mother's milk', dhénā 'stream of milk', Oss. dæjyn / dæjun 'to suck', Arm. diem 'id.', OCS doiti 'to breast-feed, nurse', Goth. daddjan, OHG tāju 'to suck', OIr. denaid*, ·den*). Note the Lat. form fēmina does not show the i-extension that the other forms do.

S.v. Lat. mulier, -eris 'woman'. Disputed. Earlier connections advocated in older sources (IEW, etc.) to an original *-i̯es- comparative of mollis 'soft', but there are phonological problems in this derivation (cf. entry for further discussion). The etymology of this word is therefore not yet solved.

S.v. TochB sark* 'back (of the body)', to be connected with TochA särśi if, as usually assumed, the word means 'backbone'. Melchert (p.c.) suggests  a plausible connection to Anatolian sark- 'high' with an original meaning 'ridge, high point' vel sim.
S.v. Lat. flāvus 'yellow, blonde', from PIE *bʰleh₃-u̯o- (cf. MIr. blá 'yellow'; OHG blāo, OE blāw, OIc. blár 'blue' < PGerm. *blēu̯a-).
S.v. *tú-, 2. *té- 'du, dich, dir' Personalpronomialstämme, 2.sg.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *amsa- 'shoulder' < PIE *h₃ém-so- (cf. Skt. áṃsa- 'shoulder', Oss. wæn, won, on / iwonæ 'shoulderblade', TochA es, TochB āntse 'shoulder', Arm. us 'shoulder', Gk. ὦμος 'shoulder, shoulder with the upper arm' < *h₃em-so-; Lat. umerus 'shoulder' < *h₃em-es-o-).
s.v. cūlus.
S.v. χόρτος 'enclosure, court', from PIE *gʰor-t- 'fence' (cf. Lat. hortus 'garden', Osc. húrz 'enclosure', Wel. garth 'hurdle, field', OIr. gort 'field').
Etymological notes s.v. gẽras, -à.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *elhja- 'evil', as though from PIE *h₁elk-io- (cf. OIr. elc 'mischievous, capricious' < *h₁elk-o-(?)). "The cluster -ll- can be derived from several sources in Old Norse and has therefore given occasion to many different etymologies. In view of the Finnish loanwords elkiä adj. 'mean, malicious' and ilkeä adj. 'bad, mean, wicked', the derivation of illr from *elhila- (with *-ila- as in *mekila- 'big', and *lītila- 'small'?) through syncope is least problematic. Alternatively it is possible to assume that the root illr arose from *ĭ́li-ligr, cf. ON dælla adv. 'friendly' < *dæli-liga, etc. […] The final i of *ĭ́li- in *ĭ́li-ligr just like Fi. elkiä points to an original ja-stem *elhja-."
S.v. Proto-Germanic *wanda- 'turned, twisted' (ON vandr 'difficult, bad, Elfd. uond 'bad', OS wand 'changeable'), an o-grade adjective derived from *windan- 'wind', from PIE *uéndʰ-e-.
Cf. s.v. *u̯endʰ- '(um)winden' (IEW 1148).

S.v. TochB enmetre 'bark', possibly from a pre-form *h₁n̥-tm(h₁)-o-tro- containing the roots *h₁en- 'in' + temh₁- 'cut off' + further derivational morphology (cf. Gk. τέμνω 'cut', Lat. tondeō 'shave, shear, clip; mow, prune', etc.
Cf. s.v. *temh₁- 'schneiden' (IEW 1062-3).

S.v. SMG μακρύς, from Ancient Greek μακρός 'long' with changes to the morphological ending on the analogy to other common adjectives, e.g. βραχύς, βαθύς, βαρύς, εὐρύς etc. The adv. is based on the neuter plural of the adjective.
S.v. πάλη 'fight' (noun) < from Ancient Greek πάλη 'wrestling'.  From πάλ-, παλεύω is a derived verb in -ευω.  The original semantics 'to wrestle' have been extended to 'to fight' more generally.

Cf. s.v. παλαίω 'to wrestle, survive a wrestling match'.  Beekes suggests a possible connection with *pelh₂- 'to approach' (cf. LIV² 470-471) with a semantic development 'make close contact' → 'wrestle' positing a zero-grade formation *pl̥h₂-e- > παλα-, but there are no synchronic traces of such a stem, thus this remains a hypothetical explanation.
Presumably a loanword event from /cognate/5307/, itself a loanword event from /cognate/399/.

S.v. λουλούδι, from Medieval Greek λουλούδι(ν) / λιλούδι(ν), loanword + suffix -ουδι, perhaps a borrowing from Albanian lule 'flower' or from Latin lilium 'flower' with vowel assimilation /i/ … /u/ > /u/ … /u/.
S.v. σκύλος. From Medieval Greek σκύλος, with o-stem inflection regularised from Ancient Greek σκύλαξ (stem: σκύλ-ακ-), replacing the inherited lexeme κύων, cf. /lexeme/18699/, /cognate/21/.
S.v. σκύλαξ, -ακος 'doggy, puppy'. No certain cognates outside of Greek.

A denominative verb to Gk. κυνηγός 'hound-leader, huntsman'. The lexical root for the 'leader' element of the verbal governing compound is from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive' (cf. {ref LIV²} 255f.), compounded with *k̑un- 'dog' (cf. {ref NIL} 436-440 s.v. *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥- 'Hund' cf. /cognate/21/).

S.v. ἁπλόος 'single, simple'. Uncompounded ἁπλόω 'develop, unfold' is a denominative verb derived from ἁπλόος 'single, simple'.  Compared to its opposite δι-πλόος 'twofold, double' it is clear that the initial syllable ἁ- is doubtlessly the copulative prefix *sm̥-, but the etymology of -πλόος is not entirely clear.

In Standard Modern Greek φλοιός is a learned reintroduction from Ancient φλοιός.  Ancient φλοιός is directly preserved in part by φλούδα, from a diminutive formation φλούδι(ον) via from Hellenistic Greek contracted φλόος / φλούς, an alternative form of φλοιός.
S.v. κίτρινος. Denominal adjective in -ινος derived from Hellenistic Greek κίτρον 'fruit of the citrus tree', a borrowing from later Latin citrium < Lat. citrus 'fruit of the citrus tree'.
Latin crusta < PIE *krus-to- 'crushed, pounded'.

S.v. OLith. pil̃vas 'Bauch, Wanst, Magen; Kropf', traditionally interpreted as a derivation to Lith. pìlti 'gießen, schütten', in turn from PIE *pleh₁- 'sich füllen' (cf. Ved. parⁱ-, Gk. πίμπλημι, Arm. lnowm, Alb. mblon, Lat. pleō, plēre. OIr. do-lin 'fließt').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *magan- 'stomach'. A European word with no IE etymology. Similar words also occur in Baltic and Slavic, cf. Lith. mãkas 'purse, pouch, scrotum', Latv. maks 'purse', OPr. danti-max 'gums'; OCS mošьna 'small bag, scrip', Ru. mošná 'pouch, purse'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *br̡ûxo, *br̡ûxъ 'belly' (ESSJa III 33-34), from PIE *bʰreu̯s-o- (cf. OIr. brú 'abdomen, belly', Welsh bru 'womb, belly').
S.v. Alb. mullë 'stomach', borrowed from Rom. *mula > OFr. mule 'id.'
S.v. *gʷi̯eh₃- 'leben' (LIV 215f., IEW 467ff.). Germ. forms reflect ?*gʷih₃-tu- > PGmc. *kʷiþu-, but cf. n5 for possible alternative explanations. Slavic forms reflect *gʷih₃-u̯o-to-.
S.v. TochB kātso 'belly, stomach, abdomen, womb', which with TochA kāts reflect Proto-Tocharian *kātsān-; further connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, but cf. entry for various proposals.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *červo 'belly, intestine' (ESSJa IV 82-83), from Balto-Slavic *ker-m/w- (cf. OPruss. kērmens 'body'), cf. also Skt. cárman- 'hide, skin'.
For the common comparison to Skt. cárman- 'skin', cf. s.v. Ved. cárman- 'Haut, Fell, abgezogene Haut' < PIE *(s)kér-men- *'cut' → 'removed skin'.
S.v. Russ. большой 'groß' (cf. Skt. bálam 'Kraft', Gk. βελτίων, βέλτερος, βέλτατος, βέλτιστος 'besser, best', Lat. dē-bilis 'schwach').

For Italic forms from Lat. plangō, cf. s.v. *pleh₂g- 'schlagen' (IEW 832-3), for the Slavic forms s.v. ?*pleh₂k- 'schlagen (auch als Gestus)' (IEW 831-3). Cf. n1 s.v. ?*pleh₂k-: certainly originally identical with *pleh₂g-, *k from forms with a voiceless suffix.

S.v. ?*steh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'träufeln; tropfen, tröpfeln' (IEW 1010).  Only as a verbal root in Greek, cf. Lat. stāgnum 'body of water', Old Breton staer f. 'river, creek'. Alternatively perhaps from *sta⁽g̑⁾-.
S.v. *skabʰ- 'kratzen, schaben' (IEW 931-2).

Cf. s.v. SMG βρόμα 'stench'; an adjective in -ικος derived from βρόμα 'stench'.  Babinotis considers the etymology from Ancient βρομέω 'I make a noise' with a semantic change via the sense 'I smell bad' → 'I stink' perhaps via an intermediary sense 'I farted'.
S.v. κάνω. From Ancient κάμνω 'exert oneself, build; be tired (from work)' → 'make something (using technical means)' → 'make, do'.
S.v. *k̑emh₂- 'müde werden, sich abmühen' (IEW 557).  Greek present κάμνω via nasal-present stem *k̑m̥-né/n-h₂-.
S.v. κάμνω 'to toil, labour, build; get tired, die, be in danger, be in need'. From PIE *k̑emh₂- 'exert oneself, get tired'.
S.v. *gem- 'drücken, zusammenpressen; fassen' (IEW 368-9).  Ancient Greek γέμω < pres.  *gém-e/o-.

S.v. πράσον 'leek, Allium porrum', could be connected with Lat. porrum if from *pr̥s-o- although the non-lenition of medial *-s- > -h- > Ø is unexpected.  For this reason Beekes considers both Lat. porrum and Gk. πράσον early borrowings from a Mediterranean substrate language.  Cf. also {ref de Vaan 2008}:481-482 s.v. porrum 'leek'.
S.v. μαλλί, from Hellenistic Greek μαλλί(ον), the diminutive of Ancient μαλλός 'flock of wool'.

S.v. μαλλός 'flock of wool'. Etymology disputed. Previous Indo-European connections with Lith. mìlas 'coarse, homespun wool' have now been abandoned; possible connections with Arm. mal 'ram' are obscure for phonological reasons and because the word may be better explained as a loanword into Armenian from Arabic (cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:232fn250).
From Ancient Greek ὧδε 'thus, in this way; here' with metathesis.
ὧδε from adverbal ὥς 'thus' < *so- + enclitic conjunction -δε.
S.v. *i̯es- 'sieden, schäumen' (IEW 506). Ancient Greek ζέω < *i̯és-e/o-.
S.v. σκότος 'darkness, dark', from PIE *sk(e)h₃t- or *skoto- 'dark'.

S.v. συκώτι, from συκώτιον, diminutive συκωτός 'fed on figs'.  This is a transferred epithet from the phrase ἥπαρ συκωτόν 'liver (of an animal) fed on figs'.  Cf. similarly in νερό 'water' from νηρόν (ὕδωρ) 'fresh (water)'.

S.v. κεντέω 'to sting, goad'. The derivative κοντός 'short' arose from reanalysis of compounds such as κοντο-βολέω 'strike with a pole' where original κοντός [m.] 'pole, crutch, staff to spur on cattle' was taken to mean 'short', ultimately derivatives from PIE *k̑ent- 'sting'.

S.v. κεντέω 'to sting, goad'. The derivative κοντός 'short' arose from reanalysis of compounds such as κοντο-βολέω 'strike with a pole' where original κοντός [m.] 'pole, crutch, staff to spur on cattle' was taken to mean 'short', ultimately derivatives from PIE *k̑ent- 'sting'.

S.v. AGk. λαιμός 'gorge, gosier'. An expressive term with vocalism in -αι- which does not allow for an etymology outside of Greek. None of the hypotheses enumerated by {ref Frisk 1960-1972} are convincing.

S.v. AGk. λαιμός 'throat, gullet'; there seems to be no basis for the Greek-internal comparison to λαῖτμα 'depth, gulf of the sea'. {ref Furnée 1972}:225 compares λαιμός 'gefrässig' with λαιφός and λαιφάσσω which "proves Pre-Greek origin".
Cf. s.v. *meu̯k- 'losbinden, abstreifen' (IEW 744), for Greek (ἀπο-)μύσσω, -ομαι, < *muk-i̯é-.
Connects Greek, Germanic, and Romance cognates to the same original stem *samdʰo-.
Reconstructs *sámh₂dʰos > (cf. Gk. ἄμαθος) > *sámədʰos > *sámdʰos > PGmc. *samdaz > ONor. sandr, OEng. sand, OHG sant.
S.v. ξύνω 'scratch', Ancient Greek ξύω 'scratch, scrape', remodelled as a nasal present in -νω, cf. also σπρώχ-νω 'push' /cognate/2843/, etc.
S.v. κοιμούμαι & κοιμάμαι, from Ancient Greek act. κοιμάω 'lull, put to sleep' mediopassive κοιμάομαι 'fall asleep, go to bed', with regularisation of stem vowel -α-.

S.v. AGk. κεῖμαι 'to lie, be somewhere, happen, etc.', from PIE *k̑ei̯- 'lie, rest' (cf. Skt. 3.sg. śaye, 3.pl. śere, Hitt. 3.sg. kitta < *k̑ei̯-to, etc.); κοιμάω 'lay to rest, put to bed' and κοιμάομαι 'go to bed' are denominative from an unattested noun *κοιμή or *κοιμός.

S.v. μῑκρός 'small, short, little'. "The group of words has a familiar and colloquial aspect, as shwon [sic!] by the variants μικός and μικκός. The initial interchange in μικρός and (older) σμικρός is unexplained and (also) points to Pre-Greek origin. The connection with the comparative μείων, assuming that the κ was taken over from the opposite μακρός, fails because σμικρός is obviously older".

S.v. μῑκρός, also σμικρός (occasional Hom., Trag. Att., etc.), μικκός (Dor., Boeot.), μικός (some Attic inscriptions, papyri). "Ohne genaue außergriechische Entsprechung." Sometimes compared with Germanic words for small (cf. OHG smāhi, etc.), but the correspondences are uncertain.

S.v. μύρον 'sweet smelling oil, salve, perfume', from which μυρίζω 'to salve, perfume' is a denominal verb.  The lexeme is traditionally grouped with Germanic and Celtic words 'to smear, fat' (OHG smero 'smear', OIr. smi(u)r 'marrow') < *smer-u-, but as a culture word, μύρον may very well be an early loan. Cf. μύρρα 'myrrh, sweet-smelling word of the myrrh plant' which is clearly a Semitic loan (Aram. mūrā, Heb. mōr, Arab. murr 'myrrh').
S.v. SMG ραβδί, from AGk. ῥαβδίον, diminutive of ῥάβδος 'stick'.
S.v. πἐτρα 'rock, rocky mountain, range, cliff, ridge; rock cavern, cave'. No convincing etymology. In all likelihood a borrowing from an old borrowing from a substrate language.
S.v. κόλυμβος 'petit grèbe, podiceps minor', with denominal verb κολυμβάω taking on the sense 'swim' and eliminates inherited νέω 'swim'. Reminicent of Lat. columba, but with difficulty.
S.v. σκέπτομαι 'to look around, look back, spy, contemplate, consider, survey', from PIE *spek̑- 'see clearly' (cf. Skt. paśyati, Av. spasiieiti, Lat. speciō 'to see').
S.v. *spek̑- 'schauen, ansehen, spähen' (IEW 984).  Ancient Greek σκέπτομαι < *spek̑-i̯é-, with metathesis *sp…k > sk…p.
S.v. γυρίζω, a denominal verb in -ιζω derived from Ancient Greek γῦρος 'ring, circle'.
S.v. Lat. gȳrus 'round circle, circut', a technical loanword from Ancient Greek γῦρος 'round, curved'. Lat. gyrāre 'turn' is a late Latin denominal verb from this loanword.

Cf. s.v. γῦρος 'round, curved', γύαλον 'hollow (of a cuirass), vales, dells', and γύης 'the curved piece of wood in a plough'. Precise etymology unclear, possibly *gou- 'hand' or *geu̯(H)- 'bend' if cognate with Av. gu- 'hand'.

S.v. *pent- '(einen Weg) finden' (IEW 808-809). Greek πατέω may be a more recent iterative formation to zero-grade *pn̥t- > πατ-, but it is unclear whether this is a direct derivation as a verb or a denominative formation from πάτος (see fn3).
Modern Greek present stem πλένω [ˈple̞no̞] was backformed from aorist ἔπλυνα [ˈe̞plina] on analogy to pairs like aorist ἔμεινα [ˈe̞mina] ~ present μένω [ˈme̞no̞].

S.v. άσπρος. Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as in the phrase nummi asperi 'rough coins', i.e. new coins which had just been cut and had not yet been worn down from circulation.  The semantic development appears to be one via a transferred adjective '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white'.

Cf. s.v. φράζομαι 'to consider, think (up), perceive, decide, discern, act'. All forms found in Ancient Greek point to an element *φραδ- which has the appearance of a zero-grade form such as *bʰr̥d-, but the root is isolated in Greek with no known cognates from other Indo-European branches.
S.v. αέρας, from Medieval ἀέρας, ultimately from Ancient ἀήρ, gen. ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds; air atmosphere'.
S.v. ἀήρ 'mist, haze, clouds', later 'air, atmosphere', from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er-.
S.v. Lat. āēr, āeris, an early borrowing from Greek ἄηρ, ἀέρος /cognate/3111/.

Cf. s.v. het 'footstep, footprint, track; after' (Bible+) 'with, together' (Ełišē, Chrysostom, etc.), *ot- 'foot'. comp. HAYT' 'to attach, adjust, put together' , = SITÁ 'bound', Av. HI- 'to chain, bind', Lith. SIẼTI 'to bind, tie', IE *sé(h)i-, s(h)i-
S.v. Lat. crassus 'thick', of unclear etymology. Cf. entry in de Vaan for a discussion of older, unconvincing proposals.
S.v. *derk̑- 'hinblicken, erblicken' (IEW 213).
S.v. *h₁eu̯- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 78).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *fugla- 'bird'. The form is likely to have developed from *flug-la- (by dissimilation) and may have been derived from *fleugan- 'to fly' (< *pléuk-e-, cf. Lith. plaũkti 'to swim, float' < *plouk-ie- and Lith. plùnksna 'feather' < *plu-n-k-sneh₂-).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *bitra- (adj.) 'bitter, sharp', a ra-stem created to PGmc. *bītan-, ultimately derived from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' (cf. Skt. binátti 'to split, break, destroy', Lat. findō, -ere, 'split, cleave' < *bʰi-né-d-ti, *bʰi-n-d-énti, Gk. φείδομαι 'to spare, save, refrain from').

S.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273). Treats Old Norse draga, Gothic -dragan etc. as derivatives from the PIE root *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to drag, to carry, pull' and notes that the expected zero grade form †durgan was analogically replaced by dragan.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *dragan- 'to draw, pull, carry', as though from PIE *dʰrógʰ-e-. Dismisses three possible IE connections: (1) Ancient Greek τρέχω which according to Kroonen should rather go with Proto-Germanic *þragjan- 'to run'. (2) Connections to Slavic words such as Russian doróga f. 'road, journey', because these words show a root-final voiced or glottalized stop. (3) Latin trahō 'to pull, haul', which is not relatable due to its initial t-.

Cf. s.v. ?2. *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (IEW 1145), as a verbal root only in Balto-Slavic, where a denominal origin cannot be ruled out (cf. Lith. válgau, válgyti 'essen', Russ. volóžit' 'anfeuchten; mit Butter kochen'). Cf. n1 comparing OHG welc 'feucht' wolchan 'Wolke'. Cf. also variant ?*u̯elk- 'feucht sein/werden' (IEW 1145) in Celtic (OIr. folcaid 'wäscht' MW golch- 'waschen' < *u̯olk-éi̯e-).
Cf. s.v. Hitt. tallii̯e/a- 'to pray to, to evoke (a deity)', from ?*de/olH-i̯e/o-? (cf. ON talja, OE talian 'to tell', Gk. δόλος 'list').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *tala- 'number; speech', from PIE *dolH-o- (cf. Hitt. tallii̯e/azi 'to pray to, evoke (a deity) < *dlH-ie-; Gk. δόλος 'bait, trick', Arm. toł 'row' < *dolH-o-).
New root: *del(H)- ‘ziehen, anziehen’ (Not in LIV²). In LIV² there is only a root *delh₁- 'to hew, to split' which does not show any connection to the words here in question.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *wainaga- 'miserable, poor', a derivative of Proto-Germanic *wainōn- 'to whine', which appears to be an n-present *uai-néh₂- to the interjection *wai- 'woe' (cf. Av. vaii-ōi, Arm. vay, Lat. vae, OIr. fáe, W. gwae, Latv. vai 'id.').
Cf. s.v. Lat. vae 'alas!' "Probably all independent onomatopoeic forms, although shared inheritance cannot be excluded."
S.v. Proto-Germanic *snīϸan- 'to cut'. Hardly related to Cz. snět 'branch' (so IEW 974). No clear cognates outside Germanic.
S.v. ?*gʰrebʰ- 'graben' (IEW 455-6). Only Germanic and Balto-Slavic, connections to *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' are uncertain.
Oscan iúkleí < *di̯o-kelo-, zicolo- probably from *di̯ē-kelo- (cf. Lat. diēcula 'short day').
Oscan tera- < *ters-ā < *ters-eh₂. Cf. O. terúm < *ters-o-.
Superlative in -aimo- (cf. maimas 'largest, biggest').  The identification of the root is unclear.

Perhaps to be connected with Lat. ualeō 'to be strong, healthy' < Proto-Italic *u̯al-ē- (cf. Oscan ϝαλε, Marrucinian uali, Paelignian ual[ 'farewell') < *u̯alē or loanword from Latin?) < PIE *h₂ulh₁-eh₁- 'be strong', but the precise identification is not entirely clear.
S.v. O. trííbúm 'Haus'; A root noun *trēb- from the *treb- 'dwell', cf. MIr., W, Bret. treb 'Wohnung'.
Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².

S.v. Proto-Slavic *pь̀sъ 'dog'. There is no agreed Indo-European etymology. The main possibilities are: (1) connection with the root of Proto-Slavic *pь̀strъ 'variegated' from PIE *pei̯k̑- (cf. Gk. πικρός 'sharp, pungent, bitter'; ποικίλος 'variegated'; OHG fēh 'variegated'; (2) *pk̑-o- from a zero-grade of the root *(s)pek̑- 'see, watch'; or (3) *pk̑-u-, a zero-grade of the root in Skt. paśú-, kṣu- 'cattle', Lat. pecus, etc.

S.v. Ved. kurkurá- 'Hund', probably onomatopoeic after the barking 'kur kur' of a dog.  The possibility of borrowing from a Dravidian language is also possible, but not provable (cf. {ref KEWA} 1:237 s.v. kurkuráḥ).

S.v. Hitt. šalli- 'big, great', which can be accounted for from PIE *solH-i-, a derivative from the same root underlying OIr. slán 'complete' < *sl̥H-no-, Lat. saluus, 'complete, intact', Gk. ὅλος 'whole, complete' Skt. sarvá- 'whole, all' < *sol-u̯o- (from earlier *solH-u̯o- with loss of laryngeal due to the o-grade).
Cf. s.v. TochB tapre 'high', 'fat', to which TochA tsopats may be connected if it is from *dʰēubotyo-.

S.v. TochB luwo 'animal; animal/bird' [birds: lwāsa ṣlyamñana; animals sensu stricto: lwāsa ynamñana]. TochA has sg. lu, pl. lwā/lwāk- corresponding to TochB sg. luwā-, pl. lwāsa-; the singular forms can be reconciled to PToch *lŭwā- < PIE *luhₓehₐ- 'animal of the chase' most closely related to OCS lovъ 'the chase' < *louhₓo- and Greek λέων 'lion' (< *'predator'). Plural forms seem to show a contamination with forms of PToch. *tsäuwā- 'animal'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. paũtas 'Ei, Hoden'. The Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'egg' is a a vr̥ddhi derivative to the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird', which is found in Baltic through the derivatives pùtė 'Huhn', putýtis 'Küken', Latv. putns 'Vogel'. Further are compounds like Lith. pùt-pela, Latv. putpele 'Wachtel'. In Slavic the diminutives OCS pъtica, SCr. ptȉca, Ru. ptíca 'Vogel' and SCr. pȁtka 'Ente'. The Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird' has no plausible connections outside of Balto-Slavic.
Proto-Slavic *lòšь adj. 'bad'. The rejection of the traditional comparison with Proto Germanic *lasiwa for semantic reasons is hard to understand.

Proto-Slavic *puxati, cf. *puxnǫti 'swell'. Derksen considers Proto-Slavic *pux- with PIE *peu̯s- (cf. Skt. púṣyati 'thrive, flourish'). [Cf. LIV² 303-304 s.v. ?*h₃peu̯s-, without Slavic cognates listed.].
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dǫti 'blow', from PIE *dʰ(o)mH- (cf. Skt. dhámati 'blow').
Proto-Slavic *dūxàti, a denominative verb based on Proto-Slavic *dûxъ 'breath, spirit', ultimately from PIE *dʰeu̯s- (cf. Goth. dius 'wild animal').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *kôstь 'bone' (ESSJa XI 167-173). "The relationship with the otherwise isolated Lat. costa ‘rib’ seems quite possible. An interesting hypothesis is to regard the *k of *kȏstь as the reflex of the initial laryngeal of PIE *h₂ost- ‘bone’, cf. Skt. ásthi, Gk. ὀστέον, in an Indo-European substratum language (cf. Kortlandt 1997b: 47, where the option is dismissed, however). Meillet (e.g. 1921, Ét. II: 262) regards the *k as a prefix. If the root is *h₂ost-, we are probably dealing with an original neuter *kosti."
S.v. O.u. nessimas 'der nächste'. Oscan and Umbrian forms from *ned-tm̥(m)o- like Old Irish nessam, Welsh nessaf; isolated superlative to an isolated root *ned⁽ʰ⁾- 'link, connect'.

Oscan anafríss 'raingods' normally explained as a dat.pl. from PIE * n̥bʰr-i-bʰos as Lat. dat.pl imbribus (nom.sg. imber 'rain, rainshower, heavy rain'), cf. Ved. abhrá- 'stormcloud', YAv. aβra- 'raincloud, rainshower' < *n̥bʰ-ró-.

S.v. Lat. imber 'rain, rain shower', from Proto-Italic *n̥fr-i- 'cloud' from PIE < *n̥bʰ-r-o- '(rain) cloud' (cf. Skt. abhrá- 'cloud', Av. aβra- 'rain, rain-cloud', Khot. ora- 'sky', Gk. ἀφρός 'foam, saliva', Arm. amb, amp 'cloud').
Cf. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV 448, IEW 315f.), note 26.
S.v. Lat. dexter, -(e)ra, -um 'right, (opposite of left)'. Lat. dexter, alongside Umb. testru and Osc. destr- may be derived from PIE *dek̑s-tero- 'right, right-hand side' (*dek̑s- 'right').

S.v. ὀξύς 'sharp, stinging'; 'sour, tartish (of taste)', etc. "Without correspondences outside Greek. It has been compared with ὄκρις, which is an o-grade of the root of ἄκρος, but there are no further examples for u-stem adjectives with o-vocalism. Alternatively, {ref Narten 1986} reconstructs a root *h₃ks- on the strength of the comparison with Skt. akṣṇoti 'to mark the ear', but this is doubtful."

Proto-Italic *olno- > *ollo- > Old Latin ollus from PIE *h₂ol-no- 'that, yonder' (Gaulish ollo-, OIr. ol 'beyond'; OCS lani, Cz. loni 'last year' < PSl. *olni).  The root vocalism in Classical Lat. ille is generally explained through analogy to the demonstrative iste 'that which you have, that of yours'.
Theoretically, Latin ubī, Oscan puf, Umbrian pufe can reflect either PIE *kʷu-bʰei̯ or *kʷu-dʰei̯.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *koxsā 'leg', cf. PIE *kok̑so- 'hollow of joint' (IEW 611), cf. Latin coxa 'hip', OHG hāhsa and Toch. B kakse 'loins'.

S.v. Lat. coxa 'hip', from PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' (cf. OIr. coss 'foot', Ved. kakṣa-, Av. kaša- 'armpit', TochB kakse 'midriff loins'). de Vaan rejects the connection with the Germanic words as assumed by IEW and Matasović (2009).

Cf. s.v. Greek ἔρεβος (n.) 'the dark of the underworld' cognate with Arm. erek, -oy 'evening' whence erēk, Skt. rájas- (n.) 'dark (lower) air, dust', Gothic riqiz, ON røkkr (n.) 'dark, dusk'. All from PIE *h₁régʷ-os- 'darkness'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *gestra- adv. 'the previous or next day'. Following the etymology of Puhvel (1987), the Goth. gistra- and West Germanic forms point to Proto-Germanic *gestra- < *dʰg̑ʰes-ro- with t-epenthesis between *s and *r (cf. *swester 'sister'). The North Germanic forms are more difficult to account for: Kroonen favours explaining Faroese gjár and Old Icelandic gær as deriving from *gāʀ < *PGmc. *gēz with monosyllabic lengthening (cf. *ūt < *ud). [To account for Sanskrit hyás Kroonen assumes that it goes back to PIE *dʰg̑ʰ-i̯es with an intrusion of the -i̯- in analogy to sadyás 'today' < *sm̥-di-és.]

S.v. Proto-Celtic *gdesi 'yesterday', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰ(i̯)es(i), an adverb fossilised from a locative of an old root noun, e.g. ?*dʰg̑ʰ(i̯)ōs, designating 'the preceding day' (cf. Skt. hyás, Gk. χθές, Lat. heri, OHG gesterēn, Alb. dje). Alternatively possible is the derivation *g̑ʰ-di̯es- where *g̑ʰ- is the demonstrative particle and *di̯es- a derivative of the root *dei̯- 'day' (Lat. diēs etc., cf. Schindler 1977).
Arm. am 'year, age' goes back to an old paradigm *s(e)m-eh₂-/*sm̥-h₂-ó-, cf. Skt. sámā- f. 'year, season', YAv. ham-, OIr. sam- 'summer'.
S.v. 3. *ser- 'nehmen, ergreifen' [IEW 909-10]. A Greek-Baltic lexical isogloss. (cf. Latv. siŗu (sirt) 'Raubzüge machen').

The most probable etymology for Umbrian aso is to *h₂eh₁s- 'burn, dry, desiccate', from a *-to- participle, i.e. *ā̆s-to- > ā̆so-, although connections with *h₂esd- to which may also belong Ancient Greek ἄζω, Czech ozditi 'desiccate' (but cf. LIV² s.v. *h₂ed- 'dry').

S.v. Lat. portō, -āre 'to transport, carry'. Most likely to be a denominal verb from Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'passage, crossing', cf. Lat. porta 'gate'. Cf. elsewhere PIE *pr̥-to-, *pr̥-tu- (Gaulish ritu-, Old Welsh rit, Welsh rhyd 'ford' < PCl. φritu-; Av. pərətu- 'crossing, bridge'; OHG furt, Engl. ford < PGmc. furδú-).
Cf. s.v. 1. per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren' (IEW 816-817).

S.v. Lat. pulpa 'fleshy parts of a body, best part of the meat', cf. Lat. derived lexeme pulpāmentum 'a small piece of meat'. The Latin forms reflect Proto-Italic *pelp-ā 'meat', *pelp-m(e)n- 'meat'. The Umbrian cognate pelmner (gen.sg.) reflects a stem *pelp-men-. There are no known cognates known outside of Italic.

S.v. Lat. fruor, frui 'enjoy (the produce of)' (vb.), from which Lat. frūctus, -ūs 'enjoyment, revenue' is a derived noun'; Umbrian frif, fri is a root noun < *bʰrūg-. Verbal fruor is from PIE *bʰruHg-ie/o- 'to use' (cf. Goth. brukjan, OE brūcan).

S.v. ?*⁽g̑⁾ʰeHb- 'ergreifen, nehmen' (IEW 407-9). Root only Italic and Celtic, and belongs to the probably originally onomatopoeic roots for 'grasp, snatch' which show the structure velar-vowel-(laryngeal)-labial, cf. *gʰebʰ-, *keh₂p-. Umbrian 3.sg.imptv. hahtu 'let (one) take', Gaulish 2.sg.imptv. gabi 'take!', Old Irish -gaib, -gaibet 'take' < pres. *gʰHb-i̯é-, Lat. habeō 'have' < essive *gHb-h₁i̯é-.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *bāno- 'white, shining', from a PIE deverbal adjective *bʰeh₂-no- 'shining'. For derivatives of the same root, cf. Skt. bhā́ti 'shines', Av. bānu- 'beam of light', Gk. φαίνω 'show, appear'.
S.v. *(s)neh₂- 'baden, schwimmen' (IEW 971-972).
S.v. *mesg- 'eintauschen (intr.), versinken' (IEW 745-6).  Baltic forms (Lith. mazgóju, Latv. mazgāju) are denominal.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *mỳti 'wash' (ESSJa XXI 76-79), from PIE *muH- (< earlier *miuH-), cf. Skt. mī́vati 'push, shove'; Lat. movēre 'move'.
*mi̯eu̯h₁- 'move' with OCS myjǫ, myti 'wash' given (as a possible cognate). The attested Slavic forms go back to *muh₁-, a root variant developed by analogy.
Cf. s.v. 2. *k̑el- 'warm werden' (IEW 551-2).
Cf. s.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5).
The meaning of the verbal root PIE *du̯eh₂- is 'entfernen, abtrennen'.
Lit. tvìrtas, Latvian tvir̂ts as well as the Slavonic words OCS tvrъdъ 'hard, solid' go back to PIE *tu̯erH- 'to catch'.
Cf. s.v. *tu̯erH- 'fassen' (IEW 1101). Lit. tvìrtas < *tu̯r̥H-tó-.

S.v. Skt. mákṣā 'Fliege', 'fly'; also found in Iranian (cf. Av. maxšī- Buddh. Sogd. mwγšk-), but there are no certain connections for this Indo-Iranian lexeme to other Indo-European languages. IIr. *makš- does however appear to have been loaned into Uralic at an early period (cf. Finn. mehilänen, mordwin. mekš, meš, Hungar. méh, etc. < *mekš-).

S.v. φῦσα 'breath, bellows'. The exact root of the base noun φῦσα cannot be determined.  Comparisons have been made with Arm. pʻowkʻ 'breath, wind', but φῦσα cannot be derived from *φῡκ-i̯α-.  Attempts at connections with other potential IE cognates are dubious.

S.v. *ég̑- 'ich' Pronominalstamm, 1.Sg., nur Nominativ.  The bare stem is found in Hitt. ūk (with analogical vocalism on the basis of early Proto-Anatolian *tū- 'you', cf. Melchert MSS 42 (1983) 155-6).  Greek ἐγώ and Italic *egō (Faliscan eco, South Picent ekú, Oscan íív(?)) are from *eg̑-óh₁ 'ich gerade, eben ich'; Proto-Indo-Iranian *aj́ʰam ( > Ved. ahám, OAv. azəm, OPers. adam), dialectal Greek ἐγών, Proto-Germanic *eka- from *ég̑-h₂-om 'ich gerade, eben ich'.
Ancient Greek forms οὗτος, (gen.sg.m. τοῦτου) is a univerbation of *so-/to- '(s)he, it' with *h₂u-to-, the zero-grade of *h₂eu̯-tó- (> αὐτός 'the same').
S.v. ἐκεῖ '(over) there, to there' < PIE *(h₁)e-k̑e(i). Based on the PIE deictic *k̑e (cf. Lat. -c in hic 'this', etc.).
S.v. k̑e, *k̑i 'dies; hier' Partikel, nahdeiktisch.
S.v. iškiš- 'back, backside, rear', the only proposed cognate is Greek ἰσχίον 'hip(s)', but the semantic connection is not very convincing.

S.v. Hitt. idālu-, idālau̯- 'bad, evil, evilness'. Kloekhorst connects Hitt. idālu- 'bad, evil', CLuw. ādduu̯a- 'evil', HLuw. átuwa- 'evil' to a Proto-Anatolian stem *ʔeduo-(l-), but rejects the proposed connections to a putative stem *h₁ed-u̯ōl- to the root *h₁ed- 'bite' as proposed by {ref Watkins 1982}.  K. mentions but does not explicitly reject proposed connections with TochB, yolo 'bad, evil'.

S.v. Hitt. šarḫuu̯ant- 'belly; innards; foetus, unborn child'. The only etymology that could possibly be credible is a connection to Arm. argand 'womb' (cf. {ref Čop 1955}), which if correct may go back to a possible PIE reconstruction *srh₂u̯ent- and the Armenian sound laws permit it.

Rejects connection of Hitt. šarḫuu̯ant- with Arm. argand from the proposed reconstruction *sr̥Hu-u̯n̥t-h₂ (lit. 'full-of-sausages', cf. ὀρύα 'sausage') on the basis that the sequence *-r̥Hu- should have yielded *-araw-.

S.v. Hitt. dankui- / dankuu̯ai- 'black, dark', from PIE *dʰn̥gʷ-(e)i- and comparable to Germanic forms from different stem formations and ablaut variants, e.g. ONor. døkkr 'gloomy, dark (of colour)' < *dʰongʷ-o-,  OFranc. diunk 'dark' < *dʰengʷ-o-, OHG tunkal 'dark' < *dʰn̥gʷ-lo-, OSax. *dʰn̥gʷ-ro-.
S.v. Hitt. ēšḫar-/išḫan- 'blood, bloodshed', from PIE *h₁ésh₂-r̥, gen. *h₁sh₂-én-s (cf. Ved. ásr̥k/asnás, TochA ysār, TochB yasar, Gk. ἔαρ, Latv. asins, Lat. sanguen/sanguis).
Reconstructs as a pre-form PIE *prh₁-(o)i-.  Cf. Palaic pariparai- 'to blow(?)', Gk. πίμπρημι 'blow up, distend'.
S.v. *preh₁- 'anblasen, anfachen' (IEW 809)
S.v. *u̯erH- 'heiß sein' (IEW 1166).  Cf. OCS vьritъ 'boil', Lith. vérda 'cook, boil'.
S.v. ur-, u̯ar- (mid.) 'to burn (intr.), to be burned', from IE *urh₁-ó-ri (cf. Lith. vìrti, vérdu 'to cook', OCS vьrěti 'to cook').
Romance words for 'breast (of woman)' are probable nursery words.

S.v. Hitt. tēta(n)- 'breast; teat' (cf. CLuw. tītan- 'breast, teat', Lyc. tideime/i- 'son, child') < *dʰeh₁i-to- from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'suckle' (cf. Skt. dháyati 'sucks', Latv. dêju 'to suck', Gk. θήσατο 'sucked').
Cf. s.v. *dʰeh₁(i̯)- '(Muttermilch) saugen' (IEW 241-2).

Hitt. ḫāšša- 'descendant', CLuw. ḫamša/i- 'grandchild', HLuw. hamsa/i- 'grandchild', Lyc. χahba- 'grandchild' may be derived from *h₂éms-o-.  Cf. Hitt. ḫāš- 'to give birth, beget, procreate' < *h₂oms-.
Cf. s.v. *h₂ens- 'zeugen, gebären' (Not in IEW).  As a verbal root, only Anatolian, cf. Hitt. ḫaššu- 'king'.

S.v. Hitt. alpa- 'cloud', often connected to Lat. albus 'white' and Gk. ἀλφός 'white leprosy; white' but the connection is formally difficult because *h₂elbʰo- would have yielded Hitt. †ḫalpa-, and also  difficult semantically because alpa- is associated with rain and thunder.  Some scholars attempt to get around this by reconstructing a second a-colouring laryngeal *h₄ which left no trace in Hittite, but the semantic connection is too weak to postulate the reconstruction of a new phoneme.

To maintain the connection with Lat. albus, Gk. ἀλφός, etc. (cf. /cognate/955/), one must postulate reconstructing a fourth laryngeal that is a-colouring but lost in Anatolian (i.e. *h₄elbʰo-); alternatively one could reconstruct *albʰo- with an original *a in the root but this likewise a less satisfactory solution (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:169).
Cf. s.v. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', from which Hitt. ekuna-, ikuna- 'cold' is a derived adjective, ultimately from PIE *i̯ég-o- 'ice' and cognate with OIr. aig 'ice', ONor. jaki 'ice-floe', etc.

S.v. Hitt. kappuu̯e/a- 'to count, to calculate'. No clear Indo-European etymology.  Some scholars have attempted to analyse the form as a compound *katt(a) + puu̯e/a- or *kom+puu̯e/a- with the latter element comparable to Lat. putāre, but the absence of other examples for such preverbal composition in Hittite makes this interpretation unlikely.
S.v. ?*h₁e⁽k̑⁾- 'sterben' (no IEW).  Only Anatolian.

S.v. Hitt. āk-/akk- 'to die, be killed; be eclipsed (of sun and moon)' perhaps also related to Lyd. akτa 'of the dead'?? The Hittite forms might be formally accounted for by reconstructing an *o ~ *Ø ablauting root-present *Hók- / *Hk- ´. The only potential cognates are Skt. áka- 'pain', Av. aka- (adj.) 'bad, evil', which, if a correct comparison, the underlying root would be *h₁ek- or *h₃ek-, but this connection is not fully certain.

S.v. Hitt. padda- / padd- 'to dig (the ground); to bury(?)', from PIE *bʰedʰh₂- (cf. Lat. fodiō 'to dig', OCS bodǫ 'to stab', Lith. bedù 'to stick, to dig', etc.) The Hitt. forms may be accounted for by an *o ~ *Ø ablauting root present *bʰódʰh₂-/*bʰdʰh₂- ´.
S.v. *h₂ed- 'vertrocknen' (IEW 3, [69]).  Cf. Gk. ἄζομαι 'dry up'.
S.v. Hitt. ištamān- / ištamin- (c. > n.) 'ear'. The noun ištamān- 'ear' is cognate with Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' < PIE (nom.) *stéh₃-mn, (gen.) *sth₃-mén-s.

S.v. šākuu̯a- 'eye' (Anat. cognates: CLuw. tāu̯a- 'eye', HLuw. tawa/i- 'eye', Lyc. *tewe- 'eye' (coll. pl. tawa), ñtewe 'facing, opposite, toward', from Proto-Anatolian *sṓgʷo- via PIE *sókʷ-o- (cf.
