PGerm. sexʷan 'to see'). An alternative proposal is a connection with the root *h₃ekʷ- 'see' with an s-mobile, but this is somewhat awkward for the Anatolian-internal evidence.
S.v. *mi̯eu̯h₁- '(sich) bewegen' (IEW 743).
S.v. Hitt. mau- / mu-, maušš- 'to fall', from PIE *móu̯h₁-/muh₁- ´ (cf. Lat. moveō 'move', Ved. mīv-, mū- 'move, push').
S.v. Hitt. tūu̯a (adv.) 'far', from PIE *dueh₂m (cf. Skt. dūram 'far away', Gk. δήν 'a long time', Lat. dūdum 'for a long time already').

S.v. Ved. dūrá- 'fern' (adj.), 'Ferne' (n.), IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. dūrat̰ 'von fern', OAv. dūirē, YAv. dūire 'fern', etc., from PIE *duh₂-ró- to PIE *du̯eh₂- 'sich entfernen, räumlich und zeitlich erstrecken'. Cf. *du̯eh₂-m > Gk. δήν, *du̯eh₂-ró- > Skt. dūrá-, Gk. δηρός, Arm erkar 'lange dauernd; Hitt. tūu̯a- 'fern' < *duh₂-i̯o-; Lat. dūdum.

S.v. (UZU)appuzzi- (n.) 'animal fat, tallow' (Sum. (UZU)I̯À.UDU).  Normally, words in -uzzi- are derived from zero-grades of verbal roots.  The only formal candidate for this in Hitt. would be ēpp-/app- 'take, seize', but it is not clear how this would work semantically.  Etymology therefore unclear.

CLuw. tāta/i-, HLuw. tata/i-, Lyd. taada-, and Lyc. tede/i- 'father' are from Proto-Anatolian *todo- (Kloekhorst 2008:225-226).  The Luwian and Lycian forms show commonly innovated i-motion in the inflection, and the Lycian form has subsequently undergone regular umlaut.  The Lydian form shows none of these changes found in the Luwic languages.  We are therefore dealing with a genuinely inherited set from Proto-Anatolian rather than a parallel derivation, even if the original lexeme were have likely to be a child-language formation within Proto-Anatolian originally.
Kloekhorst lists *todo- derived forms under the same lemma as Hitt. atta-.
S.v. *neh₂- 'in Angst geraten' (IEW 754).

Hitt. nāḫ- 'to fear, be(come) afraid, be respectful, be careful', from IE *nóh₂-ei, *nh₂-énti, *neh₂-sr. Plausibly connected with OIr. nár 'noble, modest' (< *neh₂sr-o-), which can be accounted for through a semantic development 'to fear > to  be respectful > to be modest, noble'.

S.v. Hitt. ḫulle- / ḫull- 'to smash, to defeat', proposes a root *h₂u̯elh₁-, which yielded Hitt. ḫulle-/ḫull- from a nasal-infix present *h₂ul-né-ti, *h₂ul-n-énti, comparable to OIr. follnadar 'to rule', Lat. ualeō 'to be powerful', and, with a *-dʰ- extension, Lith. véldu 'to own', Goth. waldan 'to rule', OCS vladǫ 'to rule'.

Hitt. alil- 'flower' may be considered a member of the culture words meaning 'flower' widely attested in several language families, e.g. Lat. līlium, Coptic hrēri, hlēli 'lily', Alb. lule, Cushitic ilili, Basque lili, Estonian lill 'flower'.

S.v. Hitt. me(i̯)u- / mei̯au̯- 'four'. The Hittite stem is difficult to etymologise. Perhaps to be connected with the root *meh₁- 'to measure', but ultimately unclear. Within Anatolian cf. CLuw. māuu̯a- 'four' and possib. Lyc. mupm̃m- 'fourfold?'.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', from PIE *iég-o- (cf. OIr. aig, gen. ega 'ice', MCorn. yeyn 'cold', ONor. jaki 'ice-floe', jökull 'glacier'), from which ekae-/ikae- 'to cool down' is a denominal verb.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. (GIŠ) šēšatar / šēšann- (n.) 'fruit-tree?'. Hitt. šešan- may be further related to the verb šiš- 'to prosper, proliferate', however there is no good Indo-European etymology for this verb.
S.v. Hitt. šūu-, šūu̯au̯- 'full', which may go back to either *souh₁-(o)u- or *souh₃-(o)u- by internal reconstruction.  There are no certain cognates outside of Anatolian.

S.v. Hitt. āššu- / āššau̯- 'good; dear; favourable'. The connection to Gk. ἐύς 'good' and Ved. sú 'good' < *h₁su- is generally accepted, but the details of the inner-Anatolian stem formation is still debated.

S.v. Hitt. ḫāḫḫall- 'greenery, verdure, (wild) vegetation', from which the derived adjective ḫaḫliu̯ant- 'yellow(green)'. The word appears to be genuinely Hittite, already attested in OS documents and with no aberrant case forms or morphological irregularities, but there is nevertheless no good Indo-European etymology. The meaning of the CLuw. ḫaḫḫaluu̯anti- which is marked using the gloss-wedge (Glossenkeil) is not clear and may not belong with the Hittite form (HW² Ḫ: 7f. regards it was not belonging with Hitt. ḫāḫḫall-).

S.v. Hitt. ḫaršar / ḫaršn- 'head; person; front; beginning'. Unlikely to be cognate with *k̑érh₂-s-r, *k̑rh₂-s-nós 'head' > Skt. śíras, śīrṣnas 'head' because PIE *k̑- cannot yield Hitt. ḫ-, nor is a situation of a distance assimilation *k̑ ... h₂ > *h₂ ... h₂ plausible.  Instead a connection with Gk. ὄρος 'mountain' /cognate/1509/ from an s-stem *h₃er-es- 'high' is more plausible (cf. also Ved. r̥ṣvá- 'high' which is also a secondary derivative), which has been secondarily derived as an -r/n- noun in Hittite (i.e. *h₃er-s-r, *h₃er-s-nos).

S.v. Hitt. ištamān- / ištamin- (c. > n.) 'ear', from which ištamašš- 'to hear, listen to, obey' is a denominal verb. The noun ištamān- 'ear' (cf. /cognate/3304/) is cognate with Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' < PIE (nom.) *stéh₃-mn, (gen.) *sth₃-mén-s.
S.v. *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' (IEW 1144-5).
S.v. Hitt. u̯alḫ- 'to hit, to strike', following interpretation of LIV² from root *u̯elh₃- 'hit, strike' (cf. Lat. vellō 'tear apart', Gk. ἐάλων 'is killed', TochA wälläṣtär 'dies').
S.v. *h₂er⁽k̑⁾- 'halten' (IEW 65-66).
S.v. 2. ?*h₁ai̯- 'warm sein' [IEW 11, 68]. Cf. n1: Only Anatolian; uncertain is the proposed relationship with *ai̯dʰ- 'entzünden', because this root can have *h₂, cf. h₂ei̯dʰ-.

S.v. ā(i)- / i- 'to be hot' (part. a-a-an-t-). Earlier proposed connections with Gk. αἴθω, Skt. inddhé, etc. are to be rejected since these forms require *h₂ei̯dʰ-. Internal morphological analysis suggests a stem formation *h₁eh₃i- based on the Hittite morphological evidence.  This is, however, based solely on internal reconstruction, and there are no known cognates to such a formation.

S.v. Hitt. ḫuu̯arn-/ḫurn- 'to hunt', if of IE origin, could be accounted for by a nasal-infixed stem *h₂ur-n-H from a root *h₂u̯erH-.  This reconstruction, however, is based solely upon internal reconstruction.  Previous etymological connections with Lith. varýti 'to drive, chase' and Latv. vert 'to run' are to be rejected because of lack of evidence for a root final laryngeal (lack of acute intonation).

S.v. šākk- / šakk- 'to know (about), to experience, to heed, to pay attention to, to recognize; to remember, to be expert in; to be acquainted with', from PIE *sekh₁- with the Hittite forms reflecting *o ~ *Ø ablaut: 3.sg. *sókh₁-ei, 3.pl. *skh₁-énti (cf. Lat. secō 'to cut', OCS sěšti 'to cut', PGerm. *sagṓ(n) 'to saw').
S.v. Hitt. lūli- 'pond, lake, spring, well, basin'. No IE Etymology.
S.v. Hitt. ḫuiš- / ḫuš- 'to live; to survive', from PIE *h₂u̯es- (cf. Gk. ἰαύω (aor. ἄεσα) 'to spend the night', Skt. vásati 'dwell', TochB wäs- 'to rest, reside', Goth. wisan 'to be').
S.v. 2. *h₂u̯es- '(ver)weilen, die Nacht verbringen' (IEW 72, 1170-1).
S.v. Hitt. leš(š)i-, lišši- 'liver'. No convincing IE etymology; likely a word of foreign origin along with the practice of hepatoscopy.

S.v. Hitt. *pešan- / pešn- / pišen- (c.) ‘man, male person’, from PIE *pés-ōn-s, *pes-én-om, *pes-n-ós. Cognate with various words for male sexual organs in other Indo-European languages: cf. Ved. pásas- 'penis', Gk. πέος 'penis', Lat. pēnis 'penis', OHG fasal 'seed, descendant'.
Anatolian cognates are likely originally from a child-language word, reconstructable as Proto-Anatolian *Honno-.

S.v. meḫuu̯ant- 'old, elderly'. The best possible etymology is to assume a relationship to mēḫur, mēḫun- n. 'time, period', further root etymology disputed.  Hitt. mēḫur is most plausibly related to *mei̯h₂- 'disappear' (Skt. minā́ti, Lat. minuō 'diminish', cf. LIV² s.v. *mei̯H-), pace {ref Eichner 1973}, who attempts to connect to a root *meh₂- 'to be the right time' (Lat. mātūrus 'mature', mānus 'good') with a lengthened grade *mēh₂- generalised in the Hittite paradigm. Alternatively to *meh₁- 'measure', although the presence of -ḫ- makes this etymology unlikely.

S.v. Hitt. antuu̯aḫḫaš- / antuḫš- 'man, human being, person', from PIE *h₁n-dʰuh₂-s- 'having breath within' (i.e. *h₁en- 'in' + *dʰuh₂- 'breath, smoke'; cf. Ved. dhūmá- 'smoke', Gk. θῡμός 'breath, life' < *dʰuh₂-mó-).
S.v. Hitt. tušk(ii̯e/a)- 'to be happy, to entertain (oneself), to play'. No certain etymology.
S.v. Hitt. ḫuett- / ḫuetti- / ḫuettii̯e/a- 'to draw, to pull, to pluck'. Etymology unclear.  Kloekhorst suspends judgement between competing alternatives.
S.v. *seu̯h₁- 'antreiben, in Bewegung halten' (IEW 914).

S.v. šuu̯e/a- 'to push (away), to shove, to cast off'. K. reconstructs to the same root as the LIV², but disagrees over the stem formation, preferring to reconstruct a yod-present *sHu-i̯é- (with laryngeal metathesis).

S.v. ḫēu- / ḫē(i̯)au- 'rain'. Etymology unclear.  Possibly related to Gk. αἰονάω 'to moisten' (cf. Melchert 1994:102) pointing to a root *h₂ei̯h₃-, but the maintenance of intervocalic -i̯- in the Greek form is problematic for this etymology phonologically.
S.v. *h₁erH- 'waschen' [IEW 337].  Only Hitt. ārr-/arr- 'wash' and TochA yär- 'bathe'.
S.v. *nei̯H- 'führen, leiten' (IEW 760).
S.v. nē-, nai-, *ni- 'to turn, turn someone, to turn oneself, to send'; from PIE *néih₁/₃-, *nóih₁/₃-ei / *nih₁/₃-énti (cf. Skt. nay- 'to lead').
S.v. Hitt. lāla- 'tongue, blade, speech, talk'. No good Indo-European cognates. Hitt. lāla-, CLuw. lāla/i- may go back to PAnat. *lólo- or *lālo-.
Anatolian forms reflect PAnat. *Hobó-.

S.v. Hitt. ar- 'to stand (by), to be stationed, to remain standing; to be present, to occur', from PIE *h₃r̥- following the etymology of Oettinger (1979:523f.), a middle-zero-grade of *h₃er- 'to rise (to move vertically)'. On the development *h₃r- > *ʔr-, cf. Kloekhorst (2006:77-108).

S.v. *h₁er- 'wohin gelangen, geraten' (IEW 326-329); now probably to be separated and listed under *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-329). See notes and discussion in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda.
S.v. *ses- 'ruhen, schlafen' (IEW —).
Cf. s.v. Hitt. alel- 'flower, bloom' for further references to loanword studies.
S.v. Hitt. iskis- 'back, backside, rear'. Possibly to be connected with Greek ἰσχίον 'hip-joint, hip(s)', but further connections are uncertain.

Possibly to be connected with Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip-joint' ({ref HED A+E/I}:424-425), but this is disputed (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:602-603). In view of the areal proximity it remains possible that both Greek ἰσχίον and Hitt. iškiš- are both independent borrowings from a third source (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:402).

S.v. tii̯eššar / tii̯ešn- 'forest(?)'. The contexts of this word are uncertain, but the consistent use of the determinative GIŠ indicates the word has something to do with wood.  It is argued that the word may be connected with the Sumerogram (GIŠ)TIR 'forest' that is sometimes phonetically complemented with a -šar/-šn- flexional ending, and so the translation 'forest' has commonly been adopted for this lexeme, although the evidence for this identification is admittedly circumstantial.  There are no known cognates in Anatolian or elsewhere in Indo-European, but if the expression tii̯ēššar dai- (KUB 33.66 iii) is interpreted as a figura etymologica, then it might be related to *dʰeh₁- 'put, place' via a derived form *dʰh₁-i-éh₁sh₁-r.
S.v. *h₁ai̯- 'geben; nehmen' (IEW 10-11).

S.v. OLith. kiaušìnis 'Ei', originally a substantivised adjective from OLith. káušas 'Schale' in the sense of 'mit einer Schale versehen'; cf. s.v. OLith. káušas 'Schale, Becher, Kelle' (BSl. Latv. kaûss 'Schädel, Hirnschale'). No clear further etymology. Several proposals to link words from other IE branches, cf. ALEW 469-470 for further details.
Cf. s.v. 2. *u̯elH- '(sich) wälzen, wallen' [IEW 1140-3].

Cf. s.v. OLith. uolà 'Fels' (BSl. Latv. uõla 'kleiner, runder Stein, Kiesel; Ei'). Traditionally connected to Lith. vélti (II) 'walken, zu Filz machen' (BSl. Latv. vel̂t, OCS valiti, etc.), from PIE *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. Goth. wulan 'sich ausbreiten' ON velta 'sich wälzen', OHG wellan 'wälzen', OS wellian 'rollen').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *fleugōn 'fly'. Derived from *fleugan- 'to fly'. Old Norse fluga shows the zero grade while Norw. fljuge as well as the West-Germanic lexemes show the full grade. The PIE root is the k-extended variant of *pleu̯- > *pleu̯k- (cf. LIV² 487-488).
Cf. s.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837). An extension of *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7), only Germanic and Baltic.

S.v. TochB kärn- 'hit', 'play, strike [a musical instrument]'. Earlier proposals suggested a connection with Greek κεραίζω 'devastate, ravage' and Sanskrit śr̥nā́ti 'harms, destroys', which {ref van Windekens 1976} specifically assumed to be based on a past participle *k̑r̥hₓ-no- (cf. Skt. śīrná-), but PIE *-rn- should have given Tocharian -rr-. Because we have -r- and -n- in contact suggests that this is a secondary contact. TochAB kärn- must reflect PToch *krŭn- or *kärCn- with an original meaning something like 'strike'. Thus, Adams assumes Proto-Tocharian *krŭn- to reflect PIE *kru-nehₐ- from PIE *kreu̯-s- 'strike', whence also Greek κρούω 'strike (together), strike a stringed instrument with a plectrum, knock [at the door]' < *kreusye/o-.
Cf. s.v. *u̯reh₁g̑- 'brechen, reißen (intr.)' (IEW 1181-2), to which LIV follows the traditional etymology deriving Alb. rreh 'schlägt' as a secondary *-sk̑e- present.
S.v. Alb. rrah 'to beat, strike'. Orel takes this to be from Proto-Alb. *wragska and connected with Greek ῥάσσω from PIE *u̯rāgh-.

S.v. egdu-, igdu- 'leg'. Puhvel suggests a possible etymology to *ei̯-gʰ- (IEW 296) : Lith. eigà 'a going', Gk. οἴχομαι 'go off, be gone', ἴχνος 'footstep, track', TochB yku 'gone', thus egdu < *ei̯gʰ-tu- 'a going' > 'leg' by metonymy.
Perhaps to be connected to Arm. leard 'liver' /lexeme/28544/ if from *lis-r̥t.

S.v. Hitt. lāman- / lamn- 'name; reputation', from PIE *h₃néh₃mn (cf. Lat. nōmen, Skt. nā́man-, Goth. namo, Gk. ὄνομα, Phr. onoman, Arm. anun, OIr. ainm 'name', etc.). In Proto-Anatolian there was a nasal dissimilation *n … mn > *l … mn.

S.v. Hitt. ḫatk- 'to shut, to close', from a *o ~ *Ø ablauting present stem *h₂ódʰg̑ʰ- / *h₂dʰg̑ʰ- (cf. Gk. ἄχθομαι 'to be burdened, to be depressed', ἄχθος 'pressure, burden'). Hitt. ḫatku- / ḫatgau̯- 'tight, pressed, stressful' is a derived adjective from the verbal stem.
Cf. s.v. *h₂edʰ⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'drücken' (not in IEW).
S.v. Hitt. maninku(u̯a)- 'near', cognate with CLuw. mannakuna/i- 'short'.  The variant forms in Hittite make the lexeme difficult to etymologise outside of Anatolian.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. maninku(u̯a)- 'near', cognate with CLuw. mannakuna/i- 'short' but the variant forms in Hittite make it difficult to etymologise the forms outside of Anatolian.

S.v. kunna- ‘right (hand or side); right, favourable, successful’: Two possible etymologies: (1) PIE *k̑un-no-, cf. Av. spənta-, Lith. šveñtas, OCS svętъ 'holy, sacred', Skt. śunám 'success(fully)' which reflect a root *k̑u̯en-. (2) *k̑uh₂-no- 'the strong one' (cf. Skt. śávas- 'might' < *k̑eu̯h₂-o-, śū́ra 'hero' < *k̑uh₂-ro-).  Both are semantically plausible, but Kloekhorst is inclined for follow the first one.

If Hrozný's original proposed connection [in his 1917 decipherment of Hittite, cf. Kloekhorst for the reference] of Hitt. palša- to Gk. δι-πλός, Lat. du-plus, OHG zwi-falt 'twofold' is correct, then we are dealing with a root *pel-.
The primary sense of the lexeme appears to relate to 'going', casting doubt on Hrozný's etymology.  There are, however, no other obvious comparanda as potential cognates.
S.v. šurka/i- 'root' Unknown etymology.  Connection to Lat. surcus 'twig, sprout' proposed by {ref Melchert 1994}:132 cannot be true because Lat. surcus is a ghostword.

S.v. Hitt. aruna- 'sea'. No generally accepted etymology.  The most promising connection is with Hitt. aru-/arau- 'high' < *h₃r-éu̯-no-, which is formally possible, and a semantic parallel can be found in Skt. árṇa- 'wave, flood, stream' < *h₃er-no- *'rising (water)'.  Cf. Puhvel HED A-E/I for this proposal and other alternative etymologies.

S.v. Hitt. au- / u- 'to see, look'. Connects Hitt. au-/u- 'to see, look' with Skt. āviṣ (adv.) 'evidently, before the eyes', Av. āuuiš 'id.', Gk. ἀΐω 'to perceive', αἰσθάνομαι 'to perceive', Lat. audiõ 'to hear' < *h₂eu̯-.  The Hittite form would reflect an *o ~ Ø ablaut, where initial *h₂- would merge with *h₁ before *o.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. 𒌋 u̯ar(ru)u̯alan- 'seed, progeny'. No etymology.

S.v. Hitt. alpu- 'pointed' Possibly to be connected with Welsh llym, Breton lemm 'sharp' [cf. /cognate/5421/] via *l̥pu-, but this is ultimately unclear because of the debated semantics of the Hittite lexeme.

S.v. Hitt. išḫamai- / išḫami- 'to sing'. Related to the root *seh₂- 'to bind' (cf. LIV² s.v. *sh₂ei̯- 'fesseln, binden') with a root-extension *-m-, thus *sh₂em- (*sh₂m-ói-ei, *sh₂m-i-énti), which must have already been of IE date, cf. Skt. sā́man- 'song, hymn' < *sh₂óm-en-.

S.v. Hitt. kappi-/kappai- 'small, little', from PIE *kmb-(e)i- (cf. also Lyd. καμβειν 'grandchild'), cognate with Iranian words for 'small', e.g. Av. kamna-, OPers. kamna-. The Iranian cognates which must reflect *km̥b-no- (*kembʰ- would be against IE root constraints).
S.v. Hitt. mīu-/mīi̯au̯- from a PIE u-stem *mih₁-(é)u- (√mei̯h₁-), cf. Lat. mītis 'soft', Lith. míelas 'tender, lovely', Russ. милуй 'sweet'.

S.v. Hitt. ḫāḫḫall- 'greenery, verdure, (wild) vegetation', from which the derived adjective ḫaḫliu̯ant- 'yellow(green)'. The word appears to be genuinely Hittite, already attested in OS documents and with no aberrant case forms or morphological irregularities, but there is nevertheless no good Indo-European etymology. The meaning of the CLuw. ḫaḫḫaluu̯anti- which is marked using the gloss-wedge (Glossenkeil) is not clear and may not belong with the Hittite form (HW² Ḫ: 7f. regards it was not belonging with Hitt. ḫāḫḫall-).
S.v. *dʰeh₁(i̯)- '(Muttermilch) saugen' (IEW 241-2). Lyc. tideimi originally a participle, cf. n1.
Cf. s.v. tēta(n)- 'breast, chest' /lexeme/20162/.

S.v. Hitt. zaḫḫai-/zaḫḫi- 'battle, war', from which Hitt. zaḫḫii̯e/a- is a secondary derivative. By internal reconstruction an earlier PIE stem *tieh₂-oi̯/i- may be postulated to account for Hitt. zaḫḫai-/zaḫḫi- 'fight' (n.).  There are no known cognates outside of Anatolian.

S.v. per / parn- 'house, household'. Older literature has often assumed a borrowing from Egyptian pr 'house', but the borrowing does not easily explain the archaic-looking inflection as an -r/n- stem.  From the attestation of the forms throughout Anatolian (Hitt. per/parna-,  CLuw. parna-, HLuw. parna-, Lyd. bira- 'house'; Lyc. *prñna- 'house' in prñnawa- 'tomb', prñneze/i- 'household') a Proto-Anatolian lexeme with heteroclitic inflection *Pér-r, *Pr-n-ós can be postulated.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. šīu̯att- (c.) 'day', from PIE *di̯eu̯-ot- (cf. Skt. dyut- 'shine'). Cognates with Anatolian include Pal. tii̯at- 'Sun-god', CLuw. Tiu̯ad- 'Sun-god', and their derivatives.
Cf. s.v. ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen' (IEW 450). Only Indo-Iranian.

Also cognate: OPru. keuto 'skin', Lith. kiáutas 'shell, rind, peel'; MIr. codal 'hide, skin' and Lith. kiáuklas 'shell'.
Does not mention the Greek forms.
s.v. κύτος and σκῦτος. Beekes reconstructs a root form *(s)keHu- s.v. κύτος and *(s)keh₁u- s.v. σκῦτος.
Cf. s.v. OLith. kiáutas 'Schale' Either PIE *(s)keu̯h₂- 'stochern' or PIE *(s)keu̯H- ~ 'bedecken, umhüllen'.

S.v. OHG hût 'Haut, Fell, Trieb', from Proto-Germanic *χūđi-. Different derivations in the individual language branches from PIE *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover' (cf. the explanation of Greek σκῦτος as a nominalisation of a past participle *skuH-tó- 'covered' with an accent shift as suggested by S. Neri).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kowdo- 'hiding place' < PIE *k̑ou̯dʰo- (*√k̑eu̯dʰ-, cf. Gk. κεύθω, Arm. suzanem 'submerge, hide'). The Celtic verbal forms (Welsh cuddiaf, MBret cuzaff and Cornish cuthe 'hide') are denominative verbs. Note that Matasović assumes root-initial palatal k̑- instead of velar k- for the PIE root.
Cf. s.v. ?*leu̯gʰ- 'lügen' (IEW 686-7). Root only attested in Germanic and Balto-Slavic.

S.v. -dō, -dere 'to put'. Lat. verbal compounds in -dō can formally go back to either *deh₃- 'to give' or *dʰeh₁- 'to put', in the case of Lat. abscondere, etc. the root is arguably more likely to go back to *dʰeh₁-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *gēn- 'go', from PIE *g̑ʰeh₁- (cf. Skt. jáhāti 'to leave behind', OAv. auua-zazat̰ 3.pl.pres.inj. 'id.'; Gk. κίχημι 'to overtake, reach, arrive, meet' < *g̑ʰe/i-g̑ʰeh₁-.
S.v. *geh₁- 'kommen, gehen' [IEW 418-9, 1109]. Cf. Arm. gam 'komme', Gk. 3.sg. κιχήτην 'kamen heran'.

CLuw. aruti- 'wing' is possibly an action noun in *-u-ti- (cf. Hitt. -u-zzi-) to the root *Har- 'fit' (cf. Gk. ἀραρίσκω 'fit together, join', Hitt. āra 'what is fitting', etc.).  For the semantics compare Lat. āla /lexeme/20565/ < *h₂ek̑s-leh₂ 'shoulder(-joint)'.
Cf. s.v. 1. *h₂er- 'sich (zusammen)fügen' (IEW 55-8)

S.v. *mag̑- 'streichen, schmieren' (IEW 696-7). The Germanic verbs Modern Icelandic maka 'to smear, to spread', English to make, German machen 'to do, to make' are denominative verbs Germanic *makō-. The semantic shift of 'schmieren'/'kneten' -> 'bilden' -> 'machen' is restricted to West Germanic.

S.v. TochB erkent- 'black, dark', which with TochA arkant- reflects Proto-Tocharian *erkent- but further connections are unclear. Most commonly considered to be from a putative PIE *h₁r̥gʷ-ont- 'dark' (cf. Skt. rájanī- 'night', Gk. ἔρεβος 'darkness of the underworld', Arm. erek 'evening', Goth. riqis 'darkness', however one would have expected the Tocharian words to have *-kw- rather than just -k-. {ref Beekes 2010}:1114 is dubious of the Greek-Tocharian equation, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:260 views it as a possibility only.
Etymology unclear.
S.v. *bʰle⁽g̑⁾- 'glänzen' (IEW 124-125).

TochA tärkär, TochB tärkär reflect Proto-Tocharian *tärkär, as though from a PIE verbal noun *dʰr̥g-r-u-.  Cf. *dʰerg- underlying Baltic forms in Lith. dérgia 'there is bad weather', dárgana, dárga 'bad, rainy weather', Middle Irish derg 'red', Old English deorc 'dark', etc.

TochA kārāś and TochB karāś would appear to be from Proto-Tocharian *kārāś or *kerāś.  It is usually taken to be a loan from Khotanese karāśśa- 'creeper, vine' (after Van Windekens p.625), but the word-formation of the Khotanese form is unclear, and the semantic connection of Tocharian words for 'wilderness' to Iranian words meaning 'creeper, vine' is weak.
Cf. s.v. TochB oko 'fruit', from which the Tocharian A form is likely to be a borrowing.
S.v. AGk. ποιέω 'do, make, produce (also of poetry), act', from PIE *kʷi-eu-, *kʷei-u- 'gather, deem' (cf. Skt. cinóti 'arrange, pile, erect', Av. cinuuaiti 'to select' < *kʷi-n(e)u-ti).
S.v. 2. *kʷei̯- 'sammeln, schichten' (IEW 637-8).
S.v. 2. *kers- '(ab)schneiden' (IEW 945), cf. Hitt. karaszi 'schneidet ab; trennt; versäumt'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *orbiti 'do, work' (ESSJa XXXII 116-118), a derivative of *orbъ 'servant, slave' < *h₃erbʰ-, cf. Gk. ὀρφανός 'orphan', Lat. orbus 'deprived of, orphan'.

S.v. TochB eṅkwe 'man' (as opposed to woman). TochA oṅk, TochB eṅkwe may be derived from a PIE thematised u-stem noun (transponat) *n̥k̑-u̯-o- 'mortal', cf. OIr. éc 'dead' < *n̥k̑-u-, Av. nasu- 'corpse, carrion', Gk. νέκυς 'corpse' from *nek̑- 'die, perish'.
TochA kātse, related to kāts 'abdomen, belly' < PToch. *kātsān-. [Cf. Adams 2013:165-166).]

TochAB käly- reflect PToch *käly- from *PIE *kel(h₁)- 'rise up, arise'.  The suppletive stem found in TochA ṣtäm-, TochB stäm- is probably from PIE *stem- a byform of *steh₂-, similarly as *gʷem- 'come' and *gʷeh₂- 'take a step' form a suppletive pair in PIE.

S.v. TochAB käly- 'stehen, sich befinden', 'stand, be situated' from Proto-Tocharian *kl'æ-. Malzahn prefers an etymology following LIV² to *k̑lei̯-, finding the derivation of Adams in Dictionary of Tocharian B *kel(h₁)- 'raise up' to be derivationally impossible.
S.v. *k̑lei̯- 'sich anlehnen' (IEW 601-602), on the formation of the Tocharian stem cf. n13.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tvoriti 'make', from PIE *tu̯orH- (cf. Lith. tvérti 'seize, form'; Latv. tvêrt 'seize, hold').
S.v. *tu̯erH- 'fassen' (IEW 1101). The OCS form is based on an original cs.-iter. stem *tu̯orH-éi̯e-.

Proto-Slavic *dělati (ESSJa IV 231-232), a denominative of Proto-Slavic *dělo 'work, deed', from PIE *dʰeh₁-l- (cf. Ved. dádhati 'put, place, make', Gk. τίθημι 'put down, ground, create', Lat. fēcī (1.sg.perf.) 'made', OHG tuon 'do').
S.v. TochAB kärk- '(an)binden', 'bind', connected since {ref Fraenkel 1932}:229 to Lith. ker̃gti 'bind' from either *kergʰ- or *kergʷʰ- (cf. {ref Hilmarsson 1996}:87f.).
S.v. *reh₁dʰ- 'erfolgreich durchführen' (IEW 59-60).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *raditi 'care about, heed', cf. roditi I 'give birth, bear (fruit)' "Only Balto-Slavic. LIV’s reconstruction *(H)rod-eie- (497) of an aspirated voiced stop is based on Matasović’s modification of Winter’s law (only in closed syllables), which is why in a footnote *d is not completely ruled out. The often suggested connection with Skt. várdhate ‘grow, increase, thrive’ is formally problematic, since
we would have to assume Schwebeablaut and loss of *u-."
S.v. Hitt. kaka- 'tooth'. Etymology unclear. Attempts by Puhvel HED K to connect Hitt. kaka- with OEng. hōc 'hook' are unconvincing.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *caš² 'to drip; to drink, eat?'.  The root is exclusively Iranian; Skt. caṣ- 'to eat' is attested late and likely to be a loanword.

S.v. OLith. gérti 'trinken' (BSl. cf. Latv. dzer̂t 'trinken', OCS po-žrěti, etc.), from PIE *gʷerh₃- 'verschlingen' (cf. Ved. garⁱ- 'verschlingen', Gk. βιβρώσκω 'verzehre, esse auf', Arm. 3.sg.ind.aor. eker 'aß', Alb. 3.sg.aor. an-greh Old Gheg 'aß', OHG querdar 'Köder').
S.v. *gʷerh₃- 'verschlingen' (IEW 474).

S.v. OLith. válgyti 'essen, speisen, sich ernähren', which is not to be separated from OLith. vìlgyti 'befeuchten, benetzen, bestreichen' (BSl. cf. Latv. vel̂gt 'einweichen, feucht machen', OPr. welge 'Schnupfen', OCS vlaga 'Feuchtigkeit, Saft (Pflanzen)', etc.), from PIE *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (cf. OIr. folc 'starker Regen, Regenwetter', MW 3.sg.pres. gwylch 'waschen', Bret. gwalc'hiñ 'waschen', OS wolkan 'Wolke', OHG wolkan 'Wolke').

S.v. ? 2. *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (IEW 1145). Verbal only Balto-Slavic. Possible related nominal forms in Germanic like OHG welc 'feucht', wolchan 'Wolke', cf. also ?*u̯elk- 'feucht sein / werden' (IEW 1145) (verbal only Celtic).

S.v. TochB klīye ~ klyīye 'woman', 'female (of animals)', which with TochA kᵤli reflects Proto-Tocharian *kʷliye.  Adams takes the Proto-Tocharian form to reflect PIE *gʷneh₂-h₁en- with a "definitizing" suffix to the normal PIE word for 'woman' *gʷen(e)h₂, which appears in TochB as śana- 'wife'.  The initial -l- in the Tocharian forms is the result of dissimilation *n … n  > *l … n.  Cf. entry in Adams and NIL s.v. *gʷenh₂-, n22 for discussion.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hardu- 'hard, severe', often compared with Gk. κρατύς 'strong, powerful' and related forms, but the o-grade and Schwebeablaut remain unexplained. Better is the connection with Lith. kartùs 'bitter' and OCS kratъkъ 'short' (Strunk 1976, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:282).
S.v. TochB śaumo 'person, man'; TochA śom ‘boy’ and TochB śaumo reflect Proto-Tocharian *śumo, a derivative of śāw- ‘live’ < *gʷi̯eh₃-u̯-e/o-.

S.v. TochB ṣämṣ- 'count (as)', (as though) from PIE *sem-se/o-, a verbal derivative of *sem- 'one, a unity' (cf. Skt. samayati 'puts in order', ON semja 'put together, put in order, unite' < *som(H)ei̯e/o-).

S.v. TochB ṣämṣ- 'zählen, betrachten als', 'count, count (as)'; traditionally to PIE *sem- 'one' but with some formal difficulties regarding the preservation of the nasal before -s-. Alternatively K. T. Schmidt apud {ref EWAia} II:836, Nachträge ad śaṁs-) compares the root to Ved. śaṃs- 'praise' from PIE *(s)k̑ens- '(zweckgebunden) zählen' with the line of semantic development in Vedic being 'sequentially counting' >> 'evaluate, assess'.
S.v. 2. *(s)ker- 'scheren, kratzen, abschneiden' (IEW 938-40).
S.v. 2. *kers- '(ab)schneiden' (IEW 945).
S.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' (IEW 941-2). Cf. n1: Probably an enlarged form of 2. *(s)ker- /cognate/5452/.
Etymology unknown.
S.v. TochB kauṃ, which with TochA koṃ reflects Proto-Tocharian *kāunä- from a PIE verbal abstract *keh₂u-ni- 'burning heat (as of the sun)' from PIE *keh₂u̯- 'ignite, burn' (cf. Gk. καίω).
S.v. TochB kauṃ, which with TochA koṃ reflects Proto-Tocharian *kāunä- from a PIE verbal abstract *keh₂u-ni- 'burning heat (as of the sun)' from PIE *keh₂u̯- 'ignite, burn' (cf. Gk. καίω).
S.v. *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein' (IEW 1016-7).

S.v. Alb. thua ~ thue '(finger) nail'. Orel prefers to derive from Proto-Albanian *atsāna, from PIE *ak̑- 'sharp', but alternative etymologies have been proposed comparing variously Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail', PIE * k̑er- 'horn', Gk. κεντέω  'to prick', and PGmc. *xanduz 'hand'.
S.v. Sp. golpe, from Lat. *colupus, Lat. colaphus 'puñetazo', from Greek κόλαφος 'befetón'. Sp. golpar is a secondary denominal formation from the borrowed noun golpe.
S.v. *der- 'zerreißen (intr.), zerspringen' (IEW 206-8).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *udariti 'strike, hit', a prefixed verb with a lengthened grade of the root, cf. Proto-Slavic *derti 'tear' from PIE *der(H)- (cf. Gk. δέρω 'flay', Goth. distairan 'tear apart').
S.v. *bʰei̯H- 'schlagen' (IEW 117-8).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *biti- 'beat', from PIE *biH- (cf. OIr. benaid 'strike').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'beat, strike, slay', a Germanic-Celtic isogloss (cf. MIr. slacc 'sword').
S.v. ?*slak- 'schlagen' (IEW 959).  Cf. n1 "Hierher wohl mir. slacc 'Schwert', neuir. slacairt 'das Schlagen' usw."

TochB sruk- 'die' is related to the TochA sruk- 'kill', which is based on a causative formation.  Several possible etymological proposals: {ref Adams 2013}:792 derives the root from PIE *streu̯g- 'streichen, abwischen' ({ref LIV²} 605, without Tocharian), while {ref Meillet 1911}:461 assumed a k-extension of *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' ({ref LIV²} 588, without Tocharian).  More recently {ref Hackstein 2003}:84 has preferred *su̯ergʰ- 'krank sein, sich sorgen' ({ref LIV²} 613-614, without Tocharian).

S.v. TochB rāp-, TochA räp- 'graben, pflugen', 'dig, plow' "According to Adams, DoT, 528f., the root is related to "Proto-Anatolian *terep- < *trep-" denoting 'plow' said to come from PIE *√drep 'scratch, tear', but note that ²LIV, 650 derives the Anatolian comparanda from PIE *√trep- 'wenden' (as also did Janda, 1997, 8ff. and most recently Kloekhorst, 2008, 871), from which Toch. rāp(ā)- cannot be derived by sound law."

S.v. TochB rāp- 'dig, turn up the soil, plow', which along with TochA  räp- to be connected to PIE *drep- 'scratch, tear' (LIV² 128-129), connecting Hitt. teripp- 'turn the earth, plow', Gk. δρέπω 'pick, cut', Slov. drpljem 'rip' etc.  Note, however, that LIV² connects the Anatolian cognates with 2. *trep- 'wenden' (LIV² 650, IEW 1094).

S.v. TochB krāke 'dirt, filth (e.g. semen)', derived adjective kraketstse 'dirty, filthy'. AB krāke reflect PToch *krāke, probably a borrowing from Khotanese khārgga- 'id.' with metathesis. Cf. entry for a survey of other less plausible proposals.
Contains an extensive discussion of stem-formation to this root in Tocharian languages.
Cf. s.v. ¹ās- 'dry out, dry up (intr.), parch'; 'dry out, dry up (intr.)', to be connected with PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'dry (through heat)', cf. Lat. areō 'am dry', āridus 'dry, arid'.
Romance forms from Lat. āridus, derived from āreō 'to be dry' < PIE *h₂eh₁s-.

S.v. TochB klautso 'ear'. The words for 'ear' in Tocharian are certainly some derivation from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'hear', but the precise details of the word formation are debated.  Cf. Adams s.v. for discussion of alternative proposals.
S.v. TochB śuw- 'essen, komsumieren', 'eat, consume', to be derived from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'kauen'.  See entry for detailed discussion of stem formation in the Tocharian languages.
S.v. TochB lau 'afar; far' Etymology unclear.  Presumably related to TochB lauke, TochA lok 'far (off), remote; away', but further IE connections are dubious.

S.v. TochB ṣalype ~ ṣalype '(sesame) oil; salve, ointment' which with TochA ṣälyp reflect Proto-Tocharian *ṣälype, which may be connected with a PIE word for 'fat' *sélpos, cf. Gk. ἕλπος (Hesych.) 'olive oil; rendered fat', Albanian gjalpë 'butter', Skt. sarpíṣ- 'molten butter, lard', PGmc. *salba- 'salve'.

S.v. *preK- 'sich fürchten' (IEW 820).  Only Tocharian continues a verb derived directly to the root via PIE *pr̥K-sk̑e/o-.  The Germanic forms are denominal in origin (cf. Goth. faurhts 'furchtsam', denom. faurhtjan 'fürchten').

S.v. TochB wät- 'fight, struggle', which with TochA wac 'combat, struggle' reflect Proto-Tocharian *wät- and derivatives, which can be connected with PIE *u̯edʰ- (Skt. vádhati 'strike (down)', etc.  Van Windekens's etymology to *du̯et-, a supposed derivative of the numeral 'two', is to be rejected.
S.v. *u̯edʰh₁- 'stoßen' (IEW 1115). [Tocharian cognates not listed].
S.v. TochB wät- 'kämpfen', 'fight', to be derived from PIE *u̯edʰ- 'strike down' (cf. Adams DoT 590) (*u̯edʰh₁- in LIV² (without Tocharian cognates).
S.v. TochB īte 'full, abundant, profuse'. The etymology is uncertain.  Van Windekens plausibly connects the Tocharian A & B forms together, but further IE connections are unclear.
S.v. TochB kartse ~ krent 'good, beautiful'. Connections outside of Tocharian are uncertain, cf. entry for various proposals.
S.v. TochB atiyo* 'grass'. Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain.  See s.v. for various proposals.
S.v. TochB matsi 'headhair' (collective). Etymology dubious, maybe to Latv. mats 'a hair', (pl.) mati '(head)hair'?
S.v. *g̑ʰes- *'fassen?', 'Hand', 'Griff' (IEW 446f.).  Indo-Iranian cognates reflect *g̑ʰes-to-, other languages reflect an r-stem g̑ʰes-r- or thematised r-stem *g̑ʰes-r-o-.
S.v. TochB āśce 'head'. Etymology uncertain, cf. entry for discussion of various proposals.

S.v. TochB anañce 'heart'. Adams connects Proto-Tocharian *āräñce to a PT root *ār(e)- which he connects with Hitt. ḫaḫ(a)ri-, some part of the body. {ref HED H} s.v. hah(ha)ri- translates 'lung(s), midriff'.  From this comparison Adams sets up PIE *h₂eh₂(e)ri- as a proto-form.

S.v. TochAB kärn- 'schlagen', 'hit, beat'. "The root is traditionally taken for the result of a reanalysis of a nasal present from PIE *√k̑erh₂ 'brechen (itr)' (²LIV, 327f.); see Hackstein, 1995, 34 with ref., but this etymology could not account for the preservation of -rn-; I therefore follow Adams DoT, 164 in setting up pre-PT *kru-n- (from "PIE *kreu-s- 'strike'")."

TochB emalle 'hot, warm', (n.) 'heat', TochA omäl 'id.' reflect Proto-Tocharian *emäl(y)e-, which appears to be a gerund to a verbal root em-.  Further PIE connections are speculative.  See Adams s.v. for various proposals.
S.v. TochB kau- TochA ko- 'zerschlagen, töten; destroy, kill'. From PIE *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (cf. {ref LIV²} 345f., {ref Hackstein 1995}:54ff.).

S.v. TochB lyam 'lake'. Adams rejects the etymology of {ref van Windekens 1976}:271-272 with Lithuanian lāma 'place in a field, marsh, ditch' in favour of a derivation from PIE *limn̥, the neuter equivalent to animate *limén- which is Gk. λίμην 'harbour', or its derivatives λίμνη 'pool of standing water, mere', λείμων 'watery meadow'.
Cf. s.v. u̯edʰh₁- 'stoßen' (IEW 1115).
Cf. s.v. ?*u̯edʰh₁- → 2.*u̯edʰ-?. Reconstruction of final laryngeal insecure.
S.v. TochB ckācko* 'leg, (particularly) shin, calf'. Etymology uncertain.

S.v. TochB wästarye 'liver', most closely related to the Greek words for ὑστρός 'stomach' (Hesych.) ὑστέρα 'womb, uterus; ovary' < *ud-tero-. Cf. Indo-Iranian, Baltic, and Italic words for 'belly' in /cognate/854/.
S.v. TochB pärśeri* '(head-)louse'. Etymology unknown.
S.v. TochB TochB ṣale, which with TochA ṣul reflects Proto-Tocharian *ṣwi̯äle from putative PIE *su̯elo-, related to otherwise isolated Germanic *su̯el- 'swell'.
Van Windekens (1972[74]:141-2, also 1976:141-2) has suggested a connection with Lith. gretà 'proximity' < *gr̥to-, but this equation is not entirely certain.
S.v. TochB meli 'nose' (pl.tant.), which along with TochA malañ, must reflect Proto-Tocharian *mele- (plural tantum).  Extra-Tocharian connections are uncertain.

S.v. TochB ktsaitstse 'old (of age)', which with TochA ktsets '± finished, perfect, excellent' reflect Proto-Tocharian *kätsaitstse 'finished'. All proposed etymologies beyond Tocharian are speculative. Cf. entry in Adams for various proposals.
S.v. TochB śaumo 'person', TochB śom 'boy, child' from Proto-Tocharian *ćāumo, a derivative of śāy-/śāw- 'live' < PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live'.
S.v. Hitt. karāt- 'entrails, innards; inner being, character', from PIE *g̑ʰrh₁-ód- (cf. Gk. χορδή 'gut', Lith. žárnos 'bowels', Lat. haru-spex 'entrails-examiner', Skt. hirā́- 'vein').

S.v. OLith. žarnà 'Darm' (BSl. Latv. zar̂na 'Darm'), IE cognates, cf. Ved. hirā́- 'Ader' Gk. χορδή, 'Darm, Darmsaite', Lat. haru-spex 'Eingeweideschauer, Wahrsager' Falisk HARASP[EX], HARISP[EX] 'id.', Lat. arvīna 'Fett, Speck um die Eingeweide', hernia 'Leistenbruch', ON gǫrn 'Darm', OHG garn, OE gearn 'Garn, Faden'. The forms are best reconciled as different suffixival derivatives of an original PIE root-noun *g̑ʰórh₁-/g̑ʰr̥h₁-. The commonly assumed connection with Alb. zórrë 'Darm' is problematic on phonological grounds.

S.v. TochB kāñm- 'play, be merry'. Etymology uncertain. {ref van Windekens 1976} suggests connections with *keh₂- 'love' (Skt. kāma- 'love, desire', Lat. cārus but the semantics are dubious. Hilmarsson suggests a connection with *kan- 'sing' (Lat. canō 'sing') but the semantics are also unclear.

Cf. s.v. OLith. vidùs 'Inneres, Mitte' (derived noun viduriaĩ (sm.pl.) 'Inneres, Eingeweide'; BSl. cf. Latv. vidus 'Mitte, Mittelstück, Inneres', OPr. widus 'Naht im Stiefel'), from PIE *u̯idʰh₁ú- 'Inneres' (cf. OIr. fid 'Baum, Holz', MW gwŷdd, MBret. gwez 'Bäume', ON viðr 'Baum, Holz', OE widu, wudu 'Holz; Baum; Wald', OHG witu 'Brennholz, Bauholz').
Germanic cognates from Proto-Germanic *χerþra- < Pre-Proto-Germanic *(s)ker-tro-. The Slavic cognates derive from *(s)ker-u̯o-.

S.v. OLith. rãgas 'Horn' (BSl. cf. Latv. kargs 'Horn, Blashorn, Trinkhorn', OPr. ragis 'Horn', ragingis 'Hirsch', OCS rogъ 'Horn', etc.). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can go back to an o-grade nominal derivation to a root *(H)regʰ-. LIV² 498 s.v. *regʰ- 'sich aufrichten' (n1) suggests extra-Baltic connections to forms such as Gk. ἄρχω 'fange an; herrsche', OHG regen 'aufrichten, erregen', Lith. regiù (regė́ti) 'schauen', but this material may have alternative explanations.
S.v. Proto-Celtic moni- 'neck', from PIE *moni- 'neck' (IEW 747f.), cf. Skt. mányā- 'neck', Lat. monīle 'necklace', OHG mana 'mane', Av. manaoθrī- 'neck'.

S.v. Ved. grīvā́- 'Nacken, Hinterhals' (YAv. grīuuā- 'Nacken (daēuuischer Wesen)'. IE probably *gʷriH-u̯eh₂- (cf. Russ. gríva 'Mähne, Bergrücken', grivьna 'Halsband, Gewicht, Geldstück', Latv. grĩva 'Flußmündung'; it is also difficult to separate from Gk. δέρη (Arc. δερϝα) 'Hals, Nacken'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *salā 'dirt' (OIr. sal 'filth, impurity', OW halauc 'dirty' W halog). Cf. Old English salu 'dirty'. OIr. salach 'dirty' < *salāko-. Some have postulated that the word can be derived from PIE *seh₂l- 'salt', but this is semantically dubious; further connections with Lat. salīua are possible but unconvincing.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *noxtV-. The appellative Welsh, Breton nos is borrowed from Latin nox. Proto-Celtic *noxtV- is preserved only in adverbs, cf. OIr. innocht 'tonight', OW he-noid 'tonight', MW peu-noeth 'every night', MBret. hanoez 'tonight', Corn. haneth 'tonight'.
Considers the lexemes inherited from PIE *nokʷ-t-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *volsъ 'hair', from PIE *u̯olk̑-o- (cf. Skt. válśa- 'sprout, twig', LAv. varəsa- 'hair (on the head)').

Cf. s.v. OHG lacha 'Sumpf, Morast, Suhle, schlammiges Wasser' from West Germanic *lakō(n). Middle English lāk(e) 'river, stream' (= 'Bach, Flüsschen') and Modern English lake 'river, stream' in archaic and dialectal language use are inherited from Western Germanic (Old English lacu f. 'river, stream'), but in the meaning 'lake' these words are a semantic borrowing from Old French lac 'lake, pit' < Latin lacus m. 'lake'. Contrary to older interpretations, Proto-Germanic *lākō(n)- is not connected to Lat. lacus, since Lat. must continue *-k̑-. The Germanic word is more likely to go back to PIE *le⁽g̑⁾- 'tröpfeln, sickern, zergehen', also attested in the Gmc. adj. *lek-e/a- 'undicht' and in the thematic present *lek-e/a- 'lecken, undicht sein' (> OHG lecken 'bewässern, benetzen'). Outside of Germanic this root is only further attested in Celtic (cf. OIr. lega* < Proto-Celtic *leg-e/o- 'schmelzen, [sich] auflösen', making the reconstruction of the original velar impossible.
S.v. OLith. ẽzeras 'See, Landsee' (BSl. cf. Latv. ȩzȩrs, ȩzars 'See', OPr. assaran 'See', OCS jezero 'See', etc.), from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰer- 'Rand, Ufer' (cf. Arm. ezr, G.D.sg. ezer 'id.').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ezero; *ezerъ 'lake'; from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰ-(e)r-o- (cf. Arm. ezr ‘edge, border, bank’).

S.v. Alb. trashë 'thick, fat'. Orel prefers to derive from a putative Proto-Albanian *trauša, which he connects to Lith. trąšùs 'fat, fertile (of the soil)' and (despite phonetic difficulties which he admits), also connects to Slav. *truxa- '(hay) dust', which he ultimately derives from PIE *treu- (cf. Gk. τρύω 'to destroy, exhaust', Slav. *trovǫ 'to destroy', etc.). Alternatively borrowed from Lat. crassus ~ Rom. grassus 'solid, thick, fat' (so Meyer 1891:435).
Cf. s.v. 1. *demh₂- '(zusammen)fügen, bauen' (IEW 198-9).

S.v. Lat. domus, -ī, / -ūs. The Latin (and Slavic) forms are from a u-stem derivative of PIE *dōm, *dem- 'house' (Skt. dám-, Av. dam- < *de/om-; Skt. dáma- 'house', Gk. δόμος 'house, layer of bricks' < *dóm-o-, Russ. дом 'house', (L.sg. дому) < *dom-u-)
two pronominal bases that build up a suppletive paradigm in Late PIE (cf. esp. p. 744).

S.v. Hitt. āra (adv.) 'right, properly'. Since Hrozný (1915:28) the forms connected to Hitt. āra have been connected to Skt. áram 'fittingly', r̥tá- 'truth, order', Gk. ἀραρίσκω 'to fit, join'. If this comparison is correct, Hittite āra comes from *h₂or-o- (and is an important argument in favour of the view that *h₂ neutralises before *o).
Cf. s.v. *h₂er- 'sich auflösen, verschwinden' (IEW 332-3). Cf. s.v. n0 "Falls heth. āra 'recht, angemessen' usw. hierhergehört …, muß *(h₁)ar- angesetzt werden."
s.v. modus.
S.v. σῶς 'safe, healthy, intact'. Proto-Greek *sau̯os seems to be a thematization of *tu̯eh₂-u-s (PIE root *teu̯h₂- 'be strong').
Cf. s.v. *teu̯h₂- 'schwellen, stark werden' (IEW 1080-1). [Without Greek cognates listed].
Loan from New High German.

S.v. mītis 'sweet and juicy, soft, gentle', from Proto-Italic *mīti-, from PIE *m(e)h₁i-ti- 'soft' (cf. W. mwydion 'soft parts' < *meit- < *meh₁i-ti-, OIr. mín 'soft' < *miH-ni- < *mh₁i-ni-, W. mwyn 'tender, mild', Bret. moan 'thin, fine' < PCl. *meino/ā/i- < *meh₁i-n-; Skt. máyas- 'refreshment, enjoyment', YAv. maiiah- < *meiH-os-, OPr. mijls, Lith. miélas, Latv. mĩļš 'nice, sweet, dear', OCS milъ 'pitiable', Ru. mílyj 'sweet, dear' < *m(e)iH-lo-).

S.v. Lat. lēvis 'smooth', from PIE *leh₁i-u- 'smooth' (cf. Gk. λεῖος 'level, smooth' < *leh₁-u-o-, λίς, λῑτός 'smooth' (adj.), 'smooth linen' (m.) < *liH-t-), following the derivation of Schrijver (1991:283f.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *þungu- 'heavy', from PIE *tngʰ-u-, identical to Lith. tingùs 'lazy'.
Cf. s.v. Lith. tingùs 'träge, faul, nachlässig'.
Cf. s.v. *tʰengʰ- 'ziehen' (IEW 1067).
Revised root form: *tengʰ-, not *tʰengʰ- as given in LIV².

S.v. Proto-Celtic *glasto- 'green, blue'. "In principle these forms could represent PIE *g̑lh₃-stó- > *glāsto- > *glasto- (by Dybo's shortening). The PIE root would have been *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ({ref IEW} 429ff.), as in *gel(w)o-. Cf. also MHG glasta 'shine', which may reflect a prehistoric borrowing from Celtic (if it is related at all)."
S.v. Proto-Germanic *grōni- 'green', an adjective related to Proto-Germanic *grōan- 'to grow', an o-grade strong verb from the root *gʰreh₁- 'to grow' (cf. Lat. grāmen 'grass').
S.v. ?2.*neu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 767).

S.v. TochB nätk- 'thrust/push (away); thrust forward, urge'. TochA & TochB forms reflect Proto-Tocharian *nätk-. Proposed to PIE *nud-sk̑e/o- (Skt. nudati, otherwise isolated, cf. {ref KEWA} II:176), but this is formally difficult from a Tocharian point of view. Further etymological connections are uncertain.

S.v. TochAB nätk- 'fernhalten, wegstoßen', 'to push off, push away', formerly connected to *neu̯d- (LIV² ?2.*neu̯d-, without Tocharian) by Jasanoff (1978b:39) with a derived present *nud-sk̑e/o-, but the etymology does not fit the root-initial palatalisation found in the Tocharian B preterite forms (ñätka, etc.).  The phenomenon is better accounted for by assuming a pre-Proto-Tocharian form *n(e/i)T-sk-.
TochA swase, TochB swese from Proto-Tocharian *s(u)wese- as though from PIE *suh₃-oso-.

S.v. TochB cake 'river' from Proto-Tocharian *cäke from PIE *tek- 'flow' (Skt. tákti 'hastens, rushes along', Avestan tačati 'runs, hastens, flows', Albanian ndjek 'follow', OIr. techid 'flees', Lith. tekù 'rush, flow').

S.v. TochB āmp- 'rot, putrify', a probable loanword from Middle Iranian *hampu- 'rot, fester'.  Cf. Khotanese hambūtä- 'rotted, festering', Zoroastrian Pahlavi hambūsītan, Modern Persian ambūsīdan 'to rot, fester'.

S.v. TochB waräñce* 'sand' "Clearly related to TchA wāryāñc 'id.', it is nonetheless not directly equatable. Neither the TchA long vowels nor the -y- are matched by anything in Tocharian B. Extra-Tocharian cognates are most unsure. The TchA *wār- might allow us to connect the word with the heretofore isolated Sanskrit vāluka- 'sand'"
S.v. *u̯ekʷ- 'sagen' (IEW 1135-6).

S.v. TochAB we-ñ- 'sagen, sprechen', 'say, speak'. Usually derived from PIE *u̯ekʷ-n-i̯e/o- from √*u̯ekʷ-, but this would not have yielded the Tocharian forms as attested if the form is regularly syllabified according to the rules of PIE syllabification (i.e. *u̯ekʷ-n̥-i̯e/o).  The Tocharian forms must therefore be derived from *h₂u̯edH- 'utter' ({ref LIV²} 286) via *h₂u̯od-n(h₂)-e/o- or *h₂u̯oden-i̯e/o-.

S.v. TochB śäktālye 'seed' which with TochA śäktālyi reflect Proto-Tocharian *ćäktālye-, probably to be related to kät- ‘strew’.  The exact details of the stem formation are not clear but it is probably from a reduplicated present formation *ki-kₑd-ehₐ-.  Proto-Tocharian *kät- 'strew (on purpose); sow (seeds)' goes back to PIE *(s)kedhₐ- 'scatter' (cf. Gk. σκεδάννυμι, σκίδνημι 'scatter, strew', Engl. 'shatter, scatter', Lith. kedė́ti 'burst', with possible other cognates in other IE branches.

Several candidates for a root etymology for TochAB sār-: *ser- 'aneinanderreihen, verknüpfen' by LIV², *serH- by Hackstein ("Uridg. *CH.CC > *C.CC" Historische Sprachforschung 115 (2002) p.4), and *seh₁- by Adams (1999) and others.  Malzahn remains undecided on the basis that no single etymology easily accounts for both Proto-Tocharian subjunctive stems *sārä- and *säryā-.

Derived from *sār- 'to plant, sow, cultivate'.  Root etymology not yet settled, perh. *ser- 'arrange', *seh₁-'sow', or *serH-.  Cf. entry and Malzahn (2010:935-937) for discussion of the alternative options.
Cf. s.v. SMG ανασαίνω, from Medieval Greek ἀνασαίνω, formed as a denominal verb in -αινω from Ancient Greek ἄνεσις 'loosening, relaxing'.
From Ancient Greek κυλίω 'roll along'.
S.v. κυλίνδω, to which κυλίω is a secondary present stem.  Etymology unclear.  Beekes judges the word to be non-Indo-European.

Usually understood to have formed from a collocation of Ancient/Medieval Greek preposition εἰς + pronoun (e.g. εμένα) with subsequent reanalysis of the initial vowel of the pronoun as part of the preposition, i.e.  εις εμένα [is emena] > isemena > ise-mena]. (Initial unstressed /i/ is later lost.)
S.v. SMG ράχη, from Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'lower part of the back; spine'.

S.v. ῥαχίς, -ιος 'spine, back', often metaphorically 'ridge'. Older literature compares ῥάχις 'spine; back' to Lith. ražis 'stubble', from a preform *urág̑ʰ-i-, but Beekes rejects IE connections on the basis that the apparent *a ~ *ā ablaut found in ῥᾱχός (Ion. ῥηχός) 'thorn-hedge, twig' cannot be Indo-European in origin.

Dunkel assumes that the suppletion between *í- and *e-/*ó- did not already exist in PIE, but was developed independently in several IE language branches. (p. 198).
Function of *e-/*ó- in PIE: anaphoric and substantival (p. 197).
Function of *í- in PIE: anaphoric (p. 372f.).
In Indo-Iranian, forms of the *í-pronoun extended with -ám developed a proximal deictic function (p. 372f.)
S.v. στεγνός 'dry', from Ancient Greek στεγνός 'watertight, waterproof' (as subst. τὸ στεγνόν 'covered dwelling').
S.v. στέγω 'to cover'. Ancient Greek στεγνός is a derived adjective from στέγω, ultimately from PIE *(s)teg- 'cover, roof' (cf. Lat. tegō 'to cover', OIr. teg 'house', OHG dah 'roof').

PIE *i-/e-/o-, anaphoric pronoun. Semantic specialization within the Indo-Iranian branch: IIr. *i-/a- < PIE *i-/e- developed into a proximal deictic pronoun, in the strong cases extended with -ám; whereas probably only IIr. *a- was used for distal deixis, in combination with the distal particle *u/au̯.

Dunkel argues against a laryngealic reconstruction, cf. especially pp. 96, 817. He proposes a spatial adverb PIE *au̯ 'away', out of whose zero grade the particle PIE *u 'there' might have been developed (p. 817, 822).
Identical to Ancient, NT, Modern άνθρωπος 'person, human being' /cognate/2373/.
S.v. SMG θωρώ, from Ancient Greek θεωρέω 'to be a θεωρός (spectator); to view, look, behold'.
Cf. s.v. SMG κοπέλα 'girl'.  Derived from Medieval Greek κοπέλι(ον) 'youth, boy, servant', originally a loanword from Albanian kopil 'illegitimate son; servant for hard work'.
= SMG κύρης 'father; husband; head of family'.  Derived from Ancient Greek adj. κύριος 'having power or authority over'.
Ancient Greek κύριος ultimately a derivative of PIE *k̑eu̯h₁- 'swell, be strong' via *k̑uh₂-ro- > *κῦρος.  Cf. Skt. śūra- 'hero'.

Concerning the Slavic forms: "The anlaut of the pronoun was apparently remodelled after the oblique cases. This must have occurred before the delabialization of ü, which was an allophone of /u/ after a preceding *j."
From *swī(s) which reflects the PIE acc. 2 pl. *us-we.

1. PIE *i̯ú- 'you', pronominal stem, 2nd person non-singular, only nominative, suppletive oblique stem *u̯ó-.
2. PIE *u̯ó- 'you', pronominal stem, 2nd person non-singular, oblique. Suppletive nominative PIE *i̯ú- 'you'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. žmuõ, žmuõj 'Mensch, Mann' (BSl. OPr. smoy 'Mann, Mensch'), from PIE *(dʰ)g̑ʰ-m-on- 'Mensch, Mann' (cf. Lat. homō, -inis 'Mensch, Mann', Osc. humuns 'Mensch', Umbr. homonus 'id.', Goth. guma 'Mensch, Mann', ON gumi 'id.', OHG gomo 'id.').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *mǫžь, from PIE *mon-g⁽ʷ⁾io- and to be connected with Sanskrit mánu- 'man, mankind' and OHG mann 'man, husband'.

S.v. mánuḥ 'Mensch, Mann, Menschheit', to be connected with Germanic lexemes via Goth. manna, OHG man, etc. and OCS mǫžь, etc. The cognates should thus be derived from one of the PIE *men- roots. However, due to several homophonous *men- roots reconstructable for PIE it is difficult to determine from which one exactly [cf. LIV²: 435-437].

S.v. OLith. mė́nuo (1), mė́nuoi (1), mėnuõ 'Mond, Monat' (BSl. Latv. mẽmesis 'Mond, Monat', mẽness 'id.', OPr. menig 'Mond', OCS měsęcь 'Mond, Monat', etc.), from PIE *meh₁nōt-, *meh₁nes-, *meh₁n̥s- 'Mond, Monat' (cf. Ved. mā́s-, A.sg. mā́sam, 'Mond, Monat' OAv. mā̊, YAv. mā̊, G.sg. mā̊ŋhō 'id.', Gk. μήν, G.sg. μηνός [Ion. μείς, Dor. μής] 'Monat, Mondsichel', Myc. me-no '(des) Monats', Arm. amis, G.sg. amsoy 'Monat', Alb. muoj (altgeg.) 'Monat', Lat. mēnsis 'Monat', Umbr. Abl.sg. menze 'Monat, Mond', OIr. mí, G.sg. mís 'Monat', MW mis, OBret. mis 'id.', Goth. menoþs, D.pl. menoþum 'Monat', mena 'Mond', ON mánaðr 'Monat', TochB meñe 'Mond, Monat'). The PIE word for 'moon' and 'month' would have been inflected as a t/s-heteroclitic in PIE.
S.v. *u̯reh₁- 'finden' (IEW 1160). Cf. also LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda s.v. *u̯reh₁-.
Cf. s.v. ?3.*men- 'emporragen' (IEW 726); verbal only Italic via *mn̥-h₁i̯é- > [Lat. ē-/prō-minēre 'heraus-/hervorragen'].

S.v. OLith. kálnas 'Berg' (BSl. Latv. kal̂ns 'Berg, Schloss, Haufen', etc.). Lith. kálnas and Latv. kal̂ns are o-grade formations to the same root as Lith. kélti, and may be accounted as though from PIE *kolHnós. With an n-suffix cf. Gk. κολώνη, κολωνός 'Hügel, Anhöhe, Stein-, Grabhügel', Lat. collis 'Hügel', OE hyll 'id.'. For Lith. kélti 'heben, erheben; sich erheben, auferstehen' (BSl. Latv. cel̂t 'heben, aufrichten, erheben, etc., OCS čelo 'Stirn', etc., from PIE *kelH- 'aufragen, hochragen' (cf. Gk. κελέοντες 'die Bäume des stehenden Webstuhls', Lat. prae-cellō, -ere 'hervorragen').
S.v. Lat. bucca 'puffed, filled out cheek; mouth'. Etymology unclear, possibly of Celtic origin.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ǫzъkъ 'narrow', from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-u- (cf. Skt. aṃhú-, Lat. angustus, Goth. aggwus).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *narwa- 'narrow'. Possibly (but not certainly) related to Latv. nãrs 'clamp'; if so, then possibly from PIE *neh₂r-ú-. No further etymology.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *nēhwa- 'near', a lengthened-grade adjective derived from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *blizъ, *blizъkъ 'near, close' (ESSJa II 121-122). An o-stem adjective from PIE *bʰlei̯g̑- 'to beat' (cf. Lat. flīgere 'hit'). Cf. the parallel semantic development of French près 'near' from Latin pressus 'squeezed' [cf. /cognate/1398/].
First attested in the Catholicon (1499). Loan from Medieval Latin animalium from Latin animalis.
Common Brittonic borrowing.

The word is attested from Middle Breton, Middle Welsh and Middle Cornish onwards. The sound changes found in the respective lexemes suggest that the borrowing took place earlier. i-affection in MW anifeil points to a borrowing before the loss of final syllables in the middle of the 6th century AD (Jackson, Language and History in early Britain 1953, 597, syncope lacking 652, see also Lewis & Pedersen 1961, 77). There are no attestations from this period, and the lexeme, the loanword status should be assigned to, is the reconstructed British *anevalium, which does not have its proper cognate class at present. All words listed in the present cognate class - belonging to the middle periods - are inherited.

Possibly from Syriac qəlāfā 'folium libri', qəlāfəθā 'cortex, squama, putamen mali granata'. Jahukyan (1987:482; 2010:398) suggests the form reflects PIE *(s)kel-. This is however phonetically problematic.
S.v. πετσί, from Medieval Greek πετσί(ο)ν < πέτσ(α)-ίον or *πεσκίον, diminutive of Hellenistic Greek πέσκος 'skin'.
S.v. πετσί, from Medieval Greek πετσί(ο)ν < πέτσ(α)-ίον or *πεσκίον, diminutive of Hellenistic Greek πέσκος 'skin'.
TochB 'sing, make sing', TochA hapax pis- 'blow (a musical instrument)' are probably related to OCS pěti.

S.v. TochB pi- G 'sing'; K 'make sing; blow (a musical instrument)', probably cognate with the TochA hapax pis- and to Proto-Tocharian *päy-, probably to be related to the otherwise isolated OCS pěti 'sing'.  For discussion, cf. {ref Adams 1982}:133.
Cf. s.v. TochB pi- 'blasen, trompeten', 'blow, trumpet', doubting the connections of Tocharian forms to Slavic on the basis of reconstructing semantics 'blow, trumpet', rather than 'sing'.

S.v. TochB yetse '(outer) skin', which with TochA yats reflect Proto-Tocharian *i̯ētse, which could possibly reflect PIE *h₁ēd-so- (*h₁ed- 'eat').  Terms for 'flesh' (what one eats) and 'skin' are frequently related in cognate languages, cf. {ref Buck 1949}:200-202.

S.v. TochB klänts- 'sleep', which with TochA klis- reflect Proto-Tocharian *kläns- and may be derived from PIE *klm̥H-s-, otherwise only found in Skt. klām(y)ati 'become tired, exhausted'.  Also semantically possible is a comparison with PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean' via an enlarged stem *k̑li-n-s-, but the enlargement of the stem *-n-s- is not well paralleled morphologically.

S.v. TochB klänts- 'schlafen', 'sleep', TochA klis- 'id.'. "The PT root shape is *klän(t)s-, TA shows i-epenthesis (cf. Hilmarsson, 1996, 142). According to Schneider, 1940, 203f., and Hilmarsson, 1996, 142f. the root is derived from *√k̑lei̯ 'lean', i.e. from a present *k̑li-n-, but this etymology would rather make us expect persistent (*)kly-. Adams, 1988a, 32, and DoT, 223, derives it from PIE *klm̥H-s-, with a cognate in Skt. klāmyati 'become weary' (not in ²LIV)."

S.v. TochB lykaśke 'small, lesser', which with TochA lykäly goes back to an original Proto-Tocharian stem *li̯äk- with different diminutive suffixes in either language.  Van Windekens suggested that PToch *li̯äk- may go back to PIE *legʷʰ- 'light (in weight)' (cf. Lat. leuis 'light'), but the lack of labialisation **lykw- in Tocharian is difficult to explain. More preferable is a connection with Gk. ὀλίγος 'few, small', Alb. lig 'bad, evil; thin' Lith. ligà 'illness', Latv. liga 'severe illness, pestilence', OIr. líach 'suffering, unfortunate'.
S.v. 3. *u̯er- 'beobachten, wahrnehmen' (IEW 1164). TochB warṣṣäṃ, TochA wräṣ 'riecht' (intr.) < ?*u̯r̥-sk̑é-.

S.v. TochB wärsk- 'smell', which with TochA wärsk- reflects Proto-Tocharian wär-sk- from PIE *u̯er- 'observe, pay attention to' (cf. Gk. ὁράω 'see', Lat. vereor 'honor, fear', Engl. beware, Latv. véru 'show, remark about').
S.v. TochB ṣmare (adj.) 'smooth, even, slippery; greasy'; (n.) 'oil', from PIE *smer(u̯)os (cf. ON smjǫr 'grease, butter', OE smeoru 'grease', OIr. smiur 'marrow').
S.v. TochB arṣāklo '(poisonous) snake'. Unknown etymology. TochA ārṣal is related to the TochB form in some way, but further details are obscure.
S.v. *snei̯gʷʰ- 'kleben bleiben' (LIV 573, IEW 974).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *gʷrensnā 'sun', *gʷrīns-/*gʷrenso- 'heat', derivatives from PIE *gʷʰer- 'be hot' (cf. Gk. θερμός, etc.).

S.v. TochB staukk- 'swell, bloat, be distended', probably from PIE *steu̯g- 'stiff' if to be connected with Balto-Slavic cognates (Lith. stúkti 'stand tall', Russian stugnuti 'to freeze' < *become stiff(?).
I have been unable to confirm the Balto-Slavic comparanda listed by Adams for this etymology (also not in LIV²).
S.v. TochB pälsk- 'bedenken, denken', 'consider, think', TochA päl(t)sk- 'denken', 'think'; a derived present in -sk̑e/o- to the same root as pälk- 'shine'. From IE *bʰle⁽g̑⁾- 'glänzen'.
S.v. TochAB säl- '(auf)fliegen', 'fly, arise', certainly cognate with Lat. salīre 'jump, leap', etc.

S.v. TochB (2) säl- 'throw, throw off, throw down; lay to rest [of the dead]', an inner-Tocharian formation to the same root as (3) säl- 'fly', which with TochA säl- reflect PToch. *säl- from PIE *sel- 'move quickly' (cf. Skt. ucchálati 'hurries forward', Gk. ἅλλομαι 'leap, jump', Lat. saliō 'spring, jump', etc.)
S.v. 1.*sel 'sich losschnellen, springen' (IEW 899).

S.v. TochB śänm- 'bind [something] (up/together), tie [something] into a bundle; bind [something] on; establish; proclaim; determine (rules); produce [of fruit]'. Of uncertain etymology, cf. entry for various uncertain proposals.

S.v. TochB stām 'tree', connected since Meillet (1916:383) [ref not in Adams's bibliography] with Proto-Germanic *stamma- 'treetrunk', Lat. stāmen 'warp',  Gk. στήμων 'warp', Skt. sthā́man- 'station, place' < PIE *steh₂-mn̥- '(something) standing'.
To PIE *kʷel- via a derived form *kʷl-eu̯-T-(sk̑e/o-) to account for Proto-Tocharian *kläutk- (cf. TochA lutk-).
Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-640).
S.v. *u̯lei̯kʷ- 'befeuchten' (Not in IEW).

S.v. TochB yel 'worm' which with TochA *wal (pl. walyi) reflect Proto-Tocharian *wi̯el- from PIE *u̯ēl(i)-, a derivative of PIE *u̯el- 'turn, twist' (Lat. uoluere 'roll, revolve', Arm. gelum 'turn', Skt. válati 'turns', vr̥ṇóti 'wraps, covers').
S.v. Arm. mēǰ 'the middle; (anatom.) 'back' < PIE *medʰi̯o- via PArm. *meidi̯o- through regular palatalization *-dʰi̯- > -ǰ- and anticipation of *-i- or development *-e- > *-ei- before a palatal.

S.v. Arm. hoł 'earth, ground, soil; burial, plot, cemetery' Since Meillet connected with OCS polje, Russ. póle, etc. 'field', Russ. pol 'floor', which are usually derived from PIE *pelh₂- 'wide and flat' (cf. Hitt. palḫi- 'wide', OHG feld 'field', Lat. plānus 'level, flat, plane, even', Lith. plónas, Latv. plãns 'thin, flat', etc.).
Cf. s.v. 2. *teh₂- 'tauen, schmelzen' (IEW 1053).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *pravъ adj. 'right'. If from *proH-uo-, then perhaps cognate with Lat. probus 'solid, decent' provided Lat. probus continues *pro-bʰ(u̯)o- and not *pro-bʰuH-o-. No further etymology.

Cf. s.v. pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft mit Abl.), specifically under the proposed formation *pró-o, *prṓ 'vorwärts, hervor; frühmorgens', to which perhaps might be connected Proto-Slavic ?*pra- 'vor' as a compositional prefix in e.g. OCS pradědŭ 'Vorfahre, Urahne', ]OCS pravŭ 'recht, richtig', Russ. pravyj 'rechts'.
For the Polish, Kashubian, Polabian and Belarusian forms: PIE *pro-sth₂o-.

Possibly related to Greek πρόμος 'vorderster, Vorsteher', Oscan promom 'firstly (= lat. prīmum)', Old Norse framr 'tauglich, gut, kühn, tüchtig', fram 'vorwärts, später, weiter', Gothic fram 'ἔμπροσθεν', fruma 'erster', OHG fruma f. 'Nutzen, Vorteil, NHG fromm, MHG vrum 'förderlich, tüchtig, rechtschaffen'.

Basically aligns with Vasmer's description.
Supposed semantic development for the Slavic forms: 'davor' -> 'offen daliegend' -> 'ehrlich', 'einfach'.

S.v. 1. *pér, *pérā̆, *pérām, *pérti- 'durch, darüber, hinaus, über; sehr' Adverb, lokal; oft mit. Akk. steigerndes Präfix. The Slavic forms rather are derived from PIE *per-mo- which is formed on the basis of PIE 1.*pér 'through', not PIE *pro.
OCS ravĭnŭ 'open' is derived from PIE *HoruH-ino- (< PIE *Hreu̯H-).
Child-language formation, is equivalent to SMG μάνα 'mum'.

S.v. OLith. sù 'mit' (BSl. OPr. sen 'mit', sēnku 'womit', OCS sъ, SCr. s, sa, Russ. s, so, Cz. s, se 'mit'). 

Proto-Balto-Slavic *sun (prep.) ~ *san- (pref.).
PIE 2.*sm̥- is a Neo-Nullstufe of PIE *so, *sóm 'together, with; same'. - cf. also for details on the different formations.
Slavic forms from PIE *sm̥ (cf. Skt. sám).

From the PIE Loc. Pl. *k̑s-sú 'in den Reihen' from the PIE noun *k̑as- 'Reihe, Folge'. The Loc. Pl. ending -su might go back to PIE *so, *sóm 'zusammen, mit, bei; gleich, derselbe', if it originally meant 'mitten in'. This would then entail partial cognacy on a higher level with /cognate/169/.

OHG firni, Gothic fairneis < *Proto-Germanic *fernija- 'old'; North Germanic forms with o-vocalism < Proto-Germanic *furna-. - Derivational basis Pre-Proto-Germanic *perno- whence also Latv. pę̃rns 'vorjährig'. PIE basis thus *perH₂-/*pr̥H₂-.

Cf. s.v. *pr̥-, *pró-, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft. mit Abl. and s.v. *pr̥h₂ó- 'vorne, daneben, vor', *pr̥h₂í 'vor; für', pr̥h₂ Adverb, lokal; oft. mit Abl., Lok. The Germanic forms may either go back to PIE *pr̥h₂-no- which is a nominal derivation based on the locative adverb *pr̥h₂-ó 'vorne, daneben, für', *pr̥h₂í 'vor; für', *pr̥h₂, or directly to PIE *pr̥-no- based on the zero grade *pr̥- of the PIE locative adverb *pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne'. This zero grade form *pr̥- in turn is the derivational basis of *pr̥h₂ó, *pr̥h₂í, *pr̥h₂.

S.v. Ved. purás (adv.) 'voran, vorne, nach vorn, davor' whence purāṇá- 'alt, vergangen', based on base *pr̥H-es/-os (cf. Gk. πάρος, 'vorher, vorn, früher, vor', πρέσβυς 'Alter, Angehörer des Ältestenrates, Vorsteher, etc., Goth. faur 'vor, langs – hin', faura 'vor, davor, vorne' OEng. fore 'vor', etc.).

Proto-Celtic *krundi-. Lucht discusses two possibilities, which ultimately derive this word from the PIE root *(s)ker- ‘to turn’/'drehen, biegen' (IEW 935ff.): 1. as a derivation of the extended root form *(s)kreu̯- (cf. IEW 938). 2. taken as *kr-undi with a suffix also found in e.g. Latin rot-undu-s. 3. De Bernardo Stempel 1999 proposed to view it as Proto-Celtic *kro-n-do- where a -do-morpheme was affixed to an n-suffixed root form.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hringa- 'ring, circle' as though from *kringʰ-o- (cf. OCS krǫgъ 'circle' < *krongʰ-o-). "An exclusively Slavic and Germanic root that is in violation with the IE constraint against the co-occurrence of plain stops and voiced aspirates. This makes it likely that its origin is to be found in the post-IE phase. Further cf. *hrungō- and - with irregular onset - *kringa-. Gr. κρίκος, κίρκος m. 'ring' is unrelated."
Makes the same connection as Kroonen 2013: 247 between the Slavic lexemes and Proto-Germanic *hringa- etc.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *krǫglъ 'round' (ESSJa XIII 23-24), an adjective in *-lo- derived to the same root underlying Proto-Slavic *krǫgъ 'circle' as though from PIE *krongʰ-o- (cf. OIc. hringr 'ring').
S.v. Ved. √śoc- 'leuchten, glühen, brennen', probably from PIE *k̑eu̯k-.
S.v. vákṣas- n. 'Brust'.  Etymology unclear.
Cf. s.v. ?*(s)krengʷ- 'sich krümmen, schrumpfen' (IEW 936). Verbal only Germanic, cf. OCS krǫgъ m. 'Kreis'.

5 PIE roots *(s)ker-: 1. *sker- as a basis for words meaning 'einschrumpfen, runzeln; rauhe Haut, Schorf, Kruste; vertrocknet, mager, verkümmert'; probably to 3. sker-. - 2. (s)ker-, skerə-:skrē- 'springen, herumspringen', "also and more accurately" '(sich) drehend bewegen, schwingen', "not to be separated from (s)ker- 'drehen'". - 3. (s)ker- 'drehen, biegen'. - 4. (s)ker-, (s)kerə-, (s)krē- 'schneiden'. - 5. (s)ker- onomatopoetic. - 
He derives OIr. cor, curu (acc. pl.) 'circles', Cymr. cor-wynt, Bret. cor-uent 'turbo' of the root 3. (s)ker- 'drehen, biegen'. For this root, Pokorny (p. 936) also gives the extended forms *(s)kreng- and *(s)kregʰ-, *(s)krengʰ-. Of the latter, he derives inter al. OIc. hringr, OE, OS, OHG hring 'ring' as well as OCS krǫgъ 'circle', Curch Slavonic kruglъ, okruglъ 'round'. On these cf. /cognate/2444/.

S.v. Ved. √śya- 'gefrieren, gerinnen, erstarren', to which Ved. śītá- is a derived past passive participle. Outside of Indic cf. Kati šə, Oss. syjyn / sujun, Yagh. ši-. Etymological connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not secure.

Proto-Celtic *krundi- 'round, compact'. Matasović favours the view that *krundi- is related to *krumbo- 'round, compact', as *krundi- < *krum-di-. He assumes that the PIE etymology for these words is "unknown", and that they thus might be loanwoards from a non-IE language.
LIV² does not refer to the IEW root 3. *(s)ker- 'drehen/biegen'/'to turn, to bend'.
S.v. Ved. √cakṣ- 'see, look at, observe' probably from PIE *kʷek̑- 'appear; see; show'.
S.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-639).  Vedic cakṣ- reflects a desiderative form *kʷek̑-s- / *kʷək̑s-.  (NB: -ə- in the zero-grade form is schwa secundum.)
S.v. Ved. kárṇa- 'Ohr', cf. YAv. karəna-, Khot. kārra- from Proto-Indo-Iranian *kárna- 'ear'.  Etymological connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not securely determined.

Cf. s.v. ghoṣ- 'klingen, ertönen, ertönen machen' (cf. Ir. *(-)gauš 'hören' in MPers. niyō(x)šidan, NPers. niyōšīdan, Parth. nγwš, Baluči niγōšaγ, Oss. qūsyn, etc.). The IE origins of PIIr. *gʰau̯š- '(ein Getön) hören' are not securely determined.

S.v. Ved. bhū́mi- 'Erde, Erdboden, Land' (cf. Pā. bhūmi- 'Erde', YAv. būmīm [acc.sg.], MPers., NPers. būm 'Land, Erde', BSogd. βwmh 'Welt, Erde', Chwaresm. βwm 'Erde', etc.), derived from PIIr. √*bhav- 'be, exist' < *bʰeu̯h₂-/*bʰu̯eh₂-.
Cf. s.v. *bʰu̯eh₂- 'wachsen, entstehen, werden' (IEW 146-150).
S.v. Ved. āṇḍá- 'Ei', perhaps to go back to a Proto(-Indo-Iranian?) form *ānd(r)á-.  The connection made by older literature with Proto-Slavic *jędro- 'kernel; testicle' remains worth consideration.
Skt. nanā́- f. 'mother' - "Lallwort", i.e. baby-talk or onomatopoetic.
Skt. NANA- 'mother' "nursery word".
S.v. *preu̯s- 'sprühen, spritzen' (IEW 809-10, 846).
S.v. OLith. šálti 'frieren' (BSl. Latv. sal̂t, OPr. passalis 'Frost', OCS slana 'Reif, Eisniederschlag' etc.), from PIE *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren'.
S.v. *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren' (IEW 551), cf. n1 comparing Ved. śíśira- 'kühl, kalt', YAb. sarəta- 'kalt', root noun in YAv. sarə-δā 'Kälte bringend'.
S.v. Ved. √śyā- 'gefrieren, gerinnen, erstarren', also found in Iranic (Oss. syjyn/sufun 'gefrieren', Yaghnōbī ši- 'frieren, gefrieren', etc.). Connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not certain.
S.v. ?*peu̯t- 'aufblasen' (IEW 848).  Only Baltic.
S.v. ?*peu̯k- 'hauchen, keuchen' (IEW 847).  Very doubtful reconstruction.  Cf. N1 'Verbal nur arm., wohl onomatopoetisch, kaum alt.' and n2 'Könnte auch denom. zu pʻowkʻ 'Hauch' sein'.
S.v. 5306 Skt. jválati 'burns brightly' TS. [~ jvárati. -- √jval]
Cf. s.v. *g̑u̯elH- 'brennen, flammen' (IEW 479).
S.v. 13952 Skt. haḍḍa- n. 'bone' lex.
S.v. 5005 Skt. challi- 'bark'.  Probably of non-Indic origin.
Cf. s.v. 11418 Skt. valkala- 'bark, bark garment (worn by ascetics)'.

S.v. Ved. valká- 'Bast, Rinde, Splint'; cf. Middle Indic and Prakrit vakka- 'bark'. Probably to be related to YAv. varəka-, Khot. bāggara-, Parth. wrgr, Sogd. wrkr, MPers. warg, NPers. barg 'leaf'. Perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre'.

discusses several possibilities of reconstruction and connection with other branches, not only Iranian on the one hand, but also Balto-Slavic on the other, and with more presuppositions also that with Arm. ełeamn 'hoar frost'.
s.v. ýnis (1), ỹnis (2) sm. 'hoar frost, frozen dew'. Apart from Balto-Slavic, the entry also connects Armenian ełeamn, G. Sg. ełeman 'hoar frost', but not the Germanic lexemes.

S.v. Alb. kruaj ~ kruej (aor. krova) 'to scratch', from Proto-Albanian *krābnja with a long grade of ablaut and to be connected to Alb. kreh ~ kref 'to comb' from Proto-Albanian *krebska, connected to Lith. grė́bti 'to rake', Slavic *grebǫ, *grebti* 'to row, to rake'.

Cf. s.v. *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 455) to which LIV² connects Lith. grė́biu, grė́bti), and s.v. ?*gʰrebʰ- 'graben' (IEW 455-6) to which LIV² connects OCS grebǫ, etc. Note that the Albanian forms are not listed under either lemma.
Proto-Germanic *krat-, which might be onomatopoeic.

The article for OHG krazzôn says that a verb *cratten has to be postulated for Middle Dutch and that Medieval Latin cratare, gratare, New French gratter, Provençal gratar, Italian grattare 'to scratch' are loans of this verb.
S.v. 8376 *pēṭṭa (2) 'belly', 2. *pēḍḍuka- . 3. *pōṭṭa- 2. 4. *pōtta- [similar words pēṭa-, *pēṭṭa- meaning 'basket' in Middle Indic / Prakrit which may be identical].

S.v. Ved. síkata- 'Sand, Kies, Grieß' not to be separated from Iranian cognates: OPers. θikā- 'Kies, Schotter', Khot. siyata, Sogd. šykth, Pashto šəga, səga 'sand', Oss. syǵyt/sigit, sik’it 'Erde', etc.
S.v. *gʰebʰ- 'fassen, nehmen; geben' (IEW 407-409). Not always easy to distinguish from *gʰeHb- 'ergreifen, nehmen' [cf. 'take' in /cognate/5345/].

Ved. sahá, OAv. hada, YAv. haδa 'together, with' < PIIr. *sadʰá < PIE *sm̥-dʰ- (zero-grade of PIE *sem-).  Avestan mat̰ 'together, with' = Vedic smat 'together, with' < *smat, based on *sm- (copulative prefix, from PIE *sem-).

S.v. OLith. tė́vas 'Vater' (BSl. Latv. tȩ̃vs 'Vater; ein alter Mann; Versorger', OPr. towis 'Vater'. The common Baltic word for 'father', which has replaced the inherited word from PIE *ph₂tér-. Two main hypotheses exist that might explain Proto-Baltic *tē-, either they either continue the suffixal part of PIE *ph₂tēr, or they could be based on a nursery word. Both hypotheses are conjectural.
onomatopoetic. Exists also in other Balkan languages like Serbo-Croat (nana) or Rumanian (nană).
Nursery word.
S.v. Ved. bī́ja- 'Same (des Mannes, der Pflanzen), Saat', cf. IIr. Buddh. Sogd. byz'k 'Saat, Same', Parāčī bīz 'Korn, Saatkorn', Old Iranian *bīza- in proper names. Further etymology unclear.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *staba- m. 'staff; letter', cf. also Gothic stabos m.pl. 'letters'. Possibly cognate with OIr. sab m. 'shaft, pole' and Lith. stãbas m. 'post'. < *stabʰ-o- "The correspondence of Celtic a with Baltic a points to original *a rather than *o."

Lith. stãbas I (4) sm. 'Götzenbild, Götze', Latv. stabs sm. 'Pfosten, Pfahl, Säule, Pfeiler' and Old Prussian stabis E 'Stein'.
PIE ?*stobʰ-ó- sm. 'Erstarren'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. smáugti 'würgen, erwürgen', from PIE *smeu̯g- 'ersticken', cf. OE smēocan 'rauchen, räuchern'. Outside of Balto-Slavic a similar root is found in words for σμῡ́χω 'lasse verschwelen', Arm. mowx 'Rauch', NIr. múch, MW mwg 'Rauch, Dunst' which seem to expect deviant forms like *(s)muHgʰ-, *muk- and this still requires an explanation.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *smeukan- ~ *smūkan- 'to smoke', from PIE *smeugʰ-e-(?). Cf. Gk. σμῡ́χω 'to burn up, smoulder away' < *smuHgʰ-e-; Lith. smáugti (smáugiu) 'to choke' < *smouHgʰ-ie-, Arm. mux, mxoy 'smoke' < *smoukH-o-; OIr. múch 'fire' < *smuHk-; MW mwg 'fire' < *smukH-. The underlying root is difficult to reconstruct; extra-Germanic evidence points to three different roots *smeuHgʰ-, *smeuHk-, and *smeukH-.
S.v. Lat. nūbēs, -is 'cloud', from PIE *(s)ne/ou̯dʰ- (cf. Welsh nudd 'haze', YAv. snaoδa- 'clouds').

S.v. OLith. rankà 'Hand' (BSl. Latv. rùoka 'Hand, Arm', OPr. rancko 'Hand', OCS rǫka 'Hand', etc.), an o-grade nominalisation from the same root as the verb riñkti 'suchen, lesen, wählen'. No clear connections outside of Balto-Slavic, for proposed connections in the older literature cf. IEW 1155.

S.v. ?*renk- 'auflesen, sammeln' (IEW 1155). Only Balto-Slavic. Cf. n1: An onset *u̯r- would be possible, there are, however, no specific indications for that. Lith. rankà = OCS rǫka 'Hand' are also derivatives of this root.
S.v. *kes- 'ordnen' (IEW 585).

Lithuanian taukaĩ could be explained as *tou̯h₂-kó- from PIE *teu̯h₂-. The other Baltic lexemes however are better derived from *teu̯k-. This root *teu̯k- would also be sufficient to explain OIr. tón 'bottom'. Thus taukaĩ either is a substantival Vrddhi-form, or we see in Baltic a contamination of two different, pre-existing forms *tou̯h₂-kó- and *tou̯k-ó-.

Cf. s.v. *teu̯h₂- 'schwellen, stark werden' (IEW 1080-1) and ?2.*teu̯k- 'stark/fett werden, schwellen' (IEW 1081). The nominal forms such as OCS tukъ 'fat', OIr. tón f. 'bottom' and Old Norse þjó 'thigh' are assigned to the latter. Latvian tauks 'fat' and OIr. tón both from *tŭknā-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tučьnъ 'fat, rich'. The Balto-Slavic lexemes presuppose PIE *tou̯Hk-o-, with the root *teu̯Hk- possibly being a contamination of *teu̯H- and teu̯k- or an extension of *teu̯H-.

S.v. Lith. taukaĩ 'fat' (Latv. tàuki 'fat', OPr. taukis 'lard'). The Balto-Slavic lexemes presuppose PIE *tou̯Hk-o-, with the root *teu̯Hk- possibly being a contamination of *teu̯H- and *teu̯k- or an extension of *teu̯H-. For  *teu̯H-, Derksen cites Serbo-Croat tȉti 'become fat' as a derivation. He regards the root form 2.?*teu̯k- postulated by LIV² as shaky, noting that Lithuanian tùkti was no evidence for a non-acute root.
S.v. *én 'in, drinnen; hinein' (local adverb). Cf. for different sub-derivations, also cf. p. 221 for an argumentation against initial *h₁-.
Cf. s.v. ?*sti̯eH- 'steif werden' (IEW 1010-1).  Only verbal in Indo-Iranian.  Cf. AGk. στέαρ 'hard fat', Germ. *staina- m. 'stone'; cf. Mayrhofer, EWAia II:762-763 s.v. √styā- 'fest werden'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hraini- adj. 'pure, clean'.  Kroonen takes the adjective to be a derivative from an unattested nasal-present *hrinan- 'sift, distinguish, decide', comparing Lat. cernõ, AGk. κρίνω 'separate, choose, decide' from *kri-ne-i̯e-.
Cf. s.v. *kreh₁(i̯)- 'sieben, trennen' (IEW 945-6).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *swimman- 'to swim, float'.  No good etymology outside of Germanic.

S.v. πόρσω 'forward, beyond, far away from something, away' and πρόσω 'forward, onward, further'. There are two possible etymologies for Ancient Greek πόρρω. One option is that it is identical with Lat. porrō 'forward' if < *p(o)rsō(d), with an ending like other adverbial formations ἄνω 'upwards', κάτω 'downwards'. Alternatively Chantraine (1968-1980) prefers to derived πόρρω from πόρσω (from πρότι, πρός, with metathesis) since both words have a similar sense semantically.
S.v. 1. *pér, *pérā̆, *pérām, *pérti- 'durch, darüber, hinaus, über; sehr' Adverb, lokal; oft mit. Akk. steigerndes Präfix.
S.v. 1. *lei̯p- 'kleben bleiben' (IEW 670-671).  The Germanic forms reflect an essive form *lip-h₁i̯é-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *bagma- 'beam, tree' < PIE *bʰh₂g̑ʰ-mo-.  The word is most likely related to PGmc. *bōgu- 'shoulder, upper arm) in OE bōg m. 'shoulder' < PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ-u- (cf. Gk. πῆχυς, Skt. bāhu- 'forearm', etc.). The widely spread idea that the word continues *baww-ma- and derived to PIE *bʰh₂u- 'to grow' is flawed because the original meaning 'beam' instead of 'tree', therefore the proposed connection to *bōgu- 'shoulder, upper arm' < PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ-u-.

S.v. Proto-Celtic s.v. *freswo- 'strong cold', which may be from PIE *preu̯s- 'freeze' (cf. Skt. pruṣvā́- 'drops of dew', Lat. pruīna 'hoarfrost', Goth. frius 'hoarfrost'), but one must assume a metathesis *-u̯s- > *-su̯- from earlier *preu̯s-o-.
S.v. 2. *(s)ker- 'scheren, kratzen, abschneiden' (IEW 933-5).

Cf. Proto-Celtic *rextu- 'rule, law' < PIE *h₃reg̑-tu-, root *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, to stretch' (LIV 304f.). In the following nouns: Oir. recht (u m.), MW reyth, ModW raith f. 'law, sermon, jury, verdict', MBret. rez, reiz 'law, rule, arrangement', MoBret. reizh m., Co. ryth 'sex, kind', Gaul. Rextu-genos PN, Celtib. retu-keno (Gen s, PN] (Bottorita III). All these nouns are used as adjectives as well. Cognate with Proto-Celtic *reg-o- 'extend, stretch'.
S.v. *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (IEW 438-9).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *gangan- ~ *gungen- 'to go', from PIE *g̑ʰóngʰ-e- (cf. Lith. žeñgti [žengiù] 'to stride' < *g̑ʰengʰ-ie-).
Cf. s.v. *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' (IEW 681-2).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hugi- 'understanding, mind', with denominal verb *hugjan- 'to think'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *rě̄kà- 'river', derived from PIE *h₃roi̯H- (cf. Lat. rīvus 'brook, stream', OIr. ríathor m. 'torrent').
Cf. s.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' [IEW 330-1].
S.v. Proto-Germanic *runi- 'run, stream', whence Goth. runs 'run, course', a derived i-stem to Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'run' < *h₃ri-n-H-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hwassa- adj. 'sharp', the original participle to PGmc. *hwētan- 'stab, pierce'.  K. mechanically reconstructs *kʷh₁d-to-, but cognates outside of Germanic are uncertain.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *braida- 'broad'.  No clear cognates outside of Germanic.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *owgro- 'cold' (adj.) from PIE *h₃eu̯g- 'cold' (cf. Arm. oyc 'cold', Latv. aũksts 'cold').

S.v. Lith. lẽdas 'ice, hailstone' (Latv. lȩdus 'ice'). No known cognates outside of Balto-Slavic to support a PIE form *ledʰus. Proto-Balto-Slavic *ledús may be reconstructed to account for the attested forms (cf. Proto-Slavic *ledъ 'ice').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ledъ m. 'ice'.  The PIE proto-form would be *ledʰ-u-s, but there are no known cognates outside of Balto-Slavic.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *þwahan- 'wash'.  Possibly connected with OPruss. twaxtan 'brushwood for bathing via a pre-form *tu̯ok-sto-???  No further potential cognates.
PIE *i̯uH- ~ *u̯ōs, *u̯os, *us-.
Cf. s.v. *k̑lei̯- 'sich anlehnen' (IEW 601-2).
Cf. s.v. biñgti 'mutig, stattlich, größer werden'. Latv. bìezs, bìežs may be derived from bʰ(e)ng̑ʰ-ú- (cf. Gk. παχύς).
S.v. *kʷels- 'Furchen ziehen, einfurchen' (IEW 639-40).
S.v. *deu̯k- 'ziehen' (IEW 220-1).
Celtic forms from PIE *kneh₂- 'bite, gnaw' (IEW 560).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *kǫsati 'bite' (ESSJa XII 65-66). In comparison to Baltic forms (Lith. ką́sti, Latv. kuôst) Proto-Balto-Slavic *konʔd-. If this Balto-Slavic is inherited, it would reflect a stem *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the BSl. acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾-.
