If this is so, then the root might be a nasalised variant of the root underlying Skt. khād- 'chew, bite, eat' and Arm. xacanem 'bite'.

S.v. Lith. ką́sti (3.sg. kánda), Latv. kuôst 'bite', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *konʔd- (cf. Proto-Slavic *kǫsati 'bite'). The Proto-Balto-Slavic root might be formally be accounted for from either PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾-.  This may have been a nasalised variant of the root *k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂d- found in Skt. khādati 'bite, chew, eat' and Arm. xacanem. Earlier proposed connections to Gk. κνώδαλον 'wild animal' and κνώδων 'sword, (pl.) teeth of a sword or a javelin' are unlikely due to formal difficulties (cf. Beekes 2010:279, 726-727).
S.v. ?*k⁽ʷ⁾h₂eg̑- 'verzehren' (IEW —).  Only Iranian and Armenian.
S.v. Ved. strī́- 'Frau, Weib, Ehefrau' (YAv. strī- 'Weib', etc.). The PIE etymology of PIIr. *(H?)striH- is not securely ascertained.
S.v. Ved. múkha- 'Mund, Gesicht, Antlitz'. No secure connections outside of Indo-Iranian.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'muzzle' > Old Frisian mūla m. 'muzzle, mouth'. Extra-Germanic connections are uncertain.
S.v. ?*skeu̯bʰ- 'stoßen, schieben' (IEW 955). Only Balto-Slavic and Germanic.

S.v. Hitt. partāu̯ar / partaun- (n.) 'wing, feather', to be connected to a root *per- (via a pre-form pr̥-T-u̯r/n-), which may be connected to Ved. parṇá- 'wing, feather' and Lith. spar̃nas 'wing' (with a different morphological suffix -nó-).
Cf. s.v. *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'hinken' (IEW 930).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *skinkan- ~ *skankan- ~ *skunkan- 'shank, ham', from *skéng-on- (cf. Gk. σκάζω 'to limp' < *skng-ie-, Skt. khañjati 'id.' < *skeng-e-). The Germanic forms reflect an ablauting n-stem from the PIE verbal root *skeng-.
*smerd- '(übel) riechen'.
S.v. OLith. spar̃nas 'Flügel' (BSl. Latv. spā̀rns 'Flügel', Fittich', OLatv. spārna 'id.'), from PIE *(s)por-nó- (cf. Ved. parṇá- 'Feder, Flügel, Blatt', YAv. parəna- 'Feder', OHG farn 'Farn').

"Gr. ὀπυίω besser mit J. Katz (Vortrag Kopenhagen Okt. 2009) mit ved. vapuṣyá- zu vergleichen (vgl. unten zu *u̯ep-), womit die Grundlage für den Ansatz von *h₃ entfällt (und die Reduplikation von ved. pupóṣa auch diachron völlig regulär wird)." Discounting Gk. ὀπυίω as cognate, reconstruction of initial *h₃- to the root is superfluous.

S.v. OLith. brìnkti 'anschwellen, aufquellen' (BSl. Sloven. nabrẹ́kniti 'anschwellen, aufquellen', Ru. brjáknut' (dial.) 'Wasser ziehen, im Wasser aufquellen', Pol. nabrzęknąć 'anschwellen, dick werden', from PIE *bʰrenk- 'anschwellen', (cf. ON bringa 'Brust').
No loanword, but inherited: The Brittonic words and Irish clúm *from Celtic *kʷluma.
Although Deshayes' suggestion is theoretically possible, it is not convincing. The supposed Celtic *kʷluma has no cognates outside Celtic, while Latin pluma does, cf. de Vaan (2003, 474).
Borrowed from Lat. pluma /cognate/999/.
S.v. Ved. ūrú- 'Schenkel, Oberschenkel'. Etymology outside of Indo-Iranian unclear.
S.v. Ved. vā́ma- 'link', presumably a euphemistic replacement from Ved. vāmá- 'lieb', similar to Gk. ἀριστερός 'left' (ἄριστος 'best').
Cf. s.v. Lat. pendō, pendere 'to weigh, pay', from which Lat. pensāre 'to weigh, weigh out' is a derived frequentative verb, from PIE *(s)pend-e/o- 'to spin'.
Cf. s.v. ?2.*(s)pend- 'spannen' (IEW 988).
Lat. creātūra is a derivative from Lat. creō ''create, beget', cf. crēscō 'be born, increase'.
Lat. crēscō < *k⁽ʷ⁾reh₁- 'become bigger, stronger'.  LIV² derives this verb from *k̑erh₃- 'to feed', but the position of the ablaut vowel is problematic for this identification.
Lat. creō, crēscō now to *k̑reh₁- 'wachsen'.  (Formerly assigned to LIV² *k̑erh₃-).
S.v. Lat. computāre 'sum up, reckon' > Fr. compter.
S.v. πέσκος 'skin, rind'. No clear etymology.

Cf. s.v. σῦκον 'fig'. Ancient Greek συκωτός is derived from Ancient Greek συκόομαι 'to be fattened with figs', a denominal verb from σῦκον 'fig', ultimately a loanword from an unknown Mediterranean source.  The date of the loan is obviously old, cf. Myc. su-za = Att. συκία 'fig tree'.
From Ancient Greek πρόσωπον 'face'.
From PIE *proti 'towards' + *h₃ekʷ- 'see'.
S.v. κόκκος 'kernel of fruits, especially of the pomegranate'. Etymology unknown.

S.v. ξύλον 'wood, timber', seems to correspond with Lith. šùlas 'post, pole, stave' < IE *ksulo-, Ru. šúlo 'garden-pole', SCr. šȗlj 'block' < *kseulo- (?). Germanic words like OHG sūl 'style, pole, Goth. sauls 'pillar' have a similar appearance, although the relationship between the Slavic, Baltic, and Germanic words have hardly been explained (cf. Lehmann 1986 s.v. sauls). A European substrate term?
S.v. πίμπρημι 'to blow (up), fan, kindle, burn up' << *pi-pr̥h₁- (with secondary epenthetic nasal). Ancient Greek πρήθω is a secondary present stem based on the same root.
S.v. *preh₁- 'anblasen, anfachen' (IEW 809).
Adjective derived from adv. πύκα 'dense, solid' (of unknown etymology).  Cf. entry for a rejection of earlier proposed connections to putative IE *puk̑- by Pokorny (IEW 849).
S.v. δασύς 'hairy; having a shaggy surface'.  Possibly related to Lat. dēnsus, but the exact reconstruction is problematic.
S.v. χρόνος 'period or course of time, (a definite) time, lifetime, time limit'. Etymology unknown, cf. entry for discussions of earlier but unconvincing attempts at an IE etymology.

Frequently connected to a common root *kʷu̯ap- or *kʷu̯eh₂p- uniting the Baltic forms with Lat. vapor 'vapour, steam' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:654, and Lith. kvė̃pti 'breathe' (cf. further discussion in /cognate/6321/), but due to several irregular sound changes necessary to justify the comparison, the etymology is not fully certain.
S.v. ὀμαλός 'equal, level, smooth'. Derived form from *sem-; *semh₂-l-. The root vocalism is usually considered to be analogical to ὁμός 'common, one and the same, equal, similar, level'.

S.v. ταῦρος 'bull' from IE *teh₂u-ro- 'bull'. Cf. Lat. taurus 'bull' Osc. ταυρομ (acc.sg.), Umb. turuf, toru (acc.pl.), Lith. tauras 'auroch' OPrus. tauris 'bison' OCS туръ, Russ. тур 'buffalo'. OIr. tarb 'bull' shows metathesis.

S.v.  χόνδρος (n.) 'grain, grain of salt, seed', from which χονδρός (adj.) 'granular, coarse'.  Etymology unexplained.  Older etymological connections with OE grindan 'grind', Lith. grę́sti 'shave, scour, scratch' Lat. frendō 'grind, gnash' require an initial labiovelar *gʷʰ- on the basis of Latin.  For the Greek forms to be connected one would require an ad hoc dissimilation of the labial element.
Cf. s.v. *lep- 'abschälen' (IEW 678).
S.v. ?*Ki̯eh₂p- 'verfaulen' (Not in IEW).
S.v. AGk. παχύς from PIE *bʰn̥g̑ʰ-ú- 'dense, thick', cf. Ved. bahú- 'many, much', OAv. bəzuuaitē (dat.sg.m.) 'dense', Arm. bazum (adj.) 'much', Hitt. panku- (adj.) 'total'.
S.v. SMG ξύγγι, from Medieval Greek ξύγγι(ον), from Hellenistic Greek ὀξύγγιον.
S.v. ὅμιλος 'throng, band of warriors, crowd', from which Ancient Greek ὁμιλέω 'be together, associate with (friendly or adversely), keep company, converse' is a denominal verb. No further etymology.
S.v. AGk. λαλέω 'to talk, chat, prattle' (Att.) 'to speak' (Arist., Hell.), probably of onomatopoeic or imitative origin, cf. Lat. lallāre, Lith. lalúoti, Germ. lallen.
Ancient Greek dialectal variants (Attic, Boeotian θάλαττα, Ionic, etc. θάλασσα) point to a pre-form *tʰálakʸːa, vel sim.
S.v. Hitt. šī- 'one', from PIE *sih₂, an old feminine form to *sem- 'one' which was later replaced by *sm-ih₂, (cf. {ref Beekes 1988}:79-81).
No generally agreed etymology ({ref Frisk 1960-1972}:64-66, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:609-610, {ref Beekes 2010}:817-818. For a recent attempt, cf. {ref Nikolaev 2010}.
Cf. s.v. AGk. ἵημι 'send (away), let go, throw', from PIE *(H)i̯eh₁-. Gk. ἄνεσις is an abstract noun (adv. ἀνα- + ἕσις) from the same root.
Cf. s.v. *Hi̯eh₁- 'werfen' (IEW 502).

Cf. s.v. ἀληθής 'true, real', from which Ancient Greek ἀληθινός 'true, genuine', is a secondary derivative. Originally an s-stem adjective with privative ἀ- which may be derived from the same root as the verb λήθω 'escape notice' < *leh₂dʰ- 'be hidden'.
Cf. s.v. ?*leh₂dʰ- 'verborgen bleiben' (IEW 651). Only Greek.

The etymology of ἀληθής as ἀ-ληθής 'not-forgetting' was considered already in antiquity (cf. Plato, Republic 614b – 621d).  While the connection to λήθω, λανθάνω 'escape the notice of' is semantically tempting, we should be nevertheless wary of a possible folk-etymology, especially given that there are no secure comparanda for the root *leh₂dʰ- outside of Greek.

S.v. TochB oko 'fruit; result, consequence'. Clearly related to Tocharian A oko, but the shape of the form suggests that one was borrowed from one language to the other rather than being true cognates. There are two possible etymologies: (1) to PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'grow, increase' (cf. TochB auk- 'grow, increase'), however this assumes that the TochB lexeme would be a borrowing from TochA, but it is difficult to see the B word being borrowed from A rather than A from B, which is far more often the case; more attractive is (2) that the word may be related to PIE *h₂ógeh₂- 'fruit, berry' (cf. Lith. úoga 'berry, cherry', Latv. uôga 'berry; pustule, pockmark', OCS (j)agoda 'berry', Ru. jágoda 'berry', and more distantly with Goth. akran 'fruit', ON akarn 'fruit of a wild plant', OE œcern 'acorn', NHG Ecker 'id.', Old Irish áirne 'plum', aeron 'fruit, berry'; The underlying verb survives in Arm. ačem 'grow'.
Cf. s.v. *h₂eu̯g-, to which Arm. ačem 'grow' is now connected following {ref Martirosyan 2010}:43.
S.v. Alb. dhjamë '(animal) fat, lard, suet, tallow', from Proto-Albanian *dzel-mā, which Orel relates to dhalle ~ dhalltë 'buttermilk' and in turn compares to Greek γάλα 'milk'.
S.v. παίρνω, from Medieval Greek ἐπαίρνω, a remodelled present stem from Ancient Greek ἐπαίρω 'lift up'.
S.v. ἀείρω 'to raise'.  No etymology outside of Greek, but internal reconstruction on dialectal variants and derived vocabulary point to a pre-form *h₂u̯er-.
S.v. SMG σέρνω, from Ancient Greek σύρω with regular development of /i/ > /e/ before /r/, and remodelled as a nasal present in -νω.

S.v. AGk. σύρω 'to draw, trail, drag, pull, ravish, sweep', probably with AGk. σαίρω 'sweep' if both reflect a root *tuer- 'sweep', in which σύρω reflects *tur-e/o- with analogical *σ- (rather than *tuor-e/o- with Cowgill's Law as per {ref Vine 1999a}:569ff.).
Cf. s.v. Arm. yoyr 'fat', if connected with gēr 'fat', then the both might reflect an older *u̯ei̯r-.
Northern Germanic forms with -nk- show same meaning as Middle Low Dutch denken 'think, remember', thus probably loan from Low German ("Ndd.").

S.v. Proto-Germanic *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke; to drift, fly'. A word without a generally accepted etymology. The connection with e.g. Lith. rū̃kas 'haze' and Lith. rokė̃ 'cloud of dust' {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:705-706 is unlikely as these may have been borrowed from Low German.

S.v. OHG flioga 'Fliege' and vb. fliogan 'fliegen', going back to a pre-Proto-Germanic root *pleu̯k-, also found in Baltic *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (Lith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, durch die Luft dahinfahren', etc., whose root also is to be connected to words for 'Haar, Flocke, Feder'. (cf. Lith. pláukas 'Haar, (Haar-)Farbe, Art, Gattung', Lith. plùnksna 'Feder', and probably also Lat. plūma 'Flaumfeder, Flaum'. This root is generally considered to be an enlargement of the IE root *pleu̯- with various meanings.
Cf. s.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837). An extension of *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7), only Germanic and Baltic.
Cf. s.v. *u̯ert- 'sich umdrehen' (IEW 1156-8), with OCS vraštǫ, vratiti etc. listed as a cognate.
S.v. 2.*u̯el- 'drehen, rollen' (IEW 1140-2); cf. 2. u̯elH- '(sich) wälzen, wallen' [IEW 1140-3].

S.v. ξύλον 'wood, timber', seems to correspond with Lith. šùlas 'post, pole, stave' < IE *ksulo-, Ru. šúlo 'garden-pole', SCr. šȗlj 'block' < *kseulo- (?). Germanic words like OHG sūl 'style, pole, Goth. sauls 'pillar' have a similar appearance, although the relationship between the Slavic, Baltic, and Germanic words have hardly been explained (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986} s.v. sauls). A European substrate term?

S.v. Proto-Slavic *mьrznǫti 'freeze' (ESSJa XXI 163-165), and related stems, cf. Proto-Slavic *mьrzěti 'freeze', a verb with the zero-grade of *morzъ 'frost'. Possibly a case of Winter's law, in which then *morzъ must be accounted for via *merg̑-o- (cf. Alb. mardhë 'frost').

Cf. s.v. Alb. mardhë 'chill, frost, ice', etymologically identical with Slav. *morzъ 'frost' (cf. Meyer 1891:260), both continuing *merg̑ʰ- 'to rot, to soak'. Derivative verbs: mardh 'to chill, to freeze', mërdhij 'id.'.

Cf. s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen' (IEW 652). Cf. n1: An alternative reconstruction for the root is *labʰ-, but in which case the Vedic forms exhibiting a nasal in the root would have to be a secondary innovation. [Baltic forms not connected in this entry.]

S.v. OLith. lãbas 'gut' (BSl. Latv. labs 'gut, vollkommen', OPr. labs 'gut, tüchtig', etc.). The common Baltic word for 'good'. Slavic connections are lacking. The proposed connection to Vedic rabh-, rábhate 'to seize, to grasp' / labh-, lábhate 'to get' and Greek ἀμφιλαφής 'comprehensive', λαφύρα 'haul, spoils' is only possible if the root form is *labʰ- (cf. LIV² 412n1 s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen').

S.v. Lat. plūma 'feather'. Probably a deverbal noun in *-mo- from *pleu̯- 'swim; float' or *pleu̯-k- with a root extension.  Lat. plūma could go back to a derived form *pleu̯-mo-, *plou̯-mo- or *pl(e/o)u̯-smo-, or to pl(e/o)u̯k-smo-, if the connection with OPruss. plauxdine 'feather bed', Lith. plùnksna 'feather' is accepted.
S.v. U.sp. cubrar. Perhaps a Proto-Italic primary adjective *kup-ro- (cf. Lat. cupere 'long for, desire, wish').  Identification made on basis of Varronian gloss ciprum 'bonum' (Varro 1.1.5, 159).

The contextual semantic identification of Umb. ařepes as 'FAT' is unclear, but it may be formally related to Lat. adeps. For the purposes of recording the possibility of formal cognacy I have assigned the Umbrian forms to this set, but have marked the Umbrian lexemes as 'non-Swh' in the Umbrian list.
S.v. U. nertru 'links', formally identical with Ancient Greek (ἐ)νέρτερος 'lower', cf. Arm. nerkʻin 'below'.
The Greek comparandum with initial ἐ- points to a root *(h₁)ner-. The Umbrian and Greek forms therefore reflect a comparative *(h₁)ner-tero-.

Cf. s.v. ἐσύ 'you (2.sg.). Εσείς 'you (2.pl.)' is a new formation within Modern Greek varieties: a new 2.pl. stem εσ- was abstracted from reanalysis of 2.sg. εσύ as εσ-ύ, with pluralising marker -εις taken from 1.pl. εμείς.
Cf. s.v. 10991 *laṣṭi- 'stick'. Perhaps originally a blend of Old Indic lakuṭa- 'club' and yaṣṭi- 'stick, pole'?
Cf. s.v. Ved. yaṣṭí- 'Stab, Keule, Stock', further connections uncertain.
S.v. Skt. laguḍaḥ 'Knüttel, Stock' / 'club'. Not convincingly explained.
S.v. 10875 Skt. lakuṭa m. 'club' Car.
S.v. Lat. grossus 'immature fig; thick, unripe'. Etymology unclear. IEW had earlier connected Lat. grossus with Welsh bras 'thick'.
S.v. Khot. heḍä, from *frā̆-bar-.

Cf. s.v. Lat. -cumbō, -ere, cubō, -āre 'to lie down, recline; be lying'. In Sabellic cf. Pael. incubat (3.sg.pres.), SPic. qupat (3.sg.pres.). As this root is only attested in Italic (Lat. cubō 'lie down') and Celtic (Middle Welsh kyscu, Middle Cornish koska, Middle Breton cousquet 'sleep'), it might not be reliably of PIE date.
S.v. ?*⁽k̑⁾eu̯bʰh₂- 'sich hinlegen' (IEW 590).
S.v. O. min[s (adv.) 'weniger', cf. O. minstreis (N.A.sg. of the comparative), probably to be derived from *minus (cf. perh. Goth. mins, Lat. minuere 'mindern').
S.v. Lat. minus 'less', minor 'smaller, less', from a u-stem derived from a nasal-infix stem of PIE *mei̯H- 'to lessen, diminish'; PIE *mi-n(e)-H- 'to make less' >> *min(e)-u-.
Cf. s.v. 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).
'Et. unbekannt'
S.v. κοβαλεύω 'to carry as a porter', a denominal verb from κόβαλος 'porter, transport worker'.  No known cognates outside of Greek.

S.v. Ved. √peṣ- 'zerstampfen, zermalmen, zerschmettern', from PIE *pei̯s- (cf. Gk. πτίσσω 'zerschrote, enthülse'. ἄ-πιστος 'unzerstampft', Lat. pīnsere 'zerstoßen', Lith. paisýti 'Grannen abschlagen, enthülsen'.
S.v. 8140 pāṣī́- (Sāy.), pāśī -- (Kauś.) f., gen. du. pāṣyṑḥ RV. 'stone, rock' & 8221 *piṣyatē ʻ is ground ʼ. [√piṣ].
S.v. *h₁erkʷ- 'strahlen, singen' (IEW 340). Pres. *h₁erkʷ-/*h₁r̥kʷ- > [khot. āljs- 'singen'.

S.v. Arm. erg 'song, poem', whence ergem 'to sing; to play a musical instrument' (cf. Ved. arká, 'ray (of light); praise; hymn, song'; arcati 'praises'; Hitt. arku- 'to sing', Toch.B yarke 'worship', cf. also OIr. erc 'sky, heaven'). The assumption that Arm. erg is a loan is improbable and unnecessary.
Cf. s.v. Ved. áṅgāra- 'Kohle', probably not to be separated from Lith. anglìs, OCS ǫngь 'Kohle'. Everything else remains questionable. Possible connection to agní-, but the details are unclear.
Cf. s.v. 125 Skt. áṅgāra- m. n. 'glowing charcoal'.

Cf. s.v. σπλήν 'spleen' of which Ancient Greek σπλάγχνα 'interior organs, intestines' is a derived form.  The word is similar to various IE words for 'spleen' Lat. liēn, Church Slavic slězena, Middle Breton felch, Sanskrit plīhan, Av. spərəzan-, but it is difficult to reconcile all forms to a single reconstructed form.

S.v. SMG ζερβός, from Medieval Greek *ζαβρός / *ζαρβός, with metathesis *-rv- > -vr- and raising of /a/ > /e/ / _r. The connection of ζαβός 'invisible' and ζερβός shows the popular perception of the left side as defective.
S.v. Standard Modern Greek γουλιά, a borrowing into Hellenistic Greek from Latin gula 'throat, gullet'.
Cf. s.v. Skt. khúraḥ 'Huf / hoof', probably a Dravidian word, cf. Tel. korije, gorije, gorise, Kan. gorasu, gorise = Drav. *kŏr- 'Huf' with typical Dravidian variants (Burrow BSOS 9, 718; 12, 376).
S.v. Arm. krak 'fire', some proposed Indo-European etymologies, but most likely an Iranian loan; cf. Persian kūra 'fireplace; furnace'.
Cf. s.v. Skt. caṭakaḥ 'Sperling / sparrow', probably of onomatopoeic origin. Similar words in Dravidian (cf. Kan. ceṭṭi 'Sperlingsweibchen, etc.'.

S.v. AGk. ἴσος 'equal' in number, strength, size, status, etc. (dial. Arc., Cret. Boeot. attests ϝίσϝος). Formally, earlier *u̯itˢu̯o- would work, but the proposed connection to a zero-grade *ϝιδσ- from εἶδος 'shape' is hypothetical. Other proposed etymologies are unconvincing.
S.v. ἴσος 'égal, en nombre égal, également partagé, égal en droit'. The original structure of the word ϝίσϝος is certain, but the etymology is not established.
From Ancient Greek ἑστία 'hearth, fireplace'.
S.v. ἑστία 'hearth, fireplace, altar'. No clear etymology.  Identified in antiquity with Lat. Vesta 'goddess of the hearth', but there is not a satisfactory Indo-European etymology linking the two.
The Tsakonian forms must reflect a Doric lexeme φύσκα 'large intestine' (cf. Att. φύσκη, which would have yielded **φύσκη [ˈfiski] in SMG).
From Medieval Greek κατ(α)- + αχν(ία) < Ancient Greek ἄχνη 'anything that comes off the surface; foam, froth' or Medieval ἀχνάς.
Cf. s.v. τέμνω 'cut' derived to PIE *temh₁- 'cut'.

For Tsakonian κορνιαχτέ, Italiot κουρραθτό, cf. Standard Modern Greek  κουρνιαχτός, from Ancient Greek κονι-ορτός 'dust raised or stirred up, cloud of dust' (for ὀρτός, cf. ὄρνυμι 'stir up' < *h₃er-).
Cf. s.v. ModGk. σκόνη, from AGk. κόνις, -εως, connected with Lat. cinis, cineris, cf. also κονιορτός.
Cf. s.v. AGk. χαίρω 'to rejoice', with related i-stem noun χάρις 'grace', from PIE *g̑ʰer(H)- 'desire, enjoy'.
From Ancient Greek (Hellenistic) τρανός, remodelled as an o-stem from earlier τρανής 'clear, distinct'.
Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear, distinct, definite, sure', from PIE *tr̥h₂-n- from PIE *terh₂- 'pass through, cross'.
Standard Modern Greek αδρός 'sizable, stout' from Ancient Greek ἀδρός 'thick, stout, bulky'.
Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek ἀδρός 'thick, stout, bulky', derived from ἅδην (adv.) 'to one's fill', which is in turn a derivative of PIE *seh₂- 'satiate'.

S.v. θολός 'mud, dirt, ink of the cuttlefish'.  No clear etymology. Sometimes connected with some Germanic terms for turbidity of the mind (OS for-dwelan 'neglect, forsake', OHG gitwelan 'be deafened, linger', which may be further connected with a Celtic word for blind (cf. OIr. dall), but it not clear whether these IE forms are cognate.
From Ancient Greek ἀ-κάθαρτος 'un-cleansed'.
Cf. s.v. καθαρός 'clean, pure'.  No etymology.

Standard Modern Greek φτιάχνω 'do' from Medieval Greek φτειάνω with the velar [x] introduced into the present stem from the aorist φτειάξα (i.e. *φτειάκνω > φτειάχνω with regular development of / k / > [x] / _n).  The original present φθειάζω is a de-adjectival verb in -ζω from Ancient Greek εὐθεῖα (fem. of εὐθύς 'straight, direct; straightforward').
NB: Pontic, Tsakonian, Cappadocian reflect a remodelled nasal-present ευθειάνω [e̞fθiˈano̞] without the intrusive velar from the aorist stem, as found in the SMG form.
S.v. Ved. chāyā́- f. 'Schatten; Widerschein, Abbild' < PIE *sk̑eh₁-i̯éh₂- (cf. Gk. σκιά, Alb. hije, TochB skiyo 'Schatten').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *sěnь 'shadow', from PIE *skoHi-n(-i)- (cf. Skt. chāyā́-, 'shadow, reflection', Gk. σκιά 'shadow'. Alb. hije 'shadow').
s.v. 1.*mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).
s.v. *maiwa- 'slim, narrow'.

S.v. AGk. ἀλείφω 'to anoint with oil' with related *mn̥-stem neuter noun ἄλειμμα 'unguent, fat, oil'. Ablaut variants in related vocabulary within Greek point to a lexical root *h₂lei̯bʰ-, but there are no known cognates outside of Greek. Older hypotheses attempting to connect to *lei̯p- 'stick' are untenable.
S.v. 7341 Lat. rīvus 'Bach', 2. rīus.

S.v. Lat. rīvus 'small stream, brook, channel', from PIE *h₃riH-uo- 'whirling' (cf. MIr. rīan 'river, sea' < *reino-, Skt. rī́yate 'to flow, whirl', riṇā́ti 'to make flow, run', Gk. ὁρίνω 'to whirl, stir', Ru. réjat' 'to stream fast, flow', OEng. rīð 'stream, brook', OHG rinnan 'to drip').

Cf. s.v. Lat. cavus 'hollow, excavated, concave, deep (of water)', from which Lat. cavāre 'to make hollow' is a de-adjectival verb. Lat. cavus may be derived from PIE *k̑ouH-ó- 'hollow' (cf. OIr. cúa 'hollow', Bret. keo, kev 'cave' < PIE *k̑ouio-; Gk. pl. κόοι 'hollows, excavations, gaps, crevices, gorges' (Hesych.) < *k̑óu̯o-, Gk. κοῖλος 'hollow').
S.v. ἀήρ 'mist, haze, clouds', later 'air, atmosphere', from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er-.
S.v. *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7).
Cf. s.v. SMG χώνω, from Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'heap up, raise, fill with earth'.

S.v. χώννυμι 'to heap up, raise, stuff with rubbish or earth'. The present stem of the verb χώννυμι and the derivative χῶμα 'heap, rubbish, dam, wall' are built from the aorist stem χῶσαι, which replaced the unclear form χέαι, from χέω 'pour' < *g̑ʰeu̯-, or alternatively a contracted denominative or intensive *χοῆσαι to χέω.
Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰeu̯- 'gießen' (IEW 447-8).
S.v. Modern Greek ρέμα, from Ancient Greek ῥεῦμα 'that which flows'.
Cf. s.v. ῥέω 'flow' from PIE  *sreu̯- 'flow'.
Loan from Latin lardum, possibly via Medieval Greek λαρδίον.
Loanword from French jambe 'leg'.
Loanword from Turkish kelle 'head'.
Loanword from Venetian rozza 'stone'.
Loanword from Italian alata
S.v. *melh₃- 'hervorkommen' (IEW 721-722).
S.v. *kreu̯s- 'stoßen' (IEW 622).
Cf. SMG κρούω 'hit' from Ancient Greek κρούω.
Cf. s.v. SMG βέργα, a medieval loanword from Latin virga 'twig, bough, branch'.

From Ancient Greek συλλογίζομαι 'reckon, compute' ({ref Andriotis 1974}:526), from συν- 'with' + λογίζομαι 'count, reckon' a denominal verb in -ιζω from Ancient Greek λόγος 'computation, reckoning', and o-grade noun from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' ({ref Beekes 2010}:841, cf. {ref LIV²} 397, {ref IEW} 658).
From Medieval Greek ὀψές, with final -ς taken on analogy to (ε)χτές 'yesterday', from Ancient Greek ὀψέ 'a after a long time, at length, late'.
Ancient Greek ὀψέ from PIE *h₁op-s- (*h₁ep- 'on'), cf. Lat. ops- 'towards' in compounds, e.g. obs-tendō.

Cf. s.v. SMG βράζω, from which βραστός is a derived verbal adjective, further from Medieval Greek βράζω 'boil' (cf. SMG βράζω 'boil (water)'), from Ancient (Hellenistic) Greek βράζω 'boil, froth up',  Classical Attic βράττω, Ionic βράσσω 'shake violently, agitate, boil (up)'.)

Cf. s.v. βράσσω 'to shake violently, agitate, boil (up), winnow'; older proposals perhaps to Latv. murdēt 'boil up', Lith. mùrdau, mùrdyti 'etwas im Wasser rüttelnd behandeln', but this is uncertain. No secure etymology.
S.v. OLith. pẽlenas 'Asche; Herd' (BSl. Latv. pȩ̀lni 'Asche', OPr. pelanne 'Asche', pelanno 'Herd'). Different etymological connections are considered:

S.v. Lith. kartùs 'bitter' (OPr. kārtai 'bitter'), Baltic forms to be connected to Lith. kir̃sti 'hew, sting, cut, strike' from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut', (cf. Proto-Slavic *kortъkъ 'short' in OCS kratъkъ, etc.).

S.v. OLith. júodas, -à (3), júodas -a (1) 'schwarz' (BSl. cf. Latv. juõds 'Waldteufel, böser Geist, Teufel'), cf. Lith. juodàsis 'Teufel'. The Proto-East-Baltic word for 'black' is etymologically isolated. Proposed connections with Lith. jùsti 'sich regen' are phonologically difficult and from a semantic point of view not close.

S.v. OLith. káulas 'Knochen, Bein' (BSl. cf. Latv. kaũls 'Knochen; Stengel, Kern', OPr. caulan 'Bein, Knochen', etc.; IE cf. Gk. καυλός 'Stengel, Stiel, Schaft, Lat. caulis, -is 'Stengel, Stiel, OIr. cúal 'Reisigbündel'). The words of the related languages may go back to PIE *keh₂ul(o)-; further analysis of the word-formation within PIE is less clear.
S.v. Lithuanian káulas 'bone' < PIE *keh₂u-ló- (cf. Gk. καυλός 'stem, pole', Lat. caulis 'stem (of a plant), plant, cabbage', OIr. cúal 'faggot, bundle of sticks').

S.v. OLith. dègti 'brennen, in Flammen stehen; brennen, anzünden, verbrennen' (BSl. cf. Latv. degt, OCS žešti, etc.), from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'verbrennen' (cf. Ved. dah-, dáhati 'verbrennen', YAv. daž-, dažaiti 'verbrennt', Alb. djeg 'verbrennt', Lat. foveō. -ēre 'wärmen', TochA tsāk- 'aufleuchten, leuchten', TochB tsäk- 'verbrennen', tsāk- 'aufleuchten, leuchten').

S.v. OLith. nèšti 'tragen, ertragen' (BSl. cf. Latv. nest 'tragen, bringen', OCS nesti 'tragen', etc.), from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'erhalten, nehmen' (cf. OAv. 1.pl.aor.subj. nāšāmā 'tragen', Gk. aor. ἐνεγκεῖν 'bringen', TochB eṅkastär, eṅktär 'ergreifen, nehmen').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *nesti 'carry, bring' (ESSJa XXV 19-23), from PIE *h₁nek̑- (cf. Lith. nèšti, Gk. ἤνεγκον [aor.]).

Cf. s.v. OLith. krūtìs 'Brust' (BSl. Latv. krùts 'Erhöhung, Hügel, Hümpel, Hümpel auf der Weise', etc.), to be connected with the same root at OLith. kráuti 'laden, zusammentragen, aufeinanderschichten; bewahren, behüten' (BSl. Latv. kŗaũt 'häufen, laden, packen', OCS kryti 'decken, bedecken, verbergen, hüllen', etc.). The Balto-Slavic forms can go back to an IE root *kreu̯H- 'aufhäufen, bedecken', but further connections are not very clear. Often compared is the Germanic strong verb *hreu-da- 'bedecken' found in OE hroden 'bedeckt, geschmückt', etc. continuing an original *-dʰe/o- present (cf. LIV² 371).

S.v. Lith. krūtìs (Latv. krùts 'hill, heap, breast'), the root is the same as the zero-grade of Lith. kráuti 'heap, pile', from PIE *kr(o)uH- (cf. OE hrēodan 'cover'), perhaps to be more precisely analysed as *kreh₂- if further connected with Latv. krât 'collect, save, stack'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. plóti 'zwei Flächen aufeinanderschlagen, klatschen, in die Hände klatschen', derived adj. plónas 'dünn, schmal, fein' (BSl. Latv. plât 'ausbreiten, platt machen', plâns 'flach, eben; dünn, schwach', OPr. plonis 'Tenne'), derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'flach, breit'.

S.v. Ved. √sā- (~ √say-) 'binden, festbinden, fesseln' (cf. IIr. OAv. ā-hišāiiā 'hält gefesselt', YAv. hiiąn 'sie binden', from PIE *seh₂-, pres. *sh₂-i̯-éti (Ved. syáti ~ Hitt. iš-ḫi-an-zi 'sie binden'); from the i-present *sh₂-i̯- apparently *sih₂- (s. Ved. sināti) arose.

S.v. Hitt. išḫai-/išḫi- 'to bind, to wrap; to obligate with, to impose upon' (Anatolian cogates cf. CLuw. ḫišḫii̯a- 'to bind', HLuw. hishi- 'to bind'), generally connected with Skt. sā-, si- 'to bind', Lith. siẽti 'to bind'. "The exact reconstruction of the root is difficult, however: e.g. Oettinger (1979a: 461) reconstructs a root *seh₂-, LIV a root *seh₂(i)- and LIV² a root *sh₂ei- [sic, in fact it's *sh₂ei̯-]. Apparently there is no consensus whether or not the -i- is integral part of the root." Kloekhorst sets up PIE *sh₂-ói-ei, *sh₂-i-énti to account for the Anatolian forms.
Cf. s.v. ?*seu̯k- 'drehen, winden' (IEW 914).  Only Balto-Slavic cognates.
S.v. OLith. sùkti 'drehen; verdrehen, lügen'.

S.v. OLith. šlãpias 'nass' (BSl. Latv. slapjš 'nass', SCr. slȍta, slotà (dial.) 'feiner Regen mit Schnee', Russ. slotá (dial.) 'Matschwetter, Schneeregen', Pol. słota 'schlechtes, regnerisches Wetter'), from PIE *k̑lep- 'nass, feucht' (cf. Gk. κλέπας 'something wet' (Hesych.), OIr. clúain 'meadow, pasture').

S.v. OLith. bérnas 'Junge, Bursche, Knecht' (BSl. cf. Latv. bḕrns 'Kind; Tierjunges, Schlössling von Pflanzen'), a derived noun from PIE *bʰer- with parallel semantic development to that of Goth., ON, OHG barn 'Kind'.
Cf. s.v. Lith. bérnas 'fellow, lad, hired worker' (OLith.) 'child, boy', from PIE *bʰer-no- (cf. Goth. barn 'child', OIc. barn 'id.', OHG 'id.').

S.v. OLith. vaĩkas 'Kind, Knecht' (BSl. cf. OPr. waix 'Knecht'), a regular o-grade secondary τόμος-formation to Lith. veĩkti 'handeln, wirken, machen, tun'. Lith. veĩkti itself is to be derived from PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'sich durchsetzen, überwinden' (cf. Lat. vincō 'besiegen'. OIr. fichid 'kämpft', Goth. weihan 'kämpfen', ON vega 'kämpfen, töten', OHG wīg 'Kampf').
Cf. s.v. 2. *u̯ei̯k- 'überwinden, besiegen' (IEW 1128-9).

Cf. s.v. OLith. píepala 'Wachtel (coturnix coturnix)' (BSl. cf. Latv. paîpala 'Wachtel; junges Mädchen', OPr. penpalo 'Wachtel', SCr. prèpelka, Ru. pérepel, Cz. přepel (dial.) 'Wachtel'); probably also connected to OPr. pepelis, Acc.pl. pippalins 'Vogel'. No etymological connections outside of Balto-Slavic.

S.v. OLith. kvė̃pti 'atmen, hauchen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kvêpt 'qualmen, rauchen', etc.). These lexemes are probably not to be separated from Lat. vapor, -ōris 'Dampf, Dunst', Gk. καπνός 'Raum, Qualm, Dunst', continuing a root *kʷu̯ap- or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-. Improbable is an etymological connection with Goth. afƕapjan 'ersticken', etc.
S.v. OLith. nãgas 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf' < PIE *h₃nógʷʰ-/*h₃n̥gʷʰ- 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle'.
S.v. OLith. eĩti 'gehen, kommen', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (cf. Ved. ay- 'gehen', OAv. aē- 'gehen', Gk. εἶμι 'gehen', Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', etc.).

Cf. s.v. OLith. skaitýti 'lesen, zählen' (derived noun skaĩčius, skaičiùs 'Zahl, Anzahl'; BSl. cf. Latv. skàitît 'zählen, rechnen'), from PIE *(s)kei̯t- 'bemerken' (cf. Skt. cetáyati, -te 'erkennen', cs. '(sich) zeigen').
S.v. *kʷei̯t- 'bemerken, erkennen' (IEW 637).
S.v. *reu̯dH- 'schreien, weinen' (IEW 867).

Cf. s.v. OLith. raudóti 'klagen, wehklagen, heulen' (BSl. cf. Latv. raûdât 'weinen, beweinen', OCS rydati, etc.), from PIE *reu̯dH- 'weinen' (cf. Ved. rod⁽ⁱ⁾-, róditi; OAv. rud- (3.sg. raostā) 'weinen', OLat. rudō, -ere 'schreien, brüllen', OHG riozan 'heulen, weinen, trauern', roz 'das Weinen').

S.v. Ved. √rod- 'weinen, beweinen' (cf. IIr. OAv. raostā 'weint, klagt, jammert', YAv. urūδaiiaṇt-), from PIE *reu̯d-H (athematic root present *réu̯d-H-ti/*rud-H-énti), cf. OLith. rausti 'weint', Lat. rudō 'schreie, brülle', OE rēotan 'klagen, weinen', Lith. raudà 'Wehklage', etc.).

S.v. OLith. ver̃kti 'weinen' (BSl. cf. Latv. ver̂šêt, ver̂kšķêt 'weinen, still weinen; schreien (Kinder und Ferkel), SCr. vríštati 'schreien, kreischen, winseln', ORu. vrěščati, vereščati 'schreien, weinen (Säuglinge), jammern', etc.). No known cognates outside of Balto-Slavic.
S.v. OLith. pjáuti 'schneiden, mähen, ernten, schlachten, töten' (BSl. cf. Latv. pļaũt 'mähen, ernten,; schlagen', etc.). IE root etymology debated.
S.v. *pi̯eh₂- 'schlagen' (Not in IEW).

Cf. s.v. Old Lithuanian liáuti 'aufhören, aufhören zu sündigen; Buße tun' (BSl. cf. Latv. ļaũt 'erlauben, zulassen'; OPr. aulāut 'sterben', Ukr. livýti 'nachlassen', OCz. leviti 'lindern'; IE cf. Goth. lewjan 'verraten', OE lǣwan 'id.'). The Baltic forms find the best generally agreed connection with Germanic lexemes, but further connections are disputed. The IE root identification for these forms is less clear, perhaps a u-stem to *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen' (so LIV² 399), perhaps alternatively a root *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' with laryngeal metathesis.

S.v. OLith. darýti 'machen, tun' (BSl. cf. Latv. darît, 'tun, machen', derivative with an o-grade root from the word family from Lith. derė́ti 'abmachen, verhandeln, sich einigen, sich verpflichten, sich verloben' (Latv. derêt), from PIE *dʰer- 'fest machen' (cf. Ved. dhar- 'festhalten, stützen', OAv. dar- 'festhalten', OPers. dar- 'besitzen, haben', Lat. ferē (adv.), fermē (adv.) 'ungefähr, nahezu, fast', firmus (adj.) 'stark, fest; dauerhaft, beständig').
S.v. *dʰer- 'befestigen, fixieren' (IEW 252-3).

Cf. s.v. OLith. sègti 'heften'. Old Prussian seggīt might be connected to the Old Lithuanian form, and if so from PIE 1. *seg- 'heften' (LIV² p.516, IEW 887-8), but the connection of the Old Prussian forms to the Old Lithuanian ones is not entirely clear.

Cf. s.v. Old Lithuanian šė́kas 'Gras, Heu' (BSl. Latv. sȩ̂ks 'frisch gemähtes Gras als Viehfutter', OPr. schokis 'Gras', from PIE *k̑éh₁k⁽ʷ⁾o- 'gemähtes Gras, Heu' (cf. Ved. śāka- 'Küchenkraut, Gemüse', ONor. há 'Grummet, zweite Mahd'). The transmitted form of the Old Prussian lexeme is unexpected. Sch- does not correspond to Latv. s- as is the vowel o to Lith. ė, Latv. ȩ̂. The dependability of the IE reconstruction is impaired by these uncertainties in the Old Prussian form.

S.v. OLith. kíetas 'hart, fest' (BSl. Latv. ciêts, ciêss 'hart, fest; streng'). The Baltic material is traditionally connected with SCr. cȉtī 'genauso, gleich, zusammen', but there is no secure further comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic.

S.v. OLith. slė̃pti 'verbergen, verstecken, verheimlichen' (BSl. Latv. slèpt 'verbergen, verheimlichen, hehlen; heimlich, im Verborgenen gehen'. No clear etymology outside of Baltic. Often considered is a connection to *klep- '(heimlich) stehlen, verbergen' found in Gk. κλέπω 'stehle (heimlich), hintergehe', Lat. clepō, -ere, Goth. hlifan 'stehlen'. This root can be continued in OPr. niauklipts 'unverborgen'. Formally the East Baltic lexemes may continue *slep- (cf. also *slìpti 'schleichen, sich unbemerkt bewegen').
S.v. Old Lithuanian mótė 'Frau, Ehefrau'.  The original r-stem in Old Lithuanian from PIE *meh₂ter- 'mother' has been remodelled as a i-stem in the modern language.
S.v. OLith. krẽklas 'weibliche Brust' (BSl. cf. OPr. kraclan 'Brust'). No clear comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic.

S.v. OLith. gėlė̃ 'Blume'. Etymologically isolated.  Traditionally connected with words for 'yellow' (gel̃sti 'become yellow') which are in turn often considered to be reflexes of PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow', but this root identification is uncertain due to the unexpected initial velar / g / (cf. žélti 'grünen, sprießen' < *g̑ʰelh₃- where the correspondence of *g̑ʰ- > ž- is lautgesetzlich).

S.v. Old Lithuanian žíedas 'Blüte, Blume' (BSl. cf. Latv. ziêds 'Blüte, Blume; Geschenk, Gabe, Spende, Opfergabe; Angabe, Steuer'. An o-grade derivation with the semantics of a τόμος-derivative to Lith. žydė́ti 'blühen'. Etymologically isolated; Lith. žievė̃ , Latv. zievis 'Baumrinde' deviates too strongly to be certain of a root etymology. No reliable comparanda outside of Baltic.

S.v. OLith. butà 'Gebäude, Haus, Wohnung' (BSl. OPr. buttan 'Haus'). Lith. butà, bùtas, and OPr. buttan are not to be separated from Proto-Celtic *butā- 'Haus' (OIr. both 'Hütte', MW bod 'Wohnsitz, Haus'). This exclusively Baltic-Celtic lexeme doubtlessly belongs etymologically to Lith. bū́ti 'sein' (< PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'wachsen, entstehen, werden'), but the nouns have a short vowel in contrast to the verb. The short vowel, however, is not unexpected in Celtic and it is suggestive that the word might be a loanword from a continental Celtic dialect into Proto-Baltic. A further possible Celtic loanword into Proto-Baltic is kárvė 'Kuh'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. grū́sti 'stampfen, stoßen, härten', (BSl. cf. Latv. grûst 'stoßen, stampfen', SCr. grȕda 'Scholle, Klumpen', Ru. grúda 'Haufen (Steine), Stoß (Holz)', etc.) From PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'zerstoßen, zerstampfen' (cf. ON grjót 'Gestein, Geröll', grautr 'Grütze', OE grēot 'Sand, Kies', etc.).

S.v. OLith. *skríeti 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen' (BSl. Latv. skrìet 'laufen, rennen, fliegen', with closest possible cognates found in OCS krilo 'Flügel' (etc.). Clear comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking.

S.v. OLith. šlaunìs 'Hüfte, Oberschenkel', from PIE *k̑lóu̯ni- (cf. Bed. śróṇi- 'Hüfte, Hinterbacke', YAv. sraoni- 'Hinterbacke, Hüfte', Lat. clūnis 'Hinterbacke, Hinterkeule, Steiß', Middle Welsh clun 'Oberschenkel, Hüfte, Hinterbacke', Bret. klun 'Hinterbacke, Gesäß', ONor. hlaunn 'Hinterbacke, Steiß').

Cf. s.v. levis 'light in weight' from PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light', which has been remodelled as an i-stem *leχwī̆- in Proto-Italic.  Lat. levāre 'to relieve, lessen, lift up' is a derived verb from this adjective.
S.v. Lat. filius 'son'.  Italic forms reflect an l-stem *dʰ(e)h₁i-l- 'sucking, child', which was later thematised in Proto-Italic as *fīlio/ā- 'son, daughter'.
Cf. Albanian kopil, Medieval Greek *κοπέλι(ον) /cognate/5836/, etc.
S.v. Lat. sūgō, -ere 'to suck', from PIE *seug-e/o- (cf. OE sūcan 'to suck').
S.v. Lat. focus, -ī 'foyer (domestique, demeure des dieux Lares, Penates)'.
S.v. Lat. mansio 'aufenthalt, unterkunft' > Fr. maison.
S.v. Lat. maneō 'to remain in the same place' < PIE *mn̥-eh₁-, (*men- 'stay') from which Lat. mansiō 'staying, lodging' is derived.
From Lat. iēcur fīcātum 'fig-stuffed liver'.

S.v. Lat. pēdis 'louse', from PIE *pesd- 'annoying insect' (cf. PIIr. *pazdu- 'beetle, maggot' : Skt. pedú- PN, paídva- 'the snake-killing horse of Pedu', 'an insect harming horses', YAv. pazdu- 'beetle, maggot').
Fr. viande from Lat. vīvenda (vīvō 'live').
S.v. Lat. strictus 'eng', whence Fr. étroit.
Cf. s.v. Lat. *granica.

S.v. Lat. grānum 'grain, seed', from PIE *g̑rh₂-no- 'which has ripened, fruit, grain' (√*g̑erh₂-), to be connected with Celtic, Iranian, Baltic, Slavic, and Germanic words for grain (cf. OIr. grán, W. grawn, Co. gronen, Bret. greun, 'grain' < PCl. *grāno-, Pashto zaṇai, zaṛai 'kernel, seed', OPr. syrne 'grain', Lith. žìrnis, Latv. zir̃nis 'pea', OCS zrъno, Ru. zernó, SCr. zȑno 'grain' < BSl. *źirn-, Go. kaurn, OHG korn 'grain' < PGmc. *kurna-).
Cf. s.v. 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *maiwa- 'slim, narrow', from PIE *moiH-uo- (cf. TochB maiwe 'young', derived from the PIE root *meiH- 'diminish' (cf. PGmc. minniz 'less').
S.v. *krakk-.
S.v. Lat. coxa 'hip' > Fr. cuisse
S.v. Lat. coxa 'hip of a human, haunch of an animal', from PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' (cf. OIr. coss 'foot', Skt. kákṣa-, Av. kaša- 'armpit', ToB kakse 'midriff loins').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *habanō- 'harbor' < *kap-óneh₂- (cf. OIr. cúan 'port, harbor' < *kap-ono-). The standard etymology connects it to ON haf, OE hæf, OFri. hef, MLG haf, MHG hap 'sea, lake' < *haba- < *k̑h₂p-ó- and *hafjan- ~ *habjan- 'to lift' < *k̑h₂p-ie-.
Cf. s.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-8). Cf. n1 suggesting that the root is probably onomatopoetic, so perhaps also an a-containing root *kap-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kawno- 'port, haven', from PIE *kHp-no- 'take' (cf. Lat. capiō, OHG havan 'haven'). The formation of this word with the suffix *-no- is an exclusive Germanic-Celtic isogloss.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯anH- 'to call', from PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' (cf. Ved. svan- 'to sound', Lat. sonere, sonāre, 'to sound, ring', sonus 'noise, sound', OE swinn 'music').
S.v. *su̯enh₂- 'tönen, klingen' (IEW 1046-7).
Cf. s.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-7).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *malan- 'to grind', from PIE *mólh₁-e- (cf. Hitt. mallai- ~ mallanzi 'to grind' < *mólh₁-ei, *mlh₁-énti; Lat. molō, -ere 'id.', Arm. malem 'to crush', Lith. málti (malù), Latv. mal̃t 'to grind' < *mólh₁-ei; OCS mlěti 'id.', Ru. molót' (meljú), SCr. mljȅti 'id.', OIr. meilid 'id.' < *melh₁-ie-; Skt. mr̥ṇā́ti 'crush, grind' < *ml-néh₁-).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dьlgъ adj. 'long' < PIE *dl̥h₁gʰ-ó-, (cf. Skt. dīrghá-, Gk. δολιχός).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic langa- 'long', identical to Lat. longus 'long', a nasalised version of the PIE root *dlh₁gʰ- 'long'. "The adjective thus implies a nasal present *dlénh₁gʰ-e-, which, however, is not attested."

Cf. in LIV addenda and corrigenda – Neu: ?2.*delh₁- 'verlängern' (IEW 194‑6), Präsens ?*dl̥h₁-éi̯o- aksl. (+) pro-dьľǫ, -dьliti 'verlängern' (Anm. 1 Verbal nur slav. (primär?), Basis vieler Nomina, z.B. aruss. dьlja ‘Länge’ und v.a. die Adj. *dl̥h₁-gʰó- in ved. dīrghá- = av. darəga-, aksl. (+) dlъgъ sowie *dolh₁-i-gʰo- > gr. δολιχός neben *dolh₁-u-Ki- > heth. daluki-, alle ‘lang’; *h₁ wegen gr. ἐν-δελεχής zu einem neugebildeten *δέλεχος n. < *délh₁gʰos, vgl. Stüber 172-4 mit Lit.).
S.v. Lat. crassus 'thick', whence French gras and related words in Romance.
S.v. Lat. crassus 'thick', of unclear etymology. Cf. entry in de Vaan for a discussion of older, unconvincing proposals.
Does not deem connection of Latin grossus (s:) 'immature fig', (adj:) 'thick, unripe' with Welsh bras 'thick' likely.

Proto-Celtic *brasso- 'great, violent'. Matasović considers this to go back to a PIE root *gʷred⁽ʰ⁾-, possibly the same as Lat. grossus, but de Vaan (2008:274) does not find this connection to be likely.
S.v. Lat. *coacticāre > Fr. cacher.
S.v. Lat. horridus 'scheusslich' > Fr. ort 'sale'.
S.v. Lat. caecus 'blind', from *⁽k̑⁾eh₂i-ko- and to be connected with with OIr. cáech 'one-eyed', coeg 'empty', W coeg-dall, OCo. cuic 'one-eyed' < PCl. *kaiko-, Goth. haihs 'id.'.
S.v. Lat. gula 'throat, gullet', probably of onomatopoeic origin.
S.v. *botan- (anfrk.) 'stossen, schlagen' > Fr. bouter.
PS *debelŭ is derived from PIE *deb- / *dob- and related to PS *dobrŭ ['good'].
Loanword from Latin (via) strata 'paved (road)'.
Ancient Greek ῥάμμα 'anything sewn or stitched', a derivative from ῥάπτω 'sew' /cognate/1533/
S.v. AGk. τρανής 'clear, distinct, definite, sure' from *tr̥h₂-n-, with verbal derivative τρανόω 'make clear, plain, distinct' a derivative from τρανής (PIE *terh₂- 'pass, cross').
S.v. AGk. ἀνανοῶ 'wieder bedenken' > Kapp. ἀνανοῦμαι.

S.v. AGk. νόος 'mind, sense, intellect, reason; purpose, aim', from which νοέω 'to mediate, observe, think, devise, have in mind' is a denominal verb. Νόος appears to go back to an old o-grade verbal noun (cf. λόγος, φόρος, etc.) but there is no certain etymology outside of Greek.
Cf. s.v. AGk. χῡλός 'juice (of plants), gruel, broth'; traditionally connected with χέω < PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'pour', but the long-stem vowel -ῡ- is difficult to account for.
S.v. AGk. ἀνασθμαίνω 'schwer atmen' > Pontic ἀνασμαίνω 'atmen, Luft schöpfen'.
S.v. ῥοΐζω 'ein Pferd in die Schwemme führen' > Pontic ροΐζω (1) trans. 'werfen' (2) intr. 'fallen' (3) krank werden, (4) kommen.
Cf. s.v. *συμπιάζω (AGk. συμπιέζω) 'zusammenpressen' > Pont. συμπιάνω.
Cf. s.v. δεῖσα 'Schmutz, Schlamm, Nässe' with semantic development to 'Nebel' in Pontic.
Cf. s.v. AGk. δεῖσα 'slime, filth'. Unknown etymology. {ref Solmsen 1909}:236f. connects the word with OCS židъkъ 'succosus, ὑδαρός', and Ru. žídkij 'thin, fluid, slim'.
Etymology unknown.
S.v. AGk. ῥάχις 'spine, backbone' > Pontic ρασ̌ί(ν).
χτηνόν from Ancient Greek κτῆνος 'animal (for pasturing)', cf. κτάομαι 'procure, acquire'.
Ancient Greek κτάομαι < PIE *tkeh₁- 'rule, gain, acquire'.
S.v. AGk. σκία 'Schatten' > Cypriot and Italiot οσ̆σ̆ιά related to Ancient Greek σκία (cf. also s.v. the AGk. diminutive σκαδίον).
S.v. AGk. κωφίας > Cypriot κουφή 'eine Schlangenart'.
S.v. AGk. πιέζω 'to press, push, beset'. Of uncertain etymology.
The same as 'white' /cognate/1565/ in other Modern Greek varieties.  The meaning as ash was a secondary semantic shift from 'white' > 'white ash' > 'ash' in Italiot Greek (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Cf. s.v. AGk. χλιαίνω 'to warm, soften', from PIE *g̑ʰlei̯(d)- 'gleaming, clear' (cf. OIr. glé 'clear, evident', MW gloew 'liquid, clear' < *g̑ʰloiuo-, ON gljá 'to shine, gleam' MHG glīmen 'to lighten up, gleam', Lith. žlejà 'darkness, twilight, dusk', which point to a root *g̑ʰlei̯-.
S.v. AGk. ὀξύς 'scharf, spitz' > Cal. οσ̌σ̌εία 'Gebirge'.
Greek: Italiot ῥοδινός is a derived adjective in -ινός to Ancient Greek ῥόδος 'rose'. The derived form ῥόδινος 'pink' already in Hellenistic Greek (–Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
S.v. AGk. ῥάβδος 'Rute, Stab' > Tsakonian σ̌άμντα.
S.v. Medieval Gk. ραπίς (cf. AG adj. χρυσόρραπις ‘with a golden stick’) > Cal. ραμίδα, with contamination from Lat. ramus.
Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak', of unknown etymology.
Cf. s.v. AGk. ἰσχίον 'Hüftgelenk, Hüfte' > Tsakonian ίσ̌α 'Rücken'.
S.v. AGk. ἰσχίον 'hip-joint, haunches'. No etymology.
Tsakonian κουβάνε < Ancient Greek κύανος
S.v. κύανος name of a dark blue substance, 'enamel, lapis lazuli, blue copper carbonate' (cf. Myc. ku-wa-no).  Perhaps an early loan from Hittite kuu̯anna(n)- '(blue as) copper, ornamental stone'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. *καρπίδιον dim. of AGk. καρπός 'fruit' > Tsakon. καμπζί (& Prop. Ts καβγί).
Tsakonian παρίου < Ancient Greek present ptcp. παριών of πάρειμι.
S.v. AGk. βοῶ 'schreien' > Tsakon. βου 'shout'.
S.v. AGk. βοάω 'to cry', there are some possible comparisons but it is probably onomatopoeic.
Cf. s.v. AGk. ἵστημι; > Tskaon. τ̔αίνου.
S.v. AGk. ἐσχάρα 'hearth, house, sacrificing hearth'. Without etymology. There are no known cognates in other IE languages and the word may well be borrowed from a substrate languages.
S.v. AGk. νοῶ 'wahrnehmen, erkennen, begreifen' > Tsakon. νoίου νοιούκʻου 'hören'.
Tsakonian ογί < ΑG ὡδί < ὧδε.
Tsakonian ίκ̔ου < Ancient Greek ἴσχω (< *si-sg̑ʰ-e/o-).
S.v. ΑGk. τύπτω 'schlagen, stoßen' > Tsakon. τύφου.
S.v. AGk. κύπτω 'sich vorwärts neigen, sich bücken' > Tsak. τ͡σι̬ούφτω 'schlafen'.
Cf. s.v. ΑGk. αἴρω > Tsakon. αζ̌ίκ̔ου (=*αρ-ίσκω).
S.v. AGk. ἀνεμῶ 'aufblasen, aufblähen' > Tsakon. ανεμούκ̔ου 'dem Wind überlassen, wegwerfen'.
S.v. AGk. ἐκκλύζω 'ausspülen, auswaschen' > Tsakon. κσ̌ύζου.
Cf. s.v. Gk. κλύζω 'to wash (away), clean', from PIE *k̑luH-, *k̑leHu- 'wash, purify'.
Tsakonian ψαίνου < AG ψαίω.
Etymology unclear, probably substratum.
Cf. s.v. AG ἑσπέρα 'evening' > Tsakonian επ̔έζ̌ι. [Database: επ̔έζ̌ι; printed as ἐπ‛έρι in Andriotis 1974]

S.v. Proto-Celtic *(s)kītto- 'left, clumsy'. Possibly to be connected with Lat. scaeuus, Gk. σκαιός < *skh₂ei̯-u̯o-, however in order to account for the Celtic forms one must assume a zero-grade *skh₂it-and 'expressive' gemination > *skh₂i-tto- which makes this etymology somewhat speculative.

S.v. Lith. kairỹs 'left' and Lith. kreĩvas 'crooked, curved, wrong'. The Balto-Slavic evidence could continue a PIE basic form *krei-uo- for Lith. kreĩvas (cf. Proto-Slavic *krivъ 'crooked, bent'), but there is little external evidence supporting a reconstruction outside of Balto-Slavic.

Cf. s.v. OLith. girià 'Wald, Wüste, Wildnis' (BSl. Latv. dziŗa 'Wald', dzire 'id.', OPr. garian 'Baum', OCS gora 'Berg', etc.), from PIE *gʷorH-, *gʷr̥H- 'bewaldeter Berg' (cf. Ved. girí- 'Berg, Hügel, Anhöhe', YAv. gairi- 'Berg, Gebirge', Gk. βορέας 'Nordwind, Norden', Alb. gur 'Stein, Fels').
S.v. Lat. mergō, -ere 'to plunge, immerse', from Proto-Italic *mezge/o-, from PIE *mesg-e/o- 'to sink, wash' (cf. Skt. májjanti 'to sink, plunge under, Lith. mazgóti, Latv. mazgât 'to wash').
S.v. Lat. runcō, -āre 'to grub up (plants), weed', from PIE *h₃ru-n-k- 'to dig out' (cf. Skt. luñcati 'to pluck' (ep.), Gk. ὀρύσσω 'to dig, grub').

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *kweϸan- 'to say' < *gʷét-e- (IE?). Possibly comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite' < *gʷot-ie-(?), although this verb can be reconstructed differently and is conspicuously similar to Arm. gočʻem 'to shout' < *u̯okʷ-ie- (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:811).
S.v. ?*gʷet- 'sagen' (IEW 480-1).
S.v. Lat. pāngō, -ere 'to beat, strike; mourn, bewail', from nasal-present stem *ph₂-n-g̑- to PIE *peh₂g̑- (cf. Skt. pajrá- 'solid, firm', pā́jas- 'surface, face', Gk. πήγνυμι 'to attach, to join').
Cf. s.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *lītila- 'small'. The derivation of the word is problematic, and the radical alternation in the closely related OE lȳt, OS lū̆t, MHG luz 'few' *līt- ~ *lūt-, *lutt- remains unexplained. Until this alternation has been resolved it will be difficult to find a good etymology.
S.v. OHG luzzi 'klein, winzig, gering' in other Germanic languages corresponding to OS lut 'wenig', OE lyt 'wenig, klein' if the vowel in both is short.
S.v. Lat. plānus 'flach, eben' > Fr. plain.

Cf. s.v. Lat. plānus 'level, flat', from PIE *pl(e)h₂-nó- 'flattened' (PIE *pleh₂-), cf. Hitt. palhi-, pahlai- 'wide, broad' < *plh₂-i-, OPr. plonis 'threshing floor', Lith. plónas 'thin', Latv. plãns 'flat, even, thin' < *pleh₂-no-.
Spanish, Portuguese esse <  Lat. ipse  < *so-pe-so (de Vaan s.v. ipse).
S.v. Lat. *mukyare (gall.) 'verstecken'. Of Celtic origin, cf. OIr. múchaim.
S.v. Lat. fissum 'gespalten' > Fr. fesse.
S.v. Lat. findō 'split' < *bʰi-n-d-, from PIE *√bʰei̯d- 'split'.
S.v. *handjan- (anfrk.) 'beißen', a loan from Germanic *handjan-, cf. aignier (1366) 'mordre'.
S.v. Lat. *nōdicare 'knüpfen'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. nōdus 'knot'. Possibly from PIE *nōdo-, *noHdo-, or *neh₃do- (cf. OIc. nót 'net'). The root etymology is uncertain and an analysis as a loanword is also possible.
S.v. *kseu̯- 'schaben, schleifen' (IEW 586).  Attested as a verbal root in only Greek, but cf. (fn1) *ksu-ró- *'scraper' → 'razor' in Ved. kṣurá- m. 'razor', AGk. ξυρόν n. 'razor'.

S.v. Hitt. peru / perun- 'rock, cliff, boulder', generally assumed from PIE *pér-ur / *pér-un- (cf. Skt. párvata- 'rocky, rugged; mountain' < *pér-u̯n̥-to-) with dissimilation of final -r in the nom.sg. form.

S.v. Hitt. (UZU) šiššai- 'body part of animals (bear, lion, leopard, šāša-). "We have to conclude that the ši(e)ššai is a body part of bears, šāša-s, lions and leopards, but it is not totally clear what body part is referred to. Perhaps we have to assume that here 'tails' are meant that have to be plaited together (which would explain 'unite them'; see also s.v. šumumaḫḫ-)." Semantics, and therefore etymological identification, rather uncertain.
S.v. Lat. quirītāre 'kreischen' > Fr. crier.

Cf. s.v. Lat. laxus 'spacious, wide, loose', from PIE *sl⁽g̑⁾-so- 'weak, faint' (cf. Lat. langueō < *sl-n-g̑-u-, Skt. ślakṣṇá- 'slippery, meagre, thin', Gk. λάγνος 'lascivious, voluptuous', OIc. slakr, OS slac, OE slæc 'weak, floppy').
Cf. s.v. hurnai-, hurniya- 'spray, sprinkle'.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. ḫarna- / ḫarn- 'to sprinkle, to drip (trans.), to pour'. The stem would formally reflect *h₂r-ne-h₂/₃-ti, *h₂r-n-h₂/₃-enti, but there are no convincing cognates.
Same stem as Hitt. apa- 'that'.
S.v. *kleu̯b- 'stolpern, hüpfen' [IEW 630]; cf. n1 *kleu̯p- with 'hardening' (Verhärtung) in certain contexts, partially paradigmatically generalised.
S.v. *(s)prengʰ- 'springen' (IEW 998).
S.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' (IEW 330-1).
Turkic languages have tunman 'cloud, darkness'. This is in turn probably orginally borrowed from Avestan dunman- 'fog' (/lexeme/27734/), dvąnman- 'cloud'.

The communis opinio is that the relationship between the lexemes in /cognate/5058/ and /cognate/8269/ have irreconcilable root reconstructions and must be separated into *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂- and *s⁽k̑⁾eh₃-. Cognacy has been thus assigned in this manner according to the main etymological authorities. 

The reconstruction of two separate roots, however crucially hinges on the interpretation of the Greek evidence: Germanic lexemes from PGmc. *skadu- < *s⁽k̑⁾H-tu- appear to be a close parallel formation to Greek σκοτός 'darkness' which reflect earlier *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-tó-.  These are potentially different roots, but this is based entirely on the witness of the Greek evidence.  In any case, the difference is based on disagreement over root-final *h₂ vs. *h₃.  The identity of the laryngeal in σκία < *skh₂-ih₂ is assumed from Att.-Ion. σκηνή, West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́ 'tent' < 'cloth to provide shade' < (transponat) *skeh₂-néh₂ (cf. Beekes 2010, s.v. σκία).  In Ancient Greek does exist another example of a doublet of root-final *h₂ vs. *h₃, namely the dialectal doublet of Attic-Ionic πρῶτος 'first' (ostensibly from *pr̥h₃-to-) against West Greek πρᾶτος 'first' (ostensibly from < *pr̥h₂-to-), cf. Ved. pūrvá- 'first' (formally from *pr̥H-u̯ó-).  One could imagine there may have been some inner-Greek phonological or derivational reason to account for the discrepancy in vocalism.

It seems therefore very possible, in view of the phonological and semantic similarities, that the Tocharian, Greek, Albanian, Indo-Iranian, and Balto-Slavic lexemes in /cognate/5058/ and the Celtic and Germanic lexemes (+Gk. σκότος) in /cognate/8269/ go back to the same root etymology with differing derivational morphology. Cognacy has been coded, however, according to the prevailing opinion.

Without etymology.  Puhvel rejects IEW's proposed connection of Hitt. ku(wa)ttar, kūttar 'strength, power, force, mainstay; back of neck, scruff, top of shoulders' with Lat. guttar 'throat' as semantically and formally implausible.
de Vaan (2008:276-277) s.v. guttar also rejects connections of Hitt. kuttar with Lat. guttar on account of a poor semantic match between the lexemes.

Etymology uncertain. Puhvel suggests a possible connection to a "quasi-onomatopoeic root *lab(h)- seen in Gk. λαφύσσω, λάπτω, OE lapian 'lap, slurp, swig, quaff', Arm. lapʻem, Alban. lap, Lat. lambō, OHG laffan 'lick, etc.".

Cf. s.v. Hitt. šani- 'the same, one and the same' (within Anatolian cf. HLuw. sanawa/i- (adj./n.) 'good/goods', sanawazi- (adj.) 'good', sanawastar- 'goodness'. Etymology unclear.  Perh. to PIE *sem 'one', but this identification is formally difficult.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. keššar / kiššer- / kišr- 'hand'. Hittite kiššar- reflects forms reflect an original r-stem from PIE *g̑ʰes-r-. The forms found in the Luwic subgroup, CLuw. īš(ša)ra/i-, HLuw. istra/i- and Lyc. izre/i- reflect a secondarily thematised form (as though from) *g̑es-r-o-, from Proto-Anatolian *g̑es-r- 'hand'. CLuw. išarili(a)- (adj.) ‘of the right hand (> favourable)’ is a derived adjective.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. aiš / išš- 'mouth', from PIE *h₁eh₃-es- (cf. within Anatolian: CLuw. āaš- 'mouth', āaša- 'to speak(?)', HLuw. ásaza- 'to speak'; elsewhere in IE: Skt. ā́s-, Av. āh-, Lat. ōs, OIr. á 'mouth').
S.v. Hitt. tetana- c. 'Haar', possibly a nursery word with reduplication.

S.v. OLith. tìnti 'schwellen', from PIE *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (cf. Ved. tan- 'spannen, ausbreiten', Gk. τείνω 'spanne, dehne aus', τιταίνω 'id.', Alb. nden 'breitet aus, spannt aus', Lat. teneō, -ēre 'halten', MW tannu 'Ausbreiten, Aufspannen', Goth. ufϸanjan 'ausdehnen', OHG donēn 'hingestreckt sein').
Cf. s.v. *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (IEW 1065-6).

S.v. OLith. lýgus 'eben, gleich, ähnlich' (BSl. Latv. lĩdz 'gleich, ebenso wie, zugleich, mit', OPr. a.sg. līgan 'Gericht', a.sg. lijgan 'Urteil', līgint 'richten'), the most likely connection within IE to Germanic lexemes from Goth. leik 'Körper, Leib; Leichnam, Fleisch', swaleiks (adj.) 'solch', leikan 'gefallen', ON lík 'Körper, Gestalt', líkr 'gleich, ähnlich', OHG līh 'Körper, Leichnam', līhhōn 'ebnen, glätten', etc. The forms could then be considered derivatives of a root *lei̯g- 'gleich'. Cf. entry in ALEW for further discussion.

S.v. OLith. *skrìsti 'kreisen; rund machen, runden' with derived noun apskritìs 'Kreis'. The nominal forms with dental suffixes were backformed to a root *skrit- to which belong the verbs *skrìsti and Lith. skríesti 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen' (with secondary e-grade). The the closest possible comparisons outside of Baltic found in OCS krilo 'Flügel', etc.

Cf. s.v. ?*(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'einen Kreis beschreiben' (IEW 936). Verbal only Baltic. Present stem *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾réi̯-e- > Lith. skrejù (skriẽti) 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen', Latv. skreju (skriet) 'laufen, rennen, fliegen'.

fɜšon-tɜ 'back' : from fɜs- 'behind' and on 'shoulderblade'. on goes back to PIr. *anha- (*amha-). Abaev gives Old Indic aṅsa-, Germanic *amsa (Gothic ams 'in umero'), Tocharian B āntse 'shoulder', Greek ὡμός 'id.'.
ɜvžɜr 'bad' : cf. Av. zbar-, Old Indic hvar- 'be crooked', hvaras- 'crookedness, deceit' (Hübschmann, Benveniste via Abaev).
Ved. hvar-, Av. zbar- (PIIr. *j́ʰu̯ar-) from possibly PIE *g̑ʰu̯el- or *g̑ʰu̯er-.
Probably onomatopoeic.
Probably onomatopoeic.
from PIr. *hvaǰ- / *hvaxšta-. Cf. Sogdian *xwanč in xwnčy, ʼnxwnč, ʼwxwnč 'struggle', Avestan pairiš-xʷaxta 'overtaken', Old Indic svaǰ-, svaǰate 'embrace'.
cf. Persian māst, Balochi mastaɣ, Old Indic mastu- 'sour milk'
Cf. s.v. Ved. mástu- 'saurer Rahm', probably *másd-tu- to PIIr. *masd-. No certain connections outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:218n74 for further discussion).
PIr. *tauka, cf. Old Indic toka- 'descendants', tokman- 'sprout', Avestan taoxman-, Persian toxm.
Cf. s.v. Ved. toká- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'. No clear cognates for IIr. *tau̯k- outside of Indo-Iranian.
onomatopoeic according to Abaev, but connected by Miller, Benveniste to Old Indic lap-, lapati 'chat' (phonetically and semantically dubious).
no good Iranian cognates. Abaev links to PIE *rebhyo (PIr. *raibya), cf. English rib, Russian rebro, etc.
adjectival derivate of šəvɜr 'uterus' < *su-bara 'foetus-holder'. For *su cf. Old Indic śiśu- 'child', śāva- 'cub', śu-, śvayati- 'swell'.
preverbal derivate of sɜw- 'go' < *kʷi̯eu̯- /cognate/5021/. The preverb ɜrba- is historically a combination of ɜr- < *avar-, ba- < *upa- (Thordarson 1989).
Ossetic forms from PIr. *kū-, *kav-, cf. Old Indic kāuti, kavate 'scream'.
Abaev believes this is derived from kʼaχ 'leg', an E. Caucasian loanword. In any case, due to the ejective this is most probably either a loanword or an onomatopoeic word.
Loan from Persian qiži 'dirty' (through some other language?)
PIr. *kuti-, a common East Iranian term, cf. Shughni kud, Yaghnobi kud, kut, Sogdian *kūti (ʼkwty).

originally ni-waž-ən, from pv. nə- < *ni- 'down' and the stem *waz- 'flow' in causative wāz-aya-. Cf. Khotanese nuvays- (*niwaz-) 'flow down', Avestan nivaz- 'carry downwards by stream', Old Indic nivah- 'flow'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √vah- 'fahren, Wagen lenken, Wagen ziehen, herbeiführen, befördern, bringen' < PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ-.
The Ossetic lexemes may be from Iranian *ru-ka-, but Abaev gives no Iranian cognates. They are more likely related to an East Caucasian term (Lezgian rug 'dust', Tabasaran rug 'earth', etc.).

Abaev derives from *sikita-, *sika-, *sikaya- or similar PIr. forms, and compares to Balochi six, Pashto šəga, Old Persian ϑikā- 'rubble', Khotanese siyatā- 'sand'. But Cheung rather considers it a Wanderwort, which may explain the diversity of forms.
verbal derivate *vi-tarta. Cf. Old Indic vi-tar- 'carry away', Old Persian vi-tar- 'carry over'

Cf. s.v. Ved. tarⁱ 'durch etwas hindurchkommen, etwas durchdringen, hinübergelangen, überwinden', from PIE *terh₂- (cf. Hitt. tarh-/tarhu- 'überwinden, imstande sein', Lat. trāns 'hinüber, hindurch', etc.).
PIr. *spāna-. Old Indic sphāy- 'to get fat'

S.v. Ved. √sphā- 'fett werden, feist werden, zunehmen' < PIE *speh₁- (cf. Hitt. iš-pa-a-i 'ißt sich satt' iš-pa-a-an probably 'Sättigung', Lat. spēs 'Hoffnung, Erwartung' OEng. spōwan 'gedeihen', OCS spěti 'gedeihen', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *spʰeh₁- 'wunschgemäß geraten, gelingen' (IEW 983).
origin unclear, Abaev gives some bird names as potential cognates, e.g. Persian šīšū, šīšak 'a k. of partridge'.

Ossetic Iron uses a light verb construction with 'do'; for the lexical part, cf. Avestan taxma- 'mighty', Old Persian taxma- in proper names.  The Ossetic Digor verbal stem is cognate with the Ossetic Iron lexical part.

The Ossetic lexemes are Wanderwörter with Caucasian and Uralic comparanda. It is unclear whether they may have an Iranian etymology, or they are loanwords from other languages.  The proposed Indo-Iranian comparanda are not inspiring: Old Indic kaśaku- 'Coix barbata', kaśa- 'whip'; Bailey giveskəžə 'fish' in some Pashto dialect. Consequently the Ossetic lexemes are more likely a loanword in origin.
W. Caucasian loanword or nursery word.

The origin of the Ossetic lexemes is unclear.  Abaev proposes *bin + *če(r), for former cf. German Biene 'bee'; for latter, Georgian cʼeri 'fly', but then he gives Slavic bǐčela as "composed of the same elements". Not convincing.
loan from E. Caucasian
Loan from Turkic.
*ham- + *bæxs-. Root may be from *barg-s-, which may be related to Avestan barəg- 'receive'.
Re Ossetic: from *šə with formant -kʼa. Root from PIr. *sru(wa)-. Cf. Persian surū-, Avestan srū-, srvā- 'horn'.

*war-āka, from *war 'crookedness, bend'. No good Iranian cognates, but many "European" ones (e.g. Latin vārus 'crooked-legged').  But I find the lack of Iranian cognates suspicious, and I am not sure about the phonetic correspondences. There are some similar E. Caucasian (Nakh) terms, which have been interpreted by Abaev as loanwords from Ossetic (Alan). But it is not inconceivable that the direction is opposite.
Nursery word.
Ossetic kʼɜˈzɜχ is of unclear origin; the first part kʼɜ(j) is most likely a loanword.
Loan from E. Caucasian.  The phonological correspondence between Iron and Digor forms is irregular, but the borrowing is probably Proto-Ossetic.
Probably onomatopoeic.
Nursery word (the other term gəcːəl is the same).
probably related to Sogdian *frāxš- (βrʼxš) 'shoot (from bow)'. May be related to Avestan vaxš- 'throw'.
Digor isolate. Origin unclear. Possible from *kal-s- with initial voicing. Then related to kalun 'pour, throw', cf. Persian kāštan, Av. kar- 'sow, plough'.
S.v. syandaa- 'of the left side', from Iranian *sai- 'be unfavourable' > 'left-side' (cf. Gk. σκαιός, Lat. scaeuus).

S.v. κακός 'bad, awful, worthless'. No clear etymology. Beekes assumes Phrygian κακο(υ)ν is a loan from Greek. There are some further possible IE comparisons, none of which is fully convincing. The most promising of these is to Standard Albanian keq 'bad'.
Schumacher & Matzinger assume an Early Albanian pre-form *kakii̯a/ā-, comparing Ancient Greek κακός with a simple thematic suffix (i.e. *kak-o-).
S.v. AGk. ἄμυλον 'cornstarch' with semantic development to 'fat' in Cypriot.
This cognate class encodes Ancient Greek χαμαί 'on the ground', a fossilised allative form of PIE *dʰg̑em- 'earth' + the 'hic-et-nunc' particle *-i.
S.v. κυλίνδω 'to roll', with connected verbal stem κυλί-. "The word is hardly IE."
Cf. s.v. AGk. Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak' (of unknown etymology), with denominative verb ἁπαλύνω 'to soften'.

For Ancient Greek ὀφθαλμός, variants are Boeotian ὄκταλλος, a gloss reported in the grammarian Herodian's treatise Περὶ ὀρθογραφίας (On Correct Spelling), and West Greek ΟΠΤΙΛΛΟΣ (epigraphic at IG IV²,1 121, etc.). {ref Beekes 2010} attempts to assign ὀφθαλμός to a Pre-Greek substrate language, however most other etymological authorities (cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}; {ref Frisk 1960-1972}) prefer to analyse the beginning of the word as identical with PIE *h₃ekʷ- found elsewhere in Greek as a compositional member °οψ, in a derived noun ὄμμα < *h₃ókʷ-mn̥, etc. The variants may support a connection of initial ὀφ- with PIE *h₃ékʷ-, but a convincing explanation that accounts for the remainder of the word is lacking (cf. {ref NIL} s.v. h₃ekʷ- p.376n24). Contamination of inherited material with a substrate language remains possible; as the nominal derivation of the ὀφθαλμός words is unclear, I am inclined to separate them from the ὄμμα words for the purposes of cognate coding. Note Tsakonian (ε)ψιλέ is a reflex of Ancient Doric variant ὀπτιλλός (cf. {ref Andriotis 1974}:413).
Cf. s.v. AGk. (dor.) ὀπτίλος 'das Auge' > Tsak. (ἐ)ψλὲ; AGk. ὀφθάλμιον, dim of AGk. ὀφθαλμός 'Auge' > Italiot αρτάρμι.

S.v. AGk. πλέκω 'to braid, knit, wind, twine' < PIE *plek̑- 'twine' (cf. extended root in *plek̑-t- in Lat. plectō, OHG flehtan 'braid', OCS plesti 'συρράπτειν', Ru. plesti 'to twine'; with original root found in isolated formations e.g. Skt. praśna- 'turban, headband', < *plok̑-no-, OHG flahs, OE fleax 'flax' < *plok̑-so-).
Cf. s.v. *plek̑- 'flechten' (IEW 834-5). [NB: LIV² considers Lat. plectō, OHG flehtan, OCS plesti < *plek̑-te- rather than a root enlargement.]

S.v. ἐξευπορῶ 'beschaffen, liefern' > Calab. aor. ἐτσιπόρεα,
 (α)σ̌σ̌ηπόρεα 'ich wußte'.

(με)λιγκόνι. Andriotis (1974:370) proposes a reconstructed n.pl. *μελιγκόνια. If the first part of the word is μέλι(τ)- ‘honey’, it could be related to Hellenistic μελίτ-αξ > MG μελίτακας ‘ant’ (Andriotis 1983:203), and possibly to Cypriot (με)λίμπουρος ‘ant’ (Christodoulou 1963). Cf. MG μελίγκρα ‘aphid’ < AG μελί-κηρα (Babiniotis 2009:835).

κατσίνου [katsinu]. Uncertain etymology. Pernot (1934:350) suggests τσακίνου (= MG τσακίζω ‘break’) with ad hoc metathesis tsak- > kats-, which is unlikely because τσακίνου [tshacinu] should have given [tshatsinu] (tsitacism). Maybe *κατα-δάκ- ‘to bite’ (see LSJ) > κα-(δ)ακ-ίνω (a remodelled present) > κατσίνου; for the deletion of intervocalic -δ- cf. πούα ‘leg’ < AG acc. πόδα, ύο ‘water’ < AG ὕδωρ etc. Apocope of prepositions (e.g. κατά- > κα-) is a well known Doric feature. Also cf. Pont. δάκινω ‘bite’, collateral form of Pont. δάκω ({ref Andriotis 1974}:200).
τσέα < Hell. κέλλα ‘room, chamber’ < Lat. cella (Costakis 1986-7, 3:263) [loan]. Deletion of -l- before a back vowel is regular.
Tsakonian ού(ι)θι < ΑG ὄφις. All changes are regular: fi > θi, e.g. θίλε (< φίλος) ‘friend’, νύθη (< νύφη) ‘bride’ etc.; i-metathesis next to dentals, e.g. λαλούδι > λαλού(ι)δι etc.
Tsakonian τσ̔ιμού < AG ἐξ-ἐμῶ.

Propontic κράβγω, κράου is related to AG κράζω ‘shout, cry’ (not AG κλαίω); rhotacism of λ as a second member of clusters is an exclusively Peloponnesian feature, cf. Pel. Ts. γρούσσα but Pr. Ts. γουώσσα (< AG γλῶσσα).
Tsakonian Propontis ποό = MG πολλοί
λεγνός < Hell. λέγνος, which according to Hesych. is the opposite of ἀδρός ‘stout, fat’ (LSJ). Cf. MG λιγνός.
Cypriot ξημαρισμένος. P.p. of ξημαρίζω < ξη- (< ἐξ) μαγαρίζω. An Arabic loan in MedG: μαγαρ(ίτης) -ίζω < MedG μωαγαρ-ίτης < Arab. Muhādžir (Kahane 1979:344-54, 622).
Cypriot μασσ-ός. < ΑG μασ(σ)-άομαι ‘chew’ (LSJ) (Chatziioannou 1996:108), cf. Hell. μαστ-άζω ‘chew, eat’ (LSJ).
Cypriot κουτσός < ΜedG κουτσός ‘lame’. Αccording to Babiniotis (2009) from Hell. κοξός ‘lame’ < Lat. coxus (< coxa ‘thigh’).
A borrowing from Turkish (çayır ‘meadow, grass’). (Chatziioannou 1996:196).
Cypriot δαμαί < δα(χ)αμαί < δα ‘here’ (< MedG εδά (Kriaras)) + AG χαμαί ‘on the earth’.
Explained as onomatopoeia (Chatziioannou 1996:205, Giagkoulis 2009:503), cf. MG φάπα ‘smack, clout’.

αλάτη. According to Kriaras (5:403) this word is inherited (contra Varella): MedGr ελάτη(ς) ‘wing (of a bird), branch’ < AG ἐλάτη. Τhe presence of MedGr ελατήρ ‘the muscle that moves the wing of the bird’ (Kriaras, id.) makes Kriaras’ interpretation more plausible. The cognate λατός ‘branch’ is preserved in the neighboring south-eastern MG dialect of Dodecanese (Andriotis 1974:232).
τσ̌υλι(μ)μένο (< *κυλι(σ)μένος). P.p. of τσ̌υλίω /τσ̌υλλίτζω ‘to roll (on a dirty surface), to make dirty’ < Hellenistic κυλίω ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:282-3), cf. MG κυλιέμαι.
απάλυστο < α- (privative prefix) + the verbal adjective of  (α)παλαίνω ‘to wet’ < AG ἁπαλύνω ‘to soften’, cf. WET. [The root form AG ἁπαλύνω is given by {ref Rohlfs 1964}:43].
μουτσωμένο. P.p. of μουτσώννω ‘to dull’ < μούτσ(ο) (< Italian mozzo ‘amputated’) -ώννω. (Karanastasis 3:527). So this is a borrowed word.
σ̌σ̌ιάτζομαι < οσ̌σ̌ί(α) (< AG σκιά ‘shadow’) -τζομαι ({ref Rohlfs 1964}:462), cf. ΜG σκιάζομαι ‘to be frightened’.
Italiot Greek αμπλέκω < AG ἐμπλέκω ‘to entwine’ (Rohlfs 1964:145), cf. MG συμ-πλέκομαι ‘to clash’.
σ̌σ̌ερό is a reflex of AG ξηρός (Rohlfs 1964:355). For the change ξ > σ̌σ̌, cf. (η)σ̌σ̌έρω ‘know’ < MedG εξεύρω, σ̌σ̌ύω ‘scratch’ < AG ξύω etc.
σκουλ̣λ̣ί. For the etymon (< dim. of AG σκόλλυς) see Rohlfs (1964:466-7).
χωρώ < ΑG θεωρῶ (Karanastasis 2:446-9)
Italiot μεταίρρω  < *μετ-αίρ-νω < AG μετ-αίρω (Rohlfs 1964:329), cf. παίρρω < παίρνω < AG ἐπ-αίρω ‘take’ (see AG αἴρω, ἀείρω).
Cappadocian πράμα < AG πρᾶγμα.
βαβά. Borrowed form Turkish, cf. Τs. μπαμπά, MG μπαμπάς, Cypr. παπάς etc. I don’t know if the Turkish word itself is a child-language formation.
Possible parallel borrowing?
Cappadocian αντίραδα: Imparisyllabic plural of άντιρο < (*εντέρ-αδια) < AG ἔντερα (pl.). Imparisyllabicity is a very common characteristic of Asia Minor dialects, possibly of Ancient Ionian origin.
S.v. λάξ adv. 'with the heel or foot', to which λακτίζω is a derived verb. No convincing Indo-European etymology.
Cf. s.v. AGk. σποδία 'Asche' > Tsakonian σποΐα (< *σποδίλα).
Possibly a compound of σ̌ομό (< θερμό) ‘food’ + ἐλατός ‘driven’, cf. Tsak. γαϊδουρο-άτα (< -ἐλάτης ‘driver’).
ψαχνέ < AG σαχνός ‘tender’. In MedG the word has the meaning ‘thin’; cf. MG ξερ-ακιανός ‘a thin and tall person’.
Tsakonian στομουτέ: Related to στομωμένος < στομώνω of other Greek varieties but the phonetic form (instead of *τ̔ουμουτέ < Tsak. τ̔ούμα ‘mouth’) doesn’t seem genuinely Tsakonian.

S.v. Lat. costa 'rib' "Costa has been compared with Slavic *kost-i- 'bone', yet it is unlikely that it is cognate. In Slavic, kostь may be the reflex of PIE *Host- 'bone', since there is no other word which qualifies for this. This would then be a unique case of kV- < *HV- in Slavic. Yet in Latin, PIE *Host- is reflected by os, ossis, so that costa cannot reflect
the same etymon. Since it also does not mean 'bone' but 'rib', which may have different semantic roots, we must regard costa as an isolated word without etymology."
De Vaan apparently regards the Slavic lexemes as cognates of Latin spīna and not loanwords derived thereof.
PIr. *tak- / *tač- 'flow, run'. Persian tak 'celer incessus, cursus, impetus' (Vullers), MP tak 'running', Sogdian *taxī (tɣyh) 'river', Avestan taka- 'running, flow', etc.
Loan from East Caucasian.  Same as 'leg' /cognate/3236/.
PIr. *gadā-, cf. Avestan gaδā-, Old Indic gadā- 'club', MP gaδ.
Ossetic Iron šɜl-ən 'freeze' from PIE *k̑el-. In Iranian, cf. Persian sard 'cold', sarmā 'frost', Balochi sart, sard, etc.
Ossetic Iron dərʁ 'fruit' is of unknown origin.  It may be an East Caucasian loanword.

For Ossetic Iron χorž 'good' there are two possibilities: (a) PIr. *hwarza- 'sweet' (cf. Avestan xʷarəzišta- 'sweetest'); (b) Avestan hvarəz- < hu-wārz- 'well-doing'. Abaev
considers the former to be more plausible.
Ossetic Iron kɜrdɜg 'grass' is a lexicalised participle from kɜrd-ən 'cut' from PIE *(s)kert- /cognate/762/.
Ossetic Iron šš-ən 'grind' is from Iranian *han-sā-, cf. Persian sūdan (prs. stem sāy-) 'rub'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *sauH- 'to rub, wear, whet', which reflects either a rare *u̯a-stem earlier Proto-Iranian *saH- (cf. Skt. śā- 'to sharpen, whet') or the result of contamination of semantically similar roots *dauH- and *skauH-.  Cheung considers the latter possibility more likely.
Unclear etymology.  The Ossetic forms might be compound arf 'deep', tɜn 'groin', as Abaev proposes, but this is strange.
Turkic or West Caucasian loan.
Loan from East Caucasian.
Ossetic Iron quš-ən 'hear' from *vi-gauš-. Same root as 'ear'. Cf. Avestan gaoš- 'listen'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian gauš- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Skt. ghoṣ- 'to sound'). Cognate forms outside of IIr. are not attested.
Cf. s.v. ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s- '(Geräusche) hören' (IEW 454).  Only Indo-Iranian (cf. Ved. ghóṣati 'ertönt, hört'); PIE reconstruction uncertain.

Cf. s.v. ghoṣ- 'klingen, ertönen, ertönen machen' (cf. Ir. *(-)gauš 'hören' in MPers. niyō(x)šidan, NPers. niyōšīdan, Parth. nγwš, Baluči niγōšaγ, Oss. qūsyn, etc.). The IE origins of PIIr. *gʰau̯š- '(ein Getön) hören' are not securely determined.
Ossetic Iron wɜžžaw 'heavy' : cf. Avestan wazya- 'weight'
Cf. Sogdian *čaβ- / *čaft- 'steal', Persian čāpīdan 'rob', but this is also likely to be a Wanderwort (there are many non-IE North Eurasian comparanda).
Ossetic Iron χɜzar 'house' may be a compound of *kata- 'house' (well-attested in Iranian) and car 'roof, ceiling' (South Caucasian loanword). But this is somewhat speculative.
Ossetic Iron swan kɜn-ən 'hunt' uses a light verb construction with kænyn 'do' /cognate/5037/. Lexical stem a derivate in -ɜn from sɜw- 'go' /cognate/5021/.
Ossetic Iron sad 'lake': cf. Persian čāh, Avestan čāt- 'well'.
Ossetic Iron šəf 'leaf' from *śiph-, cf. Avestan saef-, sif- 'to stroke in a sliding way'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *saif 'to flog, cane, rake?'.  No IE etymology.
Ossetic Iron galiw 'left' is of unknown origin.
Loanword from East Caucasian.  Same as 'foot' /cognate/3217/.
Ossetic Iron χʷəšš-ən 'lie' from PIr. *huf-s-. cf. Persian xābīdan etc., Avestan xʷafs- / xʷapta-.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ap/f- 'to sleep'.  From PIE *su̯ep- 'sleep'.
S.v. suptá 'asleep' VS., 'lain down to sleep' R. [√svap1] and svápati 'sleeps' RV. and *supati. [*supati after 3 pl. *supánti ~ 3 sg. svápiti Pāṇ. -- √svap1].
Ossetic Iron: sɜr-ən 'live' from PIr. *čar-. Persian čarīdan 'graze (intr.)', Avestan čar- 'move'.

S.v. Proto-Iranian *čarH- 'to come and go, wander', from PIE *kʷelh₁-  'to move, wander, settle, pasture' (cf. Skt. car- 'to move, turn, wander; to pasture; to settle and cultivate', Gk. πέλομαι 'I move [intr.], Lat. colō 'I till, cultivate, inhabit', OIr. bua-chail (m.) 'cowherd, bouvier').
Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-640).
Ossetic Iron šəšt 'louse' from PIr. *spiš- 'louse'. Persian šipiš, Avestan spiš-, Sogdian špšh.

Ossetic narɜg 'narrow' is from Proto-Indo-Iranian *nāraka-, cf. Old Indic naraka- 'Hades', Khwarezmian narak 'narrow', Pashto narai. Eventually the same PIE root as Germanic terms like English narrow.
Cf. s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt'.  Cf. AGk. νέρθεν, ἔνερθεν 'from below', νέρτερος 'lower, nether'.  Mayrhofer does not connect the IIr. and Greek forms to the Germanic ones in /cognate/2810/.
Ossetic Iron χɜštɜg 'near' is from *aštaka-. Cf. Avestan asna- 'close (adj.)', ašta- 'friend', MP aštak.

Ossetic Iron bɜržɜj 'neck', according to Abaev, is related to the stem *barz- 'high', cf. bɜržond 'high'. This, in turn, is from PIr. *bṛz-ant-, *barz-ant-. Cf. Persian buland, Avestan bərəzant- 'high'.
Cf. s.v. *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'hoch werden, sich erheben' (IEW 140-141).

Ossetic Iron fənz 'nose' might be loan from W. Caucasian according to Abaev. According to Rastorgueva & Èdelʼman (2007:49), rather related to the PIr. root *faź- etc., cf. Classical Persian pōz 'frontal part of the face', Kurdish pūz, pōz 'nostril', Balochi pōnz, pōz 'nose', Khwarezmian pncwk 'nose'. A third option is that this word is onomatopoeic.
Ossetic Iron qaž-ən 'play' has no reliable etymology. Abaev compares with Ishkashimi ɣəz-, Khwarezmian ɣāz- 'run'. Alternatively, with PIr. *gāz- 'dive', cf. Old Indic gāh-.
laš-ən 'pull' from *nas- 'take'. Cf. Yaghnobi nās- / nāta-, Khotanese nās- / nāta- 'take'.
Cf. s.v. *Hnas-'to reach, attain, take', from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, attain'.
Cf. s.v. *h₂nek̑- 'erreichen' (IEW 316-318).

Ossetic Iron šχoj-ən 'push' is from *uz-xwāy-, cf. Yaghnobi suxoy- / suxasta-, Sogdian *əsxwāy-, *səxwāy- / səxūst- (sɣwʼy-, ʼsɣwʼy, sxwʼay-, sxwʼy- / sxwst-, swxst-). The root without preverb also survives in χoj-ən 'hit' (not Swadesh), cf. Avestan xʷah- 'squeeze'.
Cf. s.v. *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh; [inch., intr.] become tired'.  No IE etymology.
Etymology unknown, probably a loanword, most likely from South Caucasian.
Ossetic Iron raχiž 'right' is from *frā-xaiza-, cf. Shughni xēz 'right', Rushan xīz etc. (Abaev only gives Pamir examples).
Ossetic Iron widag 'root' from *waitāka, from root *wai. Sogdian *wītāk (wytʼk) 'rope', Persian bīd 'willow', Avestan vaeiti- 'willow'.
Probably onomatopoeic.

Ossetic Iron žʁor-ən 'run': cf. Avestan ɣžar- 'flow'. Might be related to Turkic zügür (Abaev believes that /o/ in both dialects is due to contamination with this word; but it may also simply be a borrowing)
Ossetic Iron žmiš 'sand' is from *uz-maisa-. *maisa- is 'mix'. Avestan myas- 'mix', misva- 'mixed'.
Cf. s.v. *maiz- 'to mix, mingle', from PIE *mei̯k̑(-s)- 'mix'
Cf. s.v. *mei̯k̑- 'mischen' (IEW 714).

Ossetic Iron žɜʁ-ən 'say' is from PIr. *zag- vel sim. Often attested in bird names, e.g. Persian zāǧ 'magpie'. But also Sogdian zaɣānt- 'herald', Avestan zaxšaϑra- 'evil
saying'.
S.v. *zag- ? 'to sound (utter, say, etc.)'.  No etymology outside Iranian.
nəχ-ən 'scratch' : from nəχ 'nail, claw'.
Ossetic Iron denǯəž 'sea' is a Turkic loanword.
Ossetic Iron məkːag 'seed' from məg 'sperm' + suffix -ag.  Abaev compares məg to Lat. mucus, PIE meuk- and sees it as a "Scytho-European" term.
Ossetic Iron awwon 'shadow' has no clear etymology. It may be from *āyavana-, cf. Avestan ayaona- 'dwelling' (then 'shadow' would be through the meaning 'shelter', also attested in Ossetic)
Probably onomatopoeic.
Ossetic Iron žar-ən 'sing' from PIr. *žar-, PIE *g̑ar-, cf. Persian zār 'a cry'.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *zarH-³ 'to bewail the deceased' from PIE *g̑(e)rh₂-, (cf. Gk. γῆρυς 'voice', OIr. -gair 'to call', OE cearu 'sorrow, care').
S.v. *g̑ar- 'tönen, rufen' (IEW 352).
Ossetic Iron fən-ɜj kɜn-ən 'sleep': light verb kɜn-ən 'do' /cognate/5037/. Lexical part is abl. of fən 'sleep' < PIr. *hvafna-, cf. Persian xʷāb, Avestan xʷafna- etc.
Ossetic Iron šmud-ən 'smell' is from *əš-bud-ən < PIr. *uz-baud-. Cf. Sogdian βwδy 'smell (feeling)', Khotanese butte 'smell'.
Ossetic Iron fɜždɜg 'smoke' from PIr. *pazdaka-. Yaghnobi pazd-, Sogdian *pazd- (pzt-) 'smoke'. Also used in names of pests: Persian pazdak- 'a k. of mite', Avestan pazdu- 'a k. of insect'.
Ossetic Iron mit 'snow': Abaev believes this a Slavic loan and considers phonetic similarity to Sogdian mēϑ, Khwarezmian mīϑ 'day' to be accidental.
Ossetic Iron tu kɜn-ən 'spit'.  Light verb construction with 'do'; lexical element tu probably onomatopoeic.
Ossetic Iron lɜww-ən 'stand' from East Iranian root *rap-. Cf. Ormuri we-raf-s-, Shughni wi-ruv-d-, Yazg. u-raf-s- etc.

Ossetic Iron lɜzɜg 'stick' probably from *laštyaka-, but no Iranian comparanda (Abaev gives Lithuanian lazdà, lazà 'stick'). Alternatively, an old loan from
Armenian lcʼakʼ 'lever'.
Loanword from South or East Caucasian.
Ossetic Iron ad-ǯən 'sweet' is derived from ad 'taste', whose etymology is unknown. Abaev hypothesizes relation to root *ed- 'eat', but considers it speculative.
Ossetic Iron lenk kɜn-ən 'swim': light verb construction with 'do' /cognate/5037/. Lexical stem is either onomatopoeic or from East Caucasian.  In either case it is an Iron innovation.

Ossetic Iron kʼɜzil 'tail' is from kʼɜz 'crooked', and according to Abaev connected to Persian kāž, kāǰ 'crooked'. The ejective makes one think that this may be a loanword, even if it is indeed related to the Persian term.
Ossetic Iron iš-ən 'take' is from *ais- 'own', cf. Avestan aes- 'own'.
Cf. s.v. *Hais- 'to be able, rule', only assigning Av. is- 'be able, rule'.  Cheung does not list the Ossetic forms as cognates: "Further Ir. cognates are unknown."

Cf. s.v. *Hei̯k̑- 'sich aneignen' (IEW 298-9).  The connection of Oss. īs-/es- 'nehmen' to this root is not entirely certain, cf. fn2a "Falls dieses Verb ein altiran. *ais-a- fortsetzt und nicht anderer Herkunft ist, vgl. Abaev I 552; Kümmel, Perfekt 124⁷⁶⁻⁷⁷."

Ossetic Iron wə-sə 'that' : derived from wəj 'that' (as an independent pronoun, not determiner) < gen. *ava-hya-, cf. Old Persian avahya. The suffix -sə is probably from *čit, either as a particle or, more likely, as an interrogative 'what' (i.e. the determiner is from a relative clause 'which is that one').
Ossetic Iron wəm 'there' : inessive case (PIr. locative) of wəj 'that', *avami.
