Ossetic Iron wədon 'they' : pl. of wəj 'that'. The ending -(d)on may be from -ānam, the element -d is unclear.

Ossetic Iron qʷədə kɜn-ən 'think': light verb construction with 'do' /cognate/5037/. Lexical stem is from gen. or in. of past participle of qɜw-ən 'to need' (past stem qʷəd), cf. Yaghnobi ɣāw- 'be needed', Sogdian *ɣaw- (ɣw-) 'be needed', Parthian viɣāj- 'a decrease'.
Cf. s.v. *gaHu 'to need, be faulty, wanting; to want, desire' from PIE *gʰeh₂u̯- (not in LIV²).
Ossetic Iron bɜlaš 'tree' is a West Caucasian loanword. Also possibly related to palāśa- 'foilage' according to Abaev, but I believe borrowing is more likely.
Ossetic ždaχ-ən 'turn' from *uz-tak-, cf. Persian tā 'thread', Shughni tōǰ 'branch'.
Ossetic Iron ɜχšən 'wash' from PIr. *snā-, cf. Persian sinā 'swimming', Avestan snā- / snāta- 'wash'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *snaH- 'to wash, swim', from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to wash, swim' (cf. Skt. snā- 'to bathe, to wash', Lat. nāre 'to swim', OIr. snaid, -sná 'swims', TochB näsk- 'to bathe').
From *dānu- 'river' /cognate/2648/.
Ossetic Iron χʷələz 'wet' is probably a Turkic loanword with suffix *-ti, but this is not certain.
Ossetic Iron -imɜ 'with' is from iw-mɜ 'together', all. case of iw 'one' /cognate/91/.
Cf. Vedic yoṣit- 'woman'.

Cf. s.v. yóṣā- 'Mädchen, Jungfrau, Maid, junge Frau, Geliebte, Gattin'.  Mayrhofer doubts the connection of the Ossetic forms with the Vedic ones, the etymology of which he considers to be 'Nicht klar'.
Ossetic Iron až 'year', cf. Persian asmān, Avestan/OP asmān- 'sky' etc.
Cf. s.v. Ved. aśman- < PIE *h₂ek̑-mon-.
Ossetic Iron bur 'yellow': cf. Persian būr, Yaghnobi vur, but this seems to be a Wanderwort.
Digor isolate. Probably a W. Caucasian loanword (only Digor, not proto‑Ossetic).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √svañj- 'umarmen, umschlingen, umfassen', possibly from PIE *su̯eng- if can be compared to MHG swanc 'schwankend, beweglich' but this is not more than a possibility.
Cf. s.v. ?*su̯eng- 'umarmen' (IEW 1047).
S.v. Oss. bon 'день', from Ir. *bānu- 'shine' (cf. Av. bānu-, Ved. bhānu- 'ray, shine', from IE *bhā- (cf. Gk. φαίνω, Ir. bān, etc.).
Digor isolate. Probably a loanword, but it is unclear from where.  Might also be onomatopoeic. Similar c’ammar 'filthy' exists in both dialects.
Ossetic Digor sor 'dry' is probably a South Caucasian loanword. This word also exists in Iron, but is not the Swadesh term.
Cf. s.v. Lat. flō, flāre 'to blow', from PIE *bʰleh₁-/*blh₁- 'to blow', many compounded forms with preverbs.
S.v. *bʰleh₁- 'heulen' (IEW 121-2; 154-5).
ræzæ is a Digor isolate
Cf. s.v. ?2.*su̯el- '(ver)schlucken' (IEW 1045).  Only Iranian (cf. YAv. xᵛaraiti 'ißt, trinkt'), so the Indo-European root reconstruction is only hypothetical.
Ossetic Digor æfsnajun 'hide': *æf‑ + *snā‑. Only in Digor, but same root as Iron 'wash' cf. /cognate/3079/.
S.v. Oss. cad | cadæ 'озеро', an Iranian word, cf. words for 'колодец' ('well'), e.g. Pers. čāh-, Av. čāt-, etc.
S.v. Oss. læg 'мужчина', 'муж', 'человек'. An East Caucasian loanword, cf. Abkhaz ləgaž 'old man' from *ləg 'person', etc.

Ossetic Digor: fid 'meat' goes back to PIr. *pitu‑ 'food', cf. MP pit 'meat', Avestan pitu‑ 'food, meat'. The word also exists in Iron as fəd, but it is not the Swadesh term (more like
'flesh' than 'meat').
Cf. s.v. Ved. pitú- 'Nahrung, feste Speise' from PIE *pitu-/*pei̯tu-, cf. OIr. ith 'cereal', Lith. piẽtūs 'lunch, lunchtime', and probably also Arm. hiwt 'juice, substance, stuff'.

Cf. OInd. ā-sanna- < *ā-sad-na-.  The Iranian form attested by Av. asna- reflects a zero-grade from *ā-zd-na-.  Proto-Iranian *ašta- may likewise be explained as from Proto-Indo-Iranian *ā-zd-ta- >> *ā-z-ta-.
Proto-Iranian *ašta-, which was later expanded with a common denominal adjective forming suffix -(a)ka-.
Cf. Ved. √sad- 'sitzen' from PIE *sed- 'sit'.
Goes back to enlarged form *waitāka- from the root *wai- < PIE *u̯ei̯- 'twist' (IEW 1120-1122).  Cf. Ved. vetasá- 'Calamus rotang', etc.
Cf. s.v. Ved. vetasá- from Proto-Indo-Iranian *u̯ai̯-t- to PIE *u̯ei̯(H)-t- (cf. Lat. uītis 'tendril, twine', OHG wīda 'willow', NHG Weide 'id.', etc.).

Ossetic Digor leʒun is from PIr. *raič‑, cf. Avestan raeč‑, raek‑ 'leave'. The word exists in Iron, but not as the Swadesh term (its semantics are more like 'run away'). Conversely, the Ossetic Iron Swadesh term žʁor‑ən also exists in Digor as zʁor‑un, but this lexeme is less basic.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *raič- 'to leave, let, abandon' from PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'leave, let'.
Cf. s.v. *lei̯kʷ- 'zurücklassen, sich entfernen von' (IEW 669-670).
East Caucasian loan.

Ossetic Digor qwæcæ 'smoke' is probably a Caucasian loanword, but phonetic correspondences are not perfect and it is difficult to establish the source. This is a uniquely Digor borrowing. Meanwhile the Iron term fɜždɜg does exist in Digor (fɜzdɜg), but is less frequent (it may theoretically be a "back‑loan" from Iron, but it is impossible to verify, as the correspondences are perfect).

Ossetic Digor χelagɜ 'snake' is a present participle from χel‑un 'crawl', i.e. lit. 'crawler'. χelun is from *khairya‑ cf. Old Indic khelati 'move around'. This word also exists in Iron as χilag, but is not a Swadesh term.

Ossetic Digor zolk’æ 'worm' may be from PIr. *zaluka 'leech', cf. Persian zalū 'leech', but alternatively Turkic sülük etc. is the source of the Iranian words (Abaev believes it is the other way around). The latter looks more probable to me.
S.v. *μελιγκόνια τὰ: μελιγκόνι τὸ (Sam, Tsakon, etc). λίγκόνι Tsakon 'Ameise'. Elsewhere compare NGr. μελίτακας, ὁ, μυρμήγγι τὸ.
Probably a borrowing from Greek, if the etymology proposed by Andriotis (1974:370) for Tsakonian μελιγκόνι holds. Cf. discussion in at /cognate/6209/.
From Iranian *pa(s)nu-ka- (cf. Av. pąsnu, Ved. pāṃsu- 'soil, dust, sand').
S.v. Oss. g˳ybyn | gubun 'живот, брюхо' Refers to a type of words kpr||kpn meaning 'convex, round'.
S.v. Oss. styr | (æ)stur, (i)stur, (u)stur 'балшьой, великий', from Iranian *stūra- (Pers. suturg 'big', etc.) from PIE *steuro-.
S.v. Oss. c’īw | c’ew 'птичка'. Onomatopoeic word, cf. c’īw-c’īw 'chirping'.
S.v. Oss. ūlæfyn : ūlæft | olæfun : olæft 'дышать'. Probably onomatopoeic, cf. læf-læf 'одышка', 'breathlessness'.
S.v. *kʷels- 'Furchen ziehen, einfurchen' (IEW 639-640).
S.v. Oss. syvællon | suvællon 'дитя, младенец, ребенок', derived to Oss. syvær | suvær 'uterus' < Ir. *su-bara-.

S.v. Ved. śíśu- 'Kind, Tierjunges' probably a reduplicated noun *k̑i-k̑uh₁- to Ved. √śav-ⁱ 'anschwellen, stark werden, zunehmen, gedeihen', from PIE *k̑eu̯h₁- ~ *k̑u̯eh₁- 'anschwellen' (cf. Gk. κυέω 'bin schwanger', κῦμα 'Woge, Welle', Lat. cauus 'hohl', etc.).

The root reference form coded in this cognate set is the semantic element in Proto-Iranian *su- 'child, foetus' < PIE *k̑eu̯h₁-.  The second element in the Ossetic compounds with *-bara- is from PIE *bʰer- 'bear'.
S.v. Ved. meghá- 'cloud', from PIE *h₃mei̯gʰ- (via nominal derivative *h₃moi̯gʰ-o-); cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη 'Nebel', Lith. miglà, OCS mьgla 'Nebel'.
S.v. mīǧ (Iron) | meǧæ (Digor).
S.v. Oss. nymajyn : nymad | nimajun : nimad 'считать', from *ni + IIr. *mā- (IE *mē-).
S.v. Oss. kærdyn : karst | kærdun : karst 'резать, рубить (на кусии), кроить', from Iran. *kart- from PIE *(s)kert-/*(s)ker-, cf. Sogd. ʾkrtʾnt, Av. karət-, karəsta-, Ved. kr̥t-.
Ossetic forms from Indo-Iranian *mar-.
S.v. Ved. √kar- 'tun, machen, bewirken, handeln' < PIIr. čar-/kar- < PIE *kʷer-/kʷor- (cf. Hitt. kuer- 'schneiden', OIr. cruth, Wel. pryd 'Gestalt' (*kʷr̥-tu-), Lith. kùrti 'errichten, bauen').
S.v. Oss. xūs 'сухой', from PIr. *hauša- (cf. Persian xūšidan, MP xōšitan, Avestan haoš- / hušata- 'to dry', Khotanese hūš- 'to dry'), PIE *sauso- (cf. Ved. śoṣa-, Lith. saũsas, Gk. αὗος, etc.).
Cf. s.v. ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s- '(Geräusche) hören' (IEW 454). Only Indo-Iranian (cf. Ved. ghóṣati 'ertönt, hört'); PIE reconstruction uncertain.

S.v. Oss. syǵyt | sigit, sik’it 'земля', continuing the Indo-Iranic word for 'sand, dust, earth' in forms *sika-, *sikaya-, *sikata-, *sika- (Bel. six, Afg. šǝga, Vanetsi sǝga, Par. sǝɣa, OPers. θikā-, etc.
S.v. Oss. cæst | cæstæ 'глаз', from Iranian *čašman- (cf. Pers. čašm, Sogd. *čašm- (čšm), Av. čašman-; also Ved. cakṣu-).
S.v. Ved. cakṣús- n. 'Auge, Sonnenauge, heller Blick' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. čašman- 'Auge', MPers. čašm, etc.), derived from √cakṣ- < PIE *kʷek̑-s- 'erscheinen ~ sehen ~ zeigen'.
S.v. Oss. dard | idard 'далекий, далеко', from *vi-tarta- (cf. Ved. vi-tar-, OPers. vi-tar-).
S.v. Ved. pīvas- n. 'Fett, Speck' < IIr. *piH-u̯as- (beside *piH-u̯an-). Cf. Gk. πῖαρ 'fat, tallow'.
Cf. s.v. Ossetic Iron fīw, Digor few 'жир', 'сало'.

S.v. Oss. kæsag | kæsalgæ 'руба'; Wanderwort: cf. Hungarian keszeg 'leuciscus', 'лещ', Khanty kaśeu, Mansi kǟsen 'лещ', Georgian kašaqi 'сельдь'. Perhaps from Iran. *kasāka, if cf. Ved. kaśaku- 'Coix barbata' and kaśa- 'плеть' .
S.v. Oss. dīdīnæg | dedenæg 'цветок', likely connection with Kabardian dedī, Svan dadil Lak tuti Tsakhur tet. Further not clear. Nursery word?
S.v. Oss. k’ax 'нога', a loanword from East Caucasian (cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc.).
S.v. Oss. k’ax 'нога', a loanword from East Caucasian (cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc.).
S.v. sælyn : sald | sælun : sald 'замерзать', from IE *k̑el- (cf. Pers. sard, Sogd. srt, Av. sarəta-, Ved. śiśira-, OCS slana, Lith. šálti, Arm. saṙn, Lat. caleō, etc.)

S.v. ræzæ 'плоды, фрукты, овощи', from Proto-Iranian *raza‑, cf. Persian raz 'vine', "Kurdish" räz, rez 'garden', Old Persian *raza‑ 'vineyard', also not to be separated from Avestan razura‑ 'wood, grove', further from PIE *reg̑-.
S.v. ʒag | iʒag 'полный', goes back to *vi-čak-. for *čak: Khwaresmian cāk 'full', Persian čāq, čāǧ 'full, healthy'.
Cf. Pers. šudan : šaw-, Chorezm. ciya-, Khot. tsu-, tsuta-, Av. šav-, šyav-, Ved. cyav-, Gk. σεύω.
S.v. Oss. xorz | xwarz 'хороший, добрий, славный'.
S.v. kærdæg 'трава', derived from kærdyn : karst | kærdun : karst 'резать', from Iran. *kart-, from PIE *(s)kert-.
In all probability, a Caucasian loanword.
Cf. s.v. yssyn : yssad | insun : insad, inst.
Cf. s.v. artæn.
S.v. Oss. ʒykku | ʒikko 'коса женская, локон'; Shtakel'berg considers Turkic čika 'коса'; closer is Ubykh šequ 'волосы на голове'.
S.v. Oss. k’ūx | k’ox 'рука', 'hand'. As with k’ax 'нога', 'foot' a loan from a Caucasian substrate. Cf. Chech. kujg 'рука', 'hand'.
S.v. Oss. qæbær 'твердый, жесткий, сильный', probably from Turkic qabar, qapar- 'выпуклый, опухоль, мозоль'.
S.v. qūs | ǧos.
Proto-Iranian *wazyāwan-, cf. Av. uaziia- 'weight, load' + formant -wan(t)-.
S.v. 10329 Skt. mḗya 'to be measured' AV., 'discernible' Prab [√mā]. Marathi form has "unexplained o".

The Proto-Indo-Iranian suffix *-u̯an(t)- is cognate with PIE *-u̯ent- which formed adjectives attributing a particular quality (cf. Ancient Greek χαρίεις 'graceful, possessing grace' (m.), χαρίεσσα (f.) < Proto-Greek *kʰarí-u̯ent-, *kʰarí-u̯ent-i̯a etc. from χάρις 'grace').  Thus Proto-Iranian *u̯azi̯āu̯an(t)- 'heavy, possessing weight' from Proto-Iranian u̯azi̯a- 'weight'.
S.v. Oss. æmbæxsyn : æmbæxst | æmbæxsun : æmbæxst
Cf. s.v. Ved. gharmá- 'Glut, Hitze, Wärme' < PIE *gʷʰor-mó- (cf. Lat. formus 'warm').
S.v. Oss. xæʒar | xæʒaræ 'дом, сакля, жилище'. This important cultural word does not yet have a completely certain etymology. (Cf. for further discussion).
S.v. Oss. īx | ex 'лед', from Proto-Iranian *aixa- (cf. Pers. yax, Kurd. yex, Yag. īx, Sogd. *yīx, Chores. ēx, Av. aexa-).
S.v. Oss. maryn : mard | marun : mard 'убивать'  (cf. Ved. mārayati 'убивает' OCS moriti, Russ. морить, Lith. marinti 'убивать', Germ. Mord 'убийство', etc.).
S.v. Oss. wærag 'колено', from *warāka- or *war- 'bend' (cf. Lith. rankà (< wra-n-ka-) 'leg', OCS raka).
S.v. Oss. xūdyn : xūdt | xodun : xudt 'смеяться', from Ir. *xand- 'смеяться'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *xand- 'to laugh'. "This root is most likely expressive/onomatopoeic in origin, cf. Gk. καχάζω 'I laugh', Lat. cachinnō 'laugh loudly', OCS xoxotati 'to laugh loudly', Lith. kikénti 'to giggle', etc."
Cf. s.v. syf | sifæ 'лист', cf. Av. saef-, sif- 'проводить скользящим, обметающим движением', 'carry out a sliding, sweeping movement'.
S.v. t’af(f)æ 'лист'. West Caucasian loanword (cf. Kabardian tẖapä, Adyghe tẖap 'leaf').
S.v. galīw | galew 'левый'. Etymology unclear.

S.v. Oss. syst | sistæ 'вошь', 'Pediculus', from Iranian *spiš- 'вошь' with -t, -tæ like in Oss. myst, mistæ 'fly', cf. Pers. šipiš-, Tadj. šabušk, Kurd. spi, sipi, Yaghn. šipuš, Sogd. *špiš (špšh), Av. spiš-.
S.v. Oss. ʒiʒa (1) 'мясо' similar to a group of 'child' words for 'meat' in the Caucasian languages, cf. Gruz. čičia, Svan. ʒiʒil, Chech., Ing. žižig.
S.v. Oss. ʒyx | ʒux, c'ux. Has close parallels to Caucasian languages, cf. Veynakh. z'ok, ʒok, Balk. ǯux, Abkh. a-č'ǝ, Ubykh č̣ɛ, Abadz. že, Kab. žeh.
S.v. Oss. bærzæj 'шея', to be connected with Ir. *barz- 'высокий' (cf. Oss. bærzond), cf. Av. bərəzant-, Ved. br̥hant- 'tall' etc.).
S.v. æxsæv | æxsævæ 'ночь', from Ir. *xšap- or *xšapan- (cf. OPers. *kšap-, Pers., Tadj. šab, Kurd. šäw, šəv, Yaghn. xšap-, Sogd. *axšap- ('γšp-, 'xšp-), Khot. ṣṣava, Av. xšap-, xšapan-).
S.v. Oss. zærond 'старый', from Iranian *zar-ant-, cf. Ved. jar-ant- 'old', Gk. γέρων, γεροντ- 'old'.

S.v. γέρων, -οντος 'old man'; also as an adjective 'old' < PIE *g̑erh₂- 'be(come) old'. Ancient Greek γέρων is derived from an *-nt-participle *g̑érh₂-ont- 'old' (cf. Skt. járant-, Oss. zærond 'old (man)' whose formation is identical; cf. also Arm cer, -oy 'old man' from an o-stem).
S.v. ysxojyn : ysx˳yst | (æ)sxwajun : (æ)sxust.
S.v. Oss. syrx | surx 'красный', from Proto-Iranian *suxra- (cf. Av. suxra- 'red', OPers. θuxra-).

Cf. s.v. Ved. śukrá- 'klar, licht, hell, lauter, weiß, weißlich' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. suxra- 'rot, feuerfarben', OPers. θuxra-, MPers. suxr, Oss. syrx/surx 'rot', etc.). Derived to √soć-, possibly from PIE *k̑eu̯k- (connections outside of IIr. uncertain).
Ossetic forms from Proto-Iranian *ham-pūta-, cf. Khot. haṃbūta-, Pers. puda, Pahl. pūtak ( > Arm. putʻ 'rotten').
Cf. Pahl. pūtak 'rotten', and in general /cognate/2877/.
S.v. Oss. tymbyl | tumbul 'круглый'.

S.v. OHG halôn, holôn 'holen, herbeiholen, (herbei-)rufen', einladen, berufen, sich jemandes annehmen, zurückbringen, fordern (MHG hol(e)n '(herbei-)holen, erreichen, erwerben und mit sich fortführen', NHG holen 'hingehen und etwas herbeibringen'). The word only has West Germanic correspondences. Modern Danish hale, Swedish hala, and OIc. (of questionable attestation) hala are probably Low German loanwords. Only once attested in Old English as giholian 'get, receive'. Further etymology unclear.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. karp(ii̯e/a)- 'to take (away), take up, lift, pluck'.
Cf. s.v. ?*k⁽ʷ⁾h₂ed- '(zer)quetschen' [IEW 634 Anm.]. Only Indo-Iranian cognates.
for Palula cf. no. 792 s.v. avapatita- 'fallen down'
S.v. Skt. dolā 'Schaukel, Sänfte', 'swing, litter'. In view of ā̆n-dol° and hindolaḥ a loan from a prefixing (prob. Austroasiatic) language is very likely.

S.v. 7721 Skt. pataṅgá- 'ep. of divine (flying) things' RV., m. 'bird'. Palula phaaṭ < *phaṭ-, also in *phaṭṭiṅga- 'flying insect', cf. Vedic (RV) pataṅgá- 'flying', m. 'bird', 'flying insect', 'sun' < *pet- +; ph is due to blending with "some non-Aryan word". For Nuristan languages cf. s.v. 7733 Skt. páttra- n. 'wing, feather'.
connection with Sanskrit pinaṣṭi, piṁṣati is not clear

Cf. s.v. *gres- 'fressen, verschlingen' (IEW 404), cf. n1 possibly also to be reconstructed as *gras- in view of Lat. grāmen if from *gras-mn̥- 'Gras' or as *grens- if the Vedic verbal forms have generalised the zero-grade. Against the latter, however, Vedic grásiṣṭha- should contain an e-grade (and yet does not contain a nasal).
S.v. 497 Skt. ápaiti 'goes away' RV. (√i-). [Turner is ok here for Khowar, but incorrect in formulating Palula bii < ápaiti (H. Liljegren, p.c.)].
Cf. s.v. *h₁rem- 'ruhig werden' (IEW 864).

S.v. cūḍā f. 'Haarschur, Tonsur' / 'tonsure', probably Middle Indic from a participle *kṣur(i)ta-, cf. *kṣurá- 'shaving knife' from Dhātupāṭha-verb *kṣuráti 'schneidet, kratzt'. Usually connected with Greek ξύω 'shave'.
S.v. Oss. cæxx | cænxæ 'соль'. Cannot be connected with the Iranian or Indo-European words for salt. There are some parallels with Caucasian and Uralic languages.
S.v. nyxyn : nyxt | nixun : nixt 'чесать', denominative from nyx | nix 'коготь'.
Turkic loanword, cf. Turk. dengiz 'sea'.
S.v. myggag | muggag 1. 'семя, семена', from Oss. myg 'сперма' + suffix -ag, cf. s.v. myg | mugæ, comparing Lat. mucus, Gk. μύξα, deriving from PIE *meuk- (IEW 744).

Semantics of the PIE root *meu̯k- are reconstructed as 'losbinden, abstreifen' after LIV² pp.443-444.  The development of the more restricted semantics '(aus)schneuzen; blow one's nose' (Gk. ἀπομύσσω) and development of a noun in Lat. mūcus 'snot, mucus' < *mou̯k-o- appears to be restricted to Latin and Greek.  Abaev's semantic comparison to PIE *meu̯k- is therefore less convincing, and is at best an independent parallel semantic development that is unattested elsewhere in Indo-Iranian.
S.v. *si̯eu̯H- 'nähen' (IEW 915-6).
S.v. Oss. awwon 'тень, прикрытие'
S.v. Ved. tigmá- adj. 'scharf, spitzig, heiß'; cf. Gk. στιγμός 'a prick'. Derived from Ved. √tej- 'scharf machen, zuspitzen', from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein'.
S.v. Oss. cyrǧ | cirǧ 'острый', from PIIr. *tigra-, cf. Av. tiγra-, Ved. tigra-.
S.v. Oss. ḱysyl 'маленький', 'мало', 'немного'. A nursery word.
S.v. Oss. fæzdæg 'дым', from Ir. *pazdaka- (cf. Yaghn. pazd, Sogd. *pazd- (pzt-), derived from Ir. *pazd-, from IE *pesd- 'blow').

S.v. Oss. kalm 'змея, червь' with development r > l, from *kr̥mi-. Within Iranian cf. Pers. kirm, Kurd. kurm, kurum, Yagh. kirm, Sogd. kyrm, qrm, Av. kərəma-(?).  Outside Iranian, cf. Skt. kr̥mi-, Lith. kirmis, OIr. cruim, OCS чрьвь.

S.v. Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made' (IIr. cf. Manichaean Sogd. kyrm- 'Schlange', MPers. klm (kirm) 'Wurm, Drache, Schlange', NPers. kirm 'Wurm, Schlange'), from PIE *kʷr̥mi- (cf. OIr. cruim, W., Bret. pryf 'Wurm', Lith. kirmìs 'Wurm, Schlange', Sloven. čr̂m 'Fingerwurm, Karbunkel', etc.). Beside *kʷr̥mi- exists "a rhyme formation in Indo-European probably for reason of tabu" *u̯r̥mi- (NHG Wurm, cf. Lat. vermis), (so Watkins 1987:288).
S.v. xīlag (xīlæg) | xelagæ 'змея', a participle to the verb xīlyn | xelun 'crawl', cf. Skt. khelati, etc.
S.v. mīt | met 'снег', a loanword from Slavic *o-met- 'наметенное, снежный сугроб', 'swept (snow), snowdrift'.
S.v. Oss. læwwyn : læwd | læwwun : læwd 'стоять' (etc.); A. connects the Ossetic verbs to a root *rap- found in Pamir languages.
S.v. dūr | dor 'камень', an old loanword from Caucasian.

S.v. Oss. rast 'прямой, правый, правильный, etc.', from PIr. rāšta-, ultimately from PIE *rek̑to (*reg̑-to-), cf. Pers. rāst, Parth. rāšt, Chores. rašt, Sogd. rašt, Khot. rraṣṭa, Av. rāšta-, OPers. rāsta-, Goth. raihts, Germ. recht, Lat. rēctus.

S.v. Oss. xūr | xor 'солнце', from Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar- (Pers, xur, Kurd. xūr, xor, xwar, Yaghn. xur, Sogd. *xōr, *xwer [Budd. γwr, Man. xwr, Chr. xer], Chores. xwyr, xyr, 'xr, Av. hvar), from PIE *su̯el- (cf. Lith., Latv. sáulė, Goth. sauil, Lat. sōl, OCS слъньцє, etc.).

S.v. Proto-Iranian *sau̯H-² 'to bulge, swell up, increase', from PIE *k̑eu̯h₁- 'to bulge, swell up' (cf. Skt. śav-ⁱ 'to swell, to become strong, to increase, to prosper', Gk. κυέω 'I am pregnant', κῦμα 'wave', Lat. cavus 'hollow', in-ciēns 'pregnant', MW cyw 'young animal', OE hūn 'young one').
Cf. s.v. lenk 'плавание', lenk kænyn 'плыть, плавать'.
S.v. Oss. sīn | sujnæ 'бедро', from Proto-Iranian *srau̯ni- from PIE *k̑lou̯ni- (cf. Lith. slaunìs, OIc. hlaun, Lat. clunis, etc.).
S.v. *bʰendʰ- 'binden' (IEW 127).
S.v. Oss. yzdaxyn : yzdæxt | (æ)zdaxun : (æ)zdaxt 'поворачивать' from *uz- + *tak-/*tax-, ultimately to the PIE base *tek- 'плести' (Pok. 1058).
Cf. s.v. 2. *tek- 'weben, flechten' (IEW 1058).

S.v. Oss. cæwyn : cyd | cæwun : cud 'идти, ехать' (cf. Pers. šudan : šaw-, Kurd. čūn, čūin, Yagh. šaw-, Sogd. *šaw- (šw-), Khwar. ciya-, Khot. tsu-, tsunta-, Av. šav-, šyav- : šuta-, OPers. šiyav-, Ved. cyav- : cyuta-, Arm. ču-, Gk. σεύω).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯au̯- 'move, go', from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- (cf. Skt. cyav-, Arm. čʻogan, Gk. σεύομαι).
S.v. Oss. x˳ylyʒ | xuluj 'мокрый'.
S.v. Oss. ūrs | ors 'белый' from Proto-Iranian *aruša- (Av. auruša-), cf. Ved. aruṣa- 'reddish'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. aruṣá- 'rotlich, hellrot, glänzend, feuerfarben' (cf. Ir., YAv. auruša- 'weiß'). Connections outside of Indo-Iranian unclear.
S.v. Oss. wæræx | urux 'широкий, просторний', from Proto-Iranian *waru- ~ *uru- + suffix -ka-, cf. NPers. bar, Av. varu, vouru-, Ved. uru-, Gk. εὐρύς, etc.
S.v. Oss. dymgæ | dumgæ 'ветер' (cf. Sogd. δmʾk), derived from Ir. *dam- 'blow' (cf. s.v. dymyn | dumun).
Cf. s.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-248).
Cf. s.v. *bʰeng̑ʰ- 'dicht, fest machen' (IEW 127f.).
Cf. Av. bāzura 'arm' in snāuuar-bāzura- (= Ossetic Digor nawær-bazur 'having sinewy hands'), Parth. b’zwr 'wing'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. bāhu- 'arm' < PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰú- (Gk. πῆχυς 'arm', ON bōgr 'arm, shoulder' Germ. Bug 'shoulder').
S.v. *sh₂ei̯- 'fesseln, binden' (IEW 891-2). It is unclear whether the Baltic lexemes are original primary derivations to the root or they are secondary formations, cf. fn5.
Derived from Proto-Iranian *aiu̯a-, cf. Av. aeuua-, OPers. aiva- 'one', cf. s.v. īw 'one' and īwmæ 'together'.
Probably from *warron from *war- 'rain' (i.e. 'rainworm').  Alternatively, if gemination *r > -rr- occurred, possibly may be related to TochA walyi, TochB yel (< *u̯el-) /cognate/3141/.

S.v. Oss. būr | bor 'желтый'. Is inseparable, on one hand from Russ. бурый 'brown', on the other from Pers. būr, bōr 'бурый, рыжый, желтый', Pam.yazg. bər, Pam.sh. vṻr, Pam.m. vūr, Yaghn. vur. With them a Eurasiatic substratum word found in different language groups: Germ. *brūn 'brown', *bero 'bear', Turko-Mongolian in Mong. boro, Turk. bora, boro, boz, and others [cf. entry in Abaev for further comparisons]. A probable Wanderwort.
S.v. Oss. znon | æzinæ 'вчера', from Proto-Iranian *zyah, cf. Ved. hyas, Lat. heri, etc.
S.v. Hitt. ḫāšš- (c.) 'ashes', from PIE *h₂eh₁s- (cf. Skt. ā́sa- 'ash', OHG essa 'ash', ON aRina 'ash', Lat. ārēre 'to dry', OLat. āsa 'altar', TochAB ās- 'to dry out', Hitt. ḫāšša- 'hearth').

S.v. Hitt. u̯attai- 'bird' (hapax in KBo 4.2 ii 32: u̯a-at-ta-e-eš). According to Kloekhorst: "Because of the diphthong stem, it is likely that the word is inherited. Nevertheless, I do not know of any cognates."

S.v. Hitt. maru̯āi- 'to blacken'(?), borrowed into Hittite. Cf. CLuw. marruu̯a- 'blacken', maru̯ai- (adj.) 'black, dark-coloured(?)'.  Potential cognates in Germanic ON myrkr 'dark', mjǫrkvi 'darkness', OSax. mirki, OE mierce 'dark' pointing to a PIE root *mergʷ-.
S.v. Hitt. ḫaštāi- / ḫasti- (n.) 'bone(s); (metaphorically) strength; a measure of length (GÌR.PAD.DU)', from PIE *h₃ést-ōi, *h₃esth₁-i-. cf. CLuw. ḫāš- 'bone'.

S.v. Hitt. peda-/ped- 'to take (somewhere), to carry, to transport; to spend (time)'; Hitt. peda- may be historically analysed as the univerbation of the preverb pe- 'away, thither' with Hitt. dā- 'take' < PIE *deh₃-, thus by etymology lit. 'to take away'.  Cf. Hitt. pai- 'go' < pe + i- 'go' < *h₁ei̯-, uu̯e- 'come' < u- 'hither' + i- 'go'.
To Hitt. ḫaššu- < *h₂n̥s-u- cf. OAv., YAv. ahu- 'Herr'; Ved. ásura- (adj.) 'godly, mighty', Av. ahura-.
Cf. s.v. parta(i)- 'wing, pinion, feather', connecting to the family of words including Skt. parṇá- 'pinion, wing, feather', Lith. spar̃nas 'wing', etc.

S.v. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice' (n.), with derived adjective ekuna-, ikuna- 'cold', from IE *yeg- (IEW 503), cf. MiIr. aig 'ice' (< *yegis), MiCorn. yeyn 'cold', ON jaki 'ice-floe', jökull 'glacier'.
S.v. Hitt. u̯e-/uu̯a- 'come', from PIE *h₂ou 'hither' + *h₁ei̯- 'go'.
S.v. Hitt. šīu̯att- (c.) 'day' from PIE *di̯eu̯-ot- (cf. Skt. dyut- 'shine'). Cognates within Anatolian include Pal. tii̯at- 'Sun-god', CLuw. Tiu̯ad- 'Sun-god', and their derivatives.
Cf. s.v. Skt. ráṭati 'heult, brüllt, schreit' / 'howls, shouts', probably onomatopoeic.
ideophonic/onomatopoetic
S.v. ?*(h₃)peus- 'sich mehren, reich werden an' (IEW 848).  Slavic forms not connected by LIV².
For Kashmiri, cf. s.v. 12485 śītá (1) 'cold' RV.; For Nuristan languages cf. s.v. 12614 śaítya n. 'coldness' Yājñ. 2. *śaitiya- > Wg. šēi, šē 'ice', Kt. šē̆.
For Marathi, cf. s.v. 1074 *ācikhyati 'communicates' [√khyā-]; for Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 12842 sáṁkhyāti (*saṁkśāti) 'reckons' [√khyā-].
Indo-Aryan forms "with e- from eṣá- &c." - high frequency of analogical modifications
S.v. Skt. guḍa- (2) '(wohl:) gekochter Zuckerrohrsaft, Melasse / (possibly:) molasses'. Possibly a loanword from the Austroasiatic words for 'sugar' (cf. Malay gula, etc.). Quite uncertain.
Cf. s.v. *meld- 'weich werden' (IEW 718).
S.v. 10292 Skt. mr̥dú 'soft' VS., 'weak' AV., 'slow' MBh. [√mr̥d].
S.v. Skt. picchā 'Schleim, Schaum (von gekochtem Reis und anderen Fruchtkörnern)' / 'scum (of boiled rice and of other grain)' "Wohl eine unarische Wortsippe."
Cf. s.v. no. 11533 Skt. vā́ma- 'left', 11534 Skt. vāmá- 'lovely'

S.v. Hitt. i̯e/a- 'to do, to make' (Sum. DÙ), cf. CLuw. ā(i̯a)- 'to do, to make', Lyc. a- (act.) 'to do, to make'. K. rejects connection with *Hi̯eh₁- 'throw' on semantic and formal grounds. The form could be accounted for by mechanically reconstructing PIE *HH-i̯e/o-, but there are no known cognates to support such a reconstruction.
S.v. *Hi̯eh₁- 'werfen' (IEW 502).

S.v. Hitt. iškuna(ḫḫ)- 'to stain, stigmatise, denounce, degrade, disgrace, demote'.  The lemma iškunant- is literally an act. participle to this verb.  Puhvel compares Gk. αἰσχύνω 'make ugly, disfigure, dishonour' but does not provide a reconstruction to account for the proposed etymology.

S.v. Hitt. (LÚ)kuu̯an-/kun- 'hound-man' (a type of cult functionary), elsewhere in Anatolian cf. HLuw. swan(i)- 'dog'. From PIE *k̑uōn, *k̑uón-m, *k̑un-ós (cf. Skt. svā́, Arm. šun, Lith. šuõ, etc. 'dog'). For the contexts and interpretation of the Hittite lexeme cf. Melchert (1989).
S.v. Hitt. eku- / aku- 'to drink' < PIE *h₁egʷʰ- (cf. TochAB yok, Lat. ēbrius 'drunk').
Cf. s.v. ḫāt- / ḫat- 'to dry up, to become parched', from IE *h₂ód-ei, *h₂d-énti (cf. Gk. ἅζω 'to dry up').

S.v. Hitt. tēkan- / takn- 'earth', from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-m, *dʰg̑ʰ-m-ós (cf. Skt. kṣā́s [gen.sg. jmás], Av. zam-, Gk. χθών, TochA tkaṃ, TochB keṃ, Alb. dhe, Lat. humus, OIr. dú, Lith. žẽmė, OCS zemlja 'earth').
S.v. TochB keṃ 'earth, ground; base, place'. TochA tkaṃ and TochB keṃ reflect Proto-Tocharian *tkenä from PIE *dʰ(e)g̑ʰom- 'earth, ground'.
S.v. Hitt. ed-/ad- 'to eat', from PIE *h₁ed- (cf. Skt. ad- 'to eat', Gk. ἔδμεναι 'to eat', Lat. edō 'to eat', Lith. ė́sti 'to eat', OCS jasti 'to eat', Goth. itan 'to eat').
Tentatively adanti- from ad- 'eat' + -wali-.

S.v. Hitt. pattar / pattan- or pettar / pettan- 'wing, feather', from PIE *póth₂-r / *pth₂-én- or *péth₂(ō)r / *peth₂-én- (cf. OHG fedara, ON fjǫðr 'feather', fiðri 'feathers', Gk. πτερόν, Lat. penna, Skt. pátra- 'wing').
S.v. Skt. pītáḥ 'gelb', 'yellow'. Not satisfactorily explained. Relatively early attested (Sū., Up. etc.) but there are not yet any worthwhile connections in other IE languages.
S.v. Skt. ṭaṅkaḥ 'Bein', 'leg'. Etymology unclear, a few possible Munda correspondences suggested by Kuiper (1955) p.181 in Fs Kirfel.
S.v. paḫḫur / paḫḫuen- (n.) ‘fire, campfire, embers; fever’, from PIE heteroclite stem *péh₂-ur / *ph₂-uen-s (cf. Gk. πῦρ, OHG fuir, Arm. hur, Goth. fon, OPr. panno 'fire').

S.v. pattai-/patti- 'to run, to race; to flee; to fly' (cf. Skt. pátati 'to fly', Gk. πέτομαι 'to fly', etc.). To account for the Anatolian forms Kloekhorst reconstructs PIE pre-forms *pth₁-ói-ei / *pth₁-i-énti.

S.v. Hitt. u̯arša- 'fog, mist'. Usually connected with Skt. varṣá- 'rain', and AGk.ἐέρση 'dew' to a postulated root *h₁u̯ers-, although PA *Horso- is expected to have assimilated to medial -šš- in Hittite.  This lack of assimilation is a formal problem in the connection of the Hittite form to the Sanskrit and Ancient Greek, but the semantic comparison is otherwise quite attractive.
S.v. Hitt. pāt- / pat-, pata- 'foot, leg', from a PIE athematic root noun *pód-/*pd-. New Hittite texts attest a thematised noun pada-, cf. CLuw. pāta/i-, HLuw. pada/i-, Lyc. pede/i-.

S.v. Hitt. pai̯i-/pai- 'to go, to pass, to go past, to go by (of time), to flow'. Hittite and Heiroglyphic Luwian forms are from PIE *h₁ei̯- + univerbated preverb *h₁poi. NB: the unprefixed form i̯e/a- < *h₁i-i̯e- 'go, come' is also attested in Hittite (and Cuneiform Luwian i- 'go' with middle inflection.

S.v. TochB ai- 'geben', 'give'; mid. 'nehmen', 'take', TochA e- 'geben', give'. Precise root reconstruction disputed. May be derived from PIE *h₂ei̯-, or perhaps *h₁ai̯- (LIV² 229). Adams (2013:107) sets up *h₄ei̯-.
S.v. 1.*h₁ai̯- 'geben, nehmen' (IEW 10-1), connected with Anatolian forms.

Etymology outside of Anatolian disputed. The lexemes in this class might be related to Tocharian lexemes in /cognate/7599/ (cf. {ref LIV²}). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. {ref Adams 2013}:107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.

Etymology disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in /cognate/7599/ ({ref LIV²} 229, {ref Adams 2013}:107, cf. {ref Malzahn 2010}:542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. {ref Adams 2013}:107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. uzuḫri- 'grass', a Hurrian loanword.  The sequence of cuneiform signs might alternatively be read as Ú (plant determinative) + zuḫri-.
S.v. (Ú)zuḫrit- 'grass, hay'; Hurrian loanword. Cf. Starke (1990:220).
S.v. malla- / mall- 'to mill, to grind', from PIE *mólh₂-ei, *mlh₂-énti.

S.v. Hitt. keššar / kiššer- / kišr- 'hand'. Hittite kiššar- reflects forms reflect an original r-stem from PIE *g̑ʰes-r-.  The forms found in the Luwic subgroup, CLuw. īš(ša)ra/i-, HLuw. istra/i- and Lyc. izre/i- reflect a secondarily thematised form (as though from) *g̑es-r-o-, from Proto-Anatolian *g̑es-r- 'hand'.
S.v. Hitt. ker / kard(i)- 'heart; center, core', from PIE *k̑ēr, *k̑rd-i-ós, *k̑rd-´.

S.v. Ved. hŕ̥d- 'Herz', from IIr. *j́ʰā̆rd- /*j́ʰr̥d-, is not completely lautgesetzlich with PIE *k̑ē̆rd-/*k̑r̥d-. The presence of non-etymological *j́ʰ (> Vedic h) in Proto-Indo-Iranian is presumably due to contamination with the Proto-Indo-Iranian outcome of PIE *g̑ʰórh₁-/g̑ʰr̥h₁- 'guts', cf. /cognate/2672/.

S.v. Hitt. daššu- / daššau̯- 'strong, powerful; heavy; well-fed,; difficult; important'. Possibly to be connected with Skt. dáṃsas- 'miraculous power', cf. Skt. daṃs- 'to have miraculous power', Gk. διδάσκω 'to learn' < *deNs-.  If this etymology is correct, then Hitt.  daššu- would reflect a PIE u-stem *de/oNs-u-.
Cf. s.v. *dens- 'kundig werden, kunstfertig werden' (IEW 201-202).
Cf. s.v. Hitt. apā- 'that (one); he, she, it' < Proto-Anatolian *Hobó-.

S.v. Hitt. munnae- 'to hide, conceal', from PIE *meu̯h₂/₃-, cf. Gk. μῡ́ω 'to close the eyes'.  The Hittite form may reflect an original nasal-infix present *mu-né-h₂/₃-ti, *mu-n-h₂/₃-énti > **munāzi / munnanzi, which was later analogically remodelled as into the ḫatrae-class of inflection.
S.v. karāu̯ar / karaun- 'horn(s), antler(s)'. The Anatolian forms reflect a heteroclite stem *k̑r-o-u̯r̥ / *k̑r-o-un-.
S.v. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', from PIE *iég-o- (cf. OIr. aig, gen. ega 'ice', MCorn. yeyn 'cold', ONor. jaki 'ice-floe', jökull 'glacier', Wakhi yaz 'glacier').
S.v. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice' (n.) from IE *yeg- (IEW 503), cf. MiIr. aig 'ice' (< *yegis), MiCorn. yeyn 'cold', ON jaki 'ice-floe', jökull 'glacier'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *yegi- 'ice', from PIE *yeg- 'ice' (cf. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', ONor. jaki, Wakhi yaz 'glacier').
S.v. *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).

S.v. Hitt. kue(n)- / kun- / kuu̯a(n)- 'to kill, to slay, to ruin', from PIE *gʷʰén-ti / *gʷʰn-énti (cf. Ved. han- / ghn- 'to strike, kill, slay', OCS ženǫ 'to pursue, hunt down', Lith. genù 'id'., Gk. θείνω 'to smite', Lat. de-fendō 'to keep off, defend').
S.v. Ved. √han- 'schlagen, erschlagen, töten', from PIE *gʷʰen- (cf. Hitt. ku-(e)-en-zi, Gk. θεἰνω, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' < PIE *gʷʰen-.
S.v. Hitt. genu- / ganu- 'knee'. The Hittite forms appear to reflect a paradigm nom.sg. *g̑én-u, gen.sg. *g̑n-éu̯-s.
Onomatopoeic word.  No further etymology.

S.v. Hitt. paršdu- 'leaf, foliage'. Possibly connected to Old English brord. -es m. 'prick, point, lance, javelin, the first blade or spire of grass/corn, etc.' < PIE *bʰr̥sdʰ-, but the meaning 'leaf' in the Germanic lexeme could well be a secondary.
Cf. s.v. ipalāt(i)- 'sinisterness'.

Connected to Proto-Anatolian *g(e)ib- 'left' > CLuw. ip- > ipala/i- adj. 'left(-hand)', HLuw. i-pa-ma/i- 'west', CLuw. iparwašša/i- 'western', ipattarma- 'west'.  Follows the etymology given by Starke (1990:504ff.).
Connects the complex of Luwian words from ip- to PIE *gei̯bʰ- 'biegen' (IEW 354), Lat. gibber 'humpbacked', Lith. geibùs 'frail'.
S.v. ki- 'to lie, be laid, be in place, be set', from PIE *k̑ei̯-.
S.v. κεῖμαι 'lie', from PIE *k̑ei̯-.
S.v. Ved. √śay-¹ 'liegen', from PIE *k̑ei̯-.

S.v. Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long'. K. reconstructs as a preform for Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long' a PIE i-stem *dólugʰ-i-.  The exact reconstruction of the root is difficult, since forms elsewhere in IE (Ved. dīrghá-, OAv. darəga-, OCS dlьgъ, Lith. ìlgas) all reflect *dl̥h₁gʰ-o-, where the identity of the laryngeal is determined on the basis of Greek ἐν-δελεχής 'lasting long' < *delh₁gʰ-.

S.v. Ved. dīrghá- 'lang [zeitlich, räumlich], weitreichend, langdauernd'  (OAv. darəga-, YAv. darəγa- 'lang') which reflect PIE *dl̥h₁gʰ-ó- (OCS dlъgъ, SCr. dȕg, Lith. ìlgas 'lang', cf. Gk. δολιχός, ἐν-δελεχής 'langdauernd, ununterbrochen', Hitt. daluki- 'lang').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dьlgъ adj. 'long' < PIE *dl̥h₁gʰ-ó-, (cf. Skt. dīrghá-, Gk. δολιχός).

S.v. Lat. longus 'long' from PIE *dlongʰ-o- (cf. *dólugʰ- in Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long', PIE *dlh₁gʰ-o- in Skt. dīrghá- OAv. darəga-, OCS dlъgъ, SCr. dȕg, Lith. ìlgas, Alb. gjathë (+ *-tā-); Gk. δολιχός (< *dolh₁-i-gʰo-?), ἐνδελεχής 'lasting long, uninterrupted' < *delh₁gʰ-; PIE *dlongʰ-o- in Goth. laggs, OHG lang, OIc. langr, etc.). The root might be *de/olh₁-, cf. Cz. dél (poet.) 'length' < PSl. *dьlь, etc.

S.v. *arma- (c.) 'moon(god); month'.  No clear cognates outside of Anatolian.  The reading arma- underlying the Sumerograms ᵈEN.ZU, ITU⁽ᴷᴬᴹ⁾, or Akkadogram ᵈSÎN in Hittite is supported by derivatives like armanni- 'lunula' and names like ᵐAr-ma-zi-ti- = ᵐ˙ᵈSÎN-ma-LÚ-i-.  Derivatives are also found in CLuw. armannaima/i- 'decorated with lunulae' (the simple noun 'moon'is attested as [ᵈE]N.ZU-aš in CLuw., (DEUS)LUNA+MI-sa in HLuw.).  Also attested elsewhere in Anatolian are Lyd. armτa- 'belonging to Arma(?)', Lycian arm̃ma- 'moon', rm̃mazata- 'monthly offering(?).

S.v. Hitt. aiš / išš- 'mouth', from PIE *h₁eh₃-es-.  Cf. within Anatolian: CLuw. āaš- 'mouth', āaša- 'to speak(?)', HLuw. ásaza- 'to speak'; elsewhere in IE: Skt. ā́s-, Av. āh-, Lat. ōs, OIr. á 'mouth'.

S.v. Hitt. šankuu̯āi- 'nail; a unit of linear measure', generally connected to the complex of words meaning 'nail' elsewhere among the Indo-European languages (Lat. unguis, Gk. ὄνυξ, etc.).  This connection does not account for the initial š-.  It is possible to assume an s-mobile to account for it via a preform *s-h₃ngʰ-u-oi which would regularly yield Hitt. šankuu̯ai-.  Although the assumption of an s-mobile is here admittedly ad hoc, but other s-mobile forms not attested elsewhere in IE are also possibly found in išḫaḫru- 'tear' and šākuu̯a- 'eye' [cf. /cognate/3305/].

S.v. Hitt. išpant- 'night'. Formally Hitt. išpant- reflects a zero-grade with an added suffix -ent- (i.e. *k⁽ʷ⁾sp-ent-), which is also found in terms like ḫamešḫant- (beside ḫamešḫa-) 'spring', zēnant- (beside zēna-) 'autumn', and gimmant- (beside gim(m)-) 'winter', etc.

Regarding Hitt. natta 'not': "The word is clearly derived from PIE *ne 'not' but it is not quite clear in what way."  Cf. Pal. nī, nit 'not'; CLuw. nāu̯a 'not', nīš (prohibitive) 'not'; HLuw. na 'not', nis (prohibitive) 'not'; Lyd. ni- (prefix) 'not', nid 'not', nik 'and not', nikumek 'never'; Lyc. ne 'not', nepe 'not', nipe 'not' ni (prohibitive) 'not'.
For the comparanda to the root etymology advocated by Kloekhorst (2008:567-569), cf. s.v. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).

S.v. Hitt. mit(t)a- / miti- 'red' (adj.); 'red wool' (c.). The variety of forms attested suggest that the word is a loanword.  Čop (1958:28-32) attempted to connect it to Slavic *mědь 'copper' from a putative *moid-o-, but the lack of other IE cognates from this postulated form do not make this etymology very likely.

S.v. Hitt. ḫapa- 'river', (cf. Pal. ḫāpna- 'river', CLuw. ḫāpa/i- 'river', HLuw. hapa/i- 'river') < PAnat. *h₂ebo- < PIE *h₂ebʰ-o-, *h₂ebʰ-n- (cf. OIr. aub, gen. abae), MWe. afon 'river', Lat. amnis 'stream, river'.

Plausibly connects Hitt. ḫuu̯ai-, CLuw. ḫui(i̯a)-, HLuw. hwia- to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow', comparing English 'blow' used as 'to move as if carried or impelled by the wind' or 'to go away, move hurriedly' as a semantic parallel.

Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯ei̯- 'laufen' (not in IEW), which reconstructs a perfect form ?*h₂e-h₂u̯ói-/u̯i- as a possible stem ancestral to the Hitt. form, following Puhvel, HED H, p.423, dismissing the stem formation *h₂uh₁-i̯é- to *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow' (cf. Oettinger 1979:480-481) as semantically problematic.
For this set, the etymology to *h₂u̯eh₁- is to be preferred, after Kloekhorst, as the proposed semantic development is plausible.
S.v. tē- 'to speak, to state', from PIE *dʰeh₁- (cf. OCS děti 'to do, say', Skt. dhā- 'to put', Gk. τίθημι 'to put', etc.). Suppletive with ter- / tar- < PIE *tér- / *tr-énti.

S.v. arrir(r)a-, arir(r)a-, ar(r)ara- 'scrape'. "Phonesthetic reduplicative onomatopoeia of a grating sound."  Other proposed etymologies to comparanda elsewhere among the Indo-European languages are unconvincing.
S.v. Hitt. aruna- 'sea'. Etymology uncertain.
Lat. fruor, fruī 'to enjoy (the produce of)' from PIE *bʰruHg-i̯é/ó- (cf. Goth. brukjan, etc.), from which Lat. frūctus 'enjoyment, revenue; fruit produce' is a derivative.
Cf. s.v. *bʰreu̯H⁽g̑⁾- 'genießen, gebrauchen' (IEW 173).
S.v. Lat. vāgiō, -īre 'to cry'. Cf. for various etymological proposals.
Friulian uçât is derived from the verb uçâ < Lat. *acutiare derived from Lat. acutus, -a, -um (–G. Cadorini, p.c.)
Cf. s.v. *h₂ek̑- 'scharf sein/werden/machen' (IEW 18-22).
S.v. *h₂ek̑- 'scharf, spitz (sein / werden / machen)' (LIV 261, IEW 18ff.).
Friulian nasâ is derived from Friul. nâs < Lat. nāsus, -ī 'nose' (–G. Cadorini, p.c.).
Cf. notes to the inherited PIE word for 'nose' in /cognate/267/.
S.v. *nas- 'Nase'.
Cf. s.v. *telh₂- 'aufheben, auf sich nehmen' (IEW 1060-1).

S.v. Lat. tollō, -ere 'pick up, raise, remove', formed from nasal-infix stem *tl̥-né/n-h₂- (cf. OIr. tlenaid*, -tlen 'to lift, take away' < PCl. *tlina-; Gk. aor. ἔτλην, Goth. ϸulan 'to endure, bear', TochB tallaṃ 'raises').
Friulian o 'we' from Lat. nōs 'we' (–G. Cadorini, p.c.).
S.v. *h₂elh₂- 'ziellos gehen' (IEW 27-8).
Cf. s.v. *leu̯h₃- 'waschen' (IEW 692).
*pau̯s- 'to dress, clothe, cover'
S.v. *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren' (IEW 551), cf. n1 comparing Ved. śíśira- 'kühl, kalt', YAb. sarəta- 'kalt', root noun in YAv. sarə-δā 'Kälte bringend'.
S.v. *k̑elH ‘kalt werden, frieren’ (LIV 323, IEW 551), cf. n6 suggesting the Iranian lexemes are rather reflexes of 2. *k̑el- 'warm werden'.
S.v. j., g. vāstra- n. ‘Weide’ (p.1414); j., g. vāstrya- Adj. ‘was zur Weide-, Landwirtschaft, zum Feldbau gehört, sich darauf bezieht (usw.)’ (p. 1416).
Cf. s.v. *u̯ep- : u̯ō̆p- : up- ‚Wasser‘.
Cf. s.v. Skt. káṇṭakaḥ 'Dorn, Stachel / thorn, sting', also kaṇṭaḥ, m. 'id.'. Etymology uncertain.
Cf. s.v. Skt. valāhakaḥ 'Regenwolke, Gewitterwolke / rain-cloud, thunder-cloud'. Etymology unclear.
S.v. ?*k⁽ʷ⁾su̯ei̯bʰ- '(sich) schwingen' (IEW 625, 1041).
S.v. Skt. kṣipáti 'wirft, schleudert / throws, flings'. Further connections are hardly certain; the closest possibilities are Ru. šibátь 'werfen', šibkij 'schnell'.
S.v. *h₂ep- 'Wasser, Fluß' (IEW 1,51f., 1149, EIEC 486, 636).
Cf. s.v. Sp. cuesta 'espalda', from Lat. cŏsta 'costilla', 'costado, lado'.
Cf. s.v. *peth₂- ‘ausbreiten’
1.*peth₂- → *(s)peth₂-; S mobile wegen lat. spatium ‘Raum’, SCHUMACHER/MATZINGER 974

S.v. Skt. jāṅgalaḥ 'trocken, spärlich bewachsen, dabei nicht un-
fruchtbar / arid, sparingly grown with trees and
plants, though not unfertile' (Manu, u. a.), (…); nicht sicher erklärt.
Cf. s.v. *kʷr̥mi- ‚Wurm, Made‘

S.v. *mneh₂- 'denken an' (IEW 726-7).  CLuw. form manāti /mnāti/ 'sieht' possibly from root present *mnéh₂-/mn̥h₂- attested elsewhere via Ved. ā-manati, 'erwähnt, überliefert', Homeric Gk. μνάομαι 'denke an, freie' (+ other stem derivations), but the etymology is not fully clear (marked with '?' in LIV²).  For the etymological proposal, cf. {ref Starke 1980}:147.

S.v. Hitt. šar- (mid.), šarii̯e/a- (act.) 'to embroider(?), sew on(?); to truss(?) / sew(?), from PIE root *ser-, inflected as a root present in the mediopassive, or as active *sr̥-i̯é/ó-.  Cf. Lat. serō, Gk εἴρω 'string together'.
Cf. s.v. 2. *ser- 'aneinander reihen, verknüpfen' (IEW 911).

*dʰu̯es- ‘(ein-, aus-)atmen’; Im Bsl. auch sekundäre Vollst. I *dʰeu̯s-, vgl. ANTTILA 96, 123; in germ. *deuza- ‘Tier’ < *dʰeu̯s-ó- *‘mit Atem versehen’ dürfte eine Vr̥ddhi-Bildung zu einem Wurzelnomen *dʰus- ‘Atem’ vorliegen
S.v. eš- / aš- '(midd.) to sit down, seat oneself', etc. < PIE *h₁éh₁s- (cf. Skt. ā́ste 'to sit', āsa- 'seat', YAv. āh- 'to sit', Gk. ἧσται 'to sit').
S.v. Ved. √ās- 'sitzen, wohnen, sich niederlassen, sich aufhalten, weilen' < PIE *h₁eh₁s- (cf. YAv. āh-, Hitt. ēš-/aš- 'sitzen').
Cf. s.v. Hitt. nēpiš- 'sky, heaven' < PIE s-stem neut. *nébʰ-os, *nebʰ-és-os.
S.v. Oss. arv 'небо', from Iranian *abra-, cf. Ved. abhrá- 'cloud, thunder cloud'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. *abhrá- 'Gewitterwolke, Gewölk, Regenwolke' < PIE *n̥bʰ-ró- (*nebʰ-), cf. YAv. aβra- 'Regen[wolke]'.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. šupp- 'to sleep' (mediopassive inflection, derived to the root), šupparii̯e/a- 'to sleep' (active inflection, secondarily derived from nominal 'sleep' as through from PIE *sup-r-i̯e/o-).
MIA & NIA forms derived from Skt. suptáḥ 'sleep'.
s.v. Vedic nā́raka- / nāraká- m.'hell, underworld', naráka- 'id.', Pali naraka- 'abyss, cleft, cleavage'
s.v. Greek (ἔ)νέρθε(ν) adv. prep. '(from) below, below' for more cognates
Cf. s.v. Hitt. tuḫḫuu̯ai- / tuḫḫui- 'smoke', from PIE *dʰuéh₂-u-ōi-s, *dʰuh₂-ói-m, *dʰuh₂-u-i-ós, generally derived from the PIE root *dʰuh₂- 'to produce smoke, to breathe'.

Cf. s.v. 2. *mei̯H- 'heranreifen, gedeihen' (IEW 711-2). Cf. fn1: *H = *h₁ or *h₃. To this Ved. máyas-, YAv. maiiah- 'Erquickung, Behagen' could also belong with the semantic shift 'reifen, reif' → 'weich, mild'; and further with different suffixes Lat. mītis 'mild', Lith. míelas 'sanft, lieb', etc.
*pleu̯- ‘schwimmen, schweben’

S.v. Hitt. illui̯anka-, ellii̯anku- 'snake, serpent'. According to K., the stem alternations between ilui̯anka-, ellii̯anku-, and possibly illiunki- point to a non-IE origin of the word. The proposal of {ref Katz 1998} attempting to explain the word as a compound *eel-snake consisting of elements *illui̯- (cf. PGerm. ǣla- 'eel') and *anka- 'snake' (Lat. anguis, Gr. ὄφις) is therefore to be rejected.
Cf. s.v. 9440 Skt. bhāṇḍa- (1) n. 'pot, dish, vessel, ornament, wares'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair', from PIE *k̑ē̆s-ró- (cf. Hitt. kišzi ~ kišanzi 'to comb, card' < *kes-ti, *ks-énti; OCS česati 'to scratch, pluck' < *kes-eh₂-, etc.).
S.v. Hitt. ḫašter(a)- 'star', from PIE *h₂ster- (cf. Gk. ἀστήρ, Arm. astł, Skt. stár-, Lat. stēlla, Goth. stairno 'star').
*h₃reg̑- ‘gerade richten, ausstrecken’
In spite of the unexpected meaning, the Germanic verb [*rekan-] continues the PIE root *h₃reǵ- 'to make straight' (…).
s.v. áma- 'this here'

S.v. Proto-Germanic *berga- 'mountain', from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ-o- (cf. OIr. bri 'hill, plain' < *bʰrg̑ʰ-eh₂-; Arm. barjr 'high', Hitt. parku- 'id.' < bʰrg̑ʰ-u-; Skt. br̥hánt-, Av. bərəz(ant)- 'high' < *bʰrg̑ʰ-ent-).
S.v. *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'hoch werden, sich erheben' (LIV 78f., IEW 140f.).
Cf. s.v. *bʰerg̑ʰ- ‘hoch werden, sich erheben’ (IEW 140-1).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *salta- 'salt', a neuter collective noun derived from the strong verb saltan- 'to salt (down), pickle', from *sh₂ld-ie-, an extended form of the stem *sh₂el-, cf. (Lith. saldùs 'sweet', OCS sladъkъ 'id.', Ru. dial. solódkij 'id.').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *nasō- ~ *nusō- 'nose', as though from PIE *nh̥₂-s-eh₂-. Traditionally the root is reconstructed as *nā̆s- with a-vocalism (Pokorny IEW: 755), but Kortlandt (1985b:119) postulated an ablauting s-stem nom. *néh₂-s, gen. *nh₂-s-ós, acc. *nh₂-és-m in order to account for the ablaut of e.g. Lith. nósis  < *neh₂-s- vs. Ru. nos < *nh₂-es-.
S.v. nas- ‚Nase‘ (näs- aus den dehnstufen Kasus dieses kons. St., ursprüngl. dem Nom. Sg.), ursprüngl. wohl ‚Nasenloch‘
*anþara- adj./num. 'the other (of two), the second' - Go. anþar num. 'id.' (…) → *h₂en-tero (IE)
S.v. Proto-Germanic *spila- 'play; game'; Also cf. the apparently denominal OE spilian, OS spilon, Du. spelen, OHG spilon, G spielen w.v. 'to play' < *spilōjan-. No certain etymology.
S.v. peru- 'rock', generally compared to Ved. párvata- 'mountain', via an earlier heteroclite *per-u̯r̥, *peru̯(e)n-, although Puhvel is skeptical of aspects of the stem-formation.
Cf. s.v. *h₃reg̑- 'gerade richten, ausstrecken' (IEW 854-7).

*wega- m. 'way, road' (…) Derived from the strong verb * wegan- (q.v.); 
*wegan- s.v. 'to move, carry' (…) → *uéǵʰ-e- (IE)
*u̯eg̑ʰ- ‘schweben; fahren’
S.v. Hitt. istanu-, astanu- 'sun, sun-god(dess), solar deity; majesty'. A loanword from Hattic Eštan-, Aštan-, which matches Hitt. ᵈUTU-uš in a bilingual text, cf. {ref Laroche 1947}.
Hitt. maliddu- 'sweet' is a derivative of Hitt. militt- / malitt- 'honey' from PIE *mél-it / *ml̥-it-ós, cf. Gk. μέλι, μέλιτος, Goth, miliþ 'honey', Alb. mjaltë 'honey', Lat. mel, mellis 'honey'.

S.v. Hitt. putkii̯e/a- 'to swell (said of fermented dough and of a tumor or boil on the head'. Etymology unclear.  Earlier proposals relying on assuming PIE 'thorn' clusters *-Kþ- are now to be discarded.
S.v. νέω 'to swim', from PIE *sneh₂- 'swim'.
S.v. nō, nāre 'to swim' < PIE *(s)neh₂-(ie/o-) 'to swim'.

S.v. TochB nāsk- 'swim, bathe, take a bath', from PIE *(s)n(e)hₐ-sk̑e/o- 'swim, bathe, wash' (cf. Skt. snā́ti 'bathes', Av. snayeitē 'washes, purifies', Gk. νήχω 'swim', Lat. nāre 'swim', MIr. snáid 'swims').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *snā- 'swim', from PIE *sneh₂- (cf. Skt. snā́ti 'bathes', Lat. nō, nāre, TochB nask- 'bathe').
Cf. s.v. Ved. √snā- 'baden, sich waschen', from PIE *(s)neh₂- (cf. Lat. nāre, 'schwimmen', OIr. snām 'das Schwimmen', TochB nāsk- 'sich Baden', Hitt. sanh- 'ausspülen', etc.).

S.v. Hitt. dā- / d- 'to take, to wed, to decide' Hitt. stem dā- is inflected in the ḫi-conjugation and exhibits *-o-/-Ø- root-ablaut, reflecting a pre-form *dóh₃-/*dh₃-. Elsewhere in IE cf. Skt. dádāti, Av. daδāiti, Arm. tam, Gk. δίδωμι, OLith. duosti, Lat. dō, dāre 'to give', OCS daxъ 'he gave'.
S.v. *deh₃- 'geben' (IEW 223-5).

S.v. Hitt. maklant- 'thin, slim (of animals)', reflecting a preform *m(e)h₂k̑-lo-nt-, whose root *meh₂k̑- is attested elsewhere among the IE languages via PGerm. *magrá- 'meagre, slim', Gk. μακρός 'long, tall', Lat. macer 'meagre, lean' < PIE *mh₂k̑-ró-.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. māl- 'mental power(?)', connected with CLuw. māl- 'thought, idea' and its derivative mal(a)i- 'to think, to suppose'.  To be connected with Gk. μέλω 'to be an object of care and thought, to care for' which would point to a PIE root *mel-.
Cf. s.v. *melh₁- 'Sorge bereiten' (IEW 718).

S.v. Hitt. teri- 'three', from PIE *trei- / *tri-; *tri-i̯o- (cf. Skt. tráyas, Av. θrāiiō, Gk. τρεῖς, Lat. trēs, OIr. trí, tri, ON ϸrír, Goth. ϸrins (acc.pl.m.f.), Lith. trỹs, OCS trьje, TochA tre, TochB trai 'three').
S.v. Gk. τρεῖς 'three', from PIE *trei-es 'three' (cf. Skt. tráyaḥ, Lat. trēs, etc.).

S.v. TochB trai 'three', which with TochA tre (m.) and tri (f.) reflect PToch *treyä and *täryā. PToch. *treyä must be as though from *tróyes, with vocalism influenced from *kʷetwóres 'four'. This *tróyes replaced the earlier and more widespread PIE *tréyes 'three' (cf. Skt. tráyaḥ, Gk. τρεῖς, Lat. trēs, OIr. tri, etc.).
S.v. Lat. trēs 'three', from PIE *treies (cf. OIr. trí, tri, Bret. tri, Skt. tráyas, YAv. θrāiiō, Gk. τρεῖς, Lith. trỹs, OCS trьje, OIc. þrír, TochB trey, trai, TochA tre, tri).
S.v. Arm. erekʻ 'three', from PIE *treies 'three' (cf. Skt. tráyas, Gk. τρεῖς, Lith. trỹs 'three', etc.).

S.v. Ved. tray- 'drei' (cf. IIr. YAv. θrāiiō, θrāiias-ča, etc.), from PIE *tréi̯-es, Acc.pl. *trí-ns, m./n. Instr.pl. *tri-bʰis, DatAbl.pl.*tri-bʰ(i̯)ós, gen.pl. tréi̯-ō̆m, loc.pl. *tri-sú (cf. Gk. τρεῖς, Lat. trēs, OIr. trī, tri, ON ϸrīr, Goth. ϸrins (acc.pl.), Lith. trỹs, OCS trije, etc.).
S.v. Hitt. tāru- 'wood', from PIE *dóru- (cf. Gk. δόρυ 'wood', Skt. dā́ru- 'wood', OE trēo(w) 'tree', OCS drěvo 'tree').

S.v. AGk. δένδρεον 'arbre', the noun based on *drew-, *dru- etc. (cf. Gk. δρῦς, δόρυ, etc.). The stem *drewo- is attested in Goth. triu- OEng. treow 'arbre', etc. Expressive reduplication rests on *δερ-δρεϝ-ον, developed to δένδρον by dissimilation of the first ρ > ν. The same treatment is found in *θορ-θορυζω > τονθορύζω, *γαρ-γραινα > γάγγραινα.

Cf. s.v. Ved. dā́ru- 'Holz' (IIr. cf. YAv. dāuru-, OPers. dāruv 'Holz', NPers. dār 'Holz, Baum' šughni δōrg 'Holz, Scheit', etc.), from PIE *dóru-, *dréu̯-s, *dru- (cf. Gk. δόρυ 'Holz, Baumstamm, δρῦς 'Baum', Hitt. ta-a-ru 'Holz, Baum', OE trēo(w) = engl. tree, OCS drěvo 'Baum', etc.).

s.v. *lāma- ʻdefectiveʼ, Pa. lāmaka- ʻinferior, bad, sinfulʼ, Pk. lāmā- f. ʻwitchʼ; 
Addenda: *lāma-, cf. OHG lam ʻlame ʼ, OCS lomiti ʻto breakʼ; with reference to T. Burrow, BSOAS xxxviii, p. 76
Cf. s.v. rámate 'beruhigt, läßt ruhen, stehen still, rastet, weilt, ergötzt sich / calms, stops, rests, abides, enjoys, is pleased'.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. tān 'for the second time, again, subordinately'. Hitt. attests only adverbial dān < *du̯oi̯-om (cf. Skt. dvayá- 'twofold'), but other Anatolian languages attest the numeral properly: cf. HLuw. twi- 'two', Lyc. kbi- 'another' < *du̯i-, and derived forms via HLuw. twisu (adv.) 'twice', Lyc. kbihu- 'twice', Mil. tbisu 'twice'.
S.v. Gk. δύο 'two', from PIE *duu̯o, *duu̯-eh₃ (?) 'two'.

S.v. Arm. erku 'two', from the PIE word for 'two' (cf. Gk. δύο, Skt. dva-, etc.'). The final -u in Armenian points to a dual form *duo-h₁ (cf. Skt. dvā́ m. 'two') or *duōu (cf. Skt. NADu. d(u)váu 'two').
S.v. Lat. duo, duae, duo 'two', from PIE *du-o-h₁ (nom.du.m.), *du-o-ih₁ (nom.du.n.f.). Original *duō has become duo in Lat. by iambic shortening.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *d(ъ)va 'two' (ESSJa V 185-186), from PIE *duo-h₁, *duo-ih₁ (cf. Skt. dvā́, Gk. δυώ).
S.v. Ved. dva- 'zwei', (cf. IIr. YAv. duua [nom.du.]), from PIE *d(u)u̯ó.
S.v. *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (IEW 293-6).
S.v. Hitt. i̯e/a- 'to go, come, to walk, to proceed, to stride, to march', from PIE *h₁i-i̯e/o-.
S.v. TochB i- 'to go, to travel', which with TochA i- 'id.' reflect PToch *i̯ä- from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'go'.
S.v. TochAB i- 'gehen', 'go', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'go'.

S.v. mū́rchati ʻbecomes solidʼ (AV), mūrchayati ʻcauses (milk) to coagulateʼ Kauś. (√mūrch-), Pali mucchati ʻcurdlesʼ; Prakrit mucchaï ʻcongealsʼ; Si. midenavā ʻto coagulateʼ < MIA *mūch-; Prakrit mucchāvia- ʻcaused to curdleʼ > Si. mudavanavā. (No. 10240)
S.v. Proto-Slavic *jьti 'go' (ESSJa VIII 247-248), from PIE *h₁ei- 'go' (cf. Skt. éti 'go', Gk. εἶμι 'go', Lat. īre 'go').
S.v. Ved. √mūrch- 'fest werden, gerinnen, sich verdichten' < PIE *mr̥H-sk̑e- (*merH-).

S.v. Ved. √ay-¹ 'gehen, wandern, fahren, gelangen', from PIE *h₁ei̯- (cf. Hitt. i-it 'geh!' Luw. i-ti 'er geht', Gk. εἶμι 'werde gehen', Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', OLith. eimì 'gehe', OCS iti 'gehen', etc.).
S.v. Hitt. ārr- / arr- 'to wash', from PIE *h₁órh₁-ei, *h₁r̥h₁-énti (from root *h₁erh₁- with *o ~ *Ø root ablaut), cf. TochA yär- 'bathe'.
S.v. Hitt. u̯ātar / u̯itēn- 'water', from PIE *uód-r, ud-én- (cf. Skt. udán-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, OCS voda, Goth. wato, ON vatn, OSax. watar, OHG wazzar 'water').
S.v. TochB war 'water', which with TochA wär reflect Proto-Tocharian *wärä, probably a regular reflex of PIE *udrom, a regular thematisation of *wodr-/udn-.
S.v. ὕδωρ, -ατος 'water', from PIE *u̯od-r̥, *ud-n-, coll. udōr 'water'.
S.v. U. utur 'Wasser', the inherited word for water < PIE *u̯edōr (cf. Gk. ὕδωρ, ὕδατος, Hitt. u̯atar, u̯etenaš, etc.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *voda 'water' from PIE *uod-r/n- 'water' (cf. Skt. udan-, Hitt. u̯ātar, u̯etenas, Gk. ὕδωρ, Lat. unda, 'wave', Goth. wato, OSax. watar, OIc. vatn).
Cf. s.v. Ved. udán- 'Wasser', from PIIr. *ud-r-/*ud-n-, derived to PIE *u̯ed- (cf. YAv. vaiδi- 'Wasserlauf', Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, OS watar, ON vatn, OCS voda 'Wasser', etc.).

Cf. s.v. Ved. vā́r- 'Wasser' (YAv. vāra- 'Regen', MPers. wārān-, NPers. bārān, etc.), from PIE *(H)u̯eh₁-r- (cf. Luw. u̯a-a-ar 'Wasser', TochA wär, TochB war 'Wasser', ONor. vari 'Flüssigkeit, Wasser').
S.v. Hitt. ḫarki- / ḫargai- (adj.) 'white, bright', from PIE *h₂(e)rg̑-(e)i- (cf. Gk ἀργός 'white', Skt. r̥jrá- 'shining reddishly, brightcoloured; quick, hurrying', TochA ārki, TochB ārkwi 'white').
S.v. TochB ārkwi 'white'. TochA ārki and TochB ārkwi reflect PToch *ārkw(ä)i, which in turn must reflect (in some way) PIE *h₂erg̑-u(i)-n-.
S.v. Ved. árjuna- 'licht, weiß, siberfarben', a derivation from PIE *h₂erg̑- (cf. Gk. ἄργυρος 'Silber').

S.v. Hitt. ḫuu̯ant- 'wind', from PIE *h₂uh₁-ent-, which exactly matches Gk. ἀέντ-, functioning as the participle of the verb 'to blow'. Other cognates from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- include Skt. vā́nt- 'blowing', vā́ta- 'wind', Lat. ventus, Goth. winds, TochA want-, TochB yente.
S.v. TochB yente 'wind', which with TochA want reflect Proto-Tocharian *wi̯ente from a PIE *h₂u̯eh₁n̥to- (cf. Skt. vāta-, Av. vāta-, Lat. ventus, Goth. winds, Hitt. hwant-, etc.).
S.v. Skt. vā́ta- 'Wind, Windgott' (cf. IIr. in OAv. vāta- 'wind', YAv. vāta- 'wind', etc.), from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁-n̥t-o- to √*h₂u̯eh₁- (cf. Lat. ventus, Goth. winds, etc.).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *větrъ 'wind', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *ueʔtr- (cf. Lith. vė́tra 'storm', Latv. vȩ̄tra 'storm', derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *vějati 'blow (of wind), winnow' from PIE *h₂ueh₁- (cf. Skt. vā́ti 'blow (of wind)', Gk. ἄησι (Hes.) 'id.', OHG wāen 'id.').

S.v. Lat. ventus 'wind', from PIE *h₂ueh₁-nt-o- 'wind' (cf. W. gwynt 'wind', Hitt. huu̯ant- 'wind', Skt. vāta- 'wind, god of wind', OAv., YAv. vāta- 'wind', Gk. ἄησι 'to blow', Goth. winds, OHG wint, TochB yente, TochA want (~wänt) 'wind').

S.v. Hitt. pattar / pattan- or pettar / pettan- 'wing, feather', from PIE *póth₂-r / *pth₂-én- or *péth₂(ō)r / *peth₂-én- (cf. OHG fedara, ON fjǫðr 'feather', fiðri 'feathers', Gk. πτερόν, Lat. penna, Skt. pátra- 'wing').
Cf. s.v. πτερόν 'feather, wing, pinion', derived from PIE *pet- 'fly' (cf. Skt. pátra- 'wing, feather', Lat. acci-piter, -tris 'hawk', OHG fedara, ON fjǫðr 'feather', etc.).

S.v. Arm. tʻew 'wing; arm', related to Arm. tʻer 'leaf', together with tʻer 'side', tʻiṙ- 'to fly', and tʻitʻeł/ṙn 'butterfly' based on PIE *pter- 'feather, wing', probably derived from PIE *pet- 'fly' (cf. Gk. πτερόν 'feather', πτέρυξ 'wing of a bird', πέτομαι 'to fly', etc')
S.v. Hitt. u̯itt- 'year', a root noun from PIE *u̯et-.

Cf. s.v. Lat. lacrimāre 'cry, weep', a denominal verb from Lat. lacruma, dacruma 'tear'. Lat. lacruma, dacruma is often considered to be a loanword from Gk. δάκρυμα 'tear' on the basis that an inherited preform *dakru-mn̥ would have yielded **dacrumen in Latin, and additionally the suffix -ma is not productive in Latin (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:336). {ref Hamp 1972}:291-99, however, points out that Greek δάκρυμα is itself a recent formation in Greek, is not attested before the fifth century, and is never attested as the regular word for 'tear' (i.e. δάκρυον). Perhaps the Greek forms and the Latin forms can be reconciled via an dissimilation *d ... *n > d ... m of an earlier preform *dakruna > *dakruma (cf. the distance dissimilation *m … *b > n … b attested *temebrae > tenebrae, cf. tenebrae, s.v.), but this solution is admittedly speculative.
Cf. s.v. Lat. lacruma (lacrima), -ae (OLat. dacrima according to Paulus ex Festus 60, 5), possibly a loanword from Greek δάκρυμα.

S.v. Lat. dulcis, -e 'doux au goût' "On est tenté d'établir un rapport avec gr. γλυκύς «doux», γλεῦκος «vin doux», en admettant que γλυκύς reposerait sur *dluku- et qu'il y aurait eu assimilation.  Hypothèse non vérifiable. Pas d'autre rapprochement."

S.v. Lat. dulcis 'sweet', which may be accounted for by Proto-Italic *dulkwi- 'sweet'.  Due to difficulties in phonetic developments in both Greek and Latin, it is quite possible that Lat. dulcis, Gk. γλυκύς are common borrowings from an unknown source.  (Cf. entry for further discussion.)

S.v. γλυκύς 'sweet' < ?*dlku- 'sweet'. Mycenaean de-re-u-ko (perhaps /dleu̯kos/) makes the hypothesis of dissimilation *δλ- > γλ- possible, but the -υ- in the root is still unexpected, making a connection to Lat. dulcis via *dl̥k-u- (vel sim.) still problematic.
On the basis of Mycenaean and Classical Attic forms, I suggest a reconstructed Proto-Greek *dl(e)u̯ku- (vel sim.) for a root reference form.

S.v. paśce* (n.) '(a woman's) breast; [in the plural] the seat of wisdom'.  Connected with other cognates which appear to show thematisation from earlier *pstḗn- (Skt. stána-, Av. fštāna-, Arm. stin, Gk. στήνιον).

Cf. s.v. Ved. stána- 'weibliche Brust, Mutterbrust, Zitze'.  The form in Proto-Indo-Iranian was evidently *pstana-, cf. Av. fštāna- 'weibliche Brust', ərəduua-fšna- 'mit straffen Brusten', from PIE *psten- (cf. Arm. stin 'weibliche Brust' Gk. στήνιον· στῆθος [Hesych.]).
S.v. Arm. awr 'day; time, age', connected with Gk. ἦμαρ, Arc. ἆμαρ, -ατος 'day', Att. ἠμέρα 'day', etc. and is likely to reflect earlier *āmōr from PIE *Heh₂m-ōr.

S.v. Ved. śúṣka- 'trocken, ausgetrocknet, dürr', from PIIr. *súška- (cf. YAv. huška- 'dry', OPers. uška- 'mainland', Khot. huṣka-, MPers. hušk, NPers. xušk, Oss. x˳ysḱ/xusḱ(æ), Pashto wuč, etc. 'dry').  Cf. Ved. √śoṣ- 'dry out' < PIE *sau̯s- (Gk. αὕω 'dry out', OEng. sēar 'dry', Lith. saũsas 'trocken', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *h₂seu̯s- 'trocken werden' (IEW 880-881).
S.v. 8019 Ved. pāṁśu- (MBh.), pāṁsú- (AV.) m. ʻcrumbling soil, dust, sandʼ.
s.v. tailá- n. ʻsesamum oil, oilʼ (AV), cf. tilá- 'sesamum'
s.v. tilá- m.; origin not clear
S.v. 2944 Ved. kalpáyati ʻ sets in order ʼ RV., ʻ trims, cuts ʼ VarBr̥S. [Cf. kr̥pāṇa -- m. ʻ knife ʼ Pāṇ.: √kI̊p]
Cf. s.v. Ved. √kalp- 'in rechter Ordnung sein, sich fügen', of disputed origin, possibly with Lat. scalpere, Gothic halba- 'half'?
S.v. 12761 Skt. śvásiti 'breathes heavily' RV. (śvásantu AV.). [√śvas1] and 12769 Skt. śvāsá- m. 'breath, breathing' MBh., 'asthma' Suśr. [√śvas1].
s.v. sanná 1 ʻdepositedʼ (ŚB), √sad-; Si. sin ʻseated, restingʼ, whence innavā ʻto sit, be present'
S.v. 10650 rása m. 'sap or juice of plants' RV.

S.v. rása- 'Pflanzensaft, Saft, Flüssigkeit, Seim, Essenz, Mark', cf. Ir. YAv. raŋhā- '(name of a mythical river)', *raha-ka- 'Ader' MSogd. r'k, Chores. r'k, MPers. rhg, rg, Parth. rhk, Khot. rrā Adern, not to be separated from Lat. rōs, 'Tau, Tautropfen', Lith. rasà, OCS rosa 'Tau'. Perhaps to a root noun *(h₁)ros-.
s.v. kalāpa- m. ʻbundle, quiver of arrowsʼ (MBh.)
S.v. 6130 *daṇḍakakarman- 'forest-work'. [daṇḍaka- , kár-man- 1] (> Si. daḍayam 'hunting' (EGS 69) prob. Si. cmpd.)

S.v. 11987 Skt. viṣṭara- m. 'anything spread out, handful of grass or rushes for sitting on' Gr̥Śr., m.n. 'any seat' MBh., m. 'tree' lex. 2. vistara- m. 'spreading, diffuseness' MBh., vistarakēṇa 'in detail' Pat. [√str̥]. (Si. vatura 'water, flood' < 2. vistara-).
Cf. s.v. śpāl 'head'; on the basis of TochAB śpāl 'head' one must reconstruct *gʰebʰh₂l- or *gʰebʰōl-.
S.v.5853 Skt. tuṇḍa- n. ʻbeak, trunk, snoutʼ (TĀr., MBh.), ʻcontemptuous term for mouthʼ Bādar., túṇḍika- ʻhaving a trunkʼ (AV); certainly non-Aryan and prob. ← Mu.
S.v. *(s)teu̯p- 'stoßen, schlagen' (IEW 1034). For the Luw. & Lyc. forms cf. {ref Oettinger 1979}:417, 535, {ref Hajnal 1995}:127.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kora 'bark', derived from PIE *(s)ker- (cf. Gk. κείρω 'shear', OIc. skera 'cut').
S.v. Ved. kr̥ṣná- 'schwarz, dunkel'.  Mayrhofer reconstructs *kr̥snó-, cf. Balt. *kirsna- (OPruss. kirsnan 'black'), Proto-Slavic *čьr(ch)na- > OCS črьnъ 'black, dark', etc.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ (adj.) 'black' (ESSJa IV 155-157), from PIE *kr̥s-nó- (cf. Skt. kr̥ṣṇá- 'black').
S.v. U. adro (Umbrian, Latin script).
s.v. ā́yāti ʻcomes nearʼ (RV), āyāta- (MBh.) (√yā-)

S.v. Ved. √hras- 'verringern, klein machen, kürzen' (Skt. hrasvá- 'kurz, klein'; mi., ni., pā. rassa- pkt. hassa-, rahasa- 'klein, leicht', etc.), probably from PIE *g̑ʰres-/*g̑ʰers- (MIr. gerr 'kurz').
S.v. Proto-Iranic *braiH- 'to shave, shear, cut' < PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut off'(?) (cf. Skt. bhrī- 'to harm' OCS briti, Russ. брить 'to shave', OIr. bronnaid 'injures, damages').
S.v. *bʰrei̯H- 'schneiden' (IEW 166-167).
Cf. s.v. 3. *per- 'schlagen' (IEW 818-819). [Albanian cognates not in LIV².]
S.v. 3. *per- 'schlagen' (IEW 818-819).
Cf. s.v. √roc- 'leuchten, scheinen, glänzen' < PIE *leu̯k- 'shine'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *rauč- 'to shine, radiate'.
S.v. *bʰeh₁dʰ- 'bedrängen' (IEW 114). Cf. probably Lith. bėdà 'Not, Kummer' = OCS (+) běda (if not to *bʰedʰh₂-).

S.v. ἥλιος 'sun' from PIE *seh₂u-el- 'sun'. Note dialectal varieties Ion. ἠέλιος, West Greek ἀέλιος (Cretan ἀϝέλιος) more closely preserve the structure of earlier *seh₂u̯-el- (with e-grade ablaut generalised in both stem and suffix).

Possibly cognate with Tocharian B yolo 'bad', Gk. ὀδύνη, Arm. erkn, OIr. idu (cf. {ref Schindler 1975}, {ref Watkins 1982}, {ref Adams 2013}:555-556), but these connections are uncertain (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:420-422, and more recently regarding the Tocharian lexemes {ref Peyrot 2016}. Cf. further discussion in /cognate/7558/).

Possibly cognate with Hittite idālu-, Luwian ādduu̯āli- 'bad' ({ref Adams 2013:555-556}; tentatively mentioned but not explicitly rejected by {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:420-422). Alternatively a loan from Old Turkish ({ref Peyrot 2016}:327-335).

Accepts connection of TochB yolo 'bad, evil' to earlier PIE *h₁edu̯ol-ōn-, a derivative of *h₁edu̯ol- 'that which eats', which is possibly connected to the family of words found in Gk. ὀδύνη 'pain, suffering', Arm. երկն / erkn / 'birth pangs, great pain' < *h₁edu̯on-.
Cf. s.v. *h₂ep- 'Wasser, Fluß' (IEW 1,51f., 1149; EIEC 486, 636).

Since {ref Watkins 1973} the Celtic words have been connected to Hittite and Palaic words for 'river' from a PIE n-stem *h₂ebʰ-n-, more recently followed by {ref Willi 2004} and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:294-295 s.v. Hitt. ḫapa-. A popular alternative analysis reconciles the Celtic words with Indo-Iranic words for 'water' (cf. /cognate/157/) and Baltic and Nuristani lexemes for 'river' (cf. /cognate/7856/) via a derivation using the 'Hoffmann Suffix' *h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:23-24 s.v. Proto-Celtic *abon-; {ref NIL} 311-317 tentatively reconstructs for Celtic ?*h₂ep-h₃on-, cf. {ref NIL} with references to further literature), but this analysis must assume an inner-PIE development *-ph₃- > *-b- (e.g. *pi-ph₃-e-ti > Ved. píbati '(s)he drinks'; cf. Lat. bibō with voicing assimilation to the reduplicated syllable). Since the number of examples of *-ph₃- > *-b- are few in number, this must remain a conjectural proposal.  The cognacy in this class therefore follows the etymology of {ref Watkins 1973} to a root *h₂ebʰ-.

Perhaps root-cognate with of Anatolian and Celtic lexemes meaning 'river', if the Celtic lexemes are to be analysed as from ?*h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. {ref NIL} 311-317 and further discussion in /cognate/1735/).
S.v. Lat. rādix 'root' < Proto-Italic wrād-i- (cf. W. gwraidd 'roots', Gk. ῥάδιξ 'branch, twig', Goth. waurts, Alb. rrëzë 'root' < all from forms of PIE *ur(e)h₂-d-iH- ‘root’.
S.v. ON rotinn 'verfault', cf. OE rotian 'verfaulen, verwesen'.
Cf. s.v. *gerbʰ- 'einritzen, einkerben' (IEW 392, [478]), cf. OE (+)  ceorfan 'abschneiden, eingraben'.
S.v. *sneh₁- ‘spinnen’ (IEW 973).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *nēan- 'to sew', a strong verb derived from a PIE root *(s)neh₁- (cf. Gk. νέω 'to spin', Lat. neō, nēre 'id.', OIr. sníid 'to tie', W. nyddu 'to spin' < *snéh₁-, Ru. nit' 'thread', Lith. nýtis '(warp) thread' < nh₁i-ti-), cf. also PGmc. *nēϸlō 'needle'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *skarpa- ‘sharp’, an o-grade adjective derived to Proto-Germanic *skerban- ~ *skerpan- ~ *skrepan- 'to scrape, scratch', a strong verb based on the IE root *skrebʰ- (cf. Russ. skrestí, Latv. šķir̃ba 'fissure', Lith. skir̃bti 'to become sour', Lat. scrobis 'hole in the ground, pit').

Presumably cognate with the root of PIE *u̯és-r/n- 'spring' (pace IEW 311; cf. Greek ἕαρ, Proto-Indo-Iranian *vásri 'in spring time', which in turn must be separated from *h₂u̯és-r/n- 'dawn, time of the day-rim' > Vedic vāsará- "morgentlich leuchtend", etc., pace Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 533); also cognate with 3. *u̯es- 'to graze, eat' via 'to indulge oneself in, feast on, delight' (German 'schwelgen in etw.'), cf. LIV, p. 693f.

Parallel derivations. The stem is identical to the one of the anaphoric pronoun *(h₁)i- ~*(h₁)ei-. Initial laryngeal *h₁ is required for *(h₁)i- once this stem is etymologically connected to the relativizing pronominal adjective *h₁ió-.
PIE verbs *mel-d- and *mel-dʰ- are two different derivatives of PIE *mel- 'soft' - compare Proto.Germanic *meldi- 'mild' etc., note 1 of *mel-dʰ- (LIV 431)

The initial consonant cannot be reconstructed for PII because Vedic si : OP θi- does not conform to any regular Indo-Iranian sound correspondence. This word is highly likely to be a parallel loan with initial sound substitution or the like.
lex., masr̥ṇa- ʻsoft, tenderʼ Kāv. are sanskritized forms of MIA, √mr̥d-, cf. Pk. masiṇa-, masaṇa- ʻsoft, slipperyʼ
S.v. 4485 *ghummati 'revolves'. 2. *ghumati. [Replaces ghūrṇati; poss. < *ghūrma- : *ghūr- ] Addenda: B. ghumā read B. ghumā̆na.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √kāś- 'sichtbar werden, erscheinen', from which is derived ākāśá- 'freier Raum, Luftraum, Öffnung', perhaps to PIE *kʷek̑-, if the root is connected with Gk. τέκμωρ, τέκμαρ 'Zeichen, Merkmal'.
S.v. 12625 Skt. śoṇita- 'blood' Gr̥Śr. ; with ending -ita- by analogy to lohita- 'blood', cf. 12623 Ved. śóṇa- (1) 'red, crimson; purple'.
S.v. Ved. śóṇa- adj., 'rot, hochrot' (RV+), śóṇita- n. "nach r/lóhita- umgebildet", from PIE *k̑óu̯-no- 'leuchtend', cf. TochA koṃ, TochB 'Tag, Sonne' Welsh cun 'lieblich'.
Cf. s.v. 5500 *ṭhiṅga- (1) ʻblock, stick, legʼ, 2. *ṭheṅga-, cf. A. ṭheṅgā, B. ṭheṅg ʻlegʼ, ṭheṅgā ʻcudgelʼ; Or. ṭheṅga ʻlegʼ, etc. - seems to be related to 'leg'
S.v. 5428 ṭaṅka- (3) (a) '*rod, spike', (b) m. 'leg' lex. 2. ṭaṅga- 3 m. 'leg' lex.
Pasht. ɣər 'leap, jump' ? < IE *g(w)elH- 'to throw', = Grk. BALLOO 'I throw'
Pasht. WAYEL 'to speak' < Iran. *uab, uaf 'call, utter'
related to Pasht. māt 'broken'? < IE *máǵ- 'to knead, smear', = Gr. MASSOO 'I knead', NE MAKE

Rejects Orel (1998:524) with IEW 483-5 who give a semantic development of 'unlucky, mourning' > 'black' as semantically and phonetically questionable, and far-fetched. Offers as an alternative a comparison with *gʷʰHi-d- 'light, grey coloured' (so Demiraj 1997:427-428, cf. Gk. φαιός 'brownish, grey', but admits 'albeit uncertain'.
S.v. Alb. zi, 'black', O. connects the term to MHG quāt 'dirt', OE cwéad 'bad', Lith. gė́da 'shame', Slav. *gadъkъ 'disgusting', *gadъ 'reptile, worm', as derivatives of a PIE root *gʷed-.
if identical with Arm. Y-ET 'after, with, amidst', then prob. related to Gr. PEDA and fr. IE *ped- 'foot'
IE *k(w)em- 'to gulp, sip'
maybe Bal. JAN 'to strike, hit< IE *g(wh)en- 'to slay, kill'?
< Proto-Iran. *mad 'to coagulate', = Skrt. MÁSTU 'sour cream'
IE *uekw- 'to speak, say', = Gr. HEIPEIN 'to speak, say', OIr. FOCCUL 'word', ON VÁTTR 'witness'
< IE *Hiunegti, Hiungenti 'to yoke', = Lat. CONIU(N)X 'spouse'

S.v. 12041 Ved. vī́kṣatē 'looks at, sees' ŚBr. 2. *vēkṣatē (vēkṣayati Dhātup., vēkṣaṇa- n. 'looking after, care' Mn. v.l. cēkṣaṇē) with ē after prḗkṣatē, ávēkṣatē: or poss. < *vyēkṣatē, cf. vyādr̥śyatē. [√īkṣ]

S.v. Proto-Iranic *tarH- (1) 'to cross over' (NEIr. Oss. I. tæryn/tard, D. tærun/tard 'to chase, drive (away, forth, out)' (+ u̯i-) Oss. I. dard, D. idard 'far'). From PIE *terh₂- (*treh₂-) 'to go through, overcome' (cf. Ved. tar-ⁱ 'to pass across, pass through, get across, overcome'; Hitt. tarh(u)- 'to overcome, be able', Lat. intrāre 'to go through', Alb. sh-tir 'crosses' etc.).
prob. from Slavic
= Skt. SĀ-, Av. HĀ(H)- 'to bind'
Hitt. iš-ḫi-ma-a-aš = Skt. SĀ-, SI- 'to bind', Lith. SIẼTI 'to bind' < IE *s(h)-oi-ei, s(h)i-enti
S.v. TochA wäl- 'sterben', 'die', either from PIE *u̯elh₃- 'be killed (in battle)' or *welH-/*gʷelH- 'die'.
< Lat. PONDUS
PREWATEL < IE *ueg(h)- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly'; = Grk. HOXOS 'car', Lat. VEHO 'I ride, bring', OCS VĘZO 'I ride', OHG WEGAN 'I move'
Skrt. VÁHANI < *ueǵ(h)- 'to ride, drive, transport'
related to Ir. *xad- 'to beat, strike, hurt'?

S.v. Proto-Iranic *skar- 'to pursue, drive, look for (cattle)', no certain cognates outside of Iranic. Cf. also Middle Persian šklk /škarag/ '(bird of) prey', (+ *u̯i-) wškl /wiškar/ 'hunting-ground, wilderness'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian u̯āz-² 'to play, contend; [pass.?] to lose (in games)', cf. Sanskrit vā́ja- 'contest, decisive battle, war, prize, booty, gain, reward'.
'to grow bigger', cogn. with Goth. LIUDAN, OE LEODAN 'grow', Gr. ELEUTHEROS 'free man', OIr. LUSS 'plant' < IE *Hleudh- 'grow, rise'

S.v. Proto-Iranian *darb- (*darf-) 'to join, tie, sew (together)', from PIE *derbʰ- 'to bind together, braid' (cf. Skt. darbh- 'to tie together, join, tie in a bundle', Lith. dìrbti 'to work', BlRuss. dórob 'basket, box', IE tearflian 'to roll').
General Germanic, outside connections dubious
claims connections to outside Germanic to be far from dubious
Possibly *ol-o-/-no-, links this cognate class to the Germanic one /cognate/175/, a relationship doubted by Buck.
has /cognate/2678/ as a source for the Frisian word in addition

Semantic problems are recognized by Seebold, who characterizes the connection of Gmc. *halda and PIE *kel- as 'völlig hypothetisch'. As an alternative, he proposes a connection with PIE √kwel- 'turn, move around sth.', cf. Skt. cárati 'move, walk', Gr. pélō 'move', OFris. hals 'neck (i.e. what turns)' (q.v.), with possible (but uncertain!) loss of the labial element of *kw > *hw before rounded vowels (and apparently subsequent spread to *kwel- >> *kel-).
suggests a comparison with *kel- 'cover' (IEW 553–554) > 'protect', which has a parallel in Celtic, cf. Welsh celu < *kel- 'cover, hide'; gogel 'protect' < *upo-kel-.
for Slavic words: IE *mon-g(w)io-
root DREI-, Frisian cognate is DRIVA though

S.v. Proto-Germanic *sehwan- 'to see', from PIE *sékʷ-e- (cf. Skt. sácate 'to follow', Gr. ἕπομαι 'id.', Lat. sequor , sequī 'id.', OIr. sechid 'id.'). "The Germanic verb corresponds to the PIE root *sekʷ- 'to follow'; apparently, the meaning shifted from 'to follow' to 'to keep an eye on'."

S.v. Arm. nist 'seat, site, standing, situation, location, abode, base', from which nstim 'to sit, be seated, rest' is derived. To be connected with IE words belonging with *sed- 'to sit', (cf. nominal Skt. nīḍá- 'nest, lair, bird's nest', Lat. nīdus 'bird's nest, residence', OHG, OEngl. nest, etc. < *ni-sd-o-; verbal Gk. ἵζω, Skt. sī́dati, MPers. nišastan, etc.). It often assumed that Arm. verbal nist-, Skt. sī́dati, etc. reflect *ni- + reduplicated present *si-sd-. [For further discussion and references pertaining to the derivation of the Armenian forms, cf. the entry in Martirosyan.]
S.v. Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'to swell', an exclusively Germanic verb.
S.v. Alb. lule 'flower', singularised plural of lulë < PAlb. *lulā. "Ancient Balkan loanword from an oriental source, probably Copt hrêri, hlêli 'lily'".
the same as Alb. SHTRINJ 'to spread'? <IE *sterH-

S.v. Arm. ors 'hunt, catch; hunted animal, game'; denominal verb orsam 'to hunt' Traditionally compared to Gk. πόρκος 'kind of fish-trap' ({ref Olsen 1999}:13, accepted by {ref HAB} III:588 with reservation). {ref Clackson 1994}:164 rejects this etymology and prefers the suggestion of {ref HAB} III:588 of a connection with Lat. porcus 'pig' with a semantic development '(young pig)' > 'animal for hunting' or 'game' (meaning only preserved in Armenian) > '(young) pig'. Alternatively Martirosyan proposes a connection with the Greek and Celtic words for 'roe' (Gk. δορκάς, ζορκάς, δόρξ, δόρκος, ζόρξ, ἴορκος, etc. 'a kind of deer, roe, antelope, gazelle', Corn. yorch 'roe' MW iwrch 'roe-deer' via PIE *i̯ork̑-o-.
cogn. with UXOR 'wife' /lexeme/20563/, meaning 'spouse', comp. AM+USIN (<*uk 'be accustomed to' + root of *swesor 'sister')
From *lēg-i̯- (cf. OIr. legaim 'flow'; OE leccan 'to wet, moisten; water, irrigate'); cf. also լիկ lik 'lagoon; wash pot' and /cognate/2767/
denominative of ապուր apur 'salvation, deliverance; life; nourishment, soup; (perhaps also) booty (if not a different item)'

S.v. Arm. mat- in matčʻim, matnum 'to approach, come close', mawt 'near, close', connected to ON mót, OE mōt, etc. '(town-)meeting; assembly'; mawt presumably from Proto-Armenian *maʷt-u- due to labial epenthesis; cf. mat-čʿ-i-m 'I approach, come near'.
IE *aliā-
S.v. Greek χαλάω 'to slacken': "The connection with Arm. xał 'game', xałam 'to play' by Meillet (1936:36) would require IE *kʰ-, and should therefore be abandoned."
Cf. s.v. 3. *per- 'schlagen' (IEW 818-9).

Proto-Indo-European origin unclear. Possibilities include *sm̥-gʰδʰr-eto- (cf. Skt. kṣárati 'flows, streams'), *(sm̥-)g̑ʰrei̯(H)-etó- ← *g̑ʰréi̯(H)-os (Skt. jráyas-, Av. zraiiah-, OP draya- 'sea, ocean, river'), *g̑ʰeu̯-(t)ro-.

S.v. Arm. kʻar 'stone'; for etymology, cf. s.v. mountain name Kʻarkʻ-ē, a mountain in the province of Turuberan in the districts of Tarōn and Palunikʻ, on the river Euphrates-Aracani. "The Armenian Kʻarkʻē, the name of a mountain of a considerable religious importance, reflects substratum *kar-k- 'stony rise (where cultic rites were practiced)', itself a derivative of *kar- > Arm. kʻar 'stone'. Particularly impressive is the Germanic cognate, *karko/u- *'stony rise (where cultic rites were practiced)" (cf. OE hearg 'heathen temple, altar, sanctuary, idol', OHG harug (referring to an area in the open for cult practice), OIc. harg (referring to clumps of stones in an area for cult practice), cf. also Welsh carrog 'stony river' < *karrākā, OIr. carrac 'cliff', carn 'stone grave').

Cf. OIr. carrac 'rock; cliff', Welsh carn 'stone, cairn', carrog 'stony river'; OE hearg 'heathen temple; altar', OHG harug, OIc. harg 'open area for worship; *heap of stones, stone rise (for practicing cultic rites)'; cf. also Skt. kar-kar-a- 'hard, firm'; Gk. κάρκαρος 'rough'; etc.

S.v. Arm. *areg- : *areg-i-, an old genitive of Arm. arew 'sun', which derives from IE *h₂reu̯-i-, cf. Skt. ravi- m. 'sun, sun-god' < PIE *h₂reu̯-i-, Hitt. ḫaru(u̯a)nae- 'to become bright, get light, dawn'. Classical Arm. areg-akn lit. = 'eye of the sun'.

Cf. s.v. Arm. bor 'leprosy' a loan from Iranic *bor 'leprosy', only preserved in Sogd. βr'wk'. In view of the Iranic alternation b- : v- one might also assume that Arm. uruk 'leprous' could have been borrowed from Iranic *vorūk- via an intermediary *wuruk.

Arm. owṙnowm is probably to be connected with Arm. owrowk 'leprous, suffering from elephantiasis'. If owrowk is enlarged from a more basic adjective *uru- or *ou̯ru- (cf. manowk 'Kind', manr, gen. manow 'small' < *manu-) we could be dealing with a denominative from an u-stem adjective *urnu- or *ou̯rnu-. The Armenian words have no certain etymological correspondences in related languages.
S.v. Arm. ԼՈՂ, comparing Old Indic lelāyati 'to move to and from; shake'; Lithuanian leliúoti ‎'to swing', etc. to a putative IE root *lel-.
[=Kortlandt 1998].
tentatively connects with Gr. O-PHRA 'so long as, until' and gives IE *(h)ebhr-
(sim. Pinault, Hackstein)
judges Nepali and Hindi lexeme Persian loan
maybe ultim. cognate with /cognate/2575/ and /cognate/2576/
IE Hmerg- 'pluck, wipe', = Gr. AMERGO 'I pick, luck'
has Nep. MALNU besides MĀṚNU, both meaning 'to rub, anoint'
S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar-⁴ 'to have a sore, scratch, itch', from PIE *su̯er- 'to have a sore' (cf. OHG sweran 'to have a sore, hurt', OHG swero, Engl. sore').
S.v. Proto-Iranian *dau̯č-² 'to sew'. The root is exclusively (West) Iranian and is probably a borrowing from a substrate language.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *xšaud- 'to wash' (cf. Skt. kṣod- 'to dissolve, disintegrate'). Correspondences for this Proto-Indo-Iranian root outside of IE are unclear.
S.v. Nepali jamnu 'to coagulate, freeze', from Sanskrit yamáte 'is fixed'.
S.v. Ved. phála- 'Frucht, Baumfrucht'. The etymology of Proto-Indic *pʰal-/*pʰar- is unclear.
Cf. s.v. Gk. ἐρωή (2) 'withdrawal, rest', from PIE *h₁reh₁-u-eh₁ (cf. Gmc. *rōwō in OHG ruowa 'silence', OE row, ON ró 'rest' beside PGmc. *rēwā- > OHG rāwa 'rest'.
S.v. ?*dreh₁- 'schlafen' (IEW 226). Only Ved., perhaps a contaminated form of 2. *drem- (Lat. dormiō, possibly also OCS -drěmljǫ), but alternative explanations are also possible.
Cf. s.v. 7200 nidrā- f. 'sleep' RV. and 7201 nídrāyati 'falls asleep, sleeps' ŚBr. [√drai]
the words like Skt. prāṇin- have two roots, pra- and -an 'breathe'
IE *pau-
S.v. Proto-Germanic *guman- 'man', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰm-on- (cf. Lith. žmónės (m.pl.) 'men', Lat. homō 'man' < *dʰg̑ʰm-on-).
IE *so-, cognate with many interr./pron. stems, e.g. 'that' in /cognate/318/
< Lat. PUNGŌ 'to pierce, sting'  < IE *pu-n(e)-g/k-
