(some of the?) Romance words fr. Lat. ILLAC 'there' < ILLE 'that', see 'that' in /cognate/2438/
Palula form from ārá-, cf. āré 'at a distance' (RV)
< Lat. DELICATUS < Lat. LACIO 'to entice'  < *lak(w)- 'loop, rope'

S.v. Lat. lārgus 'generous, bountiful'. Etymology unclear. The formal derivation and semantics from earlier attempts at an etymology in Walde-Hofmann and Pokorny IEW as though from *lajes-ago- 'carrying fat' are not convincing.
Lat. LIMPIDUS 'clean, transparent'
IE *ḱmt
element MA < *ma 'if' (?), = Skrt. SMA, Hitt. -MA 'but'
IE *(h)ei-; = 'if' in /cognate/2745/
IE *melH- or m(h)l-; root of 'small' in /cognate/1173/
S.v. Proto-Slavic *biti 'beat' < PIE *bʰiH- (cf. OIr. benaid 'strike', pret. pass. -bíth; Lat. perfinēs 2.sg. pres. subj. 'you may break').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *červo 'belly, intestine' (ESSJa IV 82-83), from Balto-Slavic *ker-m/w- (cf. OPruss. kērmens 'body'), cf. also Skt. cárman- 'hide, skin'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *bělъ 'white' (ESSJa II 79-81), from earlier *bʰelH- (cf. Lith. bãlas 'white', Latv. bā̀ls, bãls 'pale'; bal̃ts 'white').

This cognate class is not related to /cognate/4989/, in spite of the superficial similarity. However, it is possible that irregular changes of the initial consonant in Polish, Polabian and Czech etc. are due to a contamination of these two etymona. The irregularities can be explained also phonetically, though.
Slavic cognates containing this root show a broad range of meanings, including 'back', 'top', 'hill', 'ridge', '(mountian) range', 'edge', 'sharp' etc. It can not be excluded that there is a relationship to one of the PIE roots with meanings 'cut', 'scratch', 'bend' like *(s)kerb-, *(s)kerbʰ or *(s)kreb- but any hypothesis would be rather very uncertain.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čisti (ESSJa IV 119), from PIE *(s)kʷ(e)it- (cf. Latv. šķist 'think, suppose, seem', Skt. cétati 'perceive, take notice of') and Proto-Slavic *čitati 'read, count' (ESSJa IV 123), likewise from PIE *(s)kʷeit-; *(s)kʷoit- (cf. Lith. skaitýti 'read, count').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *borti < PIE *bʰorH- (cf. Lat. ferīre 'hit'; OIc. berja 'beat, hit'; OHG berjan 'hit, pound, knead').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *noga 'foot, leg', as though from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. Lith. nagà 'hoof'; nãgas 'nail, claw', Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').
= OCS SKOPITI 'castrate', cogn. with 'dig' in /cognate/202/
= Lat. CALAMITAS 'damage' < IE *kolH-

Cf. s.v. Lat. tālea 'cutting, thin piece of wood'. Compared to Gk. τᾶλις, -ιδος 'young girl, bride' on the assumption of a basic meaning 'green, to sprout' (cf. IEW 1055), but this seems like a wild guess. No viable etymology unless a derivative of tālus 'knuckle'.
S.v. Lat. amplus 'large, big', from Proto-Italic *am-lo- 'seizable' to PIE *h₃mh₃- 'to grab'.
FOR related to the same root
elements PRO < Slav *pro, pra 'through' = Skrt. PRO- , Gr. PRO 'before, forward'
cogn. with NHG AUCH 'as well, moreover'
late Lat. SERRA 'saw, serrated battle formation' < IE *sers-(h)- 'cutting off'
etymology much disputed: perhaps an early loan from Green or Iran
etym. of element EI in compound EPEI (<IE *(h)ei) 'when, because'  is dub.; (= (EP+EI+part. DE)
IE *srebh- 'to sip, gulp, suck (in)'
S.v. στρέφω, -ομαι 'to twist, turn'. No known cognates outside of Greek.
= Gr. SFYDZOO 'to beat violently'?, no etym., or cogn. with SPONGOS 'sponge for wiping'?, = Lat. FUNGUS 'mushroom'
S.v. 3827 kharju- (1), °jū -- f. 'itching, scratching, scab', cf. Pali kajju-, probably of Dravidian origin [S. P. point to *khārj- : ← Drav. see kacchū-] (> M. khāj̈ṇẽ).
S.v. Skt. púcchaḥ 'Schwanz, Schweif, Hinterteil', 'tail, hinder part'. Not convincingly explained. Perhaps a connection with OHG fuhs 'fox', etc.

S.v. 9078 Skt. *phirati intr. 'moves, wanders, turns'. 2. *phērayati 'makes moves &c.' 3. *phēra -- 'turn, turning'. [Cf. *pharati ʻ moves, turns ʼ (with phálati3, phḗlati ʻ goes ʼ Dhātup.). Poss. phar -- and phir -- are MIA. < *spar -- , *spir -- and belong to √spr̥ for which the basic meaning 'convey' (~ √pr̥) would account for the uses 'rescue (from: abl.)', 'help (towards: dat.)', 'attain, win' (cf. *sparati). With this Ir. *spar -- (usu. attributed to Sk. sphuráti: Bartholomae AirWb 1613 for Av. spar -- 'tread, hasten', Horn NPE 155) may be cognate in some of its meanings, e.g. Pers. sipardan 'to travel' (J. C. W.)]
'second', = DO + Skrt. SARA- 'moving'
connects Welsh lexemes to Lat. GROSSUS 'fat'
S.v. Proto-Celtic *rendi- 'thing, matter, star, point, peak'. A convincing IE etymology is lacking.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *klukā 'stone, rock' "In all likelihood, this PCelt. etymon was borrowed from some non-IE language."
prob. comp. of neg. part. NE + Slav *KOLIKO '(how) much', KOLIKO < neut. pron. KO+ Ru. interr. part. LI+?
Celtic words after the same principle < *ne+k(w)os 'not-anyone/anything'
Skrt. PRÁPARȘI 'to carry across'
element SUD,  CAU, SHODAN: comp. cognate Sanskr. CYAV 'to (start to) move, to set out' < Proto-Iran. *čiau- 'to move, go'

S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' (cf. Pamphylian Greek ϝεχέτω 'he must bring', Gk. ὄχος 'car', Lat. vehō 'I ride, bring', OCS vezǫ 'I ride', Lith. vežù 'I ride, procure', OHG wegan 'to move' etc.).
Iran. *fšar 'to press an intoxicating drink'?, = Skt. PSÁRAS- 'enjoyment, joy', Arm. (loan) ŌŠARAK 'juice'
Ir. *ma(i)č

comp. W BRITH, Cor. BRUIT 'variegated, diversified, painted, speckled' = Grk. AMORBOS 'dark', OIce MURKR ''dark'
etym. dub.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *obnu- 'fear'. "The PIE etymology is unknown, but a connection with Croat. jéza 'fear, terror' appears plausible. Cf. also Lith. éngti 'to strangle', ON ekki 'convulsive sobbing', OE 'doubt, complaint' ({ref Orel 2003}: 84). The Slavic forms presuppose Early PSl. *endzā or *indzā, and can be derived from PIE *h₁engʷ-, with the nasal infix from the verbal base (present stem) [...] The PIE root would be *h₁egʷ-. PCelt. *obno- or *obnu- can be from PIE *h₁ogʷno- or *h₁ogʷnu-."
derives from Common Celtic *fowno-, cf Old Irish úath 'horror, fear', Lat. pauor
IE *lib- (?)
Cf. s.v. 5020 Ved. chādi- *'covering', in cmpd. chādi- muṣṭi- 'handful of ashes' (JaimBr.) (from √chad- 1); 5021 Skt. *chādi-kūṭa- 'heap of ashes' > Maithili chaur.
S.v. Engl. child (n.). Cognate with Gothic kilþei womb, inkilþō pregnant woman, further connections uncertain.
Cf. s.v. 6186 Skt. dara- (1) m. 'fear' & 6190 Skt. darati 'is frightened'.
S.v. *der- 'zerreißen (intr.), zerspringen' (IEW 206-8).

S.v. Proto-Iranic *hmar- 'to remember, recall; recount' (Av. *(š)mar- 'to remember, recall'), from PIE *(s)mer- 'to observe, consider, think of' (cf. Ved. √smar- 'to remember, to become aware, to be mindful of', Gk. ἱμείρω 'I desire, long', Goth. *maurnan, OHG mornēn, OE murnan, Engl. mourn).
IE *(s)keip-
believes that Sinhalese umba stems from *yumha < Sanskrit yuṣma-
points to Tamil influence (um obl. stem of 'you pl.')
Cf. for an exhaustive discussion of formations meaning 'head' and 'horn' built to this root.
gives Proto-Ind. *moṭṭa-
question ultimate connection of ancient languages with Germanic
IE *prei, Slav *pri 'at, with, by'
IE *do-(h), = Lat. DE (>Romance?), OIrish DÍ  'from'
element PO < *po, pa 'after, by' at', cogn. with words meaning 'at' and 'and', e.g. /cognate/2534/
maybe ultim. cogn. with /cognate/689/ and /cognate/2576/
Arm. C'TIM
IE *skeid, = Grk. SXIDZO, Lat. SCINDO
IE *tewk- 'beat, perforate', = Grk. TYKOS 'hammer
PS *ovŭ is derived from PIE *h₂eu-o-, cf. Avestan ava 'that'.
IE *g(h)rebH- 'to grab, seize'
doubts direct identity of māhhan and mān
prob. < HOMME < Lat. HOMO <IE *d(h)g(h)(e)m-on 'earthling, human'
element EI, etym. dub.

comp. neuter pronoun *kʷó-  + part. li 'whether, if'
as for Slavic: the same as Ru. KOGDA 'when'? < IE *k(u)o + Slav. *goda

Cf. s.v. Lat. vīcus 'village, block of houses', from which Lat. vīcīnus 'neighbour, neighbourhood'. Lat. vīcus ultimately from Proto-Italic *weik-o- 'settlement', derived from PIE *ueik̑-/uik̑- 'settlement' (cf. Skt. viś- 'settlement, dwelling-place, people', YAv. vīs- 'homestead, community', OPers. viθ- 'royal house, palace, house' < *uik̑- Gk. οἶκος 'house, household' < *uoik̑-o-, etc.).
IE *sm̥-tero- 'one of the two' < *sem- (cognate with /cognate/623/) + comparative part.
IE *bhoHu-eie-, = Skrt. BHAVAYATI 'cherish, refresh'
IE *(s)ker-, cogn. with 'cut' in /cognate/762/, Lith. SKÌRTI 'split, separate' and 'scratch' in /cognate/2889/

S.v. Lat. sentiō, -īre 'to sense, feel', from PIE *snt-ie/o- or *sént-i-/*snt-éi- 'to notice' (cf. Lith. sintė́ti 'to think', OCS sęštъ 'sensible, wise' < BSl. *s(e)nt- 'think', PGmc. *sandjan- 'to send').
unclear relation with Nep. CHEṚNU 'to pierce, bore, make a whole through' and CHEDNU 'to pierce, penetrate'
IE *dhoil-, dhail- 'divide'
= Skt. KŠURÁḤ 'knife, razor, dagger'
= Lat. PINSERE 'to crush' < IE *pis-

S.v. Lat. baculum 'stick, staff'. "A number of languages show words in *bak- meaning some kind of 'staff or 'peg'. Since *b was very rare in PIE, and Celtic shows an unexplained geminate, we are probably dealing with a loanword from an unidentified source." Cf. Ir. bacc 'hook, crooked staff', W. bach 'id.' < PCl. bakko-, Gk. βάκτρον, βακτηρία, βακτήριον 'stick, staff', OE pægel 'wine jug', MDu. pegel 'peg, pin, bolt' < PGmc. *pagila- < *bak-elo-, ME pegge 'peg', poss. also. Lith. bàkstelėti 'to thrust'.
IE *(e)no-, cognate with 'he' in /cognate/2680/, 'that' in /cognate/2439/, 'here' in /cognate/2693/ and maybe also 'other' in /cognate/269/
'be of the opinion' < NOMOS 'custom, law, usage'
Fr. SONGER < Lat. SOMNIARE 'sleep, dream > talk idly'
S.v. Proto-Iranic *gar-² 'turn, wind', further IE etymology uncertain.

connect CA կռիւ kṙiw 'fight, strife; uproar' (presumably from *gʷēriH-) with Proto-Germanic *krīg- (e.g. MHG kriec) 'id.', Proto-Celtic *brīgos (Irish bríg), both from *gʷriH-g⁽ʰ⁾- (cf. Kroonen 2013, 304); cf. also Gk. βρίμη 'strength, bulk; censure'.

S.v. Arm. ԿԱՆԳ-, deriving the verb from (a conflation of) PIE *gʷem- (cf. Skt. gácchati) and *gʷeh₂- (cf. Skt. á-gā-t), presumably from an original "(come to) stand". Denominative of either կանգ kang 'stop(page), halt, pause' (i.e. < */kang-(a)n-e-l/) or կանգուն kang-own 'standing, upright; remaining, enduring; (also) cubit, arm's length (if the same item and not a loan from Iranian; cf. Persian kang 'wing; arm')' (i.e. <  */kangun-e-l/).

"Kangown (AG 165, {ref HAB} II:511) is attested more than a hundred times in the meaning 'cubit' (measure of length), and it is usually inflected as an o-stem (-oy, -ocʻ) though we find two examples of inst.sg. -aw (Ex.26.13) and John 21.8) and one instance of gen.sg. -ean (Esth.7.9). Further kangown is attested twice (2.Sam.7.26 and Is.17.5) in the meaning 'standing'. It is not quite clear to me whether this is a case of accidental homonymy or originally one lexeme. If kangown 'cubit' is to be connected with NP kang 'wing, arm (from the fingertips to the shoulder)' it is difficult to understand the semantic transfer 'standing, upright', so we may consider a derivation from an otherwise extinct verbal stem (kangnel 'stand' is clearly a denominative of kangown). If we are dealing with an inherited word the best candidate may be the active or middle participle of the root continued in Gk. κιχάνω 'reach' < *-n̥u̯-ō (root *g̑ʰeh₁-, cf. also κίχημι, Skt. jahāti 'goes forth' etc.), i.e. -angown < *-n̥u̯-ont- or *-n̥u̯omǝ₁-no-, though the initial k- is troublesome. For the semantic linking 'reach' ➝ 'stretch, be upright', cf. the expression i kangown ownel 'far, eseguir puntualmente' (Ciakciak 748)."
Cf. s.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' [IEW 330-1].
believes that Sinhalese umba stems from *yumha < Sanskrit yuṣma-
also points to Tamil influence (um obl. stem of 'you pl.')
cf. ūrdhvá- 'erected', perhaps ultimately going back to PIE *h₃orHdʰú-, *h₃rHdʰuós-, a derivative of *h₃er- 'go up, rise; raise'
S.v. 2426 Skt. ūrdhvá- 'erect, being above'.

S.v. Lat. tergum 'back', interpreted in earlier literature (cf. {ref IEW} 1022-1027) as *terg-o- from a root *(s)ter- 'to be stiff' with a suffix *-g-, and the underlying assumption that tergum originally indicated the stiff hair on the back of animals. There is no evidence for this, so the etymology remains unclear.

Given the difficulties of establishing a clear reconstruction for this root at the PIE level, for the purposes of the database it would be best to only reconstruct a cognate class for only Proto-Germanic, for now.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kryti 'cover, hide' (ESSJa XIII 71-72), from PIE *kruH- (cf. OE hrēodan 'cover').
S.v. *kreu̯H- 'aufhäufen, bedecken' (IEW 616). Verbal only Germanic and Balto-Slavic, to this cf. also perhaps OIr. cró, W creu 'Stall' < *krawo-, cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:240.

S.v. Arm. *kic-, kcanem 'to bite; to sting'. No etymologies accepted by {ref HAB} II:597. {ref IEW} 356 accepts a root reconstruction *gei̯d- 'stechen, kitzeln' in view of possible Germanic cognates (OIc. kitla, etc.), but in view of the lack of further proposed cognates outside of Germanic, and formal difficulties (cf. the proposed root structure with two voiced-unaspirated stops) the etymology remains uncertain.
Apparently from *gr̥g̑-u-; Cf. Gk. γοργός 'terrible, fierce'; OIr. garg(g) 'fierce'.

derive the item from PIE *(s)keu̯-, invoking Skt. sku-nā-ti 'covers', OHG scūr 'shower, precipitation', OE scēo 'sky; (lit.) *cover(ing)'; Lat. cucullus 'head-covering'; etc.).  The development *sk- > խ- x- has been, however, phonetically controversial, if completely abandoned.
posit *k̑u̯ōk-o- from PIE *k̑eu̯(-k)-  ("aufflammen, ergluehen"; LIV², 331) presumably attested in Gk. κύκνος 'swan', Ved. śukrá- 'bright, white; pure', etc.
traditionally connected with Proto-Slavic *bedro- 'thigh; hip'

a compound of (CA) մառ(ն) maṙ(-n) 'fog' and խուղ xowł 'hut, cot' (i.e. a dark place < *sku-, cf. /cognate/5964/): the first member is derived from *mr̥-no- of (PIE?) *mer- (presumably) 'fade; dim'; cf. Gk. (Hes.) μορτός˙μέλας, φαιός (< *mr̥-to-); Czech mrknout 'blink (of eyes)' (presumably originally ≈ "black/dim out"); cf. also մայր mayr 'darkness' (e.g. մայր արեւու mayr arew-ow 'sun-set; the west' (< *mr̥-i̯o-).

S.v. 8201 Skt. pipīlá- m. 'ant' RV., °laka- m. 'large black ant' ChUp., pipī́likā- f. 'small red ant' AV., pīlaka- m. 'ant' lex.; also reconstructed *piphīla- . 3. *pippīla- . 4. *pipphīla- . 5. *pippīḍa- . 6. *pilīla-. [Variety of MIA. and NIA. forms for 'ant' may be due partly to its (unknown) non-Aryan origin (EWA ii 285), partly to contamination with kīṭá- and kŕ̥mi-, but mainly to some sort of taboo for a noxious insect. Although there appear to be six main types, not all NIA. forms can be grouped exactly under them]
S.v. 3120 Ved. kāṣṭhá- n. 'piece of wood' ŚBr.

S.v. Arm. srun-kʻ 'shin, shank; the leg', continuing Proto-Armenian *sru-u̯an- (cf. GDAbl.Pl srow-an-cʿ) from *k̑rūs-, cf. Lat. crūs 'shank'. An Armenian-Italian isogloss. It is possible that the Armenian words could in principle be loans from Iranian (cf. Av. sraoni- 'buttock, hip', NPers. surūn 'buttock' < PIE *k̑louni-; for further cognates cf. Lat. clūnis 'buttock, club, tailbone', Lith. šlaunìs 'hip, thigh', Gk. κλόνιον 'loin(s), hip-joint'), but the semantics are more difficult to account for in such a case.

S.v. Arm. agi 'tail'. No acceptable etymology listed in {ref HAB} I:77-78, and {ref Olsen 1999}:940 considers it among the words of unknown origin. A tentative proposal may be to PIE *ph₂u̯-i̯o- and connected with Arm. haw 'beginning, origin, rise' (< *ph₂u̯-); cf. kov 'cow' (< Proto-Armenian *kou̯-u- < PIE *gʷou̯-) with kog-i (< PIE *gʷou̯-ii̯o-).

S.v. Skt. kalyam 'Tagesanbruch', 'day-break', kālyam 'id.', derived from Skt. kālaḥ 'Zeit, Zeitpunkt, Schicksal', 'time, fixed time, destiny, death' ultimately from PIE *kʷel(h₁)- 'turn' (cf. Ved. cárati).
S.v. 3104 Skt. kālya- 'timely, seasonable' (> 'yesterday', 'tomorrow' in various Middle and New Indic languages).

No. 2096, No. 13236: Parallel loans from Sanskrit (partly via Hindi?), but the nasalization points to cognacy with Old Awadhi samuṃda with -m- from samudra, presupposing the existence of previously more directly inherited forms, which were hyper-corrected on the model of Sanskrit samudra-; compare *unda- 'wetted' < udna- (cf. Vedic udán-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rauda- 'red' from *h₁roudʰo- (cf. Lith. raũdas, Russ. (dial.) rúdyj 'blood-red', SCr. rȗd 'reddish', Lat. rūfus 'red, tawny, red-haired', OIr. rúad 'red').
Palula < *lohila
S.v. 12073 Ved. vr̥ddhá- 'grown, large' RV., 'grown-up, old' TS. [√vr̥dh- 2].
S.v. 12064 Skt. vr̥kká- m. du. 'kidneys' AV., vŕ̊kya- TS., vr̥kkā- f. 'heart' lex. 2. *vrakka- . 3. bukka- 1 n. 'heart'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *kanH¹ 'to dig' < PIE ?*kenh₁- 'to dig'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *blanka- 'colorless(?)', loaned into Vulgar Latin as blancus, whence the Romance forms.
element -HA, = prob. suffix in Skt. IHA 'here', KUHA 'where' or that in KATHAM 'how', TATHA 'thus; element -TA, -TU < prob. = Skt. -tra

reconstructs IE *(h)i-dhei besides *(h)i-bhei for the whole expression (2008: 295), = Av. ITHA 'here, in the same way'; cf. 'there' in /lexeme/20530/; element YA-, AY-, A- the same root *(h)e-, (h)ih(a)-, (h)id- as in 'this/that', see e.g. /cognate/2437/
S.v. 3906 Skt. khura- m. ʻhoofʼ (KātyŚr̥), 2. *khuḍa (khuḍaka, khula° ʻankle, boneʼ Suśr.) ← Dravidian origin.
Cf. s.v. *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' (IEW 1003).
Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².
~ Arm. jag(-owc') 'fledgling,sparrow'; < Early Pr. Alb *j́u̯āgV- > PIE *g̑ʰu̯eh₂gʰV-

Alb. gj- (< s-) speaks for an inherited word but in absence of a convincing IE etymology, a loan from Lat. sinus 'hallow, curve' has to be taken into consideration - but earlier than the bulk of Latin loanwords which show the development s > sh.
Assumes a relation to Albanian keq 'bad' through a Proto-Albanian pre-form *kakii̯ā̆-, cf. /cognate/6597/, whereas Proto-Greek would show the same root with a simple thematic suffix (i.e. *kak-o-).

The possible connection to Proto-Albanian *kakii̯ā̆- is worth considering, but the connection is too speculative to merge this class with /cognate/6597/.  This has been indexed as a proposed cognacy relationship at a 50/50 level. Whether these forms could be further projected back to a PIE root with zero-grade vocalism *k̑h₂k-, *kn̥k̑-(vel sim.) remains unclear.

The potential connection to Proto-Greek *kako- is worth considering, but the connection is too speculative to merge this class with /cognate/7332/. This has been indexed as a proposed cognacy relationship at a 50/50 level. Whether these forms could be further projected back to a PIE root with zero-grade vocalism *k̑h₂k-, *kn̥k̑-(vel sim.) remains unclear.
Cf. s.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (IEW 38-9).

Cf. s.v. Ved. pā́jas- 'ein Teil des Körpers', related to Iranian forms via Proto-Iranian *pādzah- 'surface' (YAv. *pāzah- in pāzaŋᵛhaṇt-, Khot. pāsya-, Oss. faz/fazæ). The Indo-Iranian forms probably go back to PIE *peh₂g̑- (cf. Lat. pāgina 'side, leaf of paper', Gk. εὐ-πηγής 'well-built' < *'having a nicer side').
Proto-Iranian *zāta- 'born' reflects a PIE past-passive-participle *g̑n̥h₁-to-.
Cf. s.v. Ved. jātá- s.v. √jan-¹ 'erzeugen, gebären, schaffen, erschaffen' < PIE *g̑enh₁-.
S.v. Ved. kṣám- 'Erde, Erdboden' = OAv., YAv. zam- 'Erde' from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, *dʰg̑ʰ-ém-, dʰg̑ʰ-m̥-´.
S.v. Bact. ραγο 'bad'. "Etymology unknown."
Bactrian στοργο (alternative forms αστοργο, στορογο) from *stūra-ka- (cf. MPers. sturg).
S.v. Bactrian βαρ- < Proto-Iranian *bara-/*br̥ta- 'bear, carry'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *bar- 'bring, carry' < PIE *bʰer- 'bring, bear, carry'.
S.v. Ved. √bhar- 'tragen, hegen, pflegen; bringen' < PIE *bʰer-.
Bactrian παζο 'front (of the body), breast, face' < Proto-Iranian *pāzah- (cf. Sogd. pʾz, Khot. pāysa-, Ved. pājas-).
Cf. s.v. pāysa- 'surface' connected to *pag̑- (IEW 787-788).
As a verbal root, cf. s.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).
Bactrian ζαδακο 'child' is a derived form from ζαδο 'born' (< Proto-Iranian *zāta- 'born') with affectionate suffix with preserved *k.
Bactrian present stem ηρσ- reflects ā-isa-, while the suppletive past stem αγαδο from Proto-Iranian *ā-gata- (cf. Sogd. ʾʾys-/ʾʾγt, Pth./Chor. ʾs-/ʾγd- 'come').
Bactrian ρωσο 'day' < Proto-Iranian *raučah- (cf. OPers. raucah-).
Bactrian μιρ- / μιρδο from Proto-Iranian *mr̥ya-/*mr̥ta- (cf. MPers. mīr-/murd).
Bactrian νακαν- (attested via past stem νακανδο) from Proto-Iranian *ni-kanta- (cf. Av. ni-kaṇta-).
Bactrian κιρ-/κιρδο from Proto-Iranian *kr̥nu-/*kr̥ta- (cf. OPers. kun(av)-/kr̥ta-, Chor. ʾk-/ʾkt-).
Bactrian κοδο < Proto-Iranian *kuta-/kutī- (cf. Sogd. kwt, Shughni kud, kid).
Bactrian ζαμιγο (alt. form ζαμιιο) '(piece of) land, ground' < *zamīkā- (cf. MMPers./Parth. zmyg 'land, earth, world').
Bactrian χοαρ-/χοαρδο 'have, possess, take (possession of); eat' < Proto-Iranian *hwara-/hwarta- (cf. Khot. kvar-/hvaḍa- 'consume, eat' Tumshuqese hvārya- 'to be taken').
Bactrian ιωλ-/ιοστο < Proto-Iranian *yauda-/yusta- (cf. Khot. juv-/justa-).
Manichaean Bactrian ʾwjyd (past stem) 'to kill' from *awa-ǰata- (= MMPers./Parth. ʾwjd).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *daH-¹ 'to give' < PIE *deh₃-.
Bactrian λαυ-, λα- / λαδο 'to give, grant, allot, assign, pay' < Proto-Iranian *daθa-/dāta- (cf. Parth. dh-/dʾd).
Bactrian þαο-/þοδο < Proto-Iranian *čyawa-/*čyuta- (cf. Ved. cyáva- 'to move, undertake', Av. š́auu(a)-, Khot. tsū-, tsuta- 'to go').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯au- 'move, go'.
Bactrian λιστο 'hand' < Proto-Iranian *dasta- (cf. Sogd. δst-).
S.v. Ved. śíras- 'Kopf, Haupt, Spitze' < PIE *kŕ̥h₂-os/k̑r̥h₂-s-n-ós (cf. Gk. κάρᾱ [G.sg. κρᾱ́ατος] 'head', Lat. cerebrum 'brain', OHG hirn(i) 'brain').
Bactrian σαρο 'head' < Proto-Iranian *sarah- (cf. Av. sarah-).
Bactrian ναγαυ-/ναγατο < Proto-Iranian *ni-gauša-/ni-gušta- (cf. Sogd. nγwš/nγwšt).

Bactrian ωγοζ- reconstructed from past stem ωγοτο, of uncertain meaning, possibly 'to conceal' < *awa-gušta- from Proto-Iranian *gauz-. Cf. Manichaean Bactrian ʾwγwt used as a noun, possibly 'secret'.

Cf. commentary to the Manichaean Bactrian fragment v5 for the connection of Bactrian ωγοτο with Manichaean Bactrian ʾwγwt, to be interpreted as 'secret' or 'secrecy' and a possible etymology *awa-gušta-.
Bactrian ζιν-/ζιδο 'to strike' < Proto-Iranian *ǰana-/ǰata- (cf. Khot. jsan-/jsata-).
S.v. Proto-Iranic *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' < PIE *gʷʰen-.
S.v. PIE *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).
Bactrian καδαγο 'house' < *kata-ka- (cf. MPers. kadag).
Bactrian αζο < Proto-Iranian *azam (cf. Manichaean Bactrian ʾz, Av. azəm).
S.v. Ved. ahám 'ich' from (perhaps) PIE *(h₁)eg̑-h₂-óm ~ *(h₁)eg̑-óh₂ > Gk. ἐγώ, Lat. egō̆, etc.  Proto-Iranian forms reflect probably *azám (cf.  OAv. azə̄m, YAv. azəm, OPers. adam, etc.).
S.v. *g̑enu, *g̑neu- 'Knie'.
Bactrian ζαν- < *zāna- (cf. Parth. zʾn 'to know', Sogd. ʾnzʾn 'to acknowledge').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian zanH-² 'to know' from PIE *g̑neh₃-.
S.v. Ved. √jñā- 'kennen, erkennen, wissen' < PIE *g̑neh₃-.
Bactrian ζο-, ζοο- 'to live' < *ǰīwa- (cf. Khot. juv-).
S.v. Ved. √jīv- 'leben', a secondary root re-analysed from a present stem < *gʷih₃-u̯e- (to PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- ~ *gʷei̯h₃-).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *ǰaiH-¹ 'to live' < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-, *gʷi̯eh₃-/*gʷh₃i- 'to live'.
Bactrian μαρδο < *martiya- (cf. OPers. martiya-, Sogd. mrty).
S.v. Ved. mártya- 'Sterblicher, Mensch' (cf. Av. maš́iia-, OPers. martiya-) derived to √mar- 'sterben' < PIE *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben'.
Cf. s.v. *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben' (IEW 735).
Bactrian μαο, μαυο 'month' < *māhV- (cf. MPers. māh).
S.v. Ved. mā́s- 'Mond, Monat' < PIE *meh₁-n̥s- (> IIr. *maHas- whence OAv. mā̊ /maHah/), ultimately a derivative of *meh₁- 'messen'.
Cf. s.v. *meh₁- '(ab)messen' (IEW 703-4).
Bactrian γαρο < *gari- (cf. Av. gairi-).

S.v. Ved. girí- 'Berg, Hügel, Anhöhe' (Iranian forms via YAv. gairi-, Khot. gara-, ggari-, Sogd. γar, Pashto γar), probably PIE *gʷr̥H-i- (cf. Alb. gur 'stone' OCS gora, 'mountain', Lith. girià 'forest').
Bactrian þουο < *srū(-kā)- (cf. Av. srū-, MPers. srū 'nail, horn').

Cf. notes s.v. Ved. śŕ̥ṇga- 'Horn' (as though) from PIE *k̑r̥-n-g⁽ʷ⁾o-. Iranian forms (Av. srū-, Khot. ṣū, MPers. srū, NPers. surū) likely belong to the same basic root *k̑er- as the basis of other 'head' and 'horn' words found in Indo-European, but with an alternative morphological derivation *k̑r-uH-. Cf. notes in Mayrhofer for further literature.
Bactrian νωγο < *nawa-ka- (cf. Chor. nwʸk).
Bactrian *χαβο attested from adv. χαβρωσο '(by) night and (by) day' < *kšapa- 'night' (cf. Chor. (ʾ)xʸb, Sogd. xšp) + ρωσο 'day'.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *hu̯anH- 'to call', from PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' (cf. Ved. svan- 'to sound', Lat. sonere, sonāre, 'to sound, ring', sonus 'noise, sound', OE swinn 'music').
S.v. *su̯enh₂- 'tönen, klingen' (IEW 1046-7).
S.v. Ved. áp- 'Wasser', from PIE *h₂ep- (cf. Hitt. directive ḫa-pa-a 'zum Fluß', TochAB āp 'Wasser, Fluß, Strom', OPr. ape 'Bach, kleiner Fluß', Lith. ùpė 'Strom, Fluß', Latv. upe 'Fluß, Bach').
Bactrian καβογγο < *kapuna-ka- (cf. Pth. qfwn 'old' < *kafwana-).
Bactrian μαρσκονδο, μορσκονδο, μασκονδο < μαρδο 'man, slave' (cf. /lexeme/58489/) + *σκονδο (present participle of a verb corresponding to to Sogd. ʾskw- 'to be, exist'?), cf. Chor. mrskwnd 'people'.
Bactrian ναμιλγο 'salt' < *namadkā- (cf. Pth. nmydk, Sogd. nmʾδkh, Pashto mālga).

Bactrian σορχιυο 'red'? attested in the name of an estate σορχιυο λιζακο, perhaps 'the red fort' (cf. Av. suxra-, NP surx 'red') + suffix -ιγο. Alternatively possible is 'the fort on the river Surkhab'.
Bactrian οην-, οιην-, οιν- < *waina- (cf. MPers. wēn).  Suppletive past stem λιδο < *dīta- (cf. MPers. dīd).
S.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4).
Bactrian τοχμανο < *tauxman-a- (cf. Av. taoxman-, Khot. ttīman-).

Cf. s.v. Ved. toká- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'; tókman- n. 'junger Getreidehalm, grüner Sproß von Getreide' (IIr. YAv. taoxman- 'Same, Keim, Verwandschaft'; OPers. tauma- 'Familie, Geschlecht'). Cf. root noun túc- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'. Correspondences of IIr. *tau̯k- outside of IIr. are not certainly ascertained.

Cf. s.v. Ved. áśman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Fels' (Av. asman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Himmel'), from PIE *h₂ek̑-mon- (cf. Gk. ἄκμων 'Amboß (auch 'Meteorstein' und 'Himmel'), Lith. ašmuõ (pl. ãšmens) 'Schneide, Schärfe', akmuõ, -ẽns 'Stein'). To PIE *h₂ek̑- 'scharf, spitz'.
S.v. Ved. mitrá- 'Vertrag, Kontrakt, Bündnis' (personified as Mitrá-, god of contract), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *mitrá-. The origin of PIIr. *mitrá- is disputed.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *band- 'to bind' < PIE *bʰendʰ- 'id.'. (cf. Gk. πεῖσμα 'rope, cord', Thrac. βενδ-, Goth. bindan, OHG bintan, Engl. 'to bind', etc.).
S.v. Ved. √bandh- 'binden, fesseln, zusammenbinden, festbinden', from PIE *bʰendʰ- (cf. Gk. πεῖσμα 'Tau, Seil', OHG bintan 'binden', Goth. bandi 'Fessel, Band', etc.).
Bactrian αλο < Iranian *hada (cf. Av. haδa).

Bactrian σαρδο (earlier *σαρλο, preserved in compounds e.g. βιδδιγονωγοσαρλο 'second new year (name of a month)', ασαρολο 'this year' < *ā-sardV- [cf. Chor. ʾʾsrδ, Shughni asid, etc.], παρασαρλο 'last year' < *parā-sardV- [cf. Yidgha prasāl]) < Proto-Iranian *sardV- (cf. OPers. θard-, Chor. srδ)

Cf. s.v. Ved. śarád- 'Herbst [auch 'Jahr']'. The Indo-Iranian forms represent an ablauting form *ćarad-/*ćard-. Further origins of Proto-Indo-Iranian *ćar(a)d- are not certain. Perhaps as *k̑el-(e)d- to *kel-h₁- 'become warm' (Lat. calēre, Lith. šìlti, etc.), but this connection remains speculative.
Cf. discussion p.415n7 to ‡k̑el-ed- and ‡k̑el-d-.
S.v. Ved. sthūra- 'groß, stark, dick, wuchtig' < PIE *stuh₂-ró- (cf. Old Swedish stūr 'groß', Middle Dutch stūr 'groß, stark').

"The word is a blend of PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu(e)h₂- ‘tongue’ (OIr. tengae, Goth. tuggō, OHG zunga, Skt. jihvā́-, juhū́- f., Av. hizuuā-, hizū- m., etc.) and PIE *leig̑ʰ- > Arm. lizem ‘to lick’ (q.v.); cf. especially Lat. lingua vs. OLat. dingua and Lith. liežùvis ‘tongue’."
TochA käntu and TochB kantwo reflect PTch *käntwo which, by metathesis, presupposes an earlier *täkwo (as if) from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-u̯eH-n-, which matches the form found in Germanic (e.g. Goth. tuggō).
S.v. Ved. jihvā́- 'Zunge'. cf. further notes by Scarborough in this cognate class regarding the cognacy of the Indo-Iranian forms to the rest of the forms in this class.

Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- 'tongue'. The forms as attested appear to have undergone multiple contaminations in several daughter languages: (1) The Tocharian forms reflect *ĝn̥dʰu̯éh₂- ← PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- by metathesis of place of articulation (cf. {ref Ringe 1996}:45-6). (2) Balto-Slavic lexemes appear to have lost initial *d- already at a common Balto-Slavic stage ({ref Derksen 2008:159}, {ref Derksen 2015}:285, cf. {ref ESSJa} 6:74-75). (3) Armenian, Italic, and Lithuanian lexemes appear to have independently contaminated with initial l-, probably under influence of their respective regular reflexes of PIE *lei̯g̑ʰ- 'to lick' ({ref Martirosyan 2010}:307-308, {ref de Vaan 2008}:343, {ref Derksen 2015:285). (4) Celtic forms appear to have undergone a distance assimilation *dengʷāt- > *tengʷāt-  ({ref Matasović 2009}:368). (5) Indo-Iranic forms have a similar preform *ºg̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*ºg̑ʰuh₂- to the form *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂- found in other branches, but instead appears to i-reduplicate the initial syllable (cf. notes to Ved. jihvā́- in {ref EWAia} I:591-593). Additionally, the Iranian forms appear to show a different Anlaut from the Indic ones (Indic *j-, Iranian *s-). This small deviation aside, the Indo-Iranian. forms surely go back to basic form *ji-ju̯aH-/*ji-juH- (vel sim.) in Proto-Indo-Iranian. This apparent reduplication could be secondary reanalysis of an original *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰuh₂- > *daju̯aH-/dajuH- as a reduplicated form *ji-ju̯aH-, (cf. forms such as *kʷe-kʷl-o- > cakra- 'wheel'), cf. {ref Mallory & Adams 2006}:175. For the purposes of root-cognacy, The Indo-Iranic forms are treated in this class as cognate with the other forms which are more clearly from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-u̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂-. The least disturbed forms appear to be found in Germanic, for which see {ref Lehmann 1986}:349, {ref Kroonen 2013}:526-527.

S.v. Lat. lingua. The basic Italic preform closely matches the form *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂ found in Germanic, Tocharian, etc. but with a secondary (and evidently late) contamination of original d- to l- from Lat. lingō 'lick' (cf. Old Latin dingua). Sabellic forms with initial f- presuppose initial *dʰ-, but the origin of the aspiration of original *d- in these forms is unclear.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *ęzykъ, which is regular from*n̥g̑ʰ-uh₂- < *dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂- with the addition a secondary suffix *-kъ in Slavic. The loss of initial *d- also apparent at the Proto-Balto-Slavic stage, cf. Old Prussian insuwis.

S.v. Lithuanian liežùvis 'tongue'. The Proto-Balto-Slavic form *inźuʔ- apparently lost initial *d- from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂- (cf. Old Prussian insuwis, Proto-Slavic *ęzy-kъ). The Lithuanian form was secondarily influenced by Lith. liẽžti 'lick'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *puxnǫti v. 'swell' Derksen considers Proto-Slavic *pux- with PIE *peu̯s- (cf. Skt. púṣyati 'thrive, flourish'). [Cf. LIV² 303-304 s.v. ?*h₃peu̯s-, without Slavic cognates listed.]

S.v. 168. լաւ law. Hübschmann proposed two possible comparisons: either to Gk. λωίων 'better' (from *λωϝιων)? or to Lith. lãbas 'good' /cognate/678/, but Hübschmann marks both with '?' to indicate that both are uncertain proposals.
Considers the etymological connection of Arm. լաւ law with Gk. λωΐων doubtful, following Hübschmann.
S.v. Lith. lãbas 'gut', connected with Ved. rabh- 'angreifen'.

Etymology uncertain. No connection to Lithuanian lãbas, etc., as suggested by {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451 is accepted by {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} or {ref ALEW} (cf. /cognate/678/). {ref Clackson 1994}:181-182 likewise finds Hübschmann's proposed connection to Gk. λωΐων doubtful. Arm. law seems to be etymologically isolated.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *akrana- 'tree fruit, acorn' (cf. OIr. áirne 'sloe, fruit of the blackthorn, kernel', MW eirin 'sloes, berries, plums' < PCl. *agrn-io-; W aeron 'fruits, berries' < PCl. *agr-on-ā; Lith. úoga 'berry' < *h₂og-eh₂-; OCS agoda 'fruit', Ru. jágoda 'berry', SCr. jȁgoda 'wild strawberry, berry'; ToB oko 'fruit, effect'). "A clear Europeanism." To be derived with a suffix -ana- (also found in ONor. aldin, Far. aldan, OSw. aldon 'tree-fruit, mast' < *aldana-) on root *agr- which is "derivationally obscure", but is similar to the base reconstructed for account to for Celtic forms (e.g. OIr. áirne 'sloe', Wel. aeron 'fruits, berries' < Proto-Celtic *agrn-io-). "[T]he appurtenance of ToB oko (see Adams 1999:109-110) is uncertain, as it may have been derived from the PIE root *h₂eug- 'to grow'."

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *akrana- 'tree fruit, acorn' (cf. OIr. áirne 'sloe, fruit of the blackthorn, kernel', MW eirin 'sloes, berries, plums' < PCl. *agrn-io-; W aeron 'fruits, berries' < PCl. *agr-on-ā; Lith. úoga 'berry' < *h₂og-eh₂-; OCS agoda 'fruit', Ru. jágoda 'berry', SCr. jȁgoda 'wild strawberry, berry'; ToB oko 'fruit, effect'). "A clear Europeanism." To be derived with a suffix -ana- (also found in ONor. aldin, Far. aldan, OSw. aldon 'tree-fruit, mast' < *aldana-) on root *agr- which is "derivationally obscure", but is similar to the base reconstructed for account to for Celtic forms (e.g. OIr. áirne 'sloe', Wel. aeron 'fruits, berries' < Proto-Celtic *agrn-io-). "[T]he appurtenance of ToB oko (see Adams 1999:109-110) is uncertain, as it may have been derived from the PIE root *h₂eug- 'to grow'."
Cf. s.v. 2.*leu⁽g̑⁾- 'biegen' (IEW 685-686).

S.v. Ved. éka- 'ein, einzig, alleinig'. Earliest attested by Mitanni Indic *ai̯ka- (a-i-ka-u̯a-ar-ta-an-na 'one turn') from PIE *(H)oi̯-ko-. The Iranian forms are attested using a *-u̯o- morpheme to the root (OAv., YAv. aēuua-, OPers. aiva-, MPers. ēw-ak, etc.) < *(H)oi̯-u̯o- (cf. Gk. οἶ(ϝ)ος 'alone').
The Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction frequently reconstructs the *-no- suffix as *-(H)no-, thus reconstructions like *Hoi-(H)no-, *Hi-Hno-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *oy-no- from PIE *h₃ei̯-no- (cf. Lat. ūnus, Goth. ains, Lith. víenas, etc.).
Arm. mi 'one', from the PIE feminine stem *sm-ih₂ (cf. Gk. μία '1' f.).
S.v. TochB ṣe 'one', which together with TochA sa- are derived from PIE *sem- (cf. Gk. εἷς, Arm. mi).

Etymological authorities differ on whether Alb. një 'one' should be assigned to PIE *sem- (Gk. εἷς, Arm. mi, etc.) /cognate/6066/ or *Hoi̯-no- (Lat. ūnus, Goth. ains, etc.) /cognate/91/ (cf. {ref Huld 1984}:101, {ref Demiraj 1997}:207, {ref Orel 1998}:304-305, {ref Holm 2011}:74 for various assessments).  Consequently the Albanian numeral '1' has therefore been placed in its own cognate class reflecting this etymological uncertainty.
S.v. një ~ nji 'one', Orel derives from Proto-Albanian *ainja < PIE *oi-no- (Lat. ūnus, etc.), rejecting Huld's theory (1984:101) that një is a back-formation from the feminine *smi̯eH.
Suggests that Proto-Albanian *ni- is back-formed from PIE feminine *smyā (*sem-) with dissimilation of *m > *n preceding *y.
S.v. *sém- 'vereint; ein' adjectivische Wurzel, inklusiv; Singulare tantum.
S.v. *ói̯- 'einzig, einzeln' adjektivische Wurzel, exklusiv.
S.v. *du̯ó-, *du̯í- 'zwei (einzelne)' Zahlwort, nicht-inklusiv.
Cf. s.v. *trí- 'drei' Zahlwort.

S.v. TochB śtwer 'four, which with TochA śtwar reflects Proto-Tocharian *ćätwerä < PIE *kʷetu̯ores (cf. Skt. catvā́ras, Av. čaθwārō, Arm. čorkʻ, Hom.Gk. τέσσαρες (cf. Att. τέτταρες), Lat. quattuor, OIr. cethair, Goth. fidwor, Lith. keturì, OCS četyre, etc.).
S.v. Alb. katër 'four', from PIE *kʷetur- ~ *kʷetu̯er- 'four'.
S.v. Gk. τέσσαρες 'four', from PIE *kʷetu(e)r-.
Cf. s.v. Ved. catvar- 'vier' (PIE *kʷétu̯or-es > Ved. nom.sg. catvā́ras)
S.v. Lat. quattuor, cf. entry for notes on peculiarities of the Latin form.

S.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος 'evening', an inherited word for 'evening' from *u̯e-kʷsp-er-o- *'towards the night, evening' (cf. Lat. vesper 'evening'). Element *-kʷsp- 'night' from PIE *kʷsep- 'spend the night' (cf. Ved. kṣáp- 'night').

S.v. Ved. doṣā́- 'Dunkel, Abend', cf. Pkt. dosā 'Nacht', Aškun dōs 'gestern', YAv. daošatara- 'gegen Abend gelegen, westlich', MPers., NPers. dōš 'letztvergangene Nacht, vorangegangener Abend', etc. The form is sometimes connected with Gk. δείελος 'nachmittaglich, abendlich; Abend', but further etymological connections outside of Indo-Iranian are ultimately uncertain.
Based on Avestan and Vedic comparanda a Proto-Indo-Iranian stem *dau̯šā́- may be reconstructed.

S.v. Arm. երեկ erek, to be connected with Skt. rájas- 'dust, mist, vapour, gloom' OAv. rajiš- 'darkness', Gk. ἔρεβος 'the dark of the underworld', Goth. riqis 'darkness, twilight' from PIE *h₁regʷ-os-.
Portuguese ontem < oonte < aōite < *a nocte.
Cf. s.v. Lat. nox. Lat. nocte is abl. of nox 'night' < PIE *nokʷt- (o-grade of *nekʷt-, cf. Hitt. nekuz).
Attempts to reconcile Hitt. illuyankaš with other words for 'snake' in Indo-European. [NB: Katz's proposal has not been widely accepted.]
S.v. Hitt. kaka- 'tooth', attempts to connect to OE hōc 'hook', etc.

S.v. Hitt. išḫaḫru- 'tear(s)', from which išḫaḫruu̯e/a- 'to weep' is a derivative. If one assumes a base *h₂ek̑-ru- the Hittite word for tear might be cognate with Skt. áśru-, TochA ākär, ākrunt (nom.pl.), Lith. ãšara, ašarà 'tear', but to make the etymology work one must assume the Hittite lexeme had a prothetic *s- and an assimilation of *h₂ek̑- to *h₂eh₂-. (This assimilation is, however, unparalleled elsewhere in Hittite.), further this might then perhaps be related to other Western IE words for 'tear' following the proposal of {ref Kortlandt 1985a} that words such as Ancient Greek δάκρυ, OHG zahar, Arm. artaswr, Lat. lacrima 'tear' reflect an earlier compound *dr̥k̑-h₂(e)k̑ru- 'eye-bitter'.
For further discussion of Kortlandt's proposed etymology *dr̥k̑-h₂(e)k̑ru- 'tear' elsewhere among the IE languages, cf. /cognate/5111/.
Puhvel's proposed etymology in HED A + E is speculative, and we are more likely to be dealing with an onomatopoeic formation.
Luw. ḫa-aḫ-ḫa-lu-u̯a-an-ti-[ "Prob. cognate of Hitt. word, pace HW² 3.7."
Considers CLuw. u̯inal- 'Stock, Stab, Stange' a derivative of PIE *gʷʰen- 'beat'.
Follows the etymology proposed by Starke (1990:313-316).
S.v. Hitt. iškunant- 'fleckig, schmutzig', etymology unclear.
S.v. Hitt. ᵈIštanu- 'Sonnengott, Sonne'. ᵈIštanun is given as the equivalent to the Sumerogram ᵈUTU in a parallel passage in a copy of a text.
S.v. 2. *h₁es- 'werfen, schießen' (not in IEW).
Cf. s.v. √as-² 'werfen, schleudern, schießen', whose judgement was 'der idg. Ursprung von iir. *as- 'werfen' ist nicht geklärt'.
Neapolitan rine from Lat. rēnēs 'kidneys'.

S.v. Lat. rēnes 'kidneys' from Proto-Italic *rēn- < PIE *h₂r-ēn- 'kidney'? or *srēn- 'loins'? Potential IE cognates are OIr. áru 'kidney, gland', Welsh arenn 'kidney, testicle' < PCl. *āron-; Hitt. ḫaḫ(ḫa)ri- 'lung(s), midriff' TochB arañce 'heart', TochA āriñc 'id.'.
S.v. Lat. rēnēs 'reins' "Mot d'origine inconnue qui a remplacé nebrundinēs (v. nefrendēs)."
Neapolitan panza from Lat. acc.sg. pănticem (Lat. pantex 'paunch, bowels').
S.v. Lat. pantex 'panse'. A popular word for belly (used since Plautus) in origin a transferred adjective panticōsus (uenter). [No further etymology given.]
Neapolitan ruosso < Lat. grŏssu(m).
S.v. Lat. grossus 'immature fig; thick, unripe'. Etymology unclear. IEW had earlier connected Lat. grossus with Welsh bras 'thick'.
Neapolitan sciatà < Lat. flatāre, a derivative of flātu(m), cf. It. fiatare.
S.v. Germanismes *bosk-, considering Fr. bois, etc. as loans from Germanic *bosk- 'bush'.
Neapolitan tuosto < Lat. tŏstu(m), cf. It. tosto.
Lat. tostum = p.p.p. of torreō 'heat so as to dry up, burn, scorch, parch' (OLD).
Cf. s.v. *ters- 'vertrocknen; durstig werden' (IEW 1078-9), where Lat. torreō from PIE cs. stem *tors-éi̯e-.

S.v. Lat. torreō 'to scorch, roast', from PIE *tors-eie- 'make dry' (cf. Hitt. tarš- 'to become dry', Skt. tr̥ṣyant- (act.part.), tr̥ṣa- (aor.) 'to be thirsty', YAv. taršu- 'dry, not fluid'), derived from PIE *ters-.
Neapolitan accirere < Lat. occīdere, cf. It. uccidere.
Neapolitan coscia < Lat. cŏxa(m), cf. It. coscia.
Neapolitan stiso < Lat. extĕndere, cf. It. steso.

Lat. tendō either to PIE *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (IEW 1065-6) or 1. *tend- 'ermatten', which is possibly *ten- with a *-d- root extension? Cf. notes to entries for further discussion and references to literature.
Neapolitan campà is a derivative of Lat. campu(m), cf. It. campare.

S.v. Lat. campus 'flat land, field', from Proto-Italic *kampo- 'field', usually derived from a putative PIE root *kamp- 'bend' (cf. Gk. κάμπω 'to bend, curve', καμπή 'bow, curvature', Lith. kam̃pas 'corner', kum̃pti 'to bend', kum̃pas 'curved', OCS kǫtъ 'corner', Goth. hamfs 'mutilated, lame', OHG hamf). However initial ca- is difficult to explain; {ref Beekes 2010} suggests that the proposed Greek cognates come from a substratum language. Perhaps Latin campus may also be originally borrowed from a European substratum word in the semantic area of agricultural terminology.
Beekes considers that the IE reconstruction would require *kh₂mp- 'a root structure that is suspicious'.
S.v. *kamp- 'krümmen, biegen' (IEW 525), cf. n1 'fraglich lat. campus m. 'Feld'.'
Neapolitan vuttà loaned from Germanic, either Franconian bōtan or Gothic bautan. Cf. It. buttare and Walloon and Anglo-Norman bouter /cognate/1042/.
Neapolitan sciummo < Lat. flūme(n), cf. It. fiume.
Neapolitan ammulato is a derivative of Lat. mŏla(m) 'millstone', cf. It. molàre 'affilare'.
S.v. Lat. molō, -ere, 'to grind in a mill', from which Lat. mola 'millstone' is a derivative. Ultimately derived from PIE *melh₂- 'crush, grind'.
Etymology unknown.
Neapolitan 'nfuso < Lat. infūsu(m), p.p.p. of in infŭndere.
S.v. Lat. fundō 'pour, let go, emit' < PIE *g̑ʰu-n-d- 'to pour'.

Cf. s.v. ?*g̑ʰeu̯d- 'gießen' (IEW 448); cf. n1: Only Italic and Germanic  (cf. Goth. giutan). A post-PIE enlargement of *g̑ʰeu̯- 'pour' for phonotactic reasons?, cf. also s.v. *g̑ʰeu̯- 'gießen' (IEW 447-448).
Neapolitan avutà < Lat. *voltāre, cf. It. voltare.
Lat. *voltāre < Lat. uolutāre, an intensive formation from Lat. uoluō 'cause to revolve, roll'.

S.v. volvō, -ere 'to (cause to) go round, roll', from PIE *uel-u- 'to wind' (cf. OIr. fillid < PCl. *u̯el-n-o- 'bend', Bret. goalenn 'green twig' < *u̯el-, Gk. εἰλύω 'to wind round', Arm. egel 'he turned', Goth. walwjan, OE wealwian 'to revolve (oneself)', TochB wäl- 'to curl (intr./tr.)').
S.v. Lat. uoluō 'rouler, faire rouler'.
S.v. 2. *u̯el- 'drehen, rollen' (IEW 1140-2).
Neapolitan chianta < Lat. plănta(m).

Cf. s.v. Lat. planta 'sole of the foot', from PIE *pl(e)h₂-nt-h₂- 'the flat one' (cf. Lat. plānus 'level, flat'). Lat. planta 'shoot of a plant' is commonly hypothesised to be backformed to an unattested verb *plantāre 'to level the earth' or 'to plant crops with the sole of the foot' (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:512 s.v. II. planta). If so, then planta 'shoot of a plant' would ultimately go back to the PIE root *pelh₂- found in Lat. plānus 'level, flat', Hitt. palḫi- 'wide, broad', Lith. plónas 'thin', etc.

S.v. II. planta 'tige, rejeton', a new substantive backformed from plantō 'enfoncer avec le pied', specialised in the language of farming in the sense 'enfoncer les rejetons, planter' and identical to planta 'plante des pieds'.
Neapolitan ruppio < Lat. dŭplum, cf. It. doppio.
Cf. s.v. Lat. duo 'two'.
Neapolitan loro < Lat. (il)lõrum (gen.pl. of ille), cf. It. loro.
Neapolitan mazza from spoken Lat. *măttea(m), cf. It. mazza.

Cf. s.v. mateola 'wooden hammer', a diminutive of a noun *matea 'hoe' (vel sim.), perhaps from PIE ?*mot-(i-), cf. Ved. matyá- 'club, harrow, roller', OCS motyka, Russ. motyga 'hoe' OHG medela 'plough'.
Neapolitan from late Lat. pileāre? Cf. It. pigliare.
S.v. Lat. vērus 'real, true', from PIE *u̯eh₁-ro- 'real, true' (cf. OIr. fir, W. gwir < Proto-Celtic *wīro-; OCS věra < Proto-Slavic *věra; OHG wār 'true').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *věra f. 'faith, belief', from PIE *u̯eh₁-r-eh₂ (cf. Lat. vērus (adj.) 'true', OHG wāra 'treaty, loyalty, protection').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *wīro- 'true', from PIE u̯eh₁-ro- (cf. Lat. uērus, OHG wār, OCS věra 'belief', OHG wâr).
Cf. s.v. *dʰegʷʰ- 'mit Feuer behandeln, verbrennen (tr.)' (IEW 240-1).
S.v. fæson 'спина' & on 'лопатка'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *lędvьje; *lędvьja 'loins' < PIE *lendʰ-u- (cf. Lat. lumbus 'loin', OHG lentīn 'kidneys, loins').
S.v. Ved. váy- 'Vogel' (cf. Kho. boik, Singh. viyā 'Vogel') < PIE *h₂u̯ei̯- (cf. Arm. haw, Lat. auis 'bird', Gk. αἰετός 'eagle', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *ę̄tro 'liver' < PIE *h₁en-tr-om (cf. Ved. āntrá- 'intestine', Gk. ἔντερα 'entrails').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *pekti 'bake', from PIE *pekʷ- 'cook' (cf. Lith. kèpti 'bake, fry' [with metathesis], Skt. pácati 'cook, bake, fry', Gk. πέσσω 'bake, cook, ripen').

Cf. s.v. Lith. kepti 'bake, fry' (Latv. cept 'bake, fry'), from PIE *pekʷ- (cf. OCS pešti, Ved. pácati 'cook, bake, fry', Gk. πέσσω 'bake, cook, ripen'). "It is generally assumed that East Baltic *kep- results from metathesis."
S.v. Ved. hári- 'fahl, gelblich, grünlich' < PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-i- (cf. Gk. χλωρός 'pale green, green-yellow', OHG gelo 'yellow', Lith. žélti 'to flourish, turn green').
S.v. Ved. hári- 'fahl, gelblich, grünlich' < PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-i- (cf. Gk. χλωρός 'pale green, green-yellow', OHG gelo 'yellow', Lith. žélti 'to flourish, turn green').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *žьltъ adj. 'yellow' based on a zero-grade fromation *g̑ʰl̥h₃-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *zelenъ, based on a full-grade formation from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-, cf. *žьltъ adj. 'yellow' /cognate/7535/ based on a zero-grade fromation *g̑ʰl̥h₃-.

Arm. dełin 'yellow' is probably related to dalar 'green, fresh' and dalukn 'jaundice'. This is usually compared to Greek θάλλω 'to bloom, flourish, grow'. In this case Arm. dalar would be directly cognate with Greek θαλερός, which may be accounted for via *dʰl̥h₁-ro-.
Cf. under §4.18 *dʰal(e)- (*dʰ(e)h₂l(h₁)-) 'sprout, be fresh, green' for a thorough philological and etymological discussion of the Armenian and Greek forms.
Cf. s.v. Ved. paryāríṇi- 'nach einem Jahr erst kalbend(e Kuh)' based on *pari-yārám 'a year long' < pári and *yār 'year' (=Av. yār- 'year', OHG jār, etc.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *aþna- 'year' < PIE *h₂et-no- (cf. Lat. annus, Osc. aceneis [gen.sg.], Umb. acnu [acc.sg]).
Cf. s.v. *rek- 'ordnen, festlegen, bestimmen' (IEW 863).
Cf. s.v. Ved. sámā- 'Jahr, Halbjahr, Jahreszeit', probably originally from PIE *s(e)m-eh₂-/*sm̥-h₂- reanalysed as *semh₂-, cf. Arm. am 'year', amarn 'summer', OIr. sam, OHG sumar 'summer', etc.

S.v. Alb. grua ~ grue 'woman', from Proto-Albanian *grāwā, to be connected with Gk. γραῦς 'old woman', derivatives of PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to become old'. Alternatively Meyer (1891:132) derives from *gʷnōn- to PIE *gʷen- 'woman, wife', but *-n- would be preserved in Gheg.

S.v. Alb. grúa, -ja 'Frau, Weib, Ehefrau'. Morphologically isolated and etymologically disputed; Against the older, formally easier comparison with Gk. γραῦς 'alte Frau' stands the (only) semantically more convincing connection to OCS žena 'Frau', Ved. gnā́ 'unirdische Frau' (cf. Meyer 1891). Against this, one must assume an interior dissimilation. Despite the unclear history of the word, the connection with Gk. γραῦς 'old woman' is to be preferred.

Cf. Lat. cīvis 'citzen' < PIE *k̑ei̯-u̯o- 'friendly, intimate, dear' (cf. Ved. śivá- 'favourable', Latv. siẽva 'wife', Goth. heiwa-frauja 'master of the household', OEng. hīwan 'members of the household' OHG hīwo 'husband', OIc. hýski 'household, family'). 

"The IE root behind this formation is often assumed to be *k̑ei- 'to lie', but this is semantically difficult. Vine 2006b: 148 embroiders on an earlier suggestion by Bader: he proposes a derivative in *-uo- from the pronominal stem *k̑i- 'this (here)' (> Skt. siva-), with full grade *k̑eiuo- 'close'"

S.v. Proto-Slavic *krīdlo- 'wing' < PIE (transponat) *(s)krei-dʰlom. Balto-Slavic has the root *(s)krei- in common, cf. Lith. skriẽti (dial.) 'rotate, circle, fly' (Standard Lith. skríeti), Latv. skrìet 'go, run, fly'.
Cf. s.v. ?*(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'einen Kreis beschreiben' (IEW 936). As a verbal root only Baltic. In Slavic without s-mobile.

Cf. s.v. Arm. *tʻiṙ- 'to fly', derived from the same root as *tʻer 'leaf, etc.' < PIE *pter-, probably a derivative of PIE *pet- 'to fly' (cf. Gk. πτερόν 'feather', πτέρυξ 'wing of a bird', πέτομαι 'to fly', etc').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ed-o-, from PIE *h₁ed- 'eat'.
S.v. *h₁ed- '(beißen →) essen' (IEW 287-9).

S.v. Ved. √tej- 'scharf machen, zuspitzen', PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein' (cf. Gk. στίζω [pf.pass. ἔστιγμαι] 'steche, tätowiere', στίγμα 'Stich, Brandmerkung', Lat. īn-stīgāre 'anspornen', NHG stehen, Stich', etc.).

Cf. s.v.  Ved. śyāva- 'dunkelbraun, schwarzbraun, dunkel' (IIr. YAv. siiāuuaº 'dunkel', Khot. śāva- 'Kupfer, kupferfarben', Parth. sy'w, MP siyā, NP siyaāh, Oss. sau 'schwarz', etc.) from PIE *k̑i̯eh₁-u̯ó- (cf. Lith. šývas 'weiß, schimmelfarbig', ORuss. sivъ, Sloven. sìv 'grau') and s.v. Ved. śyāmá- 'schwarz, dunkelfarbig' (IIr. YAv. sāma- 'schwarz') < PIE *k̑i̯eh₁-mó-.

S.v. *h₂eh₁- 'heiß sein' (not in IEW). The root is perhaps found verbally in Palaic ḫāri, ḫanta 'heiß sein' < *h₂eh₁-, which may be an unextended form of *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).
S.v. 11165 Skt. lṓhita 'red' AV., n. 'any red substance' ŚBr., 'blood' VS. [< rṓhita-].
S.v. Ved. róhita- 'rot, rötlich' a derived adjective from PIE *h₁reu̯dʰ- 'be red' (cf. YAv. raoiδita- 'rot, rötlich').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *weli-, *woli- 'blood' from PIE < *u̯elh₂/₃- 'wound' (cf. Lat. uolnus 'wound', Gk. οὐλή 'scar').
Cf. s.v. *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' [IEW 1144-5]. If the Greek verb ἑάλων 'würde überwunden, wurde gefangen' does not belong to this root, then a reconstruction with final *h₂ is also possible.
S.v. *dʰegʷʰ- 'mit Feuer behandeln, verbrennen (tr.)' (IEW 240-1).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *brinnan- 'to burn', assuming an etymology from a derived n-present from PIE *bʰreu̯h₁- 'to boil, brew' (cf. OIr. do-bruinn 'to flow, trickle' < *bʰru-n-h₁-ie-; Lat. ferveō, -ere 'to be hot, to boil' < *bʰéru̯h₁-e-).

S.v. ayrem 'to burn'. There are two possible etymologies, either (1) derived to PIE *h₂eh₁- as a denominal verb from *ayr- 'fire' compared to Av. ātar-/āθr- 'fire', Lat. āter 'black, dark', OIr. āith 'furnace', Palaic ḫā- 'be hot' (cf. Hübschmann 1897:418), or (2) from PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ-, cf. Gk. αἴθω 'to kindle, burn', Skt. edh- 'to set alight, kindle; shine' (Jasanoff 1979:145, Viredaz 2003:85). Alternatively Klingenschmitt (1982:98n16) has assumed an Iranian loanword.
S.v. *deu̯k- 'ziehen' (IEW 220-1).
Cf. s.v. 4236 Skt. gr̥bhāyáti 'takes, seizes' RV.
S.v. Ved. √grabh- 'ergreifen, nehmen, fassen, festhalten' from a PIE root probably to be reconstructed *gʰreb⁽ʰ⁾H- (cf. Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'rauben', Lett. grebt 'greifen', OCS grabiti 'rauben').
S.v. *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 455).
Cf. s.v. 11456 vahana- n. 'carrying' MBh., 'flowing of water' Nir., 'ship' Kathās. [√vah].
S.v. Ved. √vah- 'fahren, Wagen lenken, Wagen ziehen, herbeiführen, befördern, bringen' < PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ-.
Cf. s.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben, fahren' (IEW 1118-20).
5884 tulayati ʻ lifts ʼ R., ʻ weighs ʼ MBh. [√tul]
S.v. *telh₂- 'aufheben, auf sich nehmen' (IEW 1060-1).
Cf. s.v. *ut -- śrayati, úcchrayati 'raises', °tē 'rises' RV. 2. *ut-śrāpayati, ucchrāpayati 'raises' VS. 3. *ut -- śrāpaṇa- . [√śri]. Variant 2 > Si. osavanavā, usuv°, ussanavā 'to raise'.
Cf. s.v. *k̑lei̯- 'sich anlehnen' (IEW 601-2).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *fextu- 'breast' < PIE *pektu- (IEW 792), cf. Lat. pectus 'chest'.
S.v. Lat. infans 'kleines Kind' > French enfant.
Reconstructs for Gk. θάλλω, etc. *dʰalh₁- (cf. IEW 234).
S.v. Lat. infāns, infāntis, a fossilised participle of for, fāri 'speak' with the negative prefix in-, lit. 'un-speaking' > 'infant, baby'.
Cf. s.v. *bʰeh₂- 'sprechen, sagen' (IEW 105-6).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *otrokъ 'child, servant', a noun consisting of the prefix *ot- and an o-stem *rokъ from *rekti 'speak'.
Cf. s.v. *rek- 'ordnen, festlegen, bestimmen' (IEW 863).
Root reference form given as Indo-Aryan *lāma- because the precise IE root identification is uncertain.
Possible IE roots include *lemH- (LIV² 412, IEW 674) or *h₁rem- (LIV² 252, IEW 864).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bow-koli- 'cowherd' < PIE *gʷou̯-kʷolo- 'cowherd' = Gk. βουκόλος 'id.' (IEW 639).

S.v. ὄνυξ, -υχος 'nail, claw, hoof'. Greek form presupposes *h₃nogʷʰ- or *h₃nogʰ-u- to account for the raising of radical *-o- > -u- by Cowgill's Law (i.e. -o- > -u- between a labial and a nasal, cf. νύξ 'night' < *nokʷt-s). Similarly Classical Armenian eɫungn must also reflect the same forms, but is also a secondary n-stem from the accusative.

S.v. Ved. nakhá- 'Nagel, Fingernagel, Zehennagel, Kralle, Klaue'. "Iir. *nā̆kʰ- ist von idg. *h₃Engʰ-/*h₃nEgʰ- 'Nagel, Kralle' (~ lat. unguis, lit. nãgas Nagel u.a. o. I 49) nicht zu trennen." Cf. notes to entry in Mayrhofer for further discussion of the phonetic difficulties of the Indo-Iranian forms.

S.v. Ved. nakhá- 'Nagel, Fingernagel, Zehennagel, Kralle, Klaue'. "Iir. *nā̆kʰ- ist von idg. *h₃Engʰ-/*h₃nEgʰ- 'Nagel, Kralle' (~ lat. unguis, lit. nãgas Nagel u.a. o. I 49) nicht zu trennen." Cf. notes to entry in Mayrhofer for further discussion of the phonetic difficulties of the Indo-Iranian forms.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *skāto- 'shadow' (cf. OIr. scáth), probably from a PIE root noun *skeh₃t- / *skh₃t-o- with Celtic preserving the full grade of the root, cf. OEng. sceadu 'shadow', Gk. σκότος 'darkness, gloom'.

Cf. s.v. *teh₂- 'tauen, schmelzen' (IEW 1053). [Without Albanian cognates listed.]. Note LIV² tentatively assigns the Albanian forms ?[Alb. f-toh 'kühlt, läßt abkühlen to 1. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (so Demiraj 1997:173-174), but mentioning (n5) the proposal of Orel (1998:105) who connects a preform *awa-tā- to 2. teh₂-.
S.v. Alb. ftoh 'abkühlen, kalt werden lassen', continuing a present *teh₂-sk̑e/o- to 2. *teh₂- 'tauen, schmelzen' (LIV² 616).
S.v. śyā́yati 'macht gerinnen, macht gefrieren / causes to congeal, causes to freeze'. "Außerarische Anschüsse bleiben unsicher."
S.v. Proto-Germanic *kalda- 'cold', originally a past participle to the verb *kalan- 'to be cold' (cf. s.v.) from PIE *g̑ólH-e-, cf. Lat. gelus 'cold, frost, ice' < *gel-u-.
S.v. 13676 stabdha- 'firmly fixed' ŚvetUp. 2. 'stiff, paralysed, dull' MBh., 'solidified (as water)' Hariv. [√stambh].
S.v. Ved. √stambh- 'befestigen, stützen', from PIE *stembʰH- something like 'stützen, versteifen, festtreten' (cf. Gk. ἀστεμφής 'fest, starr', Lith. stem̃bti 'widerstreben', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *stembʰH- 'sich stützen, sich stemmen' (IEW 1012-3).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic zima 'winter' < PIE *g̑ʰei̯-m-eh₂ (cf. Skt. hímā-, Av. ziiā̊ [gen. zimō], Gk. χειμών, Lat. hiems).
S.v. Ved. yā-¹ 'fahren, dahinziehen, sich bewegen' < PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- (cf. Lith. jóti, Latv. jât 'reiten, fahren', TochA yā- 'gehen, fahren', Lat. iānus 'Durchgang, Torbogen', etc.).
S.v. *i̯eh₂- 'dahinziehen, fahren' [IEW 296].
S.v. 1483 Ved. ā́sadati 'sits near, approaches' RV. [√sad] (B. āsā 'to come').
S.v. Ved. √sad- 'sitzen' < PIE *sed-.
S.v. *sed- 'sich sitzen' (IEW 884-7).
S.v. 1. *leh₂- 'bellen' (IEW 650-1).
Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *latyo- 'day', from PIE *leh₁t- 'warm part of the year(?)' (IEW 680), cf. OCS lěto 'year', Croat. ljȅto 'summer', Swed. (dial.) låding 'spring'.

S.v. Arm. meṙanim, 'to die', a present stem which was back-formed on the basis of the active root aorist (3.sg. *mér-t), ultimately derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear, vanish' (cf. Skt. mar- 'to die', Hitt. mer- 'to disappear, vanish', Lat. morior, OCS mrěti, etc.).
S.v. Ved. √mar- 'sterben', from PIE *mer- 'verschwinden, hinschwinden, sterben' (cf. Lat. morior 'sterbe', Goth. maurϸr 'Mord', Lith. mir̃ti, OCS mrěti 'sterben', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *merti 'die', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *mer-/*mir- (cf. Lith. mir̃ti, Latv. mìrt 'die'), derived from PIE *mer- (cf. Skt. mriyáte 'die, Lat. morior 'die').

S.v. Lat. morior, morī 'to die', from PIE *mr̥-i̯e-, from root *mer- 'to disappear, die' (cf. OIr. marb, W. marw 'dead' < *mr̥-u̯o-; Hitt. mer- 'to disappear, vanish' < *mer-/*mr-; Skt. mriyáte < *mr-ie-; YAv. miriia- 'to die', Gk. (Hesych.) ἔμορτεν [3.sg.ipf.act.] 'died', Arm meṙani- 'to die', Goth. maurϸr 'murder', Lith. mir̃ti 'to die', OCS mrěti 'to die', etc.).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *marwo- 'dead' (adj.), from which the Brit. Celtic forms are denominative verbal formations. The PIE adjective *mrto- (cf. Skt. mr̥tá-, Lat. mortuus) as remodelled in Celtic on analogy with *gʷiH-u̯os 'alive' (cf. Lat. uīuus, etc.).
S.v. ?*su̯eld- 'verhungern, sterben' [IEW 1045]. Root only attested in Germanic. Cf. n1 "nach IEW urspr. 'verschmachten', d-Präs zu 1. *su̯el- 'schwelen, brennen'.
Cf. s.v. *gʷeh₂- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten' (IEW 463-4), to which OIr. baïd 'die' is a secondary zero-grade i̯e-present *gʷh₂-i̯é-.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *bā- 'die' (OIr. baïd) and *bāsto- 'death', derivatives of PIE *gʷeh₂- 'take a step, go'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √khod- 'hineinstoßen [des Penis]'. 'Nicht sicher erklärt'.
S.v. 3934 *khōdd- 'dig'. 2. *khōḍḍ- . 3. *kōḍḍ- . 4. *gōdd- . 5. *gōḍḍ- . 6. *guḍḍ- . [Poss. conn. with khudáti ʻ thrusts (penis) into ʼ RV., prákhudati ʻ futuit ʼ AV.]
S.v. Lith. kàsti 'dig, rake' < PIE *kes- (cf. Hitt. kiš- 'comb, card').
S.v. *kes- 'ordnen' (IEW 585).
S.v. ?2. *k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂- 'graben' [IEW 634 Anm.]. Cf. n1, comparing IIr. *kʰā́- 'spring'; from the nasal-present *k⁽ʷ⁾-né/n̥-h₂- a new PIIr. root *kanH- was abstracted.
S.v. Ved. mála- 'Schmutz, Unreinlichkeit, Unrat, Dreck', probably to be derived from PIE *mélo-, cf. Gk μέλας 'black', Lith. mė́las 'blue', mel̃svas 'blueish'.

Cf. s.v. mazati 'smear, anoint'. Derksen groups the Slavic lexemes with Lith. mė́žti 'manure, muck out', Latv. mêzt 'muck out, sweep' < Balto-Slavic *moʔź-, although he also admits that the connection with Gk. μάσσω 'knead', Arm. macanem 'thicken, stick together' < PIE *mag̑- (cf. LIV² 421).
Cf. s.v. *mag̑- 'streichen, schmieren' (IEW 696-7).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *wreg-o- 'do, make' (cf. Myc.Gk. wo-ze / worzei /, Goth. waurkjan).
S.v. 2. *u̯erg̑- 'wirken, machen' (IEW 1168-9).
S.v. 1. *h₂er- 'sich (zusammen)fügen' (IEW 55-8).
S.v. Arm. aṙnem 'to make, create' < PIE *h₂er- 'to fix, put together'.
S.v. 2. ?*su̯el- '(ver)schlucken' (IEW 1045). Only attested in Iranian, perhaps also in Germanic through enlarged *su̯el-gʰ- in OHG sweigan 'verschlucken', etc. cf. n1.

S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar¹ 'consume, eat'. The root is probably secondary to Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar³ 'to take'. Further IE connections are uncertain and postulating a PIE root *su̯el- (as in LIV², IEW) is probably unwarranted.
S.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben; fahren' (IEW 1118-20).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯az 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)' < PIE u̯eg̑ʰ-.
Gothic s.v. S177 *swarts (only acc. swart), from PIE *swordo-s 'black, dirty', cf. Lat. sordēs 'dirt', sordidus 'dirty', sordeō 'be dirty' from adj. *sordus 'dirty'.

S.v. Ved. √khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen, verzehren'. Cf. NPers. xāyīdan 'kauen' if from *kʰād-, Baluči khāδαγ 'eat', Khot. khaca 'food' (if from *xad-čā). Further connections are not certain.
Cf. s.v. √pā-² 'trinken', from PIE *peh₃-/*ph₃- (~ *peh₃-i̯-/*ph₃-i- → *pih₃-).

S.v. Gothic D33 drigkan. No accepted etymology. Possibly from PIE *dʰerH-gʰ- (cf. Lith. dìrgti, drė́gti 'become damp, etc.) or from PIE *dʰreg̑- 'move, glide' (cf. Skt. dhrájati 'glide', Lith. drė́zti 'tear', Latv. dragât 'pull'), alternatively borrowed from a pre-Germanic source, but this conjecture is unverifiable.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *þurzu- 'dry' from a PIE u-stem *tr̥s-u- (cf. Ved. tr̥ṣu- 'avaricious', YAv. taršu- 'dry, not fluid'.
S.v. Gothic þaursus (Þ25), an old u-stem *tr̥s-u- from PIE *ters- 'dry' (cf. Skt. tr̥ṣú- 'greedy, desirous', Av. taršu- 'dry', Lat. torrus, OIr. tur 'dry, dried out', tīrim 'dry' etc.).

Cf. S.v. Gothic *qiþus in *qiþu-hafto in acc.sg. -ton ἐν γαστρὶ ἔχουσα (1Th 5.3) dat.pl. þaim -tom ταῖς ἐν γαστρὶ ἔχουσα, cf. *laus-qiþrs 'with empty stomach', from Germanic *kveþu, *kveþra 'stomach, belly' (OI. kviðr, OSw. kviþer 'belly, womb', OEng. cwiþ(a) 'belly, womb, body', etc. < PIE *gʷei̯H₂- 'live' (*gʷi(ə)-tu-/-tro- 'womb, stomach').

S.v. Gothic dags (D3). Possibly from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- burn, with modifications (cf. Skt. ni-dāghás 'heat, summer', Lith. dãgas, dagà 'heat, sultry harvest time', OPruss. dagis 'summer', Skt. dāhas 'burning, heat', OIr. daig, gen. dega 'fire; Skt. dáhati, Av. dažaiti 'burns', Lith. degù, Latv. dęgu, OCS žegǫ < *degǫ 'burn', etc.). "dags would then refer to the period 'when the sun burns down'".
Cf. s.v. Ved. áhan- (~ áhar, Heterokliton) 'Tag, Tageschelle'. Perhaps from PIE *(h₂)eg̑ʰ-r/n- /cognate/8124/, which has been attempted by some scholars to be connected with Germanic words for 'day'.

S.v. Ved. áhan- (~ áhar, Heterokliton) 'Tag, Tageschelle'. In IIr. cf. OAv. G.pl. asnąm 'der Tage', YAv. L.sg. asni 'am Tage' Perhaps from PIE *(h₂)eg̑ʰ-r/n-, which one attempts to connect with Germanic words for 'day' (OHG tag 'Tag', ON dægr, dægn 'Halbtag', etc.).

S.v. *bʰleh₁- 'heulen' (IEW 121-2, 154-5). The Germanic words without -s- are traced back directly to the IE present formation *bʰléh₁-/bʰl̥h₁-, the forms containing -s- to a desiderative IE *bʰléh₁-/bʰl̥h₁-s-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *blēan- 'to blow' and Proto-Germanic *blēsan- 'to blow'. K. considers the Germanic forms without -s- to stem from a Western European thematic present *bʰléh₁-e-, the forms with -s- from a sigmatic aorist *bʰlḗh₁-/bʰléh₁-s-. Cf. Lat. flāre < *bʰlh₁-.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *fursa- 'gush(?)' < PIE *pr̥s-o-.
Cf. s.v. Ved. pŕ̥ṣant- 'gesprenkelt, weißgefleckt' < PIE *pers- 'sprühen, spritzen' (cf. TochAB pärs- 'besprengen', Hitt. papparš- 'verspritzen', Cz. pršeti 'spritzen', etc.).

S.v. pluhur ~ pluhun 'dust, powder'. Argued to be a phonetic development of *plëhur ~ plëhun derived from pleh ~ plêh 'sweepings, dung, rubbish', in turn derived from plah ~ plaf 'to cover' < PAlb. p(e)laska- incohative formation < IE *pl̥H-sk̑e/o- (cf. -πέλας 'skin', Lith. palà 'linen kerchief', plenė̃ 'thin skin, membrane' ONor. fjall 'skin' etc., cf. Demiraj (1997:323-324). Alternatively Meyer (1891:346) from Rom. *pluverem < Lat. pulverem 'dust, powder'.
Loanword from Romance *pluverem < Lat. pulverem 'dust'.
Cf. s.v. *pelh₁- 'in Schwung bringen' (IEW 801).

S.v. Ved. reṇú- 'Staub', probably to be derived from √ray- 'strömen, rinnen, laufen, wallen' < PIE *(H)rei̯(H)-, cf. Lat. rīvus 'creek', MIr. rīan 'river, sea', OEng. rīd 'stream, creek', Russ. réjatь 'flow quickly', etc.
S.v. Goth. *stubjus (S157). From Proto-Germanic *stewb- (cf. OHG zestiuben 'disperse', Du. stuiven 'fly about, scatter'; OHG stoup 'dust'). No accepted etymology outside of Germanic.
S.v. Skt. dhūliḥ 'Staub / dust'. Etymology uncertain, cf. entry for various proposals.

S.v. OLith. pùsti 'anschwellen, sich aufblähen', anticausativum to pū̃sti 'wehen, blasen'. Clear correspondences outside of Baltic are lacking. There are many roots among IE languages in *pu-, *pʰu- related to words for blowing and swelling (cf. Gk. φῦσα, Arm. pʻowkʻo, Lat. pustula) of possible (independent) onomatopoeic origin.
S.v. OLith. dùlkė 'Staub'. No clear etymology outside of Lithuanian.
S.v. Ved. pāṁsú- 'Staub, Sand, zerbröckelnde Erde'. Further connections outside of Indo-Iranian are problematic, possibly to *pē-n-s- beside *pēs- in OCS pěsъkъ.
S.v. Ved. pāṁsú- 'Staub, Sand, zerbröckelnde Erde'. Further connections outside of Indo-Iranian are problematic, possibly to *pē-n-s- beside *pēs- in OCS pěsъkъ.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √yav-¹ 'verbinden, festhalten, anschirren' < PIE *i̯eu̯- 'verbinden' (cf. Lith. jáuti, jaũti 'vermischen'). The meaning 'eat' found in Aškuni yū- 'eat' and Wakhi yaw- 'eat' is a secondary semantic development.
Cf. s.v. 1. *i̯eu̯- 'festhalten, an sich ziehen, verbinden' (IEW 507, 508).

S.v. Ved. √khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen, verzehren'. Cf. NPers. xāyīdan 'kauen' if from *kʰād-, Baluči khāδαγ 'eat', Khot. khaca 'food' (if from *xad-čā). Further connections are not certain.
Cf. s.v. ?*k⁽ʷ⁾h₂ed- '(zer)quetschen' [IEW 634 Anm.]. Only Indo-Iranian cognates.
French manger 'eat' from Lat. manducāre 'chew, eat'.

S.v. Lat. mandō 'chew, bite', from which Lat. manducāre is a secondary derivative via mandūcō 'masked figure with champing jaws' (Pl.+). Against LIV² which derives Lat. mandō from *meth₂- 'rob, snatch away' (IEW 732). De Vaan alternatively argues for a derivation from *menth₂- 'to stir, whirl' via a nasal-infix stem *mt-n(é)-h₂-. with a phonetic development paralleled by pandō < *pt-n(é)-h₂- (*peth₂- 'to spread').

S.v. *meth₂- 'wegreißen' (IEW 732). Cf. n4: thematised *mat-n̥-h₂-e- > *matane- > *matne- > mande-; regarding the semantic development 'wegreißen' → '(Beute) reißen' → 'zerfleischen' → 'fressen' → 'kauen'.

LIV² is followed representing the usual communis opinio for the root-cognacy from *meth₂-, but cf. arguments of de Vaan for a possible alternative derivation from *menth₂- with further discussion and references to secondary literature.
S.v. *h₂eu̯- 'genießen' (IEW 77-8). The Albanian forms are perhaps from a thematic present stem ?*h₂éu̯-e-.

Cf. s.v. Goth. mats 'food' (cf. OIc. matr, OFris. mete, OSax. meti, OHG maz 'food', NEng. meat), from which matjan 'eat, have a meal with' is derived. Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Perhaps PIE *mad- 'wet, become moist', *mad- 'common meal', or to *mitan- 'measure out'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *mati- 'food' to which Goth. matjan 'to eat' is a derived factitive. Considers the root probably to *med- 'to satiate' (cf. Gk. μεστός 'full', rejecting proposed connections to *mad- 'drip, melt, be moist' and Lat. mandeō 'chew'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *burzda- 'board', from PIE *bʰrzdʰ-o-, related to PGmc. *brezda- 'side, edge, board' < *bʰrezdʰ-o- (NHG Brett, etc.) and *brazda- 'edge, brim' < *bʰrozdʰ-o- (for which cf. OIr. brot 'goad, spike').
S.v. Lat. terra 'dry land, earth' < Proto-Italic *tersā- 'earth', terso- 'area'. Cf. PIE *ters-h₂- 'dry land' (OIr. tír 'territory; dry', OWel. tir < *tērs-o/es-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *tīros- 'land, earth' < PIE *ter-s- 'dry'.
S.v. Ved. pāṁsú- 'Staub, Sand, zerbröckelnde Erde', further connections outside of Indo-Iranian are problematic.
S.v. 13776 Ved. sthūlá- 'large, thick, stout' AV. [~ sthūrá- ] >  K. ṭhūl m. 'egg'.
S.v. Ved. sthūra- 'groß, stark, dick, wuchtig' < PIE *stuh₂-ró- (cf. Old Swedish stūr 'groß', Middle Dutch stūr 'groß, stark').
S.v. *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten' (IEW 133-5). The Albanian forms are from a secondarily derived e-grade thematic i̯e-present *bʰerH-i̯e/o- (= Lat. feriō 'stoßen, schlagen').
S.v. *sengʷ- 'herunterfallen, untergehen, sinken' (IEW 906). The Armenian present stem forms are probably from a stem ?*sn̥-né/n-gʷ-. Cf. aor. *séngʷ-/*sn̥gʷ- > Arm. ankaw 'fiel'.

S.v. ankanim 'to fall down; to come down, hang down; to arrive, come to end, cease, stop; to die, fall (especially in battle); to fall morally, commit a crime, sin, prostitute, etc.', probably to be derived from PIE *sn̥gʷ- 'to sink, fall' (cf. Goth. sigqan, OHG sinke/an, Germ. sinken, Engl. sink, etc.).
Cf. s.v. Gk. ἵστημι, derived from PIE *steh₂- 'stand'.
S.v. Goth. D35. *driusan, cf. OEng. drēosan, OSax. driosan 'fall', OIc. dreyra 'drip blood' from 'let drop', OHG trōran (= Goth. -drausjan) 'drip, pour away', etc. No certain extra-Gmc. cognates.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *dreusan- 'to fall' (Go. driusan 'to fall down', Nw. drjosa 'id.', OE drēosan 'to rush, fall, perish', OS driosan 'to fall'), a strong verb for which Kroonen reconstructs a preform *dʰréuHs-e-. Cf. *drūsēn- 'fall asleep'.
S.v. ?*dʰreu̯s- 'fallen, herabfallen' (IEW 274-5). Extra-Germanic comparisons given by IEW to justify a PIE root reconstruction are not entirely clear, cf. n1.
S.v. Lat. cadō 'to fall, sink' < ?*(k̑e-)k̑h₂d- 'to fall' (cf. Skt. śad- 'fall', Gk. κεκαδών 'robbing', ὑπὸ … κεκάδοντο 'they receded').

S.v. OLith. krìsti 'fallen'. Zero-grade formation to OLith. krė̃sti < PIE *kret- 'schütteln, rütteln' (cf. Gk. κροτέω 'schlage, rassele', OIr. crothaid 'schütteln, schwingen, erschüttern, erzittern machen', OHG redan 'sieben').
S.v. *kret- 'schütteln, rütteln' (IEW 620, 621).
S.v. Ved. √pad- 'treten, gehen, fallen, niedersinken' < PIE *ped- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten, *fußwärts gehen → fallen', cf. Rix (1976:278f.).
Cf. for discussion of the semantic development of *ped- as a verbal root.

S.v. AGk. μακρός 'long, great, high', from a PIE zero-grade formation *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall', also preserved in Latin and Germanic (cf. Lat. macer 'meagre, thin', OHG magar 'meagre' < *mh₂k̑ró-).
Cf. s.v. Gk. πῖαρ 'fat, tallow' < PIE *piH-u̯r̥. The derived adjective πίων, πίειρα corresponds precisely with Skt. pī́van- (pī́varī- f.) 'fat, swelling'.
Cf. s.v. *h₁ed- '(beißen →) essen' (IEW 287-9).

S.v. Goth. *smairþr 'richness, fatness' (only dat.sg. -þra). Based on PIE *smer- + -tro- as in fodr, *hleiþra, maurþr. Without -tro- there exists in Germanic OIc. smjǫr, smør, OEng. smeoru 'fat, butter', OFris. smere 'tallow', OS, OHG smero 'fat, grease'; OIc. smyrja, OEng. smierwan, smierian OHG smirwen 'smear'. From PIE *smer(u)- 'fat, grease'. Possibly to be compared with Gk. σμύρις 'emery powder, μύρον 'unguent, perfume', Lat. medulla < mer- 'marrow' OIr. smiur 'marrow'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *smerwa- 'butter, grease', from PIE *smer-u- (cf. OIr. smiur 'marrow', MW mer 'id.' < *smeru-; cf. OIr. smeraid 'to anoint' < *smer-eh₂-ie-).
Cf. s.v. *lei̯p- 'kleben bleiben' (IEW 670-1).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *faitaz (cf. ON feitr 'fat', MLG veet id. MHG veiz id.). Considers the stem related to the lexemes found in Indo-Iranian (Skt. pī́van- 'swelling, fat') and Greek (πίων id.).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *faita- adj. 'fat'. PGmc. *faita- gave rise to a factitive *faitjan- 'make fat', whose participle was in turn re-lexicalized cf. OEng. fǣtt, Du. vet, OHG feizzit, G feist. Kroonen speculates a possible connection to PGmc. *faj(j)a- adj. 'fat'(?) (Du. dial. vei 'fat, lush, fertile') with a possible connection to the PIE root *pei̯H- whence Indo-Iranian and Greek lexemes for 'fat'.

Possible connections to Indo-Iranian lexemes in /cognate/3307/, but the precise derivation is unclear. For the purposes of establishing root cognacy these two classes have been split and linked (Level 1: small minority view).
Cf. s.v. Ved. pī́vas- 'Fett, Speck', with no connection to the Germanic lexemes being made.
Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek πῖαρ 'fat, tallow', with no connection to the Germanic lexemes being made.

Some Germanic etymologists attempt to connect the lexemes from Proto-Germanic *faita- 'fat' /cognate/214/ to this class. This is less clear from an inner-Germanic point of view (cf. citations in /cognate/214/), and this connection is not mentioned in the most recent Greek and Indo-Iranian etymological sources. For the purposes of establishing root cognacy these two classes have been split and linked (Level 1: small minority view).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *bojati sę 'fear, be afraid' < PIE *bʰoi̯H-eh₂-.
S.v. OLith. bijóti 'fürchten', derived from PIE *bʰei̯h₂- 'in Furcht geraten' (cf. Ved. bhay- 'sich fürchten').
S.v. Ved. √bhay- 'sich fürchten' < PIE *bʰei̯H-.

S.v. Ved. √dar-¹ 'zersprengen, zerspalten', cf. dara- m. ʻfearʼ (MBh), Sanskrit vi-dar- 'vor Angst bersten'. From PIE *der- 'abspalten; schinden, Haut abziehen' (cf. Gk. δέρω 'häute ab', Goth. dis-tairiþ 'zerreißt', Lith. dìrti, OCS dьrati 'reißen, schinden' etc.).

Cf. s.v. σκιά 'shade' (< PIE *skeh₂-ih₂, gen. *skh₂-ieh₂-s 'shadow') and s.v. σκότος 'darkness, dark' (< PIE *skeh₃t- or *skoto- 'shadow, dark'). Note p.1351 "The relation [of Gk. σκιά] with σκότος is unclear". (Cf. Skt. chāyā́ 'shadow', Av. a-saiia 'who casts no shadow'.)
S.v. Proto-Iranian *θrah (*trs) 'to shake, tremble, fear, flee' < PIE *tres- 'tremble, be afraid'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √tras- 'zittern, erbeben, scheuen, ängstlich sein' < PIE *tres-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *āg-V- 'fear', from PIE *h₂egʰ- 'be afraid'.
S.v. Goth. O3. *ogan 'φοβεῖσθαι', 'fear', from PIE agʰ- 'fear' (cf. Gk. ἄχυμαι 'be sad, mourn', OIr. ad-āgor 'I fear').

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *angwu- adj. 'narrow', from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-u- 'narrow' (cf. Skt. aṃhú- 'narrow', Arm. anj-uk 'narrow, difficult', OCS ǫzъkъ 'narrow'). From PGmc. *angwu- OHG angust, NHG Angst 'fear' are derived forms via PGmc. *angusti-.
Cf. s.v. *u̯en- 'überwältigen, gewinnen' (IEW 1146-7).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *winnan- 'suffer', derived from PIE *u̯en- (cf. Skt. vanóti 'to win, defeat, procure' < *un-néu-, Skt. vánate [3.sg.med.] 'to win', YAv. vanaiti 'to defeat' < *uén-).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *sauč¹ 'burn, emit flames'. "The IE origin of *sauč¹ cannot be ascertained, perhaps it is a "Reimbildung" with *rauč?.
Cf. s.v. Ved. *abhrá- 'Gewitterwolke, Gewölk, Regenwolke' < PIE *n̥bʰ-ró- (*nebʰ-), cf. YAv. aβra- 'Regen[wolke]'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *garz- 'to lament, weep' cf. Skt. garh- 'to complain'. An IE origin for this IIr. root is uncertain.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √garh- 'klagen', PIE perhaps *galg̑ʰ- *gal-g̑ʰ- according to IEW 350 (cf. NHG klagen, MIr. glām 'Geschrei, Fluch'). The connections outside of Indo-Iranian remain uncertain.
Cf. s.v. ?*g⁽ʷ⁾eRg̑ʰ- 'klagen' (IEW 350-1). Only Indo-Iranian.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *kap/f-¹ 'to (be)fall, strike (down)' < PIE *kop- 'fell, chop' (LIV 555, IEW 930ff.).
S.v. 1.*(s)kep- 'hacken, hauen' (IEW 931-2).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *čak/g 'to strike, hit' (Iranian only). "This root is no doubt expressive in origin."
S.v. Proto-Iranian *bar- 'to bring, carry', from PIE *bʰer- 'bear, carry' + preverb *frā̆-.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *Hrab/f-¹ 'to go'. An IE origin of this Iranian root is uncertain.

S.v. Proto-Iranian *paiš 'to crush, grind' < PIE *pei̯s- 'to grind' (cf. Skt. peṣ- 'crush, grind, destroy', Gk. πτίσσω 'I ground, husk', Lat. pīnsere 'to crush, grind (finely)' Lith. paisýti 'to cut off the beards of chaff, peel', etc.).
S.v. *pei̯s- 'zerstampfen, (zer)stoßen' (IEW 796).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh; [incoh., intr.] to become tired' (+ *pati- > MSogd. ptxw’y ‘to kill, put to death’). No clear IE provenance for this exclusively Ir. root.
S.v. OLith. plùnksma 'Feder, Federkiel. Schreibfeder'. Possibly related to Lat. plūma, which might continue earlier *plūksma or *plouksma. The origins of the nasal in plunk- in Lithuanian is obscure.

Possibly from a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' (LIV² 487-488) → *pleu̯k- 'float, swim' (LIV² 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic. Lat. plūma might be based on the *pleu̯k- root, but alternative derivations from unextended *pleu̯- are also possible, cf. /cognate/999/.
Cf. s.v. *pleu̯- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 835-7) and *pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837).

Possibly from a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' (LIV² 487-488) → *pleu̯k- 'float, swim' (LIV² 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic. Lat. plūma might be based on the *pleu̯k- root, but alternative derivations from unextended *pleu̯- are also possible, cf. Lith. plùnksma in /cognate/2263/.
S.v. Ved. √yodh- 'kämpfen' < PIE *Hi̯eu̯dʰ-.
S.v. *bʰei̯H- 'schlagen' (IEW 117-8).

S.v. Lat. luctor, -āri 'to wrestle, struggle', a frequentative verb based on PIE *lug-to- 'bent' (cf. OIr. fo-loing 'supports' in-loing 'connects' MWel. ellwng- 'to set free' < PCl. *-lunge/o- 'to place', Gk. λύγος 'withy, twigs', Goth. ga-lūkan 'to shut', us-lūkan 'to open').
Cf. s.v. 2. *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'biegen' (IEW 685-6).
Cf. s.v. 1. *pek̑- '(Wolle oder Haare) rupfen, zausen' (IEW 797), cf. n2, where the semantics of the Germanic lexemes are derived from earlier *'sich raufen'.
Cf. s.v. *pelh₂- 'sich nähern' (IEW 801-2).
Cf. s.v. ἐμπλέκω 'verflechten'.

S.v. Lat. pungō 'to pierce, sting'. Lat. pugnāre 'fight' is denominal from pugnā 'fight' (n.), which in turn is related to the noun pūgnus 'fist' (cf. Gk. πύξ 'with the fist', πύγμη 'fist, fist-fight', etc.).

S.v. OLith. kovà 'Krieg, Kampf, Streit', either a deverbal derivation from OLith. káuti 'kämpfen, streiten' < PIE *keu̯h₂- or from PIE *keh₂u̯-éh₂-. OLith. kovauti 'kämpfen, streiten' is a secondary verbal derivative.
άψιμο < aor. stem AG ἅψ- (of ἅπτω ‘kindle’, cf. MG αν-άβω) -ιμο; cf. MedG άψιμο ‘fever’.
S.v. AGk. ἅπτω 'to join, attach; kindle' < PIE *h₂ep- 'join, fit' (cf. Hitt. ḫapp- 'join').
S.v. *h₂ep- 'passen, sich fügen' [IEW 50-51]. (Greek cognates not mentioned.)
S.v. Khot. dai (1) 'fire; caustic stuff'. Derived from base dag- 'to burn' < PIE *dʰegʷʰ- (IEW 240-1), cf. Ved. dāgha-, Goth. dags.
Cf. s.v. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (IEW 104-5).
Cf. s.v. *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'entzünden' (IEW 11-2).

S.v. *h₂eh₁- 'heiß sein' (not in IEW). The root is perhaps found verbally in Palaic ḫāri, ḫanta 'heiß sein' < *h₂eh₁-, which may be an unextended form of *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).
Cf. s.v. Lat. āter, -tra, -trum 'black' < PIE *h₂eh₁-t(-)r- 'fireplace' (cf. OIr. áith, W. odyn 'furnace, oven' < PCl. *āti-; Pal. hāri 'to be warm', Av. ātarš, gen.sg. āθrō 'fire' < PIr. *ātr-).
S.v. Alb. zjarr 'fire' < PIE *gʷʰer-es- (cf. Skt. háras- 'flame, heat', Gk. θέρος 'summer', Arm. ǰer id.).
Cf. s.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-495).
Cf. s.v. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (IEW 1069-70).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fiska- 'fish' < PIE *pisk-o- (cf. Lat. piscis < *pisk-i-, OIr. íasc < *peisk-o-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *fēsko- 'fish' < PIE pei̯(k̑)sk̑o-.
S.v. Lat. piscis 'fish' < Proto-Italic *piski- 'fish', an i-stem derivative of PIE *pisk- 'fish' (cf. OIr. íasc < *peisko-, Goth. fisks, OHG fisk < *pisko-).
S.v. žuvìs 'Fisch' (BSl. Latv. zivs 'Fisch', OPr. suckis 'Fisch'), from PIE *dʰg̑ʰ-úH- 'Fisch' (cf. Gk. ἰχθῦς, -ύος 'Fisch', Arm' jowkn, gen.sg. jkan 'Fisch').
S.v. Arm. jukn 'fish', to be connected with Greek and Baltic words for 'fish' (Lith. žuvìs, Lat. zuvs, Gk. ἰχθῦς) < PIE *dg̑ʰuH-.

S.v. ὄψον 'side-dish, especially meat'; in Athens and other places especially 'fish'. < PIE *h₁op-s. Analysed by Taillardat in DELG Supplement as a noun thematised from the adverb *ὄψ, which is reconstructed for ὀψέ 'late' and also found in Lat. obs-. The semantics would have been ὄψον 'supplementary dish (eaten on top of grain, bread)' < *h₁op- 'on, upon' (cf. Gk. ἐπί 'on, upon' < *h₁ep-i, Myc. o-pi < *h₁op-i).
Cf. s.v. *épi 'auf, darauf; auf – hin'.
Cf. the older reconstruction found in IEW: *lak̑- 'sprenkeln, tupfen', dazu wohl *lak̑-so-s 'Lachs'.
S.v. νέφος 'cloud, mass of clouds' < s-stem PIE *nebʰ-os, *nebʰ-es-. The alternative form νεφέλη (s.v.) (= Lat. nebula) is formed to the same root but with an l-suffix.
S.v. κύων 'dog, bitch', from PIE *k̑uon- 'dog' (cf. Skt. śvā́, Lith. šuõ, Hitt. (LÚ)kuu̯an-, HLuw. swan(i)-, etc.).
S.v. ὀφθαλμός 'eye'. Attempts have been made to try to reconcile this word with the root ὀπ- 'to see', but no explanation has been completely convincing.
S.v. πίπτω 'to fall (off), drop down, fall out' < PIE *petH- 'fly, fall'.

S.v. πόρσω 'en avant, devant, loin', {ref Frisk 1960-1972} compares Lat. porrō < *porsō 'en avant'; one could also derive πόρσω from πρόσω, a better explanation, by metathesis of the syllable containing the liquid from πρόσω.
S.v. πατήρ 'father' < PIE *ph₂tēr 'father'.
Tsakonian φοζούμενε < AG φοβοῦμαι. Τhe underlying form is *φο(β)-ιούμαι [fo(v)jume] (the change jV > zV being regular, e.g. υἱός > γιος [jos] > ζε ‘son’, ἐγιώ [ejo] > εζού ‘I’ etc.).
S.v. πτερόν 'feather, wing, pinion', a derivative from PIE *pet- 'fly'.
