S.v. πέτομαι 'to fly', derived from PIE *pet- 'fall' (cf. Lat. petō 'make for, reach', MW ehedec 'to fly', OIr. én, W. edn 'bird'; Hitt. pattai-/patti- 'run, fly', Skt. pátati 'to fly, fall', etc.).

S.v. πήγνυμι 'to fix, stick, join, congeal or coagulate', from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'coagulate, become fixed' (cf. Lat. pangō, -ere 'to fix firmly', Skt. pajrá- 'solid, firm' with loss of laryngeal by Lubotsky's Law').

S.v. Gk. ἔρχομαι 'to come', also 'to go, travel'. The precise Indo-European etymology is debated. Possible connection with PIE *h₁ergʰ- (cf. OIr. eirg [imptv.] 'go!', regaid [fut.] 'he will go', Skt. r̥ghāyáti 'tremble, rage', possibly within Greek as an iterative ὀρχέομαι 'dance' < *h₁orgʰ-éi̯e-) or PIE *h₁er- (cf. Ved. r̥ccháti 'to reach, arrive at', Hitt. arške/a- [iter.] 'to reach repeatedly, make incursions'.)
S.v. χλοή 'first green shoots, young verdure, etc.' < PIE *g̑elh₃- 'green, yellow' (cf. Lith. žolė̃ 'grass, herb, flower' and other words for 'green' /cognate/6332/, 'yellow' /cognate/7535/).
S.v. OLith. žolė̃ 'Gras, Kraut, Pflanze' (cf. OLith. žélti 'grünen, sprießen' < *g̑elh₃-).
S.v. καρδία 'heart' < PIE *k̑ēr(d), gen. *k̑rd-(i)os 'heart'.
S.v. βαρύς 'heavy' < PIE *gʷr̥h₂-ú- 'heavy'.
S.v. τύπτω 'to poke, stab, beat with a weapon or stick' < PIE *steup- 'push, beat' (cf. Lat. stupeō 'to be(come) numb, amazed', Alb. shtyp 'to crush', etc.).
S.v. θερμός 'warm' < PIE *gʷʰer-mó- 'warm'.
Cf. s.v. κρύσταλλος 'ice, rock crystal'. Beekes argues for a 'Pre-Greek' origin of this word.
S.v. γόνυ 'knee' < PIE *g̑enu, *g̑onu 'knee' (cf. Skt. jā́nu, Av. zānu-, Hitt. genu, Lat. genū, TochA kanwe-ṃ, TochB kenī-ne 'knees', Arm. cun-r, Goth. kniu, etc.).
S.v. οἶδα 'to know' < PIE *u̯eid- 'see, look, know'. The stem reflects an old perfect form *u̯oi̯d-h₂e.
S.v. ζώω 'to live' < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-, *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live'.
S.v. ἧπαρ 'liver' < PIE *(H)i̯ekʷ-r 'liver'.
S.v. ἀνήρ 'man' < PIE *h₂ner- 'man' (cf. Ved. nár-, Arm. ayr, etc.).
S.v. μήτηρ 'mother' < PIE *meh₂ter- 'mother'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. nãgas 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf' (BSl. Latv.
 nags 'Finder- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf', OPr. mage 'Fuß'), from PIE *h₃nógʷʰ-/*h₃n̥gʷʰ- 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle' (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ, -υχος, Lat. unguis, OIr. ingen, ON nagl, OE nægel, etc.).
S.v. ὄνομα, -ατος 'name' gramm. 'word', from PIE *h₃neh₃-mn, *h₃neh₃-mn-, *h₃nh₃-men- 'name'.
S.v. ὀμφαλός 'navel, navel string' < *h₃enbʰ-, *h₃mbʰ-, *h₃nebʰ- 'navel'. The Greek words for navel correspond closely to Lat. umbilīcus and OIr. imbliu, reflecting a common derived base *h₃mbʰ-l-.

S.v. τράχηλος 'neck, throat'. A Greek innovation, replacing inherited αὐχήν and δέρη. Possibly to τρέχω 'to run', but words for 'neck' typically denominated as 'turner, turn(ing)' (cf. OCS vratъ to vratiti 'turn', and perhaps also Lith. kãklas [to *kʷelh₁- 'turn'?] rather than 'runner'. Note {ref Furnée 1972}:115 considers the suffix -ηλο- to be common in words of substratum origin, so a borrowing also cannot be ruled out.
S.v. νέος 'new, young, youthful, unusual, unheard' < PIE *neu̯o- 'new'. The derivative form νεαρός < *neu̯eró- vel sim. is a parallel formation to Arm. nora 'new'.
S.v. νύξ, νυκτός 'night' < PIE *nekʷt-, nokʷt- 'night' (perh. from *negʷʰ- 'become dark' with a *-t- root extension).
Cf. s.v. οὐ 'not', where the etymology of Cowgill (1960) is maintained.
Separate roots in LIV² *peth₁- 'fall', *peth₂- 'fly', now merged as *pet- ‘fliegen, stürzen, fallen’¹ (IEW 825-6).
S.v. ὀδών 'tooth' < *h₃d-(o)nt- 'tooth'.
S.v. νίζω 'to wash, bathe' < PIE *nigʷ-i̯e/o- (*nei̯gʷ- 'wash'), cf. OIr. nigim 'to wash' from the same formation. Elsewhere cf. Skt. nenikté with intensive reduplication.
S.v. ἄνεμος 'wind' < PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'wind' (= Lat. animus; cf. Skt. ánila- 'wind, air' < *h₂énh₂lo-; Arm. hołm < *h₂onh₁-mo-, with *n > l dissimilation).
S.v. ξύν 'with, together'. No clear correspondences outside of Greek.
S.v. γυνή 'wife, woman' < PIE *gʷen-h₂ 'woman', cf. dial. (Boeot.) βανά.
Cf. s.v.  εὐλή for earlier proposed etymologies.
S.v. δάκνω 'to bite' also 'to sting (of insects), wound' < PIE *denk̑- 'bite'.
Argues for the separation of the Tocharian forms in this meaning to a different root *dʰei̯Hgʷ-, cf. /cognate/7228/.
Argues for an etymology from *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'sting' rather than *denk̑- 'bite' /cognate/1456/, as frequently proposed elsewhere.
Cf. s.v. *denk̑- 'beißen' (IEW 201) and *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'hineinstecken, stechen' (IEW 243-244). According to the Tocharian evidence *Η should be either *h₂ or *h₃ (cf. n1).
C.f. s.v. *pei̯k̑- 'heraushauen, herausschneiden' (IEW 794-5).

S.v. φέρω 'to bear, endure, carry off, bring away, provide, reach, move along, etc.' < PIE *bʰer- 'bear, carry'. The non-present stems in Ancient Greek are suppletive: fut. οἴσω < ?*h₃ei̯t- (LIV² 297), aor. ἤνεγκα, pf. ἐνήνοχα < *h₁nek̑- (LIV² 250-251, IEW 316-8).

S.v. Lat. ferō, ferre (irregular verb) 'to carry, take' < PIE *bʰer- 'carry'. The suppletive perfect stem tuli and p.p.p. lātum < *tlh₂-to- 'lifted' are based on the root *telh₂- 'lift, take' (LIV² 622-623, IEW 1060-1), cf. Lat. tollō 'lift'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *beran- 1 'to bear, carry, give birth' < PIE *bʰér-e-.
S.v. TochB pär- 'bear (away), carry (off); take up, wear' < PIE *bʰer- 'bear, carry'.
S.v. Arm. berem 'to bring, bear, give fruit' < PIE *bʰer- 'bear'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-o- 'carry, bear, bring' < PIE *bʰer- 'carry'.

S.v. βαίνω 'to go' < PIE *gʷem-, *gʷeh₂-. The Greek present stem and aorist stem are derived from a suppletive pair in PIE. The Greek present stem βαίνω derives from *gʷm̥-i̯e/o- whereas the athematic root aorist ἔβην is derived from *(h₁e)-gʷeh₂-m.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *gam-¹ 'to come' < PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come' (cf. Gk. βαίνω 'I go', Arm. ekn 'came', Lat. venīre, Goth. qiman, Engl. come, etc.).
S.v. ἐμέω 'to vomit', from PIE *u̯emh₁- 'vomit' (cf. Skt. athem. vami-ti; Lat. vomit, vomimus).
S.v. vomō, -ere 'to vomit', from PIE *u̯emh₁- 'to vomit' (cf. Skt. vámiti 'to vomit, spit out', YAv. auui … vaṇti 'spits upon', Gk. ἐμέω, Lith. vémti).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯amH- 'to vomit' < PIE *u̯emh₁- 'to vomit' (cf. Skt. vam-ⁱ 'to vomit, spit out', Gk. ἐμέω, Lat. vomere, Lith. vémti 'to vomit').
S.v. Ved. √vam-ⁱ 'ausspeien, erbrechen, von sich geben', from PIE *u̯emh₁- (cf. Gk. ἐμέω 'erbreche mich', Lat. uomere 'sich erbrechen', Lith. vémti 'Erbrechen haben', etc.).
Cf. for a skeptical discussion of the etymology uniting Greek οὐ(κ) with Armenian ocʻ.
S.v. ḫuett- 'to draw, pull, pluck', suggests a possible etymology with Greek ὠθέω if from *ἀοθέω < *h₂u̯odʰh₁-éi̯e-.

Pace Kloekhorst (2008:352) and Beekes (2010:1676-1677), there is no good evidence as far as i am aware among the non-Attic Greek dialects to postulate a possible *ἀοθέω justifying the reconstruction of an initial laryngeal to the root *u̯edʰh₁-.
S.v. ἐρυθρός 'red' < PIE *h₁reudʰ- 'red'.

S.v. ῥίζα 'root'. Beekes is not convinced that the words are inherited, but cf. Vine (1999) who attempts a regular solution to the problem as a zero-grade formation through schwa secundum. Cf. s.v. ῥᾱ́διξ 'branch, twig', which forms a much closer etymological match to Lat. rādix 'root', Goth. waurts, etc. < *u̯reh₂d-.
Cf. for the stem-formation of Gk. ῥίζα within this root class.

S.v. ὁράω 'to look, perceive, contemplate, see', from *u̯er- connecting the Greek forms to TochA wär- TochB wär-sk- 'to smell', Latv. veruôs, vērtiês 'to inspect, observe'. For the Modern Greek forms, cf. s.v. θεωρός 'spectator, envoy to a festival or to an oracle', properly a compound *θεᾱ-(ϝ)ορός 'one who views or watches a spectacle', from which θεωρέω is a denominal verb.
S.v. ἵστημι 'to make stand, set up, take position, bring to a standstill, etc.' < PIE *steh₂- 'stand, set'.

S.v. ἀστήρ, -έρος 'star', from PIE *h₂ster- 'star' (cf. Hitt. ḫašterza, Arm. astł, OIr. ser, Goth. stairno, ToB ścriye, Av. stār-əm (acc.sg.), Skt. tā́raḥ (nom.pl.), stŕ̥-bhiḥ (ins.pl.), Lat. stēlla).
S.v. ἅλς, ἁλός 'salt' < PIE *seh₂-l- 'salt'.
S.v. ἡδύς 'sweet, tasteful, pleasant, pleasing' < PIE *su̯eh₂d-ú- 'sweet'.

S.v. ayt-kʻ 'cheek'; aytnum (aor. ayteay) 'to swell', connected with Gk. οἰδέω 'swell', οἶδος 'swelling', OHG eiz 'abscess, boil', OIr. óil 'cheek', etc., as derivatives from the PIE root *h₂ei̯d- 'swell'.
S.v. κέρκος 'tail of an animal'. Etymology unknown.

S.v. AGk. ῥίπτω 'to throw, hurl, thrust, bolt'. Based on a root *(ϝ)ριπ- within Ancient Greek. No clear etymology outside of Greek; formally matches MLG wrīven 'to rub, wipe, scour, draw', MHG rīben 'to turn rubbing' ({ref IEW} 1159), but the semantic gap is considerable.
S.v. *u̯ergʷ- 'werfen' [IEW 1153].
S.v. ?*treh₁- 'drehen' (IEW 1072), cf. n1 mostly considered as somehow belonging to *terh₁- 'bohren'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸrēan- s.v. 'to turn', from PIE *tréh₁-e- (cf. Gk. τετραίνω 'to pierce, perforate'; Lat. terō 'to rub' < *terh₁-e-; Lith. trìnti 'to rub, file' < *tr-n-h₁-e-). "A strong verb from a root *treh₁-, apparently a variant of the more wide-spread *terh₁-."
S.v. ?*strebʰ- 'drehen, wenden' [IEW 1025]. Only Greek. If the root is inherited from Indo-European a reconstruction *stregʷʰ- is also theoretically possible (cf. fn1).
S.v. 2. *trep- 'wenden' (IEW 1094).

S.v. τρέπω 'to turn, revolve, put to flight; to turn oneself, change, take flight, etc.', from PIE *trep- to turn' (cf. Lat. trepit 'vertit' (Paul. Fest. p.367), Skt. trapate 'feels ashamed, beomes timid', Hitt. terepp- 'to plough'). "The connection of Myc. to-ro-qe-jo-me-no (meaning unknown; with q) and of Lat. torqueō is untenable."
S.v. to-ro-qe-jo-me-no. Generally interpreted as *τροκʷεyόμενος and compared to Lat. torqueō 'twist' < *terkʷ-.
Cf. s.v. *terkʷ- 'sich drehen' (IEW 1077) and 2. *trep- 'wenden' (IEW 1094). (No Mycenaean forms given in these entries.)
S.v. κάρᾱ 'head' < PIE *k̑rh₂-(e)s-n- 'head'.
S.v. AGk. θάλασσα 'sea'. A loanword from a Pre-Greek substratum language, but evidently quite an early one due to the differing reflexes of -ττ-/-σσ- among the Ancient Greek dialects.
Ancient Greek dialectal variants (Attic, Boeotian θάλαττα, Ionic, etc. θάλασσα) point to a pre-form *tʰálakʸːa, vel sim.
S.v. κόλυμβος 'little grebe, podiceps minor', from which Ancient Greek κολυμβάω 'to dive, submerge, jump into the water, swim' is a denominative verb. No further etymology.
S.v. Alb. madh 'big, large' < Proto-Albanian *madza and related to Hitt. mekkiš, Skt. mahā́nt-, Gk. μέγας, Lat. magnus, etc.
S.v. Arm. mec 'great, big, large' (a-stem). Arm. *mec-a- reflects PIE *meg̑-h₂-.

Cf. s.v. Ved. mahā́nt- 'groß, ausgedehnt, mächtig, bedeutend'. The IIr. forms are based upon PIE *meg̑- 'big' with an ablauting suffix *-(é)h₂-. Cf. entry in Mayrhofer for detailed discussion of the stem formations to this root in Indo-Iranian.
S.v. Lat. magnus 'great, big, large' < Proto-Italic *magno/ā- < PIE *mg̑-no- 'great'.
S.v. Ancient Greek πλατύς 'wide, broad, flat, level'. The Greek forms derive from a zero-grade *pl̥th₂-ú- which is identical to IIr. forms, e.g. Skt. pr̥thú-, Av. pərəθu- 'wide, broad' (√*pleth₂-).
S.v. πουλί < Medieval Greek πουλ(λ)ί(ον), a diminutive of Hellenistic ποῦλ(λ)ας, a loan from Lat. pullus.

S.v. amp (spelled also as amb) 'cloud'. The Armenian form reflects a pre-form *n̥bʰos, which may either consist of "a compromise between *m̥bʰro- and the original s-stem" (so Olsen 1999:45) or, as Martirosyan proposes, a generalisation of a zero-grade genitive from the PD paradigm of the s-stem *nbʰ-és-s.
Cf. for discussion regarding the formation of the Armenian stem.
S.v. κρύος 'Eiskälte, Frost', considers κρύσταλλος a derivative of κρύος.
S.v. κρύος 'froid, qui glace, qui fait frissonner', under which κρύσταλλος is considered a derivative.
S.v. μέτρο < Ancient Greek μέτρον 'measure', from which Modern Greek μέτρω 'I count' is a denominal verb.
S.v. μέτρον 'measure, goal, length, size; metre', from PIE *meh₁- 'measure' (cf. Skt. mā́-ti 'measures').
Root ref. form in this class follows {ref LIV²} 555, but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:748-749.
S.v. χώμα, from Ancient Greek χῶμα 'earth thrown up, bank, mound'.

S.v. χώννυμι 'to heap up, raise, stuff with rubbish or earth'. The present stem of the verb χώννυμι and the derivative χῶμα 'heap, rubbish, dam, wall' are built from the aorist stem χῶσαι, which replaced the unclear form χέαι, from χέω 'pour' < *g̑ʰeu̯-, or alternatively a contracted denominative or intensive *χοῆσαι to χέω.
S.v. τρὠω, from Ancient Greek τρώγω 'gnaw, nibble, munch'.

S.v. τρώγω 'to gnaw, browse, eat'. Beekes rejects LIV²'s explanation of the vocalism of the aorist stem τραγ- as a secondary zero-grade from *treh₃⁽g̑⁾- and consequently rejects IE origins altogether preferring a possible 'Pre-Greek' origin instead.
IE root cognacy in this class follows LIV².
S.v. φωτιά, derived from Ancient Greek φῶς -τός 'light'.
S.v. δάσος, from Ancient Greek δασύς 'thick with leaves, thickly wooded'.
S.v. φρούτο, a loanword from Italian frutto.
S.v. γεμάτος, from Medieval Greek γεμᾶτος 'full', in turn derived from Ancient Greek γέμω 'to be full'.
S.v. γέμω 'to be full of' < ?*gem- 'take, seize'.
Cf. s.v. ἄγω 'to drive, lead, bring, carry; draw etc.' < PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive, lead'.
In re Tsakonian εγγου: According to Andriotis (1974:270) < AG ἥκω, but according to HDMG < ΑG ἄγω. Τhe second interpretation seems more plausible.
Cf. for an alternative etymology of the Tsakonian forms from Ancient Greek ἥκω 'I have come'.
Tsakonian χόντι < AG χόρτος (for the change rt > nd cf. ἄρτος > Tsak. άντε ‘bread’.
S.v. χόρτο, from Ancient Greek χόρτος 'enclosure, court'. The other Modern Greek forms are also derived from this lexeme.
Cf. s.v. Lat. porrum 'leek'.
Cf. arguing against proposed connections of Arm. mal 'ram' to the Greek lexemes.
S.v. κτύπος. The verb κτυπέω 'crash, resound' is denominal (cf. Hom. κτύπος 'crash, bang, din') and already attested in Ancient Greek.
S.v. SMG ζεστός, a derived adjective from Ancient Greek ζέω 'boil'.

S.v. ζέω 'boil, seethe' < PIE *i̯es- 'boil, foam' (cf. Skt. yasati [gramm.] 'seethe, boil', OHG jesan 'ferment, foam', TochA yäs- 'boil'; perhaps also Alb. ziej; nominal formations exist in Celtic, e.g. Gallo-Rom. *i̯estā 'foam', MW ias 'boil, foam').
S.v. σπίτι < Medieval Greek σπίτι(ν) < Hellenistic Greek ὀσπίτιον, a loanword from Lat. hospitium.
S.v. κυνηγός, the verb κυνηγέω 'hunt' (lit. 'drive dogs upon') is denominative to κυνηγός 'hound-leader, huntsman'.
S.v. πάγος, from Ancient Greek πάγος 'that which is fixed or firmly set; rock, ice'.

S.v. πάγη 'snare, trap' < PIE *peh₂g̑- 'make fast, stiff'. From the same root πάγος 'pinnacle, cliff, hill; ice, hoarfrost, frost', cf. πήγνυμι 'to fix, stick, join, congeal or coagulate', from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'coagulate, become fixed' (cf. Lat. pangō, -ere 'to fix firmly', Skt. pajrá- 'solid, firm' with loss of laryngeal by Lubotsky's Law').
S.v. σκωτώνω, remodelled from Ancient Greek σκοτόω 'to make dark, to blind', a denominal verb from σκότος 'darkness, dark'.
S.v. SMG ξέρω. The new present stem ξέρω was backformed from Ancient Greek aorist ἐξεῦρον from ἐξευρίσκω 'find out, discover'.
S.v. AGk. εὑρίσκω 'to find, uncover'. Cf. entry in Beekes for a discussion of competing hypotheses for stem formations in Ancient Greek.
S.v. ξαπλώνω, from Medieval Greek ἐξαπλώνω, remodelled present stem from Ancient Greek ἐξαπλόω 'unfold, roll out' (uncompounded ἁπλόω 'make single, unfold, spread out').
S.v. SMG φεγγάρι, from Medieval Greek φεγγαρίον, diminutive in -αριον, derived from Ancient Greek φέγγος 'light, splendour, lustre'.
S.v. βουνό, from Medieval Greek βουνόν, from Ancient Greek βουνός 'hill, mound'.
S.v. SMG λαιμός, from Ancient Greek λαιμός.
S.v. χρόνος, from Ancient Greek χρόνος 'time'.
S.v. κίτριον 'citron tree (Citrus medica), citron'. Loanword from Lat. citrium.
S.v. ἄσπρος 'rough'. A loanword from Lat. asper.
S.v. νερό. From Medieval Greek νερό(ν) < Ancient Greek νηρόν, 'fresh', with meaning transferred from the collocation νῆρον ὕδωρ 'fresh water'.
S.v. περπατώ. From Medieval Greek περπατῶ, from Ancient Greek περιπατέω 'walk about'.
S.v. ξερνώ. From Ancient Greek ἐξερέω 'I speak out, utter' with semantic shift to 'spew out, vomit'. A suffix -νω has analogically replaced the original vowel-stem inflection.
S.v. 1. *h₁reh₁- 'fragen' (IEW 337). Greek ἐρέω would be from a zero-grade present stem *h₁r̥h₁-i̯é- and directly comparable to Hitt. ariyezzi 'untersucht (durch Wahrsagerei)'.

S.v. εἴρομαι 'to ask'. Beekes derives the Greek forms associated εἴρομαι, ἐρέω from PIE *h₁r(e)u- 'ask, enquire', but against this etymology cf. LIV² p.251 s.v. *h₁reh₁- 'fragen', n1, with references.
S.v. σκέπομαι, from Ancient Greek σκέπτομαι 'I look about carefully, examine'.
S.v. χοντρός, from Ancient Greek χονδρός 'granular, coarse'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *errā 'back, hinder-part, extremity', from PIE *h₁erso- 'rear-end, buttocks' (cf. Hitt. ārra- 'rump', Gk. ὄρρος 'backside', OE ears 'arse').
S.v. *h₂u̯er- 'hängen (intr.)' (IEW 1150). Only Greek and Albanian, cf. Alb. vjerr 'hängt auf' from a secondary e-grade thematic present.
S.v. SMG ομαλός, from Ancient Greek ὀμαλός.
S.v. στρογγυλός, from Ancient Greek στρογγύλος 'round, spherical'.

S.v. κόπτω 'to strike, smite, hew, hammer, disable, tire out'. May be Indo-European if cognate with Lithuanian kapiù 'hew, fell', Albanian kep 'hew'. Alternatively, the lexeme may be of substrate origin if related to σκάπτω (cf. notes in /cognate/202/).
Cf. s.v. 1. *(s)kep- 'hacken, hauen' (IEW 931-932). A Greek, Balto-Slavic and Albanian isogloss.
S.v. SMG κόβω, from Ancient Greek κόπτω, from which κοφτερός is a derived adjective from earlier κοπτ-ερός.
S.v. βλέπω, from Ancient Greek βλέπω.
S.v. Modern Greek μάτι, from Medieval Greek μάτι(ν), from Ancient Greek ὀμμάτιον, diminutive of Ancient Greek ὄμμα 'eye'.
S.v. πλάτη. The Modern Greek words derive from Ancient Greek πλάτη 'broad, flat object', (as pl. πλάται 'shoulder-blades', cf. LSJ).
Regarding the lack of -τ- in Italiot, πλάη < πλάτη (with intervocalic -t- deletion in Apulian, cf. Ap. στρα < στράτα ‘road’ etc.).
S.v. κόκκαλο, from Medieval κόκκαλον with change of gender from Ancient Greek κόκκαλος 'kernel'.
S.v. ψάρι, from Ancient Greek ὀψάριον. Diminutive of ὄψον 'cooked or prepared food', but esp. at Athens 'fish' (cf. LSJ s.v. ὄψον, meaning 1.3).
S.v. πράσινος, originally 'leek-green', cf. Ancient Greek πράσον 'leek', Modern Greek πράσο 'id.'.
S.v. μακρύς, from Ancient μακρός with the inflection remodelled on analogy to other terms describing weight, depth, etc. with υ-stem inflection, e.g. βαρύς 'heavy', etc.
S.v. ψείρα. Modern Greek varieties exhibit lexical contamination of initial consonant cluster. φθ- > ψ- from ψύλλα 'flea'.

S.v. μύσσομαι 'to blow one's nose, snort'. Ancient Greek μύσσομαι is a yod-present formation, and possible cognates are Gael. smùc, smug 'mucus', MIr. mocht 'weak' < *muk-to-, ONor. mjúkr, Latv. mukls 'marshy'. The word might also be of substrate origin.
S.v. μύτη. A noun backformed from Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)μύσσομαι 'blow (the nose)'.
S.v. δεν. Modern Greek forms come from Ancient Greek οὐδέν, analysed as οὐ- 'not' + δέ 'and' + ἕν 'one'. The part of the collocation originally meaning 'not' (οὐ) was lost by regular sound change.
S.v. cer, o-stem 'old man' from PIE *g̑erH- (cf. Skt. jar- 'to age, grow old', jarant- 'old', YAv. zar- 'id.', Oss. zærond 'old').
S.v. αέρας, from Medieval ἀέρας, ultimately from Ancient ἀήρ, gen. ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds; air atmosphere'.
Cf. s.v. Modern Greek λερώνω 'soil, stain, smear' (vb.), derived from Hellenistic Greek (ὀ)λερ(ός), from Attic Greek ὀλερός, an idiosyncratic dialectal form of θολερός, 'muddy, foul, turbid'.
S.v. AGk. ὀξύγγιον 'lard', borrowed from Lat. axungia.
S.v. κουβάλω, from Ancient Greek κοβαλεύω 'to carry as a porter'.
S.v. μιλώ, from Medieval Greek μιλῶ, from Ancient Greek ὁμιλέω 'be in company with, consort with, converse'.
S.v. δένω, from Ancient Greek δέω, morphologically remodelled as a nasal present δένω.
S.v. Ved. √dā-³ 'binden', from PIE *deh₁-.
S.v. ποταμός. Modern Greek ποτάμι is from Hellenistic Greek ποτάμιον, the diminutive of ποταμός.
S.v. μυρίζω, from Ancient Greek μυρίζω 'I salve, perfume'.

It is likely that there was some cross-contamination between loaned Semitic lexemes with Gk. μύρρα 'myrrh' and potentially inherited material attested by Gk. μύρον 'oil, perfume'. Consequently the Greek lexemes are not necessarily the best evidence for IE *smer- in this class.

S.v. πρήζω, from Ancient Greek πρήθω 'blow out, swell out by blowing'. The Modern Greek present stem πρήζω is backformed from the aorist stem ἔπρισα on analogy to verbs of the type present σκίζω : aorist  ἔσκισα.

S.v. πηγαίνω. Modern Greek present stem πηγαίνω backformed from aorist πήγα on basis of analogy έμαθα ~ μαθαίνω. Πήγα is from Medieval Greek *υπήγα, ultimately from Ancient Greek aorist ὑπῆγον, aorist of ὑπ-άγω 'lead, bring under'.
S.v. κοιλιά, from Ancient Greek κοιλία 'cavity of the body; thorax with abdomen'.
S.v. στάχτη, from the collocation σταχτή (κονία) 'distilled (ashes)', from the process of distilling ashes to produce lye.
S.v. τραυώ, from Medieval Greek τραυῶ from earlier τραυίζω < ταυρίζω (with metathesis). Ultimately derived from Ancient Greek ταῦρος 'bull' in the sense of 'pull (like a bull)'.

S.v. σπρώχνω, ultimately from Ancient Greek προ-ωθέω. (Initial *s- either from reanalysis with object pronoun τους, τις, etc., or additional prefix εἰσ- with procope of initial unstressed vowel.). The stem was remodelled as a nasal-present in -νω, after which a sound change -θn- > -xn- applied.
Greek: Italiot πώννω < MedG αμπώθω, αμπώνω < AG ἀπωθέω.
S.v. ałam 'to grind', connected with Greek ἀλέω 'to grind' < *h₂elh₁- 'grind'.
Points out that the stem formation of the Armenian forms can go back to either an n-infix present *h₂l̥-n-h₁- or a thematic root present *h₂alh₁-/*h₂l̥h₁-.
S.v. κολυμπώ, from Medieval Greek κολυμπῶ < Ancient Greek κολυμβάω 'dive into water'.
S.v. SMG χιόνι, from Hellenistic Greek χιόνιον, diminutive of Ancient Greek χιών 'snow'.
S.v. Arm. jiwn < PIE *g̑ʰ(é)i-ōm (cf. Gk. χιών 'snow', Av. ziiā̊ 'winter', Lat. hiems 'winter').
S.v. Ved. himá- 'Kälte, Frost' < PIE *g̑ʰi̯em-/*g̑ʰim- (cf. Av. ziiā̊ 'Winter').
S.v. SMG γέρος 'old', from Ancient Greek γέρων 'old man', with the inflection transferred into the ο-stem declension.
Cf. SMG άχαρος ᾽without grace, elegance, beauty' from Ancient Greek ἄχαρις, remodelled as an o-stem άχαρος.
S.v. φίδι, from Hellenistic ὀφίδιον, diminutive of Ancient Greek ὄφις 'snake'.
S.v. τραγουδώ, from Medieval Greek τραγουδῶ from Ancient Greek τραγῳδέω 'take part in a tragic drama; speak in tragic style, declaim'.

Cf. s.v. τραγῳδός 'singer and dancer in the tragic choir, tragic actor', from which τραγῳδ-έω 'to act as a τραγῳδός, treat in tragedy, to display or relate with tragic pathos' is derived. Further etymology uncertain, but traditionally derived from τράγος 'he-goat', which would have been given to the winner in the oldest dramatic contest.

Cf. s.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273). The Latin and Romance cognates may go back to this root, but one must accept an irregular dissimilation of the aspirates and devoicing of the initial consonant *dʰr- > *dr-, *tr- in order to account for Lat. trahere.

S.v. Lat. trahō, -ere 'to pull, drag, haul'. Etymologies outside of Italic are difficult. There are possible Celtic cognates (OIr. tethraig* 'ran away, receded' < PCl. *te-trāg-, OIr. tráig 'ebb, beach') which could be explained by a meaning 'pull away'. Formally possible are also Goth. þragjan 'to walk', OIr. traig W. troëd, Bret. troad 'foot', but these would require a non-IE root structure *T–Dʰ. A connection with Germanic *dragan is formally impossible.

S.v. Khot. ārr- 'to grind'. Base ar- 'to grind', pres. stem. *ar-na- > ārr-, cf. Av. -arəna- in yāv-arəna- 'tool for grinding'. To be connected with the root of Greek ἀλέω 'to grind', ἀλετών 'mill', ἄλεαρ 'flour', Armen. ałam 'to grind', aliur, aleur 'flour', alauri 'mill'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *HarH- 'to grind (grain)', from PIE *h₂elh₁- 'to grind'.
S.v. πέσκος 'skin, rind'. No clear etymology.
S.v. σπόρος, from Ancient Greek σπόρος 'sowing, seed-time; seed', cf. Ancient Greek σπείρω 'sow'.
S.v. σάπιος, derived from σαπίζω, a secondary present stem backformed from aorist ἐσάπην to Ancient Greek σήπομαι 'to rot'.
S.v. SMG βρέχω, with associated noun βροχή 'rain' from Hellenistic βροχή 'rain, inundation'.
S.v. καινούργιος 'new', from Hellenistic Greek καινουργός 'newly made', a compound of Ancient Greek καινός 'new, fresh' and ἔργον 'work'.
Cf. s.v. *ken- 'entspringen, beginnen' (IEW 563-4).
S.v. κοντά, an adverb derived from Ancient Greek κοντός 'short'.
Cf. s.v. *k̑ent- 'stechen' (IEW 567).
Cf. s.v. *k̑ent- 'stechen' (IEW 567).

Cf. s.v. Ved. púṣpa- 'Blume, Blüte' and puṣya- 'Blüte, Blume', both derivatives to Ved. √poṣ- (cf. s.v.) < Proto-Indo-Iranian *√pau̯š-. Further etymological connections for PIIr. *pau̯š- remain uncertain.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *blōman- 'flower', as if from PIE *bleh₃-mon-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *blātu- 'flower', which may be derived from either *bʰleh₃-tu- or *bʰlh₃-tu-, an abstract nominal derivative 'blossoming'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *květъ 'flower' < PIE k̑uoit-o- (cf. Proto-Slavic *kvisti 'bloom, blossom' from PIE *k̑weit-/*kuit-). NB: In Balto-Slavic, PIE *k̑ was depalatalized before *u̯ followed by a back vowel.
Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯ei̯t- 'hell aufleuchten' (IEW 628-629).
Cf. s.v. ?*h₂endʰ- 'blühen, sprießen' (IEW 40-1). Verbal only Greek, the nominal derivative ἄνθος is comparable to Ved. ándhas- 'soma plant'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *muxa 'fly', cf. also Proto-Slavic mъxa 'midge'. The root of the former etyma apparently shows an o-grade *mou̯s-, whereas the latter continues the zero-grade *mus- found more widely in other branches. Cf. entry s.v. *muxa for discussion of the possibilities on the origins of the alternative root vocalism.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷrimi- 'worm' < PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' (cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi-, Alb. krimb, Lith. kirmìs, Slovene črm).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kuli- 'mosquito, fly' < PIE *kul- (cf. Lat. culex 'gnat, midge'). The connection with Skt. śūla- 'spear' can only be from the same root if one assumes the short *u in Italic and Celtic is due to Dybo's Law.
Cf. s.v. Lat. culex 'gnat, midge' < PIE *k̑uH-ló- 'sharp', accepting the connection of Skt. śū́la- to these words.
For the older, pre-laryngeal theory etymology, cf. s.v. *k̑ū- 'spitz, Spieß'.

S.v. Arm. *tʻiṙ- 'to fly', derived from the same root as *tʻer 'leaf, etc.' < PIE *pter-, probably a derivative of PIE *pet- 'to fly' (cf. Gk. πτερόν 'feather', πτέρυξ 'wing of a bird', πέτομαι 'to fly', etc').

Cf. s.v. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschließend fliegen, stürzen, fallen', from PIE *pet- (cf. Gk. πέτομαι 'fliege', Lat. petō 'eile, begebe mich wohin' Old Welsh hedant 'volant', Hitt. pít-ti-i̯a-an-zi 'sie laufen', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *fet-o- 'fly', from PIE *pet- 'fly' (Middle Welsh ehedec < *exs-fet-o-).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √drā-¹ 'laufen, eilen' < PIE *dreh₂- (cf. Gk. ἀπο-διδρᾱ́σκω).
S.v. 1. *dreh₂- '(weg)laufen' (IEW 204).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √sthā- 'stehen, dastehen, still stehen, verweilen' < PIE *steh₂-.
Cf. s.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (IEW 1004-8).
S.v. *lei̯d- '(los)lassen' (IEW 666).
S.v. *tač-¹ 'to flow, run, walk', from PIE *tekʷ- 'to hurry, rush, walk, flow'.
S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-60).
Cf. s.v. *gʷelh₁- 'treffen, werfen' (IEW 471-2), without Italic cognates.
καμουλία < MedG καύμα, κάμα ‘excessive heat’.

Cf. S.v. καίω 'to kindle', med-pass. 'to burn' < PIE *keh₂u- 'burn',  to which καῦμα 'fire, heat, glow' is a derived noun. Attic καίω may be explained as a yod-present from *κάϝ-ι̯ω, ultimately from PIE *keh₂u̯-i̯e/o-. The Greek forms are possibly related to Baltic material in Lith. kū̃lės 'Brandpilze, Flugbrand, Staubbrand des Getreides', kūlė́ti 'brandig werden', Latv. kūla, 'old, dry, grass of last year'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *þuka/ōn- 'fog, mist', an exclusively Germanic word.
S.v. Ved. dhūmá- 'Rauch', from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- (cf. Lat. fūmus, Lith. dū́mai, etc.), derived from the PIE root *dʰu̯eh₂-/*dʰeu̯h₂-/*dʰuh₂- 'rauchen, qualmen, keuchen, erregt sein'.
Cf. s.v. *du̯eh₂- 'Rauch machen' (IEW 262-3).
Cf. s.v. Ved. nábhas- 'Feuchtigkeit, Wolke, Gewölk, Nebel', an s-stem noun from PIE *nebʰ- 'befeuchten'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *nebala- 'fog', an l-extension to PIE *nébʰ-os, gen. *mbʰ-és-os 'cloud, sky'.
S.v. Lat. nebula 'mist, fog', from PIE *nebʰ-e-lo- 'small cloud'.
S.v. 3386 *kuha- (2) 'fog, mist', kuhēḍī-, ˚ḍikā-, kuhēlikā- , kūhā- f. lex.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *widu- 'tree; firewood', from PIE uidʰ-u- (cf. OIr. fid 'tree; wood; forest', OW guid, MW gwyd 'trees'). A Celto-Germanic isogloss, but possibly also Lith. vidùs 'middle' if to be further analysed as from *h₁ui-dʰh₁-o- with an original meaning 'set apart, abandoned').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *lěsъ 'forest, woods', further etymologies outside of Slavic are not certain (cf. discussion in entry).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *walþu- 'field, uncultivated area, wood', from PIE *uólH-tu- (cf. OIr. folt W gwallt 'hair' < *uolH-to-, Lith. váltis 'panicle', OPruss. wolti 'id.', Ukr. volótь 'id.', SCr. vlȃt 'id.' < *uolH-tio-), derived to a PIE root *uelH-.
S.v. Ved. ván- 'Baum, Holz' (cf. Av. vanā- 'Baum', MPers. wan, Sogd. wn-, Pašto wana 'Baum', etc.). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranian is uncertain.
S.v. Ved. ván- 'Baum, Holz' (cf. Av. vanā- 'Baum', MPers. wan, Sogd. wn-, Pašto wana 'Baum', etc.). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranian is uncertain.
Loan from Middle Indic *ban < Proto-Indo-Iranian *u̯ána-
S.v. Ved. gadā- 'Keule', cf. YAv. gaδā- 'Wurfkeule' MPers. gad 'Keule', etc. Further etymology uncertain.

S.v. ξύλον 'wood, timber', seems to correspond with Lith. šùlas 'post, pole, stave' < IE *ksulo-, Ru. šúlo 'garden-pole', SCr. šȗlj 'block' < *kseulo- (?). Germanic words like OHG sūl 'style, pole, Goth. sauls 'pillar' have a similar appearance, although the relationship between the Slavic, Baltic, and Germanic words have hardly been explained (cf. Lehmann 1986 s.v. sauls). A European substrate term?
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hulta- 'grove', from PIE *kold-o- (cf. Gk. κλάδος 'branch, twig, sprout' < *kld-o-, OCS klada, Ru. kolóda, SCr. klȁda 'log' < *kold-eh₂-).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *lǫgъ 'depression'. "I have grouped together a number of etyma where the vacillation between *k and *g as well as between roots with and without a nasal could be interpreted within the context of a substratum origin. To a certain extent, influence of *lenk- 'bend' must be taken into consideration".
S.v. Lith. šálti 'freeze'. The Baltic forms reflect a root *k̑olH- which may have been of denominative origin.
S.v. Ved. √yam- 'halten, festhalten, zügeln, lenken, ausstrecken, darreichen'. Only Indo-Iranian, further connections remain uncertain.
Cf. s.v. ?*i̯em- 'ausstrecken, hinstrecken' (IEW 505). Only Indo-Iranian.

Cf. s.v. Arm. saṙn 'ice', cf. ON hjarn n. < *her(z)na- 'frozen snow', OHG hornung 'February', Russ. serën , serená 'crust over snow; frozen hard snow', Lith. šer̃kšnas m. < *k̂(e)r-sno- 'hoarfrost', adj. 'grey, whitish', šarmà < *k̂or-meh₂- 'frost', etc.

S.v. Arm. saṙn 'ice', cf. ON hjarn n. < *her(z)na- 'frozen snow', OHG hornung 'February', Russ. serën , serená 'crust over snow; frozen hard snow', Lith. šer̃kšnas m. < *k̂(e)r-sno- 'hoarfrost', adj. 'grey, whitish', šarmà < *k̂or-meh₂- 'frost', etc.
S.v. Ved. √śyā- 'gefrieren, gerinnen, erstarren', also found in Iranic (Oss. syjyn/sufun 'gefrieren', Yaghnōbī ši- 'frieren, gefrieren', etc.). Connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not certain.
Cf. s.v. Oss. īx | ex 'лед', from Proto-Iranian *aixa- (cf. Pers. yax, Kurd. yex, Yag. īx, Sogd. *yīx, Chores. ēx, Av. aexa-).
Proposes an etymology from *h₁e/om-o- 'what is to be taken', combined with a preverb *po- in Proto-Italic as *po-e/omo- 'taken off, picked'.
Cf. s.v. ?*bʰreu̯H⁽g̑⁾- 'genießen, gebrauchen' (IEW 173). Only Italic and Germanic (cf. Goth. brūkjan 'brauchen').
S.v. Arm. ptuł 'fruit', put (1) 'poppy', put (3) 'a small swelling' and ptuk 'to bud, germinate'. Traditionally connected with PIE *bud- 'to swell' according to {ref HAB} IV:112.
S.v. Lith. vaĩsius 'fruit' (cf. OIc. vísir 'bud, sprout'), from the same root as Lith. veĩsti 'to breed, rear' from PIE *u̯ei̯s- (cf. Lat. virēre 'be green, fresh').
Cf. s.v. 1. *u̯ei̯s- 'sprießen, gedeihen' (IEW 1133).
S.v. 9397 Skt. bhárati 'bears, brings, keeps' RV., 'fills' Pañcat. (bharita ʻnourished, full ʼ MBh.). [√bhr̥].
S.v. Ved. √bhar- 'tragen, hegen, pflegen; bringen' < PIE *bʰer- (cf. Gk. φέρω, Lat. ferō, Goth. bairan, etc.).
S.v. li 'full, abundant; perfect, whole'. Arm. li derives from either *pleh₁-(i)o- or *pleh₁-to- (cf. Gk. πλέος 'full', Skt. prātá- 'filled').
S.v. plotë 'full', from Proto-Albanian *plāta, identical with PIE *plēto- 'full' from *pelə- 'to fill' (cf. Skt. prātá-, Lat. com-plētus).
S.v. Ved. pūrṇá- 'voll, gefüllt' (cf. OAv., YAv. pərəna- 'voll, gefüllt' < PIE *pl̥h₁-nó-.
S.v. Lith. pìlnas 'full', from PIE *plh₁-nó- (cf. Skt. pūrṇá-, OIr. lán, Goth. fulls).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *pьlnъ 'full' < PIE *plh₁-nó- (cf. Skt. pūrṇá-, OIr. lán, Goth. fulls).
S.v. fulla- 1 'full', from PIE *plh₁-nó- (cf. Skt. pūrṇá-, Av. pərəna-, OIr. lán, Lith. pìlnas, OCS plъnъ 'filled, full').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *flāno- 'full', from PIE *plh₁no- 'full'.
S.v. Arm. *ta- / *tu- 'to give, bestow; to hand; to pay, etc.'. Arm. ta- and tu- respectively reflect PIE zero-grade *dh₃- and full-grade *deh₃-.
S.v. Ved. √dā-¹ 'geben, schenken, spenden' < PIE *deh₃-.
S.v. Lith. dúoti 'give' < PIE *deh₃- ; *didh₃- 'give'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dati 'give', from PIE *deh₃- / *didh₃- 'give'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *dā- 'give', from PIE *deh₃- 'give'. "Gaulish dede and Lepontic tetu might also be from PIE *dʰeh₁- rather than from *deh₃-, but this appears less probable."
S.v. ambulō, -āre 'to walk', from Proto-Italic *ala- 'to wander' < PIE *h₂elh₂- (cf. Gk. ἀλάομαι 'to wander, roam', Latv. aluôt 'to roam').
S.v. ambulō, -āre 'to walk', from Proto-Italic *ala- 'to wander' < PIE *h₂elh₂- (cf. Gk. ἀλάομαι 'to wander, roam', Latv. aluôt 'to roam').
S.v. *mesg- 'eintauchen (intr.), versinken' (IEW 745-6).
S.v. Lat. mergō, -ere 'to plunge, immerse', from Proto-Italic *mezge/o-, from PIE *mesg-e/o- 'to sink, wash' (cf. Skt. májjanti 'to sink, plunge under, Lith. mazgóti, Latv. mazgât 'to wash').
S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (IEW 1004-8). Cf. n3 Arm. er-tʻa 'gehen' < *per-steh₂- (cf. Klingenschmitt 1982:96, 104).
S.v. Arm. ertʻ(an)am 'to go; set off'. Usually linked with Gk. ἔρχομαι /cognate/5151/, usually linked to a root *h₁er-.
S.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4). Arm. forms probably go back to *u̯i-né/n-h₁-.

S.v. *faran- 'to go', from PIE *pór-e- (cf. Skt. pí-parti 'to bring across' < *pi-por-; OAv. (fra)-frā 1.sg.subj.aor. 'to cross' < pre-pr-e-, OCS pariti 'to fly' < *por-éie-; Gk. πείρω 'to pierce, to penetrate' < *per-ie-).
S.v. 1. *per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren' (IEW 816-7).
S.v. *stei̯gʰ- 'steigen, schreiten' (IEW 1017-8).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *tēg- 'go', from PIE *stei̯gʰ- (cf. Gk. στείχω, Goth. steigan).
S.v. *menH- 'treten, stampfen' (?) (IEW 726).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *mon-ī- 'go', from PIE *menH- 'tread, stamp on' (cf. Umbr. menes 'will come', Lith. mìnti 'tread on', CS męti 'tread, knead').
S.v. vadĕre 'gehen'. Fr. va < Lat. vādō, -ere.

S.v. Lat. vādō, -ere, 'to advance, proceed', from PIE *ueh₂dʰ- 'to advance' (cf. W. go-di-wawd 'overtook' < *ueh₂dʰ-, OHG watan, OFr. wada, OIc. vaða 'to wade' < *uh₂dʰ-, OIc. vað, OE væd 'water, lake', etc.).
S.v. *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'durchschreiten' (IEW 1109).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √cyav- 'in Bewegung geraten, sich bewegen, unternehmen', from PIE *ki̯eu̯-.
S.v. Ved. √yā-¹ 'fahren, dahinziehen, sich bewegen', from PIE *(H)i̯eh₂-.
S.v. 1. *i̯eh₂- 'dahinziehen, fahren' [IEW 296].
S.v. TochB i- 'go, travel', from PToch *i̯ä-, from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'go'.

S.v. Ved. √ay-¹ 'gehen, wandern, fahren, gelangen' (cf. OAv. āitī 'kommt heran', YAv. aēiti 'geht'), from PIE *h₁ei̯- (cf. Hitt. i-it 'geh!', Luw. i-ti 'geht', Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', OLith. eimì 'gehe', Lith. eĩti, OCS iti 'gehen', etc.).
S.v. Lith. eĩti 'go', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'go' (cf. OCS iti, Skt. éti, Gk. εἶμι, Lat. īre).
S.v. Lat. eō, īre 'to go', from Proto-Italic *ei-/*i- 'to go', from PIE *h₁ei̯-/*h₁i- 'to go'.
S.v. Ved. vásu- 'gut, herrlich, trefflich', cf. OAv., YAv. vohu-, from PIE *h₁u̯esu- (cf. Gk. ἐάων, 'der Güter', Luw., Pal. u̯ašu- 'gut', OIr. *feb 'Vortrefflichkeit, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dobrъ 'good', an adjective in *-ro- to *dʰabʰ- 'time' (cf. Proto-Slavic *doba 'time'). The semantic development appears to have been 'right time' → 'suitable, good'.
Cf. s.v. *dʰeHbʰ- 'passen' (IEW 233). Verbal only Germanic, cf. n1 for notes on nominal and adjectival derivatives.
S.v. Sw. bra 'good'. Loan from Low German brav, in turn from French brave, from Italian bravo.
S.v. 142 Skt. accha 1 'clear, transparent' Suśr. [Poss. ʻ shadowless ʼ cf. acchāyá- RV. Neither *r̥kṣa- (Mayrhofer EWA i 22) nor ā̆rca- (P. Tedesco JAOS 77, 197) are phonet. satisfactory. ]
S.v. 10636 Ved. ramyà- 'to be enjoyed, beautiful' ŚBr. [√ram]. (> N. rāmro 'beautiful, good').
S.v. Ved. √ram- 'zur Ruhe kommen, stillstehen, ausruhen, rasten', from PIE *h₁rem- (cf. Gk. ἠρέμα 'ruhig, sanft', Goth. rimis 'Ruhe', Lith. rãmas 'Ruhe', rìmti 'ruhig werden').
S.v. 7150 Skt. niktá- 'washed, purified' RV. [√nij]. (> Mth. nĭ̄k 'good').
S.v. Ved. √nej- 'waschen, reinigen', from PIE *nei̯gʷ-.
S.v. Alb. mirë 'good', from Proto-Albanian *mira-. Further IE connections are possible but debated.
S.v. 7366 Skt. nirmala 'spotless, clean' Up. [mála-]
S.v. Ved. mála- 'Schmutz, Unreinlichkeit, Unrat, Dreck'. Probably to be derived from PIE *mélo-, cf. Gk μέλας 'black', Lith. mė́las 'blue', mel̃svas 'blueish'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. cupiō, -ere 'to desire', from PIE *kup-(e)i-, *kup-eh₁- 'to tremble, desire', to which the Umbrian and South Picene forms might be related.
S.v. Lith. gẽras 'good', a derivative of gìrti 'praise', from PIE *gʷrH- (cf. Skt. gr̥nā́ti 'greet, praise').
Cf. s.v. *gʷerH- 'Zustimmung bekunden' (IEW 478).
S.v. 4564  Skt. caṅga- 'of good understanding' Kathās., 'handsome' lex.
S.v. caṅga 'hübsch' / 'handsome'. Origin uncertain, perhaps a Dravidian loanword.
S.v. 10755 Skt. *rukta ʻ bright, liked ʼ. [√ruc]. (> K. r˚tu, f. rüċü 'good, excellent, beautiful, sweet')
Cf. s.v. Ved. √roc- 'leuchten, scheinen, glänzen', from PIE *leu̯k- 'leuchten' (cf. Gk. λευκός 'light, white', etc.).
S.v. *śudhya ʻto be made pureʼ [√śudh].
S.v. Ved. √śodh- 'reinigen, rein machen' (cf. YAv. suδu-, prob. 'sieve'), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ-, perhaps from PIE *(s)k̑eu̯-dʰ-.
S.v. ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'rein werden' (IEW 595). Root mechanically reconstructed for PIE; there are no cognates outside of Indo-Iranian.
S.v. Khot. śśära- 'good'
S.v. 11384 Skt. vardhita 'increased, strengthened, gladdened' MBh. [√vr̥dh].

Cf. the cited page range for Proto-Slavic *morvь and various related forms. The archaic Proto-Slavic form *morvь (directly reflecting PIE *moru̯i-) was preserved in some dialects only. In the most Slavic languages and dialects there are various derivatives transferring the lexeme to *-a- and *-o- stem classes.

S.v. Ved. √vardh- 'wachsen lassen, mehren (Akt.), wachsen, groß werden (Med.)'. Connections outside of Indo-Iranian remain difficult. Sandhi evidence argues for a laryngeal in initial position, for Proto-Indo-Iranian.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *HraH- 'to offer, give' (cf. Av. rā̆- 'offer, give', Skt. rā- 'give, grant, bestow'), from PIE *Hreh₁- 'to give'.
S.v. 1. *reh₁- 'geben, schenken' (IEW 860).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *zelьje 'greens, herbs', a derivative of *zel- from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *trāva 'grass', *trěva 'grass', *truti 'to feed', and *tryti 'rub', all ultimately derivatives from PIE *truH- 'use' (cf. Gk. τρύω 'use up').
Cf. s.v. *treu̯H- 'aufreiben, verbrauchen' (IEW 1072-3).

S.v. herba 'small plant, weed'. The earlier connection with Lat. grāmen supposed by IEW (p.454) via a dental-extended root is formally impossible if Lat. grāmen is now to be accounted for via *g̑ʰrh₁- (cf. s.v. grāmen). No further etymology.
S.v. herba 'herbe'. No known cognates, without doubt a survival of a pre-Latin rural word.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *wegro- 'grass'. There are competing IE etymologies. Matasović favours a connection with PIE *h₂eu̯g- / *h₂u̯eg- 'grow' (cf. Lat. augeō, Goth. aukan 'increase') if one allows a Schwebeablaut. Alternatively Lubotsky [cited as 'p.c.' in the entry] suggests a connection with Lat. uegeō 'enliven', OHG wahhēn 'to be awake' < PIE *u̯eg̑- 'be lively' (IEW 1117-8, LIV 601) which is formally better, but would involve a more complex semantic development.

Cf. s.v. Ved. yáva- 'Getreide, Korn, Feldfrucht, Gerste', from PIE *i̯éu̯o- (cf. Hitt. eu̯a- [e-u̯a-an, e-u-u̯a-an] 'eine Feldfrucht, wohl Gerste', Lith. jãvas 'Getreidepflanze', Gk. ζειαί (f.pl.) 'Spelt, Dinkel'). For the forms in this class, cf. specifically the derived form Ved. yávasa- 'Weide, Futter, Wiese, dem Weiden des Viehs dienendes Gras', Av. yauuaŋha- 'Weide'.

S.v. Ved. tŕ̥na- 'Gras, Grashalm, Kraut', from PIE *tr̥-no-, (cf. OHG dorn, thorn, OCS trъnъ 'ἄκανθα', etc.). Perhaps derived from PIE *ster- 'starr sein' (cf. Gk. στερεός 'steif, hart'), but this root connection is not entirely clear.
Related to PS *zelen- 'green' and *zolt- 'gold', and further to Lithuanian žìlas, Latvian zils 'blue' and Greek χολή 'gall' or to Old High German kolo 'coal' and Old Indic jválati 'it burns'.
Related to Old High German kolo 'coal', Old Indic jválati 'it burns', Greek γελει̃ν 'light, shine'.
Related to Polish zielony 'green'.
S.v. bar 'grass', from Proto-Albanian *bara, etymologically related to Lat. far 'sort of grain, spelt' < *bhars-, ON barr 'spelt', etc.
Related to Greek χολή 'gall' and Avestan zāra. Reflex of PIE *g̑ʰelH- 'light, yellow, green, gray, blue'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *bariz- ~ *barza- 'barley' < *bʰar-es-.
Related to PS *zelen- 'green' and *zolt- 'gold'. Reflex of PIE *g̑ʰel- : g̑ʰol-.
Reflex of PIE *g̑ʰel- and related to Lithuanian žìlas 'grey', Latvian zils 'blue'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. far, -rris 'husked wheat, emmer; grain, flour' < *bʰars-, possibly an early European loanword into PIE.
Loanword, borrowed from German Sole 'salt water'.
There are two standard etymologies, one pointing to PIE *g̑u̯elH- and another pointing to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-.
S.v. Khot. ggīsai 'grass', from base gai-s- 'to twist' in Av. gaēsa- 'hair', cf. also base gai-p- 'to twist'.

Cf. s.v. *gaip/b- 'to spin (thread)'. Bailey's proposed connection of Khot. ggīsai 'grass' to a simplex base *gai- with a different "increment" is unclear. Bailey's base form *gai- cannot be related to any known IE root. More likely, we are dealing with borrowings from a non-IE substrate language.
Cf. s.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' [IEW 941-2].
PS *popel- and *pepel-. Reflex of PIE *pel- 'burn' with a reduplication.
S.v. 4755 Skt. cāra- (2) m. 'motion, course' ChUp. 2. '*grazing, *fodder'. [~ cāla- 2. √car].
Cf. s.v. Ved. √car-ⁱ 'sich bewegen, wandeln, gehen, wandern, fahren', from PIE *kʷel(H)- (cf. Gk. πέλομαι, Lat. colō, etc.).
Related to Old Prussian pelanne, Lithuanian pelenaĩ, Latvian pę́lni 'ash' and probably to Latin pollen 'fine flour', pulvis 'dust', Greek πάλη 'dust, fine flour'. Reduplication of the root.
PS *po-pel- is a compound of the prefix *po- and root *pel- with a meaning 'substance that remains after burning'.
S.v. Lith. žãlias 'green', from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-i- (cf. Skt. hári- 'fallow, yellowish, greenish').
Two possible etymologies are *po-pel- 'subtance that remains after burning' and a relation to Latin pollen 'dust, flour', Greek πάλη and Old Indic pálala- 'poridge, dust, dirt'.
Most probably *pel- 'burn' with a reduplication.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *mlěti 'grind, mill', from PIE *melH- (cf. Skt. mr̥nā́ti 'crush, grind', Hitt. malla- 'grind', Lat. molere 'grind', Goth. malan 'grind', OIr. meilid 'grind', Arm. malem 'crush').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *malan- 'to grind', from PIE *mólh₁-e- (cf. Hitt. mallai- ~ mallanzi 'to grind' < *mólh₁-ei, *mlh₁-énti; Lat. molō, -ere 'id.', Arm. malem 'to crush', Lith. málti (malù), Latv. mal̃t 'to grind' < *mólh₁-ei; OCS mlěti 'id.', Ru. molót' (meljú), SCr. mljȅti 'id.', OIr. meilid 'id.' < *melh₁-ie-; Skt. mr̥ṇā́ti 'crush, grind' < *ml-néh₁-).
S.v. Lat. molō, -ere 'to grind in a mill', from PIE *melh₂-/*mlh₂- 'to crush, grind'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *mal-o-, *mel-o- 'grind', from PIE *melh₂- 'grind'. OIr. meilid preserves the full grade of the root via *melh₂-o-, whereas the Brittonic forms can be derived from zero-grade *mlh₂-o- > *malH-o- > Proto-Celtic *mal-o-.
S.v. *pei̯s- 'zerstampfen, (zer)stoßen' (IEW 796).
Root ref. form reconstructed only for Proto-Germanic level as further connections are uncertain.
Cf. s.v. Skt. śā- 'schärfen, wetzen', from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- (cf. Arm. sowr 'sharp', Lat. cōs, cōt- 'Wetzstein', catus 'scharf, scharfsinnig', etc.
Cf. s.v. *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'schärfen' (IEW 541-2).
Cf. s.v. *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'schärfen' (IEW 541-2).
A reduplicated root *pelH- 'dust, flour', found also in Latin pollen, pulvis Old Indic pálala- Greek πάλη, παιπάλη, and in PS *pelv- 'chaff'. A relation to *pel- 'burn' is less probable.
Reduplicated root *pel- 'burn'.

Reduplication of *pel- 'burn', related to Old Indic palalam 'a kind of poridge', Old Prussian pelanne 'ash', Lithuanian pelenaĩ 'ash', Latvian pélni 'ash', Old Greek πάλη 'dust', παιπάλη 'fine flour', παλύνο 'strew', Latin pollen 'fine flour', pulvis 'dust', and palea 'chaff'.
The etymology is not entirely clear. Most probably a reflex of PIE *pel- 'burn' and related to reduplicated Slavic form *popel-.
Reduplication of *pel- 'dust, flour' or *pel- 'burn'. The first variant is more probable.

There are two hypotheses of the etymology of the Slavic *popel-, *pepel-. The first one assumes here a root ?*pel- 'burn' which has, however, very sparse - if any certain - attestation beyond Slavic (cf. LIV: 469). The second one assumes a relationship to various IE lexemes with meanings 'dust', '(fine) flour', 'chaff', 'poridge', etc. (*pelh₁- and/or *(s)pelH-). However, some of these lexemes are not necessarily related to each other (de Vaan 2008:  440, 477, 498). Some of the cited Slavic sources acknowledge two independent PIE roots in this case, while some other only one root with a strong semantic differentiation. From the semantic point of view the assumption of a separate root ?*pel- 'burn' and assigning the Slavic word for 'ash' to this root seems to be most resonable.
PS *pleťe < *plet-jo 'shoudler, upper back' < PIE *plet- 'wide, flat'.
PS *pleťe derived from PIE *pletH-.

Taking Russian forms like podoplëka, beloplëkij into account, it can be reconstructed as  PS *plektjo which is then related to Greek πλάξ, πλακός, Old Icelandic flá and Latin placidus. If the mentioned Russian forms with -k- are secondary, it is a reflex of PS *pletjo, related to Irish leithe 'shoulder blade', Greek πλατύς 'wide' and Lithuanian platùs 'wide'.
Reflex of IE *plet-, related to Lithuanian plesti 'extend' and platùs 'wide', Middle Irish leithe 'shoulder', and Greek πλατύς 'wide'. The Russian word podoplëka is derived from PIE *plek-.

Most probably a reflex of PS *pletje derived from PIE *plet-jo. In the reconstruction proposed by Vasmer (*plektjo) is -t- hard to explain. Maybe there were two parallel forms with two different roots *plet-je and *plek-je which are attested in simmilar meanings also in Baltic.

The Slavic lexemes are derived from PIE *pleth₂-. The original meaning of PS *pleťe was most probably 'shoulder'. Note that all Slavic languages using derivatives of this root in the meaning 'back' use the old dual form here ('two shoulders'). All stages of semantic development ('shoulder(s)', 'upper back', 'back') are attested in Slavic.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *garnō- 'intestines', from PIE *g̑ʰór-n-eh₂- (cf. Lith. žarnà 'intestine'; Lat. hernia 'hernia' < *g̑ʰer-n-ieh₂-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *þarma- 'bowel, intestine'. Possibly from PIE *torm-o- if related to Gk. τράμις 'space between the anus and genitals, perineum' < *trm-i-; no further etymology.
S.v. Lat. botellus *'darm'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. botulus 'boudin', from which Lat. botellus is a derivative. A word of non-Roman origin, possibly a borrowing from Oscan / Sabellic as a culinary term.
S.v. Lat. vīscus 'fleshy parts; entrails'. No clear etymology.
S.v. *bhuṇḍa (2) ʻbellyʼ.
S.v. rrūta- 'intestines', from *rauta- (cf. Av. uruθβan-, N.Pers. rōdah, Oss. D. rod, I. rud. Balōčī rōθ, etc.).
S.v. ənder-kʻ (pl.tant.) 'entrails, intestines, bowels', from PIE *h₁enter-h₂ (cf. Gk. ἔντερα 'intestines, bowels', Russ. ятро 'entrails, eggs, testicles', Skt. ántara- 'interior', etc.).

S.v. Arm. ałi(-kʻ) 'string of musical instruments', modern dialects as a frozen plural 'intestine'. No accepted etymology. Martirosyan proposes possibly a connection with Slavic *jelito 'Weichen, Darm, Hoden', cf. Pol. jelito 'Darm', dial. 'Wurst'.

S.v. Ved. āntrá- 'Eingeweide', a derivative of Ved. antár- 'inside'. Cf. ántara- 'innerer, im Inneren befindlich, dazwischen stehend, etc.' which is formally cognate with Gk. ἔντερα (cf. YAv. aṇtara- 'innerer').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ǭtroba 'entrails', from PIE *h₁on-tro- (cf. Skt. āntrá- 'intestine', Gk. ἔντερα 'entrails').
The root *xrĭb- along with variants *xrib-, *skrĭb-, *skrib- are related to verb *skrebti 'scratch'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *inþera- 'entrails', from PIE *h₁en-tero- (cf. Gk. ἔντερα < *h₁en-ter-h₂-).
S.v. intestīnus 'internal, civic, domestic', from which intestīnum 'intestines, guts' is a derivative. From Proto-Italic *n̥ter-sto- 'internal'. The provenance of the suffix *-sto- is debated.
Reflex of PIE *(s)gerb- 'crimple, squeeze' and/or PIE *(s)kerb- 'sharp, cutting'.
There is no clear etymology.
It is a reflex of PIE *skerbʰ-, *skorbʰ-, *skrbʰ- with a semantic development parallel to Latin spīna.
Reflex of PIE *(s)ker- 'bend' with -b- extention.
There are no clear IE parallels.
There is no clear etymology.
The Slavic lexemes are derivative(s) from *xrĭb- and *xrib- which had also variants *xrip- and *skrip-. The variant whith *sk- is probably the original one. However, there is no certain etymology.

This cognate class is not related to cognate/1196/, in spite of the superficial similarity. However, it is possible that irregular changes of the initial consonant in Polish, Polabian and Czech in cognate/1196/ etc. are due to a contamination of these two etymona. The irregularities can be explained also phonetically, though.
There is no cetrain PIE etymology.

Probably an expressive formation without any reliable IE cognates. Some existing hypotheses (linking this lexeme to Irish gerbach 'puckered' or Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle') are problematic phonetically and semantically. The Old Prussian garbis 'mountian' is most probably a loanword from Polish.

Related to Old Prussian grabis (garbis) 'mountian', Middle Irish gerbach 'puckered' or Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle'. This is probably a reflex of PIE *ger- with an extention (*ger-b-) 'bend, skew, bundle'.
It is sometimes linked to Old Prussian garbis 'mountian', Irish gerbach 'puckered' or Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle' that are reflexes of PIE *ger-b- 'bend'.
Most of authors assume here a reflex of PIE *ger 'bend, skew'.

Related to Old Prussian garbis 'mountian', Lithuanian gárbana 'curl', Old Irish gerbach 'puckered', Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle', Armenian karth 'hook, angle' which all go back to PIE *ger(H)-b- 'bend, skew'.
Reflex of PIE *ger- 'bend'. IE cognates are Old Prussian garbiš 'hill', Lithuanian gárbana 'curl', Irish gerbach 'puckered', Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle', and Armenian karth 'hook, angle'.
An expressive PS word without reliable IE cognates.
Related to Old Prussian garbis 'mountian' and Lithuanian gárbana 'curl'.
Related to Old Prussian garbis 'hill', Lithuanian gárbana,  gárbina 'curl', Irish gerbach 'puckered', Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle', and Armenian kart' 'hook, angle'.
Lithuanian gárbana / garbanà 'curl' (along with gur̃bti 'grow well') does not have any certain IE cognates. A possible one is PS *gŭrb-.
The word spina was borrowed from Latin into Polish and then from Polish into Russian.
There is no reason to assume that the Russian word was borrowed from Polish. According to Pokorny, it is a cognate of Latin spīna etc.
The Russian word was borrowed from Latin.
The etymology is unclear. It is either a borrowing from Latin or a cognate of Latin spina along with Latvian spina 'stick' and Old High German spinula 'pin'.

There is no certain etymology. It is either a borrowing from Latin (via Polish) or a cognate of Latin spīna along with Latvian spina 'stick', Old High German spinula 'pin', and Tocharian A spin- 'hook'.
The word is assumed to be a loan from Polish spina < Latin spīna.
There is no certainty which of the alternative etymologies is correct.
It is a reflex of PIE *lendhu̯- and a cognate of Latin lumbus, Old High German lenti, German Lende, Old Icelandic lend etc.
It is a reflex of PIE *lendʰ- and a cognate of Latin lumbus, Old High German lenti and Old Icelandic lend.

The word is a compund of the preposition *za 'behind' and a derivative from PIE *dhe- 'put' with a original meaning 'thing that is put in the back' (the forms are nad 'over', pod 'under', and před 'in front of' have the same structure).
Polish zad 'rump' < PS *zadŭ is a compound of *za- and *-dŭ (as nad 'over', pod 'under', and przed 'in front of') with a original meaning 'back part of something, something that is behind'.
The PS lexeme *nadŭ 'over' is a compound of *na 'on' with *-dŭ. The postpositive element *-dŭ is most probably related to the verbal root *dě-.

PS *zadŭ (*za-dŭ) has the same structure as *nadŭ (*na-dŭ), *podŭ (*po-dŭ), *perdŭ (*per-dŭ), and *pozdŭ (*pos-dŭ). The element *-dŭ can be an old adjective suffix or a reflex of *dheH 'put'. The hypothesis linking it to Avestan zaδah- 'buttock', Old Indic hadati 'he shits', χέζω 'shit' etc. (PIE *g̑ʰed- 'shit') is less plausible.

Russian 'zad' is usually linked to Avestan zadah- 'ass', Greek χέζω 'shit', Armenian jet 'tai', Old Indic hádati 'he shits', Low German gead 'ass', Irish gead 'back side' etc. However, it can be also interpreted as *za-dŭ.

The interpretation of *zadŭ as *za-dŭ with *za derived from the PIE pronominal root *g̑ʰe- and PIE verbal root *dʰeh₁- 'put, make' with a meaning 'something that is placed behind' seems to be most reasonable.
Cf. s.v. Gk. ὦμος 'shoulder, upper part of the arm'; the forms in most IE branches point back to *h₃ems-o-.

Related to Lithuanian atžū́las, atžūlùs 'harsh, inhuman', įžūlùs 'intrusive', Avestan zūrah- 'unjustice', Persian zūr 'lie', further to Lithuanian žvalus 'sneaky', žvilavo 'he was bending down', Latvian zvel̂t, zveļu, zvēlu 'turn, bend', Old Indic hvárati, hválati 'he goes on croocked ways, goes making loops, he stumbles', Avestan zbaraiti 'he goes on croocked ways, goes making loops, he stumbles', Ossetian æwzær 'bad'.

Lithuanian įžulnùs 'oblique', Latvian 'roll, wallow, flip over, tip' etc. are related to Slavic *zŭl- 'bad'. The underlying PIE root is *g̑ʰu̯el- / *g̑ʰul- whithout further IE cognates beyond Balto-Slavic.
Cf. s.v. Oss. rdū | ærdo 'волос, волосинка, шерстинка', from Proto-Iranian *drau̯- with metathesis of dr → rd.

It is a reflex of IE PIE *g̑ʰu̯el- (*g̑ʰŭlo-). The closest cognate is Lithuanian -žūlus (in atžūlùs 'sharp, unmerciful' and įžūlùs 'arrogant, intrusive'). More distant IE cognates are Old Indic hvárate 'diverge from the correct road' and Latin fallō fallere 'bring to downfall, trick, outfox'.
S.v. Khot. dro 'hair', from *dravu- (cf. Yaghn. dirau, BSogd. ẓ̌wy, Oss. D. ārdo, I. ärdu, Orm. drī, Nūristānī Aškun dro).

Sometimes connected in older literature (cf. IEW 276) to Gk. θρίξ, τριχός via root IE *dʰreu̯- with alternative root extensions *dʰr-ei̯-gʰ-, *dʰr-ei̯-kʰ-, however these theories of root morphology are now outdated and we can only securely postulate an Indo-Iranian etymon.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *tagla- 'hair'. Possible comparisons outside of Germanic (cf. Skt. daśā 'fringe' < *dek̑-eh₂-, OIr. dúal 'tuft, plait' < *dok̑-lo-(?) and SCr. dlàka 'single hair' < *dok̑-leh₂- (with depalatalisation and metathesis), but it may also be an inner-Germanic derivation as a diminutive *dHk-ló- to the root of *tahjan- 'tear, unravel', or to *tōgan- ~ *takkan- 'prickle, branch'.
S.v. Skt. kapā́la- 'skull, cranium' AV., ʻcup, jar, bowlʼ.

Cf. s.v. OLith. plùnksma 'Feder, Federkiel. Schreibfeder'. Possibly related to Lat. plūma, which might continue earlier *plūksma or *plouksma. The origins of the nasal in plunk- in Lithuanian is obscure. Cf. /cognate/2263/.
S.v. Alb. flok (pl. flokë) 'hair', borrowed from Lat. floccus 'lock, flock'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *kosa 'hair, braided hair', an o-grade derivative of the root *kes- 'comb, scratch'. Cf. Proto-Slavic *česati 'scratch, comb' < *kes- (cf. Hitt. kiszi 'combs', OIr. cír 'comb', OEng. heord 'hair').
Cf. s.v. *kes- 'ordnen' (IEW 585).
S.v. Ved. kapā́la- 'Schale, Schüssel, Hirnschale, Schädel'. No widely accepted etymology.
S.v. 4883 Skt. cūḍā- 3 'protuberance on brick; topknot on head'. (> B. cul 'hair of head, curl'.)
Cf. s.v. *kseu̯- 'schaben, schleifen' (IEW 586). Verbal only Gk. ξύω, cf. *ksu-ró- *'Schaber' → 'Rasiermesser' in Ved. kṣurá-, Gk. ξυρόν 'razor'.
S.v. Lat. pilus, -ī 'poil, cheveu', no certain connections. There is no common Indo-European word for this concept.
S.v. 11549 Ved. vā́ra- 4 'sheep's wool (as sieve)' RV & Skt. vā́la- 'hair of tail,  tail, hair'.
S.v. Ved. vā́ra-¹ 'Schweifhaare, Pferdeschweif'. The -r- ~ -l- alternation within Indic points to a probable non-Indo-European origin.
S.v. Ved. válśa- 'Schößling, Trieb, Zweig', cf. YAv. varəsa- 'Haar', Sogd. wrs, MPers. wars, NP gurs. From PIE *u̯olk̑o- (cf. OCS vlastъ, Russ. vólos, etc. 'Haar').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *wolto-, perhaps to be connected with OCS vlatъ, OE weald 'wood' if from PIE *u̯olt- (cf. IEW 1138-1139).

Connected by {ref Matasović 2009}:427-428 to Slavic and Germanic words for 'wood' (cf. /cognate/3130/) following {ref IEW} 1138-9, but since this explanation this on postulating different root-extensions to a base root *u̯el-, *u̯elə- in {ref IEW} this remains somewhat tenuous.
S.v. Khot. sakṣa 'hair', from Proto-Iranian *safša- (cf. Wakhi ṣ̌afṣ̌ 'hair', NPers. šafš 'thin branch').
Cf. s.v. Lat. palma 'front part of the hand', from PIE *plh₂-em-h₂- 'flat, wide' (cf. OIr. lám, W. llaw, Gk. παλάμη 'palm of the hand', OHG folma 'hand', OEng folm 'flat hand').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand', as though from *k̑ont-ú-, a u-stem derived from the strong verb hinϸan- 'to reach for' (< *⁽k̑⁾ént-e-). [Not in LIV².]

The PS *zŭl- is related to Lithuanian atžū́las, atžū́lus, įžulùs etc. The PIE root is *g̑ʰu̯el-. Ossetian zul, zol, zylyn, zolun 'crooked' is likely to be related. Older authors assume a relationship to Old Indic hvárate 'to walk on croocked path', hválati 'stumble on', Avestan zbarəmna 'walking crookedly' and/or to Latin fallere 'cheat'. However, these words are linked to *g̑ʰu̯er- and *(s)gʷHel- roots, respectively.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. manii̯aḫḫ- 'to distribute; to entrust' < PIE *mn-ieh₂- (cf. Lat. manus 'hand', ON mund, OE mund, OHG munt 'hand', OIr. muin 'patronage, protection').

The abstracted IE root common to these forms would be *men-, to conventionally cite it in the full grade. This however would be a homophonous root separate from the roots 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' (IEW 726-8), 2. *men- 'bleiben, warten' (IEW 729), or 3. ?*men- 'emporragen' (IEW 726) reconstructed by the LIV² (435-437).

S.v. TochB ṣar 'hand'. TochA tsar and TochB ṣar do not regularly go back to a single Proto-Tocharian preform, but they are normally understood to both go back to PIE *g̑ʰesr- 'hand' via different accent/ablaut stems. Cf. entry for further discussion and references to literature.
S.v. dorë 'hand', a singularised neut. plural from Proto-Albanian *dārā from PIE *g̑ʰesr- 'hand'.
S.v. *jeṙ-, from PIE *g̑ʰes-r- 'hand'. The Armenian singulative jeṙn derives from the PIE acc. *g̑ʰés-r-m̥.

S.v. Ved. hásta- 'Hand, Oberarm'. Indo-Iranian uniquely attests a *-to-
 suffix reflecting PIE *g̑ʰés-to- (cf. OAv., YAv. zasta- 'Hand', OPers. dasta- 'Hand', Khot. dasta-, Sogd., Khwarez. δst, Parth. dst, MPers, NPers. dast, Pashto lās, Shughni δust 'Hand', etc.).
S.v. Alb. fortë 'strong'. Loan from Lat. fortis 'strong'.
S.v. Ved. sthirá- 'fest, stark, haltbar, hart', probably to be derived from Ved. √sthā- < *steh₂-.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kaleto- 'hard, cruel, strong', from PIE *k̑lH-eto- 'cold', cf. Av. sarəta- 'cold', Lith. šálti 'be cold, freeze', OE haeled 'hero'. If this etymology is correct then the semantic development would have been 'cold, frozen' > 'hard'.
Cf. s.v. *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren' (IEW 551).
Cf. s.v. *(s)kerbʰ- 'scharf sein' (IEW 943-4); cf. n1 with variant *b in Gmc. *skerpa- 'rauh, scharf'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *skarpa- ‘sharp’, an o-grade adjective derived to Proto-Germanic *skerban- ~ *skerpan- ~ *skrepan- 'to scrape, scratch', a strong verb based on the IE root *skrebʰ- (cf. Russ. skrestí, Latv. šķir̃ba 'fissure', Lith. skir̃bti 'to become sour', Lat. scrobis 'hole in the ground, pit').
Cf. s.v. *(s)kerbʰ- 'scharf sein' (IEW 943-4).
PS *zŭl- is a reflex of PIE *g̑ʰul-, *g̑ʰu̯el-, *g̑ʰu̯ol- 'bend'. It has cognates in the Baltic and Indo-Iranian languages.

S.v. TochB ścīre 'hard; harsh (of words), rough, crude', from PToch *scärēn-, (as if) from PIE *sterh₁-eh₁-en-, cf. Gk στερεός 'solid, firm, strong', ONor. starr 'stiff, rigid, solid' OHG starēn 'stare (at)', OPruss. stūrnawiskan 'earnestness', Russ. starátьsja 'exert oneself, strive', etc.
Cf. s.v. ξερός (AGk. ξηρός 'trocken').

PIE *g̑hulo-, derived from *g̑u̯hel-. It is closest related to Lithuanian -žūlùs in atžūlùs and įžūlùs, further to Latvian zvelt 'hit', Latin fallere 'lie, cheat', Greek φῆλος 'deceitful', Avestan zūrah- 'unjustice', and Old Indic hvárate, hválati 'goes crookedly, diverges from the correct road'.

Derksen gives as cognates only Lithuanian atžū́lus, atžūlùs 'rude' and only cautiously pažvìlti ‘bend, stoop’. He only points that the Balto-Slavic root (*źulʔ-) has been connected with Skt. hvárate ‘go crookedly’.

The relation to Baltic forms as -žūl(n)ùs and the reconstruction of the PIE root *g̑ʰu̯el- is convincing. The further cognacy is uncertain. Some previous authors give here hypothetical cognates that are currently assumed not to be related to each other and/or that can not be (direct) sources of PS *zŭl- (reflexes of *g̑ʰu̯er- like Old Indic hvárate and hválati and of *(s)gʷʰh₂el- like Latin fallō, fallere). However, a reconstruction of *g̑ʰu̯el- instead of *g̑ʰu̯er- for Old Indic hvárate etc. is possible cf. (LIV: 182). Then the Slavic word would have Indo-Iranic cognates.

It is assumed that PS *loš- is a cognate of Gothic lasiws 'weak', Old English leswe 'weak, bad', Old High German er-leswen 'weaken', Old Icelandic lasenn 'weak, destroyed', and Tocharian A lyäṣk- 'soft'. However, this assumption is not convincing semantically.
*loš- is also unlikely to be a cognate of Irish losc 'lame' and Greek λοξός 'crooked'.
In the light of (dialectal) Serbo-Croat ļȍhav 'weak, sickly', lohotan 'ulgy', and Russian loh 'lazy-bones, fool', *lošĭ is to be interpreted as *lox-jo-. Its further IE cognacy is unclear. It was possibly used in magic or sacral meanings which could make its structure and cognacy relationships obscure.
Slavic lošĭ is a cognate of Gothic lasiws 'weak', along with Tocharian A lyäṣk- and Latin sublestus 'weak'. The PIE root is *ləs- an extended form of *lēy.
Russian lošij is assumed to be related to Gothic lasiws and Lower German las 'weak'. Further, a comparison with Greek λοξός 'crooked' and Irish losc 'lame' (*loskos) is also thinkable.
Related to Gothic lasiws 'weak', Old Islandic lasinn 'weak, destroyed', Old High German er-leswen 'weaken', Old Low German las 'tired', and Tocharian ljäsk- 'softness'.
Further connections of λοξόσ are not very clear.

There are no semantic obstacles to accept the traditional view, linking the Slavic lexeme to the Germanic ones, even if Old English lyso 'bad, wrong, evil' does not belong here (Derksen 2008: 286), cf. Slovenian slab 'bad' < 'weak'.
The Slavic forms with -x- are very likely to be expressive, in particular Russian loh (a derivation like in Polish brach < brat 'brother' or piach < piasek 'sand' is thinkable; note that the morphonological alternation š/x is very common in the Slavic languages, so an analogy is also possible). In any case, -x- can not be original in this phonological context.
The reconstuction PS *los-jo- (ultimately PIE *leh₁-?, cf. (Lehmann 1986: 227, 232)) is most reasonable.
PS *lošĭ < los-jo is likely to be cognate of Gothic lasiws 'weak', Old English leswe 'weak', Middle German erleswen 'weaken'. A relationship to Latin sublestus 'weak' is less probable.
It has certain cognates only in the Germanic languages, e. g. Gothic lasiws 'weak'. PS *lošĭ is a reflex of PIE root *lē- with an extention *-s- and suffix *-jo-

There is no Slavic etymology (the hypothesis of Machek assuming two irregural changes in a three/four-segment root is unreasonable) and in fact no really convincing etymology at all.
The original restriction of this cognate set along with congates of these lexemes with another meanings to West Slavic (East Slavic forms are doubtless borrowed from Polish), the initial šp- cluster and the irregular variation of the root vowel in all languages (-e- / -a- / -o-) suggest a borrowing from German.
However, it is complicated to find a convincing source of this hypothetical loanword. In the literature mainly two proposals are mentioned: Spat 'tumour on horse's leg' and Spott 'mockery' or spotten 'deride'. Both are semantically rather inconvincing, although a very broad semantic range of all špot- / špat- / špet- forms (cf. the cited sources) makes quite reasonable hypotheses possible. Another one links the lexeme to German spächtig / smächtig '(very) small, scrawny, meagre' which is semantically better but has phonetic flaws (the form "*špacht-ný" given by Králik 2015 is fully hypothetical and proposed ad-hoc). We can not exclude that the Slavic lexeme is a contamination of two original German etymona (a further contamination with Polish (wy)paczyć (się) 'buckle (about wood), misrepresent, garble' and its local cognates is also thinkable).

Polish szpatny 'very ugly, disgraceful' along with Lower Sorbian špatny 'bad, etc.', Upper Sorbian 'bad, etc.', Czech špatný 'bad, etc.' does not have any convincing etymology. It is unlikely that it is related to older Polish szpat, szpata, szpot 'a horse's flaw (crooked leg)' < German Spat.

Polish szpetny, szpatny, Czech szpata 'uglyness' are loanwords from German Spath 'a horse's flaw (crooked leg)'. The original meaning is attested in Polish: szpat, szpata, szpot, szpatawy, szpotawy. Also szpotlawy 'clumsy', szpocić 'defile', szpocić prawo 'garble the law'.
Old Polish szpatny 'ugly' (ca. 1500), zeszpacić 'make ugly' (15th century), szpot 'tumour on horse's leg' (ca. 1455), szpotawy '(horse) with a leg tumour' (1472).
The etymology is unclear. Some scholars assume here a borrowing from Middle High German spat 'tumour on horse's leg'. However, such a semantic generalization in Slavic does not seem to be probable.

The etymology is unclear. If the original meaning is 'weak' (attested in dialects), the Czech word 'špatný' (along with its Slavic cognates) could be maybe related to Lithuanian pentù, petaũ, pèsti 'get tired' with an expressive š-, suffix -ĭnŭ and -a- by some old analogy.
Schuster-Šewc points to the interpretations of Brückner and Machek with no own conclusions.
The source of this loan in West Slavic can be German spächtig / smächtig '(very) small, scrawny, meagre'.

Russian špetit' 'offend, deride' and Ukrainian špetiti 'offend crassly' are most probably directly borrowed from Polish spzpecić 'make dirty, break'. As the original source German spotten 'deride' is usually mentioned, which is, however, unsatisfying from the phonetic point of view. A comparison with German Spat, Spatz 'sickness of horse's leg' is also unconvincing.
S.v. Lat. tĕsta > Fr. tête 'head', etc.

S.v. Lat. testa 'earthenware vessel, tile, sherd, shell'. Semantically unlikely to go back to *tek̑- 'build' as suggested by earlier literature. More likely to be a loanword, as words for vessels frequently are.

S.v. glux 'head; end, summit, chief'. Commonly considered to be cognate with the Balto-Slavic word for head [cf. /cognate/1142/]. This is possible, but many details are unclear. The underlying form for Balto-Slavic may be reconstructed *gʰolHu-eh₂ and for Armenian, if cognate, something like *gʰolHu-k-h₂-o- (with the inclusion of a suffixal element *-k- and thematization) or simply *gʰolHu- + substratum suffix *-xo-.
Arm. glowx is generally considered to be root-cognate with Lith. galvà, but there are difficulties with the reconstruction of the Armenian form. See for further discussion of the stem formation.
S.v. Alb. kokë 'head, bulb, berry, grain'. A loanword from Lat. coccum 'berry'.

S.v. kamala- 'head', from *kamr̥da- (cf. Av. kamərəda-, Zor.P. kamāl 'skull', etc.). For further IE connections, cf. Skt. mūrdhan-, Gk. βλωθρός 'grown high', OEng. molda 'top of head', TochAB malto 'at first'.

S.v. Ved. mūrdhán- 'Haupt, Kopf, Stirn, Gipfel, Spitze', cf. IIr., YAv. ka-mərəδa- 'Kopf daēuuischer Wesen', MPers. kamāl, Khot. kamala-. Probably from PIE *ml̥h₃dʰ-on- (cf. OEng. molda 'der obere Teil des Kopfes, Scheitel', and probably Gk. βλωθρός 'hochgewachsen' *ml̥h₃dʰ-r-, etc.).

S.v. AGk. νόος 'mind, sense, intellect, reason; purpose, aim', from which νοέω 'to mediate, observe, think, devise, have in mind' is a denominal verb. Νόος appears to go back to an old o-grade verbal noun (cf. λόγος, φόρος, etc.) but there is no certain etymology outside of Greek.
Cf. s.v. *sent- 'gehen' → 'wahrnehmen' (?) (IEW 908).
S.v. Alb. dëgjoj 'to hear'. Dialectal forms ndëgoj, dëkgonj, diligonj reveal that this is a loanword from Lat. intelligere 'to perceive'.
S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'hören, tönen' [IEW 478]. Cf. s.v. *gʷerH- 'Zustimmung bekunden' (IEW 478).
Old Czech špatný 'bad, lame, paltry, awkward, weak' (attested from 14th century).
S.v. *(s)keu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen' (IEW 587-8).
Serbo-Croat (historical and/or dialectal) špotati 'chide, harass, deride, insult, curse, joke, ashame' < German spotten 'deride'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hauzjan- 'to hear' < PIE *h₂kous-ie-, cf. Gk. ἀκούω.

Older Polish szpatny, szpecić, szpacić 'make ugly, filthy, impure'; szpecić, szpacić 'make ugly, also in the moral sence', 'bring disgrace'; szpocić 'make filthy, ugly', 'misrepresent (e. g. sacral texts like Holy Scripture)', 'chide, ubpraid'; szpotawy 'with croocked legs, bandy-legged, crooked, crosseyed'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *klowstā 'hearing, ear', from PIE *k̑leu̯s-t- 'hear'.
Cf. s.v. *k̑leu̯s- '(zu)hören' (IEW 606-7). Cf. n1: this root is very likely to have been abstracted from a desiderative verb form of *k̑leu̯- (LIV² 334-335) already in the protolanguage.
S.v. Ved. kárṇa- 'Ohr', cf. YAv. karəna-, Khot. kārra- from Proto-Indo-Iranian *kárna- 'ear'. Etymological connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not securely determined.
S.v. *k̑leu̯- 'hören' (IEW 605-7). Cf. n1: the root *k̑leu̯s- (LIV² 336) is probably originally a derived desiderative form from this root, probably already of PIE date.

Kashubian (dialectal) špac 'thing that makes something ugly like rust, spot, dust, mud, spider-web'; špacëc 'make ugly'; špacëzna 'thing that makes ugly, scar'; špacelåk 'ugly person, scarecrow'; špacni 'ugly from the physical or moral point of view'; špet 'ugly person'; špat 'illnes of horse's ankle'; špot 'imp, tike; unfaitful husband'; špotav́ic 'make crooked, lopsided'; špotavi / špåtavi 'crooked, lopsided', 'ugly from the physical or moral point of view'; špotålc 'halting, lame, walking crookedly; imp, tike'; špotav́ėlc 'person with crooky legs, twisting his shoes; ugly person from the physical or moral point of view'. Cf. also špåcëc są 'bend, bucke (about wood)' (derived from PS *pakŭ, *opakŭ 'opposite, other way around') with an irregular initial š-.

The etymology of the East Slavic term is unclear. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses links it to Slavic *polx- 'fear, frighten' and further to PIE *pelh₁- (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:410). It is semantically convincing. However, a phonetically regular reflex should have -olo- then, e.g. Russian **polohoj. A solution is to assume a borrowing from Polish płochy (or a phonetic conforming at the Polish word). However, such a borrowing would be very isolated. Further, the Polish-like form of the root has been attested (in derivatives) already from 14th-15th centuries and it is spread in all East Slavic dialects. Another solution is to assume a contamination with ploskij 'flat'. The probability is disputable. Still another solution is to assume an irregular phonetic change driven or supported by the frequency. The phonetic circumstances are very favourable in this case. The (hipothetical) missing vowel was unstressed and East Slavic stress is dynamic and relatively strong (at least nowadays). Further, it stand between a stop and a liquid. In sequences / pR / there is always a short (prothetic, unphonological) vowel with a quality resembling the next vowel. An unstressed and therefore short, etymological vowel in / pVR / can be very easily interpreted as a prothetic, unphonological vowel articulation (and, in fact, vice versa), especially in cases as *polox- with two identical vowels. Further, we can deal with a dialectal, northern Russian feature in this case which could spread as a lexicalized inter-dialectal borrowing (cf. {ref Zaliznâk 2004}:39-41). Note that the oldest, precisely located attestations of plox-forms are found in texts from northern Russia. A combination of some of the given solutions is also conceivable.
The word is attested in Russian from the beginning of the 16th century. Most probably it is a loanword from Polish płochy 'shy, timid'.
S.v. Alb. vesh 'ear', from Proto-Albanian *wausi-, from PIE *ōus- ~ *əus- 'id.'.
S.v. Arm. unkn 'ear', to be connected with the PIE word for 'ear'; the Armenian form is derived from the stem *(H)us-n-.
It is a reflex of PS *plox- <*ploks- 'flat' or PS *polx- 'fear' < *pols-. These two etymona were probably contaminated.
The etymology is unclear. It is often linked to dialectal polóh 'fear, fright'. It is also assumed to be a loan from Polish without any justification.
There is no convincing etymology. It is most probably an old loanword from Polish płochy.

Most probably related to polóh and, with a different vowel grade, to pláha. A relationship to *ploskŭ 'flat' is often assumed.   It is not a loanword from Old High German flah 'flat' nor Middle High German blas 'weak, slight'. Also a borrowing of the East Slavic form from Polish płochy is unlikely.
East Slavic forms are not listed among the cognates of Polish płochy, płoszyć. (< PIE *pel-).
S.v. Lat. intendere, > Fr. entendre.

Either to PIE *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (IEW 1065-6) or 1. *tend- 'ermatten' (IEW 1065-6). Cf. n8, if tendō developed secondarily as a substitute *tn̥ne- for a *-néu̯/nu- present *tn̥néu̯-. Otherwise, the root of the verb should be separated with 1. *tend- (cf. Ved. tandate 'erlahmt'), possibly the same root as *ten- but with a dental root enlargement.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *xšnau-¹ 'to hear (< 'to sharpen (the ears)')', from PIE *ksneu̯- 'to whet, sharpen' (cf. Ved. kṣṇav- 'to whet, sharpen').
S.v. *ksneu̯- 'schärfen' (IEW 585).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *auzōn- 'ear', from PIE *h₂e/ous-n-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *awsos- 'ear', from PIE *h₂eus- 'ear'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *uxo 'ear', from PIE *h₂eus- (cf. Lat. auris, Goth. auso, OIr. áu, etc.).
S.v. Lith. ausìs 'ear', from PIE *h₂eus-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *slabъ 'weak', from PIE *slob-o- (cf. Lith. slãbnas [Žem.]; slõbnas [E.Lith.], Latv. slãbs, MLG slap 'weak, slack').
Cf. s.v. Lat. animus 'mind, spirit', from PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'breath'.
Cf. s.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (IEW 38-9).
S.v. Arm. sirt 'heart', since long derived from PIE *k̑ērd, *k̑r̥d-ós 'heart', etc.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *sьrdьce 'heart', with a stem derived from the PIE zero-grade *k̑r̥d-.
S.v. Lith. širdìs 'heart', from PIE *k̑ērd-, G.sg. *k̑r̥d-ós.
PS *xudŭ < PIE *ksoudo-, related to Old Indic kṣódati 'mash, flake', kṣudrá- 'small, tiny' and probably to Lithuanian skaudùs 'painful'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hertōn- 'heart', from a derived n-stem *k̑erd-n-.
Cf. s.v. *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'zerstieben, in kleine Teile zerfallen' (IEW 625).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kridyo- 'heart'.
The etymology is not entirely clear. It is usually assumed that the Slavic word is related to Old Indic kṣódati.
Cf. s.v. Sloven. hȗd, related to Lithuanian skaudùs and Old Indic kṣódati. PIE *kseu̯d- 'small, flaked' > 'weak, bad'.
Cf. s.v. *lei̯kʷ- 'zurücklassen, sich entfernen von' (LIV 406ff., IEW 669ff.), with OCS lixъ, etc. < ?*lei̯kʷ-s-o/ah₂-.
PS *lixŭ 'superfluos, excessive' < PIE *leikʷ-so-, derived from *leikʷ- 'leave'. Cf. *otŭlěkŭ 'remainder' < PIE -*leikʷ-.
Polish lichy < PS *lixŭ 'remaining, superfluous, useless' > 'worthless, paltry, poor'.
Cf. s.v. Ru. лихой < PIE *leikso- (cf. Gk. λείπω, Lat. relinquō, etc.).

It is hard to determine precisely how and when the root arose in Ukrainian (it can be an old Common Slavic loanword but it also could pass to Ukrainian or its ancestor dialects through Church Slavonic, Polish etc.).

The etymology of Belarusian drèn' 'muck, lousy, bad' (>drènnny 'bad') is not entirely clear. It is most probably parallel to Russian drân' 'muck, lousy, bad'. The Russian word is assumed to be related to drat' 'rip, tear' or to drâblyj 'flabby, deflated, weak'. In any case, the root vowel in Belarusian is not original (it has, however, a rather reasonable phonetic explanation; it can be also expressive).
Russian drân' < dran'. It is a reflex of PS *der- / *dĭr- 'rip, tear'. Forms without secondary palatalisation of *r are attested in dialects. The palatalisation is by analogy.
Russian drân' is related to drat' 'rip, tear'. The palatalisation is late and secondary.

The etymology of Russian drân' is not clear. It is probably related to drat' 'rip, tear'. As to the unexpected palatalisation of *r cf. dialectal drânina 'something that is torn off' and other similar cases. The comparison with drâblyj 'flabby, deflated, weak' is less convincing.

Polish drań 'scroundel, despicable man' is a loanword from Russian drân' which is probably related to Russian drâblyj 'withered, puckered, flabby, deflated' (PS drębnǫti 'loose freshness, power, get limp, moulder, rot').
Russian drân' is probably a reflex of *drębnĭ, related to drâblyj. It has been also linked to drat' 'rip, tear'.

Polish drań, Russian drân' and dialectal dran', along with other Slavic forms with different, usually negative meanings ('something useless, bad, with a low quality, pus, caning, something torn or cut off, scroundel, carcass, barren spoil') are listed as reflexes of PS *dĭranĭ < *dĭrati 'rip, tear'. PS *dĭrati < PIE *der- / *dr-. PS *drębnǫti is related to Lithuanian drìbti, drimbù, drebė'ti.
PS *dĭrati is a reflex of PIE *der-. Lithuanian drìbti, drimbù, drebė'ti are related to PIE *dʰrebʰ-.

The Belarusian lexeme along with its Slavic cognates is most probably related to PIE *der-. An alternative hypothesis, less frequenly adopted and, in my opinion, less plausible, links it to PIE *dʰrebʰ-.

The etymology is unlclear. It has been linked to Old High German Spat 'tumour on horse's leg' or German spächt-ig 'small, tiny' (it could be borrowed from a form without umlaut *spacht-ig > *špacht-ný > špat-ný?).
