It was also claimed that it is   an inherited word, related to Lithuanian pèsti, petaũ 'get tired'.
S.v. 10188 *muṭṭa- (2) 'heart'. [Orig. 'lump' cf. *muḍḍha- 2?]
S.v. Lat. cor, cordis 'heart', from PIE *k̑ēr, k̑r̥d-os. Latin generalised the oblique (zero-grade) form of the stem *k̑r̥d- > *kord-.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *ę̄tro 'liver' < PIE *h₁en-tr-om and *ǭtròba < *h₁on-tro- (cf. Ved. āntrá- 'intestine', Gk. ἔντερα 'entrails').
S.v. Alb. zemër 'heart; middle'. No certain etymology.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tęžьkъ 'heavy', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *ting- (cf. Lith. tingùs 'lazy'), from PIE *tngʰ-, cf. OIc. þungr 'heavy'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *swēra- 'heavy', a vr̥ddhi-adjective to an unattested strong verb *sweran-; derivationally parallel to *wēta- 'wet'. Cf. Lith. sver̃ti 'to weigh, to balance' < *suer-e-, Lith. svarùs 'heavy' < *suor-u-.
Cf. s.v. *treu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 1095-6).
S.v. Lat. lūridus 'Leichenblass' > Fr. lourd.

S.v. lūridus 'ghastly yellow, colour of bruises'. Etymology ultimately uncertain. Perhaps cognate with MW lleu 'light' < *le/ous-, alternatively with Lat. līvidus 'of a dull or greyish-blue colour; envious' < PIE *(s)l(e/o)iH-uo- (cf. OIr. lí, W. lliw 'colour', Russ. sliva 'plum', OHG slēha, OEng. slāh 'sloe').
S.v. Ved. √bhar- 'tragen, hegen, pflegen; bringen', from PIE *bʰer-. Ved. bhārá- 'Bürde, Last' is a derivative from this root.
S.v. 9459 Ved. bhārá- m. 'burden, weight' RV., bhāraka- m. 'weight' Mn. [√bhr̥] and 9465 Skt. bhārika- (2) 'forming a load, heavy' Suśr. [Cf. bhāri- 'ponderous (of a tone)' Śiś. bhārá-].
Cf. s.v. TochB krāmär 'weight, heaviness', from a putative PIE *gʷreH-mr̥ 'heaviness'.
Cf. s.v. 1962 *udguru- 'very heavy' [Skt. gurú-] for Palula اُنگُروۡ uŋˈɡuɾo.
S.v. Ved. gurú- 'schwer, gewichtig, hart, heftig, drückend, groß', from PIE *gʷr̥h₂-u- (cf. YAv. gouru- 'heavy', Gk. βαρύς 'schwer', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *kuru- 'heavy' (Goth. kaurus* 'heavy'), from PIE *gʷrh₂-u-.

S.v. Lat. gravis 'heavy; serious, weighty', from PIE *gʷreh₂-u-. As with other u-stems in Italic, the original PIE *-u- stem was remodelled as an i-stem. (cf. Skt. gurú- 'heavy', Khot. ggarka- 'heavy, respectable', Gk. βαρύς 'heavy', Latv. grũts 'heavy, pregnant' (< *gʷrh₂-u-to-), Goth. kaurjos 'weighty, opressive', TochB krāmär 'weight, heaviness', TochA krāmärts 'heavy').
S.v. TochB tuk- 'be hidden, hide oneself'. Possibly to be connected with PIE *keu̯dʰ- 'hide', but one must assume an irregular consonant metathesis, further etymological speculation is unclear.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *stekan- 'to stick', from PIE *stig-e- (cf. Lat. īnstīgō, -ere 'to stimulate, set on, incite, rouse or urge' < *-steig-e-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *felhan- 'to hide'. An extra-Germanic etymology is difficult.
S.v. *pteh₂k- 'sich ducken' (IEW 825), based on tʻakʻeaw 'verbarg sich' < from an original fientive formation *pth₂k-éh₁/h₁- (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:70, 78-79, 84).
S.v. fsheh ~ mshef 'to hide', from Proto-Albanian Pr. *en-skepska- and compares Greek σκέπω, from PIE *skep- (so {ref Jokl 1912}:192-195).
S.v. Ved. √han- 'schlagen, erschlagen, töten', from PIE *gʷʰen- (cf. Hitt. ku-(e)-en-zi, Gk. θεἰνω, etc.).
S.v. Lat. feriō, -īre 'to strike', from PIE *bʰerH- 'to pierce, strike'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *berjan- 'to fight', from PIE *bʰorH-ie-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *drepan- 'to hit', assuming a back-formation to the iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip, droop; to drop', a zero-grade variant of *drapp/bōn- 'to hit'. Both iteratives can be derived from *draban- 'to hew' < *dʰróbʰ-e- (cf. OCS drobiti (drobljǫ) 'to crumble, chop, break').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *tara-wo- 'hit, strike', from PIE *terh₁- 'drill, rub' (cf. Lat. terō, Gk. τορεύω).
Cf. s.v. *terh₁- 'bohren, reiben' (IEW 1071-2).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bi-na- 'strike, hit', from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'strike' (cf. OLat. perfines 'you should strike', OCS biti 'strike').
S.v. κρούω 'to strike, stamp, knock', from PIE *krou(s)- 'push, bump, strike' (cf. OCS sъ-krušiti, Ru. krušit', Latv. kràusêt, Lith. kraušýti).
S.v. *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (not in IEW).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hawwan- 'to hew, chop', from PIE *kóuh₂-e- (cf. TochB kāw 'kill' < *keh₂u-; Lith. káuti 'to murder, beat, hew', Latv. kaût 'to fight' < *ke/oh₂u-; OCS kovati, Ru. kovát' 'to forge, hammer' < *kouh₂-eh₂- (with laryngeal metathesis)).
S.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (IEW 535).

S.v. rreh 'schlagen'. Usually connected with *u̯reh₁g̑- 'brechen, reißen' (LIV² 698). While this is not implausible phonologically, this is not persuasive semantically. A possible alternative is to Old Albanian rā-, the suppletive aorist to bíe 'fall'. Despite these etymological uncertainties, the paradigm must continue a primary verb with a present stem suffix *-sk̑e/o-.
Cf. s.v. *dʰeh₁- 'stellen, legen, setzen; herstellen, machen' (IEW 235-9). Cf. n12 on Lat. compound verbs.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kel-o- 'hide', from PIE *k̑el- 'hide'.
S.v. 1. *k̑el- 'verbergen' (IEW 553-4).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *bergan- 'to keep (safe)', from PIE *bʰérgʰ-e- (cf. OCS brěšti 'to care', Lith. bìrginti 'to save'; OIr. commairge 'protection, security' < *k̑om-bʰorgʰ-ieh₂-).
S.v. ?*bʰergʰ- 'beachten, bewahren' (IEW 145).
PS *kora < PIE *ker-.
PS (s)kora < PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.
PS *kora, *skora < PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *br'uxo, arguing from PIE *bhreu- 'swell', comparing Old Irish brū 'belly', Welsh bru 'womb', but also Ved. bhrūṇá-s 'embryo'.
S.v. TochB krorīya* 'horn; crescent of moon'. TochA kror and TochB  krorīya reflect a Proto-Tocharian *krorŭ; Proto-Tocharian *kror- is a derivative of PIE *k̑r̥h₂s-r- 'horn'.
S.v. Ved. śŕ̥ṇga- 'Horn', from PIE *k̑r̥-n-g⁽ʷ⁾o-, derived to PIE *k̑er(h₂)- 'Horn ~ Kopf', cf. *k̑r̥-n- in Lat. cornū, Goth. haurn 'Horn'.
Cf. for an exhaustive discussion of formations meaning 'head' and 'horn' built to this root.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hurna- 'horn', from PIE *k̑rn-o- (cf. Skt. śŕ̥ṅga- 'horn' < *k̑r-n-go-, Lat. cornū < *k̑r-nu-, W. carn 'hoof' < *kr-no-, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *karno- 'horn, hoof', from PIE *k̑rno- 'horn'.
S.v. Ved. śā́khā- 'Ast, Zweig', to which the Iranic vocabulary are possibly connected: cf. MPers. šāk, NPers. šāx 'Zweig', MSogd. šnx, Wakhi šolx 'Zweig'.

S.v. Skt. śā́khā- 'Ast, Zweig' / 'branch'. Not to be separated from MPers., NPers. šāḫ-, Arm. čʻax, 'Zweig, Ahorn', Goth. hōha 'Pflug', Lith. šakà 'Ast, Zweig', Russ. sochá 'Hakenpflug', Pol. socha 'Gabelholz' etc., however not all the details of this connection are fully clear. The initial correspondence of Ved. ś- ~ Ir. š- is irregular (expected **s- in Iranic).
For lack of a better solution for the problems of phonological reconstruction among the proposed IE cognates, I reconstruct Proto-Iranian *šāxā- for the root ref. form in this set.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bando- 'peak, top', from PIE *bend- 'point, pin' (cf. OE pintel 'penis', Middle Low German pin, pinne 'pin, nail').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bando- 'peak, top', from PIE *bend- 'point, pin' (cf. OE pintel 'penis', Middle Low German pin, pinne 'pin, nail').

S.v. Alb. bri ~ brî 'horn', from Proto-Albanian *brina. According to Orel, related to Messap. βρένδον· ἔλαφον; βρέντιον· ἡ κεφαλὴ τοῦ ἐλάφρου (Hes., Et. Magn.), Swed. brind 'deer', Latv. briêdis 'elk', OPruss. brayadis 'id.' (cf. Meyer Wb. 48).

Although the cognacy of the Slavic word belonging to this class (along with further related lexemes in Slavic lanugages) is obvious, due to irregularities in the root vocalism it not trivial to determine the original PS root and to some extend also the exact morphological structure of the original word. The possibilities are *trěbuxŭ, *trĭbuxŭ, *tribuxŭ, *terbuxŭ, and *tŭrbuxŭ. The inconsistencies can be of expressive nature. If *terb- 'clean, (to) gut' is the input form, the original meaning is 'guts of a killed animal that have to be cleaned, gutted'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *saiwi- 'sea'. K. favours the connection with OI sīa, OE sēon, OHG sīgan 'filter, strain', etc. from PGmc. *sīhwan- 'to percolate' from PIE *sei̯kʷ-. [No discussion of the word as a possible pre-IE loanword.]
Cf. s.v. 1. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (IEW 1069-70).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √tap- 'brennen, heiß sein, heiß machen', from PIE *tep- 'warm sein' (cf. Lat. tepēre, 'warm sein', OIr. tē 'heiß, OCS teplostь 'Wärme').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *teplъ, a *-lo- derivative of *tep- 'be hot' (cf. Lat. tepidus 'lukewarm, warm', Skt. tápati 'burn, be hot').
S.v. Lat. tepeō 'to be warm', from which the adjective tepidus 'warm' is derived. Ultimately from PIE *tep- 'to be warm'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *tefent- 'hot, warm', derived from PIE *tep- 'be warm' (cf. Skt. tápati 'burns', Lat. tepeō 'be warm', OCS toplъ 'warm'). On the etymology, cf. OIr. téit (gloss) luxoriatae ('wanton women') < *tefentes).
Cf. s.v. Alb. nxeh 'to heat, to warm', continuing Proto-Albanian *en-dzerska. The root is the same as Alb. zjarr 'fire' < PIE *gʷʰer- 'be warm'.
S.v. Alb. ngroh 'erwärmen, warm machen', cf. for discussion of the derived stem forms in Albanian.
S.v. Arm. ǰer 'warmth; warm and bright weather', 'warm', derived from PIE *gʷʰer(-mo)- 'warm' (cf. Ved. gharmá-, Gk. θερμός, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *warma- 'warm', from PIE *gʷʰor-mo- and identical in derivation to Lat. formus 'warm'.
S.v. caleō 'to be warm'. While Lat. caleō represents a stative verb *k̑lH-eh₁-, calidus may be directly derived from *k̑lH-i-dʰo- (cf. Nussbaum 1999).
Cf. for a discussion of the IE stem formation of Lat. calidus.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷokʷ-o- 'cook, bake', from PIE *pekʷ-. The Welsh forms come from a passive participle form PIE *pokʷto- > *kʷokʷto- (distance assimilation *p … *kʷ > *kʷ … *kʷ) > Proto-Celtic *kʷoxto-.
Cf. s.v. *pekʷ- 'reif machen, gar machen' (IEW 798).

S.v. Lith. kárštas 'hot, quick tempered'. The etymology of these Baltic forms is unclear. The suggestion of {ref Smoczyński 2007}:278 that we are dealing with the root *kers- in Lat. currere 'run' is unlikely.
Cf. s.v. *h₁eu̯s- 'verbrennen, sengen' (IEW 347-8).
S.v. Ved. √oṣ- 'brennen, versengen', from PIE *(h₁)eu̯s- (cf. Gk. εὔω 'senge', Lat. ūrō 'brenne, versenge', etc.). Derived adj. uṣṇá- 'heiß'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *haita- 'hot'. There are no certain extra-Germanic cognates.
S.v. Arm. tun 'house'. From PIE *dṓm, (gen.sg. *dém-s) 'house' (cf. Skt. dám-, Av. dam-, Gk. δῶ 'house',  δῶμα 'house, temple', Lat. domus 'house, household', OCS domъ 'house', etc.).
S.v. Ved. dam- 'Haus' (IIr. OAv., YAv. dam- 'Haus, Wohnung', etc.). From PIE *dṓm, (gen.sg. *dém-s) 'house'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *domъ 'house', from PIE *dom-u- (cf. Lat. domus).

S.v. Lith. nãmas 'house, (pl.) home'. Despite the enigmatic development *d- > n (possibly from a zero-grade *dm- before a vowel?), the connection with PIE *dem-/*dom- remains the best possible etymology.

S.v. Ved. gr̥há- 'Haus, Anwesen, Wohnstätte' cf. YAv. gərəδa- 'Behausung daēuuischer Wesen', from PIE *gʰr̥dʰ-ó- (cf. Goth. gards 'Haus, Haushalt', Lith. gar̃das 'Pfersch', OCS gradъ 'Burg, Stadt', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *gʰerdʰ- 'umschließen, umgürten' (IEW 444).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *garda- 'courtyard' (Goth. gards 'house, household, enclosure, courtyard'), from PIE *gʰordʰ-o- (cf. Lith. gar̃das 'fold, pen', OCS gradъ 'city, town', Alb. gardh 'hedge, fence' < *gʰordʰ-o-; cf. also Skt. gr̥há- 'house' < *gʰr̥dʰ-ó-).
For Middle and Modern Indic forms, cf. s.v. 4428 Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit ghara- (Pāli ghara-).
Cf. s.v. Ved. veśá- 'Insasse, Eingesessener' (cf. IIr. YAv. vaēsa-, Khot. bīsa), derived from √veś- < PIE *u̯ei̯k̑-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *tegos- 'house', from PIE *teg-os 'cover, roof' (cf. Lat. tegō 'cover', Gk. τέγος 'roof', Germ. Dach).
Cf. s.v. *(s)teg- 'decken, bedecken' (IEW 1013-4).
S.v. Lat. casa 'cottage, hut'. Origins disputed; possibly an early loanword in Latin.
Cf. s.v. 2. *men- 'bleiben, warten' (IEW 729).

S.v. TochB ost 'house', which along with TochA waṣt 'house' reflects Proto-Tocharian *wostŭ. This is clearly cognate with Skt. vāstu 'house, dwelling', vástu 'place, seat, thing' and Gk. (ϝ)ἀστυ 'city'. The reconciling the reconstructed stem for these forms as a derivative of a specific IE root, however, is disputed.
Cf. Proto-Celtic trebā- 'settlement' from PIE *treb- 'settlement' (cf. Goth. þaurp 'field', OHG dorf 'homestead, village', Lith. trobà 'house, parlour').
Cf. s.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273).
S.v. τρέχω 'to run, hurry', from IE *dʰregʰ- 'run' (cf. Gk. τροχός 'wheel', OIr. droch < *dʰrogʰ-o-).
S.v. Lat. *captiare 'jagen' > Old French chacier.
S.v. Lat. capiō -ere 'to take', from which captāre 'to try to touch, grasp at' is a secondary derivative. Ultimately from either PIE *kh₂p-i- or non-IE *kap-i- 'to seize'.
S.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-8).
Cf. s.v. *selg̑- 'loslassen, entsenden' (IEW 900-1).

The precise Indo-European root etymology for this class is disputed. Therefore Proto-Celtic *klad-o- will be used the purposes of providing a root-ref. form, but cf. citations for possible further IE connections in the secondary literature.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √cyav- 'in Bewegung geraten, sich bewegen, unternehmen', from PIE *ki̯eu̯-.
S.v. *kʷi̯eu̯- 'sich in Bewegung setzen' (IEW 539).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯au- 'move, go'.
Cf. s.v. *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).

S.v. gjuaj ~ gjuej 'to hunt'. Orel prefers an etymology to Proto-Albanian *jāgnja based on a noun *jaga > gjah 'hunt, hunting' (cf. OHG jagōn 'hunt'). Other proposed etymologies include connections to (1) Gk. δίζημαι, (2) Slav. ženǫ, *gъnati 'drive away', Lith. genù, giñti 'id.', (3) to Lat. sāgiō 'to feel, suspect', OIr. saigim 'to go towards, to seek'. Cf. entry for references to further literature.

Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain. {ref Orel 1998}:137-138 prefers a connection to Old High German jagōn (cf. /cognate/243/), which has no certain etymology outside of Germanic itself; {ref Demiraj 1997}:191-192 who rejects the connection with the Germanic lexemes and suggests instead a connection with Lat. sāgiō 'spüren, ahnen, wittern', OIr. 'nachgehen einer Sache, suchen' to PIE *seh₂g- '(witternd) nachspüren'. If so, perhaps to be connected within Albanian to 'hear' in /cognate/8546/. Undiscussed, however, in connection to Albanian gjegj in {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974-975.
S.v. Ved. himá- 'Kälte, Frost' < PIE *g̑ʰi̯em-/*g̑ʰim- (cf. Av. ziiā̊ 'Winter').
Cf. s.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).

S.v. gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice', from PIE *g̑el-u- 'cold, frost, ice' (cf. Goth. kalds 'cold', OE calan 'to freeze', OIc. kala 'to freeze'). Connections with Gk. γελανδρόν 'cold' (Hesych.) are uncertain. Slavic lexemes, e.g. OCS xladъ 'coolness, cool breeze', Ru. xolod' 'cold' < Proto-Slavic *xoldъ '(the) cold' may be from an extended root *g̑oldʰo-?
σπάτζω < AG σφάζω (sf > sp dissimilation).
S.v. σφάζω 'to slaughter (by cutting the throat), kill, sacrifice'. No known cognates outside of Greek.

S.v. Alb. vras (aor. vrava) 'to kill', from Proto-Albanian *awa-rautja, a prefix derivative based on IE *reu- 'to tear, destroy' (cf. Skt. rutá- 'broken', Lat. ruō 'to fall down, to rush down', etc.).
S.v. ?*slak- 'schlagen' (IEW 959). Cf. n1 "Hierher wohl mir. slacc 'Schwert', neuir. slacairt 'das Schlagen' usw."

S.v. Proto-Germanic *drepan- 'to hit', assuming a back-formation to the iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip, droop; to drop', a zero-grade variant of *drapp/bōn- 'to hit'. Both iteratives can be derived from *draban- 'to hew' < *dʰróbʰ-e- (cf. OCS drobiti (drobljǫ) 'to crumble, chop, break').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *dauþu- 'death', from PIE *dʰóu(H)-tu-, a tu-stem created to Proto-Germanic *daujan- 'to die' < *dʰouh₂/₃-ié- (cf. Hitt. tuḫḫušzi 'to end'; Lat. fūnus 'funeral' < *dʰuh₂-n-es-(?)). On the PIE level the verb has usually been compared to *dʰeu- 'to run, to rush' (Skt. dhávate, Gk. θέω 'to run' and to *dʰueh₂- 'to blow, smoke, be misty' (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:148; LIV² s.v.), but Kroonen finds it preferable to assume a link with Hitt. tuḫḫušzi 'to end'. The forms based on Goth. dauϸs 'dead', ON dauðr, OE dēad, OHG tōt, etc. are from PGmc. *dauda-, the original past participle to *daujan-.
Cf. s.v. *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen' (IEW 259-60, 262); primary verb in ON deyja 'sterben' < *dʰou̯-éi̯e-.
S.v. *bʰei̯H- 'schlagen' (IEW 117-8).
S.v. Lat. tutari 'schützen', from which Fr. tuer 'kill' is derived.
S.v. keni* 'knees' (du.). The TochA dual kanweṃ and TochB keni reflect Proto-Tocharian *kenwäi vel sim. Proto-Tocharian *kenw- is certainly from PIE *g̑onu- 'knee'.
S.v. Arm. cung-kʻ, cunr, cungn 'knee', connected with other IE words for 'knee' (Gk. γόνυ, Skt. jā́nu-, Lat. genū, etc.). The Armenian stem *cung- probably reflects an IE dual neuter *g̑onu-ih₁.
S.v. Ved. jā́nu- 'Knie', from PIE *g̑ónu- / *g̑nu-. In Iranic cf. YAv. zānu-, žnūm (acc.sg.), Khot. ysānū-, Parth. z'nwg, MPers. zānūg, šnūg, NPers. zānū 'Knie', etc.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *knewa- 'knee', from a thematised zero-grade stem *g̑n-eu-o-.
S.v. gju ~ gjû 'knee', from Proto-Albanian *gluna dissimilated from *g(a)nuna, which in turn is a secondary n-stem derivative based on PIE *g̑enu- 'knee'.
S.v. Lat. genu, -ūs 'knee', from PIE *g̑en-u(-h₁ dual), *g̑en-u- (obl.).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *glūnos- 'knee', ultimately from PIE *g̑onu- 'knee'. The precise derivation of the stem that resulted in Proto-Celtic *gnūnos- is not fully understood, but the etymology ultimately to other IE words for 'knee' is undisputed. On the dissimilation of initial *gn- > *gl- cf. the same sound change which also occurred independently in Albanian.
Cf. s.v. Lith. kelė́nas 'knee, knee-bone, knee-cap', with the same etymology as in Derksen (2008:228-229).

S.v. 3243 *kuṭṭha- 'knee'. [Conn. √kuṭ- 1 'bend' Grierson Tor 162 with (?). But a long range of names for joints and limbs ʻ ankle, heel, foot, leg, knee, wrist' are characterized by the sequence of guttural u/ō retroflex: *kuṭṭha- , *khuṭṭa- 2, *khuḍa- 1, *guṭṭha- 2, *gōḍḍa- , ghuṭa- , ghuṇṭa- 1] Ash. kuṭäˊ ʻ heel ʼ, Wg. kūṭewīˊ NTS ii 263; Dm. khuṭṭa ʻ knee ʼ, Paš. kōṭa, Bshk. kuṭ, kuṭh, Tor. kūṭh, Kand. kūṭhu, Phal. kuṭho, khūṭu, Sh. gil. kŭṭo m. (→ Ḍ. kuṭá prob. pl.), pales. koh. kūṭhu, jij. kuṭh, K. kŏṭhu m.
Cf. s.v. *ret- 'laufen' (IEW 866).
S.v. *Hei̯k̑- 'sich aneignen' (IEW 298-9).
S.v. TochB aik- 'wissen, erkennen', 'know, recognize', to be derived from √*Hei̯k̑- 'sich aneignen' (LIV² 223).

S.v. di 'wissen, kennen, können, beherrschen'. Continues a present stem *dʰiH-i̯é/ó- or *dʰiH-e/o- of the root *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen' (LIV² 141f.); other solutions are improbable. The aorist is based on the *-to- verbal adjective.
Fr. savoir 'know' from Lat. sapere 'schmecken; wissen'.
S.v. Lat. sapiō, -ere 'to taste, be intelligent, know', from PIE *sh₁p-i- 'to notice' (cf. OS an-sebbian 'to remark, notice', OHG int-seffen 'to remark, taste', OIc. sefi 'thought').
S.v. *seh₁p- '(durch Schmecken) wahrnehmen' (IEW 880).
S.v. TochA kñas- 'kennen', 'know', from PIE *g̑neh₃- 'erkennen' (LIV² 168ff.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *znati 'know', from PIE *g̑neh₃- 'know' (cf. Skt. jānā́ti 'know', Gk. γιγνώσκω 'perceive, realize', Goth. kunnan 'know').
S.v. Lith. žinóti 'know', from PIE *g̑n-ne/n-h₃- (>> *g̑nh₃-ne/n-h₃-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *kunnan- 'to know (how), be able', (as though) from PIE *g̑onh₃-neh₂-.
S.v. Arm. *gēt- 'to know', from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to know, be acquainted with' (cf. Skt. ved- 'to know', Goth. wait 'he knows', etc.).
S.v. Ved. √ved- (1) 'finden, entdecken, erlangen' (2) 'wissen, kennen', from PIE u̯ei̯d- 'sehen, erblicken' (cf. Lat. vidēre, OCS viděti, etc.).
S.v. Old Prussian waist 'know', from PIE *uoid- (cf. Skt. véda, Gk. οἶδα, Goth. 3.sg. wait).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *věděti 'know', from PIE *uoid- (cf. Skt. véda, Gk. οἶδα, Goth. 3.sg. wait).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *witan- 'know', from PIE uoid-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *wi-n-d-o- 'find, experience', from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'see, know' (cf. Skt. vindáti 'finds', Lat. videō, Arm. gitem 'know').
Cf. s.v. πορεῖν 'to provide, donate, offer, grant', from PIE *perh₃- 'give' (cf. Skt. pūr-dhi [1.sg.imptv.] 'give!' < *pr̥h₃-dʰi).
Cf. s.v. *perh₃- 'verschaffen' [IEW 816-8].
S.v. 5635 Skt. taḍāga- 'pool' ŚāṅkhGr̥., taḍā́ka- n. lex., taṭāka- m. R., ˚kinī- f. MBh. 2. taḍaga- , talaka- m. lex.
S.v. Skt. taḍāgam n. 'pond, tank, (artificial) lake'. Etymology not securely explained.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *mari- 'lake, sea', from PIE *mor-i- (cf. Oss. mal 'stagnant water', Lat. mare 'sea', OIr. muir 'id.', MW mor 'id.' < *mor-i-; Lith. mãrios (f.pl.) 'id.' < *mor-ieh₂-, OCS morje, Ru. móre, SCr. mȍre, môre 'id.' < mor-io-).
S.v. Ved. sáras- 'See, Teich', from PIE *séles- (cf. Gk. ἕλος 'feuchte Niederung, Sumpf').
Both Ved. sálas- and Gk. ἕλος -εος are s-stem neuters < *sél-os-Ø, *sel-es-os, therefore we are dealing with an original root *sel-.
S.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.). Originally a heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥-/*u̯ed-en-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', from PIE *uod-r/n- 'water'.
S.v. 5392 *jhilla- (1) 'swamp, lake'; cf. also 14118 *hilla- (2) 'mud, swamp'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *loku- 'lake, pool' (cf. Lat. lacus, Gk. λάκκος, OE lagu, OCS loky).
S.v. Alb. qesh 'to laugh', from Proto-Albanian *kaksja related to similar onomatopoeic verbs in Skt. kákhati, Gk. καχάζω, etc.
S.v. Arm. *cicał 'laughter', cicałim 'to laugh', from the same root as całr 'laugh, laughter', to be connected with Gk. γελάω 'to laugh', etc. from PIE *g̑elh₂-.
See now addenda and corrigenda to LIV² arguing *g̑ʰer- → *gʰer- on basis of Khwarezmian (+) ɣry- ‘sich freuen’.

S.v. TochB ker- 'laugh, make laugh', from *g̑ʰor(–i̯e/o)- (cf. Skt. háryati 'find pleasure in, desire', Greek χαίρω 'rejoice', Umbrian heriest 'volet', Latin horior 'exhort, incite', OHG gerōn 'want, desire, long for', Old English giernan 'yearn', etc.).
S.v. Latv. smiêt 'laugh at, mock, (refl.) laugh', from PIE *sm(e)iH- 'laugh' (cf. Skt. smáyate 'smile').
In view of Nuristani cognates, we should reconstruct Proto-Indo-Iranian *kʰand- for root ref. form.
Cf. s.v. 1. *su̯er- 'tönen' (IEW 1049-50). [Without Celtic].

PS *terbűxъ or *trěbűxъ, *trьbűxъ, *tribűxъ are derivatives from *tȇrbъ or *trě̑bъ, *trь̏bъ, *trȋbъ that do not have any satisfying etymology. It can be related to Latin strebula, stribula 'flesh about the haunches'. Alternatively, it can be related to PS *terbiti 'clean, shell'.
Polish telbuch, terbuch, trybuch is related to torba 'bag'. However, any etymology of the latter is given by the author.

Serbo-Croat trbuh is probably related to Czech břicho, Polish brzuch, Russian brûho which are derived from PIE *bhreus- 'swell'. The first syllable tr- is maybe related to trti 'rub'. The r in *bhreus- was lost due to a dissimilation to the first r.
The lexeme (Czech terboch) is common Slavic but its etymology is unclear. Maybe, ter- is related to Latin uterus 'belly, womb'. It is also thinkable that the word is related to Latin strebula.

A reconstruction of a uniform PS form is complicated. Most probably it is a reflex of PS *terb- which is an old -b-extention of *ter- 'rub'. *-ux- is a suffix. Forms without this suffix are also found in Slavic (e.g. Ukrainian tereb 'belly'). The irregular root vocalism is due to an expressive character of this word. The hypotheses of Vasmer, Brückner and Macher are unjustified and inconvincing.

It is hard to determine a (uniform) PS form. It can be a compound of *trĭ- (an adjectival prefix with a superlative or superlative-like meaning, also preserved in its original meaning 'triple') and *bux- 'swell'. Some scholars assume here *terb and link the Russian trebuha, trebuh 'glutton' to Ukrainian tereb 'belly', terebuh 'glutton'. Both hypotheses do not explain the West Slavic forms. The hypothesis of Brückner is impossible phonetically, a comparison to Italian trippa 'belly' is dubious [Addendum of Trubačov: -ux- can be a suffix and the word can be related then to Latin strebula].

There is no commonly accepted etymology. The underlying root is probably PS *terb-, an extention of *ter- 'rub'. Then the word is related also to PS *terbiti 'clean, gut'. In this case, *-ux- is to be assumed as a suffix. The hypothesis of Vasmer is less probable. The comparisons to Polish torba, Latin strebula, Italian trippa, and Latin uterus are not much convincing.

The most convincing etymology is *terb- 'clean, gut', linking the word ultimately to PIE *terh₁- 'rub'. The irregularities in the root vocalism can be expressive and/or somehow connected to various root vocalisms that are present in Slavic reflexes of *terh₁-. However, the relationship of PS *terb- to PS *ter- (PIE *terh₁) can be disputed, cf. (Boryś 2005: 648).
A Balkan word of unknown origin.

It has been linked to Turkish karın 'belly' or to Greek χορμί 'body', χορμός 'trunk'. Most probably, it was borrowed from Proto-Bulgar. This assumption can explain best the internal -o- and final -m and is also better from the semantic point of view.
Cf. s.v. *terh₁- 'bohren, reiben' (IEW 1071-2).
Cf. s.v. Sloven. črevọ̑, from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'. Initially the word referred to internal organs, guts that are cut off from animal's belly.
PS *červo 'internal organs in the abdominal cavity, guts, intestines; skin, especially from animal's belly'. PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.
It is a loanword from Middle High German (Bavarian) wamp, a reflex of Proto Germanic *wambō 'belly'.
Ukrainian kelûh, kalûh 'gut, anus, stomach of a young calf or lamb', kelûhi, kalûhi 'guts'. It is derived from kal 'excrement, garbage'.

However, the reconstruction *kʷeh₂l-o- (cf. Greek πηλός ‘clay,
earth, mud, mire’) would be in conflict with Hirt’s law.

PS *kaľux (attested in Russian and Ukrainian dialects with meanings 'dirty container for feeding of livestock' and respectively 'belly, guts(s), stomach') is derived from PS *kalŭ. Modern Slavic reflexes of PS *kalŭ refer to 'dirt, dirty objects, mud, excrement' etc. It has for sure PIE origin and can be a reflex of PIE *kālo-s or kʷālo-s.  PS *kalŭ has been linked to Greek πηλός 'mud, clay' (if Greek π- < PIE kʷ- and not p-). However, this word is described as unclear in etymology dictionaries of Greek. Other comparisons (to Latin cālidus, Latin squālus, Greek κηλίς, Old Indic kāla-) are less convincing or just wrong.
Greek πηλόσ: "Without a convincing etymology. Pre-Greek?".
S.v. Lat. frōns, -ondis 'foliage, leaves'. No widely accepted etymology, cf. entry for various proposals.

S.v. gjeth 'foliage, green leaves', from Proto-Albanian *gadza with an irregular devoicing in Auslaut, or with a secondary th-suffix. Etymologically connected with OHG questa 'tuft', ON kvistr 'branch', Slav. *gvozdь 'wood, forest'.
S.v. տերեւ terev 'Blatt', a loan from Syriac טרפא ṭarpā.

S.v. Ved. parṇá- 'Flügel, Feder, Pfeilfeder, Blatt' (IIr. cf. YAv. parəna- 'Feder', Khot. pārra- 'Flügel', MPers., NPers. parr 'Feder', etc.), probably from PIE *(s)por-no- (cf. OHG farn 'Farn', Lith. spar̃nas 'Flügel, Schaufel, Blatt').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *blada- 'leaf, blade', derived from a strong verb *blōan- 'to bloom', as though from PIE *bʰlh₁-tó-, however the form is an internal Germanic derivation, as PIE *bʰlh₁-tó- would have yielded PGmc. **bulda-.

S.v. TochB pilta 'leaf, petal', which with TochA pält reflects Proto-Tocharian *pältā as if from PIE *bʰl̥h₁t-os- or *bʰelh₁t-os-. The closest relatives appear to be in Germanic, e.g. OE blæd 'leaf, blade', OHG blat, etc. as though from PIE *bʰl̥h₁-tó-.

S.v. folium, -ī 'feuille'. There are two possible etymologies. Either (1) with Germanic and Greek words for 'leaf' from *bʰel- (cf. /cognate/252/) or (2) to be connected with Celtic words (Ir. duille, duillen, etc.) from *dʰal- (cf. /cognate/1025/).
S.v. folium 'leaf', from PIE *dʰolH-io-, connecting the Italic forms with W. dail 'foliage' and Gk. θάλλω 'to flourish, grow'. Otherwise often compared with Gk. φύλλον 'leaf' < *bʰol-io-.

The IE root etymology for this class is disputed. It seems equally plausible that the Italic forms from Lat. folium can go with either the Germanic and Greek words for 'leaf' from *bʰleh₃- in /cognate/252/, or with the Celtic words for 'leaf' from *dʰal(h₁)- in /cognate/1025/; cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:244; {ref de Vaan 2008}:230.
Cf. s.v. *dʰalh₁- 'herausquellen, hervorsprießen' (IEW 234).
S.v. Lith. lãpas 'leaf, sheet, metal plate', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *lop-, cf. Proto-Slavic *lopъ > Bulg. lop 'tulip-like aquatic plant in lake Ohrid, white water lily'.

The etymology of kal is not entirely clear. The most probable hypothesis is to assume a relationship to Greek πηλόσ 'mud, clay' and a PIE form *qʷālos. However, the Greek word can be related to Latin palleō 'go pale' with an initial *p- and not kʷ-. The comparisons to Latin squāus and Old Indic kāla- are less probable.
All existing etymologies are somehow dubious. However, the relationship to Greek πηλός and hence a PIE root reconstruction *kʷeh₂l- seem to be the most reasonable.
Cf. s.v. 1. *u̯elH- 'stark sein, Gewalt haben' (IEW 1111-2).

PS *velĭ is most probably a reflex of PIE *u̯elH- 'be strong, have power, rule' and related to Old Nordic olla '(he) ruled', Latin valēre 'be strong', and Tocharian A walo, Tocharian B wäl 'king'. A relationship to PIE *u̯el- 'push, squeeze, turn' and Greek ἅλις is less likely.
S.v. Ved. savyá- 'link, linke Hand' (cf. in Ir. YAv. haoiia- 'link', MPers., Parth. hwy 'link, linke, Hand'), from PIE *(H)seu̯i̯o-, cf. ORuss. šujь 'link'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *šujь 'left', from PIE *seu-io- (cf. Skt. savyá-; Av. haoya-; MW aswy; MW aseu).

S.v. TochB saiwai 'left'. Related in some way to Skt. savyá-, Av. haoya-, OCS šujь 'left', perhaps with metathesis from PIE *sowyo- or with contamination with the predecessors of Gk. σκαι(ϝ)ός, Lat. scaevus, and laevus 'left'.
S.v. 3832 Skt. kharvá- (RV. ákharva) 'mutilated, imperfect'.

Cf. s.v. Gk. σκαιός 1 'left, western', from PIE *skeh₂-i-uo- which is formally and semantically identical with Lat. scaeuus 'left, inauspicious'; possibly identical with σκαιός 2 'shady' (cf. σκία 'shadow' /cognate/5058/).
Tsakonian: Peloponnese σ̌οβλέ < AG στρεβλός.
S.v. στρεβλός 'turned, twisted, crooked, cunning'. Similar to στρέφω 'turn' with a different labial, but variants with prenasalisation and -ιλ- suffix may be indicative of a non-Greek origin.
S.v. majtë ~ mâjtë 'left', borrowed from Rom. *manctus, based on Lat. mancus 'maimed, infirm'; cf. It. manca 'left hand'.
S.v. vā́maḥ 'left'. Etymology not convincingly explained.
S.v. *ped- 'treten; fallen, sinken' (LIV² 458, IEW 790ff.).

S.v. ποῦς, ποδός 'foot' < PIE *pod-. The Greek form has generalised o-grade ablaut throughout the nominal paradigm, but the e-grade is attested in some other derivative forms: πέδη 'fetter, shackles', πέζα 'instep', πέζος 'walker, footsoldier', πέδον 'soil, earth, ground', πέδλιον 'sandal', πεδά 'after, with, amidst'. A zero-grade is also attested in ἐπίβδα 'the day after a festival'.

S.v. TochB paiyye 'foot', TochA peṃ and TochB *peine must represent an older dual form *pei to which the dual ending *-ne has been added. This Proto-Tocharian *pei is the phonologically expected reflex of PIE dual *póde (cf. Gk. πόδε) of the PIE word for foot *ped-/*pod-.
S.v. Arm. *ot- 'foot'. The Armenian singulative ot-n reflects the PIE acc. *pód-m̥, from PIE *ped-/*pod- 'foot'.
S.v. Ved. pád- 'Fuß'. In Ir. cf. YAv. pad-, OPers. pāda-, Khot. päa-, Parth. p'd-, etc. From PIE *ped- (~ *pod-, *pd-) 'Fuß' (cf. Arm. ot-, Gk. πούς, OEng. fēt, Lat. pēs, ped-is, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fōt- 'foot', from PIE *pōd- (cf. Hitt. pāt- ~ pat-, Skt. pā́t, pad-, YAv. pad-, OPers. pāda-, Arm. otn, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fōt- 'foot', from PIE *pōd- (cf. Hitt. pāt- ~ pat-, Skt. pā́t, pad-, YAv. pad-, OPers. pāda-, Arm. otn, etc.).
S.v. Arm. *ot- 'foot'. The Armenian singulative ot-n reflects the PIE acc. *pód-m̥, from PIE *ped-/*pod- 'foot'.
S.v. Ved. pád- 'Fuß'. In Ir. cf. YAv. pad-, OPers. pāda-, Khot. päa-, Parth. p'd-, etc. From PIE *ped- (~ *pod-, *pd-) 'Fuß' (cf. Arm. ot-, Gk. πούς, OEng. fēt, Lat. pēs, ped-is, etc.).
S.v. Lat. pēs, pedis 'foot', from PIE nom.sg. pōd-s, acc. po/ed-m, loc.sg. ped-i.
S.v. Lat. pēs, pedis 'foot', from PIE nom.sg. pōd-s, acc. po/ed-m, loc.sg. ped-i.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *saiH- 'to lie down, go to sleep', from PIE *k̑ei̯h₁- 'to lay, lie'.
S.v. *su̯ep- 'einschlafen' (IEW 1048-9).

S.v. Lat. iaciō, -ere 'to throw', from PIE *(H)ieh₁- (aor.), from which the present stem *(H)ih₁-k-(i-) 'to throw, let go'. Lat. iacēre 'lie' can be interpreted as the stative counterpart of iaciō 'to throw' with a semantic development 'to be thrown down' > 'to lie'.
Fr. coucher from Lat. collocare 'hinlegen, aufstellen'.

S.v. Lat. locus 'place', from which Lat. locāre 'to place, award, hire out' is a derived verb. Earlier sources (e.g. IEW) derive locus from the root *stel- 'to place', but this does not make sense morphologically as there is no suffix *-oko- which may derive a stem *stloko-. The etymology remains otherwise unclear.
Cf. s.v. *sengʷ- 'herunterfallen, untergehen, sinken' (IEW 906).
Cf. s.v. ənkenum 'to cause to fall, throw down', from PIE *sengʷ- (cf. Goth. sigqan).
S.v. *peth₁- 'fallen' (IEW 825-826). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into a single root *pet-.
S.v. πίπτω 'to fall (off), drop down, fall out' < PIE *petH- 'fly, fall'.
S.v. TochB lyäk- 'lie, lie down', from PIE *legʰ- 'lie (down)' (cf. Gk. λέχεται 'he sleeps', Goth. ligan 'lie', OCS ležǫ 'lie', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic ležati 'lie', stative version of Proto-Slavic legti 'lie (down)', from PIE *legʰ- (cf. Gk. λέχομαι 'go to sleep', Goth. ligan 'lie').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *leg(j)an- 'to lie', from PIE *leg-ie- (cf. Gk. λέχομαι 'to go to sleep', OIr. laigid 'to lay, lie down', OCS lešti, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *leg-o- 'to lay, lie down', from PIE *legʰ- 'lie'.

S.v. Lith. gulė́ti 'lie, be ill', cf. Lith. gul̃ti 'lie down, fall ill, hang down'. The East Baltic root is circumflex *gul-. A full-grade gval- is also attested via gvaldýti 'cram, pack', from which we may be dealing with a PIE root *gu̯el-, but there are no convincing extra-Baltic cognates to support such a reconstruction.
S.v. TochB śāy- 'live', with TochA śo- from Proto-Tocharian *ćaw-, from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃-u̯-e/o-.
S.v. keam 'to live', from PIE *gʷeih₃-, *gʷih₃-, or *gʷh₃i- 'to live'. Arm. keam probably reflects athematic *gʷeih₃-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *žiti 'live', from PIE *gʷh₃i(-u)-.
S.v. Lat. vīvō, -ere 'to live', from PIE *gʷih₃-ue/o- 'to live'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *biwo- 'alive', from PIE *gʷiHu̯o- 'alive'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *libēn- 'to be left; to live', the stative to *līban- 'to stick' which is in turn from PIE *leip- (cf. Gk. λιπαρός 'fat, gleaming (of oil or unguent), Skt. limpáti 'to smear, adhere to, to deceive', Lith. lìpti, Latv. lipt 'to stick', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *bōan- ~ *būan- 'to live, dwell', from PIE *bʰeh₂u-, with an assumed laryngeal metathesis from the weak stem *bʰh₂u-.
S.v. *bʰu̯eh₂- 'wachsen, entstehen, werden' (IEW 146-50). On the formation of the Germanic stem in this class, cf. n31.

S.v. Lat. crūs, -ris '(lower) leg, shank', from Proto-Italic *krūs-, which with Arm. srunkʻ 'calf, shin' could go back to a root *k̑ruH-, but the Armenian word might be a loanword from Iranian *sraun-.
S.v. Lat. camba 'sprunggelenk der Pferde' > Fr. jambe 'Bein'.

S.v. Lat. gamba, -ae 'patte, jarret du cheval et, plus généralement, des quadrupèdes'. A likely borrowing from Greek καμπή 'bending, winding' in the specialised language of Greek veterinarians or breeders.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *lagja- 'leg; hollow bone; stalk', an etymologically unclear North Germanic word.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *lagja- 'leg; hollow bone; stalk', an etymologically unclear North Germanic word. English 'leg' is a loanword from this etymon via its Norse descendent.
S.v. Alb. këmbë ~ kambë 'leg, foot', a loan from Romance *camba ~ *gamba- 'leg'.

S.v. Ved. jánghā- 'unterer Teil des Beines, Unterschenkel, Bein' (cf. YAv. zaṇga- 'Fußknöchel', Oss. zæng, zængæ 'Unterschenkel, Bein, Stiel'), probably a derivative of PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (cf. Goth. gaggan 'gehen', Lith. žeñgti 'schreiten', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (IEW 438-9).
Cf. s.v. Alb. jet 'bleiben, dableiben' pret. intrans., trans. 'warten, empfangen', from PIE *i̯et- 'sich (fest) hinstellen'.
Cf. s.v. *i̯et- 'sich (fest) hinstellen' (IEW 506-7).

S.v. Alb. rri 'sitzen; sich setzen, sich niederlassen; bleiben, verweilen'. It is usually considered to be unexplained, but there is no good reason not to connect it with PIE ?*(h₁)rei̯d- '(sich) anlehnen' (LIV² 503).

S.v. Ved. āntrá- 'Eingeweide', a derivative of Ved. antár- 'inside'. Cf. ántara- 'innerer, im Inneren befindlich, dazwischen stehend, etc.' which is formally cognate with Gk. ἔντερα (cf. YAv. aṇtara- 'innerer').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *librō- 'liver'. Etymology unclear; it may possibly be an irregular continuation of PIE *iekʷ-r/n-, if the Germanic form represents an intermediate form *lipr-eh₂- with unetymological initial *l- and sporadic change of *kʷ > *p in the vicinity of resonants (cf. *fimfe 'five' < *pénkʷe).
Cf. s.v. Lat. fīcus 'fig-tree'. An early Mediterranean loanword, cf. Gk. σῦκον (Boeot. τῦκον), Arm. tʻowz 'fig'.
Cf. s.v. *(s)ker- 'scheren, kratzen, abschneiden' (IEW 938-40).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ (adj.) 'black' < PIE *kr̥s-nó-.

S.v. Arm. leard 'liver', usually connected with PIE *Hiekʷr(-t), *Hiekʷn-ós 'liver'. The initial l- is unexpected, but cf. luc 'yoke' < *i̯ugom. It has been suggested that leard may be connected or has been contaminated with Gk. λιπαρός 'oily, shiny with oil, anointed; fatty, greasy'. A minority view has compared Arm. leard with Hitt. lišši- 'liver'.
S.v. Ved. yákar- (yakn-) 'Leber', from an IE heteroclite stem *Hi̯ekʷ-r-/*Hi̯ekʷ-n- (cf. Gk. ἧπαρ, ἥπατος, Lat. iecur, iocineris, 'Leber', etc.).

Cf. s.v. Lith. jẽknos (OLith., dial.) 'liver', from PIE *iekʷ-r/n- (cf. Skt. yákar- 'liver', Gk. ἧπαρ 'liver'). Other Baltic cognates include Latv. aknas (nom.pl.) 'liver', OPruss. lagno [iagno] 'liver'.
S.v. Lat. iecur 'liver' (gen.sg. iocineris), from PIE *iekʷ-r/n- 'liver'.

Cf. s.v. Arm. leard 'liver'. A minority view has compared Arm. leard with Hitt. lišši- 'liver', but the Armenian lexemes are more usually considered to be connected to PIE *Hiekʷr(-t), *Hiekʷn-ós 'liver' /cognate/718/ with an anomalous development of *i̯- > l-. Cf. entry for further discussion and references to literature.
S.v. mëlçi 'lung, liver', used in phrases mëlçi e bardhë 'lung' and mëlçi e zezë 'liver', originally a word for 'spleen' borrowed from Italian milza.
S.v. 3103 Skt. kālēyaka- m. 'a partic. part of the intestines' Suśr., m. 'liver' lex.

Cf. s.v. Lith. vė́daras 'sausage, (coll.) belly, intestines', from PIE *ud-ero-m (cf. Skt. udára- 'belly, womb', Gk. ὕδερος 'dropsy', Lat. uterus 'belly, womb'). Other cognates in Baltic include Latv. vȩ̂dȩrs 'belly', OPruss. weders 'belly'.
S.v. Span. cumplir, from Lat. complēre 'llenar'. Cf. derived cumplido = Port. cumprido.
Cf. s.v. Lat. -pleō 'to fill' (complēre 'to fill, complete'), from PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill'.
Cf. s.v. *pleh₁- 'sich füllen, voll werden' (IEW 798-800).
S.v. Span. largo, from Lat. largus 'abundante, considerable'.

S.v. Lat. lārgus 'generous, bountiful'. Etymology unclear. The formal derivation and semantics from earlier attempts at an etymology in Walde-Hofmann and Pokorny IEW as though from *lajes-ago- 'carrying fat' are not convincing.
S.v. 10951 Skt. lamba-  'pendent' MBh. ('long' in lamba- karṇa-), lambaka- m. 'plumbline' W.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √ramb- 'schlaff herabhängen (vom Penis). Later √lamb- 'hängt herab (vorwiegend von Körperteilen gesagt)', perhaps to PIE *(s)lembʰ- (cf. Engl. limp, MHG lampen, slampen).
Cf. s.v. *lembH- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 656-7).
S.v. Khot. bulysa- 'long', to Av. bərəzant- 'high', BSogd. βrzʾk, βrz 'long', Waxī vərz, vorz 'long', Pašto ūẓ̌d, etc., from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *mīlo- 'animal', from PIE *meh₁lo- 'small animal' (IEW 724), cf. Gk. μῆλον, OCS malъ 'small'.
Cf. s.v. μῆλον (2) 'small cattle, sheep and goats', from PIE *meh₁lo- 'small cattle'.

S.v. Ved. yūkā- 'Laus' "Mit Bildungen anderer idg. Sprachen wie ahd. lūs = nhd. Laus, kymr. llau, Läuse, lit. liū̃lė Laus u.a. zu verbinden; die formalen Abweichungen (auch in pā. ūkā- f., aškun. wū u.a.) erklären sich durch Sprachtabu. S. die Lit. in KEWA III 25, 784 und bei Karulis II 459."
PIE *u̯el- 'to force, press', related to Latin valeo 'be strong, healthy', Greek εἰλω 'I force, I press', Tocharian A wäl 'prince, emperor'. It can be also linked to OCS velěti 'want, order'.

S.v. Ved. vīrá- 'Mann, kraftvoller Mann, Held, Sohn' (in Ir. OAv., YAv. vīra- 'Mann, Mensch', Sogd. wyr 'Ehemann', MPers. wīr 'Mann, Held', etc.), from PIE *u̯iHró- 'jugendkräftig, (junger) Mann, Krieger' (cf. Lith. výras 'Mann, Gatte', Latv. vir̃s 'Mann', Lat. uir, OIr. fer, Goth. wair 'Mann', etc.).
S.v. Lith. výras 'man', from PIE *uiHró- (cf. Skt. vīrá-, Lat. vir, OIr. fer, Goth. wair).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *wira- 'man', from PIE *uiH-ró- (cf. Skt. vīrá-, Av. vīra-, Lith. výras, Lat. vir, OIr. fer 'man, hero', etc.). The Germanic form developed from *u̯īró- by Dybo's Law of pretonic shortening.
S.v. Lat. vir 'man', from PIE *uiH-ró- 'man, young man, warrior' (cf. OIr. fer, Skt. vīrá-, Lith. výras, Goth. wair). The short vowel in Latin is due to Dybo's law.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *wiro- 'man', from PIE *uiHro- 'man' (cf. Skt. vīrá-, Lat. vir, OIr. fer, Goth. wair).
S.v. Alb. dhe 'earth, land', from Proto-Albanian dzō, from PIE *dʰg̑ʰōm 'earth' (cf. Hitt. tekan, TochA tkam, B kem, Skt. kṣam-, Gk. χθών).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *zemļa 'earth, land', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰ-em- (cf. Skt. kṣám- 'earth', Gk. χθών 'earth', Hitt. tēkan 'earth').
S.v. Lith. žẽmė 'earth, land', from PIE *dʰg̑-em- (cf. Skt. kṣám- 'earth', Gk. χθών 'earth', Hitt. tēkan 'earth').

S.v. homō, -inis 'human being, man', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰ(e)m-ōn- (nom.sg.), *dʰg̑ʰm-on-m (acc.sg.) 'earthling, human' (cf. OIr. duine, W. dyn, Co., Bret. den 'man' < Proto-Celtic *doni̯o-; OPruss. smunents, smūnets 'man', OLith. žmuõ 'person', Goth. guma 'man', OHG gomo, OIc. gume).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *gdonyo- 'human, person', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰom-i̯o- 'human, earthling' (cf. Lat. homō, Goth. guma).

S.v. Arm. mard 'man, human being', from PIE *mr̥-tó- 'mortal' (cf. Gk. βροτός 'mortal', Av. maš(ii)a- 'man', Skt. mr̥tá- 'died, dead'. Formally mard could reflect an Iranian loanword, but the voiced -d and the inflection in the Armenian o-stem declension favour a native origin.
S.v. Arm. ayr₁ 'man; husband', to be connected with Gk. ἀνήρ 'man; husband', Skt. nár- 'man, human, hero, warrior', etc. From PIE *h₂ner-.

S.v. Ved. nár- 'Mann, Mensch, Held, Krieger' (in Ir. OAv., YAv. nar- 'Mann', etc.), from PIE *h₂nér- 'Mann' (PIIr. *Hnár-), cf. Gk. ἀνήρ, Arm. ayr, Neo-Phrygian αναρ, Osc. ner-, Welsh ner 'Held', etc.
Cf. s.v. Lat. Nerō (PN) 'Nero', from Proto-Italic *nēr, *ner- 'man', cf. Oscan niir, South Picene nir, Umbrian nerf 'man', from PIE *h₂nēr (nom.sg.) 'man'.
S.v. Alb. njeri 'man, person, human being', from Proto-Albanian *nera and to be connected with Skt. nár- 'man', Gk. ἀνήρ 'man', Arm. ayr 'man'.

S.v. AGk. ἄνθρωπος 'man'; it resembles Hitt. antuu̯aḫḫaš, antuḫš- 'man', but this is superficial since the Hittite word can be derived from *h₁en-dʰu(e)h₂-s- 'having breath/spirit inside'. No IE explanation has been found, so the word is probably of substratum origin.
The Mycenaean attestation of a-to-ro-qo [antʰró̞ːkʷo-] necessitates postulating a labiovelar *-kʷ- in the Proto-Greek form.
S.v. pesna-, pisna-, pisena-, piseni- (c.) ‘man, male’, cognate with Lat. pēnis < *pesni-, Ved. pásas-, Gk. πέος, OE faesl, OHG fisal, fasel 'penis'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *kerla- ~ *karla- 'man, freeman', from PIE *g̑erh₂-ol-, (cf. TochB śrāy, pl. śrān- 'adult man' < *g̑erh̥₂-n-; Skt. járant- 'old man', Oss. zærond 'old', Arm. cer(un) 'old; old man', Gk. γέρων, -οντος 'old man' < *g̑erh₂-ont-).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *mannan- 'man'. The etymology is disputed. Many scholars connect Proto-Germanic *mannan- with Skt. mánu- and OCS mǫžъ (cf. Ringe 2006:139) /cognate/76/, but underlying *men-u- (not *mon-u-) would have yielded *minn- in Germanic. Consequently Kroonen proposes an alternative etymology as a secondary form of  *guman- /cognate/907/, arising through regular loss of the initial stops of original *dʰg̑ʰm-on-, giving result to a secondary Proto-Germanic root *man-.

The cognacy of these Germanic lexemes are difficult to assign. A majority view of scholars assign them with derivatives of one of the PIE *men- roots in /cognate/76/, alternatively a minority view of scholars places it with other Germanic, Italic, and Celtic words for 'human' < *dʰg̑ʰ-mon- *'earthling' /cognate/907/. The cognacy decision for these lexemes has therefore been to split these lexemes from the majority class into their own separate class, which has been appropriately indexed to the other existing classes.
On the proposed cognacy of the Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *mannan- to this class, cf. the notes in /cognate/8248/.
On the proposed cognacy of the Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *mannan- to this class, cf. the notes in /cognate/8248/.

Cf. s.v. TochB śwāl* 'food', from TochB śu- 'eat', cf. TochA śwāl 'meat'. Cf. also s.v. TochB śu- 'eat (at); consume, devour', where TochA & TochB śuwa- reflect Proto-Tocharian *ćäuwā- from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂- (cf. Pers. jāvīdan, OCS žьvati 'to chew', Lith. žiáunos (f.pl.) 'jaws', OEng. cēowan (> Engl. chew)).
Cf. s.v. *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'kauen' (IEW 400).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *mati- 'food', an old i-stem, the basis for the factitive in Goth. matjan 'to eat'. If connected with Gk. μεστός, it possibly continues an PIE root *med- 'to satiate'. Older proposed connections with Skt. mándati 'to rejoice, get intoxicated', Gk. μαδάω 'to drip, melt, be moist', Lat. madeō 'be wet' are erroneous.
S.v. TochB mīsa 'meat, flesh', from PIE *memseh₂-, the plural to PIE *memsom (nt.) (cf. Skt. māṃsá- 'flesh, meat', Arm. mis 'id.', OPruss. mensā, Alb. mish 'id.', Goth. mimz 'id.').
S.v. Arm. mis 'flesh, meat', connected with the PIE word for 'meat' *mēmso- (cf. Skt. māṃsá-, Goth. mimz, OCS męso, OPruss. menso, mensā, TochB mīsa, Alb. mish, etc.).
S.v. Alb. mish 'flesh, meat', from Proto-Albanian *miša, further to PIE *memso- 'id.' (cf. Skt. mām̆̇sá-, Goth. mimz, Arm. mis, Slav. męso).
S.v. Lith. mėsà 'flesh, meat', from PIE *mēms- (cf. Skt. mām̆̇sá- 'flesh, meat'; Skt. mā́s- n. 'flesh, meat', Goth. mimz n. 'meat').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *mimza- 'meat', from PIE *mēms-ó- (cf. TochB mīsa, Skt. māṃsá- 'meat', YAv. mā̊ŋhəm 'meat, board', Arm. mis 'flesh, meat', Lat. mēnsa 'table', Alb. mish 'meat' OCS męso, Lith. mėsà, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *(s)kerH- 'trennen, teilen' (IEW 938-40).
S.v. Khot. ggūśta 'flesh, meat', from Iranian *gau-šti- 'produced from bovine'.
S.v. Ved. gáv- 'Rind, Stier, Kuh', from PIE *gʷou̯- (cf. Gk. βοῦς, Umb. bum (acc.sg.), OIr. bó, OHG chuo, Latv. gùovs, TochA ko, TochB keᵤ 'Kuh', Luw. uu̯a-, Lyc. uwa- 'Rind', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Lat. vīvō, -ere 'to live', from PIE *gʷih₃-ue/o- 'to live'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ēskyo- 'moon', from PIE *h₁ei̯sk- 'shine, glitter' (cf. OCS iskra 'spark', Lith. áiškus 'bright', Russ. jáska 'bright star').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic jь̀skra 'spark', not to be connected with the Celtic lexemes.
Cf. s.v. Lith. áiškus 'clear', not to be connected with the Celtic lexemes.
S.v. 5301 Skt. jyṓtsnā f. 'moonlit night' TBr., 'moonlight' MBh. 2.

S.v. Ved. jyótsnā- 'mondhelle Nacht, Mondnacht, Mondschein', formed to Ved. √jyot- 'leuchten', a phonetic variant of √dyot- 'blitzen', a dental-enlarged stem from PIE *di̯eu̯- 'leuchten'. The stem formation of jyótsnā- is probably parallel to Lat. lūna < *lou̯k-s-neh₂-. On the details of the phonetic development *dy- > *jy- cf. the discussion in the etymological notes s.v. √jyot-. Cf. further s.v. Ved. dyav- 'Himmel, Himmelsgott, Vater Himmel, Tag', from PIE *di̯éu̯-/diu̯- 'Himmel, Tag' (also personified 'Himmelsgott'), (cf. Gk. Ζεύς, Lat. *dius in nudius tertius 'vorgestern' < *'und es ist der dritte Tag', from the root *dei̯- 'leuchten'.

S.v. Arm. lusin 'moon', 'month', related to Arm. loys 'light' < PIE *leu̯k-. The Armenian stem formation is either from *loukeno- (cf. Skt. rocaná- 'luminous sphere, firmament') or from *louksneh₂-. Cf. entry for further discussion and references to literature.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *gelo- 'yellow, white', from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' (cf. Lat. heluus 'honey yellow', Gk. χλωρός 'pale green', Skt. harí- 'green', OCS zelenъ 'green', OE geolu 'yellow').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *gelo- 'yellow, white', from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' (cf. Lat. heluus 'honey yellow', Gk. χλωρός 'pale green', Skt. harí- 'green', OCS zelenъ 'green', OE geolu 'yellow').

S.v. meñe 'moon', 'month', along with TochA mañ, reflecting Proto-Tocharian *mẽñẽ from PIE *meh₁nē(n)-. This n-stem was rebuilt on the nominative singular *meh₁nē(t), which was in itself analogical for *meh₁nōt, oblique *meh₁nes- (cf. Beekes 2010:945).

Cf. s.v. Gk. μήν (2) 'month', also 'moon-sickle', from PIE *meh₁nōt, *meh₁n-es-s 'moon, month'. An original derivation from *meh₁- 'measure' from the role of the moon as a measure of time is possible.
*měsę̄cь 'moon, month', from PIE *meh₁n-(e)s- (cf. Skt. mā́s 'moon, month', Gk. μείς (Ion.) 'moon', Lat. mēnsis 'month', Goth. mena 'moon', OHG māno 'moon').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *mēnan- 'moon', from PIE *meh₁n-os- 'moon'.

Cf. s.v. Lat. mēnsis 'month', from Proto-Italic *mēns- 'month, moon' (Umb. abl.sg. menzne 'moon', Marsian loc. or abl. sg. mesene 'month', Umb. gen.pl. anter:menzaru 'new moon'), from PIE *meh₁-n-s-, probably to be derived from *meh₁- 'measure'.

Cf. s.v. ā́rya- 'Arier, Angehöriger der drei oberen Großkasten', which with Ir. *arya- is the historical self-designation of the Indo-Iranian peoples. The etymological interpretation of this lexeme is debated and problematic. Cf. entry for further discussion and references to literature.

Cf. s.v. ῥάχις 'spine, back'. Compared in {ref IEW} 1180 with Lith. ražis 'stubble' for a preform *urag̑ʰ-i-, but the alternation between ϝρᾰχ- / ϝρᾱχ- with *-a-/-ā- ablaut is suspicious from the point of view of Indo-European. Perhaps an early loan from a Pre-Greek source.

S.v. ὀξύς 'sharp, stinging'; 'sour, tartish (of taste)', etc. "Without correspondences outside Greek. It has been compared with ὄκρις, which is an o-grade of the root of ἄκρος, but there are no further examples for u-stem adjectives with o-vocalism. Alternatively, Narten 1986 reconstructs a root *h₃ks- on the strength of the comparison with Skt. akṣṇoti 'to mark the ear', but this is doubtful."
σ̌ίνα < ΑG ῥίς ‘nose’ (Andriotis 174:480) or, more likely, < AG θίς ‘heap, dune’ (the change θ > σ is already Laconian).
S.v. AGk. ῥίς 'Nase' > Tsakon. σ̌ίνα 'Nase; Anhöhe, Berg'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. θίς, θινός 'heap (of sand), beach, dune, shore', without explanation.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *brig- 'hill', from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'be high, hill' (Gaul. -briga [in Toponyms], Brig-antes [Ethnonym]).
S.v. Ved. párvata- adj. 'felsig', m. 'Berg, Gebirge, Fels', from PIE *péru̯n̥to- 'felsig, mit Fels versehen', cf. Hitt. peru- (peruni, dat.-loc.) 'stone' < *perur < *peru̯r̥, *perun-/*peru̯n̥-.
On the proposed cognacy of the Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *mannan- to this class, cf. the notes in /cognate/8248/.

S.v. mánuḥ 'Mensch, Mann, Menschheit', to be connected with Germanic lexemes via Goth. manna, OHG man, etc. and OCS mǫžь, etc. The cognates should thus be derived from one of the PIE *men- roots. However, due to several homophonous *men- roots reconstructable for PIE it is difficult to determine from which one exactly [cf. LIV²: 435-437].

S.v. Proto-Germanic *mannan- 'man'. The etymology is disputed. Many scholars connect Proto-Germanic *mannan- with Skt. mánu- and OCS mǫžъ (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:139) /cognate/76/, but underlying *men-u- (not *mon-u-) would have yielded *minn- in Germanic. Consequently Kroonen proposes an alternative etymology as a secondary form of *guman- /cognate/907/, arising through regular loss of the initial stops of original *dʰg̑ʰm-on-, giving result to a secondary Proto-Germanic root *man-.

The cognacy of these Germanic lexemes are difficult to assign. Cf. the cognacy decisions made for the same lexemes in the meaning set 'man': A majority view of scholars assign them with derivatives of one of the PIE *men- roots in /cognate/76/, alternatively a minority view of scholars places it with other Germanic, Italic, and Celtic words for 'human' < *dʰg̑ʰ-mon- *'earthling' /cognate/907/. The cognacy decision for these lexemes has therefore been to split these lexemes from the majority class into their own separate class, which has been appropriately indexed to the other existing classes.

S.v. Arm. mard 'man, human being', from PIE *mr̥-tó- 'mortal' (cf. Gk. βροτός 'mortal', Av. maš(ii)a- 'man', Skt. mr̥tá- 'died, dead'. Formally mard could be reflect an Iranian loanword, but the voiced -d and the inflection in the Armenian o-stem declension favour a native origin.
S.v. Ved. mártya- 'Sterblicher, Mensch' (cf. Av. maš́iia-, OPers. martiya-) derived to √mar- 'sterben' < PIE *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben'.
Cf. s.v. *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben' (IEW 735).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *guman- 'man', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰm-on- (cf. Lith. žmónės (m.pl.) 'men', Lat. homō 'man' < *dʰg̑ʰm-on-).
On the proposed cognacy of the Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *mannan- to this class, cf. the notes in /cognate/8249/.

Cf. s.v. OLith. žmuõ, žmuõj 'Mensch, Mann' (BSl. OPr. smoy 'Mann, Mensch'), from PIE *(dʰ)g̑ʰ-m-on- 'Mensch, Mann' (cf. Lat. homō, -inis 'Mensch, Mann', Osc. humuns 'Mensch', Umbr. homonus 'id.', Goth. guma 'Mensch, Mann', ON gumi 'id.', OHG gomo 'id.').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *gdonyo- 'human, person', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰom-i̯o- 'human, earthling' (cf. Lat. homō, Goth. guma).
The Mycenaean attestation of a-to-ro-qo [antʰró̞ːkʷo-] necessitates postulating a labiovelar *-kʷ- in the Proto-Greek form.
S.v. Alb. njeri 'man, person, human being', from Proto-Albanian *nera and to be connected with Skt. nár- 'man', Gk. ἀνήρ 'man', Arm. ayr 'man'.
S.v. *h₂nér-/*h₂nr-´ m. 'Mann' (IEW 765).

S.v. Ved. √darś- 'sehen, Medium erscheinen, aussehen, sich zeigen' (cf. OAv. darəsānī 'ich werde erblicken', darəsəm 'ich erschaue, etc.), from PIE *derk̑- 'einen Blick auf etwas werfen' (cf. Gk. δέρκομαι 'sehe, blicke', OIr. derc 'Auge', Goth. ga-tarhjan 'kennzeichnen', OEng. torht 'klar, hell').
S.v. vjell 'erbrechen', best connected to PIE 2. *u̯elH- '(sich) wälzen, wallen'.
S.v. Alb. vjell 'to vomit', from Proto-Albanian *welwa- and related to Lat. volvō 'to turn' and other cognates.

S.v. Ved. svetá- 'weiß, hell' (cf. YAv. spaēta- 'white', OPers. *sai̯ta-), from PIE *k̑u̯ei̯tó- (cf. OCS světъ 'φῶς', Germ. xu̯ei̯ta- 'weiß' in Goth. ƕeits, ONor. hvítr, OHG (h)wīz, etc.). Based on the verbal root *k̑u̯ei̯t- (cf. Lith. švintù, švìsti 'hell werden, aufleuchten', OCS svьtěti (sę) 'leuchten, scheinen').
Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯ei̯t- 'hell aufleuchten' (IEW 628-629).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hwīta- ~ *kwitta- 'white', from PIE *k̑u(e)it-nó- (cf. Skt. śvítna- 'white, whitish' < k̑uit-no-; Skt. śvetá- 'white, bright', YAv. spaēta-, MPers. spēd, NPers. sapēd 'white' < *k̑uoit-o-).
Fr. blanc is a loan from Germanic *blank 'weiß'.
Cf. s.v. 1. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (IEW 104-5).
S.v. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (LIV 68f., IEW 104f.).
S.v. սպիտակ spitak 'weiss', a loan from Middle Iranian (cf. Pahlavi spētak).
Cf. s.v. Vedic pāṇḍú- 'weißlich, gelb, weiß, bleich', further etymology unclear.

S.v. Lith. gailùs 'sharp, bitter, cold, lamentable, cold, angry', Proto-Balto-Slavic *goilos (cf. Latv. gails 'voluptous, slender, without branches, glowing', OPruss. gaylis 'white', OCS dzělъ, Russ. zeló); perhaps to PIE *gʰoi-lo- if comparable with OHG geil 'reckless, frolic, strong'.

S.v. Alb. bardhë 'white', from Proto-Albanian *bardza, continuing *bʰorəg̑o-, a derivative of PIE *bʰerəg̑- 'to shine; white', cf. Skt. bhrājate 'shines, beams, glitters', Goth. bairhts 'light, shining'.
Cf. s.v. *bʰreh₁g̑- 'erstrahlen, erglänzen' (IEW 139-40).

S.v. άσπρος. Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as in the phrase nummi asperi 'rough coins', i.e. new coins which had just been cut and had not yet been worn down from circulation. The semantic development appears to be one via a transferred adjective '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white'.
S.v. ἄσπρος 'rough'. A loanword from Lat. asper.
Following NIL 34-36 we might assume that the two Indic roots in Mayrhofer EWAia II:257-258 go back to the same root *bʰes-.
Pace {ref de Vaan 2008}:115 TochB kentse is to be glossed as 'rust' not 'dust' and the Tocharian cognates proposed there are not to be connected.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *lowtu- 'ash', which may be connected with PIE *leu̯h₃- 'to wash' as a derived noun in the sense of 'washing substance'. Alternatively connected to Proto-Celtic *lutā 'mud, dirt', without the laryngeal.

S.v. Ved. skandhá- 'Schulterknochen', along with Pāli khandha- 'Schulter, Baumstamm, OAv. skəṇdō, probably 'Beschädigung', YAv. skəṇdō 'Gebrechen, Körperschaden', seem to continue a lost IIr. root *skandh- 'brechen, abbrechen'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *fergunja-. An etymologically debated word. Perhaps to *ferhwa- (1) 'oak', *furhwōn- 'fir', or the feminine equivalent to *ferga- 'god' (ON fjǫrg 'gods') with a feminine -unjō suffix, in which case the proto-form could continue *perk⁽ʷ⁾-n-ieh₂- and could perhaps be related to Lith. perkū́nas, Latv. pȩ̄̀rkuôns 'thunder' < *perkʷ-u-Hn-o-.
S.v. 13627 Ved. skandhá m. 'shoulder, upper part of back' AV.; in Si. kan̆da 'shoulder, tree trunk, collection, mass', kan̆du 'mountain' (< -- aka -- ).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fel(e)sa- 'mountain', from PIE *pe/ol-es-o- (cf. OIr. ail 'boulder, rock gravestone' < *pl-s-i-; Gk. (Hsch.) πέλλα 'stone' < *pel-s-eh₂-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *we-wlo- 'lip' (OIr. bél, MW gwefl). The reconstruction of the Proto-Celtic form is difficult, but the forms are doubtlessly related. No clear etymology outside of Celtic.
S.v. Alb. gojë 'mouth'. From the variant golë is is clear that this is a loanword from It. gola.
S.v. Ved. ā́s- 'Mund, Gesicht, Antlitz', probably from PIE *h₃éh₁-s-, *h₃éh₁-es- (cf. YAv. āh- 'Mund', Hitt. ai̯is-, Lat. ōs, OIr. ā 'Mund').
Either to *h₃eh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'Mund' (IEW 784f., EIEC 387), or to ?*h₃óu̯st-ó- 'Mund, Lippe' (IEW 785, EIEC 387).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ūsta 'mouth', from Balto-Slavic *oust- (or *aust-?), from PIE *Hous-t- (*h₂/h₃eus-t-?), cf. Skt. óṣṭha- 'upper lip'.
S.v. Lat. ōs, ōris 'mouth', from PIE *h₃eh₁-os, -es- 'mouth' (cf. OIr. á 'mouth', Hitt. aiš- / išš- 'mouth', CLuw. āaš- 'mouth', Skt. ā́s- 'mouth', Av. āh-).
S.v. bucca, -ae 'bouche'. Perhaps of Celtic origin, cf. beccus 'beak', a Gaulish loanword, and proper names Buccus, Buccō, Bucciō of Celtic origin.

S.v. OLith. burnà 'Mund, Maul' (BSl. Latv. pur̂ns, pur̃ns, pur̂na 'Schnauze, Rüssel', Bulg. bъ́rna, bъ́rla 'Lippe', Sloven. brnẹ́ti, ím 'summen, brummen', IE cf. Arm beran, G.sg. beroy', OIr. bern 'Lücke, Öffnung, Kluft'). The Latvian forms with voiceless p- is attributed to influence from pur̃slas, pur̂slas 'Schauze, Maul'. The Balto-Slavic forms appear to reflect a zero-grade, while Armenian beran a full-grade. The vocalism of the Celtic word is difficult to determine. Since PIE roots cannot end in two resonants, the nasal in Lith. burnà and its extra-Baltic correspondences is of suffixal origin. Consequently attempts at further connections are made in the literature to, for example, Lat. forō, -āre 'bohren', OHG borōn, OS boron 'bohren'.
S.v. բերան beran 'Mund', connected with Lith. burnà 'Mund', OIr. bern 'Kluft'.

S.v. Lith. burnà 'mouth, face' (Latv. pur̂ns 'snout'), cf. Proto-Slavic *bъrna 'snout' (Sloven. bŕna 'carnival mask depicting an animal'; Bulg. bắrna (dial.) 'lip', Maced. brna 'nose ring (of animals)', IE beran 'mouth'. The root can be reconstructed as a zero-grade *bʰrH-, which may be identical with Lat. forāre, OHG borōn 'perforate'. The inital p- of Latv. pur̂ns 'snout' is usually attributed to a Finnic substratum. If, however, Slovak perna 'lip' is connected to the Baltic words, then the Indo-European reconstruction is in doubt.

S.v. TochB mekwa '(finger/toe) nails'. TochA maku and TochB mekwa reflect Proto-Tocharian *mekwā, with assimilation from earlier *nekwā. To be connected with PIE *h₃nogʷʰ- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw', Lat. unguis 'nail', OEng. nægl 'nail', Skt. áṅghri- 'foot', Lith. nagà 'foot', OCS noga 'foot', etc.).

S.v. Lith. nagà 'hoof, nail' (cf. Latv. nagas Npl. 'both hands, hands and feet', OPruss. nage 'foot'), from PIE *h₃n(o)gʷʰ- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').

S.v. Lith. nagà 'hoof, nail' (cf. Latv. nagas Npl. 'both hands, hands and feet', OPruss. nage 'foot'), from PIE *h₃n(o)gʷʰ- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').

Cf. s.v. OLith. nãgas 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf' (BSl. Latv.
 nags 'Finder- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf', OPr. mage 'Fuß'), from PIE *h₃nógʷʰ-/*h₃n̥gʷʰ- 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle' (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ, -υχος, Lat. unguis, OIr. ingen, ON nagl, OE nægel, etc.).
S.v. Arm. ełungn 'nail', derived from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ- or *h₃nogʰ-u- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'talon, claw, nail', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *nogъtь 'nail, claw', a derivative of PIE *h₃nogʷʰ- (cf. Skt. nakhá- 'nail, claw', Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG 'nagal' 'nail').

S.v. Lith. nagà 'hoof, nail' (cf. Latv. nagas Npl. 'both hands, hands and feet', OPruss. nage 'foot'), from PIE *h₃n(o)gʷʰ- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *nagl- 'nail', from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ-l-o- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail', Arm. ełungn 'nail', OPruss. nage 'foot', Lith. nãgas 'nail, claw', OCS noga 'foot, leg' < *h₃nogʷʰ-; Lat. unguis, 'nail, OIr. ingen 'nail' < *h₃ngʷʰ-).
S.v. Lat. unguis 'finger-nail, claw', from PIE *h₃ngʰ-u- 'nail'. The PIE u-stem was remade into an i-stem in Latin.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *angʷīnā 'nail', from PIE *h₃nogʰu-, gen. *h₃ngʰ-eu-s 'nail'. In Celtic the zero-grade stem of the oblique cases was generalised.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *angʷīnā 'nail', from PIE *h₃nogʰu-, gen. *h₃ngʰ-eu-s 'nail'. In Celtic the zero-grade stem of the oblique cases was generalised.

S.v. TochB ñem* 'name', which along with TochA ñom reflect Proto-Tocharian *ñēmä, as though from PIE *h₁nēmn̥, a variant of the more usual *h₁nōmn̥ (cf. Skt. nā́ma, Av. nāma, Gk. ὄνομα, Arm. anun, etc.).
S.v. Arm. anun 'name; fame', connected to the IE words for name (Gk. ὄνομα, Lat. nōmen, Skt. nā́man-, Goth. namo, OCS imę, etc.), from PIE *h₃éh₃-mn.
S.v. Alb. emër ~ emën 'name', from Proto-Albanian *enmen- or *inmen, from PIE *(o)noHmn̥.

S.v. Ved. nā́man- 'Name, Benennung, Kennzeichen, Wesen, Eigentumlichkeit', from PIE *Hnéh₃-men- (in paradigmatic ablaut with *Hnh₃-mn-, *Hnh₃-mon-), cf. Gk. ὄνομα (Dor. ενυμα- in personal names, Hom. νώνυμ[ν]ος 'nameless'), Arm. anown, Lat. nōmen, Goth. namo, OIr. ainm, OCS imę, Hitt. lāman- TochB ñem, TochA ñom, etc. 'Name'.
S.v. OPruss. emmens. The Anlaut of the Old Prussian form points to an original zero-grade *h₃nh₃-men-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *jьmę 'name', from PIE *h₃nh₃-men- (cf. Skt. nā́man-, Gk. ὄνομα, Lat. nōmen, etc.).

S.v. Lat. nōmen 'name', from PIE *h₃neh₃-mn, *h₃nh₃-men- 'name' (cf. OIr. ainm, Hitt. lāman, HLuw. álaman-, Skt. nā́man-, Av. nāman-, Gk. ὄνομα, Phryg. onoman, Arm. anown, Alb. emër (< *emën); TochA ñom, TochB ñem, OPruss. emmens, OCS imę, Goth. namo, OE nama, OIc. nafn).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *anman- 'name', from PIE *h₃nomn 'name' (cf. Hitt. lāman-, Skt. nā́man-, Lat. nōmen, Gk. ὄνομα, Goth. namo, OPruss. emmens, Russ. ímja, Alb. emër, TochB ñom, Arm. anun).

Certain details of the reconstruction of the PIE word are disputed (cf. Stüber 1998:53-59), but a general shape *Hneh₃-mn̥ with different ablaut variants of the root and suffix tend to be agreed upon. Debate on the identity of the initial laryngeal as *h₁ or *h₃ hinge on interpretation of the Doric Greek forms in ἐνυμα- versus the ὄνομα forms more commonly found elsewhere.
S.v. Ved. aṁhú-, only in aṁhú-bhédi- 'engspaltig', from PIE *h₂eNg̑ʰ-ú-, (cf. Lat. angi- in angi-portus, Goth. aggwu, OCS ǫzъkъ).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *angwu- 'narrow', from PIE h₂emg̑ʰ-ú- (cf. Skt. aṃhú- 'narrow', MP hnzwg- 'id.', Arm. anj-uk 'narrow, difficult', OCS ǫzъkъ 'narrow'; OIr. cumung, < *(kom-)h₂emg̑ʰ-u-).

S.v. Lat. angō, -ere 'to strangle, to choke', from which Lat. angustus 'narrow' is a derived adjective. Lat. angō goes back to PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-e/o- 'to tie, tighten', whereas angustus is as if from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-os-to- 'characterised by narrowness'.
S.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (IEW 42-3).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *angu- and *kom-angu- 'narrow', from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-u- 'tight, narrow, contricted' (cf. Skt. aṃhú- 'narrow', Lat. angō 'strangle', OHG engi 'narrow', OCS ǫzъkъ).

S.v. Lat. stringō, -ere 'to bind fast, tighten; to strip off'. The simplex verb stringō has two different meanings (1) 'to tie, tighten', and (2) 'to strip off; bare; to scratch, shave, etc.'. It appears that this was a merger of two different PIE verbs, *strig- 'to brush, strip', and *strengʰ- 'to tie'.
Cf. s.v. 1. *strei̯g- 'streichen' (IEW 1028) and *strengʰ- 'zusammendrehen' (IEW 1036-7).

S.v. Proto-Slavic těsnъ 'narrow', from the same stem as Proto-Slavic *tiskati 'press, squeeze'. This reflects either *teiH- or *teh₁i-, but such proposed roots cannot be easily linked to non-Slavic forms.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *koylo- 'thin'. Perhaps from PIE *koi̯Hlo- if connected with Latv. kaîls 'naked, bold', but the reconstruction is uncertain and the semantic comparison is not very good.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small', probably an o-grade adjective related to Nw. smula 'to grind' < *smulēn-. Further connections unclear.
S.v. Lith. siaũras 'narrow, tight', plausibly derivable from PIE *seu̯-ro- to the root *seu̯- 'press, squeeze' (cf. Skt. sunóti, Av. hunaoiti).
Cf. s.v. ?*seu̯- 'auspressen' (IEW 912). Cf. n1 "verbal nur iir., weitere Verwandte unsicher, vgl. EWAia II 713-4".

S.v. naræg 'тонкий, узкий, тесный, тесния, ущелье', from Proto-Indo-Iranian *nāraka- (cf. Skt. naraka-). Abaev connects the root to the Germanic words cognate with Engl. 'narrow' from a possible PIE *(s)ner- on the basis of IEW p.974.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. There are some proposed possible cognates in Baltic, but these comparisons depend on the internal semantic reconstruction of Proto-Germanic *narwa-, cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:421, {ref Kroonen 2013}:383. The proposed cognacy to the Baltic lexemes is rejected by {ref ALEW} s.v. OLith. *nérti (II). In the Iranic literature, the Germanic forms are sometimes connected to Indo-Iranian *nāraka- < PIE *ner- following {ref IEW} 976, however this view is not followed in the most recent etymological dictionaries (cf. {ref EWAia} II:37 s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt'); cf. further discussion in /cognate/3247/.

Abaev follows {ref IEW} 976 in connecting the Germanic lexemes in /cognate/2810/ with Indo-Iranian *nāraka-, but this is not followed by the most recent etymological dictionaries (cf. {ref EWAia} II:37 s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt'). The connection of Greek ἔνερθεν is suggestive of a root with initial *h₁-.
S.v. Alb. ngushtë 'narrow', a loanword from Lat. angustus.
S.v. āruddha 'blocked' pp. of ā́ruṇaddhi RV.
S.v. Ved. √rodh-¹ 'hemmen, hindern', probably related to IE *leu̯dʰ- (cf. Welsh arlludd 'obstacle', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *lowdo- 'obstacle' (MIr. lod 'fence'(?), MW lludd 'obstacle', MBret. luz 'obstacle', from PIE *lou̯dʰ-o- (cf. Skt. rudh- 'hinder', ródhas- 'obstacle').
S.v. 13264 Skt. saru- 'fine' lex.
S.v. Skt. saruḥ 'minute, fine'. Etymology unclear.
S.v. 12828 Skt. saṁkula- 'crowded together, dense, disordered', n. 'battle' MBh., 'crowd'.
S.v. saṁkulaḥ 'full, filled with, abounding in', probably from kírati 'pours out, spreads, throws' probably to TochB kär- 'abschneiden' and perhaps Gk. σκαίρω, MHG scher(e)n, but not fully clear.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *þrinhan- 'to press' from PIE *trénkʷ-e- (cf. Lith. treñkti 'to bump, hit' < *trenk-ie-). According to Kroonen ON þryngva < *þringwan- points to a root *trenkʷ- with a labiovelar. In West Germanic the original verb *þrinhan- was replaced by *þringan- (cf. OHG dringan, NHG dringen).
Cf. s.v. *trenk- 'drängen' (IEW 1093-4).
S.v. Ved. nábhya- 'Nabe des Rades' (Av. nāfa- 'Nabel, Ursprung, Blutsverwandtschaft' MPers. nāfag, etc.), from PIE *h₃nebʰ-/*h₃nobʰ-/*h₃n̥bʰ- 'Nabel, usw.' (cf. Gk. ὀμφαλός, Lat. umbilīcus, etc.).
S.v. OPruss. nabis 'navel' from PIE *h₃nebʰ- (cf. Skt. nā́bhi- 'Navel', Gk. ὀμφαλός 'navel; umbilical cord', Lat. umbilīcus 'navel, centre', OHG naba 'nave', nabalo, nabulo 'navel').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *nablan- 'navel', as though from PIE *h₃nobʰ-l-on- (cf. Gk. ὀμφαλός < *h₃mbʰ-l̥-, Lat. umbilīcus < *h₃mbʰ-e/ol- + *-īko-, OIr. imbliu 'navel' < *h₃mbʰ-el-ion-).
S.v. umbilīcus 'navel, centre', from PIE *h₃nebʰ-(e/o)l- 'navel'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ambliyon- 'navel', generalised from the oblique stem of the PIE word for 'navel' *h₃nbʰ-l-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *balgi- 'skin bag', from PIE *bʰolg̑ʰ-i-, an i-stem related to PGmc. *belgan- 'swell' < *bʰelg̑ʰ- (cf. Skt. barhíṣ- 'bundle of straw' Av. barəziš- 'pad, pillow' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-is-, OPruss. balsinis 'pillow' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-ino-, etc.).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *balgi- 'skin bag', from PIE *bʰolg̑ʰ-i-, an i-stem related to PGmc. *belgan- 'swell' < *bʰelg̑ʰ- (cf. Skt. barhíṣ- 'bundle of straw' Av. barəziš- 'pad, pillow' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-is-, OPruss. balsinis 'pillow' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-ino-, etc.).
Cf. s.v. bʰelg̑ʰ- 'schwellen' (IEW 125-6).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *bolgo- 'sack, bag, stomach', from PIE *bʰolg̑ʰ- 'skin bag, bolster' (cf. Av. barəziš- 'bolster, cushion', OE belg 'stomach', OPr. balsinis 'cushion', Croat. dial. blàzina 'pillow'). Ultimately derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ-.
S.v. TochB kele 'navel, umbilicus; center', from PIE *kʷolo-, a derivative of *kʷel- 'revolve, turn'.
Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-640).

S.v. kërth (adj.) 'crosswise, askew', from which kërthiz 'navel' is derived. Ultimately derived from an adverbial form in -th based on a loanword from Lat. crucem 'cross'. Earlier {ref Meyer 1891}:188 supposed a loanword from Latin cortīna.
S.v. Hitt. nēu̯a- 'new, fresh', from PIE *néuo- (cf. Skt. náva-, Gk. νέος, Lat. novus, OCS novъ 'new').
S.v. TochB ñuwe 'new', which with TochA ñu reflects Proto-Tocharian *ñäwe from PIE *néwo-.
S.v. Arm. նոր nor 'neu', traditionally connected with Greek νεαρός 'young, youthful, tender, fresh', derivatives from PIE *néu̯o-.
S.v. Ved. náva- 'neu-, frisch, jung', from PIE *néu̯o- 'neu, jung'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *novъ 'new', from PIE *neuos (cf. Skt. náva- 'new, fresh, young', Gk. νέος, Lat. novus, Goth. niujis).
S.v. Lith. naũjas 'new', from PIE *neuios, *neuos.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *neuja- 'new', from PIE *neu-io- (cf. Skt. návya- 'new', OIr. núae, Lith. naũjas, etc.).
S.v. Lat. novus 'new', from PIE *neuo- 'new, young', *neuio- 'new'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *nowyo- 'new', from PIE *neuos 'new'.
S.v. Alb. ri 'new, young, recent', from Proto-Albanian *rija, a zero-grade derivative of IE *er- ~ *or- 'to rise, to make move'.
Cf. s.v. *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-9).
S.v. Alb. natë 'night', from Proto-Albanian *nakti- corresponding to IE *nokʷt- (cf. Skt. nakt-, Gk. νύξ, Lat. nox, etc.).

S.v. Ved. nakt- 'Nacht' (YAv. upa.naxtar- 'an die Nacht angrenzend', Wakhi naγd 'Nacht'), from PIE *nókʷt-s (nom.sg.) ~ nékʷt-s 'Nacht', perhaps assimilated from *ne/ogʷ-t-, cf. Hitt. ne-ku-[uz]-zi 'wird Abend' < *negʷ-ti. Cf. Hitt. nekuz (gen.sg.) 'of the evening', Gk. νύξ (νύκτ-), Lat. nox (noct-), Goth. nahts, Lith. naktìs, OCS noštь, etc. 'Nacht'.

Cf. s.v. *negʷ- 'dunkel werden, dämmern' (IEW 762-3). As a verbal root only Hittite (Hitt. nekuzzi 'es wird dunkel, es dämmert' < *negʷ-/n̥gʷ-). Cf. n1 regarding the derived t-stem *nógʷt-/*négʷt- 'Abend, Nacht'.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. neku- 'to become evening', reconstructing the original root alternatively as *negʷʰ- on the basis of Gk. ἔννυχος 'nightly' and the Hitt. velar <-ku->.
S.v. Lith. naktìs 'night', from PIE *nokʷ-t- (cf. Skt. nákt-, Hitt. nekuz [gen.sg.] 'in the evening', Gk. νύξ, Lat. nox, Goth. nahts).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *noktь 'night', from PIE *nokʷ-t- (cf. Skt. nákt-, Hitt. nekuz [gen.sg.] 'in the evening', Gk. νύξ, Lat. nox, Goth. nahts).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *naht- 'night', from PIE *nokʷ-t- (cf. Hitt. nekuz 'in the evening' < *nekʷ-t-s; Gk. νύξ, νυκτός 'night', Lat. nox, noctis 'id.', Lith. naktìs 'id.', OCS noštь 'id.' < *nokʷ-t-).
S.v. Lat. nox 'night', from PIE *nógʷʰ-t-s (nom.sg.), négʷʰ-t-s (gen.sg.) 'night', following the root reconstruction of Kloekhorst (2008:602).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *noxtV- 'night', from PIE *nokʷt- 'night' (cf. Hitt. nekuz (mēhur) 'at the time of night', Skt. nákt-, Gk. νύξ, Lat. nox, Lith. naktìs, OCS noštь, Alb. natë, TochB nekcīye 'at night'). Matasović considers the Middle Welsh nos a loanword from Lat. nox., but cf. {ref Falileyev 2000}:121 who considers it inherited.
S.v. Ved. rā́trī- 'Nacht'. Originally an epithet to either nákt- or kṣap- and probably to be analysed as rā́-tr-ī *'still machende, beruhigende' to √rā-³ 'ruhen, still sein', PIE *(H)reh₁-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *vȅčerъ 'evening' from PIE *uekspero- (cf. Gk. ἕσπερος, Lat. vesper, MW ucher, Arm. giser).

Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος 'evening', an inherited word for 'evening' from *u̯e-kʷsp-er-o- *'towards the night, evening' (cf. Lat. vesper 'evening'). Element *-kʷsp- 'night' from PIE *kʷsep- 'spend the night' (cf. Ved. kṣáp- 'night').

While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form for this class, we have followed the analysis of {ref Beekes 2010}:470-471) s.v. ἕσπερος, cf. also {ref Beekes 2004}. Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. {ref LIPP 2} s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-.
Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯es- '(ver)weilen, die Nacht verbringen' (IEW 72, 1170-1).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *nabja- 'beak'. No clear extra-Germanic cognates. "Some have compared the word to *nabO- 'nave' < *h3nobh-eh2- through a meaning 'protuberance, knob' (cf. Magnusson 1989: 662). Another potential lead is Gaul. nebba 'bill' as recorded by Pliny (thus already Kilian 1599: 334), but the word is not attested in the later Celtic languages."
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *srognā- 'nose'; the relationship of Welsh trwyn, OCo. trein, which appear to be from *trognī, to Proto-Celtic *srognā 'nose' is unclear.

Cf. s.v. ῥύγχνος 'snout of a pig, snout, beak'. Gk. ῥύγχνος can be hardly separated from Arm. ṙng-un-kʻ 'nostrils, nose', which if inherited must go back to IE *srungʰ- or *sringʰ- (with secondary nasalisation). Possibly also connected to ῥέγκω 'snore'.
S.v. Alb. hundë 'nose', from Proto-Albanian *skuntā, from skuna > hu (after Meyer 1891:153-154).
S.v. Ved. nás- 'Nase' (YAv. nā̊ŋha), from PIE *(H)nas- (cf. Lat. nāris, Lith. nósis, OHG nasa, Russ.-CS nosъ 'Nase', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *nosъ 'nose', following Kortlandt (1985b:119) from PIE *nh₂-es-/*neh₂-s- (cf. Skt. nás-, Lat. nāris, OHG nasa 'nose').
S.v. Lith. nósis, following Kortlandt (1985b:119) from PIE *nh₂-es-/*neh₂-s- (cf. Skt. nás-, Lat. nāris, OHG nasa 'nose').
S.v. Lat. nāris 'nose; pl. nostrils, nose', from PIE *Hneh₂-s-, *Hnh₂-es-, *Hnh₂-s- (cf. Skt. nas- 'nose', YAv. nā̊ŋha, (nom.acc.du.?), Lith. nósis, Latv. nãss, RuCS nosъ, OHG nasa, OE nasu 'nose').
Reconstructs a paradigm nom.sg. *neh₂s, acc.sg. *neh₂sm, gen.sg. *nh₂os.

The reconstruction for the PIE form underlying this class is disputed. Traditionally *(H)nas- (cf. IEW 755, Mayrhofer, EWAia s.v. Ved. nás-, ALEW s.v. Lith. nósis), elsewhere Kortlandt (1985b:119) argues for a reconstruction as an s-stem to a root *neh₂-. For the purposes of a root ref. form I give *(H)nā̆s-.
Argues for a derivation of Hitt. mēḫur from a root *meh₂- 'zeitlich passend sein, die/zur rechte(n) Zeit sein'.
Returns to the older etymology for Hitt. mēḫur from PIE *meh₁- 'measure', arguing for a secondary laryngeal epenthesis within Hittite between -e- and -u-.
S.v. Alb. vjetër 'old', a borrowing from Lat. veterem 'old'.

S.v. Arm. hin 'old, ancient, worn-out', from PIE o-stem *seno- 'old' (cf. Skt. sána- 'old', YAv. hana- 'old, grey', Gk. ἕνος 'last year's, old' < *seno-; Lat. senex 'old, aged, old man', senior 'older', etc.).

S.v. Ved. sána- 'alt, ehemalig, früher' (Av. hana- 'alt, greis'), from PIE *séno- (cf. Gk. ἕνος 'alt, vom vorigen Jahr', Arm. hin 'alt', OIr. sen 'alt', Lith. sẽnas 'Greis', Lett. sens früherm ehemalig').
S.v. Lith. sẽnas 'old', from PIE *sen-o- (cf. Skt. sána- 'old'; Lat. senex 'old man'; OIr. sen 'old').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *seno- 'old', from PIE *seno- 'old' (IEW 908), cf. Skt. sána-, Gk. ἕνος, Lat. senex, Goth. sineigs, Lith. sẽnas, Arm. hin.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *furi- 'in front of, for', from PIE *prh₂-i (cf. Gk. παρά. παραί (prep.) 'besides, by, from, next to, alongside', Lat. prae (adv./prep.) 'in front of, before' < *prh₂(-ei).)
S.v. Ved. járant- 'alt, greis, gebrechlich', from PIE *g̑érh₂-n̥t- (cf. Gk. γέρων, γέροντ- 'alt; Greis').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *starъ 'old', from PIE *steh₂-ro- (cf. OIc. stórr 'big').
Cf. s.v. *h₂el- 'nähren, aufziehen' (IEW 26-7).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *gamala- 'old'. Uncertain etymology. Previous proposals have included a derivation from IE *g̑ʰi-om-, an ablaut variant of *g̑ʰéi-m 'winter' assuming that age was measured in winters, although Kroonen considers this suggesting too far-fetched; perhaps otherwise from *ga-mēla- (prefix *ga- + mēla- 'time'), or similarly *gam-ala- < *k̑om-h₂el-o- to the same root as Gmc. *alda- 'old' < *h₂el-tó-.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √vardh- 'wachsen lassen, mehren', connected with Avestan vərəzda- 'vermehrt, zugewachsen, groß'. Connections outside of Indo-Iranian are difficult. Sandhi evidence argues for a laryngeal in initial position, for Proto-Indo-Iranian.

S.v. 9271 *buḍḍha (2) 'old'. [Initial b- in all lggs. seems to preclude direct derivation < vr̥ddhá- 2. Either same as *buḍḍha (1) (but infl. by MIA. vuḍḍh-- < vr̥ddhá -- 2) or < *br̥ḍḍha- replacing *br̥ḍha -- (√br̥h1)].
Cf. s.v. *dʰu̯eh₂- 'Rauch machen' (IEW 262-3).
S.v. πλάσσω. Modern Greek πλάσμα is from Ancient Greek πλάσμα.

S.v. Ancient Greek πλάσσω 'to knead, form, shape (a soft mass); to think up, imagine, pretend'; this could go back to a formation *pldʰ-ie/o-; this root cannot be Indo-European because roots with plain stops and voiced aspirates violate the root structure constraints; likewise it cannot be (directly) related to the group from *pelh₂- because the verb shows no traces of a laryngeal. No clear etymology.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *čelověkъ 'man'. According to the traditional etymology, this is a compound of čelo- (cf. Lith. kẽlias 'family, tribe, generation') and *věkъ, cf. Lith. vaĩkas 'child'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *čelověkъ 'man'. According to the traditional etymology, this is a compound of čelo- (cf. Lith. kẽlias 'family, tribe, generation') and *věkъ, cf. Lith. vaĩkas 'child'.

S.v. Arm. anjn 'person, ipse; soul, spirit, body'. Corresponds to OIc. angi, n-stem 'smell, scent' (Dan. ange 'damp'), often derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- 'to breathe'. If indeed from *h₂enh₁-g̑ʰ- then anjn is another example of the loss of a laryngeal before a stop.
S.v. Ved. jána- 'Wesen, Mensch; Geschlecht, Stamm, Volk', from PIE *g̑ónh₁-o- (cf. Gk. γόνος 'Nachkommenschaft, Geschlecht, Same').
Cf. s.v. *g̑enh₁- 'erzeugen' (IEW 373-5).
