S.v. Lat. lūdō, -ere 'to play, sport', from PIE *loid- 'to let go frequently, play' (cf. MIr. laídid 'impels', Gk. λίνδεσθαι 'to contend' (Hesych.), λίζει 'plays' (Hesych.), Alb. lind 'gives birth', lindet 'is born' < *li-n-d-, OLith. léidmi 'I let', Lith. láidyti 'to throw', Latv. laîst 'let, publish, set in motion').

S.v. Alb. luaj ~ luej 'to move, to shake, to play'; either from Proto-Albanian *lādnja and connected with Alb. loz (to be etymologically connected with Slav. Iadъ 'order, peace'), or a borrowing from Lat. lūdere 'to play' (so {ref Meyer 1891}:248).

S.v. Engl. play (v.) "Origin uncertain: perhaps cognate with Middle Dutch pleyen to dance, leap for joy, rejoice, be glad (compare also Dutch pleien to play a particular childrens' game), of uncertain etymology; a further connection has frequently been suggested with Old English plēon and related verbs in other Germanic languages (see plight n.1), but this is very uncertain. The Old English verb is recorded in several diverging forms, so that it is difficult to determine its original type and the conjugation to which it belonged (compare the α and β forms). The γ forms appear to mix the other two."

Traditionally Arm. xał- and Greek χαλάω 'slacken', χαλία 'rest' (Hesych.) have been connected (cf. already Meillet 1936:36). The connection, however, requires the postulation of a PIE voiceless aspirate *kʰ-. Clackson concludes "The etymological connection between Greek χαλία and Armenian xałał is possible and the two languages may share a common root not found in other Indo-European languages, or they may both have borrowed the terms from the same source. However, the phonetic correspondence between Greek χ- and Armenian x- is uncertain and the two words show no agreement on their morphological formation. The significance of the correspondence is therefore slight."
Connects Arm. xał 'game', xałam 'play' with Greek χαλάω 'slacken'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *laikan- 'to jump', from PIE *lóig-e- 'to play' (cf. OIr. lingid 'to jump' < *li-n-g-e-; Lith. láigyti 'to run around' < *loig-éie- NPers. ā-līxtan 'to jump' < lig-e-).
S.v. *lei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'springen' (IEW 667-8).
Fr. jouer from Lat. iocāri 'scherzen, spassen'.

S.v. Lat. iocus 'joke, jest', from PIE *iok-o- 'word, utterance' (cf. MW ieith, W iaith, Bret. yezh 'language', MIr., MoIr. icht 'people' < PCl. *iextV-, OHG jehan, OS gehan 'to express, utter', OHG jiht 'confession'. Lith. juõkas 'laugh, laughter', Latv. juõks 'joke' are probably borrowings from German.)
Cf. s.v. *i̯ek- 'sprechen' (IEW 503-4).
Cf. s.v. Ved. vā́ja- 'Wettkampf, Entscheidungskampf, Sieg'; 'Siegspreis, Kampfpreis, Gewinn, Lohn, Ehrengabe'.
S.v. Skt. gēnduka -- , °dū°, gin° m. 'ball for play'.
S.v. Ved. √krīḍ- 'spielen, scherzen, tändeln, tollen, sich heftig bewegen', probably from earlier *kriẓḍ-, PIE *krisd- most presumably to ON hrista 'schütteln', etc.
Cf. s.v. *rei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'binden' (IEW 861-2).
Cf. s.v. *rei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'binden' (IEW 861-2).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *tьrzati 'tear, pull' and *tъrgati 'tear', which "may be cognate with Lat. tergō 'wipe' but in that case the meaning has been totally obscured by the resemblance to *dьrgati."
Cf. s.v. ?1. *terg⁽ʷ⁾- 'reißen, ziehen' [IEW 1073]. Only Slavonic, perhaps related to ?2. *ter⁽g̑⁾- 'abwischen. entfernen'?

S.v. Ved. √karṣ- 'schleppen, ziehen, pflügen' (YAv. pairi.karšōit̰ 'er soll ringsum einfurchen', karšta- 'ausgesät', akaršta- 'ungepflügt, nicht ausgesät'), probably to PIE *kʷels- (cf. Hitt. gul-ša-an-zi 'sie ritzen ein', Gk. τέλσον 'letzte Furche des Akers').

S.v. TochB sälk- 'pull/draw (out/away), tear (out) [normally toward the agent], pluck [of fruit]; [metaphorically] produce, show, present', from PIE *selk- 'pull, draw' (Gk. ἕλκω 'pull, draw', Alb. helq 'id.' (< *solk-ye/o-), Lat. sulcus 'furrow', Lat. sulcāre 'to plow', OEng. sulh 'furrow; plow').
S.v. Arm. քարշ kʻarš 'Schleppen'. A loan from Iranian, cf. NPers. kašīdan 'ziehen, schleppen', Pahl. kašītan 'to draw, pull, drag'.
Cf. s.v. *tu̯er- 'aufrühren, erregen, antreiben' (IEW 1100). [No mention of proposed Greek cognates.]
S.v. SMG σέρνω, from Ancient Greek σύρω with regular development of /i/ > /e/ before /r/, and remodelled as a nasal present in -νω.

S.v. AGk. σύρω 'to draw, trail, drag, pull, ravish, sweep', probably with AGk. σαίρω 'sweep' if both reflect a root *tuer- 'sweep', in which σύρω reflects *tur-e/o- with analogical *σ- (rather than *tuor-e/o- with Cowgill's Law as per {ref Vine 1999a}:569ff.).
Cf. s.v. *tu̯er- 'aufrühren, erregen, antreiben' (IEW 1100). [No mention of proposed Greek cognates.]
S.v. Engl. pull, of uncertain origin.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *teuhan- 'to pull' < PIE *déuk-e- and Proto-Germanic *tukk/gōn- 'to pull, jerk', from PIE *duk-néh₂-, iterative to *teuhan-.
S.v. TochA tsäk- 'pull, take (out, away), from PIE *deu̯k- 'ziehen'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸinsan- 'to stretch', from PIE *téns-e-. The root may be an s-extended form of a more primary PIE root *ten- 'stretch'.
S.v. Lith. tę̃sti 'continue, proceed, stretch, extend' (OPruss. tiẽnstwei 'provoke'), from PIE *tens- (cf. Skt. taṃs- 'shake, move to and fro, tug', Goth. atϸinsan 'draw to oneself').
S.v. 2450 Ved. r̥ñjáti 'makes straight, pulls, stretches' RV. [√r̥ñj] (> Pa. añjati 'pulls', Si. adinavā)

S.v. Ved. √raj-² 'sich gerade ausstrecken, sich in gestreckte Bewegung setzen', from PIE *h₃reg̑- (cf. Gk. ὀρέγω 'strecke aus, reiche dar', Lat. regō 'richte gerade' OIr. rigim 'strecke aus', OHG re(c)can 'recken', etc.).
S.v. *h₃reg̑- 'gerade richten, ausstrecken' (IEW 854-7).
S.v. 2660 Skt. *kaḍḍhati 'pulls, draws' [√*kaḍḍh] and 14245 Skt. *avakaḍḍhati 'pulls away'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *dragan- 'to draw, pull, carry', as though from PIE *dʰrógʰ-e-, an o-grade intensive verb. Usually compared to Gk. τρέχω (which is more likely to be related to ϸragjan- 'to run'), but no clear etymology.
NB: S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸragjan- 'to run' Kroonen (2013:544) considers the root *tregʰ- underlying Greek τρέχω rather than *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- as per LIV² 154 s.v. and Beekes (2010:1506-7) s.v. τρέχω.
S.v. 5762 Skt. tānáyati 'makes stretch' Dhātup. [√tan].
S.v. Ved. √tan-¹ 'spannen, dehnen, sich erstrecken, ausdehnen', from PIE *ten- (cf. Gk. τείνω 'spanne', Lat. tendō 'spanne', OHG den(n)en, NHG dehnen, etc.).
S.v. *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (IEW 1065-6).

S.v. Proto-Iranian *θanǰ- 'to pull, draw', from PIE *tengʰ- 'to draw, pull back' (cf. Toch. tänk- 'to check, stop, restrain', OCS rastęšti 'distrahere', Lith. tingė́ti 'to be slow, lazy'.
"The initial *θ- of the root is puzzling: does it point to the presence of a following laryngeal ? The assumption of an older IE *tʰ-, as found in LIV, l.c. is unacceptable. One may also think of influence from the antonym *θra(n)č ‘to press’. [...] A slightly different preform is reconstructed by Kümmel in LIV, l.c.: *tʰengʰ-. His objections against the postulation of *tH- (on account of the Iranian evidence) and his explanation (invoking the loss of an s-mobile variant) are incomprehensible to me. *tengʰ- is clearly an enlarged root of *ten- (*tan)."
S.v. *tʰengʰ- 'ziehen' (IEW 1067).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tęgnǫti 'pull', from PIE *t(e)ngʰ- (cf. OIc. ϸyngja 'burden').
S.v. Gk. τύπτω 'to poke, stab, beat with a weapon or stick', from PIE *steup- 'push, beat' (cf. Lat. stupeō 'to be(come) numb, amazed', stuprum 'dishonour', Alb. shtyp 'to crush', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *(s)teu̯p- 'stoßen, schlagen' (IEW 1034).

S.v. Lat. trūdō, -ere 'to thrust, push', from PIE *treud-(e/o-) 'to push, thrust' (cf. W. cythrudd 'to vex', Lith. triũsas 'work, effort, pains', OCS trudь 'labour, work', Goth. us-þriutan 'to maltreat', etc.).
S.v. Engl. push, a loan from Anglo-Norman and Old French, Middle French pousser.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *rějati, from PIE *h₃roiH- (cf. Skt. rī́yate 'flow, whirl').
S.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' [IEW 330-1].
Cf. s.v. 1. *(s)teu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 1033-4). [Without Albanian cognates listed.]
S.v. Alb. shtyj ~ shtŷj 'to push' from Proto-Albanian *stūdnja and etymologically close to Skt. tundate 'to push, to strike', Lat. tundō 'to push', OIr. do-tuit 'to fall', Goth. stautan.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *stautan- 'to hit, jab, thrust', from PIE *stóud-e-, an o-grade intensive verb (cf. Skt. tudáti 'to beat', Lat. tundō, -ere 'to strike, beat', Alb. shtyn 'to shove, push').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸunhjan- 'to press', an old ie-present related to Proto-Germanic *ϸwinhan- 'to force', from PIE *tu̯enk- 'to force'.
Cf. s.v. *tu̯enk- 'bedrängen, einzwängen' [IEW 1099-100].

S.v. Proto-Germanic *skeuban- ~ *skūban- 'to shove', from PIE *kséubʰ-e- (assuming a regular metathesis of *ks- > *sk- within PIE), cf. Skt. kṣóbhate 'to shake, tremble', YAv. xšufsąn 3.pl.pres.subj. 'to tremble' < *kséubʰ-e-, Pol. dial. chybać 'to sway, rock; to run, rush' < *ksubʰ-eh₂-; Lith. skubùs, Latv. skubrs 'hasty' < *ksubʰ-(r)o-; unrelated to OCS skubati 'to tear' < *skoubʰ-eh₂-).
Cf. s.v. ?*telk- 'schlagen' (IEW 1062). Only Slavic and possibly Welsh talch 'Bruchstück'.
Cf. s.v. *pei̯s- 'zerstampfen, (zer)stoßen' (IEW 796).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *pьxati 'push, shove', from PIE *pis- (cf. Skt. pináṣti 'crush', Gk. πτίσσω 'winnow grain, bray in a mortar', Lat. pīnsere 'to crush').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *skeutan- 'to shoot, dash'. Extra-Germanic etymology unclear. Cf. entry for previous proposals that can no longer be maintained.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *tiskati 'press, squeeze'. The stem must contain -sk-, the root could be reconstructed as either *teiH- or *teh₁i-, neither of which have obvious cognates elsewhere in Indo-European.
S.v. Ved. √nod- 'stoßen, hinstoßen, antreiben', further etymology unclear.
Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek ἄκων, -οντος 'javelin, dart', derived from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp, point'. The verb ἀκοντίζω 'to hurl a javelin' is in turn derived from this noun.
Tsakonian Propontis κ̔ουντώ < MedG κουντώ, ασκουντώ < AG ἀκοντίζω.
S.v. 6173 *dabb- 'press'. 2. *ḍabb- . 3. *dapph- . [A. Master BSOAS xii 348 ← Drav. – Cf. *drapp- ]

S.v. *gicc ʻ press, crowd ʼ. 2. *gacc -- . 3. *gijj -- . 4. *ghicc -- . 5. *ghacc -- . 6. *ghijj -- . [← Drav., J. Bloch BEFEO xliv 49: Kurukh ginjnā 'to beat into pulp'. Cf. Muṇḍārī geje̯ geje̯ ʻ to reduce to a pulp', gijgij 'close'].
S.v. 5512 *ṭhēḍḍ- 'push'. 2. *ṭhēll- . 3. *ṭēll-.
S.v. 6701 *dhakk- 'push, strike'. [dhakkayati 'annihilates' Dhātup.]
S.v. Skt. dhakkayati 'destroys, annihilates'. Etymology unclear.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dъzdjь 'rainstorm, rain', from PIE *dus-diu-(s), where *dus- is the prefix 'bad' and *diu-(s) is 'sky' (*di̯eu̯-).
S.v. Old Prussian aglo 'rain'. Traditionally connected with Gk. ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness', which would be reconstructed as *h₂egʰlu-.

Cf. s.v. Gk. ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness', which if cognate with OPruss. aglo then from PIE *h₂egʰlu-. An additional possible connection is to Arm. ałǰa-m-ułǰ-kʻ 'darkness' which requires a metathesis of -gʰlu- and subsequent palatalisation *gʰ > ǰ. The reduplication is typical of Armenian.
S.v. νερό. From Medieval Greek νερό(ν) < Ancient Greek νηρόν, 'fresh', with meaning transferred from the collocation νῆρον ὕδωρ 'fresh water'.

S.v. νηρός 'fresh', from νεαρός 'young, youthful, tender, fresh' (with vowel contraction of medial -εα- > -η-. The r-formation is paralleled by Armenian նոր nor /lexeme/28560/ 'new' < *neu̯-eró- vel sim.
Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯ers- 'regnen' (IEW 80-1).
Cf. s.v. *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7).
*ku̯ath₂- 'foam up' with Slavic kysnǫti and kvasiti listed as cognates.

S.v. Proto-Slavic kysati 'turn sour' (ESSJa XIII 269). If one wishes to maintain cognacy with Skt. kváthant- 'bubbling, boiling' after LIV *kuHth₂-s- in order to better account for the root acute (cf. Latv. kûsât 'boil'). Ultimately it is still unclear that the Slavic root is actually cognate with the Sanskrit forms.
S.v. Skt. mucyátē (AV.), múcyatē 'is loosed' RV., 'escapes' Mn., mucyati MBh. [√muc].

S.v. Ved. √moc- 'losmachen, losbinden, lösen, befreien', from PIE *(s)meu̯k- (cf. Lith. maũkti 'abstreifen, abwischen', Pol. smukać 'streifen' Gk. μύσσομαι 'schneuze mich', Lat. ē-mungō 'schneuze aus', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *meu̯k- 'losbinden, abstreifen' (IEW 744).
S.v. 8082 Skt. pānī́ya 'water' MBh.
Cf. s.v. √pā-² 'trinken', from PIE *peh₃-/*ph₃- (~ *peh₃-i̯-/*ph₃-i- → *pih₃-).
Cf. s.v. *peh₃(i̯)- 'trinken' (IEW 839-40).
S.v. Alb. pi 'to drink, to suck', from Proto-Albanian *pīja-, from PIE *pō(i)- ~ pī- 'drink'.
S.v. Arm. əmpem 'to drink', from a PIE reduplicated present stem *pi-ph₃- with an analogical nasal infix.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *piti 'drink', from PIE *ph₃i- (cf. Skt. pā́ti 'drink' Skt. pītá- 'drunk', Gk. πίνω 'drink' (Att.), πώνω (Aeol., Dor.) 'drink').

S.v. Lat. bibō, -ere 'to drink', from Proto-Italic *pibe/o- (Faliscan pafo, pipafo) 'I will drink', from PIE *pi-ph₃-e/o- 'to drink'. Lat. exhibits word-internal distance assimilation *p … *b > b … b.
S.v. Proto-Celtic fib-o- 'drink', from PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'drink' (cf. Skt. píbati, Lat. bibō, Gk. πίνω, OCS piti).

Cf. s.v. Ved. vā́r- 'Wasser' (YAv. vāra- 'Regen', MPers. wārān-, NPers. bārān, etc.), from PIE *(H)u̯eh₁-r- (cf. Luw. u̯a-a-ar 'Wasser', TochA wär, TochB war 'Wasser', ONor. vari 'Flüssigkeit, Wasser').
S.v. *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'Wasser' (IEW 80f., EIEC 636).
S.v. *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'Wasser' (IEW 80f., EIEC 636).
S.v. Lith. jū́ra 'sea' (Latv. jũra, OPruss. luriay, iūrin 'sea'), from PIE *u(e/o)h₁-r- (cf. Skt. vā́r 'water', OIc. úr 'drizzle').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *dergo- 'red, blood red', from PIE *dʰerg- 'dark' (IEW 251), cf. OEng. deorc 'dark', Lith. dárgana- 'bad weather', dérgti 'to become dirty', (?) TochB tarkär 'cloud'.
S.v. կարմիր karmir 'roth' = Heb. כרמיל karmīl 'Carmoisinfarbe und die damit gefärbten Zeuge', via Persian?

S.v. Old Prussian wormyan 'red' < PIE *urmi- (cf. Lat. vermis 'worm', Goth. waurms 'snake', OEng. wyrm 'snake, worm'). Other colour adjectives derived from *urmi- 'worm' are Ukr. vermjáty 'red', OHG wormo 'purple', MoFr. vermeil 'scarlet' < *vermiculus.
Cf. s.v. Lat. vermiculus 'kleiner Wurm' > Fr. vermeil.

Cf. s.v. Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot', from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' (cf. Goth. waurms 'snake', OIc. ormr, OEng. wyrm, OFr. wirm 'snake', OS wormo, OHG wurm, 'worm' < PGmc. *wurma/i-). Cf. the PIE doublet *kʷrmi- 'worm, maggot', possibly secondarily from PIE *kʷrmi- > *wrmi- in Lat. and Germanic.

S.v. Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot', from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' (cf. Goth. waurms 'snake', OIc. ormr, OEng. wyrm, OFr. wirm 'snake', OS wormo, OHG wurm, 'worm' < PGmc. *wurma/i-). Cf. the PIE doublet *kʷrmi- 'worm, maggot', possibly secondarily from PIE *kʷrmi- > *wrmi- in Lat. and Germanic.
S.v. ῥόδον 'rose'. Lesb. βρόδον confirms that an earlier form must have been ϝρόδον, probably like Armenian vard 'rose' from Old Iranian *u̯r̥da-, cf. NPers. gul.

Cf. s.v. ἀληθής 'true, real', from which Ancient Greek ἀληθινός 'true, genuine', is a secondary derivative. Originally an s-stem adjective with privative ἀ- which may be derived from the same root as the verb λήθω 'escape notice' < *leh₂dʰ- 'be hidden'.
Cf. s.v. ?*leh₂dʰ- 'verborgen bleiben' (IEW 651). Only Greek.
S.v. Alb. kuq 'red', borrowed from Romance *cocceus, cf. Lat. coccineus 'scarlet'.
S.v. Khot. hätänai 'red', may be connected with *hita- of MPers. 'hyd, ''hyd 'stain', Av. āhiti-, anāhitā- 'not defiled', OInd. (RV) ásita-, ásikni- 'dark'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. ásita- 'dunkelfarbig, schwarz', connected to the Iranian lexemes via Khot. hätänai 'rot', YAv. āhita- if 'befleckt, unrein'. Perhaps further to be connected with Hitt. hanzana- 'schwarz', Gk. ἄσις  'Schlamm, Unrat' (but ultimately unclear).
S.v. Skt. rakta- (1) 'coloured, dyed' ŚBr., 'red' ŚāṅkhGr̥., n. 'blood' Mn., °aka -- 'red' VarBr̥S. [√rañj].
Cf. s.v. Ved. √raj-¹ 'sich färben, sich röten, rot werden', from PIE *(s)reg- (cf. Gk. ῥέζω 'färbe', ῥῆγος 'Teppich', ῥογεύς 'Färber' etc.).
Cf. s.v. *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- '(sich) färben' (IEW 854).
S.v. TochB ratre, which along with TochA rtär reflect Proto-Tocharian *rŭtäre from PIE *h₁rudʰ-ró-.
S.v. Ved. róhita- 'rot, rötlich' (cf. Av. raoiδita- 'rot, rötlich'), from PIE *h₁reu̯dʰ- 'rot sein' (cf. also Ved. rudhirá-).
Cf. s.v. Lith. raũdas 'reddish brown, bay, reddish', from PIE h₁roudʰ-o- (cf. Lat. rūfus 'red haired, reddish', OIr. ruad 'red', W rhudd 'red', Goth. rauþs 'red').
S.v. Lat. ruber, -bra, -brum 'red', from PIE *h₁rudʰ-ró- 'red' (cf. Skt. rudhirá- 'red, bloody', Gk. ἐρυθρός RuCS rodrъ, TochB rätre 'red', OIr. rondaid 'to paint red').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *rowdo- 'red', from PIE *h₁reu̯dʰ- 'red'.
Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰes- *'fassen?', 'Hand', 'Griff' (IEW 446f.).
S.v. TochB śwālyai 'right' (as opposed to left). A fossilized feminine accusative singular of the gerund śwālle ‘suitable for eating’ from śu- 'eat' from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂-.
S.v. TochB śu- 'eat, consume, devour' from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂-.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *pravъ adj. 'right'. "If *pràvъ < *proH-uo- […] we may compare the formation with Lat. probus ‘solid, decent’ provided that the latter form continues *pro-bʰ(u̯)o- and not *pro-bʰuH-o-."
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *rekan- 'to rake up, pile up' from PIE *h₃reg̑-e-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rehta-, from PIE * h₃reg̑-to- (cf. Av. rāšta- 'right', Gk. ὀρεκτός, Lat. rectus 'right').
S.v. Lat. directus (= di-rectus), from which Fr. droit, etc.
S.v. Lat. regō 'to direct, guide, govern', from PIE *h₃reg̑-e/o- 'guide, direct' (p.p.p. rēctum).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √raj-² 'sich gerade ausstrecken, sich in gestreckte Bewegung setzen', from PIE *h₃reg̑- (Gk. ὀρέγω, Lat. regō, OIr. rigim, etc.). For YAv. ərəzu- cf. s.v. Ved. r̥jú- < *h₃r̥g̑-ú-.
Cf. s.v. *dek̑s- 'taugen, tüchtig sein' [IEW 189].

S.v. Alb. djathtë 'right'; Old Albanian texts (Buzuku) preserve djäthe 'right (side)' showing that the djathtë is a relatively new formation in -të based on Proto-Albanian *detsa, to be connected PIE *dek̑s- 'right' (cf. Skt. dákṣiṇa-, Gk. δεξιός, Lat. dexter, etc.).

S.v. Ved. dákṣiṇa- 'recht, rechts gehend, südlich', from (East?) Indo-European *dek̑s-i-no- (cf. Lith. dẽšinas, OCS desnъ 'rechts', beside *dek̑s-(i-)u̯o- in Gk. δεξιός 'rechts', Goth. taihswo 'die rechte (Hand)', etc.).
S.v. Lith. dẽšinas 'right', from PIE *dek̑s-(i)no- (cf. Skt. dákṣiṇa- 'right, southern', Av. dašina- 'right', Gk. δεξιτερός, Lat. dexter 'right', Goth. taihswa 'right').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *desnъ 'right' (ESSJa IV 218-219), from PIE *dek̑s-(i)no- (cf. Skt. dákṣiṇa- 'right, southern', Av. dašina- 'right', Gk. δεξιτερός, Lat. dexter 'right', Goth. taihswa 'right').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *tehswō(n)- 'right hand', from PIE *dek̑s-u̯eh₂- (cf. Skt. dákṣiṇa- 'right, southern', OCS desьnъ 'right', Lith. dešinė̃ 'right hand' < *dek̑s-ino-, Lat. dexter < *dek̑s-tro-, OIr. dess < *dek̑s-o-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *dexs(i)wo- 'right, south', from PIE *dek̑s-u̯o- 'right' (cf. Lat. dexter, Gk. δεξιτερός, OCS desnъ, Alb. djathtë).
S.v. Alb. lumë (pl. lumenj) 'river', from Proto-Albanian *luma, to be connected with Gk. λῦμα 'dirt', further connected to PIE *leu(ə)- 'dirt'. Cf. also lerë 'dirt, mud' from PIE *leu-.

Cf. s.v. Gk. λῦμα, -ατος 'dirt, waste, garbage', corresponding to Alb. lum 'slime, mud' < *lum-, cf, also Alb. lerë 'dirt, mud' < *leu-d⁽ʰ⁾r-, based on PIE *luH- 'dirt, pollute' (cf. Lat. pol-luō < *por-luō, Lat. lutum = OIr. loth 'excrements, dirt').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *flōdu- 'flood', a tu-stem created to the root of *flōan- 'to flow', as though from PIE *ploh₃-tu-.

Generally connected to the same root as Ancient Greek πίπτω 'fall' to PIE *pet- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}; cf. {ref LIV²} s.v. *peth₁- 'fallen'); the stem formation of Greek ποταμός is suggestive of a formation *peth₂- (cf. {ref LIV²} s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen') which would complicate the root etymology (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:1225-1226), but cf. now {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} which now merges these two roots as the same basic root *pet- 'fliegen, stürzen, fallen'.
Cf. s.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-60).

S.v. Ved. nadī́- 'Fluß', perhaps as 'rauschend, brüllend' to Ved. √nad- 'dröhnen, brüllen, schreien, rauschen', perhaps from PIE *ned- if one may compare river names like Νέδα (Arcadia), Νέδων (Messenia), Modern German Nette, Netze.
Cf. s.v. ?*ned- 'tönen, dröhnen' (IEW 759). The comparanda for this root outside of Indo-Iranian rely on river-names, which are not wholly reliable (cf. EWAia II 8).

Cf. s.v. Ved. jráyas- 'Strecke, Erstreckung' (YAv. zraiiah-, OPers. drayah- 'Meer', MPers. drayā(b), NPers. drayā(b) 'Meer', Parth. zryh, MPers. zrēh 'Meer'). The Indo-European origins of √jray-, jráyas- are not securely determined.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √srav- 'strömen, fließen' (YAv. raonąm G.pl. of the rivers, θraotō.stāt- 'in Flußlaufen befindlich', OPers. rautah-, Parth. rwd, MPers., NPers. rōd 'Fluß', etc.), from PIE *sreu̯- (cf. Arm. aṙogane- 'bewässern', Gk. ῥέω 'fließe, ströme', ῥυτός 'fließend', OHG stroum 'Strom', Lith. sravė́ti 'sickern, langsam fließen', etc.).

S.v. Arm. get 'river', from PIE *u̯ed-os- n. 'water' (cf. Gk. ὕδος 'water'; cf. also Skt. útsa- 'spring, fountain' < *ud-s-o-). The same root found in the PIE heteroclite stem *u̯od-r̥, *u̯ed-n-s (Hitt. u̯ātar/u̯eten-, Gk. ὕδωρ, -ατος, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *voda 'water' from PIE *uod-r/n- 'water' (cf. Skt. udan-, Hitt. u̯ātar, u̯etenas, Gk. ὕδωρ, Lat. unda, 'wave', Goth. wato, OSax. watar, OIc. vatn).

Cf. s.v. Ved. jráyas- 'Strecke, Erstreckung' (YAv. zraiiah-, OPers. drayah- 'Meer', MPers. drayā(b), NPers. drayā(b) 'Meer', Parth. zryh, MPers. zrēh 'Meer'). The Indo-European origins of √jray-, jráyas- are not securely determined.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *albī- 'river' (ON elfr 'river', Elfd. ōve 'river', MLG elve 'riverbed'). Likely to be related to the name of the river Elbe. No further etymology outside of Germanic.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ahwõ- 'river', from PIE *h₂ekʷ-eh₂-. A Germanic-Italic isogloss (cf. Lat. aqua 'water'). "The word is claimed to stem from a non-IE language (Beekes 1998), but it is more likely to be a formal variant of Hitt. ḫapa- c. 'river', Skt. áp-, OAv. ap- f. 'water' < *h₂ep-, Lat. amnis f. 'stream, river' < *h₂ep-ni- and OIr. ab, aub f. W afon f. 'river' < *h₂epHon- (with *-pH- > *b) as in Skt. píbati 'to drink' < PIE *pi-ph₃-é-). Perhaps the cluster *-pH- developed into *-kʷ- in Germanic and Latin."

Pace {ref Kroonen 2013}, the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by {ref Beekes 1998}), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. {ref EWA 1} 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in /cognate/1735/).

S.v. Osc. aapam [acc.sg.], aapas [gen.sg. or acc.pl] 'water', 'water basin' vel sim. "In theory, O. -p- could correspond with -qu- in Lat. aqua 'water'; but in view of long initial /ā-/ in Oscan, it seems preferable to derive it from PIE *h₂ē̆p- 'water' as attested in IIr., Baltic and Tocharian."

"Vielleicht zu idg. *ə2ep- 'Wasser' in ai.ap- 'Wasser' und den europäischen Flußnamen mit ap-. (…) Anders Mommsen, Muller: zu aqua; [lang] a- statt a- muß dann als sekundäre Dehnung (Pisani) oder Vermischung mit ap- (Untermann 304 Anm. 47, Heidermanns § 50) erklärt werden."
Cf. s.v. Lith. šakà 'branch', from PIE *k̑ok-eh₂- (cf. Skt. śā́khā- 'branch, twig', Goth. hoha 'plough').
Cf. s.v. TochB tsäm- 'grow' < PIE *demh₂- 'build'.
Cf. s.v. TochB tsäm-, TochA tsäm- 'grow, increase, come into being', from PIE *demh₂- '(zusammen)fügen, bauen'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *wurti- '(medicinal) root, herb'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *wridā 'root', from PIE *u̯re(h₂)d- 'root' (IEW 1167).
S.v. Ved. mū́la- 'Wurzel'. Etymology unclear.
S.v. 5086 jáṭā- f. 'hair twisted together' PārGr̥., 'fibrous root, root' Bhpr.
S.v. Ved. jaṭā- 'Flechte, Haartracht der Asketen'. Etymology unclear.
Cf. s.v. pūyº 'faulig werden, stinken', from PIE *pū- (cf. Gk. πύον, πύος 'Eiter', πύθομαι 'faule, verwese', Lat. pūs 'Eiter', ONor. fūinn 'verfault', Lith. pū́ti 'faulen, modern', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Lith. pū́ti 'rot, decay, decompose', from PIE *puH- (cf. Skt. pū́yati 'rot, stink', Lat. pūtere 'rot', OIc. feyja 'let rot').
S.v. Proto-Germanic fūla- 'filthy, foul', from PIE *puH-lo-, cf. also Proto-Germanic *faujan- 'to let rot' < *pouH-éie-.
Cf. s.v. Lat. pūs, pūris 'pus', from PIE *puH-o/es- 'pus', from which Lat. putridus 'rotten' is a derived adjective via putrere 'to be in a state of decay', putrescere 'to decay, disintegrate'.
S.v. 7654 Skt. pacyátē 'is cooked, is digested' RV., pácyatē 'becomes ripe' RV. [√pac].
S.v. Ved. √pac- 'kochen, braten', from PIE *pekʷ- (cf. OCS pekǫ 'backe, brate', Lat. coquō 'koche', Gk. πέσσω, etc.).
Cf. s.v. 1. *pekʷ- 'reif machen, gar machen' (IEW 798).
Cf. s.v. kalb 'to let rot' from Proto-Albanian *kalba, (cf. qelb 'pus'). No further certain etymology. Cf. entry for references to further literature and various suggestions.
S.v. փուտ pʻut 'Fäulniss, Eiter, faul, verdorben, morsch, unecht', a borrowing from Persian (cf. NPers. pūda 'verfault', Pahl. pūtāk 'rotten, decayed, putrid').

Cf. s.v. Lat. marceō 'to be withered, droop', possibly from PIE *mrk-eh₁- 'to be soaked, be weak' if cognate with Hitt. markii̯e/a- 'to disapprove of, refuse', Skt. cs. marcáyati 'to damage, hurt', OAv. marəxšaitē 'to destroy', marəka- 'ruin', Oss. marg 'poison', Lith. mir̃kti 'to become weak, soaked', Ukr. morokvá 'quagmire, swamp', MHG meren 'to dip bread into water or wine'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *gņilъ 'rotten', from PIE *g̑ʰneiH-lo-, cf. Proto-Slavic *gņiti 'to rot' from PIE *g̑n(e)iH- (cf. OHG gnītan 'grind', OE gnidan 'grind').
S.v. *śaṭa 'falling, rotting'.

NB: S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸragjan- 'to run' {ref Kroonen 2013}:544 considers the root *tregʰ- underlying Greek τρέχω rather than *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- as per {ref LIV²} 154 s.v. and {ref Beekes 2010}:1506-7 s.v. τρέχω.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *barna- 'child', from PIE *bʰor-no-, a noun derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *þwahan- 'wash'. Possibly connected with OPruss. twaxtan 'brushwood for bathing via a pre-form *tu̯ok-sto-??? No further potential cognates.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *graban- 'to dig', from PIE *gʰróbʰ-e- (cf. OCS greti 'dig, scrape' < *gʰrebʰ-, Latv. grebt 'to scrape, excavate, sieze' < *gʰrebʰ-(ie-)).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *sweltan- 'to dwindle, starve, perish', possibly from PIE *suéld-e-, if to be connected with Arm. kʻalcʻ 'hunger' < *sul̥d-sko-(?). Further details unclear.
S.v. Alb. vdes 'to die', from *awa-takja, derivative to *teka 'to run away, go away'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bal-ni- 'throw away, die', from PIE *gʷelh₁- (cf. Gk. βάλλω, perh. TochAB klā- 'fall').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *sterban- 'to become stiff, die', from PIE *sterbʰ-e- (cf. Gk. Hsch. στέρφνιος 'hard, firm', Russ. sterbnut' 'to become solid or hard, to die').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *daujan- 'to die', from PIE *dʰouh₂/h₃-ie-, (cf. Hitt. tuḫḫušzi 'to end'; Lat. fūnus 'funeral' < *dʰuh₂-n-es-(?)). On the PIE level the verb has usually been compared to *dʰeu- 'to run, to rush' (Skt. dhávate, Gk. θέω 'to run' and to *dʰueh₂- 'to blow, smoke, be misty' (cf. Seebold 1970:148; LIV² s.v.), but Kroonen finds it preferable to assume a link with Hitt. tuḫḫušzi 'to end'. The forms based on Goth. dauϸs 'dead', ON dauðr, OE dēad, OHG tōt, etc. are from PGmc. *dauda-, the original past participle to *daujan-.
S.v. Alb. rrumbull 'rolled into a ball', borrowed from Rom. rombulus, based on Lat. rhombus 'magic whirligig or wheel' (cf. Ital. dial. rummulu, rumbulu).

S.v. Arm. bolor 'whole, entire; round, spherical, circle', derived from PIE *bʰel- 'to blow, grow, swell' (cf. Gk. φαλλός 'penis', OIc. boli 'bull', Lat. follis 'leather bag filled with air, ball', OIr. ball 'body part', etc.).
S.v. Ved. máṇḍala- 'Scheibe, Kreis, Umkreis, Ring'. Etymology disputed.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *gart- 'to turn'. The root has no secure extra-Iranian comparisons and appears to be a dental-enlarged form of the root *gar-² 'to turn, wind', probably influenced by *u̯art-.

S.v. στρογγύλος 'round, spherical, compact'. A formation like γογγ-ύλος, καμπ-ύλος, ἀγκ-ύλος, etc., connected to στάγξ 'squeezed out drop' by {ref Frisk 1960-1972}, but the meanings of the two words are not obviously connected. Possibly of substratum origin in view of the suffix -υλ-.
S.v. Skt. golaḥ 'globe, ball, jar in the form of a ball'. Not to be separated from kuṇḍám, kholakaḥ, guṭikā, guḍáḥ. etc. Probably of Dravidian origin.
Cf. s.v. Ved. píṇḍa- 'Klumpen, Fleischklumpen, Fleishkloß, runde Masse, Kugel'. Etymology unexplained.
S.v. Lith. apvalùs 'round', a compound of ap + valùs, which may be cognate with vélti (II) 'felt, full, tousle' < *uelH- (cf. Goth. wulan 'seethe').
Cf. s.v. 2. *u̯elH- '(sich) walzen, wallen' [IEW 1140-3].
*krongʷ-o- seems to be the most viable solution, cf. the citations. Revision might be needed.

S.v. TochB mäk- 'run', probably not from PIE *meuk- 'slip away (from)' as usually supposed (cf. {ref van Windekens 1976}); {ref Malzahn & Peters 2010} suggest a relationship with Greek μάχομαι 'fight' < *megʰh₂-, but the meanings are divergent (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:917 who considers μάχομαι to be possibly Pre-Greek).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *spring/kan- 'to break out, leap', from PIE *spré-n-gʰ-e- (cf. Skt. spr̥hayati 'to be eager, strive after, desire' < *sprg̑ʰ-eie-, Gk. σπέρχω, σπέρχομαι 'to come in rushing, huddle, be impassioned < *spérg̑ʰ-).
Cf. s.v. վազք vaz-kʻ 'Sprung, Springen' whence vazem 'springen'; probably a loanword from Iranian (cf. NPers. bāxtan, bāzam 'spielen', Iranian root *vaz-).
S.v. Gk. δραμεῖν 'run', from PIE *drem- 'run', originally a suppletive aorist stem to τρέχω 'run' (cf. Skt. pres. (gramm.) dramati).
S.v. 1. *drem- '(wohin) laufen' (IEW 204-5).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hlaupan- 'to jump, leap', a strong verb back-formed to iterative *hluppōn- 'to run' < *klup-néh₂- (cf. Latv. klupinât 'keep stumbling' < *klup-neh₂-).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tekti 'flow, run', from PIE *tekʷ- (cf. Skt. tákti 'rush', OIr. techid 'flee').
S.v. *bʰegʷ- 'davonlaufen, fliehen' (IEW 116).
S.v. Lith. bė́gti, from PIE *bʰegʷ- (cf. Gk. φέβομαι 'flee').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'run' < *h₃ri-n-H- or *h₃ri-nu-e- (cf. Skt. riṇā́ti 'to make flow, set off', etc.).

S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, transport, fly' (cf. Gk. (Pamph.) ϝεχέτω 'he must bring', Lat. vehō, vēxī 'I ride, bring', OCS vezǫ 'I ride' Lith. vežu 'I ride, procure' OHG wegan 'to move' etc.).
S.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben; fahren' (IEW 1118-20).
S.v. *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen' (IEW 259-60, 262).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ret-o- 'run', from PIE *(H)reth₂- 'run' (cf. Lat. rota 'wheel', Skt. rathá- 'chariot').

Cf. s.v. Lat. lārgus 'generous, bountiful'. Etymology unclear. The formal derivation and semantics from earlier attempts at an etymology in Walde-Hofmann and Pokorny IEW as though from *lajes-ago- 'carrying fat' are not convincing.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *čam-? 'to walk'. No IE origin; might be a blend of Proto-Iranian *čarH- and *gam-¹.
Cf. s.v. Skt. pálāyate 'flees, escapes, vanishes'. Probably after Middle Indic *pra-lāya(ya)te, cf. Ved. párā-i- 'weggehen, davongehen'.
S.v. 7955 Skt. pálāyatē 'flees' TS.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √ay-¹ 'gehen, wandern, fahren, gelangen', from PIE *h₁ei̯- (cf. Hitt. i-it 'geh!', Gk. εἶμι 'gehen', Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', OLith. eimì 'gehen', OCS iti 'gehen', etc.).
S.v. 6624 Ved. drávati 'runs' RV. [√dru-], 6634 Ved. drāváyati 'causes to run, makes flow, melts' RV. [√dru-].
S.v. Ved. √drav- 'laufen, eilen', from PIE *dreu̯-.
S.v. *dreu̯- 'laufen' (IEW 205-6).
S.v. 6634 Skt. drāváyati 'causes to run, makes flow, melts', under which Pa. dāpēti 'causes to run' rather from < drāpáyati [cs. stem to √drā-]
Cf. s.v. Ved. √drā-¹ 'laufen, eilen', from PIE *dreh₂- (cf. Gk. ἀπο-διδρᾱ́σκω 'laufe weg').
Cf. s.v. *dreh₂- '(weg)laufen' (IEW 204).
Cf. s.v. ?*dʰreu̯s- 'fallen, herabfallen' (IEW 274-5).

S.v. Alb. kripë ~ krypë 'salt', from Proto-Albanian *krūpā connected with ON hrufa 'scab', Lith. kraupìs 'rough', kraupis 'scab', Latv. kraûpis 'frail, brittle', Slav. *krupa 'groats'. Alternatively a borrowing from Slavic *krupa (so Meyer Et.Wb. 206).
Cf. s.v. *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' (IEW 681-2).
S.v. 10299 Ved. mr̥ṣṭá- (1) 'rubbed, washed, pure' RV. 'prepared, savoury' R., 'sweet, pleasant' MBh., miṣṭa- 1 'dainty, sweet' MBh. [√mr̥j or √mr̥ś] (> M. mīṭh n. 'salt', miṭhā 'sweet').

S.v. Ved. √marj- 'putzen, reinigen, abstreifen, streichen', from PIIr. *(H)marj́-, from the collapse of PIE *h₂merg̑- 'abstreifen, streifend berühren, reinigen' (cf. Gk. ἀμέργω, ὀμόργνυμι) and *h₂melg̑- *'abstreifen' > 'melken' (Gk. ἀμέλγω, etc.).
Reconstructs N.sg. *seh₂ls, A.sg. *sh₂elm, G.sg. *sh₂los.

S.v. TochB salyiye 'salt', reflecting pre-Proto-Tocharian *sali-h₂en-, a derivative of PIE *sali- 'salty' (cf. Skt. sali-la- 'salty, ocean', Arm. sał (an i-stem), Old Lat. sale 'salt', OCS salь; more distantly Gk. ἅλς, Lat. sāl, etc.).
S.v. Arm. ał 'salt' and ałt 'salt'; connected to Gk. ἅλς, Lat. sāl, etc.
S.v. *solь 'salt', from PIE *sh₂el- (cf. Gk. ἅλς, Lat. sāl, OHG salz, OIr. salann).
S.v. Latv. sā̀ls 'salt', from PIE *seh₂-l-, *sh₂-el-. Latv. sā̀ls reflects the N.sg. *sēh₂-l-s of a hysterodynamic paradigm according to Kortlandt (1985b:118-119).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *salano- 'salt', a derivative of PIE *seh₂l- 'salt'.

S.v. Lat. sāl, salis 'salt', from PIE *sē̆h₂-l-s (nom.), *sh₂-él-m (acc.), *sh₂-l-ós (gen.) 'salt'; *sh₂l-d- (or *sh₂el-d- or *seh₂l-d- 'salt'), cf. OIr. salann 'salt', Gk. ἅλς 'salt', Latv. sā̀ls 'salt', OCS solь, 'salt', Lith. saldùs 'sweet', OCS sladъkъ 'sweet', Goth. salt, OHG salz, etc.

S.v. TochB āyo 'bone'; most likely from PIE *h₂ést-, pl. *h₂ést(e)h₂ with the e-grade generalised, perhaps extended by PIE *-yo/eh₂- suffix found in body-part terms. (Cf. entry in Adams for further discussion of the Tocharian stem formation.).
S.v. Arm. oskr 'bone', to be derived from the PIE word for 'bone' found in Skt. ásthi, asthnás 'bone', Gk. ὀστέον 'bone', Lat. os, ossis 'bone, leg', Hitt. ḫaštāi-, ḫašti- 'bone', CLuw. ḫāš- 'bone'.

S.v. Ved. ásthi- 'Knochen, Bein' (cf. OAv., YAv. ast-uuaṇt- 'mit einem knochenhaften Leib versehen', OAv. astəṇ-tāt- 'Körperhaftigkeit', MPers., NPers. ast), probably from PIE *h₂ost-h₂/n- (cf. Hitt. hastai- 'Knochen, Gebein', Gk. ὀστέον 'Knochen', Lat. os, oss-is 'Bein, Knochen', etc.).

S.v. Lat. os, ossis 'bone', from PIE *h₃o/est- 'bone' (cf. MW ascurn, OCo. ascorn 'bone' < *ast-k-, OCo. asen, MIr. asna 'rib' < *astVn-; Hitt. haštāi-/hašti- 'bone(s), strength', CLuw. hāš- 'bone' < *h₃esth₁-ōi, -i-; Skt. ásthi- 'bone', YAv. ast- 'bone, body with bones', Gk. ὀστέον 'bone', Arm. oskr, OAlb. ashtë 'bone').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *astn(iy)o- 'rib', from PIE *h₂osth₁- 'bone' (cf. Hitt. hastāi-, Luv. hās-, Skt. ásthi- Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, ossis, Alb. asht, Arm. oskr).
S.v. Arm. haw₁ 'bird', connected with Lat. avis, -is, and other words belonging to the PIE word for 'bird' (Gk. αἰετός < *awi-etos 'eagle', Skt. váy- YAv. vaii-, etc.).
Cf. s.v. Arm. haw₁ 'bird', connected with Lat. avis, -is, and other words belonging to the PIE word for 'bird' (Gk. αἰετός < *awi-etos 'eagle', Skt. váy- YAv. vaii-, etc.).
Contra Orel (1998:497), considers the Alb. ve ~ vo inherited. (All other loans from Lat. ō- result in (h)u-.)

S.v. Alb. ve ~ vo 'egg', considers the lexeme a loan from Lat. ōvum on the basis of Old Albanian voe (Buzuku, Bardhi) where the correspondence of Tosk va- ~ Gheg vo- is typical of Latin loanwords. [But cf. objections of Holm 2011:60.]

S.v. Arm. ju 'egg', derived from the PIE word for 'egg' (cf. Gk. ᾠόν, Lat. ōvum, Celt. *āwyo- 'egg', OCS aice, etc.), the Armenian form is usually explained from *i̯ō(w)i̯o- with assimilatory addition of *i̯-, but the initial j- remains unclear.
S.v. Khot. āhā- 'egg' < *āvyā- (cf. Av. aēm [Yašt 13.2] 'egg'(?), Oss. D. ajkä, NPers. xāyah, Pašto hā, etc., from the PIE word for 'egg' (Gk. ᾠόν, Welsh wy, Lat. ōuum, ONor. egg, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ajьce 'egg', originally a diminutive of Proto-Slavic *aje 'egg' from PIE *h₂ōui-om (cf. Gk. ᾠόν, Lat. ōvum, OIc. egg, OHG ei, W wy).

S.v. Lat. ōvum 'egg', from PIE *h₂ōuiom 'egg', preferring the explanation deriving 'egg' as a vr̥ddhi-derivative of 'bird', hence 'what belongs to a bird', against Schindler (1969), who reconstructs ō-h₂uiom with a preposition *ō, thus 'toward the bird'.
Derives the IE word for egg from *ō-h₂uiom.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *āwyo- 'egg', from PIE *h₂ōu-io- 'egg' (cf. Lat. ōuum, Gk. ᾠόν, etc.).
Cf. Western Armenian hawkitʿ as a compound 'bird-produce' /cognate/6057/. Within PIE 'bird' and 'egg' must have been separate lexemes, therefore these classes have been separated.
S.v. Alb. rërë ~ ranë 'sand', borrowed from Lat. arēna 'sand'.
Suggests an alternative etymology from *er- 'Erde, Sand, Locker' (IEW 332), cf. Lat. rārus, but "[e]ven in this case, no recent cognates with the exact meaning".
Cf. s.v. *terh₂- 'durchkommen, überqueren (IEW 1074-5).
Cf. for the argument for the development *h₂ > *h₁ / _o in Proto-Anatolian.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *ględati 'look at' (ESSJa VI 122-123), from PIE *gʰlend- (cf. Latv. glen̂st 'scarcely perceive, nùogleñst 'notice', OIr. as-gleinn 'investigate, examine', MHG glinzen 'shine'). 

"LIV (200) reconstructs *gʰlendʰ- because a proto-form with root-final *d would trigger Winter's Law, which is not in agreement with the circumflex of the Balto-Slavic forms. It is unclear to me, however, what exactly is the evidence for a Balto-Slavic circumflex." […] "I therefore prefer the reconstruction *gʰlend-, which has the additional advantage of corresponding with the Germanic forms."
S.v. *gʰlendʰ- 'blicken, schauen, glänzen' (IEW 431).

S.v. Lith. matýti 'look at, watch' (cf. CS motriti, Ru. motrit' (dial.), SCr. mòtriti, Sln. mótriti). "For the *-r-, cf. → matrus. Fraenkel (LEW: 416) advocates an etymological relationship with → mesti 'throw', which he also connects with → matas and forms reflecting *mē-, i.e. *meh₁- 'measure' (I: 415, 418). I prefer to dismiss the connection between
*met- 'measure' and met- 'throw' (pace LIV: 422), but I am inclined to derive matyti from the former root. As to the semantics, we may com pare Cz. metit ( dial.) 'watch assiduously', Ru. metit' 'aim at', 1sg. meču, zametit' 'notice, remark, observe', which I assume to contain *mě- < *meh₁, or Gk. μέδομαι 'care for, think of' < *med- 'measure', cf. Go. mitan."

S.v. Old Albanian sheh 'sehen', where the traditional etymology from *sekʷ- (Orel 1998:435f., LIV² 535f.) is objected to on phonological grounds. The root identification is unclear, but the present stem ought to continue a primary derivative with a *-sk̑e/o- suffix.

S.v. Alb. shoh ~ shof 'to see', from Proto-Albanian *sāksa with dissimilation of sibilants, further connected to PIE *sekʷ- 'to follow, see' (cf. Skt. sácate 'to accompany, follow', Gk. ἕπομαι, Lat. sequor, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *sekʷ- 'sich anschließen' (IEW 896-7), under which Alb. sheh 'sieht, schaut' is tentatively derived from a cs.-it. stem *sokʷ-éi̯e-, but (marked with ?[; cf. n9.).
S.v. 3. *u̯el- 'sehen, wahrnehmen' (IEW 1136-7).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷis-o- 'to see', from PIE *kʷei̯s- 'to perceive' (cf. Av. cinahmi 'determine', Lat. cūra 'anxiety, care').
S.v. *kʷei̯s- 'auf etwas achten, wahrnehmen' (IEW 637).

S.v. Ved. √paś- 'sehen, betrachten, blicken, schauen' (OAv. spasiiā 'ich beschaue [Y 44.11], YAv. spasiieiti 'erspäht, erblickt'), from PIE *spek̑- (cf. Gk. σπέπτεται < *spek̑-i̯e-, Lat. speciō, NHG spähen, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *sěmę 'seed', from PIE *seh₁-men- (cf. Lat. sēmen) 'seed').
S.v. Lith. sė́kla 'seed, sperm' and Lith. sė́ti, from PIE *seh₁- 'to sow' (cf. Lat. serere 'sow', Goth. saian 'sow').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *sēda- 'seed' and *sēdi- 'seed', respectively *-to- and *-ti- derivatives from PGmc. *sēan- 'to sow' from PIE *séh₁-e-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *sīlo- 'seed, descendants', to be derived from PIE *seh₁- 'sow' (cf. Lat. sēmen 'seed', OEng. sāwan 'sow').
S.v. Old Welsh nes (adj. comp.) 'nearer', from PIE *ned- 'zusammendrehen, knüpfen' (MW nes, MCB nes, OIr. nessa, G neddamon).
Cf. s.v. *bʰlei̯g̑- 'schlagen' (IEW 160-1).
S.v. Khot. naysda- 'near', from base nazda-, (Av. nazdyō 'nearer', nazdišta- 'nearest', NPers. nazd, nazdīk, Balōčī nazīk, nazī, Pašto nažde, etc.), cf. Ved. nédīyas-.

Cf. s.v. Ved. nédiyas- (comp.) 'näher, sehr nahe', from PIIr. *nazdii̯as-. The analysis of the stem from an Indo-European perspective is unclear. The positive, attested via OAv. asna-, YAv. asna-, OPers. ašna- 'near' may perhaps be from *n̥sd-no-, perhaps to *na- 'dazu' + IE *sed- 'sitzen'; also questionable is the possible connection to Osc. nessimas 'proximae' to IE *ned-.
Fr. près < Lat. pressē 'knapp, kurz'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. premō, -ere 'to press', from Proto-Italic *pres-. "Italic *pres- might be an s-present to PIE *per- 'to hit', but this remains guesswork."
Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯k̑- 'eingehen in, eintreten' (IEW [1129] 1131).

S.v. Ved. ánti (adv.) 'nahe, in der Nähe, gegenüber, davor', from PIE *h₂ént-i (cf. Gk. ἀντί 'gegenüber, angesichts', Arm. ənd 'für, statt', Lat. ante 'vor', etc.). Originally a loc.sg. of *h₂ent- 'Angesicht' (cf. Hitt. ḫa-an-za 'Vorderseite, Gesicht').
S.v. cerco 'círculo', from Lat. circus 'círculo'.
S.v. Lat. cīrcus 'circle, circus', probably a loanword from Gk. κρίκος 'ring', of uncertain origin.
TochA kāts, TochB kātso reflect Proto-Tocharian *kātsān-. Beyond Tocharian the etymology is obscure, but cf. the entry for various proposals.

The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated (cf. esp. Kloekhorst 2008:819-821, EWAia s.v. Ved. dīrghá- cited in this class), the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is, however, generally agreed. The reconstructed root form for this class follows the LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda.
S.v. Alb. gjathë 'long', from Proto-Albanian *dlata continuing IE *dln̥gʰ-to- and related to other IE adjectives for 'long' from *(d)longʰ-o- (Lat. longus, Goth. lagga, etc.).
S.v. Lith. ìlgas 'long' (Latv. il̃gs 'long (of time)', from PIE *dlh₁gʰ-ó- (cf. Skt. dīrghá-, Gk. δολιχός).

S.v. Proto-Germanic langa- 'long', identical to Lat. longus 'long', a nasalised version of the PIE root *dlh₁gʰ- 'long'. "The adjective thus implies a nasal present *dlénh₁gʰ-e-, which, however, is not attested."

Cf. in LIV addenda and corrigenda – Neu: ?2.*delh₁- 'verlängern'       (IEW 194‑6), Präsens ?*dl̥h₁-éi̯o-   aksl. (+) pro-dьľǫ, -dьliti 'verlängern' (Anm. 1 Verbal nur slav. (primär?), Basis vieler Nomina, z.B. aruss. dьlja ‘Länge’ und v.a. die Adj. *dl̥h₁-gʰó- in ved. dīrghá- = av. darəga-, aksl. (+) dlъgъ sowie *dolh₁-i-gʰo- > gr. δολιχός neben *dolh₁-u-Ki- > heth. daluki-, alle ‘lang’; *h₁ wegen gr. ἐν-δελεχής zu einem neugebildeten *δέλεχος n. < *délh₁gʰos, vgl. Stüber 172-4 mit Lit.).
Cf. s.v. ?2.*delh₁- 'verlängern' (IEW 194‑6).

S.v. Lat. longus 'long' from PIE *dlongʰ-o- (cf. *dólugʰ- in Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long', PIE *dlh₁gʰ-o- in Skt. dīrghá- OAv. darəga-, OCS dlъgъ, SCr. dȕg, Lith. ìlgas, Alb. gjathë (+ *-tā-); Gk. δολιχός (< *dolh₁-i-gʰo-?), ἐνδελεχής 'lasting long, uninterrupted' < *delh₁gʰ-; PIE *dlongʰ-o- in Goth. laggs, OHG lang, OIc. langr, etc.). The root might be *de/olh₁-, cf. Cz. dél (poet.) 'length' < PSl. *dьlь, etc.

S.v. Lith. artì 'near, close', from PIE *h₂er-t- (Gk. ἄρτι 'just, just now, recently', Arm. ard 'just now'). "Originally we are dealing with the Lsg. of a derivative of the root of Gk. ἀραρίσκω 'fit, join together' etc."

S.v. Alb. afër 'near', from Proto-Albanian *apsera representing a contamination of *aps, a variant of IE *apo reflected by Gk. ἄψ 'backwards' and *apero, a derivative of *apo (Skt. ápara- 'posterior, later', Goth. afar 'after', etc.).
Regarding the proposed comparison of {ref Orel 1998} to PIE *ap-, cf. s.v. *áp, *ápo 'weg, fort, ab; zurück, wieder; hinter, nach' (Adverb, lokal und temporal), without Albanian afër connected.
S.v. Skt. pārśvá- n. 'region of the ribs, side' RV., 'nearness' MBh., pārśvaka- m. 'rib' Yājñ.

Cf. s.v. Ved. párśu- 'Rippe', from which pārśvá- 'Rippengegend, Seite, Flanke' is derived. Connections outside of Indo-Iranian are unclear. Perhaps to PIE *perk̑- if connected to OCS prъsi 'Brust', but against this Ved. pr̥thu-párśu- meaning 'mit geschwellter Brust' is difficult.

S.v. nikaṭam, °ṭē, °ṭāt adv. 'near' R. [Cf. supplementary note in DSAL Online (http://dsalsrv02.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/contextualize.pl?p.2.soas.559220): Despite EWA ii 158 derivation with P. Tedesco JAOS 65, 161 f. from nikr̥ṣṭa -- is phonet. impossible, and Mu. origin with F. B. J. Kuiper Debrunner -- Festschrift 247 unlikely. Derived from nikr̥ta -- adverbially preserving the mng. ʻ *put at ʼ (semant. cf. saṁnihita -- ʻ near ʼ) afterwards replaced by ʻ put down, humbled ʼ (J.C.W.)]
S.v. TochB ysape 'near by, close', a derivative of spe 'nearby, closely' < *(s)h₄upo 'under, below' (cf. Lat. sub 'under', Lat. suppus, '(head) downwards', Arm. hup 'near').
S.v. *súp 'unten', *súpo 'hinab' (Adverb, lokal; oft mit Akk., Lok.).
S.v. TochB krāñi(ye)* '(nape of the) neck', which is an exact match to Gk. κρανίον 'top of the head' < *k̑rh₂sníi̯om. The base stem is *k̑rh₂sn- (cf. Skt. śīrṣ(a)n- and Gk. κρα(h)ατ-).
For *k̑er- as the basic root, cf. 'head' in /cognate/53/ and 'horn' in /cognate/2457/.
For the root *k̑er- as the basis of this stem, cf. 'horn' in /cognate/2457/.
S.v. *σκουλλίον diminutive, cf. Modern Greek dialectal (Rhodos) σκοῦλος 'Hals', from Ancient Greek σκόλλυς.
S.v. σκόλλυς 'fringe of hair, a haircut in which a tuft of hair was left on the head'. "Perhaps related to σκολύπτειν 'to pluck out, cut short', although a Pre-Greek origin seems more likely."
S.v. Alb. qafë 'neck', borrowed from Turkish kafa 'occiput, head'.
S.v. Lith. kãklas 'neck', from PIE *kʷe-kʷl-o-m (cf. Ved. cakrá- 'wheel', OIc. hjól 'wheel', OEng. hweohhol, hwēol 'wheel').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- ~ *hnakka(n)- 'neck'. "In view of the close formal and semantic similarities to To. kñuk, it seems possible to reconstruct a PIE n-stem *knék-ōn, gen. kn̥k-n-ós, acc. *knok-n-ń̥s (cf. {ref Kroonen 2011}:167ff.). The regular outcome of this paradigm, viz. *hnehō, *hunkkaz, *hnakkuns was apparently remodelled into *hnekkō, *knukkaz, *hnakkuns. […] [I]t is possible that G Hunke 'hillock' is a vestige of the original genitive form. It is therefore likely that OIr. cnoc, W cnwch m. 'hill' was borrowed from Germanic rather than the other way around."
[No etymology given.]
S.v. Proto-Germanic *halsa- 'neck', from PIE *kols-o- (cf. Lat. collum 'neck; hill' from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ols-o-).
Reconstructs (post-)PIE *kólso- 'neck' (cf. Lat. collum) > PGmc. *halsaz (cf. Goth. hal, OE heals).

Root etymology disputed. Root ref. form follows {ref Ringe 2006}:95. If ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ({ref LIV² } 386-388), then these lexemes may be root-cognate with the Baltic lexemes in /cognate/1868/, but the etymology of the Baltic lexemes is less than certain; cf. further discussion in that cognate class. Alternatively a root etymology has been proposed to PIE *kelH- 'to tower, soar' (cf. {ref EWA 4} 477-480).

Etymology disputed. There are two main possibilities: either (1) to *kolso- underlying the Germanic and Italic lexemes in /cognate/265/, or (2) to PIE *kʷelh₁- ({ref LIV²} 386-388) as a reduplicated formation (cf. {ref ALEW} 433-434). The latter explanation is favoured by {ref Derksen 2015}:220. Both proposed etymologies are not precise correspondences and require special pleading to explain the deviations so that it is difficult to favour one etymology over the other (cf. {ref ALEW} 434).
S.v. Ved. mányā- (Du., Plur.) 'Nacken', from PIE *mon- with different stem derivations (OIr. muinēl 'Hals' [*°iklo-], OHG man[a] 'Mähne' [*°eh₂-]).

S.v. Ved. √vac- 'sprechen, reden, nennen, sagen' (OAv. vaxšiiā 'ich werde verkündigen'), from PIE *u̯ekʷ- (cf. Gk. εἰπεῖν 'sprechen', OIr. foccul 'Wort' (*u̯okʷ-tlo-), MHG gewahenen 'erwähnen', ON váttr 'Zeuge').
S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯ač- 'to say, speak', from PIE *u̯ekʷ- 'to speak, say, tell'.

S.v. Proto-Iranian *sanh- 'to declare, explain' (Av. sə̄ṇgh- [saŋh-] 'to declare, explain', OPers. θaⁿh- 'to declare, say'), from PIE *k̑ens- 'to announce, proclaim' (cf. Lat. censeō 'I vote for something, decide, value', Gk. κῶμος 'dionysic festival procession').
S.v. *k̑eNs- 'verkünden, (öffentlich) schätzen' (IEW 566).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √śam̆̇s- 'preisen, feierlich aussprechen, vortragen, verkünden' (OAv. sə̄ṇghaitī 'erklärt, spricht aus', YAv. saŋhāmi 'ich beschwöre', OPers. θ-h-y-a-m-h-y = θanhhyāmahi 'wir werden genannt'), from PIE *k̑ems- 'feierlich sprechen, verkünden' (cf. Lat. censeō 'stimme für etwas', Gk. κῶμος 'dionysischer Festzug, Festgesang', etc.).
S.v. Alb. thom 'to say', from athematic PAlb. tsānsmi, connected with Lat. censeō 'to assess, to value' and cognates.
S.v. Old Albanian thótë 'sagen'. The present stem thotë is a continuation of the middle of the Narten-present of the root *k̑eHs- 'anweisen' (LIV² 318f.).
S.v. *k̑eHs- 'anweisen' (IEW 533).
S.v. Lith. sakýti 'say' from PIE *sokʷ-eie- (cf. OIc. segja 'say', OS seggian 'say', Proto-Slavic *sočìti 'indicate, accuse' > SerbCS sočiti 'indicate', etc.).
S.v. φημί 'to say, explain, argue', from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'say'.
S.v. Arm. awaz 'sand, dust', connected with Gr. ἄμαθος, ψάμμος, Lat. sabulum 'sand', OHG sant, MHG sampt, etc. Probably of non-IE origin.

Cf. R.S.P. Beekes s.v. SAND: "?*samh̥ªdhos 'sand' [IEW 146 (*bhes-); Wat 8 (*bhes-); Buck 1.215]. Lat. sabulum 'sand' ?saburra 'sand in a ship as ballast', ON sandr 'sand', NE (dial.) samel 'sand bottom', OHG sant, MHG sant ~ sampt 'sand', Grk ἄμαθος 'sand'. The Greek form cannot be separated from ψάμαθος and ψάμμος 'sand', while the MHG sampt can hardly represent an old variant and, even if it is one, it can hardly be an alternative development of a PIE form. A reconstruction along the lines of *samhªdhos is impossible and the a vocalism suggests a non-IE status for the word. This is even more evident if Lat. sabulum is regarded cognate. The status of Arm awaz 'sand' is unclear."

S.v. Lat. sabulum 'coarse sand, gravel', from Proto-Italic *(p)saϸlo- / *(p)saflo- / *(p)sablo-, a substrate word *(p)sam- or *sab⁽ʰ⁾- (cf. IE cognates Gr. ψάμμος, (ψ)άμαθος, ψόμμος; OIc. sandr, OHG sant, MHG samt).
S.v. ἄμμος 'sand'. Generally the word is considered to be a contamination of ἄμαθος 'sand' with ψάμμος 'sand'. Of non-Indo-European origin.

Cf. R.S.P. Beekes s.v. SAND: "?*samh̥ªdhos 'sand' [IEW 146 (*bhes-); Wat 8 (*bhes-); Buck 1.215]. Lat. sabulum 'sand' ?saburra 'sand in a ship as ballast', ON sandr 'sand', NE (dial.) samel 'sand bottom', OHG sant, MHG sant ~ sampt 'sand', Grk ἄμαθος 'sand'. The Greek form cannot be separated from ψάμαθος and ψάμμος 'sand', while the MHG sampt can hardly represent an old variant and, even if it is one, it can hardly be an alternative development of a PIE form. A reconstruction along the lines of *samhªdhos is impossible and the a vocalism suggests a non-IE status for the word. This is even more evident if Lat. sabulum is regarded cognate. The status of Arm awaz 'sand' is unclear."
Under 1.215 SAND, Buck connects Greek, Germanic, and Romance cognates to an original stem *samdʰo-.

Under 1.215 SAND, Buck connects Greek, Germanic, and Romance cognates to an original stem *samdʰo-.
S.v. 1.215 SAND, Buck connects Greek, Germanic, and Romance cognates to an original stem *samdʰo-.

Earlier literature (cf. {ref Buck 1949}:22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- /cognate/284/, Greek ἄμμος /cognate/8262/, and Lat. sabulum /cognate/8263/ together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in {ref EIEC} objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in /cognate/8261/ are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. {ref Martirosyan 2010}:149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Reconstructs *sámh₂dʰos > (cf. Gk. ἄμαθος) > *sámədʰos > *sámdʰos > PGmc. *samdaz > ONor. sandr, OEng. sand, OHG sant.
Reconstructs *sámh₂dʰos > (cf. Gk. ἄμαθος) > *sámədʰos > *sámdʰos > PGmc. *samdaz > ONor. sandr, OEng. sand, OHG sant.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *samda- 'sand'. "Most forms point to *sanda- but MHG sampt can only be explained from *samda- < *samdʰ-o-, which is close to Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ-o- […]. Given the formal irreconcilabilities between Gm. *samda-, Lat. sabulum < *sadʰ-lo- and Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ- (the ψ of ψάμαθος was used to substitute s- after the Greek shift to h) the conclusion must be that the word is of non-IE origin ({ref Kuiper 1995}:67): it was probably adopted from a set of linguistically affiliated languages when Germanic, Italic, and Greek arrived in West-Europe. In view of the meaning 'sand', it is extremely unlikely, at any rate, that the word spread across Europe as a Wanderwort."

S.v. Proto-Germanic *samda- 'sand'. "Most forms point to *sanda- but MHG sampt can only be explained from *samda- < *samdʰ-o-, which is close to Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ-o- […]. Given the formal irreconcilabilities between Gm. *samda-, Lat. sabulum < *sadʰ-lo- and Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ- (the ψ of ψάμαθος was used to substitute s- after the Greek shift to h) the conclusion must be that the word is of non-IE origin ({ref Kuiper 1995}:67): it was probably adopted from a set of linguistically affiliated languages when Germanic, Italic, and Greek arrived in West-Europe. In view of the meaning 'sand', it is extremely unlikely, at any rate, that the word spread across Europe as a Wanderwort."

Given the formal irreconcilabilities between Gm. *samda-, Lat. sabulum < *sadʰ-lo- and Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ- (the ψ of ψάμαθος was used to substitute s- after the Greek shift to h) the conclusion must be that the word is of non-IE origin ({ref Kuiper 1995}:67): it was probably adopted from a set of linguistically affiliated languages when Germanic, Italic, and Greek arrived in West-Europe. In view of the meaning 'sand', it is extremely unlikely, at any rate, that the word spread across Europe as a Wanderwort."
S.v. *Hedʰ- 'sagen' [IEW 201]. Perfect stem, only Indo-Iranian.
S.v. Ved. √ah-² 'sagen, sprechen' only attested in perfect stems (cf. OAv. ādarə̄ 'sie sagen, nennen', YAv. ādarə 'id.'. The Indo-European origin is not established.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *HaH(a)d- 'to speak, say' (cf. Av. ād- 'speak, say', Khot. (+ *pati-) pätāy- 'to speak, say'). An IE provenance for this IIr. root cannot be ascertained.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *věděti 'know' from PIE *uoid- (cf. Skt. véda 3.sg.pf., Gk. οἴδα 3.sg.pf., Go. wait 3.sg.pf.).
Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯d- 'erblicken' (IEW 1125-7).

S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaub- 'to say (positively/negatively)' (OPers. gaub- (med.) 'to call oneself', MMP mw-, BMP gwb- /gō(w)-/ 'to say, speak', BSogd. γwβ- CSogd. γwb-, MSogd. γwβ- 'to praise', Chor. γwβ(y)- 'to boast, be proud', Bactr. γοβ- 'to make a (legal) statement, invoke the law', NP guftan/gōy-, Kurd. (Kurm.) gōtin, guhtin 'to speak'). No etymology. Cf. the Arm. loanword from Iranian govem 'I praise'.
S.v. Old Welsh guetid v. pres. 3 sg 'to speak', a cognate of dywedyd, etc.; IE etymology disputed. *u̯et- of this form was claimed by GPC to be a variant of IE *u̯ed- (Skt. vadati) (not in IEW).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *wet-o- 'say', from PIE *u̯eth₂- 'say' (cf. Lat. ueto 'forbid', Hitt. uttar 'word, speech').
S.v. *u̯eth₂- 'sagen' (not in IEW).
S.v. *mleu̯h₂- 'sprechen' (not in IEW).
S.v. Ved. √brav-¹ 'sprechen, sagen, reden', probably from PIE *mleu̯H- (cf. Cz. mluvati 'sprechen, reden', ORuss. mъlva, Russ. molvá 'Gerede, Gerücht', etc., TochB pälw- 'klagen').
S.v. *dʰeh₁- 'stellen, legen, setzen; herstellen, machen' (IEW 235-9).
Cf. s.v. Lith. bylóti 'speak' (OPruss. billītwei 'speak') and bìlti, derived from PIE *bʰelH- (cf. OHG bellan 'bark', OIc. belja 'roar').
S.v. ?*bʰelH- 'tönen, dröhnen' (IEW 123-4). Only Germanic and Balto-Slavic, difficult to distinguish from *bʰelh₁- 'heulen'.
S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'hören, tönen' [IEW 478].
Cf. s.v. Lith. girdė́ti 'hear', possibly from a PIE zero-grade formation *g⁽ʷ⁾rdʰ- (cf. OLith. gardas 'rumour, prank, messenger', OPr. gerdant [gerdaut] 'say').
Cf. s.v. *h₃óh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os n. 'Mund' (IEW 784f., EIEC 387).
From Celt. ber- 'tragen, gebären' with preverb ess-.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-o- 'carry, bear, bring' from PIE *bʰer- 'carry' (IEW 128-132).

Cf. s.v. Lat. gnārus 'knowing, experienced', whence Lat. narrāre 'to relate, tell'. Lat. gnārus from PIE *g̑nh₃-ro- 'knowing' (cf. Gk. γνώριμος 'well-known', etc.). The gemination in the verb narrāre can be explained from *nārāre by the littera-rule, which must have operated by Proto-Italic to judge from U. naratu 'speak, recite' (3.sg.imptv.), etc.
Cf. s.v. *g̑neh₃- 'erkennen' (IEW 376-8).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *velěti 'want, order', from PIE *u̯elh₁- (cf. OLith. velti 'allow', Lat. velle 'want', Goth. wiljan 'want').
Cf. s.v. *u̯elh₁- '(aus)wählen' (IEW 1137).
Cf. s.v. *ter- 'sprechen' (IEW 1088-9).
S.v. *tk̑ei̯- 'Landbau treiben, siedelen, wohnen' (IEW 626). Lat. ponō < *tk̑i-néH-nH-? Cf. discussion in n6.

S.v. Lat. pōnō, -ere 'to place, set, put' (repōnere 'to put back, down, replace'), from Proto-Italic *po-sine/o-, from PIE *po- + *tk̑-i-n-(e/o-) 'to build, live' via *po-sinō > *po-snō > *poznō > pōnō.
S.v. TochA träṅk-'sagen, sprechen', 'say, speak' (cf. TochB träṅk- 'beklagen', 'lament'). Proposed etymologies are doubtful.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *sekʷ-o- 'say', from PIE *sekʷ- 'say' (cf. Gk. ενν-έπω 'tell', Lat. in-seque 'say!', inquit 'says', OHG sagen).
S.v. Alb. gërvish 'to scratch'. A secondary formation based on *gërvij. The etymology is unclear. Perhaps a loanword from Slav. *grebǫ 'to rake up' according to Meyer Wb. 125.
S.v. gɛrvís, grɛvís 'scharre, kratze', from Serb. grebeti 'kratzen' = OCS grebą 'schabe'.
Cf. s.v. *rei̯k⁽ʷ⁾h₂- 'ritzen, kratzen (tr.)' (IEW 858).
S.v. Ved. √rekh- 'ritzen', from perhaps PIE *(h₁)rei̯k-h₂- (cf. Gk. ἐρείκω 'zerbreche, zerreiße', Lith. riẽkti 'schneiden', OHG riga, MHG rīhe 'Reihe, Linie' (~ Ved. rekhā-, lékhā-).
From Late Lat. *coctiare 'brennen, kochen' [cf. Lat. coquō, coquere, coxī, coctus 'cook'].
Cf. s.v. Lat. coquō, -ere 'to boil, bake', from Proto-Italic *kʷekʷe/o-  'to cook', from PIE *pekʷ-e/o- 'to cook'.
Cf. s.v. *pekʷ- 'reif machen, gar machen' (IEW 798).
Cf. s.v. *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' (IEW 1003).
S.v. Khot. vāma- 'sea, flood', which B. connects to Ved. aváni- 'stream' assuming a base au-, va-, vā- to IEW 78-81 au- 'be watery'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. aváni- 'Flußbett, Fluß, Strom'; connections of the Iranian material to that of the Indic are uncertain. Etymology of Iranian materials consequently unclear.
Suggests a derivation from *foirsge, an abstract noun of fairsing 'ample, broad, spacious'.

S.v. samudrá- 'breiter Strom, der durch die Vereinigung von zwei oder mehr Flüssen gebildet wird; Flut, Meer', formed from sam- (preverb 'together, with') and *udr- 'Wasser'. (cf. s.v. udán- 'Wasser' from Indo-Iranian *ud-r- / *ud-n-, based on PIE *u̯ed-).
Cf. s.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *saiwi- 'sea'. K. favours the connection with OI sīa, OE sēon, OHG sīgan 'filter, strain', etc. from PGmc. *sīhwan- 'to percolate' from PIE *sei̯kʷ-. [No discussion of the word as a possible pre-IE loanword.]

Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' may also be cognate to this class, [cf. Abaev 1959-1995 Vol. II, pp.68-69]. If the Ossetic form it is not a loanword, then the distribution of the lexeme is not exclusively to the European branches of IE.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *moŗe 'sea' (ESSJa XIX 227-230), from PIE *mor-i- (cf. Lat. mare, OIr. muir, Goth. marei).
Cf. Oss. mal 'глубокая стоячая вода', from IE *mōri or *mōryo- 'sea' with regular *r > l before *i.
Cf. Lith. mãrios 'isthmus; (dial.) sea', from PIE *mor-i- (cf. Lat. mare; OIr. muir, Goth. marei).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *mari- 'lake, sea', from PIE *mor-i- (cf. Oss. mal 'stagnant water', Lat. mare 'sea', OIr. muir 'id.', MW mor 'id.' < *mor-i-; Lith. mãrios (f.pl.) 'id.' < *mor-ieh₂-, OCS morje, Ru. móre, SCr. mȍre, môre 'id.' < mor-io-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *mori- 'sea', from PIE *mori- 'sea, standing water' (cf. Lat. mare, OHG mari, meri 'sea, lake', OCS morje 'sea', Oss. mal 'standing water').
S.v. Alb. det 'sea', from Proto-Albanian *deubeta 'depth', based on PIE *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' (cf. Gmc. *deupiϸο 'depth').

S.v. Goth. S12. *saiws 'λίμνη', 'sea' (only dat.sg. saihwa). 'marshland' in gen.pl. -we, *marisaihws 'sea' only acc.sg., from Proto-Germanic *saiwi- (cf. OI sær, sjōr, OE sǣ, sā-, OFris sē, OS, OHG sēo). No accepted etymology. Three main possibilities: (1) a borrowing from a non-IE pre-Gmc. people, (2) a connection to Lat. saeuus 'raging', or (3) a connection with OE sīgan, OFris sīga, OS, OHG sīgan, 'flow down from', 'sink' and OI sīa, OE sēon, OHG sīgan 'filter, strain', ultimately from PIE *sei̯kʷ-: *soikʷis > PGmc. -gw´- > -w-. In view of the absence of an IE word for 'sea' a borrowing from a non-IE, pre-Gmc. people is more likely.

S.v. Goth. S12. *saiws 'λίμνη', 'sea' (only dat.sg. saihwa). 'marshland' in gen.pl. -we, *marisaihws 'sea' only acc.sg., from Proto-Germanic *saiwi- (cf. OI sær, sjōr, OE sǣ, sā-, OFris sē, OS, OHG sēo). No accepted etymology. Three main possibilities: (1) a borrowing from a non-IE pre-Gmc. people, (2) a connection to Lat. saeuus 'raging', or (3) a connection with OE sīgan, OFris sīga, OS, OHG sīgan, 'flow down from', 'sink' and OI sīa, OE sēon, OHG sīgan 'filter, strain', ultimately from PIE *sei̯kʷ-: *soikʷis > PGmc. -gw´- > -w-. In view of the absence of an IE word for 'sea' a borrowing from a non-IE, pre-Gmc. people is more likely.

S.v. Goth. F11. fairguni 'ὄρος', 'mountain, mountain range', from PGmc. *fergunjō (cf. OE firgi/en- + holt 'mountain wood', -strēam 'mountain stream'. Other connections within Germanic and outside Germanic widely disputed, principally because of proposed etymologies to with names of gods and mythological beings, among such proposals include OI Fjǫrgynn 'father of Frigg (Freya)', Fjǫrgyn 'mother of Thor' = Jǫrð 'mother earth, earth, country'. Alternatively PIE *perkʷ- 'oak' (OI fura, OE furh, OHG for(a)ha 'pine', OHG fereh-eih 'oak', Lang fureha 'Italian oak', cf. also Lith. Perkū́nas 'thunder, Thundergod'. Postulations of relations between other IE branches rest on conclusions made through comparative mythology (in which folk-etymological reshaping may have been a factor in lexical developments) and therefore debate over these etymologies will doubtlessly continue.

S.v. Goth. M83. munϸs 'στόμα', 'mouth' (cf. OI munnr, mūðr, OS muð, 'mouth, opening', OFris 'mūth, mund' OHG munt 'mouth'; possibly also to OI mēl 'minþla, OE miþl, OHG mindil 'bit, bridle'). Two possible etymologies: (1) to PIE *menth- 'chew, mouth' (Gk. μασάομαι, Lat. mandō 'chew', or, less likely, (2) PIE *men- 'project' (Lat. ē-minēre 'stand out', mentum 'chin' < *mn̥-to- (cf. Wel mant 'jaw(bone)', MIr. mant 'gum, jaw(bone)' (cf. IEW 732-33 menth-, 726 men-).

Generally considered to be of IE origin, but the precise IE etymology is disputed. From PIE *ment-, if {ref Kroonen 2013}:376-377's reconciliation of the two earlier possible etymologies from {ref IEW} (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:261) is correct. Etymology outside of Germanic otherwise uncertain; cf. {ref Boutkan & Siebinga 2005} for extensive discussion of alternative hypotheses.
S.v. Goth. F62. flodus 'ποταμός', 'stream'. Goth. flodus is with PIE *-tu- from PIE *plō/ē- in Hom. δακρυπλώειν 'shed tears, πλώω 'navigate', πλωτός 'swimming'.
Cf. s.v. *pleh₃- 'schwimmen, fließen' [IEW 836]. Traditionally interpreted as a lengthened-grade form of *pleu̯-, now apparently a parallel root.
S.v. Goth. W28. wamba 'γαστήρ, κοιλία', 'womb, belly'. No etymology.
S.v. Goth. U2. ubils 'κακός', 'bad, evil', cf. Tischler (HEG I:331-32) against the connection with Hitt. ḫuu̯appa- 'bad' made by {ref Watkins 1969}:30.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *vъšь 'louse' "It is unclear if and how Slavic *vъšь and Baltic *ut- are related. The forms may have been distorted for reasons of taboo. It cannot be excluded that OHG lūs f. 'louse' also belongs here."

S.v. Proto-Celtic *luwā 'louse' "The PCelt. form is compatible with both PIE *lowHo- > *luwo-, and with PIE *luHo- > *luwo-. The Germanic reflexes contain a sigmatic suffix (PIE *luHs-). Skt. yū́ka- 'louse' might be from *luH-keh₂, but *y- instead of *r- is unexplained. ToA lu 'animal' (ToB luwo) might also be ultimately from the same PIE root, but with an unusual generalization of meaning."
S.v. utė̃ 'Laus', to be connected with Slav. vъšь 'Laus'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *vъšь 'louse' "It is unclear if and how Slavic *vъšь and Baltic *ut- are related. The forms may have been distorted for reasons of taboo. It cannot be excluded that OHG lūs f. 'louse' also belongs here."
S.v. Proto-Germanic *lūsz, Related to W (pl.) llau 'lice', Corn. (pl.) low 'id.', Bret. (pl.) laou 'id.' < luu̯ā.

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic /cognate/8267/, Baltic /cognate/8266/, Slavic /cognate/8265/, and Indic(-Nuristani) /cognate/7396/ have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

Traditionally reconstructed as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) 'Laus', with frequent tabooistic distortions in individual branches.
Traditionally reconstructed as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) 'Laus', with frequent tabooistic distortions in individual branches.
Traditionally reconstructed as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) 'Laus', with frequent tabooistic distortions in individual branches.
Cf. s.v. *(s)kedh₂- 'zersplittern, zerstreuen' (IEW 918-919).
Cf. s.v. TochAB kät- 'streuen, strew', from PIE *(s)kedh₂- 'zersplittern, zerstreuen' (LIV² 550f.).

S.v. Hitt. 𒌋 u̯ar(ru)u̯alan- 'seed, progeny'. The use of gloss-wedges as well as the occurrence of a Luw. erg.sg. u̯aru̯alanteš indicates we are dealing with an originally Luwian word. No further etymology.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fraiwa- 'seed'. Further etymology debated (cf. discussion in Kroonen for various proposals).

S.v. Alb. farë 'seed, semen, kin', from Proto-Albanian *sparā < PIE *sporā, closely connected to Gk. fem. σπορά 'seed', ultimately from PIE *sper- 'to spill, sow' (cf. Gk. σπείρω 'id.', Gk. σπέρμα 'semen, seed').

S.v. Lat. labor 'work, labour'. "Often connected, albeit hesitantly, with labō 'to waver', under the assumption of a semantic shift from 'nearly collapsing under a load' > 'burden' > 'labour'. This seems unconvincing".
S.v. sī́vyº- 'nähen', from PIE *si̯eu̯h₁-/*si̯uh₁- (cf. Lat. suere, Goth. siujan 'nähen', Lith. siū́ti 'nähen, benähen, schneidern' Hitt. šum(m)anzan- 'Strick, Seil', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *hi̯au̯H- 'to sew', from PIE *si̯eu̯h₁- 'to sew'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *šiti 'sew', from PIE *siuH- (cf. Skt. sī́vyati, Lat. suere, Go. siujan).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *siujan- 'to sew', from PIE *siHu-ie-.
S.v. Lat. suō, -ere 'to sew', from PIE *siuH-ie/o- 'to sew'.
S.v. 13444 Ved. sī́vyati 'sews' RV. 2. sīvayati Lalit. [√siv].
Cf. s.v. ?*derbʰ- '(Grasbüschel) zusammenbinden, flechten' (IEW 211-2, 257).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *čaiH-¹ 'to sew'. No clear IE etymology.

S.v. TochB skiyo 'shade, shadow', from PIE *sk̑oihª (gen. *sk̑ii̯éhªs-) 'shade, shadow' (cf. Gk. σκιά 'shadow', Alb. hije 'shadow', Av. asaya- 'who throws no shadow', Skt. chāyā́ 'shade, shadow, etc.).
S.v. Alb. hije 'shadow', a singularised plural of an archaic hē, going back to Proto-Albanian *skijā, connected with PIE *sk̑āi- ~ *sk̑ī- (cf. Skt. chāyā́-. Gk. σκιά, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *skadu- 'shadow', from PIE *skh₃-tu- (cf. Gk. σκότος 'darkness, dark' < *skh₃-to-, OIr. scáth 'shadow', MW ysgawd 'shade, darkness' < *skoh₃-to-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *skāto- 'shadow', from PIE *skeh₃t- (cf. OE sceadu, Gk. σκότος).

Cf. s.v. σκιά 'shade' (< PIE *skeh₂-ih₂, gen. *skh₂-ieh₂-s 'shadow') and s.v. σκότος 'darkness, dark' (< PIE *skeh₃t- or *skoto- 'shadow, dark'). Note p.1351 "The relation [of Gk. σκιά] with σκότος is unclear".

The communis opinio is that the relationship between the lexemes in /cognate/5058/ and /cognate/8269/ have irreconcilable root reconstructions and must be separated into *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂- and *s⁽k̑⁾eh₃-. Cognacy has been thus assigned in this manner according to the main etymological authorities. 

The reconstruction of two separate roots, however crucially hinges on the interpretation of the Greek evidence: Germanic lexemes from PGmc. *skadu- < *s⁽k̑⁾H-tu- appear to be a close parallel formation to Greek σκοτός 'darkness' which reflect earlier *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-tó-.  These are potentially different roots, but this is based entirely on the witness of the Greek evidence.  In any case, the difference is based on disagreement over root-final *h₂ vs. *h₃.  The identity of the laryngeal in σκία < *skh₂-ih₂ is assumed from Att.-Ion. σκηνή, West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́ 'tent' < 'cloth to provide shade' < (transponat) *skeh₂-néh₂ (cf. Beekes 2010, s.v. σκία).  In Ancient Greek does exist another example of a doublet of root-final *h₂ vs. *h₃, namely the dialectal doublet of Attic-Ionic πρῶτος 'first' (ostensibly from *pr̥h₃-to-) against West Greek πρᾶτος 'first' (ostensibly from < *pr̥h₂-to-), cf. Ved. pūrvá- 'first' (formally from *pr̥H-u̯ó-).  One could imagine there may have been some inner-Greek phonological or derivational reason to account for the discrepancy in vocalism.

It seems therefore very possible, in view of the phonological and semantic similarities, that the Tocharian, Greek, Albanian, Indo-Iranian, and Balto-Slavic lexemes in /cognate/5058/ and the Celtic and Germanic lexemes (+Gk. σκότος) in /cognate/8269/ go back to the same root etymology with differing derivational morphology. Cognacy has been coded, however, according to the prevailing opinion.

S.v. *ksneu̯- 'schärfen' (IEW 585). Cf. n1: Verbal only Indo-Iranian, cf. Lat. nouācula 'Messer' to a *nouāre, which is probably denominal to *ksnou̯o- or ksnou̯ā-. A connection with *kseu̯- is probable; is *ksneu̯- abstracted from a nasal-present?
S.v. Ved. √kṣnav- 'wetzen, schärfen, schleifen' (cf. Ir. xšnau- 'hören'), from PIE *ksneu̯- (cf. Lat. novācula 'Messer, Rasiermesser, Dolch' [from *novāre 'wetzen, schaben']).
Cf. s.v. 2. *su̯er- 'schmerzen, schwären' (IEW 1050).

Cf. s.v. Ved. nakhá- 'Nagel, Fingernagel, Zehennagel, Kralle, Klaue'. "Iir. *nā̆kʰ- ist von idg. *h₃Engʰ-/*h₃nEgʰ- 'Nagel, Kralle' (~ lat. unguis, lit. nãgas Nagel u.a. o. I 49) nicht zu trennen." Cf. notes to entry in Mayrhofer for further discussion of the phonetic difficulties of the Indo-Iranian forms.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *krapp/bōn- 'to scratch', from PIE *grobʰ-néh₂- (cf. Gk. γράφω 'to scratch, carve, write' < *gr̥bʰ-e-).

S.v. scratch (v.) "Apparently produced by a confusion of the synonymous scrat n.1, cratch v.". Cf. s.v. †cratch v. "Etymological history obscure: somewhat similar forms are Middle Dutch, Middle Low German kratsen (modern Dutch and Low German krassen), Old High German chrazzôn, Middle High German kratzen, kretzen, German kratzen; also Danish kradse, Swedish kratsa. Of all these the original seems to be the Old High German chrazzon, which corresponds to a West Germanic *krattôn, apparently the source of French gratter, Provençal gratar, Spanish gratar, Italian grattare."

S.v. Arm. kʻerem 'to scratch, rub, chop, skin; to write, carve', from PIE *(s)ker- 'to cut, split' (Gk. κείρω 'to cut (off), shave, mow off, ravage', OHG sceran 'to cut', Lith. skiriù, skìrti 'to separate', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *drep- 'abschneiden, (ab)reißen' (IEW 211).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian ?*draub- 'to scratch, peel off?'. Alternatively Steblin-Kamenskij 1999: 151 derives the Wa. form from IE *drōp- ‘to cut off’, Russ. drápat’ (obs.) ‘to scratch’ Gr. δρέπω ‘to cut off’, etc. < Proto-Iranian *drap- 'to wear, put on clothes'.

Inner-Iranian etymology unclear. (cf. Cheung 2007:78-79). Perhaps to be connected with PIE *drep- 'to cut off' in /cognate/2032/ (LIV² 128-129), alternatively to PIE *dʰreu̯bʰ- 'to scratch (off)' (LIV² 156).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *drāpati 'scratch' (ESSJa V 101-102), cf. Gk. δρέπω 'pluck'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *klawō- 'claw' (OEng. clāwu, clā, Eng. claw, Du. klauw, OHG klāwa, klā, klō(a); Germ. Klaue, ON kló, Far. klógv, Elfd. kluo).  Exclusively a Germanic word.
S.v. ?*gʰrebʰ- 'graben' (IEW 455-6). Only Germanic and Balto-Slavic.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *greti 'dig, scrape, rake' (ESSJa VII 109-110), from Balto-Slavic *greb- (Lith. grė́bti 'rake, seize, rob', Latv. grebt 'scrape, excavate, seize'), in turn from PIE *gʰrebʰ- (Skt. gr̥bhṇā́ti 'seize, take hold', Goth. graban 'dig').
NB: LIV² 201 assigns the Vedic comparandum gr̥bhṇā́ti 'ergreift' cited by Derksen (2008:187) to a different root *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 445).
S.v. Sp. rascar, cf. Late Lat. *rasicare, derived from radere 'afeitar, raer', 'rascar'.

S.v. Lat. rādō, -ere 'to scrape, scratch, shave', from Proto-Italic *rasd-e/o-, from PIE ?*rasd- (cf. W rhathu, Bret. rahein 'to scrape, shave', from PCl. *rasd-e/o- 'to scrape, scratch'). Because the word is an Italo-Celtic isogloss, one cannot be confident of an IE origin.
S.v. ?*rasd- 'kratzen' (IEW 854).

If one follows Orel (1998:195), perhaps to *gʰrebh₂- (LIV² 201) or to ?*gʰrebʰ- (LIV² 201-202). The relationship of the two roots themselves as reconstructed in LIV² remains unclear (cf. LIV² s.v. ?*gʰrebʰ- n1).
S.v. 4874 *cul- 'fidget, itch'.
S.v. 2689 kaṇḍūyáti 'scratches' TS., 'itches' Śārṅg., °yana- n. 'scratching, itching'. KātyŚr. [kaṇḍū- ]

S.v. Proto-Germanic *skrepanan-, strong verb OE screpan 'to scrape, to scratch' MDu schrepen 'to shove', Related to Lith. skrembù, skrèbti 'to get a thin crust, to stiffen', Latv. skrabt 'to scratch', Slav. *skrebǫ, *skrebti 'to scratch'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *skrībb-ā- 'scratch' (MIr. scrípaid 'scratches'), from PIE *skri(H)bʰ-(?). "The connection of MIr. scrípaid and Lat. scribō appears probable, but the exact relationship of these two verbs is uncertain. MIr. -p- points to a geminate in PCelt., and the long *-ī- is difficult to reconcile with Umbr. screhto, Osc. scriftas < *skribʰ-to- (Lat. scrībo is presumably from *skrei̯bʰ-)."
S.v. Lat. scabō, -ere 'to scratch', from PIE *skbʰ-ro- 'to scratch, plane' (cf. Lith. skõbti, skabiù 'to plane', Goth. skaban 'to shave', OHG scaban 'to plane').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *skaban- 'to shave, scrape', from PIE *skh₂bʰ-ie- (cf. Gk. σκάπτω 'to dig (out), work the earth' < *skh₂bʰ-ie-, Lat. scabō, -ere 'scratch' < *skh₂bʰ-e-, Lith. skóbti 'to hollow out' < *skeh₂bʰ-e-, OCS skobelь, Ru. skóbelь 'plane' < *skh₂ebʰ-l-io-.). A strong verb related to PGmc. *skapp/bōn- 'to shave, scrape'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *česati 'scratch, comb' (ESSJa IV 85-87), from PIE *kes- (cf. Hitt. kiszi 'combs', OIr. cír 'comb', OE heord 'hair').
Cf. Lith. kasýti 'scratch constantly' (Latv. kasît 'plane, rake, scratch'), from PIE *kes- (cf. PSl. *česati 'scratch, comb', Hitt. keš- comb, card').
S.v. 2972 kaṣati 'scratches' ChUp., 'rubs on a touchstone' Pāṇ. com., káṣ° 'hurts' Dhātup., and s.v. 2979 *kaṣyatē 'is scratched'.

S.v. Ved. √kaṣ- 'kratzen, schaben'. "Wohl „eine alte umgangsprachliche Form“ von √karṣ- 'ziehen, furchen'". If so, s.v. Ved. √karṣ- 'ziehen, schleppen, pflügen', probably from PIE *kʷels- (cf. Hitt. gul-ša-an-zi 'sie ritzen ein', Gk. τέλσον 'letzte Furche des Akers').
S.v. 3729 kṣuráti 'cuts, scratches, digs', churáti 'cuts off, incises' Dhātup. (cf. s.v. 3727 kṣurá m. 'razor').
Cf. s.v. ξύω 'to shave, smooth, scratch', from PIE *kseu- 'shave, scratch'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. kṣurá- 'Schermesser, Rasiermesser, scharfes Messer', from which a secondary verbal root kṣur- 'cut' was abstracted (cf. Pāli khurati 'scrapes', etc.).

S.v. Lat. umbra 'ombre, ombrage'. A connection with Skt. andáḥ = Av. andō 'aveugle' and Ved. ándhaḥ 'obscurité' is plausible; for the suffix cf. Lat. tenebrae. Lith. ùnksnā 'ombre' has also been connected; umbra would be from *unks-ra.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *těnь 'shadow'. "Probably a transformation of *sěnь on the basis of *tьma 'darkness' (cf. OCS tьmьnъ 'dark' derived from BSl. *timʔ-/*tomʔ- : Lith. tamsùs, Latv. tùmšs, tìmšs).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *skuwwan- 'mirror' (Go. skuggwa 'mirror'; ON skuggi, etc. 'shadow'), an n-stem derived from the PIE root *skeu- 'to see'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *skuwwōn (Goth. skuggwa 'mirror', ON skuggi 'shade, shadow', OE scúwa 'id.' etc.), related to Skt. skunā́ti, Arm. cʻiw 'roof', OIr. cúl 'back', from PIE *(s)k̑euə- 'to cover'.

Cf. s.v. Goth. S95 *skuggwa 'ἔσοπτρον', 'mirror'. Two possible etymologies: either (1) to PIE *(s)keu̯ə- / *(s)kū- 'cover' (Skt. skunā́ti 'cover', Gk. σκῡ́νια (pl.) 'brows', or (2) to PIE *skeu̯- 'pay attention to, observe', although this root is primarily West Germanic.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *stěnь 'shadow'. See Proto-Slavic *sěnь [cf. /cognate/5058/], the word-initial *st- may be explained by assuming contamination with *těnь [cf. /cognate/5149/].
S.v. TochB akwatse 'sharp', which reflects a putative *hₐek̑utyo-, a derivative of the root *hₐek̑- 'sharp'.
Cf. s.v. Alb. eh 'to sharpen', from Proto-Alb. *akska, derived from PIE *ak̑- 'sharp'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ostrъ 'sharp', from PIE *h₂ek̑-ro- (cf. Gk. ἄκρος 'pointed', Lat. ācer 'sharp').
S.v. Lith. aštrùs 'sharp' (Latv. ass 'sharp'), from PIE *h₂ek̑-ro- (cf. Gk. ἄκρος 'pointed', Lat. ācer 'sharp').
S.v. Lat. ācer, -is, -e 'sharp', from PIE *h₂ek̑-ro- 'sharp' (cf. Gk. ἄκρος 'highest, outermost', OLith. ãštras, Lith. aštrùs, Latv. ass, OCS ostrъ, Ru. óstryj 'sharp').
Cf. s.v. Ved. √śā- 'schärfen, wetzen', from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- (cf. Arm. sowr 'scharf', Lat. cōs, cōt- 'Wetzstein', catus 'scharf, scharfsinnig', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-7).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *lim-ā- 'sharpen, polish'; "These words are probably related to Lat. līma 'carpenter's file', OHG slīm 'mud, slime', slīman 'make smooth', etc. The PIE root would be *(s)ley- (IEW 663), with the suffix *-mo- in Italic, Germanic, and Celtic. However, the length in OIr. límaid is unexpected (but cf. the short vowel in 3 pl. Pret. limsat)."

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *bitra- (adj.) 'bitter, sharp', a ra-stem created to PGmc. *bītan-, ultimately derived from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' (cf. Skt. binátti 'to split, break, destroy', Lat. findō, -ere, 'split, cleave' < *bʰi-né-d-ti, *bʰi-n-d-énti, Gk. φείδομαι 'to spare, save, refrain from').
Cf. s.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (IEW 116-7).
