S.v. rräjsaa- 'sharp', from *ričaka-, derived from PIE *reik(h)- (IEW 858), cf. Gk. ἐρείκω 'break up', Lith. riekiù, riẽkti 'cut', Ved. rikháti, likháti 'scratch'.
Cf. s.v. *rei̯k⁽ʷ⁾h₂- 'ritzen, kratzen (tr.)' (IEW 858).
S.v. Ved. √rekh- 'ritzen', from perhaps PIE *(h₁)rei̯k-h₂- (cf. Gk. ἐρείκω 'zerbreche, zerreiße', Lith. riẽkti 'schneiden', OHG riga, MHG rīhe 'Reihe, Linie' (~ Ved. rekhā-, lékhā-).

Cf. s.v. Ved. dhā́ra-² 'Schneide (des Schwertes, des Messers)' (cf. YAv. dārā- 'Klinge', tiži.dāra- 'mit scharfer Schneide', Khot. dārā- 'Schneide' CSogd. xγry d'r 'sword-blade', Pašto lōr 'Seite, Rand', from IIr. *dʰārā- 'Klinge, Schneide'). Outside connections not certain.
From Lat. *trīnicare 'dreiteilen'.
Cf. s.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (IEW 116-7).

The form 'hurniyaz' is inherited from the Ringe et al. 2002 wordlist used in IELex. I am assuming that this would be an -nt- participle with passive meaning, formed to the verb ḫa/urnai- 'to sprinkle, to drip'; thus the intended meaning would be *'sprinkled' > 'wet'. Unfortunately, this form does not exist in HW² Ḫ (cf. s.v. ḫarnai-, ḫarniya-, pp.315-316), nor does is it listed in Kloekhorst EDHIL (cf. s.v. ḫarna-/ḫarn-, pp.308-309), nor is it to be found in Puhvel HED H (cf. s.v. hurnai-, hurniya-). As far as I have been able to ascertain, this participial form with the meaning 'wet' does not actually exist. It is not clear to me, at least, whether the unattested participle of ḫarnai- 'to sprinkle', would have actually meant 'wet'. Consequently, I have marked this lexeme as non-Swadesh.
S.v. Goth. B85. bloϸ 'αἷμα', 'blood'. Etymology unclear. With a suffix *-to- Possibly to PIE *bʰlō- < *bʰel- 'swell, gush' as in *bloma-; alternatively *bleh₂- 'blow' as in *uf-blesan.

S.v. Goth. F101. *fugls 'πετεινόν', 'bird'. "Probably from *flug-la- with loss of l by dissimilation". If so, then from PIE *pleu-k- (as in Lith. plaũkti 'swim', plùnksna 'feather'). Cf. entry in Lehmann for references to other hypotheses.
S.v. Goth. A139. *ams or *amsa 'ὧμος', 'shoulder', from PIE *omsos 'shoulder' (Skt. áṁsas, Gk. ὧμος, Lat. umerus, Arm us, TochA es, B āntse).
S.v. Goth. A245. *azgo 'σποδός', 'ashes' (OI aska, OE asca, æsca, OHG asca 'ashes'). From PIE *ā̆s- 'burn' (Arm. ačiun, Skt. ā́sas 'ashes, dust', Lat. areō 'to dry', Hitt. ḫašša- 'ashes, hearth').
Cf. s.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837). An enlargement of *pleu̯- only found in Germanic and Baltic.

S.v. TochB käm- 'come', which with TochA kum- reflects Proto-Tocharian *k(w)äm-, from PIE *gʷem- 'come, go' (cf. Skt. gácchati 'goes', Av. jasaiti 'id.', Gk. βαίνω 'go', Lat. veniō 'come', Goth. qiman 'come', Lith. gemù 'be born', etc.).
S.v. Ved. √gam- 'sich bewegen, gehen, kommen' (cf. OAv. ǰamaitī, ǰimaitī, YAv. gata-), from PIE *gʷem- (cf. Gk. βαίνω, Lat. veniō, Goth. qiman, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *gam-¹ 'to come', from PIE *gʷem- (cf. Ved. gam- 'to move, to go, to come').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *kweman- ~ *kuman- 'to come', from PIE *gʷ(é)m-e- (cf. Skt. gácchati, Av. jasaiti, Gk. βάσκω < *gʷm̥-sk̑e-; Gk. βαίνω, Lat. veniō < *gʷm-ie-, etc.).

S.v. Goth. R9. *raϸs 'λόγος', 'account, explanation' (L 16.2), 'ἀριθμός', 'number, count' (J 6.10, R 9.27); *ga-raϸjan, only nom. pl. in p.a.pl. -ϸana 'ἀριθμεῖν', 'count', from PIE *ar-, *rē-, *rə- *rī̆- 'fit together' (cf. Lat. reor 'think, calculate', ratiō 'account', OIr. rīm 'number', rīmid 'counts', Wel. rhyf 'number', cyf-rif 'count, recount, narrate').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *rīmā 'number, count', derived from PIE *h₂rei̯H- 'count' (IEW 60), cf. Gk. ἀριθμός 'number', OE rím 'number, calculation', TochB yärm 'measure'.
S.v. Goth. Q1. qainon 'κόπτεσθαι, πενθεῖν', 'mourn, sorrow', cf. OI kveina, OE cwānian 'lament, sorrow'. No clear cognates outside of Germanic.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *kwainōjan- 'to lament, mourn, wail', denominative verb derived from an unattested feminine *kwainō-, which is in turn likely to be derived from *kwīnan- 'to dwindle'. If so, then from *gʷei̯H- also found in Skt. jáyati 'to overpower'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *kwainōjanan-, of unknown origin.

S.v. Goth. *maitan- 'κόπτω', 'cut, hew'. Etymology doubtful. Possibly from PIE *may(d-) 'strike, cut off' (cf. OIr. mael 'bald, without horns', dubiously Gk. μιστύλλω 'chop in bits', μίτυλος 'mutilated, hornless', Lat. mutilus 'mutilated'), for which cf. IEW 697 s.v. *smēy- 'slice'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *maitan- 'to hew, cut'. "In view of the presumably related causative *maidjan- 'to hurt' it seems reasonable, at any rate, to assume that the original form of the verb was *maiϸan-. As a result, the reconstruction of a PIE root *meid- (Pokorny IEW: 697) must be abandoned."
Cf. s.v. Ved. múhur (adv.) 'plotzlich, sofort, augenblicklich' (cf. YAv. mərəzu- 'kurz', Khot. mulysga-, BSogd. mwrzk- 'kurz'), from PIE *mr̥g̑ʰú- (cf. Gk. βραχύς 'kurz', etc.).

S.v. Khot. mulysga- 'short', cf. Av. mərəzu- 'short', BSogd. mwrzk- 'short', from PIE *mreg̑ʰu- (cf. Ved. múhur, Gk. βραχύς, Lat. breuis, Goth. maurg-, gamaurgjan 'to shorten', OHG murgi 'short', etc.).

S.v. Lat. brevis 'short', from PIE *mrg̑ʰ-ú- 'short' (cf. Ved. múhuḥ, múhu 'suddenly', Av. mərəzu-, Oss. morz 'short' < PIr. *m(a)rzu-, Gk. βραχύς 'short', Goth. *maurgus in ga-maurgjan 'shorten', OHG murg(i) 'short'). The Latin form must have re-introduced the full-grade, presumably on analogy to the comparative and superlative (cf. Cowgill 1970:127).
Cf. regarding the reintroduction of e-grade vocalism in Lat. brevis.
Fr. court < Lat. cŭrtus 'kurz'

S.v. Lat. curtus 'mutilated, circumcised; imperfect'. There are two possible root etymologies; either (1) to *(s)ker-, via *kr-to- > *korto- > *kurto- with the development *orC > *urC (cf. Hitt. karš(ii̯e/a)- 'to cut, separate, stop', CLuw. *karš- < *kers-; Gk. κείρω 'to cut off, shave', καρτός 'cut off, shorn', Arm. kʻerem 'to scratch, cut off', etc.), or (2) to PIE *kʷer- (cf. Hitt. kuerzi 'cut', Ved. kr̥ṇóti 'make'). In view of the fact that the latter only means 'cut' in Hittite, while the forms of *(s)ker- have the meanings 'cut, shave' and the semantics of curtus meaning 'mutilated, circumcised', de Vaan's preferred etymology is to *(s)ker- (but cf. Ernout & Meillet, Meiser 1998, who prefer *kʷer-).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kortъkъ 'short' (ESSJa XI 101-104), cf. Lith. kartùs 'bitter', derived from PIE *(s)kert- (cf. Ved. kr̥ntáti 'cut (off), split, break' etc.).

S.v. Engl. short, "The Germanic adjective is commonly regarded as a popular Latin *excurtus ( < Latin ex- + curtus ). On this view it would be parallel in origin with the synonymous Old Frisian, Old Saxon kurt , Dutch kort , Old High German (Middle High German, modern German) kurz , a West Germanic adoption of Latin curtus . The Romanic languages, however, afford no evidence of a popular Latin *excurtus , and it is unlikely that such a form existed. It is possible that Germanic *skurto- may be an altered adoption of Latin curtus , with prefixed s either due to some Germanic analogy or attracted from the ending of a preceding word in some Latin context. Some scholars, however, regard *skurto- as a native Germanic word, < a root *skert- (supposed to be evidenced in Middle High German scherze , scherzel small piece) < pre-Germanic *skerd-, an extension of *sker- to cut."

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *skertan- 'to cut off'. "The root final t points to influence from an iterative *skurtōn- < *skrdʰ-neh₂-, cf. OHG, MHG schurz, OE scort, sceort 'cut off; short' < *skurta). There is no compelling reason to assume that the latter adjective was borrowed from an unattested Lat. *excurtus".
S.v. Proto-Germanic *skurtaz, probably related to OIr. scerdid 'to scrape off', Lith. skérdžiu, skérdėti 'to get fissures, to crack'.
S.v. curtus, -a, -um 'tronqué, écourté', d'où 'châtre' ou 'circoncis'. An adjective in -to- from the root *kʷer-. Alternatively to *(s)ker-.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaH-³ 'to sing, call', from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eH-(i)- 'to sing' (cf. ORuss. gajati 'to croak [ravens]', Lith. giedóti 'to sing').
S.v. Ved. √gā-² 'singen, besingen, in singendem Ton sprechen', probably PIE *geh₂-i̯- (cf. ORuss. gajati 'krächzen' (Rabe), Lith. giedóti (1.sg. gíedu) 'singen').
S.v. Lith. giedóti 'sing' (Latv. dziêdât 'sing'), from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eHi- (cf. Skt. gā́yati 'sing'). "In Baltic the root *g⁽ʷ⁾eHi- apparently received an enlargement *-d⁽ʰ⁾-."

S.v. Lat. canō, -ere 'to sing', from PIE *kh₂n-e- 'to sing' (cf. OIr. cainid, ·cain, pf. cechain, W canu, Bret. cana 'sing', Gk. ἠι-κανός 'singing early' = 'cock', Goth. hana, OHG hano 'cock', OIc. hœna, OHG huon 'hen' < PGmc. *xan-, *xōn-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kan-o- 'sing', derived from PIE *kan- (cf. Lat. canō 'sing', Goth. hana 'cock').
Cf. s.v. Khot. āljs- 'to sing'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *swan-na- 'sound, play (an instrument)', whence OIr. seinnid, -seinn. From PIE *su̯enh₂- '(produce) sound' (cf. Skt. svan-, Lat. sonō, sonus 'sound', OE swinn 'music').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *singwan- 'to sing', from PIE *séngʷʰ-e- (cf. Gk. ὀμφή 'divine voice or revelation, oracle, emblem' < *songʷʰ-eh₂-). A Germanic-Greek isogloss.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *kweϸan- 'to say' < *gʷét-e- (IE?). Possibly comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite' < *gʷot-ie-(?), although this verb can be reconstructed differently and is conspicuously similar to Arm. gočʻem 'to shout' < *u̯okʷ-ie- (cf. {ref Olsen 1999}:811).
S.v. ?*gʷet- 'sagen' (IEW 480-1).

S.v. Proto-Iranian *srau̯- 'to hear, listen', from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' (cf. Ved. śrav- 'to hear', Gk. ἔκλυον 'heard', κλυτός 'famous', Lat. cluēre 'to be called, to be mentioned', Toch. käln- 'to sound', Latv. sludinât 'to declare', etc.).

S.v. Ved. √śrav- 'hören', from PIE *k̑leu̯- (cf. Arm. aor. low(a), pres. lse- 'hören', Gk. ἔκλυον 'hörte', κλυτός 'berühmt', Lat. cluēre 'heißen, genannt werden', OIr. ro-cluinethar 'hört', OHG hliumant 'Ruf, Gerücht, Leumand', Latv. sludinât 'verkünden', Toch AB käln- 'tönen').

Cf. s.v. Ved. √śrav- 'hören', from PIE *k̑leu̯- (cf. Arm. aor. low(a), pres. lse- 'hören', Gk. ἔκλυον 'hörte', κλυτός 'berühmt', Lat. cluēre 'heißen, genannt werden', OIr. ro-cluinethar 'hört', OHG hliumant 'Ruf, Gerücht, Leumand', Latv. sludinât 'verkünden', Toch AB käln- 'tönen').

S.v. Proto-Iranian *srau̯- 'to hear, listen', from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' (cf. Ved. śrav- 'to hear', Gk. ἔκλυον 'heard', κλυτός 'famous', Lat. cluēre 'to be called, to be mentioned', Toch. käln- 'to sound', Latv. sludinât 'to declare', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *slyšati 'hear', from PIE *k̑lous- (cf. Skt. śróṣati 'listen to, obey').
S.v. *k̑leu̯s- '(zu)hören' (IEW 606-7). Cf. n1: this root is very likely to have been abstracted from a desiderative verb form of *k̑leu̯- (LIV² 334-335) already in the protolanguage.

S.v. TochB klyaus- 'hear, listen to', which with TochA klyos- reflects Proto-Tocharian *klyeus-, as though from PIE *k̑lēus-, a lengthened grade iterative-intensive of PIE *k̑l(e)us- (cf. Skt. śróṣti 'hears, listens', OHG hlosēn 'listen', OCS slyšati ~ slušati 'hear', Lith. klausaũ 'hear').
Cf. s.v. *k̑leu̯- 'hören' (IEW 605-7). Cf. n1: the root *k̑leu̯s- (LIV² 336) is probably originally a derived desiderative form from this root, probably already of PIE date.

S.v. Arm. lsem (aor. lu-a) 'to hear, to listen; to obey', derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' (cf. Skt. śrav- 'to hear', Gk. κλύω 'to hear, obey', Lat. clueō 'to be called, be named, be reputed', OCS sluti 'to be called', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kli-nu- 'hear', from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'hear' (cf. Gk. κλύω, Skt. śru-, OCS sluti).
S.v. Alb. këndoj 'to sing'. A loan from Lat. cantāre 'sing'.

S.v. Alb. rri 'to sit, stand, stay, remain' (suppletive aorist ndej). The form of the present stem goes back to Proto-Albanian *rina, etymologically close to Skt. r̥ṇóti 'to arise, to move', Gk. ὄρνυμαι 'move up, and related forms'. Meyer (1891:374) derives to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean, bend' but O. deems the phonological changes impossible.
S.v. r̄i 'sitze, halte mich auf, wohne, ruhe aus'. Compares Ved. śrayati 'lehnt sich an', Lith. szlëjù [sic!] 'lehne an' Gk. κλίνω, Lat. clinare, OHG hlinēn.
S.v. 11435 Skt. vásati 'stays, dwells'.

S.v. Ved. √vas-³ 'wohnen, weilen, übernachten' (YAv. vaŋhaiti 'verweilt'), from PIE *h₂u̯es- (cf. Hitt. ḫues- 'leben, am Leben sein, überleben', TochB wäs- 'sich aufhalten, weilen', Gk. ἄεσα 'verbrachte (die Nacht νύκτα), Arm. go- 'existieren, vorhanden sein', Goth. wisan 'sein, bleiben', OIr. fo(a)id 'verbringt die Nacht').
S.v. 2. *h₂u̯es- '(ver)weilen, die Nacht verbringen' (IEW 72, 1170-1).

S.v. TochAB ṣam- 'sitzen, bleiben', 'sit, remain'. To be derived from PIE *sed- (LIV² 513-514, without Tocharian); "root-final *-d- was bound to be lost by sound law, but the loss compensated by -m- taken over from the suppletive root läm- in order to regain a suitable root structure, according to G.-J. Pinault (p.c.)".
S.v. ἕζομαι 'to sit (down)', from IE *sed- 'sit down'. The form ἕζομαι is a thematic yod-present *sed-ie/o-, whereas ἵζω derives from reduplicated *si-sd-e/o-. Both are IE formations.

S.v. Proto-Iranian *had- 'to sit, be seated', from PIE *sed- (cf. Skt. sad- 'to sit', Gk. ἕζομαι, ἱζω, Lat. sīdō, OCS sěděti, Lith. sėdė́ti, Latv. sêdêt, Goth. sitan, Engl. sit, etc.). Note the Middle Persian, etc. forms have taken the preverb *ni- 'down'.
S.v. Ved. √sad- 'sitzen', from PIE *sed- (cf. Gk. ἕζομαι, ἵζω 'sitze, setze mich', ἔδρα 'Sitz, Wohnsitz', Lat. sedēre, Goth. sitan, Lith. sėdė́ti, OCS sěděti, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *sěděti 'sit', from PIE *sed-eh₁- (cf. Lith. sėdė́ti, Lat. sedēre).
S.v. Lith. sėdė́ti 'sit', from PIE *sed-eh₁- (cf. Lat. sedēre). NB: an example of Winter's Law.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *sed-o- 'sit', derived from PIE *sed- 'sit' (cf. Skt. sī́dati, Lat. sedeō, Goth. sitjan, Lith. sė́sti, OCS sěsti).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *set(j)an- 'to sit', from PIE *sed-ie-. Formally identical to Gk. ἕζομαι 'to sit (down)', Arm. nstim 'to sit' < *(ni-)sed-ie-. Cf. also Gk. ἵζω, Skt. sī́dati, OAv. hīšasat̰ (3.sg.des.) 'to sit' < si-sd-e-; Lat. sedeō, -ere 'to sit, be seated', OIr. saidid, 'to sit', MCo. hedhi, MBret. hezaff, 'to stop', < *sed-e-; Lith. sėdė́ti, Latv. sêdêt, OCS sěděti < *sed-eh₁-.

S.v. Lat. sedeō, 'to sit, be seated', from Proto-Italic sed-ē- (cf. U. sersi 'seat', sersitu (3.sg.imptv.), zeřef, serse [pr.ptc.act., nom.sg.m.] 'to sit'), ultimately from PIE *sed-eh₁- 'to be seated' (cf. OIr. saidid, ·said 'to sit', MCo. hedhi MBret. hezaff 'to stop' < *sede/o-, OIr. síd 'peace', W hedd 'peace', Skt. pf. sasā́da 'to sit down, settle down', OPers. niyašādaya- 'to set down, establish', Gk. ἕζομαι 'to sit down', Lith. sėdė́ti, Latv. sêdêt, OCS sěděti, Goth. sitan 'to sit').

Perhaps originally a compound *h₂k̑-h₂ou̯s-iéti '(s)he is sharp-eared' > PGmc. *hauziϸi '(s)he hears' (cf. Goth. hauseiϸ, OE hīerϸ), cf. Gk. ἀκούειν 'to hear'. [Cf. *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (LIV² 261, NIL 287-300, IEW 18-22), *h₂ou̯s- 'ear' (NIL 339-343, IEW 785).]

S.v. 2245 Skt. úpaviśati 'approaches' RV., 'sits down' ŚBr., Pp. upaviṣṭa, 'seated' KātyŚr., °aka, 'remaining too long in the womb' Car. 2. upavēśayati 'causes to sit' AitBr. [√viś] and s.v. 2249 upavēśana n. .act of sitting down. ĀśvŚr. [√viś]. NB: Contamination with vásati which by itself provides a verb 'to sit'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √veś- 'sich niederlassen, sich niedersetzen, eindringen, in etwas eingehen', from PIE *u̯ei̯k̑- 'sich niederlassen'.
Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯k̑- 'eingehen in, eintreten' (IEW [1129], 1131).

S.v. Engl. skin, a loan from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic skinn, Old Norwegian skinn (Norwegian skinn), Old Swedish skin (Swedish skinn), Old Danish skindh, skin (Danish skind ), all in sense ‘skin, hide, fur’).
S.v. Ved. tvác- 'Haut, Fell; die Haut des lebenden Menschen oder Tieres, in Kontrast zu cárman-'. Probably to be connected with Hitt. tu̯ekka- 'Körper, Person'.

S.v. *tu̯ek- 'sichtbar sein' (not in IEW), cf. Hitt. dukkāri 'ist sichtbar, wird gesehen; ist wichtig'. Cf. n1, comparing the root-noun *tu̯ek- 'das sichbare, äußere Form' in Hitt. tuekk(a)-/tukk(a)- 'Körper', Ved. tvác- 'Haut' (cf. Schindler, BSL 67 (1972) 36-7).
Cf. s.v. 4.12 'SKIN, HIDE' and 4.13 'FLESH'.

S.v. mrǰiwn 'ant', since long connected with the PIE word for 'ant' (cf. Gk. μύρμηξ 'ant', Lat. formīca 'ant', Skt. vamrá- 'ant', YAv. maoiri- 'ant', NPers. mōr 'ant', etc.). One usually assumes taboo-forms *u̯orm- : *moru̯-.
Cf. s.v. *(s)ker- 'scheren, kratzen, abschneiden' (IEW 938-40).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *skora 'bast, skin' (cf. Proto-Slavic *kora 'bark'), derived from PIE *(s)ker- (cf. Gk. κείρω 'shear', OIc. skera 'cut').

S.v. Lat. curtus 'mutilated, circumcised; imperfect'. There are two possible root etymologies; either (1) to *(s)ker-, via *kr-to- > *korto- > *kurto- with the development *orC > *urC (cf. Hitt. karš(ii̯e/a)- 'to cut, separate, stop', CLuw. *karš- < *kers-; Gk. κείρω 'to cut off, shave', καρτός 'cut off, shorn', Arm. kʻerem 'to scratch, cut off', etc.), or (2) to PIE *kʷer- (cf. Hitt. kuerzi 'cut', Ved. kr̥ṇóti 'make'). In view of the fact that the latter only means 'cut' in Hittite, while the forms of *(s)ker- have the meanings 'cut, shave' and the semantics of curtus meaning 'mutilated, circumcised', de Vaan's preferred etymology is to *(s)ker- (but cf. Ernout & Meillet, Meiser 1998, who prefer *kʷer-).
S.v. Sp. corto, from which cortar is derived. Ultimately from Lat. curtus.
S.v. Hitt. kuer- / kur- / kuu̯ar- 'to cut, to cut up, to cut off, to amputate, to mutilate', from PIE *kʷer- (cf. Ved. kr̥- 'to make', OIr. cruth 'shape, form', Lat. curtus 'short').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *skeran- (1) 'to cut; to slaughter', from PIE *(s)kerH-e- (cf. Arm. kʻerem 'to scratch' < *sker(H)-, Lith. skìrti 'to cut' < *skrH-ie-, OIr. scaraid 'to divide, separate', W. yscar, ysgar 'id.' < *skrH-eh₂-ie).
Root assignment in this class follows LIV² to *(s)ker- rather than *(s)kerH- (whence Lith. skìrti, OIr. scurid, etc.), cf. LIV² 556-557 s.v. 2. *(s)ker- and LIV² 558 s.v. *(s)kerH-.
S.v. Alb. lëkurë 'skin, hide'. O. derives from lakur 'naked', in turn from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine, be white'. Cf. s.v. lakur 'naked' for alternative etymological proposals.

Many possibilities. Reject's Orel (1998:222)'s connection with lakur 'naked', where the further derivation from *leu̯k- 'shine' is too semantically remote from 'hide'. Proposes an etymology of prefix lë- + kur = loan from Lat. corium 'thick skin, leather'.
S.v. Alb. lëkúr/ë. -a 'Haut; Leder; Fell; Schale; Rinde; Hülse'. "Nicht sicher erklärt." Cf. entry for a survey of proposals.
Cf. s.v. *der- 'zerreißen (intr.), zerspringen' (IEW 206-8).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *skenϸan- ~ *skenϸō (ON skinn 'skin (of a little animal)', MHG scint 'fruit shell'). Probably related to Bret skant 'dandruff'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *fella- 'membrane, skin, hide', from PIE *pel-ni- (cf. Gk. πελλο-ράφος 'sewing skins together' < *pel-no-; Lat. pellis < *pel-ni-; OCS pelena 'band for swathing children', Ru. pelená 'shroud, nappy', SCr. pelèna 'bandage, shroud' < pel-en-eh₂-). Cf. Proto-Germanic *felma(n)- 'membrane' (OE ǣger-felma 'skin of an egg', E film, etc. < *pel-mon-).

S.v. Lat. pellis 'skin, hide', from PIE pel-ni- 'skin, hide' (cf. Lith. plėnė̃ 'membrane', Ru. plená 'shroud, (dial.) nappy', OCS pelena 'band for swathing children', Sln. plẹ́na 'bandage' < *pel-en-h₂-; OHG fel, OE fell, OIc. fjall 'hide' < PGmc. *fel-n-). "The structure of the IE derivatives suggests a root *pel-, which may have meant 'to strip, skin', but no independent forms of such a root are attested."
S.v. ON skinn 'abgezogene Haut, bes. von kleineren Tieren', from Proto-North-Germanic *skenϸa-.
S.v. Alb. fëmijë 'child, family, spouse', borrowed from Lat. famīlia 'family'.
Borrowing from Lat. familia.
S.v. Alb. kthetër 'claw (particularly, of vulture)', a derivative in -ter of kthej 'to turn', a prefixal derivative of thyej 'to break'.
Cf. s.v. ftoh, attempting to derive from *tep- (cf. Lat. tepeō 'be lukewarm'), considers connection with *teh₂- 'sehr fraglich'.
S.v. Alb. ftoh ~ ftof 'to cool, make cold', to PAlb. *awa-tāja- and connected with Slav. *tajǫ, *tajati 'to melt' < PIE *tā-.
Rejects connection with *teh₂- 'melt, thaw' and maintains connection with *tep- 'to be warm, hot'.

Etymology in this class follows {ref Orel 1998}:105 and {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974 to PIE *teh₂- 'melt, thaw', but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:173-174, {ref Holm 2011}:56-57 for proposals to PIE *tep- 'be warm, hot'. Cf. also {ref LIV²} 616, 630.
S.v. Alb. vij ~ vinj 'to come', borrowed from Lat. venīre 'to come'.
Cf. s.v. nëmëroj 'to number, to count', borrowed from Lat. numerāre 'id.'. Other similar forms, such as numër 'number', are of Italian or learned Latin origin.
S.v. Alb. qaj ~ qanj 'to cry, to weep'. Tosk and Greco-Albanian forms preserve initial kl-, from Proto-Albanian *klaunja and cognate with Greek κλαίω (< *κλάϝιω).
S.v. Alb. qan 'weinen', continuing PIE *⁽k̑⁾leh₂u̯- or *⁽k̑⁾lau̯- (cf. Gk. κλαίω 'weinen').
S.v. Alb. pres 'to cut', from Proto-Albanian *p(e)retja, related to Lith. periù 'beat, thump', Gk. πρίω 'to saw'.

S.v. Alb. pres 'abschneiden, abhacken, (Bäume) fällen, verscheiden, schlachten'. The formation is close to other Albanian verbs whose present stems show an enlargement in *-(V)ti̯o-. Further analysis remains disputed: Possible, but semantically and formally facile is the connection with OCS perǫ 'schlagen', Lith. periù, per̃ti 'ds.'. An alternative is an inner-Albanian formation based on (m)preh, eh 'spitzen, schärfen' (< ?*(h₂)ok̑u̯-o-).

S.v. Alb. ditë 'day', from Proto-Albanian *dītā and etymologically connected with Gmc. *tīdiz 'time', Skt. dīti 'brightness, splendour', other scholars connecting with the IE word for 'day' (cf. Lat. diēs), still others to Ved. dína- 'day', OCS dьnь. Cf. entry for references to further literature.

S.v. Alb. vdes 'sterben, zugrunde gehen, absterben'. The widespread derivation of this verb from *tokʷ-éi̯e/o- (iterative from the root *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' cf. LIV² 620f.) is not phonologically tenable, since a *t can only become voiced in an environment after *n. There are no other commonly accepted roots or present stem formations that this verb can be connected to. It is probable that the root contained a final *kʷ, and in initial position there was the preverb v-. [Schumacher & Matzinger continue to suggest a possible etymology to a root *dekʷs-, comparing Av. daxš- 'lehren', and Hitt. tekkussii̯e/a- 'sich zeigen' but are at pains to admit that this suggestion is highly speculative.]
S.v. Alb. pi 'trinken', from *pii̯e/a-, derived from the root *peh₃(i̯)- 'trinken'.
S.v. Alb. ha 'essen', plausibly a derivation *h₂éu̯-e/o- to the root *h₂eu̯- 'genießen' (LIV² 274); connections to IE ?*k⁽ʷ⁾h₂ed- (LIV² 359f.) are problematic.
S.v. Alb. ha 'to eat', which O. derives from IE *ed- 'to eat'.
Rejects all previously proposed etymologies and regards the etymology of Alb. ha 'still [an] open case'.
S.v. Alb. sy 'eye', from Proto-Albanian *atšīwi, a form of the dual related to Skt. akṣī́, Av. aši, Lith. akì, Slav. *oči, etc.
Etymological authorities agree on Alb. sy < PIE *h₃ekʷ-, however the source of -y remains disputed.
S.v. Alb. bie 'fallen; schlagen; Musikinstrument spielen'. Belongs to PIE *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten', but the formation of the present stem is unclear.
S.v. Alb. bie 'to fall, to hit, to strike, to beat', from PAlb. b(e)rja and derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to strike' (cf. Lat. feriō, OHG berjan, etc.).
S.v. Alb. larg 'far (away)', borrowed from Lat. largus 'big, large'.
S.v. Alb. jep 'geben', likely a causative formation *h₁op-éi̯e/o- from the root *h₁ep- 'fassen, ergreifen' (LIV² 237), cf. also Demiraj (1997:79), Orel (1998:157).
S.v. Alb. véte 'gehen', to be derived from *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (LIV² 232f.), cf. extensive discussion in entry for argumentation.
S.v. Alb. blúan 'mahlen, auspressen, verdauen', traditionally derived to PIE *melh₂- but the stem formation is not clear. The connection of this verb to the root *melh₂- is in no way certain.
S.v. bluaj ~ bluej 'to grind'; O. considers the word a loan from Lat. molere.
S.v. Alb. hí/e, -a 'Schatten', connected to Ved. chāya-, Gk. σκιά, TochB skio, etc. < *sk̑éh₁-ih₂.
S.v. Alb. shpinë 'back, spine', borrowed from Lat. spīna 'id.'.

S.v. Alb. lëvore 'peel, skin, rag', a formation parallel to lëvere 'cloth, rag, laundry', being in turn a prefixal derivative of var 'to hang', being an ablaut variant of vjerr 'to hang', which continues PAlb. *wara and related to Gk. ἀείρω 'to raise up', Lith. veriù, vérti 'to weigh', sveriù, sver̃ti 'to open, to thread'.

Rejects the etymology of Orel (1998:222, etc.) as from the same root as vjerr 'to hang' as semantically and derivationally too remote. A better solution is to connect to Alb. lëvozhgë 'hard shell, peel, skin' < *leu̯eHgʷʰ-ske, which should be an Albanian extension of PIE *leu̯H- with the semantically close Gmc *lawa- > Lohe 'tan / abgelöste Rinde als Gerbmittel', which might have been influenced by SCr. ljuska 'peel, crust', probably from the same root.
S.v. Alb. bark 'belly, womb, abdomen', from PAlb. *baruka-, continuing *bʰor-uko-, a derivative of IE *bʰer- 'to carry' (Meyer 1891:27).

S.v. bark, -u 'Bauch, (Unter)leib, Mutterleib, Uterus, (dial.) Schwangerhaft'. The usual etymology as an o-grade derivation *bʰor-k- to the root *bʰer- 'tragen' is phonologically flawless, but semantically weak. Semantically better, but formally more difficult to reconcile is the comparison with OIr. brú 'Bauch, Leib', W. bru 'venter, uterus', Russ. brjúcho 'Unterleib, Bauch' < *bʰr̥k-?, *bʰr̥Hu-(k⁽ʷ⁾-)?
Rejects the traditional connection with *bʰer- 'to carry' (cf. Orel 1998:18, doubted by Demiraj 1997:92) as problematic, suggests instead a connection with IEW 110 *bʰarekʷ- 'vollgestopft/jammed'.
Derives from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry'.

I do not understand the alleged semantic difficulties of the traditional etymology from *bʰer- 'carry' (so Demiraj 1997:92, Holm 2011:51-52), if the semantic development could have been from *'womb' > 'belly'. For the purposes of a root-ref. form, the traditional etymology has been maintained, but cf. the discussion of Demiraj and Holm for skepticism of the usual etymology.
S.v. Alb. 2. madh (i) 'groß', from PIE *meg̑-, but with some difficulties in establishing the exact stem formation.

S.v. Alb. kafshoj 'to bite', borrowed from Lat. capessere ~ capissere 'to seize, snatch at', alternatively Rom. *capsāre based on Lat. capere 'to take' cf. Meyer (1891:176). Cf. entry in Orel for other proposals that are to be rejected.
Loan from Lat. capessere possible (so Orel 1998:164), alternatively loan from Lat. *captiare 'beißen, verschlingen'.
S.v. Alb. hídhët 'bitter, traurig, betrübt'. Jokl's connection to Gk. αἴθω 'burn' is impeccable. The Albanian basis *hið(-) appears to be a zero-grade formation *h₂idʰ- (cf. Gk. ἰθαρός 'heiter').
Cf. s.v. *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'entzünden' (IEW 11-2).
S.v. hidhët 'bitter, sad', which O. derives from hidhem 'to jump, overflow', a reflexive of hedh 'to throw, shoot' < PIE *skeud- 'to throw, shoot' (Gmc. *skiutan 'to shoot').
Etymology of Orel (1998:147) seems too semantically remote; etymology here follows Demiraj (1997:200-201).

S.v. Alb. zi 'schwarz'. Uncertain etymology, rejecting previous connections with Lith. gedù 'trauern' < *gʷedʰíi̯o- and *gʷōu- 'Mist, Exkremente', suggests a connection with Gk. φαίδιμος 'glänzend' < *gʷʰHi-(d-), *gʷʰiH-(d-) as a possible alternative.
Etymology ultimately uncertain, cf. Demiraj (1997:427), Holm (2011:53).
With IEW (1044) from PIE *s(u̯)ekʷ-o-s 'Pflanzensaft / juice of plants' > *sokʷo- > PAlb. śak-.
S.v. Alb. gjak 'blood', from PAlb. *saka related to Gk. ὁπός 'juice', Lith. sakaĩ 'resin', Slav. *sokъ 'juice', continuing an IE *sokʷo- 'juice'.
S.v. gjak 'Blut', very likely to be derived from *sokʷo- (Gk. ὀπός 'Pflanzensaft', Lith. sakaĩ 'Saft der Pflanzen und Früchte', etc. with the semantic development *'Pflanzensaft' → 'Blut').
Loan from Bulgarian коцка or similar.

S.v. Alb. koc 'bone, skull', borrowed from Slav. *kostъ 'bone' with a metathesis in the cluster *-st- > -ts-. The Slavic diminutive *kostъka is the source of Alb. kockë, koskë 'id.'. Not with Meyer (1891:202-203) who argues is a loan from Ital. coccio 'cracked pot'.
S.v. Alb. asht 'bone', from PAlb. ašti or ašta and further connected with PIE *ost(i)- 'bone' (cf. Hitt. ḫaštai-, Skt. ásthi, Gk. ὀστέον, etc.).
S.v. Alb. ásht, older áshtë (Buzuku, Budi) 'Knochen', from the IE inherited word for bone (cf. Ved. ásthi, Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, ossis, etc.), from PIE *h₃ost-.

S.v. Alb. fryj ~ frŷj 'to blow', from which the noun frymë is derived. If from PAlb. *sprūgnja, as O. suggests, then possibly connected to Lith. sprūgstu, sprūgti 'to escape, to get out', Slav. *prygati 'to jump, to spring'.
S.v. Alb. fryj ~ frŷj 'to blow'. If from PAlb. *sprūgnja, as O. suggests, then possibly connected to Lith. sprūgstu, sprūgti 'to escape, to get out', Slav. *prygati 'to jump, to spring'.
S.v. Alb. djeg 'burn', from PAlb. *dega, ultimately from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. Skt. dáhati, TochAB tsak-, tsäk-, Lith. degù, dègti, etc.).
S.v. Alb. djeg 'brennen', from PIE *dʰegʷʰ-o-.
Accepts connection of Alb. djeg / digjem 'burn' as from *dʰegʷʰ-e- (with LIV² 133, Demiraj 1997:137-138, Orel 1998:68).
S.v. Alb. djeg 'brennen', a continuant of PIE *dʰegʷʰ-e/o- from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'mit Feuer behandeln, verbrennen (tr.)'.
S.v. Ved. √dah- 'verbrennen' (YAv. dažaiti 'verbrennt'), from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- (cf. Lith. degù, OCS žegǫ 'brenne', TochAB tsäk- 'brennen', Lat. foveō 'mache warm' usw.).

S.v. TochB tsäk- 'burn up, consume by fire; apply heat to (in cooking), roast, boil, evaporate', which with TochA tsäk- reflects Proto-Tocharian *tsäk- from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. Skt. dáhati, Av. dažaiti, Lith. degù, OCS žegǫ, Alb. djek 'burn', etc.).

S.v. Alb. bart 'tragen, transportieren', certainly continues an o-grade present stem from the root *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (LIV² 76f.) but it is unclear whether this is a reflex of a PIE iterative *bʰor-éi̯e/o- because umlaut is completely lacking in the Old Gheg present stem paradigm.
Etymology dubious, cf. for discussion of various proposals.
S.v. Alb. gji ~ gjî 'breast, chest'; Orel assumes PAlb. *sina, identical to Lat. sinus 'curve, fold'.

Cf. s.v. Alb. thád/ër. -ra 'Tischlerhandwerkzeug, ἐργαλεῖον ξυλουργικόν', 'kleine Axt mit zwei Schneiden, deren eine axtartig, deren meißelartig ist', from which, among other derived vocabulary k(ë)tháder (< kë-thadër) 'Kralle, Fang; Klaue'.
S.v. Alb. re, -(j)a 'Wolke, Dunst, Lufttrübung, Schleier (vor den Augen)'. Not fully clear, cf. entry for several proposed etymologies.

Two possible etymologies: either (1) to PIE *h₂ers- 'to flow' (not followed by Demiraj 1997:345 and therefore not in LIV² 241), or (2) to *h₃rei̯H- 'wirbeln, fließen' > PAlb. *rina (cf. Ved. rinā́ti, Slav. rinǫ, Illyr. ῥίνος 'cloud' (so Orel 1998:366). The latter of which is Holm's preferred etymology.

S.v. Alb. re ~ rê, 'cloud', which O. argues is a singularized plural of *ri, from PAlb. rina (cf. Illyr. ῥίνος· ἀχλύς) to be further connected to Skt. riṇā́ti 'to pour, to let flow', Gk. (Lesb.) ὀρίνω 'to move'.

Etymology in this class tentatively assigned to PIE *h₃rei̯H- following {ref Orel 1998}:366, {ref Holm 2011}:56, but cf. {ref Demiraj 1997}:344, {ref Holm 2011}:56 for discussion of alternative etymologies.
Rejects the connection to *tekʷ-, and suggests that a connection to LIV² 150 *dʰgʷʰei̯- 'hinschwinden, sterben / pass away, die' (cf. Gk. φθίνω).

S.v. Alb. gërmoj 'to dig', which Orel considers to be a denominative verb derived from gërmë 'letter' in an unattested meaning 'line, scratch' with an original meaning 'scratch lines', as such a borrowing from Ancient Greek γράμμα 'letter'.
Cf. s.v. Alb. gërr/yej 'abkratzen, abschliefen, aushöhlen, (Erde) abtragen'. "Eine sichere etymologische Deutung ist nicht to erwarten."

S.v. Alb. tha/j '(etwas Feuchtes am Feuer oder an der Luft) austrocken, trockenlegen, dörren, räuchern, erstarren, erfrieren'. Meyer's connection with Lith. saũas, OCS suchъ 'trocken', etc. must rely on an uncertain dissimilation of sibilants which is very uncertain. D. suggests perhaps to Gk. ἅζω 'dörren, trocknen' instead.

S.v. Alb. thatë 'dry', a derivative of the verb thaj 'to dry', from PAlb. *sausnja, a derivative of PIE *sauso- 'dry' (Gk. αὗος, MHG sôr, Lith. saũsas, Slav. *suxъ). Note the dissimilation of the sibilants leading to *s- > th- (Meyer 1891:88).
S.v. Alb. θań 'trockne, dörre, wische ab, mache steif', cf. Lith. saũsas, OCS suchъ 'trocken', Gk. αὔω < *σαυσω.

Cf. s.v. Alb. than '(aus)trocknen, trockenlegen'. On the basis of phonological grounds it would be better to assign this verb to a root *k̑eh₂u̯- (LIV² Add. *k̑eh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen', cf. Gk. καίω).
Considers the forms to be cognate with the forms from PIE *h₂seu̯s- 'dry'.
Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).
Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda.
Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).

Etymology here follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1000 and {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, but be aware some scholars {ref Orel 1998}:471, {ref Holm 2011}:58-59, following {ref Meyer 1891}:88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ({ref LIV²} 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in /cognate/7551/ (cf. the skepticism of {ref Demiraj 1997}:392).
S.v. Alb. vesh 'Ohr', from PIE *h₂eu̯s-, cf. entry for further discussion on possible stem formations in Albanian.
S.v. Alb. dhe 'Erde, Boden, Festland, Land', from the inherited IE word for 'earth' (cf. Hitt. tekan, Ved. kṣā́s, Gk. χθών, OIr. dú, OCS zemlja, Lat. humus, etc.).
S.v. Alb. dhjám/ë 'Fett von Tieren und Menschen'. Without a secure etymology. Completely unclear.
S.v. Hitt. atta- 'father'. The stem is almost certainly onomatopoetic in origin. Hitt. atta- 'father' can be compared to to Lat. atta, Gk. ἄττα, Goth. atta, OCS otьcь, etc.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *otьcь 'father'. The root *ot- may be compared to Gk. ἄττα, Lat. atta, Goth. atta 'father', etc. and must be considered a nursery word.
S.v. Alb. atë 'father', from PAlb. ata, and further connected with Hitt. atta-, Lat. atta, Slav. *otьcь, and similar nursery words.
As a nursery word, true cognacy with the other IE lexemes must be regarded as doubtful (contra Orel 1998:11).
S.v. Goth. A218. atta 'πατήρ', 'father' (cf. OIc. atte, OFr. aththe, OHG atto, MHG atte, ätte 'father', NHG dial. ätte 'father'). Probably a nursery word.
As a nursery word, true cognacy with the other IE lexemes must be regarded as doubtful.
S.v. Alb. pendë 'feather; pair of oxen', borrowed from Lat. pinna, penna 'feather'. "The second meaning 'pair of oxen' seems to be a metaphoric derivative of Lat. penna 'plumage' or the like."
Loan from Lat. penna, pinna 'feather, wing, pinion', but cf. Demiraj (1997:314) who attempts alternative etymologies.
Cf. s.v. luftë 'fight, war', borrowed from Rum. luptă 'fight' < Lat. lucta 'wrestling'. Note the East Romance development of *-ct- in this word.
From PIE *gʷʰer-mo-, cf. dialectal Gheg zjarm (overlooked by Orel 1998:525, who alternatively postulates *gʷʰoros, which would not explain the -rr).
S.v. Alb. peshk 'fish', a borrowing from Lat. piscem 'fish'.
A borrowing from Lat. pisce < Lat. piscis because of /-shk-/ and regular shift of Lat. ĭ > Alb. e.
S.v. Alb. míz/ë 'Fliege', usually connected with other IE words for 'fly', cf. Gk. μυῖα 'Fliege', ON mý 'Mücke', etc., from Proto-Albanian *mū- + suff. -zë.
S.v. Alb. mizë 'fly', a derivative in -zë based on PAlb. *mūjā, identical to ON my, and further connected to Gk. μυῖα, Lat. musca, etc.
S.v. Lith. mùsė 'fly' (Latv. muša 'fly', OPr. muso 'fly'), cf. Gk. μυῖα 'fly', Lat. musca 'mosquito'.

S.v. flutur 'butterfly'. Alb. fluturoj 'to fly' was a borrowed from Romance *fluctulāre (cf. Lat. fluctuāre 'move in waves, move to and fro'). [NB: Orel does not have an independent lemma for fluturoj.]
Cf. s.v. Alb. flúg/ë 'Schindel'.

S.v. Alb. mjegull 'cloud' (variants mjergull, njegull, which O. considers to be secondary). O. prefers a derivation from Proto-Albanian *meg(u)lā, related to Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist'.

S.v. Alb. mjégull/ë 'Nebel, Wolke, Dunkel, Finsternis'. It may be necessary to separate the different variants into different etymologies.
For mje(r)gull(ë) Jokl's suggestion from PIE *mergʷ- > PAlb. *merg- > Alb. mjerg-ull(ë) is the best formal solution. [Cf. entry for further discussion of inner-Albanian variation.]
Considers the word either a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'cloud' or a cognate of Slav. *mьgla, etc.

Three main possibilities: Either connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so Orel 1998:269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- /cognate/42/), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so Demiraj 1997:271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by Meyer 1891:283-284, cf. /cognate/2150/). Ultimately unclear.
S.v. Alb. këmbë ~ kambë 'leg, foot', from Rom. *camba ~ *gamba 'leg'.
Loan from Lat. camba.
Loan from Lat. camba.
S.v. Alb. pyll 'forest', a loan from Balkan Romance *padūlem (cf. Rum. pădure 'id.') < Lat. palūdem 'swamp' (so Meyer 1891:360).
Loan from Romance.

S.v. Alb. ngrij ~ ngrîj 'to freeze'. Orel derives from PAlb. *en-kreinja, a denominative verb related to Lith. krenà 'film, thin skin (on milk)', Latv. kriena 'id.'. Alternatively Meyer (1891:306-307) to Gk. κρύος 'frost', or Jokl (1911:63-64) to Slav. čьrstvъ 'hard, dry'.
S.v. Alb. fryt 'fruit', borrowed from Lat. frūctus 'fruit'.
S.v. Alb. pemë 'fruit-tree, fruit', borrowed from Lat. pōmum 'fruit', pōmus 'fruit tree'.
Borrowing from Lat. pōmum 'fruit'.
S.v. Alb. plot 'voll, gefüllt, viel, genau' beside plótë adj. 'voll, gefüllt', the latter of which may be derived from PIE *pleh₁-to- 'full'.
Cf. s.v. *h₁ep- 'fassen, ergreifen' (IEW 50-1).
S.v. Alb. shkoj 'to go'. Etymology unclear, cf. entry in Orel for various proposals. (Principally cf. Jokl 1911:80-82 < *shteg 'path', alternatively Meyer 1891:408, comparing Lat. sequor 'follow').
S.v. Alb. škoń 'gehe vorüber, verfliesse'; the sounds satisfy a derivation from Lat. sequor, the meaning not quite ("Den Lauten genügt Herleitung aus lat. sequor, der Bedeutung nicht ganz.").
Rejects Meyer's connection to Lat. sequor as semantically implausible and proposes instead a denominative formation to Alb. štek, štegu 'Weg'.
Either a loan from Lat. mīru(s) 'wonderful' or from IE *meiH- 'lieblich/mild' > *mi-ro- (IEW 711, so Demiraj 1997:268, Orel 1998:267).
S.v. Alb. bar 'Gras, Grashalm, Kraut, Heilkraut'. An old neuter without certain connections outside of Albanian (cf. entry with various proposals).
Etymology here tentatively follows Orel (1998:16-17), de Vaan (2008:201-202), etc., but cf. the objections and further discussion of Demiraj (1997:91-92).
Loan from Lat. galbinu and gilvus 'gelb', so Orel (1998:131).
S.v. Alb. gjelbër ~ gjelbën 'green', borrowed from Lat. galbinus 'greenish-yellow'.
Obvious loan from Turkish yeşil 'green'.
S.v. zorrë 'gut', from Proto-Albanian *džārnā, etymologically identical to Lith. žarnà 'id.', continuing PIE *gʷerə- 'to swallow'.

S.v. Alb. zórr/ë 'Darm, Gedärme, Eingeweide, Schlauch'. Without secure connections outside of Albanian. Frequently compared to Gk. χορδή, Lith. žarnà. Jokl (1937:139ff.) alternatively views this as an inner-Albanian development.

S.v. Alb. zor̄ɛ 'Darm' compares to Lith. žárna 'Darm', ON garnir 'Eingeweide' which could represent a palatal correspondence to original initial *g̑ʰ. The -o-, however, does not correspond to Germ. -a-, as one expects -a-. Either this is an ablaut variant or is borrowed from a hypothetical Slavic *zorno- (which has disappeared from Slavic).
Borrowing from Lat. or Rom. floc(cus).

S.v. Alb. dórë, -a 'Hand, Handvoll, Griff'. The inherited word for 'hand' to be connected with Gk. χείρ, Hitt. keššar, TochA tsar, TochB ṣar, etc. Cf. entry in Demiraj for discussion regarding possibilities regarding the stem formation in Albanian.
Loan from VLat. coccum 'berry' (so Orel 1998:189).
Loan from Lat., either from (1) degāvo 'have learned' or (2) intelligere (so Orel 1998:62).
With Demiraj (1997:426) and Orel (1998:520) as a "difficult word without any reliable explanation", cf. further for an overview of rejected etymologies.
S.v. Alb. ba/j (öfters mbaj), from cs.-it. *bʰor-ei̯o- (cf. Gk. φορέω 'tragen').
S.v. Alb. mbaj 'to hold, carry', derived from Alb. *bera > bie 'to bring' derived from *bʰer-. [NB: distinct from homophonous Alb. bie 'fall, hit, strike beat' < *bʰerH-].

S.v. Alb. bri, ri-, -u 'Horn'. The exact stem formations remain disputed, but generally connected with Ved. bhrū́- 'Braue, Augenbraue', Gk. ὀφρῦς 'Braue, erhöhter Rand', ultimately from the root noun *bʰruH- (IEW 172), with semantic development *'brow', *'eyelash' > 'horn'.
Many explanations, but generally connected to PIE *h₃bʰreu̯H- 'eyebrow' with differing explanations of stem-formation.
S.v. Alb. shtëpi 'house', a morphological adaptation of the metathesized Lat. hospitium 'lodging, inn, guest-chamber' (cf. ModGk. σπίτι 'house').
S.v. Alb. štɛpī́, štpī́ 'Haus', most probably a derivative from Latin hospitium, from which Modern Greek σπίτι also derives.

S.v. Alb. gjúaj / gjúej 'jagen, erjagen'. An inherited word for 'hunt' with a disputed etymology. The comparison with MHG, NHG 'jagen' is semantically close, but phonologically and structurally facile. Additionally, the etymology of the Germanic lexemes are themselves disputed. It is probably to come up with a different etymology. D. ultimately suggests a connection to Lat. sāgiō 'spüren, ahnen, wittern', OIr. 'nachgehen einer Sache, suchen' to PIE *seh₂g- '(witternd) nachspüren'.
S.v. Alb. akull 'ice', a loanword from Germanic *jakulaz 'icicle, glacier', cf. ON jǫkull 'icicle', OE gicel 'id.', cf. also for a discussion of alternative etymologies.
S.v. Alb. ákull, -i 'Eis, Frost, (dial. Arb. It.) Pfeil'. Cf. for a discussion of older etymologies, considers Orel's suggestion of a loan from Germanic very attractive, but difficult to maintain.

Possibly to PIE *reu̯H- 'auffreißen / to tear, wound' (LIV² 510, without Alb. so Orel 1998:515, Matzinger 2005:99), also possible are to PIE *u̯er- 'aufreißen / to tear, to wound' with different variants, or loan, presumably by OCS u-rasiti 'durchbohren' or some other South Slavic source.
S.v. Alb. gju, -ri, gjû, -ni 'Knie', from the IE inherited word for 'knee' *g̑onu-, *g̑nu-.
S.v. Alb. 'wissen, kennen, können', an inherited word commonly agreed to be connected with Ved. dhītí- 'Wahrnehmung, Andacht' (√*dʰei̯H-).
To be connected with LIV² 141, IEW 243 *dʰei̯H- 'see, regard'.
S.v. Alb. di 'to know', connected with IE *dʰei̯(ə)- 'to see' (cf. Skt. dhyāti 'to observe, to feel, to think', Av. dā(y)- 'to see').

S.v. gjéth/e, -ja 'Laub'. The formal comparison to OHG questa, MHG quast, 'Laubbüschel', Serb. gvȍzd 'Wald' is phonologically unobjectionable, therefore possibly from PIE *gu̯osd(o)-. On the irregular devoicing in final position, cf. discussion s.v. djáthë, dríthë.
With PIE *gu̯os-d- (IEW 480).

S.v. Alb. shtrin 'ausbreiten, ausdehnen, ausstrecken; hinlegen'. A secondary nasal present either to PIE ster- 'to strike down, flatten sb.' (LIV 597f.) or *sterh₃- 'spread, scatter' (LIV 599f.) – undecideable phonologically and semanticall.y.
S.v. shtri/j 'ausbreiten, -dehnen, niederstrecken, hinlegen'.
S.v. Alb. shtrij 'to spread, to stretch', from Proto-Albanian *strinja and related to Skt. str̥ṇā́ti 'to spread, to scatter', Gk. στόρνυμι 'to spread, to stretch', Lat. sternō 'id.', etc.
With LIV² 599 as ultimately derived from *sterh₃- > Alb. shtrij 'breite aus / spread, stretch', via PAlb. *strinja with the semantic development 'be stretched, laid down'.
Either to *ster- 'niederstrecken' (IEW 1022, 1029-30) or *sterh₃- 'hinbreiten, ausbreiten' (IEW 1029-30).
Cf. s.v. Alb. jes 'to remain', a denominative of *jetë 'life' (cf. Gk. ἐτεός 'true, real', etc.).
Loan, perhaps already from Goth. *milti (cf. Catalan melsa) 'milt, spleen', or via Italian milzi (so Orel 1998:259) from the same source with shifted meaning.
S.v. Alb. gjáthë 'lang', generally connected to Ved. dīrghá-, Gk. δολιχός, OCS dlъgъ, etc., perhaps from PIE *dlh₁gʰó- > Proto-Albanian *glag(h)V́- or (?) *glág(h)a-tV- > Old Albanian glatë.
Rejects Orel (1998:274)'s etymology from PIE *mer- 'to die' > PAlb. mērwa, preferring a connection to PIE *merh₂- 'zerdrücken, to squeeze'.

S.v. Alb. morr 'louse', from PAlb. mērwa based on PIE *mer- 'to die' as Gk. φθείρ 'louse' is based on φθείρω 'destroy', alternatively to Lat. mordeō (cf. Meyer 1891:287) or Skt. marcáyati (cf. Jokl 1911:58).

S.v. Alb. morr 'Laus (als Hauptbezeichnung für alle Laussorten, wie Kopflaus, Filzlaus, Kleiderlaus, Blattlaus, u.a.)'. An isolated word in Albanian with a phonological form that cannot be connected to forms for louse in other Indo-European languages. Under the assumption of a semantic development *'scratching' > 'louse', one could consider Alb. morr a deverbative formation from the root *mer(H)- 'aufreiben'.

S.v. Alb. mish, -i/-të 'Fleisch', since long connected with several related words in IE languages, cf. Ved. māṁsá-, Arm. mis, OCS męso, Goth. mimz 'Fleisch', etc. The diachronic analysis of the Albanian cognate remains disputed. [cf. entry in Demiraj for further discussion.]

S.v. Alb. nën/ë, -a / nãnë 'Mutter, Muttertier'. A nursery word for 'mother', cf. similar nursery words that may be compared among the IE languages, e.g. Ved. nanā́ 'Mutter', Hitt. anaš 'id.', Gk. νέννος '(mütterlicher) Oheim', νίννη "Großmutter', νάννη· μητρὸς ἀδελφή (Hes.).

S.v. Alb. mal 'mountain', from PAlb. mala and connected with Lith. malà 'land', Latv. mala 'bank, shore'. Cf. also *mal- in Balkan toponomy (Illyr. Maluntum, Dac. Dacia Maluensis vs. Dacia Ripensis), borrowed into Rumanian as mal 'bank'.

S.v. Alb. mal, -i 'Berg, Gebirge, (Berg)wald'. There are several attempts at explanation: (1) connections with Rum. mal, maluri 'Flußufer', Latv. mala 'Rand, Ufer, Gegend', Lith. lýgmala(s) 'Höhe des Randes'; (2) via PIE *ml̥dʰ-o- (cf. Ved. mūrdhā́- 'Spitze, Gipfel, Kopf', OE molda 'top of the head' (although one would expect a differing reflex for a long syllabic resonant in Albanian (e.g. **blad(h)-, **blan-, cf. s.v. plak). (3) other researchers consider a Thracian or non-IE origin, (cf. thr. malva(?), Basque Malh). The connection with Rumanian mal 'Flußufer', Latv. mala 'Rand, Ufer, Gegend' is semantically appealing. In the case of an IE origin one would suppose an original o-grade root (cf. Gk. aor. μολεῖν 'gehen, kommen', προμολή 'Vorsprung, Auslauf', Serb. izmòlīti 'hervorzeigen'. If one considers a connection with Rum.(-Dac.) mal, then one would consider a neuter i-stem *m(o)lH-i-.

Two possibilities, both from IEW 721 *mel- 'Erhöhung / elevation', either (1) *ml̥h₃-dʰo-, or (2) PAlb. mall via IE *molH-(i-) (so Demiraj 1997:254, uncertainly, while noting the possibility of non-IE substratum), similarly Orel (1998:243) from PAlb. *mala, mentioning the Balkan toponyms without further comment.
Loan from Lat. gula. The vocalism, however, is only accounted for by assuming a late loan from It. gola.
Alternatively from PIE *k̑ent- 'stechen, Nagel'.
S.v. Lat. pavor 'furcht' > Fr. peur.

Cf. s.v. Lat. paveō 'to be frightened', derivative pavor 'sudden fear, terror'. The verbal stem is from *pou̯-eh₁- 'to fear' (cf. OIr. omun MW ouyn, MCo. own, Bret. oun, 'fear' < Proto-Celtic *ofno- < *pouno-, OIr. úath 'fear' < *pou-to-, W uthr 'terrible' < *pou-tro-).
S.v. Alb. ém/ër, -ri 'Name; Benennung'. From the IE inherited word for 'name' (cf. OCS imę, OPr. emnes, OIr. ainm, etc.).
Loan from Turkish kafa 'back of head' (with Orel 1998:353).
Presumably from *h₁ere(i)- 'something freshly coming into motion' (cf. IEW 330).
[Does not make an attempt at an etymology.]
S.v. Alb. nát/ë, -a 'Nacht, Morgendämmerung, früher Morgen', from the inherited IE word for 'night' (cf. Ved. nák, Lith. naktìs, Lat. nox, noctis, etc.).

Rejects earlier scholars attempts to derive from PIE *neh₂s- 'nose'. Instead perhaps via Proto-Albanian *skun-tā, from PIE *(s)keu̯- (IEW 951), often with extensions meaning something like 'shelter, canopy' (cf. Gk. σκύνια 'brows').

Either from PIE *oi-nos with the Western IE words for 'one', but considers the inner-Albanian derivation phonologically doubtful, therefore considers the connection to PIE *sem- more likely. Ultimately a debatable case.
Only mentions the lexeme in a marginal comment s.v. Alb. inj 'da! hier!' without its own entry.
S.v. Alb. njerí, -u 'Mensch, Mann', generally agreed to be connected to Ved. nár, naras, Gk. ἀνήρ, Arm. ayr, etc. from PIE *h₂nēr-.
S.v. Alb. heq ~ hek 'to draw, pull'. In dialects a more conservative helq is also attested. From Proto-Albanian *skalkja, cognate with Greek ἕλκω 'draw'.

S.v. Alb. heq 'herausziehen, wegnehmen'. Traditionally this verb is connected to PIE *selk- (cf. LIV² 530-531), but the phonological development is irregular. The underlying reconstruction seems to reflect *su̯elk- (cf. Schumacher 2005:614n59) and this suggests a possible contamination of the root *selk- with the root *h₂u̯elk- 'schleppen, ziehen' (LIV² 289-290). Alternatively also possible *sk̑ek- 'vorübergehen' (not in LIV²), but this must assume an l-contamination in the root from elsewhere to account for Old Tosk / hjelk /.
S.v. *selk- 'ziehen' (IEW 901), a Tocharian, Greek (and Albanian?) isogloss.
S.v. *sk̑ek- 'vorübergehen', to which ?alb. heq, ageg. /hjek/ ‘zieht’, /hiqetë/ ‘geht vorüber’ after the suggestion of Schumacher & Matzinger (2013:974-976).

IE root etymology uncertain. According to {ref Orel 1998}:145) to PIE *selk- (tentatively cf. {ref LIV²} 530-531); according to {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:974-976) a straightforward derivation from PIE *selk- is impossible and may represent a contamination of *selk- (cf. /cognate/451/) and *h₂u̯elk- (cf. /cognate/5274/); alternatively Schumacher & Matzinger suggest possibly *sk̑ek- with contamination of -l- in the Old Tosk form of the root (see now {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}).
S.v. Alb. shtyn 'wegstoßen, -schieben, anstoßen, antreiben', doubtless to be connected to PIE *(s)teud- 'stoßen, schlagen' (LIV² 601).

S.v. Alb. shty/j '(weg)-stoßen, (weg)schieben; anstoßen, aufschieben', to be connected with Goth. stautan 'stoßen', Lat. tundō 'stoßen, schlagen', etc. to the root *steu̯d- from an Albanian stem *stūd-ni̯o- with a long root vowel.
S.v. Alb. shi, -u, an inherited lexeme, to be connected to Gk. ὕει 'es regnet', ὑετός 'Regen', TochA swase, TochB swese 'ds.'.

S.v. Alb. shi 'rain', from Proto-Albanian *sūja- with an irregular development of initial *s- > *sh- explained by dissimilation in intermediary *jūja-, to be connected with IE *sū- 'rain, to rain' (cf. Gk. ὕει, TochA swase, TochB swese 'rain').
Loan from VLat. *coccu(m) < Lat. coccineu(s) 'scarlet'.

S.v. Alb. djáthtë 'rechter'. Since long generally agreed to be derived from the root *dek̑s- 'rechts' (cf. OHG zeso, Gk. δεξιός 'rechts', etc.). The further analysis of the original morphological structure remains disputed.

S.v. lúm/ë, -i 'Fluß, Strom'. The oldest forms go back to a primary form lym(ë), apart from that the etymology is difficult. Meyer's (EWA) derivation from Lat. flūmen is difficult phonologically (cf. flok 'hair' < Lat. floccus with initial fl- retained). Possibly with Huld from *(s)leub-no- to the root *(s)leub- 'be slick, wet', alternatively with Çabej a relatively recent new lexeme from lym 'Flußschlamm, Lehm'. If from the latter, then to be connected with Gk. λῦμα 'Schmutz, Schmach' (cf. IEW 681 *leu̯(ə)- 'beschmutzen').
S.v. Alb. rrënj/ë, -a 'Wurzel, Stück (bei Baumzählung), Stein-, Stieleiche, Quercus, Quercus robur, etc.'. Without doubt from the same origin as Lat. rādix 'Wurzel', Goth. waurts 'ds.'.
From PIE *u̯h₁reh₂d- > urh₂d-(nieh₂) > radniā (cf. IEW 1167).
S.v. Alb. rrënjë ~ rranjë 'root; oak', from PAlb. wradnjā and etymologically connected with Gk. ῥάδιξ 'branch', Lat. rādix 'root', W. gwraidd, etc.
Loanword, either from Lat. r(h)ombu > Tosk rrum(p), or via Rmc. rombulus > rrumbull 'rolled into a ball' (so Orel 1998:391), or alternatively directly from Gk. ῥύμβος 'Kreisel/top, gyro'?
S.v. Alb. vrap 'schnell, flink', from which vrap(ë)tój 'laufen, rennen; sausen' is a derivative. Without etymology.
S.v. Alb. vrap 'to run, make haste', to which O. proposes an etymological connection with rjep 'to strip off (skin or bark), to tear off'.
S.v. nënte / nãntë 'neun', mentions in passing that Alb. rëre / rãnë 'sand' is a borrowing from Lat. arēna.
With LIV² 326, rejects the derivation to *k̑eNs- 'speak formally' > *k̑eh₁nsmi > Alb. thom (Orel 1998:480), rather with LIV² 318 *k̑eHs- 'anweisen / to advise'.

S.v. Alb. krúaj / krú(e)j 'kratzen, krauen, abkratzen'. The up to now assumed connection with Alb. g(ë)rrýej 'abkratzen, ausschliefen' may only be maintained under the assumption of certain folk-etymological deformation.
With LIV² from PIE *sekʷ- 'anschließen / to follow (with the eyes)' via a cs.-iter. *sokʷ-éi̯e- > PAlb. saśā́j-sk̑-.

Three possibilities: Either (1) inherited as an old verbal noun from 3. *sper- 'ausstreuen / to scatter' > PIE *spór-eh₂  > PAlb. sparā, accepting a sound-law of *sp- > f- (cf. Demiraj 1997:56), or (2) an early loan from Greek σπορά 'seed' (predating the sound-change *sp- > f-), or (3) a later loan from Lat. far(īna) 'flour, spelt'. H. considers the case 'not decidable'.
Assumes a sound-law *sp- > f-, comparing Alb. farë 'Samen, Saat' to Gk. σπορά 'Saat'. [No entry for farë otherwise.]
S.v. Alb. shkurt 'short', borrowed from Gmc. *skurtaz 'short' (cf. OHG scurz, OE sceort).
S.v. Alb. qiell 'sky, heaven', borrowed from Lat. caelum 'id.'.
S.v. Alb. fle ~ flê 'to sleep'. O. derives PAlb. *awa-leja and connects with Slav. *lějǫ, *lějati 'to doze, slumber'.

Rejects connections to IE *k̑lei̯- (so Matzinger in review of Orel 1998, in Die Sprache 40 (2) 1998, p.234; continued in Schumacher & Matzinger 2013:973-974), as well as to IE *legʰ- (so Orel 1998:99 comparing Slavic *lějati, with problematic derivation?); instead suggests connection to *lei̯h₂-i̯é- (LIV² 406, without Albanian) with a prefix f-.
S.v. Lat. gălbĭnus 'grüngelb', whence OFr. jalne, Modern French jaune.

Cf. s.v. galbus 'vert pâle, jaune', attested only in glosses, from which galbinus is a secondary derivative. One is reminded of lexemes like heluos, holus, etc. (< PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-, cf. s.v.), but in the Italic group neither initial g- nor the -al-, nor the -b- can be explained by expected regular sound changes. The hypothesis of a Gaulish loanword is based only upon the phonological difficulties. In sum, the etymology is unknown, except the root *gal- recalls a group of Indo-European words.
Cf. s.v. helvus 'yellow, dum', which would be the true cognate from *g̑ʰelh₃-i-uo-. [NB: ≠ galbus or galbinus! There is no lemma for galbus or galbinus in de Vaan 2008.]
S.v. χλωρός, in Ancient Greek 'yellow, pale; green, fresh', only surviving in the sense 'green, fresh' in other Mod. dialects. In Cappadocian χλερό with meaning 'yellow'.

Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek χλωρός '(pale) green' < PIE *g̑ʰl̥h₃-ró-. The same root *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' occurs in Baltic, Slavic, and Latin, but with different derivations (e.g. Lith. žélti 'to green, sprout', OCS зєлєнъ (translating Greek χλωρός, πράσινος), Lat. holus 'green plants, vegetables, cabbage').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *gelwa- ~ *gulu- 'yellow', from PIE *g̑ʰ(e)lh₃-u(o)- (cf. Lat. helvus 'yellow, dun', Lith. žel̃vas 'greenish' < *g̑elh₃-uo-; Skt. hári-, Av. zairi- 'yellow, greenish' < *g̑ʰelh₃-i-; Gk. χλωρός 'pale green, greenish yellow' < *g̑ʰelh₃-ró-; Lith. žélti (želiù) 'to grow, flourish', Latv. zel̂t < *gʰelh₃-ie-; OCS zelenъ, Russ. zelënyj < *g̑ʰelh₃-en-o-).

S.v. Lith. geltónas 'yellow', derived from Lith. geltas 'yellow', ultimately derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- (cf. Skt. hári- 'fallow, yellowish, greenish'; Gk. χλωρός 'pale, greenish, yellow'; Lat. helvus 'yellowish', OHG gelo 'yellow'. The depalatalised velar must have originated in a zero-grade, where the palatovelar was originally followed by a syllabic resonant. This suggests that the Baltic e-grade in this adjective is secondary. The regular reflex before a full grade is found, e.g., in Latv. zȩ̀lts 'gold'.
S.v. Alb. fle 'schlafen', connects to IE *k̑lei̯-e/o- 'sich anlehnen' (LIV² 332f.).
Several attempts at a root-etymology, but no consensus (cf. Orel 1998:99, Holm 2011:80, Schumacher & Matzinger 2013:973-974). Etymology ultimately uncertain.

Rejects the etymology of Orel (1998:513), who attempts to derive from PAlb. *wagla, comparing Lat. vagor 'to roam around', on the basis of relying on the outdated etymology of IEW (cf. now de Vaan 2008:651 s.v. vagus 'roaming, wandering', LIV² 682 s.v. ?*u̯eng- '(sich) krümmen') and also for being semantically implausible. H. alternatively suggests a loanword from Turkish ufaklik 'tinyness' (< Arab. faqīr 'poor').

S.v. Alb. vogël 'small'. O. derives from PAlb. *wāgla, *wāgra 'undersized, dwarfed, small', connecting to Lat. vagor 'to roam around' with the semantic development *u̯əg- 'to be crooked' > 'small' (IEW 1120).
S.v. Alb. nuhas 'to smell, to sniff', borrowed from Slav. *n’uxati 'id.', otherwise unattested in South Slavic. The same root is attested in SCr. njušiti 'id.'.

S.v. Alb. tym 'smoke', rejecting the possibility of a loanword from Greek θυμός 'soul, spirit' on the basis that it "is unknown in any meaning close to 'smoke'". Rather reconstructs PAlb. *ātuma, connected with Gmc. *ēðumaz and Skt. ātmán- 'blow, breath, soul'.

Against Orel's rejection of a loan from Greek θυμός, H. points out several derivatives with related semnatics: θυμήριον 'Räucher-pfanne / smoke-pan', θῦμάλ-ωψ 'Kohlenmeiler / charcoal kiln', as verbal nouns from *dʰu̯eh₂- 'Rauch machen / make smoke'. Huld (1984:117) favours a recent loan since old /y/ would have changed to /i/ in Tosk; recent sources could have been Old Bulgarian dymъ or Turk. duman.

S.v. Alb. tym, -i. Meyer (1891:93) noted verbal tymós, which he derived as a loan from OCS timijasati 'burn incense', in turn borrowed from Greek θυμιάμα 'incense'. The consistent -y- even in Tosk dialects where native -y- becomes -i- points to a recent loan.
Cf. s.v. Alb. lëmoj 'to file, polish', borrowed from Lat. līmāre 'id.'.
S.v. Alb. gjárp/ër, -ri / gjárpën 'Schlange'. Since long generally connected to PIE *serp- (cf. Ved. sarpá- 'Schlange', Lat. serpēns 'ds.') via a Proto-Albanian nomen actionis *sérp-e/ono-.
S.v. Alb. gjarpër ~ gjarpën, from Proto-Albanian *serpena and to be connected with Lat. serpēns 'snake, serpent', serpō 'crawl', derived from PIE *serp- 'to crawl'.
S.v. Ved. √sarp- 'kriechen, schleichen', from which Ved. sarpá- 'Schlange, Natter' is derived. Ultimately from PIE *serp- (cf. Gk. ἕρπω 'schleiche, gehe', Lat. serpō 'krieche, schleiche', etc.).

S.v. Lat. serpō, -ere 'to crawl, glide', from which Lat. serpēns 'snake, serpent'. The verbal stem is derived from PIE *serp-e/o- 'to creep' (cf. Skt. sárpati 'to creep, crawl', sarpá- 'snake, adder', Gk.  ἕρπω 'to creep, crawl', ἑρπετόν (Lesb. ὄρπετον) 'animal that goes on all fours', Alb. gjarpër 'snake').
S.v. Alb. bór/ë, -a 'Schnee'
S.v. Alb. borë 'snow'. The element -bārā is to be linked to bie 'fall' (with similar semantics to Rom. zapadă 'snow' borrowed from Slav. *zapada 'falling down (snow)').

S.v. Alb. rri 'to sit, stand, stay, remain' (suppletive aorist ndej). The form of the present stem goes back to Proto-Albanian *rina, etymologically close to Skt. r̥ṇóti 'to arise, to move', Gk. ὄρνυμαι 'move up, and related forms'. Meyer (1891:374) derives to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean, bend' but O. deems the phonological changes impossible.
S.v. r̄i 'sitze, halte mich auf, wohne, ruhe aus'. Compares Ved. śrayati 'lehnt sich an', Lith. szlëjù [sic!] 'lehne an' Gk. κλίνω, Lat. clinare, OHG hlinēn.
Proposes deriving from an essive form *h₁/h₃r-h₁ié- (cf. LIV² 25) of PIE *h₁/h₃r- 'set in motion, arrive somewhere' (cf. LIV² 238, 299).
Proposes deriving from an essive form *h₁/h₃r-h₁ié- (cf. LIV² 25) of PIE *h₁/h₃r- 'set in motion, arrive somewhere' (cf. LIV² 238, 299).

Rejects deriving from *sk̑eh₂i- (cf. IEW 917), likewise Orel (1998:518), without citation to IEW, who derives from *skī̆w-ila- related to hije based on the Geg form hyll. H. suggests semantically better from PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, glow' following Huld (1984:132) via *h₁us-li- (similarly Demiraj 1997:206).
S.v. Alb. yll 'star'. O. derives from PAlb. *skī̆w-ila, which he takes to be a derivative from *skijā > hije 'shadow'.

S.v. Alb. hyll 'Stern'. A common comparison is made with OIr. súil 'Auge', OCS slъnьce 'Sonne' (cf. Meyer 1891:460); an alternative assessment following Huld (1984:132) could be from *h₁us-lo- (cf. ON usli 'glühende Asche') > PAlb. *ūl- > yll.
Cf. s.v. Lat. gălbĭnus 'grüngelb', p.26. It. giallo is a loan from Old French.
S.v. Alb. shkop, -i 'stick, shepherd's crook, sceptre', an early loan from either Lat. scāpus or Gk. σκᾶπος ~ σκήπων.
S.v. Alb. skop 'stick, cane', O. considers the word inherited from PAlb. *skāpa further related to Gk. σκᾶπος· κλάδος, σκῆπτρον 'staff', Lat. scāpus 'shaft, stem', OHG skaft 'shaft, spear'.
S.v. Alb. škop 'Stock, Szepter, Massstab', cf. Lat. scāpus 'shaft', Gk. σκᾶπος with Alb. o corresponding to PIE *ā.

Cf. s.v. Gk. σκήπτομαι 'to support oneself, lean, pretend something, use as pretention; to throw down, sling'; also several related words for stick σκᾶπος· κλάδος (H.), σκηπτός 'stick, scepter', etc. All these forms point back to a root *σκᾶπ-. The noun σκᾶπος can be equated with Lat. scāpus 'shaft, stalk' and Alb. shkop 'stick' < *skeh₂p-o-, with zero-grade forms in Germanic words for 'shaft, spear, lance' (OHG skaft, ON skapt, etc. < *skh₂pt-. "Although formally these words could certainly be of IE origin, the distribution of forms and the semantics rather point to a European substrate origin."

Cf. s.v. Lat. scōpae 'branches of a plant, broom', with derivative scāpus 'stem, stalk, shaft' (cf. Gk. σκᾶπος 'stick' [Hesych.], σκήπτομαι 'to support oneself' < *skāp-; Latv. šķèps 'spear, javelin', CS štapъ 'stick' < *skēp-?; OHG skaft, OWNo. skapt 'shaft'). "Latin scāpus might be a borrowing from Gr. σκᾶπος, but scōp- must be older and both could go back to ablaut within a PIE root *sk(e/o)h₂p-. Yet a verbal root of this form is not attested [in Latin], and the words might also be (independent?) borrowings."

IE inherited status uncertain. Certainly there is enough comparative material between Italic, Germanic, Greek, and Albanian to posit a (European) IE word *skeh₂p-, but due to the geographical proximity of the branches the possibility of (independent?) early loanwords cannot be entirely excluded (cf. {ref Meyer 1891}:408, {ref Huld 1984}:114, {ref Orel 1998}:421, {ref de Vaan 2008}:546, {ref Beekes 2010}:1350 for further discussion).
Alb. gūr|i From PIE *gʷer- 'Berg / mountain' > *gʷr̥H(i)- > PAlb. gur(i).
S.v. Alb. gur 'stone, rock', connected with OCS gora, Ved. girí-, Av. gairi- 'mountain', Lith. gìrė 'woods'.
S.v. Alb. gur 'stone, rock' from PAlb. gura continuing a zero-grade of IE *gʷer- 'mountain' (cf. Skt. girí-, Av. gairi-, Lith. girià 'wood', Latv. dziria 'id.', Slav. *gora 'mountain, wood'.
S.v. Alb. gur, -i 'Stein, Fels, Felsgestein', an inherited word generally agreed to be connected with Ved. girí- 'Berg', Lith. gìrė 'Wald' < *gʷr̥H-í-.

S.v. TochB kärweñe* 'stone', (coll.) 'rock'. Etymology unclear. Perhaps with Skt. grā́van- 'stone for pressing the soma', OIr. bráu 'millstone, quern', if so, then to be from a putative PIE *gʷr̥Hu̯on-en-, a derivative of *gʷr̥Hu̯on- underlying the Celtic and Indic forms. Alternatively possible is a derivative of *k̑érh₂u̯n- found in Gk. κέραυνος. If so the Tocharian would reflect *k̑r̥h₂u̯on-en- and the meaning would be generalised from 'thunderstone' (the stones that are supposed to be the result of a lightning strike).

S.v. Ved. girí- 'Berg, Hügel, Anhöhe' (Iranian forms via YAv. gairi-, Khot. gara-, ggari-, Sogd. γar, Pashto γar), probably PIE *gʷr̥H-i- (cf. Alb. gur 'stone' OCS gora, 'mountain', Lith. girià 'forest').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *gora 'mountain' (ESSJa VII 29-31), a derivative of the o-grade of the root *gʷerH- (cf. Lith. girià 'woods', Skt. girí- 'mountain, hill').
S.v. Alb. drejtë 'straight, right, correct', ultimately a loan from Lat. directum.
S.v. Alb. drejtë 'straight, right', a borrowing from Lat. directum.

Rejects connection with PIE *su̯el-u̯o- (cf. Gk. ἕλη, so Huld 1984:50, 148), claiming a development *su̯V́- > *dV́- (but against this cf. Demiraj 1997:48 who argues **su̯V́- > *vV́-). Considers Orel (1998:65)'s proposal from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-u̯o- 'yellow' possible, but suggests alternatively from PIE *dei̯h₂- 'glänzen / to shine' (LIV² 108) + suffix *-lo- as in Gk.  διη-λός 'clear'.
S.v. Alb. diell, -i 'sun', favours a hypothesis first put forward by Pedersen deriving from the IE word for sun *su̯el- with *su- > d- before a stressed vowel.

S.v. Alb. diell 'sun'. O. derives from PAlb. *delwa, a tabooistic substitute for the original word for sun based on a colour adjective, comparing Skt. harí- 'pale, yellowish', Av. zairi- 'id.', Lat. helvus 'yellowish', Lith. žel̃vas 'id.'; acknowledging alternative etymologies (cf. entry for references) but making no effort to refute them.
Many attempts at an etymology outside of Albanian in the standard literature with no consensus; extra-Albanian connections ultimately uncertain.
S.v. Alb. djeł or dieł 'Sonne', suggests either from PAlb. *deglo- from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' or from *delno- from PIE *dʰal- 'sprout, grow'.
Cf. against the assumption of *su̯V́- > dV́- by Huld (1984:50, 148).

S.v. Alb. ëmbël / ãmbël 'süß, mild'. Not certainly explained. The comparison with Ved. amlá- 'sauer' is semantically facile. Better is the proposed connection with Alb. mjaltë 'Honig' in the same semantic relationship as Ir. milis, W. melys 'süß' against OIr. mil 'Honig'. The Albanian derivation could be easily explained as prefixed Alb. *ambëlt < *an-blit < *(h₂)en-mlit- ‘which has honey (in it)’ with epenthesis or dissimilation.

S.v. Alb. ë(n)j 'schwellen, zunehmen, entzünden, erzürnen'. The meaning 'blow (of wind)' (so {ref Huld 1984}:63) probably does not exist. The almost exclusively followed connections to Ved. ániti 'atmen', Gk. ἄνεμος 'Hauch, Wind' and inner-Albanian end 'blühen' is semantically difficult. Another assessment by Çabej of an etymological assessment with Gk. οἰδάω, οἰδαίνω, Arm. aytnowm 'schwellen' (also Ölberg KZ 86 [1976] 128) should be considered.

S.v. Alb. ëj 'blow (of inanimate things like wind)', to be connected with Ved. ániti 'it blows', Gk. ἄνεμος 'wind', derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- (so {ref Meyer 1891}:5), rejecting the suggestion of Çabej that it should be connected with Gk. οἰδέω 'swell' as phonetically implausible'.
S.v. Alb. ëj ~ âj 'to blow, to swell', from PAlb. *anj and to be related to Skt. ániti 'to breathe', Goth. us-anan 'to blow out', etc. (so {ref Meyer 1891}:5).

IE root etymology uncertain. Two main possibilities: Either to (1) PIE *h₂enh₁- ({ref LIV²} 297-298, so {ref Huld 1984}:63, {ref Orel 1998}:91, and others), or (2) to PIE *h₂ei̯d- ({ref LIV²} 258-259, cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:256-257, {ref Demiraj 1997}:171-172).

Cf. s.v. *h₂ei̯d- 'schwellen' (IEW 774), note 1, with reference to {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:256-7, and s.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' to which Alb. ënj 'blase (auf)' is listed as an uncertain Neubildung formation ?R(e)-i̯e- Präs., cf. n9 with reference to {ref Huld 1984}:155 and {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:256-7.

Rejects the loan hypothesis unquestioningly followed by Orel (1998:301) due to atypical features, preferring the solution of Huld (1984:148) who derives directly from PIE *(s)neh₂- (cf. LIV² 572 without Albanian forms listed) Alb. notim < *(s)néh₂-t-imo-.
S.v. Alb. notoj 'to swim'. O. follows the hypothesis of a borrowing from Romance *notāre replacing Classical *natāre (so Meyer 1891:311).
In the section on sound-changes Huld rather derives earlier notim 'swimming' < PIE *snéAt-imo-.

Two possibilities: Either (1) as a loan from Romance *notāre (with irregular root vocalism from Lat. natāre 'swim', so {ref Meyer 1891}:311, {ref Orel 1998}:301), or – perhaps better – (2) directly derived to PIE *(s)neh₂- (so {ref Huld 1984}:148, {ref Holm 2011}:83). No discussion in {ref Demiraj 1997} or {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}.

Ancient Greek dialectal variants βλέπω ~ *γλέπω (cf. Alcman 23, 75 ποτι-γλέποι) points to a possible original *gʷ- with an irregular development (*gʷlep- > βλεπ- expected pan-dialectally). Additionally unexplained is the alternation π ~ φ in root-final position in apparently derived vocabulary βλέφαρον ~ γλέφαρον 'eyelid'. A Macedonian gloss also attests γλέπου. A 'Pre-Greek' substrate borrowing hypothesis, as suggested by Furnée (1972:389) and Beekes (2010:219-220) therefore seems likely in this case. Because of the irregular sound changes, I refrain from positing *gʷlep⁽ʰ⁾- as a root ref. form, however this may well have been the shape of the original stem in the source-language of the borrowing.

Rejects connections to PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'wachsen, entstehen / to grow' (so Orel 1998:27) as semantically idiosyncratic and phonetically problematic. Instead Holm prefers the conjecture of Demiraj (1997:103) to PIE *bʰei̯H- via derived *bʰi(H)-st-o- 'schlagen / to beat' > *bi-śt-, seeming to express a semantically characteristic property.

S.v. Alb. bisht 'tail'. O. proposes an etymology from PAlb. *būšta, derived from PIE *bʰū- 'to grow' (semantically viewing the tail as a bodily outgrowth), without attempting to refute other proposed etymologies.

S.v. Alb. bisht, -i 'Schweif, Schwanz'. Without a satisfying etymology. Proposed connections to Basque bustan, or PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split' are unlikely; otherwise unclear. Perhaps to Alb. bij '(auf)keimen, sprossen' from PAlb. (?)*b(h)ī̆-st-o-?
S.v. bisht, -i 'tail (of fish, animals, birds, reptiles)'. Etymology obscure.

S.v. OAlb. merr 'nehmen', which Schumacher & Matzinger relate to a present stem *arne/a-, which is thematicised from *arnu- and compounded with a preverb *me-. The stem *arnu- is in turn to be derived from PIE *h₂r̥-néu̯-/*h₂r̥-nu- also continued in Ancient Greek, Avestan, and Armenian from 2. *h₂er- 'nehmen, erwerben' (LIV² 270-271).

S.v. Alb. marr 'to take, grasp', which O. derives from PAlb. marna, a deverbative based on the heteroclitic word for 'hand' preserved by Gk. μάρη, Lat. manus (without attempting to refute other proposed etymologies).

S.v. Alb. marr 'nehmen, ergreifen; einannehmen, erhalten, bekommen'. The etymology of the word is disputed. Previous proposals have included connections to (1) Ved. mr̥śáti 'berühren' and/or Gk. μάρπτω 'fassen, ergreifen' (so Meyer 1891:261); (2) Gk. μάρη 'Hand' (so Jokl 1911:53-54), PIE *mar-n(i̯)o-A₁ (so Huld 1984:89-90), a blending of a preverb m- (comparable to the prep. *me- 'mit' with the root underlying Gk. ἄρνυμαι, Arm. aṙnowm, thus from *(s)me(d)-A₂ernō 'take away' > PAlb. *me-harno- (so Hamp 1965:140). Demiraj offers yet another possibility, to PIE *merh₂- 'packen' (via *mr̥h₂-V-).
S.v. Alb. marr, mora, marrë 'take, grasp'. Root etymology unclear, all earlier etymologies see a root *mar- with an n-present.

S.v. Arm. aṙnum 'to gain, obtain, win, plunder, take, grasp, etc.', generally agreed to be derived from PIE *h₂r-nu-, cf. Gk. ἄρνυμαι, aor. ἀρόμεν 'to win, gain', and probably also Av. ərənauu- 'to grant, allot, provide' (on which cf. de Vaan 2003:371).
Cf. for a possible comparison to Av. ərənauu- 'to grant, allot, provide'.
S.v. 2. *h₂er- 'nehmen, erwerben' (IEW 61).

Root etymology disputed (cf. esp. Demiraj 1997:257-258). Possibly related to cognates from PIE 2. *h₂er- (LIV² 270-271 /cognate/8293/, so Hamp 1965:140, Schumacher & Matzinger 2013:983), but alternative etymologies are also possible.
S.v. Alb. kofšɛ 'Hüfte, Schenkel', a borrowing from Lat. coxa.
S.v. Alb. kofshë 'hip, thigh', borrowed from Lat. coxa 'hip'.
S.v. Alb. hollë 'thin, fine, slender, slim', from PAlb. skāla and to be related to PIE *skel- 'cut' (Lith. skeliù, skélti 'to split, divide', MIr. scáilim 'to let go' etc.).

S.v. Alb. hóllë (i) 'dünn, schlank, fein'. Acknowledging the possible etymology from *skēl- (so Jokl 1916:99) and rejecting Hamp (1965:130)'s suggestion connecting Gk. ἀλέω, Demiraj suggests a possible inner-Albanian connection with hollí 'elongated hollow', húall, (pl.tant.) hóje 'Honigwabe, Beinenstock' which might be able to be compared with Gk. αὐλός 'Rohrflöte, längliche Höhlung', Lat. alvus 'Höhlung' < (?)*h₂ēu̯l-.

S.v. Alb. hollë 'thin, fine, slim', from PIE *skēl-, following Jokl (1912:192), Jokl (1916:98-99), cf. ON skála, Gk. σκῶλος 'thorn, pointed stick'. Hamp (1965:130) attempts to relate hollë and halë to Gk. ἀλέω 'grind', but this comparison is semantically weak.
Attempts to connect Alb. hollë 'thin' to Gk. ἀλέω, Arm. ałam 'grind'.
Connects Alb. hołɛ 'dünn' Germ. skāla, Slav. skala, Gk. σκῶλος from a lengthened grade formation *skēl-.

Three proposed etymologies: Either (1) to PIE *skel- 'cut' (LIV² 552-553 s.v. ?2. *(s)kel- 'spalten', *skelH- 'aufschlitzen, spalten', cf. IEW 923-6), so Jokl (1916:98-99), Huld (1984:75-76), Orel (1998:150), cf. Demiraj (1997:203); (2) to PIE ?*h₂ēu̯l- (Demiraj 1997:203); or (3) to PIE *h₂elh₁- 'grind' (so Hamp 1965:130). In this class the traditional etymology to *skel- is followed.
S.v. Alb. mendoj 'to think, count', a denominative verb from Alb. mend 'mind', in turn a loan from Lat. mentem (so Meyer 1891:274).
S.v. Alb. mend 'mind', borrowed from Lat. mentem 'id.', whence the denominative verb mendoj 'to think, to count'.
S.v. Alb. tre, f. tri 'three', from PAlb. *treje, continuing PIE *trei̯es 'id.', cf. Skt. trayaḥ, Gk. τρεῖς, Lat. trēs, etc.

S.v. Alb. tre m./n. tri f. 'drei', the inherited numeral with numerous cognates in other IE languages: Alb. tre < *trei̯es (cf. Ved. tráyas, Lat. trēs), and Alb tri < *tri-ə : *trih₂ with the same development as Gk. τρία, Goth. ϸrija.

S.v. Alb. hedh 'werfen, schleudern, schließen, losstürzen, worfeln (Getreide)'. Normally compared with Germ. *skeu̯(d)- (ON skjóta 'schießen, werfen', OE scēotan 'schießen, schleudern', etc.) to PIE *(s)keu̯d- 'werfen, schießen'. The connection with Germ. *skeu̯d- cannot however explain the variant hjedh.

S.v. Alb. hedh = hjedh 'werfen' / përhjedh / (Budi) 'verstreuen, zerstreuen'. Two different roots underlie these forms: *(s)keu̯d- '(vor)antreiben' (LIV² 560) and *(s)kedh₂- 'zersplittern, zerstreuen' (LIV² 550-551). In Old Albanian the root *skedh₂ is attested especially by Bogdani via hjedh 'zerstreuen' and by Budi in the compound përhjedh 'verstreuen, zerstreuen'. The root *(s)keu̯d- can better explain the semantics of non-active hjidhet 'eilen'. In Modern Albanian the form hedh can only be phonologically regular from PIE *skeu̯deti, not from *(s)kedh₂-.
S.v. Alb. hedh 'throw', maintaining Meyer (1891:150)'s connections to Germanic words for 'shoot' < *sk̑eu̯d- (IEW 956 *(s)k̑eu̯d- 'werfen, schliessen, hetzen').
Cf. s.v. *(s)keu̯d- '(vor)antreiben' (IEW 955-6), under which ?Alb. hedh 'wirft' < *(s)kéu̯d-e-.
S.v. Alb. heθ 'werfe', from < *heδō and to be connected with Germ. skeudō in OS skeotan, ON skjóta, OHG scioʒan 'schiessen'.
Adds to √*(s)kedh₂- under the present formation ?*(s)kedh₂-e- Alb. hjedh 'zerstreut; wirft' after Schumacher & Matzinger (2013:976).
S.v. Lat. ligō, -āre 'to fasten, bind', from PIE *lig̑- 'to tie'? (cf. Alb. lidh 'to tie') "Apart from Alb. lidh, which can be explained in various ways, there are no certain cognates."
S.v. Alb. lidh 'binden, verbinden, vereinigen'. An inherited word which is semantically and formally closest to Lat. ligō 'binden, zusammenziehen'.
S.v. Alb. lidh 'to bind, tie', from PAlb. līdza and etymologically close to Lat. ligāre 'id.'.
S.v. Alb. lidh 'bind, tie', related to Lat. līgāre 'bind' (so Meyer 1891:245), from PIE *lei̯g̑- 'binden' (IEW 668).

Considers the derivation from *gal-so- 'schreien, to shout' (IEW 350) semantically unconvincing; similarly from a proposed zero-grade Orel (1998:138) *gl̥-so- > PAlb. *glūsa because of gl- in dialectal forms. Holm prefers alternatively from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯ā 'tongue' via metathesis to *g̑ʰnud- + -sk̑e- with *gn- > gl- > gj- (as in gju 'knee'), cf. Huld (1984:71).

S.v. Alb. gjuhë 'tongue, language'. On the basis of dialectal gluhë (Cham), gl'uγε (Calabr), O. adduces PAlb *glusā and connects with IE *golso- 'sound' (ON kall 'shout', Lith. gal̃sas 'echo', Slav. *golsъ 'voice'. Because of PAlb. *-ul-, O. suggests that this must go back to a zero-grade *gl̥so- as opposed to the full grade forms of Balto-Slavic and Germanic.
Only mentions gjúhë in passing to doubt proposed etymological connections to qúaj 'to name'.

Connections outside of Albanian unclear. The two main hypotheses connect the word either (1) to Germanic and Balto-Slavic words for 'sound' < *g(o)l-so- (so {ref Orel 1998}:138, cf. {ref IEW} 350), or (2) with the IE inherited word for 'tongue' *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- (so {ref Huld 1984}:71, {ref Holm 2011}:85).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *zǫ̑bъ 'tooth', from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- (cf. Lith. žam̃bas 'sharp edge', Latv. zùobs 'tooth', Skt. jámbha- 'tooth', Gk. γόμφος 'pin, nail', OIc. kambr 'comb, jagged edge').

S.v. TochB keme 'tooth; dentition', which with TochA kam reflects PToch *keme from PIE *g̑ómbʰos 'tooth' (cf. Skt. jámbha- 'tooth', jambhya- 'molar tooth', Gk. γόμφος 'tooth; bolt, dowel', γομφίος 'molar tooth', Alb. dhëmb 'tooth', dhëmballë 'molar tooth', OCS zǫbъ 'tooth', Latv. zùobs 'tooth', Lith. žam̃bas 'edge, brim', OHG kamm 'comb', etc.).

Cf. s.v. Lith. žam̃bas '(sharp) edge, flap' (Latv. zùobs 'tooth'), from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- (cf. Lith. žam̃bas 'sharp edge', Latv. zùobs 'tooth', Skt. jámbha- 'tooth', Gk. γόμφος 'pin, nail', OIc. kambr 'comb, jagged edge').
S.v. Alb. dhëmb 'Zahn', the inherited word for 'tooth' which is identical with Ved. jámbha-, OCS zǫbъ, Gk. γόμφος, etc., from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o-s.
S.v. Alb. dhëmb ~ dhamb 'tooth' from PAlb. dzamba and cognate with TochA kam 'tooth', TochB keme 'id.', Latv. zùobs 'id.', Slav. *zǫbъ 'id.', cf. also Gk. γόμφος 'peg', Skt. jámbha- 'bit, peg'.
Loan from Lat. pōmum.
S.v. Alb. pemε 'Obst, Obstbaum, Baum', borrowed from Lat. pōmum, cf. Rum. pom 'Obstbaum, Baum'.
Cf. s.v. Alb. dru, -ri / drû, -ni 'Baum, Baumstamm, Holz; Brennholz, Bauholz' for discussion of the possible stem formations underlying the forms in Albanian.
S.v. Alb. dru ~ drû 'tree; wood', from PAlb. *druwa to be compared with Slav. *drъvo 'wood', Skt. dru- 'id.', Av. 'dru- 'id.', Gk. δρῦς 'tree, oak'.
S.v. Alb. vërtetë 'truth', borrowed from Lat. veritātem 'id.'.
S.v. kthej 'turn', O. considers a prefixal derivative of thyej 'to break', would continue PAlb. *tsā(i)nja from PIE *k̑ēi- 'to sharpen' (cf. Skt. śiśāti 'to sharpen', Arm. sur 'sharp; knife', etc.).
S.v. Alb. kεθéń, kθeń 'wende um, zurück, ändere, übersetze, schenke ein', a loan from Lat. convertere : co(n)vertebam.
Follows Meyer (1891:185).

Etymology disputed. Possibly to PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- ({ref IEW} 541-2) if one follows {ref Orel 1998}:200, 482 to Alb. thyej 'break' (cf. {ref LIV²} 319-320, without Albanian lexemes listed); older etymologies (e.g. {ref Meyer 1891}:185, {ref Jokl 1911}:94) suggest a borrowing from Lat. convertere. The verb is not discussed in {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}.
S.v. Alb. vjell 'vomit' to be connected with Lat. volvō 'turn' (for the semantics cf. the phrase 'turn one's stomach'.

Considers Orel (1998:85)'s derivation from *h₁ei̯- with the nominal suffix *-to- phonologically implausible. Considers rather the possibility of a loan from South Slavic ići 'to go', influenced by Turkish yetiş- 'to reach, catch up with' with dialectally preserved y-.
