S.v. Alb. ec(i) 'to go, to run', which O. derives from PAlb. aitatja, based on a derivative in *-to- to PIE *ei- 'go'.
S.v. Alb. etsεń 'gehe', suggesting a borrowing from Lat. *ĭti̯ō from *ĭto 'gehe!'.
S.v. Alb. škoń 'gehe vorüber, verfliesse'; the sounds satisfy a derivation from Lat. sequor, the meaning not quite ("Den Lauten genügt Herleitung aus lat. sequor, der Bedeutung nicht ganz.").
Rejects Meyer's connection to Lat. sequor as semantically implausible and proposes instead a denominative formation to Alb. štek, štegu 'Weg'.
S.v. Alb. shkoj '(move from one place to another)', following Jokl (1911:80-2)'s etymology to Alb. shteg 'path' akin to Gk. στοῖχος 'row, line', OCS stьdza 'path'.
S.v. Alb. shkoj '(move from one place to another)', following Jokl (1911:80-2)'s etymology to Alb. shteg 'path' akin to Gk. στοῖχος 'row, line', OCS stьdza 'path'.

Rejects Jokl and others from PIE *stei̯gʰ 'schreiten / walk' on the basis that the tectal should be preserved in *stoiGh-, consequently considers the proposal of a loan from Lat. sequor (so Meyer 1891:406) more likely.
S.v. Alb. la 'waschen, spülen, reinigen', probably to continue a verb of the productive *-n(i̯)o- class: *lh₃-eu̯- > PAlb. *lau̯- > Alb. la-.
S.v. Alb. laj ~ lâj 'to wash', from PAlb. *launja and related to Gk. λούω, Lat. lavō 'id.'.
S.v. Alb. l'ań 'wasche, bade', borrowed from Lat. lavāre.
S.v. Alb. laj 'wash', contra Meyer (1891:237) if laj is a loan from Lat. lavāre, then that would have yielded *lëv-oj or *loj.

S.v. Lat. lavō, -āre 'to bathe', from Proto-Italic *lowa- (cf. Umb. vutu [3.sg.iptv.]), from PIE *(le-)louh₃- 'to wash' (cf. Gk. λούω 'I wash', Arm. loganam 'to bathe', lowanam 'wash', OAlb. laa 'to wash').
Cf. s.v. Gk. λούω, -ομαι 'to bathe, wash (the body)', from PIE *louh₃- 'wash, bathe'.
S.v. OAlb. lan 'waschen', attested through Old Gheg la (Buzuku) probably continues PIE *leu̯h₃-e/o- with a present-stem n-suffix.
S.v. Lith. vanduõ (Latv. ûdens, OPr. wundan), from PIE *uod-r/n- (cf. OCS voda, Skt. udán-, Hitt. u̯ātar / u̯iten-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Go. wato, OIc. vatn, OS watar).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', from PIE *uod-r/n-.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *uden-sk-yo- 'water', from PIE *wod-r / *uden- 'water' (cf. Skt. udán-, Hitt. watar-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, Lat. unda 'wave', OCS voda, Germ. Wasser). Matasović gives this as the standard etymology, although he expresses reservations that the Proto-Celtic stem formation is correct. See entry for further discussion.

S.v. Alb. ujë 'water', from PAlb. udrjā and derived from the IE word for water *u̯ed-. The connection to *u̯ed- is generally agreed since Meyer (1891:456) [cf. entry in Orel for references to further literature], but note Demiraj (1997:401-402) alternatively derives PAlb. *urjā, related to Skt. vā́r- [< *u̯eh₁-r].
S.v. Alb. új/ë 'Wasser', D. alternatively derives Albanian forms from PIE *(H)uh₁r̥-i̯o/e-, cf. Skt. vā́r < *(H)u̯(e)h₁-r-.

S.v. Alb. lag 'naß machen, anfeuchten; mit Wasser bespritzen; eintauschen; bewässern' (adj. lagur 'naß, durchnäßt; feucht, klamm'). Not certainly explained. Demiraj prefers (though still doubting) a connection with OCS vlaga 'wetness, moisture' (no loan because a late loss of #v- is unexpected) and Lith. vìlgau, vìlgyti 'make wet', vìlgti 'become wet' pointing to a root PIE *u̯el(H)g- (= LIV: 676 ?2. *u̯elg-, where OHG welc 'wet' is connected).
Cf. s.v. Alb. lag 'to wet, to soak, to bathe, to wash', from PAlb. *lauga and to be further compared with lëgatë 'marsh'.

S.v. Alb. bardhë 'weiß, glänzend'. Meyer (1891:27)'s comparison with Goth. bairhts 'hell', Lith. béržas 'Birke' is generally accepted. The reconstruction of the form ancestral to the Albanian is not agreed, although Meyer's reconstruction of an o-grade form is phonetically unobjectionable, thus probably Alb. bardhë can be accounted for from a putative PIE *bʰorHg̑-o-.
S.v. Alb. barθ 'weiss', to be connected with Ved. bhrājate 'er glänzt, schimmert', Av. barāzaiti 'er schimmert', Goth. bairhts.
S.v. Alb. bardhë 'white', following the etymology of Meyer (1891:29) to Lith. bèržas, etc., from *bʰr̥Hg̑- (IEW 139 *bherəg̑-).

From PIE *bʰerh₁g̑-o- 'bright' > *bʰorh₁g̑-o- > barða-. The exact ablaut grade reflected by the Albanian form is disputed, cf. Huld (1984:40) for a zero-grade, Demiraj (1997:90), Orel (1998:17) arguing for an o-grade.

S.v. Alb. gjerë ~ gjanë 'broad, wide', from PAlb. *saina, a zero-grade derivative in *-no- based on PIE *sēi- 'long, late' (cf. OE síd 'long, wide', Goth. seiϸus 'late', OIr. síth 'long', Lat. serus 'late', etc.), so Jokl (1911:28).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *sīϸu- 'late' < PIE *sh₁-éi-tu- (cf. Lat. sērus 'belated, slow', OIr. sír 'lasting, eternal' W hir 'long' < *seh₁-ro-).
S.v. Alb. erë 'wind, scent, smell', of Latin or Romance origin.
S.v. Alb. erë 'wind', from Rom. *er(a), based on Lat. aer 'air'.
S.v. Alb. erε 'Luft, Wind, Geruch', from Rom. *aira = It. aria, Span., Prov. aire, Fr. air.
S.v. Alb. me 'with', from PAlb. *me(t) and to be connected with Goth. miϸ 'with', Gk. μέτα 'in the middle, between'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *medi 'with' < *met-i, cf. Gk. μέτα, μετά, (adv., prep.) 'in the midst, afterwards; between, with, after' < *met-m, Alb. mjet (adv.) 'between' < *met-. An Indo-European adverb and preposition.
Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek μέτα, μετά 'in the midst, afterwards; between, with, after' < PIE *meth₂ 'in the midst, between, after'.

S.v. grua, -ja 'woman', lists both the etymologies from *gʷn̥-ōn- after Meyer (1891:132) and the proposed connection with Gk. γραῦς (cf. Hamp 1960:276) without deciding which of the two is to be preferred.
Either to PIE *gʷe(h₁)n-ah₂ 'woman' or PIE *g̑reh₂- 'ripe, ready (of grain), grown up (of people)'. "[T]he case remains debatable."

S.v. Alb. vit, -i 'Jahr, Jahrgang'. The Albanian forms go back to a neuter form *u̯et-, which is formally identical with Gk. ϝέτος, ἔτος 'year'. [Cf. entry in Demiraj for further discussion on the stem formation within Albanian.]
S.v. Alb. vit, vjet 'year', from PAlb. *weta to be connected with Hitt. u̯itt- 'year', Gk. ἔτος 'year', etc.
S.v. Alb. vit, -i 'year', to be connected with Gk. ϝέτος 'year', Lat. vetus 'old', etc. derived from PIE *u̯et- 'year'.
S.v. Alb. verθ, verδi 'gelb', a borrowing from Lat. viridis, virdis (cf. It., Sp. verde, Fr. vert, etc.).
S.v. Alb. verdhë 'yellow', borrowed from Lat. viridis 'green'.
S.v. Alb. dje 'gestern', generally agreed to go back to the inherited word for 'yesterday' *g̑ʰ-di̯es or *dʰg̑ʰi̯es.
S.v. Alb. dje 'yesterday', from PAlb. *de and etymologically identical with Skt. hyás, Gk. χθές, Lat. heri, etc.
S.v. Alb. qiell, -i 'sky, heavens', long recognised as a borrowing from Lat. caelum [Huld prints coelum], 'sky, heaven', so Meyer (1891:225-226) and others.
S.v. TochA eprer 'air space', a borrowing from Tocharian B.
S.v. TochB iprer 'sky, air, atmosphere', from which TochA eprer is surely a borrowing.
S.v. TochB iprer 'sky, air, atmosphere', presumably reflecting zero-grade *m̥bʰ-ro- (cf. Ved. abhrá- 'cloud', Lat. imber 'rain', etc.) from PIE *nebʰ-.

Cf. s.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bevölkt, dunstig (werden) (LIV 448, IEW 315f., EIEC 110, 477). See under n21 to *n̥bʰ-ro-, the connection of TochA eprer 'Atmosphäre, Himmel, Firmament' and TochB iprer is also to be connected to this preform is disputed. Van Windekens (II.1 66) alternatively suggests a connection to TochA prār, B prāri* NPl.f. 'Finger' to be connected with Gk. πείρω 'durchbohren, -stechen, -dringen', according to which would be a proto-form *per-o/ēr with an intensive prefix i-/e- added.
S.v. Lith. debesìs 'cloud' (Latv. debess, var. debesis), from PIE *nebʰ-es-. The initial *n of the etymon was apparently replaced with d- in East Baltic.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *nemos- 'heaven, sky', from PIE *nebʰos 'cloud, cloudy sky' (cf. Hitt. nēpiš 'sky', Skt. nábhas- 'cloud', Gk. νέφος, OCS nebo 'sky'. "The irregular *-m- of the Celtic forms is best explained as the result of assimilation (n…bʰ > n…m)."

Cf. s.v. Ved. áśman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Fels' (Av. asman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Himmel'), from PIE *h₂ek̑-mon- (cf. Gk. ἄκμων 'Amboß (auch 'Meteorstein' und 'Himmel'), Lith. ašmuõ (pl. ãšmens) 'Schneide, Schärfe', akmuõ, -ẽns 'Stein'). To PIE *h₂ek̑- 'scharf, spitz'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hemina- ~ *hemna- 'heaven'. On the PIE level the Germanic word is often analysed as a distorted continuant of *h₂ek̑-mōn, gen. *h₂k̑-mn-ós, loc. *h₂k̑-mén-i. Because the regular outcome of this in Germanic would be *ahmōn, *humnaz, *meni, it would seem that the paradigm was remodelled into *hemō, *hemnaz, *hemeni, on the basis of the genitive.

S.v. Goth. H64. himins 'οὐρανός', 'heaven'. Uncertain etymology. Related by some scholars with PIE *Hek̑mon 'sharp thing', but with severe phonological and semantic difficulties. Otherwise possibly to PIE *k̑em- 'cover' (cf. Goth. af-hamon), cf. Hitt. kammara- 'cloud, vapor, smoke', however the formation is also problematic.

S.v. *h₂ek̑- 'scharf, spitz (sein / werden / machen)' (LIV 261, IEW 18ff.). There are no certain Germanic cognates listed under the derived form *h₂ák̑-mon-; cf. pp.290-291, n7 where it is considered that a zero-grade formation must have existed if Germanic *hemena 'Himmel' reflects a post-PIE vr̥ddhi-formation (as if *h₂k̑-e-men-o-), however the semantics of such a formation are require further justification. Derivation ultimately unclear, possibly of non-IE origin in Germanic (cf. Boutkan 1998:113f.).
No reliable IE etymology. Cf. for discussion with references.
S.v. *dei̯-, di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f., EIEC 513). Ved. dyáu- reflects a stem formation *di̯-éu̯-.

S.v. Ved. dyav- 'Himmel, Himmelsgott, Vater Himmel, Tag', from PIE *di̯éu̯-/diu̯- 'Himmel, Tag' (also personified 'Himmelsgott'), (cf. Gk. Ζεύς, Lat. *dius in nudius tertius 'vorgestern' < *'und es ist der dritte Tag', from the root *dei̯- 'leuchten'.
S.v. Lat. caelum 'sky, heaven, vault of heaven'. Various hypotheses.
S.v. caelum 'ciel', there are only uncertain hypotheses. The Indo-European inherited words for 'sky' (cf. diēs, Iuppiter) were preserved with different semantic values and renewed forms.

S.v. οὐρανός 'voûte du ciel', the old etymology to Skt. Váruṇa- is phonetically impossible (cf. Mayrhofer EWAia s.v.), alternatively as proposed by Wackernagel (Kl. Schr. 1.632) to *ϝορσο- corresponding to Skt. varṣá- 'pluie'. This interpretation is plausible but not certain. Οὐρανός could be borrowed.

The best IE etymology, is a derivation to *h₂u̯ers- 'rain' (so {ref Wackernagel 1888}:129 = Kl.Schr. 1.632, tentatively accepted by {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}, {ref Beekes 2010}). The hypothesis of substrate borrowing is a possibility but, given that there is no concrete extra-Greek comparison for it, gratuitous. For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form, Wackernagel's etymology has been followed here.
Cf. s.v. οὐρανός 'Himmel'.
Cf. s.v. Goth. L58. *luftus 'ἀήρ', 'air'. Etymology unclear.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'roof, air', a *-tu- stem related to *lauba- 'leaf, foliage'. No clear IE etymology.
S.v. 1008 Skt. ākāśá- m. 'sky' ŚBr. [√kāś].

S.v. Lith. dengùs 'sky, heaven' (OPr. dangus), related to Lith. deñgti 'cover, thatch, clothe, shelter, conceal', from PIE *dʰengʰ- (cf. OHG tungen 'oppress, manure'; MHG tungen 'manure, cover, oppress, scare' < *dʰngʰ-).
S.v. Hitt. šeš- / šaš- 'to sleep, to rest, to lie down', from PIE *sés-ti, *ss-énti (cf. Skt. sas- 'to sleep', Av. hah- 'to sleep').
S.v. Ved. √sas- 'schlafen', from PIE *ses- (cf. Hitt. še-eš-zi 'schläft', Luv. šašša- 'schlafen').

S.v. Arm. kʻun 'sleep', kʻnem 'to sleep', kʻunem 'to sleep', etc., long since related to the PIE word for 'sleep' from *su̯ep- (cf. nominal *su̯op-no- > Skt. svápna- 'sleep, dream', Av. xᵛafna-, Gk. ὕπνος, Lat. somnus 'sleep', Lith. sãpnas 'dream', OCS sъnъ 'sleep' etc.).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ap/f- 'to sleep', from PIE *su̯ep- 'to sleep' (cf. Lat. sōpīre 'to fall asleep', OCS sъpati 'to fall asleep', Russ. spat', OE swefan 'to sleep', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *sufan- 'to sleep', from PIE *sup-e- (cf. Hitt. šupp(t)ari 'to sleep' < *sup-e-, Skt. svápiti 'to sleep', Av. xᵛap- ~ xᵛaf- 'id.' < *suep-).
S.v. Lat. dormiō, -īre 'to sleep', from PIE *drm-i̯e- 'to sleep' (cf. CS drěmati, Ru. dremat', SCr. drijèmati 'to doze, slumber' < *drēm-, Gk. δαρθάνω 'to fall asleep'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *slēpan- 'to sleep'. [No etymology outside of Germanic given.]
S.v. ?*sleh₁b- 'schlaff sein' (IEW 656). If the forms under this lemma are cognate, then only Germanic and Balto-Slavic (if connected to Lith. slobstù, slõbti 'schwach werden').

S.v. Arm. očʻ 'not'. Since long generally linked with Gk. οὐκ, οὐκί, οὐχί 'not', cf. Meillet (1936:143), Cowgill (1960) via (*ne) *h₂oiu-kʷid. Clackson (1994:158), and Clackson (2004-2005:155-156) is critical of the etymology and regards o-čʻ as an inner-Armenian creation, as the simple pronoun o- (cf. o-kʻ and o-mn 'someone') + simple negative čʻ < *kʷid. The inner-Armenian interpretation is most plausible.

Cf. s.v. Arm. očʻ 'not'. Since long generally linked with Gk. οὐκ, οὐκί, οὐχί 'not', cf. Meillet (1936:143), Cowgill (1960) via (*ne) *h₂oiu-kʷid. Clackson (1994:158), and Clackson (2004-2005:155-156) is critical of the etymology and regards o-čʻ as an inner-Armenian creation, as the simple pronoun o- (cf. o-kʻ and o-mn 'someone') + simple negative čʻ < *kʷid. The inner-Armenian interpretation is most plausible.

S.v. Engl. die (v.), from early Middle English dēȝen, dēghen, corresponding to Old Norse deyja, generally considered to be lost from Old English (where expressed by steorfan, sweltan, or periphrastic wesan déad) and re-introduced from early Scandinavian, although a minority view view a preservation of Old English díegan, dégan, in some dialects.
S.v. Engl. dig, attested since the 14th cent. and probably from French diguer, 'to dig or hollow out the ground'.
S.v. Engl. dirty (adj.), derived from Engl. dirt + -y suffix. Engl. dirt in turn from Middle English drit, probably < Old Norse drit 'excrement'.
S.v. Engl. egg. The inherited word for 'egg', attested via OE ǽg, was replaced in Middle English by a borrowing from Old Norse egg 'egg' (Middle English egge).
S.v. Engl. flower, from Middle English flour, flur, borrowed from Old French flour, flur, flor (cf. Modern French fleur).
S.v. Engl. fruit, from Middle English frut, fruyt(e) (etc.), a borrowing  Old French fruit, in turn ultimately from Lat. frūctus.
S.v. Engl. hit, from Late Old English hyttan, apparently from Old Norse hitta 'to hit upon, light upon, meet with'.
S.v. Engl. leg, a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic leggr 'leg').
S.v. Engl. mountain, a borrowing from French montain, montaigne.
S.v. Engl. river, a loan from Anglo-Norman rivere (etc.), from Anglo-Norman and Old French, Middle French riviere (cf. Modern French rivière).
S.v. Engl. rotten, apparently a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic rotinn).
S.v. Engl. round (adj.), a borrowing from Anglo-Norman rund, runt.
S.v. Engl. sky, a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic ský 'cloud').
S.v. Engl. take, a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic taka 'to grasp, seize, catch, receive, accept, touch, reach').
S.v. Engl. they, a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic þeir m.nom.).
S.v. Engl. turn, from Old English tyrnan, turnian, both borrowings from Latin tornāre 'to turn in a lathe, round off'.

S.v. Engl. vomit, a borrowing from Lat. vomit- (participial stem of vomĕre 'to vomit'). Attested since Middle English (ME–15 vomyte, 15–16 vomite, 15 vomyt, vomitte, womit, 15– vomit; 15 vomete, womet).
S.v. Engl. wing, from Middle English (first in plural forms wenge, wengen, wenges), ultimately borrowed from Old Norse vængir.
S.v. Engl. bark, a borrowing from Scandinavian bark- (cf. Old Norse börkr, Swedish, Danish bark from Germanic *barku-z).
S.v. Engl. carry, a borrowing from Old Northern French carier.
S.v. Engl. count, from Middle English counte-n , a borrowing from Old French cunter, conter which in turn is ultimately from Lat. com-putāre.
S.v. Engl. cry (v.), a borrowing from French crier, in turn ultimately from Lat. quirītāre 'to raise a plaintive cry, to wail, scream, shriek out, cry aloud, bewail, lament'.
S.v. 1. *k̑ei̯- 'liegen' (IEW 539-40).
S.v. Ved. √drā-² 'schlafen, schlummern', from PIE *dreH-, probably an extended root (*dr-eH-) related to *dr-em- (Lat. dormīre, ORuss. drěmati) and *dr-dʰ- (Gk. δαρθάνω).

S.v. Lith. gulė́ti 'lie, be ill' (Latv. gulêt 'sleep, lie, be ill'), related to Lith. gul̃ti 'lie down, fall ill, hang down', Latv. gul̃t 'go to bed', for which an East Baltic root *gul- may be reconstructed. A full-grade *gval- is attested via Lith. gvaldýti 'cram, pack' < *'lay close together', so we may be dealing with a PIE root *gu̯el-, but there are no convincing cognates to support such a reconstruction.
S.v. Lith. miegóti 'sleep' (OPr. miecte 'sleep')
S.v. *pettīttus 'klein' > Fr. petit, from a Gallo-Romance word which may be reconstructed as *pettīttus.

S.v. AGk. κύπτω 'to bend forward, stoop to, run with the head down'. Not to be separated from AGk. κυφός 'bent forwards, hunchbacked'. Etymology outside of Greek uncertain. AGk. κυφός has been compared to Skt. kubhrá-, but a Munda origin has also been claimed for the Sanskrit lexeme. Other IE words that might be compared only show a root final *-p- (cf. Lith. kuprà 'hump', OHG hovar 'id.', etc. The variation κυφ-/κυπ- probably points to a substratum borrowing.
Cf. s.v. Ved. kaśu- (Name of a Cedi-Prince), probably identical with OAv. kasu-, YAv. kasu- 'klein, gering'.
S.v. Ved. árbha- 'klein' (in opposition to mah- 'groß'), 'jung'; arbhaká- 'klein, schwach, jung, im Kindesalter befindlich'. Not to be separated from PIE *(h₂?)órbʰo-, cf. Gk. ὀρφανός, Lat. orbus.
S.v. Skt. árbhaḥ 'klein, jung, schwach', 'little, young', cf. Gk. ὀρφανός 'verwaist', Arm. orb 'Waise', Lat. orbus 'beraubt', OIr. orpe, Goth. arbi 'Erbe', OCS rabъ 'Knecht', Cz. robě 'kleines Kind'.
Cf. s.v. Gk. ὀρφανός 'orphaned, orphan', from PIE *h₃orbʰ-o- 'orphaned, bereft'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. orbus 'deprived of, childless, orphaned' < PIE *h₃orbʰ-o-.

If the Vedic lexemes are related to Lat. orbus, Gk. ὀρφανός, then they would have underwent a secondary semantic shift (cf. {ref EWAia}, {ref Weiss 2006}:256n30). An up-to-date reconstruction of the lexeme would be *h₃orbʰ-o- (cf. {ref Weiss 2006}, {ref de Vaan 2008} s.v. orbus, {ref Beekes 2010} s.v. ὀρφανός).
"The meaning of Vedic árbha-, árbhaga-, arbhaká- 'small, young', if they are related [to Lat. orbis, orbus, etc.], is a later semantic development from the sense 'orphan'."

S.v. Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small'. "Probably an o-grade adjective related to Nw. smula w.v. 'to grind' < *smulēn- (< *smlH-eh₁-?). In spite of ON smali m. 'cattle', the adjective cannot be related to Gr. μῆλον n. 'small cattle, sheep and goats' and OIr. míl n. 'small animal' < *meh₁l-o-, which rather belong to OLFra. māla, Du. maal c. 'young cow' < *mēlo-."
S.v. Proto-Germanic *smalaz, probably to be related to Gk. μῆλον 'small cattle', Lat. malus 'bad', Slav. *malъ 'small' ({ref Solmsen 1904}:17).
Cf. s.v. Goth. S106. smals, to be connected with PIE *(s)mēlo- 'small animal' (cf. Gk. μῆλον, OIr. míl, Arm. mal).

The connection with the Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small' is unclear. An etymological connection is possible, but not fully agreed whether or not the Germanic lexemes are also cognate with Gk. μῆλον, etc. < *meh₁lo- (cf. discussion in /cognate/8298/). In any case, if this etymology is correct, it could well be a case of parallel semantic shift from *'small animal' > 'small'.
S.v. Goth. L33 leitils 'μικρός', 'little'. No etymology.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *klainja- 'fine'. An adjective to be derived from the same root found in ON, Far. klína 'to smear' < *klīnjan- and OHG klenan- 'id.' following {ref Heidermanns 1993}:332-323.
S.v. 3712 Skt. kṣudrá 'minute' AV.

S.v. Ved. kṣudrá- 'klein, winzig', probably to be related to Ved. √kṣod- in its meaning 'erschüttern, klein stampfen, stieben' (cf. YAv. xšudra- 'flüssig, (Samen-)Flüssigkeit'), IIr. cf. YAv. xšudra- 'flüssig'.
S.v. 12732 Skt. ślakṣṇá 'slippery, smooth, soft, tender, gentle' AV., 'thin, small'.
S.v. Sp. pequeño, probably of expressive origin, similar to other Romance expressions for smallness like It. pìccolo, piccìno, Fr. petit, Sard. pithinnu, etc.
S.v. 5071 *chōṭṭa 'small'.
S.v. 5071 *chōṭṭa 'small'.
S.v. 11072 *lukka- 'defective'
S.v. Ved. ślakṣná- 'schlüpfrig, glatt, weich', from PIE *slegh₂snó- (cf. Gk. λαγαρός 'schlaff, schmächtig' λαγαίω 'freilassen', ON slakr 'schlaff', Lat. laxus 'schlaff, weich', etc.).

S.v. Ved. ślakṣná- 'schlüpfrig, glatt, weich' (IIr. slakšna-, cf. parāčī lhanȫ 'schlüpfrig, NPers. lašn 'glatt', Oss. læǧz/liǧz), from PIE *slegh₂snó- (cf. Gk. λαγαρός 'schlaff, schmächtig' λαγαίω 'freilassen', ON slakr 'schlaff', Lat. laxus 'schlaff, weich', etc.).
S.v. Lith. úosti [úo, uõ] 'smell, sniff' (Latv. uôst 'smell'), from PIE *h₃ed- (cf. Gk. ὄζω 'smell').
S.v. Arm. hot 'smell, odour', from which also verbs hotim 'to smell' and redupl. hotot- 'id.'. Since long connected with Gk. ὀδμή 'smell', Lat. odor, odōris 'smell, scent, odour, perfume', etc.
S.v. Ved. √ghrā- 'riechen', considering the connection to Gk. ὀσφραίνομαι doubtful ("Ohne sicheren Anschluß").
S.v. Proto-Slavic *čùti 'sense, feel, notice' (ESSJa IV 134-136).

S.v. *(s)keu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen' (IEW 587-8). OCS čujǫ (čuti) 'fühlen, merken', either from root present *(s)keu̯h₁-/*(s)kuh₁- or a secondarily re-formed from the aorist (OCS ču 'fühlte, merkte').
S.v. 12579 *śr̥ṅkhati, śíṅghati 'smells' Dhātup. [upaśiṅghati 'kisses' Bhaṭṭ., upaśiṅghana- n. 'a thing to be smelled at' Suśr. —√*śr̥ṅkh]
S.v. *sent- 'gehen' → 'wahrnehmen'(?) (IEW 908).
S.v. ?*i̯eu̯t- 'wahrnehmen, erwachen' [IEW 346].

For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form, we tentatively follow {ref Cheung 2007}:15-16 in distinguishing two separate Proto-Iranian roots, although the semantic shift *'to perceive, notice' > 'smell' is not entirely inconceivable and the lexemes could very well belong to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- ({ref LIV²} 83-84, {ref IEW} 150-2).

S.v. Proto-Iranian *bau̯d-² 'to smell'. "In view of the well-defined, semantic distribution of 'to feel, sense'/'to smell' it seems necessary to assume two separate Ir. roots. But on the other hand, *bau̯d-² may be ultimately an ancient specialisation of the root *bau̯d-¹, cf. Engl. 'sense'." If also from *bau̯d-¹ 'to feel, sense', then from PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- 'to become attentive, be awake, perceive' (LIV² 83-84).
S.v. AB wär-/wärsk- 'riechen', 'smell', said to be derived from PIE *u̯er- 'beobachten, wahrnehmen' (LIV² 685f.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *dauna- 'smell', a *-no- stem derived to the root *dʰuh₂- 'to blow, smoke, be misty'.
Cf. s.v. *dʰu̯eh₂- 'Rauch machen' (IEW 262-3).
S.v. Engl. smell, from early Middle English smellen and smüllen, no doubt of Old English origin but not recorded. No cognates outside of English.

S.v. lukta 'riechen, duften', derived from lukt 'geruch', which is borrowed from Low German lucht [= NHG Luft]. The inherited lexeme is lopt. [cf. 'smell' in Övdalian /cognate/8301/, 'sky' in /cognate/2903/].
S.v. Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'roof, air', a *-tu- stem related to *lauba- 'leaf, foliage'. No clear IE etymology.
Cf. s.v. Goth. L58. *luftus 'ἀήρ', 'air'. Etymology unclear.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *luftuz, which O. prefers to relates to Skt. lumpati 'to break, to injure'. Other etymologies possible (cf. entry for references).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rauki- 'smoke', an i-stem noun derived to PGmc. *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke', a verb with no generally accepted etymology.

S.v. Ved. dhūmá- 'Rauch' (Ir., cf. Khot. dumä 'Rauch', etc.), from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- (cf. Lat. fūmus, Lith. dū́mai, Latv. dũmi, OCS dymъ 'Rauch', Gk. θυμός 'vitale und physische Energie, seelische geistige Instanz, Geist, Sinn, Mut, Zorn).
S.v. Lith. dū́mai 'smoke' (Latv. dũmi 'smoke'), from PIE *dʰuH-mó- (cf. OCS dymъ, Skt. dhūmá- 'smoke, vapour', Gk. θυμός 'heart, passion, courage', Lat. fūmus 'smoke, vapour').
S.v. Goth. Ϸ67. ϸwmiama 'θυμίαμα', 'incense, incense offering', a loanword from Greek from religious terminology.
S.v. Lat. fūmus 'smoke, fumes', from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- 'smoke, fume' (cf. Skt. dhūmá- 'smoke, fume', Gk. θυμός 'spirit', OPr. dumis 'smoke', Lith. dū́mai 'smoke', OCS dymъ 'smoke', OHG toum 'steam').

S.v. Proto-Celtic *dwīyot- 'smoke' [Noun], probably from PIE *duh₂-i̯o-, which developed to *dʰu̯īi̯o- (the immediate proto-form of Lat. suf-fio, to which a dental suffix was added in Celtic > Proto-Celtic *dwīyot-.
Cf. for discussion regarding the stem formation of Old Irish dé and related Celtic forms.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *muk-V- 'smoke' [Noun]. The Brittonic forms must be from *muk- with a short vowel. A connection with PIE *(s)meu̯g̑ʰ- 'smoke' (IEW 971) appears probable, but there are many irregularities in the reflexes of this root. Gk. σμῡ́χω 'burn in smouldering fire' presupposes PIE *smuHg̑ʰ-, while OE smeocan 'to smoke' appears to be from *smeu̯g̑-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *gladъkъ 'smooth, plain' (ESSJa VI 115-116), derived from PIE *gʰleh₂dʰ- (cf. Lith. glodùs, Lat. glaber 'smooth, hairless', OHG glat 'shining').
S.v. Lith. glodùs 'smooth' (Latv. gluõšs 'smooth'), derived from PIE *gʰleh₂dʰ- (cf. OCS gladъkъ 'smooth', Lat. glaber 'smooth, hairless', OHG glat 'shining').
S.v. Alb. keq 'schlecht, schlimm, böse, elend'. "Bildung und Etymologie umstritten." Considers the question of a loan from Greek open.
S.v. Alb. keq 'bad, evil', which O. considers to be from PAlb. kakja, related to Gk. κακός (so {ref Meyer 1891}:184-185). Cf. entry for references to many other alternatively proposed etymologies.

S.v. idālu- 'bad, evil', connecting the forms to the complex of forms represented by Arm. erkn 'labour pains, toil', Gk. ὀδύναι 'pain, pangs, distress', OIr. idain '(birth)pangs', as a petrified verbal noun from the root *ed- 'eat', lit. 'eating (away), consumption, ill, pain' (cf. Schindler, KZ [1975] 89:53-65).
S.v. Goth. T37. tuggō 'γλῶσσα', 'tongue', from PIE *dʰn̥g̑ʰu-, *dʰn̥g̑ʰu̯ā with varied reflexes due to taboo deformation.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *tengʷāt- 'tongue', generally connected with PIE *dng̑ʰuh₂- with initial *t instead of initial *d best explained as the result of assimilation *d … t > t … t. Elsewhere in IE cf. Skt. jihvā́, Lat. lingua, OHG zunga, OPr. insuwis, ToB kantwo.
S.v. Arm. awj 'snake'. Since long connected with Lat. anguis 'snake', assuming a development *angʷʰ-i- (*h₂engʷʰ-i-) > PArm. *anʷgi- > *awg̑ʰi- > awj-i-.
Cf. for extensive discussion of the words for 'snake', 'eel', etc. in Indo-European.

S.v. Ved. áhi- 'Schlange, Natter' (YAv. aži- 'Schlange, Drache', MPers. až 'Drache). Several connections possible to vocabulary outside of Indo-Iranian. The exact connections are exacerbated through possible taboo distortions.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ǫžь 'snake', from PIE *h₂engʷʰ-i- (cf. Lith. angìs 'snake', Latv. uôdze 'adder', Lat. anguis 'snake', OHG unc 'snake', MIr. escung 'eel').
S.v. Lith. angìs 'snake' (Latv. uôdze 'adder'), from PIE *h₂engʷʰ-i- (cf. Lat. anguis 'snake', MIr. escung 'eel', OHG unc 'snake', Arm. awj 'snake').

S.v. Lat. anguis 'snake', from PIE *h₂(e)ngʷʰ-i- 'snake' (cf. MIr. escung 'eel' (lit. water-snake), OPr. angis, Lith. angìs < *h₂e/ongʷʰ-, Ru. už, Po. wąż, OHG unc < *h₂ngʷʰ-). Several IE languages have a similar preform *h₂e/ogʷʰ- without an internal nasal (Gk. ἔχις 'snake', Arm. iž, Gk. ὄφις 'snake', Skt. áhi-, Av. aži- 'snake, dragon'. Perhaps *n was introduced into this stem on analogy to verbs for 'to twist, wind'.

S.v. Hitt. illuyanka-, elliyanku- 'snake, serpent'. "Autochthonous term, used especially of the serpent or dragon fought by the storm-god in the etiological myths of the Hattic-origin EZEN purulliyas".

S.v. Proto-Germanic *nadra- 'adder, snake', from PIE *nh̥₁tr-ó- (cf. Lat. natrix 'water snake', OIr. nathir 'viper' < *nh̥₁-tr-ik-). K. considers the word "[a] West European word of uncertain origin."
S.v. ON naðr 'Schlange', generally connected with Lat. natrix 'Wasserschlange', OIr. nathir 'Schlange'.
S.v. Goth. N1 *nadrs 'ἔχιδνα', 'snake, viper' (only attested in gen.pl.). Either to PIE *(s)nē- 'twist, wind', or less likely *snā- 'swim'.
S.v. 5110 Skt. jantú m. 'offspring, creature, man' RV., 'any animal of lowest order, insect, worm'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. jantú- 'Geschöpf, Wesen, Mensch, Stamm, Geschlecht, Leute' (YAv. zaṇtu- 'Landkreis, Gau', from PIE *g̑enh₁-tú- (cf. Ved. √jan- < *g̑enh₁-).
S.v. *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, *dʰg̑ʰ-ém-, *dʰg̑ʰ-m-´-, *g̑ʰ-m̥-m-´-, f. 'Erde' (IEW 414ff.)
S.v. Proto-Slavic *zmьja 'snake' and *zmьjь 'snake, dragon', a derivative of zero-grade of the word for earth *dʰg̑ʰ-m-.
S.v. ON slangi 'Schlange', a loan from Low German slange.

S.v. Lat. colubra 'snake, serpent'. Walde-Hofmann and IEW propose a preform *(s)kelo-dʰro- 'winding itself', while Ernout-Meillet consider a possible loanword from Gk. χέλυδρος. The former etymology is unlikely because the suffix *-dʰro- normally makes instrument nouns, whereas the latter is also unlikely because Gk. χέλυδρος is attested too recently and the meaning 'serpent' is probably secondary (χέλυς means '(kind of) tortoise'). A connection with colus 'distaff' could be possible, since a distaff is used to wind thread or fibre around it, thus *kolos-ro- might mean 'distaff-like' and a snake which winds about its own axis could be called a 'distaff-like animal'. This solution is not morphologically straightforward, however, since colus probably continues a u-stem, and one would have to assume an unattested s-stem *kʷelh₁-os- existed alongside it, from which the putative PIt. *kolos-ro- could be derived.

S.v. Lith. gyvatà 'life', a derivative in *-ot- based on the BSl. root *gʔiw- [< PIE *gʷi̯eh₃-, cf. Lith. gývas 'alive' < *gʷh₃i-u̯o-; Lat. vīvus 'alive', Skt. jīvá- 'alive']. The meaning of Lith. gyvãtė 'snake, adder' must have developed from 'living creature'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *gadъ (ESSJa VI 81-82), from PIE *gʷoh₁dʰ-o- (cf. Lith. gė́da 'shame, disgrace', OPr. gīdan 'id.', Du. kwaad 'angry, evil').

Cf. s.v. Lat. natrix, -icis 'water-snake; penis', from PIE *snh₁-tr-ih₂ 'who spins around; snake' (cf. OIr. nathir, W neidr, MBret. azr, OIc. naðr < OE nǣddre, OS nādra, OHG nātara 'adder'); derived from the root of sneō 'I spin'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *snakan- 'to crouch (?)', which may reflect a Pre-Germanic root *(s)negʰ- ({ref Kroonen 2011}:333). [No etymology outside of Germanic.]
S.v. ON snaka 'schnüffeln, wittern' and snákr 'Schlange'. Cf. OE snāca, Low German snāke  'Ringelnatter, Schlange', OHG snahhan 'kriechen, schleichen'.
S.v. Engl. snake, from Old English snaca = Middle Low German snake (Low German snake, snaak), cf. Old Norse snákr (poet.), Swedish snok, Danish snog, which may be from Low German.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *gadъ (OCS gadъ 'ἑρπετόν, animal, reptile, serpens, гад, пресмыкающееся, змея'), from PIE *gʷōdʰ-, cf. OE cwēd 'дурной, плохой' OHG quāt, Germ. Kot 'гряазь', Du. kwaad 'злой, отвратительный', Lith. gė́da 'стыд, срам', OPr. gīdan.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *slangan- 'snake', an agentive formation to the PIE root *slenk- 'to creep' (cf. PGmc. *slingan-, *slinkan-, *slunkōn-).
Cf. s.v. *slenkʷ- 'gleiten' (IEW 961), from which *slénkʷ-e- > ON(+) slyngva 'schwingen, schleudern', OHG slingan 'verfallen' (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:432-433).
Cf. s.v. PGmc. *slengw-a- 'gleiten', from which PGmc. *slangw-ōn 'Schlange' (OHG slango).

Cf. s.v. AGk. κωφός 'blunt, dumb, mute', from which κωφίας 'a kind of snake', not to be separated from κηφήν 'drone'. The vocalism could be accounted for by reconstructing *k/gʰ(e/o)h₂bʰ-, but there is no IE comparandum. If κηφήν is borrowed from a substratum language, then the same probably holds for this word.
S.v. Skt. nāgaḥ 'Schlange, Schlangendämon; Elefant', 'snake, serpent-demon; elephant'. Not securely explained.
S.v. 7039 Skt. nāgá-¹ m. 'snake' (> Si. nay, nā, nayā 'snake').
S.v. Khot. śśaysda- 'snake', according to Bailey from IE *k̑ei- 'beside' IEW 538-9 *kei- 'move', with increments *k̑i-es-d-.

The derivation proposed by Bailey (1979:395) is unclear. If his root etymology is correct, the modern reconstruction of the proposed IE root is *k̑ei̯h₂- 'sich in Bewegung setzen' (LIV² 346), but the morphological 'increments' proposed to satisfy the etymology are uncertain.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *glada- 'bright, happy'. According to K., while this form superficially appears to continue * gʰlodʰ-ó- or *gʰladʰ-o- (Lat. glaber 'bald'), it actually represents an 'intra-Germanic quasi-PIE zero-grade derivation *gʰlh̥₁-tó- to *glōan- < *gʰlóh₁-e-'.

Against Kroonen (2013:179) who derives from PGmc. glōan- 'to glow', the cognacy in this class follows the usual proposed connection of PGmc. *glada- to Lat. glaber 'smooth, hairless', Lith. glodùs 'tender', Slav. *gladъkъ 'smooth'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ʒlađaz, related to Lat. glaber 'smooth', Lith. glodùs 'tender', Slav. *gladъkъ 'smooth'.
S.v. 4782 Skt. cikkáṇa- 'slippery, unctuous'. MBh.
S.v. Skt. cikkáṇaḥ 'glatt, schlüpfrig' / 'smooth, slippery'. Perhaps a loan from Dravidian. Cf. Tamil cikku hängen bleiben, verwickelt werden, hängen klebben'.
S.v. Engl. smooth, from Old English smóð, found only once (the usual form being sméðe smeeth adj.), and not clearly represented in any of the cognate languages.

S.v. Ved. mr̥dú- 'zart, schwach, mild, weich', from PIE *(h₂)ml̥d-ú- (cf. Gk. βλαδύς 'schwach', ἀμαλδύνω 'zerstöre, schwäche', Lat. mollis 'weich, sanft' (< *moldu-i-), to Ved. √mrad- 'sanft machen, weich machen'.
S.v. Lith. lýgus 'flat, even, equal' (Latv. lĩdzs 'flat, even, equal', OPr. polĩgu 'similarly'), from PIE *lig-u- (cf. Goth. galeiks 'equal', OIc. glíkr, líkr, OE gelīc 'id.').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *rēdi- 'simple, easy', to be connected with PIE *(H)rei̯dʰ- 'ride, drive' (cf. OHG bi-reiti 'ready').
Cf. s.v. *rei̯dʰ- 'sich schwankend bewegen' (IEW 861).

S.v. AGk. ἴσος 'equal' in number, strength, size, status, etc. (dial. Arc., Cret. Boeot. attests ϝίσϝος). Formally, earlier *u̯itˢu̯o- would work, but the proposed connection to a zero-grade *ϝιδσ- from εἶδος 'shape' is hypothetical. Other proposed etymologies are unconvincing.
Cf. s.v. SMG ίσιος, from Medieval Greek ἴσιος, with stem modification from Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal'.
S.v. ἴσος 'égal, en nombre égal, également partagé, égal en droit'. The original structure of the word ϝίσϝος is certain, but the etymology is not established.

S.v. Lat. niteō 'to be radiant, shine', from which nitidus 'bright, elegant' is a derived adjective. The Latin words connected to niteō are most easily understood as a formation based on a past passive participle *nitos 'made bright, shining', but there is no known IE verbal root that fits the form and meaning.

S.v. No. 49 kʻałcʻr 'sweet'; typically explained as a blend of two adjectives *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' and *dluku- 'sweet' (Ačaṙyan HAB IV 546). De Lamberterie (1990:502), considers alternatively *saldu- as part of the source. Not in Martirosyan 2010.
Suggested to be a blend of the roots found in Greek σφάζω 'kill' and κτείνω 'kill' (Klingenschmitt 1982:227), or the root of Greek σφάζω 'kill' and the PIE root *gʷʰen- (Watkins 1995:521).
Suggested to be a blending of the roots *spek̑- 'see' and *derk̑- 'see' (Meillet 1936:135, Hamp 1984, Klingenschmitt 1982:228). Not in Martirosyan 2010.
Arm. paranocʻ 'neck', possibly explained by {ref Pisani 1934}:55 as a blend of an Iranian loanword and the second element connected with the Germanic neck words. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Argues for a possible loanword from Old Turkic yavlak 'bad, evil' via Khotanese.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. idālu-, idālau̯- 'bad, evil, evilness'. K. mentions a possible connection to TochB yolo, but does not explicitly reject it.

Cf. s.v. TochB śiñcatstse* 'snowy', a derivative of the unattested noun *śiñce 'snow'. Possibly from PIE *snigʷʰ-en- (cf. Pkt. siṇeha- 'snow', Av. snēža- 'to snow', Gk. νίφα (acc.) 'snow', νείφει 'it snows', Lat. nix, nivis 'snow', OIr. snigid 'it drips, rains', Goth. snaiws 'snow', OEng. snāw [> Engl. snow], OHG snīwan 'to snow', Lith. sniẽgas 'snow', OCS sněgъ 'snow'). N.sg. *snigʷʰēn would give PToch *ṣñäćśe > *ṣn̥će. Less likely, Van Windekens proposes from *k̑u̯indeto-, comparing Skt. śvind- 'be white'.
S.v. SNOW, under *snigʷʰ-s, *snoi̯gʷʰ-os 'snow', to which TochB śiñcatstse 'snowy' from implied *śiñce 'snow' < *snigʷʰi- or *snigʷʰen-).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *sněgъ 'snow', from PIE *snoi̯gʷʰ-o- (cf. Lith. sniẽgas, Latv. snìegs, OPr. snaygis, Goth. snaiws).
S.v. Lith. sniẽgas 'snow' (Latv. snìegs 'snow', OPr. snaygis 'snow'), from PIE *snoi̯gʷʰ-o- (cf. OCS sněgъ 'snow', Goth. snaiws 'snow').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *snaiwa- 'snow', from PIE *snoigʷʰ-o- (cf. OCS sněgъ, Lith. sniẽgas, Latv. snìegs 'snow' < *snoigʷʰ-o-; Lat. nix, nivis 'snow' < *snigʷʰ-).
S.v. ningit, -ere 'it snows', to which nix, nivis 'snow' is a derivative. The noun nix, nivi- is from PIE *sn(e)igʷʰ- 'snow'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *snigʷ-(y)o- 'snow' (vb.), from PIE *snei̯gʷʰ- 'snow'. OIr. snechtae 'snow' (n.), etc. is a derived noun.
Cf. s.v. *snei̯gʷʰ- 'kleben bleiben' (IEW 974).

S.v. Khot. baura 'snow', from PIr. vafrā- to base *vap- 'throw up, heap up' (cf. Av. vafra-, Zor.P. vafr, NPers. barf, barfēn, Sogd. (Bud.) wβrh, M.Pers.T. wpr wdzyd 'snow melts', Pašto wāwra, Orm. yōṣ̌r, yōṣ̌, Parāčī γarp. Yidγa warfo, Waxī warf), to IEW 1149 *u̯ep- (Ved. vápati 'scatters (seed)', vápra- 'earth mound').

Cf. s.v. Ved. vaprā- 'Feuerstätte', vafra- 'Erdaufwurf, Wall', derived from Ved. √vap-¹ 'streuen, ausstreuen' (further connections unclear). Ved. vapra- is formally comparable to Ir. *u̯afrā̆- 'Schnee' (cf. YAv. vafra-, Khot. borā-, MPers. wafr, NP barf).
S.v. Skt. vápraḥ 'Aufwurf von Erde, Erdwall / mound, earth raised as a wall'. Iranian forms in the meaning 'snow' from *vap-ra- are comparable. [Cf. entry in KEWA for further references].
S.v. ON kaf (1) 'untertauschen, erstickung, schneetreiben', from which in Modern Icelandic kafi 'dicker rauch', kafaldi 'dichter schneefall', Faroese kavi 'schnee', Shetl. kāvi 'schneesturm'.
Cf. s.v. 3175 Skt. kiri- 'scattering, heap'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √karⁱ-² 'ausschütten, ausgießen, ausstreuen'.

Cf. s.v. 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' [IEW 933-5], whence Ved. √karⁱ-² (e.g. kiráti, -te 'streut aus, schüttet aus' < *kérH-/*kr̥H-). Cf. n1 against the reconstruction of a root *skʷal- ~ *skʷalH- assumed by Mayrhofer EWAia ('unberechtigt').

S.v. Alb. borë 'snow'. Meyer (1891:42) related 'snow' to Rum. boură 'drizzle, mist', NGk. μπόρα 'drizzle', OCS burja 'storm' and derived all from Lat. boreus 'northwind'. Jokl (1916:93) noted the use of bie 'fall' for precipitation and proposed a productive lengthened grade form *ds-bhērā, comparing the semantics of Rum. zapadă 'snow' (borrowed from Slav. zapasti 'fall down') for the semantics.

Within Albanian borë 'snow' is generally linked to bie 'fall' following {ref Jokl 1916}:93, cf. {ref Huld 1984}:45-46, {ref Demiraj 1997}:106-107, {ref Orel 1998}:32. For etymology of Alb. bie < PIE *bʰerH-, cf. {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:966 and further references in /cognate/388/.

S.v. Ved. √sthā- 'stehen, dastehen, still stehen, verweilen' (OAv., YAv. xšta-, YAv. hišta- 'stehen'), from PIE *steh₂- (cf. Gk. ἵστημι, Lat. sistere, status 'stellen', OHG stān 'stehen', Lith. stóti 'sich hinstellen', Latv. stât 'stellen', OCS stati 'sich stellen, treten', Luw. ta- 'stehen, zum Stehen kommen').
Cf. s.v. tii̯e/a- 'to step, to go stand, to place oneself, to set in' (cf. CLuw. tā- 'to come to stand', HLuw. ta- 'to come to stand', tanu- 'to set up, erect, establish', from PIE *(s)th₂-i̯e/o-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *stati 'stand, become' from PIE *steh₂- and Proto-Slavic *stojati 'stand' from PIE *stoh₂- (cf. Skt. tiṣthati, Gk. ἵστημι, Lat. stāre).
S.v. Lith. stovė́ti 'stand' (Latv. stãvẽt), from PIE *sth₂-ẽu- (cf. OE stowian 'keep from').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *standan- 'to stand', and *stēn- 'to stand', two stems in suppletion with one another, but both ultimately derivatives of PIE *steh₂- 'stand'. The vocalism of *stēn- can be accounted for in different ways (cf. entry s.v. *stēn- for further discussion), but the best solution for the root vocalism is probably on analogy to *gēn- 'go' (cf. Seebold 1970:464-465).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *stǣ- 'stehen'. The vocalism ē against ā in other languages is unexplained. One generally assumes an original *stō- modified on analogy to *gǣ- 'gehen', although other explanations are possible.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *si-sta- 'put, stand', from PIE *steh₂- (cf. Lat. stō, stāre, Gk. ἵστημι, Lith. stóti, OCS stojati, OHG stān).
S.v. Lat. stō, stāre 'to stand; to halt', from PIE *sth₂-eh₁-i̯e/o- 'to stand'.
S.v. Lat. pēs, pedis 'foot', from PIE nom.sg. pōd-s, acc. po/ed-m, loc.sg. ped-i.
Cf. s.v. 3784 khaḍaka '*erect', m. 'bolt, post' KātyŚr. 2. *khaḍati 'stands'. 3. *khāḍayati 'makes stand'.
Cf. s.v. khaḍaka 'Pflock'. Etymology unclear.

S.v. ka- 'to stay, stand, halt; to stop, rest; to wait, to appear; to dwell'. The etymology is handled s.v. ek- (suppl. aor. to gam 'to come'). It is widely assumed that Arm. ka- reflects *gʷeh₂- with an original meaning 'to step, put the foot, arrive, establish oneself' (cf. Skt. gā- 'to put the foot down (while going), step, stride', Gk. ἔβην 'to get ready to go', etc.).
S.v. *gʷeh₂- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten' (IEW 463-4).
Listed in LIV² under *h₁er- 'wohin gelangen, geraten' (IEW 326-329) now probably to be separated and listed under *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-329).
From Old French de bot 'tout de suite', the lexical element bot is a loan from Germanic *bōtan- 'stossen, schlagen'.
[Ossetic verbs not discussed in Cheung (2007).]

S.v. Ved. ūrdhvá- 'aufrecht, erhoben, nach oben gerichtet' (cf. YAv. ərəδβa-, ərəduua- 'erhoben, in die Höhe gerichtet', likely to be cognate with Gk. ὀρθός 'aufgerichtet', where parallel phraseology can be found in poetic language (Ved. ūrdhvá- stā : YAv. ərəδβā̊ hišəṇta : Hom. στῆ δ᾽ ὀρθός), however it is difficult to reconstruct a common root. ("Doch ist es schwierig diesen Zusammenhang durch ein Rekonstrukt zu präzisieren.")
S.v. OPr. lauxnos 'luminary', from PIE *louk-sneh₂- (cf. OCS luna 'moon', Av. raoxšna- 'shining', Lat. lūna 'moon').
Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).

S.v. TochB ścriye 'star', which with TochA śre* reflect PToch *scär-ii̯ē, which seems evidently to be related to Gk. ἀστήρ, Hitt. ḫaštēr-, Skt. ins.pl. str̥bhiḥ, nom.pl. tāraḥ, OIr. ser, Goth. stairno, Lat. stēlla, all 'star'.

S.v. Arm. astł 'star'. Since long compared with Gk. ἀστήρ, -έρος, Skt. nom.pl. tā́raḥ, ins.pl. stŕ̥-bhiḥ, Av. star-, Pers. sitāra, Goth. stairno, Lat. stēlla, etc. from PIE *h₂ster-. The 'prothetic' a- in Greek and Armenian is the regular outcome of PIE *h₂-.

S.v. Ved. stár- 'Stern' (RV ins.pl. stŕ̥bhiḥ, nom.pl. tā́raḥ [RV 8.55.2]; OAv., YAv. star-, etc.), from PIE *h₂stér- (cf. Hitt. ḫa-aš-te-er-za, Gk. ἀστήρ, Arm. astł, Lat. stēlla, Goth. stairno, etc.).
S.v. Goth. S131. *stairno 'ἀστήρ', 'star' (Crimean Gothic *stern 'stella', misprinted as stein), from PIE *(s)tēr- (cf. Skt. stár-, Av. stārəm (acc.sg.), Gk. ἀστήρ, Lat. stella, etc.).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ster(r)a/jōn- 'star', as though from PIE *h₂stér-on- (cf. Hitt. ḫašter- 'star', TochA śre, TochB ścriye, 'id.', Skt. stár-, OAv., YAv. star-, NP sitāra, Oss. st’aly | (æ)st’alu, Gk. ἀστήρ, -έρος, OIr. ser < *h₂ster-; Arm. astł, Lat. stella < *h₂ster-l-eh₂).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *sterā 'star', from PIE *h₂stēr- 'star' (IEW 1028), cf. Hitt. hasterz, Gk. ἀστήρ, Lat. stēlla, Goth. stairno. OIr. ser is a hapax in one of the Leinster eulogies, therefore the PCelt. reconstruction is unknown. Gaul. sirona, if it is from the same etymon, perhaps contains the original lengthened grade of the nom.sg. *h₂stēr >> PCelt. *stīr-ōnā.

S.v. Lith. žvaigždė 'star' (Latv. zvàigzne 'star', OPr. swãigstan (acc.sg.) 'light'), cf. OCS dzvězda, Russ. zvezda, Cz. hvězda, etc. On the basis of Balto-Slavic *g/źwoi⁽ź⁾deʔ, a PIE reconstruction *g̑ʰuoig̑ʰ-dʰeh₁- may be considered, however given the variation of Lith. žvai(g)zdė̃ alongside žvai(g)ždė̃ a reconstruction *g̑ʰuoidʰ-dʰeh₁- is a possible alternative. The reconstruction *g̑ʰu̯oi̯gʷ- found in IEW is based on a comparison with Gk. φοῖβος, which Derksen considers untenable.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *gvězda 'star' (ESSJa VII 181-183). On the basis of Balto-Slavic *g/źwoi⁽ź⁾deʔ, a PIE reconstruction *g̑ʰuoig̑ʰ-dʰeh₁- may be considered, however given the variation of Lith. žvai(g)zdė̃ alongside žvai(g)ždė̃ a reconstruction *g̑ʰuoidʰ-dʰeh₁- is a possible alternative. The reconstruction *g̑ʰu̯oi̯gʷ- found in IEW is based on a comparison with Gk. φοῖβος, which Derksen considers untenable.

The first part of PS *gvězda / *zvězda is derived from PIE *g̑ʰu̯oi̯- 'glow, glare'. The etymology of the second element is disputable. It can be a deformation of *stā- 'stand'. It has been also interpreted as *dhē 'put'. The West Slavic initial *g- is probably secondary.
S.v. Lat. petra, -ae 'rocher, pierre', an old borrowing from Gk. πέτρα perhaps through the language of sailors. The normal Latin word is saxum and petra is avoided by good Latin writers.
S.v. Lat. pĕtra 'Stein, Fels', whence OFr. peddre, Fr. pierre.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *staina- 'stone', from PIE *stoiH-no- (cf. OCS stěna, Russ. stená 'wall' < stoih₂-neh₂-; Gk. στία, στῖον 'small stone, pebble' < *stih₂-io/eh₂-), a no-stem created to the PIE root *steih₂- 'to stiffen' (cf. Skt. styā́yate 'to coagulate').
S.v. ON steinn 'stein, edelstein, steinhaus', cf. Goth. stains, OCS stěna 'Mauer', Gk. στία, στῖον 'steinchen', Skt. styāyate 'gerinnt, wird hart'.
S.v. Goth. S.130 stains 'λίθος', 'stone', 'πέτρα', 'rock', from PIE *stāy- 'thicken', cf. Skt. styā́yate 'coagulate', Gk. στία, στῖον 'pebble', στέαρ 'tallow'.

PS *kamy, *kamene is related to Old Indic aśma 'stone', Lithuanian akmuõ 'stone', Old High German hamar 'hammer' etc. It is derived from PIE *ak̑- 'sharp'. Note that the depalatalization and the metathesis in Slavic is irregular.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kamy 'stone, rock' (ESSJa IX 137-140), from PIE *h₂ek̑-men- (cf. Lith. akmuõ, 'stone', Latv. akmens 'stone', Skt. áśman- 'rock, stone', Gk. ἄκμων 'anvil, meteor, heaven').
S.v. Lith. akmuõ 'stone', from PIE *h₂ek̑-men- (cf. OCS kamy, Skt. áśman- 'stone, rock', Gk. ἄκμων 'anvil, meteor, heaven').
S.v. λίθος 'Stein, Steinblock, Gestein, Edelstein'. "Unerklärt." No convincing etymology has been yet proposed.

S.v. πέτρα 'Fels, Felsgebirge, Klippe, Riff, Felsenhöhle, Grotte', sek. 'Felsblock, Stein', beside πέτρος 'Felsblock, Stein'. "Unerklärt." Previously proposed explanations remain hypothetical at best.
S.v. Old Welsh carrecc 'stone' (MW carrec, C carrag, OB carrec; cf. MIr. carric), from PIE *kar- 'hart' (cf. IEW 532).
Cf. s.v. Gk. λέπας 'bare rock, mountain'. "The similarity between λέπας and Lat. lapis, -idis [m., f.] 'stone' is hardly accidental; a Mediterranean borrowing is most probable."
S.v. λᾶας 'pierre'. The declension and structure of λᾶας is obscure.
S.v. λᾶας 'Stein'. The stem formation of λᾶας has not been resolved. Possible correspondences outside of Greek are few and not entirely unproblematic.

S.v. Lat. saxum 'rock, boulder'. Formally, the only potential cognates are OIc. sax, OHG sahs 'knife', but since the semantic connection between 'boulder' and knife' is not evident saxum has no certain etymology.
S.v. 11348 *varta-³ 'round stone' 2. *vārta -- . [Cf. Kurd. bard ʻ stone ʼ. -- √vr̥t-¹].

Cf. s.v. Skt. vartate 'turns, rolls, revolves', vartulaḥ 'round, circular', derived from the PIE root *u̯ert- (cf. Lat. uertō 'wende, drehe, kehre', OIr. ad-ferta 'aversatur', Goth. wairϸan 'werden', etc.).
Cf. s.v. u̯ert- 'sich umdrehen' (IEW 1156-8).
S.v. 8857 Skt. prastará- m. 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' RV., 'flat surface' Mn., '(v.l. prastāra -- ) plain' Hariv., 'rock, stone' Hit. [√str̥].

S.v. prastará-, cf. s.v. √star-¹ 'ausbreiten, streuen', from PIE *sterh₃-, cf. Gk. ἐστόρεσα 'habe ausgebreitet', στόρνυμι 'breite aus, streue hin', Lat. sternere 'hinbreiten', OIr. sernaid 'breitet aus', etc.
Cf. s.v. *sterh₃- 'hinbreiten, ausbreiten' (IEW 1029-30).

S.v. Ved. r̥jú- 'gerade (vom Weg), richtig, recht, gerecht' (OAv. ərəzu- 'gerade, richtig', to Ved. √raj-² 'sich gerade ausstrecken, sich in gestreckte Bewegung setzen' < PIE *h₃reg̑- (cf. Gk. ὀρέγω 'strecke aus, reiche dar', Lat. regō 'richte gerade, lenke', OIr. rigim 'strecke aus', OHG re(c)chan 'recken', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rehta- 'straight', from PIE *h₃reg̑-to- (cf. Av. rašta- 'straight', Gk. ὀρεκτός 'id.', Lat. rectus 'id.').
S.v. Lat. regō -ere 'direct, guide, govern', past-participle rēctus < *h₃reg̑-to- with lengthened root -ē- by Lachmann's Law.

Cf. s.v. §192 discussing reflexes of PIE *r in Old Irish. OIr. díriug, díriuch 'straight', where the root is comparable to Lat. regere, rectus, Gk. ὀρέγειν, Goth. uf-rakjan 'to stretch out', Skt. r̥jú-, Av. ərəzu- 'straight', etc.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *reg-o- 'extend, stretch, straighten' (vb.), from PIE *h₃reg̑-o- 'extend, stretch, rule' (cf. Skt. r̥ñjánti 'rule', Gk. ὀρέγω 'extend, stretch', Lat. regō 'rule', Goth. rikan 'heap up', TochB räk- 'extend, cover').
S.v. Skt. daṇḍáḥ 'Stock, Stab, Prügel', 'stick, staff, club' (since RV). A disputed, still undecided etymological problem.
S.v. Ved. daṇḍá- 'Stock, Stab'. Etymology unexplained.
S.v. Khot. urmaysde 'sun', from Ir. ahura- and mazdāh (Av. ahurō mazdā̊, OPers. a(h)uramazdā, Zor.Pahl. ’whrmazd, NPers. Hurmizd, Chores. rēmažd).
Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda (cf. Alb. than 'trocknet').
Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).
Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda (cf. Alb. than 'trocknet').
Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).
Cf. s.v. *dei̯-, di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f.).
The basic root is *dei̯-, from which *di̯eu̯- and *di̯eu̯-ot-. Cf. discussion in NIL and notes to *dei̯- 'shine' in 'day' /cognate/375/.
Cf. s.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (LIV 219f., IEW 493ff.).
Cf. s.v. Ved. ravi- 'Sonne, Sonnengott', from PIE *h₂reu̯-i- (cf. Arm. arew 'Sonne', Hitt. haruu̯anai- 'hell werden, dämmern').

Cf. s.v. Ved. √roc- 'leuchten, scheinen, glänzen', under which Ved. rucá- 'hell, licht', roka- 'Licht' is comparable to Ir. forms (OAv., YAv. raočah- 'Licht, Lichtraum, OPers. raučah- 'Tag', Khot. rrus- 'leuchten', Parth. rwčyn 'erhellen, leuchten lassen', MP, NP rōz 'Tag', Oss. rūxs/roxs 'Licht', etc.), and ultimately based on PIE *leu̯k- 'leuchten' (cf. Gk. λευκός 'licht, weiß, hell', Lat. lūx 'Licht', Goth. liuhaϸ 'Licht', Hitt. lukkizzi 'zündet an', TochAB luk- 'leuchten', etc.).

S.v. Ved. sū́rya- 'Sonne, Sonnengott', from a PIE stem *suh₂l-ii̯o- (or *-iHo-) from an original heteroclite *-l/n- stem *suh₂el/n- : *sh₂uu̯el/n-. A related formation *seh₂u̯el-ii̯o- is found in Proto-Greek *hāu̯elii̯o- (cf. Cret. ἀβέλιος, Dor./Aeol./Arc. ἀέλιος, Hom. ἠέλιος, Att. ἥλιος), cf. also Goth. sauil, Lith. sáulė, Lett. saũle 'Sonne').

S.v. Lith. sáulė 'sun' (Latv. saũle 'sun', OPr. saule 'sun'), from PIE *seh₂u-l, *seh₂u-en- (cf. OCS slъnьce 'sun', Skt. svàr- 'sun, sunlight', Skt. sū́rya- 'sun, deity of the sun', Av. huuarə̄ 'sun' (gen.sg. xᵛə̄ṇg), Gk. (Hom.) ἠέλιος 'sun', Lat. sōl 'sun', Goth. sauil 'sun', OE sunne 'sun'). Proto-Balto-Slavic *saʔul ~ *sʔul appears to still exhibit ablaut in the root, which was subsequently generalised in Baltic (full-grade) and Slavic (zero-grade).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *sъlnьce 'sun', from PIE *s(e)h₂-ul- (cf. Lith. sáulė, Skt. svàr- 'sun, sunlight', Skt. sū́rya- 'sun, deity of the sun', Av. huuarə̄ 'sun' (gen.sg. xᵛə̄ṇg), Gk. (Hom.) ἠέλιος 'sun', Lat. sōl 'sun', Goth. sauil 'sun', OE sunne 'sun').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *sōel- ~ *sunnōn- 'sun', from PIE *séh₂u-l/n- (Skt. svàr-, gen. sū́ras 'sun', OAv. huuarə̄ 'sun', gen. xᵛə̄ṇg 'id.', NP xwr 'id.', Oss. xur / xor 'id.', Gk. ἥλιος (Dor. ἀέλιος) 'id.', Lat. sōl, sōlis, 'id.', OIr. súil 'eye', Lith. sáulė 'sun', OCS slъnьce). The original heteroclite -l/n- inflection survived in Germanic and is possibly still intact in Gothic (cf. Goth. nom. sauil, dat. sunnin).

S.v. Lat. sōl, sōlis 'sun', from PIE *seh₂u-l (nom., acc.), *sh₂u-én- (obl.) (cf. W. haul 'sun', OIr. súil 'eye', Skt. svàr 'sun' OAv. huuarə̄ 'sun' (gen.sg. xᵛə̄ṇg), Skt. sū́rya- 'sun, deity of the sun', Gk. ἠέλιος (Hom.), ἀέλιος (Dor., Aeol., Arc.) < PGk. *σᾱϝέλιος < *seh₂-uel-io-, Lith. sáulė, Latv. saũle, OCS slъnьce, Goth. sauil, OIc. sōl).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *sāwol- / *sūli- 'sun', from PIE *seh₂u̯ōl 'sun' (cf. Skt. sū́rya- 'sun', Gk. ἥλιος, Lat. sōl, Goth. sauil, Lith. sáulė). The change of meaning in OIr. súil 'eye' is understandable from the mythological context where the sun is viewed as 'the eye of the sky'.
Cf. for an influential discussion of the unique stem-formation and ablaut of this nominal stem.

S.v. TochB swāre 'sweet', which with TochA swār reflects Proto-Tocharian *swāre from PIE *swehₐdro- with loss of -d- before a resonant and the suffix *-ro- rather than the more usual -u- found in other cognates (cf. Skt. svādú- 'sweet', Gk. ἡδύς 'id.', Lat. svāvis 'id.', etc.).
S.v. Ved. √svad- 'schmackhaft machen, (Med.) schmackhaft werden, schmecken', from which is derived the inherited word svādú-. From PIE *su̯ad- (~ TochA swār, B swāre 'süß' < *su̯ad-ro-).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *swōtu- 'sweet', from PIE *sueh₂d-u- (Skt. svādú- 'sweet, tasting good, pleasant', Gk. ἡδύς 'sweet, tasteful, pleasant, pleasing', Lat. svāvis 'sweet, pleasant', cf. also TochA swār, Toch B swāre 'sweet' < *suh₂d-ro-, OAv. hudəma- 'sweetness' < *suh₂d-mo-).
Fr. sucré 'sweet' < *'sugared', from sucre 'sugar' (Old French çucre) a borrowing from Arabic sukkar via Sicilian zúccaru, Italian zucchero
S.v. Classical Armenian անոյշ anoiš 'wohlreichend, schmackhaft, angenehm, lieblich', a borrowing from Iranian (cf. NPers. nōš 'grati saporis, suavis, dulcis').
S.v. Lith. saldùs (Latv. sal̂ds 'sweet'). The root is an enlargement (with *d) of PIE *sh₂el- 'salt', cf. Goth. salt 'salt' which may have been added on analogy to *sueh₂du- 'sweet'.
S.v. Khot. hvarra-, from base *hvar- with increment -z- (IE g̑, g̑ʰ) in Av. xvarəzišta- 'sweetest', Zor.P. xvarzist, NPers. xvālīdan 'to taste', Arm. LW axorž 'sweet', etc.

Cf. s.v. Ved. mádhu- 'süßer Trank, Süßigkeit, Honig, Soma, Milch', from PIE *médʰu- 'Süßtrank, Honigmischung, Rauschtrank, Honig' (cf. YAv. maδu- 'Beerenwein', maδumaṇt- 'Wein enthaltend', Gk. μέθυ 'Rauschtrank, Wein', OHG mito 'Met', OCS medъ 'Honig', etc.).
S.v. 9793 Skt. madhurá- 'sweet' ĀśvGr̥. [~ madhulá- – mádhu- ]
S.v. сладкий 'süß', a Church Slavic loanword used in place of the inherited Russian lexeme солодкий.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *snaH- 'to wash, swim', from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to wash, swim' (cf. Skt. snā- 'to bathe, to wash', Lat. nāre 'to swim', OIr. snaid, -sná 'swims', TochB nāsk- 'to bathe').
S.v. Oss. (Digor) nakæ 'плавание'; nakæ kænun 'плавать', from Ir. *snāka- to *snā- 'плавать'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *swemm-a- 'schwimmen'. There are no persuasive possibilities for comparison outside of Germanic. The verbal root is only indirectly attested in Gothic via swumfsl 'Teich'.

S.v. Ved √plav- '(im Wasser) schwimmen, (im Luftraum) schweben, gleiten' (cf. YAv. fra-frāuuaiiāhi 'du schwemmest fort'), from PIE *pleu̯- (cf. Gk. πλέω 'schiffe, segle, schwimme', Lat. pluit 'es regnet', OHG flouwen 'spülen, waschen', Lith. pláuti 'spülen, abwaschen', OCS pluti 'fließen, schiffen', etc.).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *plavati 'swim, sail' & *pluti 'swim, sail'. "It seems that Balto-Slavic offers evidence for both *pleh₃u- and *pleu- (cf. Derksen 1996:116-117). LIV (485, 487) distinguishes between *pleh₃- and *pleu-, while entertaining the possibility of a *u̯e-present for the former root. Balto-Slavic *pleh₃u- may be a conflation of these two roots. The existence of an acute root *pl(j)ouʔd- < *pleud-, cf. Lith. pláusti 'wash, bathe' (alongside pláuti), OIc. fljóta 'flow', may have added to the confusion."

S.v. Lith. plaũkti 'swim, float, sail', from PIE *plouk- (cf. OIc. fljúga 'fly', OE flēogan 'fly', OHG fliugan, fliogan 'fly' [*pleuk-]), an enlarged variant of *pleu- 'float' (cf. Lith. pláuti 'wash, bathe').
S.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837).

Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek πλέω 'to travel by sea, sail, navigate', from PIE *pleu- 'sail, flow'. Primary thematic πλέ(ϝ)ω is a PIE formation (cf. Skt. plávate 'to swim, flow', OCS pluti 'to flow, sail', Lat. pluit 'it rains', etc.).
Proposes a Balto-Slavic reconstruction *pleHutó- or *ploHutó- to account for the acute root (cf. Gk. πλώω < *pleh₃-).

S.v. TochB plu- G 'soar, fly up', K 'let fly', which with TochA plu- reflects PToch *pläu- from PIE *pleu- 'flow, float, swim, fly' (cf. Skt. plávate 'swims, flies', Gk. πλέω 'ships, swims', Lat. pluit 'it's raining', Lith. pláuti 'to wash', OCS pluti 'to flow', etc.).
Cf. s.v.  Latv. maût 'submerge, swim', connected with Lith. máuti 'put on, tear, pull, stab, strike, dash', from PIE *mouH- (< *miouH-) cf. Skt. mī́vati 'push, shove', Lat. movēre 'move'.
Cf. s.v. *mi̯eu̯h₁- '(sich) bewegen' (IEW 743).
S.v. 14018 *hallati intr. 'moves, shakes', hallana- n. 'tossing about' lex. [~ *halati. -- See √*hall].
S.v. 5702 tárati 'crosses (e.g. a river), escapes' RV., 'floats, swims' VarBr̥S. and s.v. 5821 tiráte 'crosses over, sails across' RV.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √tar-ⁱ 'durch etwas hindurchkommen, etwas durchbringen, hinübergelangen, überwinden', from PIE *terh₂- (cf. Hitt. tarḫ-/tarḫu- 'überwinden, imstande sein').
Cf. s.v. *terh₂- 'durchkommen, überqueren' (IEW 1074-5).

S.v. Ved. √sav-ⁱ 'anschwellen, stark werden, zunehmen, gedeihen', from PIE *k̑eu̯h₁- 'anschwellen' (cf. Gk. κυέω 'bin schwanger', κῦμα 'Woge, Welle' Lat. cauus 'hohl', W cyw 'Tierjunges', OE hūn 'Junges', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯eh₁- 'anschwellen' (IEW 592-4).
S.v. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell' (Latv. pàmpt 'swell'), cf. derivatives in Lith. pámpa 'swelling, lump', Latv. pam̃pa 'swelling', cognate with Proto-Slavic *pǫpъ, *pǫpъkъ 'bud, navel'.
S.v. Lith. tìnti (II) 'swell, bloat', from PIE *tn- (√*ten-), cf. OE ϸunian 'stretch, swell'.

S.v. φῦσα 'breath, bellows'. The exact root of the base noun φῦσα cannot be determined. Comparisons have been made with Arm. pʻowkʻ 'breath, wind', but φῦσα cannot be derived from *φῡκ-i̯α-. Attempts at connections with other potential IE cognates are dubious.

S.v. φουσκώνω, from Medieval Greek φουσκώνω, derived from φούσκα [fúska] a (West Greek) dialectal borrowing (cf. s.v. φούσκα, = Att. φύσκα), cf. Tsakonian φούκ̔α /cognate/5921/ from Doric φύσκα (i.e. [pʰúska]).

Cf. s.v. φῦσα 'breath, bellows'. The exact root of the base noun φῦσα cannot be determined. Comparisons have been made with Arm. pʻowkʻ 'breath, wind', but φῦσα cannot be derived from *φῡκ-i̯α-. Attempts at connections with other potential IE cognates are dubious.
S.v. 13828 Skt. sphāta- 'swollen, increased' Vop. [Cf. sphātí- f. 'fattening' RV., Pa. phāti- f. 'swelling, increase', Pk. phāi- f. √sphāy]

S.v. Ved. √sphā- 'fett werden, feist werden, zunehmen', from PIE *speh₁- (cf. Hitt. iš-pa-a-i 'ißt sich satt', iš-pa-a-an 'Sättigung', Lat. spēs 'Hoffnung, Erwartung', OE spōwan 'gedeihen', Latv. spẽt 'können, vermögen', OCS spěti 'gedeihen', etc.).
S.v. Lith. brìnkti 'swell, bloat, grow dry', from Balto-Slavic *brinʔk- (cf. Proto-Slavic *bręknǫti 'swell').
S.v. *bʰrenk- 'anschwellen' (IEW 167). [Without Baltic cognates.]

OIr. fo-luathar 'flies', a compound of the preverb fo- (Proto-Goidelic *wo- < PIE *upo) + the verbal stem lu- 'sich bewegen' with original deponent inflection. The Proto-Goidelic verbal root *lu- can be placed with the PIE root *pleu̯- 'rinnen, rennen, fließen'.
S.v. TochAB plu- 'schwimmen, schweben', 'float, fly, soar', to be derived from PIE *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben'.
S.v. PGmc. swell-a- 'schwellen'. There is no secure etymology outside of Germanic.
S.v. Lat. ĭnflāre 'aufblasen', whence Fr. enfler.
S.v. Lat. flō, flāre 'to blow', from PIE *bʰleh₁-/*bl̥h₁- 'to blow'?
Cf. s.v. *bʰleh₁- 'heulen' (IEW 121-2; 154-5).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dǫti 'blow' (ESSJa V 99-100), from PIE *dʰ(o)mH- (cf. Skt. dhámati 'blow').
S.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-8).
S.v. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen', OCS dъmǫ 'blase').

S.v. Proto-Iranian *damH-³ 'to blow, breathe; to swell', from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. Skt. dham-ⁱ 'to blow, play a wind instrument, fan the fire', OCS dъmǫ 'to blow', Lith. dùmti 'to blow (also of wind)'.

S.v. Lat. tumeō 'to swell, be swollen', from PIE *tum-eh₁- 'to be swelling' (cf. MW tyfu, MCo. tevi, Bret. teñviñ 'to grow' < PCl. *tum-ī- < PIE *tum-eh₁-; Skt. túmra- 'strong, thick', Lith. tumė́ti 'to become thick', OIc. ϸumal-fingr 'thumb').
S.v. Russ. толстый 'dick', from Proto-Slavic *tъlstъ, related to Lith. tulžti, tulštù, tulžaũ 'anschwellen, weich werden'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *bręknǫti 'swell' (ESSJa III 23), from PIE *bʰrnk- (cf. OIc. bringa 'chest').

S.v. Engl. chest (1), from Old English cest, apparently an early adoption of Latin cista, < Greek κίστη box, chest. Compare Old Frisian kiste, (Middle Dutch kiste, Dutch kist), Old High German chista (Middle High German and German kiste). Alternatively, some claim for Old English cest a native origin, comparing German kasten 'box'.
Cf. s.v. staukk- 'anschwellen', 'swell' (no etymological discussion).
S.v. Ved. √pay-ⁱ¹ 'schwellen, strotzen, voll sein, reichlich strömen', from PIE *pei̯(H)- (cf. Lith. pýti 'melk werden, Milch bekommen', Gk. πιμελή 'Fett, Schmalz').
S.v. 1. *pei̯H- 'anschwellen' (IEW 793).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *belgan- 'to swell' (ON bolginn ptc. 'swollen), from PIE *bʰélg̑ʰ-e- (cf. OIr. bolgaid 'to swell' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-eh₂-ie-).
Cf. s.v. *belg-a- 'schwellen, zürnen'.
S.v. Skt. 13401 siddha- (2) 'accomplished, skilled'.
S.v. Ved. √sādh- 'zum Ziel gelangen, gelingen' (p.p.p. siddha- 'vollendet, erfolgreich'), probably to PIE *seh₁dʰ- ~ *sh₁dʰ- (cf. Arm. aǰ 'recht, dexter' < *sh₁dʰ-i̯o-).
Cf. s.v. *seHdʰ- 'zum Ziel kommen, gelingen' (IEW 892).
S.v. Alb. hi 'ash', following Meyer (1891:152) to be connected with Lat. cinis, cineris via an s-mobile root variant.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *životъ 'life', a derivative of *gʷh₃i-u- 'live'.
S.v. Russ. живот 1. 'Leben' (ksl.), 'Leib, Bauch', 'Besitz, Gut' (cf. Lith. gyavatà 'Bauerngut, (ewiges) Leben', OPr. giwato 'Leben', Gk. βίοτος, Lat. vita (< *vivitā), Welsh bywyd 'Leben').
Origin unknown.
Cf. s.v. Gk. βέλτερος 'better', usually connected with Skt. bála- 'force', Lat. dē-bilis 'without power', OCS boljii 'bigger', etc. from a PIE root *bel-.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *boļьjь 'bigger, better' (ESSJa II 193-194), a comparative *bol-(i̯)is-io- from a PIE root *bel- 'strong' (cf. Skt. bálīyas- 'better', Gk. βελτίων 'better').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *bel'ьjь, *bol'ьši, *bol'e(je), from a PIE root *bel-.
From Middle English byrd , bryd, in turn from Old English brid. There is no corresponding form in any other Germanic language, and the etymology is unknown.
S.v. Ved. √daṃś- 'beißen' (cf. YAv. tiži.dąstra- 'mit scharfem Gebiß'), from PIE *denk̑- (cf. Gk. δάκνω 'beiße', NHG Zange, etc.).
Cf. s.v. Lith. gráužti 'gnaw'. [No etymology given outside of Balto-Slavic.]
PS *gryzti / *gryzati, related to Lithuanian gráužti and Latvian graûzt. PIE *g(ʰ)reu̯- 'rub, crumb' with a root extention.
S.v. 5806 Skt. tiktá- 'pungent, bitter' [√tij-].
S.v. Oss. mast 'горький', cf. NPers. māst.
Cf. s.v. *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein' (IEW 1016-7).
S.v. Khot. ttīrä 'bitter', from Ir. *tigra- 'sharp, bitter' (from PIE *(s)teig-, cf. Skt. tejate 'be sharp', tiktá- 'sharp, bitter', Gk. στίζω 'prick', etc.).
S.v. Lith. kir̃snas 'black (of a horse)' (OPr. kirsnan 'black'), from PIE *krs-no- (cf. OCS črьnъ, Skt. kr̥ṣṇá- 'black').
As the only cognates are found in satəm languages, the possibility of a root reconstruction *k⁽ʷ⁾ers- with a labiovelar *kʷ cannot be excluded.
S.v. Latv. mȩl̃ns 'black' (cf. OPr. melne 'blue spot, bruise'), from PIE *melh₂-n- (cf. Gk. μέλας 'dark, black').
S.v. Skt. kāla- 'schwarz, blauschwarz', not certainly explained. Perhaps from Dravidian kāḍu 'blackness, black' etc.?
Cf. s.v. Gk. ἔρεβος.
Cf. s.v. Arm. erek.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kry 'blood' (ESSJa XIII 67-70), from PIE *kruh₂-s; *kreuh₂- (cf. Lith. kraũjas, Skt. kravíṣ- 'raw meat', Skt. kravyá- 'raw meat', Gk. κρέας 'meat', Lat. cruor 'raw blood').

S.v. Lith. kraũjas 'blood' (OPr. crauyo, krawia 'blood'), from PIE *kruh₂-s; *kreuh₂- (cf. Skt. kravíṣ- 'raw meat', kravyá- 'raw meat', Gk. κρέας 'meat', Lat. cruor 'raw blood'). The Baltic forms reflect a derivative in *-i̯o- to the root noun reflected in Slavic.

S.v. TochB yasar 'blood', which with TochA ysār reflect Proto-Tocharian *i̯äsār from the PIE 'collective' form *h₁ésh₂ōr (cf. non-collective in Hitt. ēshar, CLuw. āshar-sa, Gk. ἔαρ, Skt. ásr̥k (gen. asnás), Arm. ariun, Old Lat. as(s)er, Latv. asins, all 'blood').

S.v. Arm. ariwn 'blood', to be connected with Gk. ἔαρ 'blood', Skt. ásr̥j-, from PIE *h₁esh₂r. One assumes a development *h₁esh₂r > *ehar > *ar- + suff. -iwn, although the function/origin of the suffix is unclear.
S.v. Latv. asins 'blood', from PIE *h₁esh₂-r-, h₁sh₂-én-s (cf. Hitt. ešḫar / išḫan- 'blood, bloodshed', Skt. ásr̥k 'blood', Gk. ἔαρ 'blood').

S.v. Lat. sanguīs, sanguinis 'blood'. Generally agreed to be cognate with the old IE word for blood *h₁esh₂-r/n-. The element san- can go back to the oblique stem *h₁sh₂-(e)n-, but the origins of the element -guen or guin is less certain.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *dyxati 'breathe' (ESSJa V 199), an intensive verb with secondary length of the root, cf. Proto-Slavic *duxъ 'breath, spirit' (ESSJa V 153-154) from PIE *dʰous- (cf. Goth. dius 'wild animal' from *dʰeus-).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *gorěti 'burn' (ESSJa VII 42-43), from PIE *gʷʰor- (cf. Skt. ghr̥ṇá- 'heat, glow', Gk. θερμός 'warm').

PIE *(e)nek̑. The lexeme is related to Lithuanian nèšti, nešù 'carry', Gothic ganah 'enough', Avestan nasaiti 'obtain', Greek ἤνεγκον, ἐνεγκεῖν 'carry', Tocharian B eṅk 'carry', Hittite ninikzi 'pick up' etc.

Cf. s.v. Lat. dūcō, -ere 'to lead, conduct', from PIE *douk-e/o- 'to draw' (cf. MW 1.sg. dygaf, 3.sg. dwc 'to lead, bring', OBret. 3.sg. duc  'carries' < *duke/o-; Hitt. tukzi-, tukkanzi- 'cultivation of plants and animals < *duk-(ent)-i-; Alb. n-duk 'to pull', Goth. tiuhan 'to draw').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *duk-o- 'lead, carry', from PIE *deuk- (IEW 220f.), cf. Lat. dūcō 'lead', Goth. tiuhan 'pull'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *breusta- 'breast, chest' (ON brjóst, OE brēost, OFri. briast, OS briost < *bʰreus-sth₂-o-) and Proto-Germanic *brust- 'breast, chest' (Goth. brusts, OFri. brust, burst, OS brust < *bʰrus-sth₂-o-), cf. Russ. brjúxo 'belly, paunch' < *bʰreus-o-, OIr. brú (gen. bronn), MW bru 'womb, belly' < *bʰrus-n-io-.
S.v. Lith. debesìs 'cloud' (Latv. debess, var. debesis), from PIE *nebʰ-es-. The initial *n of the etymon was apparently replaced with d- in East Baltic.
S.v. *h₂nek̑- 'erreichen' (IEW 316-8).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ank-o- 'reach', from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'reach, attain' (cf. Skt. aśnoti 'reaches', Lat. nanciscor).
Cf. s.v. AGk. βλώσκω 'to go, come' (aor. μολεῖν), from PIE *melh₃- 'come'.
S.v. *stei̯gʰ- 'steigen, schreiten' (IEW 1017-8).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *tēg- 'go', from PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'tread, go' (cf. Gk. στείχω, Goth. steigan).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *rōbōn- 'tail', in ablaut relation to Ice. rafi 'strip (of land)', Far. ravi 'strip of halibut; side of a ray', Nw. rave 'rag; strip of land', possibly from < *h₁rop-on- or *h₁rh̥₁p-on-. Unrelated to PGmc. *rōbjōn- 'turnip'.

S.v. ON rófa 'schwanz, steissbein'. The etymology varies between either (1) MLG rœve, OHG ruoba, ruoppa, to Lat. rāpa; (2) to répij 'pfahl', or (3) Germ. *wrōbōn to Lat. verpa 'penis', Gk. ῥαπίς 'rute'.
S.v. Span. rabo, probably to be derived from Lat. rāpum 'turnip'.

S.v. Lat. rāpum 'turnip', from Proto-Italic *rāpo- (cf. Gk. ῥάπυς, ῥάφυς 'turnip', ῥάφανος ῥαφάνη 'radish', Lith. rápė 'turnip', RuCS rěpa, OHG ruoba, ruoppa 'turnip'). "This cannot be a regular PIE word: Latin, Baltic, and OHG ruoba require *aH, Slavic has /ē/, and Greek has single -a-. There is no prothetic vowel in Greek, and the vacillation between π and φ also suggests a loanword."

Widely regarded to be cognate with other words for 'turnip' in other IE languages. There are, however, formal difficulties in reconstruction which may point to a common borrowing or parallel borrowings from a pre-PIE source language. Cf. Slavic lexemes in /cognate/2329/ and *rap- in DIEAT http://dieat.inss.sc.ku.dk/display/entry.php?lemma_id=2139
The etymology given by de Vaan (2008:99) and others (cf. entry for further literature) has been followed in this class.
S.v. ON stertr 'schwanz' (cf. OE steort, OHG sterz 'schwanz'), according to IEW 1023 from a root *(s)terd- (cf. Gk. τόρδυλον 'doldenpflanze', Latv. stersk 'wagenrunge').
S.v. Khot. dūra- 'hard', noun 'hard clod or stone'. Bailey relates Khot. dūra- to Oss. D. dor, I. dur 'stone' (via Iran. *daura-), and Lat. dūrus 'hard' (IEW 215).
Cf. s.v. dūr | dor 'камень', an old loanword from Caucasian. [Khot. dūra- not listed as a potential cognate.]

Bailey (1979:136) connects Khot. dūra- 'hard' to Oss. dūr | dor 'stone' via its nominal meaning 'stone'. Abaev (1959–1995:376), however, regards the Ossetic lexemes as old loanwords from Caucasian (cf. /cognate/3241/). The connection with Latin dūrus is more tenuous (EWAia I:739 does not list Khot. dūra- 'hard' among the Indo-Iranian cognates of Skt. dūrá- 'fern'), as the meaning 'hard' is a secondary development from 'far' in Italic (cf. de Vaan 2008:184 and /cognate/5040/). It seems more likely that we are dealing with a chance lookalike in this case than a true cognate.
Cf. s.v. Ved. dūrá- 'ferne' [Khot. dūrá- 'hard' not listed as a cognate.]
Cf. s.v. Lat. dūrus 'hard, solid, endurable', from PIE *duh₂-ró- [Khotanese dūrá- not listed as a potential cognate.]
S.v. Ved. √yā-¹ 'fahren, dahinziehen, sich bewegen', from PIE *(H)i̯eh₂-.
S.v. Skt. 10452 yā́ti 'goes, approaches, comes to' RV. [√yā]
S.v. Skt. 10452 yā́ti 'goes, approaches, comes to' RV. [√yā]
Related to MG πιάνω ‘catch’ < Hell. πιάζω < AG πιέζω 'press, press down; bear down upon'.
S.v. TochB eṅk- 'take, grip, seize; conclude; understand', which with TochA eṃts- goes back to PIE *h₁nek̑- (possibly *h₂nek̑-).
S.v. TochB eṅk-, TochA eṃts- 'ergreifen, annehmen, halten, begreifen', 'seize, take, understand', from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'erhalten, nehmen' (cf. LIV² 250f.).
S.v. *h₁nek̑- 'erhalten, nehmen' (IEW 316-8).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *Hnas- (Has-) 'to reach, attain, take', from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, attain' (Av. nā̆s- 'to reach, attain', Skt. nāś-).
Cf. s.v. *h₂nek̑- 'erreichen' (IEW 316-8).

Cf. s.v. Lat. portō, -āre 'to transport, carry'. Most likely to be a denominal verb from Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'passage, crossing', cf. Lat. porta 'gate'. Cf. elsewhere PIE *pr̥-to-, *pr̥-tu- (Gaulish ritu-, Old Welsh rit, Welsh rhyd 'ford' < PCl. φritu-; Av. pərətu- 'crossing, bridge'; OHG furt, Engl. ford < PGmc. furδú-).
Cf. s.v. 1. per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren' (IEW 816-817).
Cf. s.v. Span. leve 'ligero, leve', from Lat. levis [from which llevar is a derivative].
Cf. s.v. Span. leve 'ligero, leve', from Lat. levis [from which llevar is a derivative].

Cf. s.v. levis 'light in weight' from PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light', which has been remodelled as an i-stem *leχwī̆- in Proto-Italic. Lat. levāre 'to relieve, lessen, lift up' is a derived verb from this adjective.
S.v. Lat. prĕhĕndĕre 'ergreifen', whence Fr. prendre.

S.v. Lat. prehendō, -ere 'to grasp, seize', from PIE *gʰ-n(e)-d- 'to grab' >> *gʰ(e)nd- (cf. OIr. ro-geinn, NW genni 'to be situated' < PCl. *gan-n-d-e/o-; Gk. χανδάνω 'to grab', Alb. gjen 'finds', Goth. du-ginnan 'to begin').
Cf. s.v. *gʰed- 'fassen' (IEW 437-8).
S.v. *teh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'berühren, fassen' (IEW 1054).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *takan- ~ tēkan- 'to touch' from PIE *th₂g̑-e- (cf. TochB täk- 'to touch' < *th₂g-, Gk. τεταγών 'taking' < *te-th₂g-ont-).
S.v. Lith. im̃ti 'take' (Latv. jem̃t, OPr. īmt 'take'), from PIE *h₁m- (cf. OCS jęti 'take', Lat. emere 'take (in compounds), buy').
S.v. *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 455).

S.v. Ved. √grabh-ⁱ 'ergreifen, nehmen, fassen, festhalten' (Av. gərəβnāiti 'gewinnt, erlangt'), from PIE (prob.) *gʰreb⁽ʰ⁾H- (cf. Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'rauben', Latv. grebt 'greifen', OCS grabiti 'rauben').
S.v. 13980 Skt. hárati 'carries, brings' RV., 'takes away' Mn. 2. Pass. *hr̥yatē. [√hr̥] (> K. hyonu, pp. hyotu 'to take').
S.v. Ved. √har-¹ 'nehmen, bringen, herbeiholen, tragen, darbringen'. Without convincing etymological connections.
Cf. s.v. ?2.*g̑ʰer- 'nehmen, holen' (IEW 442). Root only attested in Indic.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kom-ber-o- 'bring together', cf. Proto-Celtic *ber-o- 'carry' from PIE *bʰer-.
Cf. s.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *gab-yo- 'take, hold', from PIE *gʰHbʰ- (IEW 407ff.), cf. Lat. habeō 'have'.

Cf. s.v. Lat. habeō 'to have, hold', from Proto-Italic *χab/f-ē- 'has taken' > 'has, holds' (cf. Umbr. hahtu, etc., from PIE *gʰh₁b⁽ʰ⁾-(e)i- 'to take' (cf. OIr. gaibaid, -gaib 'to take' < PCl. *gab-i-).
S.v. 10948 Skt. lábhatē 'catches, takes'.
S.v. Ved. √rabh- 'ergreifen, fassen', perhaps from PIE *lembʰ-/*lm̥bʰ-.
Cf. s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen' (IEW 652).

According to {ref de Vaan 2008}:89-90 at the time of publication, Beekes's (then still forthcoming) Greek Etymological Dictionary (now {ref Beekes 2010}) doubts the semantic plausibility of the connection with Gk. κάπτω with Lat. capiō.  If the Greek cognates are removed from the equation, de Vaan considers that it is just as possible that the Italic and Germanic cognates may go back to a non-IE loanword.  In the dictionary as published, however, {ref Beekes 2010} s.v. κάπτω considers that the Greek and Italic forms 'might be identical' (presumably via a zero-grade yod-present *kh₂p-i̯é- as reconstructed by {ref LIV²}), with some caveats.
S.v. Ved. bahú- 'viel, reichlich, häufig, dicht, dichtgedrangt', from PIE *bʰn̥g̑ʰ-ú- (cf. Gk. παχύς 'dick, dicht', Hitt. panku- 'gesamt', Iran. *bazu- in Arm. LW bazowm 'viel').
Cf. s.v. *bʰeng̑ʰ- 'dicht, fest machen' (IEW 127f.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic ϸeku- 'fat', from *tegu- (cf. OIr. tiug 'fat'), probably a Celtic-Germanic isogloss. Further connections are unclear.

S.v. Lat. spissus 'laborious, slow, dense', possibly from PIE *spid-to- comparing Gk. σπίδιος 'extensive, wide', σπιδνόν 'thick, coagulated', possibly Lith. spìsti 'to begin to swarm (of bees), gather', but the Baltic material is much further removed semantically.

S.v. Lith. šlaunìs 'thigh, hip' (Latv. slaũna 'hip'), from PIE *k̑lou-ni- (cf. Skt. śróṇi- 'buttock, hip, loin', Av. sraoni- 'buttock, hip', Lat. clūnis 'buttocks, haunch', OIc. hlaun 'loin, buttock').

Cf. s.v. Ved. śróni- 'Hüfte, Hinterbacke, Lende' (Av. sraoni-), from PIE *k̑lou̯ni- (cf. Lat. clūnis 'Hinterbacke, Keule, Steiß', W clun 'Hüfte', Lith. šlaunìs 'Hüfte, Oberschenkel', Latv. slauns 'Schenkelstück', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *klowni- 'thigh', from PIE *k̑lou̯ni- (IEW 607f.), cf. Lat. clūnis, OIc. hlaun, Lith. šlaunìs.
S.v. Ved. sákthi- 'Schenkel' (Av. haxtiiā̊ gen.du. 'der (weiblichen) Schenkel'). Connections outside of Indo-Iranian difficult.
S.v. Khot. hurā 'thigh', from *urāva-, from *uru- (cf. Ved. ūrú- 'thigh').

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *noga 'foot, leg', as though from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. Lith. nagà 'hoof'; nãgas 'nail, claw', Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').
S.v. Alb. këmbë, -a 'leg, foot'. Ultimately a loan from VLat. camba 'leg'. "The relation to the Vulgar Latin form is clear but the direction of the borrowing is uncertain."

There is no single PS form but three: *korakŭ, *korkŭ/*korka and *krokŭ. It is hard to explain this variation. The lexeme was obviously expressive and its nautral usage in Bulgarian is a relatively late innovation. The Slavic word has been linked to Lithuanian kárka '(front) leg of pig'. It is further related to Latvian kar̂cinêt 'shake legs while sitting' and kar̂cinât 'shake, tremble' and to Lithuanian verb kárti 'hang'. Also a derivation from PIE *(s)ker- 'bend, twist' has been proposed.
Cf. for earlier proposed connections to PIE *ak̑- (*h₂ek̑-) 'sharp'.
S.v. Khw. myθ 'day' = Sgd. C myθ, Šγn. mēθ < *maiθā- (cf. Av. maēθā- 'change, evolution').
S.v. OPr. pūton 'drink', from PIE *peh₃(i)-/*ph₃(i)- (cf. OCS piti 'drink', Skt. pā́ti 'drink', Gk. πίνω (Att.) 'drink', πώνω (Aeol., Dor.) 'drink').
S.v. TochB yok- 'drink', which with TochA yok- is comparable to Hitt. eku-/aku- 'drink' (cf. Lat. ēbrius 'having drunk one's fill, drunk', Gk. νήφω 'be sober'), most likely from PIE *h₁egʷʰ-.
S.v. Khw. βwm 'earth', from Av. būmi-, as Sogd. βwm.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *bedro, *bedra 'thigh' (ESSJa I 175-176, 179-180). "The etymology of this word is not entirely clear. The connection with Ukr. bedrá (dial.) 'large pit, valley, swamp', Pl. ubiedrze 'slope, steep bank', and Lith. bẽdrė 'swamp, valley', Latv. bedre 'pit' (Anikin 1998: 30-31), which derive from *bʰedʰ- 'dig', is semantically unattractive. In Balto-Slavic, the meaning of this root seems to shifted to 'to stab', however, which makes on wonder if → *stegnò 'thigh' may derive from a root meaning 'stab' as well, cf. OIc. stinga 'stab, thrust'. Pokorny's reconstruction of a root *bed- 'swell' (IEW: 96) is impossible because of Winter's Law."
PS *bedro is derived from *bed- / *bod- 'hit, stab' (cf. PS *bosti). As to the semantic development cf. German Bein 'leg' < PIE *bʰei̯- 'beat, hit'

Reconstruction of an IE root *stei̯gʰ- 'stab' for this class would depend on the interpretation of Proto-Slavic *bedra, *bedro 'thigh' being derived from *bʰedʰ- 'stab', which is uncertain. Cf. notes in /cognate/5207/.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *lawiz- 'ham, thigh'. OSw. and ON lær go back to *lawaz-, but OE lēow presupposes a proto-form *lawiz-, the formation may be related to *lagja- 'leg' [cf. /cognate/1352/].

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸeuha- 'thigh', from PIE *téuHk-o- (cf. Lith. taukaĩ, Latv. tàuki (m.pl.) 'lard', OPr. taukis 'id.', OCS tukъ, Ru. tuk 'fat' < *toukH-o-; OIr. tón 'behind, bottom', MW tin 'bottom, arse, rear' < *tuHk-neh₂-). A European IE word for 'thigh, hip'.
Cf. discussion in ALEW & Derksen (2015:459-460) regarding the Baltic evidence for the root reconstruction, and further discussion regarding Balto-Slavic lexemes meaning 'fat' in /cognate/6104/.

Cf. s.v. Ved. jáṅghā- 'unterer Teil des Beines, Unterschenkel, Bein' (cf. Av. zaṇga- 'Fußknöchel), probably a derivation from PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (cf. Goth. gaggan 'gehen', Lith. žeñgti 'schreiten', etc.).
S.v. *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (IEW 438-9).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *gangan- ~ *gungen- 'to go', from PIE *g̑ʰóngʰ-e- (cf. Lith. žeñgti [žengiù] 'to stride' < *g̑ʰengʰ-ie-).
S.v. 5082 Ved. jáṅghā f. 'shank (ankle to knee)'
S.v. SMG μπούτι, a borrowing from Turk. but 'thigh'.

S.v. Ved. tanú- 'dünn, schmal, schlank, fein', not to be separated from Gk. ταναός 'dünn, schmal, langgestreckt', cf. also Lat. tenuis 'dünn, fein, zart', OIr. tanae 'zart, dünn, OHG dunni 'dünn', OCS tьnъ-kъ 'zart, fein'. Probably from PIE *tn̥H-ú-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tьnъkъ 'thin', based on PIE *tnh₂-u- (cf. Skt. tanú- 'thin, slender', Gk. ταναός 'outstretched', Lat. tenuis 'fine, thin', OIr. tanae 'thin, slender').

S.v. Proto-Germanic ϸunnu- 'thin', from PIE *tnh₂-u- (cf. Skt. tanú(ka)-  'thin, slender, small, fine', OCS tьnъkъ 'thin, slender, fine', Lith. (Žem.) tę́vas, Latv. tiêvs 'thin, slender', Gk. ταναός 'thin, slender, elongated', Lat. tenuis 'thin, fine, delicate', OIr. tanae 'delicate, thin').
