S.v. Proto-Celtic *tanawyo- 'thin', from PIE *tenh₂u-, *tnh₂u- 'thin' (cf. Gk. ταναός, Lat. tenuis, OHG dunni).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *vergti 'throw', from PIE *uergʷ- (cf. Goth. wairpan 'throw').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *werpan- 'to warp, sling, throw', from PIE *uérgʷ-e- (cf. Gk. ῥέμβομαι 'to roam, go around' < *uré-m-gʷ-e-; ῥόμβος 'top, wheel, spinning motion' < *uro-m-gʷ-o-).
S.v. Lat. iaciō, -ere 'to throw', pres. stem based on PIE (aor. stem) *(H)ieh₁-. Cf. secondary intensive/iterative stem iactāre 'to throw, toss, brag'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *metati 'throw' (ESSJa XVIII 112-115) & Proto-Slavic *mesti 'throw, sweep' (ESSJa XVIII 105-108). Derksen considers, given the similarity of the movements of 'sweep' and 'mow', LIV² ?1.*met- 'mähen' (Lat. metō 'mow, harvest', W. medi 'reap') these lexemes should also be etymologically connected.
Cf. s.v. ?2.*met- 'abmessen' (IEW 703-704), verbal only Balto-Slavic.

S.v. Lith. mèsti 'throw' (Latv. mest). According to LIV² 442, verbs with the root ?2.*met- 'abmessen' are limited to Balto-Slavic. Given the similarities of the movement 'sweep' and 'mow', Derksen would advocate a connection with Lat. metere 'mow, harvest' (?1.*met- 'mähen'). De Vaan (2008:378) considers a semantic shift from 'measure off' > 'reap' possible and is also inclined to assume a single root *met-.
Cf. s.v. Lat. metō, -ere 'to reap, harvest'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *bindan- 'to bind', from PIE *bʰéndʰ-e- (cf. Skt. badhnāti 'to bind, tie, fix' < *bʰndʰ-néh₂-, Av. basta-, OPers. basta- 'bound' < *bʰndʰ-to-, Gk. πεῖσμα 'rope, cable' < *bʰendʰ-s-men-).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *vę̄zati 'tie', from PIE *h₂mg̑ʰ- (cf. Hitt. hamank- 'tie, betroth' [*h₂m-(o)n-g̑ʰ-], Gk. ἄγχω 'squeeze, strangle', Lat. angere 'strangle, choke').
S.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (IEW 42-3).
S.v. Arm. atamn 'tooth', derived from PIE *h₃dont- (cf. Gk. ὀδών, ὀδόντος, Lat. dēns, dentis, Skt. dán, dántam, Lith. dant-ìs, etc.).
S.v. Ved. dant- 'Zahn', from PIE *h₁d-ónt- *'beißend' (~*h₁ed-) (cf. Gk. ὀδὠν, ὀδόντ- [Aeol. ἔδοντ-ες], Arm. atamn, Lat. dēns, dent-, OHG zan(d), Lith. dantìs 'Zahn', etc.).
S.v. Lith. dantìs 'tooth' (OPr. dantis 'tooth'), from PIE *h₃d-(o)nt- (cf. Skt. dánt- 'tooth', Gk. ὀδών 'tooth', Arm. atamn 'tooth', Lat. dēns, 'tooth', OHG zan(d) 'tooth').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *tanϸ- ~ *tunϸ- 'tooth'. The ablaut of NWGerm. *tanϸ- and EGerm. *tunϸ- points to an original paradigm *tanϸ-, gen. tundiz < *h₃d-ónt-, *h₃d-nt-és, an archaic participle to the root *h₃ed- 'to bite, be sharp'.

S.v. Lat. dēns, -tis 'tooth', from PIE *h₃d-nt- 'tooth' (cf. OIr. dét 'tooth', Skt. dánt-, Gk. (Ion.) ὀδών, νωδός 'toothless' (< *n-h₃d-o-), Aeol. ἔδοντες 'teeth' (only in a 12th c. AD gloss in a grammatical text), Arm. atamn, OPr. dantis, Lith. dantìs, Lith. úodas, Latv. uôds 'gnat', Gk. ὀδυνή 'pain').

S.v. Proto-Celtic *danto- 'tooth', from PIE *h₁dont- 'tooth' (cf. Lat. dēns, Skt. dánt-, Gk. ὀδών, Lith. dantìs, OHG zand). The reconstruction of the initial laryngeal is uncertain. Some prefer to see an original participle of the verb 'to eat' *h₁ed-, but others reconstruct *h₃- from which Gk. ὀδών is derived more straightforwardly.

Widely considered to continue a participle *h₁d-ónt- to the verbal root *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', lexicalised as 'tooth' already in PIE ({ref NIL} 208-220, {ref LIV²} 230-231, {ref EIEC} 594). Under this explanation the original Ancient Greek form would be continued by Aeolic ἔδοντ-, which underwent vowel assimilation in other dialects. The Leiden School of Indo-European reconstruction alternatively reconstructs a distinct root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' following {ref Kortlandt 2003}:77, who argues that it would better account for ὀδών much more straightforwardly, and it would also much better account for the Ancient Greek privative adjective νωδός 'toothless' < *n̥-h₃d-ó-, (expected †νηδός < *n̥-h₃d-ó-); as for Aeolic ἔδοντ-, it only occurs in late grammatical texts and could have itself been created on the basis of an analogy to Greek ἔδ- 'eat'. For individual branches, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:776, {ref Beekes 2010}:1049, {ref Martirosyan 2010}:1049, {ref EWAia} I:693-694, {ref ALEW} 174-175, {ref Derksen 2015}:115, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:169, {ref de Vaan 2008}:166-167, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:62-63 {ref Matasović 2009}:90).
Cf. s.v. *h₁ed- '(beißen →) essen' (IEW 287-9), to which LIV² reconstructs a participle already in PIE *h₁d-ónt- 'Zahn'.
S.v. Khw. pwst 'skin' from OPers. pawastā, as NP pūst.
PS *koža is derived from PS *koza 'goat'. Its original meaning was 'goat leather'. PS *koza 'goat' itself has probably a non-IE origin.

S.v. Proto-Iranian *daiH-² 'to shine, radiate; to light a fire'. The Choresmian form pzn is in all likelihood a univerbation with the preverb *pati- (cf. Parth. pdyn- 'to kindle' < *pati-dīna-; Khot. uysdīś- 'to set alight, make burn' with preverb *uz-). From PIE *dei̯h₂- 'to shine, light up' (cf. Skt. day- 'to shine, to radiate', Gk. δέατο 'shone', διθάω 'I flash, shine', ON teitr 'cheerful').

S.v. Ved. √ay-¹ 'gehen, wandern, fahren, gelangen' (cf. OAv. āitī 'kommt heran', YAv. aēiti 'geht'), from PIE *h₁ei̯- (cf. Hitt. i-it 'geh!', Luw. i-ti 'geht', Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', OLith. eimì 'gehe', Lith. eĩti, OCS iti 'gehen', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *jьti 'go' (ESSJa VIII 247-248), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *ei- (Lith. eĩti, Latv. iêt 'go') from PIE *h₁ei̯- (cf. Skt. éti, Gk. εἶμι, Lat. īre).
S.v. Lith. eĩti 'go', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'go' (cf. OCS iti, Skt. éti, Gk. εἶμι, Lat. īre).

S.v. Gk. εἶμι 'to go', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'go', an old thematic root present with exact correspondences in many languages (Skt. é-mi, Lith. ei-mì,  Hitt. pāi-mi (with preverb *pe-, pa-), Lat. ī-s, i-t, etc.).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √mar- 'sterben', from PIE *mer- 'verschwinden, hinschwinden, sterben' (cf. Lat. morior 'sterbe', Goth. maurϸr 'Mord', Lith. mir̃ti, OCS mrěti 'sterben', etc.).
S.v. 10066 Skt. māráyati (1) 'kills' AV. [√mr̥]. [cs. of √mar- 'causes to die']
S.v. Lith. mir̃ti (Latv. mìrt) 'die' from Proto-Balto-Slavic *mer-/*mir- (cf. OCS mrěti 'die'), derived from PIE *mer- (cf. Skt. mriyáte 'die, Lat. morior 'die').
S.v. Lat. fodiō 'to pierce, to dig', from PIE *bʰodʰ-i- 'to poke, dig' (cf. Hitt. padda-/padd- 'to dig (the ground) < *bʰodʰh₂-, OPr. boadis 'stab', Lith. bèsti 'to stick, drive (into), dig', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *pat- under the Choresmian forms. "The etymology of hwβ is uncertain.", cf. entry for further discussion of problematic hypotheses that have been proposed.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *pasti (II) 'fall', from PIE *pod- (cf. Skt. pádayate 'fall', OE gefetan 'fall').
Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².

Cf. s.v. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschließend fliegen, stürzen, fallen', from PIE *pet- (cf. Gk. πέτομαι 'fliege', Lat. petō 'eile, begebe mich wohin' Old Welsh hedant 'volant', Hitt. pít-ti-i̯a-an-zi 'sie laufen', etc.).
New etymology to PIE *h₃elh₁- 'zugunde gehen' has been accepted and included in the addenda and corrigenda to LIV².
S.v. Khw. srδ 'year', from Av. sarəd-, as Sogd. srδ.

The cognacy in this class follows {ref LIV²} to PIE *(s)teup- after {ref Oettinger 1979}:417, 535, {ref Hajnal 1995}:127. Note however disagreement of {ref Melchert 1994}:242, {ref Neumann 2007}:384-385, comparing Gk. στυφελίζω suggesting a root-variant *(s)teubʰ- (after {ref IEW} 1034; not in {ref LIV²}). According to {ref Beekes 2010}:1418-1419, however, Gk. στυφελίζω has no secure connections outside of Greek.

S.v. Lyc. tubi- something like "erschlagen", corresponds to Gk. ἀπόλλυμι "zugrunderichten, vernichten". Identical to CLuw. dupai-/dupi- 'schlagen, hauen; bestrafen', HLuw. tup(a)i- 'to smite'. "Wegen des lyk. b nicht unmittelbar zu griech. τύπτω, idg. *teup- zu stellen, sondern zu dessen Wurzelvariante *(s)teub-, vgl. Pokorny, IEW 1034, Melchert AHPh 242: griech. στυφελίζω 'schlagen, stoßen, drängen, treiben, treffen'".
Connects Luw. dūpi-/dūpāi- 'strike' < PA *(s)toubéyo-, comparing Gk. στυφελίζω.

Derives Lyc. 3.sg.pres. tubidi 'er schlägt' < *tūbī́di < *tūbéidi < *tūbéii̯idi < anatol. *toubéi̯edi < (iterative) *(s)toupéi̯eti (cf. CLuw. 3.sg.pres. <tu-ú-pi-ti> tūbīdi, HLuw. <tu-pi-ri+i> to PIE *steup- (cf. Gk. τύπτω).
Connects Luwic forms to *(s)teup-.
S.v. AGk. ποιῶ 'machen' (whence Mod. Cyp. ποιγῶ, ποίω, Pont. ποίου, Tsak. ποίγω).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *činiti (ESSJa IV 112-113), as though from PIE *kʷei-n- (cf. Skt. cinóti 'gather, arrange, pile up). In view of the *-n-, the Slavic verb seems to be a derivative of the nominal *činъ (cf. OCS 'row, order, rank, file', Cz. čin 'affair, act, deed', Sln. čin 'act, deed' Bulg. čin 'rank' < *kʷei-no-).
Perhaps the IIr. verbs in from *kʷer- in LIV² could also be with 2. *(s)ker- 'scheren, kratzen, abschneiden'.
S.v. Khw. hβr- (cf. Sgd. M δβr-, C θbr- [θβar-], Khot. haur- < *fra-bara-).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *geb-a- 'geben'. Probably to be compared with a European root *g̑ʰabʰ- 'nehmen, bringen, halten', the e-vocalism of Germanic is then secondary. (Cf. Lat. habeō 'halten, besitzen, haben', OIr. gaibid 'nimmt, ergreift', Lith. gabénti 'befödern, herbeischaffen, fortschaffen'; with e-vocalism gebė́ti 'pflegen, gewohnt sein').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *geban- 'give'. The verb is often compared with OIr. gaibid 'to take, hold' < *gʰHbʰ-ie-, but this is formally impossible because of the laryngeal. LIV² 193 connects with Lith. gebė́ti 'to be able, to be used to' < *gʰebʰ-eh₁-ie-, but the semantics are problematic. Kortlandt (1992:104-5) assumes a remodelling of *ga-ef- < *k̑o(m)-h₁ep-, to be directly connected with Lat. coēpī 'seized' < *k̑o(m)-h₁eh₁p-.

The exact connections outside of Germanic are disputed. For the purposes of cognacy, this class follows the reconstruction of LIV² with possible but uncertain connections to ?*g̑ʰeHb- (cf. OIr. gaibid). But cf. the hypothesis of Kortlandt (1992:104-5), followed by Kroonen (2013:172-173), who suggests a remodelling of earlier *ga-ef- from *k̑o(m)-h₂ep-.

"The usual connection of *geb- 'give' with Latin habeō 'hold' and OIr. gaibid 'takes' must be rejected because the vocalism is incompatible. This verb can be derived from the Germanic prefix ga- plus the root of Hitt. epzi 'seizes', Lat. apīscor 'reach', coēpī 'have begun'."
S.v. Khw. xwb 'good' < Av. xwapah-, as Sogd. xwp, MP xwb.
S.v. Khw. psʾw 'grind', from *pati-sāwa- to √saw-.

S.v. Lith. málti 'grind, mill', (Latv. mal̃t 'grind, mill'), from PIE *melH- (cf. Skt. mr̥ṇā́ti, 'crush, grind', Hitt. malla-i / malla- 'mill, grind', Lat. molere 'grind, mill', OIr. meilid 'grind', Goth. malan 'grind', OHG malan 'grind, mill', Arm. malem 'crush').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *rogъ 'Horn', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *rogos (cf. Lith. rãgas, Latv. rags, OPr. ragis).
S.v. Lith. rãgas 'horn' (Latv. rags 'horn', OPr. ragis 'horn'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *rógos (cf. Proto-Slavic *rogъ 'horn').

S.v. Engl. kill, of obscure origin; not found in the cognate languages. "If in Old English, its type would be *cyllan , conjecturally referred to an Old Germanic *kuljan , ablaut-variant of *kwaljan , whence Old English cwellan to quell v.1; but the original sense is against this. Known first in Layamon, and in southern texts, in form cüllen , küllen . In midl. dialect normally kille(n , kill , the common form in Middle English; kelle is rare."
Cf. s.v. Lith. gélti 'ache, sting, bite', from PIE *gʷelH- (cf. OHG quelan 'be in pain', OE cwelan 'die').
IE root etymology debated, either to ?*teu̯H- '(freundlich) beachten, betrachten; schützen' (LIV² 639-640) or to* teu̯h₂- 'to be strong' > 'keeps strong, protects' (de Vaan 2008:632-633).

S.v. Lat. tueor 'to look at, watch over', from which Lat. tūtāre / tūtārī is a secondary derivative. Contra LIV², de Vaan argues for a derivation from PIE *teu̯h₂- 'to be strong' > 'keeps strong, protects' (cf. LIV² 639-640, IEW 1080-1).
S.v. faciō, -ere 'to make'. Interficere is a compound of faciō, -ere 'to make, to do', from PIE *dʰh₁-k-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *dōn- 'to do', an athematic verb continuing Pre-Gmc. 3.sg. *dʰóh₁-ti, 3.pl. *dʰh₁-énti. Other IE languages have a reduplicated present stem (cf. Skt. dádhati, Gk. τίθημι).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *grabH- 'to grab, seize, take' (Av. grab- 'to grab, seize, take'), from PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to grab, seize'  (cf. OCS grabiti 'to rob', Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'to rob').
Cf. s.v. *grebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 455).

S.v. Ved. √grabh-ⁱ 'ergreifen, nehmen, fassen, festhalten' (Av. gərəβnāiti 'gewinnt, erlangt'), from PIE (prob.) *gʰreb⁽ʰ⁾H- (cf. Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'rauben', Latv. grebt 'greifen', OCS grabiti 'rauben').
S.v. Lat. sciō, scīre 'to know', from PIE *skh₁-i(e/o)- 'to incise' (cf. Skt. chyáti 'to cut open, skin', Gk. σχάω 'to make an incision, slit open').
S.v. Proto-Iranian *pad- 'to fall, be stuck in' (cf. Ved. pad- 'to move, go, fall'). The Choresmian and Sogdian forms in this class are prefixed with the preverb *ni- 'downwards'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √pad- 'treten, gehen, fallen, niedersinken' < PIE *ped- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten, *fußwärts gehen → fallen', cf. Rix (1976:278f.).
S.v. *ped- 'treten; fallen, sinken' (IEW 790-2); the same root as 'foot' with the semantic development 'place one's foot' → 'to go in the direction of the feet' → 'fall', cf. {ref Rix 1976}:278f.
Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².
S.v. Alb. njeri, -u njerëz 'human being, man', cognate with Gk. ἀνήρ, Ved. nár-, Arm. ayr, all 'man'.
S.v. Khw. mrc 'man' < Ir. *martiya-.
S.v. Alb. burrë 'man, husband', a borrowing from OHG gibūro 'peasant, villager' with simplification of the initial cluster *gb- > *b-. Other possibilities have been proposed by other scholars.

Rejects the suggestion of a OHG loanword by Orel (1998:42-43) and the earlier attempts to connect to *bʰer- by Huld (1984:46-47) and other earlier scholars. The suggestion of Demiraj (1997:113-114) to PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to be, thrive, dwell' is better formally, but remains semantically doubtful.
S.v. Alb. burrë, -i 'man, husband', possibly to *bʰərno- (PIE *bʰer-), but the gemination of -rr- in the word is difficult to account for.

S.v. Alb. búrr/ë -i 'Mann, Ehemann, Gatte'. Since the original meaning is disputed, the etymology remains uncertain. Against the suggestion to *bʰerno-, Meyer's older comparison to Germanic words (NHG Bauer) to *bʰeu̯ə- (*bʰeu̯h₂-, *bʰuh₂-, *bʰh₂u-) formally has no difficulties.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *gora 'mountain' (ESSJa VII 29-31), a derivative with the o-grade of the root *gʷrH- (cf. Lith. girià 'woods', Skt. girí- 'mountain, hill').
As the etymology of Lat. strictus appears to be a blend from two earlier roots, the root ref. form is only given as Lat. strictus.

In addition to connections with Alb. hu 'penis' and hedh 'to throw', suggested by Meyer (1891:153-154), followed by Orel (1998:152) and others, Hyllested also proposes cognacy to PGmc. *skuna- 'snout' reflected in Faroese and SW Norwegian skon 'snout'.
S.v. Alb. hu-ri (Gheg. hûni 'Pfahl; männliches Glied', which M. proposes a root connection to hundε, Cal. γundε, Scut. hun 'Nase, Spitze; Vorgebirge'.
S.v. Khw. zywk 'person, anybody' < Ir. *ǰīwaka-, as Px̌t. žəway 'living, animal'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. jīvá- 'lebendig, lebend' (OPers. ǰīva- 'lebendig', OAv., YAv. ǰuua- 'lebendig, lebend'), from PIE *gʷih₃-u̯ó- to *gʷei̯h₃-/*gʷi̯eh₃- (cf. Lat. vīvos, Lith. gývas, OCS živъ 'lebendig', etc.).
S.v. Khw. ʾβwzy (2) 'to drag, pull out, away', perhaps = aββōziy from *apa-bauǰaya-.
S.v. Khw. rxtk 'red', from Ir. *raxtaka- (cf. Skt. rakta-) with exceptional preservation of -xt-.
S.v. Khot. nätā 'river', from *ni-tāka- to base *tak- (ttajs- 'to flow', cf. Av. tak-, tačaiti).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √tak- 'stürzen, dahinschießen, eilen (von Tieren, Strömen) (YAv. tax-še 'du läufst, Khot. ttajs- 'laufen, fließen', MPers. tāxtan 'laufen, lassen, fließen', Parth. tč- 'laufen, fließen', etc.), from PIE *tekʷ- 'eilen, stürzen, laufen, fließen' (cf. OIr. tech- 'fließen', Lith. tekė́ti 'laufen, fließen', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaHz- 'to run, start' (cf. Skt. gāh- 'to enter (the water), wade'), from PIE *g⁽ʷʰ⁾eh₂g̑ʰ- 'to wade' (cf. Slov. gáziti 'to wade', SCr. gȁziti 'to step, wade').
S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- '(ins Wasser eindringen, hineinwaten' [IEW 465]. Khwarazmian γ’z- 'laufen, eilen' is marked '?' from a reconstructed present stem *g⁽ʷ⁾ḗg̑ʰ-/*g⁽ʷ⁾ég̑ʰ-.
Cf. s.v. Gk. εἴδομαι 'to appear, seem, resemble', from PIE *ueid- 'see' (thematic aorist ἰδεῖν).
S.v. Lat. videō 'to see', from PIE *uid-eh₁- 'to see'.
Arm. sermn is tentatively explained as a contamination of the root *k̑erh₁- 'grow' with *sper- (as found in Gk. σπέρμα 'seed'), cf. Olsen (1999:504). Not in Martirosyan (2010).
Explains Arm. sermn as a *-mn̥(t)- stem, either from the root *k̑erh₁- (IEW 577) or a contamination of this root and *sp⁽ʰ⁾er- found in Gk. σπέρμα, -ατος.
S.v. Lith. siū́ti 'sew' (Latv. šũt 'sew'), from PIE *sih₂u- (< *sh₂-i-u-), cf. Proto-Slavic *šìti, Skt. sī́vyati, Lat. suere, Goth. siujan).

Cf. s.v. 1. *negʷ- 'dunkel werden, dämmern' (LIV 449, IEW 762f.). PIE nom.sg. *nokʷt-, gen.sg. *nekʷt- 'night' from the root *negʷ- 'to become dark' (LIV 449) with devoicing of the final consonant next to *-t-. See fn. 1 with a discussion of the different stem analyses and inflectional patterns which have been suggested for PIE.

S.v. No. 10 [Arm.] astł 'star', derived from PIE *h₂ster-, where the final -ł- has been suggested as due to a blend with PIE *seh₂u̯ol 'sun', otherwise lost in Armenian (cf. Olsen 1999:159-160, partly followed by Martirosyan 2010:122).
S.v. Proto-Iranian gauš- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Skt. ghoṣ- 'to sound'). Cognate forms outside of IIr. are not attested.

S.v. No. 18 erkinkʻ 'sky', frequently seen as having undergone contamination with its antonym erkir 'earth' (or vice versa), e.g. {ref Normier 1980}:62-3 who takes erkin from *h₁erki-u̯ent- (cf. Ved. arcivant- epithet of sky), with -k- from erkir. Not in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
Cf. s.v. *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben' (IEW 735). Cf. cs. ?*mor-éi̯e- > Ved. (AV) mārayáti 'tötet', OCS -morjǫ, -moriti 'töten'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √mar- 'sterben', from PIE *mer- 'verschwinden, hinschwinden, sterben' (cf. Hitt. merzi 'schwindet', Arm. meṙani- 'sterben', Gk. (Hesych.) ἔμορτεν· ἀπέθανεν, etc.).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *marwo- 'dead', from which OIr. marbaid is a denominative verbal formation. The original PIE adjective *mrto- (PIE *mer- 'disappear, die') was remodelled in Celtic → PCl. *marwo- on analogy to PIE *gʷiH-u̯o- 'alive' (cf. Lat. uīuus, etc.).
S.v. 10066 Ved. māráyati (1) ʻ kills ʼ AV. [√mr̥].

S.v. Proto-Iranian *kau̯š- 'to fight, struggle; kill'. This root goes back to a PIE ingressive formation *keh₂u-se/o- (cf. TochA koṣ-, TochB kauṣ- 'to kill, strike down, destroy'), non-ingressive forms are attested via Lith. káuti 'to murder, beat, hew', OHG houwan, OE hēawan, Engl. to hew, etc.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *knāmi- 'bone' (OIr. cnáim), from PIE *konh₂m 'leg', cf. Gk. κνήμη 'leg', OE hamm 'ham'. The Old Irish lexeme is derived from the oblique stem *knh₂m-.
Cf. s.v. Gk. κνήμη 'part between the knee and ankle, leg, shank', from PIE *kónh₂-m, *knh₂-m- 'bone, tibia, shank'.
S.v. OPr. pijst (inf.) 'tragen'. Without a good explanation. Some attempts to relate to PIE *ped- 'treten' through semantics 'to transport a heavy burden by foot'.
S.v. OPr. aulāut 'sterben', corresponds to Lith. liáuti + preverb au-.
S.v. OPr. siggīt (inf.) 'tun'; the verb still lacks a clear etymology.
S.v. OPr. widdai (pret.3.sg.) 'sah', based on a secondarily lengthened zero-grade *u̯id- of PIE *u̯eid- 'erblicken'.
S.v. OPr. īst (inf.) 'essen', directly comparable to OLith. ė́sti 'essen' (Lith. 'fressen'), Latv. êst, ultimately from PIE *h₁ed- 'beißen; essen'.
S.v. Lith. ė́sti 'eat (of animals)' (Latv. êst, OPr. istwei), from PIE *h₁ed- 'eat' (cf. OCS jasti, Skt. átti, Hitt. ed-/ad-, Gk. ἔδμεναι; Lat. edere, Goth. itan).
S.v. Arm utem 'to eat', since long connected to Gk. ἔδω, Lat. edō, Skt. ad-, OCS jasti, Goth. itan, etc. from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'.
S.v. Ved. √ad- 'essen, verzehren', from PIE *h₁ed- (cf. Hitt. e-id-mi 'esse', Gk. ἔδμεναι 'essen', Lat. edō 'esse', ēst 'ißt', Lith. ė́sti 'fressen', OCS jasti 'essen', Goth. itan 'essen', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ěsti 'eat', from PIE *h₁ed- (cf. Lith. ė́sti, Latv. êst, OPr. īst, īstwei, Skt. átti. Hitt. ed-/ad-, Gk. ἔδμεναι, Lat. edō, Goth. itan).
S.v. Lat. edō, ēsse 'to eat', from Proto-Italic *ed- 'to eat' (cf. Osc. edum 'to eat'), from PIE *h₁ed-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ed-o- 'eat' (OIr. ithid), from PIE *h₁ed- (cf. Skt. ádmi, Gk. ἔδομαι, Lat. edō, Goth. itan, Hitt. ēd-, Lith. ė́sti, OCS jasti).
S.v. Lith. válygti 'eat' (Latv. val̃ģît 'eat in a hurry, gobble' [LW from Lith.], OPr. walgeit 'eat'), from PIE *uolg- (cf. OHG wolchan 'cloud').

S.v. TochB pärsk- 'feel fear, be afraid', which with TochA pärsk- reflects PIE *pr̥K-sk̑e/o- to the root *p(e)rK- otherwise only seen in Germanic (and there also only in the zero-grade), cf. OE fyrhtu 'fright, fear', Goth. faurhtjan 'to fear'.

S.v. TochAB pärsk- 'sich fürchten', 'be afraid', which must be derived to a root *pre⁽k̑⁾- or *pre⁽g̑⁾- 'be afraid' (LIV² 491 *preK-), from which the Tocharian forms reflect a zero-grade *-sk̑e/o- present *pr̥K-sk̑e/o-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *furhta- 'fearful', *furhtjan- 'to fear' < *prk-sk- (cf. TochAB präskā- 'to fear').
S.v. OPr. ūlint (inf.) 'kämpfen'. Without a suitable etymology; the traditional connection of ūlint with Cz. váleti 'bekriegen', válka 'Krieg' is questionable.
Cf. s.v. *dʰegʷʰ- 'mit Feuer behandeln, verbrennen (tr.)' (IEW 240-1).
(ι)κ̔άρα < AG ἐσχάρα ‘hearth’.
S.v. TochB pūwar 'fire', which with TochA por probably reflects Proto-Tocharian *puwār and generally connected with PIE *peh₂u̯r̥ and related forms.
S.v. Arm. hur 'camp-fire', long since connected with PIE *péh₂-ur, *ph₂-uén-s 'fire' (cf. Hitt. paḫḫur, paḫḫuenaš 'fire', Gk. πῦρ, πυρός 'fire', OHG fuir, Goth. fon, OPr. panno 'fire', etc.).

Cf. s.v. Lat. pūr(i)gō, -āre 'to clean, clear', derived from Proto-Italic *pūr, *pun- 'fire' (cf. U. pir 'fire'), from PIE *péh₂-ur, *ph₂-uén-s 'fire' (cf. Hitt. pahhur / pahhuen- 'fire, embers, fever', Gk. πῦρ, πυρός, Arm. howr, Goth. fon, TochA por, B puwār).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fōr ~ *fun- 'fire', from PIE *péh₂-ur, *ph₂-uén-s (cf. Hitt. paḫḫur, paḫḫuenaš 'fire', Gk. πῦρ 'id.', Arm. hur 'id.', OPr. panno 'id.').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *ogņь 'fire' (ESSJa XXXII 30-33), from PIE *h₁ngʷ-ni- (cf. Lith. ungnìs, Latv. unguns, Skt. agní-, Lat. ignis).

S.v. Lat. ignis 'fire', from PIE *h₁ngʷ-ni- 'fire' (cf. Skt. agní- 'fire', Lith. ugnìs, OCS ognjь, Skt. áṅgāra- 'coal', Sogd. ʾnkʾyr 'hearth', Arm. acowl 'coal', Lith. anglìs, Latv. ùogle, OCS ǫglь 'coal').
S.v. Lith. ugnìs 'fire' (Latv. uguns), from PIE *h₁ngʷ-ni- (cf. Skt. agní- 'fire; Agni', Lat. ignis 'fire', OCS ognь).

S.v. HONEY *mélit (gen. mlitós) 'honey'. We are dealing with an inherited stem *melit-, cf. OIr. mil 'honey', W. mêl 'honey', Lat. mel 'honey', OE mildēaw 'mildew' (< *'sweet sap') (> NE mildew), Goth. miliϸ 'honey', Alb. bletë (< *melitih₂ 'honey-bee'), Gk. μέλι 'honey', μέλισσα (< *melitih₂) 'honey-bee' Arm. mełr 'honey', Hitt. militt- 'honey', Luw. mallit- 'honey'.
S.v. Khw. δy, δyn n.f. 'woman', cf. Av. daēnu-, Skt. dhenu- 'milk-giving'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. dhenú- 'Kuh, Milchkuh, weibliches Tier' (YAv. daēnu- f. 'weibliches Tier, Weibchen'), cf. Khot. dīnū 'Kuh', MPers. dēnōdag 'female, milch', Khw. δy(n) 'Frau'), derived from Ved. √dhay-ⁱ¹ 'saugen, Muttermilch trinken', derived to PIE *dʰeh₁- (cf. Ved. √dhā-, Gk. θηλή 'Mutterbrust', Lat. felāre 'saugen, etc.').
Cf. s.v. *dʰeh₁(i̯)- '(Muttermilch) saugen' (IEW 241-2).

S.v. Hitt. *kuu̯an- 'woman' (Anatolian cognates: CLuw. u̯ānā- 'woman', u̯(a)natti- 'woman'; HLuw. FEMINA-nat(i)- 'woman', Lyd. kãna- 'wife'). It is quite obvious that the other Anatolian cognates are cognate with other words like Gk. γυνή, Skt. jánis (gen.sg. gnā́s), OIr. ben (gen.sg. mná), OCS žena, etc. 'woman' that reflect *gʷen-h₂, *gʷn-éh₂-s.

S.v. Arm. kin (GDSg.knoǰ) 'woman, wife', from PIE *gʷén-(e)h₂-, gen. gʷn-éh₂-s 'woman' (cf. Skt. jáni- 'woman, wife', OAv. jə̄ni- 'woman, wife', YAv. jaini- 'woman, wife', MPers., NPers. zan 'wife', Parth. jn 'wife', OAv. gənā 'woman', YAv. γənā 'woman', Gk. γυνή (gen. γυναικός, Boeot. βανά 'wife, woman', OIr. ben, mná 'woman, wife', Goth. qino 'wife', OCS žena 'woman, wife', Luw. wana- 'woman', TochA śäṃ, B śana 'woman, wife' vs. TochA kᵤli, B klīye 'woman', etc.).

S.v. Ved. jáni- 'Weib, Frau' (IIr. cf. OAv. ǰə̄ni-, YAv. jaini- 'Weib, Frau', Parth. jn, MPers. NPers. zan 'Frau, Gattin', etc.), from PIE *gʷénh₂-, originally in paradigmatic ablaut with *gʷnéh₂- (> Ved. gnā́-, cf. EWAia I:504).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *žena 'woman, wife', from PIE *gʷen-eh₂- (cf. OPr. genno 'woman', Skt. jáni- 'woman, wife', Goth. qino 'woman', OIr. ben 'woman', etc.).
S.v. OPr. genno 'woman', from PIE *gʷen-eh₂- (cf. Proto-Slavic *ženà 'woman, wife', OCS žena 'woman', Skt. jáni- 'woman, wife', Goth. qino 'woman', OIr. ben 'woman', etc.).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *kwenōn- 'woman, wife', a Germanic ōn-stem based on a PIE proterodynamic h₂-stem (nom. *gʷén-h₂, gen. *gʷn-éh₂-s), cf. Skt. jáni- 'woman, wife', gnā́- 'goddess', OCS žena, Lith. ženà, OPr. genno 'woman', Arm. kin 'id.', Gk. γυνή, gen. γυναικός 'id.', OIr. ben, gen. mná 'id.', etc.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *benā, *bena 'woman', from PIE *gʷenh₂ 'woman' (cf. Skt. jáni-, gnā́, Gk. γυνή, CLuw. wānā-, OE cwen, OPr. genno, ToB śana, OCS žena).
Cf. s.v. Lith. vė́jas 'wind' (Latv. vẽjš 'wind') from PIE *h₂ueh₁-iu- (cf. Skt. vāyú- 'wind, air, god of the wind').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *winda- 'wind', from PIE *h₂uéh₁-ent-o- (cf. Hitt. huu̯ant- 'wind' < *h₂uh₁-ent-; TochA want, wänt, TochB yente 'wind', Lat. ventus, W. gwynt < *h₂ueh₁-(e)nt-o-, Skt. vā́ta-, OAv., YAv. vāta-, NPers. bād, Oss. wad / wad(æ) < *h₂ueh₁-nt-o-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'roof, air', a *-tu- stem related to *lauba- 'leaf, foliage'. No clear IE etymology.
Cf. s.v. Goth. L58. *luftus 'ἀήρ', 'air'. Etymology unclear.
Cf. s.v. 8370 Skt. pr̥ṣṭí-, °ṭī́ – f. 'vertebrae' RV., AV., 'back' & 8371 Skt. pr̥ṣṭhá- n. 'back, hinder part'.

S.v. Ved. pr̥ṣtí- 'Rippe' (cf. IIr. in YAv. paršti-, etc. with full-grade), not to be separated from Ved. párśu- 'Rippe', connections outside of IIr. are uncertain. Possibly IE *perk̑- if to be connected with OCS prьsi 'breast'.

NB: Cognacy in this class follows the judgement of Mayrhofer EWAia II:165-166 that the forms in Iranian and Middle Indic from PIIr. *p(a)ršti- are etymologically unrelated. However, cf. Turner (1962-1966:474), where the hypothesis that some of the Middle Indic forms in /cognate/6354/ class may in fact continue Ved. pr̥ṣṭhá- < possibly from *pr̥-sth₂-ó- rather than PIIr. *pr̥štī̆- (of uncertain etymology).
Regarding the Middle Indic and Iranian lexemes in /cognate/6354/, cf. s.v. 8370 Skt. pr̥ṣṭí-, °ṭī́ – f. 'vertebrae' RV., AV., 'back' & 8371 Skt. pr̥ṣṭhá- n. 'back, hinder part'.
S.v. Alb. bark, -u 'belly, womb, abdomen', following Meyer (1891:27) to PIE *bʰer- 'carry'.

The only plausible etymology outside of Anatolian is the proposed connection with Armenian argand 'womb' with the proviso that the Armenian sound laws permit it ({ref Čop 1955}, cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:733), but this proposal rejected by {ref Martirosyan 2010}:130-131.
For Nepali, cf. s.v. 13776 sthūlá 'large, thick, stout' AV. [~ sthūrá-].
S.v. Lith. stóras 'thick, fat', from PIE *steh₂-ro- (cf. Proto-Slavic *starъ 'old' > OCS starъ, etc., OIc. stórr 'big' < *steh₂uro-).
S.v. Ved. sthūra- 'groß, stark, dick, wuchtig' < PIE *stuh₂-ró- (cf. Old Swedish stūr 'groß', Middle Dutch stūr 'groß, stark').
S.v. Arm. ստուար stvar 'dick', an inherited word. Cf. Skt. sthávira- 'breit, dick, massig', sthūra- 'dick, breit', etc.
Cf. s.v. Goth. M35 mats 'βρῶσις', 'food'. Etymology uncertain.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *bruson- 'abdomen, womb', from PIE *breu̯s- 'belly'(?), cf. OE breost 'breast', Russ. brjúxo 'belly, paunch'. Proto-Celtic *bruson- is an n-stem derived from the zero-grade of the PIE root (*bʰrus-on-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bolgo- 'sack, bag, stomach', from PIE *bʰolg̑ʰ- 'skin bag, bolster' (cf. Av. barəziš 'bolster, cushion', OE belg 'stomach', OPr. balsinis 'cushion').
PS *kǫsati, derived from PS *kǫd-. It has no certain further etymology beyond the Balto-Slavic.
Proto-Slavic *xapati. The root has an ideophonic origin and no reasonable further etymology can be given.
S.v. 2854 Skt. kártati (1) 'cuts'.
S.v. Ved. √kart-¹ 'schneiden, abschneiden, spalten, brechen', from PIE *(s)kert- (cf. OHG scrinden 'sich spalten', Lith. kertù 'fälle, haue', RuCS črěsti 'schneiden', etc.).

S.v. Proto-Iranian *kart-¹ 'to cut', from PIE *(s)ker-t- 'to cut' (cf. Skt. kart- 'to cut (off)', Arm. kʻertʻem 'I skin', Lith. kertù (kir̃sti) 'I hew, hit', Latv. cḕrtu (cìrst) 'I hew, hack', Alb. qeth 'to shave').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tęti 'cut, chop, beat', from PIE *tmh₁- (cf. Lith. tìnti 'whet', Gk. τέμνω 'cut').
Cf. s.v. Ved. √kart-¹ 'schneiden, abschneiden, spalten, brechen', from PIE *(s)kert- (cf. OHG scrinden 'sich spalten', Lith. kertù 'fälle, haue', RuCS črěsti 'schneiden', etc.).

S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaz-? 'to bite, sting'. An exclusively Iranian root, only attested from Middle Iranian onwards. Earlier suggestions by Korn (2005:80fn27) deriving from PIE *geg̑ʰ- 'to enter, seep in', Skt. gāh-) and Bailey (1979:349a) to PIE *g̑eg̑⁽ʰ⁾- are semantically (Korn), or formally (Bailey) unconvincing.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. karš(ii̯e/a)- 'to cut (off), to separate; to stop' (Anatolian cognates: CLuw. karš- 'to cut', Lyd. fa-karse- 'to cut (out)'), from PIE *kers- (Hitt. forms reflect PIE *krs-i̯é/o-), cf. TochAB kärs- 'to know', Gk. κείρω 'to cut', Lith. skìrti 'to divide', etc.

S.v. TochB kärst- 'cut off, cut down, terminate; tear; destroy utterly', which with TochA kärṣt- reflect PToch *kärst-, from PIE *kers-T-, a derivative of PIE *kers- 'cut off' (cf. Hitt. kars-/karsiya- 'cut off, mutilate', CLuw. kars- 'cut off', etc.).
S.v. TochB kärst-, TochA kärṣt- 'abschneiden, zerstören', 'cut off, destroy', a denominative verb to an abstract in *-teh₂- from PIE *kers- '(ab)schneiden'.
S.v. Ru. резать, режу 'schneide, schlachte', to be connected with Lith. rė́žti, rė́žiu 'schneide, ritze', Gk. ῥήγνυμι 'breche'.
S.v. Arm. tiw 'day', from PIE *dieus 'heaven, day, Sky-God' (cf. Skt. dyau-, Gk. Ζεύς, Lat. diēs, etc.).

For Middle and Modern Indic forms in this class, cf. s.v. Ved. dyav- 'Himmel, Himmelsgott, Vater Himmel, Tag', from PIE *di̯éu̯-/diu̯- 'Himmel, Tag' (also personified 'Himmelsgott'), (cf. Gk. Ζεύς, Lat. *dius in nudius tertius 'vorgestern' < *'und es ist der dritte Tag', from the root *dei̯- 'leuchten'; and s.v. madhyámdina- 'Mittag, Mittagszeit' for °dina- (only attested in compounds in the RV) < *di-n- derived from the more basic root *dei̯- (cf. Lat. nūn-dinum 'Frist von neun Tagen, Marktzeit', perendinus 'übermorgig', OCS (G.sg.) dьn-e 'des Tages').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dьnь 'day' (ESSJa V 213-214), from PIE *d(e)i-n- (cf. Lith. dienà, Latv. dìena, OPr. deinan, Skt. -dina-, Lat. diēs).
S.v. Lith. dienà 'day' (Latv. dìena), from PIE *d(e)i-n- (cf. OCS dьnь, Skt. -dina-, Lat. diēs 'day').

S.v. Lat. diēs, diēi 'day, daytime', from PIE *di-eu- 'God of the clear sky, Clear Sky', cf. Lat. Iū-piter from PIE *diēus (cf. OIr. dïe 'day', Hitt. šiu- 'god', Skt. dyáv- 'heaven, god of the sky', Gk. Ζεύς 'Zeus', Arm. tiw 'day(-time)'; OCS dъždь 'rain' < *dus-diu- 'bad-sky') + *ph₂tēr 'father'
S.v. Proto-Celtic *dīy(w)o- 'day', from PIE *dii̯-eu̯- 'day' (cf. Lat. diēs, Arm. tiw).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *latyo- 'day', from PIE *leh₁t- 'warm part of the year(?)' (IEW 680), cf. OCS lěto 'year', Croat. ljȅto 'summer', Swed. (dial.) låding 'spring'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *lě̀to n. 'summer' (ESSJa XV 8-12), from PIE *leh₁-tóm (cf. OIr. laithe n. 'day').

While the cognacy of the Slavic and Celtic lexemes is not in dispute, the morphological segmentation of the root is less clear. We may be dealing with either an inherited t-stem to a root *leh₁- or a root *leh₁t- with a final dental. Either solution is plausible and both root forms are permissible to IE root structure constraints. The potential additional evidence from dialectal Swedish låding 'spring' (cf. s.v. låding in the Svensk Akademiens Ordbok: https://www.saob.se/artikel/?seek=l%C3%A5ding&pz=2, cf. Old Gutnish laϸigs) does not help settle this matter. {ref LIV²} *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen' ({ref IEW} 666, 682-3) does not seem a semantically convincing candidate for a root etymology, nor is there a comparable verbal root *leh₁t- attested. {ref Derksen 2008}:274-275 reconstructs *leh₁-tom underlying Proto-Slavic *lě̀to, while {ref Matasović 2009}:233-234 reconstructs *leh₁ti-/leh₁ti̯o- to a basic root *leh₁t-. For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form that is compatible with both the Slavic words meaning 'year' and the Celtic words meaning 'day', I give *leh₁t- as a the basic root.

While the cognacy of the Slavic and Celtic lexemes is not in dispute, the morphological segmentation of the root is less clear. We may be dealing with either an inherited t-stem to a root *leh₁- or a root *leh₁t- with a final dental. Either solution is plausible and both root forms are permissible to IE root structure constraints. The potential additional evidence from dialectal Swedish låding 'spring' (cf. s.v. låding in the Svensk Akademiens Ordbok: https://www.saob.se/artikel/?seek=l%C3%A5ding&pz=2, cf. Old Gutnish laϸigs) does not help settle this matter. {ref LIV²} *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen' ({ref IEW} 666, 682-3) does not seem a semantically convincing candidate for a root etymology, nor is there a comparable verbal root *leh₁t- attested. {ref Derksen 2008}:274-275 reconstructs *leh₁-tom underlying Proto-Slavic *lě̀to, while {ref Matasović 2009}:233-234 reconstructs *leh₁ti-/leh₁ti̯o- to a basic root *leh₁t-. For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form that is compatible with both the Slavic words meaning 'year' and the Celtic words meaning 'day', I give *leh₁t- as a the basic root.
Cf. s.v. Ved. bhānú- 'Licht, Strahl, Erscheinung, Glanz' (cf. Av. bānu- 'Lichtstrahl', Oss. bon 'Tag', etc.), to √bhā- < PIE *bʰeh₂- (cf. Gk. φάε 'leuchtete auf, erschien', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, erscheinen' (IEW 104-5).

NB: In LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda Hitt. u̯alḫ- 'schlagen' (s.v. *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' in LIV²) is separated toa new root *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen', and the Luwic forms (CLuw. walant-/ulant- 'tot', HLuw. wa-la/i- 'sterben', Lyc. lati 'stirbt') are assigned to *u̯elh₃- with an updated root gloss 'sterben'. Note, however, this root assignment is provisional, as the Proto-Luwic form could also formally reflect *gʷelH-.
S.v. 1. *(s)kep- 'hacken, hauen' (IEW 931-2).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kopati 'dig' (ESSJa XI 18-20), from PIE *(s)kop- (cf. Lith. kapóti 'chop, hew', Latv. kapât 'chop, hew', Gk. κόπτω 'beat, hit').
Perhaps the IIr. verbs in from *kʷer- in LIV² could also be with 2. *(s)ker- 'scheren, kratzen, abschneiden'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *garwjan- 'to prepare, make ready'. A factitive verb from PGmc. *garwa- 'ready, quick', in turn probably a prefixed variant of *arwa- < *ga-arwa-. If so, (cf. s.v. *arwa- 'ready, fast') then (as though) from PIE *h₂/₃er-u̯o- and close to TochA ārwar, TochB ārwer 'ready' < PToch. *arwer < *h₂/₃er-ur-. Formally, the root of *arwa- could be either *h₂er- 'order, arrange, fit', or *h₃er- 'set in motion'.

S.v. εὐθύς 'straight'. Etymology obscure; there are no known correspondences outside of Greek. "It may have taken the place of ἱθύς 'id.'. Perhaps a cross of εἶθαρ and ἰθύς with assimilation ει : υ > ευ : υ". DELG suggests influence of εὖ 'good'.
S.v. 4159 *girati (1) 'drips, falls'.
S.v. Ved. hyás 'gestern', from PIE *g̑ʰdi̯és- (cf. NPers. dī, dīg, Oss. znon/æzinæ, Gk. χθές, Lat. heri, OHG gesteren, etc.).

S.v. Lat. heri 'yesterday', from PIE *g̑ʰ-di-es 'yesterday' (cf. OIr. indé, MW doe, OCo. doy < PCl. *γdes(i?), Ved. hyás, Bal. zī, zīk, Oss. znon / æzinæ < IIr. *j́ʰias, Gk. χθές, Alb. dje, OIc. í gær 'yesterday', Goth. gistra-dagis 'tomorrow', OE giestron, OHG gesteron 'yesterday' < *g̑ʰes-t(e)ra-). "It has been suggested that the original PIE form was *g̑ʰ-di-es 'at that day' with the pronominal stem *g̑ʰe/o- and the gen.sg. of *di- 'day', the stem possibly reflected in Skt. sadyáḥ 'within one day'. The zero-grade of the pronoun *g̑ʰe/o- would then be a very archaic trait of the compounds. In simplifying the initial cluster *g̑ʰdi̯-, most languages have ousted one of the two stops."
S.v. PIE *g̑ʰés- 'gestern' Adverb, temporal. Cf. for extensive discussion of attempted reconstructions underlying the lexemes in this class.

The cognacy of the lexemes in this class is not disputed, however there remains much disagreement in the literature how the forms are derived in the attested languages from a common reconstruction. The two most commonly held hypotheses include (1) derivations related to the Germanic word for 'day' (cf. /cognate/200/, not without its own problems in derivation) as *dʰg̑ʰ-i̯es- (zero-grade root + comparative suffix or endingless locative) or (2) a compound of the Indo-European deictic *g̑ʰo- ~ *g̑ʰ- (cf. LIPP 2 275-276) in the zero-grade + the root *dei̯- ~ *di- 'shine' (NIL 69-81, cf. esp. fn6), which underlies words for day in many other branches (cf. /cognate/375/). For a recent extensive discussion of these and other hypotheses, cf. LIPP 2 269-270. For the root ref. form in this class, I follow LIPP 2 for a reconstruction *g̑ʰés- as the basic particle from which the attested forms are derived.
Cf. s.v. *dei̯-, *di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f., EIEC 513), specifically under the potentially derived form ?*(g̑ʰ)-di̯-es and discussion contained in footnotes 6-18.

Cf. s.v. 1. *u̯é 'weg, ab; ohne'. A reconstructed compound *u̯é-kʷsp-ero- 'Abend' is commonly assumed to underlie Gk. ἕσπερος, Lat. vesper, MW ucher, ?PGmc. *u̯est(r)ō, Arm. gišer, OCS večerŭ, Lith. vãkaras, etc. (although LIPP rejects this reconstruction). Cf. p.843n20 for extensive references to further literature.
S.v. Lith. vãkaras 'evening' (Latv. vakars 'evening'), from PIE *uekspero- (cf. OCS večerъ, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lat. vesper, MW ucher).

Cf. s.v. 1. *u̯é 'weg, ab; ohne'. A reconstructed compound *u̯é-kʷsp-ero- 'Abend' is commonly assumed to underlie Gk. ἕσπερος, Lat. vesper, MW ucher, ?PGmc. *u̯est(r)ō, Arm. gišer, OCS večerŭ, Lith. vãkaras, etc. (although LIPP rejects this reconstruction). Cf. p.843n20 for extensive references to further literature.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √car-ⁱ 'sich bewegen, wandeln, gehen, wandern, fahren', from PIE *kʷel(H)- (cf. Gk. πέλομαι, Lat. colō, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-) wenden' (IEW 639-40).
S.v. Lat. amārus 'bitter', possibly from PIE *h₂h₃m-ro-? (cf. Skt. amlá- 'sour, acid', OIc. apr 'sharp, cold', etc.). Some morphological details remain unclear.
S.v. Sp. amarillo, from hispanic Latin amarĕllus 'amarillento, pálido' the diminutive of Lat. amārus 'amargo'.
Luw. ḫa-aḫ-ḫa-lu-u̯a-an-ti-[ "Prob. cognate of Hitt. word, pace HW² 3.7."
S.v. sarí 'gelbsüchtig' (geg.) from Turk. sarε 'gelb'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *frauja(n)- 'lord'. Unclear etymology. "The assumed etymological link with Skt. pū́rva- adj. 'front, first', YAv. pauruua-, paouruua-, pouruua- adj. 'being in front, first, former', OCS prъvъ 'first' < *prH-uo- is problematic, since the full-grade form *proHu-io- would yield PGm. **frōjan- (with *-ōu- giving -ō-) rather than *fraujan-."

Cf. s.v. *pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft. mit Abl. PGmc. *frau̯i̯a- 'vorderer; Herr' (ON Freyr m., Freyja f.; OHG frouwa 'Herrin, Frau', Goth. frauja 'Herr < *frau̯i̯an-), commonly assumed to be a derivation in *-u̯o- to PIE *pro- 'forwards, ahead'.

Traditionally derived from PIE *pro-u̯o-, remodelled in PGmc. as *frau̯i̯a- 'the one in front, lord' (cf. {ref NIL} 645, {ref Kluge 2011}:314). Doubted by {ref Kroonen 2013}:153) on account of phonological difficulties. Consequently only a Proto-Germanic root ref. form has been assigned for this class, but cf. the standard handbooks for their arguments for or against positing an IE proto-form.
Cf. s.v. Goth. F87. frauja 'κύριος, δεσπότης', 'lord', from PIE *prō- + -wo- (cf. Skt. pū́rvas, Av. paurva-, etc.).

S.v. woman, originally a compound formed within the history of English from wīf 'woman, female' + mann 'person' (OE wīf-mann). [Cf. etymological notes in OED for further discussion on this word's development and chronology throughout Middle and Modern English.]

S.v. Proto-Germanic *wība- 'woman, wife'. "No clear etymology. Some have connected the word to Go. bi-waibjan, OE wǣfan w.v. 'to cover, wrap', assuming that the primary meaning was a 'veiled woman'. The connection with To A kip, ToB kwipe 'shame; modesty' (Schmidt/Strunk 1989) is possible, too, but requires a considerable semantic shift."
Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².
Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².

S.v. Proto-Germanic *feϸrō- 'feather', from a heteroclitic stem *péth₂-r/n- from the PIE root *peth₂- 'to fly' (cf. Skt. pátra- < *peth₂-ro-; Gk. πτερόν < *pt(h₂)-er-o-, Lat. penna 'feather' < *peth₂-n-eh₂-, OW atar 'bird', MW adar 'id.' < *pth₂-r-; OIr. én 'bird', W. edn 'id.' < *peth₂-no-).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *fatar, gen. *fatanos, *fetnos 'wing, bird', from PIE *potr / *ptn-os 'wing' (cf. Hitt. pattar, Skt. pátra-, Gk. πτερόν, Lat. penna).
Cf. s.v. Ved. pátra- 'Flügel (eines Vogels), Feder', from an old heteroclitic (*pat-r- / *pat-n-), cf. NHG Feder, OW eterin, 'Vogel', atan 'Flügel', etc.

S.v. Lith. spar̃nas 'wing' (Latv. spā̀rns 'wing'), from PIE *perH-o- (cf. Skt. parṇá- 'wing', OE fearn 'fern', OIr. raith 'fern'). The reconstruction of the laryngeal is based on the acute of forms such as Lith. papártis and Latv. papãrde.

S.v. Ved. parṇá- 'Flügel, Feder, Pfeilfeder, Blatt' (IIr. cf. YAv. parəna- 'Feder', Khot. pārra- 'Flügel', MPers., NPers. parr 'Feder', etc.), probably from PIE *(s)por-no- (cf. OHG farn 'Farn', Lith. spar̃nas 'Flügel, Schaufel, Blatt').
S.v. Ved. pakṣá- 'Flügel, Fittich, Schwinge' (Ind. Pā. pakkha- 'Flügel, Seite', pakkin- 'Vogel', etc.). Further connections remain unclear.
S.v. 7627 pakṣá- m. 'wing, feather, fin, shoulder, side'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *damH-³ 'to blow, breathe; to swell', from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. Skt. dham-ⁱ 'to blow, play a wind instrument, fan the fire', OCS dъmǫ 'to blow', Lith. dùmti 'to blow (also of wind)'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen' OCS dъmǫ, etc.).

S.v. Ved. urú- 'weit, umfängreich, breit, gegräumig' (IIr. cf. YAv. vouru- in compounds, e.g. vouru.dōiθra- 'dessen Augen weithin gehen', Oss. urux, etc.), from PIE *u̯r̥H-ú- (~ *u̯erH- in váras-, *u̯erH-ú- in Gk. εὐρύς 'weit, breit', etc.).
S.v. O. uruvú 'breit', from PIt. *urvo-/-ā, which was remodelled as an o-stem from PIE *ə₁ur-u- 'breit' (cf. Ved. urú-, Gk. εὐρύς 'breit').
Cf. s.v. urvum / urbum 'curved part of a plough', under which discussion of Osc. uruvú is given. O. uruvú, if meaning 'broad' could belong to PIE *h₁urHú- 'broad'.

S.v. TochB aurtstse ~ wartstse 'broad, wide', which with TochA wärts 'id.' reflect Proto-Tocharian *wärtse. The more commonly found TochB aurtstse is a compound of this proto-form + *en-. The PIE antecedents of this form are not completely clear. Two main possibilities: (1) Van Windekens takes the word to be the equivalent of Skt. vr̥ddhá- 'enlarged, augmented, big', but the past participle of the root vr̥dh- is only known from Indo-Iranian. Alternatively (2) Sieg, Siegling, & Schulze connect with Sanskrit váras- 'width, breadth, expanse, space', urú- 'broad, wide'.
S.v. Gk. πλατύς 'wide, broad, flat, level', from PIE *pl̥th₂-ú- 'broad' and identical to Skt. pr̥thú-, Av. pərəθu- 'wide, broad' (root *pleth₂-).
S.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (LIV 486f., IEW 833).
Cf. s.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (IEW 833).
Arm. layn 'wide' < *pl̥th₂ni- (cf. Gk. πλάτανος, OIr. lethan).

S.v. Lith. platùs 'broad, wide' (Latv. plašs 'broad, wide', var. plats), from PIE *plth₂-u- (Skt. pr̥thú- 'wide, broad', Av. pərəθu- 'wide, broad', Gk. πλατύς 'wide, broad, flat, level'). Baltic apparently has an o-grade in this adjective.

S.v. Ved. pr̥thú- 'breit, weit, ausgedehnt groß, zahlreich, umfänglich' (cf. IIr. OAv. pərəθu- 'breit, weit'), from PIE *plth₂-ú- (cf. Gk. πλατύς 'weit, breit, flach, eben', Lith. platùs 'weit, breit, ausgedehnt', etc.).

p.179 "práthas- n. Weite, Breite, Ausdehnung [...] Iir., jav. fraϑah- n. "Breite" - Idg. *pléth₂-es-"
S.v. 12011 Skt. vistr̥ta 'spread, expanded, wide' MBh. [√str̥].
Cf. s.v. Ved. √star-ⁱ 'ausbreiten, streuen', from PIE *sterh₃- (cf. Gk. ἐστόρεσα 'habe ausgebreitet', Lat. sternere, 'hinbreiten', OIr. sernaid 'breitet aus', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *sterh₃- 'hinbreiten, ausbreiten' (IEW 1029-30).

S.v. Arm. լայն lain 'breit', an inherited word (cf. Skt. pr̥thú- 'breit, weit', práthate 'breitet sich aus', práthas- 'Breite, Ausdehnung', Av. fraθah- 'Breite', Gk. πλατύς 'breit', πλάτος 'Breite', Lith. platùs 'breit', OIr. lethan, W. litan 'breit').

S.v. Lith. báltas 'white' (Latv. bal̃ts 'white'), from PIE *bʰolH-to- (cf. PSl. *bòlto 'swamp', Alb. baltë 'mud, swamp', Mod.Gk. βάλτος 'swamp', Rom. baltă 'mud, swamp'). For the semantics cf. Lith. balà 'swamp' = PSl. bělъ 'white'.
Cf. s.v. 3116 *kāśira 'bright', kāśíla -- Pāṇ., kāśin -- MBh. [√kāś].
S.v. 12520 Skt. śuddhá- 'clean, bright, white'.
S.v. Ved. √śodh- 'reinigen, rein machen'. IIr. *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ- perhaps from PIE *(s)k̑eu̯-dʰ- with a root enlargement of *(s)k̑eu̯-, but connections outside IIr. otherwise unclear.
Cf. s.v. ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'rein werden' (IEW 595); only Indo-Iranian cognates.

Cf. s.v. Ved. śukrá- 'klar, licht, hell, lauter, weiß, weißlich' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. suxra- 'rot, feuerfarben', OPers. θuxra-, MPers. suxr, Oss. syrx/surx 'rot', etc.). Derived to √soć-, possibly from PIE *k̑eu̯k- (connections outside of IIr. uncertain).
Cf. s.v. 1. *k̑eu̯k- 'aufflammen, erglühen' (IEW 597). Only Indo-Iranian, probably not to be connected with Gk. κύκνος 'Schwan' as 'der leuchtend Weiße'.
Cf. s.v. 1. *k̑eu̯k- 'aufflammen, erglühen' (IEW 597). Only Indo-Iranian, probably not to be connected with Gk. κύκνος 'Schwan' as 'der leuchtend Weiße'.
S.v. 1670 Skt. ujjvala- 'blazing up, bright, clean' [~ *ujjvara -- : √jval].
Cf. s.v. Ved. √jvar-ⁱ 'leiden', under which also √jval-ⁱ 'brennen' "synchron/semantisch verschieden, aber sicherlich gleichen Ursprungs (vgl. 'brennen' ~ 'schmerzen, leiden' in √tap-, √śoc-).
Cf. s.v. *g̑u̯elH- 'brennen, flammen' [IEW 479].
S.v. Arm. ճերմակ čermak 'weiss', a loan from Iranian (cf. NPers. čarma 'equus albus').
Cf. s.v. Hitt. u̯ida- (gender unclear) 'water', cf. CLuw. u̯ida- 'wet', from PIE *u̯ed-o-.
S.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', from PIE *uod-r/n-.
S.v. Ved. jála- 'Wasser, Naß' (Mi. pā. jala-, hi. jal 'Wasser', etc.). Etymology unclear.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √snā- 'baden, sich waschen', from PIE *(s)neh₂- (cf. Lat. nāre, 'schwimmen', OIr. snām 'das Schwimmen', TochB nāsk- 'sich Baden', Hitt. sanh- 'ausspülen', etc.).

S.v. Gk. πλύνω 'to wash, clean', from PIE *pleu- 'flow, swim'. The vowel length in πλῡ́νω points to a thematized nasal present < *πλύ-ν-ι̯ω, an inner-Greek formation from the root *plu- (cf. πλέω < *pleu-e/o-). A nasal present of the same meaning is also found in Armenian lua-na-m 'to wash, bathe'.
S.v. Arm. luanam 'to wash; to bathe', most commonly derived from PIE *pleu- 'to wash' (cf. Gk. πλύνω 'to wash, to clean', Skt. plávate 'to float, swim', Lith. pláuti 'to rinse, wash off' etc.).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *nig-yo- 'to wash', from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'wash' (cf. Skt. nij-, Gk. νίζω, νίπτω).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √kṣod- 'zerstieben' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. xšusta- 'geschmolzen, flüssig (vom Metall)', MPers., NPers. šustan 'waschen', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'zerstieben, in kleine Teile zerfallen' (IEW 625). [Verbal only IIr.]
Cf. s.v. *k̑leu̯H- 'reinigen' (IEW 607).

S.v. TochB lik- 'wash', which with TochA lik- reflect Proto-Tocharian *läik-, probably from PIE *u̯lei̯kʷ- 'liquid' (cf. Lat. liquēre 'be clear, liquid', Lat. liquāre 'clarify, filter, clarify', OIr. fliuch 'humid').
S.v. Lith. mazgóti 'wash' (Latv. mazgât 'wash'), from PIE *mosg- (cf. Skt. májjati 'sink', Lat. mergere 'plunge').
S.v. Goth. Ϸ63. ϸwahan 'νίπτειν', 'wash'. No etymology.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *waskan- 'to wash', a ske-present derived from *watar- ~ *watan- 'water' (< *uod-r/n-).

S.v. Gm. *wask-a- 'waschen'. Germanic *wask-a- 'waschen' has no clear possibilities for comparison. The connection taken up by dictionaries to wet- 'Wasser' is wholly improbable on the basis of morphological grounds ("aus morphologischen Gründen völlig unwahrscheinlich").
S.v. 6803 Skt. dhā́vati (2) 'rinses, washes, polishes' RV. 2. dhāvayati (2) 'washes' Mn. 3. dhāvita -- 'purified' MBh. [√ dhāv2]. For Pāli cf. no. 6886 *dhauvati 'washes' SV.
S.v. Ved. √dhav-ⁱ 'schütteln, rasch hin und herbewegen, erschüttern', from PIE *dʰeu̯H- (cf. ON dȳja 'schütteln', prob. also Gk. θυνέω 'stürme, bewege mich schnell', θῡ́νω 'tobe, wüte').
Cf. s.v. *dʰeu̯H- 'rasch hin und her bewegen, schütteln' (IEW 261-3).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *pьrati (II) 'beat, trample, wash', from PIE *pr̥- (cf. Skt. pŕ̥t- 'battle, strife, fight').
S.v. ON vaska 'waschen', probably a borrowing from Middle Low German waschen.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. lāḫu-, laḫu- 'to pour, to cast (objects from metal); (intr.) to (over)flow' (Anat. cognates: CLuw. lā(ḫ)un(a)i- 'to wash', lū- 'to pour'). The Hitt. forms may be derived from PIE formations *lóh₂u-ei, *lh₂u-énti [but no cognates outside of Anatolian are given].
S.v. 3664 Skt. kṣálati 'flows' Dhātup. [~ kṣárati, *jharati, *jhalati. -- √kṣal]. (> K. chalun 'to wash')
S.v. Ved. √kṣal- 'abwaschen', a l-variant from √kṣar- 'fließen, strömen', probably from PIE *dʰgʷʰer- (old: *gʷʰþer-) to Gk. φθείρω 'vernichte, zerstöre', etc.
Cf. s.v. *gʷg̑ʰer- 'im Wasser dahintreiben, fließen' (IEW 487-8), traditionally reconstructed as *gʷʰϸer-; cf. n1 for discussion of the root reconstruction.
Cf. s.v. ? 2. *leh₂- 'gießen' [IEW 692]. and s.v. *leu̯h₃- 'waschen' (IEW 692).

It is no longer necessary to postulate two separate roots *leh₂(u̯)- 'pour' for Anatolian and *leu̯h₃- for Italic and Albanian. The two roots can be reconciled to *leh₃u̯- (cf. Melchert 2011:127-132).

It is no longer necessary to postulate two separate roots *leh₂(u̯)- 'pour' for Anatolian and *leu̯h₃- 'wash' for Italic and Albanian. The two roots can be reconciled to *leh₃u̯- (cf. Melchert 2011:127-132). [Cf. discussion in cognate set for 'wash' in /cognate/8364/].
For root ref. form *leh₃u̯-, cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} and {ref Melchert 2011}:127-132.
Cf. s.v. *gʷg̑ʰer- 'im Wasser dahintreiben, fließen' (IEW 487-8), traditionally reconstructed as *gʷʰϸer-; cf. n1 for discussion of the root reconstruction.

The PIE root reflected in Gk. φθείρω is traditionally reconstructed as *gʷʰþer- with a 'thorn' cluster. The root ref. form follows the reconstruction of LIV² as *gʷg̑ʰer-. Cf. n1 s.v. *gʷg̑ʰer- in LIV² and Mayrhofer (1986:150-158) for discussion of the difficulties in reconstruction of the initial cluster.

The PIE root reflected in Ved. √kṣar- is traditionally reconstructed as *gʷʰþer- with a 'thorn' cluster. The root ref. form follows the reconstruction of LIV² as *gʷg̑ʰer-. Cf. n1 s.v. *gʷg̑ʰer- in LIV² and Mayrhofer (1986:150-158) for discussion of the difficulties in reconstruction of the initial cluster.
Cf. for extensive discussion of the 'thorn' cluster in the reconstruction of root initial cluster.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *renn-a- (< *ri-nw-) 'rinnen, laufen' for references to older literature.
S.v. Alb. véte 'gehen', to be derived from *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (LIV² 232f.), cf. extensive discussion in entry for argumentation.
S.v. Lith. eĩti 'go', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'go' (cf. OCS iti, Skt. éti, Gk. εἶμι, Lat. īre).
S.v. *gʰeh₁- 'kommen, gehen' [IEW 418-9, 1109]. Cf. Arm. gam 'komme', Gk. 3.sg. κιχήτην 'kamen heran'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *gēn- 'go', from PIE *g̑ʰeh₁- (cf. Skt. jáhāti 'to leave behind', OAv. auua-zazat̰ 3.pl.pres.inj. 'id.'; Gk. κίχημι 'to overtake, reach, arrive, meet' < *g̑ʰe/i-g̑ʰeh₁-.
Cf. s.v. *kʷi̯eu̯- 'sich in Bewegung setzen' (IEW 539).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √cyav- 'in Bewegung geraten, sich bewegen, unternehmen' (IIr. cf. OAv. š́iiauuāi, Parth. šw-/šd-, Khot. tsu-/tsuta- 'gehen' MPers., NPers. šudan 'gehen', etc.), from PIE *ki̯eu̯- (cf. Arm. čʻogan 'sie gingen', Gk. σεύομαι 'bin in heftiger Bewegung, laufe, stürme an').

Cf. s.v. Ved. √gam- 'sich bewegen, gehen, kommen' (IIr. cf. OAv. ǰamaitī, ǰimaitī), from IIr. *gam-/*ǰam-, from PIE *gʷom- ~ *gʷem- ~ *gʷm̥- (cf. Gk. βαίνω < *βάμ-ι̯ω, βάσκε < *gʷm̥-sk̑e- [= Ved. gáccha-, Av. ǰasa-], Lat. veniō 'komme', Goth. qiman, OE cuman, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *xoditi 'go, walk' (ESSJa VIII 48-49), from PIE *sod- (cf. Gk. ὁδεύω 'wander').
S.v. *sed- 'sich setzen' (IEW 884-7) with OCS xoditi 'go' given as a cognate assumed from a causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e-.
S.v. Sp. camino 'path', from Lat. cammīnus 'path', a loan from Celtic (cf. Ir. céimm). Sp. caminar 'walk' is an inner-Romance denominal form from this loanword.
S.v. Germ. *markôn (Old Frankish) 'bezeichnen' > Old French marchier 'fouler aux pieds, mettre le pied sur, piétiner'.

For Pāli, cf. s.v. 4686 Skt. cárati (1) 'moves', other modern Indic languages use derivatives from the √cal- root variant (cf. 4715 cálati 'goes away' MBh. 2. 'shakes, trembles' MBh. [~ cárati1. -- √cal], 4721 *calyati 'goes'. [√cal]).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √car-ⁱ 'sich bewegen, wandeln, gehen, wandern, fahren', from PIE *kʷel(H)- (cf. Gk. πέλομαι, Lat. colō, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-40).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hlaupan- 'to jump, leap', a strong verb back-formed to iterative *hluppōn- 'to run' < *klup-néh₂- (cf. Latv. klupinât 'keep stumbling' < *klup-neh₂-).
S.v. *kleu̯b- 'stolpern, hüpfen' [IEW 630]; cf. n1 *kleu̯p- with 'hardening' (Verhärtung) in certain contexts, partially paradigmatically generalised.
S.v. 5453 *ṭahall- 'walk up and down'.
Traditionally taken to reflect IE *kl̥-i̯e- (PIE *kel-); cf. Gk.  κέλλω 'drive; put to harbor'; Lat. celer 'fast'.
Cf. s.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273).
S.v. τρέχω 'to run, hurry', from IE *dʰregʰ- 'run' (cf. Gk. τροχός 'wheel', OIr. droch < *dʰrogʰ-o-).
Cf. s.v. AGk. (Dor.) τράχω 'laufen' > Tsakon. τ͡σάχου.
Cf. s.v. AGk. (Dor.) τράχω 'laufen' > Tsakon. τ͡σάχου.

S.v. Engl. walk (v.) "A merging of two distinct words: an Old English strong verb of Class VII (wealcan ), and an Old English weak verb of Class II (wealcian ), both cognate with Middle Dutch walken (weak verb) to knead, work with the hand, to press together, to full (cloth) (Dutch walken to knead, work with the hand, to full (cloth), (regional, reflexive) to roll), Middle Low German walken to knead, to full (cloth) (German regional (Low German) walken to knead, work with the hand, to full (cloth), to beat, thrash), Old High German walcan (strong verb) to press or mat together, to felt (attested only in past participle giwalcan , and in the prefixed form firwalcan , in the same sense; Middle High German walken (strong verb, later weak) to roll up, (reflexive) to roll, (transitive and intransitive) to move back and forth, to go (rare), to full (cloth), to beat, thrash, to fight, to stamp out, German walken (weak verb) to full (cloth), to beat, thrash, (regional) to move back and forth), Old Icelandic válka (weak verb) to toss about, to toy with, to ponder over, (reflexive) to wallow (Icelandic volka to rumple, mess up), Norwegian valke (weak verb) to full (cloth), Norwegian (Nynorsk) valka (weak verb) to press, squeeze, Old Swedish valka (weak verb) to roll (something) about (Swedish valka to full (cloth)), early modern Danish valcke (weak verb) to knead, work with the hand, to full (cloth) (Danish valke (weak verb) to full (cloth), (regional) to work with the hand, to roll (something) about, to beat, thrash), probably < the same Indo-European base as Sanskrit valg- to leap up and down, prance, flap, although the precise semantic connection is unclear."

S.v. 1. *u̯elg- 'sich rollend(?) bewegen' [IEW 1144]. OEng.(+) wealcan 'rollen; (aus)pressen, drücken' is listed as < ?*u̯é-u̯olg-/u̯l̥g- (thematisation of de-reduplicated *(u̯é-)u̯olg- to *u̯olg-e-).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *walkan- 'to roll'. The usual connection outside of Gmc. to Skt. válgati 'to move up and down, boil up, spring' < *uélg-e-(?) and Latv. val̃gs 'rope' < *uolg-o- (cf. LIV² 676), seems improbable in view of the intra-Germanic connection with *walk/gōn- 'to roll' (impers.) 'to be nauseated'. It may be possible that the underlying root *uelk- or *uelgʰ- can be an extension of *uelh₁- 'to roll'.
S.v. Khot. jsā- 'go', from Ir. *gā-, cf. Av. gā-, gātu-, OPers. gāθu-, to IEW 463 *gʷā- (Ved. jigāti, Gk. ἔβαν, Arm. kam, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *gʷeh₂- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten' (IEW 463-4).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √gā-¹ 'den Fuß aufsetzen (beim Gehen), treten, schreiten' (cf. IIr. OAv. gāt̰ 'soll hingehen', YAv. gāman- 'Schritt', Khot. jsā- 'gehen', etc.), from PIE *gʷeh₂- (cf. Gk. aor. ἔβην 'ging, machte sich auf', βῆμα 'Fußtritt, Schwelle', Lith. (dial.) góti 'gehen', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaH-¹ 'to go, move', from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to go, stride' (cf. Skt. gā- 'step, stride', Gk. ἔβην (aor.) 'was ready to go', etc.).

Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (IEW 438-9), where ?[air. -cing, cengait '(vorwärts) gehen, schreiten' is tentatively assigned to a thematic root present formation *g̑ʰéngʰ-e-, but cf. n3, only if Celt. *keng- is through dissimilation from earlier *geng-.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *keng-o- 'tread, step, walk', which Matasović argues to be from PIE *(s)keng- 'limp, walk lamely' (IEW 930) cf. Gk. σκάζω, OHG hinkan [s.v. LIV² *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'hinken', without Celtic cognates].
S.v. Lith. vémti 'vomit' (cf. Latv. vemt 'vomit'), from PIE *uemh₁- (cf. Skt. vámiti, Gk. ἐμέω, Lat. vomere).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *rygati 'belch', from PIE *h₁rug- (cf. Lith. ráugėti 'belch', Gk. ἐρεύγομαι 'belch out, disgorge, discharge, vomit, roar', Lat. rūgīre 'roar', ērūgere 'disgorge noisily, belch').

Arm. orcam 'to vomit' from *orucam vs. Gk. ἐρεύγομαι < PIE *h₁reug-. [Etymology only mentioned in the discussion of aspects of historical grammar. There is no dedicated lemma to Arm. orcam in Martirosyan (2010).]
Cf. s.v. *(h₁)reu̯g- 'rülpsen, erbrechen' (IEW 871). [Armenian and Slavic cognates not mentioned.]
Assumes a form PIE *pro-h₁rug- > *oruruc- > Arm. orc- to account for the initial vocalism of Arm. orcam.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *bļьvàti 'vomit' (ESSJa II 140-141), from PIE *bʰleuH- (cf. Gk. φλέω 'flow over', Lat. fluō 'flow').
1.*bʰleu̯H- 'overflow' with OCS bľujǫ, bľĭvati, Latin fluō, fluere, Greek φλέει etc. listed as cognates. Lithuanian bliáuju, bliáuti is given as a questionable cognate.

The forms in this class from Proto-Germanic *spīwan- are generally compared with similar verbs denoting 'to spit' found elsewhere among the Indo-European languages ({ref LIV²} 583-584, reconstructing *spti̯eu̯H-, cf. non-Jena 175 'spit' in /cognate/305/). Reconstructing a common IE root for these forms, however, is extremely difficult, as the forms in various branches likely underwent deformations or reformations among individual daughter languages due to onomatopoeia or phonotactic reasons. Within Germanic these forms are more-or-less regular from *spīwan- / *speiw-a- (cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:450-452, {ref Kroonen 2013}:468).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *spīwan 'to spit'. The Germanic forms almost unanimously point to *spīwan-; only štewwu in the Swiss dialect of Visperterminen points to *stīwan-.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *speiw-a- 'speien'.
Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.
Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².
Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)per- 'fliegen' [IEW 817, 850].
Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)per- 'fliegen' [IEW 817, 850].
S.v. TochB wi 'two', which with TochA wu- (m.) and we- (f.) reflect PIE *du̯ō(u) (m.) and *du̯oi (nt.).
S.v. Alb. dy 'two', from PAlb. *duwō, fem. duwai, reflexes from PIE *d(u)u̯ō(u), fem. *d(u)u̯oi.
S.v. Alb. dy 'zwei', without a doubt inherited from the PIE word for 'two'. Cf. for discussion of possibilities for the stem formation in Albanian.
S.v. Lith. dù, dvì 'two' (Latv. divi 'two', OPr. dwai 'two'), from PIE *duo-h₁, duo-ih₁ (*duo-i?) (cf. Skt. dvā́ 'two', Gk. δύω 'two').
S.v. *twa 'two', from PIE *duo-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *dwāw 'two', from PIE *du̯oh₁ 'two' (cf. Lat. duo, Skt. dvā́, Gk. δύω, OE tū, Lith. dù, OCS dъva, Arm. erku, TochB wi, Alb. dy).
S.v. Lith. trỹs 'three' (Latv. trîs 'three'), from PIE *trei-es (cf. OCS trije, Skt. tray- 'three', Gk. τρεῖς 'three', Lat. trēs).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *trьje; *tri 'three', from PIE *trei-es (cf. Lith. trỹs, Skt. tráyas, Gk. τρεῖς, Lat. trēs).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *þrī- 'three', from PIE *trei- (cf. TochA tre, f. tri, TochB trai, trey, tarya, Skt. tráyas, YAv. θrāiiō, Gk. τρεῖς, Lat. trēs, OIr. trí, tri, Lith. trỹs, OCS trьje, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *trīs 'three', from PIE *treyes 'three' (cf. Skt. tráyas, Lat. trēs, Gk. τρεῖς, Lith. trỹs, Goth. þrins [acc.pl.], OCS trьje, Alb. tre, TochB trai, Hitt. tri-).
Cf. for the contexts and interpretation of the Hittite lexeme.

S.v. TochB ku 'dog', which with TochA ku reflects *kŭwŭ from PIE *k̑úwō 'dog' (cf. Skt. ś(u)vā, Arm. šun, Gk. κύων, Lat. canis, OIr. cú, Goth. hunds, Lith. šuõ, Hitt. kuwas, HLuw. zuwana/i- 'dog').
S.v. Arm. šun 'dog; adulterer, adulteress, whore', since long connected with PIE *k̑uon- 'dog' (cf. Skt. śvan-, YAv. span-, Lat. canis, Gk. κύων, OIr. cú, Lith. šuõ, OPr. sunis, etc.).
S.v. Ved. śvan- 'Hund' (IIr. cf. YAv. span- 'Hund'), from PIE *k̑u̯on- (cf. Arm. šown, Gk. κύων, OIr. cú, Lith. šuõ, TochAB ku, Hitt. kuu̯an-/kun- 'dog-man', ON hun-d-r 'Hund', etc.).
S.v. Lith. šuõ 'dog' (Latv. suns, OPr. sunis), from PIE *k̑uōn, G.sg. k̑un-ós (cf. Skt. śván-, Gk. κύων, Lat. canis, OIr. cú, Goth. hunds).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hunda- (2) 'dog', from the IE word for 'dog' *k̑u-on- (cf. Hitt. kuu̯an- ~ kun- 'dog-man', TochAB ku, Skt. śván-, YAv. span-, Arm. šun, Gk. κύων, Lat. canēs, -is, OIr. cú, Lith. šuõ, etc.).

S.v. Lat. canēs, -is 'dog', from PIE *k̑uōn 'dog' (cf. OIr. cú [G.sg. con], Hitt. kuu̯an-/kun- 'dog-man', HLuw. swan(i)- 'dog' Skt. svā́ 'dog', YAv. span- 'dog', Gk. κύων, Arm. šown, OPr. sunis, Lith. šuõ, Goth. hunds, OIc. hundr, TochAB ku, etc.).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷon- 'dog' (nom.sg. *k(w)ū, gen.sg. *kunos), from PIE *k̑(u)u̯ōn 'dog' (cf. Skt. śvā́, Gk. κύων, Lat. canis, Germ. Hund, Lith. šuõ, TochA ku, Arm. šun). NB Proto-Celtic *kʷ < PIE *k̑w was delabialised before *ū̆.
S.v. 3275 *kutta- (1) 'dog'. [Onom.: cf. Sogd. 'kwt, Shgh. kut 'dog', Sant. kutu kutu 'sound made in calling a puppy'].

S.v. Lat. siccus 'dry', from PIE *si-sk-u- 'dry'? (cf. MIr. sesc 'dry, barren, infertile', Skt. á-saścuṣī- 'not drying up', Av. hišku- 'dry', Khot. ṣkala 'dry places', Gk. ἕσκετο φωνή 'the voice broke down', ἰσχνός 'dry, arid', Lith. sèkti 'to lower oneself, sink, dry out').

S.v. *tīros 'land, earth', from PIE *ter-s- 'dry' (cf. Hitt. tars- 'become dry', Lat. terra 'land'). The derived adjective in OIr. tírimm, tirimm 'dry' is from Proto-Celtic *tīrs-es-mi- (for the formation cf. PCl. *tefesmi- 'warm').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *berjan- 'to fight', from PIE *bʰorH-ie- (cf. OCS brati (sę) 'to fight' < *bʰorH-ie-; Lith. bárti, Latv. bãrt 'to scold' (refl. 'to quarrel') < *bʰorH-e-, Lat. feriō, -īre 'to strike' < *bʰerH-ie-; OIr. barae 'anger, hostility' < *bʰrH-en-).
S.v. Lat. battuere 'schlagen' > Fr. battre.

S.v. Lat. battuō, -is, -ere 'battre'. A word that is rare in texts, but already attested in Plautus. Similar to Celtic words in the sense but in different form. Origin unknown. As in Lat. fut(t)uō 'I fuck' the consonant gemination is expressive.
Cf. s.v. Lith. kovà 'struggle, fight', an action noun deriving from káuti 'murder, beat, hew' < *kouh₂- (cf. Lat. cūdere 'beat, grind, forge', OIc. hǫggva 'hew, beat', OHG houwan 'hew, beat').
Cf. s.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (IEW 535).

S.v. TochB piś 'five', which with TochA päñ reflects Proto-Tocharian *pi̯ä́ñćä- with differing reflexes of the final cluster. PToch *pi̯ä́ñćä- is from PIE *pénkʷe (cf. Skt. páñca, Arm. hing, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf, OE fīf, Lith. penkì, etc.).
S.v. Alb. pesë ~ pêsë 'five', from PAlb. *pentše going back to PIE *pénkʷe 'five' (cf. Skt. páñca, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, etc.).
S.v. Alb. pésë / pẽs(ë) 'fünf', to be connected with PIE *pénkʷe 'five'. Cf. entry in Demiraj for discussion of the Albanian stem formation.
S.v. Arm. hing 'five', from PIE *pénkʷe 'five' (cf. Skt. páñca, YAv. paṇca, MPers. panǰ, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf, etc.).
S.v. páñca 'fünf' (IIr. cf. YAv. paṇča 'fünf'), from PIE *pénkʷe (cf. Gk. πέντε, Arm. hing, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf, TochA päñ, TochB piś, etc.).
S.v. Lith. penkì 'five' (Latv. pìeci), from PIE *penkʷe (cf. OCS pętь, Skt. páñca, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *pętь 'five', from PIE *penkʷe (cf. Lith. penkì, Skt. páñca, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Go. fimf).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *fimfe 'five', from PIE *pénkʷe  (cf. Hitt. panza-, TochA päñ, TochB piś, Skt. páñca, YAv. paṇca, MPers. panǰ, Oss. fondz, Arm. hing, Alb. pesë / pẽsë, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, OIr. cóic, MW pymp, W pimp, Bret. pemp).

S.v. Lat. quīnque 'five', from Proto-Italic *kʷenkʷe (cf. O. pumperIas, púmperias U. pumpeřias prob. 'fifth day', etc.), from PIE *penkʷe 'five' (cf. OIr. cóic, MW pymp, Skt. páñca, YAv. paṇca, Gk. πέντε, Arm. hing, Alb. pesë, OCS pętь, Lith. penkì, Goth. fimf, TochA päñ, TochB piś 'five').
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷenkʷe 'five', from PIE *penkʷe 'five' (cf. Skt. páñca, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf, Lith. penkì, OCS pętь, Alb. pesë).

Cf. s.v. Ved. bhadrá- 'glückverheißend, glücklich, erfreulich' (Ind. cf. Pā, bhadda- 'glücklich', Ir. cf. YAv. hu-baδra- 'sehr glücklich'). The derivation of IIr. *bʰadrá- from PIE *bʰn̥d-ró- can hardly be doubted (cf. probably Goth. batista 'bester').

Cf. s.v. ?*bʰend- 'glücklich sein, sich freuen' (IEW 126-7), Pres. *bʰénd-e- > Ved. bhandate 'fühlt sich glücklich'. Only Indo-Iranian, cf. Ved. bhadrá- 'glückverheißend', YAv. hu-baδra- 'sehr glücklich', if not to also be connected with Goth. batiza 'besser', etc.

Argues for a PIE root rather *gras- ~ *gʰras- ~ *kras-, pointing to onomatopoetic ideophonic origin and a meaning 'to devour, graze', cf. Vedic grásate 'devours‘, Greek Cypr. γράσθι (see LIV, 192, note 1); for *gʰras- cf. English grass, German Gras < Proto-Germanic *ɣrasa- n. and Latin grāmen (< *g(ʰ)rásmn n. 'grass'); for *kras- cf. Greek κράστις f. 'grass, hay'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *grasa- 'grass'. Lat. grāmen, from either *g̑ʰrh₁-mn- or *g̑ʰrh₁s-mn-, is the most evident comparandum for PGmc. *grasa-. However, PGmc. *grasa- cannot be straightforwardly be derived from *g̑ʰrh₁s- since this would yield *gurs-. Instead this should be regarded as a secondary s-stem to the verb *grōan- 'to grow' < *gʰróh₁-e-, an o-grade strong verb to the root *gʰreh₁-.

Proto-Germanic *grasa- is generally compared with Lat. grāmen [cf. /cognate/8369/] but details of the etymology remain disputed. The Leiden dictionaries ({ref Kroonen 2013}:187 s.v. PGmc. *grasa-, {ref de Vaan 2008}:269-270) argue to reconcile the reconstructions through postulating a root *⁽g̑⁾ʰreh₁- (not in LIV²) underlying PGmc. *grōan- 'grow', from which the Germanic forms would be a secondary s-stem. {ref Seebold 1970}:242-243 also suggests the possibility of a connection of Gmc. *grōan- with Lat. grāmen, but has reservations whether the two forms can be compared. Similarly, cf. {ref Kluge 2011}:371-372 s.v. NHG Gras, where two possibilities are offered: Either to (1) PGmc. grōan- (as {ref Kroonen 2013}:187 and tentatively {ref Seebold 1970}:242-243), or alternatively to PIE *gras- (cf. Gk. γράω 'I devour', Ved. grásate 'devours', {ref LIV²} 192 s.v. *gres-) with an variant in initial position; cf. also {ref Pooth 2015}:116 arguing for an onomatopoeic root *g⁽ʰ⁾ras- ~ *kras- (Gk. κράστις 'grass, hay'). It seems very likely that there is a connection between the Germanic lexemes and Latin grāmen, but the problem has not yet been solved in a satisfactory way. [Cogsets for Proto-Italic *grā̆men- /cognate/8369/ and Proto-Germanic *grasa- /cognate/230/ have been cross-indexed at value 5/6: large majority view]

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *grō-a- 'wachsen'. "Gm. grō-a-, intr. 'wachsen' hat keine genaue Vergleichsmöglichkeit. In der Regel wird als Erweiterung gm. gras-a-m (n) 'Gras' (in gt., awn. gras, ae. græs, afr. gres, gers, ahd. gras) mit lt. grāmen 'Weide, Gras' verglichen. Letzteres kann aber auch zu idg. gras- 'weiden, fressen' gehören. Vielleicht ist das gm. Verbum eine Variante zu krē- 'wachsen' in lt. crēsco."

S.v. Lat. grāmen, -inis 'grass', from Proto-Italic *grāsmen-/*grasmen-, from PIE *g̑ʰr̥h₁-(s-)mn̥- 'grass', cf. Goth. gras, OHG gras, OIc. gras 'grass'; OE grōwan, OIc. gróa, OHG gruoen 'to grow' < *g̑ʰroh₁-ie/o-; OS grōni, OHG gruoni 'green' < *g̑ʰroh₁-ni-.

Proto-Germanic *grasa- is generally compared with Lat. grāmen [cf. /cognate/8369/] but details of the etymology remain disputed. The Leiden dictionaries ({ref Kroonen 2013}:187 s.v. PGmc. *grasa-, {ref de Vaan 2008}:269-270) argue to reconcile the reconstructions through postulating a root *⁽g̑⁾ʰreh₁- (not in LIV²) underlying PGmc. *grōan- 'grow', from which the Germanic forms would be a secondary s-stem. {ref Seebold 1970}:242-243 also suggests the possibility of a connection of Gmc. *grōan- with Lat. grāmen, but has reservations whether the two forms can be compared. Similarly, cf. {ref Kluge 2002}:370 s.v. NHG Gras, where two possibilities are offered: Either to (1) PGmc. grōan- (as {ref Kroonen 2013}:187 and tentatively {ref Seebold 1970}:242-243), or alternatively to PIE *gras- (cf. Gk. γράω 'I devour', Ved. grásate 'devours', {ref LIV²} 192 s.v. *gres-) with an variant in initial position; cf. also {ref Pooth 2015}:116 arguing for an onomatopoeic root *g⁽ʰ⁾ras- ~ *kras- (Gk. κράστις 'grass, hay'). It seems very likely that there is a connection between the Germanic lexemes and Latin grāmen, but the problem has not yet been solved in a satisfactory way. [Cogsets for Proto-Italic *grā̆men- /cognate/8369/ and Proto-Germanic *grasa- /cognate/230/ have been cross-indexed at value 5/6: large majority view]

Against the derivation by de Vaan (2008:269-270, 282) of Lat. grāmen to *g̑ʰrh₁-(s)men-, cf. discussion to Proto-Germanic *grasa- in /cognate/230/ and Proto-Italic *grā̆men- in /cognate/8369/. In either case, the etymology of Lat. herba is uncertain (cf. also Ernout & Meillet 1985:291-292).
S.v. 7563 Skt. nī́la- 'dark blue, dark green, black' RV., nīlaka- lex. 2. nī́la- n. 'blue substance' ŚBr., ʻ indigo ʼ Yājñ.
S.v. Ved. nī́la- 'dunkelfarbig, dunkelblau, schwarzblau', not yet convincingly explained.

S.v. Goth. H18. hairϸra pl. 'σπλάγχνα', 'bowels'. Probably from PIE *(s)ker-, *(s)krē- 'cut' with derivatives referring to the body, cf. Skt. cárman 'skin', Lat. scortum 'skin, whore', scrōtum 'scrotum'.
For the common comparison to Skt. cárman- 'skin', cf. s.v. Ved. cárman- 'Haut, Fell, abgezogene Haut' < PIE *(s)kér-men- *'cut' → 'removed skin'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *rǭka 'hand, arm', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *rónkaʔ (cf. Lith. rankà 'hand', Latv. rùoka 'hand', OPr. rānkan (acc.sg.) 'hand'). According to Derksen the Balto-Slavic word for 'hand' derives from a verbal root *u̯renk- (cf. Lith. riñkti 'gather').

S.v. Lith. rankà 'hand' (Latv. rùoka 'hand', OPr. rānkan A.sg. 'hand'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *rónkaʔ (cf. OCS rǫka 'hand, arm'), from PIE *uronk-eh₂- (cf. OIc. rá 'corner, berth in a ship'). The Balto-Slavic word for hand derives from a verbal root meaning 'gather' (cf. Lith. riñkti).
S.v. Goth. H40. handus 'χείρ', 'hand'. Etymology uncertain. A Germanic innovation, possibly with the stem of *(fra-)hinϸan 'grasp' with 'hand' from the sense of 'grabber'.
S.v. Gmc. -henϸ-a- '(fangen)'. The derivation of 'hand' from the strong verb is accepted by Seebold, but the verb itself has no certain comparisons outside of Germanic.
Cf. s.v. Latv. grūts, from Proto-Baltic *grūtas, from Proto-Indo-European *gʷru-to-s.
Cf. for discussion of the derivation of CLuw. u̯āšu(i)- 'gut' from PIE *h₁u̯ésu- and its derivatives within Luwian.
S.v. TochB samudtär 'sea, ocean', loan from Buddhist (Hybrid) Sanskrit samudra-.

Cf. other parallel loans from Sanskrit samudrá- in Modern Indic languages in /cognate/6525/. The (parallel?) loans from Buddhist Sanskrit in Tocharian A & Tocharian B should probably be separated from the parallel loans in the Modern Indic languages.
S.v. Sp. pájaro, from old pássaro which is from vulgar Latin passar 'id.', cf. Classical Latin passer, -ĕris 'gorrión'.
Alb. shpend 'bird' < *sV-pétno+to-.

S.v. Alb. shpend 'bird'. Orel regards Alb. shpend 'bird' a derivative of pendë 'feather; pair of oxen', which (cf. s.v.) he in turn regards a borrowing from Lat. pinna, penna. Alternatively cf. Meyer (1891:413) who regards as a prefixal derivative of *pet-no-.

S.v. Alb. špesε f. špes m. 'Vogel' (geg. špent-di-, špen). There is no direct connection to the loanword pendε. Rather, the word is to be derived from š-pen and pen is comparable to OIr. en, W. etn 'bird', from *petn-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *pъtica 'bird', from Balto-Slavic *put- (cf. also Proto-Slavic *pъtakъ 'bird', *pъtъka 'bird', Latv. putns) [No further cognates given.]

S.v. Lat. passer 'small bird', from Proto-Italic *pattro-, via PIE *p(e)t-tro- 'who flies, bird' (so {ref Schrijver 1991}:212, 495). "Schrijver proposes *pttro- 'bird' > *pattro- > nom.sg. *passros, gen.sg. *passrī > *passr̥s, *pazrī > *passer, *pārī. This paradigm would have been skewed, yielding two nouns: passer 'sparrow' and pārus 'tit'. It must be remarked that the expected meaning of a form *pt-tro- would rather be instrument for flying, wing' vel sim."
Cf. s.v. *gʷer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5).
S.v. 2641 Skt. kaṭú-, káṭuka- 'pungent, bitter' RV.
Cf. s.v. Ved. káṭuka- 'scharf, beissend'. Not satisfactorily explained.

S.v. TochB anāsk- 'breathe, inhale', without doubt a reflex of PIE *h₂en(h₁)- 'breathe' (cf. Skt. ániti 'breathes', Gk. ἄνεμος 'breath, wind', Lat. animus 'spirit, soul', OIr. anál 'breath', Goth. uzanan 'exhale', etc.).

S.v. Ved. √an-ⁱ 'atmen' (IIr. cf. YAv. ā̊ṇtiiā̊ parā̊ṇtiiā̊ 'des Ein- und Ausatmens'), from PIE *h₂enh₁- (cf. Gk. ἄνε-μος 'Wind', Osc. ana-múm 'animam', Lat. animus 'Seele, Geist', anima 'Lufthauch, Atem, Seele', TochB anā-sk- 'einatmen', W. ana-dl 'Atem', Goth. uz-anan 'ausatmen', etc.).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *anatlā 'breath', from *h₂enh₁-tlo- based on PIE *h₂enh₁- 'breathe' (cf. Lat. animus, Gk. ἄνεμος < *h₂enh₁-mo-). [NB: the Celtic cognates in this set are either light-verb constructions with this noun, or have formed denominal verbs from this noun.]
S.v. Engl. breathe (v.), a Middle English formation from ME breth 'odour, smell, scent'. Cf. s.v. breath (n.), ultimately from OE bræϸ, breϸ 'odour, smell, exhalation'.
Cf. s.v. 4855 *cuccu- 'female breast, nipple', 2. *cucci-. [Onom. cf. cūcuka- n. 'nipple'].
Cf. s.v. Skt. cuciḥ 'die weibliche Brust', 'the female breast', onomatopoeic rendering of the sound of suckling.

S.v. Ved. putrá- 'Kind, Tierjunges' (IIr. cf. OAv. puθra- 'Sohn', YAv. puθra- 'Sohn, Kind', etc.), from PIE *putló- (cf. Osc. puklum 'den Sohn', Paelig. puclois, Mars. pucle[s] den Söhnen < Italic *puklo- < *putlo-). Perhaps to be further connected with Gk. παΐς 'Kind', Lat. paucus 'klein'?

A connection of PIE *putló- 'son; child' with Lat. paruus 'small', Gk. πάϊς 'child' as suggested by EWAia I:143 might be possible if one assumes a zero-grade of the root *peh₂u̯- (i.e. *ph₂u-) + a derivational suffix *-tló-, but one might expect an aspirate *phutrá- in Vedic, fricative futra- in Avestan, as sequences of stop + *h₂ seem to yield aspirates in Indo-Iranian (cf. Ved. aor. ásthāt 'has positioned (oneself)' < *(h₁)e-sth₂-).

Cf. s.v. 3245 *kuḍa- (1) 'boy, son', prob. a borrowing from Mu. (cf. Sant. Muṇḍari koṛa 'boy', kuṛi 'girl', Ho koa, kui, Kūrkū kōn, kōnjē); or a borrowing from Drav. (cf. Tam. kur̤a 'young', Kan. koḍa 'youth').
Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯eh₁- 'anschwellen' (IEW 592-4).
S.v. 10396 *yaja- 'cold' [IE. *yeg̑- 'ice' IEW 503?] (cf. Kt. yūċ 'cold', Pr. (y)ǖzu. Wg. yū̆z, yoz → Kal. Kho. yoz [→Wkh. yaz]).
Cf. s.v. *i̯eg- 'Eis'.
Indo-Iranian-Nuristani cognates from *yaja- 'cold' (Turner 1962-1966:601) probably imply a reconstruction *i̯eg̑- with a palatovelar.
Cf. s.v. *i̯eg- 'Eis'.

Cf. s.v. 10396 *yaja- 'cold' [IE. *yeg̑- 'ice' IEW 503?] (cf. Kt. yūċ 'cold', Pr. (y)ǖzu. Wg. yū̆z, yoz → Kal. Kho. yoz [→Wkh. yaz]). Turner implies that Wakhi yaz is a loanword from Kaláṣa or Khowār.
Indo-Iranian-Nuristani cognates from *yaja- 'cold' (Turner 1962-1966:601) probably imply a reconstruction *i̯eg̑- with a palatovelar.
Cf. s.v. *i̯eg- 'Eis'.
Indo-Iranian-Nuristani cognates from *yaja- 'cold' (cf. Turner 1962-1966:601, 'ice' in /cognate/2741/, 'cold' in /cognate/982/) probably imply a reconstruction *i̯eg̑- with a palatovelar.
Cf. s.v. 10396 *yaja- 'cold' [IE. *yeg̑- 'ice' IEW 503?] (cf. Kt. yūċ 'cold', Pr. (y)ǖzu. Wg. yū̆z, yoz → Kal. Kho. yoz [→Wkh. yaz]).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *sarH- 'to cool, become cold', from PIE *k̑elH- 'to freeze' (cf. Lith. šálti 'to freeze, to cool (off), become cool', Latv. sal̃t 'to freeze').
Cf. s.v. Old Welsh reulaun 'icy' (lit. ice-full), with W rhew 'frost, ice', OIr. réud, < *preuswo-.
Cf. s.v. Alb. márdh/ë, -a 'Frost', an old word for 'Frost', which can be identical with OCS mrazъ 'Frost', cf. IEW 740 *merg̑- 'morschen', alternatively from *morg̑⁽ʰ⁾-.
Cf. s.v. glaciēs 'ice'. "The meaning is the same as gelus, but glaciēs cannot be derived from a root *g̑l- 'to be cold' in any meaningful way."
Cf. s.v. Lat. glaciēs 'glace'. Appears to be derived in some way from the same root as gelu 'cold' (adj.), but the stem formation is obscure.
S.v. Sp. hielo, from Lat. gĕlŭ 'id.'

S.v. Oss. wazal 'холодный, холод, стужа'. Hübschmann and Bielmeier derive from *wa-sal and connect this to šɜl-ən 'freeze' (cf. /cognate/1857/). But Abaev thinks this is phonetically implausible, and considers it a "Scytho-European" term with no Iranian cognates. He links *zal to Latin gelu 'frost', gelidus 'cold', German kalt etc.
S.v. Goth. K3. kalds (adj.) 'ψυχρός', 'cold' from PIE *gel- 'cold', cf. Lat. gelū 'cold, frost, ice'.
Etymology disputed. Either to PIE *k̑elH- (cf. 'cold' in /cognate/14/, 'freeze' in /cognate/1857/) or to PIE *g̑el- (cf. 'cold' in /cognate/196/, 'ice' in /cognate/6560/).
Cf. s.v. 2. ei-s-, ei-n- 'Eis, Frost', where the Iranian lexemes are taken to be cognate with the 'ice' words in Germanic.
Cf. s.v. 2. ei-s-, ei-n- 'Eis, Frost', where the Germanic lexemes are taken to be cognate with the 'ice' words in Iranian (cf. Av. aexa-).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *īsa- 'ice'. There are no certain cognates outside of Germanic. "Av. aexa- can only be related if it continues a form *h₁eiH-ko- that developed into *HeikHo- by laryngeal metathesis."
S.v. *k̑elH ‘kalt werden, frieren’ (LIV 323, IEW 551), cf. n6 suggesting the Iranian lexemes are rather reflexes of 2. *k̑el- 'warm werden'.
