S.v. Lith. šáltas 'cold' (Latv. salts 'cold'), cognate with YAv. sarəta- 'cold' and also connected within Baltic to Lith. šálti 'freeze', Latv. salt 'freeze, clot', which in turn reflect a root *k̑olH- which may have been of denominative origin.

Regarding the Iranian nominal forms, cf. notes s.v. Ved. śíśira- 'Vorfrühling, kühle Jahreszeit', where YAv. sarəta- 'kalt', Lith. šálti '[ge]frieren, abkuhlen, kalt werden' are connected to PIE *k̑elH- 'frieren'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *sarH- 'to cool, become cold', from PIE *k̑elH- 'to freeze' (cf. Lith. šálti 'to freeze, to cool (off), become cool', Latv. sal̃t 'to freeze').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *xoldьnъ 'cool, cold' (ESSJa VIII 59-60), an adjectival derivative of Proto-Slavic *xoldъ 'coolness, cold' (ESSJa VIII 57-58). Possibly cognate with Latin and Germanic words for 'cold' reflecting PIE *gel-, but Slav. initial *x- lacks a convincing explanation.

S.v. TochB krośce ~ kroṣce 'cold', which with TochA kᵤraś reflect Proto-Tocharian nom.sg. *kʷroscē, acc.sg. kʷroscänä(n) which can reflect PIE *kʷrus-tēn, *kʷrus-tén-m̥. The assumption of a labiovelar explains the TochA nom.sg. kᵤraś, and medial -o-. "The nearest relatives are in Gk. κρυσταίνομαι 'congealed with cold, freeze' (cf. also κρύστάλλος 'ice; numbness; crystal,' κρυμός 'icy cold, frost' < *krusmó-), κρύος (nt.) 'id.' … {ref Beekes 2010}:786 surprisingly, and surely wrongly, hesitant."

S.v. Gk. κρύος 'froid qui glace, qui fait frissoner'. No exact correspondences. The adjective κρυερός recalls to Skt. krūrá-, Av. xrūra- 'écorché, sanglant, cruel', but neither the form nor the sense coincide and there is no reason to recall Lat. cruor (cf. Gk. κρέας). Less clear is the root *qrus- that may be compared with Lat. crusta 'croûte, revêtement', TochB krost, TochA kruaś 'froid'.

If {ref Adams 2013}:236 is correct in his postulation of initial *kʷ-, then the proposed Greek cognates would have yielded †πρύος, †πρυσταίνομαι with regular development of *kʷ- > p / _C in Greek. Adams's reconstruction cannot be correct as such.

Cf. s.v. TochB krośce ~ kroṣce 'cold', which with TochA kᵤraś reflect Proto-Tocharian nom.sg. *kʷroscē, acc.sg. kʷroscänä(n) which can reflect PIE *kʷrus-tēn, *kʷrus-tén-m̥. The assumption of a labiovelar explains the TochA nom.sg. kᵤraś, and medial -o-. "The nearest relatives are in Gk. κρυσταίνομαι 'congealed with cold, freeze' (cf. also κρύστάλλος 'ice; numbness; crystal,' κρυμός 'icy cold, frost' < *krusmó-), κρύος (nt.) 'id.' … {ref Beekes 2010}:786 surprisingly, and surely wrongly, hesitant."

If {ref Adams 2013}:236 is correct in his postulation of initial *kʷ-, then the proposed Greek cognates would have yielded †πρύος, †πρυσταίνομαι with regular development of *kʷ- > p / _C in Greek. Adams's reconstruction cannot be correct as such.
Cf. s.v. ?*srei̯H⁽g̑⁾- 'frieren, schaudern' (IEW 1004). Only Greek and Italic. The e-grade of the root is not attested and therefore uncertain.
S.v. 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' (IEW 726-8). For the Old Breton form monim*, cf. s.v. Kausativ *mon-éi̯e- > ?abret. guo-monim 'zusagen' and n16 "Glossiert lat. polliceri."

S.v. Ved. √man-¹ 'denken, meinen, dafürhalten' (IIr. cf. OAv. mainiiaṇtā 'sie bedenken, verstehen', YAv. mainiiete 'denkt', etc.), from PIE *men- (cf. Gk. pf. μέμονα 'habe im Sinn, strebe' Lat. meminī 'erinnere mich', OIr. do-moiniur 'meine, glaube', Goth. man 'meine, glaube', Lith. miñti 'gedenken', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *man-yo- 'think, remember' (OIr. muinithir, -muinethar 'think'), from PIE *men- 'think' (cf. Skt. mányate, Goth. munan).

S.v. Oss. rast 'прямой, правый, правильный (etc.)', from Ir. *rāšta- via PIE *rek̑to- (*reg̑-to-), cf. Pers. rāst, Parth. rāšt, Choresm. rašt, Sogd. rā̆št, Khot. rraṣṭa-, Av. rāšta-, OPers. rāsta-, Goth. raihts, Germ. recht, Lat. rectus.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rehta- 'straight', from PIE *h₃reg̑-to- (cf. Av. rā̆šta- 'straight', Gk. ὀρεκτός 'id.', Lat. rectus 'id.').

S.v. Lat. regō, -ere 'to direct, guide, govern', from Proto-Italic *reg- (cf. U. rehte 'right'), from PIE *h₃reg̑-e/o-. Lat. rēctus is the regularly formed past passive participle to the verbal stem [< *h₃reg̑-to-].

S.v. Ved. r̥tá- adj. 'wahrhaft' n. 'Wahrheit, Übereinstimmung' (cf. IIr. OPers. art- in artxšç 'Artaxerxes', YAv. ərəta- in proper names, full-grade *arta- in OAv., YAv. aṣ̌a- 'Wahrheit'). The etymon of Ved. r̥tá- is probably PIE *h₂r̥-tó- 'gefügt' → 'richtig, wahrhaft' to PIE *h₂er- 'fügen'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *wēraz adj., related to Lat. uērus, OIr. fír, W gwīr, cf. Proto-Germanic *wērō, identical with Slav. *věra 'belief, faith'.
S.v. Ved. satyá- 'wahr, wahrhaft, wirklich' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. haiθiia- 'wahr', OPers. hašiyam 'truly', etc.), from PIE *h₁sn̥t-i̯ó-, to √as-¹ 'sein' < *h₁es-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *sanϸa- 'true', from PIE *h₁s-ónt-o-, an adjective containing the participle of the IE verb 'to be' (cf. Hitt. ašant- 'true, real', Skt. sánt- 'being real, good', Lat. sōns, sontis 'guilty').
Cf. s.v. *h₁es- 'dasein, sein' (IEW 340-1).
S.v. 13744 Skt. sthála- n. 'dry land' TS., 'ground, place' Mn., 'flat surface, roof' [√sthal].
S.v. Ved. sthála- 'Anhöhe, Erhebung, festes Land'. Not convincingly explained.

S.v. NHG wahr (adj.) (MHG wār, OHG wār), from pre-Germanic *wǣra-. Outside of Germanic may be compared Lat. vērus and OIr. fír 'wahr'. Within Germanic was formed *wǣrō 'Versprechen, Verpflichtung, Vertrag' (cf. ON várar, OE vǣr, OHG vāra), to which may be compared OCS věra 'Glaube, Vertrauen, Treue'.

Cf. s.v. pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft mit Abl.), specifically under the proposed formation *pró-o, *prṓ 'vorwärts, hervor; frühmorgens', to which perhaps might be connected Proto-Slavic ?*pra- 'vor' as a compositional prefix in e.g. OCS pradědŭ 'Vorfahre, Urahne', ]OCS pravŭ 'recht, richtig', Russ. pravyj 'rechts'.

Cf. s.v. pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft mit Abl.), specifically under the proposed formation *pró-o, *prṓ 'vorwärts, hervor; frühmorgens', to which perhaps might be connected Proto-Slavic ?*pra- 'vor' as a compositional prefix in e.g. OCS pradědŭ 'Vorfahre, Urahne', ]OCS pravŭ 'recht, richtig', Russ. pravyj 'rechts'.

Cf. s.v. ON -hœgō (only in uhœgō 'ungemach, beschwerde' to which ON hœgr 'leicht, geschickt, sanft' < Gmc. *hōgiaz (Ic. hœgr, Far. høgur), to which cpd. ON hœgri (Ic. hœgri, Far. høgri, Nor. høgre, Sw. höger) 'rechte (hand)'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √sādh- 'zum Ziel gelangen, gelingen', probably from PIE *seh₁dʰ-/*sh₁dʰ-, cf. Arm. aǰ 'recht, dexter' < *sh₁dʰ-i̯o-.
Cf. s.v. *seHdʰ- 'zum Ziel kommen, gelingen' (IEW 892).

S.v. Ved. √vart- 'sich drehen, sich wenden, rollen' (IIr. cf. YAv. varət-a- 'wenden', Parth. wrd-/wšt- 'se tourner', Chwaresm. m|ʾwrd- zurückkehren, umkehren', NPers. gard-/gaštan 'wenden, drehen', Sogd. wrtn 'Wagen', etc.). from PIE *u̯ert- 'sich drehen, wenden' (cf. OHG werdan 'werden', ON norðan-verðr 'nordwärts gerichtet', Lat. uertō 'wende, kehre', Lith. vir̃sti 'wenden, kehren', OCS vrьteti 'sich wenden, drehen').
Cf. s.v. Lith. vartýti 'turn, turn over' to which also OPr. wartint 'turn', from PIE *uort-eie- (cf. Skt. vartáyati 'turns').

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *vortiti 'turn, return' from PIE *uort-eie- (cf. Lith. vartýti 'turn, turn over', OPr. wartint 'turn', Skt. vartáyati 'turns') and s.v. Proto-Slavic *vьrtěti 'turn', from PIE *urt- (cf. Lith. vir̃sti 'fall, collapse, turn into', Skt. vártate 'turn, roll').

S.v. Lat. ve/ortō, -ere 'to turn', from Proto-Italic wert-e/o- (cf. O. ϝερσορει [dat.sg.] epithet of Jupiter prob. 'who averts' < *uert-tor, U. vurtus, etc. < *urt-us-), from PIE *uert-e/o- (cf. Skt. vártate 'to turn (around), roll', Av. varəta- 'to turn', OPr. wīrst 'to become', Lith. vir̃sti 'to turn (around), fall over, become', OCS vrьtěti, Ru. vertét 'to turn (around)' < *u̯r̥t-, Goth. wairþan, OHG werdan 'to become', etc.).

Anatolian and Baltic lexemes whose cognacy is generally agreed, but root reconstruction difficult. Cf. comments of {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:392-393. LIV¹ reconstructs *seh₂(i̯)-, {ref LIV²} *sh₂ei̯-. As a compromise between the two versions of LIV and {ref Kloekhorst 2008}, we give *seh₂(i̯)- as the root ref. form for this class. See also {ref Derksen 2015}:397-398. For Indo-Iranic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. {ref EWAia} II:720-721.

S.v. Lith. siẽti 'bind, link' (Latv. sìet 'bind, tie'), from PIE *sh₂-(o)i- (cf. Hitt. išḫāi-/išḫi- 'bind, wrap, obligate with, impose upon', Skt. sinā́ti 'bind' (aor. sāt)). Root reconstruction difficult, cf. entry for discussion of previous literature, ultimately following the solution proposed by Kloekhorst (2008:392-393).
S.v. 4353 Skt. grantháyati 'ties' MBh., gránthati Dhātup. [Cf. grathnā́ti to √granth-].

S.v. Ved. √granth-ⁱ (√grath-ⁱ) 'knüpfen, binden, verbinden' (IIr. cf. Khot. grantha- 'Knoten', MPers. grih, NPers. girih 'Knoten', Pašto gaṛəl 'winden, knüpfen, etc.'). Proposed Indo-European origins of the Indo-Iranian lexical family are only conjectural.

S.v. Proto-Iranian *hau-? 'to scorch, burn'. "This sparsely attested root has no certain IE etymology. The existence of this root might even be doubted if we adhere to the interpretation of Kellens 1984: 151, n.15 of YAv. hau-, which is traditionally translated as 'to braise, roast, vel sim.'. The WIr. forms could, alternatively, derive from older (augmented ?) *(a)-ϑāu̯a- (*dauH¹)."

S.v. Proto-Iranian *dauH-¹ 'to burn', from PIE *deh₂u̯- 'to burn, be(come) on fire' (cf. Skt. dav- 'to kindle, burn', Gk. δαίω 'I kindle', OIr. dóïd 'singes, burns', OIr. condud 'firewood', OHG zuscen 'to burn').
S.v. AGk. δαίω 'anzünden, brennen' > Tsak. δαίσου.
S.v. *deh₂u̯- 'in Brand geraten' (IEW 179-81).

S.v. AGk. δαίω 'to kindle', from PIE *deh₂u̯- 'burn'. The perfect stem δέδηα < *δέ-δᾱϝ-α resembles Skt. du-dāv-a (gramm.) to which pres. du-nó-ti 'to burn' is related. OIr. dóim 'to burn' and OHG zuscen 'id.' may also be related.

Root etymology disputed. Either to *deh₂u̯- in /cognate/8388/ (so Vendryes et al. 1959-1996, Schrijver 1995:316), or *dʰegʷʰ- in /cognate/368/ (tentatively LIV²); Matasović (2009:92-93) gives both etymologies under different lemmata.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √mā-² 'messen, abmessen, zumessen, zuteilen' (IIr. cf. OAv. fra-mīmaθa 'ihr ordnet an' [Y 32,4], YAv. māta- 'gebildet', etc.), from PIE *meh₁- (cf. Lat. mētior 'messe, messe ab', Goth. mel 'Zeit, Stunde', OHG māl 'Zeitpunkt', Ru. méra, Sloven. mẹ́ra 'Maß, Maßregel', etc.).

S.v. TochB mai- '± abschätzen, ermessen', '± gage, gauge, estimate'; TochA me- 'ermessen', 'gage' (?). "In order to connect all of these forms, one can set up a PT root *m(’)æy- 'measure, gage'. The PIE root involved then may have been either *√meh₁ 'messen' (²LIV, 424, with fn. 1, where the connection of TB maistär is doubted) or *√med 'messen, für Einhaltung sorgen, sich kümmern' (²LIV, 423 with Toch.)"
Cf. s.v. Lith. skaitýti 'read, count' (Latv. skàitît 'count, recite, read'), from PIE *(s)kʷeit-/*(s)kʷoit- (cf. Skt. cétati 'perceive, take notice of').
S.v. Lith. raudóti 'weep, lament' (Latv. raûdât 'weep, lament'), from PIE *(H)roud- (cf. Skt. rudanti 'they weep', Lat. rudere 'roar, bellow', OE rēotan 'weep, lament').

From Proto-Iranian *garz- 'to lament, weep' and Skt. garh- 'to complain' one may reconstruct PIIr. *garj́ʰ-. LIV² 187 further mechanically reconstructs PIE ?*g⁽ʷ⁾eRg̑ʰ- 'klagen', but as there are no secure cognates outside of Indo-Iranian, this reconstruction is uncertain.
Cf. s.v. 11591 Skt. vāsá- (2) m. 'abode' RV., 'staying' R., vāsaka -- n. 'sleeping quarters' Kathās. [√vas2].

Cf. s.v. Ved. √vas-³ 'wohnen, weilen, übernachten', from PIE *h₂u̯es- (cf. Hitt. hu̯es- 'leben, am Leben sein, überleben', TochB wäs- sich aufhalten, weilen', Gk. ἄεσα 'verbrachte (die Nacht), Arm. go- 'existieren, vorhanden sein', Goth. wisan 'sein, bleiben', OIr. fo(a)id 'verbringt die Nacht'). Cf. also s.v. Ved. vasar- probably 'in der Mörgenfrühe' < PIE *h₂u̯es-r- (cf. Gk. ἔαρ 'Frühling', Arm. garown 'Frühling', Lat. uēr 'Frühling', Lith. vãsara, vasarà 'Sommer', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯es- '(ver)weilen, die Nacht verbringen' (IEW 72, 1170-1).
S.v. Wakhi rwor 'день', from Ir. *fra-vā̆h(a)r-, cf. Skt. vasar- 'заря'.
S.v. Wa. šak, adapted from Tadž., Pers. šaqī́ (from Arab. šaqī).
S.v. Wa. pist 'кожа, шкура, кора'. Possibly a borrowing from other Iranian, or, in any case, contamination with borrowings.

S.v. Wa. lap 'большой, взрослый, много'. A word evidently of expressive origin.
"Очевидно, экспрессивная основа звукоизобразительной природы, типа широко распространенной lap ~ 'лопо-’ (см. lар°), ср. в тадж. говорах: бад. lumbuk ’толстяк’, кар. lum(b), дарв. lum(b) ‘большой’, ’огромный’, 'много’, а также в памирских языках: ишк. lip, шугн., руш., хуф., барт., рош., язг. lap ‘очень’, ‘много’, 'большой’. Сюда же, возможно, cap. lεwr, lawr (EVSh 42: ?) и афг. loy, luy; ср. еще кхов. lott 'большой' (Grierson. Piśāca 72), паш., гав., вот. lau, lou ‘много’ (< bahura-? CDIAL 9193), башг. ōla, ашк. aulú, кати al ‘большой’ (< *āpula- CDIAL 1211); талыш. lap ‘очень’, ‘совсем’."
S.v. Arm. čʻor-kʻ 'four', from PIE *kʷetuores 'four' (cf. Skt. catvā́ras, YAv. caθβārō, TochA śtwar, B śtwer, Gk. τέσσαρες, Goth. fidwor, Lith. keturì, OCS četyre, etc.)
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷetwores 'four', from PIE *kʷetu̯ores (cf. Skt. catvā́ras, Lat. quattuor, Gk. τέτταρες, Goth. fidwor, Lith. keturì, OCS četyre, ToA śtwar, Arm. čorkʻ).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *četyre 'four' (ESSJa IV 97-98), from PIE *kʷétur- (cf. Lith. keturì, Skt. catvā́ras, etc.).
S.v. Lith. keturì 'four' (Latv. četri), from PIE *kʷétur- (cf. OCS četyre, Skt. catvā́ras).
S.v. Ved. √khyā- 'schauen, anblicken, scheinen', a phonetic variant of Ved. √kśā- 'blicken, schauen'.
Cf. s.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9). Verbal only IIr., cf. Gk. τέκμαρ 'Zeichen, Ziel' < *kʷék̑-mr̥.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *gauma- 'heed, attention', from which the denominal verb *gaumjan- (cf. Goth. gaumjan 'to notice'), where the semantic development 'heed' > 'hide' is a secondary development. K. considers "[i]n spite of the apparent similarities, the word cannot be related to ON gá w.v. 'to heed', as this verb continues *ganhēn-, not *gawēn-. I therefore propose a relationship with the Indo-Iranian root *g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeug̑ʰ- 'to hide', assuming that this meaning developed from a more primary 'to heed, guard'." Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *ganhēn- 'to inspect; take into account'(?) "The widely accepted etymological connection with OCS gověti 'to revere (cf. Torp 1909: 121) and Lat. faveō 'to be favorable' < *gʷʰou-eh₁- (cf. Schrijver 1991: 441-2), implying a PGm. form *gawēn-, is contradicted by the nasal vowel of Elfd. gą̊ […]. It follows that the apparently obvious link with *gauma- 'attention' must be abandoned.
S.v. ON geyma 'beachten, sorgen für', cf. gaum 'aufmerksamkeit', which probably belongs to ON gá, whose etymology is disputed.

S.v. Goth. 672. gaumjan 'βλέπειν, διαβλέπειν, ἰδεῖν, κατανοεῖν', 'see, observe'. Possibly an extended form of PIE *ghou- 'perceive, pay heed to' (cf. Lat. foveō 'be favourable', OI. gá < *gawōn 'pay heed', OCS gověti 'honor').
Cf. s.v. *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen' (IEW 952). [Note the Celtic forms are not primary stem formations and therefore not listed.]
S.v. Ved. √goh- 'verbergen, verhüllen' (IIr. cf. YAv. guzaēta 'er würde verbergen', aguze 'ich versteckte (mich)', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *gauz- 'to hide, conceal' (cf. Skt. goh- 'to hide'). The root appears to be of IIr. origin. IE connections are uncertain.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaud- 'to cover', from PIE *gʰeu̯dʰ- 'to hide' (cf. Gk. κεύθω 'I hide').

Cf. s.v. ?*gʷʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen' (IEW 450) and s.v. *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen' (IEW 952). Cf. S.v. n1 in both entries: it is possible that the parallel root *gʰeu̯dʰ- unnecessary, as a blend between these two roots.
S.v. Goth. F49. filhan 'θάψαι; κρυβῆναι', 'bury; conceal', perhaps to PIE *pel- 'cover, skin' + -k- suffix, but somewhat dubious. Cf. entry for references to older suggestions.
S.v. Hitt. maklant- 'lean, emaciated', to be compared with Lat. macer, ON magar, OEng. mægar 'lean, meager', Gk. μακρός 'long', further root analysis may point to *mḀ₂k-.

Cf. s.v. Lat. māchina, -ae 'invention, machination' with the concrete sense 'machine, engin', a loanword from (Doric) Greek μᾱχανᾱ́ 'moyen ingénieux employé pour obtenir un résultat, machine'. The Latin verb māchinō is denominal from the original loanword māchina.

S.v. Gmc. *wreib-a- 'reiben'. Germanic *wreib-a- 'reiben' has no secure comparisons. It is generally considered as an enlargement of the root *wer- 'drehen, verdrehen', which is in principle possible, but is not fully sufficient to support an etymology. Compare striking similar structures in words of similar meaning in Lat. trī-vī (pf.), Gk. τρίβω.
S.v. Lith. ẽžeras 'lake' (Latv. ȩzȩrs 'lake', OPr. assaran 'lake') from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰ-(e)ro- (cf. OCS jezero 'lake', Arm. ezr 'edge, border, bank'), cf. also s.v. Lith. ežià 'boundary(-strip)'.
Cf. s.v. Arm ezr 'edge, shore, bank'. The traditional etymology with Lith. ežià 'boundary(-strip)', etc. is sometimes doubted, but Martirosyan sees no good reason to abandon the IE etymology.
Cf. s.v. 13254 Skt. sáras- n. 'lake, pool' RV. [√sr̥].
Derives Tocharian forms via zero-grade *límn̥ > *límə > *lʸímə > PT *lʸə́mə > TB lyam, TA lyäm.

S.v. Gk. λάκκος 'Grube, Wasserloch', (bov. lákko, otr. lákko, kal. lákku, lákkə, salent. lákku, luk. lákkə 'pozza d'acqua') from a Romance plural *laccora (cf. lecc. le lákkure) regg. lákkuru 'terreno basso da un fiume'. Lákku is often river name in Calabria and Sicily.
Cf. s.v. λάκκος 'pond, cistern, pit, reservoir' perhaps from a PIE zero-grade *l̥ku̯o-, but the phonetic development *-ku̯- > -κκ- is unexpected.

{ref Rohlfs 1964}:288 considers the Italiot Greek words to be borrowings from Romance. Note, however, that AGk. λάκκος does exist, and might possibly be derived from *l̥ku̯o- (PIE *laku- or *loku-, cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:827 s.v. λάκκος and further discussion in /cognate/8246/). It is difficult to exclude in principle the possibility of contamination or blending of inherited material with that of local Romance varieties. Similarly cf. Engl. lake in /cognate/5612/ which may well be a semantic calque from Romance.
S.v. *laku- 'Wasseransammlung in einer Grube, Lache, See'.
S.v. Wakhi ẓ̌uy 'водоем, пруд, небольшое водохранилище, озерцо', from PIr. *zraya- (cf. Av. zrayah-, OPers. drayah-, etc.).
S.v. PIr. čāt-, čāθ- 'яма, колодец', from PIIr. *čāt-/*čāth- (cf. Ved. cā́tvala- 'яма'), further derived from the root *kan- 'копать, рыть'.
Cf. s.v. Skt. cā́tvala- 'Grube', perhaps to be connected with YAv. čāt- 'Brunnengrube', BSogd. čʾt, Bactr. σαδο 'Brunnen'.
For Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 3815 *khandati 'laughs'.
S.v. δίδωμι 'give' < PIE *di-deh₃- 'to give'.

S.v. Proto-Iranian ?*daH-⁶ 'beat, strike'. "The forms [attested] seem to suggest a separate root *daH⁶ 'to beat, hit, strike' in Ir., which is perhaps expressive in origin, cf. Engl. thud, tick, tap, etc."
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian ⁵dā-, *dai-, dī̆- 'бить, ударять, гнать, бросать, падать'.
Cf. s.v. SMG δίνω, from Hellenistic Greek δίδω with the present stem remodelled as a nasal present stem (cf. also πτύω → φτύνω, λύω → λύνω, κλείω → κλείνω, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *lopěnъ/*lopěno, derivatives in -ěnъ, -ěno to Proto-Slavic *lopъ (ΙΙ) (cf. Bulg. dial. лопъ), which is to be connected with Lith. lãpas, Latv. lapa 'лист'.
S.v. Goth. H78. hleiduma 'ἀριστερός, εὐώνυμος', 'left', from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean' (cf. Gk. κλίτος 'hill'; OIr. clé OWel cledd < *k̑li-i̯os 'left').

S.v. Ved. kharvá- (adj.) 'verstümmelt, krüppelhaft, zwerghaft' (cf. Pkt. khavva- m. 'linke Hand', kati kawə 'left-hand' etc. (T. 3832). Cf. YAv. kauruua-, kauruuō if the terms mean 'verstümmelt' (and not 'kahl'). Further connections are unclear.
S.v. Khot. gaḍaa- 'throat, neck', from *gartaka- to base *gart- 'to turn, roll' (Zor.P. gltn, gldn, *gartan, gardan 'neck', NPers. gardan, M.Pers.T. grdn 'neck', Sogd. γrδʾkh *γarδakā-.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *gart- 'to turn'. "The Ir. root with no exact IE correspondences seems to be an enlarged root of *gar². It has probably been influenced by *u̯art-." Cf. s.v. *gar-² 'to turn, wind' "IE cognate forms of this apparently "unenlarged" Ir. root are uncertain. The nominal forms quoted by Pok. (l.c.) are set with problems. The enlarged variants are *gart- and *garš²." [Cf. IEW 385.]
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *¹gart- / *garθ- : grt- / grθ- : grat-, *graθ-.

S.v. Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made' (IIr. cf. Manichaean Sogd. kyrm- 'Schlange', MPers. klm (kirm) 'Wurm, Drache, Schlange', NPers. kirm 'Wurm, Schlange'), from PIE *kʷr̥mi- (cf. OIr. cruim, W., Bret. pryf 'Wurm', Lith. kirmìs 'Wurm, Schlange', Sloven. čr̂m 'Fingerwurm, Karbunkel', etc.). Beside *kʷr̥mi- exists "a rhyme formation in Indo-European probably for reason of tabu" *u̯r̥mi- (NHG Wurm, cf. Lat. vermis), (so Watkins 1987:288).

"[T]he word for 'worm, serpent, dragon' [in Germanic] is Old English wyrm, Old Norse ormr, Old Saxon and Old High German wurm, Gothic waurms: Germanic *wurmiz exactly cognate with Latin vermis, and presupposing Indo-European *u̯r̥mis. The word is a rhyme formation in Indo-European to *kʷr̥mis, probably for reason of tabu; kʷr̥mis is found in Celtic, Balto-Slavic, Albanian and Indo-Iranian. The usual meaning of *kʷr̥mis is just 'worm' in most traditions, but in Middle Iranian it is also the word for 'dragon'; compare the Pahlavi version of the familiar Indo-European formula: kirm ōzat 'slew the dragon' (Kārnāmak IX). There can be no doubt that in *u̯r̥mis/*kʷr̥mis we have two variants of the same designation of the Indo-European mythological serpent-adversary."

"[T]he word for 'worm, serpent, dragon' [in Germanic] is Old English wyrm, Old Norse ormr, Old Saxon and Old High German wurm, Gothic waurms: Germanic *wurmiz exactly cognate with Latin vermis, and presupposing Indo-European *u̯r̥mis. The word is a rhyme formation in Indo-European to *kʷr̥mis, probably for reason of tabu; kʷr̥mis is found in Celtic, Balto-Slavic, Albanian and Indo-Iranian. The usual meaning of *kʷr̥mis is just 'worm' in most traditions, but in Middle Iranian it is also the word for 'dragon'; compare the Pahlavi version of the familiar Indo-European formula: kirm ōzat 'slew the dragon' (Kārnāmak IX). There can be no doubt that in *u̯r̥mis/*kʷr̥mis we have two variants of the same designation of the Indo-European mythological serpent-adversary."

S.v. Lith. kirmìs 'worm, maggot, snake' (Latv. cirmis 'worm, maggot, snake, caterpillar', OPr. girmis 'maggot'), from PIE *kʷr-m-i- (cf. OCS črъvь 'worm', Skt. kŕ̥mi- 'worm, maggot', OIr. cruim 'worm', W. pryf 'id.').
S.v. Alb. krimb ~ krym 'worm', reflecting PAlb. *krim- and to be connected with IE *kʷr̥mi- 'id.' (cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi-, Lith. kìrmis etc.).
S.v. Alb. krimb, -i 'Wurm, Raupe, Made', the inherited word for 'Wurm', with Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made', Lith. kirmìs 'Made' and formally identical with PIE *kʷr̥mi-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷrimi- 'worm', from PIE *kʷrmi- 'worm' (IEW 1152), cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi-, Alb. krimb, Lith. kirmìs, Sloven. črm.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *wurmi- 'worm', from PIE *urm-i- and identical to Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot' < *urmi-, further cf. Gk. ῥόμος 'wood-worm' < *urm-o- (with dialectal vocalisation of *r̥?); Lith. var̃mas 'insect, mosquito' < *uorm-o-; OCS vьrmьje 'insects' < *urm-io-; OPru. wormyan (adj.) 'red' < urm-io-).

S.v. Goth. W42. waurms 'ὄφις', 'snake', from PIE *u̯er- 'turn, wind' (cf. Gk. Hesych. ῥόμος· σκώληξ ἐν ξύλοις 'woodworm', Lith. var̃mas 'mosquito', Lat. vermis 'worm', OSl. vermije 'grasshoppers, insects').
Cf. s.v. 4104 Skt. gavēdhuka- m. 'a kind of snake'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. gavédukhā- 'Name eines Vieh nicht gefressenen Grases, Coix barbata'. Unclear. Loanwords?
S.v. Skt. gavedukhaḥ 'eine Schlangenart', 'a kind of snake'. Unclear.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *wurmi- 'worm', from PIE *urm-i- and identical to Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot' < *urmi-, further cf. Gk. ῥόμος 'wood-worm' < *urm-o- (with dialectal vocalisation of *r̥?); Lith. var̃mas 'insect, mosquito' < *uorm-o-; OCS vьrmьje 'insects' < *urm-io-; OPru. wormyan (adj.) 'red' < urm-io-).

S.v. Goth. W42. waurms 'ὄφις', 'snake', from PIE *u̯er- 'turn, wind' (cf. Gk. Hesych. ῥόμος· σκώληξ ἐν ξύλοις 'woodworm', Lith. var̃mas 'mosquito', Lat. vermis 'worm', OSl. vermije 'grasshoppers, insects').

"[T]he word for 'worm, serpent, dragon' [in Germanic] is Old English wyrm, Old Norse ormr, Old Saxon and Old High German wurm, Gothic waurms: Germanic *wurmiz exactly cognate with Latin vermis, and presupposing Indo-European *u̯r̥mis. The word is a rhyme formation in Indo-European to *kʷr̥mis, probably for reason of tabu; kʷr̥mis is found in Celtic, Balto-Slavic, Albanian and Indo-Iranian. The usual meaning of *kʷr̥mis is just 'worm' in most traditions, but in Middle Iranian it is also the word for 'dragon'; compare the Pahlavi version of the familiar Indo-European formula: kirm ōzat 'slew the dragon' (Kārnāmak IX). There can be no doubt that in *u̯r̥mis/*kʷr̥mis we have two variants of the same designation of the Indo-European mythological serpent-adversary."

"[T]he word for 'worm, serpent, dragon' [in Germanic] is Old English wyrm, Old Norse ormr, Old Saxon and Old High German wurm, Gothic waurms: Germanic *wurmiz exactly cognate with Latin vermis, and presupposing Indo-European *u̯r̥mis. The word is a rhyme formation in Indo-European to *kʷr̥mis, probably for reason of tabu; kʷr̥mis is found in Celtic, Balto-Slavic, Albanian and Indo-Iranian. The usual meaning of *kʷr̥mis is just 'worm' in most traditions, but in Middle Iranian it is also the word for 'dragon'; compare the Pahlavi version of the familiar Indo-European formula: kirm ōzat 'slew the dragon' (Kārnāmak IX). There can be no doubt that in *u̯r̥mis/*kʷr̥mis we have two variants of the same designation of the Indo-European mythological serpent-adversary."
Cf. s.v. 3441 kr̥śá- 'lean, thin' RV.

Cf. s.v. Ved. kr̥śá- (adj.) 'mager, hager, abgemagert, schlank, schwächlich' (IIr. cf. YAv. kərəsa- in proper names with animal words as the compound member, e.g. kərəsaoxšan-, kərəsāspa-, etc.). To Ved. √karś- from PIE *kerk̑- (*kark̑-?), cf. ON horr 'Abmagerung' Lith. káršti 'alt werden, alterschwach werden, siechen', Cz. krsati 'abnehmen', etc.
Cf. s.v. *k⁽ʷ⁾erk̑- 'abmagern' (IEW 581).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrvь 'worm, maggot' (ESSJa IV 171-172), from Balto-Slavic *kir-m/w-i- (cf. Lith. kirmìs 'worm, maggot, snake', Latv. cirmis 'worm, maggot, caterpillar', OPr. girmis 'maggot'), from PIE *kʷr-m-i- (cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi- 'worm, maggot', OIr. cruim 'worm', W pryf 'worm'). Note the Balto-Slavic vocalisation *ir (instead of *ur) after an original labiovelar is unexpected.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrvь, very close to *čьrmь in the same meaning as attested in PSl. *čьrmelь, *čьrmъ, *čьrmьnъ. IE correspondence can be given for *čьrmь, but *čьrvь is less convincing. Possibly formed to the same element with different *-m-/*-v- formants. Alternatively perhaps the form in *-v arose under influence from other lexemes.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *daru-, *dāru- : dārau-, *dram(?), *drau- : *dru-, *druu̯a- : *dru̯a- 'дерево' (etc.), from PIE *deru-, *dō̆ru-, *dreu- : *dru-, *dru(u̯)-, *dreu-, *drou-; *dreu̯ə- : drū- 'дерево'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *dervo 'tree, wood' (ESSJa IV 211-213), from PIE *deru-o- (cf. Lith. dervà 'chip of kindling wood', Skt. dā́ru- 'wood', Gk. δόρυ 'tree-trunk, wood, spear', Goth. triu 'wood, tree', OIc. tyrvi 'coniferous wood', OE teoru 'tar'); and Proto-Slavic *drъvo 'tree, (pl.) wood' (ESSJa V 141-142), from PIE *dru(H)-o- (cf. Gk. δρῦς 'tree, oak').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *trewa- 'tree', from PIE *dréu-o- (cf. Hitt. tāru- 'wood', ToAB or 'id.', Skt. dā́ru- (gen. dróṣ, drúṇaḥ 'id.'), YAv. dāuru- (gen. draoš) 'wood; tree-trunk', OPers. dāruv 'wood', NP dār 'wood; tree', Gk. δόρυ 'wood, tree(stem), spear', OIr. daur, dair 'oak', W dar 'id.' < PIE *dor-u-; OCS drъva 'wood', Alb. dru / drū 'wood; tree; stem, trunk' < *dru-). The Indo-European word for 'wood' and 'tree'.
Cf. s.v. *deru-, *dō̆ru-, *dr(e)u-, *drou-; *dreu̯ə : drū- 'Baum'.

The forms in this class all go back to an original stem in IE, probably u-stem noun with different Ablaut variants *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dréu̯- ~ *dru-, etc. (cf. IEW 214-217), with individual branches levelling out different variants. IEW reconstructs a paradigm *dṓru n., Gen. *dreu-s, *dru-nó-s, with further derivatives *deru̯o-, *dreu̯o-, *dru-mó-s, *dru-nó-s, *druu̯-ó-s, *drū-tó-s.
S.v. Ved. púccha- 'Schwanz, Schweif, Rute, Hinterteil'. Not satisfactorily explained. Worth considering remains the proposed connections with Germanic words for 'fox' (OHG fuhs, etc.).
Cf. s.v. 1832 *utpruṣati 'bubbles up'. [utprúṣ- f. 'bubble' VS.: √pruṣ-1].
Cf. s.v. Oss. ad | adæ 'вкус'. Etymology unclear. Possibly from *ed- 'eat'? Speculative.
S.v. 10299 Skt. mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, washed, pure' RV., 'prepared, savoury' R., 'sweet, pleasant' MBh., miṣṭa- 1 'dainty, sweet' MBh. [√mr̥j or √mr̥ś].

S.v. Ved. mr̥ṣṭá-, either to Ved. √marj- 'putzen, reinigen, abstreifen, streichen' < PIE *h₂merg̑- 'abstreifen' or to Ved. √marś- 'berühren, anfassen' < PIE *melk̑- (cf. Lat. mulceō 'streiche, streichle, berühre leicht'.
Cf. s.v. *Hmelk̑- 'streichen, berühren' (IEW 724) and *h₂merg̑- 'abstreifen, (ab)wischen' (IEW 738).

IE root etymology uncertain: either to LIV² 226-227 *Hmelk̑- 'abstreifen, (ab)wischen' (> Ved. √marś- 'touch, stroke, handle') or LIV² 280-281 *h₂merg̑- (> Ved. √marj- 'wipe, rub, cleanse'). A blend may also be possible.
Cf. s.v. *su̯eh₂d- 'schmackhaft werden' (IEW 1039-40).
S.v. *su̯eh₂d- 'schmackhaft werden' (LIV 606f., IEW 1039f.).
S.v. *mē(m)s- 'Fleisch' (IEW 725, EIEC 374).
S.v. *mē(m)s- 'Fleisch' (IEW 725, EIEC 374).
S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.).
S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.).
S.v. 11225 vaḍra 'big' lex. [Scarcely with F. Edgerton JAOS 60, 229 < vr̥ddhá- ]

S.v. Skt. vaḍraḥ 'groß', 'big' (prākr. vaḍḍa-, Hindī baṛ 'groß' etc. Not entirely clear; an origin from Middle Indic vaḍḍa- (~ Old Indic lex. vaḍra-) from vr̥ddhá- 'erwachsen, groß, hoch' with loss of aspiration remains possible. Alternatively a Munda origin has been postulated. [Cf. entry for references to further literature.]
Cf. s.v. *gelH- 'Macht bekommen über' (IEW 351). Cf. n1: May also be reconstructed as *galH- if *a transmitted by the individual languages continues the full-grade; *gelH- is nowhere attested.
S.v. 1211 *āpula 'abundant'. 2. *āpura -- [Cf. pula- 'extended, wide' lex., vipula-].
S.v. 4118 gāḍha 'dived into' Kālid., 'pressed together, thick, firm' MBh. [√gāh]

Cf. s.v. Ved. √gāh- 'eindringen, eintreten, ins Wasser steigen, hineinwaten' (deriv. ep. + gāḍha- 'fest, dicht' < *'tief eingedrungen'), probably only to Slavic words like Sloven. gáziti 'waten', SCr. gȁziti 'treten, waten' from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾āg̑ʰ- vel sim.
Cf. s.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- '(ins Wasser) eindringen, hineinwaten' [IEW 465].

Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from or in light-verb constructions with PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth'. The root etymology is traditionally considered to be to PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', however difficulties regarding the Greek comparanda (ὀδών 'tooth', νωδός 'toothless') have led the Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction to consider an underlying root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' (cf. {ref Kortlandt 2003}:77). If the traditional etymology is followed, then these lexemes would also be cognate with Old Irish ithid 'to bite, to eat' in /cognate/6370/ which is clearly derived from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'. For the lexemes in this class, cf. {ref EWAia} I:693-694, {ref Turner 1962–1966}:352 no. 6152, {ref Deshayes 2003}:170, {ref Matasović 2009}:90). For further details regarding the etymology of PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth', cf. further discussion in /cognate/328/.

Cf. s.v. anhēlus 'gasping, panting', from PIE *h₂enh₁-slo- 'a breathing' (cf. OIr. anaid, ·ana 'to stay, wait', Skt. ániti 'to breathe', prāṇá- 'breath, breathing out, air', Goth. *-anan 'to breathe', TochB anāṣṣāṃ 'breathed in').

S.v. Lat. spīrō, -āre, -āuī, -ātum 'souffler (transitif et absolu)'. Without exact correspondences outside of Latin. One can recover here elements that feature in onomatopoeic forms pertaining to breathing. (cf. Gk.  φῦσα 'soufflet', Lith. puntù, pùsti 'souffler', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √śvas- 'schnauben, schnaufen, zischen' (mi. Pā. sasati 'breathes', etc.), from PIE *k̑u̯es- (cf. ON hvæsa 'zischen, schnauben', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ēϸman- ~ *ēdman- 'breathing, breath', from PIE *h₁eh₁t-mon- (cf. Skt. ātmán- 'soul, breath').
Cf. s.v. Ved. ātmán- 'Hauch, Seele, Selbst', pointing to an apparent PIE paradigm with mobile ablaut *éh₁-mō(n), dat.sg. *h₁t-mén-ei̯, cf. OS âthum 'Atem'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *damH-³ 'to blow, breathe; to swell', from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. Skt. dham-ⁱ 'to blow, play a wind instrument, fan the fire', OCS dъmǫ 'to blow', Lith. dùmti 'to blow (also of wind)'.
Cf. s.v. *brēan- 'to fume, smell', from PIE *bʰreh₁-e-, a marginal strong verb from which OE brǣþ 'breath' is a derivative < *brēþi-.
S.v. 12565 Skt. śūná- 'swollen, grown', 12568 Skt. śūyatē 'is swollen' Car.
S.v. Skt. rakta- (1) 'coloured, dyed' ŚBr., 'red' ŚāṅkhGr̥., n. 'blood' Mn., °aka -- 'red' VarBr̥S. [√rañj].
Cf. s.v. Ved. √raj-¹ 'sich färben, sich röten, rot werden', from PIE *(s)reg- (cf. Gk. ῥέζω 'färbe', ῥῆγος 'Teppich', ῥογεύς 'Färber' etc.).
Cf. s.v. *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- '(sich) färben' (IEW 854).

S.v. Wakhi *wəx̌ə́n, *wux̌ə́n 'кровь', from Old Iranian *vahvan(i)- (cf. Av. vohuna-, vohunī-, Khot. hūnä, MSogd. yxwn-, ywxn-, Budd. γwrn wγrn [wuxʳn], Yaghn. wáx(í)n, Ishk. wen, Sangl. wēn, Shugn., Rush. wixín, etc. Tadj., Pers. xun, etc.).
S.v. Lat. mŏrdĕre 'beissen' > Fr. mordre, etc.

Cf. s.v. Sp. morder (< Lat. mordere); Catalan mossegar, It. dial. mosegar < Lat. *mossĭcare, an assimilation from Lat. morsicare, derived from the passive past participle morsus (from the same root as Lat. mordere).

Note that the Oscan form in this class is actually the comparative form of the adjective (the positive is not attested). In Latin the positive is paruus [cf. /cognate/5287/], with comparatives minor and minimus (to this root). The possibility cannot be excluded that the Oscan positive may have also been suppletive in this manner as in Latin.
S.v. Oss. (Di.) mingi(j) 'маленкий, мало, немого, варианты', cf. Lith. meñkas, TochB menki, Ved. manā́k; cf. IE 4. *men- in (IEW 728-9).
Digor isolate. Abaev compares this (or rather the variant mingi) to Lithuanian meñkas 'minuscule, insignificant' and Old Indic manāk 'few'. The Iron term čəšəl is an Iron isolate.

Cf. s.v. Skt. manāk (ep. kl.), which is not satisfactorily explained. The Vedic formant in °āk seems to be a formation °āñc-; the element man° is with Gk. μᾱνός, μανός 'dünn, locker', Lith. meñkas 'gering, klein', etc., cf. esp. Oss. mingi(j) 'klein, wenig'.

The basis of the Ossetic lexeme may go back to a root *men- (cf. IEW 728-729) if Abaev and EWAia are correct in connecting the lexeme to the basis of Skt. manāk 'a little, slightly, in a small degree', but there are many unclear details of this etymology.
S.v. ON smár 'klein'. An etymology outside of Germanic is doubtful. [Cf. entry for references to earlier proposals.]

S.v. Gmc. *leitila- 'klein'. From the root *leit- there also are *leitena-, *leitika-/*littika-. Beside these is a root *lū̆t- in *lut(t)i-, *luttika-, *lūtila-/*luttila-. It alternates also a) ei/i and ū/u, b) t and tt, c) the suffixes -ena-, -ika-, and -ila-. The root *leit- is common Germanic, while *litt- and lūt- are only West Germanic. Close possibilities for comparisons outside of Germanic are lacking.
For the Frisian form, cf. s.v. leitika- 'klein'.
Root ref. form *leit- in this class follows Heidermanns 1993.
S.v. Lith. mãžas 'klein, gering, wenig'. The etymology of Lith. mãžas, Latv. mazs, etc. is disputed.
S.v. Alb. vogël 'small'. Inconclusive. No clear etymology.
S.v. pamʹařuk  Aj.  Small. [OIA. manʹâk ‘a little’  T. 9824 (+; or < T. 9825 mʹanu- 'man')].
Etymology unclear, cf. entry in Strand's kâtʹa vari lexicon (Strand 2011a) suggesting either to Skt. manāk 'a little, slightly, to a small degree' [cf. /cognate/8402/] or to Skt. mánu- 'man'.
If the equation of Av. kasu- with Ved. kaśu- (EWAia I:330) is correct, then we may reconstruct PIIr. *kaću-.
S.v. Rom. mic, probably from Lat. *miccus.
Cf. s.v. *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'zerstieben, in kleine Teile zerfallen' (IEW 625). Cf. n1: "Vgl. Ved. kṣudrá- 'klein, winzig', OCS chudъ 'klein, gering'".
S.v. *stinkwan- 'to thrust, to clash; to stink', from PIE *sténgʷ-e- (cf. Lat. re-stinguō, -ere 'to push back, suppress' < -sténgʷ-e-; Lith. sténgti (sténgiu) 'to exert oneself' < *stengʷ-ie-).
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *stenkw-a- 'stoßen'. NB Seebold regards the comparanda in Lat., Lith. not entirely secure.

S.v. *stengʷ- 'stoßen' [IEW 1033]. Cf. n2: "An. støkkva 'springen, stürzen', ae. stincan 'springen; riechen', ahd. stinkan 'riechen, stinken' mit weiterer Bedeutungsentwicklung, vgl. Seebold [1970:]471-2."
S.v. 4014 Skt. gandhá- 'smell' RV.

S.v. Ved. gandhá- 'Geruch, Duft', not to be separated from YAv. gaiṇti- 'übler Geruch', duž-gaiṇti- 'übelriechend, stinkend', Parth. gndʾg 'stinkend', MPers., NPers. gand 'Gestank', etc. Further connections are uncertain.
Cf. s.v. śr̥ṅkhāṇikā- 'Rotz', perhaps with Pāli śiṅghati 'riecht' to a root *śr̥ṅkh- (cf. Turner 1962-1966:729). Not securely explained.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *smeuk-a- 'rauchen'. Germanic smeuk-a- can be connected with some extra-Germanic words, but the formal and semantic aspects are less secure. The Germanic forms formally correspond to Lith. smáugiu, -ti 'erwürgen, quälen' and Gk. (aor.) ἐσμύγην 'schwelte' (auch vom Schmerz), but because of the semantics the comparison is very uncertain. Formally less secure, but semantically better are *smeu-k- found in OIr. múch 'Rauch' and *smeu-gh- in Gk. σμύχω 'schwele'.
S.v. Wakhi δαy 'муж, мужчина, человек', IIr. *δaha-, Khot. daha- 'муж, мужчина', cf. Ved. dāsá- 'не ариец, раб', etc.

Cf. s.v. Ved. dāsá- 'ein den ā́rya- feindlicher Volksstamm, Feind, feindlicher Dämon; Sklave, Diener' (IIr. cf. Khot. daha-, Waxi δay 'Mann', etc.). Probably not to be separated from dásyu- 'Götterfeind, Feind, Dämon (etc.)' < IIr. *dási̯u- 'Feind, Fremder, Fremdvolk', further connections are uncertain.
S.v. Romanian bărbát, -ă, from Lat. barbatus.

Cf. s.v. Lat. barba 'beard', from which barbātus 'bearded' is derived. Lat. barba may go back to Proto-Italic *farfā- 'beard' and compared with OPr. bordus 'beard', Lith. barzdà, Latv. bā̀rda, OCS brada, Ru. borodá 'id.' < PSl. *bordáʔ, OHG bart, OE beard, OFr. berd < Gmc. bard-a-. From PIt. farfa we expect Lat. *farba. Earlier sources (cf. Ernout-Meillet 1985) explain the initial b- from assimilation to -rb-. The *a is difficult to explain via ablaut and rather points to a non-IE borrowing into the European languages.
S.v. Oss. læǧz | liǧz 'гладкий, ровный, равнина', from Ir. *(h)laxš- < IE *sleg-sk- (cf. Ved. slakṣṇa-).
NB: Abaev further connects the Iranian lexemes to a common IE-base *(s)lei- (cf. Gk. λεῖος) with a root-extension *-g̑-, but whether these are actually the same root is unclear.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *slimono- 'polished, smooth', from PIE *slei̯- 'smear (with grease), polish' (cf. Lat. līmō 'polish', OHG slīmen 'polish'). The Proto-Celtic word appears to contain the suffix *-ono- also found in *antono- 'forehead').
Cf. s.v. Old Welsh limnint (3.pl.pres.) 'to make smooth, polish' [llyfn-], traditionally from PIE *(s)lei- 'schleimig, durch Nässe glitschiger Boden, ausgleiten' (cf. IEW 663).

Traditionally connected to a common IE root *lei- 'schlemig, durch Nässe glitschiger Boden, ausgleiten, worüber hinschleifen oder -streichen, auch glättend worüber fahren', where the Celtic forms exhibit s-mobile; Lat. & Gk. without.

NB: The usual reconstruction *(s)lei̯- is given for this root. de Vaan (2008:336-337) gives *leh₁-i-u- with *h₁ in order to include a connection to Gk. λίς, λῑτός 'smooth' (adj.), 'smooth linen' (m.) < *liH-t-, but this seems unnecessary from the point of view of Lat. lēvis alone. A PIE u-stem noun *lei̯-u- can account for both the Lat. lēuis and Gk. λεῖος; if one assumes *leh₁i-u̯-o- as a preform for Greek, one might expect *λῇος.
S.v. Sp. liso, a word common to the Romance languages of Iberia, France, the Alps, Italy, and Sardinia. They presuppose a Romance stem *līsĭus of uncertain origin, probably expressive.
S.v. Lat. lĭxare 'glätten' > OFr. lisé, MFr. lissé, NFr. lisser.
S.v. OIr. mín 'doux au toucher, uni'. The root of Ir. mín may be *mei- designating softness (cf. Skt. mayaḥ 'joie, plaisir', Lat. mītis [IEW 712, 728]).

Cf. s.v. OIr. *mēto-, *mēti- 'fat, soft' > OIr. méth 'plump, fat', etc., from PIE *mey(H)-t- (IEW 711f.), cf. Lat. mītis 'mild, mellow, juicy'. The same root could account for OIr. mín 'tender, soft' < PCl. mīno- < *miHno-.

Some aspects of the root reconstruction are disagreed upon (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:383 s.v. Lat. mītis), but generally the cognacy of the Celtic and Italic lexemes are agreed. {ref Matasović 2009}:278-279 suggests an alternative etymology s.v. Proto-Celtic *moyni- 'treasure, precious object' for potentially connected lexemes (W mwyn 'mild, tender, gentle', MoBret. moan 'tender, thin', OCo. muin 'thin' < *mēnV- < *meyHnV-), but is cryptic as to whether OIr. mín also should belong to this alternative etymology (not mentioned under the lemma for *moyni-).

Cf. s.v. OIr. mil 'miel', from which OIr. milis 'doux, agréable au goût, suave'. The same word is found under the form mel in Gaulish, Cornish, and Breton, from which Gaul. melus and melys 'doux'. The stem (meli- is inflected as an i-stem, but the dental stem appears in milis < *melit-ti- (cf. Gk. μέλι, gen. μέλιτος, Goth. miliϸ).
Cf. s.v. OIr. dó- 'brûler, se consumer', to be connected with the root *duwə-, *dū- (cf. Skt. dunóti 'il brûle, il afflige, il fait du mal' Gk. δαίω 'j'allume', etc.).

The connection of Irish: Gaelic dóigh to this class assumes that it is cognate with OIr. dó- 'burn' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:111-112, {ref LIV²} 104-105). There remains the possibility that there may have been contamination in the Middle Irish period with OIr. daig 'flame, blaze' derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:8-9 s.v. daig, {ref Matasović 2009}:93).
S.v. Wakhi θaw- : θət- 'жечь, гореть'
Cf. s.v. Dev (adj.) 'brûlé', to a Celtic root *deb-, cf. devo (v.) 'brûler' attested in Old Breton in past part. deuuet-, identical to Cornish dywy and Gaulish deifio.
S.v. OIr. ciïd 'il se lamente, pleure'. Of uncertain etymology. Cf. entry for several doubtful proposals in older literature.

S.v. adarc 'corne'. Gaulish has a word adarca that has been borrowed into Latin and Greek under the form ἀδάρκης or ἀδάρκη, ἄδαρκον, ἀδάρκιον, which designates a kind of seaweed which is attached to reeds and is used in medicine. This is without doubt the same word, but the semantic connection is not clearly visible. One could explain the word as a compound of the preverb ad- and the root *ark- 'protéger, défendre, écarter' (Lat. arceō), the horn being considered as a 'defense', but in the absence of a secure connection, the etymology is difficult to judge.

S.v. OIr. muin 'cou; partie supérieure du dos'; a word common to Celtic. Outside of Celtic it my be connected with Lat. monīle 'collier' and Skt. manyā 'nuque', as well as ON mǫn, etc. The root of all these words is *men- 's'élever, être proéminent', cf. Lat. ē-minēre, etc. (IEW 726).

S.v. TochB ek* 'eye', which with TochA ak reflects Proto-Tocharian *ek from PIE *h₃e/okʷ- (cf. Skt. ákṣi (nt.), Av. aši 'both eyes', Arm. akn 'eye', Greek ὄσσε 'both eyes', ὄμμα 'eye', Lat. oculus 'eye', Goth. augo 'eye', Lith. akìs 'eye' OCS oko 'eye', Alb. sy (< *h₃okʷi- + -ōu?) etc.).
Cf. s.v. Gk. ὄμμα, -ατος 'eye; look, sight, face', a verbal noun in -μα to ὄπ- < *h₃ekʷ-; cf. the dual form ὄσσε < *h₃ekʷ-ih₁. [NB: cf. also s.v. ὀφθαλμός and notes to /cognate/7477/.]
S.v. Arm. akn 'eye', deriving from the PIE word for 'eye' *h₃(o)kʷ- + singulative -n.

S.v. Ved. ákṣi- 'Auge' (cf. IIr. Av. aš- in YAv. du. aši 'die beiden Augen', etc.), cf. Lith. akìs 'Auge', OCS du. oči 'beide Augen' and to be further connected with Lat. oculus, Gk. ὄσσε, ὀφθαλμός, ὄκταλλος, ὀπτίλλος from PIE *h₃ekʷ-.
S.v. Lith. akìs 'eye' (Latv. acs 'eye', OPr. agins 'eye', ackis 'eyes'), from PIE *h₃ekʷ-i- (cf. OCS oko, Skt. ákṣi- 'eye', Gk. ὄσσε 'two eyes', Lat. oculus 'eye').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *oko 'eye' (ESSJa XXXII 13, 41-42), from PIE *h₃ekʷ-o- (cf. Skt. ákṣi- 'eye', Gk. ὄσσε 'eyes', Lat. oculus 'eye').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *augōn- 'eye', from PIE *h₃okʷ-n- (cf. Skt. ákṣi- 'eye', YAv. aši- 'eyes' (du.) < *h₃okʷ-s-; TochA ak, TochB ek* < *h₃okʷ-, Gk. ὄσσε 'two eyes' (du.) < *h₃okʷ-ih₁; Arm. akn 'eye; source' < *h₃okʷ-; Alb. sy 'id.' < *h₃ekʷ-ih₁; Lat. oculus 'eye' < *h₃okʷ-elo-; Lith. akìs, Latv. acs, OPr. ackis, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9).
S.v. Proto-Iranian *čašman- < *ča(ś)š-man- 'глаз', derived from Proto-Iranian *čaš-, from IE *kʷek̑-s- (cf. Ved. cákṣus-, cákṣ-as-).
S.v. Old Welsh licat 'source of river or well' (< 'eye') [llygad], derived from PIE *leu̯k- 'leuchten'.
S.v. Bret. lagad (OBret. lagat) 'œil; douille', corresponding to Co. lagas 'œil', etc., from Brythonic *lukato-.
Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).
S.v. Gk. ὀφθαλμός 'Auge', attempts to analyse the root of the stem as a continuant of the inherited word for 'eye' also found in Gk. ὄμμα, ὄσσε, ὄπωπα, etc.
S.v. Gk. ὄπωπα, ὄψομαι, ὄψ, ὤψ, with root meaning 'voir', arguing for ὀφθαλμός as a derivative of the IE root *okʷ- (*ə₃ekʷ), cf. Lat. oculus, etc.
S.v. Hitt. sakui- 'eye; opening, hole'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *glazъ (ESSJa VI 117-118): "Etymology unclear. If we accept that here the *z arose from *s as a result of Zupitza’s law (cf. Shevelov 1964: 147-148), it is possible to establish a connection with OHG glas ‘glass, amber’, MoE glare, etc. The correctness of the law is doubtful, however."
S.v. 6582 Skt. dōla- 'swinging' > M. ḍoḷā m. 'eye'

S.v. Ved. parṇá- 'Flügel, Feder, Pfeilfeder, Blatt' (IIr. cf. YAv. parəna- 'Feder', Khot. pārra- 'Flügel', MPers., NPers. parr 'Feder', etc.), probably from PIE *(s)por-no- (cf. OHG farn 'Farn', Lith. spar̃nas 'Flügel, Schaufel, Blatt').
Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)per- 'fliegen' [IEW 817, 850].

S.v. Proto-Slavic *pero 'feather', from PIE *perH-o- (cf. Skt. parṇá- 'wing', Gk. πτερόν 'feather, wing', OE fearn 'fern', OIr. raith 'fern'). The reconstruction of a laryngeal is based on Lith. papártis 'fern'. [Corrigendum to Derksen: The Greek comparandum πτερόν listed does not belong here, but rather belongs to *pet-, not *(s)per-, cf. /cognate/7563/ (MJCS).]

S.v. перо 'Feder', related to Lith. spar̃nas 'Flügel, Fittich', Latv. sparns 'id.', Ved. parṇám 'Flügel, Fittich', Av. parəna- 'Feder', OHG farn 'Farnkraut'. Less likely is the comparison with Gk. πτερόν 'Feder, Flügel', πέτομαι 'fliege', Ved. pátram 'Fittich, Flügel, Feder', etc.

S.v. TochB parwa 'feathers', which reflects Proto-Tocharian *pärwā, as though from PIE *p(e)rweh₂ (nt.pl.). The best potential cognate is OCS pero 'feather' as though from PIE *peróm (nt.), both derivatives of the PIE root *per- 'move (tr./intr.); fly (intr.) (cf. OCS perǫ 'fly', Skt. pipárti 'brings', Gk. περάω 'pierce', Lat. portō 'bring', Goth. faran 'travel', etc.).

S.v. Ved. pátra- Flügel (eines Vogels), Feder', derived from a heteroclitic *pat-r-/*pat-n- and cognate with Germ. Feder, Engl. feather, Old Welsh eterin 'bird', atan 'wing', etc., cf. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschießend fliegen, stürzen, fallen' from PIE *pet- (cf. Lat. petō, Gk. πέτομαι, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.

S.v. OIr. súil 'œil', the word goes back originally to *sūli- and originally designated the 'sun', like Skt. sū́raḥ, sū́ryaḥ, Alb. hul. The Brythonic forms still designate the sun from *sāwel- (W. haul, MCo. heuul, Co. heul, houl, Bret. heol. The semantic change is explained by the fact that the sun was considered like an eye. This concept is widespread in Vedic, Homeric Greek, and Armenian (areg-akn 'eye of the sun').
S.v. OIr. (1) derc 'œil' and 'lac', also 'ouverture, caverne' and 'tombe', 'fente (d'un vêtement)'. The same root apparently as in drech 'visage', *derk-.
Cf. s.v. *derk̑- 'hinblicken, erblicken' (IEW 213).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *feϸrō- 'feather', from PIE *péth₂-r/n- (cf. Hitt. pattar ~ pattan-, pettar ~ pettan- 'feather, wing' < *peth₂-r, *pth₂-én-s; Skt. pátra- 'wing, feather' < *peth₂-ro-, Gk. πτέρον 'wing' < *pt(h₂)-er-o-; Lat. penna 'feather' < *peth₂-n-eh₂-; OW atar 'bird', MW adar 'id.', OIr. én 'bird', W edn 'id.' < *peth₂-no-).

S.v. Lat. penna 'wing, feather', from PIE *pet-n-h₂- 'wing, feather' (cf. OW eterin 'bird', atan 'wing' < *pt-r/n-; Hitt. pattar / pattan- or pettar / pettan- < *póth₂-r, *pth₂-én-s or *peth₂-(ō)r, *peth₂-én-; Skt. pátra- 'wing (of a bird), feather', pátaṅga- 'flying; bird', Av. patarə-ta- 'winged', NHG Feder 'feather'.

OIr. ette, eitte 'a wing, pinion; fin', 'a feather, plume'; no correspondences to other Celtic languages. The derivation of this word from the PIE root *pet- 'fliegen, fallen' (IEW 825ff.) is relatively certain, but the formal reconstruction is debated regarding certain details.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *fet-no- 'bird' and *fet-o- 'fly' as derivatives of PIE *pet-. [Matasović does not discuss the origins of Goidelic forms from OIr. ette.]

S.v. Lat. longus 'long' from PIE *dlongʰ-o- (cf. *dólugʰ- in Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long', PIE *dlh₁gʰ-o- in Skt. dīrghá- OAv. darəga-, OCS dlъgъ, SCr. dȕg, Lith. ìlgas, Alb. gjathë (+ *-tā-); Gk. δολιχός (< *dolh₁-i-gʰo-?), ἐνδελεχής 'lasting long, uninterrupted' < *delh₁gʰ-; PIE *dlongʰ-o- in Goth. laggs, OHG lang, OIc. langr, etc.). The root might be *de/olh₁-, cf. Cz. dél (poet.) 'length' < PSl. *dьlь, etc.

The same root as 'long' in /cognate/257/. The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated (cf. citations to {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:819-821, {ref EWAia} s.v. Ved. dīrghá- cited in /cognate/257/), the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is, however, generally agreed. The reconstructed root form for this class follows {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ferrai (adv.) 'far', from PIE *per-n-oi-, a locative adverb originally ending in -noi.

S.v. Arm. *haṙ- 'far' : haṙi adv. 'far (of time and space); isolated, foreign', adj. 'distant, far off, of long duration'. Since long connected with Goth. fairra 'far', OHG ferro, Skt. parás 'far, further', etc.
S.v. Lat. procul 'some distance away, (far) away, apart' [adv.], from PIE *pro 'in front of', perhaps via Proto-Italic *pro-k(w)o- 'at the front'?
Cf. s.v. *pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft mit Abl.; and s.v. *li, le 'dort drüben, fern; dann' Partikel, ferndeikt.; Adverb, temporal.

S.v. Lat. procul 'à distance, au loin; loin de'. The word is probably composed of prō̆- and an old adverb connected to W. pell 'loin', Gk. τῆλε 'loin', πάλαι 'autrefois', Skt. caramáḥ 'le dernier'. The semantics of 'far' would have come from the second part of the compound (similarly cf. abhinc, exinde, etc.).
S.v. Skt. pipīláḥ 'Ameise / ant'. An unclear, probably non-Indic word.

S.v. ξανθός 'gelb, goldgelb, rötlich, bräunlich, blond'. Unexplained. On the very remote proposed relationship with Lat. cānus 'grau(-weiß)' (cf. W.-Hofmann, IEW 533 (with literature). Of less value is the comparison with Etr. zamθic, supposedly, 'made of gold'.

S.v. ξανθός 'jaune, doré, blond'. Etymology unknown. The connection with Lat. cānus recalled by Frisk and IEW 533 is not plausible, neither semantically nor formally. Likewise proposed connections to Etruscan zamθic 'd'or' is unlikely.
S.v. 8230 Skt. pīta- 'yellow', 8233 Skt. pītala (1) 'yellow' lex. 2. *pīthala- 3. *pīvala- 4. *pīvaḍa-; cf. also 8181 Skt. pittá- 'bile'.
S.v. Ved. pīta- 'gelb'. Of unclear etymology. Perhaps connected with Ved. pittá- 'Galle'.
Cf. s.v. *bʰleh₃- 'blühen' (IEW 122).
For Nuristan languages cf. s.v. 13990 haridra- '*green, *yellow' (m. 'yellow sandal tree') to Ved. hari-.

S.v. TochB tute 'yellow', which reflects a conflation of PIE *dʰuHto- and its *h₁en-stem counterpart *dʰuHte-h₁en-. PIE *dʰuHto- is exactly equivalent to Skt. dhūtá-, the past participle of Skt. dhū- 'shake, agitate, cause to tremble' from PIE *dʰeu̯H- '±(make) rise as a cloud of dust'. In Tocharian the meaning 'yellow' presumably arose from 'covered with dust'.
Cf. s.v. *dʰeu̯H- 'rasch hin und her bewegen, schütteln' (IEW 261-3).
S.v. 3993 Skt. gaṇáyati 'counts'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. gaṇá- 'Schar, Reihe, Gefolge, Anhang, kleinere Heeresabteilung'. Ved. gaṇá- probably originally meaning *'Zahl', to judge from the verb gaṇá-y° 'zählen', cf. also *gr̥nti- 'counting' (T. 4234). No further consensus on an etymology.
S.v. Kâmv'iri ćʹia- [ćinʹa- past; [no causative]]  VI.  Be cut; fray, wear out; wane [moon].  [ćiNa-D]  [PrAr. *s-či-d-a- ‘cuts’  T. 5041]
S.v. 5041 *chidati 'cuts' [√chid-].
Cf. s.v. Ved. √ched- 'zerspalten, abschneiden, abhauen, zerbrechen, zerschneiden, zerreißen', from PIE *sk̑⁽ʰ⁾ei̯d- (cf. Gk. σχίζω 'spalte, durchschneide', Lat. scindō 'schlitze, zerreiße', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *sk̑ʰei̯d- 'spalten, abtrennen, zerreißen' (IEW 920-1).

S.v. Arm. mēg 'mist, fog, darkness', usually understood to be cognate with Skt. meghá- 'cloud, gloomy weather', Av. maēγa- 'cloud', Gk. ὀμίχλη 'mist, fog', Lith. miglà 'fog', etc. From PIE *h₃meigʰ-o- or *h₃meigʰ-eh₂-. The possibility remains that Arm. mēg might also be an Iranian loan (cf. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:474 s.v. mez 'urine').

S.v. Ved. meghá- 'Wolke, trübes Wetter' (root noun mih- 'Nebel, Niederschlag, Regen'). IIr. cf. YAv. maēγa- 'Wolke', MPers., NPers. mēγ 'Wolke, Nebel', Oss. mīg/megæ 'Wolke, Nebel', etc., from PIE *h₃mei̯gʰ-, from which nominal derivations like *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- (meghá-), *h₃migʰ- (mih-) and *h₃migʰ-leh₂ (cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη 'Nebel', Lith. miglà, OCS mьgla 'Nebel').
S.v. Lith. miglà 'mist, haze', from PIE *h₃migʰ-leh₂- (cf. OCS mьgla, Skt. meghá- 'cloud, gloomy weather', míh- 'haze, rain', Gk. ὀμίχλη 'mist, haze', YAv. maēγa- 'cloud', Arm. mēg 'mist').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *mьgla, mьga, miglъ 'mist, haze' (ESSJa XXI 92-94), from PIE *h₃migʰ-leh₂ (cf. Lith. miglà 'mist, haze', Skt. meghá- 'cloud, gloomy weather', Skt. mih- 'haze, rain', Gk. ὀμίχλη 'mist, haze', Av. maēγa- 'cloud', Arm. mēg 'mist'). Cf. entry for extensive discussion of the PIE root reconstruction.

Cf. s.v. Lat. fūmus 'smoke, fumes' (denominal vb. fūmāre 'to emit smoke or steam), from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- 'smoke, fume' (cf. Skt. dhūmá- 'smoke, fume', Gk. θῡμός 'spirit', OPr. dumis 'smoke', Lith. dū̀mai 'smoke', OCS dymъ 'smoke', OHG toum 'steam').
S.v. 6849 Skt. dhūmá- m. 'smoke, vapour, mist'.
S.v. ON ϸoka 'nebel'. Etymology disputed.
S.v. 1. *men- 'emporragen' & s.v. *mono- 'Nacken, Hals'.
Cf. s.v. ?3. *men- 'emporragen' (IEW 726).

S.v. sengán 'fourmi', from seng 'mince' + a diminutive suffix. OIr. seng may perhaps be from a root *su̯eng- (or *su̯eg- with with a nasal-infix) expressing the idea of a movement of the body (cf. Germ. schwingen (IEW 1047).
Cf. s.v. Germanic *swengw-a- 'schwingen', no secure comparisons outside of Germanic.
S.v. OIr. droch (1) 'mauvais'. The Celtic forms may be related to an earlier *druko-, for which there are no plausible further connections. Cf. entry for a survey of older literature.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *swerwo- 'bitter'. These Celtic words lack a persuasive IE etymology. A connection with *su̯er- 'wound' (postulated by IEW 1050) is possible (cf. Av. xᵛara- 'wound', OHG swero 'pain').

S.v. OIr. (1) serb 'amer'. The Celtic forms suppose a root *swer- followed by a suffix -wo-. The root signifies without doubt 'faire souffrir' (cf. Av. xʷara 'blessure', OHG swero 'maladie, douleur, abcès').
S.v. séit- 'souffler', a root that appears to be *su̯eizd- in Irish, *su̯izd- in Brythonic (cf. OCS svistati, zvizdati 'sibilare', Gk. σίζω 'je siffle').

S.v. OIr. cnáim 'os'. One usually compares Gk. κνήμη 'jambe' and, in another ablaut grade *konmā in OHG hamma 'cuisse, jarret' (cf. OEng. hamm). This comparison is only possible by admitting the words go back to a base *knā- 'ronger'.

S.v. OIr. ucht 'poitrine (de l'homme et des animaux)'. Older literature compares Latv. pups, Lith. pápas 'id.' from child language. Perhaps better would be to start from *pektu- (becoming *puktu-) and admit an Italo-Celtic origin of Ir. ucht and Lat. pectus. The two words do not have any other known correspondences.

S.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'poitrine de l'homme ou des animaux'. A similar word differing in -o- root vocalism and u-stem inflection is found in Irish ucht 'poitrine'. There are no other correspondences outside of these two languages.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *stьblo 'stem, stalk, trunk', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *stib- (cf. Lith. stibnýa 'shin, calf', stíebas 'stem, stalk, mast', Latv. stiba 'staff, rod). No certain etymology beyond Balto-Slavic.

Cf. s.v. TochB karītsñe* '±wetness' (??). The identification of the meaning 'wetness' is contextual. If the abstract is correctly identified, it would be derived from an adjective of possession *karītstse (i.e. kāri + -tstse). No further etymology given.
Argues against the traditional etymology to *u̯egʷ- (cf. Ernout-Meillet 1985:745), instead to *u̯eh₁-.

Cf. s.v. Lat. ūmeō, -ēs, -ēre 'être humide (surtout poétique)': The origins of the group comprising ūueō, ūuēscō, ūuidus (ūdus), ūlīgō are less clear. We suggest a connection to Greek ὑγρός 'humide', which resembles Arm. oyc 'frais' and OIc. vokr 'humide'. One would start from *ug-sm- or *oug-sm-, and from *e/oug-w-. One cannot trace a precise history.

Etymology for these lexemes follows that of Weiss (1994:143-145) and de Vaan (2008:639-640) to *u̯eh₁- over the older connection to *u̯egʷ- (cf. Ernout & Meillet 1985:745-746). Romanian ud 'wet' < Lat. ūdus may belong to this class but could also belong to PIE *u̯egʷ- in /cognate/5276/, cf. discussion in /cognate/8427/.
S.v. Rom. ud, from Lat. udus.

S.v. Lat. ūvidus 'soaked', with derivatives ūvor 'moisture', uvēscere 'to become wet', ūdus 'liquid, wet, drunken', ūdor. "The order of attestation suggests that ūdus is a recent contraction of ūvidus, but Weiss (1995[:141ff.]) reckons with the possibility that ūdus was older, and that ūvidus was back-formed to it as a hyperarchaism. Lat. ūdus might reflect *we/ogʷ-ϸo-, *ugʷ-iϸo- or *uh₁-iϸo-. Alternatively, Weiss suggests that ūvidus acquired ū- from its close semantic cognate ūmidus, thus hiding an earlier stage *uwidos." [Ultimately de Vaan seems to accept the etymology with PIE *uegʷ- as more likely than to *ueh₁-].

Cf. s.v. Lat. ūmeō, -ēs, -ēre 'être humide (surtout poétique)': The origins of the group comprising ūueō, ūuēscō, ūuidus (ūdus), ūlīgō are less clear. We suggest a connection to Greek ὑγρός 'humide', which resembles Arm. oyc 'frais' and OIc. vokr 'humide'. One would start from *ug-sm- or *oug-sm-, and from *e/oug-w-. One cannot trace a precise history.

Lat. ūvidus usually argued to continue *u̯egʷ-, but Weiss makes the case for the possibility that it could just as well continue *u̯eh₁-. The root etymology of Lat. ūvidus, ūdus is ultimately uncertain.

Rom. ud is from Lat. ūdus 'wet, moist' (cf. {ref Ciorănescu et al. 2002} s.v. ud). The IE root etymology remains unclear. The traditional etymology of Lat. ūdus is to PIE *u̯egʷ- 'make damp (so {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:745-746, with references to earlier literature, tentatively also {ref de Vaan 2008}:648; cf. {ref LIV²} 662-663, {ref IEW} 1118), but {ref Weiss 1994}:141-143 makes a convincing case that a derivation to PIE *u̯eh₁- (cf. {ref NIL} 715-717 s.v. *u̯eh₁-r-. *uh₁-r- 'Wasser'; {ref IEW} 80f., {ref EIEC} 636) may also be a strong possibility. The prevailing majority opinion seems to judge the connection to *u̯egʷ- for Lat. ūdus to be more likely than *u̯eh₁- (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:639-640 s.v. ūmeō and notes to /cognate/1578/), albeit still uncertain.
Romanian ud < Lat. ūdus may belong to this class, but could also belong to PIE *u̯eh₁- in /cognate/1578/, cf. discussion in /cognate/8427/.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *mokrъ 'wet, damp' (ESSJa XIX 144), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *mok- (cf. Lith. makõnė 'mud').

S.v. Ved. √khan-ⁱ 'graben' (IIr. cf. YAv. us-kəṇti 'gräbt aus', ni-kaiṇti 'gräbt ein', MPers. NPers. kandan 'graben', etc.). PIE probably *kenh₁- (cf. OPhryg. keneman 'probably … a monument or part of it).

Root ref. form for this class follows the reconstruction of LIV², but cf. EWAia and Cheung 2007. We may be dealing with a specifically IIr. root *kʰanH- (< ?*kenh₁-, if the comparison to Phrygian keneman (a monument or part of it) is correct).

S.v. Khot. ṣkala- 'dry places', from hišku- > ṣka- (cf. Av. hišku- 'dry', Sogd. Man. šqwyy 'dry' (*hiškuvaka-), šwkčʾ 'dry', prʾškwč 'dry'. IEW 894-895 *sek- (cf. OIr. sesc W. hysp, Bret. hesp, hesk 'dry').

Cf. s.v. Ved. √sac-² 'versiegen, stocken, trocken sein' (IIr. cf. YAv. hi-šk-u- 'ausgetrocknet', Man. Sogd. škw- 'trocken', Khot. ṣkala 'dry places'), from PIE *sek- (cf. Lith. sèkti 'sich senken, sinken, versiegen', Hom. ἔσκετο φωνή 'es stockte die Stimme', MIr. sesc 'trocken, unfruchtbar', etc.).
S.v. Lith. saũsas 'dry', from PIE *h₂sous-o- (cf. OCS suxъ 'dry', Skt. śúṣka- 'dry, barren', Gk. [Hom.] αὖος 'dry', OE sēar 'dry').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *suxъ 'dry', from PIE *h₂sous-o- (cf. Lith. saũsas, Skt. śúṣka- 'dry, barren', Gk. [Hom.] αὖος 'dry', OE sēar 'dry').

Cf. s.v. *seu̯k̑- 'saugen' (IEW 912-3). Cf. n1: There seem to have been phonetic variants which were generalised as different roots. Italic and Germanic appear to have inherited both variants, cf. Lat. sūgō 'sauge' but sūcus 'Saft' < *sóu̯k̑-o-; OE sūcan zu *seu̯g̑- beside sūgan- < *séu̯k̑-. The identity of the velar as palatovelar is based on the OCS cognate sъsǫ (sъsati) 'saugen'.
S.v. ON mold 'erde' (cf. Goth. mulda 'staub', OE, OFr. molde), participle to PIE *mel- 'zermalmen' (Ved. mr̥d- 'lehm, ton, erde', Lith. mìltai 'mehl').

S.v. Goth. M79. mulda 'κονιορτός, χοῦς', 'dust' (OIc. mold, OE, OFris. molde, OHG molta 'dust, earth, mold', OE myl, MLG mol 'dust' NLG, NHG müll 'rubbish'), etc., from PIE *mel- 'crush, grind' as *malan (cf. Skt. mlā-tá- (mlā́yati 'wither'), Gk. ἀμαλός; OIr. mlāth, blāith 'soft', Wel. blawd, Lith. mìltai 'flour', OCS mladъ 'soft', mlěti 'grind').
Cf. s.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-7).

S.v. Goth. M79. mulda 'κονιορτός, χοῦς', 'dust' (OIc. mold, OE, OFris. molde, OHG molta 'dust, earth, mold', OE myl, MLG mol 'dust' NLG, NHG Müll 'rubbish'), etc., from PIE *mel- 'crush, grind' as *malan (cf. Skt. mlā-tá- (mlā́yati 'wither'), Gk. ἀμαλός; OIr. mlāth, blāith 'soft', Wel. blawd, Lith. mìltai 'flour', OCS mladъ 'soft', mlěti 'grind').
Cf. s.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-7).
Cf. s.v. ON mold 'erde' (cf. Goth. mulda 'staub', OE, OFr. molde), participle to PIE *mel- 'zermalmen' (Ved. mr̥d- 'lehm, ton, erde', Lith. mìltai 'mehl').
10286 S.v. Ved. mr̥ttikā- f. 'earth, clay' VS. [*mr̥tti- in Pk. and some cmpds. √mr̥d-]
Cf. s.v. Ved. √mrad- 'sanft machen, weich machen', not to be separated from Ved. mr̥dú- (PIE *(h₂)ml̥d-ú-).
Cf. s.v. *meld- 'weich werden' (IEW 718).
Cf. s.v. 10286 s.v. mŕ̥ttikā- f. 'earth, clay' (VS), and s.v. 10287 s.v. *mr̥ttya- ʻearthʼ < *mr̥tti-, cf. Prakrit macca- n. ʻdirtʼ; Ash. (Wama) mič ʻclayʼ.

S.v. Skt. mr̥tsná- 'Staub, Pulver', 'dust, powder', to be connected with the root of mr̥dnā́ti 'drückt, presst, reibt', 'presses, squeezes,
 rubs', (√mr̥d-, cf. Gk. μέλδω).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √mrad- 'sanft machen, weich machen', not to be separated from Ved. mr̥dú- (PIE *(h₂)ml̥d-ú-).
Cf. s.v. *meld- 'weich werden' (IEW 718).
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *steub-a- 'stieben'; no secure etymology.
S.v. Kâmviri pâřʹasa  [-i fem]  Aj.  Gray; dusty.  [pâřasaN]  [OIA. pʹuri:ṣa- ‘fullness; filling; rubble; dung’  T. 8287 (-T. 8019 pâ˜šu- 'dust'; prob. < Ind., cf. Hindi puras 'dust')]
Cf. s.v. 8019 pāṁśu- 'crumbling soil, dust, sand' or s.v. 8287 púrīṣa- 'fullness(?)' (Pk. purīsa- 'dung', Ku. paraso 'manure', H. puras 'dust, manure').
S.v. Ved. makṣ- 'Fliege (oder Biene)', cf. IIr. YAv. maxšī- 'Fliege', Sogd. mwxšk- 'Moskito', etc., from IIr. *makš-.
S.v. 9696 Skt. mákṣā- 'fly' (RV.).
Cf. s.v. 12620 Skt. śōcís- 'flame, glow' (RV.); Waigalī šoč 'war', Kati šuč.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √śoc- 'leuchten, glühen, brennen' (IIr. cf. OAv. saočaiiat̰ 'inflames', sūčā 'durch den Glanz', etc.), if from IE, then from PIE *k̑eu̯k-, but connections outside Indo-Iranian remain uncertain.
Cf. s.v. ?1. *k̑eu̯k- 'aufflammen, erglühen' (IEW 597). Cf. n1: Only Indo-Iranian, if Gk. κύκνος 'Schwan' as *'der leuchtend Weiße' doesn't belong here.'

S.v. Proto-Slavic *xovati (sę). Goes back to a non-attested *skovati 'смотреть с вниманием', 'look with attention', cf. the related to and close in meaning *skumati > Cz. zkoumati 'исследовать', 'investigate'. Cf. also Gk. θυο-σκόος, OHG scouwōn, Germ. schauen, Goth. us-skaws, Ved. kaví-, Gk. κοέω, Lat. cavēre, Slav. *čuti.
Cf. s.v. Ru. ховать 'erwahren, hüten', better to be connected to OHG scouwôn 'schauen', Gk. θυο-σκόος 'Opferschauer'.

Cf. s.v. *(s)keu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen' (IEW 587-8), whence the primary verbal derivatives in OCS ču 'fühlte, merkte', Gk. κοέω 'bemerke, vernehme, höre', Lat. caueō, -ēre 'sich in acht nehmen', etc.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *skuwwan- 'mirror' (Go. skuggwa 'id.', ON skuggi 'shadow, shade', OHG scuwo, scū 'id.'), from the PIE root *skeu- 'to see', cf. PGmc. *skawa- 'observant(?)' > Go. us-skaws 'sober' < *skou-ó- (cf. Gk. θυο-σκόος 'name of a sacrificial priest' < *-skou-o-; cf. also OE scēawian, OFri. skowia, OS skawon, Du. schouwen, OHG scouwōn, G schauen 'to see, inspect' < PGmc. skawōjan-).

Cf. s.v. ON skjól 'Obdach, Zufluchtsort, Schuppen' (< Germ. *skeula-), cf. Ic., Far. skjól, Norw. skjol, OSw. skīūl, Dan. skjul. (cf. Gk. σκύλος 'abgezogene Haut', σκυλόω 'verhülle', OIr. cúl 'Winkel).

Cf. s.v. PGmc. *skeulan ~ *skūlan (ON skjól 'shelter, cover'), related to Gmc. *skuwwōn (cf. ON skuggi 'shade, shadow', OE scúwa, OHG scūwo 'look', Arm. cʻiw 'roof', OIr. cúl 'back', continuing IE *(s)k̑eu̯ə- 'to cover'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *skuwwan- 'mirror' (Go. skuggwa 'id.', ON skuggi 'shadow, shade', OHG scuwo, scū 'id.'), from the PIE root *skeu- 'to see', cf. PGmc. *skawa- 'observant(?)' > Go. us-skaws 'sober' < *skou-ó- (cf. Gk. θυο-σκόος 'name of a sacrificial priest' < *-skou-o-; cf. also OE scēawian, OFri. skowia, OS skawon, Du. schouwen, OHG scouwōn, G schauen 'to see, inspect' < PGmc. skawōjan-).

Danish skjule is a derivative from skjul, in turn from Norse skjól ‘shelter, cover’ (de Vries 1977:495-496). Further etymological connections are unclear, although there are a few quite tempting comparisons formally and semantically. 
1. de Vries (1977:495-496) reconstructs Proto-Germanic *skeula-, and considers connections to Gk. σκύλος ‘animal skin’ and its derivative σκυλόω ‘to veil, cover’ (Hesych.), also to OIr. cúl ‘nook, corner’, ultimately a derivative of an IE root *(s)keu- ‘to cover (smth.)’, cf. further Ved. skunā́ti ‘covers’, Lat. obscūrus ‘covered, dark’, Ir. cuarān ‘shoe’.
2. Orel (2003:339) reconstructs Proto-Germanic *skeulan- ~ *skūlan- > ON skjól and considers connections within Germanic to *skuwwōn ‘shadow’ (ON skuggi, etc.), ultimately to IE *(s)k̑eu̯ə- ‘to cover’, comparing Skt. skunā́ti ‘to cover’, Arm. cʻiw ‘roof’, OIr. cúl ‘back’.
To the particular connection with the ‘shadow’ words, there is an additional complication: It is unclear whether the proposed connection to *skuwwōn ‘shadow’ is has the same root etymology. Lehmann (1986:313) indicates two possible etymologies from formally similar roots: either to *(s)kewə-, *(s)kū- (cf. Skt. skunā́ti ‘to cover’, Gk. σκῡ́νια ‘brows’, or to *(s)kew- ‘pay attention to, observe’ (whence also OE scēawian, OS skauwōn, OHG skouwōn = NHG schauen).
LIV² reconstructs the root underlying the ‘see, pay attention to, observe’ words found in NHG schauen, etc. as *(s)keu̯h₁-, which could be formally identical to the proposed root of the ‘hide; shadow’ words found in Germanic *skuwwōn. As the formal similarity exists, it is tempting to consider a single root. Kroonen EDPG, for instance, considers Proto-Germanic *skuwwōn to a basic root *skeu- ‘see’ (without laryngeal).
The common semantic denominator to both proposed forms seems to be whether or not something is visible or not, but it is unclear to me how these opposite meanings can be easily reconciled.
To return to the known facts, Kroonen EDPG does not discuss Norse skjól anywhere and it is unclear to me whether this is an omission due to neglect, or due Kroonen considering this North Germanic lexeme not cognate to anything else in Germanic (and by extension, in Indo-European).
On the formal level, the derivation of skjól is likewise unclear. I do not know of any productive l-stems in Germanic (but this may well be due to my own ignorance).
If the connections to LIV² *(s)keu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen' hold, then this lexeme might be cognate with /cognate/5182/ with a root etymology, but due to many uncertainties in semantics and processes of secondary derivation, it is ultimately unclear. Cf. also the uncertainties regarding the Germanic words for 'shadow' in /cognate/7022/.

NB: While the etymology for NHG 'schauen' etc. from *(s)keu̯h₁- is generally well accepted, cf. LIV² s.v., the etymology of the 'shadow' words from the same root as given by Kroonen (2013:442, 452) is less clear. Cf. 'hide' in /cognate/8433/ 'shadow' in /cognate/5058/.

Cf. s.v. Engl. hide (v.), from Old English hýdan, from PGmc. *hûdjan (cf. Middle Dutch hûden (huyden , hueden ), Middle Low German hûden to hide, Low German (ver)hüen), either to be connected with the same root as Old English hýd 'hide, skin', or to *keudʰ-, kudʰ-, seen in Greek κεύθειν 'to hide, cover up, conceal'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *xūđjanan- (OE hýdan, OFris. hēda 'id.', MLG hūden 'id.'), related to Greek κεύθω 'to cover, hide'.

S.v. Bret. moan (adj.) 'mince, étroit, grêle', from Old Breton moin 'gracieux', corresponding to Co. môn (OCo. muin), W. mwyn 'gentil, doux, cher', and OIr. min, Scots Gaelic min 'délicat', all from Celtic *mein-no-.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *moyni- 'treasure, precious object'. "The development of meaning in Breton and Cornish was from 'beautiful' to 'gracile' and (in Breton) 'thin'. The original meaning may have been '(precious) piece of property for exchange'. From PIE *mei̯-n- 'exchange' (IEW 710), cf. Lat. mūnus 'duty, charge, task', Skt. mení- 'revenge', Goth. ga-mains 'common', Lith. maĩnas 'exchange'. Less likely, but also possible in principle is a connection to Proto-Celtic *mēto-, *mēti- 'fat, soft' < *mei(H)-t-, via a different stem formation PIE *miH-no- > PCelt. *mīno- (cf. OIr. mín 'tender, soft').
Cf. s.v. 2. *mei̯- 'wechseln; tauschen, ändern' (IEW 710). Possibly *h₂mei̯- if *h₂mei̯gʷ- (LIV² 279, cf. Gk. ἀμείβω 'exchange') is an enlarged root to this one.
For Nuristani cognates, cf. s.v. 12438 Skt. śitá- 'whetted, sharp' RV.
Arm. sowr n. 'sword, dagger'; adj. 'sharp', traditionally reconstructed as *k̑ō-ro- (< *koh₃[i̯]ro-), cf. Lat. cōs, cōtis 'whetstone'.

S.v. Proto-Iranian ?*raiz-² 'jump'. "The evidence for this root is limited to some modern WIr. languages. The initial l- is rather atypical for an Ir. word: it could suggest borrowing, but perhaps in this case it is due to the influence of Pers. larzīdan 'to shake, tremble' (*rarz)? An IE provenance for this root, which is solely continued in a few modern Ir. languages, is conceivable, but difficult to establish. A connection with Goth. laikan 'to jump, hop', OE lākan 'to jump', Lith. láigyti 'to walk around wildly', is mentioned by Lehmann (1986:225a), Fraenkel I: 330b f. (and also cited in EWAia II:459 s.v. rej- 'zittern, beben')."
Cf. s.v. *lei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'springen' (IEW 667-8), to which possibly ?*léi̯⁽g̑⁾-e- > np. ā-liz- 'springen'.
S.v. Lith. vil̃kti 'drag' (Latv. vìlkt 'drag'), from PIE *u(e)lk⁽ʷ⁾- (cf. Av. varək- 'draw').

"Toch. A śaru / B śerwe 'hunter' may be taken as reflecting *k̑ēru̯o-, a vr̥ddhi derivative ('he of the stag' or the like), of *k̑eru̯o- 'stag' (as in L. ceruos […]." Cf. also n18 "The etymology given by Pedersen (Tocharisch, 48), who identifies this root as that of χαίρω, etc., and offers Skt. lubdha- 'hunter' as a semantic parallel, is not satisfactory. The g̑hēr-u̯o- it requires would have to be a deverbative adjective in -u̯o-, a formation in which a lengthened-grade root is out of place." This analysis is credited to Jasanoff.

S.v. TochB śer- 'hunt', attested once. A denominative verb (as if) from PIE *gʷʰēru̯e-i̯e/o-, from śerwe, 'hunter'. S.v. TochB śerwe 'hunter' Adams considers the lexeme with TochA śaru to reflect PToch *ćerwe, but extra Tocharian connections are uncertain, but favours an analysis from PIE *g̑ʰu̯ēr- (or *g̑ʰu̯eh₁r-) 'wild animal' + -u̯o- (cf. Lat. ferus 'wild', Lith. žvė́ris 'wild beast', Gk. θήρ 'wild animal'). Alternative proposals include a connection with Oss. sorun/sūryn 'hunt', Khot. hasūra- 'quarry' ({ref Bailey 1979}:474, followed by Pinault and Cheung) from Proto-Iranian *ćarw- 'hunt', and loaned from an Iranian language into Tocharian, although if it were a borrowing it would have to be early, before the depalatalisation and deaffrication of Proto-Iranian *ć. Adams considers less likely the derivations from PIE *gʷēru̯o- (cf. Lat. verū 'dart, javelin', Goth. qairu), or {ref Nussbaum 1986}:8 who derives from *k̑ēru̯-o- 'he of the stag' from *k̑(e)r(e)u- 'horn'. Cf. entry in Adams for references to further literature in full.
Accepts the analysis of Jasanoff apud {ref Nussbaum 1986}:8 of TB śeruweṃ (obl.sg.), nom *śeruwe < PT *śerwë < PIE *k̑ēruos (vr̥ddhi formation to *k̑erwos 'stag', Lat. cervos).

Denominative verb to TochB śerwe 'hunter', further etymology disputed. A popular analysis (Jasanoff apud {ref Nussbaum 1986}:8, followed by {ref Ringe 1996}) considers TochB śerwe to a vr̥ddhi formation from PIE *k̑er-u̯o- 'stag' (*k̑er-, cf. 'horn' in /cognate/2457/, 'head' in /cognate/53/), but other analyses are possible (cf. {ref Adams 2013}:694-695). Proto-Tocharian root ref. form *śerwë follows Ringe (1996:11).

PS *goniti (sę) is derived from PIE *gʷʰen- and related to Old Indic hánti 'hit, kill', Greek θείνω 'hit', Lithuanian genù, giñti 'chase', Hittite kuen-, kun- 'hit, kill', Latin de-fendere 'defend', Old Icelandic gunnr 'battle', Tocharian kuñac 'quarrel, battle' etc.

PS *loviti is derived from PIE *lāu- / *lau- / ləu- 'catch, gain' and related to Lithuanian lavùs 'dexterous', Greek Attic λεία (*λᾱϝιᾱ), Doric λᾱία 'gain', Latin lucrum 'gain', Gothic laun, Old High German lôn 'reward' and Old Irelandic folad 'richness', lúag 'praise'.
For Nuristani cognates, cf. s.v. 6955c *nabhalikā- 'cloud' (cf. Lat. nebula, Skt. nábhas-, etc.).

Cf. s.v. Ved. abhrá- 'Gewitterwolke, Gewölk, Regenwolke' (IIr. Av. aβra- 'Regen[wolke]', a derivative of PIE *nebʰ- via *n̥bʰ-ró-, cf. s.v. Ved. nábhas- 'Feuchtigkeit, Wolke, Gewölk, Nebel', an s-stem noun from PIE *nebʰ- 'befeuchten'.

S.v. *dei̯-, di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f., EIEC 513), cf. n56, where the Slavic lexemes in the meaning 'rain, bad weather' are probably to be derived from a compound *dus-di̯u- 'bad day/sky'.
S.v. Kâmvʹiri âpsʹa- 'swell up' cf. T.1832 *ut-prus-a- 'bubbles up' but with (â- instead of ud-).
S.v. 9093 Skt. phúllati 'expands, opens (as a flower)' (cf. Skt. phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)'.

S.v. Skt. pullaḥ 'aufgeblüht, blühend', 'blossoming' (Mahābh.) from which probably the denominative phullati 'blossoms. Perhaps from a p.p.p. *phal-na- to phálati 'birst', 'burst', taking over a labial vowel -u- after no longer being associated with the verbal stem.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √proṣ- 'träufeln, beträufeln, sprühen, besprengen, bespritzen, ausschütten' (Mi., Nu.(?, s. Tu. 1832)); cf. Ir. frau̯š-/fruš in words for milk-drinks, from PIE *(s?)preu̯s(H)-, probably to be connected with West IE words for 'Reif, Frost', Lat. pruīna-, OHG frost, etc.
Cf. s.v. *preu̯s- 'sprühen, spritzen' (IEW 809-10, 846).
Cf. s.v. 7848 Skt. *paribudhyatē 'understands' [√budh-] (> Ash. puruz-, purez- 'to hear'); s.v. 9279 Skt. *búdhyate 'is awakened, observes, understands' [√budh-] (> K. bōzun 'to hear').
Cf. s.v. Ved. √bodh- 'merken, bemerken, auf etwas achten, achtsam sein', from PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- (cf. Gk. πεύθομαι, Lith. budė́ti, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *bʰeu̯dʰ- 'wach werden, aufmerksam werden' (IEW 150-2).

Cf. s.v. Arm. mit 'mind, intelligence', related to Gk. μήδεα 'counsels, plans, arts' (pl. of unattested *μῆδος), μέδω 'to protect, rule over', μέδομαι 'to provide for, be mindful of; to plan, contrive, devise', μήδομαι 'to be minded, intend; take care, keep watch', Lat. medeor 'to heal, cure', Umbrian mers 'law, justice', etc. The Armenian a-stem may be built on a neuter plural collective *mēd-es-(e)h₂-.

Proto-Indo-Iranian pres. *bʱána- may continue *bʰn̥h₂ó/é- << *bʰn̥h₂ó, 3sg middle of infixed *bʰ~n~éh₂-: Marathi mh, may be due to blend with PIIr. *mlau̯h- /cognate/2031/ or *maR-, cf. Vedic malmalāyati (ŚBK) with m- /cognate/813/
S.v. 9383 Skt. bhánati 'calls aloud, speaks' (RV.). EWAia considers an IE origin for Skt. bhanati, but Kuiper, Proto-Munda Words in Sanskrit proposes a Munda origin for Skt. √bhan-.
S.v. Ved. √bhan- 'reden', perhaps to IE *bʰen- (~ *bʰeh₂-) (as similarly the root-pair *gʷem- : *gʷeh₂-?).

Cf. s.v. 2. *bʰeh₂- 'sprechen, sagen' (IEW 105-6), with Ved. bhánati 'spricht' possibly to a nasal-infix pres. stem ?*bʰ-né/n̥-h₂-, cf. n6: If thematised from *bhanā́- (with a trivial accent shift) and not to a parallel root *bʰen(H)-, which could also exist in OHG(+) bannan 'aufbieten, vorladen' (hardly with Seebold [1970:]89 from *bʰh₂-nu̯-).
S.v. Goth. M16. malma 'ἄμμος', 'sand' derivation with PIE *-mo- to the same root as Goth. *malan 'grind', from PIE *mel- 'crush, grind'.

S.v. Lith. smė̃lis, smėlỹs 'sand', Latv. smẽlis 'fine sand', from PIE *(s)melH-? (cf. OCS měla 'lime', Ru. mel' 'sand-bank, shoal', mel 'chalk', OIc. melr 'sand-bank', Sw. mjåg (dial.) 'sand-hill, high riverbank', smula 'chunk', Nw. smola (dial.) 'smash'; smol (dial.) 'dust'. "The Baltic and Slavic forms mentioned are formally compatible with the root *melH- 'grind' (→ mélti), the Baltic word showing s-mobile."
S.v. Proto-Slavic *morvi 'ant' (ESSJa XIX 246-249), from PIE *moru-iH (cf. Av. maoirī-, OIr. moirb).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *maura- 'ant' < *mour-o- (cf. Skt. vamrá- 'ant' < *uomr-o-; YAv. maoiri- 'id.', NPers. mōr 'id.', Oss. mælʒyg / mulʒug 'id.' < *moru-i-; Skt. vamrī́-, Av. maoirī- 'id.' < *uomr-ih₂ / *moru-ih₂; Gk. μύρμηξ, -ηκος 'id.' < *morm-; Lat. formīca 'id.' < *bʰ(o)rm-; OIr. moirb 'id.', W myr 'id.' < PIE *moru-i-; CS mravii 'id.' < *moru-ih₂-, ORu. morovej, Ru. muravéj 'id.' < *moru-io-, SCr. mrȃv 'id.' < *moru-o-; TochB warme* 'id.' < *urm-i-). "The word is of IE origin, but the original form is difficult to reconstruct due to cross-dialectal tabooistic distortions and metatheses."

S.v. Lat. formīca 'ant', from PIE *moru̯-o/ī̆-(?) (cf. OIr. moirb, W. myr, Bret. merien 'ant' < *moru̯i-; Skt. vamrá- 'ant', valmī́ka- 'ant-hill'; Av. maoiri-, Oss. mælzyg / mulzug, Pašto mežay, Sogd. ymʾwrc < PIr. *maru̯i(ka)-, Sogd. zmʾwrʾk, Khwar. zmwrk, MP, MoP mōr < *maru̯aka-; Gk. μύρμηξ, -ηκος 'ant', βύρμαξ, βόρμαξ, ὅρμικας (with β- and zero < *ϝ-); RuCS. mravьjь, ORu. morovej, Po. mrówka, SCr. mrȃv 'ant' < moru-iH-; OIc. maurr < *mour-o-, Far. meyra < *maurōn-, Dan. myre, OE mȳre, ME mire, MDu. miere, Crimean Gothic miera < *meur(j)ōn- 'ant', TochB warme* nom.pl. warmi 'ant' < *u̯r̥mo-).
