"The word for ant is difficult to reconstruct because of the deviating forms; probably taboo distortions took place in many languages. This process can still be observed in modern dialects, for instance of Dutch and German. Latin f- might go back to *m- via a dissimilation *m- – m > *f – m. Meillet (1918) assumes an intermediate stage *[ƀ] (voiced bilabial fricative), which he regards as an argument for the view that all PIE *bʰ changed to *ƀ before yielding Latin f-. In IE branches, we find the stem structures *moru̯-o/ī̆- (Celtic, Iranian, Slavic, Gm.), *mormo/i- (Greek), and *uormo/i- (Skt., Toch., Greek?). Since the latter is quite similar to PIE *u(o)rmo/i- 'worm, insect' (see s.v. vermis), it may have been influenced by it; consequently, for 'ant' the form *moruo/i- is more likely to be old."
S.v. TochB warme* 'ant', (as though) from PIE *u̯r̥mo-, a deformation of the *u̯ormo- that lies behind Sanskrit valmīka-, vamrá-, Greek βόρμαξ, βύρμαξ, ὅρμαξ, μύρμηξ, Lat. formīca.
Cf. MG μελίγκρα ‘aphid’ < AG μελί-κηρα.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *ātr-, *ātar- 'огонь' and derivatives, from PIE *āter-/*ātr- (cf. Lat. āter 'черный, темный'), based on an IE root *ā- or *ai- 'светить, гореть'.

Root reconstruction *h₂eh₁- follows LIV², cf. ESIJa for extensive discussion of the Iranian forms from this root. PIE *h₂eh₁- is probably related to the root *h₂eh₁s- in /cognate/178/ with an s-extension of the root.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *ātr-, *ātar- 'огонь' and derivatives, from PIE *āter-/*ātr- (cf. Lat. āter 'черный, темный'), based on an IE root *ā- or *ai- 'светить, гореть'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ailida- 'fire', a formation derived from *ailjan- (OE ǣlan w.v. 'to burn'), which in turn is factitive to the noun *aila- implied by OE āl 'fire' < *ailla- < *aidla- < *h₂eidʰ-lo- (cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *aida-).

S.v. ON eldr 'feuer'. Etymology uncertain, according to Sievers (IF 4, 1894), from Germ, *aila < *aiðla, and then to the IE root *aidh- 'burn', but this is not correct phonologically and the difficulty cannot be remedied by assuming contamination from another lexeme.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ailiđaz, derived from PGmc. *ailjanan (w.v.), cf. OE ælan 'to kindle', in turn derived from *ailan (cf. OE ál 'flame' "despite phonetic difficulties probably from *aiđlan connected with *aiđaz, cf. OE ád 'funeral pile', OS ēd 'firebrand', OHG eit 'id.' and identical to Skt. édha- 'fuel', Gk. αἶθος 'firebrand', OIr. áed 'fire').

S.v. OIr. úar 'froid', the same lexeme in Brythonic (W. oer 'froid', MCo. oir). It is probable that the name of the month Ogron in the Coligny calendar, which is a month in winter, contains the same root *ougro-. Lidén adds Arm. ojc 'froid' and Lat. autumnus (if from auctumnus?); this latter connnection is to be rejected. It is less more than doubtful that one can establish a base *ou- which for úar would derive from *oudro- in view of Lith. aušti 'il se refroidit'. But, we cannot separate it from Latv. aũksts 'cold' (cf. Ir. úacht). Cf. IEW 783.

Cf. s.v. OIr. mid- thème verbal 'juger, adjuger, estimer'; the same root *med- is found in Brythonic (cf. W meddu 'posséder, être maître', medd 'dit-il', meddwl 'pensée, jugement', arfedd 'dessein'. It continues a root developed in many Indo-European languages (cf. Lat. modus 'mesure', modius 'boisseau' meditārī 'réfléchir', Umbr. meřs 'droit', Osc. med-diss 'juge', Goth. mitan 'mesurer', mitōn 'réfléchir', etc., Greek μέδω 'he prends soin, je gouverne sur', μέδομαι 'je m'occupe de, je médite', μήδεα 'pensées, desseins', μήδομαι 'je prends soin').
Cf. s.v. 1. *med- 'messen, für Einhaltung sorgen, sich kümmern' (IEW 705-6).
S.v. ON klá 'kratzen, rieben', outside of North Germanic cf. OE clawan, MLG klāwen, MDu. clouwen, OHG klāwen.
S.v. Kâmviri c̣âŋʹařoa-  [c̣âŋʹařavoa-]  VT.  Scratch. [OIA. ča˜-kr̥t-a-ti ‘cuts repeatedly’  T. 4562 (?)]
Cf. s.v. 4562 *caṅkr̥tati 'cuts again and again' [√krt-].
Cf. s.v. 8171 *piṇḍara- 'round like a lump'.
S.v. Sp. llorar, from Lat. plōrare.
S.v. Lat. plōrare 'laut weinen' (> Fr. pleurer).
S.v. Lat. plōrō, -āre 'to cry, weep'. No etymology.
S.v. Lat. plōrō, -ās, -āuī, -ātum, -āre 'se plaindre, se lamenter, pousser des cris de douleur'. Without any satisfying connections, probably an expressive word like fleō.

S.v. Lat. plangō, -ere 'to beat, strike; mourn, bewail', from PIE *plh₂-n-g- 'to hit', *pl(e)h₂g-h₂- (cf. Gk. πλάζω 'to drive off course', aor. ἐπλήγην, ps. πλάγχθη 'was beaten', Goth. faiflokun 'to hit, flog', OS flōkan 'to curse').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *grētan- 'to wail' (Goth. gretan- 'to cry', ON gráta- 'id.', from PIE *g̑ʰréh₁d-e-, cf. Skt. hrādate 'to sound' < *g̑ʰreh₁d-e-, W griddfan 'to groan' < *g̑ʰreh₁d-).
S.v. ?*⁽g̑⁾ʰreh₁d- 'weinen' (IEW 439). Only Germanic.
S.v. Gmc. *grǣt-a- 'weinen', without secure comparisons outside of Germanic.
Etymological connections outside of Germanic not certainly agreed (cf. Seebold 1970:241, LIV² 202), but cf. Kroonen (2013:187-188) for proposed connections in Indic and Celtic.

S.v. Lith. pùtė 'chicken, bird' (Latv. pùtns 'bird'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *put- (cf. OCS pъtakъ 'bird', etc.). The Balto-Slavic forms are sometimes connected with Skt. putrá- 'son, child, young of an animal', Lat. putillus 'very young, tiny', pullus 'foal, chick, young of an animal'.
S.v. OLith. paũkštis 'Vogel'. No generally accepted etymology. A connection with Lith. paũtas 'Ei' is semantically close, but phonologically difficult. Cf. entry in ALEW for further discussion.

Cf. s.v. OLith. dvãsas 'Atem, Geist, Seele', cf. Latv. dvaša 'Hauch, Atem, Lebewesen; Dampf, Dunst', and s.v. OLith. dvė̃sti 'hauchen, blasen; den Geist aushauchen, sterben', derivatives from PIE *dʰu̯es- 'hauchen, atmen' (cf. OCS dyxati 'wehen, atmen', Gk. θῡ́ω, θυίω 'brausen, stürmen, toben', Goth. dius, ON dýr, OHG tior '(wildes) Tier').

Cf. s.v. OLith. áusti 'kühl, kalt werden' (BSl. Latv. aũsît, aũsêt 'mit Kochlöffel schöpfend und zurückgießend abkühlen, damet der Kessel nicht überkocht', aũksts 'kalt', aũkstîgs 'anhaltend kalt', etc.), from PIE *h₃eu̯g̑- 'kalt' (cf. Arm. oyc 'kalt', OIr. úar 'kalt, kühl', úacht 'Kälte' MW oer 'kalt, kühl').

Cf. s.v. *regʰ- 'sich aufrichten' under n1, where a suggested reconstruction *h₂regʰ- is also considered and potential connections of the associated verbal forms to the nominal lexemes in Balto-Slavic 'horn' (Lith. rãgas, OCS rogъ, etc.).

Cf. s.v. OLith. vẽtušas 'alt' (BSl. cf. Latv. vęcs 'alt; abgenutzt; vormalig, ehemalig', etc. OCS vetъxъ 'alt (Dinge)', etc.; extra BSl. cf. Lat. vetus, -eris 'alt'). The Baltic lexemes must be root-cognate with vocabulary elsewhere in IE from PIE *u̯et-, but a direct equation with the s-stem *u̯etos- (cf. Gk. ἔτος, Alb. vit) is semantically difficult and formally not probable. Cf. ALEW for further discussion of issues in the stem formation in Baltic.

Cf. s.v. OLith. vil̃kti 'ziehen, schleppen' (BSl. Latv. vìlkt, vę̀lku, vìlku 'ziehen, schleppen', OPr. awilkis, OCS vlěšti 'ziehen, schleppen', etc.), from PIE *(h₂)u̯elk- 'ziehen, schleppen' (cf. YAv. vərək- 'scheppen').

S.v. OLith. stùmti 'stoßen, schieben' (BSl. cf. Latv. stùmt, 'stoßen, schieben', etc.). The (East-)Baltic verbs seem to presuppose a zero-grade of a PIE root form *stemH-. Outside of Baltic the Germanic family from ON stemma 'stemmen, dämmen, hindern' are close.

Cf. s.v. OLith. raudà 'Röte', from which the derived adjective raudónas 'rot' (BSl. cf. Latv. ràuda 'Rotauge (ein Fisch)', OCS ruda 'Irz', SCr. rȗd 'rötlich, rotbraun', Russ. dial. rúdyj 'rot', etc.) from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'rot machen' (cf. Ved. lohá- 'rötlich, kupferfarben, eisern', MPers. rōy 'Kupfer, Messing', Lat. rūfus, 'rot, hellrot', rōbus 'rot (Rinder)' OIr. rúad 'rot', MW rud 'rot', etc. Goth. rauþs 'rot', OE rēad, OHG rōt, etc.).

Cf. s.v. OLith. sar̃tas 'rotbraun (Pferd)' (cf. Latv. sā̀rts 'rot, frisch aussehend', sar̂kans 'rot'), the (East-)Baltic colour adjective can be connected to a PIE root *ser- 'rot' (IEW 910f.), but closer correspondences in related languages are lacking.

S.v. OLith. apvalùs 'rund; vollkommen' (BSl. cf. Latv. apaļš 'rund'), derived to the same root as OLith. vélti (II) 'walken, zu Filz machen' < PIE *u̯elH- '(sich) wälzen, rollen' (cf. OCS valiti 'sich wälzen, Goth. wulan 'sich ausbreiten', ON velta 'sich wälzen', OHG wellan 'wälzen', OS wellian 'rollen').

S.v. OLith. báltas 'weiß' (BSl. cf. Latv. bal̃ts 'weiß', OCS blato 'Sumpf', etc.). The East Baltic word for white is morphologically closest to the past passive participle of OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden'. The also lexicalised Slavic correspondence shows that the adjective was already Proto-Balto-Slavic. On the semantic development of 'white' > 'swamp' in Slavic, see ESSJa 2:180. Lith. bálti is a denominal incohative to Lith. bãlas 'weiß' which has been replaced by báltas. Lith. bãlas is put together with Gk. φαλός (Hesych.) 'weiß', φαλιός 'hell; weißfleckig' (cf. Frisk 1960-1972 2.988f.), Arm. bal 'Nebel, weißer fleck' (cf. Martirosyan 2010:162f.), and Alb. bálë 'weißer Fleck auf der Stirn von Tieren, Blässe' (cf. Demiraj 1997:87). Lith. bãlas is not to be separated from the Slavic lexemes, e.g. OCS bělъ. Ru. bélyj, Cz. bílý, etc., which apparently have a reflex of Proto-Slavic *ē in the root. The morphological relationship within the family and the identification of a common is yet to be explained. The often assumed connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten' (cf. Ved. 3.sg.pres. bhā́ti, Gk. φάντα (Hesych.) 'leuchtend') is conceivable.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-. Similar words also exist in Indic languages (cf. kuttā, kuti, Turner 1962-1966 3275).

The connection of the Baltic and Slavic lexemes to each other is generally agreed upon, but extra Balto-Slavic connections, and subsequently any precise IE root reconstruction, remain debated. {ref ALEW} (90-91 s.v. OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden') suggests that a connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' is not inconceivable; {ref Derksen 2008}:40 and {ref Derksen 2015}:80 postulate a root *bʰelH-. The reconstructed PIE root ref. form for this class follows that of Derksen, but it should be borne in mind that this form remains provisional as the morphological analysis of the Balto-Slavic forms and their proposed further IE connections have yet to be satisfactorily explained. Cf. also {ref ESSJa} 2:79-81.

Cf. s.v. OLith. var̃gas 'Elend, Not, Mühsal' (BSl. cf. Latv. vãrgs 'siech, elend', OPr. wargan 'Übel, Leid', wargans (adj.) 'böse', OCS vragъ 'Feind', SCr. vrȃg 'Teufel', etc.), from PIE *u̯orgʰó- 'verstoßen, geächtet', cf. Goth. gawargjan 'verdammen', ON vargr 'Wolf; Verstoßener, Geächteter', OE wearg (adj.) 'böse, verflucht, verdammt'. etc.

Cf. s.v. Lith. var̃gas 'hardship, misery' (Latv. vā̀rgs 'misery', OPr. wargan 'misery, suffering, danger'); s.v. Lith. vargùs 'hard, difficult, tiresome' D. reconstructs the root as *(h₁)u̯org-o-, comparing Goth. wrikan 'persecute', OHG rehhan 'revenge'.

S.v. OLith. ką́sti 'beißen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kuôst 'beißen'). The (East-)Baltic group seems to based on a PIE root *kʷend-, which has no conclusive connections in related languages. From the Slavic languages words like OCS čęstь 'Teil, Anteil, Lohn', Pol. kęs 'Bisschen, Stück', kąsać, kęsać 'beißen', Russ. kuśat' 'beißen' can be gathered, which show a root form without final *-d. Further comparisons with Ved. khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen', Arm xacanem, 'beißen, stechen', are much sketchier.

Cf. s.v. OLith. rū́gti 'sauer werden, gären, aufstoßen' (BSl. cf. Latv. rûgt 'säuern, aufgehen, gären; aufstoßen, murren, verdrießlich sein', rûgts (adj.) 'bitter, berb', OCS otъrigati 'aufstoßen, ausstoßen', SCr. rìgati 'rülpsen', etc.), a zero-grade formation to OLith. ráugas (with -ū- from Winter's Law), in turn from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g- 'aufstoßen, rülpsen' (cf. Gk. ἐρεύγομαι 'erbreche', Arm. orcam 'erbreche mich', Lat. ērūgō 'rülpse aus', rūminō, -āre 'käue wieder', OE edroc (sm.) 'Wiederkäuen', OHG itarucken 'id.').
Cf. s.v. Lith. rū́gti 'ferment, grow sour' (Latv. rûgt 'ferment, grow sour'), from PIE *h₁rug- (cf. Lith. ráugėti).
S.v. Ved. ásr̥j- 'Blut' (heteroclitic with asn-), from PIE *(h₁)ē̆sh₂r̥(-gʷ?), G.sg. *(h₁)sh₂n-ós (cf. Hitt. e-eš-ḫar, G.sg. e-eš-na-aš, TochA ysār, TochB yasar, Gk. ἔαρ, Latv. asins 'Blut').

S.v. OLith. kraũjas 'Blut' (BSl. s.v. Latv. kreve 'geronnenes Blut, Schorf', OPr. crauyo 'Blut', OCS krъvь 'Blut', etc.), from PIE *kreu̯h₂- 'Blut außerhalb des Körpers' (Ved. kravíṣ- 'rohes, blutiges Fleisch', kravyá- 'blutig', YAv. A.sg. xrūm 'blutiges (rohes) Fleisch', OAv. xrūra- 'gewalttätig, blutig, grausam', Gk. κρέας 'Fleisch, Fleischstück', Lat. cruor, -ōris 'dickes Blut (außerhalb des Körpers), OIr. crú '(stockendes) Blut' ON hrár 'roh', etc.).

S.v. OLith. pū̃sti 'wehen, blasen' (BSl. Latv. pùst, etc.). The root could go back to a zero-grade *put- to a root *peu̯t-, which could be a t-enlargement of a root *peu̯-, but could also be of onomatopoeic origin. There are no clear cognates to a root *peu̯t- (in contrast to *peu̯-, *peu̯s-, etc.).

S.v. OLith. debesìs, debeỹs 'Wolke' (BSl. cf. Latv. debess, OCS nebo, etc.), from PIE *nebʰ-es- 'Himmel, Luftraum, Wolke' (cf. Hitt. nepis-, 'Himmel', HLuw. tipas- 'id.', Ved. nábhas- 'Feuchtigkeit, Wolke; Himmel', OAv. nabah- 'Luftraum, Himmel', Gk. νέφος 'Wolke, Bewölkung').
Cf. s.v. OLith. šálti 'frieren' (derived adj. šáltas 'kalt'), from PIE *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren'.

S.v. Lith. ver̃kti 'cry, weep', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *werk- (cf. CS vrěštati; Ru. vereščat’ 'squeal, chirp'), from PIE *uerk- (cf. OIc. var 'rheum', Nw. var 'rheum', OSw. var 'mucus, rheum, pus'; OHG warah 'pus, liquid manure' < PGmc. uórk-o-; connection of the Germanic forms follows Kroonen 2013:574).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *warha- 'rheum'. "A word with an original meaning 'rheum' or 'serum'. I assume that it was derived from a root *uerk- 'to cry' as found in Baltic." [No further references given.]
For Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 10840.2 Skt. rudáti 'weeps' (Ash. ẓū, etc.).
Cf. s.v. OLith. *gríežti, griẽžti 'schneiden' (BSl. cf. Latv. griêzt, griẽzt 'schneiden'), no known cognates outside of Baltic.

S.v. OLith. dienà 'Tag' (BSl. cf. Latv. dìena, OPr. acc.sg. deinan 'Tag', OCS dьnь 'Tag', etc.), from PIE *dei̯- 'hell (Himmel)', *dei̯-n-/*di-n- 'Tag' (cf. Skt. madhyáṃdina- 'Mittag' OLat. noundinum 'Frist von neun Tagen', perendinus 'übermorgig', OIr. denus 'Tag, Zeitraum eines Tages', Goth. sinteins 'täglich', etc.).

S.v. OLith. mir̃ti 'sterben' (BSl. cf. Latv. mir̃t, 'sterben', OCS mrěti 'stermen', etc.), from PIE *mer- 'sterben, verschwinden' (cf. Hitt. merzi 'verschwindet', Ved. mar-, mriyáte 'sterben', YAv. mar-, miriiete 'stirbt', Lat. morior, morī 'sterben').

S.v. OLith. kàsti 'graben, scharren, begraben' (BSl. cf. Latv. kast 'scharren, die Erde aufwerfen, harken'), usually taken to PIE *kes- 'ordnen' (LIV² 357) but the original semantics of the root may need to be revised in view of other Balto-Slavic lexemes; cf. also OLith. kasà 'Zopf, Haarzopf'.

Cf. s.v. *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen' (IEW 666, 682-3), where a present stem ?*léh₁-/*l̥h₁-u- is suggested for Goth. lewjan 'verraten', Latv. ļaũju 'zulassen, erlauben', Ukr. livlijú 'nachlassen', etc.

S.v. OLith. pur̃vas 'aufgeweichte Erde, Schlamm, Schmutz' (derived adj. pur̃vinas, -à 'schmutzig, unflätig' (BSl. cf. Latv. pùrvs 'Morast, Sumpf', etc.), a suffixival derivative to Lith. pùrti 'locker werden, sich auflockern (Schnee, Erde); porös werden, aufgehen (Teig)'. For Baltic root, cf. s.v. OLith. išpur̃sti 'weich, schwammig, morsch werden', perhaps to be connected with Cz. poura 'Hochmut, Stolz', but no secure connections outside of Balto-Slavic.

S.v. OLith. saũsas 'trocken, dürr' (BSl. cf. Latv. sàuss 'trocken, dürr, nüchtern', OPr. sausā (adj.; adv.?) 'trocken', OCS suxъ 'trocken, dürr', etc.). The inherited adjective for 'dry' with the IE root to be reconstructed either as *h₂seu̯s- or *sau̯s- (cf. Ved. śoṣa- 'austrockend', Gk αὗος 'trocken, dürr', OE sēar 'trocken, dürr', Middle Low German sōr 'id.').

S.v. OLith. ausìs 'Ohr' (BSl. cf. Latv. àuss 'Ohr', OPr. ausins 'Ohren', OCS uxo 'Ohr', etc.), from PIE *h₂eu̯s-es-, *h₂ou̯s-os-, *h₂us-s- 'Ohr' (cf. YAv. uši- 'Ohr', OPers. uši- 'id.' Gk. οὗς, ὠτός 'Ohr' (hom. G.sg. οὔατος), Myc. ti-ri-jo-we 'dreihenklig', Arm. ownkn 'Ohr', Lat. auris, -is, OIr. áu, Goth. auso 'Ohr', OHG ōra 'id.').

S.v. OLith. žẽme 'Erde, Welt; Erdboden, Land, Gebiet' (BSl. cf. Latv. zeme 'Erde, Welt, Boden, Land', OPr. semmē, same 'Erde, Acker, Land', OCS zeml’a 'Erde, Boden, Land' etc.), from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om- 'Erde' (cf. Hitt. tēkan 'Erde', CLuw. tiyammi- 'Erde', Ved. kṣam- 'Erde', Gk. χθών 'Erde, Boden, Land', OIr. dú, 'Ort, Stelle', TochA tkaṃ 'Erde, Boden', TochB keṃ 'id.').

Cf. s.v. OLith. ė́sti 'essen, fressen' (BSl. cf. Latv. êst 'essen, fressen, verzehren', OPr. inf. īst, ist 'essen', inf. istwei, OCS jasti 'essen', etc.), from PIE *h₁ed- 'essen' (cf. Hitt. ēdmi, adanzi 'esse', CLuw. ad- 'essen', HLuw. ad- 'essen', Ved. ad- 'essen', Gk 1.sg.fut.med. ἔδομαι 'werde essen', Arm. owtem 'esse', Lat. edō, ēsse 'essen', Osc. EDUM 'essen', Goth. itan 'essen', OHG ezzan 'essen').

S.v. OLith. paũtas 'Ei; Hoden' (BSl. cf. Latv. pàuts 'Ei; Testikel', OPr. paute 'Eier'); the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'egg' is a a vr̥ddhi derivative to the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird', which is found in Baltic through the derivatives pùtė 'Huhn', putýtis 'Küken', Latv. putns 'Vogel'. Further are compounds like Lith. pùt-pela, Latv. putpele 'Wachtel'. In Slavic the diminutives OCS pъtica, SCr. ptȉca, Ru. ptíca 'Vogel' and SCr. pȁtka 'Ente'. The Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird' has no plausible connections outside of Balto-Slavic.

S.v. OLith. šuõ, šuõj, šuõn 'Hund' (BSl. cf. Latv. suns 'Hund, OPr. sunis 'Hund'), from PIE *k̑u̯on- 'Hund' (cf. Hitt. kuwas 'Hundemann', HLuw. zuwan(i)- 'Hund', Ved. śvā́ 'Hund', YAv. spā 'Hund', Gk. κύων 'id.', OIr. cú 'id.', TochA ku, TochB ku 'Hund').

S.v. OLith. akìs 'Auge' (BSl. cf. Latv. acs 'Auge; Gesicht; Knospe, Öhr', OPr. N.pl. ackis 'Augen', OCS NA.du. oči 'beide Augen', etc.), from PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'ins Auge fassen' (cf. Gk. NA.du. ὄσσε 'beide Augen', Ved. akṣī́- 'id.', YAv. aši 'id.', Arm. ačʻkʻ 'Augen', Alb. sy 'Auge', TochA ak 'Auge', TochB ek 'Auge').
Cf. s.v. OPr. krūt (inf.) 'fallen'.
S.v. OLith. penkì 'fünf' (BSl. Latv. pìeci, OCS pętь, etc.), from PIE *pénkʷe 'fünf'.

Cf. s.v. tolùs -ì 'weit, fern' (BSl. Latv. tâls, 'weit, fern', tâli 'fern') from PIE *teh₂li- (adj.) 'so beschaffen' (cf. Gk. τηλίκος 'so alt, so jung, so groß', Lat. tālis 'solcher, so beschaffen; mancher').

S.v. OLith. ugnìs, ùgnis 'Feuer' (BSl. Latv. ugùns 'Feuer', OCS ognь, etc.), from PIE *h₁óngni- / *h₁n̥gnéi̯- 'Feuer' (cf. Ved. agní- 'Feuer', Lat. ignis 'Feuer'). The Indo-European lexeme is difficult to reconstruct, cf. entry in ALEW with discussion and references to further literature.
S.v. OLith. keturì, kẽturios 'vier' (BSl. cf. Latv. četri 'vier', OCS četyre 'vier', etc.), from PIE *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur-.
S.v. OLith. mìškas 'Wald' (BSl. nar. miʃzta 'Wald'), no known etymology.

S.v. OLith. mẽdis 'Baum, Holz, Wald' (BSl. Latv. mežs 'Wald, Gehölz, OCS mežda 'Straße', etc.), from PIE *médʰi̯o- 'mittlerer, in der Mitte befindlich' (cf. Ved. mádhya- (adj.) 'mittlerer'; (snt.) 'Mitte', YAv. maiδiia- 'mittlerer', Gk. μέσος, μέσσος 'mittlerer', Lat. medius 'mittlerer', Goth. midjis, ON miðr, OHG mitti 'in der Mitte befindlich').

Cf. s.v. Lith. medžias 'forest, woods' (Latv. mežs 'forest, woods', OPr. median 'forest, woods'), from PIE *medʰ-i-o- / *medʰ-i-eh₂- (cf. Skt. mádhya- 'middle, located in the middle'; Lat. medius 'middle, located in the middle'; Goth. midjis 'middle').

S.v. OLith. mẽdis 'Baum, Holz, Wald' (BSl. Latv. mežs 'Wald, Gehölz, OCS mežda 'Straße', etc.), from PIE *médʰi̯o- 'mittlerer, in der Mitte befindlich' (cf. Ved. mádhya- (adj.) 'mittlerer'; (snt.) 'Mitte', YAv. maiδiia- 'mittlerer', Gk. μέσος, μέσσος 'mittlerer', Lat. medius 'mittlerer', Goth. midjis, ON miðr, OHG mitti 'in der Mitte befindlich').

S.v. OLith. kója 'Bein, Fuß' (BSl. Latv. kãja). No clear connections outside of Balto-Slavic. There are various proposals for an IE root etymology, but not one is convincing (cf. entry in ALEW for references to further literature).

S.v. OLith. kója 'Bein, Fuß' (BSl. Latv. kãja). No clear connections outside of Balto-Slavic. There are various proposals for an IE root etymology, but not one is convincing (cf. entry in ALEW for references to further literature).

Cf. s.v. OLith. rū̃kti 'rauchen, qualmen' (derived noun rū̃kas 'Nebel, Rauch'). The word family of rū̃kti is best explained as a loan from Germanic (cf. ON riúka 'rauchen', OE rēocan 'rauchen, dampfen, qualmen' OHG riohhan 'rauchen, dampfen, dunsten' etc.).

S.v. OLith. miglà 'Nebel' (BSl. Latv. migla 'Nebel', OCS mьgla 'Nebel', etc.), from PIE *h₃migʰ-leh₂- 'Nebel' (cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη 'Nebel'). The Balto-Slavic words agree with Gk. ὀμίχλη with an *-leh₂- suffix; other nominal formations of the same root include Ved. meghá- 'Wilke, trübes Wetter', YAv. maēγa- 'Wolke'. Further connections to PIE *h₃mei̯g̑ʰ- 'harnen' (LIV² 301f. cf. Lith. mỹžti) or *mei̯gʰ- 'blinzeln' (LIV² 427, cf. Lith. miegóti) are often considered.

S.v. OLith. mùsė (2), musė̃ 'Fliege' (BSl. Latv. muša 'Fliege', OPr. muso 'Fliege', OCS muxa 'Fliege', etc.), from PIE *mus- 'Fliege, Mücke' (cf. Gk. μυῖα 'Fliege', κυνάμυια 'Hundsfliege', Arm. mown 'Mücke, Insekt', Lat. musca 'Fliege').

Cf. s.v. OLith. áugti 'wachsen' (BSl. cf. Latv. aûgt 'wachsen, größer werden, zunehmen' and Latv. aûglis 'Frucht, Baumfrucht, Erzeugnis'), from PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'stark werden' (Ved. ojmán- 'Kraft, Macht' Lat. augeō, -ere 'vermehren', Goth. aukan 'sich mehren', TochA oks- 'wachsen', TochB auks- '(heran)wachsen', gedeihen', etc.).

Cf. s.v. OLith. vaisùs 'fruchtbar', from which the derived noun vaĩsius 'Frucht, Leibesfrucht', an o-grade formation to OLith. veĩsti 'zeugen, erzeugen' (BSl. Latv. viest 'aufziehen, erziehen, entstehen lassen, verbreiten', OPr. wēisin 'Frucht'), from PIE *u̯ei̯s- 'sprießen, gedeihen' (cf. Alb. vesh 'Traube, Weintraube', Lat. vireō, -ēre 'grün sein', ON vísir 'Keim, Spross').

Cf. s.v. OLith. ìnkstas 'Niere' (BSl. Latv. îksts 'Niere', OPr. inxcze 'Niere'). Striking is the closeness of Lith. ìnkstas, Latv. îkstas to Latv. ìekša 'Inneres, Inwendiges', ìekšas 'Eingeweide' which presumes Proto-Baltic *eñksti̯ā́ or *eñkti̯ā́. Cf. s.v. OLith. į́sčia 'Bauch, Leib, Mutterleib; Eingeweide', without correspondences elsewhere in Baltic.
Cf. s.v. OLith. gróbas 'Darm, Dickdarm'. Etymology unclear.

S.v. OLith. pìlnas 'voll, vollständig, völlig' (BSl. Latv. pil̃ns 'voll, betrunken', OPr. acc.sg. pilnan 'ganz', OCS plьnъ 'voll', etc.), from PIE *pl̥h₁-nó/éh₂- (adj.) 'voll' (cf. Ved. pūrṇá- 'voll, gefüllt, ganz, vollständig', OAv. pərəna- 'voll, gefüllt', Lat. plēnus 'voll', OIr. lán, Goth. fulls 'voll', ON fullr 'id.', TochB obl. pällent 'Vollmond').

S.v. OLith. dúoti 'geben' (BSl. Latv. duôt, OPr. dāt, dātwei 'geben'), from PIE *deh₃- 'geben' (cf. Ved. dā- 'geben', YAv. dā- 'geben', Gk. δίδωμι 'geben', Arm. 1.sg.pres. tam, 3.sg.aor. et 'geben', Lat. dō, dāre 'geben', etc.).
S.v. OLith. eĩti 'gehen, kommen' (BSl. Latv. iêt, 'gehen', OCS iti 'gehen', etc.), from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (Ved. ay-, OAv. aē-, Gk. εἶμι, Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', etc.).

Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. {ref ALEW} s.v. Lith. lãbas, {ref LIV²} 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451 speculatively considered a connection with Arm. law (cf. discussion in /cognate/8081/), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} or {ref ALEW}. A lemma for Lith. lãbas is lacking in {ref Derksen 2015}. Besides the still uncertain proposal to Ved. rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

Cf. s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen' (IEW 652). Cf. n1: An alternative reconstruction for the root is *labʰ-, but in which case the Vedic forms exhibiting a nasal in the root would have to be a secondary innovation. [Baltic forms not connected in this entry.]

Cf. s.v. OLith. lãbas 'gut' (BSl. Latv. labs 'gut, vollkommen', OPr. labs 'gut, tüchtig', etc.). The common Baltic word for 'good'. Slavic connections are lacking. The proposed connection to Vedic rabh-, rábhate 'to seize, to grasp' / labh-, lábhate 'to get' and Greek ἀμφιλαφής 'comprehensive', λαφύρα 'haul, spoils' is only possible if the root form is *labʰ- (cf. LIV² 412n1 s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen').
S.v. Lith. lãbas 'gut', connected with Ved. rabh- 'angreifen'.

Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. ALEW s.v. Lith. lãbas, LIV² 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. Hübschmann (1897:451) speculatively considered a connection with Arm. law (cf. discussion in /cognate/8081/), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by Fraenkel (1962-1965) or ALEW. A lemma for Lith. lãbas is lacking in Derksen (2015). Besides the still uncertain proposal to Ved. rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

Cf. s.v. OLith. gìrti 'loben, rühmen' (BSl. Latv. dzir̃t 'rühmend nennen', OCS žrьti 'opfern', etc.), from PIE *gʷerH- '(Positives) künden; Zustimmung bekunden' (cf. VEd. garⁱ- 'rühmen, ehren, ehrend aufnehmen, preisen', YAv. (auui)gərəṇte 'preist', Lat. grātēs 'Dank', etc.).

S.v. OLith. málti 'mahlen' (BSl. Latv. mal̃t 'mahlen', OPr. malunis 'Mühle', OCS mlěti, etc.), from PIE *melh₂- 'mahlen, zerreiben' (cf. Hitt. malli, mallai 'mahlt', CLuw. mālhūta 'brach', Gk. μύλη 'Mühle, Handmühle', Arm. malem 'zerstoße', Lat. molō -ere 'mahlen', OIr. meilid 'mahlt', Goth. malan 'mahlen', etc.).

Often assumed to be cognate with Alb. zorrë 'guts' but this connection is ultimately uncertain (cf. discussion in {ref ALEW} 1292 and further references in /cognate/8287/); sometimes also connected with Lat. haru- in haruspex 'diviner (by inspection of entrails)' Umbrian arvia either 'entrails' or 'grain' but the interpretation of the Italic forms (and consequently their etymology) is disputed (cf. discussion in /cognate/8486/).

S.v. Umbrian arvia 'Wahrscheinlich Teile des Opfertiers, vielleicht 'Eingeweide'" Etymology uncertain due to uncertain semantic identification; if connected to Lat. arvīna 'Fett, Speck' and connected to haru- in Lat. haru-spex 'diviner (by examination of entrails)', alternatively, if the meaning is 'Getreide', 'cereal grain', then perhaps a connection with Lat. arvum '(gepflügtes) Saatfeld, Ackerland' derived via a suffix -i̯o-/i̯ā.

Cf. s.v. Lat. arvum 'ploughed land'. The semantic identification of Umbrian arvia is often translated as 'part of a sacrificial animal', perhaps 'entrails', but this is disputed. Alternatively an analysis connecting it to Lat. arvum 'ploughed land' and translating it as 'grain' is also possible. Cf. entry in de Vaan for references to further literature.

Cf. s.v. OLith. vidùs 'Inneres, Mitte' (derived noun viduriaĩ (sm.pl.) 'Inneres, Eingeweide'; BSl. cf. Latv. vidus 'Mitte, Mittelstück, Inneres', OPr. widus 'Naht im Stiefel'), from PIE *u̯idʰh₁ú- 'Inneres' (cf. OIr. fid 'Baum, Holz', MW gwŷdd, MBret. gwez 'Bäume', ON viðr 'Baum, Holz', OE widu, wudu 'Holz; Baum; Wald', OHG witu 'Brennholz, Bauholz').

Cf. s.v. OLith. vidùs 'Inneres, Mitte' (derived noun viduriaĩ (sm.pl.) 'Inneres, Eingeweide'; BSl. cf. Latv. vidus 'Mitte, Mittelstück, Inneres', OPr. widus 'Naht im Stiefel'), from PIE *u̯idʰh₁ú- 'Inneres' (cf. OIr. fid 'Baum, Holz', MW gwŷdd, MBret. gwez 'Bäume', ON viðr 'Baum, Holz', OE widu, wudu 'Holz; Baum; Wald', OHG witu 'Brennholz, Bauholz').

Cf. s.v. OLith. vidùs 'Inneres, Mitte' (derived noun viduriaĩ (sm.pl.) 'Inneres, Eingeweide'; BSl. cf. Latv. vidus 'Mitte, Mittelstück, Inneres', OPr. widus 'Naht im Stiefel'), from PIE *u̯idʰh₁ú- 'Inneres' (cf. OIr. fid 'Baum, Holz', MW gwŷdd, MBret. gwez 'Bäume', ON viðr 'Baum, Holz', OE widu, wudu 'Holz; Baum; Wald', OHG witu 'Brennholz, Bauholz').

S.v. OLith. širdìs 'Herz, Sinn, Gesinnung' (BSl. cf. Latv. sir̂ds 'Herz; Mut, Zorn', OPr. seyr 'Herz', OCS srьcьce 'Herz', etc.), from PIE *k̑ḗrd-/*k̑r̥d- 'Herz' (cf. Hitt. ker 'Herz' CLuw. zārza 'Herz', Ved. hā́rdi, OAv. zərəd- 'Herz', Gk, κῆρ, 'Herz', καρδία 'Herz; Seele, Geist' Arm. sirt 'Herz', Lat. cor, cordis 'Herz; Geist, Seele', OIr. crude 'Herz', Goth. hairto, etc.).

S.v. OLith. galvà 'Kopf, Haupt; Kapitel' (BSl. Latv. gal̂va 'Kopf, Haupt', OPr. galwo 'Haupt; Schuhspitze', OCS glava 'Kopf; Hauptstück; Kapitel', etc.), IE cf. Arm. glowx, G.sg. glxoy 'Kopf; Ende, Spitze, Anführer'. The Armenian lexeme is a suffixal derivative for a word for 'head' in the proto-language, which is directly continued by the Balto-Slavic lexemes.

Generally considered to be cognate with the Armenian word for 'head', glowx. The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear. Cf. further discussion and references in /cognate/8243/. Classes indexed at proposed-cognacy level 5/6: large majority view.

Generally considered to be cognate with the Balto-Slavic word for 'head' (cf. Lith. galvà, etc.). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. Olsen 1999:43, Martirosyan 2010:220). Cf. further discussion regarding the Balto-Slavic lexemes in /cognate/1142/. Classes indexed at proposed-cognacy level 5/6: large majority view.

S.v. OPr. kirdīt, kirdītwei 'hören'. There is an uncertainty in connection to the value of the initial consonant. If <k-> really designates a voiceless stop, then we may have an etymological connection to Lith. kird-/kerd- in pakìrstu, -kìrdau, -kìrsti or pakirstù, etc. 'wach werden, aufwachen, erwachen; unruhig werden, in Unruhe geraten'. If <k-> is the result of a secondary devoicing (German influence?) from *girdīt (cf. krūt instead of *grūt) then kirdīt is to be connected with Lith. girdė́ti 'hören'.
As an original compound or light verb construction that has been univerbated, the morpheme being coded for cognacy here is *h₂eu̯i(s)- << *h₂eu-.

S.v. ºauklipts: niauklipts 'unverborgen'. Etymologically reflects the zero-grade from klip- to *klep- 'verbergen', to PIE *klep- '(heimlich) stehlen' (cf. Goth. hlifan 'stehlen', Gk. κλέπτω 'stehle (heimlich), hintergehe').
Cf. s.v. *klep- '(heimlich) stehlen, verbergen' (IEW 604).

Cf. s.v. Lith. slė̃pti 'verbergen, verstecken, verheimlichen'; the root *klep- (Gk. κλέπτω, etc.) is found in OPr. niauklipts 'unverborgen', but it is not clear whether the Lithuanian forms are to be connected to the same root.

Cf. s.v. *klep- '(heimlich) stehlen, verbergen' (IEW 604). Under the present stem *klép-e- ?Lith. slepiù (slė̃pti) 'verbergen' might be connected, if there is a secondary s-mobile and the initial cluster *skl- may be simplified to *sl- (cf. n4).

S.v. OLith. sunkùs 'schwer, schwierig'. This lexeme and its derivatives are widely attested in Lithuanian, but there are no clear external connections. For older, no longer tenable proposals cf. IEW 1048 s.v. *su̯enk-.

S.v. OLith. mùšti 'schlagen' (BSl. Latv. mušît 'quälen, würgen, töten', from PIE *meu̯s- 'schlagen' (cf. Ved. muṣṭi- 'Faust', YAv. mušti.masah- 'faustgroß', TochB maśce 'Faust'). Cf. ALEW for references to further literature.

S.v. Lith. mùšti 'beat' "In Latvian, the East Baltic root *muś- occurs once in mustavas Npl. 'warping beam', cf. Lith. muštùvai 'id'. This etymon has been connected with Gk. ἀμύσσω 'scratch, tear, lacerate', ἀμυχή 'rent, wound', and Lat. mūcrō f. 'point (of a sword etc.)'. If this is correct, we would have to reconstruct < *h₂muk̑-, with unclear consonantal variation in Greek. This etymology seems highly uncertain, however (cf. De Vaan 2008:392)."
S.v. OPr. kyrteis (Ipv.2.sg.) 'schlage!'

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ha(u)beda- ~ *ha(u)buda- 'head', from PIE *kh₂p-ut- (cf. Lat. caput, -itis 'head'; OIr. cúach, W cawg 'cup' < *kapuko-). Cf. entry in Kroonen regarding the variation of the root *hab- ~ *haub- in Germanic.

S.v. Ved. kapā́la- 'Schale, Schüssel, Hirnschale, Schädel'. No explanation that has reached unanimous acceptance. Perhaps to PIE *kap- 'fassen' (cf. Lat. capere 'nehmen', capula 'Schöpfgefäß', etc.), others see 'Hirnschale, Schädel' as primary and compare OE hafola 'Kopf' and the family from Lat. caput. Certain irregularities in the Middle and Modern Indic consider Turner (1966) to consider "at least influence" from Austroasiatic.

Cf. s.v. 2744 kapā́la- 'skull, cranium' (AV.) 'cup, jar, bowl' (TS.). Cf. note: "Although IE. (cf. OEng. hafola 'head') EWA i 155, the variant MIA. and NIA. forms suggest at least influence by Austro-as. ND 73 b 27".

The Proto-Indic base *kap- is often considered to be cognate with Lat. caput, OEng. hēafod, etc., but there is some uncertainty over the etymology of the Modern Indic lexemes from Ved. kapā́la-, and of Ved. kapā́la- itself, cf. discussion in Mayrhofer EWAia I:300, Turner (1962-1966:137), and further discussion in the references to the cognate class containing the Italic and Germanic lexemes in /cognate/6432/.

Cf. s.v. SAND ?*pē(n)s- (OCS pěsŭkŭ 'dust', SCr. piejèsak 'dust', Av. pąsnu- 'dust', OInd. pāṃsú- 'crumbling soil, sand, dust'). The Indo-Iranian forms may have been *pām/nsnu- while the Slavic forms lack a nasal. The Slavic accentuation points to *ē and not *eh₁-. The long *ē of *pēns- points to a root noun.

Cf. s.v. SAND ?*pē(n)s- (OCS pěsŭkŭ 'dust', SCr. piejèsak 'dust', Av. pąsnu- 'dust', OInd. pāṃsú- 'crumbling soil, sand, dust'). The Indo-Iranian forms may have been *pām/nsnu- while the Slavic forms lack a nasal. The Slavic accentuation points to *ē and not *eh₁-. The long *ē of *pēns- points to a root noun.

Cf. s.v. SAND ?*pē(n)s- (OCS pěsŭkŭ 'dust', SCr. piejèsak 'dust', Av. pąsnu- 'dust', OInd. pāṃsú- 'crumbling soil, sand, dust'). The Indo-Iranian forms may have been *pām/nsnu- while the Slavic forms lack a nasal. The Slavic accentuation points to *ē and not *eh₁-. The long *ē of *pēns- points to a root noun.
Root ref. form follows ALEW (cf. for further discussion), but cf. also Derksen (2015:326-327), although Derksen does not seem at all persuaded by his proposed connection to the Greek forms.

S.v. OLith. kárštas 'heiß, hitzig, eifrig' (BSl. Latv. kar̂sts 'heiß', etc.), generally considered an o-grade to-formation to the family of words surrounding Lith. *ker̃šti 'in Streit geraten, in Zorn geraten', for which some formal reconstructions are possible, but comparisons outside of Baltic remain uncertain.
S.v. Lith. žudýti 'kill, torment' (Latv. zudîtiês 'take care of, get excited'). Root reconstruction unclear, cf. entry for further discussion.
S.v. OLith. lẽdas 'Eis, Hagel' (BSl. Latv. lȩdus 'Eis, Eisscholle', OPr. ladis 'Eis', OCS ledъ 'Eis', etc.). No reliable comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic.

S.v. Lith. bùtas 'flat, apartment; (dial.) house, cottage' (OPr. buttan 'house', from PIE *bʰh₂u-t- (cf. OIr. both 'hut', OIc. buð 'house, residence'). The short vowel found in the OIr. both < *bʰh₂u-téh₂- can be viewed as regular in pretonic position, but this explanation is problematic in Balto-Slavic. The short vowel found in this form is therefore problematic.

S.v. OLith. nãmas 'Haus' (BSl. Latv. nams 'Hüte, Sommerküche, kleines Gebäude', OCS domъ 'Haus', etc.), from PIE *dóm-/*dém- 'Haus' (cf. Ved. G.pl. damā́m 'Haus', thematic dáma- 'Haus, häuslicher Herrschaftsbereich', YAv. G.sg. də̄ṇg in də̄ṇg patōiš 'des Hausherrn', L.sg. dąm, dąmi 'im Haus', Gk. δεσπότης 'Hausherr', Arm. town 'Haus', Lat. domus 'Haus'). The n in initial position may be explained as a secondary assimilation to the following m.

Cf. s.v. OLith. klùpti 'auf die Knie niedersinken, stolpern, straucheln' (BSl. Latv. klupt 'stolpern, straucheln, umfallen', OPr. klupstis 'Knie'). OPr. klupstis corresponds to Lith. (dial. südaukšt.) klùpstas. For the etymology cf. OLith. klaũpti 'hinknien, niederknien', without any clear comparanda outside of Baltic. The Baltic family of words is traditionally connected to Goth. ushlaupan 'aufspringen', ON 'hlaupa 'hüpfen, springen', OE hlēpan 'springen, laufen' (cf. LIV² 364), but these are not very close semantically, and only possible if the phonological difficulties are not unsurmountable.

S.v. OLith. kẽlis (II) (2), kelỹs (4) 'Knie; Knoten; Glied; Stamm; Generation' (BSl. Latv. celis 'Knie', etc.), probably not to be separated from OCS kolěno, SCr. kòljeno, Ru. koléno, Cz. komeno 'Knie, Nachkommenschaft, Generation' (cf. ESSJa 10:132-4, EDSL 228f.). The root relationship is probably also to SCr. člȃn 'Gelenk, Glied', Cz. člen 'Mitglied', Pol. człon 'Glied (einer Kette, eines Rohres)'. Possibly further to Gk. κῶλον 'Körperteil, Glied; Bein; Abschnitt (im Text)', but the morphological relationship of these nouns to each other remain unclear.

Cf. s.v. OLith. kreĩvas 'schlief, krumm; unrichtig, falsch' (BSl. cf. SCr. krȋv 'schlief, krumm; unrichtig, falsch; schuldig', ORuss. krivyi 'krumm, verwachsen; falsch, schlecht, ungerecht', Russ. krivój 'krumm, schlief, schräg', Cz. křivý 'krumm, schlief, falsch'. The same root probably also underlies Latv. krèiss 'der linke', but there are no good comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic.

Cf. s.v. OLith. gul̃ti 'sich legen' (BSl. Latv. gul̃t 'sich schlafen legen, sich lagern', etc.). This (East-)Baltic word family lacks further etymological connections. Various attempts have been made at an IE root etymology (cf. discussion in ALEW for references to further literature) but none of the proposals is satisfactory.

Cf. s.v. OLith. gývas 'lebend, lebendig' (from which gyvénti 'leben, existieren, sich aufhalten, wohnen'); BSl. cf. Latv. dzîvs 'lebendig, frisch, wach; ganz, heil, unverletzt; lauter, echt', dzîvuôt 'leben; wohnen; arbeiten, beschäftigt sein', OPr. adj. a.pl.m. geiwans 'lebendig', OCS živь 'lebendig' etc., from PIE *gʷih₃-u̯ó/éh₂- 'lebendig' (cf. Ved. jīvá- 'lebendig', OAv. juua- 'lebendig, lebend', OPers. jīva- 'id.', Gk. ζωός 'lebendig', Lat. vīvus 'lebendig', Osk. n.pl.m. bivus 'id.', OIr. béo 'lebendig', MW byw 'id.', Goth. qius 'lebendig').

Cf. s.v. OLith. jẽknos 'Leber' (BSl. Latv. (tahm.) jȩknas 'Leber', Latv. aknis, Latv. (hll.) aknys 'id.', OPr. jagno 'Leber'), from PIE *Hi̯ekʷ-r/n-, *Hi̯okʷ-r/n- 'Leber' (cf. Ved. yákr̥t, G.sg. yaknás 'Leber', OAv. NA.sg. yākarə 'Leber', Gk. ἥπαρ, G.sg. ἥπατος 'Leber', Lat. iecur, iocur, G.sg. iecinis, iecinoris, iocineris, iocinoris 'Leber').

Cf. s.v. OLith. kèpti 'backen, braten', among the derived forms OLith. kẽpenos, kepanos sf.pl. 'Leber' (BSl. Latv. cept 'backen, braten, brennen', OCS pešti 'braten, rösten'), from PIE *pekʷ- 'reif machen, gar machen' (cf. Ved. pac- 'kocht, brät', YAv. pac- 'kochen', Gk. πέττω 'lasse reifen, verdaue, koche', Alb. pjek 'backen, braten, gären, brennen', Lat. coquō, -ere 'kochen, backen, braten', MW pobi 'Backen', TochA päk- kochen, reifen', TochB päk- 'kochen, reifen lassen'). The East Baltic words continue PIE *pekʷ- if they may be accounted for via a metathesis to *kʷep-.
Cf. s.v. 1. *pekʷ- 'reif machen, gar machen' (IEW 798).

S.v. OLith. ìlgas 'lang' (BSl. Latv. il̃gs 'lang, langdauernd', OPr. ilga (adv.) lange', OCS dlьgъ 'lang', etc.), from PIE *dlh₁gʰó- 'lang' (cf. Ved. dīrghá- 'lang, weitreichend; langdauernd', OAv. darəga- 'lang', YAv. darəγa- 'lang', Alb. gjátë 'lang'. For the lack of the dental in initial position of the Proto-Baltic adjective for 'long' there is no commonly accepted explanation.

Cf. s.v. OLith. girià 'Wald, Wüste, Wildnis', under which "Zugehörigkeit von lett. gãrša sf. 'großer Wald' (und lett. garš 'lang' bleibt zweifelhaft." The belonging of Latv. gãrša sf. 'large forest' (and Latv. garš 'long' [to the group of words connected to Lith. girià 'forest, desert, wilderness'] remains doubtful.
Etymologically isolated. The proposed connection to Lith. girià 'forest, wasteland, wilderness' is doubtful (cf. ALEW 332). Not in Derksen (2015).

S.v. OLith. výras 'Mann, Ehemann' (BSl. cf. Latv. vĩrs, OPr. wirs, wijrs), from PIE *u̯iH-ró- 'junger, kräftiger (Mann)' (cf. Ved. vīrá- 'Mann, Held', OAv. vīra- 'Mann, Mensch', YAv. vīra- 'id.', MPers. vīr 'id.', Lat. vĭr 'Mann, Ehemann', OIr. fer 'Mann', OW gur, MW gwr 'id.', Celtiberian UIROS 'id.?', Goth. wair 'Mann', ON verr 'id.', OHG wer 'id., OE wer 'Mann, Wergeld', TochA wir 'jung, jugendkräftig').

S.v. OLith. mėsà, męsà 'Fleisch' (BSl. Latv. mìesa 'Fleisch, das ungeteilte, lebendige Fleisch des Körpers', OPr. mensā 'Fleisch', OCS męso, etc.), from PIE *mē(m)s-, *mēms-ó- 'Fleisch' (cf. CLuw. mi(ya)sa- 'Fleisch', Ved. mām̆̇s-, mām̆̇sá- 'Fleisch', Gk. μηρός, μῆρα 'der obere, fleischige Teil des Schenkels, Schenkelknochen, Schenkelbein', Arm. mis 'Fleisch', Lat. membrum 'Glied, Körperglied', Teil', Alb. mish 'Fleisch', OIr. mír 'Bissen, Stück, Portion', Goth. mimz 'Fleisch', TochB misa 'Fleisch').

S.v. OLith. siaũras 'eng, schmal' (BSl. Latv. šàurs 'eng, schmal, beschränkt'. The (East-)Baltic adjective has no secure etymological connections. Older accounts attempt to connect to an IE root *seu̯- 'biegen' considering a connection to *seu̯- 'auspressen', which is only securely attested for Indo-Iranian (cf. LIV² 537f.).

Regarding the proposed connections to Indo-Iranian *sau̯-, cf. s.v. Ved. √sav- 'pressen, (Soma) auspressen, keltern', "Die idg. Vorstufe von iir. *sau̯ '(aus)pressen, keltern' bleibt unsicher." The IE precursor of IIr. *sau̯- 'press out, squeeze' remains uncertain.
Cf. s.v. *kelH- 'aufragen, hochragen' (IEW 544).

S.v. Lith. kálnas 'mountain, hill' (Latv. kal̂ns 'mountain, hill'), from PIE *kolH-n- (cf. Gk. κολώνη 'hill', Lat. collis 'hill', OE hyll 'hill'). The evidence points to an original n-stem containing the root of Lith. kélti 'lift, raise, wake, arouse, transfer' (Latv. cel̂t 'lift, erect, found, wake', etc.), from PIE *kelH- (cf. Lat. excellere 'excel').

S.v. OLith. var̃das 'Name' (BSl. Latv. vā̀rds, 'Wort; Name', OPr. N.sg. wīrds 'Wort'), from Indo-European *u̯ordʰo-; elsewhere in IE cf. Lat. verbum 'Wort', Goth. waurd, ON orð, OE word 'Wort'. The IE word for 'word' appears in the individual languages with different ablaut grades. It is hypothesised that the PIE lexeme for 'word' ultimately contains the root *u̯erh₁- 'sagen' (Palaic wērti 'sprechen', Gk. ῥητήρ 'Sprecher, Redner', Russ. vrat' 'lügen', cf. LIV² 689), but this conjecture requires an as yet more precise morphological-derivational explaination. Cf. entry in ALEW for references to further literature.

Traditionally Lith. burnà 'mouth' and Arm. beran 'mouth' have been connected etymologically (cf. {ref {Hübschmann 1897}:429, {ref Olsen 1999}:297, {ref ALEW} 152, {ref Derksen 2015}:106). Although this etymology is accepted, further morphological analysis and the isolation of an IE root remains unclear; further connections have been postulated to derive an n-stem noun from the same root underlying Lat. forō, -āre 'bore' OHG borōn 'bore', from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ({ref LIV²} 80), but these connections are not fully clear (cf. {ref ALEW}). However, if with {ref Derksen 2015}:106), who notes that if the Slovak perna 'lip' belongs with the Baltic forms, then the usually reconstruction to a root *bʰrH- is in doubt. As {ref ALEW}, {ref Derksen 2015}, and {ref Olsen 1999} are in agreement about the cognacy, it has been accepted for this class, although the precise IE root etymology is in question. [NB: Arm. beran 'mouth' is not discussed in {ref Martirosyan 2010}.]

"Beran […] 'mouth' (IEW 134, Solta 291f) is etymologically connected with Lith. burnà 'mouth', OChSl. bъrna 'lip', MIrish bern 'fissure', all derived from the root *bʰer- 'cleave' by a suffix containing *-n-. The BSl. forms point to a proto-form *bʰrnáh₂ which could be explained as a secondary derivative of a *-men- stem with a zero grade in the root and selection of *-no- (*-nah₂-) after a root containing a labial. Beran, -oy, on the other hand, immediately seems to reflect *bʰern̥no- with suffixal *-n̥no-, a possible variant of *-m̥no-, also found after roots involving a labial element"

Cf. s.v. Lith. úostas 'port, harbour, (dial. arch.) mouth of a river' (Latv. uõsta 'port, harbour, mouth of a river', OPr. austo 'mouth'), from PIE *Hous-t- (*h₂/₃eus-t-?), cf. Skt. óṣṭha- '(upper) lip'.

S.v. OLith. bámba (1), bambà (4) 'Nabel' (BSl. Latv. bam̃ba 'Kugel, Ball, Schlägel', Ru. búba 'Beule, Schwellung; Erbse, Waldbeere', Ukr. búba 'im Wasser aufgequollene Erbse oder Bohne; Beere; Beule; Abszess'. The alternating accentuation in Lithuanian is historically unclear. No comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic.

S.v. OLith. jáunas 'jung, neu' (BSl. Latv. jaûns 'jung, neu', OCS junъ 'jung', etc.), from PIE *h₂i̯u-h₃on- 'jung' (cf. Skt. yúvan- 'jung, jugendlich; Jüngling', YAv. yuuan- 'Jüngling', Lat. iuvenis, -is 'junger Mann, junger Mensch; jung', iūnīx 'junge Kuh, Färse', Gaul. Iovinc(o)- 'jung', OIr. óëc 'jung', MW ieuanc 'id.', Goth. juggs 'jung', ON ungr 'id.', OHG jung 'id.').

Cf. s.v. *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- n. 'Leben, Lebenszeit, -erwartung' (IEW 17f., 510f., EIEC 352, 655). Cf. specifically p.278 s.v. *h₂i̯-eu̯-h₃n-ó- > Lith. jáunas, 'jung', Latv. jaûns 'jung, neu' and n36, n37.

S.v. OLith. naũjas 'neu, jung' (BSl. OPr. nawans 'neu', OCS novъ 'neu', etc.), from PIE *néu̯-i̯o-, 'neu', *néu̯-o- 'id.' (cf. Hitt. nēwa- 'neu', Ved. návya- 'id.', YAv. nauua- 'neu, frisch', Gk. νέος 'neu, jung', Myc. ne-wo, ne-wa 'neu', Lat. novus, -a, -um 'neu', OIr. núae 'neu', MW newydd  'id.', Goth. niujis 'neu', TochA ñu, etc.).

There is no certain etymology. The meaning points to PS velěti 'command'. It can be related to Latin volgus, vulgus 'people, heap, great ammount', Greek ἅλῐς 'in plenty, numerous', Tocharian B walke 'long, far', wälts 'thousand'.

For Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, Beekes argues for a connection with the root *kʷsep- '(spend the) night', with a prefix *u̯e- (of less certain origin, cf. article for discussion of alternative possibilities).

For Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, Beekes argues for a connection with the root *kʷsep- '(spend the) night', with a prefix *u̯e- (of less certain origin, cf. article for discussion of alternative possibilities).

S.v. OLith. vãkaras 'Abend', under which is included vãkar (adv.) 'gestern' (BSl. Latv. vakars 'Abend', OCS vьčera 'gestern', etc.), certainly cognate with Gk. ἕσπερος 'abendlich; westlich', ἑσπέρα 'Abend; Westen', Arm gišer 'Nacht', Lat. vesper (adj.) 'abendlich, zum Abend gehörig', vesper sf. 'Abend', MW ucher 'Abend'. The precise reconstruction is however disputed, cf. Beekes (2004) for the most recent attempt.

S.v. OLith. vãkaras 'Abend', under which is included vãkar (adv.) 'gestern' (BSl. Latv. vakars 'Abend', OCS vьčera 'gestern', etc.), certainly cognate with Gk. ἕσπερος 'abendlich; westlich', ἑσπέρα 'Abend; Westen', Arm gišer 'Nacht', Lat. vesper (adj.) 'abendlich, zum Abend gehörig', vesper sf. 'Abend', MW ucher 'Abend'. The precise reconstruction is however disputed, cf. Beekes (2004) for the most recent attempt.

S.v. OLith. artùs, -ì 'nahe', derived from PIE *h₂er- 'zusammenfügen' (cf. Ved. ará- 'Radspeiche' r̥tá- 'Wahrheit', r̥tú- 'richtige Zeit, bestimmte Zeit', OAv. aṣ̌a- 'Wahrheit', Gk. ἀραρίσκω 'zusammenfügen', Arm. ard, G.sg. ardow 'Anordnung, Ordnung', ard (adv.) 'soeben, jetzt', Lat. artus 'eng in Raum und Zeit', artē 'eng, dicht, fest', ars, -tis 'handwerklickhe Kunstfertigkeit, Kunst', artus, -ūs 'Gelenk'). Lith. artùs is clearly a lexicalised past passive participle to a  primary verb that has been lost in Baltic.

S.v. kãklas 'Hals, Kehle' (BSl. kakls 'Hals'). The East Baltic words for 'neck' may either be explained as a reduplicated form like Ved. cákra- 'wheel', but on the other hand there are similarities to the Germanic words for neck like Goth. hals. Both comparisons nevertheless show marked deviations from the extra-Baltic comparanda. See entry in ALEW for further discussion and references to further literature. Like other Baltic words for body parts like kója 'leg, foot' [cf. /cognate/1856/, /cognate/1862/], Lith. kãklas 'neck' remains without a clear etymology.

S.v. OLith. naktìs 'Nacht' (BSl. Latv. nakts 'Nacht', OPr. naktin 'Nacht', OCS noštь), from PIE *negʷ- 'dunkel werden, dämmern' *nókʷ-t-, *nekʷ-t- 'Nacht' (cf. Hitt. nekuz (mēhur) 'Abend(zeit)', Ved. nákt- 'Nacht', Gk. νύξ, νυκτός 'Nacht', Alb natë 'Nacht, Morgendämmerung', Lat. nox, noctis 'Nacht', OIr. innocht 'heute Nacht', OW nos 'Nacht', Bret. noz 'id.', Goth. nahts 'Nacht', TochA nokte (adv.) 'nachts').

S.v. OLith. tráukti 'ziehen, schleppen' (BSl. tràukt/traũkt 'schlagen, etc.). The well-attested Baltic family of words have no clear further connections. The comparison with ON ϸrúga 'drohen', OHG drucken 'drücken' could go back to a common PIE root *treu̯Hk- ~ 'gewaltsam in Bewegung setzen (?)', but this form is structurally striking and would need to be more precisely semantically defined.
Etymology unclear; cf. ALEW for older proposed connections to Germanic lexemes. This verb is not listed in LIV² or Derksen (2015).

S.v. OLith. tę̃sti 'dehnen, spannen, ziehen' (BSl. OPr. tiēnstwei 'reizen'), from PIE *tens- 'ziehen' (cf. Ved. tam̆̇s- 'schütteln', hin und her bewegen, zerren', Goth. atþinsan 'heranziehen', OHG dinsan 'ziehen, schleppen').
It is related to Tocharian A wäl 'prince, emperor', Tocharian B wal 'prince, emperor' and walke 'long, further', Greek Ϝἄλις 'enough', εἴλω, εἰλέω 'press, squeeze'.

PIE *u̯elH- 'be strong, have power, rule'. It is related to Old Irish follnadar 'he rules', Old Nordic olla 'he ruled', Latin valēre 'be strong', Tocharian A walo, B wäl ‛king’. Linking to Greek ἅλῐς 'many', Latin vulgus 'people', Old Indic várga- 'group', Breton awalc'h 'enough', Welsh gwala 'a large number, enough' (PIE *u̯el-) is less probable.
Further etymology is not entirely certain. It is related to Lithuanian galėti 'can', galia 'power', Irish gal 'courage', Old Breton gal 'power, strenght'. PIE *gal- or *ghal-.
It is related to Lithuanian galėti 'can' and probably to Oscan valaimo- 'best, very good' and Latin valēre 'be strong'.
It can be related to Lithuanian galėti 'can'.

PS dialectal *duž- (*dug-j-) 'very strong, able-bodied, healthy, outstanding as to the size or number', PIE *dʰeu̯gʰ-. It is related to Lithuanian daũg 'much, a lot' and Latvian daũdz 'very, much, a lot'.
It is related to Lithuanian daũg 'many', German taugen 'be fit', Norwegian dyggr 'able, sure, worthy'. Derived from PS *dug-. PIE *dheugh-.
See for the possible further cognacy.
The Polish lexeme can be a loan from East Slavic (Ukrainian).
S.v. OLith. žaĩsti 'spielen'. No reliable comparanda outside of Lithuanian.
The root is ideophonic.
PS *pilę and *pylę, with an ideophonic origin.
The root is ideophonic.

S.v. OLith. víenas 'eins, ein(e, r); einzig; jemand, irgendein(e, r)'. (BSl. Latv. viêns 'eins, ein(e, r); einzeln, allein, derselbe', OPr. ains, etc., from PIE *(H)oi̯nó- 'eins, ein(e, r)' (cf. Gk. οἰνός, οἰνή 'Eins auf dem Würfel', Lat. ūnus 'eins, einer; einziger', OIr. oín, óen 'eins, einer', Goth. ains, etc.).

S.v. OLith. sẽnas 'alt' (BSl. Latv. sȩns 'alt, aus alter Zeit stammend, ehemalig', etc.), from PIE *sen- 'alt', *sén-o/eh₂- 'id.' (cf. Ved. sána- 'alt', YAv. hana- 'alt, greis', Gk. ἕνος, -η, -ον 'alt, vormalig', Arm. hin 'alt', Lat. senex, senis 'alt; Greis', OIr. sen 'alt', Goth. sineigs 'alter Mann', etc.).
PIE *gʷrēu̯-g̑ʰ-.
S.v. Sloven. gristi < PIE *gʷreu̯Hg̑-.

S.v. OLith. nósis 'Nase' (BSl. Latv. nãss, nãse 'Nasenflügel, Nüster', OPr. nozy 'Nase', OCS nosъ 'Nase'), from PIE *nā́s-/*nas- 'Nasenflügel, Nüster' (cf. Ved. n.du. nā́sā, g.du. nasóṣ 'Nase', YAv. n.du. nā̊ŋha 'Nase', OPers. a.sg. nāham 'Nase', Lat. naris 'Nasenloch, Nüster', nāsus, nāsum 'Nase', ON nǫs, n.pl. nasar 'Nasenloch, Nüster', OE nasu, etc.).
The root has an ideophonic origin.
S.v. lietùs 'Regen' (BSl. Latv. liêtus, etc.), from PIE *lei̯H- 'gießen', *lei̯H-tu- 'Guss' (cf. Goth. leiϸu sm. (?) 'Obstwein').
Related to PS gorěti 'burn', PIE *gʷʰer-.

Cf. s.v. OLith. dẽšinas, -à 'rechte(r, s)' (BSl. OCS desnъ, etc.), from PIE *dek̑s-, *dek̑s-i-no- 'rechts, südlich' (cf. Ved. dákṣina- 'rechts, rechts gehend', südlich', YAv. dašina- 'rechts', Gk. δεξίος 'rechts, glückverheißend', Alb. djathtë 'rechts', djathë (dialectal Old Albanian) 'id.', Lat. dexter 'rechts', OIr. dess 'rechts, südlich', MW deheu 'rechts, südlich; geschickt, recht', Goth. taihswa 'rechts', etc.).
PIE *ghel-.
PS *žĭlkŭkŭ. It is derived from *žĭlknǫti 'become bitter, become yellow'.
S.v. OLith. matýti 'sehen, wahrnehmen' (BSl. Latv. matît, fühlen, empfinden, merken', a further connection may be sought in the family of Slavic lexemes around SCr. mòtriti, mòtrȋm 'zusehen'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ(jъ), from PIE *kirno- or *kirsno- (cf. Ved. kr̥ṣṇá-).
PS *kry, *krŭve with an original meaning 'driping blood'.
PS *dǫti. It is related to Old Indic dhámati 'blow' and Lithuanian dumiu, dùmti 'blow'.
PS *duxati. It is derived from PS *duxŭ 'breath, spirit', ultimately from PIE *dheu̯-s-.
PS *puxati, derived from an ideophonic PIE root *p(ʰ)eu̯s-. It is related to Lithuanian pū̃sti, Latvian pùst, probably also to Greek phȳ̃sa, phȳsáō.
The root has an ideophonic origin.

The lexeme is common Slavic (cf. Polish fukać, Russian fukat') but it is virtually impossible to give any reasonable further etymology. It has doubtless an ideophonic origin. It could be reconstructed as PS *fukati but it is assumed that PS did not have any phoneme / f /.
It is a loan from Greek κόκκαλο(ν).
OCS gnesti, gnetǫ 'press, push', Old English cnedan 'knead'.

PS dialectal *gnatŭ 'long bone, crus'. The etymology is not entirely clear. It is possibly related to German Knoten 'knot', Norwegian knott 'burl', Old Nordic knǫtr 'clod', ultimately PIE *gnotu-. The original meaning were 'burly bone'.

The etymology is complicated. It is not excluded, that it is related to *gnetǫ, *gnesti 'press, push'. Other etymologies are highly questionable, e. g. linking to German Knoten 'knot' or Greek γόνυ, γόνατος 'knee'.

S.v. OLith. regė́ti 'sehen, schauen, bemerken' (BSl. redzêt 'sehen; traümen; sehen nach; aufpassen, sorgen, verlangen' etc.). Etymology unclear. LIV² 498 considers a possible root *(h₂)regʰ- 'sich aufrichten, but the connection is uncertain. Likewise the comparison with Alb. rúaj 'bewachen, bewahren, beobachten' remains doubtful. Cf. ALEW for references to further literature.

Cf. s.v. *regʰ- 'sich aufrichten' [IEW 854, 863], under which Lith. regiù (regė́ti) is suggested to be based on an essive formation ?*r̥gʰ-h₁é-, but this etymology is considered to be not fully certain.
S.v. OLith. jū́ra 'Meer' (BSl. Latv. jũŗa 'Meer, großer See', OPr. juriay 'Meer', from PIE *i̯uHr- 'Wasser' (cf. Arm. ǰowr, G.pl. ǰowrcʻ, ǰrocʻ 'Wasser').

PS ostĭ 'awn, fishbone' is most probably related to PIE root for 'sharp' [PIE *h₂ek̑-], and not to PIE root for 'bone' [PIE *h₃est-] but the latter hypothesis is also reasonable. Generally, Slavic *kostĭ and *ostĭ seem to be unrelated. 
The Latin word costa 'rib' is isolated and its etymology remains unclear. For a comparison with the Slavic lexeme additional closer cognates are necessary. The same applies to Old Indic kāṣṭhá- 'log'.
All existing hypotheses linking the Slavic lexeme to Latin os, ossis etc. [PIE *h₃est-] (k- as prefix, borrowing from a substrate IE language, k- as prothesis disposing the hiatus in nominal phrases, metathesis of *osthr̥k or *ostĭka, contamination with other lexemes/roots) are unconvincing. The PS word *koza 'goat' (with analogues like Old Indic ajá or Lithuanian ožỹs) is not a further example for the 'irregular initial k-' in Slavic. This lexeme is most probably a loan from Altaic and the variation in the onset has its sources there (the variation is attested in Turkic).
The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *kes- with a suffix *-to- (*kos-to-). The original meaning were 'bone protruding from under the skin, a dangling thing, a ticking thing'.

S.v. OLith. šakà 'Zweig, Ast; Zacken', derived form šãknis 'Wurzel' (BSl. Latv. saka 'Verästelung (bei Bäumen), sakns, sakne, 'Wurzel', OPr. sagnis 'Wurzel', SCr. sòha 'Gabelholz', etc.). Generally agreed to be connected to Ved. śā́kha- 'Ast, Zweig', Arm. cʻax, I.sg. cʻaxov, cʻaxiw 'grüner Zweig mit Blättern'. The continuants of this word in the individual IE branches show several anomalies that are not satisfactorily explained. The best explanation for Ved. śā́khā- is probably the reconstruction of an ablauting o-grade root, e.g. *k̑ók-eh₂- ~ *k̑ek-h₂-.
S.v. OLith. bė́gti 'laufen, rennen, fliehen' (BSl. Latv. bêgt 'laufen', OCS běžati 'laufen, fliehen', etc.), from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'davonfliehen, fliehen' (cf. Gk. φέβομαι 'fliehe').

Cf. s.v. OLith. sálti 'süß werden' (BSl. Latv. sā̀ls 'Salz', OPr. sal 'Salz', OCS solь 'Salz', etc.), from PIE *sal- 'Salz' (cf. Gk. ἅλς, ἁλός 'Salz', Arm. ał 'Salz', Lat. sāl, G.sg. sălis 'Salz; Meerwasser', OIr. sál 'Salzwasser, Meer', MW halwyn 'Salz', Goth. salt 'Salz', TochB salyiye 'Salz').
S.v. OLith. tar̃ti 'sagen, aussprechen' (BSl. cf. OPr. tārin 'Stimme'), from PIE *ter- 'sprechen' (cf. Hitt. ter- 'sprechen, sagen').
The Slavic lexeme is related to PIE *h₃est-. The irregular k- is probably due to a contamination with another root (maybe related to Latin costa).
The lexeme is related to Latin costa 'rib'.
The Slavic lexeme is usually linked to Latin os etc. (PIE *h₃est-). However, k- needs an explanation then. Most probably it is a result of a contamination (cf. Latin costa 'rib' or PIE *kes-).

PIE *h₂osti-. The Slavic lexeme is related to Old Indic ásthi- ‛bone’, Albanian asht, Latin os, Hittite ḫaštāi-. The initial k- is probably due to a contamination with a currently lost word related to Latin costa 'rib'. A simmilar irregular k- is found in Slavic *koza 'goat'.

The Slavic lexeme has no clear parallels in IE. It is usually linked to Latin os, ossis, Old Indic ásthi, Greek ὀστέον etc. The initial k- is explained as a result of a contamination (cf. Latin costa 'rib').
It is related to Latin costa 'rib'.
There is no certain etymology.
The word is derived from PIE *kes- and related to Latin costa 'rib', Old Indic kastha- 'log' and Albanian kashtë 'straw'.
The lexeme is related to Slavic *kositi and *česati [PIE *kes-]. The hypotheses about a relationship to Latin costa 'rib' or Latin os 'bone' etc. are not convincing.
The lexeme is related to Latin costa 'rib'. The hypotheses about a relationship to Latin os 'bone' etc. (assuming a prefix *k- or a metathesis from *osthr̥k-) is improbable.

It is usually assumed to be related to Latin os, ossis 'bone'. The initial k- is explained as a prefix or as a special reflex of the initial laryngal. In fact, we deal here most probably with two different etymona. The Slavic lexeme is related to Latin costa 'rib'. PIE *kos-t- [PIE *kes-] 'sharp, cutting, outstanding'.

There is no clear further etymology of the Slavic lexeme.
All hypotheses assuming a relationship to PIE *h₃est- fail to explain the initial k- in a convincing way.
Other proposed cognates are etymologically unclear themselves.
The proposed relationship to PIE *kes- seems to lack an entirely convincing semantic motivation.
The Slavic words are derived from PS *duxŭ 'breath, spirit', ultimately from PIE *dheu̯-s-.

S.v. OLith. dū́mas 'Rauch' (BSl. cf. Latv. dũmi 'Rauch', OPr. dumis 'Rauch', OCS dymъ 'Rauch, Dampf, Dunst', etc.), from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- 'Rauch, Dampf' (cf. Ved. dhūmá- 'Rauch', Gk. θῡμός 'Mut, Gemüt, Sinn', Lat. fūmus 'Rauch, Dampf'.
Derived from PIE *gʷher- / *gʷhor-, related to Latin formus etc.
The lexeme is derived from PIE *pel- / *pol- and related to Lithuanian pelenaĩ 'ash' and Old Icelandic flōr 'warm'.

S.v. OLith. úosti 'riechen' (BSl. Latv. uôst 'riechen' OCz. jadati 'undersuchen, erforschen'), from PIE *h₃ed- 'zu riechen beginnen' (cf. Gk. ὄζω, 1.sf.perf. ὄδωδα 'riechen, duften', Arm. hot 'Geruch', hotim 'riechen, stinken', Lat. olō, -ere, 'riechen, duften' Alb. ãmë 'Duft, Geruch, Gestank').

S.v. OLith. mãžas, -à 'klein; noch nicht erwachsen' (BSl. cf. Latv. mazs 'klein, gering', OPr. massais (comp.adv.) 'weniger', etc.). No known etymology outside of Baltic. The often considered connection with PIE *meg̑- 'groß' is fraught with formal and semantic difficulties (cf. ALEW for references to further literature).

There is no certain etymology. The proposed relationship to PS *karati, *koriti 'punish, humble etc.' is at first glance semantically  unconvincing. However, this lexeme shows a strong semantic variation in Bulgarian and Macedonian dialects: 'put into motion, force, drive (a vehicle or cattle), chase, lead out, jet etc.' and it would be possible to build a reasonable chain of semantic changes from 'punish' to 'carry'. In any case, it would be speculative, though. The hypothesis about the borrowing from a Romance language should be checked.

Cf. s.v. OLith. gul̃ti 'sich legen' (BSl. gul̃t 'sich schlafen legen, sich lagern'). This (East-)Baltic word family lacks further etymological connections. Various attempts have been made at an IE root etymology (cf. discussion in ALEW for references to further literature) but none of the proposals is satisfactory.

S.v. OLith. dangùs (4), dángus 'Himmel' (BSl. OPr. dangus 'Himmel, Daumen'), a lexicalised τομός-formation to Lith. deñgti 'decken, bedecken, bekleiden', derived from PIE *dʰengʰ- 'bedecken' (cf. ON dyngja 'Frauengemach', OHG tung 'Keller, Erdhaus, Webstube, unterirdisches Gemach').

Cf. s.v. OLith. sė́ti 'säen', from which is derived sė́kla (1), sėklà (3) 'Same, Saat' (BSl. cf. Latv. sẽt 'säen',, sȩ̃kla 'Samen, Saat', OCS sěti 'säen', etc.) from PIE *seh₁- 'säen, eindrücken' (cf. Hitt. sai-, si- 'einprägen, sigeln, eindrücken, werfen', Lat. serō, -ere 'säen, anpflanzen', OIr. síl 'Samen, Nachkommenschaft', Goth. saian 'säen', etc.).
S.v. OLith. siū́ti 'nähen' (BSl. Latv. šũt 'nähen', OCS šiti 'nähen, sticken', etc.), from PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'nähen' (cf. Ved. sīvy- 'nähen', Lat. suō, -ere 'nähen', Goth. siujan 'nähen', etc.).

It can be related to PS *karati 'punish' which is related to Latin carinō 'insult' and Old Irish caire 'reprimand'. However, some scholars assume here a loan from Balkan Latin, cf. Romanian a cărá, car, Latin *carrare, carrus.
S.v. OLith. šešė́lis (1), šešė̃lis (2) 'Schatten'. No clear comparanda outside of Lithuanian.
PIE *kar- (with an expressive *-a-), related to Latin carināre, Irish caire, Greek κάρνη.

S.v. OLith. ãštras 'scharf, streng' (BSl. Latv. asrs 'scharf', OCS ostrъ 'scharf, rauh', etc.), from PIE *h₂ek̑ro- (cf. Ved. -aśra- '-eckig', Gk. ἄκρος 'äußerst, oberst, höchst', OIr. ér 'hoch(gestellt), edel').

S.v. OLith. dainà 'Lied, Volkslied', with derived verb dainúoti 'singen'. The further etymology is unclear. Perhaps to either (1) to Lith. dejà 'Wehklage' (without certain etymology), or (2) to be connected with Latv. diêt 'hüpfen, tanzen, singen', in which case could be connected to PIE *dei̯h₁- 'dahinjagen' (LIV² 107).
The traditional comparisons with Latin carināre, Balto-Slavic  words like Russian kor, etc. is probably wrong. The Greek lexeme can be Pre-Greek.
S.v. OPr. grīmons 'gesungen' (Ptz. II). Belongs to the Baltic group of lexemes including Latvian gremt 'murmeln, im Affekte reden', to be derived from PIE *gʰrem- 'dröhnen, wüten, donnern'.
Cf. s.v. *gʰrem- 'dröhnen, wüten' (IEW 458-9).

S.v. OLith. sėdė́ti 'sitzen' (BSl. Latv. sêdêt 'sitzen', OPr. sindats 'sitzend', OCS sěděti 'sitzen', etc.), from PIE *sed- 'sich setzen' (cf. Ved. sad- 'sitzen', YAv. had- 'sich setzen', Gk. ἕζομαι 'setze mich', Arm nstim 'sitze', Lat. sedeō -ēre 'sitzen', OIr. saidid 'sitzt', Goth. sitan 'sitzen', etc.).
S.v. OLith. óda (1), odà (4) 'Haut, Leder, Fell' (BSl. Latv. âda 'Balg, Fell, Haut, Haut auf einer trocknenden Flüssigkeit, Hülse', etc.). No further connections outside of (East-)Baltic.

Cf. s.v. OLith. debesìs, debeỹs 'Wolke' (BSl. cf. Latv. debess, OCS nebo, etc.), from PIE *nebʰ-es- 'Himmel, Luftraum, Wolke' (cf. Hitt. nepis-, 'Himmel', HLuw. tipas- 'id.', Ved. nábhas- 'Feuchtigkeit, Wolke; Himmel', OAv. nabah- 'Luftraum, Himmel', Gk. νέφος 'Wolke, Bewölkung').
S.v. OLith. miegóti 'schlafen' (BSl. OPr. meicte 'schlafen', SCr. mȉgati 'blinzeln', etc.).

Cf. s.v. OLith. glodùs 'glatt' (BSl. Latv. glãstit 'streicheln, liebkosen', OPr. glosto 'Wetzstein', OCS gladъkъ 'glatt, flach, eben', etc.), from PIE *gʰleHdʰ- 'glatt' (cf. Lat. glaber 'glatt, unbehaart, kahl', ON glaðr 'hell, klar', OE glæd 'hell, leuchtend', OHG glat 'glatt, schlüpfrig; hell leuchtend').

PS grǫdĭ is a Slavic lexico-semantic innovation without further IE parallels. It is related to PS *grǫda / *gruda / *grǫdŭ / *grudŭ 'clod, clomp, chunk' and further to PS *grǫbŭ / *grubŭ 'rugged, rough, raw, thick' [that is ultimately derived from PIE *gʰreu̯-]. IE cognates are: Old Icelandic grjót 'stones', German Gries 'sand, gravel', Lithuanian grū́das 'corn', grúodas 'frozen earth', German groß 'big', English great.

Cf. s.v. OLith. angìs 'Giftschlange, Otter' (BSl. Latv. ùoc, 'Otter, Kreuzotter', OPr. angis 'Schlange', Slovene vọ̑z 'Grasschlange', etc. from PIE *n̥-ngʷí- 'Schlange' (cf. Lat. anguis 'Schlange', OIr. escung 'Aal', MW llysywen 'Aal', OHG unk 'Schlange, Natter', etc.).
S.v. OLith. gyvãtė 'Schlange, Otter, Natter', a derivative of Lith. gyvatà 'Leben', cf. OLith. gýti 'heilen, genesen, leben' from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃-.
S.v. OLith. sniẽgas 'Schnee' (BSl. Latv. snìegs 'Schnee', OPr. snaygis 'Schnee', OCS sněgъ 'Schnee', etc.), from PIE *snoi̯gʷʰo- 'Schnee' (cf. Goth. snaiws 'id.', etc.).

S.v. OLith. žvaigždė̃ (4), žvaĩgždė (2) 'Stern' (BSl. Latv. zvàigzne 'Stern', OCS dzvědza 'Stern', etc.). No good etymology outside of Balto-Slavic. The Balto-Slavic forms are to be considered cognates, but the precise reconstruction of a proto-form is difficult. Cf. entry for extensive discussion on the difficulties of reconstructing a proto-form for this lexeme.
The etymology of PS *grǫdĭ is not entirely clear. It is maybe derived from PIE *gʷrendʰ- 'swell, become big' and related to Latin grandis 'big' and Greek βρένθος 'pride'.
The Slavic lexeme is related to Latin grandis 'great' and Greek βρένθος 'pride'.
The lexeme is a Slavic innovation and does not have any certain cognates. It can be related to Lithuanian granda 'roughly hewed plank' and Latin grunda 'roof' from PIE *gʰrondʰ-.
IE cognacy and the IE root are uncertain. A contamination of ultimately distinct etymona is possible.
It is related to Latin grandis 'big, great', Armenian argand 'bay', Greek βρένθος 'pride'. It is derived from PIE [*gʷrendʰ-], a nasalized variant of PIE *[*gʷreu̯dʰ-].
The Slavic lexeme is related to dialectal Lithuanian pìršys 'horse chest', Old Indic párśu- 'rib', Avestan parəsu- 'rib'. It is derived from PIE *perk̑- 'rib'.

The Slavic lexeme *dětę has no full analogues in other IE languages. It is a backformation from *dětĭ (attested marginally in Old Serbian and Czech dialects). It is derived from PIE *dhē̆(i̯)- and is related to Old Indic dháyati 'suckle', Latvian dēls 'son', Latin fīlius 'son', fēlāre 'suckle', Greek θηλή 'mother's breast'.
*dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'suckle'.
PIE *ken- 'begin, to have its beginnings'.

The lexeme is derived from PIE *k(e)n-do- and related to Greek καινός 'new', Latin recēns 'new, fresh' and Middle Welsh bachgen 'boy'. (Some) other Slavic lexemes derived from *k(e)n- are *čędĭ 'people' (cf. Old Irish cenél 'nation, tribe), *konŭ 'beginning, end' (cf. Old Irish cét- 'first'), *konĭcĭ 'end', *načęti 'begin', and *ščenę (with s-mobile) 'young animal, cub, pup'.

The Slavic lexeme was long assumed to be a loan from Germanic, cf. German Kind 'child'. However, it can be better and more easily explained as a native formation, related to *čęti 'begin' (PIE root *ken-). The suffix is -d(o)- (relatively rare in Slavic nominal derivatives but surely attested) or adjectival -t(o)- with an irregular voicing (also attested in some Slavic forms like tvĭrdŭ 'hard', cf. Lithuanian tvìrtas).
PS *otŭ-rokŭ with an original meaning 'he who is unable to speak, can not speak or is not allowed to speak'. [Cf. also words like Polish niemowlę 'baby, infant' = 'not speaking'.]

S.v. OLith. stovė́ti 'stehen' (BSl. Latv. stãvêt 'stehen; sein, bestehen, bleiben, dauern, währen', OCS staviti 'stellen, zum Stehen beginnen', etc.). Lith. stovė́ti and its cognates become to the IE root *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (cf. Lith. stóti). The following u̯-element in the stem formation (as though from *steh₂-u̯- has been variously explained [cf. ALEW entry for further discussion and references to further literature].

PS *golę 'unfledged hatchling, infant, small child' is derived from PS *gol- 'naked'. This Slavic lexeme is often assumed to be related to German kahl 'bald, hairless'. However, the Gemanic root is restricted to West Germanic only and needs itself to be explained etymologicaly. PS *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('naked, smooth, not overgrown' < 'smooth' < 'shining').

PIE *golH-o-. The lexeme is related to Old High German kalo 'bald' and Old English calu 'bald'. "In spin of the incompatibility of the initial consonants (*g : *k), it is tempting to connect the (Balto-)Slavic and the Germanic forms with Lat. calvus 'bald' and Skt. kulva- 'bald, thin-haired'."

S.v. lazdà 'Stock, Stab; Haselstrauch' (BSl. Latv. lazda 'Haselstrauch', OPr. laxde 'Haselstrauch', kellaxde 'Speerschaft'). Certainly well established within Baltic, but outside connections less certain. Perhaps to be connected with Slavic words for 'hazel-bush' (cf. SCr. lijèska, Ru. leščína, Cz. líska 'Hasel', Pol. lask 'Stock'), alternatively a direct connection with OIr. slat, MW llath 'Stock, Stab' has been suggested (cf. Kroonen 2011:217f.).

Proto-Germanic *kalwa (PIE *golH-uo-) > German kahl 'bald' etc. It is related to OCS golŭ 'naked' etc. (PIE *golH-o-). It is a Germanic-Balto-Slavic isogloss unrelated to Latin calvus and Sanskrit kulvá- (PIE *klH-uo-).

S.v. Lith. lazdà 'stick, staff' (OLith. dial.) 'hazel' (Latv. lazda 'hazel', OPr. laxde 'Hazel'), in Slavic cf. Ru. ljazgá 'hazel', Bel. ljáska 'stick, cane', Cz. líska 'hazel', Slk. lieska 'hazel', Pol. laska 'stick, staff', SCr. lijèska 'hazel', etc. "In spite of formal differences, there can hardly be any doubt that the Slavic and Baltic forms are cognate." [Cf. entry in Derksen for further discussion on reconstructing the stem in Baltic and Slavic.]
The Slavic lexeme is related to German kahl 'bald'. PIE *galo-.

Cf. s.v. OLith. vė̃zdas 'Knüppel, Stock; Hebebaum, Hebestange' (BSl. Latv. vȩ̄zda sf., vȩ̄zds sm. 'Stock, Prügel'), similar words are found in the Lithuanian and Latvian dialectal areas, but a clear etymological explanation is lacking. Perhaps a recent borrowing from WRuss. vjaz 'Ulme' according to Smoczyński (2007:745).
PIE *galo-, related to German kahl and English callow etc.
PS *gol- is related do Old High German kalo 'bald' etc.

S.v. OLith. akmuõ, ãkmuo, akmuõj 'Stein, Felsen' (BSl. OLith. ašmuõ 'Schneide, Spitze', Latv. akmens 'Stein', asmens 'Schärfe, Schneide, Spitze der Ähre', etc.), from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'Stein', G.sg. *h₂k-n-és- (cf. Ved. áśman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Fels', G.sg. áśnaḥ, YAv. asman 'Himmel', G.sg. ašnō, OPers. asman- 'Himmel', Gk. ἄκμων 'Amboss', G.sg. ἄκμονος).
PIE *gal-, related to German kahl 'bald' etc.
The Slavic *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('shine' > 'smooth, not overgrown' > 'naked').

Most scholars assume the relationship of the Slavic root to German kahl 'bald' and its further Germanic cognates. The hypothesis of ESSJa (accepted by some other scholars) is reasonable but more complex.

Cf. s.v. OLith. stãbas 'Götzenbild, Götze' (BSl. Latv. stabs 'Pfosten, Pfahl, Säule, Pfeiler', OPr. stabis 'Stein'), from ?IE *stobʰ-ó- 'Erstarren' (cf. Goth. stafs 'Stab; Buchstabe', ON stafr, OHG stab 'id.').

Cf. s.v. OLith. tiẽsti 'ebnen, richten, strecken, dehnen', among derived stems tiẽsus 'gerade, aufrecht, richtig' (BSl. Latv. tìešs 'gerade, direkt, unmittelbar', etc.). No convincing connections outside of Baltic. Comparisons with the group of lexemes stemming from OCS tixъ 'still, ruhig, leise', and OCS těšti 'trösten' are formally possible, but semantically unconvincing.

S.v. OLith. sáulė (1), saulė̃ (3) 'Sonne' (BSl. Latv. saũle 'Sonne; Welt', OPr. saule 'Sonne', OCS slъnьce 'Sonne', etc.), from PIE *séh₂u̯el/n- 'Sonne' (cf. Ved. svàr, sū́raḥ, sū́r(i)ya- 'Sonne', OAv. huuarə̄, G.sg. xᵛə̄ṇg 'id.', YAv. huuarə, G.sg. hū, hūrō 'id.', Gk. ἥλιος 'Sonne', ἠέλιος (Hom.), ἀέλιος (Dor., Aeol., Arc.), 'id.', Lat. sōl, -lis 'Sonne', OIr. súil 'Auge', OW houl 'Sonne', MW heul 'id.', Goth. sauil 'Sonne', ON sōl 'id.', OE sunna 'id.', OHG sunno 'id.').

S.v. OLith. saldùs 'süß' (BSl. Latv. sal̂ds, 'süß, angenehm', OCS sladъkъ 'süß', etc.), IE cognates include Arm. ałtkʻ 'Salz', Lat. sallō, -ere, salsus 'salzen', OIr. saillid 'salzt', Goth. salt 'Salz', saltan 'salzen', etc. Lith. saldùs belongs to an array of words which phonologically have to go back to a pre-form *sald- and may be understood morphologically as a conjunction of PIE *sal- 'Salz' and the root *deh₃ - 'geben'.

PS *orbę, *orbŭ etc. are derived from PIE *orbho- and related to 
Old Indic árbha- 'young child', orbus 'orphaned', Greek ὀρφανός 'orphan', Armenian orb 'orphan'.
The PS lexeme is derived from PIE *h₃erbʰ- and related to Greek ὀρφανός 'orphan' and Latin orbus 'deprived of, orphan'. Also a relationship to Gothic arbaiþs 'labour' is highly plausible.
The lexeme is related to Latin orbus 'orphaned', Greek ὀρφανός 'orphan', Armenian orb 'orphan', Gothic arbja 'heir', Irish orbe 'inheritance', Old Indic árbhas 'small child'.

PG *arba- 'working animal, worker(?)' (PIE *h₃orbʰ-o-) is related to OCS rabŭ 'servant, slave', Armenian orb 'orphan', Greek ὀρφανός 'orphan', Latin orbus 'deprived of, childless, orphaned' and semantically more primitive Hittite ḫarp- 'to separate and reassociate oneself, to change sides'.

S.v. OLith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, spülen, abspülen', from PIE *pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (cf. ON fliúga, OHG fliogan 'fliegen'). The root is formally an semantically close to PIE *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben', but the relationship between the two roots is not fully explained. Perhaps a Germanic-Baltic (Germanic-Lithuanian?) isogloss.

Cf. s.v. OLith. máuti 'aufziehen, anziehen, abstreifen' (BSl. Latv. maût 'anziehen, aufziehen, zäumen; untertauchen, schwimmen', OPr. A.sg. aumūsman 'Abwaschung', OCS myti 'waschen', etc.), from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- '(sich) bewegen' (cf. Ved. mīv- 'schieben, drängen, drücken', YAv. mīuu- 'beseitigen', Lat. moveō, -ēre '(sich) bewegen', OIr. mún 'Urin', TochA miw- 'beben', TochB miw- 'beben, zittern').

S.v. OLith. im̃ti 'nehmen, fassen, erhalten' (BSl. Latv. jem̃t 'nehmen, fassen, packen', OPr. īmt 'nehmen', OCS jęti 'nehmen', etc.), from PIE *h₁em- 'nehmen' (cf. Lat. emō, -ere 'nehmen', OIr. ·eim 'nehmen').

The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian nagùtis 'claw, fingernail' and further to Old High German nagal, Old Icelandic nagl, negl, Old Irish ingen, Latin unguis, Greek ὄνυξ, Old Indic áṅghriḥ and nakhám etc.
PS dialectal *pazurŭ / *pazorŭ. The etymology is unclear. It can be an expressive backformation from *paznogŭtĭ [with PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ-] with *-urŭ / -orŭ suffix.

S.v. OLith. uodegà 'Schwanz, Schweif' a derivative in -ega to úodas 'Mücke', itself traditionally explained as an o-grade derivative from the same root as Lith. ė́sti 'essen, fressen', but other possibilities have also been proposed (cf. entry for further discussion).

S.v. OLith. stóras 'dick, stark, grob' (BSl. OCS starъ 'alt', etc.), outside of Balto-Slavic to be connected with ON stórr, 'groß, gewaltig, wichtig', etc. Only precise formal correspondences are found in Germanic and Slavic. It is generally considered to be an adjective with a *-ró- suffix to the full grade of the root *steh₂-.
Most probably it is a shortened form with -urŭ from *paznoɡŭtĭ [with PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ-]. The hypothesis about *paz-dor- [with PIE *der-] is unconvincing phonetically.
S.v. Lith. plónas 'thin, slender, fine, high (of voice)' (Latv. plâns 'flat, even, thin, weak'), from PIE *pleh₂-no- (cf. Lat. plānus 'level, flat').

S.v. OLith. galvà 'Kopf, Haupt; Kapitel', with derived verb OLith. galvóti (BSl. cf. Latv. gal̂va 'Kopf, Haupt', OPr. galwo 'Haupt; Schuhspitze', OCS glava 'Kopf; Hauptstück; Kapitel', etc.), IE cf. Arm. glowx, G.sg. glxoy 'Kopf; Ende, Spitze, Anführer'.

Cf. s.v. Lith. galvà 'head' (Latv. gal̂va 'head', OPr. galwo 'head'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *golʔwáʔ, from PIE *golH-ueh₂- "[Contrary to what is printed in Derksen 2008:176, a]n etymological connection with Lat. calva 'skull' is formally impossible. Nevertheless, it is tempting to seek a link with these forms, as the same irregular *k : *g correspondence is observed in words for 'bald', where we have Lat. calvus 'bald' and Skt. kulva- 'bald, thin haired' vs. OCS golъ, OHG kalo 'bald'." [No connection given to Armenian lexemes.]
For proposed cognacy to Armenian lexemes meaning 'head', cf. discussion in the main Balto-Slavic set for 'head' in /cognate/1142/.

S.v. OLith. trỹs 'drei' (BSl. Latv. trîs, OCS trьje, etc.), from PIE *tr-i- 'drei' (cf. Hitt. teri- 'drei', HLuw. t(a)risu 'dreimal', Lyc. trisu 'dreimal', Ved. tráyas- 'drei', YAv. θrāiiō 'id.', Gk. τρεῖς 'drei', Myc. ti-ri- in ti-ri-po 'Dreifuß', Lat. trēs 'drei', OIr. trí 'drei', Goth. ϸreis 'drei', OHG drī, etc.). The inherited word for 'three'.

The etymology is not entirely clear. It is possibly derived from PS *paz- 'point of contact, connection, groove, joint' [PIE *peh₂g̑- 'harden, stiffen, firm' with cognates as Lating pangō, pangere etc.]. It can be also a backformation of from *paznoɡŭtĭ [with PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ-].

PS *paz-orŭ / *paz-urŭ. The root *paz- is a reflex of PIE [*peh₂g̑-] 
'hard, firm'. The etymological meaning of the lexeme is 'hard, firm, strengthened protuberance on fingers and toes'. The interpretation as *paz-dor- or as a backformation fo *paz-nogŭtĭ is unconvincing.

S.v. OLith. mèsti 'werfen, schleudern' (BSl. Latv. mest 'werfen', OPr. N.sg.pres.part.pass. pomests 'unterworfen', OCS mesti 'werfen', etc.), extra-Balto-Slavic connections are uncertain. LIV² assigns to ?2. *met- 'abmessen', alternatively to *met- 'mähen' [cf. LIV² ?1. *met- 'mähen' to Lat. metō 'mähen, ernten'] if the semantic development was originally via 'rotate, wind'.
The etymology is not clear. It is maybe an expressive formation from PS *paznogŭtĭ [with PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ-].

S.v. OLith. rìšti 'binden', probably to be derived from a PIE root *u̯rei̯k̑- 'drehen, einhüllen' and be connected to Ved. vréśī- 'Wasserwirbel(?)', YAv. uruuaēs- 'sich wenden, drehen', uruuaēsa- 'Wirbel im Wasser', Gk. ῥοικός 'gekrümmt', OE wrēon 'hüllen, bedecken', but alternative root etymologies have also been proposed (cf. ALEW for further discussion).
S.v. Lith. rìšti 'tie, bind' (Latv. rist 'tie, separate, separated', OPr. perrēist 'connect'), from PIE *ur(e)ik̑- (cf. YAv. uruuisiieiti 'turn', OE wrīon 'hide').
