S.v. *u̯rei̯k̑- 'drehen; einhüllen' (IEW 1158-9). Lith. rišù, rìsti is considered to possibly derive from a primary pres. verbal stem ?*u̯réi̯k̑-/u̯rik̑-.

None of the proposed etymologies is really convincing.
The assumption of PS *paz-dor- fails tu explain attested forms phonetically.
The assumption of a backformation from PS *paz-noɡŭtĭ is speculative because there is no single sound of *-noɡŭtĭ remaining in the forms *pazurŭ / *pazorŭ.
Assuming the PIE *peh₂g̑- root seems to be unconvincing semantically. All certain Slavic reflexes of PIE *peh₂g̑- known to me are related to a joint of two elements and show any traces of 'hard, firm' meaning itself.
The lexeme is a loan from Middle German krempel 'claw' which is a diminutive of krampe 'claw, small axe, a kind of hoe'.

S.v. OLith. dantìs, dantỹs, dañtis 'Zahn' (BSl. OPr. dantis 'Zahn', etc.), from PIE *h₁d-ont-, *h₁d-n̥t- 'Zahn' (cf. Ved. dánt- 'Zahn', Gk. ὀδών -όντος, ἔδοντες (Aeol.) 'Zähne', Mycen. o-da-twe-ta 'mit Zähnen versehen', Arm. atamn, Lat. dens, OIr. d´t, Goth. tunþus, etc.). Traditionally analysed as a early lexicalised derivative of the root *h₁ed- 'essen' (cf. NIL 210), cf. however Kortlandt (2003:77, 94) skeptical and suggests alternatively a derivation from *h₃ed-.
It is related to Old High German hachit, hechit, German Hecht, Anglo-Saxon hacod 'pickerel', further to Old High German hakô and Anglo-Saxon hóc 'angle'.
It is related to German Hecht 'pickerel', German Hacken 'angle' etc. PIE *keg- / *kek- 'angle'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kogъtъ / *kogъtь. The Slavic lexeme is related to West Germanic lexemes for 'pickerel', e.g. German Hecht.

Cf. s.v. OLith. žam̃bas 'Ecke, Rand, Saum' (BSl. Latv. zùobs 'Zahn, Sägezahn, Schlüsselbart', OCS zǫbъ 'Zahn', etc.), from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- 'Beißen' (cf. Ved. jámbha- 'Gezähn', du. 'beide Zahnreihen', pl. 'Zähne', Gk. γόμφος 'Verbindungsstück: Pflock, Dübel, Zapfen', γομφίος 'Backenzahn', Alb. dhëmb 'Zahn', ON kambr 'Kamm', OHG camb 'id., TochA kam 'Zahn', TochB keme 'id.').

S.v. Lith. mẽdis 'tree, log, wood', cf. Lith. mẽdžias 'forest, woods', to be derived from PIE *medʰ-i-o-/*medʰ-i-eh₂- (cf. Skt. mádhya- 'middle, located in the middle', Lat. medius 'middle, located in the middle, Goth. midjis 'middle').

Cf. s.v. OLith. teĩsti 'verrichten, vollziehen' with derived adjective teisìngas 'gerecht', a formation with -ei- of the root to the group from OLith. tiẽsti 'ebnen, richten, strecken, dehnen', among derived stems tiẽsus 'gerade, aufrecht, richtig' (BSl. Latv. tìešs 'gerade, direkt, unmittelbar', etc.). No convincing connections outside of Baltic. Comparisons with the group of lexemes stemming from OCS tixъ 'still, ruhig, leise', and OCS těšti 'trösten' are formally possible, but semantically unconvincing.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hakan- 'hook', a "word with several formal problems and no certain extra-Germanic etymology."

Cf. s.v. OLith. vartýti 'wenden, drehen, wälzen' (BSl. Latv. vā̀rtit, OPr. inf. wartint 'kehren', OCS vratiti '(sich) umwenden'), from PIE *u̯ert- (cf. Ved. (cs.-iter.) vartáyati, OIr. dofortai 'gießt (aus), Goth. fra-waurdjan 'verderben', etc.).
Old English hacod, Old Saxon kahth, Old High German hehhit 'pike' are "derivationally similar to Slavic *kogŭtĭ 'claw'".
Loan from Turkish kanca 'hook'.

Párkelj, dialectal also špárkelj. Forms like dialectal Croatian šprāljàk, šprānjàk 'claw', Late Church Slavonic čьparogъ 'hoof, claw', Serbian and Croatian čȁporak, čȁporac 'claw', Czech spár, old čpár, špár ‛claw’, Upper Sorbian špara 'claw' makes possible to assume a PS protoform *porʎĭkŭ related to the verb *porti 'tear, unravel'.
Upper Sorbian sprara 'claw', PS *spara / *sparŭ belong etymologically to the PS verb *perti, *pĭrǫ.

In spite of some phonetic difficulties pertaining the Slovene and Kajkavian lexemes belonging to this cognate class, their utimate relationship to the PS *perti, PIE *per- (maybe *(s)per-) 'beat' looks very reasonable.
Cf. s.v. *drep- 'abschneiden, (ab)reißen' (IEW 211).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *drāpati 'scratch' (ESSJa V 101-102), cf. Gk. δρέπω 'pluck'.
PS *drapati 'scratch' is related to PS *dĭrati [PIE *der-].
PIE *drep- maybe related to PIE *der- (this view is supported by ESSJa) but according to the general policy and LIV a separate PIE root *drep- is assumed.
PS *drapati 'scratch' is related to PS *dĭrati [PIE *der-].
The only proposed etymology is inconvincing from the semantic point of view.
The Belarusian lexeme is a derivative from Proto-Slavic *kyp- 'seethe' [PIE *ku̯eh₁p- 'blow, puff'].
PS *obvolka / *obvolko / *obvolkŭ is derived from *obvelkťi [*ob-velkťi 'cover, overlie'].
The IE backround of *velkti 'drag' is far from solid.
PIE *h₂u̯elk- > OCS vlěkǫ, vlěšti 'drag, pull' etc.
In spite of the objections of Derksen the version of LIV is addopted.

PS *xmura / *smura is sometimes linked to Greek ἀμαυρός 'shadowy, pale, dark'. PS *xmara is doubless related to *xmura / *smura. The vowel -a- can be a result of a contamination (for example with *mara 'dream, shadow of a dead person, phantasm, ghost').

Russian words hmura, smuryj, pasmurnyj, xmara, smuryj, muryj (meanings 'cloud', 'dark', 'dark grey' etc.) are related to Old Icelandic meyrr 'dark, friable' and Greek ἀμαυρός 'shadowy, pale, dark'. The initial x- is probably expressive. The internal -a- is possibly a result of a contamination with another word (for example para, par 'vapour' or mar' 'fog').
PS *xmura (along with *smurŭ) is related to Greek ἀμαυρός 'dark'. PS *xmara is a contamination of *xmura and *mara.
"Substrate origin is probable anyhow, as the word has no etymology".
PS *morkŭ is related to Lithuanian mérkti, mérkiu 'close one's eyes', Gothic maurgins, Old High German morgan 'morning', possibly also Old Indic markás 'solar eclipse'.
PS *morkŭ 'darkness' is related to Lithanian mérkti 'close one's eyes' and Gothic maurgins 'morning'. PIE *morHk-ó-
German Morgen < *mr(H)k-e/on-, OCS mrakŭ < *mork-o-, OCS mrĭknǫti < *mrHk-ne-, Lithuanian mérkti < mérHk-e.
The Russian word is loan from Church Slavonic, cf. Russian dialectal oboloko.
The Belarusian lexeme is a loan from Church Slavonic.
*temk- 'get hard, stiffen, clot' > Hittite tamekzi 'attach', Vedic Indic ā́-tanakti 'make clot', Gothic þeihan 'succeed', Lithuanian tánkus 'dense, often' etc.

If -nk- in Lithuanian tánkus 'often, dense' goes back to -mk-, then the lexeme is derived from PIE *temk- 'get hard, clot' and is related to Hittite tamekzi 'attach', Vedic Indic ā́-tanakti 'make clot', Old Irish técht 'clotted', Old Nordic þétir 'dense' and Old Church Slavonic tǫča 'rain, rainstorm, snow'.

Slovene toča, Old Church Slavonic tǫča is related to Lithuanian tánkus 'dense', Hittite tamekzi 'attach', Old Indic tanákti ‛bend’, Avestan taxma- 'brave', Old Nordic þéttr 'dense', Gothic þeihan ‛succeed', German gedeihen 'succeed'. PIE *temk- 'get hard, get dense'.

A phonetically regular cognate of Lithuanian šáltas 'cold' in PS would be *soltŭ or *soldŭ and a regular cognate of German kalt in PS 'cold' would be *goldŭ. A development of PIE *k̑ into PS *x would be hard to explain even in terms of an expressive pronunciation. An expressive spirantisation of PS *g into PS *x is more probable phonetically and could be supported by the frequent usage of the lexeme accompanied with the lexeme *goldŭ 'hunger' with initial *ɡʷ- (it is very likely that the phrase *goldŭ i xoldŭ 'hunger and cold' existed already in PS). It can be assumed that the lost of the labialisation of *ɡʷ- in the root for 'hunger' induced the spirantisation of *g- in the root for 'cold'. PS *koldęzĭ 'well' is a loan from Germanic. The loan source had probably a meaning 'source' was derived from *kald- 'cold'. It is attested in Gemanic place names like Käldinge (Sweden) or Kolding, Kalding (Denmark).

PS *xoldŭ can be related to German kalt 'cold' etc. on the on the one hand and to Lithuanian šáltas 'cold' on the other hand. The PIE roots *gel- and *k̑el- are maybe variants of a single original root. For the Slavic is more reasonable to assume *x < g*, although the reasons of this development are disputable.

PS *xold- is derived from PIE *gel-. However, the development *g > *x has not been explainded, in spite of many attempts to. A relationship to Lithuanian šáltas 'cold' is also dubious from the phonetic point of view (*k̑- never yields PS *x-).
The Slavic lexeme is probably related to German kalt 'cold', English cold etc. It is derived from PIE *gel-, although the initial *x- has not been convincingly explained.
The Slavic lexeme is linked to Gothic kalds und Latin gelidus on the one hand and to Lithuanian šáltas on the other. Some scholars assume a loanword from Germanic here.

There are three main hypotheses regarding the etymology of PS *xold-: 1) PIE *gel- (*⁽g̑⁾el-), cf. German kalt; 2) PIE *k̑elH-, cf. Lithuanian šáltas; 3) Loan from Germanic with PIE *gel- (*⁽g̑⁾el-), cf. German kalt. All three hypotheses fail to explain the initial x- in Slavic. The regular reflexes should be: 1) g; 2) s; 3) k (cf. PS *koldęzĭ). A further flaw of the hypothesis 2 is that Slavic has a phonetically regular cognate of the Lithuanian word (*solna). Regarding to the hypothesis 3 it can be assumed that words for 'cold' seem not to be very prone to replacing by borrowings. The only example in the database is Sinhalese lexeme borrowed from Pali; Russian archaic xladnyj borrowed from Old Church Slavonic should also be mentioned here. In these both cases, however, the sociolinguistic conditions were very different from that we assume for Germanic and Proto Slavic. Hence, the hypothesis 1 seems to be better than the other ones. It is also accepted in the most existing Slavic etymology Dictionaries. However, the etymology remains uncertain.

The Slavic lexeme is probably derived from a *kh- variant of PIE *geldh- and related to Gothic kalds 'cold' and Latin gelidus. Some scholars linkt the Slavic lexeme to Lithuanian šáltas 'cold'. However, the Lithuanian word (along with another derivative, šalná 'hoar-frost, frost') has a regular Slavic cognate, cf. Old Church Slavocnic slana 'hoar-frost'. The hypothesis about a borrowing from Germanic (Gothic) ist unconvincing phonetically. 

Russian oželedica 'black ice' is related to Greek χάλαζα 'hail', New Persian žāla 'black ice, hoar-frost' annd Latvian dzeldêt 'get hard (about snow)'. A relationship to Gothic kalds 'cold' and Latin gelidus 'cold' is less probable.

S.v. NHG Ameise (MHG āmeize, OHG āmeiza), from West Germanic *ǣmaitjōn, also in OE æmete to *ǣ 'ab, weg', and *maita- 'schneiden' (cf. NHG Meißel 'Schneidwerkzeug' and 'scheiden, hauen' in Goth. maitan, OHG meizan'). The word is to be explained as 'die aus Abschnitten Bestehende', 'made up of (cut) sections'. Cf. similarly 'insect' from Lat. īnsecta, the substantivized past passive participle of Lat. īnsecāre (īnsectum) 'einschneiden, zerschneiden'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hrugja- 'ridge; back'. No certain connections outside of Germanic.

S.v. NHG Rücken (MHG ruck(e), rück(e), OHG hrucci, ruggi, rucke, OS hruggi), from Proto-Germanic *hrugja- 'Rücken', also found in ON hryggr, OE hrycg, OFr. hregg, of unclear origin. The closest possible comparison is OIr. crocenn 'Rücken' (in which case from PIE *kr̥kn-), but this word is attested only once in a gloss (the corresponding normally has the meaning 'Haut'). Possibly the same basis *keru- might be found in Ved. karū́kara- 'Wirbel des Halses und des Rückgeräts' and Lat. cervīx 'Nacken, Halswirbel', but the part of the k-suffix is unclear.

S.v. NHG schlecht (MHG sleht, OHG sleht, sliht, OS sliht), from PGmc. *slihta- 'eben, geglättet', also in Goth. slaihts, ON sléttr, OE sliht, OFr. sliuht, an adjective from an original to-participle to the verb schleichen (cf. MHG slīchen, OHG slīhhan, MLG sliken), to which can be compared outside of Germanic to OIr. fo-slig 'überschmiert'.

Cf. s.v. *sleik-a- 'schleichen', with derived adj. *slih-ta- 'schlicht, glatt' (cf. OIr. fo-slig 'überschmiert', (OCS) slьzъkъ 'schlüpfrig, glatt', Gk. λίγδην 'oberflächlich berührend, streifend'), perhaps to be analysed as a more basic root *(s)lei̯- 'schleichen, kriechen' or a contamination with *lei̯- 'kleben, schleimig sein'.

Root reconstruction *(s)lei̯g̑- follows LIV² (cf. s.v., n1 comparing Gk. λίγδην 'oberflächlich berührend', OCS slьzъkъ). For older hypotheses connecting the lexemes related to OHG slīhhan, etc. to a potentially unextended root *(s)lei̯-, cf. Seebold (1970:428-429). No lemma for OHG slīhhan, etc. in Kroonen (2013).

S.v. NHG Rinde (MHG rinde, rinte, OHG rinta, rinda, OS rinda), from West Germanic *rendōn 'Rinde', also in OE rind(e). Outside of Germanic one might possibly compare Ved rándhra- 'Öffnung, Spalt, Höhle'.

Regarding the Kluge-Seebold comparison to Ved. rándra- 'opening, hole, split', Cf. s.v. Ved. rándhra- 'ein Körperteil von Tieren (des Stiers, des Pferdes, der schwarzen Antilope), offenbar die Lende' in later texts the meaning is generalised to 'schwache Stelle', from which 'Schwäche', 'Lücke, Höhlung', originally from PIE *lendʰ- yielding words for 'loins' (cf. Lat. lumbus < *londʰu̯o-, ON lend, OHG lentī 'Lende', OCS lędvьje (f.pl.) 'Lenden, Inneres, Nieren, etc.').
S.v. ON vǫmb 'Bauch'. Etymology uncertain. Cf. entry in de Vries for references to proposed etymologies in older literature.
S.v. Goth. B41. *beitan 'δάκνειν', 'bite', from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split' (cf. Skt. bhinádmi, aor. bhed 'split'; Gk. φείδομαι 'spare', from 'separate oneself from'; Lat. findō, pf. fidī 'split').
S.v. Goth. B13. *baitrs 'bitter', only N.pl. baitrai, adv. batraba 'πικρῶς', 'bitterly', from PIE *bʰei̯d- as in *beitan 'bite', with o-grade and PIE *-ro- suffix.

S.v. NHG bitter (MHG bitter, OHG bittar, OS bittar) from Germanic *bit-ra- (adj.) 'bitter' (also in ON bitr, OE biter, beside full-grade *bait-ra- in Both. baitrs and *baiska- (from *bait-ska-) in ON beiskr. Before *r the High German sound shift does not occur.

S.v. NHG schwarz (MHG swarz, OHG swarz, OS swart), from Germanic *swarta- (adj.), also found in Goth. *swarts (Goth. swartizl 'Tinte'), ON svartr, OE sweart. Outside of Germanic one may perhaps compare Lat. sordēs 'Schmutz', sordidus 'schmutzig'. Further provenance unclear.
Cf. s.v. *su̯ordo-s 'schwarz, schmutzfarben'.

Generally connected to Lat. sordēs 'dirt' and derivatives (cf. {ref IEW} 1052, {ref Lehmann 1986}:333, {ref Orel 2003}:392; tentatively {ref Kluge 2011}:833; cf. also {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:637, {ref de Vaan 2008}:576 cited in /cognate/4865/) as though from a PIE o-stem adjective *su̯ordo-. If these lexemes go back to the same source, then they may be a post-PIE innovation in Germanic and Italic. [Not in {ref Kroonen 2013}].
Cf. s.v. *su̯ordo-s 'schwarz, schmutzfarben'.

Generally connected to Proto-Germanic *swartaz 'black, dark' and derivatives (cf. IEW 1052, Ernout & Meillet 1985:637, de Vaan 2008:576; cf. also Lehmann 1986:333, Orel 2003:392; tentatively Kluge-Seebold 2011:833 cited in /cognate/188/) as though from a PIE o-stem adjective *su̯ordo-. If these lexemes go back to the same source, then they may be a post-PIE innovation in Germanic and Italic.

Cf. s.v. Lat. sordēs, -is 'saleté(s) (sens concret); condition sordide (sense propre et figuré)'. The only clear connection is with the group of lexemes in Germanic for the concept 'black' (Goth. swart, etc.).

S.v. Goth. M63. milhma 'νεφέλη', 'cloud'. Only possible Gmc. cognate OSw. molin, Sw. moln 'cloud', a dialectal replacement for PIE *nebʰ-. Many conjectures at an etymology, perhaps to Lith. mìlšti(s) 'gather (of a storm)', Latv. milzt 'become dark or foggy', Russ. molostь 'thunderstorm'. If there was a metathesis of -l-, possibly further to Lith. miglà, Latv. migla, OCS mьgla 'fog', Gk. ὀμίχλη 'cloud' from PIE *mei̯gʰ- 'cloud', other conjectures less likely.

S.v. OLith. dù, dvì 'zwei' (BSl. Latv. divi 'zwei', OPr. dwai 'zwei', OCS dъva 'zwei', etc.), from PIE m. *du̯óh₁, f. du̯eh₂-ih₁, nt. du̯óih₁ 'zwei' (cf. Ved. dvā́, duvā́, Av. m. duua, f. duuaē, Gk. δυό, (Hom.) δυώ 'zwei', Arm. erkow, 'zwei', Lat. duo 'zwei', OIr. da, dá, 'zwei', Goth. m. twai, f. twos, nt. twa 'zwei', etc., TochA we, TochB wi 'zwei').
S.v. OLith. vémti 'speien, sich erbrechen' (BSl. Latv. vem̃t 'sich erbrechen'), from PIE *u̯emh₁- 'erbrechen' (cf. Ved. vam- 'speit aus', Gk. ἐμέω 'erbreche', Lat. vomō, -ere 'erbrechen').
S.v. OLith. eĩti 'gehen, kommen' (BSl. Latv. iêt, 'gehen', OCS iti 'gehen', etc.), from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (Ved. ay-, OAv. aē-, Gk. εἶμι, Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', etc.).

S.v. OLith. mazgóti 'waschen, schwemmen' (BSl. Latv. mazgât 'waschen'), from PIE *mesg- 'eintauschen (intr.), versinken' (cf. Ved. majj- 'untersinken, untertauschen', Lat. mergō, -ere 'eintauschen, versenken').

S.v. OLith. vanduõ, vánduõ 'Wasser' (BSl. Latv. ûdèns 'Wasser'. OPr. wundan, wunda, unds 'Wasser'), derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'benetzen' (cf. Ved. 3.sg.pres. unátti, 3.pl.pres. undánti, 3.pl.pf. ūdur 'quellen, benetzen'). Cf. notes in ALEW for the unusual nominal stem found in Old Prussian.

Pace ALEW, the etymology to PIE *k̑lep- (cf. IEW 603) is not certain. Cf. discussion s.v. Gk. κλέπας 'moist, muddy, or clayey, bushy, wet' (only attested in lexicographical works) in Beekes (2010:713), Chantraine (1968-1980:541), Frisk (1960-1972), and s.v. Proto-Celtic *klowni- 'meadow' in Matasović (2009:209) where the etymology to a putative PIE *k̑lep- is not completely certain. There is no lemma for Lith. šlãpias, Latv. slapjš in Derksen (2015).

Cf. s.v. Gk. κλέπας· νοτερόν, πηλῶδες, ἣ δασύ, ἣ ὑγρόν 'moist of muddy or clayey, bushy, wet' (Gloss from Hesychius' lexicon). The meaning 'moist' suggests a connection to OIr. cluain 'meadow' and the Baltic group of Lith. šlàpti 'to become wet', but the formation of the Greek gloss does not match the proposed cognates, which makes the etymology uncertain.

Cf. s.v. *klep- 'feucht'??, (cf. Gk. κλέπας (Hes.), Lith. šlampù, šlapti 'naß werden', possibly also OIr. cluin < *k̑lop-ni- but *k̑leu̯-ni- is also possible, cf. s.v. IEW 607 *k̑leu̯- 'spülen, rein machen').

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *klowni- 'meadow' (OIr. clúain, OW clun, MW clun). IEW hesitates between assigning these lexemes to roots *klep- (IEW 603) or *k̑leu̯- (IEW 607), but neither etymology is completely persuasive. The connection to a putative *k̑lopni- in connection to Lith. šlãpius 'wet', Gk. κλέπας 'swamp' somewhat more probable.

Cf. s.v. ?2.*steu̯d- 'kalt werden' [IEW 1035]. Root only attested in Slavic. The reconstruction is based on Slavic material only. Perhaps it could be related to 1. *(s)teu̯d- 'hit' but it had to be supported semantically.

S.v. OLith. platùs 'breit, weit, ausführlich' (BSl. Latv. plašs 'weit, breit, gräumig, ausgedehnt, etc.), from PIE *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (cf. Ved. pr̥thú- 'breit, weit', OAv. pərəθu-, YAv. pərəθu- 'id.', Gk. πλατύς 'weit, breit, flach, eben', OHG flado 'Fladen, flacher, Kuchen, Honigscheibe').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *studenъ (adj.) 'cold' & Proto-Slavic *studъ m. 'cold, shame'. "In view of [...] *stydъ, where *y probably originates from Winter’s law, the root of *stydъ is best reconstructed as *stoud-. This is reminiscent of the more common root *steug-, e.g. Gk. στυγέω 'hate, abhor, fear', Gk. στύξ f., 'Styx, well of fatal coldness, hatred, abhorrence, (pl.) piercing chill', Gsg. στυγός. A relationship is hard to demonstrate."

S.v. OLith. vė́ti 'wehen', with derived noun vė́jas 'Wind' (BSl. Latv. vẽjš 'Wind', OCS vějati 'wehen', etc.) from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'wehen' (cf. Ved. vā- 'wehen', YAv. vā- 'weht', Gk. ἅημι 'wehe', Goth. waian 'wehen', etc.).
PIE *steu̯d- 'get frozen'. It can be related to Old Indic tundate, tudáti '(he) bangs', lat. tundere 'hit, bang', Gothic stautan. A related PIE root can be *(s)teu̯g-, cf. Greek Στύξ 'river Styx'.
The Slavic lexeme has no certain further cognates among IE. However, the root itself looks very ancient and the etymology of LIV is addopted.
S.v. ?*g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- 'Winter, Schnee' (IEW 425f., EIEC 504).

Cf. s.v. OLith. ar̃, ár 'ob, oder' (BSl. Latv. àr 'auch', with I. 'mit'), an ablaut variant of OLith. ir̃ (Latv. ir̃), from IE *ŕ̥ (bekräftigende Partikel), cf. Gk. ἄρ, ἄρα 'natürlich, eben, dann, also'.
S.v. Lith. ar̃ interrogative ptcl. 'whether, if' (Latv. ar interrogative particle 'whether, if', ar prep. 'with'), from PIE *h₂er- (cf. Gk. ἄρα ῥα 'then', ἆρα interrogative particle).
Loan from Middle German komen 'come'.
S.v. ?*gʰrei̯dʰ- 'schreiten' [IEW 456-7]. Probably cognate to Old Irish in:greinn, in:grennat 'follow', Gothic grid 'step' and Lithuanian grìdyti, grìdiju 'go'.

S.v. Lith. mótė (OLith., dial. 'wife, mother', Latv. mãte  'mother'; Lith. derivatives móteris 'wife, mother', mótina 'mother'), from PIE *meh₂ter- (cf. Skt. mātár-, Gk. μήτηρ, Lat. māter, OHG muoter, OIr. máthir, Alb. mótrë 'sister').
Cf. s.v. *mah₂ter-/*máh₂tr- 'Mutter' (IEW 700f., EIEC 385f.).
PS *gręsti is derived from PIE *ghrei̯dh- 'stride' and is related to Old Irish in:greinn, in:grennat 'follow', Gothic grid, Old Middle German 'step' and Lithuanian grìdyti 'go, walk'.

S.v. OLith. kirmìs 'Wurm' (BSl. Latv. cirmis 'Wurm, Made, Raupe' OPr. ? girmis 'Made', OCS črьvь 'Wurm', etc.), from PIE *kʷr̥-mi- 'Wurm, Made', Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made', NPers. kirm 'Wurm', Alb. krimb 'Wurm, Raupe, Made', OIr. Cruim 'Wurm, Made; Drache', MW pryf 'Insekt, Larve, Made, Wurm; Schlange', etc.).

Originally it referred to counting by making scores on a piece of wood with a knife. A description of this method of counting is attested in one of the oldest Slavic texts ("On the Letters" by Chernorizets Hrabar). The meaning 'cut' is attested in Old/Middle Polish.
S.v. *bʰrei̯H- 'schneiden' (IEW 166-7). Only Church Slavic brijǫ, briti 'shear, shave' listed here.
Cf. s.v. OLith. gel̃sti 'gelb werden' with derived adj. geltónas 'gelb' (BSl. Latv. dzȩltãns 'gelb', OPr. gelatynan 'gelb', SCr. žȗtī. Ru. žëltyj, etc.).
PIE *bhrei / * bri- / *bher- 'cut'.

Polish broić 'frolic', formerly 'do evil things', in 16th century attested also as 'cut'. Russian dialectal 'poke about, rummage', Serbo-Croatian brojiti 'count'. PS *brojiti 'cut', derived from PIE *bʰrēi̯-, *bʰrī- 'cut with a sharp thing'.

PS *ličiti 1. (> Polish liczyć 'count' etc.) ist etymologically related to *ličiti 2. (> derived from *likŭ, *lice, Russian lico 'face' etc.), although the semantic development ist complex to explain: 'show the outer side of something' (literally 'face side') > 'announce, make public' (attested in Slavic) > 'count'. By the interpretation of PS *lice 'face' we have to consider that words for this meaning are often derived from roots for 'to form, to shape, to make' (cf. Polish twarz or Latin facies). The original meaning of PS *lik- coul be 'form by casting, cast'. It would be then derived from the verb *liti 'pour' (formations like *oblikŭ support a verbal derivation here). Cf. Lithuanian lytìs 'form, figure, appearance' and phrases like Russian vylityj otec 'son very similar to his father' [literally 'poured/casted father'].

PS *ličiti 'to form, to shape, to embellish', 'be visible, be similar'. The meaning 'count' is North Slavic. The lexeme is related to Lithuanian lykúoti 'count', possibly also with Latvian līkt 'make a deal' and Latin liceō, licēre 'be put up for sale'.
"There are no certain cognates of the rot *lik- outside Italic".
S.v. Proto-Germanic *kalđaz derived from Gmc. *kalanan (cf. Lat. gelū 'cold, frost, ice', Slav *zolь 'bad weather'). "Somehow related to Slav. sb. xoldъ 'cold', despite the phonetic difficulties".

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *kal-a- 'frieren' (derived adj. kal-da- to be connected with nominal formations in other languages under a probable basis *g̑el- (cf. Lat. gelū 'Frost, Kälte', gelāre 'gefrieren', Lith. gélmenis, gelumà 'heftige Kälte, Frost', Ru. gólotь 'Glatteis').
Cf. PIE *gol- 'cold' (o-grade; cf. Lat. gelū, Lith. gelumà 'frost') in PGmc. *kalaną 'to be cold, to freeze' and *kaldaz 'cold' (Goth. kalds, ON kaldr, OE ċeald).

The etymology of *lice, *likŭ 'face' proposed by ESSJa is convincing (regarding to the relationship of words for 'face', 'form, shape' and 'pour, cast' a Polish paralell wykapany ojciec 'son very similar to his father' (kapać 'drip') could be added). The ultimate PIE root would be *lei̯H- 'pour'. However, the semantic relationship to the word for 'count' is much more complicated.
Cf. s.v. *⁽g̑⁾el- 'frieren, kalt sein' (IEW 365-6). [No cognates outside of Germanic or Italic listed.]

Russian lik 'face' is related to Irish lecco, leaca 'cheek' and Old Prussian laygnan 'cheek'. Rusian lik 'number' is most probably derived from *ličiti 'make public' which is related to Russian lik 'face'.

The IE root underlying the Germanic forms in this class is generally reconstructed as *⁽g̑⁾el- on the basis of Germanic and Italic correspondences (cf. {ref LIV²} 185). The reconstruction of a palatovelar or plain velar depends on whether one additionally accepts cognacy with Balto-Slavic forms (cf. Lith. gelumà 'frost', Ru. gólotь 'Glatteis'), cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:288-289, {ref Ringe 2017}:109. The Germanic forms are considered by some scholars (cf. {ref Orel 2003}:209) to be related to Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xoldъ 'cold', but the correspondences of Slavic initial *x and medial *d to Germanic *k and *d is irregular. Consequently the connection of Slavic *xoldъ to the Germanic and Italic lexemes from IE *⁽g̑⁾el- must remain at least uncertain, if not outright rejected.
The Ukrainian lexeme was borrowed through Polish.
Polish rachować and Kashubian rachòwac / rechòwac are loanwords from Middle German rechen 'count'.
PS *plakati ist related to Latin plangō, plangere.
The Slovene lexeme is derived from the interjection jo with the suffix *-ka- which is often used for deriving lexemes for unarticulated human sounds.
The Slovene lexeme is derived fomr the interjection joj, joh.
Slovene jokati 'cry' is listed among Slavic cognates of *ękati / *ęcati.
PS *tęti, tĭnǫ is related to Lithuanian tìnti tinù 'hammer a scythe', Greek τέμνω 'cut' and Old Irish tamnaid 'cut off'. PIE *tem- 'cut'.

Cf. NHG Bache '(wildes) Mutterschein', by semantic extension from the earlier meaning 'Schinken, Speckseite', cf. OHG bahho, MLG bake 'Rücken, Speckseite'; English bacon via Old French bacon borrowed from OHG bahho), probably based on Germanic *baka- 'Rücken' (cf. ON bak, OE bæc, OFr. bek, OS bak, OHG bah).
S.v. Engl. bad (adj.). Of uncertain origin, cf. OED entry for various suggestions and possible early attestations.
S.v. *minwizan- (Hm 412) 'kleiner', from PIE *minu- 'klein' (IEW 711), cf. Lat. minus 'weniger'.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *minwizan- (> minnizan-) 'kleiner', to PIE *mei-/*moi- 'klein'.
Cf. s.v. 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).

The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian kapóti 'chop', Latvian kapât 'chop', Old Prussian en-kopts 'buried', further with Armenian kop'em 'chop, cut', New Persian kāvad, kāfat 'dig' and Greek κόπτω 'chop', σκάπτω 'dig'.
S.v. Germanic *wanda- 'sich wendend', a verbal adjective to the strong verb *wenda- 'winden'.
Cf. s.v. Germanic *wend-a- 'winden' (derived adjective *wand-a- > ON vandr 'schwierig', OS un-wand 'wandelbar', from PIE *u̯endʰ- 'flechten, winden'.

Cf. s.v. NHG bast (MHG bast, OHG bast OS bast), from Germanic *basta- 'Bast (innere Schicht der Pflanzenrinde), Bastseil', also in ON bast, OE bæst. Origins unclear. According to Koivulehto from PIE *bʰes- 'to scrape, to rub' (LIV² 82 *bʰes- 'to scrunch, to chew up', IEW 145-6). According to others a loan word. (Cf. Kluge for references to further literature.)

Cf. s.v. NHG Borke 'Rinde' (MLG borke, MDu. bark). The High German word is a borrowing from Low German; the Low German forms are related to ON bǫrkr 'Rinde', allowing the reconstruction of Proto-Germanic *barku-. Further origin uncertain.

PS *čistŭ 'clean' along with *cěditi 'strain, filter' and *cěstiti (with meanings 'clean', 'castrate', 'tear off' in particular Slavic languages/dialects) is related to Latvian šķīsts 'pure, clean', Lithuanian skýstas 'fluid', Old Prussian skijstan 'clean', further to Lithuanian skíedžiu skíesti 'water down, split', skáistas 'light (adjective)'. Further IE cognates are Old Indic chinátti, Greek σχίζω, and Latin scindō 'split'.

Cf. s.v. Schale 'Hülse' (MHG schal(e), OHG scala), from West Germanic *skalō(n) 'Schale', also in OE scealu. With corresponding meaning but deviating meaning is Goth. skalja 'Ziegel' (probably originally 'Schuppe'), ON skel, OE scill, scell 'Muschel'. Outside of Germanic the closest comparison is Ru. skalá 'Birkenrinde', skol'ka 'Muschen', whether these can go back to an (IE) root *skel- 'spalten, trennen' must remain open.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *skēlō- 'bowl', an ō-stem probably derived from skeljan-. If so, then derived from PIE *skelH-.

PS *čistŭ < *kīd-to- is most closely related to Lithuanian skýstas 'thin, fluid', Latvian šķīsts 'clean, light', and Old Prussian skīstan 'clean'. PIE *(s)kēi̯-d- < *(s)kēi̯- 'cut, split'. Polish cedzić 'strain, filter' is derived from the same root.
If to be derived from PIE *skelH- as suggested (but not certain) by Kroonen 2013, Kluge 2011, cf. s.v. *skelH- 'aufschlitzen, spalten' (IEW 923-6).
PS čistŭ is related to PS cěstiti and cěditi. These Slavic words are further related to Lithuanian skýstas, Latvian šķīsts, Greek σχίζω, Latin scindō and Old Indic chinátti.
Latin scindō, scindere (with derivatives) is derived from PIE *ski-n-d- and *skid-to. IE cognates are Sanskrit chinátti, Greek σχίζω, Old Church Slavonic cěditi etc.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *čistъ 'clean, pure', derived from PIE *(s)kid-to- (another derivatives with this root are cědìti and *cěstiti). It is related to Lithuanian skýstas 'thin (of liquids), Latvian šķīsts 'liquid, thin (of fabric), clean, clear', Old Prussian skijstan 'pure'.

Sanskrit chinátti 'he cuts off', Latin scindō, scindere 'split, tear', Lithuanian skíedžiu skíesti 'separate, dilute', Greek σχίζω 'I split', Russian Church Slavic cěditi 'strain' are derived from PIE *sk̑ʰei̯d- 'split, cut, tear'.

All sources consulted (no all are directy cited here) are consistent regarding to the further IE cognacy of the Slavic lexeme(s). The meaning of *čistŭ 'clean' is very well explainable in the context of other Slavic derivatives as cěditi 'strain, filter' ('to divide a clean/needed part from a dirty/needless one, to clean something dividing it into two parts') and cěstiti (for which the both the primary meanings 'cut, tear (off)' and the innovative meaning 'clean' are attested). However, there is an issue with the PIE root form. LIV gives a form with a palatovelar -k̑- (-k̑ʰ-), whereas the other sources give a form with a plain velar -k-. The Slavic forms can not be derived from a form with a palatovelar. Conversely, if we assume a plain velar, all Slavic forms are phonetically regular. For now a PS root reference is given, the phonetic form of the PIE root should be investigated.
Cf. s.v. *kreu̯H- 'aufhäufen, bedecken' (IEW 616). Only Germanic and Balto-Slavic, perhaps also OIr. cró, W(+) creu 'Stall' if from *krawo- < *krₔu̯o- (cf. Vendryes et al. C-240).
Most probably PS *bru-d-ŭ 'something with a hot, bad taste', then 'something ugly, ugliness'. It is related to PS *bridŭ 'ugliness' which is derived from PIE *bher- 'cut, scratch'.
S.v. Lith. nókti 'grow ripe', Latv. nākt 'come', from PIE *h₂ne-nok̑- (cf. Lat. nancīscī 'obtain', OIr. t-ánaic 3.sg.pret. 'came'), following Kortlandt (1994:192).

The origin of PS *brudŭ is uncertain. Some scholars link it to Slovene brûzga 'snow mixed with mud'. There is also a relationship to PS *bridŭ assumed. Both lexemes would be then derived from PS *bher- 'cut'. Some scholars assume that the Ukrainian and Belarusian form are borrowed from Polish.

PS dialectal *brudŭ has an uncertain origin. It is a relationship to PS *bridŭ 'sharp, cutting, bitter, bad (about taste)', 'ugly, disgusting', cf. Slovac brid 'dirt, garbage', dialectal Ukrainian bryd 'something disgusting, dirty', dialectal Belarusian bryd 'dirt'. However, the middle -u- is hard to explain.

S.v. OLith. nókti II 'jagen, treiben; folgen' (BSl. Latv. nãkt, 'kommen'). No reliable comparanda outside of Baltic. The comparison by Endzelins KZ 61 (1935:257-261) to Goth. nēƕ, OHG nāh 'nahe' is phonologically difficult. Similarly difficult is the comparison of Kortlandt with Ved. 3.sg.perf. ānám̆̇śa, ānāśa, Lat. nancio, -īre 'erreichen' by Kortlandt Linguistica Baltica 3 (1994:191-193).
Cf. s.v. *h₂nek̑- 'erreichen' (IEW 316-8), to which the Lith. pres. nẽša 'reicht hin bis' is only tentatively connected to the root aorist stem *h₂nék̑-/*h₂n̥k̑-.

Etymology outside of Baltic disputed. According to {ref Kortlandt 1994} (followed by {ref Derksen 2015}) from PIE *h₂nek̑-, but this root etymology has not been met with widespread acceptance elsewhere (cf. {ref LIV²} 282-283; {ref ALEW} 708).

Cf. s.v. OLith. kir̃sti 'hacken, hauen, mähen' (BSl. Latv. cìrst 'hacken, hauen, schlagen; bahnen, bauen', OPr. kyrteis 'schlage', OCS črьta sf. 'Streich, Balken', etc.), from PIE *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' (cf. Hitt. kartae- 'abschneiden', Ved. kart- 'schneiden, abschneiden, spalten, brechen', YAv. kərəṇtaiti 'schneidet', Arm. kʻertʻem 'ziehe die Haut ab').
Cf. s.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' [IEW 941-2].

S.v. OLith. utėlė̃ 'Laus (Pediculus)' (BSl. Latv. uts 'Laus', etc.). Lith. utėlė̃ is a diminutive of a form utìs that is preserved dialectally. There is no certain comparative material outside of Baltic. The often assumed root cognacy with the Slavic word for louse (cf. e.g. Derksen 2008:532) is uncertain due to phonological difficulties.

Cf. s.v. OLith. tìkras 'wahr, echt, wirklich; eigen, eigentümlich' (BSl. Latv. tikrs 'gut, tauglich, wert', OPr. tickars 'recht' tikrōmien 'die Rechte, die rechte Hand'). Common Baltic adjective, can be related to OLith. tìkti 'sich eignen, passen, gefallen'). Further etymology outside of Baltic unclear. Possibly either to PIE *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' LIV² 620f., or to *tek- 'die Hand ausstrecken' LIV² 618f.

Cf. s.v. Lith. tìkras 'true, authentic, correct, right, certain' (Latv. tikrs 'good, sound', OPr. tickars 'right'), a derivative of the root found in Lith. tikė́ti 'believe, trust'. Probably to be cognate with OHG dingan, MHG dingen < Proto-Germanic ϸingjan 'to believe' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:542)

PS *brudŭ is considered as etymologically obscure by some scholars. However, if we assume an original meaning 'dregs, sediment' we can propose a relationship to Latin defrutum 'boiled syrup', Thracian βρῦτος, βροῦτος 'barley beer' and Illirian (rendered as Latin brīsa 'pulp'). PIE *bhereu̯- 'boil, bubble'.
*bʰeru̯- 'boil, bubble'.

The etymology is unclear. Nor de Vaan {ref de Vaan 2008} neither Beekes {ref Beekes 2010} does not list the PS lexeme among cognates of Latin or Greek (borrowed from Thracian!) words derived from the PIE root *bʰeru̯-.

The root vocalism makes a relationship to Lithanian mė́žti 'manure, muck out' problematic. The Slavic lexeme *mazati is related to German machen 'do, make', English make, Greek μάσσω 'knead'. PIE *mag̑-.
The etymology is obscure. Existing hypotheses, assuming a relationship to Greek πίνος or Slavic *pěna 'foam' are not convincing.
It is related to Greek πίνος, even if the length of the root vowel does not match. Czech š- is a s-mobile.
There is no convincing etymology.
The etymology of this lexeme is not clear. It has been linked to PS *pěna 'foam' and Greek πίνος 'dirty'. It could be also a loan from German Spinne 'spider', cf. Spinnenflecken.

PS *skvĭrn- has not been entirely explained. It can be a derivative from PS *skverti, sed. *skvĭrǫ 'melt fat'. The etymological meaning would be 'smeared with fat'. A relationship to Latin squarrōsus 'scurfy, scabby' is less probable.
The word does not have a certain etymology. One could assume a relationship to PS *skverti 'melt fat'. The original meanig would be 'smeary, stained with grease' then.

The etymology of this lexeme is obscure, even at the PS level. If we accept the relationship to *skverti 'melt fat', the root can hav an ideophonic origin. Any certain further IE cognates can be determined.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ (adj.) 'black' (ESSJa IV 155-157), from PIE *kr̥s-nó- (cf. Skt. kr̥ṣṇá- 'black').
As the only cognates are found in satəm languages, the possibility of a root reconstruction *k⁽ʷ⁾ers- with a labiovelar *kʷ cannot be excluded.
If the lexeme share the same root as found in PS *mŭrdati, *mŭrɡati, then it has a widely accepted further IE cognacy. However, this can not be ascertained. Other hypotheses are unconvincing.
South Slavic *mŭrsĭnŭ is related to Lithuanian smársas 'suet' and Latin merda 'excrement', cf. also sm"rdâ.
Latin merda 'excrement' is related to Lithuanian smirdė́ti 'to stink' (*smrd-) and Russian smórod (*smrd-o-s). PIE *smerd-h₂-.

S.v. NHG groß (MHG grōz, OHG grō, OS grōt), from West Germanic *grauta- 'groß' also found in OE grēat, OFr. grāt, ON grautr 'Grütze', so that it is developed from a meaning 'grob gemahlen'. Formally the adjective corresponds to Lith. graudùs 'spröde, bröckelig'. Cf. the verb *greut-a 'zerreiben, zermahlen'.
Cf. s.v. PGmc. *greut-a- (2) '(zerreiben)', only attested through a past passive participle, may be compared with Lith. grū́džiu (grū́du), grū́sti 'stampfen, zerstoßen, drängen'.
S.v. ON beiskr 'bitter, böse' (cf. Ic., Far. beiskur, Norw. beisk, Sw. Da. besk), from Proto-Germanic *baitska-, with a -sk- suffix to the same stem as Goth. baitrs 'bitter'.

The etymology of the root is obscure. Taking some meanings ('disturbe, confuse') into account, it can be related to PS *mŭr-. The underlying verbal form would be *mŭrd-s-iti then. PS verbs *mŭrdati *mŭrkati and mŭrgati also belong here. All these lexemes are related to Lithuanian mirgė́ti 'shimmer, glimmer'.

S.v. Engl. black (adj.), "Cognate with Middle Dutch blac ink, Old Saxon blac ink (Middle Low German blak ink, black dye, black colour), Old High German blah- (only in blah-faro of the colour of ink, blah-māl niello decoration (Middle High German blach-māl), blah-mālōn to decorate with niello); further etymology uncertain; on formal grounds the word could be from a base related to the Germanic bases of blank adj. and the various forms discussed at blik v., but since this would give an expected meaning ‘shining, white’ there is an obvious semantic difficulty; many have sought to resolve this by hypothesizing that the word meaning ‘black’ originated as a past participle (with the meaning ‘burnt, blackened’) of a verb meaning ‘to burn (brightly)’ derived from this base; this verb may perhaps be reflected by Middle Dutch blaken (Dutch blaken) to flame, to burn."
PS *mŭrgati 'blink, wink' is related to Lithuanian mirgė́ti 'twinkle' and Latvian mir̂dzêt 'tiwnkle', further to Old Icelandic myrkr 'dark'. PIE *mr(H)gʷ-.

PS *mŭrdati 'blink, wave, wag' and *mŭrɡati 'move something fast, blink, wink' are derived from PIE *mer- 'shine, glimmer, brigthen' (*mer-dʰ- and *mer-gʷ-). They are related to  Lithuanian mirgė́ti 'shimmer, glimmer', Latvian mir̂dzêt 'shimmer, glimmer' and to Old Icelandic myrkr 'cloudy'.
Cf. s.v. Goth. K21. kilϸei 'γαστήρ', 'womb', only in dat.sg. -ϸein in L 1.31, and in-kilϸo (ἔγκυος 'pregnant'), cognate with OE cild, Engl. child; other possible Gmc. cognates dubious.

PG *merkwu 'dark', Old Norsce myrkr 'dark'. Related to Markuu̯ai̯a 'deities ind the depth of the earth', Cuneiform Luvian  maru̯ai- 'black, dark',  Lithuanian mirgė́ti 'twinkle', Latvian mir̂dzêt 'twinkle', Russian morgát' 'blink, wink', Czech Dialectal mrgat 'to move, wave, watch groomily' and Albanian mjergullë 'nebula'. PIE *mergʷ-
S.v. NHG Kralle. First attested ca. 16th c., origins unclear. Perhaps to kratzen 'scratch'.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *gręzь 'mud, dirt' (ESSJa VII 125-126), a deverbative i-stem to *gręzti 'sink' and related to Lithuanian grim̃zti 'sink' and Latvian grim̃t 'sink'. Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic are uncertain.

S.v. NHG zählen (MHG zel(e)n, OHG zellen, OS tellian, OE tellan, ON telja), from PGmc. *tal-ja- 'zählen', a derivative from the same root as in NHG Zahl 'number', in turn perhaps to be connected to Lat. dolāre 'to hew', with a special development 'to notch, to score'.
PS *gręznǫti can be related to Lithuanian grim̃zti 'sink' if we assume an original root *grĭm- with later extentions.
Lithuanian grim̃zti 'sink' is related to Polish grzęznąć 'sink' etc. PIE *grem-g̑-. Cf. Lithuanian grìmti 'sink' and Latvian grimt derived directly from PIE *grem-.
If the phonetic irregularities are in fact expressive then the Serbo-Croat words has cognates amont the Slavic. However, due to the nature of the root, no reasonable further etymology can be found.

There are three (dialectal) variants of the root the lexeme is derived from (initial p-, b- and m- are possible, cf. mrljav, prljav, prljati, brljati, burljati). The root has an ideophonic (expressive) origin. The lexeme is solely Serbo-Croat and does not have any Slavic or further IE cognates.
S.v. *dʰelbʰ- 'graben, aushöhlen' (IEW 246).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *delban- 'to dig, delve', from PIE *dʰelbʰ-e- (cf. RuCS dъlbsti 'to scoop, chisel', SCr. dúpsti < *dʰlbʰ-, etc.).

S.v. Germanic *delb-a- 'graben'. No certain comparisons outside of Germanic, most close to Church Slavic dlъbǫ, dlъbti 'meißeln'. The connection to Lith. del̃bti 'die Augen niederschlagen' is hypothetical.

Serbo-Croat prljati / brljati 'to dirty' along with its Slavic cognates is derivered from PS *bĭrlati / *bĭrľati. The root itself is ideophonic, irregular correspondences are secondary and of expressive nature.
Polish barłóg 'lare, pallet, shakedown' etc. and Serbo-Croat bŕljati are related and both derived from PS *bĭrliti 'to dirty'.
Cf. s.v. Germanic *draugi- 'trocken' (> MLG droge 'trocken, dürr, unfruchtbar'), *drūgi- 'trocken' (> OE drȳge) , *drukna- 'trocken'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *draugja- ~ *drūgja- ~ *drukknu- 'dry'. An adjective whose Proto-Germanic reconstruction is problematic because of the co-occurrence of at least four different formations, namely 1) drūgja- (OE drȳge); 2) *drūga- (OFris. drūch); 3) draugja- (MDu. droge), and 4) *drukkna- (OS drocno, OHG trockan). The correlation between the different formations is unclear.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hnefan- 'fist' (cf. ON hnefi 'id.', Far. nevi 'id.', Elfd. nevi 'hand', MHG neve-mez 'a fistful') < *knep-on-. The -v- of the MHG cognate argues for PGmc. *hnefan- rather than *hneban-, precluding any connections to the Baltic root *knebʰ- > Lith. knìbti 'to kink, snap', etc.
{ref Kroonen 2013}:234 reconstructs Proto-Germanic *hnefan- as though from *knep-on-, but does not provide any cognates justifying an extra-Germanic etymology.

An expressive variant of *ręd- 'rank, order' (Vasmer, Schuster-Sewc) with further IE cognates. Back formation with cutting the coda and inserting -x- is something productive, there are not so many words beginning wit rę- and the meaning matches. Parallels like njerjad with similar/identical meanings.

S.v. Engl. lake n. (4). "Early Middle English lac , < Old French lac, < Latin lacus basin, tub, tank, lake, pond; the popular form of the word in Old French was lai . The present English form lake (recorded from the 14th cent.) may be due to confusion with lake n.3, or perhaps rather to independent adoption of Latin lacus."
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *pāliti 'burn, singe'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *žьltъ adj. 'yellow' based on a zero-grade fromation *g̑ʰl̥h₃-.

PS *neręxa / *neręxŭ (with meanings 'mess, trash, dirt, gauche, stupid or retarded person, person careless regarding to his clothing, slob' etc. attested in Slavic dialects) is a compound *ne-*ręxa/ŭ. The second part of it is an expressive derivative from PS *ręd- 'order'.
S.v. Goth. L17. *laufs 'leaf', only nom.pl.m. -ubos 'φύλλα' (Mk 13.28), lauf n.a., only acc.sg.n used collectively φύλλα 'foliage' (Mk. 11.13), cf. OE lēaf, OHG loub, etc.
PS *rędŭ is related to Lithuanian rindà 'row line' etc. There is no further cognacy beyond Balto-Slavic given. BSl *rind-.
PS dialectal *ręxŭ is an expressive derivative from *rędŭ.
PS *rędŭ is derived from PIE *rn̥do- < PIE *rend- 'to arragne, order' and related to Latin ordīrī and ōrdō.
No Slavic cognates (and other IE) in the entries ordīrī and ōrdō are listed. The Latin words are probably derived from PIE *h₂or-d-.
S.v. Gmc. *lufta- 'schlaff; link'. Possibly a primary verbal adjective in *-to- to the IE root *(s)leup- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 964f.) only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic.

S.v. Engl. 'left' "A word apparently inherited from Germanic." Cf. West Frisian lafter, East Frisian läft, North Frisian leeft, lääft, Old Frisian lufter, lōftra, Middle and Early Modern Dutch lucht, locht, luft, Middle Low German lucht, locht, all in sense ‘left’; further etymology uncertain.

S.v. NHG link adj. (with derived adv. links; MHG linc, lenc, OHG lenca 'linke Hand'). The adjective originally meant 'ungeschickt', 'clumsy' and possibly to be connected to the late attested Ved. laṅga- 'lahm'.
There is no certain etymology.
There is no certain etymology.
Vasmer refutes the relationship to Greek νήχω 'swim' etc. and gives no alternative hypothesis.

?*gʷr̥d- 'slow, languid' > Greek βραδύς, Lithuanian gurdùs, Latvian gur̃das etc. The reconstruction of this root is uncertain, it can be also related to *gʷreh₂- 'heavy'. The relationship of Latin gurdus 'stupid' to ?*gʷr̥d- is dubious. According to Blažek's interpretation of Slavic *gŭrdŭ, South Slavic forms like Bulgarian g"rd / gr"d 'ugly, bad', Macedonian grd 'ugly', Slovene  grd 'ugly' would belong here.

PS *gŭrdŭ 'proud' may be cognate with Lithuanian gurdùs 'weak, slow, uncommunicative, stiff' and Latvian gur̃ds 'tired, weary', even though some irregular correspondence in stress. If the Slavic and Baltic words are related, they can be connected with Greek βραδύς 'slow, dull, sluggish' < PIE *gʷrdus.
In spite of the general constistence of the literature regarding to the possible IE cognacy, the etymology of this lexeme and the PIE root it was derived from remain uncertain.

Further IE cognacy of PS *gŭrdŭ is problematic. It has been linked to Lithuanian gurdùs 'slow', Latvian gur̃ds 'tired' and Greek βραδύς 'slow' (< *gʷr̥dus). The coexistence of two distinct meanings 'proud, arch' and 'terrible, ugly' and the unclear further cognacy suggest an innovative and expressive nature of this lexeme.
PS *grъdъ is probably derived from PIE *gu̯r̥Hdu/o- 'heavy' (< PIE *gu̯erH- 'heavy'), cf. Lithuanian gurdùs, Latvian gur̃ds, less probably Greek βραδύς.

Latin gurdus 'blockhead, dolt' is derived from PIE *gʷrd-o- and related to Greek βραδύς 'slow', Lithuanian gurdùs 'slow', Latvian gur̃ds 'tired', Old Church Slavonic *gŭrdŭ and Russian gordyj 'proud, haughty'.
"[...] βραδύς may morphologically be identical with Lith. gurdùs, Latv. gur̃ds 'tired', reflecting *gʷrdú- [...]. Lat. gurdus 'dolt, heavy' can be connected as well [...]".
S.v. Engl. straight, from Middle English streȝt, straȝt, originally an adjectival use of the past participle of strecchen 'to stretch'.

S.v. Arbëresh Albanian tëtimpt (drídhem ka tëtempt 'ich zittere vor Kälte', etc.), probably < të (article, preposition) + tim- <-(dissim./assim.)-<-  dim-ën/dim-ër 'winter', also: 'frost', < PIE *g̑ʰei̯-m-.
S.v. ?*pret- 'erkennen' (IEW 845). Cf. n1 "Vgl. wohl toch.B e-prete 'mutig', A partim 'Entschluß' (auch als Lehnwort in B), die *preHt- ausschließen'."

S.v. Goth. F86. fraϸi 'νοῦς, νόημα', 'mind, understanding', with denominal verb fraϸjan 'φρονεῖν, συνιέναι, γινώσκειν', 'think, recognize, understand', from PIE *prā̆t- 'understand' (cf. Lith. pràsti, prantù 'become accustomed to, understand'). Other potential cognates questionable.

Cf. s.v. OLith. *pràsti 'sich gewöhnen, sich einarbeiten' (BSl. Latv. prast, OPr. issprestun 'verstehen'), from PIE *preh₁t- 'verstehen' (cf. Goth. fraϸjan 'denken, erkennen, verstehen'. fraϸi 'Verstand, Gesinnung', froϸs 'klug', ON fróðr 'kundig, erfahren', etc. TochA pratim 'Entscheidung, Entschluss', TochB eprete 'mutig').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fraϸjan- 'to understand', from PIE *prót-ie- (cf. Lith. pràsti 'to become accustomed to, (dial.) 'to apprehend', su-pràsri 'to understand').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *smītan- 'to stroke; to strike', from PIE *sméid-e- (cf. Latv. smaidît 'to laugh, make fun of; to flatter' < *smoid-eie-; OCS smědъ 'brown, dirty' < *smoid-o-; less certain: Arm. mic 'dirt' < smid-io-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *blauta- 'soft', from PIE *bʰloudh₂-o- (cf. Gk. φλυδάω 'to be soft, weak' < *bʰludʰh₂-ie-, φλυδαρός 'weak' < *bʰludh₂-ro-).
Cf. s.v. ?*bʰleu̯dh₂- 'zerfließen' (IEW 159), only Greek. [No Germanic lexemes connected.]
Cf. s.v. Weib (MHG wīp, wīb, OHG wīb, OS wīf), from PGmc. *weiba- 'Weib', cf. also in ON wíf, OE wīf, OFr. wīf. An etymologically unclear word.
S.v. ON illr 'schlecht, böse'. Etymology disputed.
Etymology outside of Germanic unclear (cf. Kroonen 2013, Kluge 2011). Cf. Kluge (2011) for references to various attempts at an IE etymology.

S.v. NHG Bein (MHG bein, OHG bein, OS bēn), from PGmc. *baina- 'Knochen', also in ON bein, OE bān, OFr. bēn. The lexeme is not attested in Gothic. The word is a Germanic replacement for the IE inherited word for 'leg' (attested via Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc.), but its origin is unclear.
S.v. NHG Knochen (MHG knoche, MLG knoke, knake). The words can belong to IE *g̑enu- 'knee', if it is from an enlargement like in Gk. γνύξ 'on the knees'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *knuk(k)an- 'knuckle', a Germanic n-stem which is probably to be reconstructed as *knukō, gen. knukkaz < *gnug-ōn, *gnug-n-ós. Outside of Germanic the word has been compared to Lith. gniáužti 'to close one's hand' < *gneug̑-, but a connection with Gmc. *knewa- 'knee' is more likely since the IE predecessor apparently also meant 'node'. If so, then the Gmc. word can be analyzed as the zero-grade *g̑nu- with a suffix *-gon- also found *mankan- 'mane' < *mon-gon-.

The comparison of Kluge to Gk. γνύξ 'with bent knee' as evidence for a possible extended form of the zero-grade root *gnu-g- is not fully certain, as in Greek the ending -ξ can be accounted for by analogy with other adverbs, e.g. πύξ 'with the fist', λάξ 'with the foot' (cf. Beekes 2010:280 s.v. γνύξ). While the proposed connection with *g̑enu- 'knee' is semantically attractive and a close formal match, the etymology outside of Germanic must remain uncertain. Cf. Kroonen (2013:298) for an alternative proposal, as though from *g̑nu-gon-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hwēsan- 'to wheeze' (OE hwǣsan 'id.'), from PIE *k̑u̯ḗs- (cf. Skt. śvásati 'to hiss, breathe, sigh', Lat. queror 'to complain' < *k̑u̯es-; YAv. suši du.f. 'the lungs' < *k̑us-ih₁. Cf. also ON hvæsa 'to hiss', Far. hvæsa 'to wheeze', Elfd. węsa 'to breathe' (with secondary nasal vowel) < hwēsjan-.
Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯es- 'schnaufen, schnauben, seufzen' (IEW 631-2). Cf. n1 ON hvę́sa 'zischen, schnauben' can also reflect *hwēs-i̯e-, based on an original acrodynamic present *k̑u̯ḗs-.
Cf. s.v. NHG Klaue (OHG klāwa, klā 'Klaue'). There are no meaningful comparisons that can be made outside of Germanic.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *melhman- 'cloud' (Goth. milhman 'id.' as though from *melk̑-mon-; cf. Lith. mìlšti 'to become overcast' < *mlk̑-ske-; Ru. (dial.) molost' 'bad weather' < *molk̑-ti). An mn-stem created to a lost verbal root *melh-, continuing a Germanic-Balto-Slavic isogloss *melk̑- (cf. Fraenkel 1965:453). The same root is continued in OSw. moln, molen, Elfd. muoln 'cloud' < *mulhna-. Possibly both formations arose through a paradigm split of different ablaut forms.
Cf. s.v. Lith. mìlšti(s) 'sich zusammenziehen, vom Gewitter', maybe to be connected to Goth. milhma 'Wolke'.

Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Often compared to Lith. mìlšti(s) and other Balto-Slavic forms with various degrees of confidence of the etymology (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:255, {ref Kroonen 2013}:403). {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:453 suggests possibly related ('eventuell'). No lemma for Lith. mìlšti(s) in {ref ALEW} or {ref Derksen 2015}.
S.v. Engl. cloud, from OE clúd 'a mass of rock, hill'. The current sense 'cloud' is first attested in the 13th century.

Shows that Middle Indic preserves i-stem o that Avestan and Indic can be matched and there is no advantage in connecting Avestan to Vedic prṣṭí- 'rib' instead of prṣṭhá- 'back'. So, all the words for 'back' can have one single source *pr̥-sth₂-o/i- cognate with Slavic words for 'finger'.
S.v. NHG Wolke (MHG wolken, OHG wolcan, OS wolkan), from Germanic *wulkna- also in OE wolcen, OFr. wolken. Perhaps an auslaut variant *u̯l̥g- to OCS oblakŭ 'Wolke'?

S.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- 'rain, wet weather', from PIE *u̯elk- (IEW 1145f.). The relationship of the Celtic lexemes with PIE *u̯el(H)g- (Lith. vìlgyti 'make wet', CS vlaga, Russ. dial. vológa, Cz. vlaha 'wetness', OHG welk 'wet, moist' is unclear. The two roots *u̯elk- and *u̯elg- should be somehow related. Perhaps there was an original root noun *u̯ōlg-s 'rain' (phonetically *[u̯ōlks]), gen.sg. *u̯olg-os and assume that some languages generalised the voiceless velar from the nom.sg. throughout the paradigm.

Cf. s.v. Lith. vìlgyti 'befeuchten, benetzen, bestreichen', from PIE *u̯elg- (cf. OIr. folc 'starker Regen, Regenwetter' folcaid 'waschen (Kopf)', MW gwylch 'waschen', Bret. gwalc'hiñ 'waschen', OS wolkan 'Wolke', OHG wolkan 'Wolke'). The reconstruction of the root with final *g is based on Balto-Slavic and Germanic, the Celtic lexemes reflect *u̯elk-. The reason for this deviation is unclear, but could be due to an assimilation of final *g in the 2nd or 3rd person singular in the present or aorist stem.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- 'rain, wet weather', from PIE *u̯elk- (IEW 1145f.). The relationship of the Celtic lexemes with PIE *u̯el(H)g- (Lith. vìlgyti 'make wet', CS vlaga, Russ. dial. vológa, Cz. vlaha 'wetness', OHG welk 'wet, moist' is unclear. The two roots *u̯elk- and *u̯elg- should be somehow related. Perhaps there was an original root noun *u̯ōlg-s 'rain' (phonetically *[u̯ōlks]), gen.sg. *u̯olg-os and assume that some languages generalised the voiceless velar from the nom.sg. throughout the paradigm.

Cf. s.v. Lith. vìlgyti 'befeuchten, benetzen, bestreichen', from PIE *u̯elg- (cf. OIr. folc 'starker Regen, Regenwetter' folcaid 'waschen (Kopf)', MW gwylch 'waschen', Bret. gwalc'hiñ 'waschen', OS wolkan 'Wolke', OHG wolkan 'Wolke'). The reconstruction of the root with final *g is based on Balto-Slavic and Germanic, the Celtic lexemes reflect *u̯elk-. The reason for this deviation is unclear, but could be due to an assimilation of final *g in the 2nd or 3rd person singular in the present or aorist stem.

Root reconstruction follows LIV² 676, ALEW 1242-1243. Cf. ALEW 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and Matasović (2009:427) s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.

Root reconstruction follows {ref LIV²} 676, {ref ALEW} 1242-1243; cf. {ref ALEW} 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and {ref Matasović 2009}:427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.
S.v. ON ský 'wolke' (< Proto-Norse *skeui̯a-), further connections are doubtful.
S.v. ON ský 'wolke' (< Proto-Norse *skeui̯a-), further connections are doubtful.

Cf. s.v. NHG heulen (MHG hiulen, hiuweln; OHG hūwilōn, hūlōn, MLG hulen), probably originally 'screech like an owl' to MHG hiuwel, hūwel, OHG hūwo 'Uhu, Eule'. The nouns as well as the verb are probably imitative in origin.
Cf. s.v. NHG kreischen (Late MHG krīschen, MLG criscen), a -sk-formation to the stem underlying NHG kreißen, an onomatopoeic verb form.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *way 'woe, alas' "All of these interjections in different IE languages could be independent formations, but their similarity is obvious."
S.v. Gmc. *wōp-ja- 'weinen'. No secure etymology outside of Germanic.
S.v. Gmc. *sneiϸ-a- 'schneiden', no clear etymology.
S.v. NHG schneiden (MHG snīden, OHG snīdan, OS snīthan), from Gmc. *sneiϸ-a-. No clear etymology.

S.v. Engl. cut (v.), first attested in the 13th century, replacing Old English sníðan, ceorfan. Etymology uncertain. There is no secure antecedent in Old English nor any corresponding verb in Romance from which it may be a borrowing. In Swedish dialects there exists a verb kåta, (kutå) from Old Germanic *kut-/*kot-, which might also be the source of the English verb.

Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. EWAia I:154 and Kroonen (2013:97) s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion.

Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. {ref EWAia} I:154 and {ref Kroonen 2013}:97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion.

S.v. Gmc. *grab-a- 'graben'. The Germanic forms can be securely connected to *gʰrebʰ- also attested in the neighbouring languages to the east. The Germanic verb shows o-Ablaut. Cf. Latv. grebju, grebt 'ausschaben, aushöhlen, eingraben', OCS grebǫ, greti 'rudern, graben', with po- 'begraben, bestatten'.
S.v. Goth. Ϸ63. ϸwahan 'νίπτειν', 'wash'. No etymology.
S.v. Sw. smutsig, like Da. smudsig, Nw. smussig, from NHG schmutzig.

S.v. NHG machen (MHD machen, OHG mahhōn, OS makon), from West Germanic *mak-ō- 'machen', also in OE macian, OFr. makia, from (Eur.) IE *mag̑- 'kneten', also found in Gk. μάσσω 'ich knete, presse, wische ab, bilde ab', OCS mazati 'bestreichen, beschmieren, salben', Bret. meza 'kneten', Latv. iz-muõzêt 'anschmieren'.

S.v. Goth. T16. taujan 'ποιεῖν, ποιεῖσθαι, πράσσειν', 'to do, make', from PGmc. *tawjan 'prepare, make' (cf. Runic (Gallehus Horn) 1sg tawido, OHG zawjan, zowjan, MHG zouwen, zöuwen 'hasten'). No accepted etymology.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *taujan- 'to do, make'. Possibly connected to TochB tsuwa 3.sg.pret. 'to join, adjust', Gk. δύναμαι 'to be able' (cf. LIV² 123). If so, then a de-adjectival formation from *dou̯h₂-o- (the original adjective only attested in Slav. LWs such as OCS gotovъ, Ru. gotóv).

Cf. s.v. deu̯h₂- 'zusammenfügen' [IEW 218]. Goth. taujan is listed under Kausativ ?*dou̯h₂-éi̯e-, but cf. n4 where it is noted that the absence of Germanic Verschärfung (i.e. not †taggwjan) is unclear, therefore the reconstruction for the form remains uncertain.

S.v. ON gera 'machen, tun, breiten', from Proto-Germanic *garwian. Further etymology uncertain. The often assumed explanation from *ga-arwa- is faintly appealing. Cf. entry for further references to older literature.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *maka- 'fit, comfortable', an adjective with an original meaning 'fit, suitable' (cf. *makan- 'match') and serving as a derivational base to the weak verb attested via OE macian 'to prepare, make', E to make, OFri. makia 'id.', OS (gi-)makon 'to make, form, fix', Du. maken 'to make', OHG mahhōn 'id.', G. machen 'id.' < *makōjan-. The verb is usually compared to Gk. μάσσω 'to knead, mold; wipe' < *mh₂g̑-ie- and OCS mazati 'to anoint', SCr. mȁzati 'to smear' < *meh₂g̑-eh₂- assuming the original meaning was 'knead'. As the original meaning was likely to have been 'to match, put together', these older connections are to be rejected. An etymological link with OIr. mám 'yoke' < *mag-mo-(?); Lith. mė́gti (mė́giu) 'to like', Latv. mêgt 'to be able' < *meg-ie-. The reconstruction of an IE root *meg- nevertheless remains uncertain.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rak(k)an- '(sleuth) dog'. This n-stem has no certain etymology, but might be related to *rakjan- 'to reach out' (cf. OE racian 'to direct; to take a course').
Cf. s.v. ON rakki 'hund'.
S.v. Engl. dog. Of unknown origin.
S.v. NHG Staub (MHG stoup, stoub, OHG stoub), a derivative to the verb stieben (OHG stiuban), of unclear etymology.

Cf. s.v. NHG Boden (MHG bodem, boden, OHG bodam, OS bođom) from Pre-German *buϸma- 'Boden', while the other Germanic languages go back to *butma- (ON botn, OE botm), clearly coming from IE *bʰudʰ-men- (cf. Ved. budhná- 'Boden, Grund, Wurzel' with a *-mno- suffix; Gk. πυθμήν 'Boden eines Gefäßes, des Meeres, Wurzel', further probably with Lat. fundus 'Boden', MIr. bonn 'Sohle, Grundlage').
S.v. Goth. A85. airϸa 'γῆ', 'earth', from PGmc. *erϸō, an extension of PGmc. *erō in the OHG hapax ero 'earth', cf. Gk. ἔρα 'earth', (Hom. ἔρα-ζε 'earthward'), Welsh erw 'field', OBret. ero 'furrow'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *budman- ~ *buttman- 'bottom', as though from PIE *bʰudʰ-mén- (cf. Gk. πυθμήν 'bottom, depth, root' < *bʰudʰ-mén-, Skt. budhná- 'bottom', Lat. fundus 'id.', MIr. bond 'foot, sole' < *bʰudʰ-no-). "The PIE root *bʰudʰ- itself seems to have been metathesized from *dʰubʰ-, for which cf. [PGmc.] *deupa- 'deep'."

Cf. s.v. Ved. budhná- 'Boden, Grund, Tiefe', to be connected with Gk. πυθμήν 'Boden, Grund, Unterlage', Lat. fundus 'Boden, Meeresgrund, Grundstück', MIr. bond 'Sohle, Grundlage', OHG bodam, NHG Boden, etc., going back to an IE formation with a *-men- suffix to a root *bʰudʰ-.

Cf. s.v. Gk. ἔρα explained by grammarians as with γῆ 'earth'. A general resemblance is shown by a few Germanic and Celtic expressions for 'earth' (OHG ero 'earth', ON jǫrvi 'sand(bank)', MW erw 'field', all with a suffix -u̯-; with a suffix -t- (Goth. airϸa, ON jǫrðm MIr. ert 'earth'. Connections with Arm. erkir 'earth' are unclear.

S.v. NHG weit (MHG wīt, OHG wīt, OS wīd), from Germanic *weida- (adj.) 'weit' also found in ON víðr, OE wīd, OFr. wīd. Origin unclear. May formally correspond to Ved. vīta 'gerade', but the semantics are divergent and they are not readily connected.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *wīda- 'wide, distant', as though from PIE *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- (cf. TochAB wätk- 'to separate, distinguish' < *h₁ui-dʰh₁-sk-e- (cf. Lat. dīvidō, -ere 'to separate, divide' *-h₁ui-dʰh₁-). "A full-grade adj. created to a verbal formation *h₁ui-dʰeh₁- 'to set apart', with *h₁ui- being dissimilated from *dui- 'in two' due to the following dental ({ref Lubotsky 1994})."

S.v. NHG weit (MHG wīt, OHG wīt, OS wīd), from Germanic *weida- (adj.) 'weit' also found in ON víðr, OE wīd, OFr. wīd. Origin unclear. May formally correspond to Ved. vīta 'gerade', but the semantics are divergent and they are not readily connected.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *wīda- 'wide, distant', as though from PIE *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- (cf. TochAB wätk- 'to separate, distinguish' < *h₁ui-dʰh₁-sk-e- (cf. Lat. dīvidō, -ere 'to separate, divide' *-h₁ui-dʰh₁-). "A full-grade adj. created to a verbal formation *h₁ui-dʰeh₁- 'to set apart', with *h₁ui- being dissimilated from *dui- 'in two' due to the following dental ({ref Lubotsky 1994})."

S.v. NHG Angst (MHG angest, OHG angust), from West Germanic *angusti- 'Angst', also in OFr. angst. This is a (s)ti-formation or (or ti-formation to an s-stem) to IE *ang̑ʰu- 'eng, bedrängend'. The s-stem is continued in Ved. áṃhas- 'Bedrängung, Angst', Lat. angor 'Würgen, Angst', Lat. angustus 'eng, schmal' and CS ǫzoti 'Beengigung'.
Cf. s.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (IEW 42-3).

S.v. ON hræðast 'sich fürchten', hræddr 'furcht, schrecken' (> NNw. rædd, NSw. rädd, NDa. ræd), hræðsla, hræzla 'furcht' (< Gmc. *hrēðislō) (Ic. hræðsla, Far. ræðsla, NNor. rædsla, OSw. rädsla, ODa. rædsle), perhaps to be connected with ON hraðr.
Cf. for a recent attempt to derive Old English *docga from the colour adjective dox 'dark haired, dusky'.
S.v. Lat. timeō, -ēs, -uī, -ēre 'craindre, avoir peur'. Without clear etymology.
S.v. Lat. trĕmĕrĕ 'zittern'. OFr. criembre, with apparently contaminated initial *tr-  > *kr- under influence of the Celtic root *krit- (cf. Bret. kridien, W crith 'das Zittern').

S.v. Lat. tremō, -ere 'to tremble', from PIE *trem-e/o- (cf. U. tremitu 3.sg.imptv.II. perh. 'to scare', Gk. τρέμω 'to tremble', Lith. trem̃ti 'to shake up', trimti 'to tremble', TochA, trämäṣ, tärmiñc 'to tremble').
S.v. *trem- 'zittern (vor Angst)' (IEW 1092-3).
S.v. Alb. tremb 'to frighten', continuing Proto-Albanian *trema and related to TochA tärm- 'to get angry', Gk. τρέμω 'to tremble (of fear)', Lat. tremō 'id.'.
S.v. Alb. tremb 'jmdm. Angst machen, erschrecken', structural grounds argue for inheritance from IE *trem- rather than a loanword from Lat. tremō (expected Lat. tremō > Alb. **tremój).

S.v. Engl. scare (v.), from Middle English skerre, borrowed from Old Norse skirra (cf. Icelandic skirra vandræðum 'to avoid strife', reflexive skirra-sk 'to shrink from'; Norwegian skjerra, Swedish dialectal skjarra 'to scare').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *fraisan- 'to tempt', a strong verb attested only by Goth. fraisan. The original strong verb gave rise to a noun attested via OFri. frēs, OS frēsa, OHG freisa 'danger, scare' < *fraisō-, whence OE frāsian 'to try', OS frēson 'to try, risk', Du. vrezen 'to fear', etc. Of uncertain etymology. Perhaps from *pro-h₂is- 'to ask forth'?

Cf. s.v. Goth. F75. fraisan (cf. OFris. frēs, OS frēsa, OHG freisa 'danger', OS frēson 'bring into danger, temptation', OHG freison 'be in danger', MHG vreist 'danger'). Etymology obscure, possibly a compound *fra-isan (cf. OIc. eisa 'plunge ahead', Skt. ī́ṣate 'hastens', Gk. ἱαρός, ἱερός 'powerful'), or + PIE *ays- 'desire' as in Skt. iccháti, Av. isaiti 'seek for', OE āskian, OHG eiscōn 'ask', Lith. ieškati, OSl. iskati 'seek'. Less likely from PIE *per- + *ey- (cf. Gk. πεῖρα 'attempt', Lat. experior 'test').

S.v. *dūna- 'down (of a bird)' (ON dúnn 'id.', Far. dún 'id.', OSw. dūn 'id.', Elfd. daungen 'id.'), as though from PIE *dʰuh₂-no-, related to Proto-Germanic *dauma- 'vapor' < *dʰuh₂-mo- and *dauna- 'smell' < *dʰouh₂-no-.
Cf. s.v. ON dúnn (1) 'daune, flaumfeder', cf. daunn 'gestank', dýja, and dýna (1) 'daunenkissen', from PIE *dʰeu- (cf. Skt. dhūnoti 'schüttelt', Gk. θύνω 'stürme dahin').

S.v. Goth. W45. weihan, only in waurdam weihan 'λογομαχεῖν', 'dispute', from PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'exert force' (cf. Lith. veĩkti, Latv. veìkt 'carry out', OIr. fichim < *wik-yo- 'I fight', Lat. vincō 'conquer', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay'. A Germanic-Celtic isogloss. The root may originally have been onomatopoetic.
S.v. ?*slak- 'schlagen' (IEW 959). Cf. n1 "Hierher wohl mir. slacc 'Schwert', neuir. slacairt 'das Schlagen' usw."
S.v. Goth. S98. *slahan 'δέρειν, τύπτειν', 'strike', from PIE *slak- 'strike' (only Gmc. & Celt., cf. MIr. slacc 'sword', slachta 'struck').
Cf. s.v. Goth. S98. *slahan 'δέρειν, τύπτειν', 'strike', from PIE *slak- 'strike' (only Gmc. & Celt., cf. MIr. slacc 'sword', slachta 'struck').
S.v. Goth. S98. *slahan 'δέρειν, τύπτειν', 'strike', from PIE *slak- 'strike' (only Gmc. & Celt., cf. MIr. slacc 'sword', slachta 'struck').
Cf. s.v. NHG Kampf (MHG kampf, OHG kampf), cf. also OE comp and ON kapp 'Wettstreit', probably an old borrowing from Lat. campus 'Feld'. Denominal verb kämpfen.

S.v. Gmc. *brenn-a- 'brennen'. If the sound law of PIE *gʷʰ- > IE *b- is accepted, then we may consider a comparison with PIE *gʷʰer- as a nu-present (as attested in Indic [grammatical texts], and in Armenian), thus *gʷʰr̥-nu̯- > *br̥nn- > brenn-. Other possibilities include comparisons to IE *bʰreu- 'wallen' (cf. Gmc. *breww-a-) and *bʰereg- 'glänzen'.

Cf. s.v. NHG Brand (MHG brant, OHG brant, OS brand), from Germanic *branda- 'Brand', also in ON brandr, OE brond, OFr. brand, brond. A to-formation (perhaps originally older tu) to Germanic *brenn-a- 'to burn'.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *brenn-a- 'brennen'. If the sound law of PIE *gʷʰ- > IE *b- is accepted, then we may consider a comparison with PIE *gʷʰer- as a nu-present (as attested in Indic [grammatical texts], and in Armenian), thus *gʷʰr̥-nu̯- > *br̥nn- > brenn-. Other possibilities include comparisons to IE *bʰreu- 'wallen' (cf. Gmc. *breww-a-) and *bʰereg- 'glänzen'. Cf. derived noun bran-da-z > ON brandr, OE brand, OS brand, OHG brant, etc.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *brinnan- 'to burn', assuming an etymology from a derived n-present from PIE *bʰreu̯h₁- 'to boil, brew' (cf. OIr. do-bruinn 'to flow, trickle' < *bʰru-n-h₁-ie-; Lat. ferveō, -ere 'to be hot, to boil' < *bʰéru̯h₁-e-).
Cf. s.v. *bʰrei̯H- 'schneiden' (IEW 166-7) and *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5). It is unclear to which root got. (+) brinnan 'brennen' belongs.

Cf. s.v. NHG Mücke (MHG mücke, mucke, mügge, mugge, OHG mugga, muck, OS muggia), from Germanic *mugjōn (also in OSw. mugga, OE mycg, mygg). Presumably not related to the IE word for 'fly', which goes back to *mus-, but rather a zero-grade form to a word for 'fly' which goes back to *mek̑- (cf. Ved. maśáka-, Lith. mãšala[s]. mãkatas).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *muwī- 'mosquito' < PIE *muH-ih₂-. The velar in West Germanic arose due to velarisation of the *-w- in the nominative *muwī. Velars in the related forms in OSw. mygga, etc. arose by regular Verschärfung of *-jj- > -gg(j)-. Appears to be related to *musī- 'mosquito, fly' < PIE *mus-(i)eh₂- (cf. MDu. meusie 'mosquito, fly').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *mūjan (ON mý 'midge, gnat') an isolated form distantly connected with *mūsō ~ *mūsīn (> Flem. meuzie).

S.v. Engl. fog (n.) 2., Of uncertain origin. Perhaps a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. OIc. fok 'spray, flurry, windblown cloud (of snow, rain, grass, sand, etc.)', Nw. fok 'flurry, bustle, hurry', Da. fog 'shower, spray, flurry, windblown cloud (of snow, rain, dust, sand', etc.).

S.v. NHG Wald (MHG walt, OHG wald, OS wald), from Gmc. *walϸu-, also in ON vǫllr 'Feld, Weise, Boden', OE weald 'Wald, waldbedecktes Hochland'. Outside of Germanic cf. OIr. folt 'Haarschopf, Laubwerk', W gwallt 'Haarschopf, belaubte Zweigspitzen', Lith. váltis 'Haferrispe', from IE (Eur.) *wolət-; zero-grade found in Gk. λάσιος 'behaart, dichtbewachsen', also to Lat. vellere 'rupfen', and probably further to the word for 'Wolle'.

S.v. ON aldin, aldini 'baumfrucht', traditionally connected with Gk. ἄλθω, ἀλθαίνω 'cure', ἄλθομαι 'wachsen', Ved. r̥dhnóti, r̥náddhi, r̥dháti 'gedeihen, gelingen', to be interpreted as the same root as *al- with a *-dh- root extension.

Etymology uncertain. The etymology given by {ref de Vries 1977} relies on the outdated theory of root-extensions as in {ref IEW}. Additionally, the etymological connection of the comparanda given by {ref de Vries 1977} are questionable (cf. s.v. Gk. ἀλθαίνω in {ref Beekes 2010}, s.v. Ved. √ardh- in {ref EWAia}). Consequently, the basis upon which the traditional proposed etymology of Old Norse aldin rests, remains uncertain. Not in {ref Orel 2003} or {ref Kroonen 2013}.

S.v. Goth. A106. akran 'καρπός', 'fruit, results', from PIE *ōg 'grow, fruit, berry' (cf. OIr. āirne < *ag-rīn-ya 'sloe', Wel. aeron 'fruits, berries', Corn. aeran 'plum', Lith. úoga, Latv. uôga, OCS (j)agoda 'berry').

Cf. s.v. NHG Obst (MHG obez, OHG obaz, MLG ovet, avet), from pre-German *uba-ǣtaz 'Dazu-Essen', the latter word from the same word as NHG Aas to the IE root *h₁ed-, and the former identical with NHG ob in the old meaning 'hin(zu)'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. úoga 'Beere'. No secure comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic; perhaps root cognate with TochB oko 'Frucht', possibly conceivable is a further connection to the Celtic family of OIr. áirne 'Frucht des Schlehdorns', MW aeron 'Früchte, Beeren', eirin 'Pflaumen, Zwetschgen; Früchte des Schlehdorns; Beeren', which must have started with Proto-Celtic *agr-. Corresponding in Germanic is Goth. akran 'Frucht', akranalaus 'unfruchtbar', and with metathesis ON akarn, OE æcern 'Eichel'. The hypothesis that the Celtic and Germanic words go back to PIE *h₂eg̑ró- or *h₂ég̑ro- 'Feld' (cf. Ved. ájra-, Gk. ἀγρός, Lat. ager, Goth. akrs) is questionable on semantic grounds.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *agoda 'berry' (ESSJa I 57-59). From PIE ?*h₂og-eh₂- (cf. Goth. akran 'fruit (of trees, corn)'). Adams connects TochB oko 'fruit, effect' also to the Balto-Slavic forms (with the Germanic forms being more remote), although the vocalism of the Tocharian form is not without its problems.

Cf. s.v. OLith. úoga 'Beere'. No secure comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic; perhaps root cognate with TochB oko 'Frucht', possibly conceivable is a further connection to the Celtic family of OIr. áirne 'Frucht des Schlehdorns', MW aeron 'Früchte, Beeren', eirin 'Pflaumen, Zwetschgen; Früchte des Schlehdorns; Beeren', which must have started with Proto-Celtic *agr-. Corresponding in Germanic is Goth. akran 'Frucht', akranalaus 'unfruchtbar', and with metathesis ON akarn, OE æcern 'Eichel'. The hypothesis that the Celtic and Germanic words go back to PIE *h₂eg̑ró- or *h₂ég̑ro- 'Feld' (cf. Ved. ájra-, Gk. ἀγρός, Lat. ager, Goth. akrs) is questionable on semantic grounds.

[NB: This entry supersedes Adams (1999:109-110) cited in Kroonen (2013:18-19)] Cf. s.v. TochB oko 'fruit; result, consequence'. Clearly related to Tocharian A oko, but the shape of the form suggests that one was borrowed from one language to the other rather than being true cognates. There are two possible etymologies: (1) to PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'grow, increase' (cf. TochB auk- 'grow, increase'), however this assumes that the TochB lexeme would be a borrowing from TochA, but it is difficult to see the B word being borrowed from A rather than A from B, which is far more often the case; more attractive is (2) that the word may be related to PIE *h₂ógeh₂- 'fruit, berry' (cf. Lith. úoga 'berry, cherry', Latv. uôga 'berry; pustule, pockmark', OCS (j)agoda 'berry', Ru. jágoda 'berry', and more distantly with Goth. akran 'fruit', ON akarn 'fruit of a wild plant', OE œcern 'acorn', NHG Ecker 'id.', Old Irish áirne 'plum', aeron 'fruit, berry'; The underlying verb survives in Arm. ačem 'grow'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *agoda 'berry' (ESSJa I 57-59). From PIE ?*h₂og-eh₂- (cf. Goth. akran 'fruit (of trees, corn)'). Adams connects TochB oko 'fruit, effect' also to the Balto-Slavic forms (with the Germanic forms being more remote), although the vocalism of the Tocharian form is not without its problems.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *neman- 'to take' from PIE *kom-h₁ém-e- (cf. Lat. emō, -ere 'to take, buy'). The stem is a back-formation based upon the reanalysis of the compound verb *gan-eman- < *kom-h₁em-e- as containing the perfective prefix *ga-: *ga-neman-.
S.v. 1. *nem- 'zuteilen' (IEW 763).

S.v. Goth. N20. niman 'λαμβάνειν', 'take (away), accept, get'; 'αἵρειν', 'take away, take up', 'δέξεσθαι', 'receive'. Etymology disputed. Probably to be associated with PIE *nem- (cf. Gk. νέμω) in the basis of the meaning 'receive legally', cf. also the parallel between Gk. κληρονόμος 'heir' and Goth. arbinumja 'heir'. Attempts to relate to Lat. emō 'buy' (in cpds 'take'), OIr. em- in ar-fo-em 'receive', Lith. im̃ti, OCS jęti 'take' formally less likely.

S.v. Gmc. *nem-a- 'nehmen'. There are two possibilities for an etymology. Either (1) as a rhyme-variant of *em- 'nehmen, kaufen' (from complete dissimilation from *nem-?) cf. Lat. emō, OIr. do-em, Lith. im̃ti, OCS jęti, etc., or (2) to *nem- (cf. Lat. numerus 'Zahl, Anzahl, Menge', OIr. nem 'Gift, verdebliche Kraft, Härte', Lith. núoma 'Miete, Pacht', Latv. ņémt 'nehmen', Gk. νέμω 'teile aus, eigne mir an, besitze, weide, verzehre', OAv. nəmah- 'Darlehen', Ved. námati 'biegt, beugt'). One may prefer to assume an original root *nem- to account for all forms, with *em- as a rhyme-variant.

S.v. Gmc. *gǣ- 'gehen'. Whether West Germanic *gai- is a secondary development or goes back to PIE *g̑ʰēi̯- is debated. The form is comparable to Greek and Vedic verbs going back to a proto-form *g̑ʰē- (cf. Gk. κιχάνω < *g̑ʰə-nw-; Ved. jihīte).

S.v. Gmc. *far-a- 'fahren', probably going back to a proto-form *por- 'tragen, bringen', etc. which was an ablaut form of IE *per- 'durchbohren, hinüberbringen' (cf. Lat. portāre < *pr̥-tā-; W rhyd 'Furt', CS na-perjǫ, -periti 'durchbohren', Ru. poróm 'Fähre'; Gk. πείρω 'durchstoße, durchsteche', Ved. píparti 'bringt hinüber, rettet, schützt, übertrifft').

S.v. Gmc. *gǣ- 'gehen'. Whether West Germanic *gai- is a secondary development or goes back to PIE *g̑ʰēi̯- is debated. The form is comparable to Greek and Vedic verbs going back to a proto-form *g̑ʰē- (cf. Gk. κιχάνω < *g̑ʰə-nw-; Ved. jihīte).
S.v. Gmc. *gang-a- 'gehen'. May be compared with an e-grade Lith. verb žengiù, žeñgti 'schreiten' from a proto-form *g̑ʰengʰ- further connections are uncertain.
S.v. Gmc. *gang-a- 'gehen'. May be compared with an e-grade Lith. verb žengiù, žeñgti 'schreiten' from a proto-form *g̑ʰengʰ- further connections are uncertain.

Cf. s.v. Goth. M12. maitan- 'κόπτω', 'cut, hew', of unclear etymology. Perhaps from PIE *may-(d-) 'strike, cut off' if to be connected with OIr. mael (w/ -lo- suffix), but doubtful. Further hypotheses dubious.

S.v. OHG bacho. pacho 'Rücken, dorsum; Schinken, Speckseite'. The form is an exclusively Germanic formation, but one might consider a root *bʰeg- : *bʰog- '(sich) biegen, wölben' and in this case consider is applied to the parts of the human or animal body.

Cf. s.v. OHG blah-, only attested in compounds blah-faro 'tintenfarben, tiefblau', blah-mâl 'Niello-Verzierung', blah-mâlôn 'Niello-Verzierung versehen', etc., from Germanic *ƀlaka- 'schwarz; Tinte', almost completely lost in High German; perhaps to be connected with blecken and blanc to the IE root *bʰelg- : *bʰleg- 'glänzen', but because of the semantic chasm between 'glänzend, weiß' and 'schwarz' the immediate derivation from this root is doubtful.
Cf. s.v. OHG âtum 'Atem, Hauch', from Proto-Germanic *ǣđma-, related to Ved. ātmā́- 'Hauch, Seele, Selbst' from PIE *ētmē̆n-/mō̆n-.
Cf. s.v. NHG Atem, (MHG ātem, OHG ātum, OS āđom < West Germanic *ǣd(u)ma-). From PIE ētmó- ‛Atem’, also in Ved. ātmā́ ‛Hauch, Seele’ (n-stem) and perhaps OIr. athach f. ‛Hauch, Wind’.

S.v. OHG brinnan, prinnan 'brennen, verbrennen, entbrennen, glühen, leuchten'. The verb has no secure etymology; firstly there is no formally corresponding IE root in a similar meaning, and secondly the forms in -nn- in contrast to those in -n- in OE bryne, 'Feuer, Glut', OIc. bruni 'Brand' are in need of an explanation. Cf. entry in EWA 2 for discussion and extensive references to further literature.

S.v. OHG bodam 'Boden, Grund, Schiffsboden, -kiel, -deck'. Comparisons outside of Germanic including Ved. budhná- 'Grund, Boden', Gk. πυθμήν 'Boden, Fuß eines Gefäßes' point to an IE proto-form *bʰudʰ-m(e)n(o)-. Attempts to analyse the root *bʰudʰ- as a metathesis of the root *dʰeu̯b-, *dʰeu̯p- 'tief' (cf. OHG tiof) remain purely speculative.
S.v. OHG fehtan 'kämpfen, fechten, ringen, streiten'. The verb is based on a t-extension of PIE *pek̑- '(Wolle oder Haare) rupfen, zausen' (cf. Lat. plectō 'flechte', Gk. πέκτειν 'scheren').
Cf. s.v. OHG kampf '(Einzel-)Kampf, Zweikampf', borrowing from from Lat. campus 'Feld' in sense 'Kampfplatz'.

Cf. s.v. OHG brant, prant 'Brennen, Verbrennen, Brand(legung); brennendes Holzscheit, Feuerbrand'; derived from Gmc. *brennen- (*brinnan-), for which cf. s.v. OHG brinnan, prinnan 'brennen, verbrennen, entbrennen, glühen, leuchten'. The verb has no secure etymology; firstly there is no formally corresponding IE root in a similar meaning, and secondly the forms in -nn- in contrast to those in -n- in OE bryne, 'Feuer, Glut', OIc. bruni 'Brand' are in need of an explanation. Cf. entry in EWA 2 for discussion and extensive references to further literature.
