S.v. NHG grün (MHG grüene, OHG gruoni, OS grōni) from Gmc. *grō-ni- adj. 'grün', also in ON grœnn, OE grēne. Derived with a *-ni- suffix to Gmc. *grō-a- 'wachsen'.
S.v. Gmc. *grōni- 'grün', a verbal adjective to the verb *grōa- 'wachsen'.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *grō-a- 'wachsen'. No clear cognates outside of Germanic.

A verbal adjective from the strong verb *grōan- 'grow', cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:260-261, {ref Kluge 2011}:378, {ref Kroonen 2013}:191-192. Extra-Germanic connections unclear, but perhaps further connected to Lat. grāmen 'grass', but the latter may also be connected with IE *gras- 'fressen' (cf. discussion in /cognate/8369/, and in {ref Seebold 1970}:242-243, {ref Kroonen 2013}:191-192.
S.v. NHG Eingeweide, clarification of MHG geweide. A formation to IE *u̯eiə- 'winden'.

S.v. Engl. gut (coll. pl. 'the contents of the abdominal cavity; the bowels, entrails'). from Old English guttas. "[T]he vowel seems to point to a prehistoric type *guttu- ( < pre-Germanic *ghudnú- ), < the root of Gothic giutan , Old High German gioȥȥan (Gothic gieszen ), Old English géotan to pour"

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *gut(t)ōn- 'to pour; to spawn' < *g̑ʰu-t-neh₂-, to which Old English guttas m.pl. 'guts' is probably to be connected. Possibly a *-t- extended root *g̑ʰeu̯t- if to be connected with Hitt. kūtt- 'wall' < *g̑ʰeu̯-t- (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:498).

S.v. Goth. T1. tagl 'θρίξ', 'hair' (cf. OI tagl 'tail', OE tæg(e)l 'tail', MLG tagel 'rope's end' OHG zagel 'tail'). From PIE *dē̆k-, cf. OIr. dūal 'lock of hair' < *doklo-, possibly Skt. dásā 'fringe of a garment', but cf. {ref KEWA} II:27, [{ref EWAia} I:710] where the Indic correspondence is considered uncertain.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *tagla- 'hair'. Possible comparisons outside of Germanic (cf. Skt. daśā 'fringe' < *dek̑-eh₂-, OIr. dúal 'tuft, plait' < *dok̑-lo-(?) and SCr. dlàka 'single hair' < *dok̑-leh₂- (with depalatalisation and metathesis), but it may also be an inner-Germanic derivation as a diminutive *dHk-ló- to the root of *tahjan- 'tear, unravel', or to *tōgan- ~ *takkan- 'prickle, branch'.

S.v. Goth. T1. tagl 'θρίξ', 'hair' (cf. OI tagl 'tail', OE tæg(e)l 'tail', MLG tagel 'rope's end' OHG zagel 'tail'). From PIE *dē̆k-, cf. OIr. dūal 'lock of hair' < *doklo-, possibly Skt. dásā 'fringe of a garment', but cf. {ref KEWA} II:27, [{ref EWAia} I:710] where the Indic correspondence is considered uncertain.
S.v. Engl. tail, from Old English tægel , tægl , = ON tagl 'a horse's tail', OHG zagel, MHG zagel 'tail of animal', etc.; Goth. tagl 'hair (of the head, of the camel)'. Further etymology uncertain.

S.v. NHG Kopf (MHG kopf 'Trinkgefaß, Hirnschale', OHG kopf, kupf 'Becher', MLG kop), just as OE cuppe 'Becher', ON koppr 'Geschirr in Becherform, kleines Schiff' an early loan from Lat. cūpa, cuppa 'Becher'. For the semantics, cf. similarly the development of Fr. tête < Lat. testa 'aus Ton gebranntes Gefäß, Scherbe' which replaced the inherited form from Lat. caput 'head'.
S.v. Lat. testa 'coquille (= ὄστρακον), carapace (de tortue)', for the semantic development of Fr. tête, cf. similarly Germ. Kopf, as a loanword from Lat. cuppa.

S.v. Goth. H52. hausjan 'ἀκούειν', 'hear', from PIE *(s)keu̯-s- 'note, perceive, hear' (cf. Skt. kaví- 'wise; seer', Gk. κοέω 'note', ἀκούω 'hear'); others have attempted to analyse Gk. ἀκούω < *ak-ous-yō 'I hear distinctly', although this is less likely than a derivation from *keu̯-.

S.v. Gk. ἀκούω. Generally two explanations have been considered for an etymology: Either (1) as a compound *ἀκ-ουσ-i̯ω 'to extend the ear' or (2) to be connected with Goth. hausjan 'entendre', in which ἀ- may be the zero-grade of *en- 'dans'; for the forms without the prothesis, cf. κοέω 'entendre, comprendre'. The second explanation is the one generally given [at the time of this lexicon's composition].

The cognacy of the Greek and Germanic forms is generally agreed, but the derivation of the forms from a common IE proto-form is disputed. An explanation from a compound stem *h₂k-h₂ou̯s-i̯e- 'is sharp-eared' is commonly considered (cf. {ref Ringe 2006}:71), but this analysis remains uncertain (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:55). For references to older literature, cf. {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:50-51; {ref Lehmann 1986}:180-181.
S.v. Gmc. *swǣra- 'gewichtig', a lengthened-grade formation, beside the primary verb attested by Lith. sver̃ti 'wägen'.

Cf. s.v. Lith. sver̃ti 'wägen, abwägen; wiegen, Gewicht haben', cf. Goth. swers (adj.) 'geschätzt, ehrenvoll', ON svárr 'schwer', OHG swār 'id.'. The Baltic and Germanic correspondences could go back to a PIE root *su̯er(H)- 'wiegen'.
S.v. NHG treffen (MHG treffen, OHG treffan, OS -drepan), from Germ. *drep-a- 'schlagen' also in ON drepa, OE drepan. No clear comparanda outside of Germanic.
S.v. PGmc. *drep-a- 'schlagen', no suitable comparisons outside of Germanic.

S.v. PGmc. *haww-a- 'hauen', going back with certainty to the verbal root *qou- 'hauen, schlagen' (cf. Lith. káuju, káuti 'schlagen, hauen, umbringen', OCS kovǫ, kovati 'schmieden, verfertigen', TochB kau- 'töten').
S.v. NHG hauen (MHG houwen, OHG houwan, OS hauwan), from Gmc. *haww-a-, from PIE *kowə- 'hauen, schlagen' (cf. Lith. káuti 'schlagen, hauen, umbringen', OCS kovati 'schmieden', TochB kau- 'töten').
S.v. Roman. vâna, from Lat. *venare (= venari).
S.v. NHG jagen (MHG jagen, OHG jagōn, MLG jagen). Etymology uncertain.
S.v. ON jaga 'jagen, treiben', a (semantic?) borrowing from MLG jagen.
S.v. Goth. *fra-hinϸan 'αἰχμαλωτίζειν', 'take captive'. (cf. OSw. hinna, hanna 'reach', OE hentan 'pursue', huntian 'hunt', hunta 'hunter'. No accepted etymology outside of Germanic.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *dau-ja- 'sterben', belonging to isolated words from *dʰeu̯-, meaning 'die' and similar things. This probably goes back to *dʰeu̯(ə)- 'rauchen, stieben', whose meaning presumably developed from 'atmen, hauchen' (cf. Lith. dvė̃sti 'verenden' beside dvėsúoti 'schwer atmen, keuchen').
S.v. ON deyða 'töten', to Goth. dauþjan, OE ādīedan, dȳdan, OFr. dēda, OS bidōdan, MLG doden, OHG tōten (cf. ON dauðr = Goth. dauþus, OE dēað, OFr. dāth, OS dōð, OHG tōd).

The IE root etymology of PGmc. *daujan- given here follows {ref LIV²} to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:90-91 (but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. {ref LIV²} 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of {ref Kluge 2011}:919 s.v. Tod).

Cf. s.v. NHG tot (adj.) (MHG tōt, OHG tōt, OS dōd) from Gmc. *dauda- 'tot', also in Goth. dauϸs, ΟΝ dauðr, OE dēad. The NHG verb töten was historically derived from the adjective. For the etymology given, cf. s.v. NHG Tod 'death', a verbal abstract to G. *dau-ja- 'die' to which may be compared Gk. ἀποθνῄσκω < *dʰu̯enh₂- and perhaps Lat. fūnus.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *dau-ja- 'sterben', belonging to isolated words from *dʰeu̯-, meaning 'die' and similar things. This probably goes back to *dʰeu̯(ə)- 'rauchen, stieben', whose meaning presumably developed from 'atmen, hauchen' (cf. Lith. dvė̃sti 'verenden' beside dvėsúoti 'schwer atmen, keuchen').

The IE root etymology of PGmc. *daujan- given here follows {ref LIV²} to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:90-91 (but cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. {ref LIV²} 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. {ref Seebold 1970}:147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of {ref Kluge 2011}:919 s.v. Tod).
S.v. PGmc. *drep-a- 'schlagen', no suitable comparisons outside of Germanic.
Cf. s.v. NHG treffen (MHG treffen, OHG treffan, OS -drepan), from Germ. *drep-a- 'schlagen' also in ON drepa, OE drepan. No clear comparanda outside of Germanic.

S.v. ON drepa 'schlagen, stossen; töten' (within Germanic cf. Ic., Far., Nw. drepa, Sw. dräpa, Da. dræbe, OE, OS drepan, MLG drepen, OHG treffan; outside Germanic cf. drobiti 'entzweireissen' [IEW 272-273]).

S.v. ON drepa 'schlagen, stossen; töten' (within Germanic cf. Ic., Far., Nw. drepa, Sw. dräpa, Da. dræbe, OE, OS drepan, MLG drepen, OHG treffan; outside Germanic cf. drobiti 'entzweireissen' [IEW 272-273]).

Cf. s.v. NHG umbringen 'um etwas bringen'. The modern meaning has been simplified from 'ums Leben bringen'. For NHG bringen < PGmc. *breng-a- (cf. Goth. briggan, OE bringan), the root may be compared with Welsh hebrwng, hebryngaf 'führen, bringen' and perhaps TochAB pränk- 'sich zurückhalten' to IE *bʰrenk-, and if so may be a root contamination of IE *bʰer- 'tragen' and *(e)nek- 'erreichen'. Both of these roots are suppletive in Greek so this assumption seems reasonable.

Cf. s.v. PGmc. *breng-a- 'bringen', generally assumed since Karl Brugmann (IF 12 1901, 150-158) to be contamination of the roots *bʰer- 'tragen' and *(e)nek̑- 'erreichen'. Since both of these verbs are suppletive in Greek this assumption seems reasonable. Otherwise still unclear. Cf. perhaps W. hebrwng 'führen, bringen' perhaps from *sem-bhronk-, TochB pränk- 'sich zurückhalten'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *bringan- 'to bring'. A verb of obscure origin. Perhaps to be analysed as a conflation of *bʰer- 'to carry' and *h₂enk̑- 'to arrive'. Alternatively one may analyse the perfective ga-bringan as a remodelling of *kom-pro-h₁énk̑- (cf. OIr. ro-ic W rynghu 'to meet' < *pro-h₁(e)nk̑-) with the initial *b < *p explained by Verner's Law.

S.v. Gmc. *hlah-ja- 'lachen'. No precise comparanda. It belongs to a group of onomatopoeic words with the meaning 'cackle, chortle', etc. with the phonetic form tectal + l + vowel + tectal; cf. Lat. glōciō, Lith. klagė́ti, klukšė́ti, Gk. κλώσσω, etc.

S.v. Goth. H70. *hlahjan 'laugh', from PIE *kel- 'shout, call' as in Gk. καλέω, (IEW 548-50) + -eH-g- as in Gk. κλώζω 'croak', κλωγμός 'signal to a horse', κλάζω 'cry out', Lith. klegė́ti 'cackle', Latv. kladzêt 'chatter'; with nasal infix Gk. κλαγγή 'clang', Lat. clangō 'cry', clangor 'noise'. Individual forms influenced by onomatopoeia.
S.v. Sw. skratta, an intensive formation to skrata, of onomatopoeic origin, cf. Sw. dial. skrata 'scare, chase away', Nw. dial. skrata 'cackle (of birds)', Da. dial. skrade 'make a loud noise', etc.
Cf. s.v. *bʰleh₃- 'blühen' (IEW 122).

S.v. Gk. φύλλον 'feuille (d'arbre ou de plante)'. The old word for 'leaf', to be connected with Lat. folium with an o-grade to a root *bhel-. In several IE languages (Germanic, Celtic, and Tocharian) there are diverse forms showing a dental (cf. Germ. Blatt).

S.v. NHG Bein (MHG bein, OHG bein, OS bēn), from Gmc. *baina- 'Knochen', also in ON bein, OE bān, OFr. bēn. A word with this meaning is not attested in Gothic. A Germanic replacement for the IE inherited word for 'bone' (cf. Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc.). The etymology of this new word is unclear.

S.v. Gmc. *bōww-a- 'wohnen, breiten', cf. for discussion of older literature. Generally agreed to be derived from PIE *bʰeu̯ə- 'werden, wachsen, sein' (cf. OCS iz-baviti 'retten, befreien, erlösen', Ved. bhāvayati 'bringt ins Dasein', a regularly formed causative stem).

S.v. Gmc. *-leib-a- '(bleiben)', to be connected with the IE root *lei̯p- 'kleben, schmieren' (cf. Lith. limpù, lìpti 'kleben, klebrig sein, ansteckend sein', OCS pri-lьpljǫ, -iti 'kleben'. Less certain are connections to Gk. formations, e.g. λίπτω 'begehre'; ἀλείφω 'einölen, salben'; λίπα 'fett, glänzend'. Cf. also Ved. limpáti 'beschmieren, salben', TochB lip-, lyip- 'übrig bleiben').

S.v. NHG Leber (MHG leber(e), OHG lebara, lebera, MLG, MNL lever(e), from Germanic *librō(n), also in ON lifr, OE lifer, OFr. livere. The word perhaps originally meant 'the fat', maybe actually 'the fattened liver', cf. It. fegato 'liver' < Lat. iecur fīcātum 'fattened liver', and in this case one might compare Gk. λιπαρός 'fat' to λίπος 'fat, oil, unguent'. Alternatively it is not to be fully ruled out that the word continues the Indo-European word for 'liver' *i̯ekʷr (cf. Lat. iecur, etc) with some irregular phonological alteration (cf. e.g. the initial l- in Armenian, if the Armenian word also belongs to this word family).

S.v. karl 'mann', esp. 'alter mann' (cf. OHG karl 'mann, ehemann', OE ceorl 'freier mann der niederigsten klasse'), outside Germanic cf. Gk. γέρων 'greis', Ved. jarati 'lässt altern', OCS žirěti 'reifen', Arm. cer 'greis' (IEW 390).

Cf. s.v. Goth. T36. *tungl 'star, constellation'. Only dat.pl. tugglam as a gloss to (uf) stabim (ϸis fairƕaus) / (ὑπὸ) τὰ στοιχεῖα (τοῦ κόσμου). Cf. OI tungl 'moon', himin-tungl 'constellation', etc. No etymology. Older proposals to Lith. dangùs, OPr. dangus 'sky, heaven', Lith. deñgti 'cover' unsatisfactory.

Cf. s.v. mær (2) adj. 'schmal, schlank' (also mjár, mjór) < Proto-North-Germanic *maiwaR. This exclusively North Germanic word can be connected to the IE root *mi 'klein sein', cf. Lith. maĩlius 'kleinigkeit', OCS mẽlukŭ 'klein', Gk. μείων 'geringer'.
S.v. Gmc. *smala- 'klein'. The adjective has no precise correspondence outside of Germanic. Cf. entry for various uncertain proposals.

According to Heidermanns (1993:517) the Proto-Germanic adjective meant 'small', while the meaning 'narrow, thin' is a West Germanic development. If so, is the meaning 'narrow' here in Danish and Swedish a semantic calque from West Germanic?

S.v. Gmc. *narwa- '(eingeschürt)'. If the original meaning is correctly means 'constricted', then we may compare some Baltic lexemes: Lith. nérti 'einfädeln, einrenken, schlingen', Latv. nẽrt 'die Spitze des Bastschuhs zusammenziehen', Lith. nãras 'Schlinge', etc.
Cf. s.v. OLith. *nérti (II) '(Faden, Schnur) durch eine Öffnung ziehen, einfädeln', where the proposed comparison with OE nearu, OS naru, 'eng' is strongly rejected ("unbedenklich").

Cf. s.v. Goth. Ϸ53. *ϸreihan 'θλίβειν', 'press, throng, crush', from PIE *trenk- 'push, press on', cf. Av. θracta- 'hemmed in (in the line of battle)', Lat. truncus 'maimed, mutilated', Lith. treñkti 'push roughly', etc.
S.v. Gmc. *ϸeku- 'dick', an inherited adjective identical with the u-adjective in OIr. tiug, W tew 'dick, dicht' < Western Indo-European *tegu-, further connections are unclear.

S.v. Gmc. *ϸenht- 'dicht, fest'. The adjective an exact correspondence in OIr. técht 'dick, zähflüssig, gefroren' < *ténk-t- and is root-cognate with Lith. tánkus 'dicht', Av. taxma- (Slv. tančista-) 'dicht, fest, kompakt', as well as Goth. ϸaho 'Ton, Lehm'. The basis is the primary verb *tenk-, attested in Ved. ā-tanákti 'läßt gerinnen', OIr. con·téici 'erstarrt'.

S.v. NHG Nacken (MHG nac (nackes), nacke, OHG nac, nacko 'Hinterhaupt, Nacken', from Gmc. *hnakka-/ōn 'Hinterhaupt, Nacken' also in ON hnakkr, hnakki and with Ablaut in MLG necke, nec, OFr. hnekka, OE hnecca. Outside of Germanic with differing vocalism cf. OIr. cnocc, MW cnwch 'Buckel, Hügel', TochA kñuk 'Hals, Nacken'. Further origins unclear.
S.v. ON svíri 'hals, nacken; drachenhals am schiff'. Contains references to older proposed etymologies to Ved. svaru- 'opferposten', Gk. ἕρμα 'pfahl', Lat. sūrus, surculus 'zweig'.

Cf. s.v. Engl. swire 'the neck' (obs.). "Old English swéora, swíora, Northumbrian and late West Saxon swíra, late West Saxon swýra, swúra weak masculine < Germanic *swerhan-, related to Old Norse svíri neck, beak of a ship, local name of a neck-shaped ridge in Iceland < *swerhjan-; ulterior relations uncertain."
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *swerx(j)ōn, proposing cognacy to Alb. z-verk 'occiput'.
S.v. ON nef 'nasenbein, nase' < Proto-North-Germanic *nafja-. [No extra-Germanic cognates listed.]

S.v. Gmc. *alda- 'alt', an inherited formation identical with Gk. (Hom.) ἄν-αλτος 'unersättlich', just as Lat. altus 'hoch, tief', adultus 'erwachsen'. The verbal basis is attested in Lat. alō, OIr. ailid, Gmc. *ala- 'nähren, aufziehen'.
S.v. ON gamall 'alt'. The explanation is uncertain; cf. entry for a survey of older proposals.

S.v. Gmc. *laik-a- 'spielen'. There are some connections of differing value: cf. OIr. lingid 'springt', Lith. láigau, -yti 'mutwillig sein, wild herumlaufen, herumtollen', Gk. ἐλελίζω (aor. ἐλέλιξαι) 'erschüttere, drehe herum, drehe mich', Ved. réjate 'erschüttert, zittert'.

Cf. s.v. NHG Spiel (MHD spil, OHG spil, MLG spel(e), spil, spol(e), MDu. spel), to which the verb MHG spil(e)n, OHG spilōn. The original meaning seems to be 'Tanz', 'tanzen'; everything else is unclear.
S.v. Gmc. *(-)leuk-a- 'rupfen' (cf. OE lūcan, OFr. lūka 'ziehen', OHG -liohan). There are only uncertain comparisons outside of Germanic.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *trek(k)an- 'to pull', from PIE *drég⁽ʰ⁾-e- (cf. Lith. dìrginti 'to pull (the trigger)' < *drg-neh₂-; OCS drъgati 'to shudder', Ru. dērgat' 'to jerk' < *drg⁽ʰ⁾-eh₂-, etc.).
S.v. Da. trække, a borrowing from Middle Low German trecken.
Cf. s.v. NHG drücken (MHG drücken, drucken, OHG thruken, drucchen, drucken), from West Germanic *ϸrukk-ja-, also in OE ϸryccan, an intensive formation to Gmc. *ϸrūg- (cf. ON ϸrúga- 'drücken').

Cf. s.v. OHG liochan 'zupfen, rupfen', going back to a Proto-Germanic stem *leu̯ke/a- with no precise correspondences, but in different ablaut grade related to MLG lūken 'ziehen, zupfen', OFries. lūka, NWFries. luke, Saterfries. luke 'ziehen', MEngl. louken, louke, going back to PGmc. *lūka-. Proto-Germanic *leu̯ka- and *lūka- (with secondary lengthened grade) are both secondary developments from the PIE root *leu̯g- 'lösen, brechen' (cf. Ved. rujáti 'zerbricht, bricht auf', Arm. lowci 'machte los, löste'; more doubtful are the connections to Palaic luki(ye)- 'teilen', and Lat. lugēre 'trauern' < ?*lug-ēh₁- with unexpected zero-grade).
Cf. s.v. 1. *leu̯g- 'lösen, brechen' (IEW 686).

S.v. OHG drucken '(nieder)drücken, pressen, bedrücken, quälen, bedrängen, untertänig machen' from Proto-Germanic *ϸrukk(i)jan-, an intensive formation from Pre-Proto-Germanic *trūk-, possibly an enlargement of the IE root *terh₁-, which may be compared with Lith. trū́kti 'entzweireißen, bersten, einen Bruch bekommen'.

Cf. s.v. Lith. tráukti 'ziehen, schleppen', for which there are no clear connections outside of Lithuanian. the proposed comparison with ON ϸruga- 'drohen', OHG drucken 'drücken' etc. could go back to a common PIE root *treu̯Hk- ~ 'gewaltsam in Bewegung setzen(?)', but this would be structurally striking and still required to be more precisely semantically determined.

Cf. s.v. OHG folc 'Volk, Volksstamm, Bevölkerung, Menge, SChar, Volksmenge, Kohorte, Heer', with correspondences in all Germanic languages from Proto-Germanic *fulka-, from Pre-Proto-Germanic *pl̥̄-go- < plh₁-go-, a derivation with the IE suffix *-go- to the root *pelh₁- 'sich füllen, voll werden'.

S.v. OFr. folk 'people, crowd, army', from PGmc. *fulka-, possibly to PIE *plh₁-go- ? (cf. IEW 799) if to be connected with Albanian plok, plogu 'crowd' < *pleh₁-g-. Elsewhere the root *plh₁- is used to denote a crowd of people in Lat. plēbēs < *plh₁-dʰueh₁-, Gk. πληθύς < *pleh₁-dʰuh₁-s. Given that the Alb. is doubtful and the Gk. and Lat. formations represent another formation, this etymology has been doubted by de Vries (1992 s.v.).

S.v. OHG hals 'Hals, Nacken; cervix, collum', from Proto-Germanic *χalsa- and generally connected with Lat. collum 'Hals'. The IE root etymology is difficult to ascertain; the most attractive candidate semantically is *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen' (> *kʷolso-), however the necessary delabialisation of the labiovelar would be irregular. Alternatively one could propose PIE *kolH-so- to PIE *kelH- 'aufragen, hochragen'.

Cf. s.v. OFris. muth 'mouth, [fig.] opening, wound', from Proto-Germanic *munϸa-. No certain IE etymology. The word is generally believed to be IE; there are several possible derivations, but none are generally agreed. Cf. entry for further discussion and extensive references to further literature.

S.v. OHG flioga 'Fliege' and vb. fliogan 'fliegen', going back to a pre-Proto-Germanic root *pleu̯k-, also found in Baltic *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (Lith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, durch die Luft dahinfahren', etc., whose root also is to be connected to words for 'Haar, Flocke, Feder'. (cf. Lith. pláukas 'Haar, (Haar-)Farbe, Art, Gattung', Lith. plùnksna 'Feder', and probably also Lat. plūma 'Flaumfeder, Flaum'. This root is generally considered to be an enlargement of the IE root *pleu̯- with various meanings.
S.v. NHG Flügel (MHG vlügel, MLG vlogel, MDu. vleughel), as with ON flygill, an recent instrumental formation in -ila- to fliegen 'to fly'.

S.v. OHG fogal 'Vogel'. The most probable etymology is from a Proto-Germanic original form *flugla- with a -la- suffix, in which the first resonant was dissimilated, and connected to Pre-Proto-Germanic *pleuk-e/o- 'schweben, schwimmen', to the -k- enlarged root *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (to more widespread attested *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben').

S.v. OHG fliogan 'fliegen', going back to a pre-Proto-Germanic root *pleu̯k-, also found in Baltic *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (Lith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, durch die Luft dahinfahren', etc., whose root also is to be connected to words for 'Haar, Flocke, Feder'. (cf. Lith. pláukas 'Haar, (Haar-)Farbe, Art, Gattung', Lith. plùnksna 'Feder', and probably also Lat. plūma 'Flaumfeder, Flaum'. This root is generally considered to be an enlargement of the IE root *pleu̯- with various meanings.

Cf. s.v. OHG fliogan 'fliegen', going back to a pre-Proto-Germanic root *pleu̯k-, also found in Baltic *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (Lith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, durch die Luft dahinfahren', etc., whose root also is to be connected to words for 'Haar, Flocke, Feder'. (cf. Lith. pláukas 'Haar, (Haar-)Farbe, Art, Gattung', Lith. plùnksna 'Feder', and probably also Lat. plūma 'Flaumfeder, Flaum'. This root is generally considered to be an enlargement of the IE root *pleu̯- with various meanings.

S.v. OHG busc, bosc 'Busch, Strauch, Gebüsch, Brombeerbuch, frutex, silva, rubus'. In earlier literature the Germanic words words were considered to be a loanword from Medieval Latin buscus, boscus 'Wald, Gebüsch', but given that there is no satisfactory etymology for these Latin forms, more recent literature considers the forms to be inherited in Germanic. The Proto-Germanic form would be *ƀuskaz (maybe with a variant with long *-ū-) and is normally related to PIE *bʰeu̯-, bʰū- 'to inflate, to swell/to grow', either with an PIE -s- extension and then Germanic -k-extension, or with an -sk-extension as found e.g. in OHG frosc 'frog'. The semantic development is assumed to have been 'swelling' > 'voluptous, sumptous, ample' > 'ample growth of plants'. With Th. Braune 1912, EWA assumes that the Romance lexemes in /cognate/347/ are loans from Germanic.

S.v. NHG Busch (MHG busch, bosch(e), OHG busc, bosc, OS *(brāmal-)busc, from *buski-, *buskōn-. The word has no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. Medieval Latin boscus with Fr. bois, It. bosco, has no earlier origins in Classical Latin. Perhaps there was a common borrowing from a third source; there is no known corresponding word in Celtic.

S.v. A kñuk 'cou, nuque' For this term we may connect either IE *gneug- with OIc. knjūkr 'cime d'une montagne', MHG knock 'nuque' or with IE *qnequ̯- with OE hnecca, OIc. hnakki 'nuque', or with IE *qneug- with OIc. hnūka 'se tenir accroupi, s'accroupir', Mod. Ic. knjūkr 'cime de montagne ronde', etc.For these three interpretations cf. Van Windekens, Orbis 11 (1962) 506. In any of these cases TochA kñuk may have a common etymon with Germanic.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- ~ *hnakka(n)- 'neck'. "In view of the close formal and semantic similarities to To. kñuk, it seems possible to reconstruct a PIE n-stem *knék-ōn, gen. kn̥k-n-ós, acc. *knok-n-ń̥s (cf. Kroonen 2011:167ff.). The regular outcome of this paradigm, viz. *hnehō, *hunkkaz, *hnakkuns was apparently remodelled into *hnekkō, *knukkaz, *hnakkuns. […] [I]t is possible that G Hunke 'hillock' is a vestige of the original genitive form. It is therefore likely that OIr. cnoc, W cnwch m. 'hill' was borrowed from Germanic rather than the other way around."
S.v. NHG Regen (MHG regen, OHG regan, OS regan-, regin) from Gmc. *regna- m./n. 'Regen', also in Goth. rign, ON regn, OE regn, rēn, OFr. rein. Origin unclear.
S.v. Goth. R20. rign 'βροχή', 'rain'. Etymology unclear; cf. entry for various uncertain proposals.

S.v. Goth. R5. *raihts 'εὐθύς', 'straight' with derived stem ga-raihts 'δίκαιος', 'just, righteous', from PIE *reg̑-, *rek̑-to/u- (cf. OPers. rāsta-, 'straight (way)'; Lat. rēctus 'straight, upright', OIr. recht 'law, authority', etc.).

S.v. Gmc. *swenϸa- 'kräftig'. Not to be connected with an IE root *su̯ent-/*su̯n̥t-, rather with Seebold to be derived from a stem *sg̑ʰ-u- to the root *seg̑ʰ- 'festhalten; (im Kampf) überwältigen' (cf. Ved. kṣu- 'Macht', Gk. ἰσχύς 'Kraft, Stärke, Macht'; cf. r/n stem in OIr. sáhuri 'gewaltig, überlegen', Gk. ἐχυρός 'haltbar, fest, sicher' based on *ség̑ʰu̯r̥; Sogd. xšawan- 'Macht', Gk. σθένος 'Kraft, Stärke, Macht' based on oblique stem *sg̑ʰu̯én-).

Cf. s.v. Goth. S188. *swinϸs 'ἰσχυρός', 'strong'. No satisfactory etymology; may be restricted to Germanic. Hardly to Skt. suváti 'set in motion', Lith. siunčiù; cf. {ref IEW 1048} reconstructing *su̯ento-, *sunto-.

S.v. Gmc. *hōgi- 'geschickt; leicht, bequem'. Only attested in North Germanic; outside of Germanic [s.v. (-)haga- 'geschickt, gefällig'; cf. OIc. hagr; hagliga; hagari; hagastr 'geschickt, gewandt, kunstfertig' MHG behac, behage 'wohlgefällig'] the verbal root is most clear in Ved. śaknóti 'kann, vermag, ist imstande'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √śak- 'können, vermögen, im Stande sein'; possibly from IE *k̑Ek-, if connected with OIr. cēcht 'Macht' and possibly ("möglicherweise") also with OE on-hagian 'passen', NHG behagen'.

S.v. OHG felis 'Felsen, Teil eines Berges, Felsabhang, Felsbrocken, Stein'. Comparisons outside of Germanic are Ved. pāṣāṇá- 'Stein' < *parṣ- < PIE *pels-, cf. Gk. πέλλα· λίθος (Hesych.) < *πελσα, OIr. ail- < *pali-k- < PIE pl̥-i-?, etc. These forms establish IE *pel(i)s- : *pol(i)s, *pl̥(i)s-.

S.v. OHG fleisc 'Fleisch, Fleischstück'. The word has correspondences in all Germanic languages except Gothic; from Proto-Germanic *flajska-. The gender is consistently neuter. Secure connections outside of Germanic are lacking. Occasionally compared to the verbal root in Lith. plė́šiu (plė́šti) '(ab-)reißen, abschälen' and the Germanic strong verb *flaχan- (OIc. flá, OE flēan, MDu. vlaen 'schinden').

S.v. OHG lebara 'Leber; iecur', from Proto-Germanic *liƀ(a)rō⁽ⁿ⁾, a substantive in *-ō(n)- *'die Fett(ig)e' from an adjective *liƀ(a)ra- 'fett(ig)' no longer attested in the Germanic languages < PIE *lip-ró- 'fettig, schmierig', in turn a zero-grade *-ro- formation to the verbal root *lei̯p- 'kleben bleiben; klebrig, schmierig sein' which is also continued in OHG bilîban and leiben'.

S.v. OHG *lenc only as substantive f. 'die Linke, linke Hand', from Proto-Germanic *(s)lenka-, whose original meaning was probably 'clumsy, unskillful'. Proto-Germanic *(s)lenka- goes back to Pre-Proto-Germanic/PIE *(s)lengo-. The connection with extra-Germanic lexical material is difficult. Perhaps to post-Vedic Sanskrit laṅga- 'lahm', m. 'Lahmheit', Lat. languēre 'matt sein', Gk. λαγγάζω 'lasse nach, erschlaffe', λαγαρός 'matt'. Cf. entry for extensive discussion of the further literature and difficulties of connecting the Germanic material.

S.v. OHG loub 'Pflanzenblatt, Laubblatt, Laub, belaubter Zweig, Laubwerk, Blätterdach, Laubkrone, Laubwald; folium, frons, nemus, ramus, silva', from Proto-Germanic *lau̯ƀa- n., a denominal derivation in collective function to Proto-Germanic *lau̯ƀa- m. 'Blatt', only continued in Goth. laufs* 'Blatt'. The basis of Proto-Germanic *lau̯ƀa- m. 'Blatt' is probably a substantivisation of a Pre-Proto-Germanic adjective *lou̯p-ó- to the verbal root *leu̯p- 'abschälen', whose present formation is found in Lith. lùpti '(ab)schälen, abhäuten, schinden, herausreißen, herausgraben', Latv. lupt 'schälen, kahl machen'. Less probable is a connection to the IE root *leu̯bʰ- 'entrinden, abreißen'.
Cf. s.v. ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'tröpfeln' (IEW 657), only Germanic and Celtic.

S.v. OHG jagôn 'jagen, (an-)treiben, verfolgen, hetzen, vertreiben, in die Flucht schlagen'. As with other words attested in continental west Germanic with initial j-, the etymology of OHG jagôn is unclear. All previous attempts are not persuasive. Cf. entry for discussion of five different proposals.

S.v. OHG hûs 'Haus, Gebäude, Hütte, Zelt, Wohnung, Behausung, Unterkunft, Heim(statt), Hauswesen, Familie, Geschlecht', from Proto-Germanic χūsa-. There are two equally possible possibilities for a further etymology: (1) a derivation from a pre-form *kuHso- 'Schutz(ort)', a derivation from the IE verbal root *(s)keu̯H- 'bedecken', alternatively it may be (2) from Pre-Proto-Germanic *kudʰso- to the IE verbal root *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen'.

Cf. s.v. OHG heiz 'heiß, glühend, etc.', to OHG hei ?, from Proto-Germanic *χai̯(i̯)a-, a term isolated from other IE languages. Perhaps comparable to Lith. kaĩsti 'heiß machen, erhitzen', Latv. kàitêt 'sengen, heiß machen', OPr. enkaitītai 'angefochten'. Such a root *kei̯- would be otherwise isolated among the IE languages.
S.v. ON elfr 'fluss', probably to Lat. albus, Gk. ἀλφός 'white'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *ahwõ- 'river', from PIE *h₂ekʷ-eh₂-. A Germanic-Italic isogloss (cf. Lat. aqua 'water'). "The word is claimed to stem from a non-IE language ({ref Beekes 1998}), but it is more likely to be a formal variant of Hitt. ḫapa- c. 'river', Skt. áp-, OAv. ap- f. 'water' < *h₂ep-, Lat. amnis f. 'stream, river' < *h₂ep-ni- and OIr. ab, aub f. W afon f. 'river' < *h₂epHon- (with *-pH- > *b) as in Skt. píbati 'to drink' < PIE *pi-ph₃-é-). Perhaps the cluster *-pH- developed into *-kʷ- in Germanic and Latin."

Cf. s.v. Osc. aapam [acc.sg.], aapas [gen.sg. or acc.pl] 'water', 'water basin' vel sim. "In theory, O. -p- could correspond with -qu- in Lat. aqua 'water'; but in view of long initial /ā-/ in Oscan, it seems preferable to derive it from PIE *h₂ē̆p- 'water' as attested in IIr., Baltic and Tocharian." and s.v. Lat. aqua 'water', from Proto-Italic *akwā- 'water' (cf. Goth. aƕa, OHG aha < PGmc. *aχʷō 'water'). "According to {ref Beekes 1998}, other suggested cognates, such as OIc. ægir 'sea, ocean' are very uncertain. Even if cognate, Germano-Italic *akwā- may well be a loanword from a non-IE language."

S.v. OHG aha 'Wasser(lauf), Fluß, Strom'. Outside of Germanic only the Italic cognates (Lat. aqua) are unobjectionable. < *akʷā < *h₂ekʷeh₂. Less certain are further connections to river names in Baltic and Slavic, and the word for 'river' in Celtic (W afon, Gaulish -apa) and Anatolian (Hitt. ḫapa-).

Cf. s.v. OHG aha 'Wasser(lauf), Fluß, Strom'. Outside of Germanic only the Italic cognates (Lat. aqua) are unobjectionable. < *akʷā < *h₂ekʷeh₂. Less certain are further connections to river names in Baltic and Slavic, and the word for 'river' in Celtic (W afon, Gaulish -apa) and Anatolian (Hitt. ḫapa-).
S.v. Lat. aqua, -ae 'eau, considérée comme élément'. Lat. aqua has a precise correspondent in Germanic (cf. Goth. ahwa 'ποταμός', etc).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *abon- 'river', from PIE *h₂ep-h₃on- 'river' (cf. Hitt. hāpa- Pal. hāpna-, Lat. amnis). The root may be cognate with PIE *h₂ep- (cf. Skt. áp- 'water', OPr. ape 'brook') with a "(?possessive)" suffix *-h₃on- under the assumption that *ph₃ > b (as in *piph₃eti 'drinks' > Skt. píbati).

S.v. OIr. ab 'rivière'. A pre-form *abā is assumed for Germanic which continues river names in -apa, OHG -affa, on the other hand Lat. amnis can come from *abni-. One separates a common root *ab- in the western languages for courses of water. This perhaps corresponds to an Indo-Iranian root *ap- in Skt. āpaḥ 'the waters', Av. āfš 'water'.
Proposes cognacy of Celtic lexemes for 'river' (OIr. ab, aub, W afon) with Anatolian lexemes for 'river' (Hitt. ḫapa-, Pal. ḫāpna-).
For MIA, NIA and Nuristani forms, cf. s.v. 407 áp f., pl. ā́paḥ 'waters' RV.
Cf. s.v. Kâtʹa vari gulʹava 'River (in a steep-sided valley)' (to be analysed as gul-âva 'valley-water').
For MIA, NIA and Nuristani forms, cf. s.v. 407 áp f., pl. ā́paḥ 'waters' RV.
S.v. Lith. ùpė 'river, stream' (Latv. upe 'river, stream', OPr. ape 'brook, stream'), from PIE *h₂ep- (cf. Skt. áp- 'water', TochB āp 'water').

S.v. OLith. ùpė (2), upė̃ (4) 'Fluss, Strom, Bach' (BSl. Latv. upe 'Fluss, Bach', OPr. ape 'Fluss', etc.), from PIE *h₂óp-/*h₂ep- 'Wasser, Fluss' (cf. Ved. áp- 'Wasser, Strom', OAv. ap-, YAv. āfš, OPers. ap-, TochA āp-, TochB āp- 'Wasser, Fluss'.

S.v. Engl. root, a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. OIc. rót, Far. rót, Norn (Shetland) reithin (dative plural, with (analogical) mutated stem vowel), Nw. rot, OSw. rot (Swedish rot), ODa. root, rot (Da. rod)).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *digra- 'big', "An adjective apparently continuing *dʰi⁽g̑⁾ʰ-ro-. It may have been derived from *dī̆gan- 'to knead' (q.v.), which would imply a more primary meaning 'well-formed'."
S.v. Gmc. *digra- 'dick, voll', probably related to the strong verb *diga- 'kneten', in which case the meaning 'dick, voll' would have originated from 'festgeformt'.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *dig-a- 'kneten', with adjective *dig-ra- (OIc. digr 'dick'), with certainty to be derived from the common IE verbal root *dʰei̯g̑ʰ- (cf. Lat. fingō, -ere 'kneten, formeln, streicheln', OIr. com-od-ding 'bauen, errichten' Gk. θιγγάνω [aor. ἔθιγον] 'berühren, umrühren, sich mit etwas fassen', etc.).
S.v. *dʰei̯g̑ʰ- 'bestreichen, kneten' (LIV 140f., IEW 244f.). Proto-Germanic *digra- 'dick, voll' in, e.g., ON digra 'dick, stark' < *dʰig̑ʰ-ró-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ham(m)ō- 'shank', from PIE *konh₂-m-éh₂-.
PS *dělati is derived from *dělo 'work' and ulimately from PIE *dhē-.
PS *činiti is ultimately derived from PIE *kʷei̯-n-.
PS *orbiti is derived from PS *orbŭ 'slave'. It is most probably related to Old Indic árbha- 'young child', Latin orbus 'orphaned', Greek ὀρφανός 'orphan', Armenian orb 'orphan'. PIE *orbho-.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *pravъ adj. 'right'. "If *pràvъ < *proH-uo- […] we may compare the formation with Lat. probus ‘solid, decent’ provided that the latter form continues *pro-b ʰ(u̯)o- and not *pro-bʰuH-o-."

PS *pravъ < PIE *prō-wo-s. PIE *prō- is also retained in PS prefix prā- 'before, in front of'. The semantic development of PS *praviti was like 'put something straight, straighten' > 'put into an order, arrange' > 'build' > 'make, do'.

PS *praviti 'tell' is derived from PS *pravŭ in the meaning 'true, correct' and not 'straighten'. Its original meaning was 'tell the truth'. PS *pravŭ is derived from PIE *próh₃u̯o- (*prōu̯o-) and related to Old Indic pū́rva- 'first', English first etc.
PS *kutiti with no certain further etymology.
The Slavic lexeme is etymologically obscure. I has been unconvincingly linked to Greek σκεῦος 'vessel, utensil', σκευάζω 'prepare', Old Icelandic høyia, Old English hégan 'realize, fulfil, do'.
PS *kutiti does not have any certain etymology.

A relationship to Greek σκεῦος etc. is uncertain, as the Greek word itself has no convincing etymology. The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *skeu-(t)- 'cut, separate, scratch, poke, rummage' and related to Old Indic skāuti skunāti, skunṓti 'disturb, poke, rummage', Middle Irish scothaid 'cut', Lithuanian skutù, skusti 'scratch', skutas 'scrap'. The semantical development in Slavic is 'cut' > 'rummage, dig, poke' > 'make, do' (> 'make something bad').

The etymology of PS *kutiti is not entirely clear, especially due to a very divergent meanings in the particular Slavic languages and dialects. It is maybe derived from PIE *keu-t- < *keu- 'bend, crook'.

?*skeu̯t- 'scratch'. Attested in Baltic (cf. Lithuanian skutù, skùsti 'scrape') and Middle Irish (cf. scotha- 'cut off') only.
?*k(ʷ)eu̯k- 'bend', cf. Vedic ut-kucant- 'bending', Old Irish cúar 'croocked', Lithuanian kaũkas 'bump', Serbo-Croat kuka 'hook' etc.

Slavic lexemes derived from PS *kutiti have many different meanings: 'bend, hide, dig, look for, circulate, turn, escort, breed, protect, do/make, do/make something wrong, live immorally' etc. PS *kutiti is ultimately derived from PIE *keu-t-/*kou-t- with a probably participial -t- 'a bent thing, hook'. This meaning explains all particular meanings in Slavic languages and dialects. Another derivative of PIE *keu- 'bend, flex' is PS *kuka 'hook, needle'. Cf. Old Indic kucáti, kuñcate 'shrivel, get bent' and Lithuanian kaũkas 'bump'.
The etymology of PS *kutiti is unclear.

S.v. Gmc. *marwa- 'zart, fein', to which perhaps ON meyrr 'mürbe, weich'. The West Germanic attestations under this lemma go back to an earlier *marwa-. ON meyrr is not satisfactorily explained and the older comparison of Old Norse meyrr with Gk. ἀμαυρός 'schwach scheinend, undeutlich, dunkel, blind' is formally and semantically weak.

S.v. ON meyrr 'mürbe, weich'. A difficult word, going back to a proto-form *mauria. Either to be compared with Gk. ἄμαυρος 'schwach' or to be analysed as *mau-r-ia and connected to má (2), or to a root *(s)mēu- / *(s)mu- 'reiben, zerreiben'. The Old Norse word is completely isolated but nevertheless can hardly be separated from Sw. mör, Da. mør, and to OE mearu which go back to a proto-form *marwia, *murwia.
S.v. Gmc. *merk-a- '(modern)' Not attested in Old West Norse, first attested in Ic. morkinn 'verfault' (Fleisch, Fisch).
S.v. Sw. murken, cf. Nw. morken, Ic. morkinn, MHG murc.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. murka- 'mürbe (machend)' (> MHG murc 'morsch, faul, morastig' etc.). OIc. morkna- 'verwelken' and Ic. morkinn 'verfault' can be relics of a lost strong verb.
S.v. Gmc. *fūla- 'faul, stinkend'. An old primary adjective in Germanic beside the strong verb *fūa- 'faulen' which is only attested as a participle.
PS *gotovŭ has no certain further etymology.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *reut-a- '(faulen)'. The Old West Norse past passive participle rotinn 'verfault' may go back to *reut-a- 'faulen'. There are no secure cognates outside of Germanic. (Cf. secondary formations via OE rotian-, OHG rozzen, as though from *rut-ǣ-.)
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *reutanan- (II) (str.vb. I). Of unknown origin.

S.v. *merk-, *merg̑-, *merək-, *merəg̑- 'morschen, faulen, einweichen', Traditionally derived to a base *mer-, *merk- 'aufreiben' with various extensions and compared with Lat. marceō, -ēre 'welk, schlaff sein', marcidus 'welk, schlaff', Gaul. bracis 'Getreideart zur Malzbereitung', MIr. mraich, braich, MHG mer(e)n, MLG meren 'Brot in Wein oder Wasser eintunken, Lith. merkiù, mer̃kti '(Flachs) einweichen', etc.

Cf. s.v. morkna- 'morsch werden, verwelken', built to an unattested *morkinn 'murbe, morsch' (cf. Ic. morkinn, Nw. morken, Sw. murken, MHG murc 'morsch, mürbe, faul'). Following {ref IEW} 739-740 to a root *merg̑- / *merk- and compared to OIr. meirc, Lat. marcēre 'welk, schlaff sein', etc.
S.v. NHG rund (MHG runt), a borrowing from French ronde 'Tafelrunde'.
S.v. Da. rund, from Middle Low German 'runt', in turn from Lat. rotundus.
S.v. Sw. rund, from OSw. runder, a borrowing from MLG runt.
It has been linked to PIE *gā- 'go'. An idea about a borrowing from Gothic gataws 'ready' is less probable.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *renn-a- (< *ri-nw-) 'rinnen, laufen' for references to older literature.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *hlaup-a- 'laufen', no immediately useful comparanda. Perhaps the base can be found in Lith. keliáuti 'wandern, reisen', Gk. κέλευθος 'Weg, Pfad, Bahn, Reise'.
S.v. Gmc. *-hʷelba- 'rund', a strong adjective to a reconstructable strong verb *hʷelba- ᾽wölben'.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *hwelb-a- (?) 'wölben'. A Germanic strong verb *hwelb-a- 'wölben' is not more securely attested outside of the Old West Norse PPP holfinn 'gewölbt' and the OFr. hapax biwlven, but its original existence is probable. No further useful comparanda outside of Germanic.

Cf. s.v. *hwelfan- 'to vault, revolve', a marginally attested strong verb from a European root *kʷelp-; cf. *hwalfa- 'vault' (ON hvalf 'concavity', Far. hválv 'arch, vault', OE hwealf 'arched covering' < *kʷólp-o- (cf. Gk. κόλπος 'bosom; womb; hollow space, pocket' < *kʷolp-o- with dissimilation of *kʷ > *k as in καρπός < *kʷrp-o-).

Generally connected to a marginally attested strong verb *hwelban- ~ *hwelfan- ({ref Seebold 1970}:281, {ref Heidermanns 1993}:318, {ref Kroonen 2013}:265). The cognates within Germanic are generally connected to Gk. κόλπος 'bosom; womb; hollow space, pocket' to a reconstructable root *kʷelp- ({ref Kroonen 2013}:262; cf. also {ref Frisk 1960-1972}, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980}, {ref Beekes 2010} s.v. Gk. κόλπος), although not acknowledged by {ref Seebold 1970}. Root not in {ref LIV²}, probably due to its marginal attestation as a strong verb in Germanic.
S.v. Gmc. *spreng-a- 'aufspringen', with no direct comparisons; perhaps to non-nasal *spergʰ- in Gk. σπέρχω 'setze in rasche Bewegung', Ved. √spr̥h- 'sich sehnen nach, verlangen, beneiden'.

The Slavic lexeme *gotovŭ is probably derived from PIE *gʷah₂- 'go, walk' (*gʷah₂-te/ou̯-) with a primary meaning 'ready to go', cf. German bereit and reiten, fertig and fahren. A hypothesis about borrowing from Gothig gataws 'ready' is less probable.
Cf. s.v. Goth. U55. *us-hlaupan 'ἀνίστημι', 'leap up'. Etymology unknown.
Cf. s.v. OLith. klaũpti 'hinknien, niederknien', where the connection to the Gmc. forms given in {ref LIV²} 364 s.v. *kleu̯b- are rejected on semantic grounds.
The Slavic lexeme is related to Albanian gat 'ready'. The Albanian cognate shows that the Slavic lexeme can not be a borrowing from Gothic *gataws.

S.v. OLith. sakýti 'sagen, verkünden, predigen' (BSl. cf. Latv. sacît, saku, sacĩju 'sagen', etc.), from PIE *sekʷ- 'sagen', *sokʷ-éi̯e/o- (cf. ON segja 'sagen', saga 'Erzählung, Sage', OE secgan 'sagen', sagu 'Aussage, Erzählung', OHG sagēn 'sagen', saga 'Aussage, Erzählung').
PS *gotovŭ is etymologically obscure. It can be related to Albanian gat 'ready' if the latter is not a borrowing from Slavic. It can be derived from PIE *gʷā- 'go'.
*gʷeh₂- 'step, go'.
Albanian "gat 'ready', gati id. are secondary formations based on the verb which is an early Slavic loanword, from *gotovati, *gotoviti".

S.v. Gmc. *kweϸ-a- 'sagen'. There are no secure comparanda. The the main possibilities are: (1) to Ved. gadati 'spricht' as a blend of the root *u̯ed- 'sprechen' and a root *gʷet-, the basis of which would be in Germanic and perhaps also in Arm. kočem 'nenne, rufe'; (2) to Lat. vetāre (older votāre) 'nicht erlauben, untersagen'; (3) modern Iranian words in a corresponding meaning based on older *ǰat-.

S.v. Gmc. *kweϸ-a- 'sagen'. There are no secure comparanda. The the main possibilities are: (1) to Ved. gadati 'spricht' as a blend of the root *u̯ed- 'sprechen' and a root *gʷet-, the basis of which would be in Germanic and perhaps also in Arm. kočem 'nenne, rufe'; (2) to Lat. vetāre (older votāre) 'nicht erlauben, untersagen'; (3) modern Iranian words in a corresponding meaning based on older *ǰat-.
The etymology is hard to ascertain. The hypothesis linking it to PIE *gʷa- 'go, come' should be taken into account.

S.v. Goth. Q9. qiϸan 'λέγειν', 'to say', possibly from PIE *gʷet- 'speak', attested primarily in Gmc., elsewhere Skt. gádati 'say' if from *gatati, Arm. kočʻem < *gʷot-i- 'call'. Not to be connected with Lat. vetō 'forbid', or OIr. bēl 'lip'.

S.v. Goth. Q9. qiϸan 'λέγειν', 'to say', possibly from PIE *gʷet- 'speak', attested primarily in Gmc., elsewhere Skt. gádati 'say' if from *gatati, Arm. kočʻem < *gʷot-i- 'call'. Not to be connected with Lat. vetō 'forbid', or OIr. bēl 'lip'.
S.v. Da. kradse, a loan from German kratzen.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *sehw-a- 'sehen'. No certain comparisons; frequently connected with the IE root *sekʷ- 'follow' under the assumption of a semantic development 'follow with the eyes'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *kurna- 'corn, wheat', from PIE *g̑r̥h₂-no- (cf. Lat. grānum 'grain, seed', OIr. grán, OCS zrъno < *g̑rh₂-no-; Lith. žìrnis, Latv. zir̃nis 'pea' < *g̑rh₂-n-io-; OPru. syrne 'grain').

Cf. s.v. NHG Korn (MHG korn, OHG korn, OS korn), from Gmc. *kurna-, also in ON korn, OE corn, OFr. korn, Goth. kaurn 'Getreide', kaurno 'einzelnes Korn', from IE *gr̥Hnó- 'Korn', also in Lat. grānum, OIr. grán, OCS zrĭno, Lith. žìrnis.
S.v. Goth. F76. fraiw 'σπόρος, σπέρμα', 'seed'. Etymologically difficult; possibly to PIE *sproywo- without s-; other proposals are less likely.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *snōw-a- 'winden', with related forms in OHG nāen 'nähen', etc.

S.v. NHG nähen (MHG næjen, OHG nājan, MLG neien, neigen, etc., MDu. n(a)eyen; from pre-German *nǣ-ja-. Outside of Germanic one compares W nyddu, 'nähen', Lat. nēre, Gk. νεῖν; cf. also OIr. státhat 'Nadel', MIr. snīid 'dreht, bindet', Latv. snāt 'locker zusammendrehen, spinnen'.

S.v. Gmc. *skarpa- 'zusammengeschrumpft, rauh'. Only attested in North and West Germanic. The adjective can have a precise correspondence in Latv. skarbs 'scharf, streng, rauh' (if it is not a loanword). The ablauting adjective in ORu. ščьrbъ 'unvollständig, schadhaft' and OIr. cerb 'scharf, schneidend' (without s-mobile). The basis of these words is IE *(s)ker- 'schneiden'.

S.v. Gmc. *skarpa- 'zusammengeschrumpft, rauh'. Only attested in North and West Germanic. The adjective can have a precise correspondence in Latv. skarbs 'scharf, streng, rauh' (if it is not a loanword). The ablauting adjective in ORu. ščьrbъ 'unvollständig, schadhaft' and OIr. cerb 'scharf, schneidend' (without s-mobile). The basis of these words is IE *(s)ker- 'schneiden'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *baitra- 'bitter' > Goth. baitrs; s.v. Proto-Germanic *bitra- 'beißend, bitter' > North and West Germanic forms; verbal adjective in *-ra- to the strong verb *beita- 'beißen'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *bitra- 'beißend, bitter' > North and West Germanic forms; verbal adjective in *-ra- to the strong verb *beita- 'beißen'.
S.v. Gmc. *hʷassa- 'scharf'; an common Germanic verbal adjective beside the reduplicated verb *hʷǣta- 'stoßen'.

S.v. Gmc. *hwǣt-a- 'stoßen'; the related adjective *hwass-a- 'scharf' is as though from pre-Proto-Germanic *kwəd-to-. There are, however, no convincing possibilities for comparison outside of Germanic.

PS *gotovŭ 'ready' is derived from PIE *gʷā̆- 'go', from a supine *gʷătu > *ɡotŭ. Cf. German bereit and reiten, fertig and fahren, English ready and ride. Traces of the meaning 'go' in PS *gotovŭ 'ready' seem to be attested in Old Russian.
PS *pĭs- has no equivalents among IE languages and no certain etymology. It is most probably derived from an interjection used for luring dogs (ps!).
S.v. NHG kurz (MHG kurz, OHG kurz, kurt), a loanword from Lat. curtus 'kurz'.
S.v. Gmc. *stunta- 'kurz, stumpf'. Probably an old verbal adjective to the root also found in Lat. tundō (pf. tutudī) 'schlage, stoße'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *stunta- 'short'. "No further etymology. The link with the PIE root *steud- (Pokorny {ref IEW}: 1032-4) cannot be maintained in view of the ablauting formations G stanzen w.v. 'to press, cut out, punch' < *stantōn- and G stenzen w.v. 'to hit, beat' < *stantjan-."

S.v. Gmc. *skamma- 'kurz'. Formally and semantically the closest comparison is to Av. kamna- 'wenig, gering', which because of the superlative kambišta- is based on *kombh-no- (also pre-Germanic *skombh-no-?). Further connections are unclear.
Cf. s.v. ON skammr 'kurz'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *skam(m)az. Of unknown origin. Probably related to Av. kamna- 'little' < *kombh-no-.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *lītila- 'small'. The derivation of the word is still problematic and the radical alternation *līt-, *lūt-, and *lutt- remains unexplained; until this alternation is explained it will be difficult to find a good etymology.

S.v. Gmc. *leitila- 'klein'. From the root *leit- there also are *leitena-, *leitika-/*littika-. Beside these is a root *lū̆t- in *lut(t)i-, *luttika-, *lūtila-/*luttila-. It alternates also a) ei/i and ū/u, b) t and tt, c) the suffixes -ena-, -ika-, and -ila-. The root *leit- is common Germanic, while *litt- and lūt- are only West Germanic. Close possibilities for comparisons outside of Germanic are lacking.

S.v. Gmc. *sengw-a- 'singen', comparable with some isolated forms in other languages. The basis *sengʷʰ- 'sagen' is therefore not very certain. Cf. W dehongli 'aussagen, erklären, übersetzen', OCS sętъ, sęti 'inquit' ('sagen'), Gk. ὀμφή 'Stimme (der Götter), melodiöse Stimme'.
S.v. NHG Luft (MHG luft, OHG luft, OS luft), from Gmc. *luftu- 'Luft', also in Goth. luftus, OE lyft. Origin unclear.

S.v. Gmc. *swef-a- 'schlafen', connected with certainty to PIE *su̯ep- 'schlafen' (cf. Lat. sōpio, -īre 'einschläfern', OIr. súan 'Schlaf', Lith. sãpnas 'Traum', OCS sъpati 'schlafen', Gk. ὕπνος 'Schlaf', Ved. sváptu 'schläft', Hitt. šup-, šupparija- 'schlafen', TochB ṣpäne 'Schlaf, Traum').

S.v. Gmc. *slǣp-a- 'schlafen'. No certain possibilities for comparison outside of Germanic. Perhaps a root *slāb- (or *slōb-) if connected to Lith. slobstù, slõbti 'schwach werden', OCS slabъ 'schwach'.

The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian pìktas 'bad, furious', paĩkas 'stupid', and Old Indic piśuna- 'hostile'. Baltic has only variants with *-k- in contrast to Slavic and Indic *-k̑-. Cf. also Slovene psovati 'curse', Polish psuć 'break, corrupt'.

S.v. Gmc. *smǣha- 'klein, gering'. Without any clear comparisons outside of Germanic. The attempt to connect the word with Gk. σμῑκρός 'klein, kurz, gering' and Lat. mīca 'ein Krümchen, ein bißchen' is uncertain.

*pei̯k̑- 'chop down, cut out'. Among derivatives we found *?pik̑-ó-: Vedic piśá- 'a spotty animal, deer?' and Slavic *pisu 'dog', *?pik̑-r-ó-: Slavic pĭstrŭ 'mottled' etc., *péi̯k̑-men Slavic pismę 'letter'. However, the authors note that 1) it is hard to differentiate between *pei̯k̑- and *pei̯g- 'paint'; 2) some entry groups (like Lithuanian pìktas 'bad', paĩkas 'stupid', Old Indic piśuna- 'slanderous, bad', PG *faiha 'hostile') can also belong to *peh₁i̯- 'reprimand' or *pei̯g/g̑- 'irritiate, annoy'.
S.v. OHG luft 'Luft, Luftraum, Atmospäre, Äther, Himmel, Lufthauch', from Proto-Germanic *luftu-, with no correspondences in the other IE languages.
S.v. OHG fel 'Haut, Häutchen, Fell', from Proto-Germanic *fella- (< pre-PGmc. *pel-no-) and close to Lat. pellis, -is 'Fell, Haut, Pelz, Leder' < PIE *pelni-.
Cf. *pei̯g- 'paint', *pei̯g/g̑- 'irritiate, annoy' and *pei̯k̑- 'chop down, cut out'.
The further etymology of Lithuanian pìktas 'bad, furious',  paĩkas 'stupid', peĩkti 'reprimand' is obscure.

S.v. Gmc. *smala- 'klein'. The common Germanic adjective signified 'klein', in West Germanic especially 'schmal, dünn'. The adjective has no precise correspondences. Frequently compared are OCS malъ 'klein', Lat. malus, Osc. mallo- 'schlecht, böse'; in other cases to IE *mēlo- in Du. maal 'junge Kuh', OIr. míl 'Schmalvieh', Gk. μῆλον 'Schaf', the morphological connections are however unclear.

PS *malŭ is most probably related to Greek μῆλον 'small cattle', Latin malus 'bad, evil' (<'small, insufficient'), Gothic smals 'small', German schmal 'narrow' etc. It is derived from PIE *mēlo-/*(s)mēlo- 'small cattle'. As to the semantic development cf. Ukrainian mal' 'small sheep (collective!)'.
S.v. OHG kurz, kurt 'kurz', a borrowing from Lat. curtus 'kurz'.
Cf. s.v. ?*skerdʰ- 'schneiden, stechen' (?) (IEW 940-1). Cf. n1 "Vgl. […] viell. ae. scort, OHG scurz 'kurz', dann *skerd-".

S.v. Gmc. *klaini- 'fein'. Only attested in West Germanic. The Gmc. verb *klina- continues an old nasal present that is also seen in OIr. glenaid 'haftet an, bleibt kleben' and also in Gk. γλίνη  'klebrige Substanz', OCS glьna 'Lehm, Ton', to PIE *g̑lei̯- / *glei̯- 'beschmieren, haften'.

S.v. NHG klein (MHG klein(e), OHG klein(i), OS klēni) 'zierlich, fein'. The present-day meaning is a more recent semantic shift post-MHG, from West Germanic *klaini-, also attested in OE clǣne 'rein'. Etymology unclear. According to {ref Heidermanns 1993}:332f. to the nasal present *kli-na- 'beschmieren' as 'fein geputzt' to PIE *gloi- 'glänzen'.

S.v. OHG kleini, klein 'klein geformt, winzig, kurz, gering(fügig), beschränkt, unerheblich, dünn, schwach, fein, zart, kostbar, hell (von Farbe), klug, schlau, (arg-)listig, tief, gründlich im Denken' from West Germanic *klai̯nii̯a-, likely to have been originally from PGmc. *klai̯ni-. The further etymology is disputed due to the varying semantics of the lexemes in the Germanic languages, and lack of convincing comparisons in another IE language. According to {ref Heidermanns 1993}:332, to have a semantic development 'fein verschmiert, fein verputzt' can connected to PGmc. *klinō/a- 'bestreichen' (and further to *gleiH-nó- 'fein wegen Bestreichung'. {ref IEW} 336f. on the other hand compares a verbal root *g̑el- 'hell glänzen', heiter sein', although as {ref Heidermanns 1993}:333 points out this interpretation is to be dismissed since in Germanic it is not attested with the meaning 'shining'. Not seriously considerable is the assumption of a substratum word.
S.v. OHG guot 'gut, brauchbar, verwendbar, etc.', from PGmc. *gōđa-, which is based on the verbal root *gʰedʰ- 'zusammentreffen, sich vereinigen'.
Cf. s.v. ?*gʰedʰ- '(zusammen)treffen, sich vereinigen' (IEW 423-4).

S.v. Goth. D11. dauns 'ὄσφησις', 'sense of smell'; 'ὀσμή', 'smell'; 'εὐωδία', 'fragrance', from PIE *dhew- 'fly about, whirl'. (cf. Skt. dhūnóti 'shakes, agitates', dhūmás 'smoke', Av. dunman- 'cloud', Gk. θύω 'sacrifice', θυμός 'spirit, soul'; Lat. suf-fiō 'smoke, fumigate', fūmus 'smoke', OIr. dumacha 'fog', Lith. dúmai 'smoke', etc.).
Cf. s.v. OHG luft 'Luft, Luftraum, Atmospäre, Äther, Himmel, Lufthauch', from Proto-Germanic *luftu-, with no correspondences in the other IE languages.
S.v. OHG luft 'Luft, Luftraum, Atmospäre, Äther, Himmel, Lufthauch', from Proto-Germanic *luftu-, with no correspondences in the other IE languages.
S.v. Gmc. *reuk-a- 'rauchen'. There is only a possibility for comparison in Baltic via Lith. ráugti 'säuern', intr. 'aufstoßen', Latv. rûgt 'säuern, aufgehen, rauchen'.
Cf. s.v. OLith. rū̃kti 'rauchen, qualmen' and s.v. ruokė 'Sprühregen', most likely to be loans from Germanic.

The relationship to Slavic *pĭstrŭ 'mottled', farther to Old Indic piçás 'doe', Greek ποικίλος 'mottled' and Old High German fêh 'mottled' is most convincing from the phonetic point of view. It has been also linked to Latin pecus, Old Indic paçu, Old High German fihu 'cattle' (the original meaning would be either 'cattle  guard' or 'furry'). Hypotheses linking PS *pĭsŭ to words for 'urinate' (like French pisser) are unconvincing phonetically (one shoul expect a form **pĭxŭ then) and semantically (parallels for such a semantic development are unknown). The hypothesis about a derivation from an interjection ps! is unconvincing.
S.v. NHG Rauch (MHG rouch, OHG rouh, OS rōk), from Gmc. *rauki- also in ON reykr, OE rēc, OFr. rēk; derived from the strong verb underlying NHG riechen, whose original meaning was 'to smoke'.

S.v. NHG Schlange (MHG slange, OHG slango), a nomen agentis to schlingen 'wenden, flechten, etc.' as 'sich Windende'. Outside of Germanic one compares it to a (west) IE formation *slongʷʰ- (cf. Lat. lumbrīcus 'Eingeweidewurm', W llyngyr 'Eingeweidewurm' < *slonkʷ-?).

There are three hypotheses on the etymology of Bulgarian kuče 'dog'. 1) It can be derived from an ideophonic interjection kuč-kuč (attested in some Bulgarian dialects), cf. Belarusian kucu-kucu, Serbo-Croat dialectal kuci-kuci, Polish dialectal kuć-kuć, kuciu-kuciu, Romanian cuțiu cutu, Albanian kut, Italian cucciu, Spanish chuchu, Lithuanian čiùčius, cf. also Estonian kutš, Turkish küçük 'pup', Hungarian kutya. These interjections are used for various domesticated animals. 2) It can be related to Old Indic śuna-s, Avestan sūnō etc. PIE *(s)k̑ou- 3) It can have a Turkic (Proto-Bulgar) origin, cf. Kazakh кушIк 'cub of the dog or other predator'. The ultimate source could be an Iranic language. The word is widespread in the Eastern Europe, cf. Russian kutâ, kutёnok 'pup', Turkish küçük 'pup', Hungarian kutya etc.

Russian kutёnok 'pup' is derived from an ideophonic interjection kut'-kut', used for luring of various domesticated mammals and birds. Cf. also kuč- in Bulgarian kuče 'dog', kučka 'bitch', Serbo-Croat kuče, Polish kuciu-kuciu, Albanian kutsh 'dog', Latvian kuce 'bitch', kucis 'dog', Ossetian kuj, Kurdish kūčik 'dog'. However, if the Slavic *kučĭka is related to Lithuanian kaũkti 'howl', Old Indic kṓcati 'make a loud noise', kṓkas 'wolf', then it is not related to Russian kutёnok etc.
PS *kučĭka [with attestations from South Slavic only]. It is has an ideophonic origin or was derived from an interjection used for luring dogs. PS *kutę 'pup' was derived from an interjection.

It is borrowed from Middle Iranian *sabāka-, cf. Persian, sabah, Avestan spā, spaka- 'dog's', Median σπάκα. The Iranian word is related to Old Indic çvā, çúnas and Greek κύων, κυνός. In his comments Trubačev claims that a borrowing from Iranian is hardly probable and that the source of the Slavic lexeme is Turkish köbäk 'dog'.
It is usually assumed to be an early, common Slavic borrowing from Iranian.
It is an old loan from an Iranian language, probably from Scythian. A hypothesis about an indigenous origin (*sob-ak(a)) is unconvincing.
PS *pylŭ < *pū-lo-, derived from PIE *pū- 'blow'.
The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *pū- 'blow' or PIE *pūl- < *pū- 'rot' (cf. German faul 'rotten', Lituanian piaũlas 'rotted').
The Kashubian lexeme is derived from PS *pyxati 'blow strongly'.
The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *p(ʰ)ū- 'blow', cf. Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow', Latvian pùst, pùšu 'blow', Greek  φυ̃σα 'blowing', φῡσιάω, φῡσάω 'blow'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *kabla/ōn- 'piece of wood', as though from *g̑obʰ-l-on- (cf. Lith. žãbas 'branch, cane' < *g̑obʰ-o-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *kaƀlōn, probably related to Lith. žãbas.
Cf. s.v. ON kafli 'runder stock, stab'.
Cf. s.v. OLith. žãbas 'Rute, Gerte', likely to be root-cognate with Germanic words (ON kafli 'runder Stock, Stab', kefli 'Stab, Stock', etc.).
S.v. OHG gerta 'Rute, Stock, Stab, Zepter', from Proto-Germanic *ǥazdii̯ō(n)-, a -jō(n) to Gmc. *ǥazda- 'Stachel, Spitze, Rute' (> OHG gart 'Stachen, Treibstecken, Stachelstock').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *gazda- 'prickle', from *gʰazdʰ-o- (cf. OIr. gat 'withe, osier' < *gʰazdʰ-o-; Lat. hasta 'spear-shaft, lance', OIr. gas 'sprig, shoot, twig' < *gʰast-o/eh₂-). "A Germanic-Celtic isogloss; OIr. gat and PGm. gazda- are formally identical, but Lat. hasta and OIr. gas point to a variant with a voiceless dental. Since this variation cannot be of IE origin, it is likely that the word originates from a local European language."

S.v. Proto-Germanic *stukka- 'stick', derived from the strong verb *stekan- 'to stick', in turn as though from *stig-e- (cf. Lat. īnstīgō, -ere 'to stimulate, set on, incite, rouse or urge' < *-steig-e-).

S.v. NHG gerade² 'in unveränderter Richtung verlaufend' (MHG gerat, gerade, OHG gihradi 'schnell, verwandt'). For the basic word, cf. under rasch from PGmc. *raska- < *raϸ-ska- 'rasch'. There are two possibilities for a further etymology: either (1) to ONor. rǫskr 'tüchtig, tapfer', MEng. rash, without the suffix to the same root as NHG Rad < PIE *roto- (*ret-); or (2) to ONor. hraðr 'schnell', OEng. hræð 'schnell', OHG hrad, and ffurther compared to Lith. api-kratai 'schnell' (to Lith krė̃sti 'schütteln, rütteln').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *līka- (2) 'similar, equal' < *leig-o- (cf. Lith. lýgus, lygùs, Latv. lĩdzs 'flat, even, equal', OPr. po-līgu 'similarly' < *lig-o-; Lith. lýginti, Latv. lĩdzinât 'to compare, even, equalize', OPr. līginton 'to judge' < *lig-neh₂-. A Baltic-Germanic isogloss.

Cf. s.v. OLith. lýgus 'eben, gleich, ähnlich'. The obvious possibility for a connection of the Baltic words is found in Germanic, if the formations like Goth. leik, galeiks, and leikan and adjectival *līka- 'gleich' may go back to an IE root formation *lei̯g-.
S.v. Da. lig, from ON líkr, glíkr (cf. NHG gleich).
S.v. Gmc. *(-)baina* 'gerade', Perhaps Gmc. *baina- 'bone, leg' is a late substantivisation.

Cf. s.v. NHG Bein (MHG bein, OHG bein, OS bēn), from PGmc. *baina- 'Knochen', also in ON bein, OE bān, OFr. bēn. The lexeme is not attested in Gothic. The word is a Germanic replacement for the IE inherited word for 'leg' (attested via Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc.), but its origin is unclear.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg'. No further etymology.
Cf. s.v. beinn (2) 'gerade, richtig, günstig'.
Cf. s.v. *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'schwellen' (IEW 125-6).

S.v. Gmc. *(-)ϸrūt-a- (?) '(schwellen)'. Only North Germanic, unless also with OE ϸrutian 'vor Hochmut oder Zorn schwellen'. No possibility at a certain etymological assessment; above all the vocalism makes difficulties.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *halan- 'tail, tip', as though from IE *⁽k̑⁾olH-on- (cf. OIr. cail 'lance' < *⁽k̑⁾lH-i-).

S.v. NHG Schwanz (MHG swanz), a backformation to MHG swanzen, an intensive formation to schwanken (or maybe schwingen). The original basic meaning was 'was sich hin- und herbewegt', 'what moves back and forth'. NHG schwanken in turn is derived from the adjective schwank.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *swanka- 'schlank, biegsam', perhaps to be compared with OIr. seng 'eng, dünn, schlank'.
S.v. ?*(h₃)peus- 'sich mehren, reich werden an' (IEW 848). Slavic forms not connected by LIV².

"Gr. ὀπυίω besser mit J. Katz (Vortrag Kopenhagen Okt. 2009) mit ved. vapuṣyá- zu vergleichen (vgl. unten zu *u̯ep-), womit die Grundlage für den Ansatz von *h₃ entfällt (und die Reduplikation von ved. pupóṣa auch diachron völlig regulär wird)." Discounting Gk. ὀπυίω as cognate, reconstruction of initial *h₃- to the root is superfluous.

Cf. s.v. NHG Schwanz (MHG sterz, OHG sterz, MLG stērt, MDu. stert), from Gmc. *sterta- 'Schwanz' also in ON stertr, OE steort, OFr. stert; presumably to the group including starr as 'aufgerichtet, steif'. If so, then to be connected with Gk. στερεός 'steif, hart, fest', Lith. stérti 'erstarren, den Mund aufsperren'.

Proto-Slavic *puxati, cf. *puxnǫti 'swell'. Derksen considers Proto-Slavic *pux- with PIE *peu̯s- (cf. Skt. púṣyati 'thrive, flourish'). [Cf. LIV² 303-304 s.v. ?*h₃peu̯s-, without Slavic cognates listed.].
S.v. ?*(h₃)peus- 'sich mehren, reich werden an' (IEW 848). Slavic forms not connected by LIV².

"Gr. ὀπυίω besser mit J. Katz (Vortrag Kopenhagen Okt. 2009) mit ved. vapuṣyá- zu vergleichen (vgl. unten zu *u̯ep-), womit die Grundlage für den Ansatz von *h₃ entfällt (und die Reduplikation von ved. pupóṣa auch diachron völlig regulär wird)." Discounting Gk. ὀπυίω as cognate, reconstruction of initial *h₃- to the root is superfluous.
PS *puxati, derived from an ideophonic PIE root *p(ʰ)eu̯s-. It is related to Lithuanian pū̃sti, Latvian pùst, probably also to Greek phȳ̃sa, phȳsáō.
PG *fūla- 'filthy, foul' < PIE *púH-l-o-.
*peu̯H- 'rot, stink'.
PS *ěsti < PIE *ē̆d-.
PS *aje < PIE *ōi̯om. Cf. also PS derivatives *ajĭce and *ajĭko.
PS *oko, očese < PIE *okʷ- / *Hokʷ-.

S.v. NHG überlegen (MHG überligen 'auf etwas liegen, belagern'; 14th c.; in present meaning 16th c.); cf. s.v. NHG legen (MHG legen, OHG leg(g)en, lecchen, etc., OS leggian; from Gmc. *lag-eja- 'legen', also in Goth. lagjan, ON leggja, OE lecgan, OFr. ledza, lega, leia, etc. Outside Germanic correspondes to OCS -ložiti.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *lagjan- 'to put', from PIE *logʰ-éie-, the causative to PGmc. *leg(j)an- and formally identical to Hitt. lāki 'to knock out; fall, be felled, be toppled', CS ložiti 'to lay', etc.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. leg-ja- 'liegen', with derived stem lag-eja- 'legen', from the PIE verbal root *leg̑ʰ- 'sich legen'.
Cf. s.v. *legʰ- 'sich (hin)legen' (IEW 658-9).
S.v. Da. tænke, from Middle Low German denken.
S.v. Sw. tänka, just as Da. tænke a borrowing from MLG denken.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸankjan- w.v. 'to think', as though from PIE *tong-éie- (cf. Lat. tongō, -ēre 'to know'; TochA tuṅk, TochB taṅkw 'love' < PToch. *tənkw < *tng-u-).

S.v. Goth. Ϸ2. *ϸagks 'χάρις', with denominal verb ϸagkjan 'βουλεύεσθαι', 'think, plan'. From PIE *tong- 'think, feel' (cf. Lat. tongēre 'know', Osc. tanginom = Lat. sententiam 'thought', Osc. tanginúd = sententiā).
S.v. Goth. H100. *hugjan 'φρονείν, νομίζειν', 'think'. No etymology; proposed cognates are problematic. Cf. entry for further discussion and references to older literature.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *windan- 'to wind' (Elfd. winda 'to hurl, sling'), from PIE *uéndʰ-e- (cf. Umb. vetu, aha-uendu, pre-uendu 3.sg.imptv. 'must turn' < *uend-e-tōd, Arm. gind 'ring' < *uendʰ-eh₂-), a strong verb to *uendʰ-.
Cf. s.v. *u̯endʰ- '(um)winden' (IEW 1148).

S.v. Engl. throw (v.) 1, from Old English þráwan (past tense þréow , past participle þráwen) strong verb, to turn, twist; corresponding to Old Low German *thrâjan, Middle Low German dreien, Low German draien, dreien, Middle Dutch draeien, Dutch draaien, Old High German drâen (< *drájan ), Middle High German dræjen, dræn, German drehen  weak verb, to twist, twirl, turn.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸrēan- s.v. 'to turn', from PIE *tréh₁-e- (cf. Gk. τετραίνω 'to pierce, perforate'; Lat. terō 'to rub' < *terh₁-e-; Lith. trìnti 'to rub, file' < *tr-n-h₁-e-). "A strong verb from a root *treh₁-, apparently a variant of the more wide-spread *terh₁-."
S.v. ?*treh₁- 'drehen' (IEW 1072), cf. n1 mostly considered as somehow belonging to *terh₁- 'bohren'.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *ϸrǣ-a- 'drehen', belongs probably to the IE root *ter- with a development in meaning 'rub' > 'bore' > 'turn'.
S.v. ?*smei̯d- 'schmieren' (IEW 966); cf. n1 perhaps related to CS smědъ 'dunkelbraun' < 'schmutzig, schmierig'.

S.v. Gmc. *(-)smeit-a- 'schmeißen'. No convincing etymological connections; the closest possibility is Lat. mittō, mittere 'gehen lassen, werfen', but with formal difficulties and not fully corresponding semantically.
S.v. ON kasta, generally connected to ON kǫs 'haufe', kǫstr 'hügel', and kasa 'in einem steinhaufen begraben'. No clear etymology outside of Germanic.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *gaujan- 'to throw; to spawn', perhaps related to PIE *g̑ʰeu- 'to pour'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *knūϸan- ~ *knuttan- 'knot', likely to be a ton-formation to the PIE root *g̑nu- 'knee, node'.
S.v. ON knýta 'zusammenbinden, knüpfen', cf. knútr 'knoten'.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *ϸrǣ-a- 'drehen', belongs probably to the IE root *ter- with a development in meaning 'rub' > 'bore' > 'turn'.
S.v. Da. dreje, borrowed from MLG dreien.

S.v. Gmc. *wend-a- 'winden', probably belonging to a reconstructed IE root *u̯endʰ- 'flechten, winden' (cf. Umbr. aha-uendu, Ved. vandhura- 'Wagensitz' (of which on good grounds it can be assumed was weaved), TochAB wänt- 'umhüllen', perhaps also OCS vęžati 'binden' with a root final variant or contamination).
S.v. Engl. tie (v.), from Old English tígan, for Old West Saxon *tíegan < *téag-jan 'to bind', a denominal formation to OE téag (f.) 'rope', probably from Gmc. *taug- (cf. ON taug (f.) 'rope').
Cf. s.v. ON taug 'faser; tau, strick' (cf. OE teag, NE tie 'band, riemen, fessel').
S.v. *sneu̯H- 'drehen, winden' (IEW 977).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *snewan- ~ *snūan- 'to rush', from PIE *snéuH-, *snuH- (cf. RuCS snuti 'to warp', Ru. snovát' 'to warp, dash about', SCr. snòvati 'to warp' < *snouH-eh₂-; Latv. snaujis 'noose' < *snouH-io-).
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *snōw-a- 'winden'.
Cf. s.v. OHG guot 'gut, brauchbar, verwendbar, etc.', from PGmc. *gōđa-, which is based on the verbal root *gʰedʰ- 'zusammentreffen, sich vereinigen'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *gōda- adj. 'suitable, good', an o-grade adjective to a lost strong-verb *gadan- 'to fit' < *gʰedʰ-. Cf. denominal verb *gadōjan- 'to fit (together)' (pp.162-163).
Cf. s.v. ?*gʰedʰ- '(zusammen)treffen, sich vereinigen' (IEW 423-4).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *windan- 'to wind' (Elfd. winda 'to hurl, sling'), from PIE *uéndʰ-e- (cf. Umb. vetu, aha-uendu, pre-uendu 3.sg.imptv. 'must turn' < *uend-e-tōd, Arm. gind 'ring' < *uendʰ-eh₂-), a strong verb to *uendʰ-.

S.v. Gmc. *wend-a- 'winden', probably belonging to a reconstructed IE root *u̯endʰ- 'flechten, winden' (cf. Umbr. aha-uendu, Ved. vandhura- 'Wagensitz' (of which on good grounds it can be assumed was weaved), TochAB wänt- 'umhüllen', perhaps also OCS vęžati 'binden' with a root final variant or contamination).
S.v. ON kasta, generally connected to ON kǫs 'haufe', kǫstr 'hügel', and kasa 'in einem steinhaufen begraben'. No clear etymology outside of Germanic.
Cf. s.v. *bʰre⁽g̑⁾- 'brechen (intr.)' (IEW 165).

Cf. s.v. NHG brechen (MHG brechen, OHG brehhan, OS brekan), from Gmc. *brek-a- s.v. 'brechen', also in Goth. brikan, OE brecan, OFr. breka, from PIE *bʰreg- (often elsewhere in IE as a nasal-present stem, cf. Lat. frangere 'brechen' [pf. frēgī]).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *brekan-, from PIE *bʰrég-e-, a strong verb closely related to the *bruk(k)ōn-, which may be etymologically identical to Lat. frangō 'break' < *bʰrg-néh₂-.
From PGmc. *uber- 'over' (cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:557) + *geban- 'to give'. For the problems in the reconstruction of the root underlying PGmc. *geban- < PIE *gʰebʰ-, cf. 'give' in /cognate/228/.
S.v. Sw. kräkas, from OSw. kräkias, a derivative of the same root found in MLG kraken, LG kraken, NHG krachen, OE cracian, etc.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *hlaup-a- 'laufen', no immediately useful comparanda. Perhaps the base can be found in Lith. keliáuti 'wandern, reisen', Gk. κέλευθος 'Weg, Pfad, Bahn, Reise'.
Cf. s.v. Goth. U55. *us-hlaupan 'ἀνίστημι', 'leap up'. Etymology unknown.
Cf. s.v. OLith. klaũpti 'hinknien, niederknien', where the connection to the Gmc. forms given in LIV² 364 s.v. *kleu̯b- are rejected on semantic grounds.
Cf. s.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' (IEW 330-1).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'run' < *h₃ri-n-H- or *h₃ri-nu-e- (cf. Skt. riṇā́ti 'to make flow, set off', etc.).
S.v. Gmc. ϸwah-a- 'waschen', is only comparable to OPr. twaxtan 'Badequast', and in this regard maybe also to Lith. tvaskė́ti 'schlagen, klopfen' (vom Herzen, Puls).

S.v. NHG waschen (MHG waschen, weschen, OHG wascan, OS waskan), from West Germanic *wask-a- 'waschen', also in OE wascan. Etymology unclear. A derivation from the word 'Wasser' would be semantically close, however that would not explain the strong stem in Germanic.

Cf. s.v. Goth. N9. natjan 'βρέχειν', 'moisten', derived from PGmc. *nata- as in OS, Du nat, OHG naz (adj.) 'wet', nazi 'moisture', naz(z)ēn 'become wet, rain', nez(z)en 'moisten', NHG nass 'wet'. No further etymology.

S.v. Gmc. *nata- 'naß', only attested as an adjective in West Germanic, also indirectly attested in East and North Germanic. If one assumes pre-Proto-Germanic *nod-, then there are only vague possibilities for comparison (perhaps Ved. nadī́- 'Fluß', W nodd 'Feuchtigkeit').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *nata- 'wet'. Of uncertain origin, but possibly to be continuing *unod-o-, an o-stem adjective derived from an n-present 3.sg. *u-né-d-ti, 3.pl. *u-n-d-énti (cf. Skt. 3.sg. unátti, 3.pl. undánti 'to well up, moisten').

S.v. Gmc. *hʷeita- 'weiß', in the pre-Germanic form *k̑u̯ei̯d- without clear comparisons, but with IE *-t- cf. Ved. śvetá-, Av. spaēta- 'weiß', Ved. śvítna- 'weißlich', śvitrá- 'weiß, weißlich'; the verbal basis in Ved. śvit- 'hell, weiß sein', Lith. šviẽsti, OCS svьtěti 'leuchten, scheinen'.

S.v. NHG weiß (MHG wīz, OHG (h)wīz, OS hwīt), from Gmc. *hweita- 'weiß', also in Goth. ƕeits, ON hvítr, OFr. hwīt, as a variant in final position corresponds to IE *kʷei̯t- 'glänzen, hell sein, weiß sein' in Ved. śvit-, Lith. šviẽsti, OCS svĭtěti. The Germanic final *-t- can be explained as either due to the influence of the geminate *-tt- in OFr. hwitt. MLG wit(t), MDu. wit(t)e < an n-assimilation (cf. Ved. śvítna- 'hell, licht', although the attestation of this geminate is late. Also considerable is secondary influence from the Auslaut of Gmc. *swart- 'black' (cf. NHG schwarz).

S.v. Gmc. *braida- 'breit'. The Germanic words recall in initial position PIE *bʰer- in Lith. ber̃ti 'streuen, ausbreiten' or *sper- (cf. Gk. σπείρω 'streue, säe'), however the character of such a root-enlargement necessary to explain such a connection remains unclear.
S.v. NHG breit (MHG breit, OHG breit, OS brēd, from Gmc. *braida-, also in Goth. braiϸs, ON breiðr, OE brād, OFr. brēd, breid. Further etymology unclear.

S.v. Gmc. *wīda- 'weit'; several possibilities at a formal connection with Ved. vītá- from different sources: (a) 'gerade, nicht krumm, eben' (RV, of uncertain origin); (b) 'eingehüllt, bedeckt, verbogen' (RV, to vyáyati 'umhüllt, bedeckt, birgt'); (c) 'unternommen, angenommen' (RV, to véti 'wendet sich zu, trachtet nach'), (d) vergangen, gewichen' (to vi-i- RV 'in verschiedene Richtungen gehen, sich verbreiten, sich verstreuen, sich verschwinden'), but nevertheless unclear.

S.v. Germ. Frau (MHG vro(u)we, OHG frouwa, OS frūa, from *frawjōn 'lady', a feminine stem formation based on *fraw-jōn 'lord' (cf. Goth. frauja, OHG frō). Considered to go back to *prō-wo- or *prH-wo- with the meaning 'first' (cf. Ved. pū́rva- 'vorderer, früherer', OCS prĭvŭ 'erster'.
S.v. Goth. M36. maϸa 'σκώλεξ', 'worm', etymology outside of Germanic uncertain.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *maϸan- 'maggot, moth' (cf. Ru. motýl' 'maggot'?), cf. {ref Kroonen 2011}:218-211 for the stem formation.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *maϸōn "Of unknown origin".
S.v. Wakhi parg 'зола, пепел', to IE *pel- (Ru. пе-пел, Lith. pelenaĩ).
Cf. s.v. Engl. ill, from Early Middle English ill, borrowed from Old Norse illr ill, bad, wicked, difficult, injurious, etc. Further etymology unknown; not related to Old English yfel.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *ubela- 'böse' (cf. Goth. ubils, OE yfel, etc.). The North Germanic forms from Old Norse illr perhaps belong here if de-rounded from *yllr and -βl- irregularly assimilated to -ll-.

S.v. NHG übel (MHG übel, OHG ubil, OS uƀil), from Gmc. *ubila- 'übel', also in Goth. ubils, OE yfel, OFr. evel. Outside of Germanic one compares OIr. fel 'schlecht', which may go back to IE *upelo-). Further origins unknown. Perhaps to Hitt. hwappa- 'böse, schlecht', in which case the Germanic forms could go back to a zero-grade of an IE root *Hu̯ep-.

S.v. Gmc. *ubela- 'böse'. The West Germanic form of the adjective *upélo- can be identical with OIr. fel (of uncertain attestation), if this is not a borrowing from Old French fel 'treulos'. {ref Watkins 1969}:30 further attempts to connect Hitt. ḫuwappa- 'schlecht' and ḫuwapzi 'behandelt schlecht' to a root roun *ḫuwap-, from which the Germanic correspondence may be derived via a root *Hu̯e/op- : *Hup-.

The further connections of the Germanic adjective *ubila- 'bad' are debated. It is generally agreed that OIr. fel 'bad, evil' may be formally identical with the Germanic lexemes from earlier *upelo-, if the Celtic lexemes are not borrowings from Old French fel 'faithless, unfaithful, disloyal' (cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:637-638, {ref Matasović 2009}:396, {ref Kluge 2011}:938, {ref Kroonen 2013}:557). Debated remain the further proposed connections to Hitt. ḫuu̯appa-, connected since {ref Juret 1942}:71 and further advocated by {ref Watkins 1969}:30, {ref Melchert 1988}:233n1, {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:369-371, but doubted or rejected by {ref Lehmann 1986}:371, {ref Kluge 2011}:938, {ref Kroonen 2013}:557. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} tentatively reconstructs *h₂u̯óbʰh₁-/h₂u̯(é)bʰh₁- for the proposed Anatolian cognates.
S.v. ON dár (2) 'unangenehm, gewalttätig', cf. also dáligr 'schlecht, schädlich, elend'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *dampa- 'vapour', derived from PGmc. *dimban- ~ *dimpan- 'to fog' < PIE *dʰembʰ-e-.

S.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.). Cf. Celt. *lāma- in OIr. lám, MW llaw, OCo. lof, OBret. lom 'Hand', and etymologically identical with Gk. παλάμη '(flache) Hand, Handhabe, Mittel', Lat. palma 'flache Hand, etc. < *pl̥h₂-mo/ah₂-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *kelϸaz (OE child), cf. also derived form in Goth. kilϸei 'womb' < *kelϸīn. Of uncertain origin.
Cf. s.v. *kulda- 'litter (of progeny)', to which K. says is "probably" connected with Goth. kilϸei 'womb' < *kelϸīn and OE cild 'child' < *keldiz-.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *wahs-ja- 'wachsen', with derived stem *wahs-t-ma- (OE wæstm 'Wuchs, Gestalt, Frucht', OS wastom 'Gedeihen, Wachstum, Frucht', going back to an enlarged form of *aug- 'mehren'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *wahs(j)an- 'to grow', an s-extension to the more common IE base *h₂eug- 'grow' (cf. Goth. aukan), cf. also PGmc. *wahstu- 'growth, stature' (Goth. wahstus, ON vǫxtr 'growth; stature; yield', Fa. vøkstur 'id.', and PGmc. *wahsman- > ODu. wa(h)smo, OHG wahsamo 'growth, fruit'.
S.v. Da. jage, a borrowing from Middle Low German.

Cf. s.v. NHG Weidmann 'Jäger' (MHG weideman to MHG weid(e) 'Jagd, Fischerei', OHG weida 'Jagd, Beute', OS weiđa), from Gmc. *waiϸi-, also in ON veiðr, 'Jagd, Fischfang', OE wāϸ 'Jagd, Umstreiten'. Most closely comparable to OIr. fíadach 'Jagd' and Lat. venari (from *wēidʰ-n-), which may be originally connected to the root *weiə- 'verfolgen'.

S.v. ON veiða 'jagen, erbeuten', a denominal formation to ON veiðr 'jagd' < Gmc. *waiϸjō and to be further connected to Ved. vēti 'verfolgen, streben', Lith. vejù, výti 'jagen, verfolgen', OCS vojĭ 'krieger', cf. Gk. ἵεμαι 'begehren, trachten'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *waiϸiz ~ *waiϸ(j)ō, continuing *u̯oití- ~ *u̯oi̯tā́ derived from *u̯ei- (cf. Skt. véti 'to have in view, to approach', Gk. ἵεμαι 'to move forward, to hurry', Lith. vejù, výti 'to hunt, to drive'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *wenistraz, generally assumed to be derived from PGmc. *weniz 'friend' as a taboo motivated name for the 'friendly' left side (cf. similar replacements elsewhere in IE in Gk. ἀρίστερος, Lat. sinister).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *weni- 'friend', as though from IE *Hu̯enh₁-i-, (cf. OIr. fine 'family' < *Huen-ieh₂-; cf. also TochA wañi, TochB wina 'pleasure', Lat. venus, -eris 'love, charm' < *Huenh₁-es-), cf. Proto-Germanic *wana- (2) 'accustomed' < *Huonh₁-o- (cf. Skt. vánate 'love, desire' < *Huenh₁-e-).

Cf. s.v. Gmc. ϸeuϸa- 'gut, freundlich, vertraut'; in discussion of the derivation of this adjective, the common assumption of a connection between *wenistra- 'left' and *weni- 'friend' is also repeated.
Cf. s.v. *u̯enH- 'liebgewinnen' (IEW 1146-7).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *wiϸra- 'toward, against', from PIE *h₁ui-tro- (cf. Skt. vitarám (adv.), 'further' < *h₁ui-tero-), originally a formation of the PIE root *h₁ui- 'apart' and the contrastive suffix *-tero-.
S.v. *u̯í- 'auseinander; getrennt' (Adverb, lokal), cf. PGmc. *u̯íϸrō 'wider, gegen'.
S.v. vængr 'flügel, fittich; ausbau am hause', from Proto-Norse *wāingja-.

Cf. s.v. NHG Strick (MHG stric, stricken, OHG stric, stri(c)k, stricken, MLG strik, MDu. stric) (also NHG stricken), cf. OE strician 'stricken, Netze ausbessern', probably to Lat. stringere in the meaning 'schnüren, zusammenbinden'.

Cf. s.v. NHG schießen (MHG schiezen, OHG skiozan, OS skiotan), from Gmc. *skeut-a- (also in ON skjóta, OE scēotan, OFr. skiāta, Crim.Goth. schieten). Outside of Germanic one compares, if necessary Lith. šáuti 'schießen, schnell laufen', OCS sovati 'drängen' < PIE *k̑eu̯-; otherwise no clear possibilities for comparison.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *skeutan- 'to shoot, dash'. Etymology outside of Germanic unclear. Kroonen proposes that the verb was back-formed to the iterative *skut(t)ōn-, which may have been formed to a pre-Gmc. root *sket-, and consequently rejects older etymological connections to *skeu-(d)- (Lith. šiáuti 'to shoot', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *skeut-a- 'schießen'.

Similar to Iranic *kutī̆- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Iranic.
