The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also {ref ESIJa} IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.

Similar to Indic *kutta- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Indic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also {ref ESIJa} IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *ƀrēđaz, derived from *ƀrējanan, possibly distantly connected with Skt. bhuráti 'to move', Gk. πορφίρω 'to heave, to rise'; otherwise unclear.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *strakkjanan, derived from *strak(k)az
Cf. s.v. *strakka- 'gestreckt'? The adjective may have been back-formed to the ja-verb strecken.

S.v. NHG Stock (MHG stoc, OHG stoc, OS stokk), from Gmc. *stukka- 'Stock, Balken, Baumstumpf', also in ON stokkr, OE stocc, OFr. stokk. Together with stauchen and stochern to be connected to a common root *steu-, which is also found in stoßen, cf. Skt. tujáti 'drängt, stoßt'.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *stukka- 'steif' (an adjectivisation of *stukka- 'Stock, Baumstumpf').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *stukkaz, with an irregularity in the inlaut geminate to be related to Skt. stúkā 'tuft of wool, of hair'.
S.v. ἰσχίον 'os de bassin où s'emboîte le fémur, hanches'. No clear etymology.
S.v. ῥάχις, -ιος 'colonne vertébrale, échine'. One connects in view of {ref IEW} 1180 to Lith. ražỹs 'chaume' with rãžas 'chaume, pointe de fourche, branche sèche'.
Cf. s.v. 1. g̑ʰer- 'Gefallen finden, begehren' (IEW 440-1).
S.v. πέσκος 'peau, écorce'. An obscure technical term. Cf. entry for references to various suggestions.
S.v. πέσκος 'peau, écorce'. An obscure technical term. Cf. entry for references to various suggestions.
Cappadocian Greek καρι̯ά, from earlier καρδία 'heart'.
Cf. s.v. καρδία 'heart' < PIE *k̑ēr(d), gen. *k̑rd-(i)os 'heart'.
Cf. s.v. *k̑ḗr, k̑r̥d-´ n. 'Herz' (IEW 579f.).
S.v. AGk. φύσκη 'Magen, (Dick)darm' > Tsakon. φούκ᾽α 'Unterleib, Bauch'.

Cf. s.v. AGk. φῦσα 'breath, bellows' with derivative φύσκη 'intestine, sausage'. The exact root of the base noun φῦσα cannot be precisely determined. Comparisons have been made with Arm. pʻowkʻ 'breath, wind', but φῦσα cannot be derived from *φῡκ-i̯α-. Attempts at connections with other potential IE cognates are dubious.

S.v. AGk. πικρός 'qui pique, qui perce'. The root *pik- is attested in the Skt. nasal-infix present piṁśáti 'tailler, couper, façonner, orner', etc., Av. paēs- 'colorer, orner', Lith. piẽšti 'peindre, écrire', cf. OCS pĭsati 'écrire', as well as the adjective pĭstrŭ 'bariolé' which corresponds precisely to the form πικρός. Cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} for other hypothetical connections in Indo-Iranian.

S.v. μέλας 'sombre, noir', compared by {ref Frisk 1960-1972} with Skt. malinī- which corresponds to μέλαινα but is a term that signifies 'femme qui a ses règles', malina- 'sale' (attested only late), and very simple comparisons with terms in Baltic *mēlna- < *melə-no- in Latv. męl̃ns 'noir', OPr. melne 'tache bleue', Lith. mė́las, mė́lynas 'bleu'.
S.v. ἀμαυρός, -ά, -όν, first attested in Od. 4.824, 835 as an epithet of a ghost 'sombre, difficile à distinguer'. There is no etymology.

S.v. Gk. κόκκος 'noyau, pépin', Modern Greek uses κόκκος 'graine' and κόκκινος 'rouge' with many derivatives, also  κόκκαλον 'os' with many derivatives. Of unknown etymology, possibly a Mediterranean loanword.
Greek: Italiot λαλίτζω < ΜedG λαλ(ώ) ‘1. to talk, to speak, to sing 2. play a wind instrument (by blowing air into it)’ (< AG λαλέω ‘to talk, to speak’) -ίτζω.
S.v. AGk. λαλέω 'to talk, chat, prattle' (Att.), 'to speak' (Arist., Hell.). A likely onomatopoeic formation in origin, as similarly Lat. lallāre, Lith. lalúoti, NHG lallen.
Cf. s.v. AGk. λαλέω, rests on an onomatopoeic formation, cf. similarly Lat. lallō, 'chanter pour endormir un enfant', Lith. lalúoti 'bégayer', Ru. lála 'bavard', etc.

Cf. s.v. ἄσθμα 'short-drawn breath, panting', with denominative verb ἀσθμαίνω 'to pant, breathe with difficulty'. Etymology unclear. -θμα is a possible suffix but older proposed derivations to PIE *h₂enh₁- 'breathe' (cf. ἄνεμος) is impossible as one would expect a base †ἀνε-.

S.v. AGk. ἄσθμα 'respiration difficile, halètement, essoufflement'. "On cherche à rattacher le mot à la R. de ἄνεμος en posant *ἀν-σθμα avec un suffixe -σθμα ; un suffixe -θμα est connu ; le σ est isolé, mais cf. ἰσθμός (Schywzer, Gr. Gr. 1,337 avec la bibliographie) ; dans le cas de ἄσθμα le σ confère au mot une certaine valeur d'harmonie imitative."

This is an obscure form. Perhaps ΑG ἐξ- (αν)αλίσκω ‘consume’. The meaning ‘burn, destroy’ of cognate καταναλίσκω / καταναλώνω is already medieval. Suffix -ίγκω is the equivalent of Peloponnesian Τs. -ίντου [indu] < Lac -ίδδω = Att. -ίζω.
S.v. AGk. κόβαλος 'vaurien, filou, voyou'. Of obscure origins; the previously proposed connection to κοάλεμος 'stupid person' is very vague; likewise to καβάλλης, caballus remains indemonstrable.
S.v. AGk. στῆθος 'breast, chest'. [More or less directly translates/paraphrases the discussion of {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:795.]

S.v. AGk. στῆθος 'poitrine' (de l'homme et de la femme). The etymology is obscure. One frequently compares Hesych. στήνιον· στῆθος, which is directly comparable to Skt. stána- 'poitrine d'une femme', Arm. stin (gen. stean), however the suffix -θος then remains unclear.

S.v. AGk. στῆθος 'männliche od. weibliche Brust'. Origin unclear, the similarity to στήνιον· στῆθος (Hesych.) (to Arm. stin, Ved. stána- 'weibliche Brust' is hardly coincidental ("kaum zufällig"). (Perhaps an analogy along the lines of στήνιον : στῆθος similarly like Lat. plēnus : πλῆθος???)

Cf. s.v. Arm. stin 'breast of a woman', connected with Skt. stána- 'breast of a woman, mother's breast, nipple', YAv. fštāna- 'breast of a woman', MPers., NPers. pestān 'breast', AGk. στήνιον· στῆθος (Hesychius), Lith. spenỹs 'nipple', etc., cf. also Gr. στῆθος, -εος 'breast (of both sexes)'; the PIE by-form is considered a lexical agreement which unites Indo-Iranian, Greek, and Armenian, but probably also belonging here is TochA päśśäṃ, B päścane (du.) 'woman's breasts' < PToch. *päścäne < PIE thematic dual *pstenō, (cf. Skt. stánā).

Cf. s.v. καρπός 'fruit, fruits of the earth, corn, yields'. The Greek forms are usually compared with the root *kerp- (Lat. carpō 'pluck (off)', Lith. kerpù 'cut with scissors', Hitt. karp(ii̯e)- 'take away, lift, pluck', assuming a zero-grade *kr̥p-o-.
S.v. AGk. παῖς, based on a root παυ- or παϝ-, from which a stem παϝ-ι-δ-. The root παυ- is attested in παῦς and connected with Lat. puer, etc.

Cf. s.v. κρύος 'icy cold, frost'. The etymology is difficult to assess. There are two alternatives: Either (1) Possibly from IE *kreu̯s- 'shiver', cf. ON hrjósa 'to shiver', OHG hroso 'ice', to the root *kreus- 'to stamp, strike'. Semantically TochB krośce 'cold' would be a perfect comparison but the -o- in the TochB form is difficult to account for; or (2) a connection of the group of words connected to Av. xrūma- 'horrible' < *kruh₂-mo- and connected with the *kruh₂- 'blood' root.

S.v. ψῡχρός, ψῦχος, ψῡ́χω : notion de 'froid'. The related forms within Greek conform to Caland's Law which suggest that they are inherited, but the there are no known cognates in other IE languages.
S.v. μόλω, subj. aor. to AGk. βλώσκω 'gehen, kommen' > Tsakon. μόλου 'kommen'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. βοή 'cri, clameur'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. κράζω 'to croak, to cry', of onomatopoeic origin.
Cf. s.v. AGk. κράζω, of onomatopoeic origin.
S.v. AGk. τέμνω 'couper, fendre', to the IE root *temh₁- or *temh₂-.

Cf. s.v. AGk. θόλος 'saleté dans l'eau, liquide noirâtre et trouble', going back to *θϝολος and may be connected to some Germanic words that designate turbidity of the mind (cf. OS fardwelan 'négliger', OHG gi-twelan 'avoir l'esprit engourdi', etc.).
Cf. s.v. AGk. καθαρός 'propre', etc. No etymology.
Cf. s.v. κυλίω (SMG κυλῶ) 'rollen, wälzen'.
Cf. s.v. SMG κυλώ < Med. Gk. κυλῶ, a morphologically remodelled form from AGk. κυλίω 'roll along'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. κυλίνδω 'rouler'; Gk. κυλίνδω presents a structure comparable to that of ἀλίνδω (thematisation of a base to a nasal suffix + d?), which may be connected to κύκλος and the root *kʷel-.

Italiot τσ̌υλι(μ)μένο (< *κυλι(σ)μένος), the passive participle of τσ̌υλίω /τσ̌υλλίτζω ‘to roll (on a dirty surface), to make dirty’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c., cf. {ref Rohlfs 1964}:282-283). Further etymology disputed: possibly to IE *kʷel(h₁)- ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:598, cf. {ref LIV²} 386-388), but cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:800, who sees the word based on a substratum borrowing.

S.v. AGk. εὐθύς 'droit'. Without IE etymology. It evidently substituted Homeric and Ionic ἱθύς. Perhaps we are dealing with a cross of εἶθαρ and ἰθυς with an assimilation εἰ : υ > εὐ : υ, or a simple alteration of ἰθύς under the influence of εὖ 'bien, droit'?

S.v. AGk. εὐθύς 'droit'. Without IE etymology. It evidently substituted Homeric and Ionic ἱθύς. Perhaps we are dealing with a cross of εἶθαρ and ἰθυς with an assimilation εἰ : υ > εὐ : υ, or a simple alteration of ἰθύς under the influence of εὖ 'bien, droit'?
S.v. AGk. σκύλαξ, -ακος 'jeune chien, chiot', an expressive term for which many different etymologies have been proposed.
Cf. s.v. AGk. στέγω 'mettre à l'abri, couvrir, protéger'.
Cf. s.v. *(s)teg- 'decken, bedecken' (IEW 1013-4).
Cf. s.v. Italiot ἁπαλύνω (SMG ἁπαλένω) 'weich machen'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. ἁπαλός, -ή, -όν 'tendre, délicat, mou'. No etymology.
Cf. s.v. χώννυμι 'amonceler, terrasser, combler'.
Tsakon. τσ̔ιτ̔αίνου: τσ̔ι- ‘un-’ (< AG ἐξ-, cf. τσ̔ι-μού < AG ἐξ-εμῶ ‘vomit’) τ̔αίνου ‘to get up’ (< AG ἵστημι) ({ref Andriotis 1974}:285)
Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥέω, with specialised derivative (based on a denominal formation) ῥοΐζω 'mener un cheval à l'eau', to the IE root *sreu̯-.
Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥέω, with derivative ῥοΐζω 'to drench' (cf. ῥοϊκός 'fluid'). Based on the IE root *sreu̯- 'flow, stream' (cf. Skt. srávati 'flow', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' (IEW 1003).
Cf. s.v. λάργος 'weit' (SMG ἀλάργα adv.), loan from It. largo.

S.v. λίπα 'grassement, de manière à être bien gras ou huilé' (adv.), from which the s-stem λίπος. To be connected with the root underlying Skt. rip- 'fait d'enduire, de salir, tromper', cf. verbal forms in Skt. limpáti (with nasal infix) 'enduire', Lith. limpù, lìpti 'être collant, visqueux'.
S.v. AGk. παχύς 'gros, épais, massif', an archaic u-stem adjective from IE *bʰn̥g̑ʰ- (cf. Skt. bahú- 'abondant, grand, vaste').
S.v. SMG πάχος, derived from AGk. παχύς.
No Tsakonian word has a final -s, so this is borrowed from MG.
S.v. AGk. ὀξύγγιον 'graisse de porc', a borrowing from Lat. axungia.

S.v. AGk. ἄμυλος 'cake of fine meal'. "Starch is made from unground grain which suggests that ἄμυλος derives from μύλη (cf. ἄμυλον· στερρόν, ἄκλαστον 'firm, unbroken' EM) with privative ἀ-. However, given the form, we expect a basic meaning 'having no mill', not 'unground' which casts some doubt on the etymology.", cf. further s.v. μύλη, a primary verbal noun to μύλλω 'grind'.
S.v. AGk. ἄμυλος 'espèce de pain', a technical term of evident etymology, privative ἀ- + μύλη 'meule' = 'non moulu').
Cf. s.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-7) for primary verbal derivatives to the same root.
S.v. AGk. ἀλείφω 'oindre', cf. for older hypotheses attempting to connect to a basic root *lei̯- with various extensions.

S.v. AGk. φέβομαι 'fuir, spécialement en parlant d'une troupe saisie par la panique; fuir dans la précipitation et le désordre', with related causative verb φοβέω 'faire fuir, mettre en fuite' (Hom., Hes.); post-Homeric 'terrifier, effrayer'; the basic verb φέβομαι has an exact correspondent in Balto-Slavic, cf. Lith. bė́gti 'courir', Latv. bȩ̄ga 'fuite', etc., and may go back to IE *bʰegʷ-.
Cf. s.v. σκιάζομαι 'vor Schatten scheuen', 'sich furchten'.
S.v. AGk. σκία 'Schatten' > Cypriot and Italiot οσ̆σ̆ιά related to Ancient Greek σκία (cf. also s.v. the AGk. diminutive σκαδίον).

S.v. AGk. πλέκω 'tresser', cf. t-enlarged forms in Lat. plectō, OHG flehtan, non-enlarged forms in OHG flahs, OE fleax 'lin', etc. going back to an IE root *plek- (cf. also Skt. praśna- 'turban' < *plok-no-).
S.v. AGk. πιέζω 'to press, push, beset', the variant πιάζω is an innovation after verbs in -αζω. The etymology is uncertain.
S.v. πιέζω 'presser, serrer, serrer, écraser, poursuivre'. Etymology disputed.
S.v. AGk. φάε, φάος, φῶς 'lumière', to be connected with Skt. bhā́-ti 'il luit, il éclaire', bhā-ti- 'lumière' based on the IE root *bhā- (= *bheə₂-).
S.v. AGk. ἐσχάρα 'foyer bas, brasier'. A technical term, apparently a derivative in -ρα, no etymology.
κατσ̔αβάρα / κατσ̔ιφάρα < MedG κατσηφ-άρα ‘fog’ < AG κατήφεια ‘being downcast, sad’, cf. MG κατσούφης. A Medieval Greek loanword.
A register-loanword into Standard Modern Greek from Katharevousa (expected †μίχλη, vel sim.). A reflex of the expected word might be found in SMG μούχλα 'mould, mildew' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Cf. s.v. SMG ὀμίχλη 'fog'; for μουχλά 'mildew, mould', cf. s.v. @ http://www.greek-language.gr/greekLang/modern_greek/tools/lexica/triantafyllides/search.html?lq=%CE%BC%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%87%CE%BB%CE%B1&dq=
Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda (cf. Alb. than 'trocknet').
Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).

Cf. s.v. AGk. δεῖσα 'boue, crotte'. {ref Solmsen 1909}:236 connects to OCS židŭkŭ. Lasso de la Vega (Émerita 22, 1954, 89). Possibly a popular term derived from the aorist ἔδεισα 'horreur, chose à redouter'? A simple hypothesis.

S.v. AGk. δασύς 'à la surface hérissée, touffue', 'poilu', etc.; one is reminded of Lat. dēnsus, but reconciling the reconstruction is difficult with the dialectal Greek data. Ultimately no etymology.

S.v. AGk. ὕλη 'region boisée, bois, forêt'. Etymology unknown. None of the earlier connections proposed in {ref Frisk 1960-1972} are plausible. Lat. silva has the sense of Gk. ὕλη, but there is no common ancestor to both of these terms.
S.v. SMG λόγγος, a loanword from Old Slavic logŭ.
S.v. AGk. πήγνυμι 'planter, fixer; rendre solide, geler, coaguler', -ν-υμι verb to the same root as Lat. pangō 'consolider, fixer'.
S.v. Old Welsh agit v 3.sg.pres. 'to go', from IE *ag̑- 'treiben' (cf. Lat. agō).
Attempts to derive Gk. ἀγαθός from a reconstructed IE formation *mg̑ʰh₂-dʰh₁-o- 'make great'
Argues for a possible loanword from a European substratum language.
S.v. AGk. καλός 'beau'; the original stem in Greek was καλϝός, but the geminate in κάλλος, καλλίων, κάλλιστος remains unexplained. The etymology is unclear.
S.v. AGk. ποά 'herbe [collectif], herbage, herbes médicinales', from earlier *ποιϝᾱ and corresponding to Lith. pieva 'prarie'.
Cf. s.v. OLith. píeva 'Wiese' (Latv. pieva) from PIE *poi̯H-u̯eh₂- 'Weise' (cf. AGk. ποίη [Hom., Ion.], ποία [Dor.], ποά [Att.] 'Gras, Kraut, Rasenplatz').

S.v. AGk. πράσον 'poireau, allium porrum'. The probable relation with Lat. porrum 'poireau' has been long considered. If one postulates an IE etymology on *pr̥som, there is the same problem of the maintenance of intervocalic *-s- as also in the proposed etymology between δασύς and Lat. densus. More likely is a case of parallel borrowings from a third source.

S.v. σπλήν 'rate', variously compared with Av. spərəzan- as though from *spl̥gh-en-, Skt. plīhán-, Lat. liēn (without initial sp-); other possibly connected forms but more or less aberrant: Ir. selg, Lith. blužnìs, OCS slězena, Arm. pʻaycaln.
S.v. AGk. θρίξ, τριχός 'Haar'; cf. for references to older literature and very uncertain proposed etymologies.
S.v. AGk. μαλλός 'touffle de laine'; etymology unclear. Cf. {ref IEW} 724 who supposes *ml̥-no- and compares Lith. mìlas 'drap', Latv. mil(n)a 'drap'.
Cf. s.v. SMG σέρτικος, based on a loanword from Turkish sert.
S.v. AGk. σκέλλομαι, to a root *skelh₁- with variant *skleh₁- (cf. Dor. σκληρός).
S.v. ξηρός 'dry, arid'. Possibly from PIE *ksē̆ro-? Proposed etymologies outside of Greek are unclear.

Martirosyan connects Greek ξηρός with Armenian čʻir 'dried fruit' čʻor (o-stem) 'dry'. This proposed etymology is usually doubted because one normally expects Armenian cʻ from PIE *ks, *sk, but Martirosyan argues (2.1.12) that čʻ- is the correct reflex of *ks- in initial position. The etymology is possible, but this word is the only example that Martirosyan cites in favour of this sound law.
Clackson (among others) regards the connection between Greek ξηρός and Armenian չոր čʻor as doubtful.
S.v. κεφαλή 'tête (d'un homme ou d'un animal)', to be connected with TochA śpāl 'tête', OHG gebal 'crâne', etc.
S.v. AGk. νόος, with denominative verb νοέω, clearly a nomen actionis with o-grade vocalism, but no known etymology outside of Greek.
Cf. s.v. χώννυμι 'amonceler, terrasser, combler'.

S.v. AGk. κρύπτω 'envelopper pour cacher'. AGk. κρύπτω is very similar to καλύπτω 'cover' and the two verbs may have influenced each other. If one ignores the vowel quantity and the final labial the verb is very close to OCS kryjǫ, kryti 'cacher'.
S.v. AGk. κρούω 'schlagen, stoßen' > Pont. κρούγω.
S.v. AGk. κτύπος 'bruit fort', probably of expressive origin.
τσ̌όχανε < AG τραύσανον (Ηesych) / τραύξανα.

S.v. AGk. τραύξανα 'dry wood, brushwood', with variant τραύσανον· ξηρὸν πᾶν ἢ φρύγανον 'all dry items or firewood' (Hesych.). "Acc. to {ref Frisk 1960-1972}, it may replace τρώξανα (see τρώγω) after θραύω. However, the variation αυ : ω betrays a Pre-Greek word ({ref Furnée 1972}:286)".
S.v. AGk. τραύξανα 'bois sec, petit bois', a doublet of τρώξανα (cf. τρώγω) on the model of θραύω 'briser'.
λεχουτέ < verb. adj. of λεχ-ούκ̔ου which, according to {ref Andriotis 1974}:353, goes back to AG λεχώ ‘new mother’.
Cf. s.v. AGk. λεχὼ 'Wöchnerin' > Tsakon. vb. λεχ-ούκ̔ου with semantic developments 1) '(ein Kind) ins Bett liegen', 2) 'ausbrüten, wärmen'.
Cf. s.v. *legʰ- 'sich (hin)legen' (IEW 658-9).
Cf. s.v. AGk. λέχεται 'lies down in bed', from PIE *legʰ- (cf. related noun λέχος 'bed').
S.v. AGk. ζέω 'bouillir, chauffer', from a root *i̯es- (cf. Skt. yasati 'bouillonner, bouillr', OHG jesan 'fermenter, bouilloner').
S.v. *χλίος (SMG χλιός 'warm').
Cf. s.v. SMG χλιαίνω.
Cf. s.v. χλῑ̆αίνω; no etymology more precise than to Celtic and Germanic forms which signify 'brilliance', which only satisfies poorly; cf. OIr. glē 'brillant', MHG glīmen 'briller', etc.

S.v. AGk. βράσσω 'agiter, vanner'; it has been long connected by Bezzenberger (BB 27, 152f.) to Latv. murdêt 'bouillonner', Lith. murdýnas 'source', mùrdyti 'agiter dans l'eau', etc., but this is only a simple possibility.
Cf. s.v. ἄγω 'to drive, lead, bring, carry; to draw, etc.' from PIE *h₂eg̑- for the verbal element of the compound.

S.v. AGk. θήρ 'bête de proie, bête sauvage', with derived form θηρεύω 'chasser, donner la chase'; Gk. θήρ is an old root noun from PIE *gʷʰu̯ēr- (cf. East Lithuanian žvė́res vs. more common i-stem in Lith. žvėrìs, OCS zvěrĭ; Lat. fērus, etc.).
Cf. s.v. τρέχω 'laufen'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. σφάζω 'égorger', based on a Greek root σφαγ- (cf. compounds in -σφαξ), but there is no plausible etymology outside of Greek. See also φάσγανον 'sword'.
S.v. σφάζω 'morden, töten'.

S.v. AGk. κτείνω 'tuer, condamner à mort'. It is possible that the present stem κτείνυμι (with a secondary e-grade replacing *κτανυμι) corresponds to Skt. kṣa-ṇó-ti 'blesser'; the verbal adjective *-κτατος supposed by ἀνδρο-κτασίαι to Skt. a-kṣa-ta-, OPers. a-xša-ta-.
S.v. AGk. θάλασσα (Att. θάλαττα), general term for designating the sea, of obscure origin.
S.v. AGk. θάλασσα (Att. θάλαττα), general term for designating the sea, of obscure origin.
S.v. AGk. γελάω 'rire, se rire de', etc. To be connected to the Armenian word in the same sense całr, (gen. cału).
A unique Greek-Armenian lexical isogloss. Cf. for an extensive discussion of the derived vocabulary.

S.v. AGk. σκέλος 'jambe', which corresponds exactly to Lat. scelus 'crime', which originally signified 'ce qui est courbe, de travers', also found in Germanic with a suffix *-ko-, i.e. PGmc. *skélha- > OHG scëlah, OE sceolh 'de travers, tordu, etc.), with a suffix *-no- in Alb. tshalë 'boiteux, estropié.
S.v. Gk. ἁπλόος 'simple'; the first element ἁ- is evidently *sm̥-,  the zero-grade of IE *sem-, the etymology of the semantic-bearing head of the compound is less clear.
S.v. AGk. μακρός 'long, mince, grand', from a well-attested root *māk̑-/*mək̑- (cf. Lat. macies 'maigreuer', macer 'maigre', also in OHG magar, ON magr, etc.; perhaps OIr. mēr 'doigt' < *makro-).

S.v. AGk. ἄνθρωπος 'homme, être humain'. Etymology unclear (see {ref Frisk 1960-1972} for various older hypotheses). Mycenaean atoroqo could suggest the existence of a second term -ōkʷo- (expressing the idea of face or appearance?), cf. ὄψ 'eye', πρόσωπον 'face' but this remains speculative.

S.v. AGk. ἄνθρωπος 'homme, être humain'. Etymology unclear (see {ref Frisk 1960-1972} for various older hypotheses). Mycenaean atoroqo could suggest the existence of a second term -ōkʷo- (expressing the idea of face or appearance?), cf. ὄψ 'eye', πρόσωπον 'face' but this remains speculative.
S.v. AGk. κρέας 'morceau de viande, viande', traditionally connected to Skt. kraviṣ-, etc.

S.v. AGk. σελήνη 'lune' (Dor. -ᾱ́νᾱ, -ᾰ́ννᾱ), a derivative of σέλας with a derivational suffix in *-nā, cf. further s.v. σέλας, -αος 'éclat, lueur brillante'. Further etymology obscure, cf. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} for various older proposals.

Cf. s.v. AGk. φέγγος, -ους 'lumière, clarté, éclat', φέγγος vaguely resembles Lith. spingė́ti 'louire doucement', OE spincan 'jeter des étincelles' etc. for which {ref IEW} 989 reconstructs *speng-, but there are difficulties in reconciling the initial consonant cluster. Another hypothesis is an old blend of *σπεγγος with φάος (so {ref Frisk 1960-1972}). In sum, nothing clear or certain.
Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥάχις, -ιος 'colonne vertébrale, échine', generally compared to Lith. ražỹs 'chaume', rãžas 'chaume, pointe de fourche, branche sèche' to a root *u̯rā̆gʰ- cf. {ref IEW} 1180.
S.v. AGk. βουνός 'montagne, colline'. Etymology unknown, attributed to the Cyrenaean dialect by Herodotus.
S.v. AGk. ὄρος 'montagne, hauteur', a verbal noun from the same root as the verb ὄρνυμαι, ὀρέσθαι 's'élever' with the vocalism of the verb rather than the expected e-grade; cf. Skt. r̥ṣvá- 'haut'.
Cf. s.v. *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-9).
S.v. AGk. στόμα 'bouche, gueule, embouchure, entrée', to be connected with Av. staman- 'gueule (d'un chien)'.

S.v. AGk. στενός (Ion. στεινός, Aeol. στέννος), going back to an earlier *στενϝός which may have been a thematisation of an original u-stem (cf. compounds such as Στενύ-κληρος), but an etymology outside of Greek is unclear.
S.v. AGk. ἐγγύς (adv.) 'proche'; it is tempting to see in ἐγγύς the old noun for 'hand' as in ἐγγύη (cf. s.v. γύη, γύαλον, etc. with the preverb ἐν in the sense 'at hand').

Cf. s.v. AGk. πλάσσω 'façonner, former', the family of related vocabulary rests on a root πλαθ- with a present stem formation *πλαθ-i̯e/o- > πλάσσω. No certain etymology, but a connection with the root *pelh₂- 'étendre, étendue' is probable.
S.v. AGk. σκόλλυς 'toupet', a hypocoristic term with gemination, with the same root as in σκολύπτειν, cf. s.v.

S.v. AGk. τράχηλος 'cou, gorge', in contrast to δέρη and αὐχην 'nuque' probably a familiar and expressive creation in Greek. The connection with the family of τρέχω (Pedersen IF 5, 1895, 56, etc.) is the most plausible as 'part of the body that turns'. In many languages  the name of the neck is attached to the notion 'tourner' and 'roue', cf. OCS vratъ to vratiti 'tourner', Lith. kãklas apparently to Gk. κύκλος, etc.

S.v. AGk. πάλαι adv. 'autrefois, il y a longtemps', with derived adjective παλαιός 'vieux (dit de personnes, de vin, de vaisseaux)'. An adverb in -αι with an obscure final, perhaps a locative. Traditionally the etymology was supposed to be a zero-grade formation with the same root as τῆλε 'au loin', Boeot. πήλυι, but the appearance of Mycenaean parajo complicates this problem, as there one would expect an initial labiovelar to be preserved. Therefore this etymology must be abandoned.

Argues for connecting the root of πάλαι to the same root underlying πέλας 'near', πελάζω 'approach, draw near', πίλναμαι 'draw near, approach', πλησίον 'near' (adv.) from *pelh₂-, in the sense *'in the (near, recent) past' > 'old'.

From Ancient Greek παλαιός, -ά, -όν 'old, aged, ancient', derived from the adverb πάλαι, probably a fossilised case form of a root noun *pl̥h₂-ei̯ and to be connected with πέλας 'near', πελάζω 'approach, draw near', πίλναμαι 'draw near, approach', πλησίον 'near' (adv.) from *pelh₂-, in the sense *'in the (near, recent) past' > 'old' ({ref Chadwick 1976}, {ref Beekes 2010}:1144-1145). Older etymologies attempting to connect to the same root as Att. τῆλε 'far away' (cf. Aeol. πήλυι) cannot be correct since Mycenaean pa-ra-jo does not contain a labiovelar as one would expect ({ref Chantraine 1968–1980}:851, {ref Beekes 2010}:1144-1145).
Cf. s.v. AGk. ταῦρος 'taureau', corresponding to Lat. taurus, Osc. τουρομ (acc.sg.), Umb. turuf, Lith. taũras 'buffle, aurochs', OPr. tauris 'bison', OCS turŭ, Gaul. taruos (with metathesis).

Cf. s.v. OLith. taũras 'Auerochs, Büffel, Stier' (BSl. Latv. tàurs, taũrs 'Auerochse', OPr. tauris 'wesant (Wisent)' OCS turъ 'Stier'), from PIE *tau̯ro- 'Auerochse, Stier' (cf. Gk. ταῦρος 'Stier', Lat. taurus 'Stier', Gaul. tarvos 'Stier', OIr. tarb 'id.', MW tarw 'id.', Alb. ter 'Stier, Rind, Bulle').
S.v. AGk. λαχτίζω 'mit dem Fuß ausschlagen, einen Fußtritt geben' > λαχτῶ (Kapp.).

S.v. AGk. λάξ adv. 'avec le pied, le talon' with denominative verb λακτίζω 'donner un coup de pied, de talon, ruer'. An adverbial formation comparable to γνύξ, ὀδάξ, πύξ; perhaps comparable to Lat. calx requiring an earlier *κλάξ with dissimilation, but Lat. calx is itself obscure. Other hypotheses even less likely.
S.v. Gk. νηρὸν 'Wasser' > It. ta nerá 'le pioggie', nerò tu kjerú 'acqua piovana'.

S.v. AGk. βρέχω 'tremper, inonder, remplir d'eau'. Of obscure etymology, long connected with Balto-Slavic terms (cf. Latv. merguôt 'pleuvoir doucement', Ru. morositĭ 'pleuvoir doucement' which can go back to an IE *merg⁽ʰ⁾-, *mregʰ-.
S.v. ἀληθινός 'wahr', 'echt' > It. aliθinó 'rot'.
Derives Gk. σύρω < *tu̯or-i̯e/o- (> *tu̯ur-i̯e/o- via Cowgill's Law, with zero-grade *tur-i̯e/o- yielding σαίρω).
S.v. δραμ- aorist stem to τρέχω 'laufen' > Tsakon. δράγγε 'laufen', etc.

S.v. AGk. στρογγύλος 'rond, en forme de boule compact, courbe'; the same suffix also appears in γογγύλος, καμπύλος, ἀγκύλος, etc. The word originally signified 'mis en boule, serré', from which 'rond' from the same root as στράγξ with a different meaning 'trickle, drop'. The alternation in o / a vocalism may be seen in OHG strang.

S.v. στρογγύλος 'rund, kugelförmig, gedrungen, kompakt'; a formation like γογγ-ύλος, καμπ-ύλος, ἀγκ-ύλος etc., as *'zusammengezogen, zusammengeballt, gedrungen' to Gk. στράγξ. Here στρογγύλος can contain an old o-grade as in NHG Strang or the -o- can be secondary after γογγ-ύλος.
Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-640).

S.v. AGk. λαλέω 'bavarder' (Att., etc.), 'parler' (Arist., Hellen., LXX, NT, etc.), an onomatopoeic form, cf. similarly Lat. lallō 'chanter pour endormir un enfant', Lith. lalúoti 'bégayer', Ru. lála 'bavard', etc.

S.v. λέγω, in the original sense 'rassembler, cueillir, choisir' (Hom.), later 'compter, dénombrer', finally 'raconter, dire' (Hes., Att.-Ion., etc.). A thematic root present identical to Lat. legō 'cueillir, choisir; lire'.
Cf. s.v. deṇiz 'sea', a loanword from Turkish.
Cf. s.v. Capp. τρανῶ 'I see'.

S.v. AGk. ῥάπτω (Myc. pass.part. erapemena), the evidence of Mycenaean ruins the traditional etymology which connects Baltic lexemes (e.g. Lith. verpiù, ver̃pti 'filer', etc.) due to the lack of initial w- in the Mycenaean form.
S.v. keskin 'sharp', a loan from Turkish.

S.v. AGk. δέρω  'écorcher, dépouiller' with derived abstract noun δέρμα, with correspondences in Germanic and Balto-Slavic (cf. Goth. dis-, ga-tairan 'déchirer, détruire', OHG (fir-)zeran, etc., Lith. derù 'dépouiller', OCS derǫ, etc.'
Cf. s.v. AGk. κεῖμαι 'être couché, être placé' with exact correspondences in Indo-Iranian (Skt. śéte, Av. saēte 'être couché, placé', cf. also Hitt. kitta, kittari).
S.v. AGk. κύπτω 'se pencher en avant, se courber, baisser la tête', maybe backformed from the perfect stem κέκυφα, maybe further connected to Skt. kubhrá- 'buffle bossu', but this is doubtful.

S.v. NHG glatt (MHG glat, OHG glat, OS glad- 'froh') from Germanic *glada- 'glatt, schlüpfrig'. Outside of Germanic one compares Lat. glaber 'glatt, kahl' (*gʰladʰ-ro-) and with full-grade Lith. glod(n)ùs, OCS gladŭkŭ- 'glatt, eben'. Further origins uncertain.
S.v. AGk. ὁμός 'un, le même, commun, uni' with related derivative ὁμαλός, a derivative of IE *sem- (cf. Lat. semel, similis, Goth. simlē 'une fois, autrefois', OHG simble, etc.).

S.v. κωφός 'émoussé', with derivative κωφίας (also gloss in Hesych. ὄφεως εἶδος, ὁ καὶ τυφλίας), surely to be connected to κηφήν 'faux bourdon', a derived substantive in -ήν, -άν of an adjective *κηφός (*καφός?), perhaps also connected to κέκηφε· τέθνηκε (Hesych.). These connections present a problem of an alternation ᾱ/ω which is exceptional but not without parallel.
S.v. Gk. ῥαπίς 'Rute' > It. ramíδa 'verga', 'lungo bastone'; the -m- is due to contamination with Lat. ramus.

Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥαπίζω 'to beat with a stick, a rod, by hand', (pass.) 'to be beaten'. The simplex ῥαπίς may have been extracted from χρυσό-ρραπις where -ις can be explained as a compound suffix. Further analysis of the basis is uncertain, with several possibilities either to an unattested noun *ῥάψ, *ῥαπ-ή vel sim., or as a primary verb, or a zero-grade formation of ῥέπω, cf. also ῥώψ, ῥάβδος, ῥάμνος, ῥάπτω. A final possibility is a substratum origin.

S.v. ῥάβδος 'baguette, badine', probably related to ῥάμνος and ῥαπίς, usually connected to Lith. vir̃bas 'branche, baguette', etc., OCS vrъba, Ru. vérba 'osier' with a zero-grade, with an e-grade in Lat. uerbera 'verges, coups'.
S.v. λίθος 'pierre', etymology unknown.
S.v. πέτρα 'roche, rocher', of the etymologies enumerated by {ref Frisk 1960-1972} none are satisfying.

S.v. ὀρθός 'upright, straight, right, true'. Traditionally from PIE *h₃rdʰ-u̯o- and cognate Skt. ūrdhvá- 'raised, high' and derived from *u̯ordʰ-u̯o-. However, there is no evidence for initial u̯- in Mycenaean where it is expected.
Cf. s.v. ὀρθός 'debout, dressé', cf. for an overview of competing etymological proposals.
S.v. Gk. γλυκύς 'doux', a single ingenious hypothesis, but on narrow ground: if one admits a development *δλ- > γλ- supposing *δλυκύς one may connect Lat. dulcis.
S.v. κέρκος 'queue mince d'un animal (sauf en principe pour les oiseaux), porc, chien, etc.). Etymology unknown.
Cf. s.v. λεῖος 'smooth', probably from a root PIE * lei̯- 'smooth' with a derived u-stem that has been later thematised, i.e. *lei̯-u̯-o- > *λεῖϝο-, cf. Lat. lēvis 'smooth'.
Tsakonian λιανέ < MedG λειανός ‘thin, narrow’ < AG λεῖος ‘smooth’.
S.v. AGk. ψιλός 'bald, bare, smooth, exposed'. No etymology. Some parallels are found in the group of words around ψῆν 'to rub, grate, scratch, stroke, wipe' but the formation remains unclear.
S.v. AGk. ψιλός 'chauve, glabre, pelé, à poil ras', an adjective in -λο- to the expressive base ψίω, and further connected with the group of ψῆν, but no clear IE etymology.

S.v. AGk. λέπω 'éplucher, enlever l'écorce', etc. (derived adjective λεπτός). No correspondences outside of Greek for the verbal stem, but there are nominal stems that correspond formally to the Greek forms (cf. Lith. lãpas 'feuille', Alb. lapë 'lambeau, feuille', Lith. lõpas 'pièce, lambeau').
S.v. AGk. νόος, with denominative verb νοέω, clearly a nomen actionis with o-grade vocalism, but no known etymology outside of Greek.
Cf. s.v. AGk. συλλογίζομαι 'berechnen, schließen, folgern' > 'denken'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. λέγω 'collect, gather; to count, recount; say', from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' (cf. Lat. legō 'collect', etc.).
S.v. οἴομαι 'avoir l'impression que', etc. The variant forms appear to go back to *ὀϝις-yομαι, but the etymology is unknown.
Derives Gk. σύρω < *tu̯or-i̯e/o- (> *tu̯ur-i̯e/o- via Cowgill's Law, with zero-grade *tur-i̯e/o- yielding σαίρω).
Cf. s.v. AGk. ἄνεμος 'wind' < PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'wind' (= Lat. animus; cf. Skt. ánila- 'wind, air' < *h₂énh₂lo-; Arm. hołm < *h₂onh₁-mo-, with *n > l dissimilation).
Cf. s.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (IEW 38-9).

S.v. AGk. ῥίπτω 'jeter violemment, brandir, jeter à bas, arracher'. Etymology obscure. The forms go back to a root *ϝριπ- with a present suffix -ye/o-; {ref IEW} 1159 supposes *wrī-p- and a connection to Germanic lexemes meaning 'frotter, tourner' in OHG rīban, MHG rīben, MLG wrīven.
S.v. γλῶχες, γλωχίς, γλῶσσα. The etymology of the hapax γλῶχες that is the basis of the word family has not been established. The proposed connection with OCS glogъ 'épine', etc. is uncertain.

S.v. AGk. ξύλον 'bois', one usually connects Lith. šùlas 'bâton, poteau, pilier' postulating IE *ksulo-, and with different vocalism forms in Slavic and Germanic  (Ru. šúlo 'pieu', OHG sūl 'poteau, colonne').

Cf. s.v. OLith. šùlas 'Säule, Pfeiler, Stab' (BSl. cf. OPr. sulis 'Ständer', SCr. šȗlj 'abgesägter Baumstamm, Holzblock', Ru. šúlo (dial.) 'Zaunpfahl', from PIE *ksúlo- 'Holzblock (cf. Gk. ξύλον 'Holz, Baum; Balken, Stock'). Fully unclear is the connection of the Germanic lexemes in the group of Goth. sauls 'Säule', etc.

S.v. AGk. σῶς 'sain et sauf, en bonne santé; en bon état; sûr, certain'. If one accepts the analysis of Leumann, the forms go back to σαϝο- to which one may compare Skt. távas-vānt-, tavā́ḥ, turá- 'fort', pf. tutāva, Av. tav- 'être en état de'. One considers with a zero-grade characteristic of a u-stem *tw-ə₂-ú- > *σαΰς replaced by thematic *σαϝος > σῶς (cf. Beekes, Laryngeals 249).
S.v. AGk. γῡρός 'rond, courbé', recalls the root *geu-/*gu- in γύαλον, but note the u is long (popular variation?). {ref IEW} 397f. compares Arm. kuṙ-n 'dos' with another vocalism kor 'courbé'.
(α)παλυμένο. p.ptcp of AG ἁπαλύνω ‘to soften’
S.v. AGk. χρόνος 'temps', of unknown etymology; cf. entry for further discussion of previous proposals.

S.v. σκώληξ 'ver' entre autres 'ver de terre', derivative in the suffix -ηκ- (probably earlier -ᾱκ-) used with various small animals, cf. μύρμηξ 'ant'. The base *σκῶλος may perhaps be an analogy to καλύπτω 'hide' or σκολύπτω 'cut short'.
Cf. s.v. SMG αναγουλιάζω < ανα- + -γουλ(ιάζω) < Hellenistic Greek γούλ(α) 'λαιμός'.

S.v. λευκός, -ή, -όν, formally corresponding to Skt. rocá- 'brillant' next to the present stem rócate, cf. also OIr. luach, Lith. laũkas, etc.; with o-grade Lat. lūcus, Skt. loká-, Lith. laûkas, OHG loh.
Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).

S.v. τρέπω 'tournet, diriger vers, se tourner vers, changer, mettre en fuite'. The etymology is a problem. On may connect Skt. trápate 'avoir honte, être embarrassé' which remarkably resembles the sense of ἐντρέπομαι; Lat. trepit (P.F. 504,23) may be the creation of a grammarian. One could also think of a base *trekʷ-/*trokʷ- in view of Mycenaean toroqejomeno which is confirmed by toroqo 'torsade', or 'façon' applied to wool, but these words could also be in turn be connected with στρέφω. One also considers Lat. torqueō, cf. also εὐτρόσσεσθαι· ἐπιστρέφεσθαι· Πάφοι (Hesych.) < *trokʷ-i̯e-?

S.v. τρέπω 'tournet, diriger vers, se tourner vers, changer, mettre en fuite'. The etymology is a problem. On may connect Skt. trápate 'avoir honte, être embarrassé' which remarkably resembles the sense of ἐντρέπομαι; Lat. trepit (P.F. 504,23) may be the creation of a grammarian. One could also think of a base *trekʷ-/*trokʷ- in view of Mycenaean toroqejomeno which is confirmed by toroqo 'torsade', or 'façon' applied to wool, but these words could also be in turn be connected with στρέφω. One also considers Lat. torqueō, cf. also εὐτρόσσεσθαι· ἐπιστρέφεσθαι· Πάφοι (Hesych.) < *trokʷ-i̯e-?

S.v. τρέπω 'to turn, revolve, put to flight; to turn oneself, change, take flight, etc.', from PIE *trep- to turn' (cf. Lat. trepit 'vertit' (Paul. Fest. p.367), Skt. trapate 'feels ashamed, beomes timid', Hitt. terepp- 'to plough'). "The connection of Myc. to-ro-qe-jo-me-no (meaning unknown; with q) and of Lat. torqueō is untenable."
S.v. AGk. καρπός 'fruit', to be connected with Lat. carpō 'cueillir', probably a zero-grade; with an e-grade cf. Lith. kerpù 'couper avec des ciseaux'.
Cf. s.v. *(s)kerp- 'abschneiden, abrupfen' (IEW 944-5), cf. n1: often of the harvest, cf. Gk. καρπός 'Frucht', Germ. *harbista- 'Ernte' > 'Herbst'.
S.v. AGk. καρπός 'fruit', to be connected with Lat. carpō 'cueillir', probably a zero-grade; with an e-grade cf. Lith. kerpù 'couper avec des ciseaux'.
Cf. s.v. *(s)kerp- 'abschneiden, abrupfen' (IEW 944-5), cf. n1: often of the harvest, cf. Gk. καρπός 'Frucht', Germ. *harbista- 'Ernte' > 'Herbst'.
S.v. AGk. σαχνός 'tender, mellow'. "Derivation from σώχω, ψώχω 'to rub down' has been assumed, but the details remain unclear. The variations σ-/ψ- and -κ-/-χ- point to Pre-Greek origin".
S.v. AGk. σαχνός 'tendre', one connects the present σώχω (Hdt.) but the but the alternation ω/α is rare.
The word is Common Slavic but there is no convincing Slavic etymology. It is not excluded that it is a loanword from Germanic, cf. Old High German glas 'amber'.

Frequently connected to a common root *kʷu̯ap- or *kʷu̯eh₂p- uniting the Baltic forms with Lat. vapor 'vapour, steam' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:654, and Gk. καπνός (cf. further discussion in /cognate/1583/), but due to several irregular sound changes necessary to justify the comparison, the etymology is not fully certain.
S.v. Lith. kvė̃pti 'inhale, breathe in, inspire', possibly from *k⁽ʷ⁾h₂uēp- and connected with Gk. καπνός 'smoke, Lat vapor 'steam, heat' (both probably < *k⁽ʷ⁾uh₂ep-).

S.v. καπνός 'fumée, vapeur, fumet'. A form *κϝαπ-νός corresponds well to the root of Lith. kvãpas 'souffle, haleine'm etc., with e-vocalism Lith. kvėpiù, kvė̃pti 'haleter, respirer', etc. Latv. kvêpstu, kvêpt 'fumer, exhaler', etc., possibly also to Lat. vapor, but the expected initial qu- is lacking. For further uncertain comparisons cf. {ref IEW} 596.

Cf. s.v. OLith. kvė̃pti 'atmen, hauchen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kvêpt 'qualmen, rauchen', etc.). These lexemes are probably not to be separated from Lat. vapor, -ōris 'Dampf, Dunst', Gk. καπνός 'Raum, Qualm, Dunst', continuing a root *kʷu̯ap- or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-. Improbable is an etymological connection with Goth. afƕapjan 'ersticken', etc.
Russian glaz 'eye' does not have any commonly accepted etymology. Most probably it is derived from the same root as Russian gladkij 'smooth'.

S.v. AGk. πρᾱ́σσω 'achever, accomplir, travailler à, traiter une affaire, pratiquer'. The Homeric usages guarantee that is may be derived from a more basic root πρᾱ-, cf. πραθῆναι and see s.v. πέρνημαι and that the whole family depends on the root of πείρω, πέρᾱ, etc. The final velar must connote the outcome of the process (cf. Schwyzer Gr. Gr. I:702).

Cf. s.v. OLith. šùlas 'Säule, Pfeiler, Stab' (BSl. cf. OPr. sulis 'Ständer', SCr. šȗlj 'abgesägter Baumstamm, Holzblock', Ru. šúlo (dial.) 'Zaunpfahl', from PIE *ksúlo- 'Holzblock (cf. Gk. ξύλον 'Holz, Baum; Balken, Stock'). Fully unclear is the connection of the Germanic lexemes in the group of Goth. sauls 'Säule', etc.

S.v. AGk. ξύλον 'bois', one usually connects Lith. šùlas 'bâton, poteau, pilier' postulating IE *ksulo-, and with different vocalism forms in Slavic and Germanic (Ru. šúlo 'pieu', OHG sūl 'poteau, colonne').

S.v. AGk. ξύλον 'bois', one usually connects Lith. šùlas 'bâton, poteau, pilier' postulating IE *ksulo-, and with different vocalism forms in Slavic and Germanic (Ru. šúlo 'pieu', OHG sūl 'poteau, colonne').

Cf. s.v. OLith. šùlas 'Säule, Pfeiler, Stab' (BSl. cf. OPr. sulis 'Ständer', SCr. šȗlj 'abgesägter Baumstamm, Holzblock', Ru. šúlo (dial.) 'Zaunpfahl', from PIE *ksúlo- 'Holzblock (cf. Gk. ξύλον 'Holz, Baum; Balken, Stock'). Fully unclear is the connection of the Germanic lexemes in the group of Goth. sauls 'Säule', etc.

S.v. κοντός 'petit, court' (Late Greek and Byzantine); the oldest attestation in the meaning 'short' appears to be κοντοπορεία 'chemin de plus court entre Corinthe et Argos' (Polybius 16.16, Athenaeus 43e); other early forms appear to be in compounds like κοντο-μάχος, -βόλος, -βολέω. Perhaps this semantic evolution was originally in military vocabulary.

S.v. κοντός 'petit, court' (Late Greek and Byzantine); the oldest attestation in the meaning 'short' appears to be κοντοπορεία 'chemin de plus court entre Corinthe et Argos' (Polybius 16.16, Athenaeus 43e); other early forms appear to be in compounds like κοντο-μάχος, -βόλος, -βολέω. Perhaps this semantic evolution was originally in military vocabulary.

S.v. στρέφω 'tourner, détourner'. The lexical root forms a coherent system in Greek, but there is no known etymology outside of Greek. If connected to Mycenaean kusutoroqa, then we should reconstruct a final labiovelar.

S.v. στρεβλός 'tortillé, tordu, enroulé', the voiced labial β marks the expressive and popular character of this family of words; the verbal in the general sense is στρέφω 'tourner, détourner', cf. s.v. [in /cognate/1558/] where the lexical root forms a coherent system in Greek, but there is no known etymology outside of Greek. If connected to Mycenaean kusutoroqa, then we should reconstruct a final labiovelar.
S.v. AGk. ῥόδον 'rose', a borrowing from a language of the east, probably from Iranian *u̯r̥da- from which Persian gul, likewise Armenian vard.

S.v. AGk. χόνδρος 'gruau'. Various proposals; perhaps to Lat. frendō 'grincer des dents, broyer' and OE grindan 'moudre' on a base *gʰrendʰ- if from earlier *χρονδρος with dissimilation of the first ρ, although the non-aspirated *d in the Greek and Latin forms would be unexplained. Alternatively, according to Szemerényi (Mélanges Chantraine) the word is a loanword from Semitic (cf. Ugaritic ḫndrṭ 'vieux froment'.
S.v. κανείς 'no one', in certain Cappadocian dialects meaning 'a person'.
Tsakon. σ̌υλωμένο < p.ptcp of AG χυλόω, -ῶ

S.v. AGk. χῡλός 'jus', long connected to the root of χέω, but the zero-grade is χῠ-; two explanations have been proposed: 1) a popular expressive vocalism or 2) supposing a suffix -σλο- with cluster simplification and compensatory lengthening, abut the doublet in -σλο- is otherwise unparalleled.
Cf. s.v. SMG πιάνω, remodelled from Hellenistic πιάζω, Ancient Greek πιέζω.
PS *glazŭ is most probably *gl-a-zŭ, derived from PIE *g(h)el- 'something round, spherical; small stone'. There are many other disputable hypotheses.

PS *glazŭ 'small, smooth, spheric stone; peeble; amber, glass ball; bead'. There is no clear etymology. It is often assumed that the Slavic lexeme is a loanword from PG *glāza (c.f Old High German glas 'amber') which is derived from PIE *g̑ʰel- / gʰel- 'shine, glitter'.

Russian glaz is possibly related to CS gleznŭ, glezno 'malleolus' and further to Old Icelandic klakkr 'clod'. Other hypotheses (assuming a relationship to PS *gladŭkŭ 'smooth', *ględati 'see, look', to Old High German glas 'amber, glass' or a borrowing of its PG cognate) are inconvincing.

Derived from *PS *pŭk-, a variant of *puk-, cf. *pukati 'bang, knock, beat'. The semantic development would be 'bang, knock, beat' > 'fall with a loud noise' > 'fall' then. The hypothesis about a relationship to PS *potknǫti sę 'stumble' is phonetically and morphologically inconvincing. The interpretation of the Polabian attestations as representing PS *padati is misreading.
Cf. for a recent attempt at an etymology.

Re: Sogd. wcny: Rejects Henning's etymology < *witacina- and proposes derication from *watuša- < *wetuso-. This view is also supported by the fact that the development *čn > *šn postulated by Henning (followed by Gershevtich) is ad hoc. The rare spelling appears to support Henning, but may possibly be secondary (influence of following /č/ or just for [ə]). The absence of in all other attestations is rather unusual for original *wi-.

S.v. AGk. ὄξυς 'aigu, pointu'. The word ὀξύς shows the same difficulties in vocalism as ὄκρις, Lat. ocris with regard to the large family of words based on ἀκ-. On the other hand one tries to connect the s of ὀξύς the from the sigmatic root included in ἀκοστή, the compounds in -ήκης, Lat. acus. Cf. {ref IEW} 21.
Cf. for earlier proposed connections to PIE *ak̑- (*h₂ek̑-) 'sharp'.

S.v. AGk. ὄξυς 'aigu, pointu'. The word ὀξύς shows the same difficulties in vocalism as ὄκρις, Lat. ocris with regard to the large family of words based on ἀκ-. On the other hand one tries to connect the s of ὀξύς the from the sigmatic root included in ἀκοστή, the compounds in -ήκης, Lat. acus. Cf. IEW 21.
S.v. AGk. ἴσος 'gleich' > Tsakon. ἴσε.

S.v. AGk. ἴσος 'equal' in number, strength, size, status, etc. (dial. Arc., Cret. Boeot. attests ϝίσϝος). Formally, earlier *u̯itˢu̯o- would work, but the proposed connection to a zero-grade *ϝιδσ- from εἶδος 'shape' is hypothetical. Other proposed etymologies are unconvincing.
S.v. ἴσος 'égal, en nombre égal, également partagé, égal en droit'. The original structure of the word ϝίσϝος is certain, but the etymology is not established.

In spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. {ref Hamp 1972}). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:322, {ref Beekes 2010}:299-300) generally follow the proposal of {ref Kortlandt 1985a}, assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'. Under this interpretation the related Hittite form išḫaḫru- is considered an original compound of *skʷ-h₂k̑ru-, although this formulation has its own etymological difficulties (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:391 in /cognate/8095/).

S.v. Lat. lacrimāre 'cry, weep', a denominal verb from Lat. lacruma, dacruma 'tear'. Lat. lacruma, dacruma is often considered to be a loanword from Gk. δάκρυμα 'tear' on the basis that an inherited preform *dakru-mn̥ would have yielded **dacrumen in Latin, and additionally the suffix -ma is not productive in Latin (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:336). {ref Hamp 1972}:291-99, however, points out that Greek δάκρυμα is itself a recent formation in Greek, is not attested before the fifth century, and is never attested as the regular word for 'tear' (i.e. δάκρυον). Perhaps the Greek forms and the Latin forms can be reconciled via an dissimilation *d ... *n > d ... m of an earlier preform *dakruna > *dakruma (cf. the distance dissimilation *m … *b > n … b attested *temebrae > tenebrae, cf. tenebrae, s.v.), but this solution is admittedly speculative.
S.v. Lat. lacruma (lacrima), -ae (OLat. dacrima according to Paulus ex Festus 60, 5), possibly a loanword from Greek δάκρυμα.

Occasionally considered a loanword from Ancient Greek δάκρῡμα (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:336). Elsewhere, in spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru- 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. {ref Hamp 1972}). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:322, {ref Beekes 2010}:299-300) generally follow the proposal of {ref Kortlandt 1985a}, assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'. Under this interpretation the related Hittite form išḫaḫru- is considered an original compound of *skʷ-h₂k̑ru-, although this formulation has its own etymological difficulties (cf. {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:391 in /cognate/8095/).

S.v. AGk. δάκρυ 'larme', connected with the old words for tear in Armenian artasu-kʻ (pl.), Germanic (OHG trahan, etc.), and Celtic (OIr. dēr, etc.). The eastern group of Indo-European has a form without an initial dental (cf. Skt. áśru-, Av. asrū-, Lith. āšarà-, TochA ākrunt, TochB ākrūna). Lat. dacruma, lacrima is possibly a loan from Greek.
S.v. SMG υγρός, a inner-Greek borrowing from Ancient Greek ὑγρός 'wet'.
S.v. Ro. scrum, cf. Bulg. skrum, Alb. shkrump.
Cf. s.v. AGk. ἰσχίον 'hip-joint, haunches', no etymology.

The Slavic lexeme is usually linked to PS *dĭlgŭ(jĭ). However, the apophonic relationship is somehow complicated. An alternative etymology links the Slavic word to Lithuanian tolì, tolùs 'far' (which has a pronominal etymology).
Cf. s.v. Hitt. kappuwai- 'tally, reckon, calculate' for older etymological proposals.

PS *tlŭstŭ is derived from PIE *tu-l- / tū-l-, ultimately from *teu̯(ə)- / *tēu̯- / *tū̆- 'swell'. PS *tukŭ is derived from PIE *teu̯-k-, ultimately from *tēu̯(ə)- / *tēu̯- / *təu̯ / *tū 'swell'.
PS *mazati 'smear' is derived from PIE *maĝ-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *mastь 'ointment' (ESSJa XVII 30-31) and Proto-Slavic *mazati 'smear, anoint'. Two possibilities: either (1) to Balto-Slavic * are derived from PIE *maĝ- (*meh₂ĝ-).
S.v. Hitt. hulla-, hulliya- 'smash, defeat'. Cf. for older etymological proposals.
Cf. s.v. *mag̑- 'streichen, schmieren' See n1: Not *meh₂g̑- (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:219n75).
PIE *sed- 'sit', among others cognates OCS saditi 'plant' and seděti 'sit'.
PS *sadlo 'inner fat' is derived from PS *saditi 'plant, seat' (the etymological meaning is 'something that silts up').
The word is derived from PIE *sed- 'sit' or *sah₂- 'sate'.
Russian salo is related to sadit' 'seat'. The etymological meaning is 'something that silts on the meat'.
The Belarusian lexeme is a loanword from Polish tłuszcz.
PS *žirŭ does not have a commonly accepted etymology. It can be related to PS *žiti 'live' or PS *žerti 'eat, raven'.
The Slavic lexeme is most probably related to PS *žiti 'live'.

S.v. Hitt. (SI) šāu̯ītra-, (SI) šāu̯ātar- 'horn (a musical instrument); horn (a drinking vessel)' (cf. Pal. šāu̯ita/ir- (n.?) 'horn(?)'). Earlier attempts at an IE etymology unconvincing. Possibly a loanword.
PS *žirŭ is derived from *žerti 'eat, raven'. Another possibility is to assume a relationship to *žiti 'live'.
*gʷi̯eh₃- 'live', *gʷerh₃- 'swallow'.
PS *žirŭ hat two possible etymologies: it can be related to *žĭrati 'eat, raven' or to *žiti 'live'.
S.v. (UZU) titita- n.? 'Nase, Schnauze', probably a nursery word, but cf. entry for various other proposals.

PS *otĭcĭ is derived from PIE *att-iko-s, an adjectival formation ('paternal') which was later reinterpreted as a substantive ('father'), cf. Greek ἀττικός. It is related to Greek ἄττα, Latin atta, Gothic atta, Old Indic attā 'mather', Albanian at, Irish aite 'guardian', Ossetian œda and Hittite attaš.

It is an archaic kinship term comparable with *baba, *papa, *tata and *mama. Despite the widespread etymology, it is not derived from *brat(r)ŭ 'brother' (some attested relationship of these words are secondary). The lexeme can be related to Latin pater etc. The initial b- would be of expressive nature then.

The word can be related to Latin pater etc. or derived (by a phonetic simplification) from *bratrŭ 'brother'. It is not justified to assume a loan (from Iranian or Turkic) or a Balkan substrate word here.
S.v. Hitt. arrir(a)- 'abkratzen'. Without etymology, likely of onomatopoetic formation with a kind of expressive reduplication.

The etymology of this word is obscure. The most of scholars assume a diminutive formation from PS *brat(r)ŭ 'brother'. Some scholars propose a relationship to Mycenaean Greek βάττος 'king' and a protoform *bhati̯-. It has been also linked to PIE *pəter-. After all, the lexeme is sometimes described as a substrate word or a loan from Turkic, Iranian or Hungarian. All these hypothesis are inconvincing. The Slavic lexeme was probably formed independently in child speech.
It is a diminutive of PS *brat(r)ŭ 'brother'.
The PS lexeme is assumed to be derived fro PIE *pə-ter- / *pa-tr 'father' with an expressive weakening of the initial stop.
It is etymologically a diminutive derivative from brat 'brother'.

The lexeme is derived from *bratrŭ 'brother' (meanings like 'father' or 'uncle' are secondary). The instability of the internal -r- segments could arise by a distant dissimilation. It probably was a diminutive (nursery) form of PS *b(r)at(r)ŭ. Cf. Russian dialectal bat, batan 'brother; cousin'.

S.v. mel(ul)i-, mil(ul)i-, maluli- 'flesh(y) tissue, soft parts, body fat, marrow', perhaps to be related to Gk. μέλος 'limb', Lat. membrum, Ved. márman- 'soft spot', Lith. mélmenys 'small of the back, lumbar adipose'.
Cf. s.v. mīluli-, maluli-, meluli- 'Haut (?), Fleisch (?), weiches Gewebe(?)'.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ab/f- 'to call, utter (sing, speak, sim.)', cf. OAv. uf- 'to sing', no clear etymology outside of Iranic.
It is a typical nursery word with a syllabic reduplication. Cf. similar words in other IE languages: Latin tata, Greek tétta, Old Indi tatás or Lithuanian tė̃tis.
A nursery word with many parallels in Slavic and IE.
A nursery word with many parallels (with many different meanings) in other (Slavic) languages.
The Polabian lexeme is a loanword, cf. Eastern Frisian heite 'father', Old Frisian heitha 'father', Geman Dialectal aite 'father'.
The Polabian lexeme is a loanword from Lower German Vadder 'father'.
The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian bijóti(s), Old Indic bháyate, Avestan bayente etc.
S.v. Khw. hwβ '(herab)fallen, einstürzen; geraten (in Kummer, usw.)', from a stem *hauba-? A root *haub-/hub- is otherwise unknown.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *bauǰ-² 'to release, free, open; to save, deliver' (cf. YAv. būj- 'to save, redeem'); the connection of the Khwarazmian form to this Proto-Iranic root is uncertain, but if the etymology is correct, then may be further related to PIE *bʰeug- 'to release, flee'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *xand- 'to laugh'. "This root is most likely expressive/onomatopoeic in origin, cf. Gk. καχάζω 'I laugh', Lat. cachinnō 'laugh loudly', OCS xoxotati 'to laugh loudly', Lith. kikénti 'to giggle', etc."

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *kart-¹ 'to cut'; the Khwarazmian form kcy- 'to throw (away), put on, to; to dictate' is frequently connected to this root since Henning (cf. further {ref Samadi 1986}:101-102), but it is difficult to reconcile the different meanings of the Khwarazmian verb to this root, if it is to be derived from it at all.
S.v. Khw. fyʾdrc 'ashes, embers', from -ātar-? if the element ʾdr is to be connected with Khw. ʾdr 'fire'.
S.v. Khw. mγk 'nape, neck', perhaps < Av. maγa- 'cavity' + -k?
S.v. Khw. cwb 'water', certainly not the same as NPers. ǰūb 'canal'; perhaps from *cāb < *usačā-āpah and assimilated to Turk. sūv?
S.v. Khw. ʾnbzmk 'short'; "a connection with Sogd. mwrzk, Khot. mu(l)ysga-, *mrzuka- is most improbable (-rz- to -ž-)".

S.v. Proto-Iranic *gram- 'to thunder, roar; to anger', from PIE *gʰrem- 'to roar, be angry' (cf. Goth. gramjan, OHG gremmen 'to become angry', OE gremman 'to scorn', etc., NHG grimm, Engl. grim, Lith. gramù, etc.).

Cf. s.v. Gk. μῡ́ω 'to close, be shut'; of the eyes 'shut the eyes, abate'; can be formally derived from either a root *meu̯s- or *meu̯H-; a connection to Hitt. munnae- 'to hide, conceal' was proposed by {ref Oettinger 1979}:161ff.

S.v. Hitt. parastu- 'shoot, sprout, sprig, (budding) leaf(age), (fresh) foliage, (first) greenery, (new) verdure, (bursting) bloom'; "The basic meaning plausibly has to do with the budding of leaves and flowers of trees and plants alike, pointing to /barstu-/ cognate with Old Slavic *brĭstĭ or *brĭstŭ 'bud, shoot' (Belorussian brost’, Serbian bȓst, etc.), i. e. *bhr̥stu- cognate with Hitt. par(a)s-, parsiya- 'break, burst', and with other springtime "bursts" in the vegetal and animal realms (Lith. brãzdas 'vernal tree sap', ON broddr 'beestings, colostrum')." Older comparisons with Gk. π(τ)όρθος 'shoot, sapling' are to be rejected.

Always written using the Sumerograms LÚ.ŠU.GI, but probably to be related to Hitt. mēḫur 'time, period', from which a stem *meḫuu̯ant- can be reconstructed on the basis of derived vocabulary ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:568-569, cf. derived factitive verb meḫuu̯andaḫḫ- 'to make old; to age', etc.). Further root etymology disputed. According to {ref Eichner 1973}:53-107, ultimately to PIE *meh₂- 'to be at the right time'; {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:567-568 to *mei̯h₂- 'disappear' (= {ref LIV²} 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, verschwinden sein'), or to *meh₁- 'measure' (semantically better, but formally more difficult). {ref Yakubovich 2011}:277-279 argues to *meh₁-, with the presence of Hitt. -ḫ- explained by secondary epenthesis.

S.v. Hitt. peššii̯e/a- 'throw away, to cast, shove; abandon, cast off' *h₁poi̯ + šai-/ši- 'to propel, shoot, throw' < *h₁s-i̯e/o- (cf. Skt. ásyati 'throw'); a univerbation of the preverb pe- 'away, thither' < *h₁poi̯ + šai-/ši- 'to propel, shoot, throw' < *h₁s-i̯e/o- (cf. Skt. ásyati 'throw').

Root etymology disputed. Either to *h₁es- 'throw' ({ref LIV²} 2. *h₁es-; cf. {ref Kimball 1987}; {ref Kimball 1999}:215, 391; {ref Kloekhorst 2008}:670-671 with references to earlier literature), alternatively others (cf. {ref Melchert 1994}:133) see a connection with the Hittite verb šii̯e/a- 'to shoot' and šai- 'to press' (cf. {ref LIV²} 1. *seh₁(i̯)-). Cf. also {ref HED PE, PI, PU} 27-37, Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar, Vol. 2, pp.581-584.
S.v. 2. *h₁es- 'werfen, schießen' (not in IEW) with ?siēzzi 'wirft, schleudert'; 1. *seh₁(i̯)- 'loslassen' (IEW 889-891) with ?siēzzi 'schießt'.

S.v. Goth. H98. hrugga 'ῥάβδος, staff' (only acc., at Mk. 6.8). Within Germanic cf. OE hrung 'pole', MLG, MHG runge 'pole, spoke, NE rung (of ladder). Probably from an extended form of PIE *(s)ker- 'turn, bend', *krengh-, cf. Umbr. cringatro 'shoulder-band', MIr. crūach 'heap', Lith. kriáuklas 'rib, skeleton', also OI hryggr, OE hrygcg, OF hregg, OS hruggi, OHG hrucki 'back'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hrungō- 'rung', a zero-grade formation related to *hringa- 'ring' < *krongʰ-o-, a root exclusive to Germanic and Slavic  which violates the IE constraint against the co-occurrence of plain stops and voiced aspirates, making it likely that the root was created post-PIE.

Cf. s.v. Engl. rung, to be connected with WFris. ronge 'structural support in a cart', MDu. ronge, rong, rung 'structural support in a cart (Dutch rong)', MLG runge, ronge 'rod, structural support or rail in a cart', OHG runga 'rod, structural support in a cart' (MHG runge, NHG Runge), Goth. hrugga (rendering ancient Greek ῥάβδος rod), further etymology uncertain.
S.v. Old Welsh ceng 'back' [ceing, cefn].
S.v. Bret. fall, adjective of quality 'mal, mauvais'. It is most probable that to comes from Old French faloir 'manquer' (1160), itself from popular Latin fallere.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *wlkʷo- 'bad, evil' (cf. OIr. olc), from PIE *u̯l̥kʷo- 'wolf' (cf. Skt. vŕ̥ka-, Gk. λύκος, Lat. lupus, Lith. vil̃kas, OCS vlъkъ, Goth. wulfs). Less persuasive is a suggested connection to Lat. ulciscor 'take vengeance'.

S.v. OIr. rúsc 'écorce'. According to {ref Pedersen 1909}:332 OIr. rúsc is a borrowing from Brythonic, but it could well be the other way around. In any case this doesn't provide an indication of an etymology.
S.v. Bret. klor 'cosses, gousses, écorces dures, bogues, carapaces', supposes Old Breton *clotr without correspondences in other Celtic languages.

S.v. OIr. 1 brú 'sein, ventre, matrice'. The words suppose a root *bhreus-, *bhrus-, from which Celtic created a stem *bhrusnyo-. The same root is attested in Germanic, cf. Goth. brusts, OHG brust, OE breost, OS briost, etc.

S.v. OIr. 1 brú 'sein, ventre, matrice'. The words suppose a root *bhreus-, *bhrus-, from which Celtic created a stem *bhrusnyo-. The same root is attested in Germanic, cf. Goth. brusts, OHG brust, OE breost, OS briost, etc.
S.v. Goth. B106. brusts 'σπλάγχνα, entrails, heart; στῆθος, chest', derived from IE *bʰreu̯s-, *bʰrus- 'swell' as in OIr. brú, gen. bronn 'breast, belly'.

S.v. OIr. már 'grand', common Celtic adjective (cf. Gaul. maros, W mawr, MCo. maur, Co.. mur, Bret. meur) to a root *mē- with a suffix *-ro-. The same adjective is attested a compound member in Gk. ἐγχεσί-μωρος, Slavic Volodi-měrŭ and Germanic (OHG Hlodo-mâr).

S.v. OIr. bras 'grand' and 'effronté, vaniteux, violent'. {ref IEW} distinguishes two Irish bras words: 1. bras 'rapide, emporté' which he connects with a root *bher-s- (Lat. festinare) {ref IEW} 143; 2. bras 'grand' corresponding to Brythonic bras and may be compared with Lat. grossus ({ref IEW} 485). One may only see the uncertainty of the etymology and and the unity of the Celtic languages around a stem *brasso- with a variable sense 'grand, gros' from which 'víf, violent' is without doubt an expressive word with vocalism that was subject to variation.

S.v. OIr. uiseóg, later fuiseóg 'alouette', cf. further s.v. uis 'doux, soumis, convenable'. Seems to be confused early on with uisse 'juste, convenable' to the point that it is sometimes seen as the same word. If uisse is to be connected to the root of Lat. iūstus one should look for a different etymology. It is possible that two different words have merged in their meaning.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *gremmen- 'seizure, grasp' (OIr. greimm 'seizure, grasp, profit, advantage, sway'), presupposing a stem *greb⁽ʰ⁾(h₂)-(s)men-. For the root *gʰreb(h₂)-, cf. Skt. grabh- 'seize', 3.sg.pres. gr̥bhṇā́ti, Lith. grė́biu, grė́bti 'snatch', OCS grabiti 'seize'.
Cf. s.v. *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 455).
S.v. Bret. kalon 'cœur; âme (de cordage)', from Old Breton calonn, corresponding to Cornish calon and Welsh calon, from Celtic *kal-ona-.
S.v. Manx cleeau 'breast, chest, stomach, forehead', = Ir. cliabh.
Cf. s.v. OIr. clíab 'corbeille, récipient tressé, ruche'; Zupitza has compared the word to ON hlíf 'bouclier' (BB 25 94), cf. {ref Pedersen 1909}:116.

S.v. OIr. nél 'nuage'. Attempts to reconcile to a pre-form *nebʰlo- (cf. Lat. nebula, Gk. νεφελή, OHG nebul, OE nifol) is phonetically impossible. Thurneysen's hypothesis of *miglos (cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη) with the change of *m- > *n- under the influence of nigíd 'he washes' is less plausible. The Brythonic forms (Welsh niwl, nifwl, Corn. niul may be borrowings from Lat. nūbilus (< nībulus), and according to {ref IEW} 315 Ir. nél is borrowed from Brythonic.
PS *straxŭ is related to Lithuanian strė́gti, stregiu 'harden, freeze', Latvian terglis 'stubborn' and Middle High German strac 'tight, stretched, straight'.
S.v. Bret. koumoul 'nuages', corresponding to Co. comol and W cwmwl, all three recall Lat. cumulus, although the conservation of medial -m- is difficult.
S.v. OIr.  tíag- 'aller, s'avancer, partir', to be connected with the IE root *(s)teigh- (cf. Gk. στείχω, Goth. steigan, Skt. stíghnute, etc.).
S.v. Manx coontey 'counting, thinking, considering', cf. ScG. cunndadh.
S.v. Manx keayney 'crying' (= Ir. caoine).
S.v. Bret. garm 'cri', corresponding to Co. garm, Wel. garm, and Ir. gairm, from Proto-Celtic *gar-(s)mn.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *gar(r)man- 'cry, shout', which may be derived from a zero-grade formation *g̑h₂r-smen-, cf. Proto-Celtic *gāri-, *garyo- 'word, command' (OIr. gáir), from PIE *g̑eh₂r- 'shout, call' (cf. Gk. γῆρυς 'voice, call', Lat. garrio 'chatter', OE cearu 'care, sorrow', Khot. ysār- 'to sing' (cs.)).
PS *straxŭ is derived from PIE *strōg-so- or *strōk-so, ultimately from PIE *ster- 'hard, firm'.

S.v. Bret. Troc'h 'coupe, coupure; tranchant; épaisseur', from Old Breton truch 'émousse, épais' and corresponding to Co. trogh (Old Cornish troc) 'coupé, cassé, fêlé; coupe, section', W trwch 'épaisseur, cassé', and MIr. tru, troch, from Proto-Celtic trokk-o-.
PS *straxŭ is most probably derived from PIE *strōg-so-, ultimately from PIE *(s)terg- / *(s)treg-. Another PS derivative from this root is probably *strogŭ 'austere'.
PS *straxŭ is derived from PIE *strōk-so 'hardening'. The PIE root is *ster(H)- 'hard'.
S.v. Manx reuyrey 'digging, searching', cf. Ir. rómhar.

S.v. Bret. toull 'trou, embrasure, entrée; vide, lacune', from Old Breton tull and corresponding to Co. toll 'trou, terrier', W twll 'trou', Ir. toll 'creux' and ScG. toll 'creux', from Proto-Celtic *tuk-slo-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *tullo- 'pierced, perforated', derived from PIE *teu̯k- 'beat, perforate'.
Cf. s.v 1. *teu̯k- 'stoßen, schlagen' (IEW 1032).
Cf. s.v. Bret. kaw 'cave, creux, sous-sol', like W cau 'creux, fermé' a borrowing from Lat. cavus.
S.v. Manx broghe 'dirty, soiled' (= Ir. bróghach).
Cf. s.v. *pelh₁- 'in Schwung bringen' (IEW 801). Semantic connections with the meaning 'fear' are attested also in Germanic and Greek (the linking concept is swinging hearth).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *polšiti 'scare' and further s.v. Proto-Slavic *polxъ 'fear': "Etymology unclear. The connection with Gk. πάλλω ‘sway, swing’ from *pelh₁- is a possibility, cf. παλλομένη κραδίην (Il. XXII 461) 'with pounding heart' (LIV: 469-470). The *x of the suffix must have arisen secondarily for *s".
PS *polxŭ is derived from PIE *polo-, ultimately from PIE *pel- and related to Old Nordic felms-fullr and Gothic us-filma 'frightened'.
S.v. Bret. mous 'rance, miasmatique', corresponding to W mws 'rance, fétide, puant' and MIr. mosach 'puant, infect, ignoble', from a root *meud- 'horreur, objet d'horreur'.
PS *borti, *boriti 'fight' is related to Lat. feriō, ferīre 'hit', Old High German berjan 'hit' and Lithuanian barti, baru 'chide'.
PS *biti is derived from PIE *bhei̯ə-.
S.v. OIr. mosar 'saleté', mosach 'sale'. The related Celtic words are to be connected with Gk. μύσος 'souillure, infamie' to a root *meud- via a formation *mud-so- (cf. {ref IEW} 742).

Cf. s.v. Gk. μύσος 'pollution, defilement, horrible sight', without certain etymology. Traditionally compared to words meaning 'unclean' in Celtic, Germanic, and Slavic in {ref IEW 742} (OIr. mosach < *mussāko-, LG mussig 'dirty', Ru. múslit' 'to suck, beslaver'), further compared to the root of μυδάω 'to be moist, decay' as *mud-s-o- but this remains hypothetical.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bowd-ro- 'dirty', from PIE *gʷeu̯-dʰ- 'excrement, defecate' ({ref IEW} 484), cf. Skt. guváti 'cacat', OE cwéad 'dirt'.

S.v. sal 'saléte', outside of Celtic to be connected with an adj. in -wo-, cf. OHG salo 'sombre, sale', OE salu 'id.' OIc. sǫlr 'jaune, sale', and Latin salebra 'saleté'. Russian solovój 'couleur isabelle' might also be added here, if we compare the colour term in Scandinavian.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *gn-iyo- 'beget, create, do', from PIE *g̑enh₁- (cf. Lat. gignō, Skt. jánati 'begets').
S.v. *g̑enh₁- 'erzeugen' (IEW 390-1).
S.v. OIr. madrad (matrad) 'chien', various possible comparisons with different animal names within Celtic but all rather obscure. Perhaps of onomatopoeic origin?
S.v. Old Welsh sich 'dry', borrowed from Lat. siccus.
S.v. Manx joan 'dust' (= Ir. deann).
PS *vojĭ is derived from PIE *u̯oi̯h₁-o- and related to PS *povinǫti. The Slavic lexemes are related to Sanskrit véti 'persecute, strive, chase'.

Polish wojna 'war', wojować 'fight', wojsko 'army', wój 'soldier' are derived from PIE *u̯ei̯- and related to Lithuanian výti, vejù 'chase', Old High German weidōn 'hunt', Old Indic véti, váyati 'chase', Greek ίεμαι 'hasten, go'.
S.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4). Among listed cognates are Vedic véti, Lithuanian výti and OCS povinǫti.
Polish walka 'fight' is borrowed from Old Czech válka, which is a derivative from váleti 'fight, pull'.

Czech válka 'war' etc. is limited to Czech only. The Polish and word is a loanword. In Czech it is derived from váleti 'fight'. The Czech lexemes themselves can be loans from Old High German wal 'battelground', supported by (and contaminated with?) the native váleti 'pull, hit'. The ultimate source root is PIE *u̯el-.
The Belarusian lexeme is derived from PS *mog- / *mag, which is also found in Belarusian magčy 'can'.
Cf. s.v. *magʰ- 'können, imstande sein' (IEW 695, 697).
S.v. ognĭ.

Some scholars assume here a native word related to Avestan ātar- 'fire', Armenian airem 'burn', Irish áith 'oven' etc. Others consider the lexeme as a loanword from Romanian (where it can be, in turn, a loan from Albanian). The distribution of vatra/watra in Slavic and its abscence in older texts seem to support the loanword hypothesis. However, it can be still a native word (cf. Russian CS obaštritisâ 'get inflammate').
The word is related to Avestan ātar- 'fire' etc. and was borrowed into Slavic from Dacian.
It is a Balkan shepherd word which was probably diffused in the Serbo-Croat area by Vlachs and in the North by Romanians.

It is a Carpathian shepherd term. It is assumed that the word was diffused by Romani language, where it could be borrowed from Iranian. It is also possible, that the word comes from substrate IE languages in the Balkans
The lexeme is limited to Slavic only and has no certain etymology. The existing hypotheses (linking it to PS *ryti 'dig', *rǫbati 'chop' or Old High German rûp(p)a 'caterpillar') are unconvincing.
PS *ryba is an etymologically obscure innovation. There are many etymologies but none of them is convincing.
PS *ryba is a taboo innovation.

The Slavic lexeme is most probably a taboo-word. It has been linked to Old High German rûppa, rûpa 'catepillar', Latin rubēta 'frog', PS *ryti 'dig', Russian ryxlyj 'loose, powdery', Old Icelandic rjúpa 'partridge', Latvian rubenis 'black grouse' and PIE *ūr- 'water'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷrīyet- 'clay, earth, mud'. "These words are probably related to Lat. crēta 'chalk', but details are obscure. {ref Mallory & Adams 2006}: 121 reconstruct PIE *tkʷreh₁yot- and add ToB tukri 'clay'. Perhaps it is more sensible to start with the root *kʷreh₁- with the suffix (?) *-yet- and assume that the Tocharian words contain some kind of prefix. It is also possible that all these words were borrowed from non-IE languages."

S.v. OIr. cré 'terre, glaise, boue'. In view of the corresponding Brythonic forms (W pridd 'terre, glaise', Co. pry, Bret. pri 'id.') one may reconstruct Proto-Celtic *kʷrīi̯ets. A connection with Lat. crēta is not impossible in view of IE *ē > PCl. *ī; the connection of these words further to the root *kʷer- seems very adventurous.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *telamon- 'earth, ground', from PIE *telh₂-m- 'surface, support' (cf. Lat. tellus 'earth', OPr. talus 'ground, floor', OCS tьlo 'ground', OE ϸel 'floor', Arm. tʻał 'district'). The IE root is probably *telh₂- 'raise, support'.
S.v. OIr. talam 'terre', to be connected with Skt. tala- 'surface plane', Lat. tellūs 'terre', OIc. ϸel 'sol', etc. to a base *tel-, *telə-.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *bēto-, *biyato- 'food' (OIr. bíad, MW bwyd), derived from PIE *gʷei̯h₃- ~ *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live' (cf. Lat. uīta 'life', Lith. gyvatà. The Brythonic words can be derived from *bēto- < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-to-.
S.v. W bwytâf: bwyta, byta, derived from W bwyd 'food'.
Cf. s.v. *gʷi̯eh₃- 'leben' (IEW 467-9).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *tud-o- 'fall', from PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'hit' (cf. Skt. tudáti, Lat. tundō, Goth. stautan).
Cf. s.v. *(s)teu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 1033-4). [Without Celtic cognates listed.]
S.v. OIr. tuit- 'tomber'
S.v. Proto-Celtic *-tud-e/o- 'fallen', derived to PIE *steu̯d- ({ref LIV²} 601; cf. {ref IEW} 1033f. s.v. *steu-d-).

S.v. OIr. cleitte 'plume à écrire'. Doubtlessly comparable to eitte 'aile, plume', of which it would be an expressive variant (under the influence of clúm, clúit?). Otherwise maybe connected to the verb cel- 'cacher' and 'couvrir' and have later adapted the form of eitte.
S.v. Manx caggey 'war' (= Ir. cogadh).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *wik-o- 'fight', from PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'fight, conquer' (cf. Lat. uincō 'conquer', ON vega 'fight, kill').
S.v. Engl. cwffiaf, cwffio, a loanword from English 'to cuff' in the sense of 'to strike, buffet'.

S.v. OIr. troit 'combat, bataille'. {ref Pedersen 1909} supposes *trud-no- comparing Lat. trudō 'frapper', Goth. us-ϸriutan 'tomber lourdement'; {ref IEW} 1026-1027 supposes a dental-extended root from *streu- (cf. OE strútian, 'se tenir raide', MHG strūz 'opposition, combat', ON ϸrūtinn 'enflé'), where he also cites Ir. trot and W. *trythu 'enfler'. But the latter does not exist, and there is no reason to suppose a development 'enflure' > 'combat' for Irish.
S.v. W fflio, loanword from English '(to) fly'.
PS *květ 'flower' and *svět 'wolrd, light' are ultimately derived from PIE *ku̯ei̯-t-.
Cf. s.v. Bret. nij adj. qual. 'volant', corresponding to Corn. nyj, 'vol, nage, fait de flotter' and W naid 'bond, saut' from Brythonic *natia-, with many derivatives in Breton.
Cf. s.v. *(s)neh₂- 'baden, schwimmen' (IEW 971-2).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kiw-o- 'fog', generally connected to PIE *k̑ei̯H- 'gray' (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'gray', Lith. šývas, but Matasović comments "The derivation from the PIE root is doubtful both formally and semantically (for the phonetic development cf. OIr. béo from PCelt. *biwo- 'alive'). The vowel length could have been lost by Dybo's law if PIE end-stressed *kiH-wó- is posited. OE héow, hiw 'appearance' and the related Germanic words probably do not belong here ({ref Orel 2003}: 171 relates them convincigly (sic!) to OE heawan 'to hew')."

S.v. OIr. ceó 'nuée, brume, brouillard'. One may compare Goth. hiwi 'apparence', OE héow, hiw 'apparence, forme, visage, couleur', also with enlargement *kiē-wo- (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'brun foncé') or *kī-wo- (Lith. šývas 'blanchâtre', OCS sivŭ 'gris foncé').

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:68-69, {ref IEW} 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ({ref Matasović 2009}:205, cf. {ref ALEW} 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, {ref EWAia} II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this class).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kallī- 'wood, grove'. Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain. A connection with PIE *kl̥do- (Gk. κλάδος 'branch', ON holt 'woody hill') is impossible because one would expect Proto-Celtic *klido-. Perhaps a derivation from *kelH- 'cut', but details are obscure.
S.v. OIr. caill 'bois, forêt', cf. entry for various etymological proposals.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kayto- 'wood', from IE *kai̯to- 'wood, field' (IEW 521), cf. Goth. haiϸi 'field'. The reflexes *kai̯to- are restricted to Celtic and Germanic; perhaps a borrowing from a NW European substratum language.
S.v. ON skógr 'wald'.
S.v. Bret. skorn 'glace', a word of obscure origin.
S.v. OIr. secc 'desséché, dur, rigide', a borrowing from Lat. siccus. The verb seccaid 'il (se) raidit, (se) durcit, (se) dessèche' is a secondary derivative.
S.v. Manx mess 'fruit' (= Ir. meas).
S.v. W ffrwyth 'fruit' (cf. OCo. fruit, MBret. froez) a loanword from Lat. fructus.
S.v. OIr. torad 'produit, profit, résultat, fruit'. In all likelihood a compound of rith 'course' < *retu, the verbal noun of reth- 'courir'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *messu- 'acorn'; usually connected to IE *med- 'measure'. Goth. mats, OE mete 'food', etc. < *meh₂d- 'be wet', but this is formally difficult for Proto-Celtic *messu-. Alternatively PCl. *messu- may have borrowed from a non-IE language.
S.v. *med- 'voll werden, satt werden' (LIV 423f., IEW 706), from with *med-tu- > OIr. mess 'Eichelmast, Mastfutter, Baumfrucht', MW, etc. mes 'Eicheln'.
S.v. coyrt 'giving' = Ir. tabhairt contaminated with cur; and s.v. cur 'putting, giving, planting, setting, sending' = Ir. cur.
S.v. OIr. maith 'bon, excellent, avantageux'.
S.v. OW guel 'grass' < Brythonic *u̯elt-. According to {ref IEW} these words are to be connected with *u̯el- 'Haar, Wolle', but they could also belong to *gel- 'verschlingen'.
S.v. *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'besteigen' (IEW 328), cf. Hitt. arkatta 'bespringt' < *h₁érg̑ʰ-/h₁r̥g̑ʰ-, Gk. ὀρχέομαι 'tanze' < *h₁org̑ʰ-éi̯e-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic 3. *rig-e/o- 'gehen', from PIE *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'gehen', originally a suppletive future to OIr. téit.
S.v. regaid , future to the verb tiagu, going back to a form *r̥gh- connected to the Gk. verb ἔρχομαι.
S.v. Manx goll (cf. NIr. gol).
S.v. Old Welsh guird 'green' [gwyrdd], cf. OCo. guirt, gl. viridis, MB guezr, Ir. urdai. A borrowing from Lat. viridis.
S.v. Bret. bouzell 'fondement intestinal', a borrowing from pre-Roman *bodel, from Lat. botellus 'small sausage'.
S.v. OIr. dona 'infortuné, malchanceux, malheureux', derived from OIr. don 'malheur, revers, infortune', but further etymology uncertain.
S.v. OIr. dub 'noire; terrible, triste' Ir. dub goes back to *dʰubʰu- and comparable to Gk. τυφός 'aveugle', Goth. daufs 'sourd'.

Etymology in this class follows {ref NIL} 122-124; traditionally (but dubiously) connected to Greek τυφλός 'blind' ({ref IEW} 264, followed by {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} D:210-211, {ref Matasović 2009}:107-108, against which cf. {ref NIL} 123n4).
S.v. OIr. do-gní 'il fait, agit, accomplit, produit'. Composed of the verb gní- 'faire' and the preverb di-.
S.v. OIr. dag 'bon', no plausible etymology.
S.v. Bret. dorn 'main, poing, poignée', from Old Breton durn and equivalent to Co. dorn, W dwrn in the same sense, Ir. dorn 'poing' and Scots Gaelic dòrn, from Proto-Celtic *dur-no-.
S.v. OIr. dorn 'main, poing', corresponding to W dwrn, Bret. dourn, dorn 'poing, main', etc. Root etymology uncertain. Either *der- or *dher- is possible (cf. Hamp ZCP XLI 253).
S.v. OIr. crúaid 'dur, rude, cruel'. May go back to *kroudi- and consequently have the same origin as Lat. crūdus < *kroudo-.
Cf. s.v. Lat. crūdus 'raw, bloody, rough, cruel' from ?*kreuh₂-odʰ-o- perhaps cognate with MIr. crúaid 'hardy, harsh, stern'.
Cf. for discussion against the etymology with Lat. crūdus, with references to further literature.
S.v. cenn 'tête, sommet, extrémité, fin, chef', from Proto-Celtic *kʷenno-, with no known cognates outside of Celtic.
S.v. OIr. trom 'lourd' corresponding exactly to OW trumm, MW trwm, OBret. trom, trum 'lourd', derived from *trud-smo-, cf. Lat. trudō, etc.
S.v. W pwys (1) 'weight', a loan from Lat. pēnsum 'weight'.
S.v. OIr. ceilid 'il cache, dissimule', corresponding to Lat. *-celō in the compound occulo, OHG hellan, from IE *k̑el- (cf. {ref IEW} 553).
S.v. Manx follaghey or follagh 'hiding, concealing', cf. Ir. folachadh.
S.v. W hitiaf (1): hitio, a loanword from English '(to) hit'.
S.v. OIr. 1 ben- 'frapper, couper, blesser, tuer, enlever', to the IE root *bʰei-ə- 'frapper' ({ref IEW} 117).
S.v. OIr. buailid (bualaid) 'il frappe, bat, attaque'. Cf. for a summary of various attempts at an etymology by {ref IEW}. Possibly of expressive origin.
S.v. OIr. benn 'sommet, pointe, montagneuse; pignon, pinacle, créneau; corne, pointe (de lance), crête (d'une coiffure)'
S.v. OIr. benn 'sommet, pointe, montagneuse; pignon, pinacle, créneau; corne, pointe (de lance), crête (d'une coiffure)'
S.v. OIr. tech, teg 'maison', from *tegos, gen. *teges-os, corresponding exactly to Gk. τέγος 'toit, construction' and from the verbal root *teg- 'couvrir', cf. Lat. tegō, togā, etc.
