S.v. OW helcha and helgha(ti) 'to hunt', from Britt. *selg- < PIE *selg̑- 'loslassen, ensenden, werfen, ausgießen'.
S.v. 1 selg- 'chasse' and 'fait de chasser', to be connected with a root *selg- seen in Skt. sr̥játi 'il lance, il fait courir'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic s.v. *freswo- 'strong cold', which may be from PIE *preu̯s- 'freeze' (cf. Skt. pruṣvā́- 'drops of dew', Lat. pruīna 'hoarfrost', Goth. frius 'hoarfrost'), but one must assume a metathesis *-u̯s- > *-su̯- from earlier *preu̯s-o-.
Cf. s.v. *preu̯s- 'sprühen, spritzen' (IEW 809-10, 846).
Cf. s.v. Old Welsh reulaun 'icy' (lit. ice-full), with W rhew 'frost, ice', OIr. réud, < *preuswo-.
S.v. OIr. réud 'grand froid'. The connection with Skt. pruṣvā́- 'glace', Lat. pruīna < pruswinā-, Goth. frius 'gel' is not certain as the Proto-Celtic form is difficult to reconstruct.
S.v. OIr. réud 'grand froid'. The connection with Skt. pruṣvā́- 'glace', Lat. pruīna < pruswinā-, Goth. frius 'gel' is not certain as the Proto-Celtic form is difficult to reconstruct.
S.v. W rhew '(hoar-)frost, ice' (cf. OCo. reu, Bret. rev, etc. < PIE *prēuso-, cf. Goth. *frius).
S.v. W rhew '(hoar-)frost, ice' (cf. OCo. reu, Bret. rev, etc. < PIE *prēuso-, cf. Goth. *frius).

The connection of the Celtic lexemes to this class follows {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:137, {ref Matasović 2009}:140, but cf. doubts in {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:24-25, {ref EIEC} 287.

The connection of the Celtic lexemes to this class to PIE *preu̯s- follows {ref Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)}, {ref Falileyev 2000}:137, {ref Matasović 2009}:140, but cf. doubts in {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} R:24-25, {ref EIEC} 287.
Cf. s.v. org- 'tuer, détruire, ravager' with references to older literature.
S.v. Bret. stank 'étang, lavoir', a borrowing from Old French estanc (< Lat. stagnum).

S.v. Bret. lenn 'lac, plan d'eau, bassin, bief, lavoir, viver' from Old Breton linn 'lac, étang; liquide, humeur' corresponding to Co. lyn 'lac, mare', W llyn 'lac; boisson', Ir. linn (OIr. lind 'liquide, étang'), ScG. linne 'lac' and Gaul. lindon 'liquide, étang', all going back to Proto-Celtic *lindos in the primary sense 'liquid'.
S.v. OIr. tibid 'il frappe, il se heurte; il frappe un sourire (un rire) à l'address de' No clear etymology; cf. entry for various doubtful suggestions.
S.v. OW guardam 'to laugh' (MW chward-) from IE *su̯ard- 'lachen'.

S.v. OIr. duille 'feuille, feulliage', to Gk.  θάλος, θαλλός, Arm. dalar 'vert, frais', Alb. dal 'je pousse' from *dhal-/*dhel-. The connection with Lat. folium is uncertain since Lat. folium could reflect either *dholio-, as in Celtic, or *bhol-io- as in Gk. φύλλον.
S.v. W chwith 'left' from Celtic *skittu- (cf. *skaiu̯os, Lat. Scaeuus, Gr. σκαιός). [entry published 1959].

S.v. Proto-Celtic *towto- 'left, north'. Old Breton tut 'good, favourable' appears to be the same word as OIr. túath 'left, north'. "It is unclear if the meanings 'left', 'good', and 'magic' can be brought together, since the associations of the left hand side are almost universally negative. Perhaps some sort of taboo replacement is involved, but in any case the IE part of this etymology remains somewhat conjectural." Possibly to IE *teuto- if cognate with Lat. tūtus 'safe', Goth. ϸiuϸ 'good'.
Cf. s.v. OIr. 2 tuath 'gauche'.

Possibly to IE *teuto- if cognate with Lat. tūtus 'safe', Goth. ϸiuϸ 'good' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} T:164-165; cf. {ref Matasović 2009}:387 with some doubts). However, the connections with the Italic and Germanic lexemes are judged difficult by {ref Lehmann 1986}:362-363 and not even discussed by {ref de Vaan 2008}:632-633. For possible semantic parallel for a euphemism, cf. Greek ἀριστερός in /cognate/1504/.
Cf. s.v. Goth. Ϸ45. ϸiuϸ 'τὸ ἀγαθόν', 'the good'. Etymology difficult.
Cf. s.v. Lat. tueor 'to look at, watch over' (p.p.p. tūtum) [No Celtic cognates listed.]
S.v. Bret. gar 'jambe' corresponding to Co. gar, W gar, Gaul. *garra-, all from Proto-Celtic *garri- 'jarret'. Old French gare 'jambe, cuisse' is a borrowing from Gaulish.
S.v. Manx lurgey 'leg, shin-bone' (cf. OIr. lurga).
S.v. OIr. óa 'foie'. The Celtic languages have replaced the inherited IE word for 'liver' with a new word of unknown etymology and whose proto-form is impossible to reconstruct.
S.v. OIr. sír 'long, durable', from Proto-Celtic *sīro-, corresponding exactly to Lat. sērus 'tardif'.
S.v. OIr. míl 'animal en général, surtout animal de petite taille', from IE *mēlo- preserved in Greek μῆλον and Germanic mâla in the Salic Law.
S.v. OIr. feóil 'flesh' both of living and dead bodies, often of meat; internal reconstruction on this word within Irish is not possible and there is no known etymology elsewhere in Celtic.
Cf. s.v. OLith. áiškus, -i (1), aiškùs -ì (4) 'klar, deutlich', without clear correspondences outside of Balto-Slavic.

S.v. OIr. gelach 'moon', only a few attestations in late texts. Clearly a derivative to the adjective gel (o/ā) 'hell, leuchtend'. There are two formal possibilities at a root etymology, either to *g̑ʰel(ə)- 'glänzen, schimmern' (IEW 429ff.) or *g̑el(ə)- 'hell heiter glänzen, lächeln, lachen' (IEW 366f., cf. LIV² 162 *g̑elh₂- 'in Lachen ausbrechen'); the connection to the former *g̑ʰel(ə)- is preferable. [Cf. also 'white' pp. 431-432.]
S.v. Gaul. briga 'colline, mont' > 'forteresse', cf. in Insular Celtic OIr. brí 'colline' < *brigs < *bʰr̥g̑ʰs, W, Co. Bret. bre 'id.', from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'haut'.
S.v. W mynydd 'mountain, large hill', from *monijo-, derived from IE *men- 'stretch out'.
S.v. Bret. menez 'mont, montagne', from Old Breton monid 'montagne' corresponding to Co. meneth, W mynydd, and ScG. monadh from Proto-Celtic *mon-iyo-.

S.v. OIr. slíab 'montagne', later also 'terrain de montagne, lande'. Considered an enlargement *sleib- to a root *(s)lei- 'glisser, glissant' (cf. OHG slipf 'lapsus', MHG slīfan 'glisser'. In this case sliab would have originally signified 'pente (glissante)', but this explanation is not semantically satisfactory. Consequently the etymology remains uncertain.
S.v. W ceg 'throat, gullet, windpipe, neck; mouth, opening, entrance', possibly a loanword from Old English céce 'the swallow, fauces; mouth, cheek'? [entry last revised 1959].

S.v. Gaul. bocca 'bouche'. A relationship with an IE onomatopoeic root *buk- meaning 'aboyer, hurler' has been proposed, cf. Skt. búkkati 'il aboie', Gk. βύκτης '(le vent) mugissent', Serb. búkati 'hurler', etc. The Gaulish inscription however shows bocca, not *bucca.
S.v. Bret. beg 'bec, bouche; pointe, embouchure'. Old French bec is a loanword from Gaulish *beccos, Latinised as beccus.

S.v. OIr. bél 'lèvre' in plural 'bouche'. Various etymologies have been proposed that suppose a -l- added to a root which has the form *gʷet- signifying 'parler' or 'enfler, gonfler', or to the form *bʰes- (cf. Lat. basium). These etymologies are valueless. In view of W gwefl 'lèvre, lippe' (des humains ou des animaux), MBret. guefl 'gueule', Bret. geol 'id.' one would like to see in bél an old reduplicated form from a root *bel- preserved in Ir. belach and bil (cf. {ref Pedersen 1909}:117).

S.v. OIr. gin 'a mouth', doubtless to PIE *g̑enu- 'Kinn, Kinnbacke' (cf. Ved. hánu- 'Kinnbacke', Av. zanu- 'id.', Gk. γένυς, -υος 'Kinn, Kinnbacke', Lat. gena 'Wange, genīnus dens 'Backenzahn', Goth. kinnus 'Wange', TochA śanwe-m (du.f.) 'Kinnbacken').
S.v. Bret. strizh 'étroit, strict, rigoureux, austère' from Old Breton strit 'serré, étroit; austère', borrowed from Lat. strictus.

S.v. OIr. cáel 'mince, étroit' later forms cóel, cáel, caol. Corresponds exactly to Brythonic forms in W cul 'étroit', OBret., Corn. cul 'id.', and a Gaulish PN Coilos (gen. Coili) which is perhaps the same word. These forms presuppose Proto-Celtic *koi̯lo-, which may find a connection in Latv. kaîls 'nu, chauve, simple'.
S.v. W botwm 'button', a loanword from Middle English botoun 'button'.
S.v. W bol 'belly', from Proto-Celtic *bolgos, from PIE *bʰolgʰ- (cf. Goth. balgs, Engl. belly, bellows).
S.v. Engl. belly-button 'navel'. Colloquialism, first attested 1877.
S.v. W bogail, bogel 'navel, umbilicus, belly button'.
S.v. Bret. begel 'cordon ombilical, zeste (de noix)', from Old Breton becel, of uncertain origin. Corresponds to Cornish begel, Welsh bogail.

S.v. OIr. ocus 'proche, voisin de' In Welsh the word 'wnc' or 'wng' 'voisin' and 'voisinage' go back to *onk-, that is to say equivalent to Ir. oc; but it has been replaced early by agos. The same in Middle Cornish ogas, Middle Breton hogos 'presque', hogosder 'voisinage'. The g of these forms is embarrassing. Pedersen I 161 considers a borrowing from Irish, where ocus, from *oggu- (Thurn. 525) is derived from oc.

S.v. OIr. fota, fata 'long'. Internal reconstruction suggests possibly earlier *woddio-/*waddio-. There are no correspondences within Celtic, and no known etymology outside of Celtic. A connection with Lat. vastus 'weit' was considered in older literature (cf. {ref IEW} 1113-1114).

S.v. OIr. fota, fata 'long'. Internal reconstruction suggests possibly earlier *woddio-/*waddio-. There are no correspondences within Celtic, and no known etymology outside of Celtic. A connection with Lat. vastus 'weit' was considered in older literature (cf. {ref IEW} 1113-1114).

S.v. Arm. šunčʻ 'breath; soul, person; blowing, wind', denominal verb šnčʻem 'to breathe, blow', according to Ačaṙyan (HAB 3: 535b) an onomatopoeic formation composed of š- and the suffix -nčʻ which is frequent in onomatopoeic words. "Though this is basically correct, the connection with cognate forms should not be excluded, cf. Skt. śvasiti 'to hiss, pant, snort', Lith. švañkšti 'to wheeze', OIc. hvæsa 'to hiss, snort'."

S.v. Goth. S99. *slaihts 'λεῖος', 'smooth', probably from PIE *(s)ley- + -g-, cf. OIr. slig- as in ad-slig 'persuade', fo-sligim 'besmear, anoint' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:133, without s- Gk. λίγδην 'scraping').
S.v. Gmc. *slihta- 'glatt, eben', an old verbal adjective to the strong verb *sleika- 'schleichen'.
S.v. Gmc. *sleik-a- 'schleichen', from an extended form of IE *(s)lei̯- (cf. OIr. fo-slig 'überschmiert', OCS slьzъkъ 'schlüpfrig, glatt', Gk. λίγδην 'oberflächlich berührend, streifend').
Cf. s.v. *slei̯g̑- 'schmieren, glatt machen' (IEW 663-664).
Cf. s.v. *gʷi̯eh₃- 'leben' (IEW 467-9).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *bēto-, *biyato- 'food' (OIr. bíad, MW bwyd), derived from PIE *gʷei̯h₃- ~ *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live' (cf. Lat. uīta 'life', Lith. gyvatà. The Brythonic words can be derived from *bēto- < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-to-.
S.v. W abwyd 'bait, lure; earthworms' (dim. abwydyn), from W a- + bwyd 'food'.
S.v. Pashto kor 'house', OPers. kāra- 'people, army', cf. Sh. čōr 'husband', Kurd bē (kas ū) kār 'without relatives'. Note the semantic change 'social group, family' > 'house (building)'.
S.v. Pashto nuk 'fingernail, claw'; n'uka 'tip, point, nib'. A connection with Ir. *nā̆xa- (Prs nāxun, etc.) is unlikely. Perhaps *nau- as Prs nauk, nōk, Sogd. nwk 'tip, point'?
S.v. Pashto nuk 'fingernail, claw'; n'uka 'tip, point, nib'. A connection with Ir. *nā̆xa- (Prs nāxun, etc.) is unlikely. Perhaps *nau- as Prs nauk, nōk, Sogd. nwk 'tip, point'?
S.v. Pashto nund, more commonly lund 'wet'. Most dialects show dissimilations, cf. Phl naft, Sogd. nβtyy, Av. napta- 'damp', Pers. nam 'moisture', Sogd. nmb 'dew' < *namba-, √*nab-, IE *nebh-.
S.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV 448, IEW 315f., EIEC 110, 477).
S.v. Pashto uğd, from Ir. *br̥za- (Av. ba/ərəz- 'high', Khot. bulysa- 'long').
S.v. Pashto wāx̌ə 'grass, fodder', from Ir. *wāstr(iy)a-, cf. Av. vāstra- 'pasture, grass', Pth. wʾš 'straw', Bact. οαϸο 'straw' or 'hay', Khwar. wš 'grass', Khot. kvāṣṣa- 'id.'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. śrī́- 'Schönheit, Glanz, Pracht, Herrlichkeit', in Iranic cf. Khot. śśära- 'gut', Sogd. šyr- 'gut' (< *ćrīra-), Pašto ṣ̌ə 'gut', Orm. šir 'gut', etc., from PIE *k̑ríH- (cf. Ved. √śray- 'vollkommen machen, glänzen machen' to PIE *k̑rei̯H-, cf. Gk. κρείων, κρέων (epithet of kings and heroes), εὐρυ-κρείων 'weithin Glanz habend').
S.v. Pashto x̌ə 'good', cf. Av. sraiiah- 'more beautiful', Skt. śreyas-, Sogd. šyʾtr 'better, more excellent'.
S.v. Pashto xānd- : xand- 'to laugh', probably a LW from Prs xandīdan.

S.v. OIr. men- (verbal root) 'penser', from PIE *men- and to be connected with Skt. mányate 'il pense', mána- 'pensée', Gk. μαίνομαι 'je suis agité de transports', μένος 'esprit, cœur', Lat. (pf.) memini 'je me souviens', Goth. munan 'penser'. Brythonic only preserves this root in more distant derivatives like W mynnu 'vouloir'. Cf. s.v. OIr. menn- (cf. MBret. mennat 'vouloir, souhaiter, demander').
S.v. W gwddf, gwddw, gwddwg 'neck, crag, throat', from Celtic *u̯udu̯o-
S.v. OIr. úr 'frais, jeune, tendre', also in Brythonic (cf. W ir 'frais, vert, nouveau'. Connected by {ref Pedersen 1909}:91 with Lat. pūrus, which is acceptable. Cf. entry for other proposals.
S.v. OIr. adaig 'nuit'. Without certain etymology.
S.v. W nos 'night, evening, darkness (of the night)', from IE *nokʷt- 'night'.
S.v. Bret. nos 'nuit, soir', from Old Breton nos 'nuit', corresponding to Co. nôs (OCo. nos), W nos, and OIr. nocht, all going back to Celtic *nok-ti-, apparently from Lat. nox.
S.v. Old Welsh nos 'night' (MW nos, OC nos, OB nos; cf. OIr. innocht < PIE *nokʷt-stu-, IE *nekʷ-(t-), *nokʷ-(t-).
S.v. Bret. nos 'nuit, soir', from Old Breton nos 'nuit', corresponding to Co. nôs (OCo. nos), W nos, and OIr. nocht, all going back to Celtic *nok-ti-, apparently from Lat. nox.
S.v. OIr. srón 'narine, nez'
S.v. W trwyn 'nose, snout; sense of smell' (cf. OCo. trein gl. 'nasus', Late Cornish tron, Gaul. *trugnā (> Fr. trogne).

S.v. OIr. srón 'a nostril', in dual 'nose'. Connections outside of Celtic are uncertain, various proposals have been made to (a) Skt. sr̥kván-, srákva- 'Mundwickel', (b) Gk. ῥίς, ῥινός, (c) Gk. ῥέγκω, ῥέγχω 'schnarche' < *srenk- (IEW), (d) Arm. ṙngun-kʻ < *srongh-on-.
S.v. ῥοῦγχος τὸ (Hesych.) > Tsak. σ̌ούκ̔ο 'Maul, Schnauze, Schnabel'.

S.v. AGk. ῥύγχος. An expressive term for its sonority. {ref Frisk 1960-1972}, among others connects Arm. ṙng-un-kʻ 'narines, nez' and supposes IE *srungh- or *sringh- with expressive nasalisation. These words evoke Gk. ῥέγκω, ῥέγχω and this connection may be etymological, cf. {ref IEW} 1002.
S.v. Bret. kozh (adj.) 'vieux, ancien' from Old Breton coth and corresponding to Co. coth 'vieux, ancien, âgé', W coth, and Gaul. cottos 'vieux'.
Cf. s.v. Gaul. cottos 'vieux', connected with Bret. coz and OCo. coth 'vieux', a substrate word?
S.v. W person 'person', a loanword from Medieval English person(e) or directly from Old French person. Early attestations spelled berson, bersson, persson, etc.
S.v. OIr. nech 'quelqu'un' (indefinite pronoun), formed from IE *ne 'not' + *kʷo- (relative pron.), cf. OIr. cia.
S.v. Manx peiagh 'person', cf. Ir. peacach 'sinner'.
Cf. s.v. OIr. peccad 'péché' with secondary derivative pecthach 'pécheur'. OIr. peccad is a straightfoward loanword from Lat. peccatum.
S.v. Old Welsh guarai 'play, amusement, theatre'. No etymology, possibly *worigo-, cf. Ir. fuirech < *fo-rig.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *rig-o- 'to bind', cf. *(H)rei̯g- 'to bind, to reach' (IEW 861, LIV 503), cf. Lat. rigeō 'be stiff', MHG ricken 'bind', OHG reihhen 'reach', Lith. réižti 'to stretch, tighten'. OIr. con-rig 'binds together' < *kom-rig-o-, MW gwarny 'play' (GPC gwarny, gwary), MBret. hoari 'play' < MW gwarny and MBret. hoari < *ufo-rig-o-.
S.v. OIr. imm-beir 'to carry around; play (a game), gamble, stake; etc.'
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-o- 'carry, bear, bring', from PIE *bʰer- 'carry'.
Cf. s.v. *ánbʰi 'um – herum, ringsum' (Adverb, lokal; oft mit Akk., Lok.). Proto-Celtic *ámbi > OIr. imbᴸ < PIE *án/n̥bʰí.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-e/o- 'tragen, bringen' < PIE *bʰer-.
S.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).

S.v. OIr. cluiche 'jeu, épreuve, sportive', with secondary derived verb cluichigidir. From *kloki̯o-, a form of the verbal root *klek- (cf. OIr. clich- 'il meut, il se meut'), surely of onomatopoeic origin.
S.v. Manx tayrn 'drawing, dragging, rowing, pulling; catch (of fish)' = Ir. tarraing.
S.v. OIr. sreng- 'tirer, traîner'.
S.v. Bret. pouls 'pouls, pousse, bourgeon; mal, toux'; from Old Breton  puls, corresponding to Co. pols 'battement de cœur, moment, instant', both words borrowed from Lat. pulsus 'pouls'.
S.v. Bret. bou(n)t 'poussé', a borrowing from Old French boute 'coup', deverbal from bouter 'heurter, pousser'.
S.v. Manx puttey 'pushing, shoving, thrusting, stretching' (= ScG. putadh).
S.v. OIr. bráen, bróen 'goutte, averse, pluie', without etymology, cf. entry for various proposals.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *uden-sk-yo- 'water', from PIE *wod-r / *uden- 'water' (cf. Skt. udán-, Hitt. watar-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, Lat. unda 'wave', OCS voda, Germ. Wasser). Matasović gives this as the standard etymology, although he expresses reservations that the Proto-Celtic stem formation is correct. See entry for further discussion.
S.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).

S.v. OIr. uisce 'eau', evidently derived to the root which designated in Indo-European a liquid element *wed-/*ud- (cf. Skt. udán-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, Hitt. watar, Goth. wato, OCS voda). Cf. for various proposals for explaining the Celtic stem formation.

S.v. OIr. uisce 'eau', evidently derived to the root which designated in Indo-European a liquid element *wed-/*ud- (cf. Skt. udán-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, Hitt. watar, Goth. wato, OCS voda). Cf. for various proposals for explaining the Celtic stem formation.
S.v. Manx fliaghey 'rain' = OIr. flechud.
Cf. s.v. Old Welsh rudcoch 'purple-red' (Middle Welsh rudgoch), the second element of the compound -coch is a loan from Medieval Latin coccum (cf. MW coch).
S.v. W coch, a loan from Late Latin coccum.
S.v. OIr. derg 'rouge, sanglant', one connects OE deorc 'sombre', Engl. dark, OHG tarchanjan 'obscurcir', which suppose a root *dʰerg-.
Cf. s.v. Gmc. derka- 'dunkel', the word can be identical with OIr. derg (o-stem) 'rot (bes. von Blut)', perhaps further to be compared with Lith. dérgti 'schmutzig werden, sich besudeln'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *stagrā 'river, stream', which may be derived from IE *steh₂g- 'pool' (cf. Lat. stāgnum 'pool', Gk. στάζω 'drip').
S.v. Bret. staer 'rivière, ruisseau; berge, étier', from Old Breton staer 'fleuve', from Proto-Celtic *stag-ra
S.v. ?*steh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'träufeln; tropfen, tröpfeln' (IEW 1010). Only as a verbal root in Greek, cf. Lat. stāgnum 'body of water', Old Breton staer f. 'river, creek'. Alternatively perhaps from *sta⁽g̑⁾-.
Cf. s.v. W pwdr (2) 'rotten, decayed, putrid', a borrowing from Lat. putris, cf. Late Cornish podar.
S.v. Bret. brein 'pourri, en mauvais état, inculte', corresponding to Cornish bryn 'pourri, carié', Welsh braen 'putride corrompu, pourri', MIr. brén. These words are from Proto-Celtic *mrakno-.
S.v. W braen (1) 'rotten, putrid, corrupt, mouldy, withered, fragile', from IE *bʰreHg-, cf. Lat. fragrāre [entry last updated 2013].

MIr. brén 'putrid, foul', MW braen 'putrid, corrupt', B brein 'id.' formally reflect PCl. *brakno-, *bragno- or *mr-. The usual reconstruction is *mrakno- in view of the proposed connection to Lat. marcēre 'to be withered, rotten', Lith. mir̃kti 'to become soft as a result of soaking'. {ref de Bernardo Stempel 1987}:89 assumes a development *mrakno- < *mrHkno-, but the Lat. and Lith. forms clearly indicate that the root did not contain a laryngeal. Proto-Celtic -a- in this form is problematic. A different etymology can account for the Proto-Celtic *-a-: cf. OHG braccho, Du. brak 'hound', MHG brǣhen < *brēhian 'to smell', perh. Lat. fragrāre 'to emit a scent' < *bʰr(e)h₁g- ({ref Schrijver 1991}:185), hence PCl. *brag-no- would reflect *bʰr(e)h₁g-no-.
S.v. Bret. ront 'rond', a borrowing from French roont (1155), ultimately from Lat. rotundum.
S.v. OIr. reth- 'courir', from IE *reth- ({ref IEW} 866), cf. Lith ritù 'je roule', Skt. ráthaḥ 'char'.

S.v. graua 'sable, gravier'. A word attested in Romance dialects that have been attributed to a Gaulish origin on the basis of correspondences in Insular Celtic (cf. Fr. grève, gravier, dial. groue, Provençal, Catalan grava, Venetian grava, Friulian grave = Welsh gro, Old Cornish grou 'arena', Breton gro 'sable de rivière' from Proto-Celtic *grau̯ā < *grou̯ā, further OIr. griän 'gravier', and river names Grosne (Saône-et-L.) and Grouesme (Côte-d'Or) < *Grauonā, *Grauisamā 'rivières graveleuses'. Perhaps to an IE root *gʰreu- 'écraser, broyer' ({ref IEW} 460, among others); a pre-IE word according to {ref Campanile 1974}.
S.v. Bret. sabl 'sable de carrière', a loanword from French attested at the end of the 11th century, itself ultimately from Lat. sabulum.
S.v. OIr. gainem 'sand'. Without secure correspondences in other Celtic languages or elsewhere in Indo-European. The word should possibly be considered of non-IE origin.

S.v. Gaul. labaro-, labro- 'éloquent, bavard, sonore', corresponding to W. llafar 'loquace', llyferydd 'voix, parole' (< *labaríi̯os), OBret. labar 'parler, dire', OCo. lauar 'sermo' Bret. helavar 'éloquent' < *su-labaros, OIr. labar 'talkative, arrogant', sulbair (*su-lab[a]ris) 'well-spoken', labraid 'il parle', etc. A possible connection with Lat. *labium, labrum 'lèvre'.

Cf. s.v. Bret. lavar 'dire, diction, langage', from Old Breton labar 'dit, parole, maxime', corresponding to Co. lavar 'discours, dire, parole', W llafar 'déclaration, discours, parole', Ir. labhar 'sonore', ScG. labhar 'id.', from Proto-Celtic *labaro-.
Cf. s.v. OIr. as-beir 'say, speak' < ess-ber {ref Pedersen 1913}:466.
Cf. s.v. *ég̑̑ʰ 'aus, von drinnen hinaus' (Adverb, lokal; oft mit Abl.) for the OIr. preverb ess- < *ég̑̑ʰ-s.
S.v. Bret. skrab 'gratte; poil à gratter; éponge de mer' a borrowing from Old French escraper.
S.v. OIr. cúan (2) 'port, havre, baie, golfe', from the IE root *kap- (cf. Lat. capiō 'saisir'; with a nasal suffix *kap-no- > ON hǫfn, OE hæfen, E haven 'port', OHG havan 'port', etc.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷis-e/o- 'sehen', from PIE *kʷei̯s- ({ref LIV²} 381f., {ref IEW} 637).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *u̯el-e/o- 'sehen' from PIE 3. *u̯el- (LIV² 675, IEW 1. *u̯el-).
S.v. 3 úag- 'coudre, lier, assembler';
S.v. W miniog 'sharp' < min + -iog, cf. s.v. W min 'lip, mouth; margin, side, bank; margin, border, edge', cf. MCo. myn, MBret. min, ?MIr. men 'mouth'?.
S.v. Bret. min 'mine, minois' corresponding to Co. myn 'bouche, museau; bord, rive', W min 'lèvre, bouche; marge, côté', Ir. meàn 'bouche', derived from Proto-Celtic *mikna- 'bouche'.
S.v. llym 'sharp, pointed', cf. MCo. lym, MBret. lemm, OIr. slim, possibly to *slibsmos < PIE *(s)leib- to the IE root *slei-.

S.v. Bret. lemm 'pointu, acéré, aigu, coupant, taillant', from Old Breton lem, lim 'aigu', corresponding to Co. lym 'pointu, afflié, tranchant', W llym, llem 'pointu, tranchant' and Ir. slim 'lisse'; these words come from Celtic *slib-mo-.

Cf. s.v. slim 'lisse, uni; plat', apparently from the root *slei- (cf. IEW 663); one connects the Brythonic adjectives in W llymm, Bret. lemm, 'tranchant, aigu', OBret. lemhaam gl. acuo < *slibsmos (?), however with a certain semantic divergence.
S.v. Bret. berr 'court, à court, de court', corresponding to Co. ber, W byr, Ir. ber and ScG. beàrr from Proto-Celtic *berso-.
S.v. OIr. berr 'court'.
S.v. Bret. son 'son', a borrowing from Lat. sonus from which also Old French son 'son, chanson, mélodie'.
S.v. OIr. spéir 'sphère' loanword either from sphaera or Franco-Norman spere.
S.v. OIr. croiccenn 'peau'; two different proto-forms are required to be postulated: *krokno- > W croen, and with gemination of medial -k-, *krokkeno- > Ir. croccenn, Bret. croc'hen.

S.v. OIr. con-tuili 'il dort, s'endort', a compound of the verb tuil- 'dormir', from the root *tel- 'souffrir, supporter', cf. OCS toliti 'calmer, endormir (causatif), Lith. tyléti 'se taire' (Gk. τλῆναι 'supporter', Goth. ϸulan 'souffrir', Arm. tʻołum 'je laisse', Lat. tollō, etc.).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *tol-ī-yo- 'sleep', from PIE *(s)telH- 'be quiet, be still' (IEW 1061f.), cf. OHG stillen 'make still', Lith. tylà 'quiet person', tìliti 'fall silent', OCS u-toliti 'quench, soothe'.
S.v. *telH- 'still werden' (IEW 1061-2).

S.v. Bret. oabr 'ciel, nues' corresponding to W wybr 'ciel' to Proto-Brythonic *oepr. Bret. oabrenn 'cloud' is formed with the singulative suffix -enn, which is also contained in Corn. ebren, W wybren.
Cf. s.v. W wybr 'sky, firmament, heaven; cloud', cf. Old Cornish huibren, Middle Cornish ebron, ebren, Middle Breton noabrenn, Modern Breton oabl, oüaber.
S.v. OIr. bec 'petit'. A word with expressive gemination and of unknown origin, like many words designating smallness.
S.v. OIr. becc 'small', with no clear connections outside of Celtic. It could be a loanword from a substratum language or an ad hoc expressive formation (so {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} s.v.).
S.v. Manx soar 'smell' (Engl. savour).

S.v. OIr. bolad 'odeur, parfum'. No certain etymology. The proposed connections with Latv. buls, bula 'temps lourd, nuageux' or Arm. bal 'obscurité' are less satifying ({ref IEW} 162, etc.), and less still to that of Skt. buliḥ 'vulve', Lith. bulis 'derrière, anus' (Stokes, IF II 168).
S.v. Bret. sant 'sensation', deverbal from santañ (santaff 1499), santiñ, santoud 'sentir; (se) ressentir', borrowings from Old French sentir, ultimately from Lat. sentire.
S.v. W. synhwyraf, synhwyriaf: synhwyro, synhwyrio 'to sense, smell, sniff, etc.' derived from W. synnwyr 'sense, wisdom, sensibleness', borrowed from Lat. sentīre 'perceive'.

S.v. Bret. klew 'ouïe', from Old Breton clou 'perception, audition', corresponding to Co. clew, W. clyw in the same sense as Ir. cliù 'honneur, réputation', from Proto-Celtic *kleu- and related to Lat. cluere.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kiw-o- 'fog', generally connected to PIE *k̑ei̯H- 'gray' (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'gray', Lith. šývas, but Matasović comments "The derivation from the PIE root is doubtful both formally and semantically (for the phonetic development cf. OIr. béo from PCelt. *biwo- 'alive'). The vowel length could have been lost by Dybo's law if PIE end-stressed *kiH-wó- is posited. OE héow, hiw 'appearance' and the related Germanic words probably do not belong here (Orel 2003: 171 relates them convincigly (sic!) to OE heawan 'to hew')."

S.v. OIr. ceó 'nuée, brume, brouillard'. One may compare Goth. hiwi 'apparence', OE héow, hiw 'apparence, forme, visage, couleur', also with enlargement *kiē-wo- (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'brun foncé') or *kī-wo- (Lith. šývas 'blanchâtre', OCS sivŭ 'gris foncé').

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:68-69, {ref IEW} 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ({ref Matasović 2009}:205, cf. {ref ALEW} 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, {ref EWAia} II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this class).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kiw-o- 'fog', generally connected to PIE *k̑ei̯H- 'gray' (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'gray', Lith. šývas, but Matasović comments "The derivation from the PIE root is doubtful both formally and semantically (for the phonetic development cf. OIr. béo from PCelt. *biwo- 'alive'). The vowel length could have been lost by Dybo's law if PIE end-stressed *kiH-wó- is posited. OE héow, hiw 'appearance' and the related Germanic words probably do not belong here (Orel 2003: 171 relates them convincigly (sic!) to OE heawan 'to hew')."

S.v. OIr. ceó 'nuée, brume, brouillard'. One may compare Goth. hiwi 'apparence', OE héow, hiw 'apparence, forme, visage, couleur', also with enlargement *kiē-wo- (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'brun foncé') or *kī-wo- (Lith. šývas 'blanchâtre', OCS sivŭ 'gris foncé').

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:68-69, {ref IEW} 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ({ref Matasović 2009}:205, cf. {ref ALEW} 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, {ref EWAia} II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this class).

S.v. OIr. múch 'fumée'. The root appears to have the form *smeugʰ- in Greek σμύχω 'je broule à petit feu' (cf. Arm. mux, gen. mxoy 'fumée'), and the form *smeug- in Gk. σμυγῆναι and in Germanic (cf. OE smocian 'fumer', smoca 'fumée'. Is there also a connection between these words and the root of Lat. mūcus, Gk. ἀπομύσσω and the Germanic words designating 'le nuage, l'humidité' in OIc. mygla, 'moisissure' and mugga 'pluie fine'? Starting from a root *smeu- with various enlargements we can account for a series of forms which occur among the languages (cf. {ref IEW} 971).

S.v. Arm. mux 'smoke', cf. MIr. múch 'smoke', W mwg 'fire', MBret. mog, moug 'hearth', MHG smouch 'smoke', OE smoca 'smoke', smēocan 'to smoke', Gk. σμύχω 'cause to carbonise, be consumed in a slow fire, smoulder away'. "The etymon presents as with difficulties concerning the vocalic length and the velar. We may be dealing with a European substratum word *(s)m(e)u/ūK/G⁽ʰ⁾-."

Cf. s.v. Arm. mux 'smoke', cf. MIr. múch 'smoke', W mwg 'fire', MBret. mog, moug 'hearth', MHG smouch 'smoke', OE smoca 'smoke', smēocan 'to smoke', Gk. σμύχω 'cause to carbonise, be consumed in a slow fire, smoulder away'. "The etymon presents as with difficulties concerning the vocalic length and the velar. We may be dealing with a European substratum word *(s)m(e)u/ūK/G⁽ʰ⁾-."

Cf. s.v. OLith. smáugti 'würgen, erwürgen', from PIE *smeu̯g- 'ersticken', cf. OE smēocan 'rauchen, räuchern'. Outside of Balto-Slavic a similar root is found in words for σμῡ́χω 'lasse verschwelen', Arm. mowx 'Rauch', NIr. múch, MW mwg 'Rauch, Dunst' which seem to expect deviant forms like *(s)muHgʰ-, *muk- and this still requires an explanation.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *smeukan- ~ *smūkan- 'to smoke', from PIE *smeugʰ-e-(?). Cf. Gk. σμῡ́χω 'to burn up, smoulder away' < *smuHgʰ-e-; Lith. smáugti (smáugiu) 'to choke' < *smouHgʰ-ie-, Arm. mux, mxoy 'smoke' < *smoukH-o-; OIr. múch 'fire' < *smuHk-; MW mwg 'fire' < *smukH-. The underlying root is difficult to reconstruct; extra-Germanic evidence points to three different roots *smeuHgʰ-, *smeuHk-, and *smeukH-.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *smeuk-a- 'rauchen'. Germanic smeuk-a- can be connected with some extra-Germanic words, but the formal and semantic aspects are less secure. The Germanic forms formally correspond to Lith. smáugiu, -ti 'erwürgen, quälen' and Gk. (aor.) ἐσμύγην 'schwelte' (auch vom Schmerz), but because of the semantics the comparison is very uncertain. Formally less secure, but semantically better are *smeu-k- found in OIr. múch 'Rauch' and *smeu-gh- in Gk. σμύχω 'schwele'.

Cf. s.v. Gk. σμύχω 'to cause to carbonise, be slowly consumed in a fire, smoulder away' < IE ?*smeug⁽ʰ⁾- 'smoke'. "Beside the primary verb σμύχω, we find a noun in Arm. mux, gen, mxoy 'smoke'. In Celtic, OIr. múch, MW mwg 'fire' may go back to IE *muk-. In Germanic, there is a primary verb with a diphthong and a root-final IE voiced stop, e.g. OE smēocan 'to smoke, fumigate' < IE *smeug-, beside the zero-grade smoca [m.] 'smoke' < IE *smug-on-, smocian 'to smoke'. An Indo-European reconstruction for all these forms is difficult, as a voiceless aspirate *kʰ (PIE *(s)mūkʰo-; Meillet MSL 8 (1894): 294, followed by Frisk) is not reconstructed anymore for PIE. Lith. smáugti, 1sg. smáugiu 'to strangle, string together, plague' should probably be explained differently (Fraenkel 1955 s.v.), while for Ru. smúglyj 'dark, brown' etc., other interpretations are possible (Vasmer 1953 s.v.)."

S.v. OIr. múch 'fumée'. The root appears to have the form *smeugʰ- in Greek σμύχω 'je broule à petit feu' (cf. Arm. mux, gen. mxoy 'fumée'), and the form *smeug- in Gk. σμυγῆναι and in Germanic (cf. OE smocian 'fumer', smoca 'fumée'. Is there also a connection between these words and the root of Lat. mūcus, Gk. ἀπομύσσω and the Germanic words designating 'le nuage, l'humidité' in OIc. mygla, 'moisissure' and mugga 'pluie fine'? Starting from a root *smeu- with various enlargements we can account for a series of forms which occur among the languages (cf. IEW 971).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *muk-V- 'smoke' [Noun]. The Brittonic forms must be from *muk- with a short vowel. A connection with PIE *(s)meu̯g̑ʰ- 'smoke' (IEW 971) appears probable, but there are many irregularities in the reflexes of this root. Gk. σμῡ́χω 'burn in smouldering fire' presupposes PIE *smuHg̑ʰ-, while OE smeocan 'to smoke' appears to be from *smeu̯g̑-.

Cf. s.v. Arm. mux 'smoke', cf. MIr. múch 'smoke', W mwg 'fire', MBret. mog, moug 'hearth', MHG smouch 'smoke', OE smoca 'smoke', smēocan 'to smoke', Gk. σμύχω 'cause to carbonise, be consumed in a slow fire, smoulder away'. "The etymon presents as with difficulties concerning the vocalic length and the velar. We may be dealing with a European substratum word *(s)m(e)u/ūK/G⁽ʰ⁾-."

Cf. s.v. Gk. σμύχω 'to cause to carbonise, be slowly consumed in a fire, smoulder away' < IE ?*smeug⁽ʰ⁾- 'smoke'. "Beside the primary verb σμύχω, we find a noun in Arm. mux, gen, mxoy 'smoke'. In Celtic, OIr. múch, MW mwg 'fire' may go back to IE *muk-. In Germanic, there is a primary verb with a diphthong and a root-final IE voiced stop, e.g. OE smēocan 'to smoke, fumigate' < IE *smeug-, beside the zero-grade smoca [m.] 'smoke' < IE *smug-on-, smocian 'to smoke'. An Indo-European reconstruction for all these forms is difficult, as a voiceless aspirate *kʰ (PIE *(s)mūkʰo-; Meillet MSL 8 (1894): 294, followed by Frisk) is not reconstructed anymore for PIE. Lith. smáugti, 1sg. smáugiu 'to strangle, string together, plague' should probably be explained differently (Fraenkel 1955 s.v.), while for Ru. smúglyj 'dark, brown' etc., other interpretations are possible (Vasmer 1953 s.v.)."
S.v. ScG. tóit 'smoke, fume', cf. Ir. tóit, MIr. tutt 'smoke'.
Cf. s.v. OIr. tút, túth 'odeur, puanteur', of uncertain etymology.
S.v. Bret. flour (adj. qual.) 'doux', a borrowing from Old French flor 'fleur; choix, élite', ultimately from Lat. florem.
S.v. Bret. lenkr (lencr 1499) 'glissant, coulant', apparently related to Middle French lincable and Gascon linqua 'glisser'.

S.v. OIr. réid adj. 'plat, uni, aisé, simple' and subst. 'terrain plat, plaine', within Celtic to OW ruid gl. uacuum, W rhwydd 'aisé, faxile', Corn. rŷth 'aisé, clair, plat'; outside of Celtic to Gmc. Goth. garaid 'bien disposé', Engl. ready, OHG bi-reiti NHG bereit 'prêt' all to the IE root *reid- 'aller en voiture'
S.v. Bret. erc'h 'neige', corresponding to Co. ergh (OCo. irch), W eira (MW eiry) and OIr. arg 'goutte', from Proto-Celtic *arg(i)o-.

Cf. s.v. OIr. arg 'goutte'. One compares W eiry, eira 'neige', MCo. irch gl. nix, Bret. erc'h starting from a root *(s)perg- or *spreg- 'jaillir, bondir' according to WP II 672ff. but only OIr. arg 'goutte' can be attached to this root. It cannot be excluded that the Brythonic words in the sense 'snow' may have been an adjective meaning 'white' and connected to Gk. ἀργός 'clair, blanc'.
S.v. OIr. rind (2) 'constellation, étoile', no known etymology.
S.v. Manx rollage 'star', cf. Ir. réaltóg with metathesis of -lt- and assimilation of -lt- > -ld- > -ll-. Early Manx has redlayg.
S.v. ScG. reul 'star' (Ir. reult, OIr. retglu < rét glé 'bright thing', perhaps rét 'thing' + *gland 'shining').

S.v. Proto-Celtic *rentu- 'thing, matter' (OIr. rét). Sometimes compared with Skt. rátna- 'possession, precious object', but this etymology is speculative because the reflexes of the IE root are limited to two branches and a metathesis *-nt- > -tn- must be assumed for Sanskrit. {ref EWAia} s.v. Ved. rátna- considers the word without IE etymology.

S.v. rétglu 'étoile', cf. s.v rét 'chose, matière, substance', the form rétglu is generally assumed to form a compound (Corm.² 1086). OIr. rét < *rn̥tu-, perhaps to be connected with Skt. rátna- < *rn̥t-no-? (cf. {ref IEW} 865).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *slattā 'stalk, staff' "This could easily be a loanword from some non-IE language of NW Europe. Both the geminate and the a-vocalism testify to a foreign origin. The same source may have been the origin of the Germanic words such as OHG latta 'plank' (but note the absence of the initial *s-)."

S.v. OIr. slat (1) 'tige, baguette, verge', the same word also in Brythonic (W llath 'baguette, tige, canne à pêche', from Proto-Celtic *slattā, which only has a possible correspondence in Germanic (OHG latta 'planche, latte', MHG lade 'planche', OE lætt 'id.'), but the consonantal correspondences are difficult. Perhaps the Germanic words are loans from Celtic.
S.v. Manx maidjey 'stick' (= Ir. maide).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *mazdyo- 'stick' (cf. PIE *mazdo- {ref IEW} 702, Lat. mālus, OIc. mastr 'mast'), cf. also OIr. mátan 'club' which could be from *māzd-ān-o-. "In principle it would be possible to explain all the Celtic-Italic-Germanic correspondences by assuming ablaut *meh₂sd-/*mh₂sd-, but I think it is more probable that these words were borrowed from some pre-IE source."

S.v. Bret. bazh 'bâton; barreau', from Old Breton bath and corresponding to Cornish bath (Old Cornish bat) 'pièce de monnaie', W bath. The word is a low register Latin loan *batto- from *batta- in Gaulish (cf. Latino-Gaulish bata, from which Fr. batte).
S.v. ScG. bat, bata 'stick', Ir. bata; from MEng. batte 'stick', now 'bat', which is in turn from OFr. batte, from Gaul. Lat. battuere. Bret. baz seems borrowed from Fr. though it may be native.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff' (cf. MIr. sond 'stake, beam, palisade'), from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' (cf. Lat. sponda 'bedstead, bed', OE spōn 'sliver, shaving', Gk. σφήν 'wedge'). An alternative etymology derives PCelt. *sfondo- and Lat. sponda from PIE *(s)pend- 'to spin' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:582), but the semantics of this comparison are less appealing.

S.v. Bret. karreg 'rocher' (Old Breton carrec, 1050), corresponding to Cornish carrek, Welsh carreg; Irish carraig is a borrowing from Middle Welsh carric from Welsh. These words go back to Proto-Celtic *kars-ekki-.
S.v. OIr. cloch 'pierre, caillou', possibly from Proto-Celtic *klukā (Stokes), but the -u- vocalism is uncertain. No certain connections outside of Celtic.
S.v. Bret. maen 'pierre, noyau', from Old Breton maen, main corresponding to Co. mên 'pierre, rocher', from Brythonic *magno-.
Cf. s.v. OIr. magen 'endroit, place'. Despite the difference in meaning, doubtlessly to be connected with W maen 'pierre' and other Brythonic words for 'stone'.

S.v. Bret. eün (effn, 1499, eun 1633), 'droit, simple', from Old Breton eunt 'juste, équitable, égal' with a non-etymological final -t. This word corresponds to Brythonic ebn from *ibn, apparently to Engl. even, OHG eban and to Goth. ibns.

S.v. Goth. I3. *ibns 'πεδινός', 'level', only dat.sg. ibnamma, connected with OIc. jafn, OE ifn, OHG eban 'even', etc. No clear etymology outside of Germanic; contrary to {ref Pedersen 1909}:92 and others, not to be connected with MBret. effen, OCo. eun-, etc.

S.v. OIr. grían 'sun', there are no correspondences elsewhere in Celtic, but there are two suggestions of an IE etymology. Either (1) to PIE *gʷʰer- 'warm, heiß', or (2) to PIE *g̑ʰer(ə)-/*g̑ʰrē- 'strahlen, glänzen, schimmern'. Of the two of these *gʷʰer- is probably more plausible since the root is well-attested in Celtic (cf. e.g. OIr. gorim 'Hitze'), while *g̑ʰer(ə)- is unattested, or else OIr. grían would be the only example. In either case, however the stem formation in -i-nā is without parallel and exceptional.
S.v. Bret. douss 'doux', a borrowing from Old French dous, ultimately from Lat. dulcem.
S.v. OIr. att 'tumeur, enflure', from which attaid 'il gonfle'. No plausible etymology, cf. entry for various proposals.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *su̯ei̯d-e/o- 'anschwellen', from PIE *su̯ei̯d- (LIV² 607).
Cf. s.v. 1. *su̯ei̯d- 'in Schweiß ausbrechen' (IEW 1043).
PIE *ku̯oi̯to- a depalatalised variant of *k̑u̯oi̯to. The depalatalisation is an internal process, there is no reason to assume a loanword here, cf. Old Indic śaṇa- and kaṇa or *śarkara-.
?*keh₁u̯- 'shake' with Church Slavonic po-kyjǫ, po-kynǫti 'nod (with one's head)' and Latin cēueō, cēuēre 'shake' given as cognates.
PS *kyta is derived from PS *kyti, a sparsely attested verb related do PS *kyvati. This word family is related to PS *kyjĭ 'stick' and *kovati 'hammer (also about blacksmith)'.
PS *kyta 'bunch, tuft, bundle' is likely to be derived from *kyti 'shake' which is related to PS *kyvati and further to Latin cēvō cēvere / cēveō, cēvēre 'waggle'.
The word is derived from PIE *mū, *mus- and related to Lithuanian musià, Latin musca, Old High German mucka etc.

It is usually assumed that this word is related to Lithuanian lė̃kti, lekiù 'fly, fall' which has been further linked to Greek λακτίζω 'tread, bang' Middle High German lecken 'hit with leg, jump', dialectal Norwegian lakka 'jump' etc. *-te- (*lek-te-) is most probably a verbal stem suffix.
The PS lexeme is derived from PIE *lek- 'jump, move', directly from *lek-te / *lek-to- with a present tense stem suffix *-te-/-to-. It is related to Lithuanian lė̃kti, lekiù 'fly, run, chase' etc.
PS *letěti 'fly' and Lithuanian lė̃kti, lekiù are cognates.
S. v. *mĭɡla.
It is a loanword from Turkic, cf. Kazakh, Kirghiz, Karaim tuman and Turkish duman 'fog, darkness'. The ultimate source is probably Avestan dunman- 'fog'.
S.v. cymeraf: cymryd, cymrud, cymeryd 'to take, seize, take possession of', from Celtic *kom-ber- to PIE *bʰer- 'carry' (cf. Lat. ferō, etc.).
S.v. Bret. kemer 'prise', from Proto-Celtic *kom-ber-o-.
S.v. OIr. tiug 'épais, dense, solide', from earlier *tegu-, common to Celtic and Germanic (cf. OIc. ϸykkr, ϸjukkr 'épais', OE ϸicce, OHG dicki <*tegw-yo-, IEW 1057).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *truk-, *truxso- 'trunk, broken part' (cf. MIr. trú 'doomed person, man condemned to death', MW trwch 'wounded, broken, sad, thickness, density', OBret. truch gl. obtusi, MoBret. trouc'h troc'h 'cut', OCo. trech gl. truncus, MoCo. trogh 'broken'), from PIE *treu̯k- 'cut' (IEW 1074), cf. Lat. truncus '1. mutilated, 2. stem'. The meaning 'thickness, density' in Modern Welsh trwch is a secondary semantic shift. "Despite formal and semantic problems, the connection to Lat. truncus 'trunk', trucidāre, Lith. trenkiù 'hit' remains probable, but forms adduced in IEW (1074) belong to several different roots." The Brythonic forms presuppose *trukso- with regular metathesis to *trusko- > W trwch.
Cf. s.v. Lat. truncus 'mutilated, maimed, trimmed'. There is no compelling reason to connect *tru/onko- with Go. ϸreihan 'to push' or Lith. triñkti 'to thrust' (cf. LIV s.v. *trenk- 'to push').
For Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 12729 Ved. śrṓṇi f. usu. du. (lex. also m.) ʻ hip and loins, buttocks ʼ RV.

S.v. OIr. sliasat, sliasait 'cuisse'. May go back to a base *(s)pleigh- 'écarter les jambes' (cf. Skt. pléhate 'il marche, il se meut', Gk. πλίσσομαι 'marcher à grands pas'), further to an unextended root *(s)plei- (cf. IEW 1000).
Cf. s.v. Skt. plehate 'geht, bewegt sich / goes, moves' (Dhātup.). Maybe (?) an explanation can be contrived to plīhán- 'Milz', however hardly a continuant of IE *(s)pleig̑ʰ- (IEW 1000).

Cf. s.v. Gk. πλίσσομαι 'to cross the legs'. Etymology uncertain. Perhaps to be related to OIr. sliassait 'shank' < *spleigʰ-s-ont-ih₂ or Skt. plehate 'to go' < *pleig̑ʰ-e/o- according to {ref IEW} 1000.
S.v. Bret. morzed 'cuisse', corresponding to Co. môrdhos (OCo. mordoit) and W morddwyd 'id.', the words are derived from Proto-Celtic *mar-yeito-.
Cf. s.v. W morddwyd 'thigh(-bone), haunch, ham' (cf. OCo. mor[þ]oit, gl. femur uel coxa, MCo. morʒosow (ll.), Late Cornish morzat, Bret. morzhed).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷetwores 'four', from PIE *kʷetu̯ores (cf. Skt. catvā́ras, Lat. quattuor, Gk. τέτταρες, Goth. fidwor, Lith. keturì, OCS četyre, ToA śtwar, Arm. čorkʻ).
Cf. s.v. Ir. cethramthu 'quarter, fourth part', from Ir. cethair 'four'.

S.v. OIr. cáel 'mince, étroit' later forms cóel, cáel, caol. Corresponds exactly to Brythonic forms in W cul 'étroit', OBret., Corn. cul 'id.', and a Gaulish PN Coilos (gen. Coili) which is perhaps the same word. These forms presuppose Proto-Celtic *koi̯lo-, which may find a connection in Latv. kaîls 'nu, chauve, simple'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *koylo- 'thin'. Perhaps from PIE *koi̯Hlo- if connected with Latv. kaîls 'naked, bold', but the reconstruction is uncertain and the semantic comparison is not very good.

S.v. OIr. smúain- 'penser, réfléchir, considérer; méditer'; has been connected to Goth. ga-maudjan 'rappeler à la mémoire', Lith. ãp-maudas 'chagrin, souci', OCS myslь, Gk. μῦθος 'parole', μυθέομαι 'je parle, réfléchis' to a root *meudh- 'penser à', etc. The diphthong -úa- of Irish may be a from a long -ō- or diphthong -ou- or just as well a compensatory lengthening from earlier *smudn- and the initial group shows an alternation *sm- : m-, but this is difficult to elucidate given the lack of Brythonic correspondences. (cf. {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911} 331, {ref Pedersen 1909}:113, 185, 296, 317, {ref IEW} 743).
S.v. W cynffon 'tail' a compound of cyn- 'before' + ffon 'stick'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff' (cf. MIr. sond 'stake, beam, palisade'), from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' (cf. Lat. sponda 'bedstead, bed', OE spōn 'sliver, shaving', Gk. σφήν 'wedge'). An alternative etymology derives PCelt. *sfondo- and Lat. sponda from PIE *(s)pend- 'to spin' (cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:582), but the semantics of this comparison are less appealing.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *rād-ī- 'talk', from PIE *(H)reHdʰ- 'perform successfully' (cf. Skt. rādh- 'perform successfully', OCS raditi 'take care of, work', Goth. rodjan 'talk', Lith. rodýti 'show').

S.v. OIr. rád- 'dire, parler', from a root *rēdh-, *rōdh- in the sense 'parler' (cf. Goth. rodjan, OIc. roda, OHG redon; also Skt. rádhayati, rādhnóti 'il satisfait, réussit, OCS raditi 'prendre soin de', Goth. ga-redan 'id.', etc.).
S.v. *reh₁dʰ- 'erfolgreich durchführen' (IEW 59-60).
S.v. Bret. soñj 'pensée, idée, intention, souvenir', a borrowing from an Old French continuant of Lat. somnium, derived verb soñjal 'penser, réfléchir, songer'.
S.v. Bret. sko 'frappe, heurt', from Old Breton sco, further origins obscure.

S.v. OIr. caithid 'il utilise, mange, jouit, de, lance'. Etymology difficult to explain. Cf. entry for various proposals. Probably connected to Gaul. cateia 'projectile' a gloss given by Servius ad Aen. 7.741, to which Pokorny (ZCPh 20 p.404) connected to Cz. kotiti 'retourner, tourner'.

Cf. s.v. Gaul. cateia 'sorte de projectile', a word reported by the Latin grammarian Servius (ad Aen. 7.741), glossing 'tela gallica' designating a projectile similar to a boomerang. Generally connected to the OIr. verb cathaid, with numerous senses among with 'il lance' and Cz. kotiti 'retourner, tourner' (cf. Pokorny ZCPh 20 1936 p.44, LEIA C-24).

S.v. OIr. do-léci 'il lâche, relâche, laisse aller, concède, accorde, décoche, lance, jette, rejette, abat…', originally a compound of the verb léic- 'laisser, lâcher' and the preverb to-, later interpreted as a simple verb teilcid, tarlaicid.
S.v. Manx tilgey 'casting, vomiting' (=ScG. tilgeadh).
S.v. *lei̯kʷ- 'zurücklassen, sich entfernen von' (IEW 669-70).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *li-n-kʷ-o- 'leave, let' (OIr. léicid, -léici 'leaves, lets, allows') from PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'leave' (cf. Skt. riṇákti, Lat. linquō, Gk. λείπω, Go. leihwan, Lith. lìkti).

S.v. 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' [IEW 933-5]; cf. n8: fo-ceird 'wirft, legt' < *kérH-dʰe- is synchronically suppletive within Irish to -cuirethar 'wirft, setzt in Bewegung, legt' < *korH-éi̯e-, but they share the same root etymology.
PS *kuriti is related to Gothic haúri 'coal', Old Icelandic hyrr 'fire', Armenian krak 'fire' and Lithuanian kùrti 'make fire'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kerd-o- 'put, lay, move', from PIE *kerd- 'swing' ({ref IEW} 934f.), cf. Gk. κραδάω 'swing, wave'.
Cf. s.v. cerd- (3), principally in fo-ceird 'il lance', jette'.
S.v. OIr. cengal 'lien, ceinture, attache, entrave' with derived verb cenglaid 'il attache', a borrowing from Lat. cingulum 'ceinture, cinturon, sangle (du harnais)'.
S.v. Bret. liamm 'lien', a borrowing from Old French liem 'lien, entrave'.
S.v. W clymaf, cylymaf: clymu, cylymu 'to bind, tie, set, unite, couple' (cf. Co. kelmy, Bret. coulmaff, Late Bret. koulma).
Cf. Ir. fíacail 'a tooth, a tusk', of unknown etymology, perhaps a loanword from a substratum language. A connection with OIr. fec 'Spaten' (in glosses also 'tooth') is possible.
S.v. OIr. cráeb 'branche, buisson, arbre'; the suggestion of {ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:104 to connect to a root *krei- seems poorly founded.
S.v. ScG. craobh 'tree', from OIr. cróeb, cráeb, *croib? 'the splittable' from *krei-, kri- 'separate'.
S.v. Manx billey 'tree' (= Ir. bile).
S.v. OIr. bile 'arbre'; etymology uncertain. The proposed connection with Lat. folium, Gk φύλλον is less satisfactory, cf. {ref IEW} 122.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *belyo- 'tree', from PIE *bʰolh₃i̯o- ({ref IEW 122, cf. Lat. folium, Gk. φύλλον).

S.v. Gaul. bilio- 'arbre', etymologies outside of Celtic are less convincing, but the existence of loanwords in French bille, billot, Provençal bilha 'tronc d'arbre' argue for the existence of a Gaulish pre-form *bili̯a.

S.v. OIr. crann 'arbre; bois (matière)', corresponding to W, Co., Bret. prenn 'arbre, bois' and may go back to *kʷr̥sno- for Ir. crann and *kʷresno- for Brythonic and Gaulish, to a base *kʷres- which can be seen in W prys 'buissons, boqueteau'; with the same suffix (*kʷr̥s-to-) in OE hyrst 'broussailles, taillis), cf. {ref IEW} 633.
S.v. OIr. cert 'correct, exact, juste, droit'. A borrowing from Lat. certus 'determined, resolved, fixed, settled, purposed, certain'.
S.v. Manx chyndaa 'change, changing, turn, turning, transaction' (= NIr. tionntódh).
S.v. soíd-, saíd-, a verbal root which only appears in composition. Etymology uncertain.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *suw-o- 'turn, wind', from PIE *seu̯h₁- 'move, set to motion' (cf. Hitt. suwezzi, Skt. suváti').
S.v. *seu̯h₁- 'antreiben, in Bewegung halten' (IEW 914).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *suu̯-e/o- 'drehen', to PIE *seu̯h₁- (LIV² 538f.).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kasso- 'curly, woven, twisted' "The connection to the root *kes- 'to comb' ({ref IEW} 585, cf. OCS česati, PCelt. *kīsrā 'comb') is semantically appealing, but the a-vocalism in Celtic is unexplained (a secondary zero-grade *kasto- instead of the expected *ksto-, with epenthetic *a?).
Cf. s.v. OIr. cas 'bouclé, embrouillé, tordu, etc.' for a survey of older etymological hypotheses.
S.v. ScG. bìd 'a very small portion, a nip, a chirp', from Scots English bite, bit, English bite, bit.
S.v. W cariaf: cario 'to carry, bear', a loanword from Engl. carry.

S.v. sceïd 'il vomit, crache, rejette; il jallit, coule, se déverse', one attaches the verb to the base *skei- 'couper, séparer', an enlargement of sek-, but without the enlargement -d- found in Gk. σχίζω 'je fends, je sépare', Lat. scindō, OIc. skīta, etc. 'cacare'. ({ref Pedersen 1909}:77, {ref IEW} 920).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *kerd-e/o- 'setzen, legen, stellen', from PIE *//kerdʰ-//, a secondary formation from a nominal compound *ker-dʰh₁o- < *kerH-dʰh₁-o-), the root being PIE 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' (LIV² 353-355).
S.v. ScG. cuir 'put', Ir., EIr. cuirim, OIr. cuiriur.

S.v. 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' [IEW 933-5]; cf. n8: fo-ceird 'wirft, legt' < *kérH-dʰe- is synchronically suppletive within Irish to -cuirethar 'wirft, setzt in Bewegung, legt' < *korH-éi̯e-, but they share the same root etymology.
Cf. s.v. OIr. do-cuirethar 'puts'.
Cf. s.v. OIr. cuirethar 'mettre, placer, jeter' and s.v. cerd- (3), principally in fo-ceird 'il lance', jette'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *kerd-e/o- 'setzen, legen, stellen' > OIr. -ceird.

S.v. OIr. cingid 'il marche, il avance', from Celtic *king- or *keng- with *e > i before a nasal and velar. Either from *g̑ʰengʰ- (= Go. gagg, OHG gang, etc., {ref IEW} 439, {ref Pedersen 1909}:187) with a voicing dissimilation of initial *g- > k, or to a root *kenk- comparing Lat. cingō in the sense of a circular movement.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *keng-e/o- 'schreiten', from PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- (cf. {ref LIV²} 555). An etymological derivation from this root is phonologically more likely than from *g̑ʰengʰ- ({ref LIV²} 175f.).
S.v. ScG. coisich 'walk' (= Ir. coiseachd), from cas 'foot, leg' (Ir. cos, OIr. coss, W coes) < *koksā (Lat. coxa 'hip', OHG hahse 'bend of the knee', Skt. kákshas 'armpit').
S.v. OIr. cos 'jambe, pied', related to Lat. coxa, cf. OHG hahsa 'creux de l'articulation du genou', Skt. kákṣa- 'aisselle'.
S.v. OIr. cos 'jambe, pied', related to Lat. coxa, cf. OHG hahsa 'creux de l'articulation du genou', Skt. kákṣa- 'aisselle'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *koxsā 'leg', cf. PIE *kok̑so- 'hollow of joint' (IEW 611), cf. Latin coxa 'hip', OHG hāhsa and Toch. B kakse 'loins'.
S.v. OIr. cos 'jambe, pied', related to Lat. coxa, cf. OHG hahsa 'creux de l'articulation du genou', Skt. kákṣa- 'aisselle'.
Cf. s.v. cerd- (3), principally in fo-ceird 'il lance', jette'.

S.v. 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' [IEW 933-5]; cf. n8: fo-ceird 'wirft, legt' < *kérH-dʰe- is synchronically suppletive within Irish to -cuirethar 'wirft, setzt in Bewegung, legt' < *korH-éi̯e-, but they share the same root etymology.

PS *kuriti 'burn with smoke' is related to Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'make a fire', Gothic haúri 'coal', Old Icelandic hyrr 'fire', Old Indic kūḍayāti 'ignite', kunḍate 'burn' and Tocharian B kurk 'oven'. Ultimately, all these words are derived from PIE *ker(ə)- 'burn, glow'.
S.v. sibal (1) 'mouvement, marche, expédition, promenade', with derived verb siblaid 'il circule, il voyage'; etymology unclear, cf. entry for a survey of various proposals.
S.v. OIr. sibal '(a) walk, progress, journey; act of walking, travelling, moving'. The etymology is disputed; cf. for a survey of various proposals.
S.v. OIr. nig- 'laver'.

Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'make a fire' and 'make', cf. Latvian kur̃t 'make a fire', Old Prussian kūra 'he made, did'. The word is derived from PIE *kʷer- 'cut, make, do' and related to Hittite kuerzi 'cut' and Vedic kóti 'make, do'. However, Lithuanian acute stress is an issue. No Slavic cognates given.
S.v. dobur (2) 'eau'
S.v. 8082 Skt. pānī́ya 'water' MBh. [√pā1].
Cf. s.v. √pā-² 'trinken', from PIE *peh₃-/*ph₃- (~ *peh₃-i̯-/*ph₃-i- → *pih₃-).
S.v. OW gulip 'liquid, wet' [gwlyb], from IE *u̯l̥k-u-, √u̯elk- 'feucht, naß' ({ref IEW} 1145).
S.v. ?*u̯elk- 'feucht sein/werden' (IEW 1145), probably a variant of *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (IEW 1145).

Cf. s.v. Lith. vìlgyti 'befeuchten, benetzen, bestreichen', from PIE *u̯elg- (cf. OIr. folc 'starker Regen, Regenwetter' folcaid 'waschen (Kopf)', MW gwylch 'waschen', Bret. gwalc'hiñ 'waschen', OS wolkan 'Wolke', OHG wolkan 'Wolke'). The reconstruction of the root with final *g is based on Balto-Slavic and Germanic, the Celtic lexemes reflect *u̯elk-. The reason for this deviation is unclear, but could be due to an assimilation of final *g in the 2nd or 3rd person singular in the present or aorist stem.
PS *kuriti (according to Sławski) is related to Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'fire, heat'.

PS *kuriti is related to Lithuanian kùrti 'heat', Gothic haúri 'coal', Old Nordic hyrr 'fire', Old Indic kunḍate 'burn' and Tocharian B kark 'oven'. The details are obscure. The PIE root is probably *ker(H)- or *kʷer(H)- 'burn, smolder, smoke'.

S.v. OIr. gel 'white'. There are two formal possibilities at a root etymology, either to *g̑ʰel(ə)- 'glänzen, schimmern' (IEW 429ff.) or *g̑el(ə)- 'hell heiter glänzen, lächeln, lachen' (IEW 366f., cf. LIV² 162 *g̑elh₂- 'in Lachen ausbrechen'); the connection to the former *g̑ʰel(ə)- is preferable. [Cf. also 'moon' pp. 259-260]

S.v. OIr. bán 'blanc', from IE *bhā-no- or *bhō-no- from a root *bhā- or *bhē- 'briller, luire' from which the Sanskrit verb bhā́ti 'il brille' and substantive bhánam 'éclat lumineux', cf. also Gk. φάος 'lumière', etc.

PG *hurja 'burning coal(?)', cf. Gothic hauri 'coal, burning charcoal, ember', Old Norse hyrr 'fire', Latin carbō 'piece of charcoal'(?), Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'to light, kindle', Old Church Slavonic kuriti 'to smoke, set fire to'. Derived from Germanic and Balto-Slavic root *kerh₃-.

S. v. carbō 'piece of charcoal'. "The root with Pokorny 1959 postulates as 'to burn' is now no longer regarded as a verbal root (Lith. kùrti is simply 'to make'). The meaning of carbō is quite specific, and  the suffix not attested in the words outside Italic which are usually compared (e.g. Go. hauri 'charcoal', OIc. hyrr [m.] 'fire' < PGm. *hurja-), sot that PIE origin is uncertain.

S.v. Gaul. uindos 'blanc; heureux', also attested in insular Celtic (OIr. find 'blanc', W gwynn, OCo. guyn 'albus', OBret. guinn 'blanc, lumineux'. One connects either to the root of Gk. ἰνδάλλομαι 'j'apprais', Skt. vindáti 'il trouve' formed to the nasal-infix stem of IE *u̯ei̯d- 'voir (clairement), savoir' or to the root *su̯ei̯d⁽ʰ⁾- 'briller', cf. Lat. sīdus, -eris 'étoiles', Lith. svidė́ti 'briller'.
S.v. OIr. find / finn 'white', from earlier *windo-/ā, but with no certain correspondences outside of Celtic.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *bodyo- 'yellow', from IE *bodyo- 'yellow' ({ref IEW} 92), cf. Lat. badius 'bay, chestnut brown'. "Lat. badius can be derived from *bodyos (with *o > a after labials, as in mare < *mori), but the initial *b-, and the fact that this adjective is limited in its distribution to Italic and Celtic, make it likely that we are dealing with a loanword from some non-IE source."

"If *kūrìti is cognate with Lith. kùrti, the vocalism *ū < *ou must be secondary. The Lithuanian verb, which also means 'make, create' has been connected with Skt. kr̥ṇóti 'do, make' < *kʷr-. This etymology is not implausible, though the fact that the East
Baltic evidence points to a root-final laryngeal is problematic. One may consider an extended root *kʷrH-, which would not be unprecedented. A reconstruction with a labiovelar has the advantage that it explains why we find *ur instead of *ir. It seems to me that if we also wish to establish a link with Lat. carbō 'charcoal', Go. hauri n. 'coal', OIc. hyrr m. 'fire', it might be best to give up the above-mentioned etymology and simply reconstruct *kerH-".
S.v. OIr. biast, béist 'bête, animal (grand ou petit), ver, pou, monstre, etc.' a loanword from Lat. bestia.
S.v. Bret. plac'h 'fille', from Lat. pallaca via popular Latin *placca.
S.v. OIr. scíath 'aile', from Celtic *skeido- but no certain etymology outside of Celtic.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *skēdo- 'wing, shoulder'. [No etymology outside of Celtic given.]
S.v. Bret. gwreg 'femme', corresponding to Co. gwrêk, W. gwraig, all from Celtic *urako-.
S.v. OW gurehic 'female', cognate to W gwraig, OCo. grueg, greg, MBret. gruec, of uncertain origin.

S.v. Bret. maw 'gaillard', from Old Breton mauu 'juvénile, réjoui; jeune homme, serviteur', corresponding to Co. maw 'garçon, serviteur, jeune'; derived form mawes (moues, 1557) 'femme', corresponding to Co. mowes.
Cf. s.v. OIr. mug 'garçon, serviteur', comparable to Germanic *magu- in Goth. magus 'garçon, valet', OIc. mǫgr 'fils, jeune homme', OE mazo 'fils, valet'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *magu- 'boy, relative', from IE *magʰ-u- (cf. OIr. mug 'servant', Co. maw 'id.' < *magʰ-u-). A West European word of obscure origin.

Cf. s.v. Goth. M3. magus 'παῖς', 'child, boy'. Etymology disputed, probably a non-IE term for 'son of maternal lineage' beside sunus 'son of paternal inheritance' (cf. OIr. mug, less likely IE *mogus 'boy, servant').

Derived from Old Breton mauu 'young man, servant' ({ref Deshayes 2003}:498), further connected to Old Irish mug 'boy, servant' and generally compared to lexemes from Proto-Germanic *magu- 'boy, relative' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} M:70-71, {ref Matasović 2009}:274). Further etymology uncertain; the lexemes may well have been substratum borrowings in the Western Indo-European languages (cf. {ref Lehmann 1986}:240, {ref Kroonen 2013}:347 for discussion of the Germanic comparanda).
PS *morkŭ 'darkness' is related to Lithanian mérkti 'close one's eyes' and Gothic maurgins 'morning'. PIE *morHk-ó-
PS *morkŭ is related to Lithuanian mérkti, mérkiu 'close one's eyes', Gothic maurgins, Old High German morgan 'morning', possibly also Old Indic markás 'solar eclipse'.
German Morgen < *mr(H)k-e/on-, OCS mrakŭ < *mork-o-, OCS mrĭknǫti < *mrHk-ne-, Lithuanian mérkti < mérHk-e.

Cf. s.v. ANT *moru̯is ~ *morm- ~ *moruos for further discussion. "The number of phonological variants suggest that the designation for the 'ant' in IE traditions was more than usually subject to phonological deformation (via metathesis, etc.) owing to some sort of affective semantics of the word. Though it is hard to reconstruct the exact PIE shape of the word, it is clearly of PIE date."
Cf. s.v. BLOOD *h₁ésh₂r̥ ~ *h₁ésh₂ōr (nom.), *h₁sh₂nós (gen.).
S.v. TochB orotstse ~ wrotstse 'big, great, large'. Cf. entry for various proposals, of which a remote suggestion is a connection to Hitt. ura- 'great' (Melchert, marked as 'p.c.' in the entry).

S.v. TochB kolyi '± hoof, paw' (?), in general 'animal's foot' (?); suggests a derivation from *golu-h₁en- and a connection to Proto-Germanic *klāwo-/*klēwo- 'claw' (OE clawu 'claw, hoof', OHG klāwo 'claw').

Cf. s.v. TochB kolyi '± hoof, paw' (?), in general 'animal's foot' (?); suggests a derivation from *golu-h₁en- and a connection to Proto-Germanic *klāwo-/*klēwo- 'claw' (OE clawu 'claw, hoof', OHG klāwo 'claw').
Cf. s.v. NHG Klaue (OHG klāwa, klā 'Klaue'). There are no meaningful comparisons that can be made outside of Germanic.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *klawō- 'claw' (OEng. clāwu, clā, Eng. claw, Du. klauw, OHG klāwa, klā, klō(a); Germ. Klaue, ON kló, Far. klógv, Elfd. kluo). Exclusively a Germanic word.
S.v. DOG *k̑(u)u̯ón (gen. *k̑unós) 'dog (canis familiaris)'.

S.v. TochB taur '± dust, ashes; rubbish-heap', together with TochA tor from Proto-Tocharian *teurä (as though) from PIE *dʰou(hₓ)-ro- (Ru. dur 'folly', Belorussian dur ~ dura 'giddiness, vertigo'), a derivative of *dʰou(hₓ)- 'move agitatedly'.

There is no single PS form but three: *korakŭ, *korkŭ/*korka and *krokŭ. It is hard to explain this variation. The lexeme was obviously expressive and its nautral usage in Bulgarian is a relatively late innovation. The Slavic word has been linked to Lithuanian kárka '(front) leg of pig'. It is further related to Latvian kar̂cinêt 'shake legs while sitting' and kar̂cinât 'shake, tremble' and to Lithuanian verb kárti 'hang'. Also a derivation from PIE *(s)ker- 'bend, twist' has been proposed.
S.v. TochB klāy- 'fall', while clearly related to TochA klā(w)- 'id.' extra-Tocharian cognates are very uncertain.

PS *krokŭ / *korkŭ / *korakŭ is probably related to Lithuanian kárka 'part of pig's leg, horse's ankle, part of insect's leg' and maybe also to Albanian krahë 'hand, arm' and Old Indic kiṣku- 'forearm'. The Slavic lexeme is probably ultimately derived from PIE *(s)ker- bend, twist, turn' with an original meaning 'bending, movable part of the body'. The reasons of the PS formal variety is hard to determine.

S.v. TochB klāy- 'fallen', 'fall', TochA klāw- 'fallen', 'fall'. The different root finals of TB -w and TA -y are best explained by setting up PToch *klāw’ā- with a palatal *w’ > TochB y by regular sound change. Two possible root etymologies, to PIE *kleu̯h₂- (so Hilmarsson, cf. LIV² 365 *kleu̯H- 'wohin geraten'), alternatively PToch *klāw’ā- could be derived from pre-PToch *klou̯Pi̯ā-, derived from PIE *kleu̯b- 'stolpern, hüpfen' (LIV² 364).
Cf. s.v. ?*u̯edʰh₁- → 2.*u̯edʰ-?. Reconstruction of final laryngeal insecure.

Lithuanian kárka 'part of pig's or sheep's leg, front leg of pig with scapula, horse's ankle' is related to PS *korkŭ and *krokŭ. The etymology is not entirely clear. It has been linked to PIE *(s)ker- 'bend'. The etymological meaning would be then 'bending part of the body'.
Lithuanian kárti 'hang' is derived from PIE *kerH-, cf. Old English heorr, Old Norse hjarri 'door wing'. If one would assume an s-mobile here, a link to PIE *skerH- 'split off, hang off' would be possible.
Cf. s.v. ?*u̯edʰh₁- → 2.*u̯edʰ-?. Reconstruction of final laryngeal insecure.
S.v. kâmvʹiri vʹia- 'beat, hit', from OIA vedh-a-ti ‘pierces’  T. 12109.
S.v. 12109 *vēdhati 'pierces'
Cf. s.v. Ved. √vadh- 'schlagen, töten' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. vadar- 'Mordwaffe'), from PIE *u̯edʰ-H- (cf. Gk. ὠθέω 'stoße', OIr. fodb 'Waffenbeute', Lith. vadegà 'eine Art Zimmeraxt', etc.).
Cf. s.v. SALMON *lok̑s 'large anadromous salmonid, salmon(-trout)'.
Albanian krah, krahë 'arm, shoulder, side' is borrowed from Slavic *krajĭ 'end, side, extremity'.

S.v. TochB pyāpyo 'flower', which with TochA pyāpi reflect PToch *pyāpyā(-i̯än)- where *-i̯än- reflects the PIE "definitizing" suffix *-h₁en-. The stem "probably reflects a (reduplicated) PIE *p(e)yehₐ- [: Sanskrit pyā́yate ‘is swollen’ and others from the extensive group of *peihₐ-: Sanskrit páyas- (nt.) ‘liquid, water, milk,’ pā́van- (adj.) ‘fat,’ Greek pī́ōn
‘id.,’ etc. (P:793-794; MA:194, 382)] (VW, 1941:104, 1976:398)."
Cf. s.v. *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).
S.v. TochAB ās- 'austrocknen, trocken werden', 'dry (out)', to be derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' or rather *h₂es- as set up by Ringe 1991:86.
S.v. TochB warto* ~ wartto* 'forest', which along with TochA wärt reflect PToch wärto/wärtonta, which should be connected with OE worϸ 'piece of land, farm' and Skt. vr̥ti- 'enclosure'.

S.v. Hitt. pai- / pi- 'to give, to pay, to grant, to hand over'. Kloekhorst prefers to split the Anatolian lexemes from Tocharian and Greek (αἴνυμαι), instead setting up a derived form *h₁p-ói̯-ei̯/*h₁p-i̯-énti, in comparison to Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'to take, seize'.

S.v. TochB ai- 'geben', 'give'; mid. 'nehmen', 'take', TochA e- 'geben', give'. Precise root reconstruction disputed. May be derived from PIE *h₂ei̯-, or perhaps *h₁ai̯- (LIV² 229). Adams (2013:107) sets up *h₄ei̯-.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. pai- / pi- 'to give, to pay, to grant, to hand over'. Kloekhorst prefers to split the Anatolian lexemes from Tocharian and Greek (αἴνυμαι), instead setting up a derived form *h₁p-ói̯-ei̯/*h₁p-i̯-énti, in comparison to Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'to take, seize'.

S.v. OIr. cocad 'guerre, fait de mener la guerre', a compound of com- + cath 'guerre'; cf. s.v. (1) cath 'combat; bataillon, troupes', seems to be very close to a verbal noun *katu-, also found in Germanic (cf. OIc. hǫd and in the OHG onomastic element Hadu- in e.g. Hadu-mār, etc.), one may connect Skt. śátru- 'ennemi', śātayati 'il abat'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *katu- 'battle' from PIE *k̑atu- 'fight' (IEW 534), cf. Hitt. kattu- 'enmity', Skt. śátru- 'enemy', OHG hadu- 'fight', OCS kotora 'fight'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. śátru- 'Feind, Gegner, Rivale', not certainly explained ("Nicht sicher erklärt"). Commonly compared with words for 'Kampf' with initial k- in the western satəm languages, which isn't a insurmountable difficulty, cf. ON hǫd 'Kampf, Streit', OHG hadu- = Gaul. katu- in personal names, MHG hader 'Zank, Streit, Hader' Ru.CS., OCS kotora 'μάχη', Thrac. katro-.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. kattu- 'enmity, strife', from PIE *k̑h₂et-(e)u- ?, generally compared with Gk. κότος 'spite, anger', OIr. cath 'strife, battle' (catu- in Gaulish personal names), OHG Hadu-, MHG hader 'fight, struggle', and Skt. śátru- 'enemy', pointing to *k̑h₂et- (with laryngeal needed to explain OIr. -a-).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *haϸu- 'battle', from PIE *⁽k̑⁾h₃-tu- (cf. Hitt. kattu- 'enmity, strife', OIr. cath, OW cat, MW cad 'battle, strife' < *⁽k̑⁾h₃-tu-; Gk. κότος 'spite, anger' < *⁽k̑⁾h₃-to-), a tu- stem to a root *⁽k̑⁾h₃-, perhaps the same underlying Gmc. *harōjan- 'sharpen'.
Cf. s.v. *k̑at- 'kämpfen', *k̑atu-, *k̑at(ₑ)ro- 'Kampf'.

S.v. TochB wālts- 'crush, grind, agitate, trouble', perhaps from PToch. wäl(t)s- either as a denominative verb *wel(t)sā- from a nominal derivative *wel(t)se from *wäl(t)s- or directly from *wäl(t)s- by analogical extension of the root vowel -ā- regular as the result of ā-umlaut in the subjunctive and/or preterite. Alternatively a Tocharian descendant a putative PIE o-grade ehₐ-iterative-intensive *wolh₂-s-ehₐ from *welh₂- 'strike' (cf. Hitt. walh- 'strike').
S.v. TochB wālts- 'zerstampfen, mahlen', 'crush, grind', either a denominative or o-grade eh₂-stem based on PIE *(h₂)u̯elh₂- 'strike' (Hitt, walaḫzi), as per Adams DoT, 589.

Cf. s.v. Neu: *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' (IEW 1144-5) and n1 "Aus semantischen und lautlichen Gründen (anatol. Laryngalschwund) besser von *u̯elh₃- ['sterben'] zu trennen." Formerly merged with *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' in {ref LIV²}.

Cf. s.v. Neu: *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' (IEW 1144-5) and n1 "Aus semantischen und lautlichen Gründen (anatol. Laryngalschwund) besser von *u̯elh₃- ['sterben'] zu trennen." Formerly merged with *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' in {ref LIV²}.

S.v. TochB motartstse* 'green'. Must be related to TochA motarci which also reflects a colour term, however TochA motarts- and TochB motärtsts- cannot be reconciled to a common Proto-Tocharian form. Some potential comparisons on Germanic and Slavic.
Cf. now LIV² 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben'.

Cf. {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda} for {ref LIV²} 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben'. Tentatively I assign the lexemes in this class to the new root *u̯elh₂- 'beat, hit' assuming a semantic development 'beat, hit' > 'wound' > 'blood'. See further {ref {Lucht 2007}:65, {ref Matasović 2009}:410.
S.v. OIr. fuil 'blood', cf. W gweli 'Wunde', Co. goly, Bret. goulyow 'id.', generally connected to *wel- 'reißen; verwunden; töten' ({ref IEW} 1144f.), *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' ({ref LIV²} 679).
S.v. TochB tuk- 'sich verbergen, Zuflucht nehmen', 'hide oneself, seek refuge in', TochA tpuk- 'verbergen, verborgen sein', 'hide'.

S.v. TochB kau- 'kill, strike down, destroy; chop up', which with TochA ko- reflect PToch. *kāu- from PIE *kehₐw- 'hew, strike' (OHG houwan, OE hēawan 'beat, hew', Lith. káuju 'beat, strike; forge', OCS kovǫ 'forge', and more distantly Lat. cūdō 'beat, pound, thresh'.

S.v. TochB aik- 'know, recognise'; TochAB aik- and its derivatives come from PIE *hₐeik̑- 'to have as one's own, be master of' (Av. iše 'is master of', Goth. aih, aigum 'have, possess', OE āgan 'id.', etc.).
S.v. TochB kärs- 'know, understand, recognise', reflecting PToch. kärs-, probably from PIE *kers- 'cut off'.
Cf. s.v. *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'kauen' (IEW 400).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √car-ⁱ 'sich bewegen, wandeln, gehen, wandern, fahren', from PIE *kʷel(H)- (cf. Gk. πέλομαι 'rege mich, bewege mich', Lat. colō 'behaue, bewohne', etc.).
S. v. kiṣkuḥ, a relationship to Albanian krahë ist not certain. No Slavic cognates listed.
PS *lěsŭ has no certain etymology. It has been linked to Old English lœ̄s, lœ̄swe 'meadow' or Lithuanian lãiškas 'leaf'. Both etymologies have phonetic issues.
S.v. Gmc. *teuh-a- 'ziehen', from PIE *deuk- 'ziehen' (cf. Lat. dūcō 'führen, leiten, ziehen', W dwyn, dwgyd (dygaf) 'bringen, stehlen, (ein Leben) führen', etc.).

S.v. TochB witsako 'root', probably (with {ref van Windekens 1976}:644) a borrowing from Iranian *vityaka- or *vaityaka- 'root' (cf. Av. vāeti-, Pers. bēd) or *vaitāka- (Oss. uedāgä), although there is a lack of exact Iranian parallels and one may have expected *-ty- to yield Tocharian -cc-. Assuming Middle Iranian *wīδikā- (Winter 1971:222, {ref Tremblay 2005}:426) makes things a bit easier, but -δ- > -ts- is still formally difficult.

S.v. TochB läk- 'see; look at, catch sight of; visit, behold; look forward to', with TochA läk- from PToch. läk- probably from PIE *leg̑- 'gather'. Less likely is the connection to PIE *leuk- 'shine' because the change of PIE *-u- > Toch. -ä- appears to be quite late.
Cf. s.v. *leg̑- 'sammeln, auflesen' (IEW 658) and s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9), both without TochAB läk- listed.
Cf. s.v. TochB träṅk- 'lament', with TochA träṅk- 'say' from PT *träṅk-, but extra-Tocharian connections are uncertain.

PS *lěsŭ has been linked to Greek ἄλσος 'sacred grove', Anglo-Saxon læs, læswe 'meadow', Lithuanian laĩškas, láiškas 'leaf', Latin larix 'larch', Latin lūcus 'a grove sacred to a deity', and Latin lignum 'firewood'. Some of these hypotheses show clear formal issues.
A common view is that the meaning 'forest' is secondary. Taking into account lexemes like Old Polish lasa 'small field in a clearing' and the fact that PS *lěsŭ refers often to deciduous forest or bushes (which are first to grow in a clearing), one could assume that the primary meaning was '(artificial) clearing'. The PS lexeme could be then derived from PIE *u̯el- 'tear, rip, hit' (*u̯loi̯-k̑os).
S.v. TochB śakāto* 'stick, club'. Etymology unknown; previous proposals to *sek- 'cut' unlikely because it requires the assumption of expected **ṣ to ś under the influence of a following -k-.

*PS *lěsŭ is likely to be related to Anglo-Saxon lǣs, lǣsve 'meadow, pasture' which is probably derived from PIE *leh₁- 'leave, abandon'. If it is right, the original meaning would be 'a field that is abandoned, not farmed anymore, where bushes started to grow'. Another possibility were a reconstruction *leg̑-so- with PIE *leg̑- 'to buckle, bend, arch'. The etymological meaning would be 'place where wicker grow, flexible vegetation' then.
S.v. TochAB lik- '(ab)waschen', 'wash', to be derived from PIE *u̯lei̯kʷ-  'befeuchten' (cf. {ref LIV²} 696f., {ref Hackstein 1995}:122f.).
S.v. TochB empreṃ 'truth'. Etymology uncertain, cf. entry for a survey of various proposals.
Cf. s.v. 2. *u̯el- 'drehen, rollen' (IEW 1140-2).

S.v. TochB pälsk- 'think about, consider'. "Etymology uncertain. It is probable that AB pälsk- reflect PTch *päl(k)sk- (as if) from PIE *bʰl̥g-sk̑e/o-, with zero-grade and an inchoative suffix from PIE *bʰelg- 'burn' > 'shine' > 'look (at)'" with a semantic development 'come to look (at)' > 'consider' > 'think' (for semantic parallels cf. Gk. σκέπομαι 'look, examine, consider' > Modern Greek 'think'; Skt. dhī- 'think' but Avestan dī- 'look at, observe'). Alternatively AB pälsk- could reflect PToch *pälsk- (as though) from PIE *bʰl̥sk̑e/o-, an inchoative of *bʰel- 'speak, yell; bark' which may also be seen in päl- 'praise' and pälw- 'bewail', with a semantic development something like 'come to say' > 'deliberate' > 'think' (cf. OIr. imrádim 'think' from im- 'about' + -rādi- 'speak').

S.v. OIr. bliadain 'an, année'. All the Celtic forms appear to be based on a root *bleid-, of unknown origin, to which several derived stems have been formed in Celtic: a nasal stem *bleid-n- / *blid-n-, and an i-stem *bleidnī- from which Ir. bliadain and W blwyddyn.
Cf. for a discussion of the stem formation in Goidelic, with references to further literature.
S.v. TochB ²kärk- 'bind', which with TochA kärk- reflect PToch. *kärk- from PIE *kergʰ- 'tie, bind', otherwise only seen in Lith. ker̃gti 'tie, bind' *kergʰ- ({ref Fraenkel 1932}:229-30).
S.v. TochB śänm- 'binden, fesseln; festlegen (Regeln)', 'bind; determine (rules)', of uncertain etymology, cf. for discussion of various proposals.

S.v. TochB spärtt- G 'to turn (intr.), stop (intr.), find oneself; conduct oneself, behave; spend [time]', K 'to turn' (tr.). The basic verb has been generalised from spārttā-, which may have been historically an interative-intensive or denominative built on spertte. The root may be related to the family of Skt. spárdhate 'contends for', Khot. spal- 'twitch', Hitt. ispart- 'escape', Skt. spr̥dh- 'contest, struggle', Av. spərəd- 'effort', Goth. spaurds 'race-course', OE spyrd 'race-course, contest', etc.

S.v. TochB spārtt- 'sich drehen; sich verhalten; sich befinden', 'turn, behave, be', TochA spārtw- 'id.'. According to Adams a denominative with the underlying noun TochB spertte 'function, behavior (?)' and in TochA spartu 'lock, curled hair'. In any case, the formation does appear to be denominal in formation.
S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.), cf. p.639 s.v. *steh₂-(s)mn̥- > TochA ṣtām B stām 'Baum'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' "[T]he 'nose' word, MMP wynyg, BMP wynyk /wēnig/, probably contains *u̯ai(H)n-". The IIr. root is nominal in origin from the noun *u̯ai(H)na- 'watch, survey(or)', cf. Skt. vená- 'watch', YAv. vaēnā- 'nose', from PIE *u̯ei(h₁)-no- 'survey' (cf. Lat. vēnārī 'to chase, hunt').
S.v. TochB ātstse 'thick', which with TochA ātsäts reflects PToch *āts(ä)tse or *āt(ä)tse, but there are no known extra-Tocharian connections.
Cheung reconstructs *su̯aH-, which would correspond to Proto-Indo-Iranic *ću̯aH- in his system.

S.v. TochB mlyuwe* 'thigh', as though from PIE *m(e)lewe/os- from PIE *mel- 'member, joint' (cf. Gk. μέλος 'member', Breton mell 'knuckle' < *melso-, Lith. mélmenys 'fat around the kidneys', Skt. márman- 'member, vulnerable part of the body').
Cf. s.v. Gk. μέλος 'member'. No clear cognates, perhaps to Bret. mell, Co. mal.

Cf. s.v. Lith. melmuõ 'krzyż, częśc kręśc kręgosłupa w okolicach miednicy; pachwina', 'cross, part of the spine in the pelvic area; groin', with related form mélmenys 'częśc pleców, która otacza nerki', 'part of the back that surrounds the kidneys'. Without etymology.
S.v. Ved. márman- 'verwundbare Stelle des Körpers', perhaps originally 'tödliche Stelle' to √mar- [< PIE *mer- 'disappear, die'].

Etymology dubious. {ref Adams 2013}:517 connects to a putative PIE *mel- 'member' comparing Gk. μέλος 'member', Breton mell 'knuckle' < *melso-, Lith. mélmenys 'fat around the kidneys', Skt. márman- 'member, vulnerable part of the body', but the etymologies of these compared lexemes are all for the most part considered to be unknown or dubious (cf. {ref Beekes 2010}:927-928, {ref EWAia} II:329, {ref Smoczyński 2007}:386).
Cf. s.v. TochB we- 'speak, say, state', tell'.
Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯edH- 'tönen, sprechen' (IEW 76-7) [without Tocharian cognates].
Cf. s.v. Alb. gjálp/ë, -t, -i 'Butter', generally assumed to be connected to Ved. sarpíṣ- 'Schmelzbutter', Gk. ἕλπος· ἔλαιον, στέαρ (Hes.) from PIE *selpo-.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *salbō- 'ointment', from PIE *solp-éh₂- (cf. TochA ṣälyp, TochB ṣalype '(sesame) oil; salve, ointment', Gk. (Hesych.) ἔλπος 'oil, fat', Alb. gjalpë 'butter' < *selp-o(s)-, cf. also Skt. sarpíṣ- 'melted butter, melting butter, lard' with secondary -íṣ- suffix).
Cf. s.v. Ved. sarpíṣ- 'zerlassene Butter, Schmelzbutter, Schmalz', from PIE *selp- 'fett sein' (cf. Gk. ὄλπη 'Ölflasche', OHG salba, etc.).

Cf. s.v. Gk. ἔλπος 'olive oil, rendered fat, abundance', usually compared with the IE word for 'fat' *selp- (cf. Skt. sarpíṣ- 'molten butter, lard', ToB ṣalype 'fat, oil', PGmc. salba- 'salve', Alb. gjalpë 'butter', but the lack of aspiration is unexpected in the Greek form.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'to swell', an exclusively Germanic verb.
Cf. s.v. PGmc. swell-a- 'schwellen'. There is no secure etymology outside of Germanic.
S.v. TochA wärs- 'atmen', 'breathe', a hapax with the same root as TochA wraseṃ 'breath' and TochA wrasom 'being'.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike; [inch., intr.] to become tired'. "A plausible IE provenance cannot be given for this apparently exclusively Ir. root."

S.v. PIr. *garH-³ 'to steep, soak, moisten' (Chor. (+ *fra-) šɣr- 'to become wet, moist'), from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾elH- 'to drip, well' (cf. Hitt. ku(u̯a)lii̯a- 'to flow; run smoothly, be calmed', OHG quellan).

S.v. PIr. *tāp- 'to twist, wind' (> ? (+us-) m|(w)stnb 'to throw up, vomit'). "The consistently long stem vowel of these Iranian (verbal) forms is puzzling (the inclusion of Chor. m|(w)stnb- is uncertain): it cannot be explained from a zero grade *tm̥p- (> Ir. *tap-), cf. LIV, ibid. Explaining the forms as a secondarily arisen causative is difficult in the absence of the corresponding regular formation.
