Perhaps, the long vowel has been imported from the semantically and formally similar Ir. causative continuations of *u̯ab/f (2) ‘to weave’"

Samadi considers a development "jdn. mit einer Hymne befriedigen, loben" > "singen" with reference to New Persian āf(a)rīn "Hymne". However, the imperfect would be expected to be formed with the augment m-, which is not the case.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *fraiH- 'to rejoice? to atone, [med.] please', from PIE *preiH- 'to please, be pleased, enjoy' (cf. Skt. pray- 'to please, be pleased, enjoy, satisfy', OCS prějǫ 'I take care', OHG frīten 'to look after' NHG Friede 'peace', Engl. free, etc.).
S.v. Khot. hvarandaa- 'right side, right hand' from base hvar- 'be fit', see  hvara- 'proper, fit' to PIE *su̯er- Pok. 1049.
PS *šuměti 'hiss, swish, make noise' has an ideophonic origin. It  is derived from a root *šu- with a suffix *-m-.

Serbo-Croat šuma is most commonly interpreted as a deverbative from šumiti 'hiss, swish, make noise' (these words have neither Baltic nor further IE cognates). The semantic motivation would be the sound of leaves and branches (in the wind). However, most probably it is a loan from a Thraco-Illyrian language, related to Albanian *shem in proshem 'bushes'.

Šuma 'forest' is related to šum 'noise, murmur'. The latter is derived from PIE *k̑ēu̯-mó-, ulitmately from the root *k̑eu̯- (or *k̑eH₂u̯-). IE cognates are Old Indic śuka- 'parrot', Lithuanian šaũkti 'call', Greek κωκύω 'lament', Old Indic kū́jati 'growl', Gothic hiufan 'lament', Tocharian B śauśäṃ 'call'. Other Slavic reflexes of this root are sova 'owl', kurŭ 'cock', kavka 'jackdaw'.

S.v. Lat. cinis -eris 'residue of fire, ashes, ashes of a dead person'. From an s-stem *ken-is-. de Vaan reconstructs the s-stem as an extension of an earlier PIE i-stem noun *kon(H)-i- / *ken(H)-i- 'dust', of which Latin cinis continues the e-grade. Compares to Ancient Greek κόνις 'dust' from the o-grade, TochB kentse 'dust' < *koniso-. Dismisses Walde-Hofmann (1938-1954)'s connection to PIE *kneh₂- 'to plane, rub' (Ancient Greek -κναίω) as 'not compelling).
The only other witness of this root in Iranic would be the "spider" kārtana(k).
Alternative suggestions: *ham-kana- as "Gegenbildung" to *wi-kana-, i.e. "to repaire (?)" vs. "to destroy".
?2.*k̑eu̯k- 'call, shout' with Lithuanian šaukiù, šaũkti 'call, shout', Tocharian B śauśäṃ 'call' and Vedic śuka- 'parrot' as cognates. No Slavic words listed here.
PS *gora is derived from PIE *gʷer- and related to Old Indic girí- 'mountian', Avestan gairi- 'mountian', Lithuanian girià 'forest' and Albanian gur 'rock'.

S.v. dorsum, -ī 'le bossu, le gros dos', the etymology conjectured by P. F. 60,18 'dorsum dictum qui pars ea corporis deuexa sit deorsum' is no doubt a popular etymology, but there are no better suggestions.
Cf. s.v. Sp. esquina 'ángulo exterior que forman dos superficies, canto', probably from Germanic *skĭna- 'barrita de madera, metal, o hueso' (cf. OHG scina 'tibia', 'alfiler'.
S.v. 8128 Lat. spatha (griech.) 'Schwert' and s.v. 8130 Lat. spatula 1. 'Rührlöffel', 2. 'Schulterblatt, Schulter'.
S.v. 2755 Lat. dorsum 'Rücken', 2. dossum.
Cf. s.v. Lat. spatha 'battoir, spatule; épée large et longue', a borrowing from Greek σπάθη, and from which spatula 'épaule (d'animal)'.
S.v. Sp. espalda, from late Latin spatula 'omóplato', earlier 'espátula', 'pala de ciertos instrumentos', diminutive of Lat. spatha, in turn a loanword from Greek σπάθη 'id.'.
S.v. 7206 Lat. ren 'Niere'.
S.v. Lat. tergum 'dos (de l'homme et des animaux)', no known etymology.
S.v. 2279 Lat. costa 'Seite, Rippe'.
The etymology is not entirely clear. It has been linked to PIE *kes- or to PS *xvorstŭ and *xvastŭ.

S.v. Lat. costa, -ae 'côte, flanc', there are no precise correspondences. It is sometimes compared with OCS kostь 'os', but this same word seems inseparable from the group of Lat. os, Skt. ásthi, etc., perhaps there was a prefix k-, but the existence of such a prefix has been contested.

S.v. Lat. capiō, -ere 'to take', from PIE *kh₂p-i- or non-IE *kap-i- 'to seize' (cf. Gk. κάπτω 'to gulp down', Go. haban 'to have' < *kap-eh₁-i̯e/o-), secondarily derived noun captiō 'trick, loss', from which captīvus (adj.) 'taken prisoner'.
Cf. s.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-528); in addition to Italic cognates are found in Germanic (NHG haben 'to have') and Greek (κάπτω 'gulp down').
S.v. Rom. rău, rea, from Lat. reus 'accused, guilty'.

Polish chaszcze 'thicket, bushes' is derived from older *charszcze and *chwarszcze, cf. dialectal forms like charszcz or chwarsty. All these words are derived from chwarszczeć 'scrunch, swish, hiss', PS *xvŭrščati, *xvŭrstiti, *xvŭrstati. The root is ideophonic.

Cf. s.v. Lat. reus 'party in a lawsuit; defendant', from PIE *Hreh₁-i-unt- 'possessing wealth'?. Connected with Lat. rēs 'property, goods, thing, affair' from PIE *Hreh₁-i- 'wealth, goods' (cf. Skt. rayí- 'property, goods', Av. raii-i- 'wealth'). The root is probably the same as that of IIr. aor. *rā-s- 'bestow'.
Cf. s.v. *reh₁- 'geben, schenken' (IEW 860).
S.v. Lat. trīstis, -e. Without etymology.

S.v. Lat. trīstis 'depressed, unhappy', according to {ref Hill 2003}:128 trīstis may go back to *trenksti- and cognate with Germanic words such as OE thriste, but in view of tēmō < *tenksmōn-, the raising of *e > i postdates the cluster simplification so that *trenksti- could at most yield *trēsti-. No other etymology.
S.v. Sp. barriga, possibly from barrica 'barrel', a loanword from Gascon barrique which presupposes *barrīca-, whose further origin uncertain, perhaps Gaulish.
S.v. Rom. burtă 'abdomen, pântece'. Etymology unknown.
S.v. Rom. mare (1), probably from Lat. mas, maris.
S.v. Lat. amārus, -a, -um 'amer', one connects Skt. amlá- 'aigre', Sw. & ODu. amper 'aigre'.
S. v. *xvorstŭ, xvostŭ etc.
The Slavic lexeme is related to German kahl 'bald'. PIE *galo-.

PS *golę 'unfledged hatchling, infant, small child' is derived from PS *gol- 'naked'. This Slavic lexeme is often assumed to be related to German kahl 'bald, hairless'. However, the Gemanic root is restricted to West Germanic only and needs itself to be explained etymologicaly. PS *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('naked, smooth, not overgrown' < 'smooth' < 'shining').

Most scholars assume the relationship of the Slavic root to German kahl 'bald' and its further Germanic cognates. The hypothesis of ESSJa (accepted by some other scholars) is reasonable but more complex.

Proto-Germanic *kalwa (PIE *golH-uo-) > German kahl 'bald' etc. It is related to OCS golŭ 'naked' etc. (PIE *golH-o-). It is a Germanic-Balto-Slavic isogloss unrelated to Latin calvus and Sanskrit kulvá- (PIE *klH-uo-).
PIE *gal-, related to German kahl 'bald' etc.
PIE *galo-, related to German kahl and English callow etc.
PS *gol- is related do Old High German kalo 'bald' etc.
The Slavic *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('shine' > 'smooth, not overgrown' > 'naked').

Cf. s.v. Lat. fuscus 'dark-coloured, dusky; (of persons) dark-skinned', from PIE *dʰus-ko-; cf. Lat. furvus 'dark-coloured, dusky' < *dʰus-u̯o- 'dark, black, brown' (cf. OIr. donn 'dun, light brown', MW dwnn 'dusky', OE dox 'dark-haired, dusky', MoE dusk, OE dosen 'dun, dingy-brown, dark-coloured').
S.v. 3611 Lat. fuscus 'dunkel'.
S.v. 540 appectorare 'an die Brust drücken' > Port. apertar, from which Port. preto, perto 'eng, knapp', 'schwarz'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'breast, chest'. Originally a proto-Italic s-stem formation *pektos-. The root is likely to be cognate with OIr. ucht < *puktu-, if from earlier *pektu-.

S.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'poitrine de l'homme ou des animaux'. A similar word differing in -o- root vocalism and u-stem inflection is found in Irish ucht 'poitrine'. There are no other correspondences outside of these two languages.
S.v. Rom. respira, a borrowing from French respirer.
Cf. s.v. Rom. sufla, from Latin sufflare.
S.v. Lat. cremō, -āre 'brûler'. Uncertain, perhaps an enlargement in *-em- of a root attested by OIc. hyrr 'feu', Goth. hauri 'charbon', Lith. kuriù, kùrti 'faire de feu').
S.v. ?*⁽k̑⁾remH- 'verbrennen' (IEW 572). Only Latin.
S.v. Rom. copil, cf. Alb. kopil.
Romanian copil is a loanword from either Thraco-Dacian or Albanian.
S.v. Lat. for, fārī 'to speak, say', from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to speak', from which Lat. īnfāns, -ntis 'unable to speak; infant' is a derivative.
S.v. Rom. gheară; etymology unknown.

S.v. Sp. garra 'mano de las fieras y aves de rapiña, armada de uñas corvas, fuertes y agudas’, 'hand of beasts and birds of prey, armed with nails, strong and sharp' probably a loan from Andalusian Arabic ġárfa 'puñado', 'handful'.
S.v. Rom. rece, from Lat. recens 'freshly, recently'.

S.v. Lat. recēns, -ntis 'of recent origin, new, fresh'. Probably a compound of re- 'again, back' and *kent(i)- 'young, first' (< PIE *ken-t- 'young, new', cf. MIr. cana, cano 'wolf cub', Gaul. cintu-gnatus, OIr. cét- 'first', MW cynt MCo. cens, Bret. kent 'earlier' < PCl. *kento/u-, Skt. kanyā-, Av. kaine, kainīn- 'girl' < PIE *ken-i-Hn-, Skt. kanīna- 'young', Gk. καινός 'new, unheard of', etc.).

S.v. Lat. putō, -āre 'to prune (trees), scour (wool); make up (accounts), think, reckon' (with preverb: computō, -āre 'to calculate, reckon'), from Proto-Italic *puto- 'cut off, clean', PIE pHu-tó-. The adjective putus must be primary (and to the same root as Lat. paviō 'to thump, pound, strike' < PIE *ph₂u-i̯e/o-, cf. LIV² 481-482 s.v. *pi̯eh₂- 'schlagen'), with putāre a verbal derivative.
S.v. Lat. numerus 'nombre', one connects Gk. νέμω 'je distribue, je partage'.
S.v. Lat. quirīs, -ītis 'name for Rome's citizens in their peacetime function' (derived verb: quirītāre 'to make a public outcry'). Indo-European connections uncertain.
S.v. Lat. quirīs, -ītis, of obscure origin.
S.v. Lat. uāgiō, -ire 'vagir, chevroter'. An expressive formation similar to Lat. ragiō.
S.v. 8542 Lat. taliare 'schneiden'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. tālea 'rejeton, bouture; piquet, pointe'. Technical term, without doubt borrowed.

Cf. s.v. Lat. tālea 'cutting, thin piece of wood'. Compared to Gk. τᾶλις, -ιδος 'young girl, bride' on the assumption of a basic meaning 'green, to sprout' (cf. {ref IEW} 1055), but this seems like a wild guess. No viable etymology unless a derivative of tālus 'knuckle'.
S.v. Rom. săpa, from Lat. sappare.
Cf. s.v. Lat. sappa, -ae 'sorte de hoyau' (Fr. sape, cf. {ref Meyer-Lübke 1935} No. 9599).
Cf. s.v. 1788 Lat. cavare 'graben, ausgraben' and 2964 Lat. excavare 'aushöhlen'.
S.v. 8194 Lat. spŭrcus 'schmutzig'.
S.v. Lat. spurcus, -a, -um 'sale, impur', etymology uncertain, perhaps connected to Lat. spurius 'bâtard'?

Cf. s.v. Lat. horreō 'to be stiffly erect, shudder' (derived adj. horridus 'rough, crude, horrible'), from PIE *g̑ʰrs-eh₁- 'to be stiff, surprised' (cf. Skt. hárṣate 'to be delighted', YAv. zarǝšiiamma- 'excited', Sogd. wɣš- 'to be glad').
Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰers- 'sich sträuben, erstarren' (IEW 445-6).
S.v. Rom. murdar, a loan from Turkish murdar 'unclean'.
S.v. Lat. brūtus 'lourd', popular word without a doubt a loanword from Oscan with a labial reflex b- from *gʷ-, from the same root as Lat. grauis 'heavy'.
S.v. Lat. brūtus 'heavy, inert, brute; brutish', generally regarded as a Sabellic dialect word with PIE *gʷ- > b- and from the same stem as Lat. gravis 'heavy'.
S.v. 8414 Lat. sucidus 'schmutzig'
S.v. Sp. perro, of uncertain origin, possibly an imitative/expressive creation.
S.v. Rom. praf, a loanword from Slavic prachŭ.
S.v. Rom. pământ, from Lat. pavimentum 'paved area, pavement'
S.v. Lat. paviō 'to thump, pound; strike', derived form: pavīmentum 'pavement', derived from PIE *pi̯eh₂-.
Cf. s.v. *pi̯eh₂- 'schlagen' (not in IEW).
S.v. Rom. departe, from Lat. dē + parte.
S.v. Lat. pars, -tis 'part, piece', from Proto-Italic *parti- 'part', a late Inner-Latin formation connected with Lat. pariō 'to give birth, to bear' from the root *perh₃- 'to provide'.
S.v. Sp. lejos, from Lat. laxius 'más ampliamente, más libremente, más separadamente', comparative adverb of Lat. laxus 'amplio, suelto'.
S.v. Gmc. *sunni- 'sorge, gram'.
S.v. Rom. frică, a loanword from Gk. phrikē.
S.v. Sp. miedo, from Lat. metus, -ūs.
S.v. Lat. metus, -ūs 'fear, alarm', no clear etymology outside of Italic.
S.v. Lat. metus, -ūs 'crainte', no agreed etymology.
S.v. Sp. pelear 'fight' (n.), derived to pelo 'hair' < Lat. pilus 'id.'.
S.v. Lat. pilus, -ī 'poil, cheveu', no certain connections. There is no common Indo-European word for this concept.
S.v. Lat. pilus 'hair' [No etymology given.]
S.v. Rom. ceață, from Lat. caecus 'blind'.
S.v. Lat. caecus, -a, -um 'aveugle, qui ne voit pas', only comparable to lexemes in adjacent language families, cf. Ir. cáech, W coeg, Goth. haihs.
Cf. s.v. Sp. boira 'niebla', an Aragonese word taken from Catalan boira from Lat. boreas 'viento Norte'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. boreās, -ae 'vent du nord et région d'où souffle ce vent, nord', a borrowing from Gk. βορέας 'north wind'.
S.v. Rom. pădure, from Lat. padule.
S.v. Sp. soto, from Lat. saltus, -ūs 'pastizales; pastizales con bosque; desfiladero, quebrada'.

S.v. Lat. saliō, -īre 'to jump, leap' with derivative saltus, -ūs 'jump, leap; narrow passage, woodland'. Lat. saltus may be derived from PIE *sh₂l-to- (cf. OIr. saltraid 'to trample' MW sathar 'trampling' < *sal-tro-, Gk. ἅλλομαι 'to jump' < *sl-i̯e/o-, etc.).
Cf. s.v. 1. *sel- 'sich losschnellen, springen' (IEW 899).
Cf. s.v. Lat. saliō 'sauter, bondir', with derivative saltus 'passage étroit, pas'; the verbal root can also be found Gk. ἅλλομαι in the same sense.
S.v. Rom. merge, from Lat. mergere 'to sink'
S.v. Lat. bonus (OLat. duenos, duonus).
S.v. Rom. măruntaie, from Lat. minutalia 'intestina animalium'.
S.v. Lat. uīscus, -eris 'parties internes du corps, chair(s), entrailles', without a clear etymology.
S.v. Sp. tripa, a word common to the West Romance languages, but of uncertain origin.
S.v. Lat. pilus 'hair' [No etymology given.]
S.v. Lat. capillus 'cheveu, poil de barbe, chevelure des plants, des arbres', reminiscent of caput 'head', but the connection is not obvious formally or semantically.
S.v. Rom. tare, from Lat. talem.
S.v. Rom. inimă, from Lat. animus 'soul, spirit, heart'.
PS *gvozdĭ, gvozdŭ 'nail' (Slovene gozd 'forest' is listed as a cognate) is perhaps cognate with PG *kwasta (Middle Low German quast(e) 'bundle, broom, besom'). Otherwise unclear.

PS *gvozdŭ, *gvozdĭ is derived from PIE *gu̯os-d- and related to German Quast, Quaste, Middle High German quast(e) 'bundle, whisk, broom'. Other comparisons (e.g. to Old Icelandic gaddr, gadd 'blade, nail' or Latin hasta 'lance') are inconvincing.

PS *lǫgŭ 'curve, bend, depression (in a river meander), wetland  with grass, bushes, trees' is etymologically identical with PS *lǫgŭ 'flexible' (cf. Kashubian łąǵi 'flexible, agile', Polish dialectal łężny 'giętki', Kashubian łąžni 'flexible, agile, strong'). It is derived from PIE *leng- 'bend, twist'.

PS *lǫgŭ is related to PS *lǫka, *lǫkŭ with an expressive *-g- < *-k-. All these words are ultimately related to Lithuanian lenkiù, leñkti 'bend', Latvian lìekt 'bend', Old Icelandic lengia 'belt' and Albanian lëngór 'flexible'.

PG *lingwa- 'heather' (Old Norse lyng, Faroese lyngur, Old Swedish liung, Swedish ljung, Elfdalian lingg) is derived from *lengʷʰ-o- and related to OCS lǫgŭ 'meadow, underbrush' and Russian lug 'meadow' (*longʷʰ-o-). The alternative etymology linking to Lithuanian leñkti 'bend' and OCS lǫkŭ 'bent' is semantically unattractive.
?*lenk- 'bend' with OCS -lękǫ, -lęšti 'bend' and Lithuanian lenkiù, leñkti 'bend' listed as cognates.
Cf. s.v. Lat. lūror, -ōris 'teint blême ou jaunâtre', with derived adj. lūridus. No certain connections.
S.v. Sp. pesar, from Lat. pensare (Sp. derived adj. pesado).
S.v. Lat. repōnere 'zurücklegen' > OFr., MFr. repondre 'cacher'.

S.v. Lat. pōnō, -ere 'to place, set, put' (repōnere 'to put back, down, replace'), from Proto-Italic *po-sine/o-, from PIE *po- + *tk̑-i-n-(e/o-) 'to build, live' via *po-sinō > *po-snō > *poznō > pōnō.
Cf. s.v. *tk̑ei̯- 'Landbau treiben, siedeln, wohnen' (IEW 626). Lat. ponō < *tk̑i-néH-nH-? Cf. discussion in n6.
S.v. *leh₁g̑ʰ- 'kriechen' (IEW 660), with OSL -lězǫ, lěsti and -lažǫ -laziti listed as cognates.
Cf. s.v. Sp. amagar 'hacer ademán de ir a ejecutar alguna cosa en dãno de otro', of unknown origin.

S.v. Lat. battuō, -is, -ere 'battre'. A word that is rare in texts, but already attested in Plautus. Similar to Celtic words in the sense but in different form. Origin unknown. As in Lat. fut(t)uō 'I fuck' the consonant gemination is expressive.
S.v. frap-; {ref Meyer-Lübke 1930–1935} assigns the lexemes to No. 3173 faluppa, but this is unlikely for semantic reasons. More likely we are dealing with an onomatopoeic formation.
S.v. Rom. lovi, a borrowing from Slavic loviti 'hunt, catch, fish'.

Cf. s.v. legō, -ere 'to gather, collect; read' (w/ preverb con- > colligere 'to gather, collect'), from PIE *leg̑-e/o- 'to collect' (cf. Gk. λέγω 'to collect, count; speak', Alb. mb-ledh 'to collect').
Cf. s.v. *leg̑- 'sammeln, auflesen' (IEW 658).
PS *loza is derived from PS *lězti 'crawl, creep'.
For the (non-target meaning) Germanic lexemes attached to this class, cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hlewa- 'shelter (from wind)', *hlēwa- 'lukewarm'.
S.v. Lat. casa 'hutte, cabane', popular word of unknown origin. The intervocalic -s- is suggestive of a loanword from a pre-Indo-European language.

Cf. s.v. OLith. trobà 'Gebäude, Haus, Hütte', from PIE *treb- 'von Menschen besiedelter Ort (cf. Lat. trabs 'Balken', Osc. acc.sg. TRÍÍBÚM 'Haus', OIr. treb 'Haus, Gehöft', MW tref 'Gehöft, Dorf' Celtib. Contrebia, Goth. ϸaurp 'Feld, Acker' ON ϸorp 'Dorf, Gehöft', OHG dorf 'Dorf, Hof').
Cf. s.v. Lat. hospitalis 'gastfreundlich' > 1. Unterkunft.
S.v. Rom. omorî, a loanword from Slavic umoriti.

S.v. Sp. matar. Etymology uncertain, possibly from a Latin verb *mattare, a derivative of mattus 'estúpido, embrutecido'; the proposed etymology to Lat. mactare 'sacrificar' is absolutely impossible from a phonological point of view.
Cf. s.v. Sp. rueda 'wheel', from Lat. rota 'id.' with related form rodilla 'knee' from a diminutive.
S.v. Rom. frunză, from Lat. frondea (frons, frondis).

S.v. Sp. izquierdo, vocabulary common to Portuguese (esquerdo) Catalan (esquerre), Gascon (querr, esquerr) and Languedoc (esquer, -rra), from the same origin as Basque esker(r) in the same meaning, probably from a pre-Roman Hispano-Pirenaican language. It can not be guaranteed that the current Basque form is not of Romance origin, it is more plausible that the vocabulary extended from the Basque language area in the Visigothic era.
S.v. Rom. stâng, from Lat. *stancus (= stanticus).

S.v. Lat. mancus 'maimed, crippled (at the hand)', from Proto-Italic *manko-? "If cognate with manus 'hand', mancus must contain the athematic stem *man- 'hand'. This etymology would imply a semantic shift *man-ko- 'handy' > 'handicapped, having a defect of the hand'."
S.v. Lat. mancus 'manchot, infirme de la main', from *man- + -ko-, with a suffix characteristic of physical qualities (cf. caecus and peccāre?).
S.v. Lat. sinister, -tra, -trum 'gauche'.
S.v. Sp. pierna, from Lat. perna 'muslo y pierna juntos en un animal', 'muslo del cerdo', 'zanca, en el hombre'.
S.v. Rom. picior, from Lat. petiolus 'small foot'.

S.v. perna '(upper) leg, thigh', from PIE *tspērn-eh₂- 'heel' (cf. Hitt. paršna- 'unknown body part, heel?' < *persno-, paršnae- 'to squat down, crouch'? Skt. pā́rṣṇi-, YAv. pāšna-, Khot. pārrā-, Gk. πτέρνη, Goth. fairzna, OS fersna 'heel'). For the IE reconstruction given, cf. {ref Lubotsky 2006}.

S.v. Lat. perna 'jambe tout entière (cuisse et mollet)', in particular 'cuisse de porc, jambon', corresponding to Hitt. paršna- 'haut de la cuisse, jambon', Gk. πτέρνα, Skt. pā́rṣṇi-, Goth. fairzna 'talon'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. pā́rṣṇi- 'Ferse', from PIE *persneh₂- 'Ferse' (cf. Lat. perna 'Hinterkeule', Goth. fairzna, OS fersna 'Ferse', Gk. πτέρνη 'Ferse', Hitt. paršina- 'Hinterbacke').

Reconstructs IE *tpērsneh₂- 'heel', connecting with *sp⁽ʰ⁾erH- 'to kick with the foot' (Skt. sphuráti, Av. sparaiti, Lat. spernere 'to push away, despise, reject'), and positing a new verbal root reconstruction *TsperH-.
S.v. Rom. trăi, loanword from Slavic trajati.
S.v. Lat. fīcus 'figuier; figue', appears to be a Mediterranean loanword, as in other languages (cf. Gk. σῦκον, [Boeot.] τῦκον 'fig', Arm. tʻuz 'dried fig').
S.v. Lat. largus, -a, -um 'abondant', without certain correspondences.
S.v. Lat. pēdis, -is 'pou'. The name of this insect differs from one language to another. Av. pazdu- designates a small annoying insect. Cf. perhaps pēdō 'péter'?

The proposed connection of {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:497 to Lat. pēdō 'to fart' is not particularly convincing semantically. We could well be dealing with a homophonous root *pesd-, distinct from PIE *pesd- 'leise furzen, fisten' ({LIV²} 829), perhaps originally onomatopoeic of a 'buzzing' noise?
Cf. s.v. OLith. barzdá 'Bart' (cf. OCS brada 'Bart', Lat. barba 'Bart', OE beard 'Bart', OHG bart 'Bart' < PIE *bʰarsdʰó- 'Bart').
S.v. U. pelmner 'Wahrscheinlich "Fleisch"' < *pelp-men- as Lat. pulmentum 'Fleischspeise' < *pelp-men-to-, derived to Lat. pulpa 'Fleisch'; only in Umbrian and Italic. A Proto-Italic creation?
S.v. 6450 *pettia (gall.) 'Stück'.

S.v. Lat. carō, carnis 'morceau de chair, de viande' originally in the sense 'part' as seen elsewhere in Italic (cf. Osc. carneis 'partis', Umb. karu 'pars', abl. karnus 'partibus'), to the same root as Gk. κείρω 'je coupe', etc.
S.v. Rom. gură, from Lat. gula 'gullet'.
S.v. Lat. gula, -ae 'partie de la bouche par laquelle on avait gosier, cou'.
S.v. *bot-, probably of onomatopoeic origin.
S.v. 540 appectorare 'an die Brust drücken' > Port. apertar, from which Port. preto, perto 'eng, knapp', 'schwarz'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'breast, chest'. Originally a proto-Italic s-stem formation *pektos-. The root is likely to be cognate with OIr. ucht < *puktu-, if from earlier *pektu-.

S.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'poitrine de l'homme ou des animaux'. A similar word differing in -o- root vocalism and u-stem inflection is found in Irish ucht 'poitrine'. There are no other correspondences outside of these two languages.
S.v. Lat. cīrcus, -ī 'cercle', etc. Probably a loanword from Gk. κίρκος, κρίκος 'anneau', a loanword in a technical sense (as also Lat. gȳrus and tornus').
S.v. Rom. gât, a borrowing from Slavic glŭtŭ 'sip, gulp'.
S.v. Sp. tirar, a word common to the Western Romance languages of uncertain origin. Maybe from Germanic teran 'desgarrar'.
S.v. 8755 *tīrāre 'ziehen, schießen', of uncertain origin.
S.v. Lat. pulsāre 'stossen' > Fr. pousser.

S.v. Lat. pellō, -ere 'to beat against, push, strike', from PIE *pl-n(e)-h₂- 'to approach' (cf. OIr. ad-ella* 'to visit', MW el, MCo. ello, MBret. yel, yal 'to go', Gk. πίλναμαι 'to approach'). The p.p.p. is pulsus, from which Lat. pulsāre 'to strike, beat'.
Cf. s.v. *pelh₂- 'sich nähern' (IEW 801-2).
Cf. s.v. *pelh₂- 'sich nähern' (IEW 801-2).

S.v. Lat. pellō, -ere 'to beat against, push, strike', from PIE *pl-n(e)-h₂- 'to approach' (cf. OIr. ad-ella* 'to visit', MW el, MCo. ello, MBret. yel, yal 'to go', Gk. πίλναμαι 'to approach'). The p.p.p. is pulsus, from which Lat. pulsāre 'to strike, beat'.
S.v. trūdō, -ere 'pousser (par opposition à trahō 'tirer')', cf. Goth. us-ϸriutan 'κόπον παρέχειν' and OCS trudъ 'κόπος'.
Loan from German Forst 'forest'.
PS *morzŭ 'frost' and *mĭrznǫti 'freeze' are related to Albanian marth 'frost' etc. and derived from PIE *merg̑-.
Av. tąϑra-; Khot. ttāra- (DKS 126), Sogd. tʾrʾk 'dark', Prs. tār 'id.'; Y[i]d[gha]-M[un]j[i] t'ū/īro 'darkness'.- *tanϑra-.
S.v. Pašto haḍ 'bone', cf. T 13952 and Lhd, Pnj haḍḍ(ī) 'bone', etc.
Cf. s.v. 5345 Lat. marcere 'welk werden', with derivative found in It. marcio.
or'ǝ, owr'ǝ, war'ǝ, etc. m., Kak[ari Pashto] aw'ar 'a cloud'.- *abrya- (but why no palatalisation of the vowel?); w(ǝ)ryaj, w(ǝ)rej f. 'cloud(s)' < *abračī.
S.v. 3465 Lat. fracidus 'sehr weich'.

S.v. Lat. fracēs, -um 'fragments of olive pulp left after pressing', derivative fracidus 'soft, pulpy', from Proto-Italic *frak- (cf. OPr. dragios 'yeast', Lith. drãgės, Latv. dradži, OCS droždьje 'dregs', OIc. dregg 'dregs', Alb. dra 'dregs, sediment'). The Gmc., BSl., and Latin words for 'dregs' belong together, but the vowels don't match and point to a non-IE *a. The velars don't match either. It appears that we are dealing with a loanword from an unknown, non-IE language, or a lost IE language in which the root *dʰregʰ- 'to drag' or *dʰreh₂gʰ- 'to soil' yielded a form *dʰragʰ- 'dredges of wine, oil, fat'.

S.v. fracēs, -um 'marc d'olives', attested since Cato. A rare technical term. One has connected words like OIc. dregg 'levain, lie' OPr. dragios, OLith. dragės which go back to *dʰregʰ- 'lie, dépôt', on the other hand OIr. mraich or braich, W brag 'malt', alternatively maybe a loanword.
S.v. Lat. largus, -a, -um 'abondant', without certain correspondences.
S.v. Lat. largus, -a, -um 'abondant', without certain correspondences.
S.v. Rom. alerga, from Lat. *allargare (< largus).

S.v. Proto-Iranic *tač- (1) 'to flow, run, walk', from PIE *tekʷ- 'to hurry, rush, walk, flow' (cf. Skt. tak- 'to rush, hurry', Hitt. u̯atk- 'to jump from', OIr. tech- 'to flow' OCS tešti, Lith. tekė́ti 'to run, flow', etc.).
S.v. Lat. harēna 'sable', without certain etymology.
S.v. Rom. nisip, a loan from Bulgarian nasip.
S.v. Rom. spune, from Lat. exponere.

S.v. Pashto st'ərga f. 'eye'. Diminutive * stṛ-kā-, which he compares with Balochi čamm-istār "pupil of the eye". Since he also refers to the meaning "planet" of the Pashto word, he probably suggests the "star"-word as etymology.
Cf. s.v. 4809 Lat. labor 'Arbeit' > Catalan llavor 'Samen' (cf. Span. labor 'Bearbeitung des Feldes; Näherei'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. ùnksna, unksnà 'Schatten', connected with OLith. ū̃kas, ū́kas 'Dunst, Nebel'; no certain comparanda outside of Lithuanian, traditionally assumed to be related to Lith. vãkaras 'Abend', but this etymology is difficult to explain in terms of its derivational morphology.

Cf. s.v. Lith. uñksnė 'shade, shady place'; possibly connected with Lat. umbra 'shade, shadow' if it reflects *unksra-, but cf. also variant ūksna without a nasal, possibly to be connected with vãkaras 'evening'.
Cf. s.v. 8542 Lat. taliare 'schneiden'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. tālea 'rejeton, bouture; piquet, pointe'. Technical term, without doubt borrowed.
S.v. Sp. hilo, from Lat. fīlum 'thread, string', derived verb afilo 'sacar filo' (derived adj. afilado).

S.v. Lat. fīlum 'thread, line; build (of a person)', from PIE *gʷʰiH-(s-)lo- 'sinew, sinew thread' (cf. MW gieu, W gïau 'sinew, nerves', OCo. goiuen < PIE *gʷiH-, Skt. jyā́- 'tendon, bowstring' < *gʷiH-o-, Av. jiia- 'bowstring', Gk. βιός 'bow; bowstring' < *gʷiH-o-; Arm. ǰil- 'sinew, cord' < *gʷiH-sl-; OPr. pettegislo 'back vein', Lith. gýsla, Latv. dzî(k)sla 'vein, sinew' < Proto-Baltic *giHla-, OCS žila 'vein'). The individual branches do not agree on whether the initial velar was aspirated or not. Indo-Iranian and Greek require *gʷ-, while Latin and Armenian require *gʷʰ-; in the Celtic and Balto-Slavic lexemes the velar is uncertain.
Cf. s.v. *gʷʰeiə- : gʷʰī- 'Ader, Sehne, Band'.
S.v. Rom. mirosi, a loan from Slavic mirosati.
S.v. 3476 Lat. fragrare 'riechen, duften' 2. flagrare.

S.v. Lat. fragrō, -āre, from PIE *bʰrh₁g-ro- 'smelling' (cf. MIr. brén 'putrid, foul', MW braen, Bret. brein 'putrid, corrupt' < PCl. *bragno- < *bʰrh₁g-no-; OIr. braig(a)id* -braig 'to fart' < *brag-ie-, etc.), following {ref Schrijver 1991}:185f., {ref Schrijver 1995}:170f., {ref IEW} 163.
S.v. Rom. neted, from Latin nitidus 'bright, shining'.
S.v. Lat. niteō, -ēre 'briller, être luisant, éclatant', one hypothesis by Vendryes connects Ir. niam 'éclat' from a hypothetical root *nei- 'briller', but this is very uncertain.
*pleh₁- 'fill up, get full'.
S.v. Paš. m'ewa f. 'fruit' "LW < Prs, like Bal mewag, nīwag 'id.', cf. Man. MPrs myw, Pth mygdg, Sogd. mγδʾk < *migda- (v. Henning, BSOAS 12/1, 1947, 56)"

Imperf. 3 sg. m. tǝ prob. < *taxta-, cf. Sh[ughni] tūyd- (EVShG 82, s.v. ti(y)-), Ishk[ashmi] tōyd 'went', etc. But l has beeen introduced from the other pret. forms, and we find in many dialects also a 3 sg. m. tl(ǝl)o, etc. A borrowing from Dardic (Torwali, etc. til- 'to go', cf. S[ans]k[ri]t til-, T 5856 tillati 'id.') is unlikely. Pres. j- (but Afr[idi, Pashto dialect], Waz[iri Pashto], etc. c-) < *t-j- < *tač-, cf. Sh[ughni] 3 sg. tīzd- (< ti(y)-), Sar[iqoli] tej- (v. above); Yaghn[obi] taž-; rather than < *cyaw-.
S.v. Paš. šin (m.), šna (f.) 'green, blue'. Cf. Av. axšaēna-, etc. 'dark coloured, dark blue', Khot. āṣṣeina, Phl. axšēn, Prs. xašēn; Oss D. æxsin, Orm. ṣ̌īn, Kurd. šīn.
PS *plodŭ 'fruit, fetus' is derived from PIE *pel- 'pour, fill'.
PS *sadŭ 'planting' is derived from PS *saditi 'plant, put' and related to Latin sedeō 'sit' etc.
Cf. s.v. *sed- 'sich setzen' (IEW 884-887).
S.v. colubra, -ae f. & coluber, -brī, -bris m. Without a clear etymology, perhaps a borrowing from Gk. χέλυδρος?
S.v. 2060 colubra 'Schlange', 2. *culǫbra.

PS *ovoktĭ, formerly probably *ou̯oɡ-tĭ, derived from PIE *au̯eg- / *u̯ōg- / *au̯g- 'multiply, increase, grow', related to Lithuanian áugti 'grow', Latvian augt 'grow', German wachsen 'grow', Latin augēre 'grow'. The semantic development was 'growth' > 'something that grows'.
S.v. Rom. zăpadă, a loan from Slavic zapadati 'to fall'.
Cf. s.v. 6578 Lat. plāntare 'pflanzen'.

PS *(o)voťe is probably derived from PIE *au̯eg- / *u̯ōg- / *au̯g- 'grow' (cf. Lithuanian áugti 'grow', Latvian augt 'grow', German wachsen 'grow', Latin augēre 'grow'). A similarity to German Obst 'fruit' etc. is probably a coincidence.

Cf. s.v. Lat. planta 'sole of the foot', from PIE *pl(e)h₂-nt-h₂- 'the flat one' (cf. Lat. plānus 'level, flat'). Lat. planta 'shoot of a plant' is commonly hypothesised to be backformed to an unattested verb *plantāre 'to level the earth' or 'to plant crops with the sole of the foot' (cf. {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:512 s.v. II. planta). If so, then planta 'shoot of a plant' would ultimately go back to the PIE root *pelh₂- found in Lat. plānus 'level, flat', Hitt. palḫi- 'wide, broad', Lith. plónas 'thin', etc.
This word is assumed to be a loanword from Old High German (cf. German Obst 'fruit'). It has been also explained as a reflex of PIE *au̯eg- 'grow'.
S.v. 5263 Lat. malus 'schlecht'.

The etymology is obscure. It can be a loanword from German dialects. However, the exact source has not been determined. An alternative is to assume here a reflex of PIE *au̯eg- / *aug- / *u̯ōg- 'grow'.
S.v. 1663 Lat. captīvus 'gefangen, elend' > It. cattivo 'elend', 'schlecht', 'böse'.
S.v. 8918 Lat. trīstis 'traurig', 2. trīstus.
S.v. 6207 Lat. pantex, -ice 'Wanst'
S.v. 4393 Lat. infans, -ante 'Kind'.
S.v. 5974 Lat. nūbes 'Wolke'.
S.v. 2107 Lat. computāre 'rechnen, zählen, erzählen'.
S.v. 6606 Lat. plōrāre 'weinen'.
S.v. 2034 Lat. colaphus 'Schlag', 2. *colpus, 3. kolaphos (griech.).

The widespread hypothesis about a borrowing from Old High German is phonetically inconvincing. Furthermore, a very wide distribution of this word in Slavic makes the Old High German origin improbable. The lexeme is probably derived from *voksti, a form related to Gothic wahsjan, Old High German wahsan 'grow', Avestan vaχšaiti 'grows', Lithuanian áugu 'grow', áukštas 'high', Greek αὔξω 'multiply', Irish úasal 'high' etc.
The PS lexeme is related to Gothic wahsjan 'grow' etc. and derived from PIE *aweg-. The hypothesis about a West Germanic origin shows phonetic and chronological issues.
Cf. s.v. Lat. colaphus 'taloche, coup de poing', a transcription of Gk. κόλαφος, already in Plautus colaphizō; reflexes in Romance reflect a popular word colpus with syncope of interior -a-.
Cf. s.v. Lat. colaphus 'taloche, coup de poing', a transcription of Gk. κόλαφος, already in Plautus colaphizō; reflexes in Romance reflect a popular word colpus with syncope of interior -a-.
S.v. 2034 Lat. colaphus 'Schlag', 2. *colpus, 3. kolaphos (griech.).
Cf. s.v. zapp- (illyr.) 'Ziegenbock' > Rom. sapă, It. zappa (> Friul., Fr. sape) 'Hacke' after the comparison with the horns of a billy-goat.
S.v. Lat. brūtus 'roh', certain Romance forms reflect *bruttus with expressive gemination.
S.v. 996 Lat. battuere 'schlagen', 2073 Lat. combattuere 'kämpfen, bekämpfen'.
S.v. 5147 lucta 'Ringkampf, Kampf' and 5148 Lat. luctāre 'kämpfen'.
S.v. 3400 Lat. focus 'Feuer'.
S.v. 9431 Lat. volāre 'fliegen'.
S.v. Lat. uolō, -āre 'voler (de l'oiseau)'. The connection with Ved. garútmān 'ailé' name of a celestial bird and Skt. garuḍáḥ (prakritised form of ?*garutra-?) is attractive.
*wr̩siya- [as input for Pashto]
S.v. Paš. arw-, awr- : -ed-, etc. : Wan awr 'to hear' – Av. hauuruua-, √har- 'to observe'; Par. harw- 'to hear'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *har- (1) 'to guard, observe' (> Pash. arwēdəl ‘to hear’ = arw-, awr- / -ed-, (Wan.) awr-). From PIE *ser- 'to look after, protect' (cf. Gk. ὄρονται 'they respect' (Hom.), ?Lyd. kaτared- 'stands guard', sarẽta- 'protector'.

S.v. Paš. drund, m. dran'a f. 'heavy'. "Prob. with secondary -d, cf. Pash gərānd 'heavy, pregnant' < Prs girān; Waz armond, darmond < armān, darmān. Perhaps a contamination of an old LW< Prs girān with *drūnd < Av ϑrqfδa- 'satisfied, replete'?"

Cf. s.v. Paš. poh 'aware, intelligent'; poha 'intelligence'. A loanword from Indic (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966} no. 8699 prabhōdha- 'awakening, knowledge', Lhd *poh. Cf. poh-eğ- : poh-ed- denom. 'to understand'.
cf. Sanskrit śardha- 'host, troop'
S.v. Lat. 1. volō 'fliege'.
S.v. 1219 Lat. boreas 'Nordwind'.
S.v. 3771 Lat. glacies 'Eis'.
S.v. 3771 Lat. glacies 'Eis'.
S.v. 9117 Lat. vadere 'gehen'.
S.v. 4109 Lat. herba 'Kraut; Gras'.
S.v. 9368a Lat. viridis 'grün', 2. virdis.
S.v. Lat. uireō, -ēre 'être vert (en parlant des plantes)', with derived adjective uiridis 'vert'. No clear etymology. Celtic words such as OW guird 'herbida' are borrowings from Latin.
S.v. 5206 Lat. machināre 'mahlen'.
S.v. 5596 Lat. minutalia 'Kleinigkeit' > Rom. măruntaie 'Eingeweide'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. minus 'less', minor 'smaller, less', from a u-stem derived from a nasal-infix stem of PIE *mei̯H- 'to lessen, diminish'; PIE *mi-n(e)-H- 'to make less' >> *min(e)-u-.
Cf. s.v. 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).

IE root etymology disputed. The Italic and Romance lexemes in this class might be connected with the lexemes from Proto-Germanic *dragan- in /cognate/2839/ via PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- but this would require the assumption of an irregular dissimilation of aspirates and devoicing in initial position. Alternatively some Celtic cognates are formally possible (cf. Old Irish tethraig* 'ran away, receded'), but note that the required reconstruction *tre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- violates Indo-European root structure constraints. Cf. {ref de Vaan 2008}:626-627 and {ref LIV²} 154 for further discussion.
S.v. 6837 Lat. pulsāre 'stoßen' > pg. puxar.

S.v. Lat. pingō, -ere 'to colour, paint'. Most IE forms show a root *pei̯k̑- (cf. Gk. ποικίλος 'multicoloured', Lith. piẽšti 'to draw lines, adorn', OCS pьsati 'to write', etc.), but Italic seems to require *pi⁽g̑⁾-.
S.v. 1. *pei̯g- 'malen' (IEW 794). Cf. n1, probably a variant of the better attested root *pei̯k̑-; verbal only in Latin (and Tocharian?), cf. Ved. piṅgalá-, piṅga˚ 'rötlich', OCS pěgъ 'bunt'.

S.v. Lat. rāpum 'rave'. The absence of prothesis in Greek ῥάπυς and ῥάφυς 'rave' ῥάφανος, ῥαφάνη 'radis' and the -ě- of Church Slavic rěpa 'rave' make it difficult to see this as an old Indo-European word, as OCS ruoba 'rave', and Lith. rópė. The way in which these words are related is uncertain.
Cf. s.v. OLith. rópė, ropė̃ 'Rübe'. In general a Wanderwört of unknown origin, which has come into various European Indo-European languages in different forms.

S.v. Lat. gurdus 'blockhead, dolt', possibly an o-stem *gʷr̥d-o- if root cognate with the u-stem found in Gk. βραδύς 'slow', Lith. gurdùs 'id.', Latv. gur̃ds 'tired', OCS grьdъ Ru. górdyj 'proud, haughty'. Of Spanish origin according to Quintilian, but there is no proof of this.

S.v. Lat. gurdus 'lourd (sens propre et figuré); épais, lourdaud, balourd', possibly comparable to Gk. βραδύς, if it goes back to an initial *gʷrd-, but for a popular word of this sort an Indo-European etymology does not impose itself. A word of Spanish origin according to Quintilian (I 5.57), but there is no proof of this.
NB: A root *gʷr̥d- with two voiced-unaspirated plosives violates Indo-European root structure constraints (no roots of shape *DED- permitted).

S.v. Lat. spissus 'épais', an adjective in *-to- which may be explained in connection to a root attested by Greek σπιδνόν· πυκνόν, συνεχές, πεπηγός (Hesych.), ἀσπιδής 'éntendu', and Latv. spiežu, spiêdu, spiêst 'presser'.
S.v. 8160 Lat. spissus 'dicht'.

Cf. s.v. Gk. σπίδιος 'extensive, wide', with derivatives. An obsolete group of words only preserved on learned and poetic language; authors were no longer certain about the original meaning. Comparable to Latin spissus 'laborious, slow, dense' < *spid-to- or *spit-to-), Lithuanian spìsti 'to begin to swarm (of bees), to gather' is probably not related as it requires a different dental *spit-.
Cf. s.v. spiẽsti 'schwärmen (Bienen)', from an East Baltic root *spei̯t- without any clear connections outside of Baltic.
S.v. 2292 Lat. coxa 'Hüfte'.
S.v. Lat. femur, -inis (-oris) 'cuisse', an isolated -r/n- stem with no clear comparisons.
Cf. s.v. Ved. dhánuṣ- 'Bogen' (pre-Vedic *dhánvr̥ (cf. YAv. ˚uuarǝ), from PIE *dʰen-u̯r̥ ~ *dʰn̥-u̯én-s, probably in Latin femur, feminis 'Schenkel'.
S.v. 5772 Lat. mūsculus 'Muskel' > Sp. muslo 'Hinterbacke'.

S.v. Lat. mūs, mūris 'mouse', with derivative mūsculus 'mussel, small fish, small rodent; muscle', from PIE *muH-s 'mouse' (cf. Skt. mū́ṣ- 'mouse, rat', YAv. mūš- 'name of a Parikā', Gk. μῦς 'mouse', OHG mūs, OCS myšь, TochB maścītse* 'mouse, rat').

S.v. Lat. mūs, mūris 'souris, rat', derivative mūsculus 'petite souris; muscle (cf. l'emploi du fr. souris pour désigner un muscle du gigot)'. An Indo-European word (cf. Skt. mū́ḥ, Alb. mī, Gk. μῦς, OHG mūs, etc.).
Cf. s.v. MOUSE *mūs ~ *múss (gen. *musós).

Precise stem analysis difficult; the attested languages consistently show a non-ablauting nom.sg. *mūs, but it is unclear whether this is inherited as such from PIE, or the result of secondary compensatory lengthening from laryngeal loss (e.g., {ref de Vaan 2008}:396-397 assuming a stem *muH-, cf. also {ref EIEC} 387 assuming *mūs < *mus-s).
S.v. Lat. gracilis 'schlank' > OFr. graisle 'mince, gracile'.
Cf. s.v. 3829 Lat. gracilis 'schlank'.

S.v. *pr̥-, *pró, *prí- 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft mit Abl.), cf. p.640 s.v. prí-s > [Lat. prīmus 'erster', cf. Paelignian prismu (gynonym).

MIr. cana, cano 'wolf cub', Gaul. cintu-gnatus, OIr. cét- 'first', MW cynt MCo. cens, Bret. kent 'earlier' < PCl. *kento/u-, Skt. kanyā-, Av. kaine, kainīn- 'girl' < PIE *ken-i-Hn-, Skt. kanīna- 'young', Gk. καινός 'new, unheard of', etc.).

Kashubian brzôd is derived from PS *brědŭ 'fruit, sprout', cf. dialectal Russian bred 'leaves and twigs used as fodder', dialectal Russian and Ukrainian bredina 'willow'. Some Slavic dialects show reflexes of a related protoform *brędŭ, cf. dialectal Polish  jabrząd 'poplar'. The most close cognates are Lithuanian brę́sti, brę́stu, bréndau 'grow, mellow' and brį̀sti, brį̀stu, brìndau 'swell'.
PS *brědŭ is related to a prefixed form *abrědŭ and *abrędŭ. These words are derved from PIE *brend- / *brei̯d- / *broi̯d- and related to brę́sti, bréndau 'swell, mellow'.
*?bʰrend- with Lithuanian brę́sti listed as a reflex.
S.v. 5973 Lat. nox, nocte 'Nacht' > OPg. aontem 'gestern'.
S.v. 1152 *blank (germ.) 'weiß'.
The word was borrowed from Turkish meyva 'fruit'. Its ultimate source is Persian mäyva 'fruit'.
The word is borrowed from Turkish yemiş 'fruit'.
Loan from German voll.

S. v. *jĭti.
S.v. Sp. gusano, of uncertain origin. It is very doubtful that it comes from Latin cossus 'carcoma de la madera, larva de ciertas mariposas, lombriz instinal' as previously supposed.
S.v. 2278 Lat. cossus 'Larve'.
S.v. 2733 domina 'Herrin', 2. domna.

Cf. s.v. Sp. muelle from Lat. mollis; cf. related derivative mojar from Late Latin *molliare 'reblandecer'.

S.v. Lat. mollis 'soft, gentle', from PIE *mld-u- 'soft' (cf. W blydd 'soft', Skt. mr̥du- 'delicate, soft', Gk. *βλαδύς 'powerless' (in βλαδεῖς Hsch.); the connection of the Greek forms is uncertain).
Cf. s.v. *meld- 'weich werden' (IEW 718).
Cf. s.v. 4415 Lat. infundere 'hineingießen'.

S.v. Lat. lātus 'broad, wide'; {ref Meiser 2002}:112 sets up *stlātus > lātus positing PIE *stlH-to- 'spread' to Gk. στέλλω 'to prepare, dispatch', OCS stьlati 'to spread', but this root is now reconstructed without a final laryngeal (LIV *stel- 'to place'), perhaps instead to Proto-Celtic *-slā- 'to go away' attested in OIr. con·slá?
S.v. 4912 Lat. largus 'geräumig, weit, breit'.
S.v. 4912 Lat. largus 'geräumig, weit, breit'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *rand- 'to scrape, smoothen' (> Khot. (+fra) haraṇ- 'to throw'), from PIE *lendʰ- 'to lower, go down' (cf. Skt. √randh- 'unterliegen', Lith. lendù 'I crawl, crouch', OPr. lindan 'valley').

S.v. Lat. tempus, -oris 'time, moment', from PIE *temp-os, -es- 'stretch', from which is derived Lat. temperāre 'to restrain oneself, modify, blend'.

S.v. Lat. albus, -a, -um 'blanc'. The -f- of Umbrian alfu demonstrates that Lat. -b- must go back to a voiced-aspirate *-bʰ-, cf. Gk. ἀλφούς· λευκούς (Hesych.) and ἀλφός 'éruption blanche'.
S.v. 331 Lat. albus 'weiß'.
Sets up *stlātus > lātus positing PIE *stl̥H-to- 'spread' to *stelH- 'ausbreiten', comparing OCS stьlati 'to spread'.
S.v. 6314 Lat. pavor, -ōre 'Furcht'.
Cf. s.v. pēu- : pəu- : pū̆- 'schlagen, scharf, schneidend hauen'.
S.v. 2001 Lat. *coacticāre 'zusammendrücken', 2003 Lat. coactus 'gepreßt'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. agō, -ere 'to drive', < PIE *h₂eg̑- (prefixed cōgere 'to collect, compel' [pf. coēgī, p.p.p. coāctum]).
S.v. 1228c *bōtan (fränk.) 'stoßen'.
Cf. s.v. 2. *tek- 'weben, flechten' (IEW 1058).
S.v. sûr (anfrk.) 'sauer' > Fr. sur 'sour'
S.v. 8471 sūr (fränk.) 'sauer'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *damH-³ 'to blow, breathe; swell', from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. Skt. dham- 'to blow, play a wind instrument, fan the fire', OCS dъmǫ, ORu. dъmu 'I blow', SCr. dȕti 'to blow', Lith. dùmti 'to blow (also of wind)'.

S.v. PIr. *dais- (1) 'to show' (> Pth. (+ ham-) ʾndyš 'to think, contemplate') from PIE *dei̯k̑- 'to show, point out, announce', cf. Gk. δείκνυμι, OHG zeigen, Lat. dīcere 'to utter, say, proclaim', etc.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *nau- 'to move' < PIE *neu- 'to nod (the head)?' (cf. Gk. νέυω 'I nod', Lat. ad-nūit 'nodded', Lith. niaũsti 'to nod').

S.v. Osc. aapam "Vielleicht zu idg. *ə₂ep- 'Wasser' in ai.ap- 'Wasser' und den europäischen Flußnamen mit ap-. (…) Anders Mommsen, Muller: zu aqua; [lang] a- statt a- muß dann als sekundäre Dehnung (Pisani) oder Vermischung mit ap- (Untermann 304 Anm. 47, Heidermanns § 50) erklärt werden."
S.v. Rom. borî, etymology unknown.
Cf. s.v. 1228c *bōtan (fränk.) 'stoßen'.

S.v. Lat. sūs, suis 'pig, sow', from PIE *suh₁/₃-s, gen. *suh₁/₃-os 'pig, swine' (cf. Skt. sūkará- 'wild boar', YAv. hū-, Gk. ὗς, ὑός, Alb. thi 'pig', OHG, OE sū 'sow', etc.), derived noun sūcīdia 'joint of pork'.

S.v. Lat. sūs, suis 'sanglier, laie; porc, truie', derivative suc(c)īdia, -ae 'quartier de porc salé', from the IE word designating either a wild boar or a domestic pig (Gk. ὗς, ὑός, OHG sū, Alb. thi, Av. hū, etc.).
S.v. PIG, cf. discussion under *sūs (gen. *s(u)u̯ós) 'pig (wild or domesticated)' (cf. {ref IEW} *sū̆-s) for discussion of the reconstruction of the IE stem.
S.v. 4789 kuč, kos (Schallwort) 'Hund'.
S.v. *brod- (germ.) 'Brühe'.
Cf. s.v. 1321 *brǫd- (germ.) 'Brühe'.
S.v. 6183 palus, -ūde 'Sumpf', 2. padūle > Rom. pădure 'Wald'.

S.v. Lat. palūs, palūdis 'fen, swamp' (cf. Skt. palvala- 'pond, pool', OPr. pelky 'marsh', Lith. pélkė 'marsh', Žem. 'puddle', Latv. pel̃ce 'puddle' < *pelHk-iH-h₂). "If the Baltic words for 'swamp' are cognate, Latin palūs could be connected with pall- 'grey, pale'. However, [{ref Schrijver 1991}:210f.] rightly objects that the semantic connection between 'grey' and 'swamp' is uncompelling."
Cf. s.v. Skt. palvala- 'Pfuhl, Teich, kleiner Wasserbehälter', cf. Lat. palūs, palūd- 'Sumpf, Pfütze, stehendes Wasser', Lith. pal̃vas 'fahl', OHG falb.
Cf. s.v. OLith. pélkė 'Moor, Sumpf, Bruch', without clear connections outside of Baltic.
S.v. *brekan- (germ.) 'brechen'.
S.v. 3214 Lat. fascis 'Bund, Bündel' > Cat. feix 'bundle', with secondary derivative feixuc 'heavy' (adj.).

S.v. Lat. fascis 'bundle, faggot; (symbol of) power' (cf. OIr. basc 'necklace', W beich 'burden', Bret. bec'h 'load' < PCl. *baskio-). A unique Italo-Celtic isogloss that can accounted for via *bʰaski-(o-). (Cf. also {ref Schrijver 1991}:102-103).
S.v. 5425 Lat. *mattea 'Keule'.

Cf. s.v. mateola 'wooden hammer', a diminutive of a noun *matea 'hoe' (vel sim.), perhaps from PIE ?*mot-(i-), cf. Ved. matyá- 'club, harrow, roller', OCS motyka, Russ. motyga 'hoe' OHG medela 'plough'.
For Old Spanish finojo, cf. s.v. Sp. hinojo (II) 'rodilla' < Lat. genuculum, diminutive to Lat. genu 'knee'.
S.v. *wenkjan (anfrk.) 'wanken'; Middle, Modern Fr. gauche derived from French gauchir 'to warp, deform' originally in the sense 'mal équerri (bois), mal fait, sans grâce, etc.'
S.v. 6742 Lat. presse 'knapp, kurz'.
S.v. 1539 Lat. camba (griech.) 'Bein'.

S.v. Lat. gamba, -ae 'patte, jarret du cheval et, plus généralement, des quadrupèdes'. A likely borrowing from Greek καμπή 'bending, winding' in the specialised language of Greek veterinarians or breeders.
S.v. 1539 Lat. camba (griech.) 'Bein'.
S.v. Lat. camba 'sprunggelenk der Pferde' > Fr. jambe 'Bein'.
S.v. 982 *bastum 'Stock'
S.v. Lat. bastum 'bâton' (attested only once); Romance forms must go back to an n-stem *bastō, -ōnis. No further etymology.
S.v. Lat. bastum 'Stock'.
S.v. 5559 Lat. mīca 'Krümchen'.
S.v. Lat. mīca, -ae 'parcelle, miette, grain', attested since Cato. Etymology uncertain, cf. Gk. (σ)μικρός?

S.v. Lat. mīca 'grain, crumb'; according to {ref Nyman 1987} the word originally meant a 'grain of salt' and was subsequently generalised to mean any kind of 'glittering crystal(line) particle'. As such he derives mīca from the same root as micāre 'to quiver, dart, flash' in the sense 'the glittering particle', this seems semantically possible and no better etymology has yet been proposed.
Cf. s.v. 6550 pitzinnus 'klein', 2. pīsinnus.
S.v. 6494 *pīkk- (Schallwort) 'klein'.
S.v. 6544a pit (Lallform) 'klein'.
S.v. tumb- (schallwort).
S.v. 8975 tum(b) (Schallwort) 'Fall, Plumps'. The proposed connection with OHG tūmōn is questionable and does not explain the -b- found in some Romance forms.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *ǰi̯au̯H- 'to chew' (> CSogd. (zbʾqy) ˣžybʾmnty 'the biting (of their tongues)' "Sogd. -β- (CSogd. -b-) is perhaps due to the influence of zβʾk (CSogd. zbʾq) 'tongue, language'."; NWIr. > Bal. jāθ-, jā-). "On the development of initial *g̑i̯- > Ir. *ǰi̯- see Rasmussen 1989: 114, no. 5. This development suggested by Rasmussen may also account for the doublet roots *ǰi̯aH ~ *zaiH ‘to perish; to destroy’ and *či̯aH³/čiH ~ *saiH/siH ‘to freeze’, but both cases have no clear IE etymology." From PIE *g̑i̯euH- ‘to chew, bite’ (cf. Toch. śu- ‘to eat; consume, devour’, OCS uju, Russ. ujú ‘I chew’, OHG kewa, OE cēowan, Engl. to chew, Lith. (f. pl.) iáunos ‘jaws’, etc.).
S.v. PIr. *i̯am- 'to hold; to stretch, reach out' (> BSogd. ''s-, CSogd. 's- 'take, receive') < PIE *i̯em- 'to hold'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *kaH- 'to take pleasure, desire' (> BSogd. kʾtʾk 'game, play' Chor. kʾt 'game', etc.), from PIE *keh₂- 'to love, desire' (cf. Skt. kā- 'to desire, wish', Lat. cā-rus 'dear, beloved', Goth. ho-rs 'adulterer', Engl. whore, etc.).

S.v. Proto-Iranic *drauH- 'to cut (down), mow, reap', cf. Skt. drav- 'to cut down'. A root attested in Indo-Iranic only; perhaps an enlarged form of IE *der- 'to tear, split', or at least contaminated with it.
S.v. *medʰ- 'mittlerer' (IEW 706f., EIEC 380). Arm. mēǰ- < *médʰ-i̯o-.
S.v. 605 վատ vat 'schlecht, müssig, faul, feig'. A loan from Iranic, cf. NPers. bad 'böse, schlimm, schlect', pāz. vad 'evil, bad', comp. vadtar 'worse, viler', Phl. vat.

S.v. Arm. gam, suppletive aor. ek- 'to come', usually interpreted as an athematic verb *u̯eh₂(-dʰ)-mi (cf. Hitt. uu̯ami 'to come', Lat. vādere 'to go, walk, rush', Welsh go-di-wawd 'overtook' < *u̯eh₂dʰ-, OIc. vaða, OHG watan 'to advance, wade' < *u̯h₂dʰ-. The connection of the Hittite verb is uncertain ({ref Kloekhorst 2008}:992)). The comparison with Greek κιχάνω 'to reach, arrive, meet' ({ref Hübschmann 1897}:441, {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:86 is untenable since this root has an initial palatovelar *g̑ʰ- (cf. Av. za-zā-mi 'to leave' Skt. já-hā-ti 'to leave, abandon', etc. (cf. {ref EWAia} II:813-814).
S.v. *gʰeh₁- 'kommen, erreichen' (IEW 418-9, 1109); cf. s.v. *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'durchschreiten' (IEW 1109), without Armenian lexemes connected.

Armenian ga- has been considered since Meillet, Esquisse, S.134 to a root *u̯ā- that may be seen in an extended form *u̯ā-dʰ- in Latin uādō, uādere 'gehen, schreiten', uadum 'seichte Stelle im Wasser', Furt' and Germanic *u̯ada- 'waten' (cf. OHG waten, ON waϸa 'waten', etc.). This possibility cannot be a priori excluded, cf., e.g. *leh₂-dʰ- in Gk. λανθανε/ο- 'verborgen sein' < *lh₂-n-dʰ-, ληθε/ο- < *lah₂dʰe/o- vs. *leh₂- in Lat. lateō 'verborgen sein'. There are semantic difficulties, however, since Latin uadum and the Germanic cognates have the connections to wading or moving through water. Better is a connection to the root *gʰeh₁- 'erreichen, kommen zu' (cf. Gk. κικη- 'erreichen').

S.v. Arm. hat 'grain, seed; piece, cut, fragment, section'; hatanem 'to cut, split'. No etymology accepted by {ref HAB} 3:51-52, 'etymologically unclear' according to {ref Olsen 1999}:90. The best possible proposal is that Arm. hat (o-stem) goes back to PIE *h₂ed-os- (n.) 'sort of cereal, grain' (cf. Lat. ador, -oris 'coarse grain, spelt', Goth. atisk (*ades-ko-) 'cornfield'.
S.v. Arm. ճանճ (čanč), a Caucasian loanword.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *drafš-? 'to "behave" like a banner, fly up, shine, tremble"? Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain. The etymology of {ref Bailey 1979}:168 is difficult.
S.v. PIr. *gar- (1) 'to rejoice' < PIE *gʰer- 'to like', cf. Gk. χαίρω 'I rejoice, enjoy', Lat. horior 'I cheer up', OHG gerno 'eager, readily', Engl. yearn, etc.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *xrau- 'to tear, break, scratch', further IE correspondences remain uncertain.
Of unknown origin, cf. {ref HAB} II:510f.

S.v. Arm. pind 'firm, tight, strong, fastened'. Comparing Skt. bandh- 'to bind, fasten', Gk. πεῖσμα 'bond, fetter', Goth. bandi 'fetter, bond', etc. < IE *bʰendʰ-. "Initial p- points to Grassmann's Law. Although we have no further secure examples of this law in Armenian … I see no compelling reasons for rejecting this etymology." Alternatively an Iranian loan (cf. Khot. piṇḍaa- 'lump'. {ref Olsen 1999}:965 considers the word of unknown origin and adds "Probably Iranian".
"Probably Iranian", but ultimately of uncertain origin.
Of uncertain origin. "The traditional comparison with Gk. ξηρός, Skt. kṣārá- seems to be incompatible with the sound laws. Even a metathesized *skoro- (cf. Solta l.c.) would probably yield *cʻor."
Etymology obscure.
S.v. Arm. *տերեի 'տերեւ'. A loanword from Syriac.
A loanword from Syriac ṭarpā (stat.abs. ṭǝref 'leaf').
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} II:436).
S.v. Arm. ձախ.
Generally derived from a full grade *du̯āró- < *du̯eh₂ró-, but preferably directly from *duh₂ró- = Skt. dūrá- 'far, distant', Av. abl. dūrat̰ 'from afar', Lat. dūrus 'hard'.
Loanword from Iranian (cf. Sogd. krmʾyr).
S.v. aǰ 'right', connected with Greek ἰθύς 'gerade, gerecht', Skt. sādhú- 'zum Zeil führend, gerade, richtig, wirksam'.

"Armat (-oy, -ocʿ) 'root', also arm*, armn, has an aberrant o-stem inflection and a somewhat unclear etymological background, but in view of the alternative meaning 'stem' some connection with Gk. ὄρμενος 'Schoß, Stengel' (< *h₃r̥mǝ₁no-? IEW 328f), probably contaminated with the stem of Gk. ῥάδιξ, Lat. rādix (IEW 1167), seems possible."
An Iranian loanword, cf. MP pwtk' 'foul, rotten', subst. Av. pūiti- 'Fäuligwerden, Verwesung'.
Armenian vaz* 'leap, jump', a loan from Iranian (cf. Parth. wz- 'blow (of the wind; move swiftly, fly', Av. vaz- 'fahren').

Cf. in an excursus s.v. Arm. arcui 'eagle', where the etymology of cov 'sea' is discussed. Armenian cov 'sea' is sometimes considered a loanword from Urartian ṣûə 'inland sea', but the Urartian word could just as well be a loan from Armenian.
Of unknown origin. (cf. {ref HAB} II:468).
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} IV:280).
Of unknown etymology (cf. {ref HAB} III:348f.).
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} II:517f.).
footnote 299

S.v. Proto-Iranic *pad- 'to fall, be stuck in' ((+ ni-) > NWIr. Kurd. (Kurm.) nivīn, nivistin/niv-, (Sor.) nūstin/nū- 'to lie down, to sleep'), from PIE *ped- 'to move at a walking pace, be on one's feet' (cf. Lat. pessum 'to the bottom, to the ground, downward', OCS pasti 'to fall', Lith. pė̃dinti 'to go slowly', ON fata 'to find one's way', Engl. to fetch).

S.v. *Hrab/f- 'to go' (> NEIr. Sariq. warofs-/warůvd, Wa. wərə(f)s-/wərə(f)st-, vərə(f)-/vərə(f)st-). "An IE origin of this Ir. root is uncertain. The WIr. forms, Pth. rf- ‘to attack’ and NP rav- ‘to go’, have been connected to MHG reben ‘to move’, Lat. rabiō ‘I rage’ in LIV: l.c. This can be doubted. Pth. rf- may point to a different root. MHG reben ‘to move’ has probably a different etymology (it is compared to OIrish reb ‘play’, Russ. rebënok ‘child’ by Häusler 2000: 144). The Latin connection is declined by {ref Schrijver 1991}: 305."
Cf. s.v. Paš. k'āṇay 'stone', possibly from *karna-ka-, cf. Lith. kálnas 'collis' etc. Pok. 544.
S.v. Paš. lanḍˈay 'short, cut short; a kind of quatrain' "LW < Lhd lanḍā, lunḍā 'crop-tailed', cf. T 11081, where the Lhd form given ('lundā "tailless, shameless"') is an error.
S.v. Paš. ganḍ- 'to sew' "Despite the retroflex -ḍ-, prob. < OId Ir *han-gan-" cf. Skt. sam-han- 'put together, unite' < PIE *gʷʰen-.
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} III:596).
S.v. Classical Armenian anoyš 'sweet', a borrowing from Iranian (cf. MParth. ʾnwšyn 'ambrosial, sweet' MP ʾnwš 'immortal', Av. anaoša- 'dem kein Verderben droht, unsterblich').

S.v. Proto-Iranic *rand- 'to scrape, smoothen' (> MPers. lnd- /rand-/ 'to scratch, grate, abrade, rake'), from PIE *lendʰ- 'to lower, go down' (cf. Skt. √randh- 'unterliegen', Lith. lendù 'I crawl, crouch', OPr. lindan 'valley').
Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref HAB} I:77-78).
Arm. stowar 'thick' < PIE *stuh₂-ró- (< *sth₂u-ró-), cf. Skt. sthūrá- 'big, strong, thick', Av. stūra-, MLG stūr).

S.v. Arm. hast 'firm, steady, standing still, tough; thick, dense, broad', since Hübschmann connected to the Germanic word for 'hard, steady, strong, dense' (OIc. fastr, OHG festi, fasti, Engl. fast, etc.); possibly also Sanskrit pastyà-. On the basis of the limited distribution and the vowel -a-, not a PIE word. Possibly from a European substratum.

S.v. hast 'firm, strong' ({ref IEW} 789), a cognate of ON fastr, etc. OHG festi 'firm' and may be derived from a vocalic stem *pastV-. Note that a *-tó- participle *ph₂k̑tó- to the root *pah₂k̑-/*pah₂g̑- 'fest machen' would probably yield the same result.

S.v. Arm. azdr 'thigh'. Etymology uncertain. The proposed connection to Skt. sákthi- 'thigh', Gk. ἰσχίον 'hip joint' requires a metathesis *sa- > as- and a voicing of the stops and is highly improbable. Jahukyan and {ref Olsen 1999}:149 independently propose a connection to Gk. ὀσφῦς, -ύος 'loin or loins, lower part of the back', etc. although noting that the formal divergences are not easily overcome. This proposed connection to the IE word for 'bone' is also improbable.
"Azdr (-er, -erē) 'thigh; shoulder (of an animal)' is faintly reminiscent of both the group of oskr with cognates and Gk. ὀσφῦς 'Hüfte, Lende', but the formal divergences are not easily overcome"

S.v. Arm. ənkenum 'to cause to fall, throw down', generally connected ({ref HAB} II:128) with Arm. ankanim 'to fall down' < *sn̥gʷ- although there is some debate over the precise stem formation. Alternatively {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:249 and others propose a compound of ənd- and *ke- which they derive from *ges- (cf. OIc. kasta 'werfen' and Lat, gerere 'to carry on', but this is not convincing.
The phonetic shape is suggestive of an Iranian borrowing, but there is no certain etymology.
Uncertain, but probably a loanword from Iranian.

S.v. Arm. net 'arrow'; Middle Armenian netem 'to throw (an arrow, etc.)', derived from PIE *nedo- 'reed', cf. Skt. naḍá- 'reed' ManMPers n'y, Pahl. n'd 'reed, cane; tube, flute, clarion'; Parth. nd 'pipe, flute; cane, rod'.
Arm. net 'arrow, dart' is apparently cognate with Skt. naḍá- 'Schilfrohr, Rohr', nādī́- 'Pfeife, Röhre, Flöte, Ader', Hitt. nata- and nati- 'Schlifrohr, Trinkrohr; Pfeil'.
Generally agreed to be cognate with Skt. rájaḥ 'dusk, darkness', Gk. ἔρεβος 'Dunkel der Unterwelt', Goth. riqis 'darkness'. Cf. for a discussion of the stem formation in Armenian.
Derived from Armenian deł 'herb; drug, medicine; eye-salve, resin; ink', traditionally related to Gk. θαλερός, etc.
Arm. am 'year', seems to continue a deverbative stem in *-ah₂- to the root *sem-, (cf. Skt. sámā 'Halbjahr, Jahreszeit'; compare the root noun continued in Av. instr.sg. hama, gen.sg. hamō.
Arm. tari 'year' has no generally accepted etymology.
Cf. related noun darj 'turning; return, departure' (vb. daṙnam) to root *dʰreg̑ʰ- or *dʰerg̑ʰ- (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:111f.).
An Iranian loan.
also discusses the suggestions by MacKenzie (*api-tuši̯a- < *tauš "to be empty") and Samadi (*pati-ϑruši̯a- < *ϑraHu „to nourish“).
Probably a compound of 'ear' (Av. uš) and 'do' (kan- / ku(r)t-).

S.v. Alb. zjarr 'Feuer, Brand, Feuersbrunst; Fieber'. The variant zjarm may be formally compared with Gk. θερμός 'warm' and Arm. ǰarm 'warm' < *gʷʰer-mo-, but whether zjarr comes from the same stem formation remains disputed. An e-grade formation in *-no-, i.e. *gʷʰer-no- could be possible (cf. Latin fornus beside formus 'warm'). Cf. entry in Demiraj for further discussion regarding the possible stem formations in Albanian.
S.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (LIV 219f., IEW 493ff.).
S.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (LIV 219f., IEW 493ff.).
S.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (LIV 219f., IEW 493ff.).

S.v. Arm. kṙtʻ-un-kʻ '(anatom.) back'. {ref HAB} II:669 posits an unattested form *kiṙtʻn or kuṙtʻn and offers no etymology. The form is probably comparable CArm. kuṙn '(anatom.) back; side', which in turn – if the original semantic meaning was 'curved/bending body-part' – may be related to CArm. kor 'curved, crooked' (disputed etymology, cf. s.v.).
S.v. vat 'bad' cf. MP wt', ManMP wd 'bad, evil'.
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} IV:519).

S.v. daṙn 'bitter' ({ref HAB} I:624f., {ref IEW} 258. "[E]tymologically unclear. The alleged relation to the verb daṙnam 'turn' (with reference to Gk. οἶνος τρέπεται 'the wine turns sour' as a semantic parallel) is no more than a possibility."

"Lełi or łełi (-woy, -wov) 'gall' cannot be traced back to an IE proto-form straightaway, but from a reconstruction *g̑ʰelh₃iom one would expect *jełi which might have been subject to (tabuistic?) distant assimilation or influenced by the semantically related leard 'liver'."
S.v. seaw 'black', a loanword from Iranian (cf. MParth. sy'w, Av. siiāuua- 'black').
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} II:666f.).
Loanword from Syriac ṭalyā 'adulescens, puer'.
S.v. Arm. kełt 'filthy; filth'. Of unknown origin ({ref HAB} II:570f.).
Cf. for a critical discussion of previous etymological proposals.
S.v. Arm. čarp 'fat, fatness', a loan from Iranic (cf. MP clp 'mild, gentle; fatty, oily', MParth. crb 'smooth, mild').
S.v. Arm. krak 'fire' ({ref HAB} II:678f.), perhaps Iranian.
Of uncertain origin, perhaps Caucasian (cf. {ref HAB} III:184f.).
Uncertain origin (cf. {ref HAB} I:180).
Cf. s.v. *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike'; NB: Hawrom. citation form kawtáy < PIr. *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike (down)' is suppletive to gın-, v. *ǰan.
< *wazaϑra-? But most of the apparently related Ir forms point to *be- and none require *w-: [...] Av °bazura- ‘arm’.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ar(H)- (1) 'to choose, convince; (med.) believe' (+ *u̯i- > Khw. ywʾry- 'to know, experience, understand'), from PIE *u̯elh₁- 'to want, wish' (cf. Skt. var- 'to choose, pick', Lat. volō, OCS velitъ 'wants, orders', Lith. vélti 'to wish, prefer', Goth. wiljan 'to want', Engl. will, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Iranic *skauH- 'to poke, touch; to earmark, ? to cover' from PIE *skeu(h₂)- 'to poke, mark' (cf. Skt. skav- 'to poke, tear up; earmark; to cover', Hitt. iskunahh- 'to mark, designate').
Of unknown origin.

Arm. ors 'hunting, fishing; venison, draught of fish' "formally identical with Greek πόρκος 'sort of fishing net' < *pórk̑os, apparently a *bʰóros-derivative, even though the underlying verbal root is otherwise unknown."
Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref HAB} IV:101, {ref IEW} 96).
S.v. Arm. anjn 'person; life, soul; body', probably < *Hn̥g̑ʰen-, corresponding to ON n-stem angi 'Duft, Geruch'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *anʒōn (ON angi 'sweet odor'), close Arm. anjn 'soul' < *ang̑ʰen-.
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} II:556f.).
S.v. Arm. ԿԱՐՃ 'կարճ', follows {ref Bailey 1979}:65, who suggests a loan from Iranian *kart-čā.
Cf. s.v. Khot. ke̮ca 'cleft, ravine', where it is suggested "Armen. karč 'short', and kirč 'defile, pass' may be Iranian loan-words."
No consensus for an etymology. Cf. with further discussion and references.
S.v. 6303 Lat. paucus 'wenig' > Catalan poc.

Arm. pʿokʿr 'small, little', traditionally vaguely connected to the root of Gk. παῖς, Lat. paulus, paucus, Skt. putrá-, Osc. puklo-, etc., but this requires the assumption of initial pʿ- < *p instead of expected *h-/Ø- (few parallels, of 'expressive' origin?), intervocalic kʿ < *k (cf. Lat. paucus?) and the root vocalism might be the result of a dissimilatory umlaut *pʰukʰu- > pʰokʰu- in oblique cases of the singular.
S.v. *sed- 'sich setzen' (IEW 884-7) with OCS xoditi 'go' given as a cognate assumed from a causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e-.

PS *xoditi is derived from PIE *sed- / *sod- 'sit'. The semantic development can be related to an invention of a new form of transport in a sitting position, cf. Russian vsadnik, Old Indic sādín 'horse rider'. It can be also motivated by the concept of destination aprproaching ('to sit down at the end of the way'), cf. Old Indic ā-sad- 'to approach, reach'.
The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *dhabh-.
This lexeme is most probably derived from a back-formation from xorobryj 'brave'.

There is no certain etymology. A relationship to PS *xorostĭ 'beauty' and *xorŭjĭ 'dark, black' (PIE *sker- 'scratch') PS Xorsŭ 'a Slavic deity', Ukrainian harnyj, garnyj 'beuatiful', PS *xoroniti 'protect, hide', PS *korsta 'blotch' has been assumed. Some scholars believe that the lexem is borrowed from East Ossetian horz, West Ossetian hvarz 'beautiful' or Avestan hvarəz- 'beneficent'.

It had a meaning 'beautiful, tidied' in 13.-17. centuries in Russian. It is derived from PS *xoroščĭjĭ, which is derived from PS *xorostĭ 'convenience, beauty', ultimately from *xorŭjĭ 'black' (PIE *skoro-). It has been also explained as a loanword from Old Ossetian horz 'good'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *raH- 'to howl, cry', from PIE *leh₂- 'to bark' (cf. Skt. rā- 'to bark' , Gk. λαίειν 'to sound' (Hes.), OCS lajati, Russ. lájat', Lith. lóti, Alb. leh-, Lat. lātrāre 'to bark').

There is no commonly accepted etymology. Some scholars assume an expressive derivative (back-formation) from xorobrŭ 'brave'. However, this kind of derivatives - known well in other Slavic subgroups - is not widespread in Russian. Moreover, the oldest attested meanings of horošij and horobryj ('beautiful' and 'brave') are clearly distinct. Another possibility is to assume a relationship to a Slavic deity name Xorsŭ which was probably borrowed from Iranian. However, the secondary polnoglasie should be assumed here. This deity was a god of light and sun, so the etymological meaning of horošij could be 'fulgent, beautiful'.

Russian horošij can be probably a back-formation from PS *xoroščinŭjĭ, a derivative from PS *xorostĭ 'convenience, beauty' (PIE *sker- / *skor- 'scratch, clean'), words related to PS *xorŭjĭ and *xarŭjĭ 'dark?, black?'.

No clear etymology according to {ref HAB} IV:577-578, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:783. The only clear parallel to Armenian kʻitʻ can be found in Khinalug, an isolated North Caucasian language in North-Eastern Azerbaijan: Khinalug k’ɨtʰ-ɨr 'nose' (cf. k’ɨtʰ-ɨri 'nasal, of nose'), which appears to be inherited from Proto-North Caucasian *k’ʷēmtī-. If this parallelism between Arm. kʻitʻ 'nose' and Khinalug k’ɨtʰ- 'id.' is valid, then the Armenian lexeme may be an element of a South Caucasian adstratum.
Of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} IV:577-578).
Arm. gēǰ 'moist' < PIE *gʰei̯dʰ(u)i̯-.

S.v. Arm. gēǰ 'moist; lascivious' subst. 'moisture'. Generally connected with Ru. žídkij, SCr. žídak 'liquid, watery' as though from PIE *gʷʰe/oidʰ-io- (cf. {ref HAB} I:551, and others). Cf. for further discussion of the possibilities of stem formation.
Cf. for the stem formation of Armenian tʻanam 'to wet, moisten (smth.)'.
The South Slavic lexeme is a borrowing from Turkish χob 'beautiful' which is, in turn, a borrowing from New Persian hūb 'beautiful'.

Rejects the usually given etymology with Lithuanian jū́ra 'sea' on the grounds it cannot be separated from OPr. wurs 'pond', Skt. vā́r 'water', TochA wär, TochB war 'id.' with an initial j- of secondary origin.
Cf. s.v. OLith. jū́ra 'Meer' (BSl. Latv. jũŗa 'Meer, großer See', OPr. juriay 'Meer', from PIE *i̯uHr- 'Wasser' (cf. Arm. ǰowr, G.pl. ǰowrcʻ, ǰrocʻ 'Wasser').
Polabian zilĕ is derived from PS *zelĭje 'herb'.

PS *trava (dialectal *trěva) is derived from PS *truti, trovǫ 'use up, eat; poison'. The original meanig was 'things that are used up, feed, fodder' > 'plants used as feed, fodder'. The words belonging here are ultimately derived from PIE *treu̯- 'rub, rub off'.
The word is borrowed from Middle German grö̂ne 'green'.
PS *melti is derived from PIE *mel- 'flake, grind'.

Rejects the usually given etymology of Armenian ǰowr with Lithuanian jū́ra 'sea' on the grounds it cannot be separated from OPr. wurs 'pond', Skt. vā́r 'water', TochA wär, TochB war 'id.' with an initial j- of secondary origin. [= {ref Kortlandt 2003}:122]
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *lorgo- 'trace'. "[{ref Pedersen 1909}:105] compares Arm. ołork 'smooth', but this is more likely to be a chance similarity."

S.v. Arm. ołork 'smooth, soft' ({ref HAB} III:555f., {ref IEW} 679), of uncertain origin. "usually internally connected with lerk 'bald, hairless; soft' and derived from the same root as Old Irish lerg, translated by RIADict. by 'sloping expanse, stretch (of ground etc.)', in particular 'hillside' and 'surface, level', further lorc 'trace, track, path'. The semantic connection between Arm. and Celtic is quite weak, and even though the two Arm. words are probably interrelated they are difficult to account for in detail, so until we have a more striking external cognate it remains to be seen if they belong to the inherited part of the vocabulary."
Of uncertain origin, (cf. {ref HAB} III:58f.).
Cf. s.v. 3865 Skt. khā́dati 'chews, bites; eats'
Cf. s.v. ?*k⁽ʷ⁾h₂ed- '(zer)quetschen' [IEW 634 Anm.]. Only Indo-Iranian cognates.

S.v. Ved. √khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen, verzehren'. Cf. NPers. xāyīdan 'kauen' if from *kʰād-, Baluči khāδαγ 'eat', Khot. khaca 'food' (if from *xad-čā). Further connections are not certain.
PS *červo is derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.
*ku̯ath₂- 'foam up' with Slavic kysnǫti and kvasiti listed as cognates.
Polabian ťėsin is derived from PS *kŭsenĭ '(fish) guts'. It is not related to Polish kieszeń 'pocket'.
PS *kŭsenĭ and *kyšĭka are related to PS *kysati, *kysati, *kysnǫti ('turn sour').
See for discussion on the root reconstruction.
Belarusian vantroby is a loanword from Polish wątroba 'liver'.
Polish flaki 'guts' is a loan from Middle High German vlëc, vlëcke 'piece, piece of cloth, piece of cut guts, place'.

PS *drobŭ (with meaning 'guts' in many Slavic languages and dialects) is derived from PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush'. PIE *dhrebh-, cf. Greek τρέφω 'make dense, make clotted' and Gothic (ga)draban 'gouge, cut out'.

?dʰreb- 'hit, push' with Old High German treffan 'hit' und OCS drobljǫ, drobiti 'shatter, crush' listed as cognates (however, the autors point that the Slavic and Germanic meanings are not very close). Gothic ga-draban is most probably a mistake of the writer (instead of ga-graban). The lack of Winter's lengthening in Slavic can be caused by the inter-vocalic position of -b-.
*dʰrebʰ- 'clot, sediment' with Greek τρέφω 'make dense, make clotted' listed as a cognate.
PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush' is derived from PIE *dʰrebʰ- and related to Gothic ga-draban 'cut off, gouge'.

PG *draban 'to hew', cf. Gothic ga-draban 'chip, hew out' < *dʰróbʰ-e- and OCS drobiti 'crumle, chop, break' < *dʰrobʰ-eie-. The root is Germanic-Slavic.
PG *drepan 'to hit': "A back-formation to the iterative *drupp/bōn 1, a zero-grade variant of *drapp/bōn (q.v.). As both iteratives were derived from the strong verb *draban 'to hew' < *dʰróbʰ-e-, the strong verb *drepan- cannot be used to reconstruct a Pre-Gm. formation *dʰréb-e- with root-final *b, as traditionally assumed (cf. LIV²: 153). The late, internally-Germanic origin of the *p further speaks against the assumption of a non-Indo-European loanword [...]".

PS *drobiti 'crumble, crush' with Gothic gadraban 'cut out' listed as a cognate ("unnless this is a mistake for gagraban"). "LIV (153) reconstructs *dʰreb- on the basis of Germanic forms such as OIc. drepa ‘beat, kill’, OHG treffan ‘hit’. Since this proto-form is in conflict with Winter’s law, I reconstruct *dʰrobʰ-eie- for Slavic. The discrepancy between Slavic and Germanic may have something to do with the fact that the etymon is of non-Indo-European origin or Kluge’s law may have played a role".
Ukrainian kalûh, kelûh is derived from kal 'excrement'.

PS *kal'ux is derived from PS *kalŭ. PS *kalŭ is very productiv but fully unmotivated in Slavic, therefore it has most probably a PIE origin (*kālo-s or *kʷālo-s). However, there are not clear IE cognates. A possibe one is Greek πηλός 'mud, dirt' which is, however, assumed to be etymologically obscure in Greek etymology dictionaries.
PS *kalŭ: "Unfortunately, the reconstruction *kʷeh₂l-, cf. Gk. πηλός f., Dor. πᾱλός f. ‘clay, earth, mud, mire’, would be in conflict with Hirt’s law".
*k̑ei̯h₂- 'sich in Bewegung setzen'

Perhaps identical with մուխ mowx 'smoke' ({ref Olsen 1999}: 33); if so then related to /cognate/647/ [cf. /cognate/8305/].For comparison, Classical Armenian աճիւն ačiwn (Bible 2x) seems to specifically refer only to the remains of a fire (cf. աճիւնախառն ačiwn-a-xaṙn 'mixed with ashes', աճիւնացուցանէմ ačiwn-a-c'owc'anem 'I reduce to ashes'); whereas մոխիր moxir (Bible 43x) has a wider, more general scope, including 'dust', etc. (cf. մոխրագոյն moxr-a-goyn 'gray, i.e. ash-colored', մոխրամած moxr-a-mac 'prostate in the dust', մոխրաթաւալ moxr-a-tᶜawal 'rolling in ashes, dirt', etc.).
S.v. 2. *peth₂- '(auf)fliegen' (IEW 825-6). NB: "Präsens ?*pt-né/n̥-h₂- > arm. ən-tʻanam 'laufe'.
Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².
Of uncertain origin (cf. {ref HAB} II:541f.).

S.v. Arm. zist 'the fleshy parts between the loin and the knee'. "Meillet p.c. apud {ref HAB} II:96 interprets zist as z- + hisdo- < IE *si-sd-o-, redupl. of *sed- 'to sit' as seen in nist 'seat, site'".

Arm. zist 'thigh, flank', probably a compound comparable to nist 'nest' containing the prefix z- so that while nist is that which you sit in, zist may be interpreted as what you sit on (cf. {ref HAB} II:96).
Arm. bir 'rod, staff, stave', but be derived from a root *berH- ({ref IEW 134}), also attested in Lith. bárti 'schelten', Gk. φαρόω 'plough', Lat. forāre 'pierce'.
Cf. s.v. *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten' (IEW 133-5).

Perhaps an Iranian loan. Denominative of ուռ owṙ 'swelling, tumor', cf. CA ուռնում owṙ-nu-m (intr.) 'I am swollen, bloated; (fig.) grow proud"; ուռուցանեմ owṙ-owcʿ-an-e-m (tr.) 'I swell; stuff'; ուռոյց owṙ-oycʿ 'swelling; blister', etc.
Arm. caṙ 'tree', of uncertain origin (cf. {ref HAB} II:446f., unconvincingly {ref IEW} 392).
Arm. caṙ, perhaps a loanword from Urartian ṣâre 'orchard', cf. Hurr. sar-me 'wood' attested in an Akkadian lexical text, both < PEC *c̣wāl₁hV 'wood, fire-wood; big stick'.
Arm. cov 'sea' considered a loanword from Urart. ṣûǝ (if to be interpreted as /c̣ô(w)ǝ/) 'inland sea'.
Arm. tʻiw 'number' < Hurr. tiw- 'to say, speak', tiwǝ 'word, deed'.

Arm. tʻiw 'number' is connected with Sanskrit tavá- 'stark, kräftig' (subst. *távas-, Av. tauuah-), vb. tavīti 'ist stark, hat Macht' etc. to a root *teuh₁-. The root vocalism points to a vr̥ddhi formation *tēu̯h₁-esó- based on the s-stem *teu̯Hos.
Cf. Arm. hašiw 'account, calculation, consideration', a loan from Syriac (cf. Syr. xəšīw 'gerechnet, geachtet für').

S.v. Arm. leaṙn 'mountain'. Etymology uncertain ({ref HAB} II:270). Traditionally derived from *k̑l(e)i̯-tr- (cf. Gk. κλιτύς,  Lat. clīvus 'slope, rise; hill'; Goth. hleiþra 'booth, tent' (PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean'). Alternatively, from *lḗh₂-sr̥ ‎(cf. Alb. lerë '(heap of) stone(s)', Gk. λᾶας, OIr. líe 'stone' according to {ref Hamp 1967}:16-17, accepted by {ref Olsen 1999}:122. Both etymologies are ultimately rejected by Martirosyan as unconvincing.
Arm. całik 'flower' is sometimes assumed to be etymologically connected with całr, całow 'laugh, laughter' < *g̑élh₂ōs (cf. {ref IEW} 366f.).
Arm. całik is possibly connected to PIE *g̑elh₂-, with the semantics justified on the basis of the gloss from Hesychius's lexicon: γέλειν· λάμπειν, ἄνθειν 'to shine, bloom'.

S.v. Arm. cał- 'flower, blossom', some scholars have suggested an etymology to Arm. cał- 'laugh' (< *g̑elh₂-) comparing the Hesychius gloss γελεῖν· λάμπειν, ἀνθεῖν 'shine, bloom'. For discussion cf. {ref Clackson 1994}:128, {ref Olsen 1999}:459, among others.
Arm. mirg 'fruit' < *miδgV- ~ Sogd. mγδʾk 'id.' (cf. {ref Benveniste 1964}:5).
Arm. neł 'narrow', of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} II:439f.).

Traditionally connected with Proto-Germanic *narwa- 'narrow' (cf. /cognate/2810/), presumably via *(s)ner-lo- (cf. J̌ahukyan and Sargsyan).  The Germanic form, however, ultimately goes back to PIE *neh₂r-u- (Kroonen).  Moreover, the connection with the Germanic forms was originally based on the once reasonable assumption that Armenian ղ ł may partially reflect PIE *R, which split in the European languages into *r and *l (see, e.g., Huebschmann); cf. the formerly presumed correspondence between սրունք srownkʿ 'leg; shank' and Lat. clūnis 'rump; buttocks', Lith. šlaunìs 'hip; thigh' (< PIE *k̑lou̯-ni-) vis-a-vis Skt. śroṇi-, Av. sraoni- formerly believed to represent the original state of the proto-language (i.e. PIE *k̑Rou̯ni- > European *k̑lou̯ni-, with սրունք srownkʿ believed to sporadically represent the original rhotic).

The often assumed relationship between OAv. ufiia- ‘to sing’ and *u̯ab/f ‘to weave’ (as quoted in for instance EWA
II: 506; Porzig, Gliederung: 186), should be given up, in view of the evidence from the other Ir. languages, which clearly point to two separate roots. Ir. *u̯ab/f¹ is probably expressive or onomatopoetic in origin, of the type woof. The root has been
connected to OCS vabiti ‘to summon’, Goth. wopjan ‘to call loudly, call out’, Engl. to weep (etc.) by H.W. Bailey (his notes can be found on his copy of Pokorny, IEW: 1109). This proves to be phonologically difficult as the Slavo-Germanic forms point
to a structure that is not typical for an IE form, having long *ā followed by *-b-.

Arm. cʻowrt 'cold' < *sk̑ū-do- (?) has been compared to OHG, OS, OE scūr 'Platzregen, shower' < *sk̑uH-ro-. The supplementary *-d- of the Armenian stem may not necessarily be an actual suffix, but one might consider the verbal stem *-dh₃o- 'giving' in which case cʻowrt could be an original compound. Alternatively one might consider influence from semantically related 'hail' karkowt.

S.v. Arm. cʻurt 'cold; cold water'. The word has been compared with Pers. sard, Arm. saṙn 'cold', alternatively it has been compared with OCS sěverъ 'North, Northern wind', SCr. sjȅvēr 'North', Lith. šiáurė 'North' < *k̑eh₁uer-o-; Lat. caurus 'northwestern wind' < *k̑h₁-u̯er-o-.

Cf. s.v. Skt. rā- 'bellen', IIr. cf. Pkt. rāi 'lärmt', etc., YAv. gāθrō.raiiaṇt- 'die Gesänge ausschreiend', Parth. ghr'y- 'prahlerisch sein', Khot. rrai- 'lärmen', BSogd. r'y 'weinen', Oss. ræjyn/ræjun 'bellen', etc., probably from PIE *leh₂- (cf. Lat. lātrāre, Lith. lóti, OCS lajati 'bellen', etc.).

Arm. la- probably belongs to a group of probably not independently created sound-symbolic words, e.g. Alb. lot f., best. lodja 'Träne' (< *låti- < *lāti- or *lēti-), Lat. lāmentum 'Wehklage'. As a proto-form then we may consider *lah₂- or lah₂-i̯e/o-. Less probable is a connection with  Gk. κλαιε/ο-, Alb. (Old Gheg) kla-.
Arm. gēr 'fat', possibly goes back to *gʰei̯ro- (cf. OCS žirъ 'Weide, Weidefutter', Russ. žir 'fat').
Arm. ptowł 'fruit', of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} IV:112f., {ref IEW} 100).

Origin uncertain. Traditionally connected with Proto-Germanic *buddǭ 'bud, seed-pod', which are both taken to reflect PIE *beu̯-d- 'to swell'.  Cf. also պտուկ ptuk (< *put-uk-) 'nipple; bud'.  The Germanic form, however, may also reflect PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'become; come to exist; grow' (cf. LIV²: 98), which is incompatible with the Armenian development.
Arm. gna- < Proto-Armenian *gina- or *guna- is phonologically ambiguous. Several root etymologies are possible. Most probable is a connection with Arm. ga- 'kommen' from *gʰh₁-.
Classical Armenian tʻakʻowcʻanem 'verbergen' is derived from Classical Armenian tʻakʻcʻi- 'sich verbergen', to be derived from an enlarged -sk̑e/o- formation based on PIE *pth₂k-eh₁-.

Arm. martncʻi- probably derives from a pre-Armenian root *mr̥d- or *smr̥d-. Further etymological connections are uncertain, perhaps *mr̥-d- stands beside *mr̥-h₂- in Gk. μάρναται 'kämpft' < *mr̥-n-h₂-, or to Lat. mordēre 'beißen', etc.?

Arm. mart 'fight, struggle, combat' (vb. martncʻim, marteay cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:81, {ref IEW} 736) probably to a root or root variant *(s)merd-/(s)mrd-, cf. perhaps Lat. mordeō 'bite', OHG smerzan.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *gargo- 'rough' ({ref IEW} 353 *garg̑o-, cf. OCS groza 'horror', Arm. karcr 'hard'). "This is presumably an onomatopoeic or expressive word, which may explain the a-vocalism in the root. The parallels in other IE languages may be accidental similarities."
Cf. s.v. Gk. γοργός 'grim, fierce, terrible'. Not to be related with OIr. garg(g) 'raw, wild', OCS groza 'shiver', nor to Arm. karcr 'hard' (pace {ref Pedersen 1906}:379).

Obscure origin. This word is unattested in the classical language (cf. /lexeme/28586/).  A remote possibility is a dialectal development of CA գլոր gl-or '(in) rolling; tumbling down' (< *gil-or- < PIE/inner-Arm. *u̯ēlH-; cf. գելում gel-ow-m 'I squeeze, twist; (orig.) *roll' < PIE 2.*u̯elH-, cf. OCS valiti, OHG wallan; ?Lat. volvo) in a variety X with a three-way opposition of stops in which CA /T : D : Tʰ/ corresponds to /D : T : Tʰ/ (such as Kharberd, Middle Armenian, etc.), i.e. CA [gəlɔɾ] > variety X [kəlɔɾ] 'round'.  The latter was loaned in parallel prior to the Western Armenian shift, i.e., variety X [kəlɔɾ] → *[kəlɔɾ] (= EA) > WA [gəlɔɾ].  Needless to say, this is a speculation.
