Cf. s.v. viysānvā 'in bindings', suggesting Arm. viz, vizi 'neck' is a loan from Iranian.

Perhaps ultimately a derivative of պար par 'circle; dance; choir, troop' (cf. պար- par- 'around' a calque on Gk. περι- or Lat. circum-, e.g. պարագրեմ par-a-gr-e-m 'I circum-scribe'); i.e. Proto-Armenian *par-an- (lit.) 'circling, circled; twisting, twisted' (cf. պարան par(-)an 'rope') → par-an-ocʿ-  (< PIE *-sko/a-), the latter suffix denoting instrument/tool. The connection of պար par with Gk. περί, Skt. pári, etc. (< PIE *per-i) is controversial.
Cf. s.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' [IEW 330-1].

Cf. s.v. PIr. HraiH- 'to defecate' "The Ir. cognate root fo Skt. rayⁱ has become an euphemism for 'to defecate', [...].", from PIE *h(3)reiH- 'to flow, stream' (cf. Gk. ὀρίνω 'bring in commotion, confuse', Lat rīvus 'brook', OIr. rían 'river, sea', Ru. réjat' 'to stream fast, flow', etc.).

S.v. Proto-Iranic *bram- 'to cry, weep', from PIE *bʰrem- 'to cry' (cf. Lat. fremō 'I make a thud, mumble, moan', MWelsh bref- 'to roar', Pol. brzmię 'I sound, buzz', OE barmen, NHG barmen 'to complain, moan').

Arm. saṙn 'ice; crystal' has cognates in ON hjarn, Russ. serën 'frozen snow' < *k̑erno- which might also account for the Armenian form except for the vocalism of the root, which could have been influenced by the verb saṙnowm 'freeze' (suggested by Godel 1972:64). It is also possible that the original formation was an n-stem, in which case *k̑érōn, loc. k̑r̥én- > Arm. *sarin → saṙin. The exact stem formation is uncertain.

Cf. s.v. OLith. šer̃kšnas 'Reif' (BSl. Latv. sę̄̀rsna 'Reiffrost, Nachtfrost im Frühling; Harsch über dem Schnee'. Sloven. srẹ̑n 'Raureif; Harsch', ORuss. serenъ 'Harsch, Eisregen, Raureif', Ru. séren, serën 'Schneekruste; Raureif; Frost nach Tauwetter', Pol. śrzon, szron 'Reif'), Elsewhere in IE ON hjarn 'gefrorener Schnee; mit Eiskruste bedeckte durchgefrorene Erde'.
"Diese Grundform is nicht ganz sicher [...]"

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *herzna- 'hard snow' (< *k̑ers-nó-), close to Lith. šer̃kšnas 'hoarfrost', Latv. sȩ̄rsna 'id.' < *sers-neh₂-, Ru. dial. serēn, séren 'crust of ice' < *k̑ers-n-o-/eh₂-; with zero-grade Lith. šir̃kšnas 'hoarfrost' < *k̑rs-no-.

Cf. s.v. OLith. šer̃kšnas 'Reif' (BSl. Latv. sę̄̀rsna 'Reiffrost, Nachtfrost im Frühling; Harsch über dem Schnee'. Sloven. srẹ̑n 'Raureif; Harsch', ORuss. serenъ 'Harsch, Eisregen, Raureif', Ru. séren, serën 'Schneekruste; Raureif; Frost nach Tauwetter', Pol. śrzon, szron 'Reif'), Elsewhere in IE ON hjarn 'gefrorener Schnee; mit Eiskruste bedeckte durchgefrorene Erde'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *herzna- 'hard snow' (< *k̑ers-nó-), close to Lith. šer̃kšnas 'hoarfrost', Latv. sȩ̄rsna 'id.' < *sers-neh₂-, Ru. dial. serēn, séren 'crust of ice' < *k̑ers-n-o-/eh₂-; with zero-grade Lith. šir̃kšnas 'hoarfrost' < *k̑rs-no-.

Arm. saṙn 'ice; crystal' has cognates in ON hjarn, Russ. serën 'frozen snow' < *k̑erno- which might also account for the Armenian form except for the vocalism of the root, which could have been influenced by the verb saṙnowm 'freeze' (suggested by Godel 1972:64). It is also possible that the original formation was an n-stem, in which case *k̑érōn, loc. k̑r̥én- > Arm. *sarin → saṙin. The exact stem formation is uncertain.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike (down)' Cf. Under NEIr." "The 'old' forms, MMP qhwn, BMP khwbn /kahwan/, Pth. kfwn, NP kuhan, Bal. kwahn (kwān) Khot. kuhana-, Bact. καβογγο also contain this root [...]", further from PIE *kop- 'to fell, chop' (LIV 555, IEW 930ff.), cf. Gk. κόπτω, Lith. kapiù (kàpti) 'I chop, I fell', Lith. kapóti, Latv. kapât 'to hack, strike, cut', Alb. kep- 'to hew, chisel, stitch').
S.v. Arm. ՀՈՒՄԵԼ
S.v. Arm. ՀՈՒՄԵԼ

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian xmem 'to drink, to imbibe'. Further origins uncertain, probably a more recent loanword on the basis of dialectal variation but the exact source is difficult to establish ({ref HAB} III:122-123, {ref Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010}:467) Not in {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}, {ref Martirosyan 2010}.
[Classical Armenian kṙiw 'fight' included in a list of 'etymologically more opaque' nouns, but not listed in the final index of vocabulary of unknown origin.]
Arm. daṙna-, aor. darj(a)- belongs to a root *dʰr̥g̑ʰ- which is also found in Alb. dreth, aor. drodha 'zusammendrehen, zwirnen, spinnen'.
S.v. *dʰerg̑ʰ- '(sich) wenden' (IEW 258). Probably to be connected with the Schwebeablaut variant dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- (Gk. τρέχω, ON dragan etc.).

S.v. Arm. daṙnam (3.sg.aor. darj-a-w) 'to go/come back, return; to turn, become' connected with Alb. dredh, aor. drodha 'to turn, wind' on one hand, and to Gk. τρέχω 'to run', τρόχος 'wheel; potter's wheel', OIr. droch 'wheel', and Arm. durgn 'potter's wheel'; these forms are often assumed to be two different lexemes.

Arm. kʻar 'stone' (i-stem in sg., n-stem in the pl.) has been suggested to be connected with Old Irish carrac 'rock' ({ref Pedersen 1905}:220, cf. {ref IEW} 532, {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:42f.), but it is also possible that this is a word of non-IE origin (and in which case the irregular inflection cannot be determined).
Suggests "vielleicht gehört kʻar 'stein, fels' zu ir. carric 'stein, fels'."
Arm. hogi 'spirit', with the etymologically identical ogi 'spirit, breath' ({ref IEW} 847) probably going back to *p⁽ʰ⁾ou̯(H)io- from the root *p⁽ʰ⁾eu(H)-.

Cf. հոգի hogi 'spirit, soul; ghost' (< ?*pou̯(H)-i̯o-); հեւամ hew-a-m 'I pant; puff, am breathless' (< *peu̯(H)-); perhaps also հոգ hog 'care; worry, anxiety; mental pain' (< ?*pou̯(H)-os-) if originally from hypothetical "panting; (state of being) breathless, anxious".
S.v. Arm. ՀՈՎ, from the IE inherited vocabulary and to be connected with the same root *pou-, *p(h)u- found in Arm. hewal, hog, hogi, etc.

The paradigm present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair of Proto-Armenian or Proto-Indo-European roots. Probably present to *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen', ḫarnik- 'vernichten, zugrunde richten'), aorist stem to *per- 'schlagen' (Lith. per̃ti '(im Dampfbad) mit dem Badequast schlagen', Latv. pḕrt 'schlagen, prüglen; (mit dem Badequast) schlagen'.

The paradigm present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair of Proto-Armenian or Proto-Indo-European roots. Probably present to *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen', ḫarnik- 'vernichten, zugrunde richten'), aorist stem to *per- 'schlagen' (Lith. per̃ti '(im Dampfbad) mit dem Badequast schlagen', Latv. pḕrt 'schlagen, prüglen; (mit dem Badequast) schlagen'.
S.v. 3. *per- 'schlagen' (IEW 818-9). Root aorist *pér-/pr- > Arm. ehar 'schlug'.

Arguably from earlier *z-ar-an-e-, the root morpheme /-ar-/ from PIE *(-)pr̥- of 3.*per- (Lith. per̃ti; OCS pьrati; OIr. orgaim 'to slay'; Ved. prt- 'battle''); cf. LIV² 473; Klingenschmitt (1982: 215). See also /lexeme/28521/.

The paradigm present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair of Proto-Armenian or Proto-Indo-European roots. Probably present to *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen', ḫarnik- 'vernichten, zugrunde richten'), aorist stem to *per- 'schlagen' (Lith. per̃ti '(im Dampfbad) mit dem Badequast schlagen', Latv. pḕrt 'schlagen, prüglen; (mit dem Badequast) schlagen'.

Cf. s.v. OIr. carrac 'roche'. There is no need to posit a root *kar- 'dur' but it's rather a derivative of an Ibero-Mediterranean *carrā 'pierre' which is found, among others in Basque harri 'pierre', Béarnese carroc and with various suffixes in the languages of Western Europe. Cf. also MW carrawc, Modern Welsh carrog 'torrent' (= le ruisseau rempli de cailloux?). Cf. {ref Pedersen 1909}:23, 83; {ref IEW} 532.

Cf. s.v. OIr. carrac 'roche'. There is no need to posit a root *kar- 'dur' but it's rather a derivative of an Ibero-Mediterranean *carrā 'pierre' which is found, among others in Basque harri 'pierre', Béarnese carroc and with various suffixes in the languages of Western Europe. Cf. also MW carrawc, Modern Welsh carrog 'torrent' (= le ruisseau rempli de cailloux?). Cf. {ref Pedersen 1909}:23, 83; {ref IEW} 532.

Arm. lič 'lake, pond' ({ref IEW} 657), reconstructed as *lēgi̯a- (collective formation?) from *leg- 'tröpfeln, sickern, zergehen'. The lengthened grade is consistent with other derivatives (e.g. *to-stem W. llaith, Bret. leiz 'humid' < *lekto-).
Cf. s.v. ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'tröpfeln' (IEW 657). Only Germanic and Celtic.
< *kþah₂kh₂ah₂-

Of unknown origin (cf. {ref HAB} III:262). The proposed connection (cf. {ref IEW} 734) with Gk. μεμορυχμένος 'beschmutzt, geschwärzt', Russ. maráju 'schmieren, sudeln' is formally unsatisfactory (cf. also {ref Frisk 1960-1972} II:252).
< *kau̯tá-ka-ka-

Of unknown origin. Apparently a denominative of ապուր apur 'salvation, deliverance; life; nourishment, soup; (perhaps also) booty (if not a different item)', attested in compounds such as անձնապուր(ծ) anjn-(a-)apowr(c), մազապուր maz-(a-)apowr, մարդապուր mard-(a-)apowr, դիւրապուր diwr-(a-)apowr, all denoting riddance or escape, esp. from harm or death.
"(zu lit. kélti 'auf-, emporheben')"
gō(n)

Cf. s.v. Alb. arg, -u 'picolo, pidocchio; uovo di pidocchio; gancetto che sta al lato della pezza di stoffa nel telaio' (cf. dialectal forms including ergjëz, ergjíz). Without certain comparisons within Albanian, outside of Albanian one first compares Arm. o(r)ǰil 'Nisse'; Lith. érkė 'Milbe, Zecke' which shows a voiceless velar. From *Hor(H)gʷʰ-???
Cf. s.v. OLith. érke 'Zecke, Milbe', no certain comparisons outside of Baltic.

Arm. mōt 'near' ({ref IEW} 746) with the related verb matčʻim 'approach' is related to Goth. gamōtjan 'meet' etc. Proto-form is *mā̆du- < *mHdu- or *maHdu- and the o-inflection should probably be ascribed to secondary thematicisation of the u-stem by epenthesis.
Cf. s.v. Goth. G46. ga-motjan ἀπαντῆσαι 'meet' (within Gmc. cf. OIc. møta, OE (ge-)mētan, OFris mēta OS mōtian 'meet', etc.), from PIE *mōd- 'meet, approach', cf. Arm. matčʻim 'approach'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *mōtan- 'to approach, concede to(?)', a preterite-present probably based on the root *mod- as attested by Arm. matčʻim 'to approach, come close' < *mod-.
S.v. *klor 'spheric, ball-shaped; round', probably to be connected with dialectal words from *klmp/b- of uncertain origin.

Uncertain etymology. A denominative of խուփն xowpʿ-n 'lid, cover; (en)closed, shut'.  The semantic development apparently proceeded from "to close, shut, cover" presumably via "to shut abruptly or forcefully, slam' to 'attach, fasten, nail; (also) fire, shoot' and eventually 'hit, strike, beat'.
Arm. xowpʻ 'cover' (vb. xpʻanem, xpʻi/xpʻem, -ecʻi < *sk⁽ʰ⁾upp-? cf. {ref IEW} 956).
Arm. ełǰewr 'horn' may be derived from *gʰrḗu̯r̥ (< *gʰréh₁u̯r̥ or *gʰreh₁u̯r̥) if connected with Hitt. karawar 'horn' and TochB obl. krorīyai, A kror 'crescent, horn of the moon'.
Its etymology is not clear. It cannot be connected to OInd. kṣupa- "bush" [...] since OInd. kṣ- corresponds to Bal., NP š-"
S.v. Ved. kṣīrá- 'Milch', IIr. cf. MPers. šīr 'Milch'
The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *kes-.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *staHn- ? 'to take' "This root is perhaps originally a pres. n-stem of *staH (?)."
Suggests the direction of the borrowing is uncertain, and the Caucasian parallels (Archi xotu 'grass', Udi xod 'tree') could be borrowings from Armenian.
S.v. ON pústr 'ohrfeige', Ic. pústur, NSw., ODa. pust 'ohrfeige; schnaufen, blasen', to which NNw. pusta, NDa. puste 'blasen', MLG puster 'blasebalg', poesten, puysten 'blasen'.
S.v. ON reikna (schw.) 'berechnen, zahlen, ansehen, bewirten' (Ic. reikna, NNw. rekna, NSw. räkna, NDa. regne), a loanword from MLG rekenen.

PS *volsŭ is related to Avestan varəsa- 'hair', Middle Persian vars 'hair' and Old Indic válśa- 'young twig, sprout'. These words are derived from from PIE root *u̯el(ə)- with a suffix *-so-, cf. words without that suffix: Lithuanian valaĩ 'hair of horse tail', Old Indic vā́la- 'hair of horse tail' and dialectal Polish włoć 'spike'.

S.v. NHG Holz (MHG holz, OHG holz, OS holt, from Gmc. *hulta- n. 'Holz' also in ON holt, OE holt, OFr. holt). Connected with Gk. κλάδος 'Zweig', MIr. caill, W celli 'Wald, Hain'. Semantically further is Ru.CS klada 'Balken, Holz'. To PIE *kelə- 'schlagen, brechen' in Gk. κλάω 'ich breche, beschneide junge Zweige', Lat. percellere 'zu Boden werfen, zerschmettern', Lith. kálti 'schlagen, schmeiden'.

Cf. s.v. Gk. κλάδος 'branch, twig, sprout' < PIE *kl̥do-. The further proposed connection to the root *kelh₂- 'to hit, cut off' cannot explain the Greek form which presupposes a root *kld-. Connection with Germanic word for 'wood' ON, OE holt, etc. and the Slavic group of CS klada, Ru. koloda 'log, block of wood' is suggestive.
PS *rǫka is derived from PIE *u̯renk- 'gather', ultimately from PIE root *u̯er- 'to spin, to wind'.
Cf. s.v. NHG Krach (MHG krach, OHG krah, krac, to OHG krahhen, MHG krachen, OHG krahhōn, MLG kraken, MDu. kraken, OE cracian), to an onomatopoeic interjection Krack, Krach.
Slovene, Serbo-Croat, Macedonian etc. jak 'strong, hard' is most probably derived from the relative pronoun *i̯o, *i̯e, cf. Polish jaki 'what (kind)'.
Cf. s.v. NHG Knoten (MHG knote, knode, OHG knoto, knodo, OS knotto), also variants in ON knútr 'Knoten', ON knúta. It may be a derivative of IE *g̑enu- 'Knie', cf. Gk. γόνυ 'Knie, Gelenk'.
Cf. s.v. *strei̯g- 'streichen' (IEW 1028).
S.v. ON hali 'schwanz; schaftspitze', to be connected with Gk. κῆλον 'stange, schaft, pfeil', MIr. cail 'speer', Ved. śalá- 'stock, spitze' to IE *k̑el- 'stechen' ({ref IEW} 552).
S.v. ON ϸrútinn 'geschwollen', ϸrutna 'aufschwellen'. Etymology disputed.
S.v. ON kortr, kurtr 'kurz' < MLG kort < Lat. curtus.
Cf. s.v. 570 Lat. aqua 'Wasser' (> Friaul. age, etc.).
Cf. s.v. 570 Lat. aqua 'Wasser' for Romance lexemes.

Cf. s.v. Lat. aqua 'water', from Proto-Italic *akwā- 'water' (cf. Goth. aƕa, OHG aha < PGmc. *aχʷō 'water'). "According to {ref Beekes 1998}, other suggested cognates, such as OIc. ægir 'sea, ocean' are very uncertain. Even if cognate, Germano-Italic *akwā- may well be a loanword from a non-IE language."
S.v. ON mjǫrkvi 'dichter Nebel' (> Far. mjørki, NDa. mørke).
S.v. ON  ϸefa 'riechen, duften, wittern' (NIc. ϸefa, NNw. teva). Cf. ON ϸefr 'geruch, duft' < Proto-Norse *ϸafiR.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸefōjanan (wk.vb.) (ON ϸefa 'to smell, to sniff', OE ðefian 'to pant, be agitated' and connected with Skt. tápati 'to warm, to burn', Lat. tepeō 'to be tepid', OIr. té 'hot', Slav. *teplъ 'warm' (cf. {ref IEW} 1069-1070).
Cf. s.v. 1. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (IEW 1069-1070), without Germanic.

PS *čujǫ, *čuti is derived from PIE *kēu̯-i̯- and related to Avestan čəvīšī 'I hoped' and to forms with o-grade like Old Indic kaví- 'prophet', Greek κοέω 'notice', Latin caveo 'beware', further to Greek ἀκούω 'hear', Gothic hausjan 'hear' and Old High German 'look'.
S.v. *ętro. The word is derived from *en-tr-o-m, cf. Old Indic antrám, Armenian ənderk', Greek ἔντερα 'guts'.
S.v. wutroba.
S.v. *gʷi̯eh₃- 'leben' (LIV 215f., IEW 467ff.). Germ. forms reflect ?*gʷih₃-tu- > PGmc. *kʷiþu-, but cf. n5 for possible alternative explanations. Slavic forms reflect *gʷih₃-u̯o-to-.
Polabian zaivåtăk 'heart' is derived from PS *životŭkŭ, a diminutive of *životŭ. Cf. also Polabian zaivåt 'life, belly, body, heart'.
PS *tęžĭkŭ is derived from PIE *tengʰ-.
It is a loanword from Old High German, probably via Polish.
Polabian svoră is borrowed from Middle Low German swâr 'heavy'.
PS *sĭde is derived from the pronoun *sĭ. The latter is derived from PIE *k̑is and related to šìs, Latin cis, Gothic himma, Greek ἐ-κεῖ, Armenian -s, Hittite kā-, ki-, Irish cé etc.
Polabian sem 'here' is ultimately derived from the PS pronoun  *sĭ.

PS *tu is the original locative of the pronoun tŭ 'this'. PS *tuta, *tuto, *tutŭ are its derivatives. All these forms are ultimately derived from PIE *to-, cf. Lithuanian tàs, English that, Greek tó etc.
Lower Sorbian how is derived from a pronoun, cf. Polish ów, Macedonian ovoj, Slovene ov. It is related to Lithuanian ova 'oh yes', Avestan ava- 'that' and Old Indic avṓs 'that from these two'.

PS *kryti is derived from PIE *krū-. It is related to Lithuanian kráuti 'load, put as a pile, heap'. Further comparanda are uncertain. It has been linked to Greek κρύπτω 'hide' and Gothic hrot / hrōt 'roof'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *xād- 'to devour, eat, gorge' (Parth. x'z, Khot. khāś-, NP xāyīdan/xāy- 'to chew, gnaw, eat', Bal. kʰāδiθ-/kʰāδ- 'to chew'. To Sanskrit khād- 'to chew, bite, eat'. "An IE provenance for this IIr. root is uncertain: the IE preform *k(ʷ)h₂eg̑- (cf. Arm. xacanel ‘to bite’) reconstructed by Klingenschmitt 1982: 210 and Kümmel, LIV: 360 has little to recommend."
Perhaps a reflex of PIE *molh₂- (or *mu̯elh₂-) 'grind' (cf. Gk. μύλη 'mill').  Cf. also մամուլ ma(-)mowl 'press(ing machine)', մղեղ mł-eł 'dust', etc.
Regarding młeł 'chaff; powder, ashes, dust': Of unknown origin.
PS *prętati is related to PS *prǫtŭ 'sprout, sprig'. The PIE root is *preu- / *prou- / *prū- 'jump, burst', cf. also Russian prygat' 'jump'.
Russian prâtat' ['hide'] is related to prut ['sprout, sprig']. The original meaning of the verb was 'wrap' (and that of prut 'sprout good for binding, intertwining, wrapping').

It is complicated to explain PS *prętati etymologically without linking it to *prǫtŭ ['sprout, sprig'], although it is not fully convincing semantically. However, if we assume that the meaning 'hide' is not original, this problem can be solved (*prętati could originally mean 'wrap, cover with sprouts' etc.).
It is usually linked to PS *prǫtŭ ['sprout, sprig']. However, it has not been proven, that PS *prętati had meanings like 'entwine, wrap'.
PS *prętati and *prǫtŭ have no certain etymology.

PS *prǫtŭ is etymologically obscure. There are similar words in Germanic (cf. German Spross, English sprout, Old Icelandic sproti) but it is complicated to put them together with the Slavic lexeme (the Slavic form points to *pronto- and the Germanic one to *spreudo-). However, the Slavic and Germanic forms could be maybe linked to PIE *(s)per- 'splash, sparkle, sprout'.
Most authors reconstruct PIE *mele-k-, *mlāk- 'soft, weak, turbid' and link it to Greek βλᾱ́ξ 'faint, weak, blunt'. More probably it is related to PS *smola 'pitch'.

The lexeme is derived from PS *molka 'puddle, mud' (PIE *melk- 'wetness, dampness', cf. Greek mélkion 'spring', Gothic milhma 'cloud', Lithuanian mal̃kas, let. màlks 'gulp'). It is less probable that this lexeme is related to Greek blā́ks 'turbid, soft' or derived from PIE *(s)mel- 'burn slowly, smolder'
The adjective *molčĭnŭ(jĭ) is derived from PS *molka and related to *melko 'milk'. These lexemes are derived from PIE *melk- (*mel-k-) 'drain, spill, swell'.
PS *domŭ is derived from PIE *domu-s, cf. Latin domus etc.
S.v. ON bǫrkr 'rinde', from Proto-Germanic *barku-. Etymology uncertain.

Cf. s.v. NHG Borke 'Rinde' (MLG borke, MDu. bark). The High German word is a borrowing from Low German; the Low German forms are related to ON bǫrkr 'Rinde', allowing the reconstruction of Proto-Germanic *barku-. Further origin uncertain.
S.v. Da. bitter, a loan from Low German.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rauki- 'smoke'. An i-stem derived to the strong-verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke, drift, fly' (without a generally accepted etymology), cf. also ON ryk 'dust' < *rukja-.
S.v. NHG Rauch (MHG rouch, OHG rouh, OS rōk), from Gmc. *rauki- also in ON reykr, OE rēc, OFr. rēk; derived from the strong verb underlying NHG riechen, whose original meaning was 'to smoke'.

It is widely assumed that PS *kǫtja is derived from PS *kǫtati 'clean up, hide'. However, such a derivation is improbable morphologically. It is better to assume a derivation from PS *kǫtŭ '(inner, concave) corner' here. PS *kǫtŭ is most probably derived from PIE *kompto- / *kampto- 'bend' and related to Greek κάμπτω 'bend' and Lithuanian kam̃pas, kum̃pas 'corner, edge'.
S.v. Sloven. hiša, a loanword from Germanic (PG *hūsa-).
Cf. s.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben; fahren' (IEW 1118-20), with OCS vezǫ, vesti etc. listed as a cognate.
It is derived from PS *vezti 'drive, carry', ultimately from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'move, go (by a vehicle)'.
Polish budynek is a loanword from Middle German *buding 'building'. It was further borrowed from Polish into Ukrainian and Belarusian.
S.v. Sw. damm (2). To be connected with Germ. Dampf, etc.

Cf. s.v. NHG Dampf (MHG dampf, tampf, OHG dampf, MLG damp, MDu. damp), from Gmc. *dampi- 'Ausdünstung, Dampf', considered to a be a labial extension of the same root also found in OHG toum 'Dampf, Dunst' and with s-mobile OE stēam, NE steam (cf. Lat. fūmus < *dʰūmo-), based on a meaning 'blasen, fauchen' (cf. similarly Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen, schnuppern', with labial extension dùmples 'Blasebalg').
PS *xysŭ, *xyša is a loanword from Germanic, cf. Old High German hūs 'house'.

The etymology is not entirely clear. It can be reconstructed as PIE *skormo-. Then it would be related to Old High German scirm, scërm 'cover, shield' and Old Indic cárman 'leather, skin'. An alternative is to reconstruct *sor-mo- and assume a relationship to Latin serere 'tie, bind' and Greek ὅρμος 'chain, rope'. The second hypothesis is weaker phonetically (it does not explain the initial x- reasonably) and semantically (the original meaning would be 'plaited cover, plaited cabin', it would also denote a primitive construction, whereas PS *xormŭ refers rather to more sophisticated constructions, cf. the meaning 'temple, church' in some Slavic languages).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *đampaz, based on strong verb *đempanan > MHG dimpfen 'to steam, to smoke', and related to Lith. dùmpti 'to blow'. ({ref IEW} 247-248 to Skt. dhámati 'to blow').

S.v. NHG Erde (MHG erde, OHG erda, OS ertha), from PGmc. *erϸō, also Goth. airϸa, ON jǫrð, OE eorϸe, OFr. erthe. Outside of Germanic in the same one compares in the same meaning Gk. ἔρα (gloss, more widely attested in ἔραζε 'to the earth, on the earth') and within Germanic OHG ero. Semantically deviating is Welsh erw 'Feld, Land'. Further connections are uncertain.
PS *xata 'primitive kind of house, hut, cabin' is doubtless a loanword, most probably from Iranian *kata- < *kn̥-ta-, a participle of Iranian *kan- 'dig'.
PS *xata is a loanword from Iranic. [The exact source is disputable].
S.v. Da. spise (vb.) 'eat', from spise (n.) 'something one can eat', a loan from Middle Low German, in turn from Medieval Latin spesa from Classical Latin expensa (pecunia).
Cf. s.v. ON spiza 'speisen' (NNw. spissa 'gut essen', NSw. spisa, NDa. spise) < MLG spīsen to spīse 'essen' < MLat. spesa 'ausgabe' < Lat. expensa.
S.v. borð (2) 'brett, speisetisch' following {ref IEW} 136 to a root *bʰerdʰ- 'schneiden', cf. OE bardha-ka- 'abschneidend', Gk. πέρθω 'zerstöre'.
Cf. s.v. ?*bʰerdʰ- 'erbeuten, einnehmen' (IEW 138), only Greek lexical material discussed.
S.v. ON frykta 'befrachten' based on a loanword from MLG (cf. vrucht, vracht 'fracht, last')

S.v. aidu- 'feu, ardeur', a word that may be adduced from the name of a Gaulish tribe, Aedui < *aidu̯oi, which could be understood as 'les Ardents'; thematisation of aidu 'fire' comparable to OIr. aed 'feu'. An old IE word *aidh- 'feu', cf. Lat. aedēs 'foyer, pièce où l'on fait le feu, temple, maison', Gk. αἶθος 'incendie', Lith. íesmē (< *aidh-smi̯ā) 'bois à brûler', Skt. édha- 'id.', etc.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *dimma- 'dark'; s.v. *dumbōn- 'fog, haze' (> ON dumba 'dust, cloud of dust', Elfd. dumba 'fog, haze', a zero-grade formation to the strong verb dimban- ~ *dimpan- 'to fog')
Cf. s.v. ON dimma (1) 'finsternis' (> NSw. dimma 'dünner nebel', dial. dimba 'dampf'), ON dimmr 'dunkel', ON dumba 'staub, staubwolke' (> NSw. dial. dumba 'nebel, dunst').

S.v. Gmc. *merkʷa- 'dunkel', with derived nominal in ON myrkvi 'Finsternis, Dunkelheit, dichter Nebel', mjǫrkvi 'id.'. Only North and North Sea Germanic, no precise correspondences outside of Germanic but derived from a root *mergʷ- which may be compared to Lith. márgas 'bunt', mirgė́ti 'glitzern, flackern'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *merkwu- 'dark', from PIE *mergʷ- (cf. Hitt. Markuu̯ai̯a- 'deities in the depth of the earth', CLuw. maru̯ai- 'black, dark' < *m(o)rgʷ-oi-, Lith. mirgė́ti, Latv. mirdzet 'to twinkle' < *mrgʷ-eh₁-, Ru. morgát' 'to wink, blink', Alb. mjergullē 'nebula' < *mergʷ-l-eh₂.

Cf. s.v. NHG diesig 'dunstig', a borrowing from Low German sailor-language. Cf. Low German disig, dialectal Dutch dijzig, Modern Danish diset, Modern Swedish disig, North Frisian dīs. Cf. Middle Low German disinge 'Nebelwetter'. No clear comparisons. Perhaps with the loss of the nasal and compensatory lengthening from Germanic *ϸemsa- 'dunkel' (with variant *ϸemza-?). Cf. {ref Heidermanns 1993}:619.
Polish polować 'hunt' (along Russian polevat', Ukrainian polûvati and Belarusian palâvac') is derived from *poľe 'field' (PIE *pel- 'even, broad'). The original meaning was 'hunt in fields'.
Ukrainian polûvati is derived from pole 'field'.
Belarusian palâvac' is derived from pole 'field'.
S.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.) with OCS *poľe 'field' listed as a reflex.
Kashubian jachta 'hunt', jachtowac 'to hunt' is a loanword from German, cf. German Jagd, Middle German jacht.
Russian oxota, dialectal oxvota is derived from xotet', xoču ['want'].

PS *xotěti ['want'] is most probably related *xvatati 'catch, take'. The *xvot- grade, PS *xotěti would be directly derived from, has not been attested elsewhere. The further etymology is obscure. It can be derived from an expressive form of the pronominal root *su̯e- (cf. PS *svojĭ ['one's own'], as to the semantic development cf. Russian prisvoit' 'grab').

PS *xotěti does not have any convincing etymology. The hypothesis that is was derived from original *xvotěti, related to chvátat ['catch', *xvatati], is problematic due to a weak attestation of *xvo- (only in Russian dialectal ochvota 'desire').

PS *ledŭ is related to Lithuanian lẽdas, ledùs, Latvian ļedus and Old Prussian ladis 'ice'. Further etymology is obscure, the existing hypotheses are inconvincing. [See p. 92 for a overview of the existing comparisons.]
Cf. s.v. Alb. márdh/ë, -a 'Frost', an old word for 'Frost', which can be identical with OCS mrazъ 'Frost', cf. IEW 740 *merg̑- 'morschen', alternatively from *morg̑⁽ʰ⁾-.
PS *morzŭ 'frost' and *mĭrznǫti 'freeze' are related to Albanian marth 'frost' etc. and derived from PIE *merg̑-.

Cf. s.v. Alb. mardhë 'chill, frost, ice', etymologically identical with Slav. *morzъ 'frost' (cf. Meyer 1891:260), both continuing *merg̑ʰ- 'to rot, to soak'. Derivative verbs: mardh 'to chill, to freeze', mërdhij 'id.'.
PS *biti is derived from PIE *bhei̯ə-.

PS *kolěno is doubtless related to Lithuanian kelỹs, Latvian celis 'knee', Greek κῶλον 'limb' and κωλήν 'thighbone'.
A strict semantic and formal discrimination between reflexes of PIE *kel- 'rise, lift' and PIE *kʷel- 'turn (round), spin' is problematic even in languages that make a distinction between PIE *k and *kʷ.

PS *kolěno is related to Lithuanian kelỹs, Latvian celis 'knee', Greek κῶλον 'joint', Latin collum 'neck', German Hals 'neck' etc. All these words are derived from PIE *kʷel- 'turn, twist'. The etymological meaning is 'movable, bending part of the body'.
PS *ezero, *ezerŭ is a reflex of PIE *eg̑ʰ-er-o- or *ag̑ʰ-er-o (cf. PS *ězŭ 'dam').
It is a loan from Turkish göl 'lake'.
PS *smĭjǫ sę, smijati sę is derived from PIE *smei̯- 'laugh' and related to Old Indic smáyate 'laugh'.
S.v. Ved. √darh- 'festigen, fest sein, stark sein', cf. OAv. dīdərəžō 'du begehrst zu festigen', YAv. darəziieiti 'fesselt, bindet fest'. The origin of IIr. *d⁽ʰ⁾arjʰ- is unexplained.
проблематична связь с тадж., перс. saxt
From base sā- 'to cut', sāta- 'cut, smoothed, even'
Cf. s.v. PIr. saH- 'to whet, cut' < PIE *k̑eh₃- 'to sharpen, whet' (cf. Lat. cōs 'whetstone', OIr. cath 'wise', Arm. sur 'sharp', ON hein 'whetstone'.

PS *listŭ is probably a back formation from PS *listati 'to foliate, frondescent'. Taking into account Lithuanian laĩškas 'letter', one can assume that -sk- and -st- are verbal suffixes. Lithuanian laĩškas < *loi-sk- and Slavic *listŭ < *lei-st- are derived from PIE *lei- 'let (out), exsert (sprout, leaf)'.
PS *listŭ is derived from PIE *lei̯s-to- 'leaf'.
PS *listŭ is somehow related to Lithuanian laĩškas, even though it is not possible to reconstruct one single protoform. Maybe these word are different derivations from PIE *lei- 'sprout leaves'.
S.v. prič 'червь', 'гусеница'.
PS *šujĭ is derived from PIE seu̯i̯o- 'left'.
PS *lěvŭ is related to Latin laevus 'left', also 'bended', Greek λαιός < λαιϝός 'left' and Lithuanian iš-laivóti 'screw' and derived from PIE *laiu̯o- 'bended'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. nãgas 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf' (BSl. Latv. nags 'Finder- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf', OPr. mage 'Fuß'), from PIE *h₃nógʷʰ-/*h₃n̥gʷʰ- 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle' (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ, -υχος, Lat. unguis, OIr. ingen, ON nagl, OE nægel, etc.).
S.v. NHG reiben (MHG rīben, OHG rīban, MLG (w)riven, MDu. writven, NWFr. wriuwe, based on pre-German *wreib-a- (str.vb.). Outside of Germanic corresponds to Gk. ῥίπτω 'werfen'.

Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥίπτω 'to throw, hurl, thrust, bolt'. Based on a root *(ϝ)ριπ- within Ancient Greek. No clear etymology outside of Greek; formally matches MLG wrīven 'to rub, wipe, scour, draw', MHG rīben 'to turn rubbing' (IEW 1159), but the semantic gap is considerable.

PS *krokŭ / *korkŭ / *korakŭ is probably related to Lithuanian kárka 'part of pig's leg, horse's ankle, part of insect's leg' and maybe also to Albanian krahë 'hand, arm' and Old Indic kiṣku- 'forearm'. The Slavic lexeme is probably ultimately derived from PIE *(s)ker- bend, twist, turn' with an original meaning 'bending, movable part of the body'. The reasons of the PS formal variety is hard to determine.

S.v. AGk. ῥίπτω 'jeter violemment, brandir, jeter à bas, arracher'. Etymology obscure. The forms go back to a root *ϝριπ- with a present suffix -ye/o-; {ref IEW} 1159 supposes *wrī-p- and a connection to Germanic lexemes meaning 'frotter, tourner' in OHG rīban, MHG rīben, MLG wrīven.
Albanian krah, krahë 'arm, shoulder, side' is borrowed from Slavic *krajĭ 'end, side, extremity'.

Lithuanian kárka 'part of pig's or sheep's leg, front leg of pig with scapula, horse's ankle' is related to PS *korkŭ and *krokŭ. The etymology is not entirely clear. It has been linked to PIE *(s)ker- 'bend'. The etymological meaning would be then 'bending part of the body'.
Lithuanian kárti 'hang' is derived from PIE *kerH-, cf. Old English heorr, Old Norse hjarri 'door wing'. If one would assume an s-mobile here, a link to PIE *skerH- 'split off, hang off' would be possible.
S. v. kiṣkuḥ, a relationship to Albanian krahë ist not certain. No Slavic cognates listed.

PS *noga is derived from PIE *onogh- (: *ongh-, *nogh-, n̥gh-) and related to Lithuanian nagas 'fingernail', Latvian nags 'fingernail, claw', Old High German nagal 'fingernail', Old Irish ingen 'fingernail', Latin unguis 'fingernail', Greek ὄνυξ 'fingernail, claw' etc.
It was originally a collective noun with a meaning 'a set of nails/claws' (>'paw, hoof'>'leg, foot').

PS *noga is derived from PIE *onogh- (: *ongh-, *nogh-, n̥gh-) and related to Lithuanian nagas 'fingernail', Latvian nags 'fingernail, claw', Old High German nagal 'fingernail', Old Irish ingen 'fingernail', Latin unguis 'fingernail', Greek ὄνυξ 'fingernail, claw' etc.
It was originally a collective noun with a meaning 'a set of nails/claws' (>'paw, hoof'>'leg, foot').
It is a loanword from New High German laben.
S.v. *ętro. The word is derived from *en-tr-o-m, cf. Old Indic antrám, Armenian ənderk', Greek ἔντερα 'guts'.
Russian pečen' (cf. Ukrainian pečìnka 'liver' and Polish pieczeń 'roast') is derived from peku, peč' ['bake, fry, roast']. Originally it referred to 'roasted liver'.
PIE *kirno- or *kirsno-.
PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush' is derived from PIE *dʰrebʰ- and related to Gothic ga-draban 'cut off, gouge'.

PS *drobiti 'crumble, crush' with Gothic gadraban 'cut out' listed as a cognate ("unnless this is a mistake for gagraban"). "LIV (153) reconstructs *dʰreb- on the basis of Germanic forms such as OIc. drepa ‘beat, kill’, OHG treffan ‘hit’. Since this proto-form is in conflict with Winter’s law, I reconstruct *dʰrobʰ-eie- for Slavic. The discrepancy between Slavic and Germanic may have something to do with the fact that the etymon is of non-Indo-European origin or Kluge’s law may have played a role".

PS *drobŭ (with meaning 'guts' in many Slavic languages and dialects) is derived from PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush'. PIE *dhrebh-, cf. Greek τρέφω 'make dense, make clotted' and Gothic (ga)draban 'gouge, cut out'.

PG *draban 'to hew', cf. Gothic ga-draban 'chip, hew out' < *dʰróbʰ-e- and OCS drobiti 'crumle, chop, break' < *dʰrobʰ-eie-. The root is Germanic-Slavic.
PG *drepan 'to hit': "A back-formation to the iterative *drupp/bōn 1, a zero-grade variant of *drapp/bōn (q.v.). As both iteratives were derived from the strong verb *draban 'to hew' < *dʰróbʰ-e-, the strong verb *drepan- cannot be used to reconstruct a Pre-Gm. formation *dʰréb-e- with root-final *b, as traditionally assumed (cf. LIV²: 153). The late, internally-Germanic origin of the *p further speaks against the assumption of a non-Indo-European loanword [...]".

?dʰreb- 'hit, push' with Old High German treffan 'hit' und OCS drobljǫ, drobiti 'shatter, crush' listed as cognates (however, the autors point that the Slavic and Germanic meanings are not very close). Gothic ga-draban is most probably a mistake of the writer (instead of ga-graban). The lack of Winter's lengthening in Slavic can be caused by the inter-vocalic position of -b-.
*dʰrebʰ- 'clot, sediment' with Greek τρέφω 'make dense, make clotted' listed as a cognate.

Russian potroh, potroha, Ukrainian potruh, potruhy 'guts, giblets' etc. are derived from PS *troxa 'mite, driblet'.
PS *troxa does notd have any certain etymology. It can be related to PS *troska 'sliver, splinter'.
PS *troska is probably derived from an unattested *troskati 'burst, crack', probably related to Polish trzaskać 'crack'.
Polish trzaskać < PS 'trěskati 'make a dry, sharp sound, crack (by breaking of a hard thing), hit strongly' has an ideophonic origin a was probably derived from an interjection as *trěsŭ (cf. Polish dialectal trzas!, Bulgarian trjas!).
Russian potroh is apparently related with Polish trocha, trochę 'a bit' etc.

PS *troxa is morphologically and etymologically obscure. However, it can be possibly linked to *troska, *trěska, *trěskati. One had to assume a metathesis sk>ks(>x) then, cf. Lithuanian trekšė́ti 'crack'.
PS *trěskati is related to Lithuanian trekšė́ti 'crack', Gothic þriskan 'thresh', German dreschen 'thresh', English thrash, thresh. All these words are derived from PIE *tre-sk-, which can have an ideophonic origin or be derived from PIE *ter- 'rub'.

S.v. NHG Darm (MHG darm, OHG darm, OS tharm), from Gmc. *ϸarma- 'Darm', also in ON ϸarmr, OE ϸearm, OFr. therm. This can be compared with Greek τόρμος 'Zapfen, Loch, Radnabe' etc. and further to IE *ter- 'drehen, reiben, bohren'; the original meaning would be 'Loch'.
S.v. NHG Germ. hart (MHG herte, OHG hart, from PGmc. *hardu- 'hart' (also Goth. hardus, ON harðr, OE heard).

S.v. Gmc. *hardu- 'hart, rauh'. The word is formally identical to Lith. kàrtus 'bitter (schmeckend)', CSl. kratъ-kъ 'kurz' (PIE *kortú-), cf. also Lat. curtus 'verkürzt, verstümmelt', Ved. kaṭu- 'scharf, beißend'.  In Germanic the original meaning of the adjective as 'rough, harsh' is confirmed though MLG hart 'scharfer, anhaltender (Ost)wind', MHG 'Schneekruste, fester Sandboden'. The semantic comparison with the Balto-Slavic lexemes is possible through assuming a basic meaning 'cutting'. The comparison with Gk. κρατύς 'stark, mächtig' is less likely because of formal and semantic difficulties, likewise the proposed connection to a root *kar- 'rauh' is simply a root etymology.
PS *vŭšĭ (< *(u̯)ŭxĭ- < *(u̯)ŭsĭ-) is a taboo deformation of PIE lŭs-, cf. German Laus, Welsh llau etc. Various deformations appear also in other languages, e.g. Latvian uts etc.

PS *mǫžĭ is related to Old Indic manu-, manus-, Old High German mann etc. and derived from PIE *manu-(s) or *monu-(s) 'man', further probably from *men- 'think'. The exact protoform for Slavic is *mon-g-i̯o-.
It is a compound of *čelo- (cf. kiltìs 'tribe') and věkŭ (cf. Lithuanian vaĩkas 'child').
It is a loanword from Middle German kerl 'man'.

PS *xolpŭ has been compared to Gothic halbs- 'half', Slavic xolstŭ, xolkŭ, Lithuanian šel̃pti, šelpiù 'help', Old Indic jálpati 'gibber', jālmás 'dastard', Lithuanian sil̃pnas 'weak', German Schalk 'scoundrel', Greek σκόλοψ 'sharp pale', Russian paholok and holit'. All these comparisons are unreliable.
PS xolpŭ is not entirely clear. It can be related to pachole derived from PS *xoliti 'take care' (with no certain further etymology). However, suffix -p(ŭ) is unusual.
PS *xolpŭ without certain further etymology. It is maybe derived from PS *xoliti 'embosom, encompass' > 'take care, nurture, clean' with a rare suffix *-p(ŭ). Other explanations are less reliable.

Many existing analyses of PS *xolpŭ claim that a morphological interpretatiion as *xol-p(ŭ) is dubious as a suffix -p- does not exist in PS and PIE. However, this suffix does exist. PS *xolpŭ is also related to PS *xolkŭ, *xolstŭ, *pa-xolŭ and *xoliti.
PS *xolstŭ 'unmarried'. Meanings of the related lexemes (PS *xolkŭ, *xolstŭ, *pa-xolŭ and *xoliti) point to the etymological meaning 'to shear, to barber'. For the semantic development cf. Greek κόρος, κοῦρος 'boy, son', κόρη 'girl' and κείρω 'to shear, to barber', τριχοκουρία 'ceremonial hair-cutting by juveniles'.
PS *xolkŭ 'unmarried'. Along the related lexemes it does not have paralells beyond Slavic. The PIE root is *ksol- / *skol-.
PS *xoliti is derived from PIE *ksol- < *ks- 'scratch', cf. Old Indic kṣāláyati 'wash, clean' and Lithuanian skaláuti 'wash, flush'.
PS *męso < PIE *mēms- / meməs.
PS *měsęcĭ < *mē(n)s-en-ko. The ultimate root is *mē- 'to measure'.
PS *luna is derived from *luxna < *louk-sn-ā, cf. Latin lūna (< *louxnā), Avestan raoχšna, Old Prussian lauxnos and Old High German liehsen.
It is a loanword from Middle German mân 'moon'.
Polish księżyc 'moon' is derived from PS *kŭnęgŭ 'ruler, duke, regnant'. PS *kŭnęgŭ is a loanword from Germanic *kuningaz 'king', cf. Old High German kuning and German König.
It is a derivative from PS *kŭnęgŭ 'ruler, duke, regnant', a loanword from Germanic *kuningaz, cf. German König.
PS *gora is derived from PIE *gʷer- and related to Old Indic girí- 'mountian', Avestan gairi- 'mountian', Lithuanian girià 'forest' and Albanian gur 'rock'.
S.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.) with OCS *poľe 'field' listed as a reflex.
PS *palninā is derived from PIE *pel- / *pol-, and related to Icelandic fell, fjall 'mountain', German Feld 'field', Latin planus 'flat' and Lithuanian plonas 'thin'.

PS *usta is derived from PIE *ōu̯s-t- / *əu̯s-t-, a derivative from PIE *ōu̯s- 'mouth', and related to Old Prussian austo 'mouth', Lithuanian uostà, úostas 'estuary, bay', Latvian uosts, uōsta 'harbor, bay', Latin ōstium 'door, entrance', Old Indic ṓṣtha- 'lip', Avestan aošta 'lip', further to Latin ōs, ōris, Old Indic ā́ḥ and Avestan āh- 'mouth'.
*reu̯H- 'tear (up)' with OCS rŭvǫ, rŭvati 'tear' and ryjǫ, ryti 'dig' given as cognates.
It is most probably related to ryt' ['dig'] and rylo ['snout'].
PS *rŭtŭ is derived f *reu-, *reuə-, *rū̆- 'dig, tear, churn up'. Cf. also another derivatives like Russian rylo 'snout' or Polish ryj 'snout'.
There is no commonly accepted etymology. It has been linked to PS *ryti 'dig', Serbo-Croat rupa 'hole', Kashubian retk 'sandbar, bay, puddle' and German Rüssel 'snout.'
PS *rŭtŭ is derived from PIE *h₃er- 'move forward, raise' [for reflexes of this root see {ref LIV²}: 299-300].

PS *rŭtŭ is often linked to PS *ryti ['dig']. However, it is semantically not convincing. It is rather derived from PIE *(e)r-eu- 'raise'. The original meaning were 'something raised' (> 'tip, top' > 'beak' > 'mouth').

Russian guba 'lip' (cf. Ukrainian guba 'mouth', Czech huba (older húba) 'mouth', Polisk gęba 'mouth, snout', Upper Sorbian huba 'mouth' etc.) is probably related to Greek γαμβαί, γαμφηλαί 'cheekbone' and Lithuanian gémbė 'nail' (originally 'blade, protrusion).
Russian guba (modern stess gu'ba, older 'guba) 'sponge, mushroom' (cf. Ukrainian guba 'tree-fungus', OCS gǫba 'sponge', Serbo-Croat guba 'leprosy', Czech houba 'sponge, mushroom', Polish gąbka 'sponge') is related to Lithuanian gum̃bas, gumbras 'bump, burl', gum̃bulas 'gland', gùmulas 'clod', Old Icelandic kumpr 'bump', Afgan ɣumba 'bump' and Middle Persian gumbad, gubmað 'bulg'.
It is also possible that both words have a common origin.

"I have adopted the widespread view that *gǫba 'tree-fungus' and *gǫba 'lip, mouth' are etymologically identical, the latter being secondary. Formally there are no problems. In the case of Cz. huba and houba we may be dealing with differentiation resulting from the generalization of either the short or the long variant of the root (the long variant originated from the so-called "Czech lengthening", see Kortlandt 1975a: 19). The connection with Gk. σπόγγος, σφόγγος  'sponge' is formally very difficult."

PS *gǫba 'mouth, snout' is usually linked to homonymic PS *gǫba '' on grounds of common semantic features ('something soft, swelled etc.'). Some authors, however, assume a relationship to Greek γαμφαί 'jawbone' (PIE *ghambh-).
PS *gǫba ['sponge, mushroom'] is related to Lithuanian gum̃bas 'protuberance'. It is sometimes linked also to Latin fungus, Greek σπόγγος and German Schwamm. However, it is problematic phonetically. A reconstruction *(s)gʷombʰo- is very uncertain.

PS *gǫba 'soft excresence on a human, animal body or on a plant', 'mushroom, also growing on trees'. The meanings 'lip, snout, mouth' are metaphoric. Its exact analogue is Latvian gum̃ba 'excresence, bump', cf. also Lithuanian gum̃bas 'protrusion, excresence'. These words are derived from PIE *gʰeu̯b(ʰ)- '' with a nasal infix. The original meaning was 'something protuberant'.

Upper Sorbian huba 'mouth' has the same origin as hubica 'tree-fungus, sponge'. PS *gǫba is related to Lithuanian gum̃bas and Latvian gum̃ba. It is derived from a nasalised variant (*gu-m-b-) of PIE *geu̯b 'bend'. Another forms of that root prestent in Slavic are *gŭb-, *ɡub-, *ɡyb-.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *(H)spar(H)ǰ- 'to break, burst open (of plants), ?release (sound), bloom, blossom, sprout', from PIE *sperh₂g- 'to crack, burst open, sprout'? (cf. Skt. sphūrj- 'to rumble, roar, thunder, crash; to burst forth', Lith. sprógti 'to burst; to open, blossom out', Lith. spùrgas 'sprout, offshoot, bud', Lat. spargō 'I scatter, sow, spread', OE spranca 'twig').
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *spaič- (*spaiǰ) 'to shine; to bloom'. "The root appears to be Iranian, with no further IE cognate forms. It may have ended in a originally voiced velar consonant"

S.v. Proto-Iranic *stamb(H)- 'to withstand, be stiff, stern, unmoving' (MMP ʿstft, BMP stpt /staft/ 'hard; firm, strong, cruel; savage, fierce', from PIE *stembʰ(H)- 'to be firm, unmoving', vel sim. (cf. Ved. stambhⁱ 'to support, prop up', Lith. stem̃bti 'to oppose', Gk. ἀστεμφής 'unshakable', TochA ṣtäm, B stäm 'to stand').

The meanings 'mushroom' and 'lip' are doubtless related and the latter developed from the former (probably it referred originally to puckered lips of eldery people, cf. analogous phenomena in the semantic development of *gribŭ 'mushroom'). PS *gǫba is also related to *guba, a lexeme referring to different kinds of 'pleatings' and 'bends'. Both lexemes belong to verbal roots *gub-, *gŭb-, *ɡyb- 'bend, fold'. Comparisons to Lithuanian gum̃bas and Latvian gum̃ba are correct, the relationship, however, is probably not direct. The words can be deformations of an older form present in Greek σπόγγος, σφόγγος, Latin fungus (that is probably a loan from Greek) and German Schwamm. However, it is often assumed that these lexemes are derived from a wanderwort.
?*gʰeu̯bʰ- 'bend'.

The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian nagùtis 'claw, fingernail' and further to Old High German nagal, Old Icelandic nagl, negl, Old Irish ingen, Latin unguis, Greek ὄνυξ, Old Indic áṅghriḥ and nakhám etc.
Polish miano, dialectal miono and Slovincian mjʉ̀ɵ̯nɵ (along with Polish imię, imienia and archaic imiono) are listed among reflexes of PS *jĭmę.
Polish miano, dialectal miono and Slovincian mjʉ̀ɵ̯nɵ (along with Polish imię, imienia, archaic imiono, Slovincian ï̂mją Kashubian jiḿą) are listed among reflexes of PS *jĭmę.

Polish miano (with derivatives as mianować 'appoint, name', wzmianka 'a mention', nadmienić 'mention, drop a hint', wymienić 'list, enumerate, mention') is related to German meinen ['think, mean']. It has nothing in common with imię (and miono).
Polish miano and Kashubian miono are listed (along with imię and jimiã) as cognates of Upper Sorbian mjeno and reflexes of PS *jĭmę. However, the autor mentions an alternative etymology of miano.

Cf. s.v. ON manneskja 'mensch' an umlaut-less secondary formation to mannr after the example of adjectives like saxneskr. In contrast to this the dialectal Norwegian menniskja, New Swedish människa, New Danish menneske must be a loan from West Germanic because of the umlaut (cf. OFr. menniska). It is possible that manniska is a new formation based on a loanword.

S.v. ON ýta 'aussetzen, ausstossen' (< Germ. ūtian) (cf. OE ytan, ūtian 'vertreiben, verbannen', OFr. ūtia, OHG ūzōn 'ausschließen'. Denominal to út 'hinaus' (cf. Ved. ud- 'hinauf, hinaus' Gk. (Cypr.) ὑ-, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *úd- 'empor, hinauf; hinaus' (Adverb, lokal). See p.824 s.v. Adverbiale Ableitungen PIE *ū̆́d-na > Proto-Germanic *ūta- 'aus, hinaus' whence Goth. ūt, ON út, OHG uz.
Polish miano is listed among reflexes of PS *jĭmę, *jĭmene with an additional reconstructed form *jĭměn-.

Polish miano, miono and Kashubian miono (cf. Upper Sorbian mjeno, Old Czech meno, méno, Slovak meno) are reflexes of West Slavic *měno 'name'. It was derived from PS *měniti 'call, give a name'. This lexeme was contaminated by forms of the synonymic PS *jĭmę (*-e- instead of *-ě- in older Polish miono and Kashubian miono).
PS *měniti 'think, mean, understand, consider, call, give a name' is related to German meinen 'think, say' and derived from PIE *mei̯-no- 'opinion, view, intention'.

S.v. Gmc. *trek-a- 'ziehen', probably belonging to the complex of variants related to Germanic *drag-a-. The gemination of -k- > -kk- probably originated in a North Sea Germanic dialect, similarly to bak-a- and skrekk-a-.

S.v. Gmc. *skrep-a- 'schaben', to a root *(s)kreb- (cf. Latv. skrabt 'kratzen, schaben, mießeln, aushöhlen', Ru. skresti, skrbu 'kratzen, schaben'; without s-mobile W crafu 'kratzen, reiben', Lith. krapštýti 'kratzen, scharren, reiben').
S.v. W crafaf: crafu, to be connected with English scrape from a root *(s)ker-.
PS *ǫzŭkŭ is derived from PIE *ang̑ʰ- 'narrow', cf. German eng, Latin angustis, Old Indic aṁhús etc.
PS *těsnŭ (< *těsknŭ < *toi̯sk-no) is related *tiskati 'squeeze, press'. It is ultimately derived from PIE *tei̯sk- 'squeeze, press'.

PS *těsnъ is derived from *tiskati. It was derived from PIE *tḗh₂isk-, ultimately from *tah₂- 'melt, dissolve'. IE cognates are Ossetic tayun 'thaw, melt', Welsh tawdd 'liquefy', Breton tuezi 'melt, smelt', Latin tābēre, tābēscere 'melt, wilt', Greek tḗkō 'melt'. Cf. also PS *tajati 'thaw'.
*teh₂- 'melt, thaw' with OCS tajati 'thaw' and Welsh tawdd 'melt' listed as cognates.

S.v. OIr. buide 'yellow' (most unmarked form for 'yellow'). OIr. buide may derive from either Proto-Goidelic *bodio- or *badio-. There are no certain correspondences in Brythonic, but perhaps Gaulish bodio- in Bodio-casses may belong here. The word is generally compared with Lat. badius 'kastanienbraun', without further correspondences. From this comparison three etymologies have been proposed: (1) OIr. buide, Lat. badius < PIE *badios ({ref IEW} 92), where the correspondence of the root vowel (Lat. -a-, Celt. -o-) remains unexplained (but there are parallels in, e.g. Lat. lacus, OIr. loch); (2) OIr. buide, Lat. badius < PIE (Italo-Celtic?) *bodio- ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B-113) with *-o- > Lat. -a- as in Lat. mare < PIE *mori- 'sea'; (3) {ref de Bernardo Stempel 1999}:358 suggests Proto-Celtic *ba-dyo- < PIE *bʰə-dyo- to the root *bʰā- / *bʰō- / *bʰə- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen (cf. {ref IEW} 104f.), in which case the Celtic word would be borrowed into Latin. In this case however the Gaulish attestation of the form Bodio- would be in need of an explanation.
S.v. Goth. A27 *af-skiuban 'ἀπώσασθαι', 'reject' (OE sceofan, OHG scioban 'shove', etc.), to PIE *skewb(h)- 'throw, shove' (cf. Lith. skùbti 'begin to hurry' CS skubǫ 'pluck').
S.v. Gmc. *skeub-a- 'schieben'. "Gm. skeub-a-, trans. 'schieben' hat keine überzeugende Vergleichsmöglichkeit."

S.v. Gmc. *skeut-a- 'schießen', probably doesn't belong to skeud- 'eilen, treiben', but rather to *sk̑eu- 'schießen, eilen' only otherwise securely attested in Baltic (Lith. šáuju, šáuti 'schießen, schnell laufen'). Less certain is the connection to OCS isunǫti 'herausziehen, zücken (Waffe)' sovati vъnъ 'überschäumen'.
S.v. Goth. W27 *walus 'ῥάβδος', 'staff'. To PIE *wel- 'turn'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *walu- 'lump; staff' < *u̯olh₁-u- (cf. Lith. ap-valùs 'round' < *u̯olh₁-u-). The word has sometimes been connected to Lat. vallum 'palisade' < *ueh₂l-so-, Gk. ἧλος 'nail' < *uh₂l-so-, but Faroese vølur 'lump, tumor, growth; steering pole' shows that the original meaning was 'something round'.
Cf. s.v. 2. *u̯elH- '(sich) walzen, wallen' [IEW 1140-3].
S.v. ON pinni 'stift, pflock, nagel'.

S.v Goth. B5 bagms 'δένδρον', 'tree', precise etymology difficult, but assumed to be connected to PIE *bʰeu̯- with a laryngeal extension (cf. Gk. φῦμα 'growth', Skt. bhū́ma 'being, earth'. Other hypotheses such as mixture with reflexes of *bagʰ- or relationship with Skt. bahúṣ 'arm' are dubious.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ƀaʒmaz ~ *ƀaʒnaz, an irregular phonetic transformation of *ƀaumaz 'beam' and further connected with PIE *bheu- 'to grow', cf. Gk. φῦμα 'growth', bhū́man- 'being, world, earth'.
S.v. Goth. L33 leitils 'μικρός', 'little'. No etymology.

Cf. s.v. NHG Dampf (MHG dampf, tampf, OHG dampf, MLG damp, MDu. damp), from Gmc. *dampi- 'Ausdünstung, Dampf', considered to a be a labial extension of the same root also found in OHG toum 'Dampf, Dunst' and with s-mobile OE stēam, NE steam (cf. Lat. fūmus < *dʰūmo-), based on a meaning 'blasen, fauchen' (cf. similarly Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen, schnuppern', with labial extension dùmples 'Blasebalg').
S.v. Proto-Germanic *dampa- 'vapour', derived from PGmc. *dimban- ~ *dimpan- 'to fog' < PIE *dʰembʰ-e-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *đampaz, based on strong verb *đempanan > MHG dimpfen 'to steam, to smoke', and related to Lith. dùmpti 'to blow'. ({ref IEW} 247-248 to Skt. dhámati 'to blow').
PS *pǫpŭkŭ is related to Lithuanian pam̃pti, pampstù 'swell', Latvian pàmpt 'swell', Latin pampinus 'wine leaves' etc. and derived from a ideophonic PIE root *pamp- 'blow, swell'.
Lithuanian pam̃pti 'swell' has an ideophonic oriɡin, exactly as Latvian paupt 'swell'. [No Slavic cognates listed.]
PS *blizŭ is derived from PIe *bʰlei̯g̑(ʰ)- 'beat'.
PS *šĭja 'neck, back of neck' has no certain etymology.

PS *šija 'back of the neck' is most probably related to PS *šiti 'sew', cf. Czech vaz ['neck, back, ligament'] and vázat 'tie'. PS *šiti 'sew' is derived from PIE *si̯ū- 'sew' and related to Latin suere, Old Indic sī́vyati, English sew etc.
PS *šija is probably derived from PS *šiti 'sew'. If this etymology is correct, its etymological meanigs is 'part of body that ties head with thorax'.
*si̯eu̯H- 'sew'.

Bulgarian vrat is related to v"rtâ 'turn'. The etymological meaning is 'movable, turning part of body'. It is related to Lithuanian verčiù, ver̃sti 'turn', German werden 'become', Latin vertō 'turn', Old Indic vartate 'turn'. The PIE protoform is *wer-t-.
PS *vortŭ < *PIE *u̯órto- 'turning' is derived from PIE *u̯er-t- 'turn'. As to the semantic development cf. Latin collus, Gothic hals etc., all derived from PIE *kʷel- 'turn'.
Cf. s.v. *u̯ert- 'sich umdrehen' (IEW 1156-8).
PS *kŭrkŭ is related to Old Indic kŕ̥kāta- 'cervical vertebrae' and Gaelic cricon 'throat' and derived from PIE *kr̥ko-, ultimately from PIE *(s)ker-k- 'turn (around).
PS *kŭrkŭ is related to Old Indic kŕ̥kāta- and Gaelic cricon 'throat' and derived from PIE *kr̥ko-, ultimately from PIE *(s)ker-k- 'turn (around).

PS *kŭrkŭ is most probably a reflex of PIE *kr̥ko- (cf. Old Indic  kŕ̥kātam and Gaelic cricon 'throat'). Taking into account that lexemes for 'neck' are often derived from the meaning 'turn', it can be related to PS PS *kŭrčiti. The PIE root protoform *kr̥k- is expressive, its further linking to PIE *(s)ker- 'cut' is speculative.
This lexeme is etymologically obscure.
PS *vyja. Its further etymology is obscure.
Cf. s.v. *u̯eh₂- 'sich wenden' (IEW –). Cf. n1 "Vgl. ursl. vyja f. 'Hals' < *u̯h₂-i̯eh₂- 'Drehung, s. Reinart, MSS 49 (1988) 97-100.", cf. Hittite wēhzi. wahhuweni 'turn (over)'.
S.v. PS *novŭ(jĭ).
S.v. PS *noktĭ.
S.v. PS *nosŭ.
S.v. PS *ne, *ně.
PS *starŭ is derived from PIE *stā-ro- and directly related to Lithuanian stóras 'thick' and Old Icelandic stórr 'huge, strong, important, male'. The same root is found in PS *stati 'stand'.
S.v. PS *edinŭ / *edĭnŭ.
It is a compound of *čelo- (cf. kiltìs 'tribe') and věkŭ (cf. Lithuanian vaĩkas 'child').
*h₁leu̯dʰ- 'rise, grow' with OCS ľudĭje listed as a cognate.

PS *ľudŭ, *ľudĭ, *ľuda, *ľudo, *lŭdĭje is related to Latvian, ļàudis Lithuanian liáudis, German Leute 'people' etc. and derived from PIE *leu̯dʰ- (cf. also Gothic liudan, Sanskrit rṓdhati, Greek εἰλήλουθα etc. 'grow').
Slovene špilati 'play' is a loanword from Middle High German spilen.

The etymology is obscure. It has been (unconvincing) linked to Russian gul 'buzz' (etymologically unclear itself), Serbo-Croat gúliti 'booze' (etymologically unclear itself) and Lithuanian guliù, gulė́ti 'lie down'.
There is no commonly accepted etymology.
It is probably derived from an interjection hu-la! hul!
PS *guľati is derived from PS *guliti. These verbs are related to PS *golŭ ['naked'] which is, ultimately, derived from PIE *gʰel- 'shine'.
PS dialectal *guľati 'play, dance, sing, have fun, rave' is, probably, ultimately derived from PIE *gou̯(ə)- 'shout, call', cf. also Polish gaworzyć, gwarzyć 'chat, babble'.

The original meaning of PS *jĭgra was most probably 'singing with dancing'. It looks archaic has no phonetic variants suggesting a late derivation. It has been linked to Old Indic yájati 'enshrine a deity' and Greek ἅɡιος 'sacred'. A formal issue is that a reconstruction with *-g̑- for these words is probable. A centum-reflex in Slavic can be, however, a result of the context next to *-r-. PIE *i̯aɡ- / *iɡ- / *i̯eɡ- / *i̯əɡ-.

S.v. BITTER *h₂em-ro-s 'bitter, sour' (IEW 777-778: *om-): Lat. amārus 'bitter', ON apr 'sharp, hard, cold', OE ampre 'sorrel, dock', OHG ampfaro 'sorrel, dock', Alb. ëmbël 'sweet' (Tosk), tëmbël 'gall', Arm. amok' 'sweet', OInd. amlá- 'sour', from *h₂em- 'raw, bitter'.

Cf. s.v. BITTER *h₂em-ro-s 'bitter, sour' (IEW 777-778: *om-): Lat. amārus 'bitter', ON apr 'sharp, hard, cold', OE ampre 'sorrel, dock', OHG ampfaro 'sorrel, dock', Alb. ëmbël 'sweet' (Tosk), tëmbël 'gall', Arm. amok' 'sweet', OInd. amlá- 'sour', from *h₂em- 'raw, bitter'.

Cf. for discussion regarding the possibility of an early loanword into Pre-Proto-Tocharian when the Pre-Tocharians were still in Eastern Europe and in contact with non-Iranian IE languages. In such a scenario the specific source of the borrowing, however, cannot be identified and other explanations remain possible.

PIE root widely remodelled; some forms seem to be blends of PIE 'tongue' and root *leig̑ʰ- 'lick'; Proto-Indo-Iranian *j́ij́ʱū́- (**j́ij́ʱú-) may continue a simple PIE (masculine) u-stem *dʰng̑ʰú-, but it shows reanalysis of the initial syllable as reduplication *j́i- ~ *j́u- to *j́i-j́ʱū́- (cf. *babʱrú- adj., etc.), cf. Vedic (RV) juhū́- f. 'tongue'; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 591f.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. hah(ha)ri- 'lung(s), midriff', of obscure etymology.
S.v. TochB klutk- 'to turn, become', klautk- 'to turn, return, become'; to be derived from PIE *kʷel- 'turn'.

The root *kur- is probably nominal in origin. The Oss. verbal formation appears to be denominative: the absence of an ablaut alternation in the pres./partic. is an indication. [...] Similar forms for a small animal, young are also found in geographically close languages: Hitt. /kurka-/ (c.)
‘foal, colt’, Gr. κύρνος ‘bastard son’ (Hes.), Arm. k‘uṙak ‘foal’ (< Hitt., Ir. ?).The Skt. form does not fit in this category very well: different origin ? The Lith. cognate kùrtas ‘greyhound’ quoted by Mayrhofer, EWAia I: l.c. appears to be an old Slavic
borrowing *xъrtъ ‘id.’, which can hardly be traced back to IE.

S.v. TochB klutk- 'sich umdrehen, werden', 'to turn, become', TochA lutk- 'werden lassen, machen zu', 'to turn, make into', to be derived from Proto-Tocharian *kläwtk- based on the assumption that TA l- is due to dissimilatory loss of initial *k-. Generally further derived from a u-extension of PIE *kʷelh₁- 'turn' (cf. LIV² 387ff. without this root), from which we should expect a stem *kluh₁-T-sk̑- which possibly was to turn into PToch *kl’äwtk-.
Cf. s.v. 3. *u̯er- 'beobachten, wahrnehmen' (IEW 1164), under which ?*u̯r̥-sk̑é- > TochB warṣṣäṃ A wräṣ 'riecht (intr.).
*u̯ai̯č- "to sift, select, elect, sort out, separate"
S.v. TochB yām- 'to do, commit, make, handle act; treat as'. Etymology uncertain.
S.v. TochB yām- 'machen', 'do', TochA yām- 'id.', from *√i̯em- according to Adams DoT¹ 492, Peters 2004 [FsRasmussen] 429ff.
Cf. s.v. Lat. grossus 'immature fig; thick, unripe', of uncertain etymology. IEW had earlier connected Lat. grossus with Welsh bras 'thick'.
PS *jĭgra 'ritual event with dancing' is probably derived from PIE *ai̯g- 'move quickly, briskly, shake', cf. Old Indic ejati / ī́jati, iŋgati 'move'.

PS *jĭgrati is related to Lithuanian aikštytis 'be fussy, rage'. Latvian aîkstîtiês 'shout, make noise', Old Indic ḗjati, ī́jati 'move' and Old Icelandic eikinn 'wild, strong'. It can not be relateed to Old Indic yájati 'enshrine, sacrifice', Avestan yazaitē and Greek ἅζομαι 'fear, enshrine', ἅγος 'sacred awe'.

S.v. OIr. loiscid 'burns, consumes by fire, lays waste by fire', earlier derived to *leu̯k- via a preform *luk-sk̑-(e/o)- ({ref IEW} 687 and others), better to the same root as Gk. λάμπω 'leuchte', OPr. lopis 'Flamme' (*leh₂p-) after the analysis of {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:194fn40.
No etymology outside of Brythonic given s.v. W calon.

S.v. Bret. kalon, kaloun 'cœur' (Co. colon, W calon 'id.') Proto-Celtic *kal-onā may be cognate to 1) Latin calidus 'warm, hot' or to 2) Latin callidus 'experienced' (the heart was conceived as the organ of intelligence).
No etymology outside of Brythonic given s.v. W calon.

*Hei̯ɡ- 'move (violently?)' with Vedic iṅgáyati, éjati andn ejayant- listed as cognates. PS *jьgra 'play' may belong here (however, it would be problematic due to the lack of Winter's lengthening). Cf. also Old Nordic eikinn 'furious'.
S.v. OIr. caínid, coínid 'il pleure, il déplore'. Probably a borrowing from Brythonic.

A denominal verb caíne 'act of weeping, lamenting', borrowed from W cwyn following {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} C:18. OIr. caíne and W cwyn cannot be simple cognates and a borrowing would be a straightforward solution, however the same problem occurs with OIr. maín 'riches' and W mwyn, and in view of this perhaps there is a sound law that is not yet understood.
The lexeme has an ideophonic origin and was derived from an interjection used for 'noise of hit'.
Bulgarian d"rpam has the same origin as drapam 'scratch'.
Cf. s.v. *drep- 'abschneiden, (ab)reißen' (IEW 211).

PS *telkti 'hit, beat, press' may be related to Lithuanian tel̃ktì, telkiu 'convoke (for a collaborative work), collect together', tìlkti, tílksu 'be tamed', Latvian nuo-talcît 'to birch, beat up' and Old Welsh talch 'chaff'. PS (Balto-Slavic and Celtic only) *telek- / *telk- 'hit, beat'.

Cf. s.v. W llefaf : llefain 'to cry out, exclaim, cry, shout, lament; call, entreat; weep, shed tears' cf. Middle Cornish lefes ‘?gwaeddodd’, Middle Breton leffaff, leuffal, Modern Breton leñvañ, leanein.

PS *pĭxati is related to Lithuanian paisýti 'thresh', Latin pinsō, pīnsere 'hit, grind', Greek πτίσσω 'grind in mortar and pestle, winnow corn' and Old Indic pináṣṭi 'hit, grind' and derived from PIE *pei̯s- / pis 'hit, crush, crumble'.
Cf. s.v. Bret. leñvañ 'pleurer, crier'.
S.v. Sloven. ríniti, rȋnem nedov. lat.‛trudere, promovere’ (16. stol.),  derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'flow', cf. Old Indic rinā́ti etc.
PS *těsnŭ (< *těsknŭ < *toi̯sk-no) is related to *tiskati 'squeeze, press'. It is ultimately derived from PIE *tei̯sk- 'squeeze, press'.

PS *těsnъ is derived from *tiskati. It was derived from PIE *tḗh₂isk-, ultimately from *tah₂- 'melt, dissolve'. IE cognates are Ossetic tayun 'thaw, melt', Welsh tawdd 'liquefy', Breton tuezi 'melt, smelt', Latin tābēre, tābēscere 'melt, wilt', Greek tḗkō 'melt'. Cf. also PS *tajati 'thaw'.
S.v. 1. *teu̯k- 'stoßen, schlagen' (IEW 1032), with Slavic tŭkǫ, tŭkati 'spin', tŭknǫti, tykati 'push' and Greek τέτυκον 'produced, prepared' listed as cognates.
PS *tŭknǫti 'touch, hit, push' is related to Latvian tukstet 'hit' and Greek τύκος 'hammer, pickaxe, pollaxe'.
S.v. Bret. kalon 'cœur, âme (de cordage)', from Old Breton calonn and corresponding to Co. colon and Welsh calon, from Proto-Celtic *kal-ona-.
No etymology outside of Brythonic given s.v. W calon.

S.v. Bret. kalon, kaloun 'cœur' (Co. colon, W calon 'id.') Proto-Celtic *kal-onā may be cognate to 1) Latin calidus 'warm, hot' or to 2) Latin callidus 'experienced' (the heart was conceived as the organ of intelligence).
S.v. W perfedd 'middle, centre', a loanword from Latin permedius.
S.v. ScG. can 'say, sing' (Ir. canaim, OIr. canim, W. cana 'sing', cf. Lat. canō 'sing', Engl. hen).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *kan-o- 'sing', derived from PIE *kan- (cf. Lat. canō 'sing', Goth. hana 'cock').
Cf. s.v. *⁽k̑⁾an- 'singen, klingen' (IEW 525-6).
S.v. Manx diane 'earthworm, lugworm in the earth', cf. Ir. daoi 'embankment, sandhill', also dhiane.
Russian but, Bulgarian butam, Slovene buti, butiti may be loanwords from Itaian bottare, buttare 'hit, push'.

Bulgarian butam etc. is probably related to Italian bottare, buttare 'push, hit'. It can be a loan from Germanic or a native PS word (< PIE *bhout-), related to Armenian but 'dull', Gothic bauþs 'deaf, dumb', Lithuanian butùs 'having no tip, dull', Old Icelandic bauta, Anglo-Saxon beaten, Old High German bozan 'hit', German Am-boss 'anvil' and Latin con-futo 'supress', re-futo 'refute'. It has been interpreted as a derivation of PIE *bheu-, *bhou- 'grow', 'hit, beat'.

PS *buta, *butati, *butiti are derived from PIE *bʰeu̯t-, *bʰou̯t- 'swell', this root being related to *bʰau̯t-, *bʰūt- 'hit, beat' (cf. Latin futuo 'fuck' and Old Icelandic bauta 'push'). An Italian origin is improbable.
PS butati, butiti 'push' is derived from PIE *bʰau̯H-t- 'push', cf. Latin confutare 'supress, refute' and futuere 'have sexual contact'.

PS *gurati, *guriti is related to Lithuanian gū́ra 'person walking bended down' and Greek γῡρός 'round, curved' (other forms linked here are Norwegian kūra 'lie huddled' and German kauern 'be huddled') and derived from PIE *geu̯-r- < *geu̯- 'bend'.
"The nominal forms, NP šikam, Bal. šikam (< NP), uškumag (< NP ?) ‘belly’, Chor. šknbyk ‘entrails’, etc. may derive from this root [PIE *skep-] too, cf. NP šikaft."
"From *upāntai, Pašto bānde 'upon' < *upăntai, possibly joining with Sogd. pnt 'near'."
S.v. Khot. haṃga- 'sour' "Sogd. Man. nˀmry 'sweet' is *an-āmara-ka- ‘not sour’, as the reverse, Khotan Saka āhvarai ‘sour’, is ‘not sweet’."
Cf. s.v. 9097 ūstulāre 'sengen', 'verbrennen'.
S.v. Lat. ūstulāre 'sengen' > Fr. brûler. The origin of initial br- is uncertain, perhaps by influence of Italian, etc. bruciare < *brūsiare or Germanic brennen.

S.v. Lat. ūrō 'brûler', with secondary derivative ūstulāre attested already by Catullus. Lat. ūrō corresponds to Gk. εὔω, Skt. óṣāmi 'je brûle' and nominal forms in OIc. ysia 'feu', etc. The expressive verb ustulāre is formed like postulāre.
Cf. s.v. Lat. ūrō 'to burn, scorch', from PIE *h₁eus-e/o- 'to burn' (cf. Skt. oṣati 'to burn, scorch', uṣṇá- 'hot', Gk. εὕω 'to singe', OIc. usli, OE ysle 'hot ashes', OIc. ysja 'fire'.
Cf. s.v. 9097 ūstulāre; end of entry: Italian bruciare 'verbrennen' montal. brucello 'Rauhreif' requires a basis *brusiāre, which lacks explanation.
S.v. Sp. zarpa 'garra', a late word only existing in Castilian, but other derivatives are preserved elsewhere.
"The Ir. root with no exact IE correspondences seems to be an enlarged root of *gar². It has probably been influenced by *u̯art."
S.v. 4054 harpa (germ.) 1. Egge, 2. Harfe.

Cf. s.v. Sp. arpa 'instrumento músico', a loanword from Germanic. The original meaning in Germanic was that of a curved instrument or an instrument that was played with curved fingers, from which Old Occitan arpa 'rake', Fr. harpe 'claw', harper 'to grab'.

"Because of the wide-ranging meanings this Kurdish
verb may have two different origins, viz. *paiš and *pais, but not from *(H)u̯aiǰ, YAv. vij- ‘to shake, swing ?’ (pace Cabolov 2001, ibid.)."
Cf. s.v. *grîpan- (anfrk.) 'greifen'.
S.v. 2035 cōlāre 'durchseien' (> friaul. kolá 'herabfallen').
S.v. Lat. cōlum 'passoire, filtre à vin', technical term in rustic language doubtlessly non-Roman. Without a clear etymology. (Denominative verb cōlāre 'filtrer [couler]'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. pars, -tis 'part accordée à un individu sur un ensemble', to be connected with Lat. pariō.

S.v. forestis 'wald, der dem könig gehört' (> Fr. forêt). The basis forestis must be a derivative of either Lat. foras 'outdoors' or forum 'open place, public space'. Both are semantically plausible. It. foresta, Sp., Pg. floresta, are loans from French.
Cf. s.v. 6586 plattus (griech.) 'flach', derivative friaul. platási 'sich verstecken'.
S.v. 2409 cuppa 'Becher', with derivative kopa(r) 'töten' in Lomb., Venez., Friaul.
S.v. 2052 collocāre 'sitzen, stellen, legen'.
S.v. 4764 kratten (germ.) 'kratzen'.
S.v. dam 'спина'
Cf. s.v. PIr. *hu̯ar- (5) ‘to paint, colour; to stain’ > NP xvāl ‘soot, lamp-black’ (< *hu̯ar-da- ?). To PIE *su̯er- (*su̯or-) ‘to darken, make dark, stain’ ?

"The etymology is not clear yet. The only words which have been considered as possible cognates are NP lambar "bottom" and Gurani lam "belly" (Geiger 1890:134). However, the connection is questionable (note that Kurdish lam means "cheek")."
"(+ *abi-) NP āftāb ‘sun(shine)’"
S.v. Gk. κλαίω 'laut klagen, (be)weinen'. Only a reasonable connection is offered by Albanian klanj, kanj 'weinen' from *qlau-n-i̯ō with a combination of a nasal and yod-suffix.
S.v. Gk. κλαίω 'pleurer, gémir bruyamment', etc. No etymology. {ref Frisk 1960-1972} recalls a connection with Albanian klanj, kanj 'pleurer' < *qlau-n-yō.
S.v. γῡρός 'round, curved'. "Connection with *gou- 'hand', *guH- 'curved' (see Frisk) seems quite possible."

S.v. Alb. ditë 'day', connected by {ref Meyer 1891}:68 to OCS dьnь with a common -të suffix (cf. also Lith. dienà, Ved. dina- 'day'), but rejected by Vasmer on the grounds that there is no trace of expected nasalisation and instead proposing to NHG Zeit, OEng. tīd, etc. 'time'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *tīdi- 'time' < *dh₂i-tí- (cf. Arm. ti, tioy 'age, time' < *dh₂i-to-; Skt. dáyate 'to divide, distribute', OAv. d(a)ii- 'to allot(?)', Gk. δαίομαι 'to divide' < *dh₂-ei-). [Proposed Albanian cognates not mentioned.]
Cf. s.v. *deh₂(i̯)- 'teilen' (IEW 175-6).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *tīđiz 'time', etymologically close to Arm. ti 'age', Alb. ditë 'day'.

PS *turati, *turiti is probably a denominal derivation from PS *turŭ 'movement'. Its further etymology is uncertain. It can be derived from PIE *teu̯H- (a verbal root referrinɡ to motion), or *(s)teu̯- 'push' (both roots can be related to each other). Other comparisons are less probable.

S.v. Alb. gjak 'blood', since {ref Meyer 1891}:136 connected with OCS sokъ 'juice' and Lith. sakaĩ 'resin'; later also Gk. ὀπός (Pedersen 1937:128). Cf. {ref IEW} 1042 s.v. *s(u)ekʷo- 'pflanzlicher Saft, Harz'.

Ukrainian druliti, driliti. A relationship to Serbo-Croat drljati 'harrow, scratch' and Czech droliti 'crumble, crush' is doubtfull. It is probably a variant form of trulâti. The latter is a contamination of trutiti (PS *trǫtiti) and turlâti (related to PS *turiti, turati without a convincing etymology).
Czech drolit is related to drát and dřít (< PIE *der-). This form exists only in Czech.
PS *druľati is (along with *drolĭ, *droľa and *dĭrľati, *dĭrliti) an expressive derivation (extention) of [PIE] *der-.
S.v. Alb. bie 'strike, fall' (aor. rashë, rarë). Cognate with Lat. feriō, ON berjask 'strike'.

S.v. Alb. larg 'far (away)'. A loanword from Lat. largus 'big, large, great (of distances)'; unlikely is the proposal of {ref Meyer 1891}:238 from Turkish alargu since intervocalic -l- should invariably yield ł.
S.v. Alb. peshk 'fish', a loan from Latin piscem 'fish' (already {ref Meyer 1891}:329).

S.v. Alb. lule 'flower', origin uncertain. Possibly a Wanderwort in view of similar forms as names of flowers in various languages (cf. Burushaski lilio 'violet', Coptic hlēli, Basque lili, Estonian lill, Hittite alel). In view of the recent vowel shift *i > u (cf. luvadh 'meadow' < NGk. λείβαδι) {ref Meyer 1891}:250 proposed a loan from Lat. lilium, but this is uncertain.
S.v. Alb. mjegull 'raincloud'. Cf. for various hypotheses considering lexical contamination.

The etymology of PS dŭždžĭ is problematic. Despite the lack of an internal motivation in Slavic, it is most probably a Slavic-only innovation and has no convincing parallels. The widespread etymology *dus-di̯u- 'bad sky, bad day' (with antonymic Greek εὐδία 'serene sky, fair weather' given as parallel) can not be assumed to be entirely convincing. The issue is even not that rain is beneficial for farmers (taboo expressions of this kind are known). The crucial thing that we do not know any ancient names for 'rain' with a motivation of 'bad weather' and it has to be considered as a typological aspect.
Most lexemes for 'rain' are derived from roots meaning 'pour', 'wet', 'water'. PS -ždž- can be also a reflex of palatalized *zg, cf. here cf. Lithuanian dūzgė́ti 'buzz, make noise'. PS dŭždžĭ can be, in the end, ideophonic.
[Cf. also a summary of other etymologies.]

It could be an ancient compound *dus-di̯u- 'bad sky, bad day'. An issue is that the parts of this compounds are not attested as such in Slavic. Further, the original meaning would be unexpected, as rain is desirable for farmers and shepherds. However, it can not be exluded, that it was originally used for a harmful kind of rain, like a lingering rain during time of harvesting.
PS *kyša is derived from PS *kys, cf. PS *kysiti etc.
S.v. rdeč and rdeti.

PS *čĭrv(j)enŭ is an early adjectivised and lexicalised past passive participle of *čĭrviti, a verbal derivation from *čĭrvĭ 'grub, worm, maggot' (cf. the ancient technology of the red pigment). PS *čĭrvĭ (and a more archaic form *čĭrmĭ) is related to Lithuanian kirmìs and Old Indic kṛmi-ḥ-. PIE *kʷr̥mi-.
S.v. NHG schreien (MHG schrī(e)n, OHG scrīen, OS scrīan, from West Germanic *skreia-), no certain comparisons outside of Germanic.
S.v. Gmc. *skrei-a- 'schreien'. No certain comparisons outside of Germanic.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *salwa- 'yellowish brown', from PIE *solH-uo- (cf. Ru. solóvyj 'light bay' < *solH-uo-). A Germanic-Slavic isogloss.
S.v. Gmc. salwa- 'dunkel, schwärzlich'. Inherited adjective, identical with the basis of CS slavo-očije 'bläuliche Augenfarbe' and Russ. solovoj 'gelblichgrau (Pferd)'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fahsa- 'hair of the head' < *pok̑-so- (Gk. πέκος 'fleece' < *pek̑-es-, Gk. πόκος 'wool, fleece' < *pok̑-o-; Arm. asr 'sheepwool, fleece' < *pok̑-u-).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *helan- 'to conceal, hide' < *k̑él-e- (cf. Lat. occulō 'to hide, conceal', OIr. ceilid, MW kelu 'id.' < *k̑él-e-).
S.v. Gmc. *hel-a- 'verbergen', with certainty to be related to the IE root *kel- 'verbergen' also attested in Latin occulō, OIr. celid, etc.
S.v. Gmc. *hwerb-a- 'sich wenden'. No certain comparisons outside of Germanic.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *hwerban- 'to turn, move around', perhaps from *kʷérp-e- if connected with Gk. καρπός 'wrist' ({ref IEW} 631), but it is unclear why Go. ƕairban and G werben generalised the Verner variant *b but MHG werven may be related to original *hwerfan-.

Russian krasa 'beauty', krasivyj 'beautiful' etc. are probably related to Old Icelandic hrósa 'display', Icelandic hrós 'glory', further Old Icelandic hróðr 'glory', Gothic hrōþeigs 'victorious' and Old High German hruom 'glory'. A relationship to Lithuanian krósnis 'oven' and Latin corpus 'body', Old Incdic kr̥p̩- 'shape, beauty' is less likely. It can not be related to krutit' ['curl, spin']. It has been also linked to Lithuanian grõžis 'beauty' (an irregular correspondence *k- / *g- is assumed here).

PS *krasa. The original meaning was probably 'glare, red(ness), colour of fire'. Then it can be linked to PS *kresati. The latter has no entirely clear etymology. If related to *krasa and *krěsiti, the original meaning was 'make fire' and the maning 'hit' is secondary. Then it is derived from PIE *ker-s- < *ker- 'burn' (cf. Lithuanian kárštas 'hot'). If the meaning 'hit' is primary, then it is derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'. PS *krěsiti 'ressurect' < 'set in someone the fire of life'.
A relationship to Latin crassus 'fat' or Lithuanian grõžis 'beauty' is less probable.
PS *krasa 'colour of fire, red(ness), brightness, beauty, brilliance, adornment' is related to Lithuanian kárštas 'hot' and derived from PIE *ker- or *kʷer- 'burn'.

PS *krasa shows formal features of an ancient derivative from an e-grade verbal root. It is related to *kresati which is derived from PIE *kē̆r-s- 'create, make', cf. Latin creō 'create, produce' and crēscō 'grow'.
Meanings of *kresati referring to fire ('making fire'!) developed in phrases like *kresati *ognĭ 'create fire', cf. Lihuanian kùrti 'make, do' and secondarily 'make fire' that developed in the phrase ugnį kùrti 'make fire'.
The verb *kresati had a connotation 'create (a living being)' (note that the fire was considered as a living being in the ancient time; the verb *kresati was also just the right for the phrase *kresati *ognĭ). This connotation was realized derivative *krasa which orignally referred to the semantic field of 'life, colours of life' etc. with a later development into 'red colour, blush, flower' > 'beauty'.
Cf. related lexemes *krěsiti (with meanings 'resurrect, inspirit, revive, bring to life' and also 'make fire, spark, start fire with flint' in Slavic languages and dialects) and *krěsŭ (referring to 'ceremonial, ritual fire', 'solstice, solstice rituals', 'hot weather' in Slavic languages and dialects). Porównania do Lit grożis, karśtas, Staroisl hrós nieprawidłowe
"The Š[ughni]Gr[oup] forms in ǰ/č have been influenced by Prs."
"Š[ughni]X[ufi]R[oshani] upper part of the back."
"Cf. Taj. kiš exclamation for scaring away birds"

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *dar- (1) 'to hold, keep; to dwell', from PIE *dʰer- 'to hold' (cf. Skt. dhar- 'to hold, keep, preserve', Hitt. dar- 'to hold, to say(?)', Lat. firmus 'firm, steady', Lith. derù 'I am good for').
(> Sariq. waδor-/waδord ‘to grasp, seize’)

"A derivation < *traxra- < *taxra-, Prs. talx, etc., seems phonetically impossible. Prob. < *ϑraxša- (with xš > ŠGr. x̌, Y š), in its turn < *tarxša-, although this form is not known from other Ir. languages." [Note that Kurdish tırš probably < *tarxša-.]
"This IIr. root has no verbal correspondences in IE."
S.v. varm SY 'cloud' (S (Sh.) also fog. "Av. dvąnman-, with irregular v-?"
p.39 "On *či̯aH³/čiH < (?) PIE *ḱi̯-, cf. *ǰi̯auH ‘to chew’ < PIE *ǵi̯euH-, see Rasmussen 1989: 114, no. 5. The variant *saiH/siH may derive from the variant *ḱ(e)iH-."
p.39 "On *či̯aH³/čiH < (?) PIE *ḱi̯-, cf. *ǰi̯auH ‘to chew’ < PIE *ǵi̯euH-, see Rasmussen 1989: 114, no. 5. The variant *saiH/siH may derive from the variant *ḱ(e)iH-."
p.39 "On *či̯aH³/čiH < (?) PIE *ḱi̯-, cf. *ǰi̯auH ‘to chew’ < PIE *ǵi̯euH-, see Rasmussen 1989: 114, no. 5. The variant *saiH/siH may derive from the variant *ḱ(e)iH-."

S.v. Proto-Iranic *i̯at- 'to go, reach, approach, take position ?', from PIE *i̯et- 'to bring, conform, support ?' (cf. Skt. yat 'to line up, take up a position, place in order', Lat. nītor 'I support one self, brace one self', Toch yät- 'to adorn', yāt- 'to be able', Gk. ὅσιος 'pleasing to, just, fair').

S.v. Proto-Iranic *i̯at- 'to go, reach, approach, take position ?', from PIE *i̯et- 'to bring, conform, support ?' (cf. Skt. yat 'to line up, take up a position, place in order', Lat. nītor 'I support one self, brace one self', Toch yät- 'to adorn', yāt- 'to be able', Gk. ὅσιος 'pleasing to, just, fair').
S.v. *kʷer- 'cut off, carve'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *nau(H)- 'to cry, wail', from PIE *neu(H)- 'to cry out, shout' (cf. Skt. nav-(i) 'to roar, cry', Toch. nu- 'to cry out; threaten', Lat. nuntius '(official) message', OIr. núall 'cry, alarm, proclamation').
S.v. Alb. fortɛ 'stark, fest', from Italian forte.

S.v. Alb. tha/j '(etwas Feuchtes am Feuer oder an der Luft) austrocken, trockenlegen, dörren, räuchern, erstarren, erfrieren'. Meyer's connection with Lith. saũas, OCS suchъ 'trocken', etc. must rely on an uncertain dissimilation of sibilants which is very uncertain. D. suggests perhaps to Gk. ἅζω 'dörren, trocknen' instead.
Considers the forms to be cognate with the forms from PIE *h₂seu̯s- 'dry'.
Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda.
Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).
S.v. Alb. θań 'trockne, dörre, wische ab, mache steif', cf. Lith. saũsas, OCS suchъ 'trocken', Gk. αὔω < *σαυσω.

S.v. Alb. thatë 'dry', a derivative of the verb thaj 'to dry', from PAlb. *sausnja, a derivative of PIE *sauso- 'dry' (Gk. αὗος, MHG sôr, Lith. saũsas, Slav. *suxъ). Note the dissimilation of the sibilants leading to *s- > th- (Meyer 1891:88).

Etymology here follows {ref Schumacher & Matzinger 2013}:1000 and {ref LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda}, but be aware some scholars {ref Orel 1998}:471, {ref Holm 2011}:58-59, following {ref Meyer 1891}:88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ({ref LIV²} 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in /cognate/7551/ (cf. the skepticism of {ref Demiraj 1997}:392).

Cf. s.v. Alb. than '(aus)trocknen, trockenlegen'. On the basis of phonological grounds it would be better to assign this verb to a root *k̑eh₂u̯- (LIV² Add. *k̑eh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen', cf. Gk. καίω).
Albanian lexemes ~ Gr. κρᾱνίον 'upper part of the head, skull', Ved. śīrṣṇá- 'id.'; < Early Pr. Alb. *krōna- <(--) PIE *k̑roh₂sno- 'head'.
"**apa/i-, upa-rāzaya- but the semantic development is obscure."
"Sok[olova] (Gen.[=1967] 164) suggests a possible derivation < lE *ḱei- 'dark, black' (Av. syāva-), but W[akhi] x̌ǝt, S[an]gl[echi] šǝt/ṭ points to it being a migratory word, < lA ?"
