S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' (cf. Pamphylian Greek ϝεχέτω 'he must bring', Gk. ὄχος 'car', Lat. vehō 'I ride, bring', OCS vezǫ 'I ride', Lith. vežù 'I ride, procure', OHG wegan 'to move' etc.).
for Sarikoli: "*us-ϑrahāka-"

PS *praviti 'tell' is derived from PS *pravŭ in the meaning 'true, correct' and not 'straighten'. Its original meaning was 'tell the truth'. PS *pravŭ is derived from PIE *próh₃u̯o- (*prōu̯o-) and related to Old Indic pū́rva- 'first', English first etc.

Cf. s.v. pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft mit Abl.), specifically under the proposed formation *pró-o, *prṓ 'vorwärts, hervor; frühmorgens', to which perhaps might be connected Proto-Slavic ?*pra- 'vor' as a compositional prefix in e.g. OCS pradědŭ 'Vorfahre, Urahne', ]OCS pravŭ 'recht, richtig', Russ. pravyj 'rechts'.
PS *desnŭ is derived from PIE *dek̑s- and related to Latin dexter, Lithuanian dẽšinas, Old Indic dákṣiṇa-, Greek δεξιτερός etc.
It is a loanword from Middle German recht or its derivative.
S.v. Alb. shtëpi 'house', a loan from Latin hospitía 'inns' with metathesis to *hostipía, cf. qingj 'lamb' < *acínglu metathesised from *agnículus < agnus 'lamb'.
S.v. Alb. akull 'ice' [cf. for a survey of older uncertain hypotheses].
PS *rěka < *roi̯-kā is derived from *(e)rei̯- and related to Latin rivus 'stream', Old Indic ráya- 'current' and Middle Irish rīan 'river, road'.

PS *korenĭ is derived from PIE *kʷer- 'make'. The exact meaning the PS lexeme was derived from was 'lay foundation, lay ground', the etymological meaning of the *korenĭ was also 'base, basis' (then 'base of a tree').
S.v. Alb. këmbë, -a 'leg, foot'. Ultimately a loan from VLat. camba 'leg'. "The relation to the Vulgar Latin form is clear but the direction of the borrowing is uncertain."
S.v. Alb. shalë 'saddle; inner side of thigh, pair of legs', borrowed from Latin sella 'seat, saddle'.
S.v. Alb. mal 'mountain'.
S.v. Alb. gojë 'mouth', a borrowing from Lat. gula. The distribution of the variant gojë argues against a late loan source.
PS *gniti is derived from PIE *gʰnēi̯- and related to Anglo-Saxon ɡnídan 'rub' Old High German ɡnītan 'grind' and German χνίει 'fall into small pieces'.

S.v. Alb. thua, thoi; thonj 'finger- or toe-nail'. A form *keEn-T- would account for the Albanian forms and a zero-grade *kEn-tú- is compatible with Germanic *xanðú- but there is some discrepancy in the semantics.
S.v. Alb. nguštε 'eng; karg, geizig', a loanword from Latin angustus (cf. also Rom. îngust 'eng').
S.v. Alb. i, e ngushtë 'narrow, mean (metaphorically)' a loan from Latin angustum 'narrow, tight' with typical Albanian loss of the pretonic vowel.
PS *truxlŭ 'rotten' is derived from *trou̯-so-, ultimately from PIE *ter(H)- 'rub'.
Cf. s.v. *terh₁- 'bohren, reiben' (IEW 1071-2).
PS *krǫgŭ 'circle' is derived from PIE *kreng(ʰ)- (< probably *(s)kr-en-ɡ(ʰ)- 'twist, circulate, bend') and related to German Ring etc. and Umbrian krenkatrum 'belt, girdle'.
"Prob. < Prs. paša mosquito."

S.v. Alb. qafë 'neck'. Earlier {ref Meyer 1891}:219 rejected the view that qafë is a Turkish loanword and instead attempted to connect to Germanic *xalsa- 'neck', however there is no good reason to reject the Turkish loan hypothesis and Alb. q has been observed as the usual reflex of dorsals in Albanian.
PS *obvĭlŭ < *ob-vĭl-. The root *vĭl- related to PS *valiti, cf. also Lithuanian apvalùs, Latvian apvals and Old Icelandic valr.
S.v. Alb. vjetër 'old (of things)', semantics and final -r (never -rr) point to a loan from Latin veterem, the acc. of Lat. vetus 'old'.
S.v. Alb. vjet , vit 'alt'; Alb. vjétεrε 'alt' is from Latin veterem.
"*karaka- 'active' ( ?), but a < ?"
S.v. Alb. kuq 'red', since {ref Meyer 1891}:210 considered a loan from Lat. cocceus 'red'.

S.v. Alb. lëkurë 'skin'. "Regarding lëkurë as native, Meyer (1891b:236) related it to Gk λέπω 'strip, peel'. Jokl (1911:39) instead derived lëkurë from Lat lacer 'naked' as a loan. His etymology was accepted by Tagliavini (1937:166)."
"No exact IE cognates are known, except for a corresponding "unenlarged" root in Lith. máuti ‘to put on, don’, which is to be separated from máuti ‘to rush, tear along’"
S.v. S θům 'hot, burning', cf. V θāw- 'burn'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *dauH- (1) 'to burn', from PIE *deh₂u̯- 'to burn be(come) on fire'? (cf. δαίω 'I kindle', pf. δέδηα 'blazed, burnt', OIr. dóïd 'sings, burns', OHG zuscen 'to burn'. "The initial θ- found in many forms is puzzling. The appearance of this θ- is mainly (?) confined to EIr. languages."
"γ̌ must be derived < *zr (**uz-raiwa- ?)."
"Prob. early lw. in Š[uγni]Gr[oup], on account of z-, not *γ̌-."
S.v. ŠRB θōd, S θūd, Y θed 'liver' [No further etymology given.]
"našεwr S[arikoli] nail. — **naxōr? Cf. W[akhi] digεr, dγ̌ör (> Khow. doγur) < *n(a)γūr? Very doubtful derivation."
S.v. Alb. shalë 'saddle; inner side of thigh, pair of legs', borrowed from Latin sella 'seat, saddle'.
Loan from Lat. pōmum.
S.v. Alb. 2. madh (i) 'groß', from PIE *meg̑-, but with some difficulties in establishing the exact stem formation.
S.v. Alb. madh 'big, large' < Proto-Albanian *madza and related to Hitt. mekkiš, Skt. mahā́nt-, Gk. μέγας, Lat. magnus, etc.

S.v. NHG Hand (MHG hant, OHG hant, OS hand), from Gmc. *handu- 'Hand', also in Goth. handus, ON hǫnd, OE hond, OFr. hand, hond. Origin disputed. Conceivably there is a connection with Gmc. *henϸ-a- 'fangen, ergreifen' in Goth. frahinϸan with the original meaning of 'hand' being 'grabber'. Morphologically, however, this connection is problematic because no Germanic agent noun is formed in this way.

Polish kula 'ball', 'bullet' is a loan from Middle High German kūle 'ball, knob' (cf. German Kugel) and kula 'a kind of stick' is a loan from Middle High German kūle 'stick, club' (cf. German Keule').
Czech koule etc. is a loan from Old High German kūle (a non-contracted variant is kugel(e), cf. German Kugel) which is derived from PIE *geu̯- 'bend, arch'.
It is a loan from Middle High German kûle 'ball, bullet'.
"S[arikoli] vïnuǰ < *nuvaǰ < *nābaka-?"
"*sitik, cf. W[akhi] štik?"

S.v. Proto-Iranic *tanč- 'to twist (together), become narrow, dense, constrict' (> NEIr. Sh. tāž-/tīžd, Sariq. tož-/tīžd 'to pull, draw, haul, drag, stretch'), from PIE *tenk- (*temk-?) 'to twist together, pull oneself together, condense (cf. Skt. tañc- 'to pull together, coagulate, solidify', Lith. tenkù (tèkti) 'I stretch, reach, attain', OIr. -téici 'solidifies, coagulates', ON ϸéttr 'close, thick', Lith. tánkus 'dense, thick; frequent').
"Lw. < Prs. rušt brightly coloured, rather than (with Tom[aschek: Centralasiatische Studien II, Wien 1880]) < rušta coloured"
"Cf. W[akhi] peṭ round ( < *IA ?). Cf. also pit Y[azghulami] (Ed. JJ 176) convex (about the eye)."
"**xā(ha)xa- ?"
S.v. lův-d Š; luv-d RB; löv- : lüvd O levd S; laf-t Y 'to speak'. "Lw., cf. S[an]gl[echi] be-lav- to read; Taj[ik] Darw. luw kardan to speak, etc."

PS *kuľa (with dialectal Bulgarian kula 'gnarl on a tree', Slovene kulj, kulja '[an animal] with broken horns or without horns', dialectal Slovak kuľa 'pole with a hook at the end', Polish kula 'crutch', peg (also a bended one) used for various purposes', (dialectal) Russian kul'tâ 'hand/foot without fingers/toes', 'person without fingers', 'lame person', dialect Ukrainian kulâ 'crutch' listed as reflexes) is derived from PS *kuliti.
PS *kuliti, *kuliti sę (with the meanigs 'roll, mill', 'skate, tumble', 'wrap up', 'huddle, squinch', 'creep down' attested in Slavic lanugages and dialects) is derived from PIE *keu̯-l-, *kou̯-l-, *kū̆l- 'compressed, shortened, maimed, bended' (cf. Old Indic kora 'movable joint' if < *kou̯la) and Greek κυλλός 'shrivelled, maimed'.
Cf. also related *kulakŭ 'fist' ('something round') and *kuľavŭ 'lame', 'inured' etc.
The whole word family described above is also related to PS *kuka 'hook' etc. < PIE *keu̯-k- / kou̯-k- 'bend'.
"Cf. W[akhi] jǝqlai, etc. < *jǝl-qai? But cf. also Y[azghulami] cǝl-důr younger?"
"Cf. W[akhi] (Sh.) sūδγ, id., but neither S[arikoli suγδ] nor W[akhi] can be phonetically derived < * sātaka- (cf. sǟδ)."

divūsk, etc.; dǝγůfs "The Š[uγni]Gr[oup] -sk can hardly be original (-*sku??), but goes back to *-sx < -*xs ( = Ishk[ashmi] S[an]gl[echi]), from which also W[akhi] -ks. Initial Š[uγni] div- [...] can be derived < *dw- [...] B[artangi]O[roshori]S[arikoli] t-f- < d-v- is prob. due to taboo. [...] Poss. < *dwaxsa-, cf. Av. dvag- to flutter”

"An IE origin for this apparently IIr. root cannot be ascertained: only the Germanic forms, OHG tuoh, MHG tuoch, NHG Tuch, OSax. dōk, MLG dōk, OFr. -dok ‘cloth’, might be considered, as suggested by Mayrhofer, EWAia, l.c. It is quite striking that initial *du̯° is shared with the semantically similar roots *du̯anH and *du̯ar: these "roots" are perhaps extended formations of *dau² (Skt. dhāv) ‘to run’, which may have risen in IIr. (differently *du̯ar ?)."
(no etymological information)

S.v. Alb. lig 'schlecht, böse; krank; mager'. No further connections within Albanian, but outside one may compare Lith. ligas 'schlecht, krank', ligà 'Krankheit', Latv. liga 'Seuche', further probably Gk. λοιγός 'Verderben, Unheil, Tod'. Since long connected further to words with deviating semantics like Gk. ὀλίγος 'klein', Arm. ałkʻat 'arm, wenig, dürftig'.

"Generally (e. g. Gen. 27) derived < *hwarza-, cf. Av. x-arǝ-zišta-; Oss. xorz/xwarz good. But *rz regularly > Š[uγni] γ̌j, R[oshani], etc. wj, S[arikoli] rz; Y[azghulami] (w)z. Note also Psht. xōǧ, f. xwaǧa sweet (Wan[etsi] xōrž, xwarža), but *rz > ǧd. - Ir. *rž ( < lE *rǵh+s) might give Psht. ǧ. Wan. rž, Oss. rz, but not Š[uγni]Gr[oup] γ̌ (cf. s. v. wūrγ̌). The exact derivation of xīγ̌, etc., therefore remains uncertain."
S.v. Alb. l'ik-gu 'böse, mager', cf. Gk. ὀλίγος, Lith. ligà 'Krankheit'.
S.v. Alb. i lig, ligë 'bad, ill', akin to Gk. ὀλίγος 'few', Lith. ligà 'illness' since {ref Meyer 1891}:245, and accepted by others.
S.v. Alb. lig 'bad, ill' reflecting PAlb. *liga and further connected with Gk. ὀλίγος 'small, few', λοιγός 'destruction, death', Lith. ligà 'illness', Latv. liga 'id.'.
S.v. Alb. mułε 'Magen; Laab', identical with Old French mule 'Magen, Tasche', cf. French mullette 'Fleischmagen der Falken'. Bulgarian mura 'Magen' is borrowed from Albanian.
Cf. s.v. Standard Albanian trup 'corpse', borrowed from Slavic *trupъ 'id.'
S.v. Alb. trup 'Leib, Körper' = OCS trupъ 'venter, truncus membrum', also Rom. trup 'Körper'.

S.v. Alb. mjégull/ë 'Nebel, Wolke, Dunkel, Finsternis'. It may be necessary to separate the different variants into different etymologies. For mje(r)gull(ë) Jokl's suggestion from PIE *mergʷ- > PAlb. *merg- > Alb. mjerg-ull(ë) is the best formal solution. [Cf. entry for further discussion of inner-Albanian variation.]
S.v. Alb. mjegull 'raincloud'. Cf. for various hypotheses considering lexical contamination.
Considers the word either a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'cloud' or a cognate of Slav. *mьgla, etc.

S.v. Alb. mjegull 'cloud' (variants mjergull, njegull, which O. considers to be secondary). O. prefers a derivation from Proto-Albanian *meg(u)lā, related to Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist'.

Three main possibilities: Either connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so Orel 1998:269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- /cognate/42/), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so Demiraj 1997:271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by Meyer 1891:283-284, cf. /cognate/2150/). Ultimately unclear.

S.v. Alb. bëj (t.) / bãj (g.) 'machen, tun; werden, vorkommen; erscheinen, (statt)finden'. Inherited verb, compared since {ref Meyer 1891} with Gk. φαίνω 'sichtbar machen, ins Licht bringen' as an original *-ni̯o- formation.
S.v. 1. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (IEW 104-105).
S.v. Alb. bëj ~ bâj 'to do, make', from PAlb. *banja compared with Gk. φαίνω 'to appear' and further connected with IE *bhā-. For the semantic development cf. OIr. bann 'deed' from the same root.
S.v. Alb. bëj, bëra, bërë 'do, make', connected with Greek φαίνω 'appear', cf. OIr. bann 'deed' for the semantics.
S.v. Alb. bąj (geg.) bεń (to.) 'mache, thue', originally a present *bani̯o- = Gk. φαίνω.

Cf. s.v. Alb. lesh, -i 'Wolle; Haar; Vlies', an inherited word without certain correspondences outside of Albanian. The designation of the PIE word for 'wool' *Hu̯l̥h₁neh₂- (cf. Lat. lāna, Lith. vìlna, Gk. λῆνος 'wool' etc.) is semantically attractive, setting forth a different derived proto-form: lesh < Alb. laš- : prob. *Hu̯l̥h₁-so-/-seh₂-, cf. Lat. vellus 'Wolle, Schaffell, Vlies'
S.v. Alb. godís, godiń 'treffe, schlage', a borrowing from Slavic goditi.
S.v. Alb. gjeth 'leaf, blade'; since {ref Jokl 1912}:204 generally connected with SC gvozd 'wood', OHG questa 'leaf mold'.

S.v. PIr. *haič- 'to pour out, moisten' (> NEIr (+ *abi- Sariq. bïlis-/bïleyd, bůlis-/bůlɛyd 'to swell, inflate'), from PIE *seikʷ- 'to pour' (cf. YAv. haēc- 'pour out, irrigate', Skt. sec- 'to pour out', OHG sīhan 'to sift', OCS sьcati 'to urinate').

S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.). Sarikoli is given with wux̌t „to fall“, rawůx̌t “to fly up” and rawazon- “to cause to fly etc.”; wōzd is given for Bartangi as a causative “to make swim, carry across (a stream)”, which is probably identical with Sarikoli. From PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' (cf. Skt. vah- 'to ride, drive, transport' Gk. (Pamph.) ϝεχέτω 'he must bring', Lat. vehō, vēxī 'I ride, bring', OCS vezǫ 'I ride' Lith. vežu 'I ride, procure' OHG wegan 'to move' etc.).

S.v. Proto-Iranic *zai- (1) 'to set in motion, impel' (? > Sariq. zoz- > zux̌t), from PIE *g̑ʰei̯- 'to impel, drive'? There are no verbal correspondences for this root outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. Ved. hay- 'to impel, drive, hurl'; cf. Arm. ji, jioy 'horse', OE gād 'point, spine, sting', Goth. gain-, OE gǣn- 'weapon, zyn' (in PN)).
"*dwąza-, Av. bąz-, etc."
Sarikoli with prefix *pati-
"wayεw S[arikoli] step, pace; [...] **wi-yāwa-. Cf. Skt. vi-yā- to go/pass through."
S.v. x̌ac Š-S 'water' via *xšudrā̆- 'liquid' (cf. Avestan)
S.v. PIr. xšaud- 'to wash' (> Av. *xšaod- 'to become liquid', YAv. xšudra- 'liquid, fluid'). Cf. Skt. kṣod- 'to dissolve, disintegrate'. "The IE correspondences of the common IIr. root are unclear."
"Lw.? Cf. W[akhi] xašč; Y[i]d[gha] xusto (IIFL 268); Prs. xušta; Gabri (Ivanow) xus-."
Sarikoli < **fraϑna-?
S.v. ax̌īb Š, ax̌eb S 'the day before yesterday' – *ā-xšapa-, cf. Oss. axscev(i) 'tonight', cf. x̌āb 'night' < *xšapa-

Cabolov refuses the derivation from *piyāda as it leaves the final -w in some varieties unexplained. He suggests a derivation from Arabic banı adam (lit. 'sons of Adam' i.e. 'humans') via *pnı-ayaw. [ādam > āyaw would work]

"Сравн. тюрк. qap 'хватать ртом, зубами', 'кусать' [Радлов, 11, 404]; перс. qāp zadaп, qapıdaп 'хватать', 'схватывать', 'выхватывать'. В.И.Абаев [ИЭС, 1, 627] объясняет осет. kʾæрр kænyn 'цапнуть'' 'щелкнуть' как звукоподражание, объединяемое с тюркским словом звукосимволической природой (отметим, однако, закономерное соответствие осетинского kʾ тюркскому q в заимствованиях из тюркского). Сравн. тж. рус. хапать, укр. хапати 'хватать', болг. хапвам 'кусаю', чеш. chapac 'хватать' и некоторые другие индо-европейские формы, рассматриваемые как продолжение и.-е. *khар- [Фасмер, IV, 222]."

"the IE preform *k(ʷ)H₂eǵ- (cf. Arm. xacanel ‘to bite’) reconstructed by Klingenschmitt 1982: 210 and Kümmel, LIV:
360 has little to recommend."
S.v. Alb. l'os 'spiele, bewege, reize', certainly a loanword from Latin ludere.

S.v. OAlb. nden 'ausbreiten, ausstrecken', originally early Albanian *ten-i̯e/o- (to *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen', LIV² 626f.) with a preverb *an-. The basic stem formation is comparable to AGk. τείνω.
S.v. Alb. ndej ~ ndêj 'to stretch out, spread', continuing PAlb. en-tenja and related to Gk. τείνω 'to stretch', Skt. tanóti 'to expand', OHG denen 'to stretch' and other reflexes of IE *ten-.

S.v. Alb. nde/j (t.) / ndẽj (g.) 'ziehen, spannen; ausstrecken, ausbreiten'; cf. secondary (dial. south Tosk, Arb. Gr./It.) ndë(n)j 'id.', intr. 'gehen nach, (um)ziehen nach' with dialectally restricted darkening of the root vowel. Generally connected with Greek τείνω via a -i̯o- stem formation *teni̯o-.

S.v. kripε, geg. krüpε 'Salz', a borrowing from Slavic (cf. OSlov. krupa 'mica', Cz. kroupa 'Graupe, Hagel', Pol. krupa 'id.'). Similarly cf. Lith. druskà 'Salz', Latv. druska 'Krume' where the inherited word for 'salt' has been lost in Baltic.

S.v. kripë 'salt', according to {ref Meyer 1891}:206 a loan from OSlov. krūpa 'mica', a phonetically plausible solution but semantically weak. Alternatively krypë is a native word cognate to and not loaned from Slavic, but Albanian -y- is a secondary Gheg rounding of -i- after kr- and before a labial stop.
S.v. Alb. zhur (shur) 'gravel', a borrowing from Latin saburra 'sand ballast'.
S.v. Alb. šūr, žūr 'Sand, Kies', a borrowing from Latin saburra 'Sand, Schiffsballast'.
S.v. *dʰeu̯b- 'tief' (IEW 267f., EIEC 154).
S.v. Alb. det 'sea'. {ref Jokl 1911}:14-15 reconstructed *dʰeu̯b-etos connecting to Germanic words for 'deep' and has been generally accepted; earlier proposed etymologies are very uncertain.
S.v. Alb. kεndóń 'singe, krähe lese, studiere', from Latin cantāre.
S.v. Alb. këndoj 'sing', a loan from Latin cantāre.
Cf. s.v. rri, ndenja, ndejtur 'sit, remain' for a discussion of various proposals.
Cf. s.v. rri, ndenja, ndejtur 'sit, remain' for a discussion of various proposals.

S.v. Alb. rri 'sitzen; sich setzen, sich niederlassen; bleiben, verweilen'. It is usually considered to be unexplained, but there is no good reason not to connect it with PIE ?*(h₁)rei̯d- '(sich) anlehnen' (LIV² 503).

S.v. Alb. rri 'sitzen; sich setzen, sich niederlassen; bleiben, verweilen'. It is usually considered to be unexplained, but there is no good reason not to connect it with PIE ?*(h₁)rei̯d- '(sich) anlehnen' (LIV² 503).

S.v. Alb. rroj 'to live, to stay', continuing PAlb. *rānja and identical with Lith. róju, róti 'to cope, to be ready', further connected with ríeti 'to stack (wood)' and derived from IE *rēi-. Other proposals include to Gk. ῥώομαι 'to move strongly, to dance' (Camarda I 92), to Lat. regere 'to direct' ({ref Meyer 1891}:375), from Romance *remanāre (Mann, Language 17 p.12).
Cf. s.v. Alb. nuhurít 'spüre, spüre nach, suche (vom Hünde)'. nuhár 'Feinschmecker', from se. njuh 'Geruch', njušiti 'schnüffeln (vom Hünde), cf. Slov. njuhati, Russ. njuchatь.
S.v. Alb. laj 'wash', contra Meyer (1891:237) if laj is a loan from Lat. lavāre, then that would have yielded *lëv-oj or *loj.
S.v. Alb. la 'waschen, spülen, reinigen', probably to continue a verb of the productive *-n(i̯)o- class: *lh₃-eu̯- > PAlb. *lau̯- > Alb. la-.

It is no longer necessary to postulate two separate roots *leh₂(u̯)- 'pour' for Anatolian and *leu̯h₃- for Italic and Albanian. The two roots can be reconciled to *leh₃u̯- (cf. Melchert 2011:127-132).
S.v. Alb. l'ań 'wasche, bade', borrowed from Lat. lavāre.
S.v. Alb. laj ~ lâj 'to wash', from PAlb. *launja and related to Gk. λούω, Lat. lavō 'id.'.
S.v. OAlb. lan 'waschen', attested through Old Gheg la (Buzuku) probably continues PIE *leu̯h₃-e/o- with a present-stem n-suffix.

It is assumed im many etymological sources that kula 'ball' etc. is a loan from Middle German kūle. However, in light of many dialectal Slavic attestations with meanings like 'hook, a bended object, gnarl, lump' it is very unlikely. This lexeme has also rather a PS origin, *kuľa < PIE *kou̯l-, cf. PIE *(s)keu̯l- 'something bent, puckered'. Kula 'stick' also belongs here.
German Keule etc. is derived from PIE *geu̯l- and related to Polish gula ['bump'].

S.v. Alb. lis 'oak, high tree', a borrowing from Slavic *lesъ 'wood, forest, tree' ({ref Meyer 1891}:247). "The Slavic dialect from which the word was borrowed must have had a narrow *ě > Alb. i, i.e. it may be identified as "ikavski" Serbo-Croatian" ({ref Jokl 1923}:177).
S.v. l'is 'Eiche, Baum' "cal. gr. 'Eiche' für alle Arten, wie ngr. δένδρον". From Sl. lêsъ 'Wald' (Se. lijes, with i for e).

S.v. Alb. lis 'oak(tree), tree', because of the difficulties of the root vocalism, instead considering an inherited term akin to lëndë 'material, lumber' and lende 'acorn' with lis reflecting *lent-to- with the dental cluster becoming -s- and *en becoming i before spirants as in mish 'meat' and vidh 'elm', ultimately comparable to OE lind 'linden', Gk. ἐλάτη 'pine' OCS latъ 'linden'.
S.v. Alb. ūδε 'Weg, Reise; Gesetz, Vorschrift', which can belong to IE *uegh- (weak form ugh-), which also in Alb. vieδ- has taken on a quite different meaning.

S.v. Alb. udhë 'road, path', generally derived from the zero-grade of the root *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'drive, go' (Lat. veho, Av. vazaiti), cf. for further discussion of other hypotheses to be rejected or not met with general acceptance.

Bulgarian kul, kulav 'gnarled' and kula 'gnarl, bump on a tree or human body' is derived from PIE *keu̯- / *kou̯- and related to Greek κουλλός. Kuka 'hook etc.' is derived from the same root.
Russian kulak 'fist' is an old, most likely a Turkic loanword, cf. Turkish kol and Bashkir kul 'hand'.

S.v. Alb. i, e gjërë 'wide, distant, far'. "{ref Meyer 1891}:140 failed to etymologise this word. {ref Jokl 1911}:27 saw a possible relation to Lat sērus 'late' and W hir  'tall' from *sē̆i- […] but the Welsh and Latin forms clearly point to a long vowel and the Gheg forms require an intervocalic *n not *r."
It is a loanword from Middle German runt 'round'.

Macedonian trkalo 'wheel' etc. is derived from PS *tŭrkati, *tŭrčati 'run'. The further etymology is uncertain. It can be derived from PIE *ter-k-, cf. Middle Irish tricc 'fast'. Also Gothic þragjan 'run', Greek τρέχω 'run' and Gaulish ver-tragus 'fast running dog' (derived from PIE *trāgʰ-, *trē̆gʰ-) are related.

Gothic þragjan 'run' is related to Greek τρέχω 'run' and Old Irelandic tethraig 'ran away, receded'. A link to OCS trk 'course, flight' (< *trk(ʷ)-o-) and Slovene trčati 'run' (< *trk(ʷ)-i-eh₂-) is less attractive.
*terkʷ- 'turn, rotate' with Hittite tarukzi, tarkuanzi 'dance', Albanian tjerr 'spin', Latin torqueō, torquēre 'turn, wind' and Tocharian tetarku 'turned' listed as reflexes.

S.v. Alb. krah '(Ober)arm, Schulter, Flügel'. Inherited word, probably originally a neuter. Unclear. Perhaps from Alb. *kri-, which allows the assumption of a possible etymological connection with Arm. srownkʻ "Scheinbein, Wade", Lat. crūs, -ris, from Proto-Albanian *krū : *k̑ruh₂(s), krah(-) < *krav- : Pl. *k̑rh₂-eu̯-es.

S.v. Alb. krah 'arm, shoulder', compared by {ref Meyer 1891}:203-204 to Lith. kárka 'upper arm', SCr. krák 'leg, femur', althernatively Tagliavini and Wiedemann derived *krok-sk̑ā, compare Ved. kara 'hand'. Both of these formations could give krah but morphological parallels are lacking. "The Baltic form seems to reflect an o-grade with a lost interconsonantal laryngeal; the Albanian on the other hand seems to be a zero-grade syllabic liquid plus laryngeal while the Serbo-Croatian form seems to be a lengthened grade, probably without a laryngeal. If, as seems reasonable, these central European forms are all related, there must be some borrowing in at least one form, but the direction is obscure."
S.v. Alb. fletë 'wing, leaf', from Alb. awa-lekta, a prefixal derivative of IE *lek- 'to fly' (cf. Lith. lekiù, lė̃kti, OHG lecken 'to jump, to kick').
S.v. Alb. fl'etε 'Blatt am Baum, Papierblatt; Flügel, Fensterladen', loanword from Italian foglietta.
Regarding the root *lek- postulated by {ref Orel 1998}:100, cf. s.v. ?*lek- 'die Gliedmaßen bewegen' (?) (IEW 673).

S.v. Alb. zog, -u 'Vogel', originally proposed by {ref Meyer 1892}:18 not to be separated from Arm. jag 'young bird'. Not conclusively convincing ("Im übrigen nicht eindeutig.") Probably to be accounted for onomatopoeically.
S.v. Alb. zog, -u '(young) bird', probably a culture word rather than the widespread idea that the Albanian is to be related with Arm. jag 'chick'.
S.v. zok 'junger Vogel', stem zog-, cf. Arm. jag 'junger Vogel', which can be both reconciled to a proto-form *g̑ʰāgʰos.
PS běgti 'run' is derived from PIE *bʰeu̯ɡ- / *bʰeɡʷ- / *bʰūɡ(ʰ)- / *bʰu̯eɡ- and related to Greek φέβομαι 'run away, fear' etc.
PS *teťi 'go, run, flow' is derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'run, flow'.

Macedonian trkalo 'wheel' etc. is derived from PS *tŭrkati, *tŭrčati 'run'. The further etymology is uncertain. It can be derived from PIE *ter-k-, cf. Middle Irish tricc 'fast'. Also Gothic þragjan 'run', Greek τρέχω 'run' and Gaulish ver-tragus 'fast running dog' (derived from PIE *trāgʰ-, *trē̆gʰ-) are related.

Gothic þragjan 'run' is related to Greek τρέχω 'run' and Old Irelandic tethraig 'ran away, receded'. A link to OCS trk 'course, flight' (< *trk(ʷ)-o-) and Slovene trčati 'run' (< *trk(ʷ)-i-eh₂-) is less attractive.
*terkʷ- 'turn, rotate' with Hittite tarukzi, tarkuanzi 'dance', Albanian tjerr 'spin', Latin torqueō, torquēre 'turn, wind' and Tocharian tetarku 'turned' listed as reflexes.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *goniti ‘chase, persecute’ (ESSJa VII 23), from PIE *gʷʰon- (cf. Gk. θείνω 'kill', Skt. hánti 'strike, slay').

PS *goniti (sę) is derived from PIE *gʷʰen- and related to Old Indic hánti 'hit, kill', Greek θείνω 'hit', Lithuanian genù, giñti 'chase', Hittite kuen-, kun- 'hit, kill', Latin de-fendere 'defend', Old Icelandic gunnr 'battle', Tocharian kuñac 'quarrel, battle' etc.
Cf. s.v. *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).
PIE *teu̯k- 'hit, beat' with Slavic tŭkǫ, tŭkati 'spin', tŭknǫti, tykati 'push' and Greek τέτυκον 'produced, prepared' listed as cognates.
PS *pěsŭkŭ is related to pāṃsú- 'sand, dust' and derived from PIE *pēs- / *pēns-.
PS *rekti, *rekǫ is derived from PIE *rek- 'speak, shout'.
The etymology of PS *kazati is complicated. However, it is most probably derived from PIE *kek̑- / *keg̑-. A reconstruction as *kʷeg̑- is also thinkable.
PS *věděti is derived from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'see, catch sight of, spot'.
PS *velěti is derived from PIE *u̯elh₁-, cf. Latin volō, volere, Lithuanian vélti, Gothic wiljan etc. 'want'.

Cf. s.v. pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal; oft mit Abl.), specifically under the proposed formation *pró-o, *prṓ 'vorwärts, hervor; frühmorgens', to which perhaps might be connected Proto-Slavic ?*pra- 'vor' as a compositional prefix in e.g. OCS pradědŭ 'Vorfahre, Urahne', ]OCS pravŭ 'recht, richtig', Russ. pravyj 'rechts'.

PS *praviti 'tell' is derived from PS *pravŭ in the meaning 'true, correct' and not 'straighten'. Its original meaning was 'tell the truth'. PS *pravŭ is derived from PIE *próh₃u̯o- (*prōu̯o-) and related to Old Indic pū́rva- 'first', English first etc.
Upper Sorbian prajić is derived from PS *praviti < *pravo 'law', *pravŭ 'right, straight'.

PS *gorniti (Polabian gornĕt and Lower Sorbian groniś, cf. also Serbo-Croat granati 'tell, speak with a great inspiration') is derived from PS *gornŭ / *gorno. The latter is obviously a derivative *gor-n- with no further internal Slavic etymology. I has been linked to Old Indic gṛṇā́ti 'call, praise' and Avestan gar- 'praise'. It can not be related to Lithuanian ger̃bti, as it is a result of a consonant metathesis.
Gṛṇā́ti 'calls, invokes, praises' is related to OCS granŭ 'verse, phrase', Lithuanian giriù 'praise', Albanian gërshás, grish 'invite to a wedding' and Old High German queran 'sigh'.
Albanian gërshas 'invite' is derived from PIE *gʷer- and related to Sanskrit gṛṇā́ti ''call, invoke and Lithuanian giriù, gìrti 'praise', cf. also Celtic *bardos 'bard'.

PG *kweran 'to sigh' (*gʷérH-e-), cf. Greek δερίαι 'cuss, expletive' (gʷerH-ieh₂-) and Lithuanian gurti 'scream' (*gʷrH-).
"The verb seems most closely related to Lith. gùrti, whose round vowel points to a root *gʷerH- rather than *gerH-. The form would then be unre­lated to Lith. gìrti, (giriù), Latv. dzir̃tiês, OPru. girtwei 'to praise' < *gʷrH-ie­- and Skt. gr̥ṇā́ti, gr̥ṇītḗ 'id.' < *gʷr-n(é)H-. Skt. járate 'to call; crackle (of fire)' continues a dissimilar root *ǵer(H)-."

*gʷerH- 'express agreement' with Vedic gṛṇā́ti 'welcome, praise', Middle Welsh barn- 'judge', Iranian parāči ǰar- 'say', Lithuanian giriù, gìrti 'praise', OCS žiŕǫ, žrĭti 'sacrifice' etc. listed as cognates.

Latin grātus 'thankful, grateful, pleasand, charming' is derived from PIE *gʷr̥H-to- 'praised (in a song)', cf. Welsh barnu 'judge', Sanskrit gṛṇā́ti 'praise, honour, welcome', Lithuanian girtas 'praised', OCS žrĭcĭ 'priest', žrĭti, žrěti 'sacrifice' and OCS granŭ, grano 'verse, line' (< *gʷorH-no-).
PS *česati is derived from PIE *kes- 'scratch'.

PS *skrabati, *skrobiti, *skre(b)ti are related to Latvian skrabt, English scrape, Welsh crafu etc. 'scratch'. All these lexemes are derived from PIE (s)kreb(ʰ)-, ultimately *(s)ker- 'cut, process with a sharp tool'.
PS *skrebti is derived from PIE *(s)kerb- 'cut'.

PS *grebti is derived from PIE *gʰrebʰ- and related to Latvian grebt 'dig', Old High German graban 'dig', Avestan grab- 'catch' and Old Indic gr̥bhṇā́ti 'catch'. Maybe Hittite karp-/karp- 'devour'  also belongs here.
Slovene grabsati, grabastati, grabasvati are expressive derivatives from grebsti, grebem.

Slovene praskati 'scratch, crack' is derived from an old ideophonic root, cf. Latvian prakšķêt, prakšêt 'crackle'. A homonymic lexeme praskati 'run' can also belong here. It can be, however, also an expressive -sk- derivative from PS *pĭrati 'hit, push'.

S.v. Alb. fryj, fryta, fryrë 'blow'. {ref Meyer 1891}:112 gave no etymology but connected to Alb. frymë 'breath', Tagliavini (1937:98) notes Barić's derivation from *sphrugniō without comment. Çabej (1962a1:108) suggested the verb is of onomatopoeic origin.

S.v. Alb. fryj, fryta, fryrë 'blow'. Meyer 1891:112 gave no etymology but connected to Alb. frymë 'breath', Tagliavini (1937:98) notes Barić's derivation from *sphrugniō without comment. Çabej (1962a1:108) suggested the verb is of onomatopoeic origin.
cf. "Av. saēni- 'top, peak'"

Cf. s.v. Ved. √śā- 'schärfen, wetzen' < PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- cf. Arm. sowr 'scharf', Lat. cōs, cōt- 'Wetzstein', catus 'scharf, scharfsinnig' etc. For the expanded -i̯- (beside *k̑eh₃-, *k̑h₃- in Ved. śā- : śi-tá-, Lat. cō-t- : ca-tus, cf. the reflexes in Iranic like Av. saēni- 'spitz' and outside of Indo-Iranic forms like Old Norse hein 'Wetzstein'.
Cf. s.v. *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'schärfen' (IEW 541-2).
Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰed- 'scheißen' (IEW 423).
"Bal. puṭ 'hair; feather' has probably been borrowed from Br[ahui] puṭ 'hair' (Emeneau/Burrow 1972, Rossi 1979:109); a semantic shift from 'hair' to 'feather' is not improbable."
S.v. Alb. ndoh 'beschmutzen'; connected by {ref Meyer 1891}:301 with (g.) ndyj, (t.) ndyr; {ref Jokl 1911}:61-62 instead suggests an inner-Albanian connection to dhjes 'scheißen'.

S.v. Alb. (T) ndohtë 'dirty, foul', based on ndoh 'to make dirty', an inchoative desiderative form of ndyj ({ref Meyer 1891}:301), alternatively {ref Jokl 1911}:61-62 to dhjes, {ref Demiraj 1997}:290-291.

S.v. OAlb. drúan (intrans.) 'Angst haben, sich fürchten, erschrecken', may be best connected to a root *dʰreh₂s-, which is to be understood as a parallel root to *dʰreh₂gʰ- 'aufgewühlt werden, in Aufruhr geraten' ({ref LIV²} 154f.)
S.v. druaj ~ druej 'to be afraid', derived from dre, droe 'fear' < PAlb. drāwā and further related to Latv. druvas 'fear' and further to Lith. draudžiù , draũsti 'to forbid, to deter, to scare off'.
Cf. s.v. Alb. bushtër 'bitch' (f., pl.), adj. 'raging, wild', an early borrowing from Slav. *bystrъ. Cf. also for alternative etymologies proposed by others.

S.v. dushk 'Hauptbegriff für verschiedene Laubbäume (evtl. mit Eicheln als Früchte) bzw. für dicht verwachsene hohe Sträucher, deren Laub als Winterfutter verwendet wird.' There are no certain inner- or outer Albanian correspondences.
S.v. Alb. dushk 'oak', to be connected with dru 'tree' on the basis of the variant drusk.

S.v. Alb. gjegj intrans. 'to answer', trans. 'to listen, consent, heed, listen, obey'. përgjégjet nicht-akt. 'antworten, entgegnen', to be connected with IE *seh₂⁽g̑⁾- (cf. Proto-Germanic *sak-e/a-, OIr. saigid, ·saig).
S.v. *seh₂g-, also to root present [aalb. gjegjetë ‘hört’.
Cf. s.v. *seh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'einer Fährte nachgehen' (IEW 876-7).

S.v. Alb. i, e rëndë 'heavy'. Difficult. {ref Meyer 1891}:365 suggested a loan from Latin grandis 'large', to which {ref Jokl 1911}:74 objected on semantic grounds, instead considering Alb. rëndë a participle of a now lost verb cognate with Lith. rė́ju 'put together'. "The failure of this verb to be attested is a serious handicap, but Jokl's assumption of an underlying verb stem *reE- is the best solution yet advanced."

S.v. Alb. zë (trans.) '(an)fassen, fangen; erfassen; anfangen'. This verb and its compounds are eminently polysemous, moreover on phonological grounds several root structures are conceivable: *gʷen(H)-, *gʷʰen(H)-, *g̑u̯enH- and *g̑ʰu̯en(H)-. There are no convincing cognates anywhere else in Indo-European. Phonologically it would be possible to derive this verb from the root *gʷʰen(H)- whose meaning is 'schwellen', but semantically this is improbable.

S.v. Alb. 2. zë 'fassen, anfassen; fangen; erfassen; (mit) etw. anfangen; verstopfen, blockieren'. Otherwise unclear, up to now the most frequent attempted derivation is to a root *gʷ⁽ʰ⁾en- which can explain developments in initial position, but not the lowering of the root vowel.
S.v. Alb. zë, zâ 'to seize, grasp, touch', from PAlb. džeina, a derivative in *-no- based on IE *gʷei̯H- 'to overpower' (cf. Skt. jyā́ 'force, power', jáyati 'to win, to conquer', Gk. βίη 'power').

“The word is probably neither to be connected to síkatā- as Horn 1893:142 assumes nor to Av. √rič, OInd. √ric, Bal. rēč- ‘pour’ as Geiger 1890:143 maintains, but rather to OInd. √ri ‘flow’ and words for ‘river’ derived from this root in a number of IE languages, for which cf. EWAia II:437.”
"The root is originally identical to *u̯aid¹."
"For cognates (e.g., Khot. vanda- "small"), cf. Morgenstierne 1929:256a, Bailey 1979:374b." Korn argues against loan from Sindhi/Lahnda and the stipulation of an EIr. "substrate".
"An IE etymology for *šan is lacking. The root may be related to *san (which is a "substrate" borrowing)."

PS *praskati 'crack, burst' has an ideophonic origin. The meaning 'scratch' in Slovene developed from 'crack, burst' through a meaning referring to sounds produced by cracking [like 'crackle, crunch']. It can be derived from PIE *pers- 'drizzle, raise dust, gush'.

S.v. Alb. hedh 'to throw, to shoot' (variant hjedh), from PAlb. *skeuda and connected with ON skjóta, OHG scioʒan and other Germanic continuants of PGmc. *skiutan 'to shoot' < IE *skeud- 'to throw, to shoot'.

Czech praskat ['burst, fissure; crackle'] has an ideophonic origin. Czech práskat ['clash; crackle'] is either etymologcally identical with praskat ['burst, fissure; crackle'] or it is derived from prát (< PIE *per- 'hit, beat').

PS *praskati has an ideophonic origin. An assumption of two etymona here (c.f. e.g. Czech praskat and práskat), one derived from [*per-] and the second related to German springen etc., is unjustified.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *xāpàti 'seize' (ESSJa VIII 18-19). [No etymology outside of Slavic given.]
Proto-Slavic *xapati. The root has an ideophonic origin and no reasonable further etymology can be given.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *murϸa- 'murder', a *-to-stem to the IE root *mer- 'to die', whence the derived weak verb *murϸjan- (ON, Ic. Far. myrða, OHG murdjan, MHG mūrden 'to kill' (NB: Goth. maurϸr, OE murðor 'murder' continue an instrumental formation *mŕ-tro- to the same root).
S.v. Gmc. *(-)drǣd-a- '(fürchten)'. No certain comparisons outside of Germanic. Cf. OS -drādan (MLG ontraden), OHG -trātan (MHG entrātan).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *kwaljan- 'to make suffer, pain' (ON kvelja 'to torment, torture', OE cwellan 'to kill', etc.), from PIE *gʷolH-éie-, a causative formation comparable to non-causative Proto-Germanic *kwelan-.
S.v. Alb. afër 'near' (adv., prep.), cf. for discussion of various proposals, none of which can be considered definitive.
S.v. Alb. afër (prep.) 'bei, an'; (adv.) nahe, bei, herbei; beinahe, etwa'. Etymology disputed, cf. for further discussion.
The etymology of Ukrainian šìpatisâ is obscure.
PS *moŕe is derived from PIe *mori 'sea'.
PS *viděti is derived from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'look, see', cf. Latin videō vidēre etc.
S.v. *h₃ekʷ- 'ins Auge fassen, erblicken' (LIV² 297f., IEW 775ff.)

S.v. Proto-Slavic *obačiti, often interpreted as *ob-ačiti with *ačiti related to PS *oko ['eye']. However, the nature of the root vowel lengthening (*o>*a) were obscure then. Further, *ačiti itself is not attested anywhere else in Slavic. Thus, this etymology is doubtful and illusive.
It is commonly accepted that lexemes like Polish baczyć developed through a morphological re-interpreatation (*ob(-)ačiti > *o-bačiti). The East Slavic cognates are also normally treated as loanwords from Polish.
This dialectal Slavic lexeme can be a loanword from Iranian, cf. Avestan *aiwy-āxšayeinti < Eestern Iranian *abi-āxšaya- 'they observe, they guard' (with a long root vowel!).
[Cf. also for a summary of other hypotheses.]
(PS *oko, očese < PIE *okʷ- / *Hokʷ-.)

Most scholars assume that Ukrainian bačiti is a loanword from Polish where it developed trough a morphological re-interpretation of PS *ob-ačiti > *o-bačiti. PS *-ač(-iti) is considered to be related to PS *oko 'eye'.

S.v. Gmc. *berg-a- 'bergen', may be compared with Balto-Slavic *berg- (*bʰerg̑ʰ-) 'verwahren, bewahren' (cf. Lith. berginti 'nicht viel ausgeben, sparen, geizig sein', OCS nebrěgǫ, -brěšti 'außer Acht lassen, sich nicht kümmern, mißachten', perhaps also Oss. æmbærzyn 'bedecken' < Ir. *ham-barz- according to {ref Abaev 1959–1995}).

S.v. NHG ritzen (MHG riz(z)en, OHG rizzen, rizzōn), an intensive formation < *writt-ija- to the same root as NHG reißen (MHG rīzen, OHG rīzan, OS wrītan < *wreit-a-, also in ON ríta, OE wrītan). The origin of this group is unclear.

S.v. Gmc. *wreit-a- 'ritzen'. No secure possibilities for comparison. The related lexemes in this class are to diverse semantically to establish a meaningful etymology. A contamination or blending of two or more roots is possible, especially in German.

Cf. s.v. *wrītan- 'to carve', "A strong verb derived from a further unknown root *ureid-. It merged with *rītan- 'to tear' (cf. Du. rijten s.v. 'id.') in Old Norse and Old High German, where initial *w was lost in front of r.", OHG rizzōn, rezzōn 'to carve, write' continues the iterative formation *writtōn- as though from *urid-néh₂-.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *solvъ, from PIE *sal-uo- (solH-uo-?), cf. OIc. sǫlr 'dirty yellow', OHG salwo 'dirty yellow', MoE sallow 'sickly yellow, pale brown', OIr. salach 'dirty'. "I suspect that we are dealing with a root *sal- with "European a". According to {ref Schrijver 1991}: 212-213, ablaut *solH- : *slH- is an alternative solution."
Cf. for further discussion of these words possibly in connection to Lat. salīva 'spit', reconstructing a zero-grade root form *slH-.
S.v. NHG wandeln (MHG wandel(e)n, OHG wantalōn, OS wandlon. An iterative formation to OHG wantōn 'wenden' and further connected with NHG wenden and winden.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *windan- 'to wind' (Elfd. winda 'to hurl, sling'), from PIE *uéndʰ-e- (cf. Umb. vetu, aha-uendu, pre-uendu 3.sg.imptv. 'must turn' < *uend-e-tōd, Arm. gind 'ring' < *uendʰ-eh₂-), a strong verb to *uendʰ-.
S.v. *u̯endʰ- '(um)winden' (IEW 1148).

S.v. Gmc. *wend-a- 'winden', probably belonging to a reconstructed IE root *u̯endʰ- 'flechten, winden' (cf. Umbr. aha-uendu, Ved. vandhura- 'Wagensitz' (of which on good grounds it can be assumed was weaved), TochAB wänt- 'umhüllen', perhaps also OCS vęžati 'binden' with a root final variant or contamination).
S.v. Gmc. *flaka- 'flach', to be connected with Latin plaga 'Fläche' and to be considered a g-enlarged form of PIE *pelə- / *plā- 'flach, ausbreiten'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *flaka- 'flat' < PIE *plók-o- (cf. Gk. πλάξ, -ακός 'plane, plain; flat stone, board table' < *pl̥k-; Lith. plãkanas, Latv. plakans 'flat' < *plokono-).

S.v. NHG nah(e) (MHG nāch, nācher, OHG nāh, OS nāh), from Gmc. *nǣhwa- (adj.) 'nah', also in Goth. neƕ(a), ON ná, OE nēah, OFr. nēi.). Most likely to be an adjectival formation to a local particle *nē which appears in OCS mna, Ru. na 'auf, an, zu'. Perhaps further to OCS vъznakъ 'zurückgeneigt, rücklings', Ved. nāka- 'Firmament, näherer Himmel'.

S.v. Goth. N14. neƕ adv. (only atiddja neƕ razn / ἤγγισεν τῇ οἰκίᾳ 'he approached the house'), neƕa adj. 'ἐγγύς', 'near'. Within Germanic OI nā-, OE nēah, OFris. nēi, nī, OS, OHG nāh, OS, OHG nāhōr 'closer, near', etc. Etymology obscure, possibly to Skt. náśati, Lat. nanciō 'draw near, arrive'.

S.v. Gmc. *nǣhwa- 'nah'. No direct correspondences outside of Germanic. Seebold (cf. {ref Kluge 2002}:644 [= {ref Kluge 2011}:647]) considers in Proto-Germanic *nǣhwa- an adjectival formation to IE local particle *nē and connected with OCS vъznakъ 'zurückgeneigt, rücklings', Ru. na (prep.) 'auf, an, zu', and perhaps further to Ved. nā́ka- 'Firmament, näherer Himmel' which would have developed from an original meaning 'zugeneigt, in Richtung auf, da', while Bammesburger 1990:257f. (following {ref IEW} 316f. and others) suggest a connection to *h₂nek̑- 'reichen'. In the latter case Gmc. *nǣhwa- would have to be explained as a lengthened grade formation.

Polish baczyć 'notice, watch over, guard', Old Polish also 'remember, conclude, know, examine' (cf. dialectal Czech báčit, dialectal Slovac bačic 'observe, realize', Ukrainian bačyty 'see, presume, think', Belarusian bačyc' 'see') developed by a re-interpretation ob-aczyć > o-baczyć from PS *ačiti (probably 'see, perceive'), derived with a lengthening of the root vowel from *oko ['eye'].
Russian dialectal (southern, western) bačit', Ukrainian bačiti and Belarusian bačyc' are loanwords from Polish baczyć < PS *ob-ačiti (related to oko 'eye').

S.v. Engl. near (adv.2). The comparative degree of the adjective replaced the original positive degree i.e. *'nearer' > 'near', probably after the same development in Scandinavian (cf. OIc. nær 'nearer' having taken over the positive sense 'near').
It is a loanword from Polish. It was borrowed into Russian dialects through Ukrainian.
PS *ględati has been linked to Middle High German glinzen 'shine'.
PS *sěmę, sěmene 'seed' is related to Old Prussian semen, Latin sēmen, seminis, Old High German sāmo etc. and derived from PIE *sē-men- < PIE *sē- 'sow'.
Cf. Middle Low German sât.
PS *šiti is derived from PIE *si̯uh₁/h₃-.
S.v. Gmc. *skald-a- 'stoßen'. No convincing comparisons outside of Germanic.
Cf. s.v. NHG schalten (MHG schalten, OHG scalten 'fortschieben, fortführen', OS skaldan < Gmc. *skald-a- 'stoßen').
S.v. Gmc. *kʷǣda- 'schlecht, böse', stands next to a substantive in the meaning 'Kot, Dreck, Dung' which could have been adjectivised in predicate position (cf. OE cwēad 'Dung').

PS *těnĭ is maybe derived from *tem-nĭ with a simplification of the cluster *-mn- and a lengthening of the root vowel. It would be ultimately derived from PIE *tem(ə)- 'dark' then. A derivation from PIE *ten- 'pull, extend' (cf. Polish cienki 'thin') with a motivation 'something getting longer and shorter, something mobile' is less likely.

It is usually reconstructed as *tēmnĭ and linked to *tĭma ['darkness'], *tĭmĭnŭ ['dark']. Some scholars try to connect it to sten' or with sten' and sen'.
Russian sen' is related to Latvian sejs 'shadow', Gothic skeinan 'shine', Greek σκιᾱ́ 'shadow', Old Indic chāyā́ 'shadow, glare, reflex', Albanian hē 'shadow' etc. It has been tried to connect it with ten' and sten' with a taboo-deformations assumed.
A comparison of sten' to Greek σκιᾱ́ 'shadow' etc. has phonetic issues. It is probable that the connection of *sěnĭ and *stěnĭ is secondary and conditioned by a contaminaton of *sěnĭ and *těnĭ.

The original form is probably sěnĭ which can be linked to German Schein, Greek σκιᾱ́, Old Indic chāyā́ etc. However, Slavic forms with st- and t- are an issue. Taboo-deformations and contaminations (with *tĭma ['darkness'] and *stěna ['wall']) can be assumed here.

PS *těnĭ is maybe derived from *tem-nĭ with a simplification of the cluster *-mn- and a lengthening of the root vowel. It would be ultimately derived from PIE *tem(ə)- 'dark' then. A derivation from PIE *ten- 'pull, extend' (cf. Polish cienki 'thin') with a motivation 'something getting longer and shorter, something mobile' is less likely.

The original form is probably sěnĭ which can be linked to German Schein, Greek σκιᾱ́, Old Indic chāyā́ etc. However, Slavic forms with st- and t- are an issue. Taboo-deformations and contaminations (with *tĭma ['darkness'] and *stěna ['wall']) can be assumed here.

It is usually reconstructed as *tēmnĭ and linked to *tĭma ['darkness'], *tĭmĭnŭ ['dark']. Some scholars try to connect it to sten' or with sten' and sen'.
Russian sen' is related to Latvian sejs 'shadow', Gothic skeinan 'shine', Greek σκιᾱ́ 'shadow', Old Indic chāyā́ 'shadow, glare, reflex', Albanian hē 'shadow' etc. It has been tried to connect it with ten' and sten' with a taboo-deformations assumed.
A comparison of sten' to Greek σκιᾱ́ 'shadow' etc. has phonetic issues. It is probable that the connection of *sěnĭ and *stěnĭ is secondary and conditioned by a contaminaton of *sěnĭ and *těnĭ.
PS *ostrŭ is derived from PIE *ak̑- 'sharp' > *ak̑-ro-, cf. Lithuanian ašrùs, Old Indic aśtrā, Latin ācer etc.
It is a loanword from Middle Low German scharp, scherp.
PS *kortŭkŭ is derived from PIE *kert- ['cut'], cf. Lithuanian kertù, kir̃tsti 'chop', kar̃tas 'time [(as in (once, twice,) three times...)]'. Cf. PS *čersti, čĭrtǫ.
*(s)kert- 'cut, split' with Lithuanian kertù, kir̃tsti and CS črĭtu, črěsti listed as cognates.

PS *kǫsŭ 'short' is derived from PS *kǫsati 'bite' ('bitten of' > 'short').
PS *kǫsati, derived from PS *kǫd-. It has no certain further etymology beyond the Balto-Slavic.

S.v. OLith. ką́sti 'beißen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kuôst 'beißen'). The (East-)Baltic group seems to based on a PIE root *kʷend-, which has no conclusive connections in related languages. From the Slavic languages words like OCS čęstь 'Teil, Anteil, Lohn', Pol. kęs 'Bisschen, Stück', kąsać, kęsać 'beißen', Russ. kuśat' 'beißen' can be gathered, which show a root form without final *-d. Further comparisons with Ved. khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen', Arm xacanem, 'beißen, stechen', are much sketchier.

S.v. Lith. ką́sti (3.sg. kánda), Latv. kuôst 'bite', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *konʔd- (cf. Proto-Slavic *kǫsati 'bite'). The Proto-Balto-Slavic root might be formally be accounted for from either PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾-. This may have been a nasalised variant of the root *k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂d- found in Skt. khādati 'bite, chew, eat' and Arm. xacanem. Earlier proposed connections to Gk. κνώδαλον 'wild animal' and κνώδων 'sword, (pl.) teeth of a sword or a javelin' are unlikely due to formal difficulties (cf. Beekes 2010:279, 726-727).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *kǫsati 'bite' (ESSJa XII 65-66). In comparison to Baltic forms (Lith. ką́sti, Latv. kuôst) Proto-Balto-Slavic *konʔd-. If this Balto-Slavic is inherited, it would reflect a stem *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the BSl. acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾-. If this is so, then the root might be a nasalised variant of the root underlying Skt. khād- 'chew, bite, eat' and Arm. xacanem 'bite'.
It is a loanword from Greek κούντουρος.
Slovene kantata is a loanword from Italian (maybe borrowed through German) cantata, derived from cantare 'sing'.
Taking into account its phonetic form and the geographical distribution, it is most probably a loanword from Polish.
The root vowel -u- points to a Polish origin.
PS *skora is derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.
The standard Russian form nebo is a loanword from CS. The native and phonetically regular form, preserved in dialects and in the meaning 'palate' the standard Russian, is nëbo.
PS *nebo, *nebese is derived from PIe *nebʰos- and related to Lithuanian debesìs, Old Indic nábhas-, Greek νέφος, Hittite nepiš etc.
Czech obloha = ob-loha (literally 'something coating, wrapping') with the second part related to ležet 'lie'.
Cf. s.v. *legʰ- 'sich (hin)legen' (IEW 658-9).
S.v. PS *obloga < *ob-legťi.
The connection with PG *smala- 'small', Gk. μῆλον etc. is widely accepted in the Slavic etymology.
PS *dymŭ is related to Old Indic dhūmá-, Latin fūmus, Lithuanian dū́mai etc. and derived from PIE *dhūmo-.

PS *čadŭ is related to *kaditi. The difference in the initial consonant (*k- / *č-) has been explained as a result of a root vowel alternation, it have, however, rather an expressive nature. PS *kaditi does not have any clear further IE cognates. It has been linked to Old Prussian accodis 'chimney' which has been interpreted as *at-codis for the purposes of this comparison. However, as there are no other Baltic parallels of PS *kaditi, this comparison is unreliable and the Prussian word should be treated as etymologically obscure.

PS *kaditi 'burn incense'. "Due to the absence of reliable cognates, the reconstruction of the root presents difficulties."
PS *čadŭ 'smoke, fumes'. "Since the etymology is also unclear, there are a number of possible reconstructions, e.g. *k(ʷ)ed-o-, k(ʷ)eh₁d(ʰ)-o or [...] k(ʷ)ēd(ʰ)-o-."
PS *kuriti is related to Gothic haúri 'coal', Old Icelandic hyrr 'fire', Armenian krak 'fire' and Lithuanian kùrti 'make fire'.

PS *kuriti 'burn with smoke' is related to Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'make a fire', Gothic haúri 'coal', Old Icelandic hyrr 'fire', Old Indic kūḍayāti 'ignite', kunḍate 'burn' and Tocharian B kurk 'oven'. Ultimately, all these words are derived from PIE *ker(ə)- 'burn, glow'.

"If *kūrìti is cognate with Lith. kùrti, the vocalism *ū < *ou must be secondary. The Lithuanian verb, which also means 'make, create' has been connected with Skt. kr̥ṇóti 'do, make' < *kʷr-. This etymology is not implausible, though the fact that the East Baltic evidence points to a root-final laryngeal is problematic. One may consider an extended root *kʷrH-, which would not be unprecedented. A reconstruction with a labiovelar has the advantage that it explains why we find *ur instead of *ir. It seems to me that if we also wish to establish a link with Lat. carbō 'charcoal', Go. hauri n. 'coal', OIc. hyrr m. 'fire', it might be best to give up the above-mentioned etymology and simply reconstruct *kerH-".

PG *hurja 'burning coal(?)', cf. Gothic hauri 'coal, burning charcoal, ember', Old Norse hyrr 'fire', Latin carbō 'piece of charcoal'(?), Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'to light, kindle', Old Church Slavonic kuriti 'to smoke, set fire to'. Derived from Germanic and Balto-Slavic root *kerh₃-.

PS *kuriti is related to Lithuanian kùrti 'heat', Gothic haúri 'coal', Old Nordic hyrr 'fire', Old Indic kunḍate 'burn' and Tocharian B kark 'oven'. The details are obscure. The PIE root is probably *ker(H)- or *kʷer(H)- 'burn, smolder, smoke'.

S. v. carbō 'piece of charcoal'. "The root with Pokorny 1959 postulates as 'to burn' is now no longer regarded as a verbal root (Lith. kùrti is simply 'to make'). The meaning of carbō is quite specific, and the suffix not attested in the words outside Italic which are usually compared (e.g. Go. hauri 'charcoal', OIc. hyrr [m.] 'fire' < PGm. *hurja-), sot that PIE origin is uncertain.

Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'make a fire' and 'make', cf. Latvian kur̃t 'make a fire', Old Prussian kūra 'he made, did'. The word is derived from PIE *kʷer- 'cut, make, do' and related to Hittite kuerzi 'cut' and Vedic kóti 'make, do'. However, Lithuanian acute stress is an issue. No Slavic cognates given.
Bulgarian pušek is related to PS *pušiti, *puxati. PIE *peu̯s-, *pus-, *p(ʰ)ŭ-.

Proto-Slavic *puxati, cf. *puxnǫti 'swell'. Derksen considers Proto-Slavic *pux- with PIE *peu̯s- (cf. Skt. púṣyati 'thrive, flourish'). [Cf. LIV² 303-304 s.v. ?*h₃peu̯s-, without Slavic cognates listed.].
S.v. ?*(h₃)peus- 'sich mehren, reich werden an' (IEW 848). Slavic forms not connected by LIV².

"Gr. ὀπυίω besser mit J. Katz (Vortrag Kopenhagen Okt. 2009) mit ved. vapuṣyá- zu vergleichen (vgl. unten zu *u̯ep-), womit die Grundlage für den Ansatz von *h₃ entfällt (und die Reduplikation von ved. pupóṣa auch diachron völlig regulär wird)." Discounting Gk. ὀπυίω as cognate, reconstruction of initial *h₃- to the root is superfluous.
PS *puxati, derived from an ideophonic PIE root *p(ʰ)eu̯s-. It is related to Lithuanian pū̃sti, Latvian pùst, probably also to Greek phȳ̃sa, phȳsáō.
PS *gladŭkŭ is most closely related to Lithuanian glodus, German glatt and Latin glaber.
PS *mazati 'smear' is derived from PIE *maĝ-.
Cf. s.v. *mag̑- 'streichen, schmieren' See n1: Not *meh₂g̑- (cf. {ref Klingenschmitt 1982}:219n75).
Mazen is derived from maz 'fat' or maža 'smear'.
PS *ǫžĭ is related to Lithuanian angìs, Latin anguis and Old High German unc. PIE *angʷ(ʰ)i- 'snake, viper, worm'.
PS *zmĭjĭ and *zmĭja are derived from the same root as PS zeḿa 'earth'.

Slovene kača (originally 'viper') is derived from PS *kačiti 'ascend'. The latter is related to PS *skakati, *skočiti ['jump']. The etymological meaning is 'jumper'. That corresponds to the behaviour of the viper, cf. also Serbo-Croat poskok 'viper' < poskočiti 'jump (up)'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *arga- 'unmanly' (cf. ON argr 'unmanly, cowardly; lewd', OE earg 'cowardly, timid', OFri. erch 'evil, wrong'), an Indo-European adjective derived from the root *h₃erg̑ʰ- 'to copulate'.
The etymology of Slovene kača is not entirely clear. It can be derived from PIE *keu̯k- 'bend, hunch'. [See also for a summary of further hypotheses.]

S.v. Gmc. *arga- 'unzüchtig', according to {ref Puhvel 1986}:154f. to be originally an expletive from PIE *órg̑ʰo- 'gefickt' beside *org̑ʰó- 'copulator', cf. denominative verb in Gk. ὀρχέομαι 'tanze, springe, bebe' (in the sense 'act like an *ὀρχός). The verbal root may be found in Hitt. ark- 'besteigen, bespringen', and may be further connected to Lith. aržùs, eržùs 'lüstern, geil'.
S.v. Gmc. *arga- 'unzüchtig'. [Following the etymology given in {ref Heidermanns 1993}].
Cf. s.v. *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'besteigen' (IEW 328) for the proposed verbal cognates in Hitt. ark- 'bespringen', Gk. ὀρχέομαι 'tanze'.
PS *kačiti is most probably related to Old High German hāhan 'hang' and further to German hangen, English hang (with nasal infix).
PG *hangjan / *hankjan and *hanhan are derived from PIE *k̑onk-.

PS *smokŭ 'a mythical being with a form of a flying reptile' has no certain etymology.
PS *smukati 'make quick movements, smoothe, rub' and *smykati 'pull, draw' are derived from PIE *(s)meu̯k- 'slippy, to glide, to smoothe, make quick movements'.

Slovene smok 'dragon', smokulja 'kind of viper', Serbo-Croat smuk, smok 'dragon', Bulgarian and Macedonian smok 'grass snake' etc. are probably derived from PS *sŭmŭkŭ. Forms with -o- and -u- are irregular. Cf. PS *smykati sę 'crawl' and Slovene smukati se 'rub'.
The etymology of Slovene smok is obscure. If the PS protoform is *smokŭ, it is derived from PS *smokati 'suck'. Less probably it is a loanword from Germanic, cf. English snake.

S.v. NHG Gras (MHG gras, OHG gras, OS gras) from Germ. *grasa- 'Gras, Kraut', also in Goth. gras, ON gras, OE græs. The closest relative in IE seems to be Lat. grāmen (from *grasmen) '(Gras)Stengel', (especially as animal feed). It can also belong to Gk. gráō 'ich fresse', Gk. grástis 'Futterkraut, Grünfutter', Ved. grásati 'verschlingt, frißt'. On the other hand, maybe related to Germ. grō-a- 'wachsen' as a morphologically unclear derivative.

S.v. Germ. Laus (MHG lūs, OHG lūs, MDu. lūs), an s-stem from *luw-, which is also found in W. llau. The correspondence in Ved. is yūkā, Balto-Slavic *ū- (cf. Lith. utė̃), Russ. voš. It is possible that the differences can be accounted for by taboo deformation of the same base or expressive deformations.

S.v. NHG Haupt (MHG houbet, OHG houbit, OS hōbid), from Germanic *haubida- 'Haupt', also found in Goth. haubiϸ, ON haufið, OE hēafod, OFr. hāved, hā(u)d, hafd. May be compared with Lat. caput and probably from a formation with suffix ablaut *kapwet-, *kaput-. Other words from the same root like Skt. kapā́la- 'Schale, Hirnschale, Schädel' suggest semantics from 'Hirnschale'.
Cf. s.v. NHG Luft (MHG, OHG luft), from Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'Luft' (cf. Goth. luftus, OE lyft). Provenance unclear.
*(s)meu̯k- 'glide, slide' with Slovene smukati, smučem 'slip', Czech smeknouti 'wipe', Old English smūgan 'crawl, cuddle' etc. listed as cognates.
PS *plĭvati, *pľujǫ is related to Lithuanian spiáuti, spiáuju, Gothic speiwan, Latin spuō, spuere, Greek πτῡ́ω etc., all derived from PIE *(s)pi̯ēu̯- 'spit'.

S.v. NHG Dreck (MHG drec, OHG drec, MLG dreck, MDu. drec), from Gmc. *ϸrekka- 'Dreck, Kot' also in ON ϸrekkr, OE ϸreax, OFr. threkk. The basis is an IE root *(s)terg- which may be connected with Gk. στεργάνος 'Dung' and with variation in root final voicing Lat. stercus 'Dünger', cf. also Lith. ter̃šti '(be)schmutzen'.
Cf. s.v. Gk. στεργάνος· κόπρων (Hesych.).
Cf. s.v. Gk. στεργάνος· κόπρων 'place for dung'. No etymology. Not related to Lat. stercus 'excrements'.

S.v. NHG Schmutz, from Early Modern High German smu(t)z from the verb smutzen 'beflecken'. Semantically stands closest to the root of Greek μυδάω 'ich bin feucht, verderbe von der Nässe, verwese' without s-mobile.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ferrai (adv.) 'far', from PIE *per-n-oi-, a locative adverb originally ending in -noi.
S.v. 1. *pér, *pérā̆, *pérām, *pérti- 'durch, darüber, hinaus, über; sehr' Adverb, lokal; oft mit. Akk. steigerndes Präfix.
S.v. Gmc. *hreit-a- (?) 'reißen'. Uncertain. Perhaps a secondary deviation from PGmc. *wreit-a-, perhaps contamination from another root.

PS *zoŕa / *zaŕa 'dawn, aurora' is derived from PS *zĭrěti 'look'. Cf. Lithuanian žarà 'dawn, aurora', žarijà 'glowing coal, embers', žėrėti, žėriù 'shine, glimmer', Old Prussian sari 'embers' and, further, German grau 'gray' and Old Irish grían 'sun'. PIE *g̑ʰer(ə)-.

Cf. s.v. ?3. *g̑ʰer- 'strahlen, scheinen; sehen' (IEW 441-2). An exclusively Balto-Slavic root. The reconstruction of aspiration on the initial consonant of the root is uncertain, and the semantics are problematic.
Cf. s.v. ON klifra, comparable to OE clifrian 'kratzen' and related to ON klífa klettern.
Cf. s.v. ?*glei̯bʰ- 'kleben, bleiben' (IEW 363). Only Germanic and Balto-Slavic.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *klīban- 'to stick' (ON klífa 'to climb', OHG klīban 'to stick', etc.) < PIE *gleibʰ-e- (cf. Latv. gliêbtiês, -juos 'to cling' < *gleib-ie-. A root exclusive to Germanic and Balto-Slavic.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *klīƀanan str.vb.

Cf. s.v. Gmc. *kleib-a- 'haften'. See under derivatives klib-ǣ- > OE clifian 'haften bleiben'. Only potential cognates in Balto-Slavic (cf. Latv. gliêbjuos 'sich an jemand klammern, anschmiegen', OCS u-glьběti 'stecken bleiben') pointing to a root *gleibh-.

Russian palka (along with Serbo-Croat palica, Slovene palica, Polish pałka etc.) is most probably not a loanword from Old High German pfâl 'pal' (which is, in turn, a borrowing from Latin pāllus). It is maybe related to Old High German spaltan 'split', Old Indic spháṭati 'split', spuṭáti 'tear' etc. It is also rather unrelated to palec ['finger'].
Russian palec ['finger'] (cf. also Polish palec, Czech palec, Upper Sorbian palc etc.) is derived from PS *palŭ (cf. Russian bespalyj, šestipalyj). It is usually linked to Latin pollex 'thumb, big toe'. It can be further related to New Persian pālidan 'look for' and Old High German fuolen 'feel'.
[Cf. also for a summary of other hypotheses.]

The etymology of PS *palica is not entirely clear.
It can be related to pálit 'bounce' that is related to Latin pellere 'drive away, kill, beat' and maybe also to Old Indich sphāláyati 'clash, beat'. Then it would be derived from PIE *(s)pel- 'beat'. In Slavic, it has been contaminated with pálit 'glow, burn'. It is also possible that both verbs have a common origin.
Another hypothesis links PS *palica to PS *paliti 'glow, burn' (derived from PIE *pel-/*pol-). The semantic motivatition were that sticks as tools were seared over the fire to get durable.
If the meaning of PS *palica was originally 'thick stick', it could be also compared with PS *palŭ that is derived from PIE *pōlo- 'thick', cf. palec ['toe, thumb'].
S.v. Arb. dúshku 'Wald'. (=StAlb dushk). Because of the larger family of words in Albanian, it is certainly an old word, whose further etymology cannot, however be more precisely determined.
S.v. 9425 Skt. bhásman- n. 'ashes'.

S.v. NHG Asche (MHG asche, OHG asca, MLG asche) from Germanic *aska- 'Asche', also found in ON aska, OE æsce, beside *azgo- in Goth. azgo. Probably a formation belonging to IE *has- 'Herd' (cf. similarly Ved. ā́sa- Hitt. hašš- 'Asche'); cf. also NHG Esse 'Feuerherd, Schmiedefeuer' (MHG esse, OHG essa, from Gmc. *esjō 'Esse', also in OSw. æsja), outside of Germanic compare Lat. āra 'Brandaltar' Hitt. hašš- 'Herd, Feuerstelle')
S.v. Ved. ā́sa- 'Asche, leicht verfliegender Staub', connected with an IE root *h₂es- 'brennen, vertrocknen' (cf. Lat. āridus 'trocken', OHG asca 'Asche', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).
S.v. Ved. aghá- 'böse, schlimm, gefährlich' (adj.); 'Übel, Gefahr, Schaden' (n.). See YAv. aγa- 'schlecht, böse'; probably to be connected with Goth. aglaiti 'Unzucht', agl 'Bestrafung', etc.
Cf. s.v. Goth. A49. *agls (only n.sg. agl), from PIE *agh-(lo-) 'disagreeable' (cf. Skt. aghás, Av. aγō- 'evil', MIr. ālad 'wound').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *agla- 'painful' (Goth. agls* 'disgraceful') < PIE *h₂egʰ-lo- (cf. Skt. aghá- 'evil, bad, dangerous', YAv. aγa- 'bad, evil' < *h₂ogʰ-o-, Gk. ἄχνυμαι 'to grieve, lament for' < *h₂egʰ-néu̯-).
Cf. s.v. *h₂egʰ- 'in Furcht geraten, betrübt werden' (IEW 7-8). Cf. n1 also comparing Ved. aghá- n. 'Leid, Gefahr', Gk. ἄχος 'Leid, Schmerz' = Goth. agis 'Furcht, Angst'.
S.v. Ved. pāpá- 'schlimm, übel, böse', an Indo-Iranian word if YAv. pāpa- 'übel' is attested in the compound pāpō.vačah-. The origin of Ved. pāpá- is uncertain.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *volknò 'fibre' (< PIE *u̯olk̑-nom, cf. OE wlōh 'fibre, fringe' [no connection to Indo-Iranic lexemes mentioned]).
Cf. s.v. 2852 Skt. karta- (2) m. *'cutting'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. mála- 'Schmutz, Unreinlichkeit, Unrat, Dreck', probably to be derived from PIE *mélo-, cf. Gk μέλας 'black', Lith. mė́las 'blue', mel̃svas 'blueish'.

Cf. s.v. μέλας 'dark-colored, black' < PIE *mel(h₂)-n- 'black'. The feminine stem μέλαινα is traditionally identified with Skt. malinī < *melh₂-n-ih₂ and the masculine/neuter stem μελαν- would be a modification of an earlier thematic *μέλανο- equivalent to Skt. malina- 'dirty'. It should be noted, however, that malinī is only known in the form of a gloss 'menstruating woman' and malina- is an epic classical Sanskrit derivative from Ved. mála- 'dirt', which could in principle also be derived from *molh₂-o-. There are additional colour words which may be compared from Baltic: Latv. męl̃ns 'black', OPruss. melne 'blue spot', Lith. mul̃vas 'yellow (of clay)'.

Cf. s.v. μέλας 'sombre, noir', compared by {ref Frisk 1960-1972} with Skt. malinī- which corresponds to μέλαινα but is a term that signifies 'femme qui a ses règles', malina- 'sale' (attested only late), and very simple comparisons with terms in Baltic *mēlna- < *melə-no- in Latv. męl̃ns 'noir', OPr. melne 'tache bleue', Lith. mė́las, mė́lynas 'bleu'.
Cf. s.v. Latv. mȩl̃ns 'black' (cf. OPr. melne 'blue spot, bruise'), from PIE *melh₂-n- (cf. Gk. μέλας 'dark, black').
S.v. 9905 Skt. maliná- 'dirty'.

S.v. Ved. pr̥thivī́- 'die Erde, Mutter Erde, vergöttliche Erde', originally the feminine stem to pr̥thú- 'wide' as an epithet of the earth; cf. s.v. Ved. pr̥thú- 'breit, weit, ausgedehnt groß, zahlreich, umfänglich' (cf. IIr. OAv. pərəθu- 'breit, weit'), from PIE *plth₂-ú- (cf. Gk. πλατύς 'weit, breit, flach, eben', Lith. platùs 'weit, breit, ausgedehnt', etc.). p.179 "práthas- n. Weite, Breite, Ausdehnung [...] Iir., jav. fraϑah- n. "Breite" - Idg. *pléth₂-es-"
S.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (LIV 486f., IEW 833).
Cf. s.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (IEW 833).
S.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (LIV 486f., IEW 833).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *ę̄drò 'kernel, core' (ESSJa VI 65-66). "The connection with Skt. āṇḍá- (RV, AV+) n. 'egg; testicle' has generally been abandoned."

S.v. Proto-Iranian *Hi̯au̯d- 'to fight, to struggle (for something), strive, seek', from PIE *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'to fight, to set out, move (to fight)' (cf. Skt. yodh- 'to fight', OLat. ioube-, Lat. iubēre 'to order, command', Lith. judė́ti 'to move', Lith. judùs 'belligerent', Gk. ὑσμίνη 'battle, fight').
S.v. 9758 Ved. mátsya- m. 'fish'. 2. *matsiya-.
Cf. s.v. 8303 Skt. púṣpa- n. 'flower' and 8306 Skt. púṣya- (1) n. 'vigour'.
S.v. 11258 Skt. vána- (1) n. (once m. R.) 'single tree' RV., 'forest, timber' RV. 2. vanikā- f. 'grove' MBh.
S.v. 11258 Skt. vána- (1) n. (once m. R.) 'single tree' RV., 'forest, timber' RV. 2. vanikā- f. 'grove' MBh.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯aH-³ / *čiH- 'to freeze' > NPers. čā(h)īdan/čay- 'to become cold', Yaghn. ši- 'to freeze', etc.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯aH-³ / *čiH- 'to freeze' > NPers. čā(h)īdan/čay- 'to become cold', Yaghn. ši- 'to freeze', etc.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯aH-³ / *čiH- 'to freeze' > NPers. čā(h)īdan/čay- 'to become cold', Yaghn. ši- 'to freeze', etc.
S.v. śyā́yati 'macht gerinnen, macht gefrieren / causes to congeal, causes to freeze'. "Außerarische Anschüsse bleiben unsicher."
S.v. śyā́yati 'macht gerinnen, macht gefrieren / causes to congeal, causes to freeze'. "Außerarische Anschüsse bleiben unsicher."
S.v. 14021 Skt. hásati ʻ laughs ʼ ṢaḍvBr. [√has].
Cf. s.v. *h₂énti 'vorne, vor', *h₂énto 'gegenüber, entgegen' (Adverbien, lokal; oft mit Gen., Akk.).

PS *pala 'thick stick' (with diminutives *palŭka and *palica) is probably derived from PIE *pōlo- 'thick', see also palec ['finger' < 'thoe, thumb']. Cf. Latin pollex 'thumb', polleō, pollēre 'be strong'.
Polish pal 'pole' is a loanword from Middle High German pfâl.

"The alleged connection with CS palьcь [...] < PSl. *palьcь < *pōl- does not explain Latin pollex. Meier-Brügger 1990 proposes to explain pollex from *por-likʰ-s 'which is licked over' to the root *leiɡ́ʰ- 'to lick' (see Lat. linɡō)."

PS *pala (along with *palica, *palŭka, *palĭ) has some possible explanations. Most probably it is related to PS palĭcĭ 'thick finger'. I has been also explainded as derived from PIE *(s)p(ʰ)el- 'chop, bang' or compared to *paliti 'burn'.
Cf. s.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (IEW 535).
PS *kyjĭ is related to PS *kovati and ultimately derived from PIE *kou̯- (cf. German hauen, Latin cūdo, cūdere, Lithuanian káuti etc.).
PS *prętati and *prǫtŭ have no certain etymology.

PS *prǫtŭ is etymologically obscure. There are similar words in Germanic (cf. German Spross, English sprout, Old Icelandic sproti) but it is complicated to put them together with the Slavic lexeme (the Slavic form points to *pronto- and the Germanic one to *spreudo-). However, the Slavic and Germanic forms could be maybe linked to PIE *(s)per- 'splash, sparkle, sprout'.
PS *prętati is usually linked to PS *prǫtŭ ['sprout, sprig']. However, it has not been proven, that PS *prętati had meanings like 'entwine, wrap'.

It is complicated to explain PS *prętati etymologically without linking it to *prǫtŭ ['sprout, sprig'], although it is not fully convincing semantically. However, if we assume that the meaning 'hide' is not original, this problem can be solved (*prętati could originally mean 'wrap, cover with sprouts' etc.).
Russian prâtat' ['hide'] is related to prut ['sprout, sprig']. The original meaning of the verb was 'wrap' (and that of prut 'sprout good for binding, intertwining, wrapping').
PS *prętati is related to PS *prǫtŭ 'sprout, sprig'. The PIE root is *preu- / *prou- / *prū- 'jump, burst', cf. also Russian prygat' 'jump'.
PS *ščapa, *ščapŭ 'flaked piece of wood' (cf. Serbo-Croat štap 'stick', Polish szczapa 'chip of wood' etc.) is derived from PIE skep 'chop, split'.
Cf. s.v. 1. *(s)kep- 'hacken, hauen' cf. n1 with Russian ščepa 'woodchip' listed as a reflex.
The Slavic lexeme is related to German kahl 'bald'. PIE *galo-.

PIE *golH-o-. The lexeme is related to Old High German kalo 'bald' and Old English calu 'bald'. "In spin of the incompatibility of the initial consonants (*g : *k), it is tempting to connect the (Balto-)Slavic and the Germanic forms with Lat. calvus 'bald' and Skt. kulva- 'bald, thin-haired'."

PS *gol- 'naked' is often assumed to be related to German kahl 'bald, hairless'. However, the Gemanic root is restricted to West Germanic only and needs itself to be explained etymologicaly. PS *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('naked, smooth, not overgrown' < 'smooth' < 'shining').

Most scholars assume the relationship of the Slavic root to German kahl 'bald' and its further Germanic cognates. The hypothesis of ESSJa (accepted by some other scholars) is reasonable but more complex.

Proto-Germanic *kalwa (PIE *golH-uo-) > German kahl 'bald' etc. It is related to OCS golŭ 'naked' etc. (PIE *golH-o-). It is a Germanic-Balto-Slavic isogloss unrelated to Latin calvus and Sanskrit kulvá- (PIE *klH-uo-).
PIE *gal-, related to German kahl 'bald' etc.
PIE *galo-, related to German kahl and English callow etc.
PS *gol- is related do Old High German kalo 'bald' etc.
The Slavic *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('shine' > 'smooth, not overgrown' > 'naked').
Czech klacek is a borrowing from German Klotz.
Polabian klac is a loanword from Middle German kloz.
Cf. Turkish çomak.

PS *praviti 'tell' is derived from PS *pravŭ in the meaning 'true, correct' and not 'straighten'. Its original meaning was 'tell the truth'. PS *pravŭ is derived from PIE *próh₃u̯o- (*prōu̯o-) and related to Old Indic pū́rva- 'first', English first etc.

PS *prostŭ is probably a compound of PIE *pro- 'forward, ahead, in front of' and *sto-, a derivative from *stā- 'stand'. The original meaning would be thus 'something standing in the front of something/someone'.
S.v. *steh₂-.
PS *orvĭnŭ is derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'spread out, open'.
It is ultimately derived from PIE *per-, cf. also related PIE *pro-.
PS *vedrŭ is certainly related to German Wetter 'weather'. The protoform was *u̯e-dʰro-, derived from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *vedro 'nice weather', from PIE *u̯edʰrom (cf. OIc. veðr 'weather', OHG wetar).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather'. "The Walser German form wedar as in 's wedar dr fenstro 'windowpane' (Schott 1842: 340) points to a variant *weϸra- beside *wedra-. This means that the word may have been a mobile neuter in Pre-Gm., viz. *uétr-om, pl. *uetr-éh₂. This proto-form further implies that the received etymological link with OCS vedro n. 'clear sky' < *uedʰro- cannot be maintained. The connection with OCS vetro 'air, wind' < *ueh₁-tro-, Lith. vė́tra < *h₂ueh₁-treh₂- (see *wēan-) is formally problematic as well, because the underlying form would give PGm. *weϸra- (laryngeals are not lost before *CR-, pace Schindler apud Peters 1999). Olr. feth f. 'wind(?)' can theoretically be derived from *ueto- without a laryngeal, but is more likely to have developed out of *h₂ueh₁-tó- by pretonic shortening (Dybo's law). The only way to retain the connection of the Germanic word with the PIE root *h₂ueh₁- 'to blow' is to reconstruct it as *h₂uh₁-etr-o- (or *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- in view of OCS vedro) with the same suffix as found in e.g. Gr. Hom. λοετρόν 'bath, bathing site' (derived from λούω 'to bathe')."
Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯eh₁- 'wehen' (IEW 81-4).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *bolgъ 'good' (ESSJa II 174). "Etymology unclear. The etymon has been compared with Skt. Bŕ̥haspáti- (name of a God) and Av. bərəg- f. 'rite', but this is highly speculative."

The etymology of PS *bolgo is not entirely clear. It has been linked to Avestan bərəg- 'rite, custom'. However, this etymology is rather a question of belief. A comparison to bolĭjĭ ['better, bigger'] were formally possible (then *bolgo < *bol-g-o).
PS *bolgŭ is rerived from PIE *belg̑- 'shine, glimmer'. The semantic development was 'shining, light' > 'good' (cf. Polish świetny 'very good, great' < 'light, shining').
PS bolgŭ does not have any convincing explanation. It has been assumed to be derived from PIE *bʰel-ɡ- 'shine' (cf. PS bělŭ 'white').
PS *blagŭ is derived from PIE *bʰelɡ- 'shine, glow' (cf. Old Indic bhárgas- 'brightness, glare'), a derivetive from PIE bʰel- (cf. PS *bělŭ 'white').
PS *dǫti. It is related to Old Indic dhámati 'blow' and Lithuanian dumiu, dùmti 'blow'.
PS *puxati, derived from an ideophonic PIE root *p(ʰ)eu̯s-. It is related to Lithuanian pū̃sti, Latvian pùst, probably also to Greek phȳ̃sa, phȳsáō.
PS *teťi 'go, run, flow' is derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'run, flow'.
PS *teťi 'go, run, flow' is derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'run, flow'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tekti 'flow, run', from PIE *tekʷ- (cf. Skt. tákti 'rush', OIr. techid 'flee').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tekti 'flow, run', from PIE *tekʷ- (cf. Skt. tákti 'rush', OIr. techid 'flee').
S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-1060).
S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-1060).
PS *pǫčiti, *pučiti is certainly a derivative from *pǫkati, *pukati 'burst, fissure'. The root is ideophonic.
This word has an ideophonic origin.
PS *pǫčiti, *pǫkti 'swell, burst', *pǫčati 'bud, germinate', *pǫkŭ 'bud' are derived from PIE *ponHk-, cf. Latin pānus 'tumour'.

"In the meaning 'spool with thread', pānus may well be a loanword from Doric Greek *πα̃νης  [...]. In the meaning 'abcess', pānus is comared with Ru. puk 'bunch, bundel', OCS pǫ̀čiti sę 'be inflated', Ru. púčit' 'become swollen' < *ponHk-; a root *pnHk- is reconstructed from which Schrijver phonetically derives pānus. This is conceivable, but it is just as likely that the word for 'spool' was metaphorically used for 'abces', and certainly for 'tuft' of reed (pānicula) [...]."
S.v. Skt. mū́lam 'Wurzel', 'root'. 'Nicht eindeutig erklärt.'
S.v. 10250 Ved. mū́la- (mū́ra- AV.) n. 'root' RV.
S.v. Ved. √dhāv- 'laufen, eilen, fließen, strömen', from PIE *dʰeu̯- (cf. Gk. θέω 'laufe', θοός 'schnell').

The etymology of PS *rępŭ is obscure. IE protoforms *u̯repos (with a comparison with Albanian vrap 'run' and Greek ῥεπω 'bend') and *u̯rempi- (with a comparison with Swedish rumpa 'tail' and German Rumpf 'thorax') has been proposed.
PS *rępŭ does not have any convincing etymology. It has been linked to Swedish rumpa 'tail' and German Rumpf 'thorax'. However, it is not without phonetic issues.
PS *rępŭ is etymologically obscure.
Note that Slavic etymology dictionaries do not compare PS *ręp 'tail' an PS *rěpa 'turnip' at all.

PS *ręp 'chondral vertebra with tail base, backbone' is related to Lithuanian rem̃bti 'become lethargic', rémbėti 'become gnarled, scarred', rim̃bas 'whipcord', rum̃bas 'scar', Latvian rùobs 'notch, gap', Old Icelandic rumpr 'bum', Swedish rumpa 'bum' and German Rumpf ['thorax'].
Lexemes like Upper Sorbian rjapać, Polish rzępolić, Slovene repeti are derived from an ideophonic root *rep-, *rĭp-, *rop-, *rŭp-, *ręp- 'make rattling, drumming, creaky, banging noises, murmur, buzz, grunt (about goats, pigs etc.)'.

Polish rzępolić 'play unskillfully a violin [and general any string instrument' and Kashubian rzãpic 'to cut unskillfully (with a blunt knife)' are expressive derivatives, cf. dialectal Polish rzępić 'cut clumsy (with a blunt knife)', rzępieć na kimć 'to annoy someone with speaking', Kashubian rząpic, rzëpic 'breathe with difficulties, rasp, crepitate, rattle, cough strongly', Lower Sorbian rjapaś, rjapiś 'crack the whip, chastise', Upper Sorbian rjapać 'crack, crackle, creak', dialectal Czech řapět 'clatter, knock, make a noise'. All these lexemes are derived from PS *rępiti / *rępati / *rępěti 'make rumbling, creaky, crispy sounds' with an ideophonic origin.

Kashubian řąp 'a clumsy cut piece of bread, thick slice', 'shred, snippet, rag' is derived from PS *rępiti / *rępati / *rępěti 'make rumbling, creaky, crispy sounds' (> 'cut with a primitive or inappropriate tool with creaky noises').
Kaszubian řąpolëc etc. 'cut clumsy', 'play unskillfully an instrument (especially violin)', 'scrap the fiddle' is derived from PS *rępiti / *rępati / *rępěti 'make rumbling, creaky, crispy sounds'.
A link to Old Polisz rząp (PS *rępŭ 'tail') is inconvincing.
Polish rząp 'tail', Upper Sorbian rjap 'backbone' and Polish rzępolić ['play unskillfully an instrument'] have a common origin.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *xvostъ. Probably, the best explanation is to link PS *xvostŭ to the expressive word family with meanings 'catch' etc. and onsets *xva-, *xvo-, *xu-, *xy-.

PS *xvostŭ does not have any certain etymology. Taking Slovene hosta 'forest' into account, one could assume a voiceless variant related to hvozd 'huge, thick forest' (then it could be compared to German Quast[e] 'tassel'. It can be also derived from PS *xvostati with an ideophonic origin. The original meaning of PS xvostŭ was probably 'broom'.
It does not have any universally accepted etymology. It has been compared to German Quast.
PS *obpašĭka is ultimately derived from PS *ob-paxati (*paxati 'sweep, broom, wave').
Bulgarian opaš, opaška is derived from PS *paxati 'blow'.
S.v. 10978 Skt. lavaṇá n. 'salt'.
The etymology of PS *paxati 'blow' and related *paxnǫti 'smell (of)' is unknown. According to Vasmer, it is of ideophonic origin.
PS *paxati is derived from PIE *pē̆s- 'blow'.

PS *paxati 'blow' is probably related to Lithuanian puošti 'clean',  Old High German fegōn 'prepare, sweep, arrange', Old Nordic fága 'clean' etc. and derived from PIE *pēk̑- 'clean, tidy, decorate'.
PS *paxnǫti has probably an ideophonic origin. It resembles the roots *pyx-, *pux- which, however, have a wider cognacy.

PS *goniti (sę) is derived from PIE *gʷʰen- and related to Old Indic hánti 'hit, kill', Greek θείνω 'hit', Lithuanian genù, giñti 'chase', Hittite kuen-, kun- 'hit, kill', Latin de-fendere 'defend', Old Icelandic gunnr 'battle', Tocharian kuñac 'quarrel, battle' etc.
Cf. s.v. *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).
PS dialectal *ogonŭ is derived from *o(b)-goniti sę 'keep off, drive off', cf. PS *goniti 'chase, drive, run'.
S.v. 9250 Skt. bī́ja- n. 'seed, semen'.
S.v. 13236 Skt. samudrá- m. (n. once) 'sea' RV. [udán-].

S.v. Ved. √hras- 'verringern, klein machen, kürzen' (Skt. hrasvá- 'kurz, klein'; mi., ni., pā. rassa- pkt. hassa-, rahasa- 'klein, leicht', etc.), probably from PIE *g̑ʰres-/*g̑ʰers- (MIr. gerr 'kurz').

The etymology of Czech ocas is unclear. For Czech itself a relationship with dialectal cásati 'tear, pluck, pull' could be assumed. However, this hypothesis does not work for other lanugages (cf. Serbo-Croat dialectal oćas, CS očesŭ, Polish dialectal ocas, oczas). Conversely, a link to PS *česati would work only for CS. It is possible that we deal here with a contamination of two etymona or a folk etymology.
An interesting alternative is an interpretation as PS *ot-jasŭ (cf. *po-jasŭ ['belt']) with a meaning 'a thing hanging at the midsection'.

As to (Old) Russian očes 'tail', an explanation as a derivative from *česati would be attractive. However, it does not explain forms in other Slavic languages. It has been also reconstructed as *otjas (with PIE *jōs-, cf. poâs 'belt'). However, this hypothesis is improbable from the semantic point of view.
Cf. s.v. *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein' (IEW 1016-7).
