PS *ocasŭ? (the reconstruction uncertain) is etymologically obscure. The relationship to *česati can be a result of folk etymology. The interpretation as *ot-jasŭ (cf. *pojasŭ) is inconvincing semantically. If one would assume that the original meaning focused on the protruded nature and the hardness of tail, on could link PS *ocasŭ? to PS *ostĭ and other words referring to sharpness.
S.v. *g̑ʰeres-, *g̑ʰres-, *g̑ʰers- (Ved. hrasvá- 'minder, kurz, klein', MIr. gerr 'kurz').

Cf. in discussion to OIr. gar 'short; near', garait 'short'(?), with synonymous gerr with e-grade; not necessarily continuing an s-extension as commonly assumed, but could perhaps be accounted for due to expressive gemination.
Alternatively to {ref IEW} 443, {ref EWAia} II:823, {ref de Bernardo Stempel 1999}:68n57, perhaps an original s-stem adjective to a root *g̑ʰer- could also be considered.
PS *o-pušĭ, *o-pyšĭ 'tail' is derived from PS *puxati 'blow, breathe strongly'.

Proto-Slavic *puxati, cf. *puxnǫti 'swell'. Derksen considers Proto-Slavic *pux- with PIE *peu̯s- (cf. Skt. púṣyati 'thrive, flourish'). [Cf. LIV² 303-304 s.v. ?*h₃peu̯s-, without Slavic cognates listed.].
S.v. ?*(h₃)peus- 'sich mehren, reich werden an' (IEW 848). Slavic forms not connected by LIV².

"Gr. ὀπυίω besser mit J. Katz (Vortrag Kopenhagen Okt. 2009) mit ved. vapuṣyá- zu vergleichen (vgl. unten zu *u̯ep-), womit die Grundlage für den Ansatz von *h₃ entfällt (und die Reduplikation von ved. pupóṣa auch diachron völlig regulär wird)." Discounting Gk. ὀπυίω as cognate, reconstruction of initial *h₃- to the root is superfluous.
PS *puxati, derived from an ideophonic PIE root *p(ʰ)eu̯s-. It is related to Lithuanian pū̃sti, Latvian pùst, probably also to Greek phȳ̃sa, phȳsáō.
It is a loanword from Turkish kuyruk 'tail'.
PS *ęti, *jĭmǫ is derived from PIE *em-, cf. Latin emō, emere 'buy', older 'take' and Lithuanian imù, im̃ti 'take'.

Cf. s.v. *teu̯h₂- 'schwellen, stark werden' (IEW 1080-1) and ?2.*teu̯k- 'stark/fett werden, schwellen' (IEW 1081). The nominal forms such as OCS tukъ 'fat', OIr. tón f. 'bottom' and Old Norse þjó 'thigh' are assigned to the latter. Latvian tauks 'fat' and OIr. tón both from *tŭknā-.

S.v. Lith. taukaĩ 'fat' (Latv. tàuki 'fat', OPr. taukis 'lard'). The Balto-Slavic lexemes presuppose PIE *tou̯Hk-o-, with the root *teu̯Hk- possibly being a contamination of *teu̯H- and *teu̯k- or an extension of *teu̯H-. For *teu̯H-, Derksen cites Serbo-Croat tȉti 'become fat' as a derivation. He regards the root form 2.?*teu̯k- postulated by LIV² as shaky, noting that Lithuanian tùkti was no evidence for a non-acute root.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tučьnъ 'fat, rich'. The Balto-Slavic lexemes presuppose PIE *tou̯Hk-o-, with the root *teu̯Hk- possibly being a contamination of *teu̯H- and teu̯k- or an extension of *teu̯H-.

PS *tlŭstŭ is derived from PIE *tu-l- / tū-l-, ultimately from *teu̯(ə)- / *tēu̯- / *tū̆- 'swell'. PS *tukŭ is derived from PIE *teu̯-k-, ultimately from *tēu̯(ə)- / *tēu̯- / *təu̯ / *tū 'swell'.

Lithuanian taukaĩ could be explained as *tou̯h₂-kó- from PIE *teu̯h₂-. The other Baltic lexemes however are better derived from *teu̯k-. This root *teu̯k- would also be sufficient to explain OIr. tón 'bottom'. Thus taukaĩ either is a substantival Vrddhi-form, or we see in Baltic a contamination of two different, pre-existing forms *tou̯h₂-kó- and *tou̯k-ó-.
Cf. s.v. 4520 ghōṇā f. 'nose, beak (of owl)'; 4531 Skt. ghrāṇá- n. 'smelling'.
Cf. s.v. Skt. ghoṇā 'Nase / Nose'; probably a dialectal variant of ghrāṇā 'id.'.

S.v. Ved. √dhay-ⁱ (2) 'hinblicken, schauen, wahrnehmen, ersinnen, nachdenken, denken' (IIr., cf. OAv. daidiiat̰ 'ob er sieht; ob sie sehen' Y 44.10, YAv. ā-diδaiia 'betrachtet', OPers. dīdiy 'betrachte, schaue an!', Khot. dai-/däta-, MPers., NPers. dīdan 'sehen', Parth. dydn⁽ʾ⁾ 'apparition', etc. Further is uncertain. Formally PIE *dʰei̯H- or *dʰeH-i-?
S.v. *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen' (IEW 243). Only IIr. and Albanian (Alb. di 'weiß, kennt' < ?*dʰiH-i̯é-).
Cf. s.v. OAlb. di (trans.) 'wissen, kennen, können, beherrschen', continuing a present stem *dʰiH-i̯é/ó- or *dʰiH-e/o- from the root *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen'; other solutions are improbable.
S.v. Ved. √kṣep- 'schleudern, werfen', not to be separated from YAv. xšuuaēβa- 'sich rasch schwingend, schnellend'.

S.v. Ved. √ard- 'zerstieben, sich schütteln', with derivative ārdrá- 'feucht, naß', perhaps to be connected with YAv. arəduš- 'Verletztung, Hieb' and outside of IIr. ON erta 'aufstacheln, aufreizen', Lith. ardýti 'zerlegen, auftrennen'.
S.v. 1340 Skt. ārdrá- 'wet' RV. 2. *ālla- < *ārdla-.
Cf. s.v. *Herd- 'ins Schwanken geraten' [IEW 329-30, 334].

PS *grubŭ, *grǫbŭ is related to Lithuanian grùbti 'become numb, stiffen' and Latvian grumbt 'dimple'. It is reconstructed as PIE *gʰreu̯-bʰ- < *ɡʰer- 'rub strongly, tear'. Cf. als PS *gruda ['clod'].
PS *gruda is related to Lithuanian grū́das 'corn', English grit, German Grütze 'groats' etc. PIE *gʰreu̯-d- 'rub (to powder)'.

PS *grubŭ, *grǫbŭ 'raw, rugged, rough, thick, obese' is related to Lithuanian grùbti, grumbù 'roughen, become numb, stiffen' etc. and derived from PIE *ɡʰru-m-bʰ-o < *gʰreu̯-bʰ- which is an extention of PIE *ɡʰrēu̯-, *ɡʰrəu̯- 'rub'. The semantic development was like 'rub' > 'rugged, rough' [attested in Slavic], > 'raw, clumsy' [attested in Slavic] > 'thick, fat' [attested in Slavic].
PS *gruda 'clod' is derived from PIE *ɡʰreu̯d- 'rub, pound, crumb, shatter'.

PS *grǫbŭ (originally 'gravelly, rugged' < 'uneven, crooked') is related to Anglo-Saxon crumb, Old High German krump, German krumm 'crooked', further with Lithuanian grùbti, grùmbu 'stiffen', Greek γρυμπάνειν 'bend' and Middle High German krimpf 'crooked'. PIE *gerb 'crooked' < *ger- 'wind, turn, twist'.

PS *grǫbŭ, *grubŭ is related to PS *grǫda, *gruda, *grǫdŭ, *grudŭ. Semantic and formal connections make it possible, to assume a suffix -d- an a nasal infix in the latter. Cf. Latvian grauds 'corn', Lithuanian grudas 'corn', Old Icelandic grjót 'stones', Anglo-Saxon gréot 'sand', German Griess 'grit' and further Latin grandis 'big' (*gʷrə-n-dʰ-) and forms without the nasal infix like German groß 'big' and English great (West Germanic *grauta-).

PS *grǫbŭ, *grubŭ 'coarse, rude' is derived from PIE *gru(m)bʰ- and related to Lithuanian grubùs 'uneven, rough', Lativian grum̃bulaȋns 'uneven, rough', Old Icelandic kryppa 'hump' and Old High German kropf 'crop, gizzard'.
PS *grǫda, *grǫdŭ, *gruda, grudŭ 'heap, lump' is derived Balto-Slavic *grouʔd- and grúodas 'frozen earth or mud'. "These words are usually considered cognate with Latv. graûds ‘grain’, OIc. grautr 'groats', etc., in which case the root is *gʰroud-. The nasal in Pl. grąd may be secondary. I have adopted the ESSJa's set of lemmata, but it should be noted that the evidence for a nasalized vowel is very limited. One may wonder if the o-stem *grǫdŭ belongs here. The reconstructions with *ǫ are partly based on the suggested connections with *gręda and grǫ̑dь, neither of which is beyond doubt. Forms such as Bulg. gărdá 'breast', which points to a nasal, may not belong here."

PG *gruba- 'coarse' (cf. Middle Dutch grof 'large, crude, loud', Dutch grof 'coarse', Middle High German grop 'thick, strong, big') < *gʰrubʰ-o- is related to Lithuanian ɡrubùs 'uneven, rough' < *gʰrubʰ-u- and OCS grǫbŭ 'coarse, rough, rude' < *gʰru-m-bʰ-o-.
PS *greutan 'grind, crush' (cf. Middle High German ver-griezen 'grind into very small pieces' < *gʰréu̯d-e-) is related to Lithianian grū́sti 'thrust, pestle, stamp' < *gʰrud-ie- and Russian gruda 'heap, pile' < *gʰrou-eh₂-.
It is a loanword from Turkish but.

PS *udŭ 'part of body, limb' is etymologically obscure. It can e related to sparsely attested PS *uděti 'swell', derived from PIE *eu̯dʰ- 'swell' (cf. Polish wymię 'udder'). The original meaning woudl be then 'swollen, fleshy part of body'. Other etymologies are less probable, e.g. an interpretation as *au̯-dʰo- with *dʰē-  'put' (with a hypothetical meaning 'part of body put aside the thorax').
PS *udŭ is best explained as *au̯-dʰo- 'parto for body put aside the thorax'.
The etymology of ud 'part of body, limb' is obscure. [See further for a summary of the existing etymologies.]

PS *noga is derived from PIE *onogh- (: *ongh-, *nogh-, n̥gh-) and related to Lithuanian nagas 'fingernail', Latvian nags 'fingernail, claw', Old High German nagal 'fingernail', Old Irish ingen 'fingernail', Latin unguis 'fingernail', Greek ὄνυξ 'fingernail, claw' etc.
It was originally a collective noun with a meaning 'a set of nails/claws' (>'paw, hoof'>'leg, foot').
PS *klinŭ (with meanings referring to 'chock, cotter pin, nail etc.' and to 'thigh, lower part of belly, knies etc.') is related to PS *kolti ['stab'].
*kelh₂- 'hit' with OCS koľǫ, klati 'slaughter' listed a cognate.
PS *myslĭ 'thought, thinking' is derived from PIE *meu̯dʰ- and related to Lithuanian maũsti 'desire, miss', Gothic ga-maudjan 'remember' and Greek μυ̃θος 'word, speech, mythos'.

The mainstream view is that PS *myslĭ is derived from PIE *meudʰ- / *mudʰ- 'desire, aim at' and related to Lithuanian maũsti 'desire', Gothic gamaudjan 'remember' and Greek μυ̃θος 'word, speech, mythos'. The Lithuanian word has, however, an alternative explanation. An alternative etymology is to link it to PIE *men and reconstruct it as *monslĭ- (cf. Lithuanian mąslus 'thoughful'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *myslь 'thought, idea' (ESSJa XXI 47-50), to be derived from PIE *muHdʰ- and related to Greek μυ̃θος 'word, fact, purpose'.

Russian dumat' 'think' is a loanword from Gothic dōmjan (it can be also derived from duma 'thought', borrowed from Gothic dōms). The comparison to dym 'smoke', Greek θῡμός 'soul, thought, spirit' and Old Indic dhūmás is inconvincing. This lexeme has been also etymologized as a back-formation from do-uměti [(uměti 'be able, can')].

PS *duma does not have any certain etymology. The hypothesis about a borrowing from Gothic dōms 'judgement' shows phonetic, morphological and semantical issues. Also a reconstruction as *dʰou̯(ə)mā < PIE *dʰeu̯(ə)- 'blow' (cf. PS *dǫti 'blow') is doubtful.

This word is etymologically obscure. The hypothesis about a borrowing from Gothic dōms 'judgement' is nowadays losing support. Alternative etymologies (assuming a metathesis *meu̯dʰ- > *dʰeu̯m- or linking it to duch ['spirit'], dmout ['blow']) are inconvincing.

The hypothesis about a Germanic loanword is doubtful. First of all, Slavic *duma is incompatible and much richer semantically. Consequently, the Germanic hypothesis should be abandoned. PS *duma is related to *dux- / *dyx- / *dŭx- / *dym- and *dŭmǫ, *dǫti ['blow']. After all, it is the only way to explain the meaning of Polish duma 'pride'.
PS *uměti is derived from umŭ 'mind' and derived from PIE *au̯-mó < *au̯- 'perceive, feel, understand'.
PS *umŭ is derived from PIE *(H)au̯-mó- < *(H)au̯ 'perceive', cf. Hittite uḫḫi 'I see', autti 'you see', uu̯a- 'appear' etc.
*h₁eu̯- 'see, spot' with Hittite uḫḫi 'I see', autti 'you see' etc. listed as a reflex.
It is a loanword from Middle Low German denken 'think'.
S.v. ON œpa 'rufen, schreien' (< germ. *wōpjan), cf. Goth. wōpjan, OE wēpan 'weinen', OFr. wēpa 'schreien', OS wōpian, OHG wuoffan 'wehklagen', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *vedro 'nice weather', from PIE *u̯edʰrom (cf. OIc. veðr 'weather', OHG wetar).
S.v. ON veðr 'wetter, witterung; geruch'. Probably PIE *u̯edʰro- to OCS vedro 'heiteres wetter' and then a -dʰro- derivative to the root *u̯ē- 'blow' (cf. vindr).

S.v. Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather'.  "The Walser German form wedar as in 's wedar dr fenstro 'windowpane' (Schott 1842: 340) points to a variant *weϸra- beside *wedra-. This means that the word may have been a mobile neuter in Pre-Gm., viz. *uétr-om, pl. *uetr-éh₂. This proto-form further implies that the received etymological link with OCS vedro n. 'clear sky' < *uedʰro- cannot be maintained. The connection with OCS vetro 'air, wind' < *ueh₁-tro-, Lith. vė́tra < *h₂ueh₁-treh₂- (see *wēan-) is formally problematic as well, because the underlying form would give PGm. *weϸra- (laryngeals are not lost before *CR-, pace Schindler apud Peters 1999). Olr. feth f. 'wind(?)' can theoretically be derived from *ueto- without a laryngeal, but is more likely to have developed out of *h₂ueh₁-tó- by pretonic shortening (Dybo's law). The only way to retain the connection of the Germanic word with the PIE root *h₂ueh₁- 'to blow' is to reconstruct it as *h₂uh₁-etr-o- (or *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- in view of OCS vedro) with the same suffix as found in e.g. Gr. Hom. λοετρόν 'bath, bathing site' (derived from λούω 'to bathe')."

Cf. s.v. *au̯(e)-, *au̯ē(i)-, *u̯ē- 'wehen, blasen, hauchen', under c. *u̯e-dʰro- presumably ("vermutlich") in ON veðr n. 'Wind, Luft, Wetter', OS wedar n. 'Witterung, böses Wetter', OHG wetar 'Wetter, Witterung, freie Luft' and OCS vedro 'heiteres Wetter', vedrъ 'heiter (vom Wetter)'.
PS *vergti is derived from PIE *u̯er-ɡ- < *u̯er- 'turn'.
PS *mesti and *metati are related to each other.
PS *xvŭrliti has an ideophonic origin.
It is derived from PIE *reu̯-t- < *reu̯- 'dig' (cf. Polish ryć ['dig'], rwać ['tear']).
PS *ŕutiti, *rutiti is commonly linked to PIE *reu̯- 'dig, break'.
*reu̯H- 'rip' with OCS ryjǫ, ryti 'dig' and rŭvǫ, rŭvati 'tear' listed as reflexes.

PS *tiskati was derived from PIE *tḗh₂isk-, ultimately from *tah₂- 'melt, dissolve'. IE cognates are Ossetic tayun 'thaw, melt', Welsh tawdd 'liquefy', Breton tuezi 'melt, smelt', Latin tābēre, tābēscere 'melt, wilt', Greek tḗkō 'melt'. Cf. also PS *tajati 'thaw'.
*teh₂- 'melt, thaw' with OCS tajati 'thaw' and Welsh tawdd 'melt' listed as cognates.

S.v. Proto-Slavic *tiskati 'press, squeeze'. The stem must contain -sk-, the root could be reconstructed as either *teiH- or *teh₁i-, neither of which have obvious cognates elsewhere in Indo-European.
Cf. s.v. ?*gʰedʰ- '(zusammen)treffen, sich vereinigen' (IEW 423-4) with OCS ugoditi 'please (be liked)' and Czech hoditi 'throw' listed among cognates.

OSC godŭ '(suitable) time, year', Serbo-Croat goditi 'please', Russian godit' 'wait, loiter' etc. are related to Old Frisian gadia 'engage in', Middle Dutch gaden 'fit, please, mate', Old High German be-gatōn 'gather' and further to English good, German gut 'good', Dutch goed 'good' etc. PIE *gʰodʰ-o-.
Czech hodit is related to English good etc. and derived from *gʰedʰ- / *gʰodʰ- 'merge'. The modern meaning 'throw' is easily explainable from Old Czech meanings: 'suit, aim at something, hit'.

PS *xytati is related to PS *xvatati ['catch'] and to PS *xotěti ['want']. The further etymology is obscure. It can be derived from an expressive form of the pronominal root *su̯e- (cf. PS *svojĭ ['one's own'], as to the semantic development cf. Russian prisvoit' 'grab').

The etymology of PS *bacati / *bocati is complicated. One of the main issue is that similar forms in particular Slavic dialects could derive spontaneously and independently from interjections like Russian bac. However, the most forms can go back to PS *bodĭcati (cf. Latin fodicō ['stab, prickle']). PIE *bʰodʰ-.
Serbo-Croat bacati, baciti is of ideophonic origin.
PS *brŭsati with Russian brosat' 'throw', Bulgarian b"rša 'rub, grind' etc. listed as reflexes. Cf. also related PS *brŭkati.
?*bʰreu̯k̑- with Bulgarian b"rša 'wipe' etc. listed as a reflex.

PS *brŭsati, *brŭkati, *brŭsnǫti, *brŭknǫti (with meanings like 'throw, scutch flax, push, rush, kick, touch, shave, squeeze' attested in the daughter languages) is related to Lithuanian brùkti 'poke, thrust, press, scutch (flax)' and derived from PIE *bʰruk̑-.
PS *vęzati is related to PS *ǫzŭkŭ 'narrow' and derived from PIE *ang̑ʰ-.
S.v. *u̯erg̑ʰ- '(zu)binden' [IEW 1154-5] with OCS -vrŭzǫ, -vrěsti 'tie', Lithuanian veržiù, ver̃žti 'tie, restrict', Old English wyrgan 'strangle' etc. listed as cognates.
Bulgarian vr"zvam is related to Lithuanian ver̃žti, veržiù 'tie', Old High German wurgen 'strangle', Anglo-Saxon wurgil 'knot' etc.
PS *ęzykŭ is related to Latin lingua, Gothic tungō, Old Prussian insuwis etc. It is, however, impossible to give an universal PIE protoform.
PS *zǫbŭ is derived from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o-.
PS *dervo is derived from PIE *deru-, cf. Old Indic dāru-, dru-, Avestan dauru-, dru-, Greek δόρυ, Hittite taru- etc.
Czech strom is derived from strmý ['steep']. The latter is ultimately derived from PIE *(s)ter- 'firm, hard'.
PS *stromŭ, *strĭmŭ is derived from PIE *(s)terH- 'be hard'.
PS *strĭmŭ is related to German stramm 'tight' and Greek στερέμνιος 'hard' and derived from PIE *(s)terh₁- 'be hard'.

PS *stĭblo is derived from PIE *stĭb(ʰ)- / *steb(ʰ)- and related to Lithuanian stìbliai 'bare twigs', stìbilas 'stalk, heart (of cabbage)', Latvian stiba 'rod, club', Old Indic stíbhi- 'bunch, bundle', Latin tĭbia 'crus, pipe, flute' etc.
Latin tībia 'reed-pipe, shin-bone' with Greek σίφων 'tube, siphon' listed as a cognate. "There is no good IE etymology; maybe the word is a loanword from the same source as Gr. σίφων."
Stibhiḥ 'bunch, panicle' has no convincing etymology. A possibility is to link it to Greek στιφρός 'stocky', Latvian stiba 'rod'.

?*stei̯b- (?*stei̯bʰ-) 'make stiff, make hard' with Greek στιφρός and Lithuanian stiebiù listed as coɡnates.
?*stei̯p- 'make stiff', a "variant" of ?*stei̯b-.
It is a loanword from Middle German bom, boum.
It is a loanword from East Middle German stomm, cf, Middle High German stam.
PS *dǫbŭ is probably derived from PIE *dʰŭm-bʰo- 'dark, with a colour of smoke', a derivative of *dʰū-mo-, cf. dym ['smoke']. It was motivated by the dark colour of oak wood.

PS *dǫbŭ does not have any certain etymology. It is a Slavic innovation, perhaps motivated by taboo reasons. It has been interpreted as a derivative from PIE *dem- ([cf. PS *domŭ 'house']). Other explanations link it to PIE *dʰeu-bʰ- 'dark', *dʰeu-b- 'deep' or *dʰamb(ʰ) 'beat'. A non-IE origin has been also proposed.

PS *dǫbŭ is a late Slavic innovation and all etymologies that link it to IE lexemes referring to 'wood' are doubtful. It has been derived from PIE *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' with an original meaning 'lowland [tree]'.
PS *věra is derived from PIE *u̯ēro-, cf. Latin vērus and German  wahr.

PS *praviti 'tell' is derived from PS *pravŭ in the meaning 'true, correct' and not 'straighten'. Its original meaning was 'tell the truth'. PS *pravŭ is derived from PIE *próh₃u̯o- (*prōu̯o-) and related to Old Indic pū́rva- 'first', English first etc.
The etymology of PS *jĭstŭ 'the same' is not entirely clear. It is probably derived from *id-to-, cf. PIE pronoun *īd 'this'.
Most probably, it is derived from *is-to-, cf. Latin iste, ista, istud.
[see for IE reconstructions of the relevant pronominal forms.]
PS *rěsknŭ is related to Lithuanian raiškùs 'clear, intelligible' etc.

The etymology of Lithuanian réikšti etc. is entirely obscure. It has been compared to Old Russian rěsnŭ 'true' and Slovene resen 'serious' (with a Proto-Baltic reconstruction *raišk-na- proposed). However, this hypothesis has phonetic and morphological issues.
PS *obvortiti is derived from *vortiti, cf. Lithuanian ver̃sti, verčiù, Gothic wairþan and Latin vertō, vertere. PIE *u̯ert- < *u̯er-.
PS *rygati is related to Lithuanian rū́gti, raugeti, Latin erugō, erugere and Greek ερευγομαι. PIE *reu̯ɡ-. Some Slavic cognates (e.g. Polish rzygać) show an irregular vowel change (*y > *i).
S.v. Ved. pipīlá- 'Ameise', of uncertain etymology.
S.v. 2900 Skt. karmín, kármika- 'active' (~ Ved. karmán-).
S.v. Ved. √kar- 'tun, machen, bewirken, handeln' < PIIr. čar-/kar- < PIE *kʷer-/kʷor- (cf. Hitt. kuer- 'schneiden', OIr. cruth, Wel. pryd 'Gestalt' (*kʷr̥-tu-), Lith. kùrti 'errichten, bauen').
Cf. s.v. Skt. kárma- 'Werk, Arbeit (usw.) / work, labour (etc.)' to Skt. kr̥ṇóti 'machen, tun'.
S.v. 10552 Skt. rakṣā (2) f. ʻ ashes ʼ lex. [Same as rakṣā- 1? 'protection' √rakṣ-]
Cf. s.v. Ved. √rakṣ- 'schützen, beschützen, behüten, bewachen', from PIE *h₂leks- (cf. Gk. ἀλέξω 'wehre ab, verteidige').
Cf. s.v. *h₂leks- 'abwehren, schützen' (IEW 32).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √chad- 'bedecken, zudecken, verhüllen'. Morgenstierne connected YAv. sāδaiiaṇtī- meaning something like 'lange Hose', further connections are unclear. Perhaps to IE *sk̑ed- 'bedecken' if connected with OE hætera 'garments' (cf. {ref IEW} 919).
Cf. s.v. ?*(s)k̑ed- 'bedecken' (IEW 919).
PS *bľĭvati is of ideophonic origin and is maybe related to Lithuanian bliáuti. Cf. plivat ['spit'].
S.v. 3677 Skt. *kṣāradhānikā 'receptacle for ashes'. [kṣārá- 'caustic substance',1 dhā́na- 'container'] > N. kharāni 'ashes'.
S.v. Skt. kṣāráḥ 'beizend, brennend, scharf / caustic, sharp' to the same root as kṣā́yati 'brennt / burns'.
S.v. Ved. √kṣā-¹ 'brennen', no secure connections outside of Indo-Iranic.
The meaning of PS *bľĭvati was originally 'generate inarticulate sounds, bleat, grunt', cf. Lithuanian bliáuti. The question is if the Slavic word belongs to PIE *bʰleu̯H-, cf. Latin fluere.

PS *bľujǫ, bľĭvati is a parallel formation to *pľujǫ, pľĭvati ['spit']. It is possible that -ľ- is an epenthetic consonant here. The most plausible reconstruction would be then *bjou-. In this case, it can not be related to Lithuanian bliáuju, bliáuti, Greek φλύειν and Latin fluō.
S.v. 5582 Skt. *ḍhākka 'back, waist'
PS *vortiti, cf. Lithuanian ver̃sti, verčiù, Gothic wairþan and Latin vertō, vertere. PIE *u̯ert- < *u̯er-.
S.v. *reu̯H- 'aufreißen' (IEW 868), with OCS rŭvǫ, rŭvati 'tear' and ryjǫ, ryti 'dig', Latin ruō, ruere Vedic rávat, Tocharian B rwātär etc. given as cognates.
S.v. 9289 *bura 'defective' 2. *bōra-.
Russian rvat' is related to Latin ruō, ruere, Old Indic rávati, Lithuanian ravė́ti, raviù etc.
PS *rŭvati is related to Lithuanian ráuti, ráuju 'tear out, pull out', Latin ruō, ruere 'fall down, squirm', Tocharian A, B ru- 'tear'. PIE *reu̯- 'dig, tear'.
Belarusian vanìtavac' is loanword from Polish wonitować, womitować which is, in turn, a loanword from Latin vomere.

PS *xoditi 'go, walk' is derived from PIE *sed- / *sod- 'sit'. The semantic development can be related to an invention of a new form of transport in a sitting position, cf. Russian vsadnik, Old Indic sādín 'horse rider'. It can be also motivated by the concept of destination aprproaching ('to sit down at the end of the way'), cf. Old Indic ā-sad- 'to approach, reach'.

PS *myti (sę) is derived from PIE *meu̯-, *meu̯ə-, *mū̆- 'wet, damp, dirty, dirty liquid (urine); wash, clean', cf. Lithuanian máudau, máudyti 'bathe', Latvian maut 'submerge', Greek μιαρός 'dirty', μω̃μος 'shame', μύζω 'suck', μύδος 'dampness', Old Indic mū́tra 'urine', Old Irelandic muad 'cloud', Middle Irelandic mūn 'urine', mosach 'impure', Low German moder 'mildew', Armenian geta-moyn 'submerged in a river'.
Some scholars link it to Latin movēre 'move'.
S.v. Nep. narāmro adj. 'bad, evil, ill; ugly' [cmpd. na and rāmro].
Cf. s.v. 10636 Skt. ramyà 'to be enjoyed, beautiful' ŚBr. [√ram].
Cf. s.v. Ved. √ram- 'zur Ruhe kommen, stillsehen, ausruhen, rasten', from PIE *h₁rem- (cf. Gk. ἠρέμα 'ruhig, sanft', Goth. rimis 'Ruhe', Lith. rãmas 'Ruhe', rìmti 'ruhig werden').
Cf. s.v. *h₁rem- 'ruhig werden' (IEW 864).
S.v. 3153 Skt. *kicca 'mud, dirt '. 2. *kacca- 2. 3. *khacca- . [Cf. Drav. words quoted s.v. *gicc -- and further groups s.vv. kiṭṭa- and kaccara- 1, and *cikka- 2]
S.v. 9235 Ved. bā́hya- 'external' AV.
Cf. s.v. Ved. bahíṣ (adv.) 'draußen, von außen, hinaus, außerhalb', probably from IE *bʰeg̑ʰ- (cf. OCS bez, Lith. bè, Latv. bez 'ohne').
S.v. Skt. challī- 'Rinde / bark' (Pāli challi, Prākrit challī), probably from the same non-IE source as colakam (coḍaḥ). Probably Dravidian, but a Munda origin is not to be ruled out.

S.v. *tu̯ek- 'sichtbar sein' (not in IEW), cf. Hitt. dukkāri 'ist sichtbar, wird gesehen; ist wichtig'. Cf. n1, comparing the root-noun *tu̯ek- 'das sichbare, äußere Form' in Hitt. tuekk(a)-/tukk(a)- 'Körper', Ved. tvác- 'Haut' (cf. Schindler, BSL 67 (1972) 36-7).
S.v. 6087 Ved. tvác f. 'skin, hide' RV.
Cf. s.v. bhāṇḍam 'Gefäß, Topf, Schüssel / vessel, pot', no satisfactory explanation.
Cf. s.v. Ved. bhaṇḍa- 'Hausgeräte', of unclear etymology.
S.v. 4571 Skt. caṭaka m. 'sparrow' MBh., °kā- f. Pañcat., °ṭikā- f. lex. 2. *ciṭaka- . [Onom. cf. *caṭa -- and similar words in Drav. and Mu. EWA i 368]
S.v. 11304 váyas- (1) n. 'bird' RV. [ví-]. Kho. boik 'bird' (< *vayaska- ?), Si. viyā.
S.v. 827. Lat. avicella 'kleiner Vogel', 2. aucella.; 828. Lat. avicellus 'Vogel', 2. 'aucellus'; 831 Lat. avis 'Vogel'.
S.v. 5476 *ṭōkk- 'strike, bite'. 2. *ṭōkka- 3. *ṭōkkarā-.
S.v. 4675 *cappayati 'chews'. [Onom., cf. Pa. capucapukāra- 'making the sound of chewing', cf. cárvati]

S.v. 4711 Skt. cárvati, carváyati 'chews' Dhātup., Pañcat. [√carv: but NIA. points to both *cavv- and *cabb- (as well as *camb- , *cabbh- , *cibb- , *cobb- ) in MIA. and therefore supports F. B. J. Kuiper (EWA i 379) in separating cūrṇa- : cf. onom. *cappayati]
S.v. Skt. cárvati, carváyati 'zermalmt, zerkaut / grinds with the teeth, chews', cf. cūrṇam n. 'feiner Staub, Mehl'. Etymology difficult to determine.
Cf. s.v. Ved. cūrṇa- 'feiner Staub, Mehl'; etymology unclear.
S.v. Goth. G106. gretan. Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Older proposals (e.g. {ref IEW} 439) uncertain. No ascertainable cognates; possibly an onomatopoeic formation.

S.v. Goth. A137. alϸeis 'γέρων', 'old'. Differing in suffix from CrimGo. alt 'senex', OE eald, OFris, OS ald, OHG alt, 'old', etc. but from the same root, PIE *al- 'grow' + -to- (cf. Gk. ἄν-αλτος 'insaitiable, Lat. altus 'high', ad-ultus 'adult', OIr. al 'bank').
S.v. Goth. T30. tiuhan 'ἄγειν', 'lead, bring', from PIE *dewk- 'lead' (cf. OLat. doucō, Lat. dūcō 'lead', etc.).

S.v. Goth. A215 atisk, only acc sg in ϸairh atisk 'διὰ τῶν σπορίμων', 'grainfield'. Elsewhere in Germanic cf. MLG esch < *etisc, OHG ezzesc, MHG ezzisch 'sown grainfield', Du. esch 'cultivated fields of a village'. Cognates elsewhere uncertain.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *atiska- n.(?) 'grainfield', a derivative from an old PIE word for 'spelt' or other type of cereal, cf. ?Hitt. ḫātar 'unknown foodstuff' (Watkins 1975); YAv. āδū.frāδana- 'abounding in grain'; Arm. hat 'grain, seed'; 'piece, fragment, section', Lat. ador, -oris 'coarse grain, spelt, barley' < *h₂ed-(o)r-.
S.v. 1. *per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren' (IEW 816-7).

S.v. Gmc. *far-a- 'fahren', probably going back to a proto-form *por- 'tragen, bringen', etc. which was an ablaut form of IE *per- 'durchbohren, hinüberbringen' (cf. Lat. portāre < *pr̥-tā-; W rhyd 'Furt', CS na-perjǫ, -periti 'durchbohren', Ru. poróm 'Fähre'; Gk. πείρω 'durchstoße, durchsteche', Ved. píparti 'bringt hinüber, rettet, schützt, übertrifft').

S.v. *faran- 'to go', from PIE *pór-e- (cf. Skt. pí-parti 'to bring across' < *pi-por-; OAv. (fra)-frā 1.sg.subj.aor. 'to cross' < pre-pr-e-, OCS pariti 'to fly' < *por-éie-; Gk. πείρω 'to pierce, to penetrate' < *per-ie-).
S.v. Goth. F22. *faran 'wander, travel', from PIE *per- 'go across' (cf. OCS peru 'move, fly').
OSC myti 'wash' (< *muH-) is a cognate of Latin moveō 'move'.
PS *myti is related to Lithuanian máudyti 'bathe, wash', Old High German muzzan 'clean', Old Indic mū́tram 'urine' and Avestan mūŋəm 'dirt'. PIE *meu̯-, *meu̯ə-, *mū̆- 'wet, damp' and 'wash'.
PS *pĭrati, *perǫ 'hit, beat' is derived from PIE *per- and related to Lithuanian per̃ti 'lash', Latin premō, premere 'push, squeeze' and Old Indic pŕ̥t- 'battle'.
S.v. 3083 Skt. kāla- (1) 'black, dark blue' MBh. Probably a loanword from Dravidian according to {ref KEWA} I:203.
Cf. no. 1494 (Ta. kār̤ 'blackness, blemish, defect', Ka. kār̤, kāḍu 'blackness, black', etc.) for Dravidian parallels.
S.v. Skt. kālaḥ 'blauschwarz, schwarz / dark-blue, black', probably a loanword from Dravidian (cf. Ka. kāḷ 'Schwärze', kāḍu 'Schwärze, schwarz', Tel. kaṟa 'schwarz', etc.
S.v. Skt. haḍḍam 'Knochen / bone'. Unexplained.
S.v. 2670 *kaṇṭa- (3) 'backbone, podex, penis' 2. *kaṇḍa-, 3. *karaṇḍa-, 4. (Cf. *kāṭa- 2. *ḍākka- 2: poss. same as káṇṭa- (1) 'thorn' [no. 2668]]
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *ra(n)ǰ- 'to colour, dye', from PIE *(s)reg- 'to colour (dark)' (cf. Skt. raj- 'to colour, become red', Gk. ῥέζω 'I dye, paint', ῥῆγος 'carpet, rug', ῥογεύς 'dyer').

PS *mokrŭ is derived from *mok- (cf. *močiti, *moknǫti). It is related to Armenian mōr 'dirt'. Further, it has been linked to Greek μάκαρ 'blessed' and Lithuanian màkaruoti 'pug, mix, beat', cf. also Lithuanian makõnė 'dirt', maknà 'muddy, damp place'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √jvar-ⁱ 'leiden', differing from √jval-ⁱ 'brennen' synchronically, but certainly from the same origin. Without certain etymology.
S.v. 8397 *pōḍ 'burn'.

An issue in the reconstruction of PS *bělŭ is the root vowel. However, it can be established that the output form was *belo-, with a short monophthong. It is related to Greek φαλός 'white', Breton bal 'white spot on the forehead (of a horse, cow, dog)' and Lithuanian bãlas 'white'. PIE *bʰel- / *bʰol-.
S.v. 5610 Skt. ḍhaukayati 'brings near' Kathās., pp. ḍhaukita- MBh. [√ḍhauk].
S.v. Skt. ḍáukate 'nähert sich / approaches'. Of unclear origin "kaum arischen Ursprungs" (Wack. I 148).
S.v. 9311 *bōkk 'carry' [Poss. < 'carry on the back': cf. bukka- (1) s.v. vr̥kká-]
S.v. N. बोक्नु boknu, vb. tr. 'to lift, carry'. Perh. orig. 'to carry on the back or neck' der. Sk. vr̥kkáu, vŕ̊kyau m. du. 'kidneys'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √śray- 'sich anlehnen', from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lehnen' (cf. Gk. κλίνω 'neige, lehne, beugen', Lat. clīnāre 'biegen, beugen', OIr. clī 'housepost', OHG hlinēn 'lehnen', Lith. šliẽti, Latv. slìet 'anlehnen', TochA kalyme, B kälymiye 'Richtung, Himmelsgegend', etc.).
S.v. 5014 *chātti 'chest, breast'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. vr̥kká- 'Nieren', from IIr. *u̯r̥t-ka- (cf. variant form *vŕ̥tya-) and probably to √vart- ('kidney' ~ 'round').
S.v. 9090 Skt. phupphusa m. 'lungs' Suśr., phuphusa- n. ŚārṅgS., pupphusa- m. lex. (Si. papuvā, pl. papu 'heart and liver and lungs, breast, bosom'.)
Cf. s.v. Skt. puppuṭaḥ 'swelling of the palate and the gums' to which also probably pupphulaḥ 'Blähung', pupphusaḥ, phupphusaḥ; Pāli papphāsa- 'Lunge'. Probably sound-symbolic of breathing.
S.v. 11567 Skt. vārdala- n.m. 'rainy day, bad weather'.
Cf. s.v. Skt. vārdalaḥ 'regnerischer Tag, Schlechtwetter, Regenwetter / rainy day, bad weather'. Not satisfactorily explained.
Cf. s.v. 11411 Skt. valāhaká-, ba° m. 'thunder-cloud, cloud' MBh.
S.v. 2561 Skt. ṓṣati 'burns' RV., uṣyatē 'is burnt' Suśr. [√vas3]. Dm. oṣḗ -- 'to be frostbitten' (NTS xii 157 < uṣ -- ?); Kho. uṣák 'cold'; K. wuhun 'to glow, smoulder' or poss. < vyuṣati.
Cf. s.v. h₁eu̯s- 'verbrennen, sengen' (IEW 347-8)
Cf. s.v. Ved. √oṣ- 'brennen, versengen', from PIE *(h₁)eu̯s- (cf. Gk. εὕω 'senge', Lat. ūrō 'brenne, versenge', ustus 'gebrannt', etc.).
S.v. 3574 Ved. krándati 'roars, neighs, laments' RV. [√krand1].
Cf. s.v. Ved. √krand- 'schreien, wiehern, dröhnen' (MI, NI cf. Pā. kandati 'jammert, schreit, Bengali kā̃dā 'weinen', etc.). Connections outside of Indic uncertain.
S.v. Wa. pыṣ̌ : poṣ̌t- 'рыть, копать', cf. Tadj. dial. (gor.) pošidan 'копать, раскапывать', Khow. paṣ̌iman, paṣ̌ik, Yid. paš- : pašč- 'копать'.
PS *širŭ is related to Avestan xšaeta- 'bright, shining' derived from *ksoi̯- < PIE *sk/k̑ei̯- 'shine' (with a consonant metathesis).

PS *širŭ is usually linked to Gothic skeirs 'bright' and German schier 'clean' < PIE *skəir- 'bright'. A metathesis *sk- > *ks is assumed here. The semantic development 'bright' > 'open' > 'wide' is plausible.

PS *širŭ is related to Gothic skeirs 'bright', German schier 'clean', Old Icelandic skīrr 'clean, bright' < PIE *skei̯- 'bright, light'. In PS a metathesis of the initial consonant group took place.
PS *kridlo / *skridlo is derived from PIE *(s)krei̯-

S.v. OLith. báltas 'weiß' (BSl. cf. Latv. bal̃ts 'weiß', OCS blato 'Sumpf', etc.). The East Baltic word for white is morphologically closest to the past passive participle of OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden'. The also lexicalised Slavic correspondence shows that the adjective was already Proto-Balto-Slavic. On the semantic development of 'white' > 'swamp' in Slavic, see ESSJa 2:180. Lith. bálti is a denominal incohative to Lith. bãlas 'weiß' which has been replaced by báltas. Lith. bãlas is put together with Gk. φαλός (Hesych.) 'weiß', φαλιός 'hell; weißfleckig' (cf. Frisk 1960-1972 2.988f.), Arm. bal 'Nebel, weißer fleck' (cf. Martirosyan 2010:162f.), and Alb. bálë 'weißer Fleck auf der Stirn von Tieren, Blässe' (cf. Demiraj 1997:87). Lith. bãlas is not to be separated from the Slavic lexemes, e.g. OCS bělъ. Ru. bélyj, Cz. bílý, etc., which apparently have a reflex of Proto-Slavic *ē in the root. The morphological relationship within the family and the identification of a common is yet to be explained. The often assumed connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten' (cf. Ved. 3.sg.pres. bhā́ti, Gk. φάντα (Hesych.) 'leuchtend') is conceivable.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *bělъ 'white' (ESSJa II 79-81), from earlier *bʰelH- (cf. Lith. bãlas 'white', Latv. bā̀ls, bãls 'pale'; bal̃ts 'white').

S.v. Lith. báltas 'white' (Latv. bal̃ts 'white'), from PIE *bʰolH-to- (cf. PSl. *bòlto 'swamp', Alb. baltë 'mud, swamp', Mod.Gk. βάλτος 'swamp', Rom. baltă 'mud, swamp'). For the semantics cf. Lith. balà 'swamp' = PSl. bělъ 'white'.

An issue in the reconstruction of PS *bělŭ is the root vowel. However, it can be established that the output form was *belo-, with a short monophthong. It is related to Greek φαλός 'white', Breton bal 'white spot on the forehead (of a horse, cow, dog)' and Lithuanian bãlas 'white'. PIE *bʰel- / *bʰol-.

The connection of the Baltic and Slavic lexemes to each other is generally agreed upon, but extra Balto-Slavic connections, and subsequently any precise IE root reconstruction, remain debated. {ref ALEW} (90-91 s.v. OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden') suggests that a connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' is not inconceivable; {ref Derksen 2008}:40 and {ref Derksen 2015}:80 postulate a root *bʰelH-. The reconstructed PIE root ref. form for this class follows that of Derksen, but it should be borne in mind that this form remains provisional as the morphological analysis of the Balto-Slavic forms and their proposed further IE connections have yet to be satisfactorily explained. Cf. also {ref ESSJa} 2:79-81.

It is an expressive word without certain etymology. All existing, numerous etymologies are unjustified and inconvincing. Also the morphological structure is obscure, a putative suffix -'et(a) does not exist anywhere else.

It is an exclusively Polish lexeme and it has been attested relatively late. Thus, its PS origin is dubious. Even the original phonetic form is hard to determine (*kobita or *koběta). The only solution is to link this lexeme to PS *kobĭ. It would be originally an adjective which could occure in phrases like *kobita žena 'capricious women'.[See also for a summary of other etymologies.]
PS *kobĭ [with meanings 'divination', 'bad fate', 'meeting', 'evil thing', 'bounder', 'obstinacy' attested in Slavic languages and dialects] has been linked to Old Icelandic happ 'luck, success' (with formal issues) and Irelandic cob 'victory'.
It is a loanword from Middle German made 'worm'.
West Slavic *xrobakŭ is derived from an ideophonic verb *xrobati 'crackle, scrunch, chomp'.
PS *xrobakŭ is derived from *xrobati. The root is ideophonic. However, a relationship to PS *skrobati, *skrebti can not be overseen.
Cf. s.v. ?*gʰedʰ- '(zusammen)treffen, sich vereinigen' (IEW 423-4) with OCS ugoditi 'please (be liked)', Russian godit'sâ 'to be suitable, useful' etc. listed as cognates.

OSC godŭ '(suitable) time, year', Serbo-Croat goditi 'please', Russian godit' 'wait, loiter' etc. are related to Old Frisian gadia 'engage in', Middle Dutch gaden 'fit, please, mate', Old High German be-gatōn 'gather' and further to English good, German gut 'good', Dutch goed 'good' etc. PIE *gʰodʰ-o-.

PS *godŭ is derived from or related to *goditi. PIE *gʰadʰ-, cf. Old Frisian gadia 'unify', Middle High German ergetzen 'gladden, satisfy', gaden 'suit, please', Old High German gi-gat 'suitable' (PG *gattjan).
PS *rokŭ 'something said, appointed, prearranged; date, appointment' is derived from PS *rekti, *rekǫ 'say' < PIE *rek- 'speak, shout'. Cf. Polish rokować 'negotiate, parley'.

The etymology of PS *lěto is still disputable. Most probably is related to Lithuanian lė̃tas 'soft, easy, amenable', Latvian lė̃ts 'light' and derived from PIE *lē- 'become weak'. Cf. also Gothic lētan 'leave, let out, refuse'. Thus, the original meaning was 'part the year without cold'.
It is a loanword from Middle Low German gel, gele 'yellow'.
See /cognate/7768/.
Cf. s.v. 1. *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'rot machen' (IEW 872). CS rŭděti 'become red' listed as a reflex.
S.v. Slov. rumȅn. PS *rumenŭ / *ruměnŭ is derived from PIE *rou̯dʰ-men-m̥ < PIE *reu̯dʰ- 'red, rust-colored, yellow'.
S.v. 3890 *khucc- 'pierce, tear'. 2. *khōcc- . 3. *khuñc- . 4. *khōñc- . [Poss. formations fr. *sku-. For list of poss. enlargements of IE. *sqeu -- see √sku].
In Indic cf. 3275 *kutta- (1) 'dog'. [Onom.: cf. Sogd. 'kwt, Shgh. kut 'dog', Sant. kutu kutu 'sound made in calling a puppy']
S.v. 3329 Skt. kurkurá- m. ʻ dog ʼ AV., kukkurá- m. Mr̥cch., °rī- f. VarBr̥S. 2. *kuṅkara- . [Onom. EWA i 237: cf. *karkuṭaka- , *kuccura- , *kutta- 1, *kukka- 1]

S.v. Skt. naḍáḥ 'Schilf, Schilfrohr / reed' under which also nāḍī́- 'Röhre, Kanal, Pfeife, Flöte (RV, AV, etc.). Probably not to be separated with Ved.  nadá- (in RV mostly 'Stier, Brüller' to nádati, possibly identical with Ir. *nada- 'Rohr' in Av. naδa-, MParth. nd 'Flöte', MPers. n'y 'id.' Not fully clear is the relationship to naḍa-. There are possible comparisons in Dravidian (Kannada naḷḷu 'reed', verbal Tamil ñeḷ 'to be hollow'. Perhaps an Indo-Iranic word *nada- became influenced in India by an indigenous word?

S.v. OLith. giedóti 'singen, krähen (Hahn)'. The East Baltic family is connected with ORu. gajati, gaju 'krächzen' and Ved. gā-, gā́yati 'singen' to a root *geH(i̯)- or *gʷeH(i̯)- 'singen'. To this the Baltic forms alone show a -d- after the original root, which is analysed as an enlargement or a reanalysed present-stem formation in *-d⁽ʰ⁾-e/o-. A further possible point of departure could be a connection of *geH(i̯)- (vel sim.) as a root noun with a continuation of IE *dʰeh₁- 'place, set, lay', originally the univerbation of a light-verb construction.
Cf. s.v. 14184 Skt. hrasvá- 'short, weak (of voice)' VS. (> Pk. rahassa-).
S.v. 13271 sarpá- m. 'snake' RV., sarpī- f. MBh. [√sr̥p].
S.v. 7855 Lat. serpens, -ente 'Schlange', 2. *serpes, -is.
S.v. 5798 Skt. tārā- f. 'fixed star' Yājñ., tā́raḥ nom.pl. RV. 2. tā́rakā- f. 'star' AV. 3. *tārikā-. 4. tāraká- 'belonging to the stars' VS.
S.v. Paš. l'ax̌ta f. 'rod, stick, wand'; lax̌t'ay m. 'brook, small stream'. — A 'Dardic' form < IA, cf. T 10091 laṣṭi- 'stick'.
Cf. s.v. 10991 *laṣṭi- 'stick' [→ Psht. laṣ̂ta 'rod'].
S.v. 12459 Ved. śilā́- f. 'rock, crag' AV., 'lower millstone' lex. 2. *śillā-.
S.v. 13574 sū́ra m. 'sun' RV. 2. sū́rya- m. 3. sū́riya- m. (metr.) RV. 4. sūrī- f. 'a name of Kuntī as wife of the sun' Pāṇ.vārtt. 5. saurī́-.
Cf. s.v. Ved. śilā́- 'Fels, Stein' (pā. silā- 'Fels, Stein'), etymology uncertain.
S.v. 8138 Ved. pāṣāṇá 'stone' ṢaḍvBr.

S.v. Ved. pāṣāṇá- 'Stein'. Associated Nuristani forms such as Kati parši perhaps allow that the pre-form for Ved. pāṣ- as *parṣ- and this could support the old connection with PIE *pel(e)s- in Gk. πέλλα· λίθος (Hesych.), OHG felis = NHG Fels, etc.
S.v. 2420 ūrú- m. 'thigh' RV.
S.v. 9182 Skt. bahala- 'thick' Suśr.
S.v. 4236 Ved. gr̥bhāyáti 'takes, seizes' RV. 2. gr̥hṇā́ti, gr̥bhṇā́ti 'takes, seizes' RV.
S.v. 8249 Ved. púccha- m.n. 'tail, hinder part' AV.

S.v. 11009 Skt. lāṅgūlá- (lāṅgula- Pañcat., laṅgula- lex.) n. 'tail' ŚāṅkhŚr., adj. 'having a tail' MBh., 'penis' lex. 2. *lāṅguṭa- . 3. *lāṅguṭṭa- (> Si. nan̆guṭa) . 4. *lāṅguṭṭha- . 5. *lēṅgula- . 6. *lēṅguṭṭa-.
S.v. Ved. lāṅgūla- n. 'Schwanz, Schweif'. Etymology unexplained.
S.v. 4815 Skt. cintáyati 'thinks' MBh., 'cares for' Mn.
S.v. Ved. √cetⁱ- 'erkennen, auf etwas achthaben', reconstructed as *kʷei̯-t- and not to be separated from √cay-¹ 'wahrnehmen, bemerken, beachten'.
S.v. *kʷei̯t- 'bemerken, erkennen' (IEW 637), cf. n1: Traditionally reconstructed as a root enlarged form of 1. *kʷei̯- 'wahrnehmen, bemerken'.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *godìti v. 'please' (ESSJa VI 188-190), from PIE *gʰodʰ- (cf. Proto-Slavic *godъ 'right time' < PIE *gʰodʰ-o-).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *rъvati 'tear' from PIE *(H)ruH- (cf. Lat. rūta caesa 'minerals and timber already quarried and felled at the time an estate is put up for sale', OIc. rýja 'tear out wool').
S.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (LIV 264f., IEW 42f.).
Cf. s.v. AGk. μῦθος 'word, discourse, conversation, deliberation, story, saga, tale, myth'. There are no certain comparanda, and the word may be a borrowing from a Pre-Greek substrate language.

Cf. s.v. AGk. μῦθος 'suite de paroles qui ont un sens, propos, discours'. Etymology obscure. Perhaps a popular onomatopoeic expression based on a syllable μῦ according to {ref Frisk 1960-1972}, but the sense of the word in the earliest texts is not in favour of this hypothesis.
S.v. 6410 Ved. dunóti 'distresses' AV., 'is consumed with internal heat or sorrow' MBh. [√du1].
S.v. *deh₂u̯- 'in Brand geraten' (IEW 179-181).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √dav- 'anzünden, verbrennen', from PIE *deh₂u̯- (cf. Gk. δαίω 'zünde an', δέδηα 'lodere, brenne', δήϊος *'brennend' > 'feindlich, schrecklich', OIr. dōïd 'sengt, brennt', MIr. condud 'Brennholz', OHG zuscen 'brennen', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *gonìti 'chase, persecute' (ESSJa VII 23), to be derived from PIE *gʷʰon- (cf Skt. hánti 'strike, slay', Gk. θείνω 'kill').
S.v. Ru. сладкий, a loanword from Church Slavic, used in place of inherited солодкий.

Traditionally compared to Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather' and further connected with PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- via *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- or *u̯edʰrom, although there are formal difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic comparanda (cf. discussion in /cognate/9440/). The difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic form, however, do not preclude the possibility of the derivation of the Slavic form being ultimately derived from PIE **h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow', however the uncertainty over the etymological identity of the proposed Germanic cognates weakens the case somewhat (cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:513, {ref Kroonen 2013}:583-584, {ref Snoj 1997-2016} 4:287-288).

S.v. Proto-Slavic *palica 'stick, staff' "The obvious connection with forms containing a root *pol- (e.g. *polìca) forces us to reconstruct a lengthened grade *pōl- for *palica. This is not in agreement with the accentual evidence, however. The etymology of the root is unclear."

S.v. Proto-Slavic *kyjь 'stick, club' (ESSJa XIII 257-258), a jo-derivative of *ky < *kuh₂-, cf. *kovati 'forge' (ESSJa XII 10-12) < PIE *kouh₂- (cf. Lith. káuti 'murder, beat, hew'; Latv. kaût 'fight', Lat. cūdere 'beat, grind, forge', OIc. hǫggva 'hew, beat'; OHG houwan 'hew, beat').
S.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (IEW 535).
S.v. 7547 salo, salawer (langob., ahd.).
S.v. *salo (anfrk.) 'trübe, schmutzig' (> Fr. sale).
S.v. Alb. qúaj, qú(e)j 'benennen; betrachten als, halten für', dial. quhem 'heißen'. To be connected with *k̑leu̯- 'hören', cf. entry for further discussion on the verbal stem formation in Albanian.

Cf. s.v. Alb. dím/ër, -ri 'Winter', übertr. 'Frost', an inherited word with many cognates in other IE languages (cf. Gk. χεῖμα, OCS zima 'Winter', etc.), either derived from a zero-grade stem *g̑ʰim-m(e)n-, or if the original accent was on the second syllable (cf. Lith. žiemà 'Winter', Gk. χειμών) the *-ei̯- diphthong of the first syllable would have been contracted to -i- (*g̑ʰei̯-mōn-).

Cf. s.v. OLith. jaũsti 'wach sein; fühlen, empfinden' (cf. OCS oštutiti 'fühlen, merken, begreifen', ORu. očutiti 'vernehmen, merken, hören, spüren) with further discussion on the Balto-Slavic background if the underlying root. No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *otjutiti 'feel, perceive' and Proto-Slavic *otjьtnǫti, to a BSl. root *jout-/jut- (cf. Lith. jaũsti 'feel, sense', Latv. jàust 'feel, notice, heed, understand'; Lith. jùsti 'feel', Latv. just 'feel, notice').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *čuti.
S.v. *(s)kreb- 'schaben, kratzen' (IEW 943-4).
S.v. Lat. *rīparia 'Ufergelände' > Fr. rivière.
S.v. 7328 Lat. rīpa 'Ufer'.

S.v. Lat. rīpa 'river bank', from PIE *h₁reip-h₂ 'steep slope' (cf. Gk. ἐρείπω 'to throw down, fall down', ἐρίπνη 'slope', OIc. rifa 'to demolish, tear down, ONo. rīp 'upper side of a boat', East Frisian rip(e) 'shore').
Cf. s.v. *tʰengʰ- → *tengʰ-

Cf. s.v. Hitt. u̯eḫ- 'to turn (oneself); to patrol', rejecting the etymology advocated by {ref Oettinger 1979}:99-100, etc. that the Hittite forms are derivatives from an acrostatic root present *u̯ḗh₂-/*u̯éh₂- with Narten ablaut on the basis that the forms require the assumption of Eichner's Law (non-colouration of *ē in the vicinity of *h₂), the validity of which Kloekhorst rejects. Instead Kloekhorst tentatively sets up *u̯ei̯h₂- comparing Skt. véti 'to pursue, strive after, Lith. výti 'to pursue', etc.  [In re Eichner's Law, cf. also discussion in /cognate/5403/ –MJCS].
Cf. s.v. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell' and Lith. pámpa 'swelling, lump', derivatives from Balto-Slavic *pomp- (cf. PS *pǫpъ 'bud, navel').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *morzъ 'frost' (ESSJa XX 10-14), to be connected with Alb. mardhë 'frost'. "Possibly an example of Winter's Law, in which case we must reconstruct *mórg̑-o-."
S.v. Proto-Slavic *xoditi 'go, walk' (ESSJa VIII 48-49), from PIE *sod- (cf. Gk. ὁδεύω 'wander').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *sadъ 'plant, garden', cf. Proto-Slavic *saditi 'to plant' < *sod-eie- (cf. Skt. sādáyati 'to set').
S.v. *sed- 'sich setzen' (LIV 513f., IEW 785f.; 884ff.); OCS sadъ 'Pflanze, Garten' < *sōd-u-.
S.v. Arm. ałt 'filth' (adj. ałt-ełi). Etymology disputed, cf. for various proposals.
Cf. s.v. 1476 ā́sa- (2) *'throwing', m. 'ashes, light dust' AV.
Cf. s.v. 994 Ved. áhi 'snake' RV.
S.v. 3023 Ved. kā́ṇḍa- (kāṇḍá- TS.) m.n. 'single joint of a plant'
S.v. Ved. kā́ṇḍa- 'Abschnitt, Stück, Halmglied'. Uncertain origin, probably of Middle Indic or non-IE origin.
S.v. 13627 Ved. skandhá- m. 'shoulder, upper part of back' AV.

Cf. s.v. Ved. skandhá- 'Schulterknochen', apparently going back to an Indo-Iranic root *skandh- 'brechen, abbrechen', cf. OAv. skǝṇdō probably 'Beschädigung', YAv. skǝṇdō 'Gebrechen, Körperschaden', further connections uncertain.
4979 Skt. chadana- n. 'cover' R., 'leaf' Suśr. [√chad1]
S.v. Ved. √chad- 'bedecken, zudecken, verhüllen', perhaps further related to YAv. sāδaaiianti 'lange Hose', but uncertain. Further connections are unclear.
S.v. 4015 *gandhapūrikā- 'flower'. [gandhá- , pūra- 1] > Kal. gambhūri 'flower', Kho. gambùri

S.v. Ved. gandhá- 'Geruch, Duft', not to be separated from YAv. gaiṇti- 'übler Geruch', duž-gaiṇti- 'übelriechend, stinkend', Parth. gndʾg 'stinkend', MPers., NPers. gand 'Gestank', etc. Further connections are uncertain.
S.v. 612 Skt. aru- m. 'sun' lex. > Kho. yor
S.v. 7641 Skt. *pakṣya- (2) 'hot' [√pac-].
Cf. s.v. Ved. √pac- 'kochen, braten', from PIE *pekʷ- (cf. OCS pekǫ 'backe, brate', Lat. coquō 'koche', Gk. πέσσω, etc.).
S.v. Ved. tr̥prá- 'ein Beiwort für Soma-Säfte', etc. Etymology unclear.
S.v. 5934 Ved. tr̥prá- (3) 'pungent' (Geldner) RV., 'salty' KātyŚr. (> Kho. trup 'salt').
S.v. 24 akṣa- (4) n. 'blue vitriol' lex. [Cf. Av. axšaēna -- ʻ dark- coloured ʼ, Yid. axšin ʻ blue ʼ Horn NPE 109, Morgenstierne IIFL ii 195, W. S. Allen The Classical Quarterly xli 88 note 1]
Khowar zērč 'yellow', loan from *zërt + č, cf. Seistani zerča or zardi 'rust disease of wheat '. Shgh. zereč ' rust '. Kho. zērbali 'yellow rose' < *zērd-wali?
For Khowar, cf. s.v. 876 *avasnāyati 'bathes'.

S.v. 6145 Ved. dádhāti 'places, lays on, gives, seizes' RV. [Already in RV. there was some contact of meaning with dádāti, and in meaning ʻbeatsʼ it collides with it also phonetically in Kaf. and Dard. There is similar confusion in Iranian (e.g. Shgh. dā- ʻto giveʼ and dā- ʻto put, strikeʼ)]
Cf. s.v. Ved. √nej- 'waschen, reinigen', from PIE *nei̯gʷ-.
S.v. 7167 *nigna- 'washed'. [Cf. niktá- √nij]. > Kho. Kho. nigik 'to wash (hands, clothes, &c.)', nigeik 'to wash something for someone else'.

S.v. Ved. √vāś- 'brüllen, blöken', a root of onomatopoetic origin without connections outside of Indo-Iranic.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ās- 'to make a noise (roar, shout, vel sim.)', an IIr. root probably of onomatopoetic origin without certain IE connections.
S.v. 12684 śraya- m. 'refuge' W. [√śri]
Cf. s.v. 6802 Ved. dhā́vati (1) 'runs, flows' RV. 2. dhāváyati (1) 'makes run, drives' ŚBr. [√dhāv1]

S.v. 2061 Ved. údricyatē 'is prominent' RV. 2. *udriñcati 'empties'. 3. údrikta- 'superfluous' TS. 4. *udrēcati 'leaves'. 5. udrēcayati 'causes to increase' Rājat. 6. *udrēcyatē 'is poured out'. [ud + √ric-]. From (5) > Kho. uléik 'to throw away, pour out, sprinkle' whence intr. ulúik 'to fly away, fall' and its caus. uluwéik 'to make fly'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √rec- 'verlassen, lassen, überlassen, loslassen, freimachen', from PIE *lei̯kʷ- (cf. Arm. lkʻane-, aor. lkʻ[e]- 'verlassen', Gk. λείπω, λιμπάνω 'lasse, verlasse', Lat. linquō 'überlasse', Lith. liekmì 'bleibe', OPr. po-līnka 'bleibt', Goth. leiƕan, etc.).
S.v. 2538 *ōkk 'vomit'. 2. *ōgg- . 3. *vākk- . [Onom.]
S.v. 3193 Ved. kīṭá- (1) m. 'insect, worm' ŚBr.
S.v. 3193 Ved. kīṭá- (1) m. 'insect, worm' ŚBr.
S.v. 13640 *skambha- (2) 'shoulderblade, wing, plumage'.
S.v. 8714 *prabhindati, prábhinatti ʻ splits ʼ RV. [√bhid] > N. pĩdhnu, pĩdnu, pinnu 'to grind corn' (infl. in meaning by pisnu < piṁṣáti?)
S.v. 10302 Ved. meghá- m. 'cloud, rain' RV. [√*mih- (2)] (> P. meh, mẽh, mīh (f. PhonPj 121), mīhī˜ m. 'rain').
S.v. 13095 Skt. sajya- 'strung (of bow)' Kauś., sajja- 'id., put in place on bow (of arrow)' MBh., sajjā- f. 'equipment, dress' lex. (> P. sajjā 'righthand').
S.v. 1041 Skt. ākhyāti 'tells' Ep. [ākhyāyatē ŚBr., aor. ākhyat RV.: √khyā]
S.v. 13578 sr̥ṣṭá- 'released' RV., 'thrown, emitted, produced' AV. [√sr̥j].

Cf. s.v. Ved. √sarj- 'loslassen, entlassen, abschießen', probably to PIE *selg̑- (cf. OIr. selg 'Jagd', MHG selken 'tropfend niederfallen, sich senken (von Wolken), perhaps also Hitt. salk- 'kneten, vermengen').
Cf. s.v. *selg̑- 'loslassen, entsenden' (IEW 900-1).
S.v. 6733 Ved. dhamáni- f. 'vein, nerve' AV., 'throat, neck' lex. [√dham].
S.v. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen', OCS dъmǫ 'blase').
S.v. Skt. dhamániḥ 'Ader / vein', clearly derived from √dham- 'blasen'; dhamani- 'Hals, Nacken' probably comes from a intermediate meaning *'Röhre / pipe'.
Cf. s.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-8).
S.v. 13791 Skt. snāpáyati 'causes to bathe, washes' >  P. nhāuṇā tr. 'to wash', etc.
S.v. 4424 Skt. ghaná- (2) 'compact, firm, dense' Suśr., 'densely filled, deep (of sound or colour)' MBh. 2. n. 'any compact mass' ŚBr., m. 'cloud' MBh. [*han- 3]
S.v. 1008 Skt. ākāśá- m. 'sky' ŚBr. [√kāś].

Cf. s.v. Ved. √kāś- 'sichtbar werden, erscheinen', from which is derived ākāśá- 'freier Raum, Luftraum, Öffnung', perhaps to PIE *kʷek̑-, if the root is connected with Gk. τέκμωρ, τέκμαρ 'Zeichen, Merkmal'.
S.v. 7974 *palva 'grey' (Bshk. pála 'blue, green' rather < palāśá-, *palvara-).

Cf. s.v. Ved. palitá- 'grau, ergraut, altersgrau, greis' < PIE *pelh₂itó-/*pélh₂itnih₂- (cf. Gk. πελιτνός 'blauschwartz, fahl', root-cognate with paruṣá-; cf. further Lat. pallidus 'blaß, bleich', Lith. pálšas 'fahl, blaßgeld', pìlkas 'grau' etc. etc.
S.v. 406 amārus 'bitter', 2. 'gelb'.
S.v. 6267 *passāre 'durchgehen'.
S.v. 412 ambulāre 'gehen'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. boreās, -ae 'vent du nord et région d'où souffle ce vent, nord', a borrowing from Gk. βορέας 'north wind'.
S.v. 1219 Lat. boreas 'Nordwind'.
Cf. s.v. 1534 calx, -ce 'Ferse'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. calx 'heel; hoof', doubtfully compared with BSl. *kulʔk- 'some part of the leg'; perhaps a non-IE (Etruscan?) origin, but a concrete comparandum is lacking.
S.v. 9134 Lat. vallis 'Tal'.
S.v. Lat. vallēs, -is 'valley'. No certain etymology.
Cf. s.v. 1208 Lat. bonus 'gut' under which megl. nebun 'schlecht'.
S.v. 7328 Lat. rīpa 'Ufer'. (> megl. råpă „Abhang", „Stein").

S.v. Lat. rīpa 'river bank', from PIE *h₁reip-h₂ 'steep slope' (cf. Gk. ἐρείπω 'to throw down, fall down', ἐρίπνη 'slope', OIc. rifa 'to demolish, tear down, ONo. rīp 'upper side of a boat', East Frisian rip(e) 'shore').
S.v. 3422 Lat. 1. 'Balg', 'Schlauch' 2. 'Blasebalg'. 3. 'Hülle der Seele'; 1. > Rum. dial. foale 'Bauch'.

S.v. Lat. follis 'bag, sack; ball, testicles'; possibly connected with Proto-Celtic *bol- in OIr. ball 'member, body part', W. balleg 'sack, purse' ({ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} B-12). No further etymology.
Cf. s.v. 6826 Lat. *pullius 'junges Tier'.
Cf. s.v. Lat. putus 'boy' with derivative pullus 'foal, chick, young of an animal'. from PIE *put-lo- 'little boy, young of an animal'; pullus < *put-slo-.
S.v. 5412 Lat. matia 'Eingeweide'. (> Rum. maţe, maţ 'Darm', etc.).
S.v. Lat. *matia (glossary word) 'intestina (-nae), unde matiarii dicuntur qui eadem tractant aut uendunt' (CGL V 32,7). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps identical to Lat. mattea 'friandise'.
S.v. 3750 Lat. geusiae (gall.) 'Kehle'.
S.v. Lat. *geusiae, -ārum 'gosier'. Without doubt a loan from Gaulish (cf. ML 3750).
S.v. 352 *allargāre 'in die Weite gehen'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. vipula- adj. 'umfangreich, ausgedehnt, groß', without certain etymological explanation.

Cf. s.v. SAND ?*pē(n)s- (OCS pěsŭkŭ 'dust', SCr. piejèsak 'dust', Av. pąsnu- 'dust', OInd. pāṃsú- 'crumbling soil, sand, dust'). The Indo-Iranian forms may have been *pām/nsnu- while the Slavic forms lack a nasal. The Slavic accentuation points to *ē and not *eh₁-. The long *ē of *pēns- points to a root noun.
S.v. 4471 Ved. ghāsá- m. 'food, pasture grass' AV. [√ghas]
For Sp., Pg. comer, cf. s.v. 2077 Lat. comedere 'essen'.
Cf. s.v. Sloven. perọ̑ -ẹ̑sa s lat.‛penna, pluma’ (16. stol.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *pero 'feather', to be derived from PIE *perH-o- (cf. Skt. parṇá- 'wing', Gk. πτερόν 'feather, wing', OE fearn 'fern' and OIr. raith 'fern').
Cf. s.v. *(s)ter-, *(s)terə- : *(s)trē 'starr, steif sein, starrer, fester Gegenstand', etc.
Cf. s.v. *(s)ter-, *(s)terə- : *(s)trē 'starr, steif sein, starrer, fester Gegenstand', etc.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kydnǫti
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kydnǫti 'throw, fling' (ESSJa XIII 252-253), from PIE *kud-, cf. also Proto-Slavic *kydati 'throw, fling' < PIE *(s)kud- (cf. Skt. códati 'impel', OIc. skjóta 'shoot, shove').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *zoŗa 'dawn, aurora', a derivative of the root of *zьrěti 'I see', cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *zьrěti 'see, look at'. "The reconstruction of the root is uncertain. One might posit *g̑⁽ʰ⁾r(H)-." Cf. Lith. žėrė́ti 'shine, sparkle'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. žėrúoti 'glühen, glimmern, schwelen', with Lith. žėrė́ti 'glühen, glimmern; funkeln', a secondary derivative to the root of OLith. žer̃ti, žérti 'zusammenscharren (glühende Kohlen)'. Cf. OLith. *žãras 'Röte am Himmel, Morgenrot, Abendrot', comparable to OCS zor'a 'Licht, Schein, Glanz, Morgenröte', etc. No certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic.

Cf. s.v. Lith. gráužti 'nagen, benagen' (BSl. cf. Latv. graûzt 'nagen; reiben, wund reiben' OCS grysti, gryzǫ 'nagen, beißen), from PIE *gʷreu̯g̑- 'nagen', cf. Gk. βρύχω 'mit den Zähnen knirschen', βρύκω 'beißen, gierig abfressen', βρύγμος 'beißend, schlingend; mit den Zähnen klappernd, schaudernd'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. βρῡ́κω 'to bite, eat greedily' beside βρῡ́χω 'grind the teeth' < PIE *gʷruHg̑ʰ- (cf. OCS gryzǫ, grysti 'gnaw', Lith. gráužiu, gráužti 'id.').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *gręsti 'go' (ESSJa VII 123-124), from PBSl. *gri(n)d- (cf. Lith. grìdyti [Jušk.] 'go, wander') < PIE *gʰri-n-dʰ- (cf. Goth. grid 'step', MHG grit 'step'; OIr. ingreinn 'persecute').

S.v. Proto-Slavic *pьrsь 'chest, breast' < BSl. *pírʔśis (cf. Lith. pìršys Npl. f. 'chest (of a horse)'. "Since the connection with Skt. párśu- 'rib, curved knife' is better abandoned, the etymology must be designated as unclear."
Cf. s.v. Ved. párśu- 'Rippe', where "außer-iir. Anschlüsse sind unsicher".

Cf. s.v. Lith. pìršys 'chest (of a horse)'. "In Derksen 2008a (429), l stated that the connection with Skt. párśu- 'rib' is better abandoned, but at least semantically the etymology is plausible ('ribs' → 'chest'). The Balto-Slavic evidence for a laryngeal presents a problem, however."

S.v. Proto-Slavic *pravъ adj. 'right'. "If *pràvъ < *proH-uo- […] we may compare the formation with Lat. probus ‘solid, decent’ provided that the latter form continues *pro-b ʰ(u̯)o- and not *pro-bʰuH-o-."

S.v. Lat. spīna, -ae 'épine (arbrisseau épineux, églantine)', from which 'pointe, piquant, arête; épine dorsale', to be connected with Lat. spīca and Umbrian spina, spinia 'columna'? in uncertain sense. No certain etymology outside of Latin.
S.v. 8150 Lat. spīna 'Dorn'.

S.v. Lat. spīna 'thorn, prickle', from PIE *spein-/*spiHn- (cf. Latv. spina 'rod', OPo. spina 'spine', Ru. spiná 'back, spine', OS/OHG spinela, spenula 'hairpin', MHG spenel 'needle'). "Might be derived from the same basis *sp-i(H)- as spīca."
Cf. s.v. Umb. spinia (uncertain meaning). Usually connected to Latin spīna (with uncertain attempts at an etymological explanation).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *lixъ 'superfluous, incorrect' (ESSJa XV 99-102), reconstructing *lei̯kʷ-so-.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *xudъ 'small, thin' (ESSJa VIII 111-113), from PIE *ksoud-o- (cf. Skt. kṣudrá- 'small').
Cf. s.v. Sloven. slab.
PS *červo is derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.

S.v. bot (1) 'been, knook'. From Proto-Germanic *but- 'stump', a derivative of Proto-Germanic *bautan- 'to beat'. The original meaning seems to have been 'blunt, truncated thing' and used in relation to bones with joint bumps at the ends.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *bautan- 'to beat', from *bʰóud-e-(?), (cf. Lat. -fūtō 'to strike' < *bʰou-t-eh₂-ie-, MIr. búailid 'to beat, strike' [a denominal formation from an instrumental formation *bʰou-dʰlo-?]; Alb. butë 'tender' < *bʰu-to-).
Cf. s.v. ?*bʰeu̯d- 'schlagen' (IEW 112).
Cf. s.v. *magʰ- 'können, imstande sein' (IEW 695, 697).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *mogtì 'be able' (ESSJa XIX 107-111), from PIE *mogʰ- (cf. Lith. magė́ti 'please, interest', OPr. massi 'be able', Skt. maghá- 'power, wealth, gift' Goth. mag 3.sg. 'has power, is able', OIc. mega 'be able', OHG magan, mugan 'be able').
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kǫtja 'hut' (ESSJa XII 70-74). "Etymology obscure. To all appearances, the etymon was originally limited to East and South Slavic."
Cf. s.v. Sloven. kọ́ča -e ž lat.‛casa’
Cf. s.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).
S.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).
S.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).
Cf. s.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).
Cf. s.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).
Cf. s.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *dьrpati (ESSJa V 225), connected to Proto-Slavic *drāpati 'scratch' (ESSJa V 101-102), cf. Gk. δρέπω 'pluck'.

Cf. s.v. Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot', from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' (cf. Goth. waurms 'snake', OIc. ormr, OEng. wyrm, OFr. wirm 'snake', OS wormo, OHG wurm, 'worm' < PGmc. *wurma/i-). Cf. the PIE doublet *kʷrmi- 'worm, maggot', possibly secondarily from PIE *kʷrmi- > *wrmi- in Lat. and Germanic.

Cf. s.v. Lith. kẽras 'Baumstumpf, Staude' (BSl. Latv. cȩrs 'Staude, Strauch', comparable in Slavic to -ii̯o-formations in Cz. keř, OPol. kierz 'Strauch, Staude' and the o-grade n-stem in SCr. kȍrēn, Ru. kóren', Cz. kořen 'Wurzel'. No certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic.

S.v. Lith. kẽras 'tree-stump, stub, bush, shrub' from BSl. *ker-, cf. PSl. *černъ *černь 'stem, stub', also to Slavic *kory 'root' (Ru. kóren', etc.). If further connected to OIr. cern 'angle, corner', W cern 'cheekbone, side of the head' then it may be possible that we are dealing with the root *(s)kerH- to which Lith. skìrti 'separate, divide' belongs.

S.v. Du. kwaad 'slecht, ontstemd', from Proto-Germanic *kwēda- and possibly related to Lithuanian gė́da 'shame'; OCS gadŭ- 'creeping things' (Russian gad 'reptile, amphibian') < PIE *gʷeh₁dʰ-, *gʷoh₁dʰ- (IEW 483-485).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *xwēdaz (adj.), related to Lith. gė́da 'shame', Slav. gydъkъ 'disgusting', Alb. zi 'black < *gʷedi-.
Cf. s.v. OLith. *gė́da 'Schande, Scham', from PIE *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'eklig' (cf. OCS gadъ 'Kriechtier, Gewürm, Ungeziefer' SCr. gȁd 'Reptil, Schlange', MLG kwād 'böse, schlecht', etc.).
Cf. s.v. OLith. *gė́da 'Schande, Scham', from PIE *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'eklig' (cf. OCS gadъ 'Kriechtier, Gewürm, Ungeziefer' SCr. gȁd 'Reptil, Schlange', MLG kwād 'böse, schlecht', etc.).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *umъ 'mind', from PIE *h₂eu̯-m-, from a root *h₂eu̯- underlying forms such as Skt. āvíṣ 'evidently' < *h₂ouis and Gk. αἰσθάνομαι < *h₂euis-dʰ-.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. au- / u- 'to see, to look' from PIE *h₂óu-ei, *h₂u-énti (cf. Skt. āvíṣ (adv.) 'evidently, before the eyes', Av. āuuiš 'id.', Gk. ἀΐω 'to perceive', αἰσθάνομαι 'to perceive', Lat. audiō 'to hear').
Cf. s.v. Lith. makénti, -ė́ti 'in sumpfigem Boden herumwaten' etc., connected with Latv. makņa 'Sumpf, moorige Stelle' and derivative mãkuôņa, -nis, mãkulis 'Wolke'.
Cf. s.v. Lith. maknà 'marshy spot, quagmire'. "A connection with Lat. mācerāre 'to soak, wet' is problematic within an Indo-European context'". Cf. Arm. mōr 'mud'.

S.v. Lith. pjáuti 'cut, saw, mow, bite, sting, torment' < PIE *p(i)eh₂-u- (cf. Gk. πταίω 'nudge, crash into, stumble', TochB pyakar 'they struck down', OE ā-fȳran, fȳran 'castrate', OHG ar-fūrian 'castrate').

S.v. Lith. uolà 'rock', Latv. uõla 'small round stone, egg'. "The traditional etymology, which involves a connection with vélti 'felt, tousle', does not seem to present any serious formal difficulties. Initial *v- would be lost before uo and the falling tone of the Latvian variant ùolis may result from a retraction of the stress from prevocalic i. As to the semantics, it is not at all obvious that the etymology is correct." Cf. s.v. Lith. vélti (II) 'felt, full, tousle' < PIE *uelH- (cf. Goth. wulan 'seethe').
Cf. s.v. OLith. anglìs 'Kohle' (cf. Ved. áṅgāra- 'Kohle'), probably from a noun *ángol-/*angl- or *Héngol-/*Hengl- already in PIE.
Cf. s.v. Lith. griū́ti 'einstürzen, zusammenbrechen; sich stürzen' and s.v. Lith. kráuti 'laden, zusammentragen, aufeinanderschichten, bewahren, behüten'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. kvė̃pti 'atmen, hauchen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kvêpt 'qualmen, rauchen', etc.). These lexemes are probably not to be separated from Lat. vapor, -ōris 'Dampf, Dunst', Gk. καπνός 'Raum, Qualm, Dunst', continuing a root *kʷu̯ap- or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-. Improbable is an etymological connection with Goth. afƕapjan 'ersticken', etc.
Cf. s.v. Lith. kvė̃pti 'inhale, breathe in, inspire', possibly from *k⁽ʷ⁾h₂uēp- and connected with Gk. καπνός 'smoke, Lat vapor 'steam, heat' (both probably < *k⁽ʷ⁾uh₂ep-).
Loanword from Russian, cf. discussion s.v. Lith. gadyna 'Zeit, Stunde, Jahr' < WRu. godina and s.v. Lith. gãdyti 'versöhnen, aussöhnen' < WRu. goditъ.

Cf. s.v. Lith. mãtas 'measure, index' and s.v. Lith. mẽtas 'time period, year'. The etymological identification of the Indo-European root is difficult. "From an Indo-European perspective, the Baltic root *met- seems to occur alongside *meh₁- and *med-, e.g. SCr. mjȅra f. 'measure, weight' (*meh₁-reh₂-), OE mǣð f. (*meh₁-ti-) 'measure' : Go. mitan 'measure' (*med-e-)."
S.v. OLith. mẽtas 'Zeit, Zeitpunkt; Jahr' (BSl. cf. Latv. mȩts 'Zeitraum, Zeit', OPr. mettan). Root identification uncertain, either to *meh₁- 'measure' or *med- 'measure'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. šeimatìs 'Hausstand, Hausfamilie, Hausgenossen' (cf. Goth. haims 'Dorf' ON heimr 'Wohnort, Heimat', OE hām), to which may probably be connected Latv. siẽva 'Ehefrau' (cf. OHG hīwa 'Gattin', and probably also Ved. śéva- 'lieb, vertraut', śivá- 'freundlich, lieb', Lat. cīvis, -is 'Bürger'). Cf. {ref Villaneuva Svensson 2011}:32.

"Latv. siẽva “wife” […] can hardly be interpreted otherwise than as a vr̥ddhi-derivative of *k̑éi‑u̯o‑ “socially close” (: Ved. śéva- “dear”, śivá- “friendly”, Lat. cīuis “citizen”, Gmc. *heiwa “household”)."
S.v. Latv. gaļa. of uncertain origin. It might be possible that it is a derivative to the same root as galēt 'to kill' with an original meaning 'killed animal'.
S.v. Latv. mute, to be connected with Germ. Maul, etc. (cf. also other stem in Germ. Mund, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *terp-, *trep- (nur BSl.) : Lett. tārps 'Wurm' ('der Zerbrechende'), assumed to be an extended form of the root *ter- 'reiben, durchbohren' etc.
S.v. Latv. tārps, following etymology of {ref IEW} 1073.

Cf. s.v. OLith. grę̃žti 'wenden, kehren' (BSl. Latv. grìezt 'kehren, wenden, drehen'), from PIE *greng̑ʰ- 'drehen' (ON í kring, í kringum 'herum, umher', kringja 'einkreisen, umgeben', kringla 'Kringel, Ring, Kreis', MLG kring 'Ring, Kreis', MDu. kringhen 'sich wenden', MHG krangel 'Kreis, Kranz'. No comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic or Germanic.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *kringan- ~ *krinkan- 'to fall' as though from PIE *gréng̑ʰ-e- (cf. Lith. grę̃žti 'to turn, wring; bore, perforate' < *greng̑ʰ-).
S.v. ?*greng̑ʰ- 'drehen' (IEW 386). Only Germanic and Baltic.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *kringan- ~ *krinkan- 'to fall' as though from PIE *gréng̑ʰ-e- (cf. Lith. grę̃žti 'to turn, wring; bore, perforate' < *greng̑ʰ-) and derivative Proto-Germanic *kringa- 'circle'.
Cf. s.v. ?*greng̑ʰ- 'drehen' (IEW 386). Only Germanic and Baltic.
Cf. s.v. ON kringr (1) 'kreis, ring', to be connected with Lith. grėžiù 'wenden, drehen' from a root *greng̑ʰ-.

Cf. s.v. NHG Ring (MHG rinc, OHG (h)ring, OS hring), from PGmc. *hrenga- 'Ring' also in ON hringr, OE hring, OFr. hring. Outside of Germanic one also compares OCS krǫgŭ 'Kreis' and perhaps Umbr. cringatro 'Schulterband'. Further provenance unclear.

Etymology difficult. Comparisons are typically made with Proto-Germanic *hringa- 'ring, circle' ({ref Derksen 2008}:251, {ref ESSJa} 13:25-27, {ref Kroonen 2013}:247, {ref Kluge 2011}:768). As {ref Kroonen 2013}:247 points out, however, the necessary reconstruction of *krengʰ- violates IE root structure constraints and may well point to a post-PIE origin for the Germanic and Slavic lexemes. Inexplicably, Kroonen also appears to consider that the lexemes are also related to Proto-Germanic *kringa- < PIE *greng̑ʰ- (cf. /cognate/9606/). An alternative possibility would be that both the forms as though from *krengʰ- and *greng̑ʰ- were independent loan events from a third source although without any firsthand knowledge of a substratum source this solution is speculative.
Cf. s.v. Lith. sárkanas 'pink, ruddy, with healthy appearance', to a root *ser-.
S.v. Latv. sarkans, following {ref IEW} 910 to *ser-.
S.v. 3. *ser-, *sor- 'rot, rötlich'.
S.v. *mei̯g⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- 'blinzeln, zucken' (IEW 712).
S.v. Lith. miegóti, from PIE *mei̯gʰ-.
S.v. *mei̯gʰ- '(die Augen) schließen, blinzeln'
S.v. OPr. moicte 'schlaffen', meicte 'schlaffen'.

S.v. Latv. aste. Two possible etymologies: either to PIE h₂ek̑- 'sharp' and connected with OCS ostьnъ 'sharp point', or to PIE *Host- 'bone' and cognate with Hitt. ḫāstai-, Skt. asthi-, Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc.
Cf. s.v. Lith. peldė́ti 'schwimmen'.
S.v. *pel-ed-.
Lithuanian pam̃pti 'swell' has an ideophonic oriɡin, exactly as Latvian paupt 'swell'. [No Slavic cognates listed.]

S.v. OLith. druskà 'Salz' (BSl. Latv. druska 'Brocken, Krümchen'), generally attempted to be derived (as though) from IE *dʰrus-ko/eh₂- (cf. {ref LIV²} 157-158n1 s.v. *dʰreu̯s- 'herabfallen, abbröckeln), with a primary verb attested in Germanic (cf. Goth. driusan, OE drēosan, OS driosan 'fallen').

Cf. s.v. OLith. teĩkti 'geben, gewähren; wünschen, gönnen'. Next to teĩkti 'gewähren' is northern Žemaitian teĩkti 'sagen' corresponding to Latvian tèikt 'sagen, erzählen, berichten'. The etymology is unclear; perhaps a secondary full grade teik- to tik-, which could be the zero-grade form PIE *tek- 'die Hand ausstrecken'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic ϸingjan- 'to believe' < *ti-n-k-ié- (cf. Lith. tikė́ti 'to believe').

Cf. s.v. OLith. pū́ti 'faulen' with various derivatives. From PIE *peu̯H- 'faulen, stinken' (cf. Ved. pū-, pū́yati 'faulig werden, stinken', YAv. pū-, puiieiti 'modern, stinken', Gk. πύθομαι 'faule, verwese', ON fūna 'faulen', feyja 'verfaulen lassen, verrotten lassen', prc.part. fúinn 'verfault').
S.v. Lith. trum̃pas 'kurz, zu kurz, eng, zusammengepreßt'. [No etymology outside of Baltic given.]

Cf. s.v. Lith. krapalióti, under which is discussed Lith. krapštýti 'kratzen, scharren, reiben, klauben, stochern', an onomatopoeic formation to the interjection krapš, in imitation of the sound of something dragging along a hard floor.
S.v. Lith. į́sas 'kurz' (Latv. îss, Pr. īnsan) connected to Ved. īṣát 'ein wenig, etwas, leichthin'.

S.v. Lith. į́sas "krótki, kusy", from Proto-Baltic *insa-. One may assume a connection to Proto-Baltic *eis- / *is- from PIE *h₁eish₂- / *h₁ish₂- 'rush; urge on' (cf. Ved. iṣṇā́ti 'rushes, sends', īṣát (adv.) 'a bit, lightly').
S.v. Lith. smė̃lis 'piasek', a derivative of PIE *(s)mel-.

S.v. Lith. smėlỹs 'Sand', further related to the family of lexemes around Lith. smiltìs 'Sand' and to be connected with OSw. smola, smula, smule 'Brokken', Nw. smola 'zermalmen', smol 'Staub, Splitter, Abfall', Goth. smals 'klein, gering', Ir. smal 'Staub'.

PIE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with North Germanic lexemes in the meaning 'dust; small bits' etc., which with Slavic cognates (cf. OCS měla 'lime', Ru. mel' 'sand-bank, shoal') one may reconstruct a common root *(s)melH-. This root might be identical with PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' with s-mobile (cf. {ref Derksen 2015}:414-415), or alternatively connected with Germanic words for 'small' ({ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:842-843, 846-847; but cf. discussion in /cognate/5112/, without Baltic lexemes connected).

S.v. OLith. skrìsti, perhaps to a neo-root *(s)krei̯dʰ-, which could go back to a *-dʰ- present to *(s)krei̯- (cf. skríeti) and be sought after also in OCS okrьstь 'ringsherum, umher' and OE scrīðan 'gleiten, schweben, schreiten', OHG skrītan 'gleiten, schreiten'.
S.v. ?*(s)krei̯t- 'im Kreis gehen' (?) (IEW 937).

S.v. ?*(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'einen Kreis beschreiben' (IEW 936). Verbal only Baltic. Present stem *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾réi̯-e- > Lith. skrejù (skriẽti) 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen', Latv. skreju (skriet) 'laufen, rennen, fliegen'.
S.v. Lith. trum̃pas, -a 'krótki'.

S.v. Lith. į́sčios 'womb, entrails, interior', Latv. ìekšas 'entrails' (cf. OIc. ístr 'fat', MLG instr 'entrails of a slaughtered animal'). "The first element of this noun must be identified with the prefix 'in-', cf. į-" (< *h₁n̥-).
S.v. Latv. iekša (Lith. įsčios) from *en-sti̯ā-s > iešas, where the velar is a secondary development.
S.v. Lith. skrudė̃ 'Ameise'.
S.v. Lith. skruzdėlė̃ 'mrówka, Formica'. Etymology unclear.
Cf. s.v. Lith. blagnas 'ungeeignet, schlecht, böse'. The variant blõgas 'schlecht, gering, mager' is a loan from Belorussian.
S.v. Lith. blõgas, -à 'niedobry, zły, marny, chudy, słaby'. A loan from Old  Belarusian blágij 'lichy, marny, zły'.
S.v. Latv. slikts, loanwords from Middle Low German slicht.

Cf. s.v. OLith. lãbas 'gut' (BSl. Latv. labs 'gut, vollkommen', OPr. labs 'gut, tüchtig', etc.). The common Baltic word for 'good'. Slavic connections are lacking. The proposed connection to Vedic rabh-, rábhate 'to seize, to grasp' / labh-, lábhate 'to get' and Greek ἀμφιλαφής 'comprehensive', λαφύρα 'haul, spoils' is only possible if the root form is *labʰ- (cf. LIV² 412n1 s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen').

Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. {ref ALEW} s.v. Lith. lãbas, {ref LIV²} 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. {ref Hübschmann 1897}:451 speculatively considered a connection with Arm. law (cf. discussion in /cognate/8081/), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965} or {ref ALEW}. A lemma for Lith. lãbas is lacking in {ref Derksen 2015}. Besides the still uncertain proposal to Ved. rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.
S.v. Lith. pil̃vas '(dicker) Bauch, Magen, Wanst, Magen'.
S.v. Lith. pil̃vas 'brzuch', a derivative of PIE *pleh₁- / *pelh₁-.
S.v. Lith. júodas, -à 'czarny'. Etymology unclear.
Cf. s.v. Lith. švarùs 'czysty', etymology unclear.
S.v. Lith. spalvà 'Farbe', cf. Latv. spal̃va 'Haarfarbe von Tieren, Haar von vierfüßigen Tieren, Feder, Gefieder der Vogel'. [No further etymology given.]
S.v. Latv. puķe, a loanword from Finnic.

Cf. s.v. Lith. smagùs 'schwer (vom Gewicht), fest, stark, kräftig (von Schlagen), laut (von einem Pfiff)'. Usually connected with Greek σμογερόν· σκληρόν, ἐπίβουλον, μοχθηρόν (Hesych.), μογερός 'mühselig', μόγος 'Mühe Anstrengung'; much closer however lies a connection with Lith. smõgti 'peitschen' etc. This etymology is confirmed through idioms like 'árklį smagiaĩ smõgti, sukir̃sti, dróžti' 'dem Pferde einen kräftigen Schlag versetzen'. Lith. smõgti 'peitschen, schlagen', etc. is to be connected with Pol. smagać 'peitschen, geißeln, züchtigen', Ru. smagatь, Ukr. smahnuty, smahaty, etc.

Cf. s.v. Lith. smõgti 'ciąć, uderzyć, zadać cios, rzucić (coś
ciążkiego)'; adj. smagùs 'rzutki, rączy (koń), gwałtowny, silny (deszcz,
wiatr), mocny (o piwie)'. The morpheme smog- < PBSl. smāg- may be related to Ru. smagatь, Ukr. smaháty, Pol. smagać.
S.v. Latv. māja, loan from Finnic *mā- 'earth'.
S.v. Latv. deguns. Etymology uncertain, there are many competing proposed etymologies.
Cf. s.v. Lith. kùkis 'Misthaken', kúoka(s) 'Knüttel', connected with Latv. kùoks 'Stock, Baum, Holz'.
Cf. s.v. Lith. kúokas, etymology uncertain.
S.v. Latv. doma 'thought, idea', a loanword from Old Russian дума. Also borrowed was the verb domāt 'to think' < Old Russian думать.
S.v. Lith. uodegà 'ogon', appears to be a derivative from úodas 'komar'.
Cf. s.v. Lith. úodas 'mosquito' for further discussion on the problems of its etymology.
S.v. Latv. nūja, loanword from Livonian nuja 'id.'.
S.v. Lith. asmuõ (gen.sg. asmeñs) 'osoba, indywiduum, osobistość', a neologism based on the present stem asù < esù 'I am'.
For Lithuanian esù 'I am', cf. s.v. 1. *h₁es- 'dasein, sein' (IEW 340-1).
S.v. Latv. cilvēks, a loanword from Old Russian человҍкъ 'id.'.
S.v. Latv. ēna.
S.v. Latv. spēle, loan from Low German (cf. LG spel(e), NHG Spiel); verbal spēlēt.
Cf. s.v. Lith. võras 'bardzo stary', the etymology remains a mystery.
Cf. s.v. Lith. võras 'alt', cf. Pr. urs, uraisins 'Eltern'.
S.v. Lith. bámba 'pępek', cf. Latv. bam̃ba 'kula, gałka; tłuczek'. Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain.
Cf. s.v. Lith. bámba 'Nabel', assuming a connection with OHG naba 'Nabe', Gk. ὀμφάλος, Lat. umbilicus, etc.

S.v. Arm. *ałǰ- 'darkness, fog, twilight' : ałǰ-utʻiwn-kʻ 'darkness', derived  by Meillet from a root *ałǰ- and connected with Gk. ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness' and OPr. aglo 'rain'. Etymology rejected by {ref HAB} I:335-336, but the etymology remains very plausible.

Cf. s.v. OLith. bìlti 'zu sprechen beginnen, sprechen' (BSl. bil̂st, bil̂stu, bil̂du 'sagen, sprechen', OPr. billīt (III), bilītwei, billitwei (III) 'sagen, sprechen', etc.), from PIE *bʰelH- 'tönen' (cf. OE bellan 'brüllen (Löwe, Eber)' OHG bellan 'bellen', TochA pällātsi 'loben, preisen', TochB 3.sg.pres.med. pällātär 'loben, preisen').
Cf. s.v. OLith. žieždrà 'Sand' (BSl. OPr. sixdo 'Sand'). No certain comparisons outside of Baltic.
Cf. s.v. OLith. vyžà 'Pareske, Bastschuh'. The often assumed connection with OPr. winsus 'Hals' is not certain because of the semantic distance.
Cf. s.v. Latv. elpa.
Cf. s.v. Lith. al̃pti 'faint, crave', probably cognate with Latv. èlpt 'breathe, breathe heavily', elpêt 'breathe, recover', and ȩl̃pa, el̃pe 'breath'. Further etymology unclear.

Cf. s.v. OLith. al̃pti 'kraftlos sein; schmachten, verlangen nach', traditionally connected with Latv. èlpt 'schwer atmen', elpêt 'atmen, aufatmen, sich erholen'. No certain comparisons outside of Baltic.

S.v. Latv. depsis 'small, fat boy', OPr. debica 'big', A.sg. debijkan, debīkan, debbīkan. From Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- (cf. Proto-Slavic *debelъ 'fat') ultimately from PIE *dʰebʰ- (cf. OIc. dapr 'sad', Nw. daper 'sad; with young' Nw. dabb(e) 'small, fat fellow' OHG tapfar 'firm, heavy, thick-set).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *dapra- 'heavy'  (cf. RuCS debelyj 'fat', Ru. debelyj 'plump, corpulent' SCr. dèbeo 'fat' < *dʰebʰ-lo-; OCS doblь 'strong', Ru. dóblij 'valiant', Latv. dabļš 'strong, lush' < *dʰobʰ-l-io-). "This adjective is usually directly compared to the aforementioned forms in Slavic, but the underlying root *dʰebʰ- can only be reconciled with PGm. *dapra- by assuming that it was derived from *dapōn-, an analogical variant belonging to the iterative *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' (q.v.) < *dʰobʰ-néh₂-."

Cf. s.v. NHG tapfer (MHG tapfer, dapfer, OHG tapfar 'schwer, gewichtig', MLG dapper, MDu. dapper), from Proto-Germanic *dapra- 'schwer, gewichtig'. Also in ON dapr 'traurig, betrübt', NE dapper 'gewandt'. Comparisons outside of Germanic are uncertain. One may compare OCS debelŭ 'dick', OPr. debīkan 'groß', TochA tpär B tapre 'hoch'. The meaning also fits to OCS dobrŭ 'gut', etc.

Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ({ref IEW} 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:97-98, {ref Derksen 2015}:530-531, {ref Kroonen 2013}:89, {ref Kluge 2011}:907 for further discussion.

Cf. s.v. NHG tapfer (MHG tapfer, dapfer, OHG tapfar 'schwer, gewichtig', MLG dapper, MDu. dapper), from Proto-Germanic *dapra- 'schwer, gewichtig'. Also in ON dapr 'traurig, betrübt', NE dapper 'gewandt'. Comparisons outside of Germanic are uncertain. One may compare OCS debelŭ 'dick', OPr. debīkan 'groß', TochA tpär B tapre 'hoch'. The meaning also fits to OCS dobrŭ 'gut', etc.

S.v. Latv. depsis 'small, fat boy', OPr. debica 'big', A.sg. debijkan, debīkan, debbīkan. From Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- (cf. Proto-Slavic *debelъ 'fat') ultimately from PIE *dʰebʰ- (cf. OIc. dapr 'sad', Nw. daper 'sad; with young' Nw. dabb(e) 'small, fat fellow' OHG tapfar 'firm, heavy, thick-set).

Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ({ref IEW} 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. {ref Kroonen 2013}:89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-).
