Cf. {ref Derksen 2008}:97-98, {ref Derksen 2015}:530-531, {ref Kroonen 2013}:89, {ref Kluge 2011}:907 for further discussion.
Cf. s.v. ùpė 'Strom, Fluß'. OPr. wupyan 'Wolke' possibly to be connected on the basis of semasiological parallels (but remains conjectural).

Cf. s.v. OLith. garbiniúoti 'krausen', a derivative of Lith. garbinỹs, garbìnis 'Locke'. Traditionally OPr. <grabis> 'Berg' is considered connected with this noun, as found in mountain names such as Smaydegarbs, Nirtegarbe, Wittergarbe, but the substantial semantic distance between 'Locke' and 'Berg' makes this etymology doubtful. No certain comparisons outside of Baltic.
Cf. s.v. *gerb- 'sich kräuseln, runzeln, einschrumpfen, sich zusammenkrampfen' relating OPr. grabis 'Berg' and Lith. gárbana, garbanà 'Haarlocke'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. gaĩla 'schmerzlich, bedauerlich, schade'; Latv. gaîlêt, gàilêt 'glimmen, glühen' gàile 'Glimmen, Glut', and OPr. gaylis 'weiß' are probably not root-cognate on the basis of the divergent semantics.
Cf. s.v. Lith. ràkti, rakù 'kopać, ryć' (Latv. rakt, rùoku).
Cf. s.v. Lith. ràkti 'mit einem spitzen Gegenstand stochern, aufstechen, aufstechen, aufpicken, ausgraben'.
S.v. Latv. rakt (= Lith. ràkti), from PIE *er(e)k- : *rek- (following {ref IEW} 335).
S.v. 2. *er(e)k-, *rek-, *rok- 'aufreißen, spalten, schinden'.
For the older proposed comparison of {ref IEW} 335, {ref Karulis 1992} I:103, {ref Fraenkel 1962–1965}:694 to Ved. r̥kṣá-, cf. {ref EWAia} s.v. Ved. r̥kṣá-, considering its etymology unclear.
S.v. Latv. sēta, a derivative of the IE root *sē(i)- 'siet'.

S.v. Hitt. me(y)u-, mi(y)u- 'four'. "Pending further illumination, Proto-Anatolian *mēyu- < *meE₂ʸu- can be postulated as an u-stem adjective meaning basically '(firmly) measured, (four)square', comparable to Ved. sam-mā́ya (RV 1.67.10 'staking out' [like craftsmen do an abode]), vi-mā́ya (RV 10.114.6 'measuring out' [a sacrifice, after dividing four catúraḥ) cups of soma]), pra-mā́- 'prime measure, prototype')."
Cf. s.v. AGk. μέλι 'honey' < PIE *melit- 'honey' (cf. Hitt. milit- < *melit-; Goth. miliϸ, Alb. mjaltë < *melit-o-; OIr. mil, Lat. mel < probably *meli-t-).
S.v. Tocharian AB tsāk- 'to pierce, bite', belonging either with Gk. δάκνω  or PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷʰ- 'hineinstecken, stechen'.
S.v. TochB ²tsāk- 'pierce, bite (of a snake)'. Etymology uncertain. Generally either to PIE *denk̑- or *deihₓgʷ-.
Cf. s.v. *ām-r/n 'day'.
S.v. Italiot *λούκιον 'Feuer', loanword from dialectal Italian lúći 'fire'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. ándhas- 'zur Somapressung verwendeter Sproß, Schoß (und ähnliches)' < PIE *h₂éndʰes- (cf. Gk. ἄνθος 'Keim, Sproß, etc.'; cf. also Fries. åndul 'feines zartes grünes Gras auf den Hellern').
Cf. s.v. καβοῦλα 'Nebel'. The origin of the Modern Greek word is unknown. In Italy it has evidently become blended with καῦμα, κάμα 'Hitze'.
Cf. s.v. *deh₃- 'geben' (IEW 223-5).
Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰeu̯- 'gießen' (IEW 447-8).
S.v. ῥεῦμα 'Strömung, Flut' > It. ῥέμα.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. sal(l)- 'swell, expand, extend', with derivative salli- 'big, large, tall high; adult, aged, great, grand; main principal chief, royal, regal', connecting the complex of related vocabulary to PIE *s(w)el(H)- also in ON svella, OHG swellan 'swell'. The adjective salli- has otherwise been connected since Sturtevant, Comp. Gr. 138 to Skt. sárva-, Av. haurva-, Gk. οὗλος, ὅλος, Lat. sollus, 'whole' from *solwo-, which remains semantically possible.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *dankʷa- 'dunkel' with a close parallel in Hitt. dankui- 'black, dark'.
S.v. Luw. al(l)attar / *allattn- 'fruit' (?)

S.v. Hitt. luli(ya)- (c.) 'pool, lake, pond; (well)basin, cistern, reservoir, tank, vat', assuming a connection with luwaressa- 'level ground, flatland' to a heteroclite stem *lewr-/lewn- (Gk. λευρός 'even, level, smooth').
S.v. Hitt. he(w)u-, he(y)au- (c.) 'rain'.
Cf. s.v. Hitt. kunna- 'right (hand or side); right, favourable, successful'.

S.v. Hitt. putkiya- 'swell, be tumescent'. "A plausible cognate is Lith. pùsti 'swell' […]. The verb putkiya- can be denominative from e.g. put-ko- 'swelling, edema, tumor' (vel sim.); cf. Belorussian potka (< *pŭtĭka) 'penis' beside Lat. prae-pūtium 'foreskin'."
Cf. s.v. Lith. pùsti 'anschwellen, sich aufblähen', an anticausative formation to Lith. pū̃sti 'wehen, blasen', without clear correspondences outside of Baltic.
S.v. Hitt. lala- (c., rarely n.) 'tongue' (either in anatomical sense or as ritualistic model, 'blade', metonymically 'speech, talk'.
S.v. 6590 Ved. doṣā́ 'night, night personified' RV. > Phal. dohṓṛ, dhōṛ, doṛ 'yesterday'.
S.v. 3084 Ved. kālá- (2) 'time' AV. 'any fixed point in time' ŚBr. 'fate, death' MBh. "in many [NIA] forms the word or at least its meaning has been influenced throughout by contact with Sanskrit".

S.v. Ved. kālá- 'Zeitpunkt, günstiger Augenblick, richtige Zeit, Zeit'. IIr. cf. Sogd. kry' 'succession in time', Oss. (Iron) kār 'Alter', Khot. karāvatä 'am Morgen'. Two main possibilities at an etymology: Either (1) an l-form  to kārá- (√kar-) if this means 'Erfolg(s-Augenblick)', 'entscheidende Handlung' (> kālá- 'richtige Zeit') or (2) to √car- (via *kʷōlH-o-?) as something like 'sich drehend, Turnus' ultimately to PIE *kʷelH- 'drehen'.
S.v. Paš. kāl 'year', "Cf. T 3084 and Pamir languages kāl 'id.' (Ashkun, Kati, Prasun, Waigali, Dameli, Tirahi, etc.) [E]"
S.v. 13734 Ved. strī́- 'woman, wife' RV.
S.v. 7733 Ved. páttra- n. 'wing, feather'.
S.v.  6732 Skt. dhamana- 'blowing with bellows' lex. [√dham].
Cf. s.v. 1929 cinis, -ere 'Asche'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. áṁsa- 'Schulter' (IIr. cf. Oss. on 'Schulterblatt < *anha- {ref Abaev 1959–1995} II:227f.), from PIE *Homso-, cf. Goth. amsans (acc.pl) 'die Schultern', TochA es 'Schulter'.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *stōra- 'gewichtig', inherited adjective, identical with Lith. stóras 'dick, grob', 'tief, rauh', OCS starъ 'alt', derived from PIE *stā- 'stand', cf. Ved. sthávira- 'breit, dick, derb' and 'alt, angesehen'.

S.v. 971 Ved. ásr̥j, nom. ásr̥k, gen. asnáḥ 'blood' RV., asra- n. Kālid.
1. asn- > Pr. usũ̄̈. 2. ā̆sr- > Paš. lauṛ. ār, kuṛ. ōel, dar. āš, ar. ōstr.
S.v. 7574 sanguis 'Blut', 2. sanguen, -ine.
Cf. s.v. 472 anhēla 'Atem', 2. alēna, 473 'anhēlāre 'atmen'.
Cf. s.v. 11097.3 *loṣati ʻburnsʼ
S.v. Latv. auksts (cf. Lith. áušti).
S.v. *k̑elH ‘kalt werden, frieren’ (LIV 323, IEW 551)
S.v. Proto-Iranic *Hai- 'to go', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' (cf. Hitt. i-it 'go!' Luw. i-ti 'he goes', Gk. εἶμι 'I go', Lat. īre, OCS iti, Lith. eĩti 'to go', etc.).
S.v. Gmc. *kwem-a- 'kommen'.
Cf. s.v. 9200 Lat. venīre 'kommen'.

S.v. 5524 *ḍagga- (2) 'defective'. 2. *ḍaṅga- 2. 3. ḍaṅgara- 2 'expression of contempt' lex. (→ Psht. Orm. ḍaṅgar ʻ lean ʼ IIFL i 393, NTS ii 255). 4. *ḍikka- 2. 5. *ḍiṅga- 2. 6. ḍiṅgara- m. 'rogue, servant' lex. 7. *ḍēṅga- 2. 8. *ḍhagga- . 9. *ḍhaṅkha- . 10. *ḍhiṅka- 2. 11. *dhaṅga- . 12. *dhiṅga-.
S.v. 3157 Skt. kiṭṭāla m. 'copper vessel' lex. (Ash. čitā'l 'bowels', Kt. kṭyȧl, Pr. kṭal; Bashg. ktol 'belly' (NTS ii 252 prob. ← Ind.?).)
S.v. 4798 Skt. cíti- f. 'layer, pile, stack of wood' TS. [√ci1].
S.v. 10507 yuvátē 'yokes' RV., yauti 'takes hold of' AV. 2. *eats
S.v. Wax. yaw- : (y)it- 'есть, кушать' < OIr. *yav(a)- : *yauta-, *yūta-.

Cf. s.v. NHG Bauch (MHG būch, OHG būh), from Gmc. *būka- 'Bauch', also in ON búkr, OE būc, OFr. būk, būch. The word goes back to a root with different initial labials designating fat, belly-like things (cf. Ru. púzo 'Bauch, Wanst'), perhaps originally a sound-symbolic word for blown up (and hence fat) cheeks. Perhaps to this also OIr. abach 'Eingeweide' (< *ad-bhug-).

S.v. Du. buik. There are no certain cognates outside of Germanic. Some attempt to see a connection with the same root in Du. buigen 'to bend', but this is formally problematic as Proto-Germanic has *-g- for that verbal stem. As a body part, perhaps it is of substrate origin.
Cf. s.v. Arm. tʻitʻełn 'butterfly', pp.293-294 where a case is made attempting to consider Arm. pʻetowr an inherited derivative of PIE *pet-.
S.v. 2922 Skt. kalaha m. 'quarrel, fight' MBh. (<-> Kt. kəle 'war, fighting').
S.v. Kâmviri âŋʹo 'fire' [OIA. ʹa˜gâra- ‘glowing coal’  T. 125].

Cf. s.v. ModEng. mist "Cognate with Middle Dutch mest, mist (Dutch mist), Middle Low German mist, Middle High German mist, Icelandic mistr, mistur, Norwegian (regional or archaic) mist, Swedish mist, Danish mist < an extended form of the Indo-European base of Sanskrit mih mist, vapour, megha cloud, ancient Greek ὀμίχλη mist, cloud, Old Church Slavonic mĭgla mist, cloud, Russian mgla haze, Lithuanian migla mist, Albanian mjegull cloud, mist."

S.v. Du. mist, to be connected with Greek ὀμίχλη ‘nevel’; Sanskrit megha- ‘wolk’; OIr. mēgha ‘wolk’; Lith. miglà ‘nevel’; OCS mĭgla ‘nevel’ (Ru. mgla); Arm. mēg ‘nevel’; from the PIE root *h₃meigʰ- (IEW 712).
S.v. 6955c Skt. *nabhalikā- 'cloud'. [Cf. Lat. nebula, &c., nábhas-]
S.v. 11258 vána- (1) 'single tree' RV., 'forest, timber' RV. The Nuristani lexemes are loaned from a Middle Indic language which had undergone the sound-change *w- > b-.
S.v. Kâmviri kâc̣ʹavec̣ 'fruit' [OIA. kʹakṣa- ‘undergrowth’  T. 2589 (+)]
Cf. s.v. 2589 kákṣa- (2) 'undergrowth'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. kákṣa- (2) 'Gebüsch, Gestrüpp', certainly distinct from kákṣa- (1) 'Achselhöhle', perhaps to be connected with NHG Hag, Hecke?
S.v. 12614 śaítya n. 'coldness' Yājñ. 2. *śaitiya- > Wg. šēi, šē 'ice', Kt. šē̆.
For Middle and Modern Indic languages, cf. s.v. 8339 Ved. pūrṇá- 'filled, full' RV.; for Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 8107 pāráyati (2) 'fills' Dhātup.
For Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 8655 Ved. prádadāti 'gives away' RV.
Cf. s.v. Alb. dáshë, aor. to ap 'geben', to be connected with PIE *deh₃-, cf. for further discussion on the possibilities of stem-formation.
Cf. s.v. Alb. (Arb.) jap 'to give', to which aor. dha stem continues PIE *deh₃-.
Cf. s.v. Alb. jap (aor. dashë) 'to give'. The aorist dashë continues Proto-Albanian *e-das-a based on the zero-grade of PIE *dō- 'to give'.

S.v. Gaul. dede 'a offert', the word dede has been compared to Lat. dedit 'a donné', although Szemerényi KZ 88 (1974) 281-282 and others prefer to see a reduplicated perfect from the root *dʰē- (*dʰeh₁-) 'poser, mettre, établir'.
S.v. W niwl 'fog, mist, vapour, haze, cloud(s); also fig. and transf.; obscured eyesight', loanword from Lat. nūbilus?
Cf. n15: The late Latin *nibulus (for nūbilus) was loaned into Celtic, cf. MW nyfel, NW niwl, nifwl, Co. niul 'Wolke, Nebel' (cf. {ref IEW} 315).

S.v. OIr. nél 'nuage'. Attempts to reconcile to a pre-form *nebʰlo- (cf. Lat. nebula, Gk. νεφελή, OHG nebul, OE nifol) is phonetically impossible. Thurneysen's hypothesis of *miglos (cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη) with the change of *m- > *n- under the influence of nigíd 'he washes' is less plausible. The Brythonic forms (Welsh niwl, nifwl, Corn. niul may be borrowings from Lat. nūbilus (< nībulus), and according to IEW 315 Ir. nél is borrowed from Brythonic.
S.v. 10436 Ved. yávasa- m.n. 'grass' RV.
S.v. 560 Ved. amā́ 'at home, in the house' RV.
S.v. áma- (2) pron. 'dieser (hier)', to which probably amā́ 'zu Hause'. In view of the deixis perhaps to be compared with Gk. ἐμοῦ 'meiner', but uncertain.
S.v. 10795 rúh f. 'growth, sprouting' RV.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √rodh- (2) 'wachsen', daneben √roh- 'wachsen', to PIE *h₁leu̯dʰ- 'wachsen' (cf. OE lēodan 'wachsen', OIr. luss 'Pflanze' etc.).
S.v. 2587 Skt. kakkhaṭa- , kha˚ 'hard, solid' lex. 2. *kakkhāṭa-, 3. kakkaṭa-.

S.v. ṭâkʹoa-  [ṭâkʹavoa-]  VT.  Conceal, hide.  [ṭâka-ov-]  [optionally with directional pointer] cf. ṭâkʹa-  [[no causative; cf. ṭâkʹoa- ʹconcealʹ]]  VI.  Be stuck; be bound.  [ṭâka-V]  [OIA. *ṭakk- ‘remain; stop’  T. 5420.1 (+)]

S.v.7165 *nigāti 'learns', cf. nyágāt 'went down' RV. [Cf. nigan- tavya- 'to be learnt' Āpast., nigacchati 'acquires knowledge' lex., Pk. ṇiacchaï 'sees'. – √gā-] (> Pk. ṇiaï 'sees'; Ash. niṅā- 'to know, recognize'; Wg. niṅā- 'to understand').
S.v. 7918 Ved. parṇá- sg. or pl. 'plumage, foliage (of tree)' RV., 'betel leaf' lex.
S.v. 9888 Ved. mártya- m. 'a mortal, man' RV. [√mr̥]
S.v. 395 Ved. ánna- 'food' RV. Ash. andá ʻ meat ʼ, Wg. andá, ána, Kt. anṓ (< *adnāka -- NTS xvii 226), Gaw. āˊnda, Shum. ã̄də.
S.v. Ved. ánna- 'Speise, Nahrung', a substantivization of *anná- 'gegessen' < *ad-ná- (*h₁ed-).
S.v. Kâmviri dʹâ  N.  Mountain.  [dâ]  [OIA. dhʹâra-:- ‘edge; mountain edge’  T. 6793]
S.v. 6793 dhā́rā- (2) f. 'sharp edge, rim, blade' RV., 'edge of mountain' lex.
Cf. s.v. Ved. dhā́rā- 'Schneide (des Schwertes, Messers), Klinge' < IIr. *dʰārā- 'Klinge, Schneide' (cf. YAv. dārā- 'Klinge', tiži-dāra- 'mit scharfer Schneide', etc.).
S.v. AGk. πέντε 'five' (Aeol. πέμπε) < PIE *penkʷe 'five'.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *fedwar- 'four' < PIE *kʷét-uor-.

Cf. s.v. Lith. -žala, atžalà 'junger Zweig, Spross, Schössling' with derivatives žalė́tis 'grün werden' and žãlinti 'grün machen', o-grade formations to Lith. žélti 'grünen, sprießen', derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'hellgrün' (cf. Ved. hári- 'fahl, gelblich, grünlich', YAv. zairi-, zāiri- (adj.) 'gelb', Gk. χλωρός 'hellgrün, blassgrün, grüngelb, gelblich, blass; frisch, lebendig', Lat. holus, -eris 'Grünzeug, Gemüse').
S.v. 2830 Ved. kárṇa- m. 'ear, handle of a vessel' RV.
Cf. s.v. 3855 Lat. gravis 'schwer', 2. grevis (nach levis).
S.v. 5679 Ved. taptá- 'heated, hot' RV. [√tap-]
S.v. Paš. tod 'hot' (cf. Av. tafta-, Khot. ttauda-, etc.).
S.v. PGmc. *kwel-a- 'leiden', probably from an original verb *gʷel- 'sterben', perhaps from an original meaning 'stechen'.

S.v. OIr. marb 'mort' (derivative marbaid 'il met à mort, il tue'), cf. W. marw 'mort', Co. marow, MBret. marf, and maru, Bret. maro. Derived fro the root *mer- signifying death and preserved in most IE languages (Skt. mriyáte 'il meurt', Lat. morior, OCS mrěti, Lith. mir̃ti). The adjective in Celtic is formed with the suffix *-wo- (cf. Lat. uīuos, Ir. beo 'vivant').

Cf. s.v. Ved. √vay-ⁱ 'nachspüren, nachspürend suchen, auf etwas losgehen, nach etwas trachten, verfolgen, hinter etwas her sein, etwas heimsuchen', from PIE *u̯ei̯H- 'auf etwas losgehen, verfolgen', cf. Gk. ἵεμαι (= ϝῑ́εμαι) 'strebe, trachte nach, begehre, eile' Lith. výti 'treiben, verfolgen, nachjagen'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯aid- (1) 'to know', from PIE (pf. stem) *u̯oid- 'to know' (cf. Gk. οἶδα, Arm. gitel, OIr. ro-fetar, MW gwyr, OCS vědě, Goth. wait, witum, ON vita, OE witan 'to know', Engl. wit, etc.).
S.v. OIr. clé 'gauche' from *kleiyo- or *kliyo- (cf. Goth. hleiduma 'gauche', Lat. clīuis 'de mauvais augure'), derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'incliner, pencher'.

Arm. srownkʻ 'leg, shank' is cognate to Lat. crūs, crūris 'id.'. "The traditional reconstruction *k̑rūs-ni- has been considered a contamination between two original lexemes, *k̑rūs- and *k̑lou̯ni- as continued in Skt. śróṇi- 'hip, buttock', Lith. šlaunìs 'hip, thigh', etc."

Cf. s.v. LIVER: *i̯ekʷr̥(t) 'liver' "Presumably the most likely candidate for the PIE word for 'liver'", but not entirely certain in view of Hitt. lissi-, which might be a very old word for liver replaced everywhere else by *i̯ekʷr̥(t), or more likely an Anatolian innovation.

Cf. s.v. Ved. br̥hánt- 'groß, umfänglich, reichlich, erhaben, hoch, kräftig, weit, dicht, laut' (YAv. bərəzaṇt- 'hochragend, hoch, laut', Oss. bærzond 'hoch', MP, NP buland 'hoch, groß'), from PIE *bʰr̥g̑ʰ-ént-.
S.v. O.u.sp. niir 'Mann', from PIE *h₂nē̆r- 'Mann' also in Gk. ἀνήρ, Arm. ayr, Ved. nā́, cf. W ner 'Chef, Meister', Alb. njer 'Mann'.
Cf. s.v. 9982 Ved. māṁsá- n. 'flesh'.

Cf. s.v. Lith. girià 'Wald, Wüste, Wildnis', from PIE *gʷorH-/*gʷr̥H- 'bewaldeter Berg' (cf. OCS gora 'Berg, Gebirge, Höhe', Ved. girí- 'Berg, Hügel, Anhöhe', YAv. gairí- 'Berg, Gebirge', Gk. βορέας, -ου 'Nordwind, Norden', Alb. gur 'Stein, Fels').

S.v. Proto-Germanic *namōn- 'name', from PIE *h₃nh̥₃-men- (cf. Hitt. lāman- 'name', HLuv. álaman- 'id.', Lyc. alãman 'id.', TochA ñom, TochB ñem 'id.', Skt. nāman-, Av. nāman 'id.', Gk. ὄνομα 'id.' Phryg. onoman 'id.', Arm. anun 'id.' Alb. emër 'id.', OCS imę, OPr. emmens 'id.').
S.v. Arm. anjuk 'narrow; difficult', long since connected to PIE *h₂(e)ng̑ʰ-u- 'narrow' (Skt. aṁhu-, Goth. aggwu, etc.).
S.v. Wa. naɣ̌d 'ночь', from Old Iranian *naγda- < *naxta(r)- (cf. Av. [upa.]naxtar-, Ved. nákt-, Lat. noct-is).
Cf. s.v. NOSE *hₓnáss ~ *hₓnā́s (gen. hₓnasos) 'nose'.
S.v. 8283 Ved. purāṇá- 'ancient' RV. [purás]
S.v. Latv. vecs (Lith. vẽtušas), cf. Hitt. u̯itt-, Skt. vatsaráḥ, Gk. étos, Lat. vetus from PIE *u̯et- 'gads'.
Cf. s.v. 9291 Lat. vetulus 'alt', 2. veclus; and 9292 Lat. vetus 'alt'.
S.v. 2462 Ved. éka- 'one' RV.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *aiu̯a- 'один' < IE *oiu̯e, *oi̯u̯os.
Cf. s.v. 10298 mr̥ṣā 'in vain' RV., 'falsely' AV., miṣa- n. 'false appearance' Kāv. [√mr̥ṣ?]
Cf. s.v. Kâm-viri mišʹa- 'play' [PrAr. *mr̥sa- ‘in vain; falsely’  T. 10298].
Cf. s.v. Slov. rdẹ́ti -ím nedov. lat.‛rubescere’ (19. stol.). With derivative rdeč 'ruber', derivatives from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ-.
S.v. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade', 2. dērēctus.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *dānu- 'вода, река', from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dānu-, cf. Ved. dānu- 'каплющее течение, капающий; капель, роса' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:719-720). Not to be excluded is the possibility of a contamination with Proto-Indo-Iranic *dhan- 'бежать, течь' < PIE *dʰen- 'бежать, течь' (cf. {ref IEW} 249, {ref EWAia} I:772).

Cf. s.v. Ved. dā́nu-, a Rigvedic word designating rain and by many interpreted as 'träufelend, träufelnde Flüssigkeit', by others as 'Gabe', if the former possibly with YAv. dānu- 'Fluß', Oss. don 'Fluß, Wasser', and further to European river names.
Cf. s.v. 6878 Lat. pūtidus 'stinkend', 6887 Lat. putridus 'faul'.

S.v. Proto-Celtic 2. *sekʷ-e/o- 'sagen', Anm. d) (PIE 2. *sekʷ-, LIV² 526f.). MW heb serves as a citation verb (cf. Latin inquit) which is usulally unmarked with regard to time, person and number. The 1sg. hebaf and the verbal noun hebu both occur only once in a poetic context involving a word play. 
OBr. hep is attested twice as a citation verb, cf. Fleuriot (1964a, 209).
Cf. s.v. 2174 Lat. consuere 'nähen'.
S.v. 134 Lat. *acūtiāre 'wetzen' and 135 Lat. acūtus 'spitzig, scharf'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kan-e/o- 'singen' (PIE *kan- or *k̑an-, cf. LIV² 342f.).
Cf. s.v. 6377 Lat. pellis 'Fell'.

S.v. OIr. nathir 'serpent', going back to a stem *natrik- ({ref Pedersen 1913}:98), a stem *natri- is seen in W neidr, etc. {ref Pedersen 1913}:45 assumes an agent noun in *-te/or with various additional suffixes to the root *(s)nā- 'nager'; {ref IEW} 767 attaches to the root *(s)nē- 'tordre, se tordre'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷrimi- 'worm', from PIE *kʷrmi- 'worm' (IEW 1152), cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi-, Alb. krimb, Lith. kirmìs, Sloven. črm.
S.v. 14096 Ved. himá- m. 'cold, frost, snow' (in himávant-) RV., 'snow, hoarfrost' ṢaḍvBr.
S.v. 6128 Ved. daṇḍá- m. 'stick, club' RV.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *gari- ' гора, холм; валун, скала', cf. Ved. girí-; from PIE *gʷr̥-i-, *gʷer-i-.
S.v. Wa. ɣ̌ar 1. 'камень', from PIr. *γar(i)-, cf. Av. gairi-, Ved. girí-, Khot. ggara-, Sogd. γr-, Yaghn. γar, etc.
S.v. OIr. diriug 'droit, juste', an old u-stem formed with the prefix di- + the root *reg- corresponding exactly to Indo-Iranian r̥jú- 'droit, juste', Av. ərəzu- 'id.'
Cf. s.v. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade', 2. dērēctus.
S.v. *sal- 'Salz' (IEW 878f., EIEC 498), reconstructing a stem *sal-dh₃-u- for the Balto-Slavic forms.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *tungōn- 'tongue' < *dng̑ʰ-u̯eh₂- (cf. TochA käntu, TochB kantwo 'tongue' < *g̑ʰnd⁽ʰ⁾-ueh₂- (with metathesis), Skt. jihvā́ 'id.', Av. hizuua-/hizu- 'id.' < *d(i)ng̑ʰ-ueh₂-; Lat. lingua 'id.' < *lng̑ʰ-ieh₂-, OIr. tengae; Lith. liežùvis 'id.', OPr. insuwis < *ng̑ʰ-ueh₂-, OCS językъ, Ru. jazyk, SCr. jèzik < *ng̑ʰ-u-(ko-); Arm. lezu, gen. lezvi 'id.').

S.v. Lat. dēns, dentis 'dent de l'homme ou des animaux'. A pan Indo-European word. The Greek forms ὀδών, ὀδόντος (Aeolic ἔδοντες) indicate a connection with the group of words related to edō, etc., of which this is the participle.

S.v. AGk. ὀδών. Given the variation, two etymologies have been proposed: (1) Traditionally one considers a participle of *ed- 'manger' with a zero-grade, with an e-grade in ἔδοντες, like ἔων beside ὤν. The second hypothesis of Benveniste (BSL 1931 74ff.) considers the character of the vocalic alternation *ed-, the semantic difficulty of calling the tooth 'the eater' instead considering a prothesis to a base *den-t-, *don-t-, *dn̥t-, parallel to *den-k-, *dn̥k- in Greek δάκνω, Skt. dáśati.
S.v. Bret. dant 'dent' corresponding to Co. dans, W dant. Denominal verbal formation dantañ (dantaff, 1499) 'denter, cranter, mordre'.
Cf. s.v. 4939 Ved. cyávate 'moves to and fro, retires' RV.
Cf. s.v. Kâmviri ǰʹukuř, ǰʹukuřo/oa˜ obl.  NHF.  Woman.  [ǰü-kuřa-], cf. ǰʹü  NKF.  Daughter [OIA. duhitʹr̥- ‘daughter’  T. 6481].
Cf. s.v. 6481 Ved. duhitŕ̥- f. 'daughter' RV.
Cf. s.v. Ved. duhitár- 'Tochter', from PIE *dʰugh₂tér- (cf. Gk. θυγάτηρ, TochB tkācer, A ckācar, Lyc. kbatra, Arm. dowstr, Osc. futír, NHG Tochter, Lith. duktė̃, OCS dъšti, etc.).
S.v. Proto-Iranic *i̯ār(a)- 'год; период, времени', derived from PIE *i̯ēro- : i̯oro- ~ i̯əro-, cf. OHG jār, NHG Jahr, Engl. year, Gk. ὤρα, etc.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √arc- 'strahlen, glänzen; singen, lobsingen, preisen' (IIr. cf. Khot. āljs- 'singen' ({ref Bailey 1979}:25b), from PIE *(h₁)erkʷ- 'strahlen' (OIr. erc 'Himmel') and 'singen' (TochA yärk, B yarke 'Verehrung', Arm. erg 'Lied').
S.v. Skt. khura- 'Huf, Klaue'. "Nicht überzeugend erklärt.'
Cf. s.v. no. 114 Skt. khura- 'hoof', KatySrS., Mn., etc. ~ Ta. kuracu, kuraccai 'horse's hoof', Ka. gorasu, gorise, Te. gorije, gorise, korise 'id.'
Cf. s.v. no. 114 Skt. khura- 'hoof', KatySrS., Mn., etc. ~ Ta. kuracu, kuraccai 'horse's hoof', Ka. gorasu, gorise, Te. gorije, gorise, korise 'id.'
S.v. Skt. khura- 'Huf, Klaue'. "Nicht überzeugend erklärt.'
S.v. 3906 Skt. khura- m. ʻhoofʼ (KātyŚr̥), 2. *khuḍa (khuḍaka, khula° ʻankle, boneʼ Suśr.) ← Dravidian origin.
Cf. s.v. Skt. khúraḥ 'Huf / hoof', probably a Dravidian word, cf. Tel. korije, gorije, gorise, Kan. gorasu, gorise = Drav. *kŏr- 'Huf' with typical Dravidian variants (Burrow BSOS 9, 718; 12, 376).
S.v. 3894 *khuṭṭa- (2) 'leg'
Cf. s.v. Skt. guṭa- 'Fußknochel / Ankle', perhaps Dravidian, cf. Kurukh mal-guṭa- 'Rist', etc. (Burrow BSOAS 11, 342, 12, 377).

Cf. s.v. 8792 Ved. právahati 'carries forward', ˚tē intr. 'drives on' RV. > M. pohṇẽ 'to swim, float, abound in'; for Kashmiri cf. ? s.v. 11612 Skt. vāhayati1 'drives (a chariot), rides (a horse)' MBh. [√vah].
S.v. Ved. √vah- 'fahren, Wagen lenken, Wagen ziehen, herbeiführen, befördern, bringen' < PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ-.

S.v. AGk. ὄρνις, ὄρνεον. The root of the Greek word is found in the word for 'eagle' in Hittite and Germanic: Hitt. ḫar-aš, gen. ḫaranaš, Goth. ara (gen. *arins), ON are and ǫrn, OEng. earn, OHG aro, aru. There exist parallel forms in -l- in Baltic and Slavic: Lith. erẽlis, arẽlis, Latv. ḕrglis (from *ḕrdlis), OCS ŏrĭlŭ 'aigle', cf. {ref IEW} 325f.

S.v. AGk. ποταμός 'course d'eau, fleuve, rivière'. Ποταμός is a suffixival derivative corresponding to the type οὐλαμός, πλόκαμος. It has been long connected with πίπτω, aor. ἔπετον 'tomber' : the torrent, the course of water which falls, but the epithet διιπετής (cf. s.v. πίπτω) does not allow this connection without difficulty. The etymology which evokes the semi-homophonous root of πετάννυμι supposes that the river is considered as a sheet of water that spreads is not very plausible. Cf. also further bibliography apud {ref Frisk 1960–1972}.
S.v. AGk. -κναίω 'gratter, frotter, racler', etc.
Cf. s.v. AGk. λειμών, -ῶνος 'prairie humide', with secondary derivative with zero-grade of root and suffix λί-μν-η 'eau stagnante, lac, étang'.

S.v. AGk. οὐρά 'queue' notably of lions, dogs, wolves, and horses. Distinct in principle from κέρκος. Οὐρά < *ὀρσά is evidently connected with ὄρρος 'croupion' < *ὄρσος. Outside of Greek to be connected to OIr. err 'queue' with e-grade vocalism.
Cf. s.v. AGk. σπείρω 'semer' with nominal derivative σπέρμα 'semence, fait de semer, origine', from PIE *sper- 'réprandre'.

S.v. AGk. πνέω 'respirer', etc. The word may be connected to a family of expressive words which may be more or less based on onomatopeia. In Germanic cf. ON fnýsa 'haleter, souffler bruyamment', OEng. fnēosan 'éternuer'.
S.v. AGk. καίω 'brûler, mettre le feu à, cautériser', based on earlier *καϝ-yω, cf. καῦμα, etc.
S.v. AGk. κόνις, -ιος (Att. -εως) 'poussière; cendre, sable d'une arène', plausibly connected with Lat. cinis, -eris (with e-grade vocalism).
S.v. AGk. κόπτω 'frapper d'un coup sec, tailler, frapper une monnaie, trancher, hacher'. One has connected Lith. kapiù (inf. kàpti) 'tailler, abattre', Alb. kep 'tailler'.
S.v. AGk. ἔρχομαι 'aller, venir', sometimes 'marcher', without certain etymology.
S.v. AGk. ἔρχομαι 'aller, venir', sometimes 'marcher', without certain etymology.
Cf. s.v. NHG schwingen < PGmc. *swengw-a-, without clear correspondences outside of Germanic.

Cf. s.v. Alb. merimangë 'spider' with variants merimagë, mirëmangë, milimangë, milingonë, and merimajkë, to be interpreted as tabooistic distortions of merming 'id.' borrowed from Modern Greek μυρμῆγγι 'ant, midget'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. kīṭá- 'eine Wurm-Art'. Etymology unclear. Perhaps a loanword.
Cf. s.v. Ved. kīṭá- 'eine Wurm-Art'. Etymology unclear. Perhaps a loanword.
Cf. s.v. Alb. shkrumb 'black ashes, anything burned to ashes' < PAlb. *iš-kruma with non-etymological -mb (cf. Alb. loanword in Romanian scrum 'id.').
S.v. 7994 skĭna (fränk., langob.) 'schmales Stück Knochen; Schiene'.
S.v. Lith. nùgara 'grzbiet, plecy'. No etymology.

S.v. Paš. šā 'back' "No connection seems possible with Mj škyī, Yd. šīlë 'neck' (or Av ušaδā- a hapax, prob. also 'neck', Sogd B šδʾkw 'neck', GMS §96), whose similarity with Turki šillä (Menges, Glossar zu den Volltexten aus Ost-Turkistan, Wiesbaden, 1955) is only coincidental. There is conceivably a connection with šamz'əy f. šamjº, šənjº PQ 'spine', Wan mula-š'amzi 'back' < *ša-məzay 'back-cord, -wire'."
S.v. Ved. áka- 'Leid, Schmerz', adv. ákam 'übel, auf schlechte Weise' (IIr. cf. Av. aka- 'schlecht, übel, böse', axti- 'Leiden'). No convincing comparisons outside of Indo-Iranic.
Cf. s.v. Lith. mãkas '(Geld)beutel'. Whether OHG mago 'Magen' is to be connected with Lith. mãkas is questionable.
S.v. 3842 Lat. grandis 'groß'.
S.v. Lat. grandis 'grand'. The etymology of this word is unknown.
S.v. AGk. ἅδην, evidently from the root of ἄω, ἄμεναι; cf. s.v. ἆσαι (aorist infinitive), to go back to a root *seə₂-/*sə₂-.
S.v. Paš. loy 'big, large, great' "A derivation < Av hu-δāta- 'well-created, -built' is semantically unsatisfactory. [< *dahāka- acc. to Skjærvø 1989, 398.] Cf. Lodi s.v. ¹lo."

S.v. AGk. τρανής 'clair, distinct', the sense of the related vocabulary invites a comparison with the adjective τορός 'pénétrant; clair', then the family designating 'percer' cf. τείρω, τέρετρον, τετραίνω, etc.
S.v. Lat. pullus, -ī 'petit d'un animal' especially 'poulet'. Lat. pullus may be explained by *put-slo-.
S.v. 5679 Lat. mordere 'beißen'.
S.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' (IEW 941-2). Cf. n1: Probably an enlarged form of 2. *(s)ker- /cognate/5452/.
S.v. Oss. xæcyn : xæst | xwæcun : xwæst.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √drav- 'niederschneiden'. Uncertain. {ref Bailey 1979}:168b considers an IE extended form *dr-euH- connected with √dar-.
S.v. Lith. kartùs 'gorzki'
Cf. s.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' [IEW 941-942].
S.v. Latv. rūgts, a derivative of the verb rūgt (cf. Lith. rū́gti 'skābt, rūgt', from PIE *reug-.
Cf. s.v. *(h₁)reu̯g- 'rülpsen, erbrechen' (IEW 871).
Cf. s.v. 9793 Skt. madhurá- 'sweet' ĀśvGr̥. (Pā. madhura- 'sweet', Pk. mahura-).
S.v. Kho. ṣā 'black' (cf. Wkh. ṣ̌īu, Sgl. ṣ̌ūi).
S.v. AGk. κύανος 'smalt, émail de couleur bleue foncée, azurite'. A loanword, comparable to Hitt. kuwanna- 'azurite'; a Mediterranean culture word according to Kammenhuber, KZ 77 1961, 53.

Cf. s.v. Ved. támisrā- 'finstere Nacht' (IIr. cf. YAv. tąθra-, Khot. ttāra- 'dunkel', MP tār, NP tārīk 'dunkel', Pašto tōr 'schwarz', Oss. tar 'finster, Finsternis' usw.), from PIE *témH-s-reh₂- (Lat. tenebrae 'Finsternis') to PIE *temH- 'finster sein'.

S.v. Khot. haryāsa- 'black', from base har- 'of dark colours', Av. harəta-, harəδa-, harəda- 'red', Oss. xärä- 'dark', from {ref IEW} 910-1 *ser-, *sor- 'red' (cf. Lith. sar̃tas 'red (of a horse)', Latv. sârts 'red in face', sarks 'reddish'.

Cf. s.v. OLith. sar̃tas 'rotbraun (Pferd)' (cf. Latv. sā̀rts 'rot, frisch aussehend', sar̂kans 'rot'), the (East-)Baltic colour adjective can be connected to a PIE root *ser- 'rot' (IEW 910f.), but closer correspondences in related languages are lacking.
S.v. 3. *ser-, *sor- 'rot, rötlich'.
Cf. s.v. Lith. sárkanas 'pink, ruddy, with healthy appearance', to a root *ser-.

S.v. NHG Blut (MHG bluot, OHG bluot, OS blōd), from Germanic *blōda- 'Blut' also in Goth. bloϸ, ON blóð, OE blōd, OFr. blōd. An exclusively Germanic word, which replaced the inherited IE words for 'blood', probably an epithet (or euphemism?), probably to PIE *bʰel- 'schwellen' ~ 'platzen' ~ 'fließen' (cf. Lat. fluere 'fließen', etc.) but the details remain unclear.

"Fettgedrucktes = unmarkierte Bezeichnungen nach ELSIE 1983/84, S. 112. – Aus den älteren Sprachstadien entsprechen mkymr. gwaet, abret. gouet (wohl für *gwoet; FLEURIOT, DGVB, S. 179 s.v.); vgl. ELSIE 1979, S. 83; STOKES, ZCP 1 (1897), S. 23; LOTH, RC 36 (1915), S. 158; VG I, S. 385; LP, S. 10; Henry LEWIS, BBCS 15 (1954), S. 123 f.; WG 114; GPC s.v. gwaed. – Die angeführten Belege sind auf proto-brit. *waito- <
älter (proto-kelt.?) *woito- zurückzuführen (ebd.). – Die weitere Etymologie ist unbekannt."
Assumes Proto-Celtic *u̯aitV- 'blood' > PBr. *u̯ɛ̄tV- > LPBr. *Woed- > SWBr. *gwoed > *goed > OCo. guit gl. sanguis, MCo. goys > B goad, gwad 'blood'; WBr. *gwoed > MW gwaed 'blood'.
S.v. Oss. tūg | tog 'кровь' from Indo-Iranic *tauka- cf. Ved. toka- 'потомство' < 'семя'.
Cf. s.v. 13952 Skt. haḍḍa n. 'bone' lex. [Iranic loan as Par(ači). haḍḍ IIFL i 258]

Cf. s.v. NHG schnaufen, a (first attested 16th c. MHG snūfen) High German variant to NHG schnauben (cf. MHG snūben 'schnarchen, schnauben'. The words belong to a large group of formations designating to noises made with the nose, mucus, sneezing, etc. They are frequently phonetically similar, but they are unable to be brought together as a single initial form.
S.v. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen', OCS dъmǫ 'blase').
S.v. 4469a Lat. inspirāre 'einatmen' > OFrz. espirer.
S.v. 620 Lat. ardere 'brennen'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √karṣ- 'ziehen, schleppen, pflügen', probably to PIE *kʷels-, cf. Hitt. gul-ša-an-zi 'sie ritzen ein', Gk. τέλσον 'letzte Furche des Ackers'.
S.v. ScG. giùlain 'a carrying' : *gesu-lo-, root *ges- 'carry' (Lat. gero, gestum).

Cf. s.v. Lat. gerō, -is, gessī, gestum, gerere 'porter'. A verb like gerō has no chance of being a loanword, but there are no good comparisons among the Indo-European languages for a root *ges-. It is exceptional that a verbal root of this archaic type has no correspondences outside of Latin.

"The connection of gerĕre, gessī, gestum with the root *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' goes back to Osthoff (BB. 19, 321). EM [{ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}] do not even mention it, and WH [{ref Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954}] have reservations regarding its correctness. The pair *h₂eg̑-, *h₂eg̑-es- is probably paralleled by *h₂euh₁-, *h₂uh₁-es- in Gr. αὐλή vs. Hitt. ḫuiš-zi 'lives' (see Barton 1988, esp. 54-55). gerere is a possible case of *HC-."
S.v. Lat. gerō, -ere 'to bear, carry', following the rehabilitation of the etymology to *h₂g̑-es- after the discussion of {ref Schrijver 1991}:18-19.

{ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:195 suggested a connection to a basic root *ges- and to be compared with Latin gerere 'to carry, bear about' (past participle gestum), however the root etymology of Latin gerō, -ere is disputed. {ref Schrijver 1991}:18-19 tentatively rehabilitates an old proposal by Osthoff to *h₂eg̑- via a perform *h₂g̑-és-, and this followed by {ref de Vaan 2008}:259, but cf. the skepticism of {ref Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954} I:595-596, {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}:273-274. If the connection of Scottish Gaelic giùlain to a neo-root *ges- (< *h₂g̑-és-?) is to be maintained, this would be a unique Italo-Celtic lexical(-morphological) isogloss. Given the multiple degrees of speculation required to posit an ultimate root etymology to PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' for this exclusively Scottish Gaelic cognate set, the root reference form has been given as the Gaelic form itself.

S.v. Goth. *dragan (only 3pl. pres. -and 'ἐπισωρεύειν', 'accumulate, take on'. Etymology uncertain; PIE *dh(e)rāgh- 'pull' Walde-Pokorny 1927-1932 I:862, possibly Lat. trahō 'pull' according to Walde 1906 IF 19:106 by dissimilation from *dhraghō.
S.v. Wa. yund- : yut- 'нести, отность; вести, уводить; брати в жены (мужья)' from Old Iranian *yat-.
Cf. s.v. *i̯et- 'sich (fest) hinstellen' (IEW 506-7).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √yat- 'sich aufstellen, in fester Weise eine Stellung einnehmen' (IIr. OAv. yōiθəmā 'wir haben den Platz eingenommen', YAv. yataiia-, yātaiia- 'hinstellen', Christ.Sogd. pt-yt- 'ankommen', Yaghnobi yat- 'Platz finden', Šughni yad- 'kommen', etc.' Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain; perhaps Lat. nītor 'stütze mich, stemme mich' < ni-i̯et-e-.

S.v. Ved. úras- 'Brust' (IIr. cf. YAv. varah- n. 'Brust', paiti.varah- 'Nacken', pərəθu.varah- 'mit breiter Brust', MP var, NP bar). The IIr. word for 'breast' certainly belongs with urú- 'wide' and váras- 'width, extent'. The unusual weak stem of the s-stem úras- etc. probably originated in an ablauting paradigm. Cf. s.v. Ved. urú- 'weit, umfängreich, breit, gegräumig' (IIr. cf. YAv. vouru- in compounds, e.g. vouru.dōiθra- 'dessen Augen weithin gehen', Oss. urux, etc.), from PIE *u̯r̥H-ú- (~ *u̯erH- in váras-, *u̯erH-ú- in Gk. εὐρύς 'weit, breit', etc.).
Kho. pāz 'breast' < Wkh. pūz, Sar. puz, etc.

S.v. *speno-, *stē̆no-, *p(ǝ)stē̆no- 'Zitze, Brustwarze, Brust', under which is connected Gk. στηνίον· στῆθος Hes. "daß στῆθος verwandt sei, ist schwer glaublich; hat neben θήνιον, τιθήνη einst ein *θη-θος, *τῆ-θος bestanden, das neben στηνίον eine Parallelbildung στῆθος ins Leben treten ließ??"

S.v. Khot. ṣaṃbajsa- 'claw' "The second component may be traced to vak- 'be crooked' (with the badzä of Oss. D. kärd-badzä), to Zor.P. w'hr *vahr *vaxr 'crooked', Pāzand *avāhar for *huvahr, *huvaxr, M.Pers.T. xwhr 'crooked', Pahlavī Psalter hwhly. IE Pok. 34 u̯enk-, u̯ek-, 1148 u̯eng-, and 1120 u̯āg- 'bend', O.Ind. vancati, vakrá, vánkri- 'rib'; with u̯ek, Av. nivaštakō.srva- 'with bent horns'."
S.v Lat. nūbēs 'nue, nuage', cf. W nudd 'nuage', Baluči nōd 'nuée' and perhaps the hapax in Av. snaoδō which may be interpreted as 'nuée'.
S.v. W cwmwl 'cloud', loanword(?) from Latin cumulus, cf. Medieval Breton commoull.
S.v. Manx bodjal 'cloud' = ScG. baideal
Cf. s.v. ScG. baideal 'tower, battlement, ensign', baidealach 'bannered; from Middle English battle, battlement.
Cf. s.v. Oss. synæg | sinæk, sinæg 'грудь, бок', from Iranian *sainaka-, cf. Pers., Taj. sīna, Pehl. sēnak, Bel. sīnag, Kurd. sīnk, sīng, Av. saēni- 'вышуклый'
S.v. 4847 *cīssa- 'sharp pain' > P. cīs f. 'sudden pain'; Ku. cīs 'keen pain, scorching'; N. ciso 'cold'; H. cīs f. 'sudden pain'; G. cīs f. 'scream'.
Cf. s.v. 12487 Skt. śītalá 'cold' MBh. [śītá- 1].
S.v. Lat. frīgus, -oris 'froid, froidure', seems to have an exact correspondence in Greek ῥῖγος < *srīgos.
S.v. 3512 Lat. frīgidus 'kalt', 2. frigidus.
Cf. s.v. Ved. ū́dhan- 'Kälte', IIr. cf. OAv. aodərəš-čā '(und) vor Kälte', YAv. aodra 'durch Kälte'. "Im weiteren ist ū́dhan- / av. aodº wohl nicht von jav. aota- 'kalt' […] zu trennen."
Cf. s.v. Oss. īx | ex 'лед', from Proto-Iranian *aixa- (cf. Pers. yax, Kurd. yex, Yag. īx, Sogd. *yīx, Chores. ēx, Av. aexa-).
S.v. Proto-Iranic *aixa- : *īxa- 'лёд, холод, мороз'.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *aixa- : *īxa- 'лёд, холод, мороз'.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *aixa- : *īxa- 'лёд, холод, мороз'.
S.v. OIr. do-icc 'il arrive, il vient'; from preverb *to- + vb. icc-, cf. {ref Pedersen 1913}:557.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *-an-n-k-e/o- 'erreichen' (PIE *h₂nek̑-, LIV 282-284),
Cf. Pers. šudan : šaw-, Chorezm. ciya-, Khot. tsu-, tsuta-, Av. šav-, šyav-, Ved. cyav-, Gk. σεύω.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯au- 'move, go'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √cyav- 'in Bewegung geraten, sich bewegen, unternehmen', from PIE *ki̯eu̯-.
Cf. s.v. *kʷi̯eu̯- 'sich in Bewegung setzen' (IEW 539).
S.v. tl- 'to go', rā-tl- 'to come'; pres. j- < *t-j- < Ir. *tač-.
Cf. s.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-1060).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √tak- 'stürzen, dahinschießen, eilen (von Tieren, Strömen), from PIE *tekʷ- 'eilen, stürzen, laufen, fließen' (cf. OIr. tech- 'fließen', W go-deb 'Zuflucht', Lith. tekė́ti 'laufen, fließen', OCS tešti 'laufen, eilen', tokъ 'Lauf, Strom', TochB cake 'Fluß' Hitt. watku- 'springen, entspringen').

Cf. s.v. Ved. √tak- 'stürzen, dahinschießen, eilen (von Tieren, Strömen), from PIE *tekʷ- 'eilen, stürzen, laufen, fließen' (cf. OIr. tech- 'fließen', W go-deb 'Zuflucht', Lith. tekė́ti 'laufen, fließen', OCS tešti 'laufen, eilen', tokъ 'Lauf, Strom', TochB cake 'Fluß' Hitt. watku- 'springen, entspringen').
Cf. S yoδ- : yot 'to come' (cf. Sogd. yt-, Yaghn. yat-, Av. yat-).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √yat- 'sich aufstellen, in fester Weise eine Stellung einnehmen' (IIr. OAv. yōiθəmā 'wir haben den Platz eingenommen', YAv. yataiia-, yātaiia- 'hinstellen', Christ.Sogd. pt-yt- 'ankommen', Yaghnobi yat- 'Platz finden', Šughni yad- 'kommen', etc.' Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain; perhaps Lat. nītor 'stütze mich, stemme mich' < ni-i̯et-e-.
Cf. s.v. *i̯et- 'sich (fest) hinstellen' (IEW 506-7).
S.v. 5993 Lat. numerāre 'zählen'.
Cf. Kho. išmärēik 'to count', loan from Iranic.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √smar- 'gedenken, sich erinnern, einer Sache bewußt werden, eingedenk sein, ins Herz schließen', probably from PIE *(s)mer- 'an etwas (sorgenvoll?) denken', cf. Gk. μέριμνα 'Sorge, Besorgnis', OE murnan 'sich um etwas sorgen', etc.
Cf. s.v. 1. *(s)mer- 'denken an, sich erinnern' (IEW 969).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *briti 'shave' (ESSJa III 31-32), from PIE *bʰr(e)iH- (cf. Skt. brīṇā́ti 'injure', OIr. bronnaid 'injure, damage'; OIc. brinna 'cause a cutting, sharp sorrow' NHG brennen 'id.').
Cf. s.v. Bret. niver 'nombre' from Old Breton nimer, corresponding to Cornish nyver, Welsh nifer, and Irish uimhir, all borrowed from Latin numerus.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *(H)raudH- 'to moan, (be)wail' > Av. raoδ- 'to moan, (be)wail', from PIE *(H)reudH- 'to weep, cry' (reconstructing and initial laryngeal assuming that IE roots cannot begin with *r-), cf. Lat. rudō 'to cry, roar', OCz. ruditi 'to sadden', Lith. raudà, Latv. raûda 'lament', ON rauta 'to roar', OE rēotan 'to complain, to weep'.
S.v. huilen ww. (NN) ‘schreien, wenen’. Originally an mimicking/onomatopoeic word.
Cf. s.v. cri² 'cry, clamour', a loanword from Middle English crye; and s.v. criaf : crio 'to cry, to shout; to cry, to weep'.

S.v. NHG weinen (MHG weinen, OHG weinōn, MLG we(i)nen, MDu. wenen), from Germanic *wainō- (weak verb), also in ON veina, OE wānian, OFr. wainia, weinia, wēnia; Goth. wainahs 'elend', presumably derived from the same root as NHG weh (MHG wē, OHG wah, OS wē) from Gmc. *wai, also in Goth. wai, ON vei, OE wā corresponding outside of Germanic to Lat. vae, MIr. fae, W. gwae, Lith. vaī, Av. vaiiōi, etc.).
S.v. *bʰrem- 'brummen, brüllen' (IEW 142-3).
S.v. Oss. kæwyn : kₒyd | kæwun : kud 'плакать', from an Iranian root *kū- *kav-, IE *kū-, *kau- 'кричать, вопить', cf. Skt. kāuti, kavate, OCS kyti, Gk. κωκύω.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *gard- (1) 'to call', from PIE gʷerdʰ- 'to raise the voice, call, sing' (cf. Arm. kardam 'to raise the voice', OPr. gerdaut 'to say', Lith. girdė́ti, Latv. dzìrdêt 'to hear', Gall-Lat. bardus, OIr. bard, W. bardd 'poet, singer').
S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'hören, tönen' [IEW 478]. Cf. s.v. *gʷerH- 'Zustimmung bekunden' (IEW 478).

Cf. s.v. OLith. girdė́ti 'hören' (BSl. Latv. dzìrdêt), from a univerbation of a PIE collocation or light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- dʰeh₁- 'Kunde geben', cf. Arm. kardam 'rufe', OIr. bard 'Barde', MW bardd 'id.', cf. *gʷer(H)- 'to consent' (LIV² 210f.) and *dʰeh₁- ''to put, to place, to make' (LIV² 136ff.). See also PIE *gʷerdʰ- 'to hear, to sound' (LIV² 187).

S.v. OLith. girdė́ti 'hören' (BSl. Latv. dzìrdêt), from a univerbation of a PIE collocation or light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- dʰeh₁- 'Kunde geben', cf. Arm. kardam 'rufe', OIr. bard 'Barde', MW bardd 'id.', cf. *gʷer(H)- 'to consent' (LIV² 210f.) and *dʰeh₁- ''to put, to place, to make' (LIV² 136ff.). See also PIE *gʷerdʰ- 'to hear, to sound' (LIV² 187).

Cf. s.v. Skt. káuti 'schreit / cries'. An onomatopoeic family, cf. κωκύω 'schreie', Lat. cavannus 'Nachteule', W cuan 'id.', MHG hiulen 'heulen', Lith. kaũkti 'heulen', Ru. kúkatь, TochB śauk- 'rufen'.
Cf. s.v. *kā̆u-, *kē̆u-, *kū- 'heulen' "Schallwurzel, teils mit anlaut k-, teils mit *k̑-."
Cf. s.v. 1301 Skt. āraṭa- n. 'crying out' and s.v. 1302 Skt. āraṭati 'shrieks' Kathās. [√raṭ].
S.v. Skt. √nav- 'brüllen, schreien', from PIE *neu̯(H?), perhaps an onomatopoeic root, cf. OIr. núall 'Schrei, Lärm', TochAB nu- 'brüllen, etc.'.
S.v. *neu̯H- 'schreien, brüllen' (IEW 767), cf. n1: Or *neu̯- if Ved. aor. anaviṣṭa isn't old.
S.v. Bret. gouel 'pleur(s)', apparently a loanword from English wail 'gémissement, plainte', with derivative goueliñ (ouilein, 1723) pleurer.

"MoB gouelañ, V gouilein 'to weep', MW wyl-aw 'id' The MCo. equivalent is ole, wole 'id'. B g- is secondary ({ref Pedersen 1909}: 321). The etymology is unknown: LPBr. *uil- may reflect PCl. *(φ)eil-, *(φ)idl-, *(φ)ugl-, or *(φ)udl-."
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' < PIE *gʷʰen- (cf. Skt. han- 'to slay, kill', Hitt. ku-(e-)en-zi 'kills', Gk. θείνω 'I kill', φόνος 'murder', OIr. gonim 'I hurt, kill', etc.).
S.v. Ved. √han- 'schlagen, erschlagen, töten', from PIE *gʷʰen- (cf. Hitt. ku-(e)-en-zi, Gk. θεἰνω, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).
Cf. s.v. 4843 Skt. cī́ra- n. 'strip (of bark or cloth)' TĀr. & verbal derivative s.v. 4844 *cīrayati 'splits'.

S.v. Skt. cī́ra- 'Streifen, Zeug, Fetzen, Lumpen'. Further etymology uncertain. {ref Bailey 1979}:103b compares Khot. cile 'dress' and suggests a pre-form *kī-lo- (~ Lat. cilium 'eyelid'?) but this proposal is unclear.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √bhrī- 'verletzen, versehren', to PIE *bʰriH, pres. *bʰri-n-(e)H- ~ *bʰrei̯H- 'abschneiden', cf. OCS briti 'scheren', OIr. bronnaid 'injures, damages', and Germanic *brinna- = NHG brennen (if from *bʰri-n-H- 'schneidenden, brennenden Schmerz verursachen').
S.v. Kâmviri gâǰʹâr  NF.  Daytime; day.  [gârešᴺvorᴺ]  (cf. Kâta-vari garǰʹor.), cf. Kâmviri gârʹeš  NF.  Midday.  [gârešᴺ]  [OIA. ghar-asya- ‘sun's heat’  T. 4440]
Cf. s.v. 4440 Skt. *gharasya- 'sun's heat' [√ghr̥-] > Ash. gerés 'midday', Kt. gəríš, Wg. garaš, ˚riš.
Cf. s.v. Ved. gharmá- 'Glut, Hitze, Wärme' < PIE *gʷor-mó- (cf. Lat. formus 'warm' (~ *gʷʰer-mó- > Gk. θερμός) to PIE *gʷʰer- 'brennen, heiß sein'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *bānu-, *bānau- 'свет, луч; дневной свет, рассвет(?)', derived to Proto-Iranic *bā-.
S.v. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (LIV 68f., IEW 104f.).

S.v. Shughni mēθ (Sarikoli maθ) 'day', from Proto-Iranic *maiθā- (cf. Sogd. myδ, Yaghn. met/θ, Yd.-Mj. mīx̌). Not with Junker (Drei Erzähl. auf Yaɣn. 13) with Lithuanian mẽtas 'time, year' etc., cf. Av. maēθa- 'unstable, vacillating' > 'interchanging (with the night??)'.

S.v. Khot. haḍā 'day', from *harta- or *hr̥ta-, *haḍāka- masc. to base har- 'go up; pass' (Sogd.Man. xrṭyẖ 'passed'). Further root etymology uncertain; either to PIE er- 'to go' or ar- 'to rise' (cf. s.v. hada- 'attained').

Cf. s.v. Gmc. sterb-a- 'sterben'; only uncertain comparisons (MIr. ussarb 'Tod', W serfyll 'schwach, unbeständig' < *uks-sterbhā-?; Ru. stérbnutь 'hart werden, erstarren, absterben'; Gk. στέρφος 'Haut, Fell' etc.; alternatively without s-mobile and with final p: Lat. torpeō 'steif sein, betäubt sein', Lith. tirpstù, tir̃pti 'erstarren, gefühlos werden, einschlafen', Ru. terpnutь 'erstarren (vor Furcht)'.
Cf. s.v. *kelh₂- 'schlagen' (IEW 545-6).

Cf. s.v. W tyrchaf, tyrchiaf: tyrchu, tyrchio 'to burrow, dig (up); root up (of pigs, &c.), nuzzle; rummage, delve; also fig.', a denominal formation to W twrch 'hog, (wild) boar; mole', from IE ?*tu̯ork̑os, cf. Av. θβərəsa-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *tworko- 'boar' (OIr. torc, MW twrch 'young pig, boar'), from PIE *tu̯ork̑o- 'cutter, boar' (cf. Av. θβərəsa- 'piglet', perh. Gk. σάρξ 'flesh').
Cf. s.v. PIG ?*tu̯ork̑ós 'boar' (OIr. torc 'boar', Av. θβərəsa- 'boar', a derivative to PIE *tu̯erk̑- 'cut' (cf. Gk. σάρξ 'flesh' < *tu̯r̥k̑s 'that which is cut off').
Cf. s.v. *tu̯erk̑- 'schnitzen, zurechtschneiden' (IEW 1102).

S.v. AGk. σκάπτω 'creuser'. Two possibilities: σκαπ- with final aspiration on analogy to θάπτω 'bury', vs. τάφος 'tomb', ταφῆναι 'to bury' or from σκαφ- with σκαπ- either phonetically or analogically. In the first case it may resemble Lat. scapulae 'épaules', Umb. scapla (acc.sg.); one finds a large group of for σκαφ- with a general meaning 'râcler, gratter': Lat. scabō, in Germanic OHG scaban, etc., in Baltic Lith. skabiù 'tailler, couper'.

S.v. Goth. *swiltan, ga-swiltan ᾽ἀποθνήσκειν', 'die'. Etymology uncertain, possibly an extended form of PIE *swel- 'burn, smoulder' + d, also in Arm. k'ałc 'hunger', k'ałc-nu-m 'be hungry' < swl̥d-sk̑o-, unextended form Skt. svarati 'shine'.
S.v. *krosu- (?gall.) 'hŏhl' > OFr. crues, NFr. creux.

S.v. AGk. ὀρύσσω 'creuser, faire, un canal, déterrer, enterrer, arracher', A formation in *-ye/o- resembling the root found in the Latin nasal present formation runcō 'sarcler', Skt. luñcati 'arracher', perhaps Latv. rūkēt 'fouiller, remuer la terre'; further isolated nouns, cf. in Celtic rucht < *ruqtu-, Alban. rrāh 'excavation, essart' < *rouq-so-.
S.v. Proto-Insular-Celtic *bā- 'sterben', from PIE *gʷeh₂- (LIV² 205, IEW 463f.).

Cf. s.v. OIr. 2 ba- 'mourir', corresponding to W bad 'fléau, peste', Ir. bath 'mort', connected by {ref Pedersen 1913}:458, Stokes KZ 37 p.254 to the root *gʷā- 'aller' (Gk. ἔβην, Skt. agāt 'il est allé' supposing the semantic evolution 'passer' > 'trépasser'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bal-ni- 'fortwerfen' → 'sterben', from PIE *gʷelh₁- (LIV² 208).
S.v. OIr. at-baill 'il meurt', composed of a root bal- or ball- preceded by the preverb ess- with an infixed 3rd sg.n. pronoun.

S.v. W torraf: torri 'to break, shatter, smash, fracture, crack, tear, rupture, damage, ruin', cf. Medieval Cornish terry, tyrry, torraf, Middle Breton terriff, torret (rhang. grff.), Late Breton terriñ

S.v. Proto-Germanic *swarta- 'schwarz', to be connected with Latin sordeō 'bin schmutzig', sordēs 'Schmutz', sordidus 'schmutzig', based on an original adjective *sordus 'schmutzig', this is either identical via a preform *su̯ordo-, or corresponds to a zero-grade *su̯r̥do-.
S.v. 4188 Lat. horridus 'struppig' > Frz. ord.
Cf. s.v. Da. snavse, from which Da. snavset; originally a loanword from dialectal Swedish snafsa 'snappe, snavse til'.

S.v. Goth. H92. hrains 'καθαρός', 'clean', un-hrains 'ἀκάθαρτος', 'unclean'; PIE *krey- + -ni- adj. suffix; cf. verbal forms in Gk. κρίνω 'cut, decide', Lat. cernō 'separate, decide'; Gk. κρί-σις 'decision', Lat. cer-tus 'decided, certain'. [Lehmann accepts an inner-PIE root derivation to PIE *(s)ker- 'cut' following {ref IEW} 619].
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hraini- 'rein', a common Germanic adjective; an old verbal adjective to the nasal present in Greek κρίνω, Latin cernō to the IE root *krei-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic fūla- 'filthy, foul', from PIE *puH-lo-, cf. also Proto-Germanic *faujan- 'to let rot' < *pouH-éie-.
Cf. s.v. 2. *peu̯H- 'faulen, stinken' (IEW 848-849).
S.v. Du. vies. First attested in Early Modern Dutch vijs (1539). Etymology uncertain.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ(jъ), from PIE *kirno- or *kirsno- (cf. Ved. kr̥ṣṇá-).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hurhwa- 'dirt, mucus', possibly related to MIr. corcach < *kork-āko-??, if so then perhaps *kork-uo-.
S.v. c’umur (Digor) 'грязный', further discussion under c’ammar 'мерзкий'.
S.v. OIr. brod 'poussière, paille, éclat, tache'; derived adjective brodach 'sale'; same word as broth 'épi, poil, brin de paille'.

Cf. s.v. Lith. tyras, -a "nie porosły drzewami, pusty, opustoszały, niezamieszkały, bezludny"; equivalent to Latv. tīrs "czysty, niezmieszany, niesfałszowany"; Proto-Baltic *tī-ra- < *tiH-ró-. Further etymology uncertain.
S.v. Latv. tīrs, equivalent to Lith. týras, tyrùs 'skaidrs, dzidrs, tīrs; svaigs; klajš, tukšs'.
S.v. Lith. týras 'rein, sauber, klar, lauter, kahl, öde, waldlos, wüst', cf. Latv. tĩrs 'rein, unvermengt, unverfälscht'.
S.v. Gmc. *dō- 'tun' belonging with certainty to the root *dʰē- (*dʰeə₁-) 'setzen, stellen, legen'.
S.v. Lat. faciō, to the root *dhē-; the perfect fēcī is comparable to the Greek aorist ἔθηκα like iēcī to Gk. ἧκα.
S.v. 3128 Lat. facere 'tun, machen'.
S.v. OW guragun 'to make', from PIE *u̯erg̑-, *u̯reg̑- 'wirken, tun'.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *u̯reg-e/o- 'tun, machen', from PIE 2. *u̯erg̑- (LIV2 686f.).
S.v. AGk. κάμνω 'se fatiguer, être fatigué, se donner du mal, souffrir, être malheureux'. A present thematic stem remodelled from an athematic stem *km-neh₂-/*km-n-h₂-.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *gn-ii̯e/o- '(er)zeugen, tun, machen', from PIE *g̑enh₁- ({ref LIV²} 163-165).
S.v. Lith. darýti 'robić, czynić, sprawać' (Latv. darît), to be derived from PIE *dʰer-, cf. Av. dərətā, Ved. dādā́ra, etc.
S.v. Lith. daryti 'do', from PIE *dʰor-eie- (cf. Skt. dhārayati 'hold').
S.v. Alb. qen 'dog' "A relatively late loanword from Lat canem id. […] or, rather, its Balkan continuations (Rum caine), reflecting no traces of rhotacism in Tosk."
S.v. Alb. qen 'dog' "A relatively late loanword from Lat canem id. […] or, rather, its Balkan continuations (Rum caine), reflecting no traces of rhotacism in Tosk."

S.v. Alb. qen, -i; qene 'dog' "qen is regarded as a loan from Lat canis 'dog'; so {ref Meyer 1891}:222, Tagliavani (1937:94), Haarmann (1972:47). The failure of Lat n to rhotacize implies lateness of borrowing or a Balkan origin, note Rum caină 'dog'."

S.v. Alb. qen, -i; qene 'dog' "qen is regarded as a loan from Lat canis 'dog'; so {ref Meyer 1891}:222, Tagliavani (1937:94), Haarmann (1972:47). The failure of Lat n to rhotacize implies lateness of borrowing or a Balkan origin, note Rum caină 'dog'."
S.v. Gmc. *drenk-a- 'trinken', no certain etymology outside of Germanic.
S.v. Lith. gérti 'drink' (Latv. dzer̃t 'drink'), from PIE *gʷerh₃- (cf. Skt. giráti, Gk. βιβρώσκω 'eat, digest'; Lat. vorāre 'devour, eat greedily').
Cf. s.v. 3865 Ved. khādati ʻ chews, bites ʼ RV. & 3867 khādana n. 'eating'.
S.v. Lat. siccus 'sec'.
S.v. 7897 Lat. siccus 'trocken'.

S.v. Gmc. *ϸurzu- 'dürr', an old verbal adjective to the strong verb only attested through the past passive participle *ϸursa-, an inherited u-stem identical with Skt. tr̥ṣú- 'gierig', Av. taršu- 'trocken, fest', OLat. torrus 'verdorrt'; cf. OIr. tur, taur 'trocken, vertrocknet'.
S.v. OIr. tírim 'sec', the root is *ter-s- 'sécher' and tírim is from tír 'terre, sol'
Cf. s.v. *ters- 'vertrocknen; durstig werden' (IEW 1078-9).
S.v. *ters- 'vertrocknen, durstig werden' (LIV 637f., IEW 1078f.).
Cf. s.v. 3074 Lat. exsūctus 'trocken'
S.v. Lat. sūgō 'sucer' (cf. OIr. súgim, OE súcan, OHG sūgan, etc.).
Cf. s.v. 6724 Ved. dhánu- (2) (dhanū́- AV.) f. 'dry land', dhánvan- (2) m. 'desert' RV.
Cf. s.v. Ved. dhánvan- 'Wüste, Steppe, trockenes Land, Strand'; no certain etymology.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *staubjan- 'to make steam(?)', cs. to *steuban- ~ *stūban-. G Staub 'dust' is derived from *stauba-.
S.v. Luw. pa/ušūriya- 'dust' (??) "I assume single word with Laroche, DLL 81. Object is sprinkled and may belong to hand or foot (also then to *pes- 'rub'?)."
S.v. Gmc. *reuk-a- 'rauchen'. There is only a possibility for comparison in Baltic via Lith. ráugti 'säuern', intr. 'aufstoßen', Latv. rûgt 'säuern, aufgehen, rauchen'.
Cf. s.v. Oss. rug | rugæ 'пыль, прах'.
S.v. 6835 *dhūḍi m., Skt. dhūli- f. 'dust, powder'.
S.v. OIr. clúas 'fait d'entendre'; 'l'ouïe, oreille'.
S.v. OIr. tír 'terre, sol'
S.v. Lat. terra 'terre' < *ters-ā (cf. v. torreō).
Cf. s.v. *telh₂- 'aufheben, auf sich nehmen' (IEW 1060-1).
Cf. s.v. 13493 súmahānt- (nom. súmahān, voc. sumahaḥ) 'very great' RV.

Cf. s.v. Ved. mahā́nt- 'groß, ausgedehnt, mächtig, bedeutend'. The IIr. forms are based upon PIE *meg̑- 'big' with an ablauting suffix *-(é)h₂-. Cf. entry in Mayrhofer for detailed discussion of the stem formations to this root in Indo-Iranian.
S.v. *meg̑- 'groß' (IEW 708f., EIEC 344). Cf. entry for extensive discussion of stem derivations found in individual IE branches.

S.v. Gaul. talu-, talamon- 'front, surface', cf. OIr. tul, taul < *talu meaning 'bosse, protubérence, umbo de bouclier, front'.  From an IE root *telh₂- (cf. Skt. talam 'surface, paume', talimam 'sol', Gk. τηλία 'table à jeux', OIr. talam 'terre' < *talamon-, Lat. tellūs 'terre', Lith. pã-talas 'lit', OPr. talus 'sol', etc.).

S.v. Khot. śśandā 'earth, ground, piece of ground, place', from *śuantakā-, fem. adj. to *śuanta- 'beneficient, making to increase and prosper', Av. spənta-, Zor.P. spand, to base *sau- 'increase, have profit', to PIE *k̑eu̯- 'swell', Ved. śváyati, śuná-, śūná-, śávas-, Greek κόοι 'holes', κοῖλος 'hollow', Lat. cauus 'hollow', Lith. šaunùs 'active', etc.

Cf. s.v. Ved. śvāntá- in the further discussion: OAv. YAv. spəṇta- 'heilvoll, heilkräftig' belongs with OAv. spǝ̄ṇ, Ved. śuná- probably ultimately to Ved. √śavⁱ-; Ved. √śavⁱ- 'anschwellen, stark werden, zunehmen, gedeihen' continues PIE *k̑eu̯h₁- 'anschwellen' (~ *k̑u̯eh₁-) (cf. Gk. κυέω 'bin schwanger', κῦμα 'Woge, Welle', Lat. cauus 'hohl', W cyw 'Tierjunges', OE hūn 'Junges', etc.).
S.v. ScG. ùir 'mould, dust, earth'. Ir., MIr. úir, E.Ir. úr, g. úire : *ûrâ, Norse aurr 'loam, wet clay, mud', Ag.S. eár 'humus'. Stokes hesitates between *ûrâ and *ugrâ, Gk. ὑγρός 'wet'

Cf. s.v. 13386 Skt. síkatā f. 'grain of sand', (usu. pl.) 'sand, gravel'. Nuristani and Dardic forms attest IA ś- corresponding to Ir. θ- and s- (OPers. θikā-, Bal. six, Pasht. šəga, etc.), suggesting that the s- forms of Skt. and Dardic may be loans or influenced by Iranic.

Cf. s.v. Ved. síkata- 'Sand, Kies, Grieß' not to be separated from Iranian cognates: OPers. θikā- 'Kies, Schotter', Khot. siyata, Sogd. šykth, Pashto šəga, səga 'sand', Oss. syǵyt/sigit, sik’it 'Erde', etc.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *ag-e/o- 'treiben, führen', from PIE *h₂eg̑- (LIV 255f.); with preverb tu- > Welsh dyfot '(an)kommen, sich ereignen', Middle Breton donet 'kommen' (1.sg. deuaff, 3.sg. deu); Middle Cornish devones, dones, dos 'kommen'
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *ag-o- 'drive', from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive' (cf. Skt. ájati, Lat. agō, Gk. ἄγω, Arm. acem).
Cf. s.v. 1. *h₂eg̑- 'treiben' (IEW 4-5).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *ag-e/o- 'treiben, führen', from PIE *h₂eg̑- (LIV 255f.)

S.v. OIr. úr (1) 'sol, terre'; without certain etymology. One has connected the words from the root *weg- (cf. Gk. ὑγρός etc.), without likelihood. The comparison with ON aurr 'gravier, terre', OE éar 'humus' but the vocalism doesn't have a clear correspondence.

Cf. s.v. NHG Grund (MHG grunt, OHG grunt, OS grund), from Gmc. *grundu- 'Grund, Boden', also in Goth. grundu-, ON grunnr, OE grund, OFr. grund. The possibilities for comparisons outside of Germanic are problematic. On one hand OIr. grindell 'Grund eines Sees, Untergrund', which would require PIE *gʰrn̥dʰ- which contradicts the Nordic, which seems to require *gʰrn̥t-. On the other hand Lith. pãgrindas 'Grundlage, Fundament' with the same formal problem and further clear connections to words for 'Brett, Bohle' so that in this case one is to think of an artificial floor. For the time being, the etymology must be regarded as unexplained.

S.v. Proto-Germanic *grumϸu- ~ *grundu- 'floor' "Usually reconstructed as a tu-stem to a root *gʰren- (cf. {ref Orel 2003}: 144). Cimb. grumpf, however, points to a form *grumfϸu- with an epenthetic f between the m and the ϸ (for which cf. *kwumϸi- and *samϸu-). Related to Skt. harmyá- 
'permanent building' < *g̑ʰer-m-io-?"
S.v. Proto-Germanic *ʒrunđuz ~ ʒrunϸuz, continues *ghrn̥-tu- based on *ghren- (Gk. χραίνω 'to touch slightly, to smear', Lith. pã-grindas 'lake bottom').
S.v. Goth. G109. grundu-waddjus, possibly from PIE *gʰrendʰ- (PGmc. *grundu- < *gʰrn̥-tu-) is in *grinda-fraϸjis; *grundus then was something crushed, crushed ground like malma to *malan.
Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯eh₁- 'anschwellen' (IEW 592-4).
S.v. OW dibid (3.sg.pres.) 'to come' [deuaf] "This form of the verb contains *do-, and the form of the substantive verb. See also dibu (3.sg.pret.).
S.v. 5292 Lat. mandūcāre 'essen'.

S.v. Lat. mandō 'manger gloutonnement, dévorer'. An expressive word with root vocalism in -a-. The connection with Gk. μάθυιαι· γνάθοι (Hesych.), μασάομαι 'je mâche', μαστάζω 'je mâche', μάσταξ 'bouche; pâtée', μέστακα· τὴν μεμασημένην τροφήν (Hesych.), μοσσύνειν· μασάσθαι βραδέως (Hesych.) is not determinable. Cf. Gall. mant and OHG ga-mindil 'mors'?

S.v. AGk. τρώγω 'ronger, croquer' (of herbivore animals, people eating fruits, vegetables, desserts, etc.). The word evokes two Armenian words  distant from each other: aracem 'paître' and tʻurc, (gen. tʻrcoy) 'menton', which may go back to PIE *trōg-. The vocalism of Tocharian AB trāsk- from *trāk-sk- is ambiguous, cf. {ref IEW} 1073.

S.v. Gaul. depro- 'nourriture', attested in the name of a potter Depro-sagiíos; the second term is interpreted as 'qui cherche', the first term is connected with Breton debri 'manger', Old Breton diprim 'essum, fait de manger', Old Cornish diberi, Cornish dybbry 'id.' Campanile PECA 37 compares to Greek δεῖπνον 'repas', δειπνέω 'je dîne' to a root *deikʷ-. No mention of these words in {ref IEW}, nor {ref Frisk 1960-1972}, {ref Chantraine 1968–1980} who consider the Greek word a 'mediterranean word'
S.v. 9092 Skt. phulla 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' MBh. > N. phul 'flower, menstrual flow, egg'.

S.v. Kâm-viri âṣʹo, also âṣiʹo  NF.  Egg (of bird).  [âṣo]  [OIA. â-ri-:-â- ‘lets go; releases; defecates’  T. 10743 (+; < IE ri- < r̥ 'move away' in ri-: 'flow; melt'; ri-k *'move out; leave; empty'; ri-gh 'move'; ri-kh and ri-˜-kh 'move; crawl'; Kmv. form probably < Aṣkuňu, because of ṣ < ẓ)]
S.v. 9092 Skt. phulla 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' MBh.

S.v. Skt. phullaḥ 'aufgeblüht, blühend / blossoming', possibly from a p.p.p. *phal-na- to phálati 'birst', corresponding to Buddh. phulla- 'gebrochen', Pāli phulla- 'gebrochen' and 'blühend'; the formation no-longer associated with the verb *phalla- would have then would have taken on a labial vowel -u-.

S.v. Skt. phullaḥ 'aufgeblüht, blühend / blossoming', possibly from a p.p.p. *phal-na- to phálati 'birst', corresponding to Buddh. phulla- 'gebrochen', Pāli phulla- 'gebrochen' and 'blühend'; the formation no-longer associated with the verb *phalla- would have then would have taken on a labial vowel -u-.

S.v. EGG *hₐō(u̯)iom 'egg' [{ref IEW} 783-784 *ō(u̯)i̯-om)]. Arm. ju 'egg' and OInd. aṇḍa- cannot be derived from this IE proto-form. It is quite possible that the word for 'egg' is a vr̥ddhi-derivative of the IE word for 'bird' *hₐeu̯ei-.
S.v. Gaul. derco- 'oeil'; the same word as in Insular Celtic (cf. OIr. derc 'oeil', from the root *derk- 'regarder'.
Cf. s.v. 5798 Skt. tārā f. 'fixed star'; 4. tāraká- 'belonging to the stars' > B. tārā 'star; pupil of the eye'

S.v. Ved. stár- 'Stern' (RV ins.pl. stŕ̥bhiḥ, nom.pl. tā́raḥ [RV 8.55.2]; OAv., YAv. star-, etc.), from PIE *h₂stér- (cf. Hitt. ḫa-aš-te-er-za, Gk. ἀστήρ, Arm. astł, Lat. stēlla, Goth. stairno, etc.).
S.v. 3856 *khasati (1) 'falls, slips'
S.v. 1451 Lat. cadere 'fallen', 2. cadēre.
S.v. 4157 *giḍḍ- 'fall' > metath. P. ḍiggaṇā, H. ḍignā
S.v. Wakh. plan- : plat- 'падать, опадать'. Etymology uncertain.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √vah- 'fahren, Wagen lenken, Wagen ziehen, herbeiführen, befördern, bringen' < PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ-.
S.v. 7423 Lat. ruere 'stürzen' > Log. ruere 'fallen'.

S.v. Lat. ruō, -ere (1) 'to rush, hurry on; tumble down, collapse', from PIE *h₃reu-e/o- 'to run, hurry' (cf. OIr. rúathar 'assault'; Gk. ὀρούω 'to hurry', Alb. ra 'to fall (down); strike, hit' (< PAlb. *(a)rau-?); Bel., Ukr. rux 'movement, bustle', Cz. ruch 'movement' < *(H)rous-o-); possibly a neo-root to PIE *h₃er- 'to set in motion' according to {ref Meiser 2003}:236.

S.v. Oss. xawyn : xawd | xawun : xawd 'падать, попадать, доставаться', from Iranic *kap- 'to fall', cf. Kurdish kautin 'fall', Zazaki kaun- 'fall', Balochi kap- / kapta- 'fall', Shughni xāfs- / xavd, Khotanese kas-.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh; to become tired' (> Oss. ? ? Oss. I. xawyn/xawd D. xawun/xawd 'to (be)fall' (with dissim. of first *u̯- + pres. u̯a-suff.); or s.v. Proto-Iranic *xa(m)p/b- 'to dismount, descend, move away, leave behind'? (> ? Oss. I. xawyn/xawd D. xawun/xawd 'to (be)fall' (with unexpl. -w-, LW?)). Inner-Iranic difficulties make extra-Iranic connections uncertain.
Cf. s.v. 5116 Lat. langē 'fern', and s.v. 5119 Lat. longus 'lang'.

S.v. Gmc. *langa- 'lang', an inherited adjective identical with Lat. longus 'lang' < PIE *dlongho-, next to this stands *dl̥əgho- in Ved. dīrghá-, OAv. darəga-, Gk. δολιχός, OCS dlьgъ, cf. also Hitt. dalugai- 'lang'. Probably related to Ved. drā́ghate 'macht lang, ermüdet, quält'.

S.v. Gmc. *langa- 'lang', an inherited adjective identical with Lat. longus 'lang' < PIE *dlongho-, next to this stands *dl̥əgho- in Ved. dīrghá-, OAv. darəga-, Gk. δολιχός, OCS dlьgъ, cf. also Hitt. dalugai- 'lang'. Probably related to Ved. drā́ghate 'macht lang, ermüdet, quält'.

S.v. Gmc. *wīda- 'weit'; several possibilities at a formal connection with Ved. vītá- from different sources: (a) 'gerade, nicht krumm, eben' (RV, of uncertain origin); (b) 'eingehüllt, bedeckt, verbogen' (RV, to vyáyati 'umhüllt, bedeckt, birgt'); (c) 'unternommen, angenommen' (RV, to véti 'wendet sich zu, trachtet nach'), (d) vergangen, gewichen' (to vi-i- RV 'in verschiedene Richtungen gehen, sich verbreiten, sich verstreuen, sich verschwinden'), but nevertheless unclear.
S.v. *meh₂k̑- 'lang' (IEW 699, EIEC 357, 574).
S.v. *meh₂k̑- 'lang' (IEW 699, EIEC 357, 574).
S.v. *meh₂k̑- 'lang' (IEW 699, EIEC 357, 574).
S.v. AGk. μακρός 'long, mince, grand', from a well-attested root *māk̑-/*mək̑- (cf. Lat. macies 'maigreuer', macer 'maigre', also in OHG magar, ON magr, etc.; perhaps OIr. mēr 'doigt' < *makro-).

Cf. s.v. Ved. br̥hánt- 'groß, umfänglich, reichlich, erhaben, hoch, kräftig, weit, dicht, laut' (YAv. bərəzaṇt- 'hochragend, hoch, laut', Oss. bærzond 'hoch', MP, NP buland 'hoch, groß'), from PIE *bʰr̥g̑ʰ-ént-.
Cf. s.v. Khot. bulysa- 'long', to Av. bərəzant- 'high', BSogd. βrzʾk, βrz 'long', Waxī vərz, vorz 'long', Pašto ūẓ̌d, etc., from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ-.
Cf. s.v. 5441 *ṭaḍḍha- 'distant'
S.v. 4956 Lat. laxus 'schlaff, weit' > Sp. lejos 'fern'.
Cf. s.v. *sle⁽g̑⁾- 'erschlaffen' (IEW 959-960).
Cf. s.v. *terh₂- 'durchkommen, überqueren' (IEW 1074-5).
S.v. Lith. bijóti 'fear, be afraid', from PIE *bʰ(o)iH- (cf. OCS bojati sę, Skt. bhay- 'fear, be afraid').
Cf. s.v. Goth. F33. *faurhts ῾δειλός', 'fearful', *faurhtjan wkvI 'φοβεῖσθαι', 'be afraid'; PIE *perg- possibly in TochAB pärsk-.
S.v. Proto-Germanic *agan- pret.-pres. 'to fear' > Goth. ogan, 3.sg. og 'id.' (cf. Gk. ἄχομαι 'to grieve, lament' < *h₂égʰ-e-, OIr. -ágadar 'to fear' < *h₂e-h₂ogʰ-e-).
S.v. Lat. tremere 'zittern', with contamination with Gaul. crem : OFr. criembre, Fr. craindre, Prov. cremer 'fürchten'.
S.v. 8737 Lat. timēre 'fürchten'.
Cf. s.v. Du. bang 'angstig'
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *frais-a- 'versuchen'. No certain etymology. The best connection is to the root *per- 'versuchen, prüfen'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *drita- 'shit, dirt' and s.v. *drītan- 'to shit'. No good etymology. Perhaps to Ru. (dial.) dristát', SCr. drískati, dríćkati 'to have diarrhea < *dʰreid-ske-???
Cf. s.v. Gmc. *dreit-a- 'scheißen'.
Cf. s.v. 8089a sọnium 'Sorge' > OFr. soin 'Sorge', perhaps a loan from Goth. bisunja 'Fürsorge' > It. bisognio, Fr. besoin, etc.
Cf. s.v. ON ugð 'angst, fürcht', ugga 'fürchten'. Perhaps to a PIE root *ak̑-, ok̑- 'scharf, spitz sein' ({ref IEW} 18).
S.v. ScG. eagal, feagal 'fear', Ir. eaguil, eagla, E. Ir. ecla, OIr. ecal (adj.), *ex-gal; see gal 'valour'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *galā 'valor, ability', from PIE *gelH- 'be able' (cf. Lith. galiù 'be able').
Cf. s.v. *gelHº- 'Macht bekommen über' (IEW 351).
S.v. Manx aggle 'fear' (= ScG. eagal).
Cf. s.v. OIr. ecal adj. 'timorous, fearful' <*ek(s)gal
S.v. Manx fedjag 'feathers, whiskers', cf. ScG. eiteag.
Cf. s.v. éiteag 'white pebble, precious stone'; from Engl. hectic, lapis hecticus, the white hectic stone, used as a remedy against dysentery and diarrhea.
Cf. s.v. *pleu̯- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 835-7) and *pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837).

S.v. Lat. plūma 'plume qui recouvre le corps'. A popular term without an exact correspondence. The most attractive connection is with that of Lith. plùnksna 'plume', OPr. plauxdine 'lit de plume'; the connection with OHG fliogan 'voler' is to be discarded because of the sense. Other proposed connections are uncertain.
S.v. Du. pluim zn. ‘(grote) veer, verenbos’, an early borrowing, in the context of trade in goose feathers and down with Rome, from Latin plūma 'down; feather'.
S.v. 8151 Skt. piccha- n. 'tail-feather' MBh.
S.v. Skt. piccham 'Schwanzfeder', 'tail-feather' (since Mahābh.), Pāli piccha-, piñja- 'id.', Prākr. piccha-, piñcha- 'Schwanzfeder, Schwanz'. Without convincing explanation.
S.v. Gmc. feht-a- 'fechten', going with certainty back to the common-IE verbal root *pek̑- 'rupfen, raufen'.
S.v. Gmc. *slah-a- 'schlagen', no certain comparisons. In question comes MIr. slacc 'Schwert', slahta 'geschlagen' (both sparsely attested).
S.v. sabaid 'a brawl, fight', see tabaid 'fight, brawl' cf. Scots debate
S.v. γoš S; γaš 'dispute, scandal' etc. < Persian γaš(š) stupor, deceiving, etc.?
Cf. s.v. Gaul. exobnos 'hardi, sans crainte'
S.v. Proto-Celtic *u̯ik-e/o- 'kämpfen', from PIE 2. *u̯ei̯k- (LIV² 670f.)

S.v. OPers. hamarana- n. 'Kampf (allgemein); Gefecht, Schlacht', from Proto-Indo-Iranic *samárana- 'Kampf, Schlacht'; literally 'Zusammentreffen', a verbal abstract to *sám-ar- = YAv. hamarəna, Ved. samárana- 'id.'
Cf. s.v. *h₃er- 'sich in (fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-9).
S.v. 10920 *laḍ- (2) 'fight'. 2. *laḍḍ- 2. 3. *laḍh- > H. laṛnā (→ N. laṛnu, Mth. laṛab, Bhoj. laṛal).
S.v. लड़्नु laṛnu ², vb. intr. To fight; (c. sita) fight against. [K. laḍun to fight (prob. lw. H. P.)]

S.v. Proto-Iranic *part- 'to fight, struggle'. "This IIr. root appears to be an incremented root of IE *per- 'to hit, fight' (*par- 3), but it has no further IE cognates.", cf. s.v. [aor.] ehar 'struck', OCS pьrjǫ 'I argue, quarrel', Ru. pru, perét') 'I push, drag', Lith. periù 'I beat, lash with a besom (in the bath)'.

"(23) mygdyyn " consisting of fruit ". In M 93, 14b, mygdg "' fruit " occurs. Sogdian myδ'kw (etc.) =maγδe " fruit " and MPers. myw (Mir.Man., i), Pers. meve "fruit " (for which Morgenstierne proposed a different origin, Acta Orientalia, i, 272) belong here; MPers. mew < *mey from *maδg (miδg ?) with metathesis. The Parthian, Sogdian, and Persian words, in conjunction, prove Old Iranian *migda- (and *migdaka-) " fruit "; all of them are collective nouns. This Old Iranian migda- " fruit " cannot well be separated from the Aramaic and Hebrew migdā (etc.) "fruit ", words which are often mis-translated because of etymological considerations (√mgd in Arabic and Palmyrene). Syriac maγδā means nothing but "fruit ", and so does Talm. mygd' (mgd'), for which Levy, iii, 12, gives Kostbarkeit, kostliche Frucht, while the passage he quotes has b-'sprmqy w-mgdy, evidently " with flowers (MPers. isparhmag) and fruit . Biblical Hebrew mä́gäd, in Deut., 33:13 sqq., and unquestionably in Cant., 413, 16, 714, means " fruit ", both literally and metaphorically (" fruit of heaven ", etc.); Brown-Driver-Briggs say " excellence: excellent or choice things; always of gifts of nature…"
Cf. s.v. Du. ooft 'boomvruchten (zoals appels en peren)’, from Proto-Germanic uba-etaz 'side-dish' (for etymologies of elements cf. s.v. Du. op, and eten).

Cf. s.v. Ved. yúvan- 'jung, jugendlich' (IIr. YAv. yauua- 'Jüngling', Khot. jvaa-, MP ǰuwān, Parth. ywʾn, NP ǰawān 'jung, Jüngling'), from PIE *h₂i̯éu̯-Hon-/*h₂i̯u-Hén-/*h₂i̯u-Hn-, to PIE *h₂i̯éu̯-, *h₂oi̯u- 'Lebenskraft'; cf. Lat. iuvenis 'junger Mann', Goth. jund- 'Jugend'.

Lat. māturus 'rechtzeitig, zeitig, reif', Osc. maatúís < Mātīs = 'Dī Mānēs', probably also Hitt. mēḫur 'rechte Zeit' < PIE *meh₂u̯r̥ ({ref Eichner 1973}).

Cf. s.v. Paš. sāb'ə 'greens, vegetables', also 'fodder grass' "sābə is apparently the pl. of *sob- < *sāpa-; semantically a connexion with Prs sabz 'green, fresh', sabzī 'vegetable' seems likely, and the derivation of this < *sapa-čī- [is] possible (in spite of Henning's daring etymology < *spiz-, ultimately < *spr̥ǰ, √sparg- BSOAS 12/1, 1947, 47)."

"As [Parth.] spc-/'spyz- (a)spez- can mean "to be verdant", should one not connect with it Persian sabz "green, fresh, in full bloom", sabz sudan "sprout, shoot, germinate " (etc.)? Although there are difficulties, this etymology of sabz may seem better than the one proposed by Morgenstierne, EVP., 66; NTS., i, 66. To come to the origin of 'spyxt/'spyz- itself, the obvious etymon is the Iranian base sprg (sparg) "to sprout, blossom". The past participle *sprxta- would become sprixt in early Middle Persian: for the rule is that -r̥- becomes brief vowel + r before a simple consonant, but r + brief vowel (generally -i-) before two consonants. As a word may not begin with three consonants, irrespective of a prothetic vowel, sprixt was necessarily shortened and became spixt; but where it was preceded by a preverb, no change took place, cf. Parth. wyspryxt (or Saka hasprīya as against spätai). The present stem, *sprjya-, would develop in the same manner, spriǰy- > spiǰy- > spiǰ- > spiz- > (ə)spiz-. We have to call in the help of analogy to explain the noun 'spyg, -spyg (Pahl. spyk, inverse spelling), i.e. (ə)spig < *sprig < *spr̥ga- (which should have become *spurg). Nyberg, Texte zum mazd. Kal., 77 sq., has a different etymology."
S.v. Skt. akṣam n. 'blauer Vitriol / blue vitriol', cf. Khowar oč̣ 'light blue', Av. aḫšaēna- 'dunkelfarbig'(?), Morgenstierne 74, Burrow ArchLing. 6 (1954) 61.

S.v. akṣa- 'blauer vitriol' (Lex.) – Eine Farbezeichnung? "Man hat Dardisches (wie Kho. oc[h] 'green, blue') und Iranisches (wie jav. axšaēna- 'dunkelfarbig' u.a.) herangezogen; s. die Lit. in KEWA I:543, III:623, Tu 24, Hinz NÜ 25, Bai, Dict 26bf. 346b"
