S.v. Proto-Celtic *gurmo- 'dun, dark' (MIr. gorm 'blue', MW gwrm, OBret uurm-haelon 'with brown eyebrows'). "There does not seem to be any cognates in other IE languages, so this adjective was probably borrowed from some non-IE source."

S.v. *gorsmo-s 'warm, roth' > Ir. gorm 'blau', W. gwrm 'niger, nigricans, infuscus', OBret. uurm in Uurm-haelon, Uuorm-haelon 'aux sourcils bruns', etc. [a subheading of PCl. *gorô 'Wärme' to be connected with *gʷʰer-].
"ags. tourma m. ,Purpurschnecke, Waid, Purpur', daraus entlehnt abret. uurm , dunkel', cymr. gwrm ,dunkel (blaa)*, woraus wiederum air. gorm ds."
S.v. 12961 Ved. sáṁbharati 'brings together, prepares, rolls up' RV. (> Si. am̆baranavā 'to twist, grind').
Cf. s.v. Ved. √bhar- 'tragen, hegen, pflegen; bringen' < PIE *bʰer-.
S.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).
S.v. 6216 Skt. dálati intr. 'cracks, splits' Suśr., dalayati tr. Dhātup. (> M. daḷṇẽ 'to grind').
Cf. s.v. Skt. dálati 'brist, springt auf' / 'bursts, cracks, flies open' (ep., etc.). The verb is not attested before the epics; we probably have an l-form of the group of Skt. dr̥ṇā́ti.

S.v. √dar-ⁱ 'zersprengen, zerspalten', from PIE *der- 'abspalten; schinden, Haut abziehen', cf. Gk. δέρω 'häute ab', δρατός 'abgehäutet', Goth. dis-tairiϸ 'zerreißt', Lith. dìrti, OCS dьrati 'reißen, schinden' etc.
Cf. s.v. *der- 'zerreißen (intr.), zerspringen' (IEW 206-8).
Cf. s.v. √bhed- 'spalten, zerbrechen, zerschlagen, zerschneiden', from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'spalten, brechen' (Lat. findō 'spalte', OE bītan, NHG beißen', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (IEW 116-7).

Cf. s.v. OIr. bleith, mleith, verbal noun of the root mel- 'moudre' and s.v. OIr. mel-, verbal root 'moudre, écraser' (cf. Skt. mr̥ṇā́ti 'il écrase', Goth. malan, NHG mahlen, Lith. malù 'je mouds', OCS meljǫ, Lat. molō, etc.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *kaup- (1) 'to pound, beat'. The root appears to be exclusively Iranian.
S.v. Kurd. kutān (kut-) | kutān (kutē-) 'бить, колотить, ударять; стучать; молотить, биться (о сердце)', from Old Iranic *kup- (Parth. kwbg, MPers. kōv-, kōftan, Pers. kōb, kōbīdan, etc.).
Cf. s.v. 1628 Lat. capillus 'Haupthaar'.
S.v. 6508 Lat. pilus 'Haar (am Körper)'
S.v. कपाल् kapāl, s. Forehead; scalp; hair of the head. < *kappāla- (cf. Sk. kapā́lam n. crock, skull: Pa. kapālaṁ n., Pk. kavāla- n.)
S.v. *skufta- (1) 'hair of the head', further connections (e.g. to Ru. čubъ čupъ 'shock') are unclear. Cf. also ON skúfr 'tassel' < *sküba-, G Pal. Schaupe 'forelock' < *skübbōn-.

S.v. Wa. ṣ̌afṣ̌ ‘волос(ы)’ (на голове человека). Maybe from Turkish sač, čač ’волосы (на голове человека)’, or to Khot. sakṣa; {ref Bailey 1979}:417 reconstructs Proto-Iranic *safša- (cf. Pers. šifša- 'локон').

S.v. Ved. kéśa- 'Haupthaar'; difficult to separate from Av. (º)gaēsa- 'Kraushaar', gaēsu- 'lockenhaarig', MPers. gēs, NPers. gēsū 'Locken' etc. Perhaps a contamination of *geśa- (= Av. gaēº) and késara- 'Haar, Mähne'. Further etymological connections unclear.
S.v. 3471 Ved. kḗśa- m. 'hair of the head' AV.
S.v. Kurd. qiž с. 'волосы'. A reliable explanation is lacking. Cf. Teleut gыž 'овчинный', 'sheepskin'.
S.v. Khw. γwnyk 'Haar' [cf. šγn. brt. gūnǰ 'id.', Av. gaona- 'Farbe', originally maybe 'Fell', cf. Mackenzie BSOAS 32 (1969) 398.]
S.v. Goth. S94. *skuft 'θρίξ', 'hair of the head'. Now generally to PIE *(s)kewp-, *skewbh-, elsewhere only Slavic (Ru. čup, čubák, Pol. czub 'tuft').

S.v. Alb. lesh 'wool, fleece, hair', from PAlb. laiša, etymologically connected with the Balto-Slavic word for foliage : Lith. laĩškos 'leaf', Latv. laĩska 'leaf on a linen stalk; stalk', Slav. listъ 'leaf'.

Under 'hair' 3. lesh|i 'wool, fleece, hair'; {ref Orel 1998}:219 to Balto-Slavic forms for foliage without a reference "semantically too far, and not mentioned in Pk [{ref IEW}]"; Perhaps with {ref IEW} 681 to *leu̯H-so- 'abgeschnitten/cut off', alternatively {ref IEW} 1139 *u̯elH- 'hair, wool' > *Hu̯l̥h₁-so- > PAlb. (u)laś 'wool, hair, fleece' similarly cf. {ref Huld 1984}:85, {ref Demiraj 1997}:238.

S.v. OW bleuporthetic 'wool bearing'. Hapax in Welsh, A compound whose first element bleu was linked by G. Lane Language 7 (1931), 279 to PIE *mel- 'Wolle' ({ref IEW} 721); the second element is porthedig, a loan from Latin portāre.
S.v. 7. mel- 'Wolle, Wollgewand'? : Gk. μαλλός (*ml̥-nó-) 'Zotte, Flocke', Lith. mìlas 'Tuch', Latv. mil(n)a 'großes Tuch', OPr. milan 'id.'. [Without Celtic cognates].

Cf. s.v. W. blew 'hair, hairs, bristles, fur', cf. Old Cornish bleu (en lagat), gl. palpebre, bleuyn (pen), gl. capillus, Middle Cornish blewennow (diminutive fem. pl.), Late Cornish bleaw, Old Breton bleuou, gl. iubis, Middle Breton bleau, Late Breton blew; cf. also Old Welsh blewborthedig. [No etymology outside of Brythonic].

2. Welsh blew, Breton bleo: "The common Brythonic word for 'hair', Welsh blew, Bret. bleo, has never received a satisfactory explanation. Henry (Lexique étymologique 37) hazards a comparison with Grk. φλοιός 'bark, peeling' (IE *bhleu- 'swell', cf. further on this group Walde-Pokorny 2. 212f.). The attempt made by Morris-Jones (Welsh Gramm. 157) to link the Celtic words to Lith. plùskos 'hair', NE fleece, etc. (IE *pleus-) is of course to be discarded so long as nothing is established regarding the alternation of initial sonant and surd in Indo-European. Moreover the correct Celtic cognate for the latter group is OIr. lō 'flock of wool' (cf. Walde-Pokorny 2. 96f.). The possibility of deriving Celtic *bleus² from *mleus, an extended form of IE *mel- in Grk. μαλλός 'bunch of hair, wool', Lith. milas 'cloth (of wool)', etc. (cf. id. 2. 294) has been overlooked as far as I can discover The change ml > bl is common enough in Celtic, cf. e.g. Welsh blith 'milk' : OIr. mlicht, blicht, Goth. miluks, etc."
S.v. Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair', from PIE *k̑ē̆s-ró- (cf. Hitt. kišzi ~ kišanzi 'to comb, card' < *kes-ti, *ks-énti; OCS česati 'to scratch, pluck' < *kes-eh₂-, etc.).

S.v. NHG Haar (MHG hār, OHG hār, OS hār), from Gmc. *hǣra- 'Haar' also in ON hár, OE hǣr, hēr (in Gothic instead tagl, cf. Zagel). The closest thing that may be compared is an original s-stem, cf. Lith. šerỹs 'Borste, (Tier-)haar', Lith. širỹs 'Haar' (IE *k̑er-, *k̑r̥-); with an s extension (reflex of an s-stem?) Ru. šerštь 'Wolle', further origin unclear.

S.v. Du. haar 2 zn. ‘draadvormige huidbedekking bij mensen en dieren’; Further etymology unclear. Traditionally related to Lithuanian šerys 'animal hair'; Old Russian sĭrstĭ 'hair, wool' (Russian šerst' 'wool'); < PIE *ker(s) 'spine, hair of plants' (IEW 583). Another possibility is that PGmc. *hēra- with grammatical change and rhotacism going back to PIE *kēsó-, from the root * kes- 'combing', which also includes: OCS kosa 'haar', česati 'combing'; Lithuanian kasà 'braid'; Hittitisch kis-zi 'he combs'. Maybe Old Irish cír 'comb, rake' is also related < PIE * ḱēs-. Partly because of the field of meaning and the limited geographical spread, this is possibly a pre-Indo-European substrate word.
S.v. Latv. mats (Lith. mãtas 'mērs, mērvienība')
S.v. PGmc. *faxsan, based on an original s-stem as in Gk. πέκος 'fleece'.
Cf. s.v. AGk. πέκω 'to comb (oneself), card, shear' (ll.). < IE *pek- 'pluck, card'.
Cf. s.v. *pek̑- '(Wolle oder Haare) rupfen, zausen' (IEW 797).
S.v. Kurd. pirc̑ 'волосы, ворс, пух', cf. Av. parša-, Ved. parṣa- (Kurd. -rc̑- ~ Av. -rša-).
Cf. s.v. Ved. parṣá- (only RV 10.48.7) 'Garbe (von Ähren), Bündel' (cf. YAv. parša- 'Getreideähre, Ähre', further connections unclear.

S.v. Skt. parṣá- 'Garbe (von Ähren), Bündel', 'sheaf, bundle', cf. Av. parša- 'Getreideähre'. Further is unclear, comparison with Arm. her 'hair', Lat. jūni-perus 'Wacholder', OE fyrs 'Stechginster', OCS proso 'Hirse', etc. do not bring any clarification.
S.v. x̌ad S 'hair of the head' < *fšatā- 'combed'?

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *fšan- 'to drag, tear, split'? "The initial f- of the Iranian root is peculiar, if it is connected with Skt. (vi)kṣan and Gr. ξαίνω: does it point to an IE root *pksen- (or *pk̑sen-)? If this is indeed the case, then we may consider an etymological relation with the IE 'shear, comb' forms, *pek̑- (cf. *paš)."

S.v. (1) r̄aq 'высохший', 'черствый', 'жесткий', 'твердый'. Cf. Gurani raq 'твердый', Luri riiq 'затвердевшая на морозе мокрая одежда',
'накрахмаленная одежда', 'высохший на морозе', Shugn. rāx 'онемелый', 'затекший'.
S.v. 8814 Lat. tostus 'gebacken' (> Neap. tuoste, Venez. tosto, Trient. tost 'hart').
S.v. 6508 dr̥ḍhá- , dr̥ḷhá- 'firm, hard, strong' RV. [√dr̥ṁh]

S.v. Ved. dūrá- 'fern' (adj.), 'Ferne' (n.), IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. dūrat̰ 'von fern', OAv. dūirē, YAv. dūire 'fern', etc., from PIE *duh₂-ró- to PIE *du̯eh₂- 'sich entfernen, räumlich und zeitlich erstrecken'. Cf. *du̯eh₂-m > Gk. δήν, *du̯eh₂-ró- > Skt. dūrá-, Gk. δηρός, Arm erkar 'lange dauernd; Hitt. tūu̯a- 'fern' < *duh₂-i̯o-; Lat. dūdum.
S.v. Khot. dūra- 'hard', from *daura- (cf. Oss. D. dor, I. daur 'stone', Lat. dūrus 'hard' ({ref IEW} 215).
S.v. 13676 stabdha- 'firmly fixed' ŚvetUp. 2. 'stiff, paralysed, dull' MBh., 'solidified (as water)' Hariv. [√stambh] (> Si. tada 'firm, hard').
S.v. Ved. √stambh- 'befestigen, stützen' from PIE *stembʰH- something like 'stützen, versteifen, festtreten', cf. Gk. ἀστεμφής 'fest, starr', Lith. stem̃bti 'widerstreben' etc.
Cf. s.v. *stembʰH- 'sich stützen, sich stemmen' (IEW 1012-3).
S.v. 2650 Skt. kaṭhiná- 'hard, stiff' Suśr. [EWA i 144 with lit. groups kaṭhiná-, káṭhōra-, ˚ōla-, kaṭhara-, kaḍḍati as ← Drav. Tam. kaṭṭu 'hardness', Tu. gaṭṭi, &c.]
S.v. 2657 kaḍḍ 'be rough', káḍḍati Dhātup. [See kaṭhiná-] N. B. Or. kaṛā 'rough', H. kaṛā, kaṛṛā.
S.v. Skt. kaṭhiná- 'hart, fest', 'hard, firm', probably a Dravidian loanword, cf. Tamil taṭṭu- 'hart machen'. Cf. káḍḍati 'ist hart'.
S.v. Skt. kaṭhiná- 'hart, fest', 'hard, firm', probably a Dravidian loanword, cf. Tamil taṭṭu- 'hart machen'. Cf. káḍḍati 'ist hart'.
S.v. 5566 *ḍōka- 'head'. 2. *ḍōkka- 1.
Cf. Kho. sor 'head'. "The o indicates a rather early borrowing. Yd. soro 'ear of corn' from Kho."
S.v. Wa. sar 'голова’, ’верх’, a borrowing from Tajik, Persian sar.
S.v. 2112 Lat. concha 'Muschel' (> nlog. konka 'Backtrog; Kopf').
S.v. Lat. concha 'coquille, coquillage, conque', loan from Gk. κόγχη (already Plautus conchita, κογχίτης).

S.v. 9926 masta- m. 'head' Dhūrtas., mástaka- m.n. 'head, skull' Mn., mastika- n. lex. 2. *mastra- . 3. mastuluṅga- m. (n.?) 'brain' Suśr., mastakaluṅga- m. or n. 'membrane of brain' lex. 4. mastíṣka- 'cranium' RV. [Orig. heteroclite declension: *másti or *mástr̥g nom. ~ *mastnás gen. whence másta-ka- < *mastn̥-ka- , *mastr-a- or *mastrr̥-ka-, combined in *mastr̥ṅga- > MIA. mastuluṅga- (?) as in Av. mastrəgan- m. 'temples' (~ mastíṣka- < *mast-ə-s- ) WP ii 309, EWA ii 606 with lit.]

S.v. Ved. mastr̥han- 'Gehirn' (IIr. cf. YAv. mastərəγan- 'Gehirn', Orm. mastərγ 'Gehirn'), IIr. *mastr̥gʰan- is not to be separated from RV+ mastíṣka- 'Gehirn', mastaka- 'Schädel, Kopf', etc. The IIr. forms suggest an original *-r/n- stem *mast-r̥-gʰ- / *mast-(a)n-. Perhaps the forms mastr̥han-, mastaka-, mastíṣka-, etc. are to be connected with *mosgʰ- 'Mark, Gehirn' (cf. majján-)?
Cf. s.v. 5803 tā́lu n. 'palate' under which "N. ṭāuko 'head', M. ṭaũkī f. 'forepart of skull' are obscure."

S.v. N. टाउको ṭāuko,s. Head. -- ṭ˚ ghumnu c. ko to feel dizzy. -- tero ṭ˚ blockhead. [cf. G. ṭālkũ n. crown of head ? -- but also M. ṭaũkī f. forepart of skull, half of eggshell, coco- nut shell, etc. -- Cf. tālu².]
S.v. 4483 Lat. intendere 'hinwenden'.
Cf. s.v. Kurd. bihīstin 'сльшать, спушать; узнавать', from Old Iranic *vi-vaid-, cf. Av. vaēd-, etc.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯aid- (1) 'to know' (NWIr. + *u̯i- > Kurd. (Kurm.) bihīstin/bihīs-, bihīz-, bihē-, (Sor.) bīstin/bīya- 'to
hear, listen, get to know'), from PIE *u̯oi̯d- (pf. stem) 'to know' (cf. Skt. ved- 'to (get to) know', Gk. οἶδα 'I know', Arm. gitel, OIr. ro-fetar, MWelsh gwyr, OCS vědě, Goth. wait, ON vitum, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯d- 'erblicken' (IEW 1125-7).
S.v. 779 Lat. audīre 'hören'

S.v. Lat. audiō 'entendre'. "On rapproche gr. ἀίω 'j'entends' (sans doute ancien *αϝιω), ἐπ-άϊστος, αἰσθάνομαι, et skr. āviḥ 'évidemment', gāth. āvišya- 'évident', v. sl. avě 'manifestement'. Mais la formation du mot latin est obscure".
S.v. *h₂ou̯s-os-, *h₂au̯s-os-, *h₂us-es- n. 'Ohr' (IEW 785); cf. h₂us-i- > Av. uši- 'Ohr', OPers. uši- 'Ohr'.
S.v. 1. *ser- 'aufpassen auf, beschützen' (IEW 910).
Cf. s.v. ?*h₂u̯ei̯s- 'hören' (IEW 78); cf. n1 "Verbal nur gr., hierher u.U. lat. audīre 'hören', vgl. dazu Meier-Brügger, FT Wien 287-92."
S.v. Wax. pəzы́v, pǝzы́w 'сердце, желудок; дух'. Etymology unclear. {ref Morgenstierne 1938}:536 considers *apa-zābya- (?).
S.v. Wax. pə'zöv, pi'zuv, etc.'heart' "A purely phonetic reconstruction *apa-zābya- gives no possible etymology."
Cf. s.v. 1356 *ālagyati 'adheres to', 2. ālagna- 'fastened to' lex. [Cf. ālagati ʻ adheres ʼ Kāvyād.: √lag]
S.v. Kâmviri âlʹaŋo  [-i fem]  Aj.  Heavy.  [â-laŋvo]  [OIA. â-lag-na- ‘fastened to’  T. 1356.2 (+; gn > ŋ?)]
S.v. Ved. √lag- 'an etwas haften, sich anheften'; etymology unexplained.
S.v. PGmc. *xaƀiʒaz ~ *xaƀuʒaz, based on xaƀiz > OE hefe 'weight' derived from *xafjanan.

S.v. Gmc. *haf-ja- 'heben', cf. derived adjectives *haf-uga- 'gewichtig, schwer' > OWN hǫfugr, *hab-iga- 'gewichtig, schwer' > OE heftig, etc.; the strong verb goes back with certainty to the common IE verbal root *qap- (probably *qǝ₁p-) 'fassen, nehmen', cf. Lat. capiō, Latv. kàmpju, kàmpt, Gk. κάπτω.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic hafjan- ~ *habjan- s.v. 'to raise, lift' < *kh₂p-ie- (cf. ?Gr. κάπτω 'to gulp down', Lat. capiō 'to take' < *kh₂p-ie-; Latv. kàmpt 'to obtain' < *kh₂-en-p-e-).
Cf. s.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-8).
Cf. s.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).
S.v. Latv. smags, cf. Lith. smagùs.
S.v. Bret. kuz 'caché' < Proto-Celtic koud-o- (denom. vb. kuziñ 'cacher').
Cf. s.v. ?2. *(s)kep- 'bedecken' (IEW 930), without Albanian.
S.v. 5420 *ṭakk- (1) 'remain, stop'. 2. *ṭikk- . 3. *ṭēkk- usu. tr. [Cf. *ḍakk- 3, *ṭhēkk-]

S.v. Proto-Germanic laugnjan- w.v. 'to keep hidden, deny' (Go. laugnjan; ON leyna, etc.), probably a factitive to the adjective *laugna- and related to *leugan- 'to lie', a strong verb to *leugʰ-, cf. OCS lъgati 'to lie', OIr. fol-lugaid 'to hide' < *lugʰ-eh₂-.
Cf. s.v. Da. skjul 'hide, cover' (n.), from Old Norse skjól, to the same root as sky 'cloud'.
S.v. 4994 *chapp- 'press, cover, hide'. 2. *chipp- .
S.v. Khot. prīh- 'conceal', See pärsta- 'hidden'

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *snaH- 'to wash, swim' (> NEIr. (+ *apa-, *abi- ?) Oss. I. æfsnajyn/æfsnad, D. æfsnajun/æfsnad ‘to clean up’), from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to wash, swim' (cf. Skt. snā- 'to bathe, to wash', Lat. nāre 'to swim', OIr. snaid, -sná 'swims', TochB näsk- 'to bathe').
S.v. Oss. æfsnajyn : æfsnajd | æfsnajun : æfsnajd; from Ir. *apa- or *abi- + *snā-.

Cf. s.v. OLith. glabstýti 'umarmen, umfassen, anfassen', a st-iterative to Lith. *glė́bti 'umfassen, umarmen', cf. also other secondary formations such as Lith. glabóti 'umarmen, umschlingen; zusammenlegen, zusammenfalten', Latv. glabât, -ãju 'hüten, schützen', see further s.v. OLith. *glė́bti 'umfassen, umarmen' comparing Latv. glabât 'hüten, schützen; pflegen, beaufsichtigen, nähren; vergraben, verbergen', SCr. zglȍb 'Gelenk', Ru. glóba, globá (dial.) 'Querbalkan, Querstange auf Heuschober', etc.; from PIE *gleh₁bʰ- 'umfassen', cf. ON klafi 'Joch für Rinder', MLG klave 'Joch für Kühe' klachter 'Maß der ausgespannten Arme, Klafter' OHG klāftra 'Klafter'.
S.v. Gmc. *slah-a- 'schlagen', no certain comparisons. In question comes MIr. slacc 'Schwert', slahta 'geschlagen' (both sparsely attested).
Cf. s.v. 2998 Lat. excutere 'herausschlagen', with derivative log. iskuttinare.

Cf. s.v. Lat. quatiō, -ere 'to shake, toss, hurry along', with derivative excutere 'to shake out, throw off', from PIE *(s)kuot-i-? (cf. Lith. kùsti, 3s. kùnta 'to recover', OS scuddian, OHG scutten 'to shake', OIc. hossa 'to throw').
S.v. *(s)ku̯eh₁t- 'durchschütteln, aufrütteln' (IEW 632, 957-8); *(s)kuh₁t-i̯é- > [lat. quatiō, -cutiō 'schütteln, erschüttern, stoßen'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √peṣ- 'zerstampfen, zermalmen, zerschmettern', from PIE *pei̯s- (cf. Gk. πτίσσω 'zerschrote, enthülse'. ἄ-πιστος 'unzerstampft', Lat. pīnsere 'zerstoßen', Lith. paisýti 'Grannen abschlagen, enthülsen'.
Cf. s.v. *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben' (IEW 735)

S.v. W trawaf, tarawaf: taro, trawo, tarawo "to strike, give (a blow, knock, &c.) (to), hit, beat, knock, buffet, pound; ?pound (in mortar, &c.); beat (of heart, &c.), pulsate; attack, clash, fight, battle." cf. Old Breton toreusit, gl. atriuit, Middle Breton tarauat ‘treulio, rhwbio’, Late Breton (taf. Gwened) torein ‘taro, bwrw’: from PIE *terə-, cf. Latin terō, Gr. τορεύω]
S.v. Proto-Celtic *bi-na- 'schlagen', from PIE *bʰei̯H- (LIV² 72).
S.v. 11004 Skt. lāgáyati 'lays on' [√lag]. (> K. lāyun 'to apply, fix, set up, beat').
Cf. s.v. Skt. √lag- 'etwas haften, sich anheften'. Etymology unexplained.
S.v. Latv. sist "Vārda cilme nav pilnigi noskaidrota." Etymology uncertain.
Cf. s.v. 5421 *ṭakk- (2) 'cut, break' and 5424 Skt. ṭakkarā f. 'blow on the head' Rājat.
Cf. s.v. ṭakkarā 'Kopfnuß, Schlag auf den Kopf', 'a blow on the head'. Not certainly explained.
S.v. 4450 Skt. ghárṣati 'rubs' tr. Suśr., 'rubs oneself' MBh. (> Si. gasanavā, gaha˚ 'to beat, strike').
S.v. Ved. √gharṣ- 'reiben' (cf. Mi., nu., ni., pā. ghaṁsati 'reibt', etc.); further connections are unclear.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike; [inch., intr.] to become tired'. "A plausible IE provenance cannot be given for this apparently exclusively Ir. root."

S.v. Proto-Iranic *čap- 'to seize, attach, stick, strike'. "This root may have an IE etymology. The connection with Gr. κάπτω, Lat. capere,
etc. (cf. IEW, l.c.) is semantically very attractive. IE "a" would not palatalize the preceding velar in (I)Ir. though: Ir. *č- in *čap- is from *čak/g- ?", if this conjecture is correct, then PIE *k(e)h₂p- (*kap-) 'to grab, stick to'.

S.v. Gaul. banna, benna 'pointe > sommet', cf. OIr. benn 'sommet, pointe, corne' (*bennā), W, Co., Bret. ban(n) 'id.' (*bannā). One may reconstruct a form *bn̥dno- which has correspondences only in Germanic. The alternation -an-/-en- of the reflex of the syllabic sonorant *n̥ is found elsewhere in Gaulish and is perhaps dialectal.

S.v. Gaul. banna, benna 'pointe > sommet', cf. OIr. benn 'sommet, pointe, corne' (*bennā), W, Co., Bret. ban(n) 'id.' (*bannā). One may reconstruct a form *bn̥dno- which has correspondences only in Germanic. The alternation -an-/-en- of the reflex of the syllabic sonorant *n̥ is found elsewhere in Gaulish and is perhaps dialectal.
S.v. Gmc. *haita- 'heiß'. No precise correspondences outside of Germanic.
Cf. s.v. Lith. ker̃šti, no certain etymology.

Cf. s.v. NHG stecken (MHG stecken, OHG stehhōn, steckōn), a variant of stechen with a generalised, perhaps intensifying geminate. Cf. s.v. NHG stechen, from West Germanic *stek-a-. Outside of Germanic one may compare Lat. īnstīgāre 'anspornen', Gk. στίζω 'ich tätowiere, kennzeichne', and a variant without s-mobile Ved. tigmá- 'sharp'.
Cf. s.v. Du. steken ww. 'prikken', cf. OHG stehhan (NHG stechen); OFr. steka (NFr. stekke), < pgm. *stekan-, derivatives of PIE *(s)tei̯g-.

Cf. s.v. Ved. vā́stu- 'Wohnstätte, Hofstatt, Haus', not to be separated from Gk. ἄστυ 'Stadt' < *u̯astu- (Myc. wa-tu[-o-ko]), TochA waṣt, TochB ost 'Haus'. These words may be united under a reconstruction *u̯āstu- ~ *u̯astu-; the forms are not compatible with an etymology from PIE *h₂u̯es- 'dwell, spend the night'.

Cf. s.v. Gk. ἄστυ 'town', comparing Ved. vā́stu- 'residence, abode', Messapic vastei (dat.), and TochA waṣt, TochB ost 'house', PIE *u̯eh₂stu- 'town', postulating an ablauting u-stem *ueh₂stu-, *uh₂steu-, which the latter was generalised in Gk. ἄστυ.
S.v. Wa. xun 'дом, жилище'. An old borrowing from Tadj./Pers. xāna- 'house'.

S.v. Lith. bùtas 'do mieszkalny, chata; budynek gospodarski; obejście; (w mieście) mieszkanie'; corresponding to Old Prussian buttan (acc.sg.) 'dom'; it is normally connected with Lith. bū́ti 'być', but note that the problem of the short -u- in the form remains unresolved.
Cf. s.v. 6663 dvā́ra- n. 'door' ŚBr., dvārī- f. ŚāṅkhŚr.

Cf. s.v. Ved. dvā́r- 'die beiden Türflügel', from PIE *dʰu̯er-, *dʰu̯or-, *dʰur- 'Türe, Tor', cf. TochB twere 'Türe', OCS dvorъ 'Hof', Gk. θυρ-, OHG duri, etc. The lack of aspiration in the Old Indic form can be explained in different ways, possibly originally from Graßmann's dissimilation from case -bh-; also thinkable is lexical influence from dva 'two'.
S.v. Khw. pθk (2) 'Haus' [< ?paδa- ({ref Henning 1955}:43)].
Cf. n3 "Recte pθk (پثک), perhaps from paδa- with change of -δ- to -θ- (as in Younger Avestan)."
"pθk 'house' < padakā-"

S.v. Lat. hospes, -itis 'guest, visitor; host, entertainer', from Proto-Italic *χosti-pot- (cf. Paelig. hospus 'stranger'); IE cognates in OCS gospodь, Ru. gospód' 'the Lord, god' < *gʰost(i)-pot-, a compound of hostis and potis.
Cf. s.v. P. hospus 'Fremder', probably *gʰosti-pot-s with syncope of the second syllable and weakening of the vowel o > u, closely comparable to Lat. hospes 'Gastgeber, Gast'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. goṣṭhá-, º-ṣṭhā́na- > √sthā-.
S.v. 11480 Skt. vāṭa- (1) m. 'enclosure, fence' MBh. [Early east MIA. < *vārtra-; √vr̥1]. Addenda: vāṭa- 1 [Perhaps < *vārta- < IE. *worto- rather than < *vārtra- T. Burrow BSOAS xxxviii 68]

"Classical Sanskrit vāṭa- 'fence; enclosure', vāṭī 'enclosed ground', vāṭīkā 'idem' are of Middle Indo-Aryan orgin. R. L. Turner (BSOAS, xxx, 1, 1967, 77; cf. also CDIAL nos. 11480 and 11565) reconstructs *vārtra- and *vārti- regarding them as formations with derivative vr̥ddhi from vártra and vr̥ti- respectively. Of these the former is possible but hardly the latter. Alternatively we may have in both cases long -ā- from original -o-, and if vāṭī is to be derived from *vārti- (or *vārtī), then vāṭa- may not have to be connected with the tra-formation but could be from a stem with suffix -ta and o-grade of the root, i.e. *vārta- < *worto-."
Cf. s.v. *Hu̯er- 'einschließen, stecken, hineintum' (IEW 1150, 1160), 1. *u̯el- 'einschließen, verhüllen' (IEW 1138), and 1. u̯er- 'aufhalten, (ab)wehren' (IEW 1160-2).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √var- (2) 'umschließen, zusammenhalten, einschließen, zurückhalten, einhüllen' (IIr. cf. YAv. hąm.vaori- 'mit dem Rahm', Oss. wart 'Schild, Schutz', etc. The assignment of Indo-Iranic *var- to Indo-European sources is difficult. (Cf. for further discussion).

Cf. s.v. Du. stoppen w.v. ‘dichtmaken, insteken’, cf. MLG stoppen, OHG stopfōn, stupfen, stoppōn, stopfōn, (dial.) stupfen, OFr. stoppia, NFr. stopje, OE forstoppian, NE stop < PGmc. *stuppōn-; further to Latin stupēre, Grieks τύπτειν, Sanskrit tupáti, Latv. stups, stupe; < PIE *(s)teup-/*(s)teub-, a root with labial extensions from a basic PIE *(s)teu- ‘stoten, slaan’ (IEW 1034). Proto-Germanic *-pp- is probably from *-bhn- (Kluge's Law).
S.v. Wa. šundr 'hot', possibly < *k̑u̯on-ro- or *k̑u̯ondʰ-ro-, cf. Arm. šand 'spark, red-hot iron' < *ku̯n̥ti-??
S.v. Wa. šundr 'теплый', šundrí(ɣ̌/k) 'жара, теплота'; possibly from Iranic *śvan-ra-, IE *k̑u̯on-? ({ref Morgenstierne 1938}:542).
S.v. 10648 raśmí m. ʻ rope, bridle, ray of light ʼ RV. (> Si. räs- a 'beam of light').

Cf. s.v. Ved. raśmí- 'Zügel, Zugseil, Leitseil', Mi., dard., ni., pā. raṁsi- 'Strahl', etc. Vedic raśmí- and raśmán- are together with Vedic raśanā- derivatives to an otherwise unattested root *raś- (IIr. *rać-), probably 'to bind', cf. s.v. Ved. raśanā- 'Strick, Seil, Halfter' comparable to MPers., NPers. rasan, Chwarez. rsyn 'Strick, Seil', Arm. (< Iran.) erasan 'Zügel', etc.
Cf. s.v. Skt. daṇḍáḥ 'Stock, Stab, Prügel', 'stick, staff, club' (since RV). A disputed, still undecided etymological problem.
S.v. Ved. daṇḍá- 'Stock, Stab'. Etymology unexplained.
Cf. s.v. Turk. av 'hunting, game' > Capp. ἄβι.
S.v. Lith. mẽdžias (1) 'las', (with derived verb medžióti), derived from the PIE adverb *medʰi 'w środku', 'in the middle'.
S.v. *medʰ- 'mittlerer' (IEW 706f., EIEC 380). (> *medʰ-i̯o/ah₂- > OPr. median 'Wald', Lith. mẽdžias 'Baum, Holz', Latv. mežs 'Wald').
Cf. s.v. 10396 *yaja 'cold' (Wg. yū˘z, yoz → Kal. Kho. yoz).
S.v. 744 astrātum 'gestirnt' (> Log. astráu, ástrau 'Eis', bistradu 'Eis' (with bi- taken over from biddia).

S.v. Lat. stēlla 'star', from PItal. *stērla-, derived from PIE *h₂stēr-s, *h₂ster- 'star' (cf. OIr. ser, W. seren, Co. sterenn, Bret. sterenn < PCl. *ster-, OIr. sell 'iris' < *stillo-, MIr. sellaid 'to see', MW syllu 'to gaze', Bret. sellout 'to watch' < PCl. stīrlo- 'star' < PIE *h₂stēr-lo-; Hitt. hašter(a)- 'star' < *h₂ster-; Skt. tā́raḥ (nom.pl), stŕ̥bhiḥ (instr.pl.), Av. star-, Khot. stārra- 'star', Gk. ἀστήρ, -έρος, Arm. astł, Goth. stairno, TochB ścriye 'star'). The Italic forms reflect an additional adjectival suffix *-lo- added to nom.sg. stem *h₂stēr-, from which the new substantive 'star' was taken from the feminine form, i.e. Proto-Italic *stēr-lā- > Lat. stēlla.
S.v. *h₂stḗr-, *h₂ster- ́ f. 'Stern' (IEW 1027f. EIEC 543).
For Kashmiri, cf. s.v. 12485 śītá (1) 'cold' RV.; For Nuristan languages cf. s.v. 12614 śaítya n. 'coldness' Yājñ. 2. *śaitiya- > Wg. šēi, šē 'ice', Kt. šē̆.
S.v. 1921 Ved. udaká- n. 'water'. RV. 2. Skt. daka- n. Suśr., BHSk.; Si. diya continues the variant having lost initial u-.
Cf. s.v. Ved. udán- 'Wasser', from PIIr. *ud-r-/*ud-n-, derived to PIE *u̯ed- (cf. YAv. vaiδi- 'Wasserlauf', Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, OS watar, ON vatn, OCS voda 'Wasser', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.). Originally a heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥-/*u̯ed-en-.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √star-ⁱ 'ausbreiten, streuen', from PIE *sterh₃- (cf. Gk. ἐστόρεσα 'habe ausgebreitet', Lat. sternere, 'hinbreiten', OIr. sernaid 'breitet aus', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *sterh₃- 'hinbreiten, ausbreiten' (IEW 1029-30).

S.v. Kurd. nēčīr 'дичь, охота', cf. NPers. naxčīr, Z.MPers. naxčīr, M.MPers.  nhčyhr, Sogd. nɣšʾyr, nɣšyr, Khot. načira, Yaghn. naxšir, naxčir, etc.; according to Bailey 1946:774, from Iranic *naxti-čiθra- 'originating in the night'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *kata- / *xata-, *kāna- / *xāna- 'дом, хижина; сооржение;  укрепленное лоселение'. Derived from the verbal root * kan- / * xan-, Indo-Iranic *k(h)an- in the meaning 1) 'to dig', 2) 'to fill' as * kata- / xata- <* k(h)n̥to- and verbal noun * kāna- / * xāna- <* k(h)ā-na- (Cf. Abaev). Less likely to from the verb * kat- / * čat- 'to cover, cover, hide' ({ref Bailey 1979}:50). The connection with the verb * kan- 'dig' is rejected by Bartolome [Barth. AiW, 432]. It is possible that these names were already lexicalized in common Iranian in most dialects as “house, structure, room”, in certain languages as “roof”

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *kata- / *xata-, *kāna- / *xāna- 'дом, хижина; сооржение; укрепленное лоселение'. Derived from the verbal root * kan- / * xan-, Indo-Iranic *k(h)an- in the meaning 1) 'to dig', 2) 'to fill' as * kata- / xata- <* k(h)n̥to- and verbal noun * kāna- / * xāna- <* k(h)ā-na- (Cf. Abaev). Less likely to from the verb * kat- / * čat- 'to cover, cover, hide' (Bailey 1979:50). The connection with the verb * kan- 'dig' is rejected by Bartolome [Barth. AiW, 432]. It is possible that these names were already lexicalized in common Iranian in most dialects as “house, structure, room”, in certain languages as “roof”
S.v. Kurd. ǰamad 'мороз, лед', a loanword from Arabic ǰamad 'лед, льдина'.

"I explain this word by an Old Iranian *naχti-čiθra- 'originating in the night' with allusion to the epithet Zor.Pahl. tam-tōχmak (a translation of Av. təmasčiθra-) applied to the wild beasts in Zoroastrian terminology.

"Important for Indo-Iranian interpretation is also Lit. nókti, Let. nãkt. The basic meaning was 'reach, arrive '. Thus we find Lit. nókti 'to ripen' (like NPers. rasīdan 'arrive, ripen') and pranókti, panókti 'overhaul, overtake' beside Let. nãkt 'come', ie-nãkt 'enter', ie-nãkties 'to ripen', panãkt 'over-take'. These assure a base *nãk-. From a similar *nak- we can trace some Iranian words with the sense of 'extension' (from which 'extend up to, reach' is derived). Ossetic näx- in näxstar can be well taken to mean 'extension, open space'. It occurs in rānäxstär un 'to betake oneself' and in fännäxstär with känun and känyn. The word stär, with adjectival stäron, stäjron, refers to a man on expedition or wandering in difficult ways. In Miller's dictionary we have the Nārty stärtä, and in a translation of the Russian Igor poem we have the stärtä for the 'heroes' on a foray. In the first component näx- of näxstäron we have reference to the place of the wandering or foray.
The same *naxa- is to be seen in the first component of Mid. Pers. nxšyr, Mid. Parth. nxšyr- 'wild animals, quarry, hunting' in the Šāhpuhr I inscription as part of the title of the naxčīrpat 'huntsman' (Persian line 30, Parthian 24). This I would now explain as containing *naxa-čarya- 'moving about in the expanse, open spaces, the wilds'. It is equivalent to the Avestan ravasčarāt- rendered by Zor. Pahl. frāxv raftār 'ranging widely'."

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *kauš- 'to fight, struggle, kill', going back to a an ingressive so-formation of IE *keH₂u-, cf. OCS kovati 'to forge', Lith. káuti 'to murder, beat, hew', OHG houwan, OE hēawan, Engl. to hew, etc. The ingressive formation has a direct correspondence in Tocharian A koṣ- B kauṣ- 'to kill, strike down, destroy'.
Cf. s.v. Kurd. kuštin (kuž-) 'убивать', from Old Iranian *kauš-.
Cf. s.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (IEW 535).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *grabH- 'to grab, seize, take' < PIE *gʰrebh₂-
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' < PIE *gʷʰen- 'to slay, kill'.
S.v. Proto-Iranian *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' < PIE *gʷʰen-.
S.v. OIr. claidid 'il creuse' cf. in Brythonic in W claddu 'creuser, enterrer', Bret. vann. klaouein 'id.', the root is *klad-, cf. clad 'fossé', 1 clas 'id.', claideb 'épée'.
Cf. s.v. *kelh₂- 'schagen' (IEW 545-6).
S.v. Proto-Slavic *kolti 'stab, sting' (ESSJa X 154-156), from PIE *kolH- (cf. Lith. kálti 'beat, forge', Latv. kal̃t 'beat, forge', Lat. calamitas 'damage').
S.v. Lat. cuppa 'coupe'
S.v. Lat. cūpa 'cask, tub, barrel' (variant cuppa). "Probably a non-IE loanword *kū̆p- which was borrowed by and from many languages. This explains, among others, the length of the ū̆."
S.v. Wa. šay- : šit- 'убивать', from Old Iranic *xšay(a)- : xšita- √xšay-.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *xšan- 'to harm, hurt, wound' (> NEIr. > Wa. šit- : šay- 'to kill'?), from PIE *tken- 'to harm' (Gk. κτείνω 'I kill, slay').
S.v. Latv. sist "Vārda cilme nav pilnigi noskaidrota." Etymology uncertain.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *mrauH- 'to say', from PIE *mleuH- 'to speak' (cf. Ved. brav- 'to say, speak' TochB pälw- 'to complain, bewail one's fate', Cz. mluviti 'to speak', ORu. mъlva 'chatter, murmur').  "The root *mrauH- is clearly attested only in Avestan: it has apparently been ousted by the other roots for 'to speak', *u̯ač and *gaub- respectively, in the other Iranian languages"

Cf. s.v. Lith. klaũpti "klękać, padać na kolana" and klùpti "potykać sią, kląkać", connecting OPr. klupstis "kolano, Kny", and deriving from PIE *kleu̯b- (cf. Goth. ushlaupan "skoczyć, poderwać się na nogi", OIc. hlaupa "biec, skakać").
Cf. s.v. *kleu̯b- 'stolpern, hüpfen' [IEW 630].
S.v. Kurd. čōk, čawōk, čōng, čōg 'колено', a loanword from Turkish čök 'id.'

S.v. Wa. brin, bᵊrin 'колено', from Pre-Wakhi *dba-rūna-, where the members are dba- 'two' and rūna- 'thigh' < Proto-Iranic *rāna- 'thigh', The 'two' as a compound member apparently also occurs in Wakhi brət 'elbow'
Cf. s.v. Paš. wrun, run 'thigh' (cf. Av. rāna-, Persian rān).
S.v. 5605 *ḍhōṅga- (1) 'projecting part of body'. [Cf. *ḍhuṅga- ʻ lump ʼ] (> Ash. ḍoṅg, ḍoṅ 'knee', Gaw. ḍuṅgɔ́ 'knee').
S.v. 7586 Lat. sapere 'wissen'. 2. sapēre.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √gā-¹ 'den Fuß aufsetzen (beim Gehen), treten, schreiten' (cf. IIr. OAv. gāt̰ 'soll hingehen', YAv. gāman- 'Schritt', Khot. jsā- 'gehen', etc.), from PIE *gʷeh₂- (cf. Gk. aor. ἔβην 'ging, machte sich auf', βῆμα 'Fußtritt, Schwelle', Lith. (dial.) góti 'gehen', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *gʷeh₂- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten' (IEW 463-4).
Cf. s.v. *u̯elh₁- '(aus)wählen' (IEW 1137).
Cf. s.v. 8699 Skt. prabōdha m. 'awakening' R., 'knowledge' Kāv. [√budh] (> L. *pōh → Psht. pōh ʻ understanding, wise ʼ NTS vii 104).
S.v. Wa. diš- : dišt- 'знать, понимать, уметь', from Old Iranian *daisya- : *ham-daisya-, cf. Av. ham- + daēs- 'учиться', Khot. uysdīś- 'разьяснять'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *dais- (1) 'to show' (> NEIr. + *ham- Wa. diš-/dišt- 'to know, understand, be able'). From PIE *dei̯k̑- 'to show, point out, announce' (cf. Skt. deś- 'to show, point out', Gk. δείκνυμι 'I show', NHG zeigen, Lat. dicere 'to utter, say', Goth. ga-teihan 'to announce, proclaim', etc.).
Cf. s.v. 1. *dei̯k̑- 'zeigen, weisen' (IEW 188-9).

Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' may also be cognate to this class, [cf. {ref Abaev 1959-1995} Vol. II, pp.68-69]. If the Ossetic form it is not a loanword, then the distribution of the lexeme is not exclusively to the European branches of IE.
Cf. Oss. mal 'глубокая стоячая вода', from IE *mōri or *mōryo- 'sea' with regular *r > l before *i.
S.v. Lith. juõkas "żart, śmianie się (z żartu), śmiech", without a good etymology.
Cf. s.v. Ved. śíphā- 'Name eines Flusses', possibly to YAv. saēf- if something like 'darüberstreichen', further connections are uncertain.

S.v. Khot. bāggara- 'leaf', from Ir. *u̯arka-ra- (M.Parth.T. wrkr, Sogd.Bud. wrkr) to base *u̯ark- (Av. varəka-, Zor.P. vark, valg, NPers. barg. To {ref IEW} 1139 *u̯el- (of hair, wool, grass'), with -k- Skt. valká- 'bark', with -k̑- Skt. válśa- 'twig, sprout', Av. varəsa- 'hair', OCS vlasъ 'hair'.

S.v. Ved. valká- 'Bast, Rinde, Splint'; cf. Middle Indic and Prakrit vakka- 'bark'. Probably to be related to YAv. varəka-, Khot. bāggara-, Parth. wrgr, Sogd. wrkr, MPers. warg, NPers. barg 'leaf'. Perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *volknò 'fibre' (< PIE *u̯olk̑-nom, cf. OE wlōh 'fibre, fringe' [no connection to Indo-Iranic lexemes mentioned]).
S.v. Kurd. barg, balg, barū (m.) | barg, balg 'лист', from OIr. *varka- (cf. Av. varka- 'лист (растения)', Skt. valka- 'древесная кора' < {ref IEW} 1139 *u̯el-k-.
S.v. 7969 Skt. pallava- (1) m.n. 'sprout, twig, blossom' MBh.
S.v. Skt. pallavaḥ 'Sproß, Schößling, Zweig' / 'sprout, shoot, twig', not certainly explained.
S.v. 7947 Lat. sinister 'links', 2. sinexter (after dexter).
S.v. AGk. ἀρείων, ἄριστος, ἀριστερός, etc.

S.v. 5539 *ḍavva 'lefthand, crosswise'. 2. *ḍāva- 2. 3. *ḍābba- . 4. *ḍivva- . 5. *ḍēvva- . 6. ḍhēvva- . 7. *dēva- 2. 8. *dēvva- . [Non-Aryan: A. Master BSOAS xii 348 ← Drav.] (M. ḍāvā 'left' < 2. *ḍāva-).
Cf. s.v. no. 449 Ta. iṭai, iṭam 'left side', Te. eḍama 'left, left-hand, left-hand side', etc.
S.v. 2758 *dēramāre 'entästen' (> Vegl. dramuor 'schlachten, töten').

S.v. rāmus 'branch, twig', from PIE *u̯r(e)h₂-(d-)mo-? "Possibly from *rād-mo- < *wrād-mo-, if cognate with rādix 'root'. The semantics can
be justified by referring to Gr. ράδιξ, -ικος 'branch, twig', showing that *ur(e)h₂d- could mean either 'branch' or 'root'."
S.v. Lat. rāmus 'branche, rameau', cf. rādix.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *su̯ar-i̯e/o- 'lachen', from PIE *su̯er- (LIV² 613, *su̯ard- IEW 1040, *su̯er- IEW 1049f.).
S.v. Manx gearaghtee 'laughing' (ScG. gàireachdaich).
S.v. ScG. gàir 'laugh', gàire 'a laugh' (Ir. gáirim, gáire, OIr. gáire (n.)) from root *gar- as OIr. gáir, W gawr (cf. Gk. γῆρυς, Doric γᾶρυς 'voice').
Cf. s.v. *g̑ar- 'tönen, rufen' (IEW 352).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *gar-i̯e/o- 'rufen, schreien' (PIE *g̑ar- LIV 161).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *gar-yo- 'call, cry', from PIE *g̑eh₂r-, cf. Lat. garrīre, Oss. zaryn/zarun 'sing'.

S.v. 6128 Ved. daṇḍá- m. 'stick, club' RV. (> Gaw. ḍaṇḍ-bār 'large broom' (bārik 'broom'), dōṇḍī́k 'stick', ḍḗṇḍī 'calf of leg, shinbone').

S.v. NHG Schenkel (MHG schenkel, MLG schinkel, MDu. sc(h)enkel), a diminutive formation to OE sceanca, MLG schinke 'Schenkel', To this perhaps a with a dissimilated initial position Ved. sákthi- 'Schenkel'. Cf. also 'hinken' in Ved. kháñjati, Gk. σκάζω, and without s-mobile NHG hinken.

S.v. PGmc. *skankaz ~ *skankōn- sb.m. (Norw. skank 'shank', OE sceanca, LG schanke, OHG scanc 'rack, cupboard'), derived from *skankaz adj. related to Gk. σκάζω 'to limp' < *skn̥gi̯ō, MIr. scingim 'to spring'.
Cf. s.v. PGmc. *skanka- 'schief', from which E scanca 'Unterschenkel, Schienbein' etc.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √sthā- 'stehen, dastehen, still stehen, verweilen' (OAv., YAv. xšta-, YAv. hišta- 'stehen'; paiti-stā- 'Standort'), from PIE *steh₂- (cf. Gk. ἵστημι, Lat. sistere, status 'stellen', OHG stān 'stehen', Lith. stóti 'sich hinstellen', Latv. stât 'stellen', OCS stati 'sich stellen, treten', Luw. ta- 'stehen, zum Stehen kommen').

S.v. 8201 Skt. pipīlá- m. 'ant' RV., °laka- m. 'large black ant' ChUp., pipī́likā- f. 'small red ant' AV., pīlaka- m. 'ant' lex.; also reconstructed *piphīla- . 3. *pippīla- . 4. *pipphīla- . 5. *pippīḍa- . 6. *pilīla-. [Variety of MIA. and NIA. forms for 'ant' may be due partly to its (unknown) non-Aryan origin (EWA ii 285), partly to contamination with kīṭá- and kŕ̥mi-, but mainly to some sort of taboo for a noxious insect. Although there appear to be six main types, not all NIA. forms can be grouped exactly under them]

S.v. B kātse, A kāts 'belly, abdomen, womb'; etymology disputed. Traditionally to Goth. qiϸus 'stomach', but there are morphological and morphophonological difficulties. Possibly with TochA kāc 'skin' with semantic development from 'sack' to 'belly', as though CT *kʷātså < IE *kuH-ti̯-eh₂-.
S.v. B keni, A kanweṃ 'two knees' CT *kænw- reflects PIE *g̑onu̯- (cf. Gk. γόνυ 'knee', Skt. jā́nu 'id.').

S.v. A knā- 'to know', connected to IE *g̑neh₃- 'to know' and the A pres. stem *knānā- is more or less equivalent to the stem of Ved. jānā́ti on the basis of an IE stem *g̑n̥-n-(e)h₃-, but remodelled in a different manner.

S.v. B kery- 'to laugh', A kary- 'id.'. "{ref van Windekens 1976}:188 associates this verb – probably correctly – with Lat. horior 'I encourage', Skt. háryati 'likes, desires', Gk. χαίρω 'I rejoice' to IE *g̑ʰer- 'rejoice in, desire'."

S.v. A kñuk 'neck'. Two early propsals to either OIc. knjúkr 'round mountain summit', MHG knock 'neck' < *gneugo- (van Windekens 1941: 42), or to IE *kneugo-, cf. OIc. hnjúkr 'rounded mountain summit' (Duchesne-Guillemin 1941: 157) are semantically satisfactory. Pedersen's (1944: 29) connection to OE hnekka- 'neck', OIc. hnakki 'id.' is semantically more satisfactory but there is no evidence in Germanic for a *-kw-. "This proposal might therefore be rejected as well. Instead the following might be considered. Assuming A kñuk, through *kñäkw, reflects CT *kñäkwæ, this word may go back to IE *knigʷʰo- 'neck (lit. 'the one that bows or bends')' to the root *kneigʷʰ- 'to bow', cf. Goth. hneiwan 'to bow', OHG hnīgan 'to bow, bend', OIcel. hníga 'to sink down', hneigja 'to bow' etc."
S.v. B käly- 'to stand', A käly- 'id.', since van Windekens 1941:33 to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to incline', cf. Skt. śráyati 'to lean'.

S.v. B kauṃ, A koṃ 'sun; day', the proposed connection with Gk. καίω 'I set fire to, kindle' is attractive', and simpler than and more preferable than the etymology to IE *kaih₂o- suggested by Hilmarsson 1991a: 187.

S.v. B karītsñe (hapax) '?', probably also to an adj. *karītstse*) "In its context one might guess that karītsñe means 'heat', vel sim. but that is quite uncertain […]. Etymological speculation is futile."
S.v. TochB ku, kū, TochA ku, kū 'dog', clearly continuing the IE word for 'dog' (cf. Skt. ś(u)vā́, Gk. κύων, etc.).
S.v. TochB kau- 'to kill, slay, strike down', A ko- 'id.', derived from PIE *keh₂u- 'to hew, cut down, strike' (cf. Lith. kaúti 'to strike, hammer; fight', OHG houwwan 'hew', etc.).

S.v. B koyṃ, A koyäṣ 'mouth', "traditionally – and correctly – associated with the root *g̑ʰeh₁i- 'to gape, open up' […] [h]owever, various details have under any explanation been left obscure, partly because non-existent A ko has been taken into account."

S.v. OPers. kau̯fa- 'Berg, Gebirge', from Iranic *kau̯fa- = YAv. kaofa- 'Berg; (Kamel-)Höcker'. Its original meaning was perhaps 'hump'.

Cf. s.v. √gar-ⁱ (2) 'verschlingen' (Mi., ni. s. pkt. giraï, gilaï 'verschlingt' etc.), to PIE *gʷerh₃-, cf. Arm. e-ker 'aß', Gk. βιβρώσκω 'esse, verzehre' Lat. vorāre 'verschlingen, gierig essen', Lith. gérti 'trinken', etc.

Cf. s.v. Alb. grykë 'throat', from PAlb. *grīwīkā and related to IE *gʷrīu̯ā 'neck' (Skt. grīvā́, Av. grīvā, Latv. grĩva 'river mouth', Slav. *griva 'mane' (Orel Linguistica XXIV 438). Camarda 65 (correctly links grykë to IE *gʷer- 'to swallow, eat').

Cf. s.v. ngrë́në / ngrãnë 'essen, verzehren; speisen; fressen; verschlingen; beißen; abnagen', without doubt that the stem of the formation -grënë / (-)grãne (< Alb. (-)*granⁿǝ) to be connected to Ved. giráti 'verschlingen', Lat. vorō 'id.'. {ref Jokl 1937}:139ff. further connects grýkë, gurmaz 'Hals'. etc. To root *gʷerh₃-.

S.v. Proto-Iranic (1) *kah- : kas- 'открывать(-ся), отверзать, разверзать', cf. Ved. kas- 'трескаться, раскалывать(-ся) from PIE *kas- or *kʷas- (not *kes-), from which is derived Proto-Iranic *kāhman-, or *kāman- > Oss. kom 'рот', Chor. bž-kʾm, pž-kʾm 'криворотый, тот, у кого кривой рот'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √kas- 'bersten, sich spalten, brechen', etymology unclear. {ref Abaev 1959–1995} I:599 connects Iranian words like Oss. kom 'Mund, Öffnung, Spalte' < *kahman-.
S.v. Wa. ɣ̌aṣ̌ 'рот, пасть, устье', from OIr. *γastra, γaštra-, from the root √gaṣ, cf. Av. gah- 'есть, жрать', Ved. ghásati 'ест'; Chor. γš 'зуб' < *gaštra-, Yag. γāx̌, γax̌ 'рот', etc.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to gorge', cf. Skt. ghas- 'to eat, devour'. Plausible cognates outside of Indo-Iranic are lacking.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √ghas- 'essen, verzehren' (IIr. cf. YAv. gah- 'essen, fressen (von daēuuischen Wesen)'. Further connections are not securely ascertained.
Cf. s.v. ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'essen, fressen, verzehren' (IEW 452). Only IIr., further connections uncertain.
S.v. Shughni γǟv 'mouth; opening, entrance'.
S.v. 2680 Ved. kaṇṭhá- m. (a) 'throat, neck' ŚBr. (b) 'narrowest part of a hole' Suśr. (c) 'voice' MBh., 'sound' W. (d) '*border, immediate proximity' Pañcat. ((a) > Si. kaṭa 'throat, mouth').
S.v. Ved. kaṇṭha- 'Hals'. Etymology unclear. Perhaps to the family of Kan. gaṇṭ(a)lu- etc. 'throat' ({ref Burrow & Emeneau 1984}:127).
S.v. PGmc. *maiwa- 'schmal, schlank', a wa-adjective only attested in North Germanic < *moiu̯o- (cf. TochB maiwe 'klein, jung' on the basis of PIE *meiu̯- in PGmc. *minwizan-.
S.v. 8305 Lat. strictus 'eng'.
S.v. 7736 Skt. pattralá- 'leafy' lex. 2. '*leaflike, thin'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. pátra- Flügel (eines Vogels), Feder', derived from a heteroclitic *pat-r-/*pat-n- and cognate with Germ. Feder, Engl. feather, Old Welsh eterin 'bird', atan 'wing', etc., cf. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschießend fliegen, stürzen, fallen' from PIE *pet- (cf. Lat. petō, Gk. πέτομαι, etc.).
Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.
Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².
S.v. Kurd. tang 'тесный, узкий, стесненный, тонкий, тугой, душный', from IIr. *tanka-, cf. Pers. tang, MPers. tang, Bel. tanak, Zaza tang, etc.
S.v. Pā. sambādha, cf. Skt. sambādha-.
S.v. Ved. √bādh- 'verdrängen, bedrängen, bedrücken', mi., dard. ni., pā. bādhati 'bedrückt, behindert', usw. (IIr. cf. YAv. auui.bāδ(a)-) without certain further connections.
PIE *(s)tég-es- n. 'covering'

The Brittonic forms MW, MCorn., OBr., MBr. nos 'night' etc. are based on *nox(s)s < PIE *nókʷts. Contrary to this, it is traditionally assumed that nos is based on a suffixed form PCl. *noxt-stu-, as suggested by Pedersen (1909, 123) and followed e.g. by Fleuriot (1964a, 271), Matasović (2009, 294). PIE *nokʷ-t- is also found in the adverb OW henoid, MW henoeth, MBr. henoez, MCorn. haneth 'tonight', lit. 'this night', which contains pronominal *se- or *so- as a first element and Dat/Loc.Sg. PCl. *noxt-i or AccSg. *noxt-am as a second (Schrijver 1997, 24).
S.v. *sen- 'alt' (IEW 907f., EIEC 409).

From OBr. guoath, guoeth, goeth 'stream. Cognate with OCorn. guid, MCorn. gwyth, goth, MW guyth, W gwyth 'vein, sinew; stream, brook; channel; estuary', OIr. féith 'fibre, sinew; swamp, marsh'.
Further cognate: Latin vitta 'ribbon, cord'.

In Olr. there is also feith [f] which means 'sinew', but also 'kidney'
(in the glosses); this is probably just a homonym of feith 'swamp' (as suggested by DIL). It is probably the same word as W gwythi [p] 'veins'. These words are usually derived from the root *weyh₁- 'twist, turn' (IEW 1122), but this is dubious on semantic grounds. PIE *weyh₁- 'wither' (IEW 1123) is a better candidate (cf. PCelt. *wiwo- 'withered'). The Brit. reflexes point to a double stop (*-tt-) in PCelt., but the Olr. form is derivable from PCelt. *weta with a single *-t-.
Discusses the formal problems of this difficult cognate set, i.e. different suffixes in Irish and Brittonic, simple -t- in Irish vs. -tt- in Brittonic, underlying PIE roots.
s.v. rivier 'fleuve, rivière', variant forms riñvier, reñvier, rinier.

Does not accept the Celtic etymology *stagrā originally proposed by Henry (1900, 253) and repeated by several recent etymological dictionaries. 
He follows Trépos 1954 instead, who suggested that OBr. staer, ModBr. ster 'river' was borrowed from Latin aestuarium, Vulgar Latin estuarium, esterium 'étier, an inlet, etc., covered by the sea at high tide, tidal opening; a river estuary'. There are no words supporting the alleged Celtic *stagrā in the other Celtic languages. The oldest attestations for OBr ster are the rivernames found in the Cartulaire de Redon (10th or 11th c.) like Stergavale, Stergaule fluvius. In the 13th c., the Cartulaire of Landévennec notes "an-Staer " (containing the definite article) as a name of an estate. At the same time, legal documents contain place-names like Banastère (1300-1305), Benester (1300), Beneistier, Benetier (1365), Staerguezel (1366), Lestoer, Listoir (1434). While some of these names render Breton in Old French orthography, others are hybrid forms employing estoir, estier, the Old French continuation of Latin aestuarium. 
OBr. staer has become the word for 'river' in the Modern dialects of Léon, Landéda, a part of Cornouaille and around the Golf of Morbihan. But iits original meaning is broader like in Latin. Regionally, ster means 'river mouth, estuary', 'saltworks' or 'washhouse, washplace'.
Latin estuarium is neuter, while Breton ster has feminine instead of the expected masculine gender. Trépos argues it could have been influenced by aven f., the word for river used by the Brittonic immigrants.

Br. rivier 'river' is attested from the Middle Breton period onwards. The word is cited as riuyer in the Catholicon (1499). It was borrowed from Old or Middle French riviere f. 'rive, rivage, seashore, coast', first attested in the 12th century.

OBr. goed 'stream, ruisseau' (with d representing [θ]) is first attested in dol goed, a plant-name 'potamot, epis d'eau; caprifolium, woodbine'. The literal meaning is 'leaf/leaves of the stream'. The Breton word corresponds to Middle Irish duille féithe 'caprifolium, woodbine'.

Br. ster from Latin estuarium, esterium 'étier; an inlet, etc., covered by the sea at high tide, tidal opening; a river estuary' is found in place-names, either on its own or compounded. Ster as first element: Ster-goz, Ster-zu, Ster-Kreiz, Sternalé, Sterlan, Stervins, etc. Ster as second element: Pen-er-Ster, Pont-Ster, Kerester, etc.

OBr hep is attested twice as a citation verb, cf. hep Augustus 'says Augustus' (Angers 477A fo. 47b) and hep Teopil in suo libro 'says Teophil in his book' (Angers 477A fo, 80b).
The fragmentary OBr sources do not contain any information about further finite forms of this verb, but it seems likely that OBr hep is defective like MW heb and that its use was restricted to the marking of citations. OBr hep is thus not the target.

Attested as a second element in the three compounded nouns OBr. he-labar, dar-leber-iat and torleberieti.
OBr. he-laber gl. graecus, 'who speaks good, is eloquent' (Fleuriot 1964a, 208)
OBr. dar-leber, probably abbreviated for darleberiat gl. phitonicus (for pythonicus) 'soothsayer' (Fleuriot 1964a, 129)
OBr. tor-leberieti gl. phitonistarum (pythonistarum) 'of the soothsayers'. Plural of a noun torleberiat, which contains leberiat 'sayer, one who says' (Fleuriot 1964a, 316)
In OBr. attested as the first member of several compounds like mor-bran gl. merges 'cormoran', lit. 'sea-raven' or mor-moch gl. delphini 'dolphin', lit. 'sea-pig'.
The simple noun is attested in the Catholicon (1499), but the compound armor m. 'coast' is found already in 1384.

In gloss: gueledint ou nimer 'were seen in their (big) number' (Angers 477A, fo. 14b).
Seems to correspond to MW gwelydeint 'were seen'.
See p. 191 for a list of all instances of the verbal root OBr. guel-, guil- 'to see'.
OBr. att 'seed, grain' with ommission of etymologic initial h-.
OBr att, MBr., NBr., MW, W had, Corn. has from PCl. *sato-.

Celtic has two different stems: 
PIE *seh₁-lo- in W, B, hil, OIr. síl 'seed, offspring'; PIE *sh₁-to- > PCl. satom in W, B had, Corn. has 'seed, grain'

The feminine forms of the adjective MW cron (vs. mask. crwn) and OBr. cron have lowering of the root vowel which is normally caused by *-ā and thus unexpected in the case of the i-stem *krundi-. According to LEIA, this is the result of an assimilation to the o/ā-stems.
Attested in cron gl. tornatili 'round', cronn main gl. cylindro, salin cron 'la saline ronde' and cronion pl. gl. assiles 'rounded, round'.

In OBr. only attested in the compounds guascot and pl. guascotou gl. frigora 'shadowy/sheltered places'. Compounded with the prefix guo- 'under' (developed into gua-) and scot 'shadow', i.e. *u̯o-skātu- < *upo-skātu-. The OBr. word has exact cognates in MW gwascaut m. 'shadow' and Oir. foscad (n., u, later o) 'shadow, shelter'.

Cf. s.v. TochA kñuk 'neck'. Two early propsals to either OIc. knjúkr 'round mountain summit', MHG knock 'neck' < *gneugo- (van Windekens 1941: 42), or to IE *kneugo-, cf. OIc. hnjúkr 'rounded mountain summit' (Duchesne-Guillemin 1941: 157) are semantically satisfactory. Pedersen's (1944: 29) connection to OE hnekka- 'neck', OIc. hnakki 'id.' is semantically more satisfactory but there is no evidence in Germanic for a *-kw-. "This proposal might therefore be rejected as well. Instead the following might be considered. Assuming A kñuk, through *kñäkw, reflects CT *kñäkwæ, this word may go back to IE *knigʷʰo- 'neck (lit. 'the one that bows or bends')' to the root *kneigʷʰ- 'to bow', cf. Goth. hneiwan 'to bow', OHG hnīgan 'to bow, bend', OIcel. hníga 'to sink down', hneigja 'to bow' etc."

Cf. s.v. TochA kñuk 'cou, nuque' For this term we may connect either IE *gneug- with OIc. knjūkr 'cime d'une montagne', MHG knock 'nuque' or with IE *qnequ̯- with OE hnecca, OIc. hnakki 'nuque', or with IE *qneug- with OIc. hnūka 'se tenir accroupi, s'accroupir', Mod. Ic. knjūkr 'cime de montagne ronde', etc.For these three interpretations cf. Van Windekens, Orbis 11 (1962) 506. In any of these cases TochA kñuk may have a common etymon with Germanic.
"Pedersen's connection of W gwddw(g), B gouzoug 'neck, throat' with Goth. gatwo 'street, path' ({ref Pedersen 1909}: 63) is highly uncertain."
S.v. Kâmviri mârʹaňiŋ  N.  Back of neck.  [mâraňaᴺi¹ᴺkᴺ]  [pâm'arařiŋ]  [OIA. maṇi- ‘hump; Adam's apple’  T. 9732 (?)]

S.v. 9732 maṇi- (2) m. 'hump of camel' MBh., 'glans penis' Suśr., 'clitoris' lex., 'fleshy excrescence on a goat's neck' VarBr̥S., 'thyroid cartilege (= kaṇṭhamaṇi- ), wrist' lex., maṇika- m. 'globular formation of flesh on an animal's shoulder' AitBr., maṇilá- 'having fleshy excrescences (e.g. on the dewlap)' TS. [Semantic development is prob. 'protuberance – Adam's apple <-> throat, neck', hence connexion with mányā- and (despite EWA ii 557) with maṇí- 1 is unlikely]
Cf. s.v. Ved. maṇi- 'am Hals getragener Schmuck', IIr. mani- < PIE *monh₂-i- (~ *moneh₂-) 'Hals' (cf. OHG mana 'Mähne' etc.).
Cf. s.v. Skt. maṇi- 'am Halse getragener Schmuck, Perle, Edelstein, Juwel' / 'necklace, pearl, gem, jewel', to mányā- 'Hals, Nacken', cf. for discussion of proposals of a possible loanword origin.
S.v. Kurd. mil (m.) 'плечо, шея; рука, рукав', from IIr. *mr̥z-, cf. Av. mərəzu-, OPers. *mrdu- 'позвонок', MPers. mrd' (*mrda-) 'шея', Gor., Zaza mil, Avrom. möł 'затылок, шея', Lur. mell 'шея'.
S.v. YAv. (1) mərəzav- n. ''Wirbel' des Halses und Rückens'. Et. & Bed.?

S.v. TochB krāñi 'neck, nape (of the neck)', probably reflecting CT *krāñ-äy- < *krāñ-än-, ultimately (as though) reflecting PIE *k̑r̥h₂-n-en-, an n-stem formation to *k̑r̥h₂-n- to the root of *k̑er-h₂- 'head'.
S.v. ScG. amhach 'neck', < *om-âk-â- (cf. Lat. humerus 'shoulder' < *om-es-os, Gk. ὦμος, Goth. amsa, Skt. amsas).
S.v. Kurd. stu, stū, stō 'шея' (K.) 'затылок' (S.). Continuing Old Iranian *stū-, *stav-, a variant of the root *stā- 'стоять', cf. Av. stūna-, Ved. sthūṇa- 'столб', Oss. astæw 'поясница', etc.

Cf. s.v. Ved. sthū́ṇā- 'Pfosten, Pfeiler, Säule', IIr. cf. YAv. stūnā-, OPers. stūnā- 'Säule', Khot. stunā- 'Pfeiler', MPers. stūn, NPers. sutūn 'Säule, Pfeiler', etymologically probably to be connected with Ved. sthūrá- 'groß, stark, dick' < *stuh₂-ró-.

Discusses the different morphological analyses that have been suggested for the Celtic material. The preforms *scātu-, scōtu- or *scōto- could be tu- or to-formations of a root *sk̑eh₂- or *sk̑eh₃-, or, less likely, a root noun *skōt- with later thematisation.
*skek- 'to move around, to jump'

OIr. scál n. o 'phantom, supernatural being, hero' is probably cognate to MW ysgawl 'young hero'. O'Brien, Ériu 11 (1932) 89 compares this to Goth. skōhsl, which translates Gr. daímōn 'demon' in the Bible. Both are based on *skōk-slo- from the PIE root *skek-. Further cognates are Ir. scuchid 'parts, disappears' and possibly Ir. scén 'horror, panic'.
Follows the analysis proposed by  Vendryes et al. 1959–1996 Pages: S-30.
OIr. scál is a neuter o-stem, but in later sources, it is also fem.

The attested form si-scuint is 3pl. pres. subj. with the intensifying prefix si-. It is based on a stem sco-* oder scu-*. Cf. the cognate noun Old Breton sco 'blow, stroke'.
From *sk̑eu̯- 'to hit, to throw, to shoot' (IEW 953f.) or *skeu̯d- 'to throw, to shoot' (IEW 954f. = *skeu̯d- 'to drive, to push' LIV² 560)?
If related to OBr. nom 'curve' rather from *nem- 'to bend' (LIV² 463) than connected with words meaning 'cloud'.

S.v. 719 Skt. alupta 'not cut off, undiminished' Kālid. [lupta- 2: √lup] (>
Pa. alutta- 'unreduced'; Si. alut 'new, fresh').
Cf. s.v. *reu̯p- 'brechen, (zer)reißen (intr.)' (IEW 870). Präsens *ru-né/n-p- > Ved. (AV) lumpáti 'zerbricht etw.'
Cf. s.v. Ved. √lop- 'zerbrechen, beschädigen, beseitigen, zunichte machen', originally with Ved. √rop-, also PIE *reu̯p-/*rup-/*ru-N-p-e- (Lat. rumpere).
S.v. Wa. ṣ̌əɣ̌d 'новый, свежий; снова, недавно'. Etymology unclear. {ref Morgenstierne 1938}:543 compares Shughni šuvde 'младший'.
S.v. Wa. ṣ̌əɣd 'new' "cf. Shgh. (Sk.) šəvdä 'the younger'?"
Brittonic *oepr possibly cognate with Lat. aequor 'level surface, the sea'; cf. l'expression aequora caeli.
ModBr oabl m. 'sky, firmament', V èbr (< *oebr), MW wybyr f. 'sky' < Proto-Brittonic *ẹ̄pl-V- or *ẹ̄pr-V-
Cf. s.v. PGmc. naƀjan, to be derived from naƀō and connected with Skt. nábhya- 'nave (of a wheel)', nā́bhi- 'navel, nave', OPr. nabis 'id.' Latv. naba 'navel'.
S.v. Paš. pˈoza 'nose', "hardly directly < *pauzā- […] but via Prs poz(a) 'muzzle, snout, parts around the mouth'" cf. Bal. pō(n)z 'nose' (LWs < Prs or Pš?).
From the root PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to see', Br. oabl, W wybren 'sky' lit. 'horizon, Gesichtskreis'.

"As Pokorny pointed out (1960), MW trwyn, OCo. trein 'nose' reflect *trugnV-, with -u- in view of Continental Celtic *trugna- reflected in Romance ({ref Meyer-Lübke 1935}: 8947). The different vocalism renders an etymological identification of W ffroen (with -o-, Continental Celtic *frogna) with trwyn, which was advocated by Meid (1960:44; 1960a: 268), impossible."

S.v. nǟj Š; nēj XR, nōj BO; noj S; neǰ Y 'nose', "cf. Sogd. nyc 'nostrils' < *nāh(y)a-či-; not (with Meillet, BSL 23, 108) < *nahya-či, or (with Gersh. 247) < *nāhikā-. Khwar. nʾc, f. nʾh, but Yaghn. nays < *nāsya-, if not for *nayc."
Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4).

S.v. Khot. haysga- 'nostril', pl. 'nose', from *hazg- to fra-zga- 'to smell' from following the scent as in Av. vohuna-zga- 'clinging to the blood', Arm. LW zgam 'feel, hear, know, to scent', cognates cf. s.v. aysagamu-, ajs- 'to cling to, pursue', to be connected with Ved. sájati, saktá- 'cling to'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *ha(n)j- 'to hang (on), cling on', from PIE *seg- 'to adhere' (cf. Skt. sa(ñ)j- 'to adhere, hang (on)', Lith. segù 'I adhere', ?OIr. sén 'safety net (for catching birds)'.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √sañj- 'heften, hängen', IIr. cf. OPers. frahǰm /frāhaǰam/ 'ich hängte', Khot. ajs- 'verfolgen, nachsetzen', probably from PIE *seg-, cf. Lith. segù 'hefte, beschlage', MIr. sén 'Fangnetz (zum Vogelfang)', etc.
Cf. s.v. 1. *seg- 'heften, anhängen' (IEW 887-8).
S.v. Kurd. difn 'нос, ноздря'. To be compared with Persian dam-īdan, Av. dam- 'дуть', in this case it would proceed from OIr. *dam-na- > *dav-n > *dafn.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *damH-³ 'to blow, breathe; to swell', from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. Skt. dham-ⁱ 'to blow, play a wind instrument, fan the fire', OCS dъmǫ 'to blow', Lith. dùmti 'to blow (also of wind)'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen', OCS dъmǫ 'blase').
S.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-8)
S.v. Kurd. ¹lūt 'нос', cf. Gor. lūt 'нос' [No further etymology].
From Proto-Celtic *stagrā and cognate with Gk. σταγών 'drop', στάζω 'drip', Lat. stāgnum 'pool'.
S.v. PGmc. *ʒamalaz "Probably related to Lat. humilis 'low', Gk. χθαμαλός 'near the ground, low' (Szemerényi Word VIII 50)."
S.v. B ktsaitse 'aged', A ktsets 'perfect, achieved'.
S.v. Wa. x(i)yár 'старый, пожилой', a borrowing from Persian hūšyār 'умный, трезвый' ({ref Morgenstierne 1938}:552).
Compares OBr. to Latin and Greek.

OBr. limn gl. lentum 'soft, supple, flexible'. Also in the compounds 
 limn-collin gl. tilia 'lime-tree', limn-collou gl. tiliiae 'lime-trees' (literally: 'soft hazel-tree(s)); gur-limun or gur-limnn gl. diliniti 'softened, corrupted'.
OBr. becan, bican < becc- + suffix -an.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √kā- 'begehren, gern haben', from PIE *keh₂- cf. Lat. cā-rus, 'lieb, wert', Goth. ho-rs 'Ehebrecher, Hurer' etc.
Cf. s.v. *keh₂- 'begehren' (IEW 515).
S.v. Du. trekken 'naar zich toe halen, slepen; gaan'.
Cf. s.v. 5524 *ḍagga- (2) 'defective'.

S.v. Goth. *dragan (only 3pl. pres. -and 'ἐπισωρεύειν', 'accumulate, take on'. Etymology uncertain; PIE *dh(e)rāgh- 'pull' Walde-Pokorny 1927-1932 I:862, possibly Lat. trahō 'pull' according to Walde 1906 IF 19:106 by dissimilation from *dhraghō.
S.v. 10954 Skt. lámbate 'hangs down, loiters' MBh. [~ rámbatē. - √lamb] (> K. lamun 'to pull, pull at, tow').
Cf. s.v. *lembH- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 656-7); Präsens *lémbH-e- > Ved. rámbate 'hängt (schlaff) herab'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √ramb- 'schlaff herabhängen (vom Penis). Later √lamb- 'hängt herab (vorwiegend von Körperteilen gesagt)', perhaps to PIE *(s)lembʰ- (cf. Engl. limp, MHG lampen, slampen).
S.v. 3881 *khiñc- 'to drag, pull'
Cf. s.v. *temk- 'fest werden, gerinnen' (IEW 1068).
S.v. Š. tāž : tīžd, S tož : tīžd 'to pull, draw, haul, drag, stretch'.

S.v. Skt. mŕ̥ṣā 'umsonst, irrig', 'in vain, uselessly, wrongly' to Skt. mŕ̥ṣyate 'vergißt, vernachlässigt, ist lässig' / 'forgets, neglects', outside of Indo-Iranian cf. Arm. moṙanam 'vergesse', Lith. mir̃šti, už-mir̃šti 'vergessen', maršùs 'vergeßlich', TochAB märs- 'vergessen'.
S.v. Ved. √marṣ- 'vergessen', from PIE *mers- 'vergessen', cf. Arm. moṙana-, Lith. už-mir̃šti, TochAB märs- 'vergessen'.
Cf. s.v. *mers- 'vergessen' (IEW 737-8).
S.v. 3048 Lat. expingere 'ausstoßen' (zu pangere) > it. spingere, etc.; 4309 Lat. impingere 'hineinstoßen' > Rum. împinge.
S.v. ScG. put 'to thrust, push' from Scots put 'push, thrust', M.Eng. putten 'push', now Eng. put.

S.v. Lith. stùmti "pchać, popychać, trącać, szturchać, sunąć,
suwać, odsuwać zasuwą drzwi, wtłaczać, wypychać, odpychać, naglić, nacierać". Without good etymology. If -um- is a reflex of *m̥, then it is possible to posit *stm̥H- to * stemH- "to push"
S.v. gwthiaf, gythiaf: gwthio, gythio 'to push, shove', denominal to gwth 'a push, lunge, thrust'. Root etymology uncertain, either to *ĝhei- or *u̯ei-.
S.v. 11392 Ved. varṣá- n. 'rain' RV., pl. 'the Rains' AV. 2. 'year' ŚBr. [√vr̥ṣ]
S.v. 6620 Lat. pluvia 'Regen', 2. plovia, 3. ploia.
S.v. Oss. k'væda 'дождь, ненастье', Of uncertain origin, perhaps a loan from Caucasian cf. Gruz. k'ad-va 'flow'

ModBr. stêr 'river' originates from Old French estier 'canal', which comes from Lat. aestuarium 'estuary'. Its use in the modern dialects is restricted to Vannetais and Western Cornouaille. At a very early time, it superseded the Brittonic word avon. Gives a list of place-names and river names containing stêr.
Lists place-names containing 'aven', e.g. Coetaven (1444), Pen-Aven (1672). These are all located in the departement Finistère (29).

In Middle Breton, auon 'river' is known and used by educated people. The example from the Catholicon illustrates its use in a religious context. In this context, it probably was also current to illiterate speakers. It remains however unclear, if it was the Swadesh term for 'river'. Place-names with auon are restricted to Western Brittany, and it is not used any more in Modern Breton.
The Catholicon also has an entry for riuyer, borrowed from French. This word is used today in Treger Breton.  The Gwened word gwaz is listed s.v. goaz with the equivalents Middle French russeau, Latin hic riuulus. It denotes thus smaller water courses in Middle Breton.
Cf. s.v. Kâmviri âgʹol  NSb.  Rain. [OIA. a-kâla- ‘out of time; unseasonable’  T. 11 (modern compound; -T. 1977.2 *ud-ghâla- 'pouring out')]
S.v. 1008 Skt. ākāśá- m. 'sky' ŚBr. [√kāś].

Cf. s.v. Ved. √kāś- 'sichtbar werden, erscheinen', from which is derived ākāśá- 'freier Raum, Luftraum, Öffnung', perhaps to PIE *kʷek̑-, if the root is connected with Gk. τέκμωρ, τέκμαρ 'Zeichen, Merkmal'.
Cf. s.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9).
Cf. s.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9).

Cf. s.v. 11 akāla- 'out of time' MBh., m. 'wrong time', 1977 *udghāra- 'pouring out'. 2. *udghāla- . [√ghr̥- (1)]
S.v. 6732 Skt. dhamana n. 'blowing with bellows' lex. [√dham-] (Paš.lauṛ. dāmān, kuṛ. domón, uzb. damūn 'rain' < *'storm') "These Kaf. and Dard. forms altern. < dhmāna-?"
Cf. s.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-8)
S.v. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen', OCS dъmǫ 'blase').
Cf. s.v. *peh₃(i̯)- 'trinken' (IEW 839-40).
S.v. 570 Lat. aqua 'Wasser'.
S.v. 3585 Skt. kravyá- 'bloody, raw' TS., n. 'raw flesh, carrion' Nir. 2. *kraviya- . [kráviṣ-] (2. > Kho. krui 'red, bloodshot, reddish brown, auburn, crimson').
Cf. s.v. *kreu̯h₂- '(geronnenes) Blut, Blut außerhalb des Korpers' (IEW 621f.)

S.v. Ved. kraviṣ- 'rotes, blutiges Fleisch', from PIE *kreu̯h₂-s- from *kreu̯h₂- ~ *kruh₂- with which AGk. κρέας 'Fleisch' is identical. Closely related is also Lat. cruor 'rotes, dickes Blut', Lith. kraũjas 'Blut', OPol. kry, etc.

S.v. Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made' (IIr. cf. Manichaean Sogd. kyrm- 'Schlange', MPers. klm (kirm) 'Wurm, Drache, Schlange', NPers. kirm 'Wurm, Schlange'), from PIE *kʷr̥mi- (cf. OIr. cruim, W., Bret. pryf 'Wurm', Lith. kirmìs 'Wurm, Schlange', Sloven. čr̂m 'Fingerwurm, Karbunkel', etc.). Beside *kʷr̥mi- exists "a rhyme formation in Indo-European probably for reason of tabu" *u̯r̥mi- (NHG Wurm, cf. Lat. vermis), (so Watkins 1987:288).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √sañj- 'heften, hängen', IIr. cf. OPers. frahǰm /frāhaǰam/ 'ich hängte', Khot. ajs- 'verfolgen, nachsetzen', probably from PIE *seg-, cf. Lith. segù 'hefte, beschlage', MIr. sén 'Fangnetz (zum Vogelfang)', etc.
Cf. s.v. 1. *seg- 'heften, anhängen' (IEW 887-8).
S.v. Skt. sajjaḥ 'mit Bogensehne versehen; fertig, bereit' / 'having a bow-string; ready, prepared', cf. sájati.
S.v. Wa. wʊrzg(ə) 'правый' (о руке), cf. Av. ərəzu-.
Cf. s.v. 4635 Lat. jūstus 'gerecht, recht'
S.v. Lat. iūs, -ris 'law', with deriv. adj. iūstus 'lawful, just', from PIE *h₂oi-u-, gen. *h₂i-eu-s 'vital force, eternity' >> s-stem *h₂ieu-os-, -es-.

"Zu lat. iūs, das wegen alat. iovestod (iūstō? CIL I² 1, Forum-Inschr.) iovesat (iūrat?) CIL 1² 4, Duenos-Inschr.) zunächst auf *i̯ou̯-es- zurückgeführt werden kann, s. auch WH I 733f., Schrijver 1991, 273f. Szemerényi loc. cit. 170f. bevorzugt Anschluß an *i̯eu̯- 'verbinden' (LIV 314), Willi HS 114 (2001) 136f. erwägt Zusammenhang mit *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'in Bewegung geraten' (LIV 225f.), dessen eigene Rekonstruktion freilich zu modifizieren sei, schleißt aber Verbindung zu ved. yóḥ, aav. yaoš- wiederum nicht aus. s. ferner Willi, Ériu 52 (2002), 235ff."
S.v. 3952 Ved. gáṅgā f. 'the river Ganges' RV. (> Si. gan̆ga, pl. gaṅ 'river')

S.v. Ved. gáṅgā- 'Flußname, Ganges' "Originally only a appellative 'Fluß' and a reduplicated formation to √gam-? Although this etymology might be possible, it is just as likely that it is a pre-IE river name.
S.v. 13415 Ved. síndhu- f. 'river, the Indus', m. 'flow (in general), sea' RV. (> Kho. sin).
S.v. Ved. síndhu- 'Fluß, Strom; der Indus'. Etymology unexplained.

S.v. 13415 Ved. síndhu- f. 'river, the Indus', m. 'flow (in general), sea' RV.
S.v. Lat. valles, vallis 'val, vallée', maybe to the group of uoluō 'turn'?
S.v. 3943 *khōla- (2) 'cavity, hollow'. 2. *khōlla- 2. 3. *khōḍa- . 4. *khōra -- 2. [Cf. Par. khur ʻ cave ʼ IIFL i 265] (> N. kholo 'small river, valley')
S.v. 6788 Ved. dhā́ra- (2) 'stream' in dhā́ra-pūta- RV., adj. 'streaming down' Suśr., m. 'heavy rain' Hariv. 2. dhā́rā- 1 f. 'stream, flood' RV.

YAv. dārā- 'Klinge', tiži.dāra- 'mit scharfer Schneide', Khot. dārā- 'Schneide' CSogd. xγry d'r 'sword-blade', Pašto lōr 'Seite, Rand', from IIr. *dʰārā- 'Klinge, Schneide').

Cf. s.v. Ved. hári- 'fahl, gelblich, grünlich' < PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-i- (cf. Gk. χλωρός 'pale green, green-yellow', OHG gelo 'yellow', Lith. žélti 'to flourish, turn green').
