S.v. 7400 Lat. rotundus 'rund', 2. retundus.
S.v. 4321 gōla- (1) m. 'ball' BhP., ˚aka- m. 'ball' BhP., 'glans penis' Sāy., ˚likā- f. ʻ little ball ʼ SāmavBr. 2. *gōḍa- . [Cf. 4181 guḍá- (1) m. 'globe, ball']

S.v. Kurd. t́aza | tāza 'новый; свежий; снова', cf. Pers. tāza, Zaza taza, Tal. toza, Gur. tāza, Sang. tāže, Von., Kokhr. toza, Kash. toǰa, Zef. tože, Siv. toze, Sede, Gazi tože, Kafr. toze, Afg. tāza, Mundzh. toza 'новый', etc.

Cf. s.v. (3) xir̄ 'круг'; 'круглый', 'сферический', 'шарообразный', from (2) xir̄ 'всякий круглый предмет', 'валун', 'голыш'; 'русло (потока), в котором много валунов', which with a prothetic x- with Ossetic xwyr, xwyra ({ref Abaev 1959–1995} IV:266, and perhaps to Pokorny IEW 1140-1144 *u̯el- 'катать', 'обкатывать'.
S.v. Kurd. ganī 'гнилой, вонюочий', ultimately from IE *gʷedʰ- ~ gʷendʰ- cf. Av. ganti- 'вонь' OPers. gasta- 'тошнотворный, отвратительный', Ved. gandha- 'запах, аромат', MPers. gand 'вочь' etc.

Cf. s.v. Ved. gandhá- 'Geruch, Duft',  not to be separated from YAv. gaiṇti- 'übler Geruch', duž-gaiṇti- 'übelriechend, stinkend', Parth. gnd'g 'stinkend', MPers., NPers. gand 'Gestank', etc. Further etymology uncertain.

S.v. Ved. vr̥kṣá- 'Baum'. Mi. ni. pkt. vaccha- 'Baum', with metathesis *rukṣá- > pā., pkt. rukkha- etc., IIr. YAv. varǝša- 'Baum', varǝša.ǰī- probably 'Wurzel' or 'Stengel', perhaps from PIE *u̯l̥k̑-s-ó- to Ved. valśa- 'Schößling, Trieb, Zweig'.
S.v. 10757 *rukṣa- 'tree', rūkṣa- 2 m. lex. [~ vr̥kṣá- ], cf. 12067 vr̥kṣá m. 'tree' RV. [~ *rukṣa- ]

S.v. Ved. vr̥kṣá- 'Baum'. Mi. ni. pkt. vaccha- 'Baum', with metathesis *rukṣá- > pā., pkt. rukkha- etc., IIr. YAv. varǝša- 'Baum', varǝša.ǰī- probably 'Wurzel' or 'Stengel', perhaps from PIE *u̯l̥k̑-s-ó- to Ved. valśa- 'Schößling, Trieb, Zweig'.
Cf. s.v. 3282 Skt. *kuthati 'rots', kuthita- 'stinking' Suśr. [kúthyati 'rots' Dhātup. – √kuth] (> N. kuhunu 'to rot')
Cf. s.v. Skt. kuthita- 'stinkend' / 'stinking', only attested quite late.
Cf. s.v. nikothaka- 'Name eines Lehrers' – Nicht klar. According to Whitney, Roots 19 the only Vedic attestation of √kuth- 'stinken'.
S.v. 2415 Lat. currere 'laufen'.
S.v. žoz- ŠRB, žǟx̌t Š, žēx̌t RB, žuz : žux̌t S, γaz : γex̌t Y 'to run', cf. Khwar. γʾz, Mj. Yd. γaz-, Ishk. γəz-.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *du̯ar- 'to run' (> Av. duuā̆r- 'to run'). Etymology uncertain. According to Kellens 1984: 108n11 metathesized from IIr. *drau-; otherwise possibly contaminated with Proto-Iranic *θu̯ar-/tur-.
S.v. Kâmviri âčʹuṇa-  [âčʹuṇoa-; âčʹuṇavoa-]  VI.  Run.  [âčuṇa-]  [PrAr. *â-čsu˜d-a- ‘tramples’  T. 1030 (whence ṇ?)]

S.v. 1030 *ākṣundati 'tramples'. [Cf. ākṣōdana- n. 'hunting' lex.: √kṣud]
(> Kt. ačune- 'to run').

Cf. s.v. Ved. √kṣod- 'zerstieben' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. xšusta- 'geschmolzen, flüssig (vom Metall)', Khot. kṣusti- 'serum', MPers., NPers. šustan 'waschen', etc., further comparisons outside of Indo-Iranic disputed.
S.v. व्यक्ति vyakti, or b-, (l.) s. Manifestation; clearness, discrimination, distinction; individuality; an individual, a person; (gram.) inflection. [lw. Sk. id.]
S.v. Wa. xalg 'человек, мужчина', Persian/Tajik adaptation of Arabic xalq 'people'.
S.v. 10761 Skt. rucaka- 'pleasing, sharp, acid' W., m. 'natron, sochal salt' lex. [rucá- ʻ bright ʼ VS. - √ruc] (> Ash. ẓōk, žōk 'salt', Wg. wřūk, Kt. ẓuk, Pr. užúx: NTS ii 288.)
Cf. s.v. Ved. √roc- 'leuchten, scheinen, glänzen', from PIE *leu̯k- 'leuchten' (cf. Gk. λευκός 'light, white', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).
S.v. Kurd. xwē 'соль', from PIr. *hwā̆d-, PIIr. *su̯ad-, cf. Ved. svad-.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √svad- 'schmackhaft machen, (Med.) schmackhaft werden, schmecken', from which is derived the inherited word svādú-. From PIE *su̯ad- (~ TochA swār, B swāre 'süß' < *su̯ad-ro-).
Cf. s.v. *su̯eh₂d- 'schmackhaft werden' (IEW 1039-40).
Cf. s.v. *su̯eh₂d- 'schmackhaft werden' (LIV 606f., IEW 1039f.).

S.v. Wa. lworč 'песок', from PIr. *fra-vārači- > *rworč > lworč (with dissimilation) from VAR 'покрывать' (or 'vertere'?), but nothing similar in other Iranian or Indic. The etymology of words in the meaning 'sand' in Indo-Iranian is usually not clear.
Cf. s.v. 3851 grava (gall.) 'Stein', cf. Welsh gro 'Kieselstein'
Cf. s.v. Kurd. r̄amil 'гадание, предсказание, колдовство', from Arab. raml 'песок' in darb-ar-raml 'гадание на песке'.
S.v. Oss. yzmīs | (æ)zmesæ, (æ)zmensæ 'песок', from Ir. *uz-maisa- to IE *mei̯k̑- смешивать', cf. Av. myas-, Ved. mikṣ-, etc.
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kan-e/o- 'singen', from PIE *kan- or *k̑an- (LIV 342f., IEW 525f.).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *u̯et-e/o- 'sagen, sprechen', from PIE *u̯eth₂- (LIV 694f.).
S.v. Proto-Celtic *su̯an-na- 'zum Ertönen erbringen', from PIE *su̯enh₂- (LIV 611), cf. IEW 1046f. *su̯en-.
S.v. 9837 Ved. mantráyate 'speaks' RV., 'consults with' ŚBr., 'advises' MBh. [mántra-]

S.v. Ved. mántra- 'Spruch, heilige Formel, Ausspruch, (formulierter) Gedanke, Plan', derived to Ved. √man- (1) 'denken, meinen, dafürhalten', from PIE *men-, cf. Gk. μέμονα 'habe in Sinn, strebe' Lat. meminī 'erinnere mich', OIr. do-moiniur 'meine, glaube', Goth. man 'meine, glaube', Lith. miñti 'gedenken', etc.
Cf. s.v. 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' (IEW 726-8).
S.v. Oss. zæǧyn : zaǧd | zæǧun, ʒæǧun : zaǧd, ʒaǧd 'сказать, говорить'.
S.v. Paš. wāy- : way- 'to speak' < *waf/bya-, cf. Av. vaf- 'to sing', Bal. gwap- 'to summon', but Sogd. wʾβ, C wʾb 'to speak'.
S.v. 2703 Skt. katháyati 'converses with, describes' MBh. [Denom. from kathā : √kath]
S.v. 10620 Ved. rápati 'talks, chatters' RV. [~ lápati – √rap- (1)]

S.v. Ved. kathā́ 'wie? woher?' to which ep. kl. kathayº 'erzählen', Pā. kathā- 'Erzählung', katheti 'spricht' etc., cf. Ved. kathám adv. 'wie?, auf welche Weise?, woher?', to Ved. ká- Interrogative pronoun 'wer, welcher?', to PIE *kʷe-/*kʷo- (cf. Hom. τέο 'wessen', πό-θι 'wo', Lat. quod 'was, welches', Goth. ƕas 'wer', Lith. kàs 'wer', etc.).

S.v. *kʷó-, kʷí- 'wer?; irgendwer' Pronominalstamm, interrogativ; indefinit, wenn enklitisch; ?relativ. Cf. p.467 s.v. *kʷó-th₂ éh₁, *kʷó-tā 'genau wie' > Urar. *katʰā 'wie?' (Ved. kathā́, Av. kaθā̆).
S.v. Ved. √rap- 'vertraulich sprechen, vertraut reden, undeutlich sprechen, schwatzen', maybe to an onomatopeic root *lep-, cf. Ru. lépet 'Stammeln, Lallen', etc.
S.v. Ved. √khyā- 'schauen, anblicken, scheinen'. √khyā- is a phonetic variant of √kśā- 'blicken, schauen'

S.v. 11342 Skt. varṇayati 'relates, describes' MBh., 'observes' Kathās., 'praises' W. [varṇa- 2] (> K. wanun 'to describe, name, call, recognize'), cf. s.v. 11339 varṇa- (2) m. 'sound, syllable' AitBr.

S.v. Skt. várṇaḥ 'Farbe; Stamm, Art, Gattung; Menschenart, Kaste' / 'colour; race, species; class of men, caste' (cf. Av. varənah- 'Farbe'), to vr̥ṇoti (1). várṇaḥ in the meaning 'Laut, Silbe, Wort' is probably a special development of the word for 'Art, Gattung, Farbe' and not evidence for *u̯er- 'to speak' in Indo-Iranian (pace Turner IAL no. 11339]).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √var- (2) 'umschließen, zusammenhalten, einschließen, zurückhalten, einhüllen' (IIr. cf. YAv. hąm.vaori- 'mit dem Rahm', Oss. wart 'Schild, Schutz', etc. The assignment of Indo-Iranic *var- to Indo-European sources is difficult. (Cf. for further discussion).
Cf. s.v. *Hu̯er- 'einschließen, stecken, hineintum' (IEW 1150, 1160), 1. *u̯el- 'einschließen, verhüllen' (IEW 1138), and 1. u̯er- 'aufhalten, (ab)wehren' (IEW 1160-2).
S.v. 10816 Skt. retra- n. 'perfumed powder' lex. [Scarcely with F. B. J. Kuiper IL xix 352 sanskritization of *reṭ- ← Mu. - *rē- ]
S.v. Skt. retram, cf. s.v reṇuḥ 'Staub, Staubkorn' / 'dust, grain of dust'. "Zu riṇā́ti?" Uncertain. Cf. for further discussion on possible IE correspondences and loan hypotheses.
S.v. 9406 bhálatē 'expounds, describes' Dhātup. [√bhal- (1)]

Cf. s.v. Skt. bhal-, attested only ni-bhālayati 'nimmt wahr/perceives' (Up., etc.) and sam-bhālayati 'vernimmt, erfährt, hört' (Naiṣadhacarita) and found in Middle, Modern Indic continuants. Etymology not certainly explained.
Cf. s.v. NHG Klaue (OHG klāwa, klā 'Klaue'). There are no meaningful comparisons that can be made outside of Germanic.
Cf. s.v. *kʷels- 'Furchen ziehen, einfurchen' (IEW 639-640). Cf. n3 "Eine „alte umgangsprachliche Form“ von kárṣa- könnte ved. (AV+) káṣa- 'kratzen' sein, Gotō 114).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hraifan- 'wrist(?)' (ON hreifi 'wrist; the hand and fingers; seal's fin, flipper' as though from *kroip-on-). "Also cf. ON hraifa 'to scratch; to grasp' < *kréip-e-, and OE ge-hrifnian w.v. 'to pull, grab'."
S.v. Proto-Germanic *xrībanan str.vb. ON hraifa 'to catch, to grapple', etc. Of unknown origin.
S.v. PGmc. hreib-a- 'greifen', no certain possibilities for comparison outside of Germanic.
S.v. Du. krabben w.v. ‘de nagels of een scherp voorwerp over iets heenhalen’
S.v. Kurd. bahr, bar, bár | baḥr 'море', loanword from Arab. baḥr 'море'.
S.v. 8012 Ved. páśyati 'sees' RV. [√paś1]

S.v. Ved. √dhay-ⁱ (2) 'hinblicken, schauen, wahrnehmen, ersinnen, nachdenken, denken' (IIr., cf. OAv. daidiiat̰ 'ob er sieht; ob sie sehen' Y 44.10, YAv. ā-diδaiia 'betrachtet', OPers. dīdiy 'betrachte, schaue an!', Khot. dai-/däta-, MPers., NPers. dīdan 'sehen', Parth. dydn⁽ʾ⁾ 'apparition', etc. Further is uncertain. Formally PIE *dʰei̯H- or *dʰeH-i-?
S.v. *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen' (IEW 243). Only IIr. and Albanian (Alb. di 'weiß, kennt' < ?*dʰiH-i̯é-).
Cf. s.v. OAlb. di (trans.) 'wissen, kennen, können, beherrschen', continuing a present stem *dʰiH-i̯é/ó- or *dʰiH-e/o- from the root *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen'; other solutions are improbable.
S.v. Ved. √īkṣ- 'wahrnehmen, bemerken, erblicken, sehen', a secondary root within Vedic from PIE *h₃i-h₃kʷ-s-, cf. Ved. ákṣi- 'eye' < *h₃ekʷ-s-
S.v. *h₃ekʷ- 'ins Auge fassen, erblicken' (IEW 775-7).
Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *motriti 'look at, watch' (ESSJa XX 65-67), From BSl. *mot(r)-, cf. Lith. matýti 'look at, watch'. For the -r- cf. Lith. matrùs 'sharp eyed, vigilant'.
S.v. Paš. kas- : kat- 'to look at, see', cf. Av. √kas-, Sgl. kas-, Sh čis-, etc.
S.v. Proto-Iranic *kas- (1) 'to look, appear', from PIE *kʷek̑- 'to appear, show' (cf. Skt. kāś- 'to become visible, appear', Gk. τέκμωρ, τέκμαρ 'sign, mark').
Cf. s.v. 3114 Skt. kā́śatē ʻ shines, is visible ʼ MBh. [√kāś-]

Cf. s.v. Ved. √kāś- 'sichtbar werden, erscheinen', from which is derived ākāśá- 'freier Raum, Luftraum, Öffnung', perhaps to PIE *kʷek̑-, if the root is connected with Gk. τέκμωρ, τέκμαρ 'Zeichen, Merkmal'.
Cf. s.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9).
S.v. W. gwnïaf: gwnïo 'to sew, stitch, seam, bind' etc., cf. Co. gwryas, OBret. gruiam, gl. suo, MBret. gruyat; Bret. gwriat, griat from root *u̯er- ‘troi, troelli, plygu’.

"Fraglich ist hingegen, ob auch das kymrische Verb für 'nähen' und sein
bretonisches Gegenstück auf *gn-ii̯e/o- zurückgehen (vgl. VKG II: 544) und wenn ja, wie. Die beiden Verben lauten mky. gwni-aw (Stamm
/gu̯ni-/) bzw. mbret. gruy-at (Stamm /gu̯ri-/, GIB I154f., vgl. auch abret. gruiam gl. suo, DVB I: 180); hinzuzufügen ist noch das mko. Substantiv
gwry 'Naht' (RD 1921, zu lesen als /gu̯ri/). Diese Verbalstämme mky.
/gu̯ni-/ und mbret. /gu̯ri-/ sowie das mko. Substantiv /gu̯ri/ müssten ebenfalls auf einer Kontamination von /gu̯ra(γ)-/ 'tun, machen' mit der Kontinuante von *gn-ii̯e/o- basieren."

S.v. 9710 *macyate 'is produced, grows, is kindled, is rubbed. 2. *macya- . 3. Pp. *makta- . [mácatē 'grinds, is arrogant', máñcatē 'id., grows high, shines' Dhātup. <-> It is difficult in NIA. to separate forms of √mac meaning 'excite, excited' from √mad (mādyati, mattá-) of which in MIA. pres. st. majj- was partially replaced by macc- after the type sitta- ~ siccaï. -- The meanings in NIA. support IE. origin (Gk. μάσσω, &c.) IEW 730. -- √mac]
S.v. Skt. mácate, a Dhātupāṭha verb for which numerous meanings are given. Cf. entry for further discussion.
S.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (LIV 70f., IEW 116f.).
S.v. 10187 1. *muṭṭa- 'defective'.
Cf. 11081.4 *lunda- > L.mult. lundā 'tailless, shameless'.
S.v. *k̑leu̯- 'hören' (IEW 605-7).
S.v. Oss. zaryn : zard | zarun : zard 'петь', from Iran. *žar-, IE *g̑ar-.
S.v. Kâmviri lʹâalu, also lʹâa˜lu  NF.  Song; music.  [OIA. *lalla- ‘inarticulate noise’  T. 10972.1]
Cf. s.v. 10972 *lalla- 'inarticulate noise', 2. lallara- 'stammering' lex., lalalla- Kathās.
Cf. s.v. *prei̯H- 'vertraut, lieb sein/werden' (IEW 844).
S.v. Manx arrane 'song, ditty, hymn; singing' [= Ir. amhrán]. Cf. also goaill.
S.v. OIr. amar 'chagrin, souffrance', corresponding to W. afar 'tristesse, lamentation', deriv. amrán 'chant; sorte de poème', further etymology unknown.
S.v. Skt. kharju- 'Jucken, Kratzen' / 'itching, scratching', probably with kaccū- (id.) from Dravidian.
S.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' (IEW 941-2). Cf. n1: Probably an enlarged form of 2. *(s)ker-.
S.v. Ved. √kart-¹ 'schneiden, abschneiden, spalten, brechen', from PIE *(s)kert- (cf. OHG scrinden 'sich spalten', Lith. kertù 'fälle, haue', RuCS črěsti 'schneiden', etc.).
Cf. s.v. *lendʰ- 'sich senken, nach unten geraten' [IEW 675, 961].
S.v. *skeu̯h₂- 'stochern, stoßen' (IEW 954).
S.v. Paš. gəraw- 'to scratch', denom. < *han-kara-, cf. Av. (4) kar-?, cf. bagār; cf. also gerǧ- 'to scratch, scrape'.
S.v. Skt. kaṇḍū- 'das Jucken, Beißen, Kratzen' / 'itching, biting, scratching', because of the prefixed form sr̥kaṇḍu-, with high probability an Austroasiatic loanword.
S.v. kaṇḍūyº 'kratzen, schaben', etc. Etymology unclear.
S.v. 5005 Skt. challi- 'bark'. Probably of non-Indic origin.
S.v. Skt. challī- 'Rinde / bark' (Pāli challi, Prākrit challī), probably from the same non-IE source as colakam (coḍaḥ). Probably Dravidian, but a Munda origin is not to be ruled out.
S.v. 2751 Lat. dormīre 'schlafen'.
Cf. s.v. Kurd. nivīn | nwēn 'постель, постельные принадлежности', from IIr. *ni-pad-ana-.
Cf. s.v. Ved. √pad- 'treten, gehen, fallen, niedersinken' < PIE *ped- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten, *fußwärts gehen → fallen', cf. Rix (1976:278f.).
S.v. *ped- 'treten; fallen, sinken' (IEW 790-2); the same root as 'foot' with the semantic development 'place one's foot' → 'to go in the direction of the feet' → 'fall', cf. {ref Rix 1976}:278f.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *mauč- (1) 'to release, let loose/free' (> Chor. (+uz-) m|zmxs- 'to (go to) sleep', from PIE *meuk- 'to take, untie', etc. (cf. Skt. moc- 'to release, be(come) free; to liberate, free', Gk. μύσσομαι 'I blow my nose', Lat. e-mungō 'I blow out, snuff', Lith. maũkti 'to take off').
Cf. s.v. *meu̯k- 'losbinden, abstreifen' (IEW 744).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √moc- 'losmachen, losbinden, lösen, befreien', from PIE *(s)meuk-, probably 'streifen, abstreifen', cf. Lith. smaũkti 'abstreifen, abwischen', Gk.μύσσομαι 'schneuze mich', Lat. e-mungō 'schneuze aus' etc.

S.v. Lat. fragrō 'exhaler une odeur forte ou agréable'. The connection with Skt. ghrā́ti and jíghrati is attractive semantically, but phonologically problematic. Another possibility is a connection with OHG bracko 'chien de chasse', a simple possibility.
[Rehearses the two possible etymologies suggested by {ref Ernout & Meillet 1985}, favouring the latter to OHG but considering both uncertain.]
[Proposes a connection of MIr. brén 'putrid, foul', MW braen 'putrid, corrupt', B brein 'id.' to the OHG and Latin forms, but ultimately considers the etymology uncertain.]

[Regarding the proposed comparison of OIr. braigim (1sg.) 'fart' etc.] "Schrijver (1995: 170–171) suggests an alternative etymology, connecting braigim with MHG. brǣhen ‘smell’ < *brēhia̯ n, Lat. fragrāre ‘emit a (sweet) smell’ < *bʰreh₁g-, which suggest a development *brag(i̯)-e/o- < *bʰr̥h₁g-(i)̯ e/o- as well as *bʰr̥h₁g-smn̥ > bram. The closer semantics perhaps make this etymology more likely than the connection with *bhreg- ‘break’, but it is not at all certain."
Cf. s.v. PGmc. reuk-a- 'rauchen', with deriv. rauk-i-z 'Rauch', possibly comparable with Lithuanian ráugti 'säuern; aufstoßen', although the connection is very uncertain.
S.v.  8152 picchala- 'slimy, slippery' MBh.
S.v. 5081 Lat. *līsius 'glatt'.
S.v. Kurd. ḥilī 'красивый, приятный на вид', from Arabic ḥulw 'красивый, прелестный'.
S.v. *g̑enh₁- 'erzeugen' (LIV 163ff., IEW 373ff.).
Cf. s.v. *g̑enh₁- 'erzeugen' (IEW 373-5).
S.v. Ved. nāga- 'Elefant' (AitB.+), 'Schlange' (ŚB +), probably in both meanings 'the hairless, naked animal'.
S.v. Khot. śśau 'one'. The earlier proposal of {ref Bailey 1979}:404 to Proto-Iranic *aiu̯a- is unsatisfactory. No satisfactory etymology has yet been agreed upon. [Cf. with extensive discussion].

Cf. s.v. Ved. toká- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'; tókman- n. 'junger Getreidehalm, grüner Sproß von Getreide' (IIr. YAv. taoxman- 'Same, Keim, Verwandschaft'; OPers. tauma- 'Familie, Geschlecht'). Cf. root noun túc- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'. Correspondences of IIr. *tau̯k- outside of IIr. are not certainly ascertained.
S.v. Kâmviri bâbʹista  NAnF.  Snake.  [pa-büm-ta-], cf. bʹüm  NSb.  Earth; ground.  [büm-]  [OIA. bhʹu:-man- ‘earth; world’  T. 9556]
Cf. s.v. 9556 Ved. bhūman n. 'earth, world' RV. [√bhū]

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *pazd- (1) 'to blow, smoke' "This apparently exclusively Ir. root may in fact reflect a causative da-present stem (cf. Kellens 1984:155 ad 6.2.) of IE *pes- ‘to blow’ (Pokorny: 823 f.), similar to MMP rwzd- ‘to desire’ (*rau²), CSogd. sxwrd- ‘to shout’ (*har²). See also *pazd²."
Cf. istā̆ri 'star'. "Prob. IA., cf. Ashkun is'ta, etc."
S.v. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade' and 2899 Lat. erigere, erēctus 'erheben, aufrichten', 2. *ergere, *erctus (> it. erta 'Anhöhe', all'erta 'aufwärts, aufgepaßt').

S.v. Lat. regō, -ere 'to direct, guide, govern', from Proto-Italic *reg- (cf. U. rehte 'right'), from PIE *h₃reg̑-e/o-. Lat. rēctus is the regularly formed past passive participle to the verbal stem [< *h₃reg̑-to-].
Cf. s.v. *h₃reg̑- 'gerade richten, ausstrecken' (IEW 854-7).
S.v. PGmc. *rehta- 'gerade, recht', an inherited verbal adjective identical with Av. rašta- 'gerichtet', Gk. ὀρεκτός '(vor)gestreckt', Lat. rēctus 'gerade, aufrecht; recht, richtig').
S.v. *rebʰ- 'sich (heftig) bewegen' (IEW 853). Präsens ?*rébʰ-e- > Parth. rf- 'angreifen', NP rav- 'gehen', MHG reben 'sich bewegen'
S.v. Wa. šəpk 'прут, лоза', from IIr. *xšupaka-, cf. Skt. kṣupa- 'ветка, прут' or from the onomatopoeic verbal root *(x)ši/ap- 'to beat'.
S.v. Ved. kṣupaḥ 'Staude, Busch' / 'shrub, bush', connected by Leumann to waxi šöpk, kurd. šīv 'Staude, Holz', further etymology uncertain.
S.v. PGmc. *kip(p)az (ON koppr 'cudgel, club', OE cipp 'log, coulter, plowshare'), related to *kaipaz ~ *kaipō.

Cf. s.v. *kippōn- (2) 'to chop(?)' ON kippa w.v. 'to pull, snatch', Icel. kippa w.v. 'to jerk', Far. kippa w.v. 'to cut off, OE cippian w.v. 'to chop, cut', E chip 'to cut away', MDu. kippen w.v. 'to catch'. No certain cognates outside of Germanic.
S.v. Lat. pālus 'pieu, pal, échlas, pilori, poteau', from pā̆k-slo- to the same root as Lat. pangō, a nasal-infixed root derived from IE *pā̆g̑-.
Cf. s.v. Lat. pangō, -ere 'to insert firmly, fix' < PIE *ph₂-n-g̑-; the noun pālus is derived from an instrument noun *pā̆g-slo-.
Cf. s.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).

Cf. s.v. NHG Bengel 'ungezogener Junge' (MHG bengel 'Knüppel, Stange', MDu. bengel 'Knüppel, Stange', like Schlegel to schlagen this is derived from Low German bangen (cf. NE to bang, ON banga 'klopfen, schlagen').

S.v. PGmc. *ƀanʒōjanan wk.vb.: (Icel banga ‘to hammer’ E bang, G dial. bangen ‘to knock’). "If not of imitative origin, probably related to Skt bhanákti ‘to break’, Arm bek ‘broken’, Lith beñgti ‘to finish’").
S.v. Rom. băț, etymology unknown.

S.v. Lat. baculum 'bâton, canne'. Greek βάκτρον, βακτηρία 'bâton' shows a root *bak- of a popular type in Indo-European with *b and *a. Also found with a geminate *-kk- in Ir. bacc 'bâton recourbé'. In Latin the noun has an instrument suffix as in Greek.
S.v. *bak- 'Stab als Stütze', auch 'stechen, stoßen, schlagen'?
Cf. s.v. wal'āṛ 'standing' < *awa-/wi-darta/i-, cf. Av. √dar- (3) 'hold'.

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *dar- (1) 'to hold, keep; to dwell', from PIE *dʰer- 'to hold' (cf. Skt. dhar- 'to hold, keep, preserve', Hitt. dar- 'to hold, to say(?)', Lat. firmus 'firm, steady', Lith. derù 'I am good for').
Cf. s.v. *dʰer- 'befestigen, fixieren' (IEW 252-3).
S.v. kāṣṭhá- 'Holzstück; ein Längenmaß, ein Holzmaß', etymology uncertain.
S.v. Kurd. gōpāl 'дубинка, палка', loan from Persian gōpāl, kōbāl (< kōb-āl) where *kōb- is abstracted from the stem of kōftan | kōbidān 'бить, колотить, ударять'.
S.v. 4966 *chaṭa 'stick, cane'. 2. *chaṭṭa- 2. 3. *chiṭṭa- .
S.v. 2661 Ved. káṇa- m. 'a grain of corn' AV., 'drop (of water)' Kāv., kaṇikā- f. 'a single grain' MBh.
S.v. Ved. káṇa- 'Korn, Samenkorn'. Etymology unclear.
S.v. Kâmviri sṭʹâla  [-i fem]  Aj.  Straight; true; honest.  [sṭâla>]  [OIA. sthʹal-a- ‘flat surface’  T. 13744]
S.v. 13744 Skt. sthála n. 'dry land' TS., 'ground, place' Mn., 'flat surface, roof' Kālid.
S.v. Skt. sthálam 'Erhebung, Anhöhe, trockenes festes Land' / 'elevation, dry land, firm earth', connected with the Dhātup. root sthal- '(fest)stehen'. Further etymology uncertain.
S.v. 4161 Ved. girí- m. 'rock, mountain' RV.

S.v. Gaul. acaumon 'pierre', corresponding to IE *ak̑mōn 'pierre', Skt. áśman- 'pierre', Gk. ἄκμων 'enculme, pierre météoritique', Lith. akmuõ 'pierre', etc. with thematisation of the suffix -men- : *ak̑mōn = *akm̥non > *acamnon > acounon.

S.v. Ved. √śodh- 'reinigen, rein machen'. IIr. *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ- perhaps from PIE *(s)k̑eu̯-dʰ- with a root enlargement of *(s)k̑eu̯-, but connections outside IIr. otherwise unclear.
S.v. ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'rein werden' (IEW 595). Root mechanically reconstructed for PIE; there are no cognates outside of Indo-Iranian.
Cf. s.v. Ahura Mazdā
Cf. s.v. Mithra (i). Mitra in Old Indian and Mithra in Old Iranian.

S.v. Skt. vā́ta- 'Wind, Windgott' (cf. IIr. in OAv. vāta- 'wind', YAv. vāta- 'wind', Khot. bāta-, Parth. w'd, MPers. wād, NPers. bād, etc.), from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁-n̥t-o- to √*h₂u̯eh₁- (cf. Lat. ventus, Goth. winds, etc.).
Cf. s.v. Kurd. mala c. 'плавание'; mala kirdan 'плавать, купаться', Cf. Arab. milāḥa 'плавание, мореплавание', mallāḥ 'моряк'.

S.v. Du. staart 'achterste uitsteeksel', from Proto-Germanic *sterta-, with -e- > -aa- before r + dental just as in haard. From PIE *sterd-, probably a dental enlargement of the root *(s)ter- ‘stiff'.
Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *stertaz.
S.v. Proto-Germanic xalōn sb.m. "Closely related to Skt. śalá- 'staff', MIr. cail 'spear'."
S.v. Proto-Germanic *spurđaz sb.m. > ON sporðr 'fish tail', MHG sporte id. cf. Lith. spūrù, spùrti 'to be fringy', spùrdu, spurdė́ti 'to flounder, fidget, struggle', Latv. spurstu, spurt 'to rove'.
S.v. ON sporðr 'schwanz' (bes. von fisch oder schlange), cf. sparri.
S.v. 10918 *laṭṭa- (2) 'hanging, tangled' (> K. loṭu m. 'tail', lüṭü, laṭar f. 'short tail'; S. laṭkaṇu 'to hang, dangle'; L. lāṭ m. 'tail', etc.).
S.v. Proto-Germanic *rumpaz sb.m. > ON rumpr 'rump, buttocks', MHG rump 'body, beehive'.

S.v. Gmc. *tak-a- 'nehmen', without precise comparisons outside of Germanic. The Germanic verb may be an irregular development or secondary variant of IE *tag- ~ *teg- (cf. TochB tek-, tak- 'berühren', Lat. tangō, tetigī, tactus 'berühren', Gk. τεταγων 'fassend').

S.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-e/o- 'tragen, bringen' < PIE *bʰer-, cf. composita with preverb *kom-.
S.v. Paš. axl- : axist- 'to take, seize', cf. Skt. ā-khid- 'seize' (rather than Av. (vī-)xad-).

Cf. s.v. ?*g̑ʰei̯- 'antreiben' (IEW 424-425). Attestations confined to Indo-Iranic.

Cf. s.v. Ved. √hay- 'antreiben, anfeuern; schleudern; fördern, helfen' (IIr. cf. YAv. frazaiiaiiāmi 'ich lasse hindringen', to which nominal formations like OAv. zaēman- 'Wachsein', YAv. zaēna- 'Waffe', Parth. zyn, MPers. zēn 'Rüstung') further is unclear.

PS *čĭrv(j)enŭ is an early adjectivised and lexicalised past passive participle of *čĭrviti, a verbal derivation from *čĭrvĭ 'grub, worm, maggot' (cf. the ancient technology of the red pigment). PS *čĭrvĭ (and a more archaic form *čĭrmĭ) is related to Lithuanian kirmìs and Old Indic kṛmi-ḥ-. PIE *kʷr̥mi-.

S.v. Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made' (IIr. cf. Manichaean Sogd. kyrm- 'Schlange', MPers. klm (kirm) 'Wurm, Drache, Schlange', NPers. kirm 'Wurm, Schlange'), from PIE *kʷr̥mi- (cf. OIr. cruim, W., Bret. pryf 'Wurm', Lith. kirmìs 'Wurm, Schlange', Sloven. čr̂m 'Fingerwurm, Karbunkel', etc.). Beside *kʷr̥mi- exists "a rhyme formation in Indo-European probably for reason of tabu" *u̯r̥mi- (NHG Wurm, cf. Lat. vermis), (so Watkins 1987:288).

S.v. Old Prussian wormyan 'red' < PIE *urmi- (cf. Lat. vermis 'worm', Goth. waurms 'snake', OEng. wyrm 'snake, worm'). Other colour adjectives derived from *urmi- 'worm' are Ukr. vermjáty 'red', OHG wormo 'purple', MoFr. vermeil 'scarlet' < *vermiculus.
S.v. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade' and 2899 Lat. erigere, erēctus 'erheben, aufrichten', 2. *ergere, *erctus (> it. erta 'Anhöhe', all'erta 'aufwärts, aufgepaßt').
Cf. s.v. *h₃reg̑- 'gerade richten, ausstrecken' (IEW 854-7).
Cf. s.v. 6152 Ved. dánta- 'tooth' RV. [dánt- RV.]
S.v. Ved. dant- 'Zahn', from PIE *h₁d-ónt- *'beißend' (~*h₁ed-) (cf. Gk. ὀδὠν, ὀδόντ- [Aeol. ἔδοντ-ες], Arm. atamn, Lat. dēns, dent-, OHG zan(d), Lith. dantìs 'Zahn', etc.)

Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from or in light-verb constructions with PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth'. The root etymology is traditionally considered to be to PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', however difficulties regarding the Greek comparanda (ὀδών 'tooth', νωδός 'toothless') have led the Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction to consider an underlying root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' (cf. Kortlandt 2003:77). If the traditional etymology is followed, then these lexemes would also be cognate with Old Irish ithid 'to bite, to eat' in /cognate/6370/ which is clearly derived from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'. For the lexemes in this class, cf. EWAia I:693-694, Turner 1962–1966:352 no. 6152, Deshayes 2003:170, Matasović 2009:90). For further details regarding the etymology of PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth', cf. further discussion in /cognate/328/.

S.v. Alb. hën/ë, -a / hãnë 'Mond'. Dialectal comparison allows the reconstruction of a Proto-Albanian form *skandanā, which can be further connected to Ved. candrá-, -ścandrá- 'leuchtend, glänzend', candrá-(mās-) 'Mond' (to which further cf. W. cann 'weiß, hell', MBret. cann 'Vollmond').
Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)kend- 'erglänzen' (IEW 526).

S.v. Proto-Celtic *danto- 'tooth', from PIE *h₁dont- 'tooth' (cf. Lat. dēns, Skt. dánt-, Gk. ὀδών, Lith. dantìs, OHG zand). The reconstruction of the initial laryngeal is uncertain. Some prefer to see an original participle of the verb 'to eat' *h₁ed-, but others reconstruct *h₃- from which Gk. ὀδών is derived more straightforwardly.

S.v. Proto-Celtic *danto- 'tooth', from PIE *h₁dont- 'tooth' (cf. Lat. dēns, Skt. dánt-, Gk. ὀδών, Lith. dantìs, OHG zand). The reconstruction of the initial laryngeal is uncertain. Some prefer to see an original participle of the verb 'to eat' *h₁ed-, but others reconstruct *h₃- from which Gk. ὀδών is derived more straightforwardly.
S.v. Alb. hëne ~ hanë 'moon', from Proto-Albanian *ksandā and further compared with Skt. cándati 'shines, is bright', candrá- 'shining; moon'.
PS *straxŭ is most probably derived from PIE *strōg-so-, ultimately from PIE *(s)terg- / *(s)treg-. Another PS derivative from this root is probably *strogŭ 'austere'.

S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.). Sarikoli is given with wux̌t „to fall“, rawůx̌t “to fly up” and rawazon- “to cause to fly etc.”; wōzd is given for Bartangi as a causative “to make swim, carry across (a stream)”, which is probably identical with Sarikoli. From PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' (cf. Skt. vah- 'to ride, drive, transport' Gk. (Pamph.) ϝεχέτω 'he must bring', Lat. vehō, vēxī 'I ride, bring', OCS vezǫ 'I ride' Lith. vežu 'I ride, procure' OHG wegan 'to move' etc.).

Arm. hołm 'wind' is probably dissimilated from *h₂on(h₁)-mo- and cognate with Gk. ἄνεμος, Lat. animus, although this connection is rejected in {ref IEW} 39.

S.v. Arm. hołm 'wind', usually derived from *h₂onh₁-mo- (with dissimilation *-nm- > -łm-), cf. ἄνεμος 'wind', Lat. animus 'soul, mind, spirit', etc. The precise Ablaut grade of the root *h₂enh₁- underlying the Armenian form is debated. Cf. entry in Martirosyan for further discussion with references.
SHAKING *polh₁mos (WIND *h₂enh₁mos) → WIND (hołm)
Uridg. *pleh₂g-o- 'flach, breit' → vorurarm. *plēh₂g-o/eh₂ 'Meeresoberfläche' > arm. lik; vorurarm. *plēh₂g-i̯o/eh₂ > lič
HIMMELFARBENES (*di̯eu̯-o-bʰh₂u-) Meer → MEER (cov)

OIr. grúac (f. -ā): ‘hair of the head’. – Not attested in the OIr. glosses. No known etymology. Internal reconstruction points to Proto-Celtic *grounkā which {ref IEW} 389 suggests a suffix *-eu- and nasalised k-enlargement to a PIE root *ger- 'drehen, winden', but there are no parallels for such an root enlargement.
Cf. s.v. PGmc. *hafjan- ~ *habjan- 'to raise, lift'< *kh₂p-ie- (? Gk. κάπτω 'to gulp down', Lat. capiō 'to take').

Cf. s.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-528)
S.v. ON dynt 'schlag, stoss' with assimilated secondary dyttr, from which verbal dytta 'stossen' in Modern Norwegian and dötta in northern Swedish dialects.
S.v. PGmc. *dent-a- 'stürzen' with derivative *dunt-i-z > OWN dyttr 'Schuß', OE dynt 'Schlag, Stoß'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic.

S.v. ScG. fagus, faisg 'near', Ir. fogus, E. Ir. focus, ocus, O. Ir. accus, W. agos, Br. hogoz, *aggostu-.
S.v. W. agos 'near'; cf. OCo. ogos, gl. affinis vel consanguineus, MCo. ogas, OBret. ocos, MBret. hogos; uncertain relationship to OIr. acus, ocus

Ir. ocus, acus, accus 'nahe' ocuis, oeus, acus 'und', NIr. fogus 'nahe' agus 'und' point to a proto-form with -gn- and could be related to Lat. angustus 'eng' and similarly with caution to like Greek ἄχ-νυ-μαι 'betrübe mich' cf. Ir. agur 'fürchte' to Gr. ἄγχω 'schnüre zu'. Mysterious however remains then C. agos 'nahe', Corn. ogas, likewise Bret. hogoz, hogos 'beinahe' (the secondary form hegos may have originated in proclisis). The assumption of a loanword from Irish would help.
S.v. Lat. pandō, -ere 'to spread out, extend' (derv. passus, -ūs 'step, pace'), from PIE *pt-n(é)-h₂- 'to spread', cf. Gk. πίτνημι 'to spread out, open'.
Cf. s.v. 1. *peth₂- 'ausbreiten' (IEW 824-5)
S.v. Bret. krabissad 'égratigner, gratter', is a form of the prefix kra- and the French verb (denasalised) pincer.
S.v. OIr. scrip- 'gratter, égratigner', perhaps to be connected with Lat. scribō, leaving open the question of the geminate *-bb-.
Cf. s.v. 7452 rupta via 'durchgebrochener Weg'

Cf. s.v. Lat. rumpō, -ere 'to burst, break open' < PIE *Hru-n-p-, cf. Skt. rupya-, cs. ropáya- 'suffer from stomach ache' OAv. urūpaiia- 'to cause racking pain', MPers. rubūdan 'to rob, grab', OE rēofan 'to break, tear'.
Cf. s.v. *reu̯p- 'brechen, (zer)reißen (intr.)' (IEW 870)
Cf. s.v. Sw. ihjäl, from < Old Swedish i häl 'into hell'. The meaning of the adverb ihjäl is determined by the verb it is used with.
S.v. hel 'totenreich; Todesgöttin', to be connected with the root *k̑el- 'verbergen, verhüllen'
S.v. PGmc. *haljō- 'hell'; k̑ol-ieh₂- (drv), cf. OIr. cel 'concealment(?), dissolution, extinction, death'< *k̑el-o-. "Possibly a derivation from *k̑el- 'to cover' (see *helan-)."

Cf. s.v. NHG Hölle "Man kann vermuten, das die Germanen die Totenwelt als das sie Toten Bergende bezeichneten und damit an g. *hel-a- 'bergen' anschleißen; doch bleibt dies bei einem mythologischen Begriff eine bloße Vermutung."
S.v. NHG holen (MHG hol(e)n, OHG holōn, beside MHG haln, halōn, OS halōn, halonian) from West Germanic *hal-ō-.
S.v. फराकिलो pharākilo,adj. Wide, extensive. [der. pharāk.], cf. फराक् pharāk, adj. Broad, wide, roomy. [lw. H. farāḵẖ fr. Pers.]
S.v. 5536 *ḍala- 'lump' > Gaw. ḍal 'big, thick'
S.v. 8182 *pittaka- 'relating to bile', cf. 8181 pittá n. 'bile' AV.
S.v. Ved. pittá- 'Galle' "Nicht aufgeklärt."
S.v. 3590 Lat. fūr, fūre 'Dieb', deriv. log. furriare 'wegwerfen', 'drehen', 'wenden'.
S.v. Lat. fūr, -is 'thief', from PIE *bʰōr 'thief' (cf. Gk. φώρ 'thief'), a derivative of PIE *bʰer- 'to carry'.
Cf. s.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-132).
S.v. 9300 Lat. vibrāre 'schwingen' 2. vīrāre
Cf. aroglau 'scent, odor', cf. clywaff 'to hear'
S.v. Proto-Celtic *kli-n-u- and *klus-ī- 'hören' < PIE *k̑leu̯- (LIV² 334f.) and *k̑leu̯s- (LIV² 336).
"W B tro 'turn' < *trogo- (PIE *tregʰ-? Pok. 1089)"
S.v. W tro n. 'rotation, revolution, turn, a turning', cf. MCo., MBret. tro.
"बान्त bānta,or bāntā, l. vānta-, s. Sickness, vomit. b˚ garnu to vomit. [lw. Sk. vānta-.]"
Cf. s.v. 7189 *rejectāre 'zurückwerfen'
Cf. s.v. Lat. iaciō, -ere 'to throw'; aor. iēci, based on PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw, let go'
Cf. s.v. *Hi̯eh₁- 'werfen' (IEW 502).
S.v. 5878 Ved. turáti 'hurries, presses forward' RV. (> P. turṇā, ṭu˚ 'to set out, go, walk, depart, pass as current, succeed')
S.v. Ved. √tvar- 'eilen, in Eile sein', prob. PIE * tu̯er-, cf. Gk. ὀτρύνω 'treibe an'.
Cf. s.v. *tu̯er- 'aufrühren, erregen, antreiben' (IEW 1100).

S.v. Proto-Iranic *dānu- 'вода, река', from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dānu-, cf. Ved. dānu- 'каплющее течение, капающий; капель, роса' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:719-720). Not to be excluded is the possibility of a contamination with Proto-Indo-Iranic *dhan- 'бежать, течь' < PIE *dʰen- 'бежать, течь' (cf. {ref IEW} 249, {ref EWAia} I:772).

Cf. s.v. Ved. dā́nu-, a Rigvedic word designating rain and by many interpreted as 'träufelend, träufelnde Flüssigkeit', by others as 'Gabe', if the former possibly with YAv. dānu- 'Fluß', Oss. don 'Fluß, Wasser', and further to European river names.
S.v. 4386 *grilla- 'wet, damp'. [< *gr̥dla- cf. √gaḍ: very doubtful]
S.v. 13640 *skambha- (2) 'shoulderblade, wing, plumage'.
S.v. 3119 kāṣāyá- 'brownish red, dyed reddish' Kauś. (> S. kaha- 'yellow')
S.v. Ved. kaṣāyá- n.m. 'ausgekochter Saft', also adj. 'rot'. Etymology unclear.

Cf. s.v. 5443 *ṭan 'be tight'. 2. *ṭān- 'tighten'. 3. *ṭhān-;  1. N. ṭanna 'tense, swollen', ṭanṭani 'securely', ṭankanu 'to become tense'; B. ṭanṭanāna 'to be tense, throb', ṭankāna 'to stiffen'; M. ṭaṇṭaṇṇẽ 'to be strained very tightly', ṭaṇkā, 'strong, healthy'.
Cf. s.v. TochB kwīpe 'shame; modesty' for discussion of the proposed Tocharian cognate. Ultimately regarded as uncertain.

S.v. W llyngyr, llynger 'parasitic worms, esp. intestinal worms, tapeworms, cestodes; earthworms; also transf. and fig. and derog.' cf. Old Breton lencquernenn, Late Breton lenkernenn: ?from IE *slenk-, cf. 
Old High German slango 'snake']
Cf. 9500 *bhiyagna- 'smeared, wet', 9501 *bhiyaṅga- 'smearing, wetting', 9502 *bhiyajyatē 'is smeared, gets wet' 9503 *bhiyañjati 'anoints, wets, is wetted', derivatives of √añj- + preverb abhi-
S.v. Ved. √añj- 'salben, bestreichen, beschmieren', from PIE *h₃engʷ- (cf. Lat. unguere 'salben', OIr. imb, OHG ancho, OPr. anctan 'Butter', etc.)
Cf. s.v. *h₂engʷ- 'bestreichen, salben' (IEW 779).

S.v. Kurd. рāl (f.) I pāl, рālu 'бок', 'сторона', 'скат', 'склон' (горы); рāl dān 'лечь, облокотиться'; с. тж. предлог ·к'. From PIr. *parθu-, Av. parəsu-, pərəsu- 'ребро', OInd. parśu- 'ребро', MPers. pahlūk 'ребро', 'бок'
Cf. s.v. Ved. párśu- 'Rippe' for further etymological speculations outside of Indo-Iranic.
S.v. W. taflaf (1) 'throw, fling' (etc.). from the same root as Gk π(τ)όλις 'city'?
S.v. 2345 crusta 'Rinde'

S.v. Lat. crusta 'crust, shell; thin slab; leaf', suggests *krus-to- from PIE *krus- 'to thrust, pound' and compares Av. xrūždra- 'hard', xrūždisma-, '(made from) hard soil, xrūžda- 'hardship'; Gr. κρούω 'to strike, smite' < *krous(i)e/o-; Lith. krùšti 'to crush', OCS sъ-kruš- 'to break into pieces', Lith. krušà 'hail', < *krus-a-; against the traditional etymology to the Greek words for 'ice', 'frost' κρύσταλλος, κρύος on the basis that the words do not have any indication that they referred to ice or cold.
S.v. 14152 hŕ̥daya- n. 'heart' RV. [hr̥d- ]

S.v. Ved. hŕ̥d- 'Herz', from IIr. *j́ʰā̆rd- /*j́ʰr̥d-, is not completely lautgesetzlich with PIE *k̑ē̆rd-/*k̑r̥d-. The presence of non-etymological *j́ʰ (> Vedic h) in Proto-Indo-Iranian is presumably due to contamination with the Proto-Indo-Iranian outcome of PIE *g̑ʰórh₁-/g̑ʰr̥h₁- 'guts', cf. /cognate/2672/.
Cf. s.v. 5592 *ḍhukyati 'approaches' [√ḍhauk] (> A. ḍhukiba 'to enter', ḍhukāiba 'to come to an end, die')
Cf. s.v. ḍháukate 'nähert sich / approaches'. Of unclear origin, probably a non-Indic loanword.

S.v. 11056 *litta- 'defective'. 2. *littara- . 3. *litra- (cf. *latra- s.v. *latta- 1). 4. *lidda- 1. 5. *liddhara- . 6. *lētta- . 7. *lēttha- . 8. *lēdda- 1. 9. *lēddha- 1. 10. *lēnda- (~ *rēnda- ). 11. *lēndara-. From variant 6. > Ku. leto 'filth, foulness, dust'; A. leterā 'dirty, untidy'.
S.v. 10713 *rāyaṇika- 'barking'. [rāyaṇa-, √rai] > Kho. reni 'dog'.
S.v. Ved. √rā- (2) 'bellen', perhaps PIE *leh₂- cf. Lat. lātrāre, Lith. lóti, OCS lajati, etc.
Cf. s.v. 1. *leh₂- 'bellen' (IEW 650-1).

S.v. 1623 vikala 'deprived of a part, mutilated, deficient in' Up., f. ˚lī- Pāṇ.gaṇa. [Perh. belongs to ʻ defective ʼ group of víkaṭa- and bec. of -l- became associated with kalā- ] > Si. Si. viyalu 'old, fragile, dried up' viyalanavā 'to dry up'

S.v. Ved. vikala- 'verstümmelt, verkrüppelt, unvollkommen' "Bei dem ein Teil (kalā-) weg (vi-) ist, um einen Teil vermindert." further s.v. Ved. kalā- 'kleiner Teil, Bruchteil, Sechzehntel', further etymology uncertain.

S.v. Skt. vikala- 'unvollkommen, Mangel leidend, verkrüppelt, verstümmelt, niedergedrückt / imperfect, deficient in, crippled, maimed, depressed', cf. Si. viyalu 'alt, gebrechlich, ausgetrocknet' to vi- + kalā- 'kleiner Teil'?
S.v. 2661 káṇa- m. 'a grain of corn' AV. (> A. kanā 'a minute particle', kani 'egg, testicle')
S.v. Ved. káṇa- 'Korn, Samenkorn'. Etymology uncertain. A derivation (with context-free -ṇ- for -n-) from *kána- 'small' (~ kánīyas- 'smaller') is possible.

Following {ref Delamarre 2003}:139 connecting Gaulish onomastic depro- to this group, I tentatively reconstruct Proto-Celtic *dēkʷro- underlying these forms (not in {ref Matasović 2009}). Enrico Campanile, Profilo Etimologico del Cornico Antico (Pisa 1974, non vidi) tentatively proposed a possible connection to Ancient Greek δεῖπνον 'dinner, supper' which is formally possible and reconcilable to a root *dei̯kʷ- (not in {ref LIV²}). {ref Beekes 2010}:310 considers Ancient Greek δεῖπνον without certain etymology.
"Etym. dub. but perh. fr. a *skeu- beside IE *keu- in Grk. κοέω 'perceive, hear', Lat. cavēre 'beware', Goth. hausjan 'hear' OE scēawian 'look at' etc. […] less probably Pedersen 2.53"
"vielleicht zu gr. κυβερνάω 'steuere' skr. kūbara-m 'Deichsel'"
S.v. 4055 gárbha- m. 'womb, foetus, offspring' RV. deriv. K. gọ̆bᵘ 'heavy'
S.v. Ved. gárbha- 'Mutterleib, Leibesfrucht, Embryo, Neugeborenes', from PIE *gʷolbʰo- (*gʷelbʰ-), cf. Gk. δελφύς 'Gebärmutter', ἀδελφεός 'Bruder'.
S.v. Kurd. qurs (2) с. 'тяжелый, твердый, сильный'. Possibly a loan from Arabic qaras 'твердый', but cf. Persian qurs 'твердый', 'крепкий', 'прочный' (via Arabic?).

S.v. 14468 ghaná- (2): *ghanta- ~ *ghanda- in Ash. gandalə 'heavy, pregnant' (rather than < *ghanatara- ); Shum. gandalä 'heavy', Gaw. gandā́la, f. gandā́lī 'pregnant'. Cf. main entry under 4424 ghaná- (2) 'compact, firm, dense' Suśr.

S.v. ghaná- (2) 'Klumpen, kompakte Masse' also adj. 'dick, kompakt, voll', etym. uncertain. If connected with Ved. āhanás- 'schwellend, strotzend, geil, üppig' perhaps a root *gʷʰen- 'to swell' [NB: distinct from *gʷʰen- 'to beat'], cf. I:184-185 for further discussion.

Cf. s.v. 5090 jaḍa- 'stupid, dumb' Mn., 'cold' Pañcat. 2. *jaḍḍa- . 3. jáḍhu- , jáḷhu- 'dull' RV. 4. *jūḍa- . [Certainly of non-Aryan origin EWA i 414 with lit.] (> M. jaḍ 'cold, stupid'; Ko. jaḍa, zaḍ 'heavy').
S.v. Skt. jaḍa- 'kalt, starr, stumpf, dumm / 'cold, stiff, dull, stupid'. Not satisfyingly explained. Probably a loanword from Dravidian or Munda.

Cf. s.v. 12851 *saṁgōpayati 'hides' [Cf. saṁgupta- 'well hidden' MBh., saṁgōpana- n. 'concealment' Pañcat. √gup] > Pa. saṅgōpēti 'guards'; Pk. saṁgōvēi 'hides', caus. saṁgōvāvaï; Si. san̆gavanavā, ha˚ 'to cause to be hidden'.
S.v. Ved. √gop- 'behüten, beschützen', a new root in Vedic backformed from Sanskrit gopā́- 'Hirt, Hüter'.

As though continuing Sanskrit *saṁgōpayati 'hides' (cf. {ref Turner 1962–1966}:745 no. 12851). The verbal root, √gop- ~ √gup-, was backformed in Vedic from gopā́- (n.) 'cowherd', itself a nominal compound *gʷou̯-peh₂- 'cow-protector' (cf. {ref EWAia} I:499-500). Of the two elements, *peh₂- (cf. {ref LIV²} 460 *peh₂(i̯)- 'schützen, hüten, weiden') is arguably the original semantic head here (i.e. 'to protect (cattle)' > 'to hide') although I am hesitant to consider PIE *peh₂- as the root-reference form here because of the process of backformation that occurred to create the new root √gop- within Vedic.
S.v. Kurd. dāγ (f.) | dāγ, dāx 'клеймо, прижигание, метка; горячий' Loan from Persian dāγ 'клеймо, тавро'
S.v. 11529 vāpī́ f. 'pond, tank' Mn. [√vap2] (> Si. väv-a 'pond')
S.v. vāpī́ 'großer Teich, Zisterne, Pfuhl / large pond, tank, pool', probably like -vapā 'Aufwurf' and vápra- 'Erdwall, Erdaufwurf' to be connected with vápati 'scatter'.
S.v. 2603 kaṅkāla (1) m.n. 'skeleton' MBh. (> Si. kakula 'calf of leg, foot')

Cf. s.v. Skt. kaṅkāla- 'Gerippe / skeleton'. Perhaps to OE hōh 'Ferse', Lith. kenklė̃ 'Kniekehle', but it does not seem that this rare and late word can be unconditionally justified to go back to an IE root.
S.v. 77 Skt. agramāṁsa- n. 'heart' lex. [ágra-, māṁsá-] > Si. agamas 'heart', akmāva 'liver'.
Cf. s.v. Ved. mām̆̇sá- 'Fleisch', from PIE *mēms- (cf. Arm. mis, Goth. mimz, OPruss. mensā, menso, OCS męso, TochB mīsa- all 'Fleisch').
Cf. s.v. *mē(m)s- 'Fleisch' (IEW 725, EIEC 374).
S.v. N. लोग्ने logne s. 'Male being, man; husband' l˚ mān che a man. [Ku. lokiṇi woman; H. logwan pl. males, loknī f. female servant (v. lokanti); der. lok, log.]
S.v. ĉīyā, ĉīya, čyā, čīyā 'гора', from Old Iranian čakāta-, cf. Middle Persian čakāt, Persian čakād 'mountain peak', Arm. (Ir. lw.) čakad 'forehead'.
S.v. PIr. *čakā̆ta- 'лоб' (?).
Cf. s.v. PIr. *kart- (1) 'to cut' < PIE *(s)ker-t- (> Oss. I. kærdyn/karst, D. kærdun/karst)

S.v. Proto-Iranic *hmar- 'to remember, recall; recount' (Av. *(š)mar- 'to remember, recall'), from PIE *(s)mer- 'to observe, consider, think of' (cf. Ved. √smar- 'to remember, to become aware, to be mindful of', Gk. ἱμείρω 'I desire, long', Goth. *maurnan, OHG mornēn, OE murnan, Engl. mourn).

Cf. s.v. Ved. √smar- 'gedenken, sich erinnern, einer Sache bewußt werden, eingedenk sein, ins Herz schließen', probably from PIE *(s)mer- 'an etwas (sorgenvoll?) denken', cf. Gk. μέριμνα 'Sorge, Besorgnis', OE murnan 'sich um etwas sorgen', etc.
Cf. s.v. 1. *(s)mer- 'denken an, sich erinnern' (IEW 969).
Cf. s.v. 1. *dei̯k- 'zeigen, weisen' (IEW 188-189).
S.v. Khw. δmʾdyk 'dick', pp. to (ʾ)δmʾs- 'dick werden'.
Cf. s.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-248).
Cf. s.v. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen' OCS dъmǫ, etc.).
S.v. 3624 s.v. Skt. kliṣṭa- 'distressed' R. (> Si. kiluṭu 'dirty, used up')
Cf. s.v. √kleś- 'plagen, quälen', derived adj. kliṣta- 'geplagt, gequält'. Etymology unclear, perhaps to Lith. klišės 'Krebsschere', Ru. klestitь 'drücken, pressen'.

S.v. 7618 *pakk 'move forward, reach'. [Loss of final syllables and of -m- in K. would make derivation from prákramati doubtful. Pk. paccala- 'sufficient, able' suggests connection with pakvá-] (> K. pakun 'to go, tread, advance, go on well, succeed')
Cf. s.v. Ved. pakvá- 'gekocht, reif'
S.v. 5836 Skt. tíllati 'goes' Dhātup. [Perh. → Psht. tləl EVP 80, AO xviii 253. √til]
Cf. s.v. OPers. kamna- 'wenig, gering' < Ir. *ka(m)b-ná- = OAv., YAv. kamna- 'id.', superlative kamb-išta-.

Cf. s.v. Hitt. kappi-/kappai- 'small, little', from PIE *kmb-(e)i- (cf. also Lyd. καμβειν 'grandchild'), cognate with Iranian words for 'small', e.g. Av. kamna-, OPers. kamna-. The Iranian cognates which must reflect *km̥b-no- (*kembʰ- would be against IE root constraints).

S.v. OIr. cor (1) 'fait de placer, planter, envoyer, jeter; coup, tour mouvement tournant, détour, circut, mélodie, contrat, etc.' Irish cor is connected to the root *(s)ker- 'tourner, courber', lat. curuus 'courbe', cortina 'vase rond', gr. κυρτός 'courbe', κορώνη 'objet courbe', skr. (sic!) skarəna 'rond'.

Cf. s.v. Gk. κυρτός 'vaulted, rounded, bulging, hunchbacked'. Without general etymological consensus. Comparison often made with Lat. curvus 'vaulted, crooked, suggesting a root *k⁽ʷ⁾r-to- with u-colouring but this reflex for a reduced grade reflex is difficult. Schrijver 1997: 297 assumes an lE root *kur-, but such a root structure is foreign to lE.
Cf. n9 rejecting the older connection of related vocabulary with a putative PIE *(s)ker- 'turn, bend' as formally impossible.

Cf. s.v. Lat. curvus 'curved, bent'. Uncertain etymology. Earlier sources suggest a root *(s)ker- assuming curvus < *kr-uo-. The best possibility may be to OIr. corr, MW cwrr 'hooked' < *kurso-, Gk. κυρτός 'curved', but *kur- is not a valid root structure.
Cf. PIr. *darz- 'to attach, fasten; to load; to sew' < PIE *  dʰerg̑ʰ- 'to fasten, hold'? (cf. Gk. δράσσομαι 'I grasp', OCS drьžati 'hold, possess', etc.)
Cf. s.v. 1. *g̑ʰer- 'Gefallen finden, begehren' (IEW 440-1).
See now addenda and corrigenda to LIV² arguing *g̑ʰer- → *gʰer- on basis of Khwarezmian (+) ɣry- ‘sich freuen’.
S.v. Khot. hayär- 'to play, sport, be merry'
Cf. s.v. *neu̯- 'nicken, (den Kopf) neigen' (IEW 767).
Cf. s.v. *neu̯- 'neu' (IEW 769, EIEC 393).

S.v. Old Welsh v. pret. 3sg. rodesit 'to give'. "Various etymological explanations of this verb have been offered have been offered, which consider its relationship with Sanskrit rā 'give' (Vendryes), or derive it from IE *dō- 'geben' (WG: 386, cf. VGK: II, 473)."
Cf. s.v. PIr. *gan- 'to strike to, befall, become', a neo-root extracted from an o-grade derivative *gʷʰono- 'slaying', without this Pashto lexeme mentioned.
Cf. s.v. PIE *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).
S.v. 4424 ghaná- (2) 'compact, firm, dense' Suśr., 'densely filled, deep (of sound or colour)' MBh. 2. n. 'any compact mass' ŚBr., m. 'cloud' MBh. [*han- 3]

S.v. Ved. ghaná- 'Klumpen, kampakte Masse' also adj. 'dick, kompakt, voll', apparently to be separated form √han- 'schlagen' and with āhanás- 'schwellend, strotzend', perhaps to a root *gʷʰen- 'anschwellen' (Gk. ἐυθενέω 'gedeihe', OCS goněti 'genügen').
S.v. Alb. ikëj 'to go away, run away', continuing PIE *ei- 'to go'. Various hypotheses exist to explain the anomalous -k- in the stem.
Cf. s.v. OIr. dul 'faît d'aller'. Only mentioning {ref Pedersen 1913}:648 comparing Albanian dal 'je sors'.
Cf. s.v. PCl. *dal-nV- 'aus etwas hervorgehen' < PIE *dʰh₂elh₁- or *dʰalh₁-
S.v. ScG. dol 'going', Ir. dul, OIr. dul, inf. to doluid from PIE *leudho 'go' (Gk. ἐλεύσομαι 'will come', ἦλυθον 'came').
Cf. s.v. war- (3) prefix 'to him/her/them' as adv. 'there' < *awáθra-.
Cf. s.v. *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'schärfen' (IEW 541-2).
Cf. s.v. *lendʰ- 'sich senken, nach unten geraten' [IEW 675, 961].
S.v. YAv. paθana- 'breit, weit' (cf. NP pahn).

S.v. Khot. hvāha- 'wide', from base *paθ- 'be wide' (Av. paθana- 'broad, wide', Phl. pahan, N.Pers. pahan. IE Pok. 824-825 *pet- 'extend' (Gk. πετάννυμι, Lat. pateō, etc. The Khot. form can derive from either hu-pāθa- or from *fra-pāθa-.

S.v. PIr. *tač- (2) 'to reach for, attain, receive' (> NPers. (+*ham-) andāxtan 'to throw; afflict, exhaust'). From PIE *tek- 'to stretch the hand, receive, reach' (cf. Lith. tèkti 'to reach (out), suffice, receive', OEng ϸicgan 'to receive, take', Ukr. tjáknuty 'to touch').
Cf. s.v. 1. *tek- 'die Hand ausstrecken, empfangen, erlangen' (IEW 1057-8).
S.v. Khw. m|stnb- / m|wstnb- 'sich erbrechen', from *us-stamba-, Intr. of m|stnbȳ- 'zum Erbrechen bringen', with difficulty to the root *stamb- 'stützen'.
Cf. s.v. *sei̯kʷ- 'ausgießen' (IEW 893-4).
S.v. biγ̌is : ºid Š, etc. 'to swell, inflate' from *upa-/api-šičya-, cf. Av. haēk- 'to let flow'.

S.v. Lith. taukaĩ 'fat' (Latv. tàuki 'fat', OPr. taukis 'lard'). The Balto-Slavic lexemes presuppose PIE *tou̯Hk-o-, with the root *teu̯Hk- possibly being a contamination of *teu̯H- and *teu̯k- or an extension of *teu̯H-. For *teu̯H-, Derksen cites Serbo-Croat tȉti 'become fat' as a derivation. He regards the root form 2.?*teu̯k- postulated by LIV² as shaky, noting that Lithuanian tùkti was no evidence for a non-acute root.
S.v. Proto-Slavic *tučьnъ 'fat, rich'. The Balto-Slavic lexemes presuppose PIE *tou̯Hk-o-, with the root *teu̯Hk- possibly being a contamination of *teu̯H- and teu̯k- or an extension of *teu̯H-.

Cf. s.v. *teu̯h₂- 'schwellen, stark werden' (IEW 1080-1) and ?2.*teu̯k- 'stark/fett werden, schwellen' (IEW 1081). The nominal forms such as OCS tukъ 'fat', OIr. tón f. 'bottom' and Old Norse þjó 'thigh' are assigned to the latter. Latvian tauks 'fat' and OIr. tón both from *tŭknā-.

Lithuanian taukaĩ could be explained as *tou̯h₂-kó- from PIE *teu̯h₂-. The other Baltic lexemes however are better derived from *teu̯k-. This root *teu̯k- would also be sufficient to explain OIr. tón 'bottom'. Thus taukaĩ either is a substantival Vrddhi-form, or we see in Baltic a contamination of two different, pre-existing forms *tou̯h₂-kó- and *tou̯k-ó-.
S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.). cf. p.641 under ?*sth₂-ró-. Cf. further discussion p.656 fn129.
S.v. Sogd. ptštʾn 'thigh', cf. Av. patištāna, Pahl. padištān.
Cf. s.v. 13768 sthitá- 'standing, settled' ŚBr. [√sthā]
Cf. s.v. PIr. *hu̯ar- (5) ‘to paint, colour; to stain’ > NP xvāl ‘soot, lamp-black’ (< *hu̯ar-da- ?). To PIE *su̯er- (*su̯or-) ‘to darken, make dark, stain’ ?
Cf. s.v. 2. *su̯er- 'schmerzen, schwären' (IEW 1050).
Cf. s.v. 2. *su̯er- 'schmerzen, schwären' (IEW 1050).
S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.).

S.v. *Hrab/f- 'to go' (> MMP rwyd, rwyyd). "An IE origin of this Ir. root is uncertain. The WIr. forms, Pth. rf- ‘to attack’ and NP rav- ‘to go’, have been connected to MHG reben ‘to move’, Lat. rabiō ‘I rage’ in LIV: l.c. This can be doubted. Pth. rf- may point to a different root. MHG reben ‘to move’ has probably a different etymology (it is compared to OIrish reb ‘play’, Russ. rebënok ‘child’ by Häusler 2000: 144). The Latin connection is declined by {ref Schrijver 1991}: 305."
S.v. 12621 Skt. śocyate 'is made to feel pain' Kālid., 'is purified' Kathās., śocya- llamentable' MBh. [Pass. of śocáyati 'sets alight, burns' RV., 'pains' AV., 'feels pain' MBh. √śuc]
Cf. s.v. Ved. √soć- 'leuchten, glühen, brennen', probably from PIE *k̑eu̯k-.
Cf. s.v. 1. ?*k̑eu̯k- (IEW 597), but cognates are only from within Indo-Iranian.

S.v. Slov. ráven, cf. OCS ravьnъ, SCr. rávan, Rus. róvnyj, Cz. rovný. from Proto-Slavic *órvьnъ, to PIE *reu̯h₁- 'spread out, open up', cf. "If arbor 'tree' < *arbos is cognate with *h₃rdh- 'high' (see no. 17), it must reflect a zero grade root *h₃rdh-ōs. The connection is, however, doubtful."

Cf. s.v. 5034 lignum 'Holz' > it. legno, friaul. leñ, etc.
S.v. Lat. lignum 'wood'. Either from (1) leg- 'to collect' in the sense 'wood collected for firemaking' or (2) *legʰ- 'lie' as in 'stray wood'. Both etymologies are plausible.

S.v. Bret. lonk 'fait d'avaler', from Old Breton lunc 'gosier, gorge, fait d'avaler', to W llwnc in the same sense and Old Irish slocod, slucud going back to Proto-Celtic *slunko-. Further derivative dislonkiñ v. vomir < dis- + lonk + -añ, -iñ.
Cf. s.v. OIr. slucc- 'avaler', corresponding to W. llyncu 'avaler', Bret. lonka 'avaler'.
S.v. PCl. *slu-n-k-e/o- 'schlucken, verschlingen', from PIE *sleu̯k- (LIV² 568).

Cf. s.v. *slu-n-k-o- 'swallow' "The root-form *(s)lewk- is a variant of *(s)lewg- (LIV 964), from which we have Germ. schlucken, etc. and aIr. loingid 'eat' < PCelt.*lu-n-g-o-). The variation *k/g is unexplained, but such irregularities are not uncommon in expressive verbs."
